headline: American Solo Sailor May Change a Culture
keywords: ['Sailboats and Sailing', 'Vendee Globe Challenge', 'Boats and Boating']
abstract: Ryan Breymaier has been training for the Imoca Ocean Masters New York to Barcelona race, in which he will sail across the Atlantic against four other teams starting Sunday.
lead_paragraph: At 3 a.m. Wednesday, Ryan Breymaier had been prone on a two-inch foam pad for barely 30 minutes when the call came for him to get up. He was delivering the 60-foot racing sailboat Hugo Boss from Newport, R.I., to Manhattan as training for the Imoca Ocean Masters New York to Barcelona race, in which he and Pepe Ribes of Spain will sail across the Atlantic against four other teams starting Sunday.

headline: Identity Intelligence: Image Is Everything

lead_paragraph: An excerpt of a document obtained by Edward J. Snowden, a former contractor with the National Security Agency, referring to the agency’s use of images in intelligence gathering.

headline: Lesson for P.O.W.’s Father: Men Sometimes Do Come Back
abstract: Robert Bergdahl fought in Washington for his son’s release from the Taliban for five years. On Saturday, President Obama said Bowe Bergdahl was coming home.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For five years Robert Bergdahl waged a father’s war for the return of his soldier son.

headline: Police Search for Upset Teenager Who Sank Into the Hudson
abstract: Omotayo Adeoye, 17, was seen crying and wading into the river fully clothed on Thursday after she was confronted by a teacher who believed she was cheating on a test.
lead_paragraph: A distraught student left her elite high school in Harlem between classes on Thursday, classmates and witnesses said, and went to Fort Washington Park, along the Hudson River. She laid her phone and wallet on a rock on the bank of the river. She walked into the water and sank beneath the surface.

headline: Players Seek Approval of $40 Million Deal in Video Games Case
abstract: A judge’s approval would signify the end of the players’ dispute with EA Sports and the Collegiate Licensing Company but would not halt the litigation against the N.C.A.A. in the Ed O’Bannon case.
lead_paragraph: College athletes, prohibited under N.C.A.A. rules from being paid, are moving closer to being compensated for the use of their likenesses in video games.

headline: After 5 Months of Sales, Colorado Sees the Downside of a Legal High
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Children and Childhood', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Adult deaths and children’s emergency room visits in Colorado are being linked to newly legal marijuana, often in its edible form, and opponents of legalization are warning other states to pay heed.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Five months after Colorado became the first state to allow recreational marijuana sales, the battle over legalization is still raging.

headline: Environmental Groups Focus on Change by Strengthening Their Political Operations
abstract: Environmental groups are raising and spending more money than ever to mount a revitalized climate-change campaign that looks nothing like failed past efforts.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — When the police arrested seven students at Washington University in St. Louis recently after a crowd of protesters sought to crash a board of trustees meeting, leaders of the environmental movement were thrilled.

headline: N.S.A. Collecting Millions of Faces From Web Images
keywords: ['Computer Vision', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Identification Devices', 'Face', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The National Security Agency’s reliance on facial recognition technology has grown as it has used new software to exploit images in emails, text messages, social media, videoconferences and other communications.
lead_paragraph: The National Security Agency is harvesting huge numbers of images of people from communications that it intercepts through its global surveillance operations for use in sophisticated facial recognition programs, according to top-secret documents.

headline: Another Slog for Mets, but This Time, It’s Worth It
abstract: For the second day in a row, the Mets played a 14-inning game, but on Saturday they pulled out a victory over the Phillies, with David Wright singling in the decisive run.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Mets were asking much of Jacob deGrom without much to offer him in return. Their bullpen was depleted and their spirit broken after a loss in 14 innings the night before, and now they were asking him to pitch deep into their game against the Philadelphia Phillies, to be effective and efficient and essentially carry the team.

headline: A Soldier Is Missing. What Comes Next?
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The military first used drones, armed checkpoints and raids on suspected militant strongholds to try to find Pfc. Bowe Bergdahl, according to classified military logs given to WikiLeaks.
lead_paragraph: When the United States Army in eastern Afghanistan discovered that one of its soldiers, Pfc. Bowe Bergdahl, was missing in action, it began a frantic search. As detailed in the classified military logs given to WikiLeaks by Pfc. Bradley Manning, now Chelsea Manning, the initial hunt for the captured sergeant included surveillance drones, armed checkpoints and infantry raids on suspected militant strongholds. Intercepts of Taliban communications included in the military records reveal that the militants immediately thought to use the capture for propaganda purposes, and derided American forces for looking in all the wrong places. Andrew W. Lehren

headline: An Entertaining Match, Not Only for the Volleys

headline: Texas Beer Finds Home in the Heart of New York
abstract: By the time Shiner Bock entered the New York market last year, the craft beer already had fans in patrons of some city bars, as their owners bought cases from other states.
lead_paragraph: Until last year, one of the few ways Texans living in New York could get a bottle of Shiner Bock, the popular craft beer from an 105-year-old brewery in Shiner, Tex., was to carry the beer back in their luggage. Or find a New York bar that had smuggled the beer into the city.

headline: With More Inmates on Dialysis, Officials Deal With Rising Costs
abstract: The number of Texas inmates who need dialysis, which costs $1.25 million a year, is growing, and lawmakers are considering asking for federal aid and putting a greater emphasis on prevention.
lead_paragraph: Less than 1 percent of the Texas prison population needs dialysis, a treatment that removes waste and water from the bloodstream.

abstract: The suspect, a 29-year-old Frenchman with a long criminal history, had traveled to Syria last year to join with radical Islamist fighters there, the authorities said.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television listings for Sunday, June 1.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (AMC) HALT AND CATCH FIRE Set in Texas during the 1980s tech boom, this new series stars Lee Pace (“Lincoln,” “Pushing Daisies”) as Joe McMillan, a former IBM salesman who enlists the help of a has-been computer engineer (Scoot McNairy, above left, with Mackenzie Davis and Mr. Pace) and a talented computer science student (Ms. Davis) to reverse-engineer an IBM PC. The story is fiction, but based on the actual technology race of that decade, in which companies were trying to create their own version of a PC. With AMC’s “Mad Men,” focusing on the ad executive Don Draper, ending next year, the network “seems to be looking for another period drama that can seduce viewers with old-fashioned customs and atavistic sins,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “Joe, like Don, is handsome, suave and moodily enigmatic, a salesman who pitches his product with passionate intensity.” Unfortunately, “Halt and Catch Fire” doesn’t seem to carry the same panache. “The period music is fun, but there is nothing particularly glamorous about high-tech Dallas. Most of all, the early 1980s are not a distant enough memory to cast a retro glow.”

headline: Mexico Authorizes Arrests in Fraud at Citigroup Unit
abstract: Mexican authorities declined to say how many or which former executives of the Citigroup subsidiary Banamex were being sought.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:56 p.m. | The authorities in Mexico have issued arrest warrants for former executives of Citigroup’s Mexican subsidiary, Banamex, in an investigation of a $400 million fraud.

headline: Bouchard Helps Ensure a Big Day for Canada
abstract: Eugenie Bouchard, 20, needed only 52 minutes to knock out eighth-seeded Angelique Kerber and reach the French Open quarterfinals. Her fellow Canadian Milos Raonic also advanced.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Eugenie Bouchard is in a hurry.

headline: Three Kidnapped Missionaries Are Freed in Cameroon
abstract: The two Italian priests and a Canadian nun were held for nearly two months near Cameroon’s border with Nigeria in a region rife with Boko Haram militants.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Two Italian priests and a Canadian nun, kidnapped nearly two months ago near Cameroon’s border with Nigeria in a region rife with Boko Haram militants, have been freed, Cameroon’s communications minister said on Sunday.

headline: President of Georgian Abkhazia Resigns Under Pressure
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: President Aleksandr Z. Ankvab, whose popularity had plummeted amid deteriorating economic conditions, stepped down as the leader of Abkhazia, a breakaway region of Georgia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The president of Abkhazia, a breakaway region of Georgia heavily supported by Russia, resigned on Sunday after less than a week of unrest during which demonstrators stormed the presidential administration building and the Kremlin sent high-level emissaries from Moscow in a bid to calm the situation.

headline: Lewis Katz, Victor in Fight to Own Philadelphia Inquirer, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Katz, a prominent figure in Philadelphia political circles, agreed on Tuesday with his business partner to pay $88 million for The Inquirer, Philly.com and The Philadelphia Daily News.
lead_paragraph: Lewis Katz, a co-owner of The Philadelphia Inquirer who had only recently emerged triumphant in a battle for control of the newspaper, died in a plane crash on Saturday night in Massachusetts. He was 72.

headline: ‘Maleficent’ Casts Spell, Burying ‘Ways to Die’
abstract: Angelina Jolie and Walt Disney’s live-action label turned out large crowds for “Maleficent,” as Seth MacFarlane discovered there is no surer way to die in the West than making a vanity film.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Angelina Jolie and Walt Disney’s live-action label turned out surprisingly large crowds for “Maleficent” over the weekend, as Seth MacFarlane discovered there is no surer way to die in the West than making a vanity film.

headline: Tony Awards Predictions: Leading Actress in a Musical
abstract: The best actress race is one of the fiercest, and has big implications for shows.
lead_paragraph: Do you think Kelli O’Hara will score a big upset next Sunday and win the Tony Award for best actress in a musical for Broadway’s “Bridges of Madison County”? Or will front-runner Jessie Mueller and “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical” emerge dominant, with the show winning the Tony for best musical over “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder”? As we survey the 800 Tony voters this week for our annual predictions story, we’re adding new voices to the mix: Yours.

headline: Administration Defends Swap With Taliban to Free U.S. Soldier
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The White House pushed back against Republican criticism that the deal was a dangerous transgression of longstanding policy against negotiating with terror groups, and might have violated American law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top Obama administration officials pushed back on Sunday against Republican criticism that a deal freeing the last American held prisoner in Afghanistan could allow dangerous Taliban leaders to return to the fight, might encourage terrorist groups to seize American hostages and possibly violated a law requiring notification of Congress.

headline: Love-Struck Hero in a Quandary: The Other Woman’s a Real Doll
abstract: The three-act “Coppélia” returned to the American Ballet Theater’s repertory on Friday, with Misty Copeland, Herman Cornejo and Roman Zhurbin playing the leading roles.
lead_paragraph: The music for the ballet “Coppélia” abounds in vitality, color, melody, folk energy, innocence, narrative charm and youthful freshness in each of its three acts. You seem to breathe more deeply when listening to it; your head clears. The composer is Léo Delibes; his 1870 score has several features that have never been surpassed in the ballet repertory. In the overture (and again in Act II), a sweet, high, ravishing violin melody suddenly takes the air after a soft horn introduction, like the answer to a prayer or light after darkness. What mazurka and what czardas are more irresistible than those here? In the Act I variations on a Slavic theme, the fast-cascading joy of one rapid string phrase squeezes the heart.

headline: Six Climbers Are Missing on Mount Rainier
abstract: Matt Hegeman, a well-known climber, was among those presumed dead after an avalanche or a fall in what could be the worst episode on the mountain in Washington State in decades.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, Wash. — Six climbers were missing and presumed dead on Sunday in an avalanche or fall on Mount Rainier in Washington State, in what could be the worst accident on the mountain in decades.

headline: At WWDC, Apple Is Set to Make Push Into Monitoring Health and Home
abstract: Apple is expected to introduce mobile apps that will track a user’s health and fitness routine, and smart home devices, at its annual Worldwide Developers’ Conference.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is unlikely to introduce new devices this week, the things that most excite customers and investors these days. But the company is expected to dive deeper into two new areas: connected health and the so-called smart home.

headline: Prospecting for Riches in Broadway Bombs
abstract: “Panning for Gold: Great Songs From Flop Shows,” an offering from the series Lyrics & Lyricists, handily fulfilled its title’s mission.
lead_paragraph: “Hi! I’m so-and-so. And I’m a recovering flopaholic!”

headline: A Lawman With a Lot to Deal With, Including Himself
abstract: “Longmire,” a crime drama set in Wyoming, begins its third season on A&E.
lead_paragraph: Every time a new tortured-cop show turns critics all gushy and trend-chasing television watchers all buzzy, a guy in Wyoming just shrugs and emits a noncommittal grunt. He’s Sheriff Walt Longmire, and if he’s upset that shows like “The Following” and “True Detective” get more attention than his does, he’s not letting on.

headline: Obama to Take Action to Slash Coal Pollution
keywords: ['Coal', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency will unveil a draft proposal on Monday to cut carbon pollution from the nation’s power plants 30 percent from 2005 levels by 2030, according to people briefed on the plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Monday will announce one of the strongest actions ever taken by the United States government to fight climate change, a proposed Environmental Protection Agency regulation to cut carbon pollution from the nation’s power plants 30 percent from 2005 levels by 2030, according to people briefed on the plan who spoke anonymously because they had been asked not to reveal details.

headline: Mentally, G.I. Has Long Path Back to Idaho
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Prisoners of War', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Military officials said that the recovery of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl would be a multistep process, beginning with treatment in Germany before further care in the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the road home to Idaho began with a brief helicopter ride from the rugged frontier of eastern Afghanistan to Bagram Air Base, north of Kabul. His return to anything close to a normal life will take much longer.

headline: The Bergdahls’ News Conference
abstract: Jani and Robert Bergdahl, the parents of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, addressed supporters on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Jani and Robert Bergdahl, the parents of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, addressed supporters on Sunday.

headline: Another Ending for Arsenio Hall
abstract: The February announcement that Arsenio Hall’s syndicated late-night show would return for a second season turned out to be both premature and mistaken.
lead_paragraph: The February announcement that Arsenio Hall’s syndicated late-night show would return for a second season turned out to be both premature and mistaken. CBS Television Distribution, which owns the show with Tribune Media, has announced a cancellation because of a ratings decline among the viewers most advertisers pay for in late night, people between the ages of 18 and 49. (The ratings leader in that group is Jimmy Fallon on NBC.) Mr. Hall, left, who had a hit syndicated late-night show in the early 1990s, revived the franchise with some fanfare in September, and he scored some early impressive ratings. But the late-night scene had become intensely crowded, with as many as 10 shows fighting for a shrinking number of viewers. The ratings drop set in motion a pattern of downgrades from a host of local television stations, which began relegating Mr. Hall’s show to little-watched hours of the night. In February, his old friend Jay Leno appeared on the show with a letter confirming a second year. The ratings slide forced CBS’s syndication division to rescind that decision.

headline: Yankees’ Robertson Fails, Making Twins’ Hughes a Winner
abstract: Minnesota’s Phil Hughes, facing his former team for the first time, avoided becoming a hard-luck loser when the Yankees’ David Robertson blew a save opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Even though Phil Hughes was once an 18-game winner for the Yankees, had been an All-Star and had helped them win a World Series as an important relief pitcher, things could hardly have ended worse for him in the Bronx. A 4-14 record last season, including a 1-10 mark at home, made him the target of loud booing by fans who were only too happy to see him leave.

headline: Relevant? Nurturing? Well, So’s Your Old Man
abstract: “Do Fathers Matter?” cites research that shows that fathers have an outsize effect on their children’s vocabulary, and that their presence can delay daughters’ puberty, among other findings.
lead_paragraph: When our young daughters first decided to play on top of our Honda minivan, parked in our driveway, my wife was worried. But to me, it seemed no less safe than chasing a ball that frequently ended up in the street. And they loved the height, the novelty, the danger. So I let them stay. They never fell. And with the summer weather here, playing on the car is once again keeping them occupied for hours.

headline: Mermaids’ Flashlights, and Other Illuminations
abstract: “Light House,” by the choreographer Anne Zuerner, used fluorescent lights as part of an expression of dance and nature at Invisible Dog Art Center.
lead_paragraph: The graceful sight of a lighthouse — preferably on a cliff with ocean waves crashing onto the rocks below — is more than a postcard symbol of summer. It’s a reminder of what happens when nature turns violent. In “Light House,” performed at the Invisible Dog Art Center on Friday, the choreographer Anne Zuerner drew on movements from the natural world, both calm and forceful.

headline: Skirball Announces  Its 2014-15 Season
abstract: Classic Shakespeare, Canadian acrobats and a GPS-led trek are among events planned for the 2014-15 season at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts at New York University.
lead_paragraph: Classic Shakespeare, Canadian acrobats and a GPS-led trek are among events planned for the 2014-15 season at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts at New York University. Highlights include “King Lear,” from Sept. 29 to Oct. 12, presented by Shakespeare’s Globe, the company behind Broadway’s recent productions of “Twelfth Night” and “Richard III”; Quebec’s high-flying troupe Cirque Alfonse (Oct. 13 to 19); and the Joshua Light Show Festival, a psychedelic mix of music, light, dance and projections (Oct. 23 to 25). Next spring, a three-week run of “Remote New York” is to guide participants through the city with GPS instructions delivered via headphones. More information: nyuskirball.org.

headline: For Ensembles and Singers, a Night of Backbreaking Labor
abstract: The NY Phil Biennial presented two compositions dedicated to manual labor on Friday at Avery Fisher Hall: Julia Wolfe’s “Anthracite Fields” and Steven Mackey’s “Dreamhouse.”
lead_paragraph: The NY Phil Biennial presented a diptych of New York premieres dedicated to manual labor on Friday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. Julia Wolfe’s “Anthracite Fields” (2014) commemorates the Pennsylvania coal miners whose work fueled the industrial revolution. Steven Mackey’s “Dreamhouse” (2003) examines the process of building a house. Both works feature singers and an ensemble mixing acoustic and amplified instruments; both express unease with the American culture of comfort and consumption.

headline: A Composer’s Sensual Side
abstract: More accessible works by the stern postwar Modernist Pierre Boulez, and those he influenced, were featured in a NY Phil Biennial concert Saturday at the Rose Theater.
lead_paragraph: During the composer and conductor Pierre Boulez’s tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic in the 1970s, he challenged the repertorial status quo and reached out to new audiences with events like the Rug Concerts, where patrons lounged on cushions while listening to contemporary music.

headline: Hachette Chief Leads Book Publishers in Amazon Fight
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'E-Books and Readers']
abstract: Michael Pietsch, chief executive of the Hachette Book Group, finds himself fighting not just for the future of his company, but for that of every publisher that works with Amazon.
lead_paragraph: As a young book editor at Little, Brown & Company in 1992, Michael Pietsch paid $80,000 — $45,000 more than the next-highest bidder — for a postmodern novel by a little-known writer named David Foster Wallace.

headline: Showcasing Music Till the Sun Comes Up
abstract: Primavera Sound in Barcelona is an expansive music showcase that has gradually become one of the top tickets of the European festival season and a template for other promoters worldwide.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Caetano Veloso, the bossa nova elder statesman, was holding court here on Saturday evening, floating his baritone voice and easy guitar over an amphitheater audience that swayed and sang along as he offered a slightly raunchy paean to his native Brazilian sounds.

headline: Returning to Ice, Rangers Have Spring in Their Strides
abstract: After taking two days off to recharge, the Rangers, welcoming an unusual opportunity to play in June, geared up for the team’s first Stanley Cup finals in 20 years.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — After the Rangers’ first practice since their triumph over the Montreal Canadiens in the Eastern Conference finals, their coach spoke to the news media Sunday under a makeshift tent in front of their training complex. With the warm sunshine outside and a breezy spirit inside, the scene had the feel of a September training camp. The Rangers, though, have games ahead in June as they make their first Stanley Cup finals appearance in 20 years.

headline: Library Reveals Details and Costs of Upgrade Plan
abstract: The New York Public Library’s revised renovation plan is expected to cost about $300 million.
lead_paragraph: The New York Public Library’s revised renovation plan — to upgrade the Mid-Manhattan Library and create more public space in its flagship Fifth Avenue building — is expected to cost about $300 million, according to library officials who outlined new details of the project in interviews.

headline: A Post-Punk Band in Early Metamorphosis, Luxuriating in Unease
abstract: Lower has the noisy, hopeful drive toward reinvention, toward finding value in its own guesswork, impulses, mistakes, openness.
lead_paragraph: There is great meaning in the post-punk reaction, as there is always great meaning in the reaction of any child toward unstable parents. That reaction wasn’t confined to one period of time. It didn’t stop in, say, 1981. Punk, behind sound, is declarative and self-annihilating at the same time. It wants to assert itself and to disappear, and has done so, in regular overlapping cycles, all over the place, for all kinds of reasons.

headline: No-Trump Outscores the Major at Eastern States Regional
abstract: At the Eastern States Regional in Manhattan last month, the winners of the main pair event on the second day, May 22, were Augie Boehm and Donald Simmons of New York City.
lead_paragraph: At the Eastern States Regional in Manhattan last month, the winners of the main pair event on the second day, May 22, were Augie Boehm and Donald Simmons of New York City. They finished 0.75 match points ahead of Deborah Murphy of San Francisco and Gary Donner of Bluffton, S.C. Third were R. Jay Becker of New York City and Ron Smith of Las Vegas.

headline: Duda Homer Leaves Mets Delighted, if Exhausted
abstract: The Mets and the Phillies played into extra innings for the third time in three days, with Lucas Duda finally deciding the game in the 11th with a two-run homer in his first at-bat.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Mets and the Philadelphia Phillies were already familiar with each other, as division rivals, but on Sunday, as they entered extra innings for the third time in three days, they seemed to understand each other on a deeper, more intimate level.

headline: Kind of Test
abstract: The return of Monday queen Andrea Carla Michaels.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — We haven’t had an Andrea Carla Michaels Monday puzzle since March, but she’s back with a phonetic hint theme that unfurled itself slowly for me.

headline: The Rise and Fall of the Goddess of Democracy
abstract: A 33-foot-high statue became a mute yet powerful actor in the final drama on Tiananmen Square in 1989, reinvigorating the student protests and infuriating Communist Party leaders.
lead_paragraph: A 33-foot-high statue became a mute yet powerful actor in the final drama on Tiananmen Square in 1989, reinvigorating the student protests and infuriating Communist Party leaders who crushed the demonstrations, and the statue, five days after its birth.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Political Advertising', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: A Digital Agency Draws a Pair of Aces in Brazil
abstract: Hugo Veiga and Diego Machado, who created acclaimed initiatives for Unilever’s Dove brand, will open AKQA’s creative center in São Paulo.
lead_paragraph: AN acclaimed advertising creative team that has been celebrated for several successful campaigns is joining a digital agency on a fast growth curve to help it grow faster.

headline: The Story of Gay America, via Personal Interviews
abstract: OutLoud, which will begin on June 28, the 45th anniversary of the Stonewall riots in Greenwich Village, will focus on young and minority gays and those who lived before the riots.
lead_paragraph: David Isay, the founder of the nonprofit oral history group StoryCorps, tried for many years with little success to raise money for a project to collect stories from the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and questioning community.

headline: Down on Modi’s Farm
abstract: India’s new prime minister has a lot of new seed to plant.
lead_paragraph: India’s new prime minister has a lot of new seed to plant.

headline: Inside the Fixing: How a Gang Battered Soccer’s Frail Integrity
abstract: The history of a duo working for a Singaporean match-fixing syndicate reveals how pervasively illicit gambling operations have infected global soccer.
lead_paragraph: ROVANIEMI, Finland — A man arrived at the police station here in 2011 with an unusual tip. He told the police that a Singaporean man was fixing matches with the local professional soccer team. The police were incredulous.

headline: Can the Market Stave Off Global Warming?
abstract: Is cap and trade the best chance for stemming climate change, or are other methods needed?

headline: Sex Crimes That Shouldn’t Be
abstract: H.I.V. disclosure laws are not just unfair; they no longer serve any practical purpose.
lead_paragraph: As creatures who are both participants in public life, and individuals with private lives and concerns, we are constantly challenged to balance our own needs and rights against the public good. In many cases, that challenge comes down to weighing the societal benefits of transparency against the need for for personal privacy. The most familiar and heated debates of late, of course, involve high-tech government spying without consent from individuals — surveillance that in many cases extended to the unsuspecting person’s bedrooms.

headline: A River Runs Through Their Pictures and Lives
abstract: More than half a century since Inge Morath photographed the Danube, nine young female photographers will follow her footsteps and add to her legacy.
lead_paragraph: More than half a century since Inge Morath photographed the Danube, nine young female photographers will follow her footsteps and add to her legacy.

headline: America’s Highways, Running on Empty
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Transportation', 'Gasoline Tax (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The government can no longer rely on gas taxes to fix the nation’s roads.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IF you think your commute is getting worse, it’s probably not your imagination. And no, it’s not because there are more cars on the road. The potholes, the stalled construction projects, the congestion — it’s because the highway trust fund is almost empty and, without a fix, could run out of money this summer.

headline: Amazon Absorbing Price Fight Punches
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'BookExpo America', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'E-Books and Readers']
abstract: By blocking inventory from the Hachette Book Group, Amazon has become the less-than-everything store.
lead_paragraph: Books, we are told, are relics that have reached their sell-by date, put out by an industry that is a desiccated shell of its former self.

headline: Amazon and a Mattel Unit Plan a ‘Content Hub’ Focusing on Children
keywords: ['Toys', 'Television', 'E-Commerce', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Children and Childhood', 'Online Advertising', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists']
abstract: The shopping website is teaming with Hit Entertainment to offer episodes of the children’s television program “Fireman Sam” and the opportunity to buy related products, side by side.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Fireman Sam,” a cartoon aimed at preschoolers, has long been a hit overseas. Now Mattel and Amazon are teaming up to sell the yellow-hatted hero to American children — a potentially controversial experiment that, if successful, could create a new model for marrying television shows with related merchandise.

headline: Lee Chamberlin, ‘Electric Company’ Actress, Dies at 76
abstract: Ms. Chamberlin, whose career took off when she joined Bill Cosby and Rita Moreno on the funky 1970s show, jumped from children’s television to Shakespeare.
lead_paragraph: Lee Chamberlin, an actress whose career took off when she joined Bill Cosby and Rita Moreno on the funky 1970s children’s show “The Electric Company,” died on May 25 in Chapel Hill, N.C. She was 76.

headline: A Verdict on Budgets in Europe and Jobs Data in U.S.
abstract: The European Commission is expected to rule on whether budgets for its member states pass muster, and American figures on manufacturing, job creation and unemployment are due.
lead_paragraph: EUROPEAN COMMISSION TO RULE ON STATE BUDGETS

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 2
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Education (K-12)', 'Income Tax', 'Government Bonds', 'Auctions']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: The Vanishing Cry of ‘Repeal It’
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Campaigning Republicans thought they could coast into office on a wave of public fury over health care reform. They thought wrong.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be so easy this election year for Republican congressional candidates. All they would have to do was shout “repeal Obamacare!” and make a crack about government doctors and broken websites, and they could coast into office on a wave of public fury. The failure of the Affordable Care Act was simply assumed.

headline: Emerging From the Shadows Cast Across a River
abstract: A radio station in Arkansas that ignited the careers of several musical greats before shutting down in 1960 is being revived by a community college, which hopes its return will lift the local economy.
lead_paragraph: WEST MEMPHIS, Ark. — It takes little prodding to draw stories from Larry Manuel about how, before they were the subjects of films and supernatural sightings, Johnny Cash and Elvis Presley were just two musicians trying to make it along the Mississippi River.

headline: Israel Warns Against Embracing Newly Reconciled Palestinian Government
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel called on the international community “not to run to recognize” the new Palestinian government scheduled to be sworn in Monday, saying it rests on a terrorist organization.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel called on the international community on Sunday “not to run to recognize” the new Palestinian government scheduled to be sworn in Monday, saying it “rests on Hamas,” the militant Islamic faction that Israel and much of the West deem a terrorist organization.

headline: With South Bronx Trail, a History and a Culture Will Be Clearly Marked
abstract: The South Bronx Culture Trail, funded by an $80,000 grant from the New York Community Trust, will create a self-guided tour of the neighborhood’s cultural history.
lead_paragraph: Casa Amadeo on Prospect Avenue, a Latin record store on the National Register of Historic Places, is perhaps the only place in the city where one can worship at a shrine dedicated to the Puerto Rican composer Rafael Hernández.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: June arrives with a different Final Four, as the Miami Heat take on the San Antonio Spurs in the N.B.A. Finals — a rematch of 2013.
lead_paragraph: June arrives with a different Final Four, as the Miami Heat take on the San Antonio Spurs in the N.B.A. Finals — a rematch of 2013.

headline: In GPS Battle, Russia Sets Restrictions of Its Own
abstract: In imposing restrictions on the American satellite navigation system, Russia is answering the refusal of the United States to allow similar base stations on its soil.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The deputy prime minister in charge of Russia’s space programs said Sunday that he had started to impose restrictions on Global Positioning System base stations here, as retribution for the refusal of the United States to allow similar base stations on American territory that would improve the accuracy of Russia’s navigation system.

headline: On Inequality Denial
abstract: It persists because there are groups with a strong interest in creating a fog of doubt.
lead_paragraph: A while back I published an article titled “The Rich, the Right, and the Facts,” in which I described politically motivated efforts to deny the obvious — the sharp rise in U.S. inequality, especially at the very top of the income scale. It probably won’t surprise you to hear that I found a lot of statistical malpractice in high places.

headline: Ann B. Davis, 88, Dies; Comic Actress Played Maid on ‘Brady Bunch’
abstract: Her Alice Nelson, housekeeper for a blended family, was Ms. Davis’s best-known plain-Jane character. Schultzy, on ‘The Bob Cummings Show,’ was another.
lead_paragraph: Ann B. Davis, the comic actress best known as the wistful, wisecracking live-in maid on the long-running ABC sitcom “The Brady Bunch,” died on Sunday in San Antonio. She was 88.

headline: Lewis Katz’s Vision for the New Jersey Nets Went Unrealized
abstract: As an owner of the Nets when they were in New Jersey, Lewis Katz, who died Saturday in a plane crash, had a plan to help Newark, the state’s largest city.
lead_paragraph: In November 1999, Lewis Katz stood on a high school stage in New Jersey’s largest city and told an audience of students, local politicians and a smiling President Bill Clinton, “The New Jersey Nets are coming to Newark — remember that.”

headline: Bad Food in School Cafeterias
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Lunch and Breakfast Programs', 'Education (K-12)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Congress must resist any push to weaken the lunch guidelines, and states must guard against accounting tricks used to snare a waiver.
lead_paragraph: Republicans on a powerful House committee have balked at requiring all schools to serve healthy lunches in the coming school year. The action drew a well-deserved rebuke from the first lady, Michelle Obama, who has focused public attention on combating obesity among young people through exercise and better nutrition. Let’s hope the Senate holds out against such inanity.

headline: A Vote on Medical Marijuana
abstract: The State Senate should follow the Assembly’s lead and approve legislation that has wide support from medical groups.
lead_paragraph: The New York State Assembly easily approved a law legalizing medical marijuana last Tuesday, and there appear to be enough votes to pass similar legislation in the State Senate if that chamber’s leaders agree to allow a vote. They ought to do so before the legislative session ends on June 19. The bills would make the drug available, under tight regulation, to patients who, in many cases, do not get relief from other medications.

headline: As Antics Subside, Both Cuomo and the Left Claim the Last Hurrah
abstract: After a vote by the Working Families Party to support Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, liberals were exulting in what they believed would be the start of a tectonic shift in New York politics.
lead_paragraph: COLONIE, N.Y. — Weeks of intense negotiations between Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and an impatient, insurgent left resolved themselves shortly before midnight on Saturday in a stormy night of brinkmanship and shuttle diplomacy.

headline: Encouragement (Sort of) About Press Freedom
keywords: ['News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Editorials', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. may have suggested that he wouldn’t send reporters to jail for doing their jobs, but he did not rule out steep fines or inflicting other damages.
lead_paragraph: UPDATE June 2, 2014:  The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear the appeal from James Risen, a reporter for The Times who has been ordered to testify in the criminal trial of a former Central Intelligence Agency official.

headline: Yes, All Men
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', "Women's Rights", 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Fighting sexism and misogyny isn’t just women’s work.
lead_paragraph: As I drove my son back to college last week, where he’ll take a summer chemistry course, he said something that struck me: “I believe it’s very important for everyone to be a feminist.”

headline: Insider-Trading Inquiry Could Rattle Icahn’s Efforts to Shape His Legacy
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Insider Trading', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has a record as an activist investor that rivals call enviable, but it could be scorched by a spotlight turned harsh.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Carl C. Icahn has enjoyed the spotlight.

headline: Scots Are Divided Over Independence, and Its Economic Costs
abstract: Voices inside and outside Scotland are warning of the implications of leaving the United Kingdom, even as supporters say Scotland would be better off by itself.
lead_paragraph: BEITH, Scotland — The case for tearing apart the United Kingdom was made on a recent evening at a community center in this small town near Glasgow. More than 200 people were packed into folding chairs and standing along walls lined with posters promoting an independent Scotland, like the one with the word “Aye” emblazoned on a Scottish flag. A disco ball hung overhead.

headline: Pitching for Fun, and for a Future
abstract: Jeff Francoeur and Jason Lane, veterans on the Class AAA El Paso Chihuahuas, see pitching as a way to return to the major leagues.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — It is early on a Wednesday afternoon, and most of the schoolchildren have been called to their buses. From his spot in right field — beneath the Woofdeck, close to the stand that sells nachos in a dog dish for $10 — Jeff Francoeur has been roasting in the blistering desert heat.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 1, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: June 1, 2014

headline: Trying to Reclaim Leadership on Climate Change
abstract: New rules to reduce coal pollution are calculated to keep President Obama’s pledge to cut greenhouse gases, but by itself, the plan will barely budge global emissions.
lead_paragraph: At the end of his first year in office, President Obama flew to Copenhagen and made a big promise: that the United States would cut its greenhouse gas emissions substantially by 2020 — a bold and risky pledge that hinged on a balky Congress to make it possible. His efforts became bogged down within months, and Mr. Obama’s pledge to the rest of the world soon looked like a pipe dream.

headline: At Ukraine’s Perilous Border, Law Is Dispensed by Men in Masks
abstract: Ukraine’s easternmost province of Luhansk has become a lawless expanse where dying coal mines and joblessness feed an insurgency.
lead_paragraph: KRASNYY LUCH, Ukraine — Just over the bridge here, near a crumbling blue electric station, a white sign with plain blue letters informs travelers that they are about to enter foreign territory: “Luhansk People’s Republic, Independent State.”

headline: With Mixed Showing, U.S. Gives Its Coach a Win to Study
abstract: The men’s national team beat Turkey, 2-1, on Sunday in a game that gave Coach Jurgen Klinsmann an opportunity to find the best starting lineup for the Americans’ World Cup opener on June 16.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — Jurgen Klinsmann has been preparing for World Cups long enough to know not to show his hand two weeks before the opening game. Not to reporters, certainly. But not to his players, either. So he tinkers with his lineups and his tactics, and he generally keeps his opinions to himself.

headline: Visitors Fault Sept. 11 Museum’s Portrayal of Islam
abstract: Some visitors to the National September 11 Memorial Museum described its treatment of Islam and terrorism as “clinical” and “light” and said they thought a Muslim might feel uncomfortable visiting.
lead_paragraph: After the vivid audio recordings, diagrams and personal artifacts that take visitors minute by minute through the Sept. 11 attacks, and before the images of recovery workers combing through rubble, a small section of the National September 11 Memorial Museum is devoted to explaining Al Qaeda and terrorism.

headline: Experience at Muirfield Helps a 22-Year-Old Win in a Playoff for His First PGA Title
abstract: Hideki Matsuyama of Japan defeated Kevin Na on the first extra hole to win the Memorial Tournament.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — It felt like October all over for Japan’s Hideki Matsuyama, who played the final round of the Memorial Tournament with Australia’s Adam Scott, his International team partner at last year’s Presidents Cup.

headline: Census Records Shed a New Light on Some of the Mayor’s Forebears
abstract: New details about how Mayor Bill de Blasio’s relatives arrived from Italy may help explain how his “Tale of Two Cities” campaign theme evolved.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio’s mother was born in the house on East 17th Street in Manhattan. His grandmother, great-grandmother and other relatives lived there, too, at the start of the 20th century. Now, newly-digitized records from a 1905 New York State census have filled in some of the gaps in the congenial Italian heritage that he says grounded him, while his German-American father struggled with alcoholism and ultimately killed himself.

headline: At Least 13 Are Wounded by Gunfire Across New York City
abstract: The string of shootings followed an annual cycle of violence recognized by the New York Police Department: When the temperature rises, the level of violence climbs along with it.
lead_paragraph: The victims were at outdoor celebrations or cookouts with friends. In one case, a teenager was wounded on a basketball court; two others were struck while walking together in memory of a 15-year-old killed by gunfire four years before.

headline: Will the Kingdom Stay United?
abstract: In September, Scots will vote on whether Scotland will remain in Britain or become an independent nation.
lead_paragraph: In September, Scots will vote on whether Scotland will remain in Britain or become an independent nation.

headline: Underdog Seeks Jump From Second to Spoiler
abstract: Ride On Curlin was not coveted by many bidders as a yearling in 2012, but under the trainer Billy Gowan, he has developed into a threat to win the Belmont Stakes on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The horse does not look the part of one of the top 3-year-olds in the country. The trainer oversees only four horses, and his fortunes took such a horrible turn two winters ago that he had none to work with. The owner has a passion for racing but lacks a budget to match.

headline: Rangers, Despite Odds, Have a Lot in Their Favor
abstract: The Rangers may be regarded as an underdog against the Kings, but they have advantages that have served them well so far in the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Rangers and the Los Angeles Kings have met twice in the playoffs since the Kings entered the N.H.L. in 1967, but they have never met in the Stanley Cup finals. That will change Wednesday when the finals begin in Los Angeles.

headline: Before Brief, Deadly Spree, Trouble Since Age 8
keywords: ['Isla Vista, Calif, Massacre (2014)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Before Elliot O. Rodger killed six people and took his own life in Isla Vista, Calif., his mental health and increasingly withdrawn behavior worried his parents and others.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was the summer of 1999, and the parents of Elliot O. Rodger were battling over the boy’s deep and puzzling psychological problems as they struggled through a divorce.

headline: Etihad Nears Deal for a Stake in Alitalia
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Etihad, owned by the government of Abu Dhabi, plans to make an offer for a stake of up to 49 percent of the money-losing Italian airline.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After more than five months of negotiations, Etihad Airways of Abu Dhabi confirmed on Sunday that it was nearing an agreement that could lead to a sizable investment in Alitalia.

headline: An Ideal Place, Except for All the Dead Bodies
abstract: Theater for a New Audience has revived Ionesco’s “The Killer,” in which an Everyman tries to track down the source of evil that is leaving people dead in an otherwise idyllic place.
lead_paragraph: There are little-known plays by well-known writers that, when once viewed, strike you as being unjustly, even criminally neglected. Eugene Ionesco’s “The Killer” is not one of them. Au contraire! This is the kind of rarity that theater aficionados may be eager to see until they have the misfortune of seeing it.

headline: Women’s Hats on a Harlem Bus
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A new arrival marveled at the color and the designs of the hats worn by women on a bus.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary,

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 11
abstract: Mexico and Italy both lost key players in pre-World Cup friendlies this weekend.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Prisoner Trade Yields Rare View Into the Taliban
abstract: Representatives of both sides played down the idea that the exchange, long seen as a crucial prelude to any broader talks, might breathe new life into a peace effort.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The freeing of five senior Taliban figures in exchange for the American soldier, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, has offered both a rare insight into the insurgent group’s inner workings and a diplomatic first in the long Afghan war: a negotiated agreement between the highest levels of the American government and the pinnacle of the Taliban command.

headline: Trial Begins for Queens Democrat Charged With Bribery, Extortion and Fraud
abstract: Malcolm A. Smith was open about his ambitions to run for mayor of New York City. On Monday, he goes on trial in federal court on charges of bribery and extortion for trying to influence county leaders to certify him as a Republican in the 2013 race.
lead_paragraph: Malcolm A. Smith wanted to be the mayor of New York City so badly that he, a Democratic Queens state senator and onetime Senate majority and minority leader, was willing to run as a Republican in a city where Democrats hold a 6-1 edge.

headline: Next Move for Fisher: Coaching, or Maybe Politics
abstract: With the end of the Oklahoma City Thunder’s season, the veteran Derek Fisher could have tantalizing opportunities as a coach or an executive, in television or even in politics — that is, if he does not continue playing.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — The first time Derek Fisher arrived in New York, in 1996, a wide-eyed rookie with the Los Angeles Lakers, he did not enjoy any of the city’s restaurants, visit Central Park, take in any theater or hop to any clubs.

headline: Planned Celebration for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl Just Got a Whole Lot Bigger
abstract: In Hailey, Idaho, the soldier’s hometown, interest has skyrocketed in an event that was scheduled for this month and originally called Bring Bowe Back 2014.
lead_paragraph: HAILEY, Idaho — It looked as if it was going to be a big weekend here in the Wood River Valley in Central Idaho.

headline: Panel to Create Plan to Reduce Number of Mentally Ill People in New York City Jails
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio has asked a task force that includes police and correction commissioners to provide him with ideas on how to reduce the rate of incarceration.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has asked several of his commissioners and aides to provide him with a plan by September to reduce the rate of incarceration among New Yorkers with mental illness.

headline: Drama Desk Embraces ‘A Gentleman’s Guide’
abstract: The Broadway musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” led the trophy tally with seven on Sunday night at the Drama Desk Awards.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” led the trophy tally with seven on Sunday night at the Drama Desk Awards, which honor Broadway and Off Broadway productions. “Gentleman’s Guide,” a strong contender in next weekend’s Tonys competition, won for outstanding musical, outstanding actor (Jefferson Mays), featured actress (Lauren Worsham), director (Darko Tresnjak), lyrics, book and projection design. “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical” followed with three awards, including for actress in a musical (Jessie Mueller as Carole King), sound design and featured actress (Anika Larsen, who tied with Ms. Worsham). Robert Schenkkan’s “All the Way” won for outstanding play and actor (Bryan Cranston as Lyndon B. Johnson), with other top awards for plays going to Audra McDonald (“Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar & Grill”) for best actress and “Twelfth Night” for outstanding revival and director (Tim Carroll). In the musical category, “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” took honors for outstanding revival and actor (Neil Patrick Harris as Hedwig, who shared the award with Mr. Mays). Featured acting awards went to Reed Birney (“Casa Valentina”), Celia Keenan-Bolger (“The Glass Menagerie”) and James Monroe Iglehart (“Aladdin”).

headline: K.K.R. Shuts Stock Hedge Fund
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has closed its equity strategies fund, known as KES, and the firm will focus on other ways to build out a hedge fund arm.
lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts made waves in the fall of 2010 when the investment giant poached a trading team from Goldman Sachs to set up a hedge fund focused on stock trading.

headline: Is Global Warming Real? Most Americans Say Yes
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Global Warming']
abstract: A majority of people favor action to slow climate change, although it is not among their top policy priorities.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration announced new regulations Monday meant to reduce carbon emissions and combat climate change.

headline: Major Malfunction: Revisiting Challenger
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Challenger (Space Shuttle)', 'Columbia (Space Shuttle)', 'Explosions (Accidental)', 'Space Shuttles']
abstract: Thirty years ago, on Jan. 28, 1986, seven astronauts “slipped the surly bonds of earth to touch the face of God.” America’s space program was never the same.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, on Jan. 28, 1986, seven astronauts “slipped the surly bonds of earth to touch the face of God.” America’s space program was never the same.

headline: Challenger, Columbia and the Nature of Calamity
keywords: ['Columbia (Space Shuttle)', 'Challenger (Space Shuttle)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: Over 30 years, there were 135 American shuttle launches and returns, and 133 were successes. Perhaps inevitably, it is the other two that people remember best.
lead_paragraph: They died as they slipped the surly bonds of Earth. The last words of that sentence, haunting words, were written by John Gillespie Magee Jr., an American airman and poet who enlisted in the Royal Canadian Air Force in 1940, before the United States entered World War II. He was killed the following year in a midair collision over England. He was all of 19.

headline: Boy, 6, Dies After a Stabbing in Brooklyn
abstract: A man stabbed two children in a Brooklyn housing development on Sunday evening, killing a 6-year-old boy and leaving a 7-year-old girl in critical condition, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Mikayla Capers and her best friend, Prince Joshua Avitto, wanted to get Icees. The two hopped in an elevator on Sunday at the Brooklyn housing project where they lived. A man got on after them, pulled out a knife and stabbed the children, the police said, in an attack that left residents stunned.

headline: With Ukraine Still Unsettled, Obama Sets Off to Soothe European Friends
abstract: The United States is boasting it rallied allies on the Continent to contain the Eastern European crisis, but many remain wary of what Putin may have in mind to do next.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama leaves for Europe on Monday night cautiously optimistic that the crisis in Ukraine has turned a corner, but he will find himself face to face with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for the first time since the two squared off in a Cold-War-style showdown in Eastern Europe.

headline: ‘Halt and Catch Fire’ Recap: Can Geekiness Be Entertaining?
abstract: A couple of broody guys drawn together, against their better judgement.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 1: The premiere of “Halt and Catch Fire,” which aired on Sunday on AMC, owes much to that long-ago first episode of “Breaking Bad.” A couple of mysterious, broody guys are drawn together against their better judgment. Together they set off on a scheme both hyper-technical and legally dubious, one that seems certain to tear apart everything else in their lives. And we get to witness their tricks through a parade of luscious, barely comprehensible montages.

headline: ‘Penny Dreadful’ Recap:  Blood and Gore Are so Entertaining
abstract: The sharpshooter and Dorian Gray find a new dimension to their relationship.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 4: Up until now, the “Penny Dreadful” recaps have focused on what just happened, not what may be around the fog-shrouded corner. But one plot point that has been hovering around the edges comes just shy of bursting to the surface in this episode, “Demimonde,” to the point where it can’t really be ignored anymore. (As before, here lie spoilers galore.)

headline: Kings Go the Distance, and Then Some, to Reach the Finals
abstract: Winning a Game 7 on the road for the third time this postseason, Los Angeles outlasted Chicago, 5-4, in overtime and advanced to play the Rangers in the Stanley Cup finals.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Chicago Blackhawks, the defending Stanley Cup champions, won two straight games to force Sunday’s Game 7 on their home ice. A year ago, they sliced through the Los Angeles Kings in five games on this very stage, the Western Conference finals.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. 2, Turkey 1
abstract: Player ratings for the U.S. men’s national team’s second exhibition game ahead of the 2014 World Cup in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: The United States national team defeated Turkey on a sunny spring day at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J., in its second exhibition game ahead of the 2014 World Cup in Brazil.

headline: With New Palestinian Government Come Many Questions, and Some Answers
abstract: What is in it for Hamas? What might Israel do? Jodi Rudoren, the Jerusalem bureau chief of The New York Times, provides some answers.
lead_paragraph: The new Palestinian government sworn in on Monday in the West Bank city of Ramallah, will be led by Prime Minister Rami Hamdallah and is to consist of 16 other ministers, some handling more than one portfolio. Four are from the Gaza Strip and were barred by Israel from attending the ceremony. The government grew out of a reconciliation pact signed between the Palestine Liberation Organization, dominated by the secular Fatah faction, and Hamas, the militant Islamic movement that has ruled Gaza since 2007.

headline: New Therapies for Bowel Diseases
abstract: Treatment for inflammatory bowel disease — Crohn’s and ulcerative colitis — has made great advances, with less disruptive surgery.
lead_paragraph: Decades ago, I met a surprisingly quiet, withdrawn young man. Surprising because I knew his bright, vibrant wife and wondered what had attracted her to him. He barely participated in conversations even at friendly family gatherings.

headline: After Interruption, No Stopping Sharapova at French Open
abstract: Maria Sharapova pounced on Samantha Stosur’s momentary lapse in the second set to rally for a 3-6, 6-4, 6-0 victory.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Maria Sharapova looked as if she might be bowing out of the French Open in the fourth round to Samantha Stosur — until she heard a call.

headline: Study Examines Efficacy of Taxes on Sugary Drinks
keywords: ['Soft Drinks', 'Taxation', 'Sugar', 'Calories', 'Weight', 'Law and Legislation', 'Research', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: A system that is based on calories rather than size would be fairer to consumers and could curb consumption, according to research financed by an organization that advocates the tax.
lead_paragraph: A new study of how taxes might be used to curb consumption of sugary drinks suggests that applying a tax based on the amount of calories contained in a serving rather than its size would be more effective.

headline: Tales of Army Discord Show Tiananmen Square in a New Light
abstract: In 1989, a Chinese general refused to take part in violence against protesters, sending tremors through the Communist Party establishment, documents and interviews show.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — On a spring evening in 1989, with the student occupation of Tiananmen Square entering its second month and the Chinese leadership unnerved and divided, top army commanders were summoned to headquarters to pledge their support for the use of military force to quash the protests.

headline: What’s On Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) A HARD DAY’S NIGHT (1964) When this film from the director Richard Lester had its debut, Bosley Crowther of The New York Times was astounded. “I wouldn’t believe it either, if I hadn’t seen it with my own astonished eyes,” he wrote of this first fiction film of the Beatles, adding that it “has so much good humor going for it that it is awfully hard to resist.” The film stars the Fab Four poking fun at Beatlemania in a plotline that takes viewers through the misadventures before a big show. “And all the way through the picture, there are frenzied episodes of the Beatles’ encounters with squealing fans and with reporters who ask silly questions, all in a facile, witty vein,” Mr. Crowther wrote. “But more than this, it’s a fine conglomeration of madcap clowning in the old Marx Brothers’ style, and it is done with such a dazzling use of camera that it tickles the intellect and electrifies the nerves.” Above, Mr. Lester at the train window with the Beatles.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on June 2, 2014.

headline: Anger in China After McDonald’s Patron Beaten to Death
abstract: Six people from a group known as the Church of the Almighty God were arrested in the killing of a woman at a McDonald’s restaurant in eastern china, but a cellphone video of the attack raised questions about whether witnesses should have intervened.
lead_paragraph: The beating death of a woman in a McDonald’s restaurant in eastern China has triggered widespread anger over the slow response of witnesses and condemnation of a fringe religious group that the police say influenced the attackers.

headline: China’s Solar Panel Production Comes at a Dirty Cost
abstract: A solar panel made in China would have to be in service as much as 30 percent longer than a European model to compensate for the extra energy used in its production, an American study found.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:23 a.m. ET| Although China may be a cheaper place than Europe for producing solar panels, the savings come at a higher cost to the environment, a new study says.

headline: Marathon Oil Sells Norwegian Unit for $2.1 Billion
abstract: Marathon sold its Norwegian business to Det Norske Oljeselskap of Norway and said it had called off the sale of its British business after failing to receive an acceptable offer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The exploration and production company Marathon Oil said on Monday that it would sell its North Sea oil business in Norway to a Norwegian oil producer for $2.1 billion in cash.

headline: As Poles Focus on Belonging to Europe, Their Love for the U.S. Has Cooled a Bit
abstract: When President Obama visits Poland on Tuesday, he will find a nation still heavily pro-American, but where the focus has turned to the European Union.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — “Poland is the most pro-American country in the world — including the United States,” goes a quip, well known here, from an American foreign policy expert more than a decade ago.

headline: Roche to Pay Up to $350 Million for DNA Sequencing Business
abstract: The Swiss company will pay $125 million in cash for Genia Technologies of California, plus as much as $225 million in contingency payments if the business reaches certain milestones.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Roche, the Swiss drug and health care diagnostics maker, said on Monday that it would pay as much as $350 million for Genia Technologies, a privately held DNA sequencing company.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Bowe Bergdahl, American Soldier, Freed by Taliban in Prisoner Trade
abstract: What kinds of struggles will Sergeant Bergdahl likely face after being freed from long-term captivity?
lead_paragraph: In “Bowe Bergdahl, American Soldier, Freed by Taliban in Prisoner Trade,” Eric Schmitt and Charlie Savage report on the release of the lone American prisoner of war from the Afghan conflict.

headline: A River Changes Young Women’s Photography, and Their Lives
abstract: More than half a century since Inge Morath photographed the Danube, nine young female photographers will follow her footsteps and add to her legacy.
lead_paragraph: Inge Morath grew overwhelmed with panic one day in 1958, as she was on the road to the source of one of Europe’s largest rivers, the Danube.

headline: Are Your Parents Too Overprotective?
abstract: What kind of freedoms do you wish you had that you do not have?
lead_paragraph: Do you feel your parents are always watching over you — worried you will get hurt or in trouble? When you were younger, did your parents give you free reign to explore the neighborhood or woods with your buddies — or did you always feel that you were on a short leash?

headline: GlaxoSmithKline in $350 Million Cancer Drug Venture
abstract: The deal with the biotechnology company Adaptimmune comes a little over a month after Glaxo agreed to sell its cancer drug business to the Swiss pharmaceutical maker Novartis.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Adaptimmune, a biotechnology company, said on Monday that it had reached a deal that could be worth more than $350 million to develop an early stage cancer drug with the pharmaceutical maker GlaxoSmithKline.

headline: A King Makes a Powerful Change, for Stability
abstract: Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain announced that Crown Prince Felipe would succeed King Juan Carlos.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — King Juan Carlos of Spain said Monday that he was abdicating in favor of Crown Prince Felipe, his 46-year-old son, explaining in an address to the nation that it was time for a new generation to “move to the front line” and face the country’s challenges.

headline: Coal Comfort
abstract: Really good news on environmental policy.
lead_paragraph: I recently had a discussion with someone who felt disappointed in Obama; he had not, this person complained, lived up to the high hopes of his supporters. My response apparently came as a surprise: I’m liking Obama more and more as he slogs through his second term.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Scott Anderson on the Lasting Pain of Conflict in Srebrenica
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Scott Anderson, a war correspondent and novelist, wrote the June 1 cover story about life in Srebrenica, where genocide occurred during the breakup of Yugoslavia.
lead_paragraph: Scott Anderson, a war correspondent and novelist, wrote the June 1 cover story about life in Srebrenica, where genocide occurred during the breakup of Yugoslavia. Anderson is the author of the novel “Moonlight Hotel” and is working on a book about World War I. His last article for the magazine was about a man who killed his parents when he was 14.

headline: For Bonds, This Time is Different
abstract: Where have all the working-age people gone?
lead_paragraph: Bloomberg has an interesting piece on how high bond prices and low yields have been shocking investors who relied on old models. Some of this, I suspect, is because many people still — after all these years — haven’t wrapped their minds around the implications of a zero-lower=bound economy and the risks of a low-inflation trap.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today: June Is for Hockey Heroes
abstract: What you need to know for Monday: the Rangers get ready to take on the Kings, glorious weather, and a former lawmaker’s bribery trial begins.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this fair Monday.

headline: Separatists Attack a Border Guard Headquarters in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: The station, whose function is to check for smuggled goods, not to fight paramilitary forces, was under siege for more than 12 hours.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Several hundred separatist fighters mounted a coordinated assault against a border guard headquarters in the eastern city of Luhansk on Monday, holding it under siege for more than 12 hours in what appeared to be an attempt to eliminate the strategic control center for the region’s long and porous border with Russia.

headline: Q. and A.: Chen Guang on the Soldiers Who Retook Tiananmen Square
abstract: Chen Guang, one of the soldiers ordered to clear the protesters from Tiananmen Square in 1989, describes those days in an interview conducted before his detention by the Chinese authorities in the lead-up to the anniversary of the crackdown.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1989, Chen Guang was a 17-year-old soldier with the 65th Group Army, which was instructed to clear student protesters from Tiananmen Square. The 65th Group Army, based north of Beijing in Hebei Province, made two attempts to enter the capital, the first on May 20 after the declaration of martial law. That attempt failed, after thousands of Beijing residents swarmed the streets and halted their convoy. The second, successful, attempt was on June 3, and Mr. Chen was among the first soldiers to make it past the blockades of protesters and enter the Great Hall of the People with thousands of weapons he had secretly transported on a public bus.

headline: Celebration, and Lingering Tensions, as India’s 29th State Is Born
abstract: The streets of Hyderabad were thronged by Telangana supporters as it became India’s 29th state on Monday.
lead_paragraph: HYDERABAD, India — On Monday, the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh officially split in two, and India’s 29th state, Telangana, was born. President’s rule — the interim government of united Andhra Pradesh — lifted in the new state, and the first popular government of Telangana came into power.

headline: Pinpointing Another Reason That More Hispanics Are Identifying as White
abstract: Evidence suggests that it’s partly because of a subtle change in a question in the 2010 census.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I wrote about new research that showed that a net 1.2 million Hispanics changed their racial identification from “some other race” to “white” between the 2000 and 2010 censuses.

headline: Calling an Ordinary Health Problem a Disease Leads to Bigger Problems
abstract: Words matter. Putting a label on normal variations of physiology can cause needless worry, spending and even bodily harm.
lead_paragraph: As any parent knows, babies spit up. It’s gastroesophageal reflux, a pediatrician will explain — milk leaking backward from the stomach. When I was a pediatrics resident, my hospital constructed foam wedges for infants to sleep on. The thinking was that infants who were sleeping at an angle would be less likely to have milk come back up.

headline: Japan’s Dai-ichi Life to Consider Investments in United States
keywords: ['Life Insurance', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: But the Japanese insurer declined to confirm media reports that it was weighing a $4.9 billion acquisition of Protective Life of Alabama.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Japanese insurer Dai-ichi Life said on Monday that it was considering investments in life insurance companies in the United States, but it declined to confirm media reports that it was weighing an acquisition of Protective Life of Alabama.

headline: A Question of Family Ties Between G.E. and Alstom Law Firm
abstract: Some French media outlets have raised a fuss that G.E.’s chief executive shares family ties with the incoming chief executive of a law firm that works for Alstom.
lead_paragraph: General Electric has faced a number of questions over its proposed takeover of most of the French energy giant Alstom.

headline: Gay Travel: Normalcy Becomes the Story

headline: Answers to Questions About the New Palestinian Government
abstract: What does the new government, with the support of Fatah and Hamas, mean for the Palestinians, for Israel and for the American-backed peace process?
lead_paragraph: As a new Palestinian government was sworn in on Monday, The Times’s Jerusalem Bureau chief, Jodi Rudoren, answered readers’ questions. The transitional government of 17 ministers grew out of a unity pact reached in April between the Palestine Liberation Organization, which is dominated by the mainstream Fatah faction, and its rival Hamas, the Islamic militant group that has controlled the Gaza Strip since 2007. As Ms. Rudoren reported, the development has alarmed Israel and could prompt reactions from the European Union and the United States.

headline: Pakistani Premier in Delicate Dance With India
abstract: Over the course of 15 years, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan has courted and been at odds with neighboring India.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, returned home from New Delhi to faint praise and considerable criticism, the latter suggesting that his 30-hour sojourn in Delhi to attend the swearing-in ceremony of Prime Minister Narendra Modi last week had been his riskiest gamble yet in improving his country’s relations with India.

headline: On the Verge | The Swedish Takeover of L.A.
abstract: Blame the weather. The city of eternal sunshine has become a haven for many a creative Swede.
lead_paragraph: Throngs of Swedes eager to escape the land of the midnight sun are traveling to the land of eternal sunshine. Blame the obvious (weather), the logistical (Norwegian Air Shuttle’s new direct flight from Stockholm) or the sartorial (Acne Studios’ opening of a West Coast outpost); whatever the reason, Los Angeles has become a new home away from ‘Holm for many Swedish creatives. “Without fail, every single day there’s a bunch of Swedes in the lobby,” says Fredrik Carlstrom, who ensconced himself at the newish Ace Hotel while overseeing the recent launch of Austere, a nearby Scandi-centric retail showroom and event space. Come late next year, downtown L.A. will also house AYD (short for “All Your Dreams”), a Nordic-influenced members club designed by Andreas Fornell (formerly Acne’s in-house architect). AYD will boast Swedish chefs (Adam & Albin of Matstudio in Stockholm) and club “ambassadors” like the pop icon Robyn. “A lot of people are skipping New York and going straight to L.A.,” says Patrik Berger, who co-produced the Swedish duo Icona Pop’s massive 2012 hit “I Love It.” “It’s all in L.A. when it comes to pop music.”

headline: Allman Brothers Band Announces Final Concerts
abstract: The band will make up its canceled performances at New York’s Beacon Theater in October, and said that two more concerts there will be its last.
lead_paragraph: When the Allman Brothers Band pulled into the Beacon Theater in March, it was set to play what it said was the last of its annual New York residencies at the hall. But when Gregg Allman, the band’s singer and keyboardist, fell ill toward the end of the run, the final week of sold-out concerts were canceled, with a promise that the band would make them up. The question was whether that would happen before the end of the year, when, word from around the group had it, the Allmans were planning to disband (something Mr. Allman denied in interviews).

lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The last time 50 Cent appeared at Hot 97 Summer Jam, in 2004, he was the most popular rapper of the day, the most feared, and in some circles, the most hated. But what could have been a coronation was instead a fiasco: Some old enemies started trouble in the crowd, sending chairs flying toward the stage, which 50 Cent and his crew sent flying right back before walking off with a harrumph and a ban from future Summer Jams.
