headline: Secret Global Strike Kills 2 Malicious Web Viruses
keywords: ['Computer Malware', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A coordinated effort by government agents in the United States and Europe aimed at two pernicious viruses also led to the identity of the Russian man suspected of masterminding the malware.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal agents over the weekend secretly seized control of two computer networks that hackers used to steal millions of dollars from unsuspecting victims. In doing so, the Justice Department disrupted the circulation of two of the world’s most pernicious viruses and turned a 30-year-old Russian computer hacker into a most-wanted fugitive.

headline: Asparagus, Green Beans and Potatoes With Green Mole Sauce
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Green mole sauce, thickened with nuts or seeds, is a natural with seasonal vegetables.
lead_paragraph: Mole sauce, which is thickened with nuts or seeds, is as wonderful with vegetables as it is with meat or fish, something I was reminded of recently when I had a main dish of mole with vegetables at El Naranjo, the chef Iliana de la Vega’s restaurant in Austin, Tex. Green mole especially lends itself to vegetables. At this time of year I’m buying asparagus and green beans. They should not be too crunchy – five minutes was just the right amount of cooking time.

headline: Whole-Wheat Seeded Loaves
abstract: Soaked seeds make this bread wonderfully moist.
lead_paragraph: This is a whole-wheat adaptation of Jacquy Pfeiffer’s seeded bread from “The Art of French Pastry.” The seeds and the flaked oats are soaked overnight before they’re mixed into the dough. This allows them to absorb moisture and softens them, so that the bread is wonderfully moist, and the seeds won’t be hard on your teeth when you bite. Soaking the seeds also breaks down phytic acid and protease inhibitors, which allows the nutrients to be more readily absorbed by the body. This is a two-day recipe, as you must allow time for soaking the seeds overnight.

headline: Rice Pilaf With Pistachios, Almonds and Spices
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: This dish is based on Persian rice pilafs, but uses much less butter.
lead_paragraph: There are sweet and tart flavors at play here, especially if you use barberries, but apricots also have a tart edge to them. Rose water makes the pilaf wonderfully fragrant. The dish is inspired by a number of Persian rice pilafs, but it’s simpler, and calls for much less butter than an authentic Persian pilaf. I’ve made it with plain basmati rice, but I also like to use a purple jasmine rice mix that Alter Eco packages.

headline: Seeded Chocolate-Chip Oatmeal Cookies
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health', 'Desserts', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Cookies']
abstract: There’s plenty of chocolate in these cookies, but also nutrients and fiber from seeds.
lead_paragraph: If you want to indulge in chocolate-chip cookies that taste like chocolate-chip cookies but have some wholesome ingredients thrown in, here’s your recipe. I use as much chocolate in these as I use in Sherry Yard’s Quintessential Chocolate Chip-Cookies (isn’t it great that chocolate offers us healthful phytonutrients?) but I’ve reduced the sugar by 25 percent and added a good measure of rolled oats and sunflower, chia and pumpkin seeds. I’ve made the cookies using half whole-wheat flour and using all unbleached all-purpose flour, and I prefer the whole-wheat version – and not just because it’s healthier:The nutty flavor of the flour complements the nutty flavor of the seeds. You could soak the seeds, but you’ll have to take the time to dry them completely in a low oven; otherwise they will contribute too much moisture and the cookies won’t brown properly.

headline: Yogurt With Mixed Seeds, Toasted Oatmeal and Ginger Syrup
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A delicious breakfast with pumpkin, poppy, chia, sesame and sunflower seeds as well as toasted oatmeal for crunch.
lead_paragraph: The inspiration for this breakfast yogurt comes mainly from an amazing breakfast yogurt and fruit bowl I had at the Elizabeth Street Café, a Vietnamese-French bakery and restaurant in Austin, Tex. Its baker, Jennifer Tucker, is exceptionally talented: Anyone who can pull off croissants that incorporate whole-wheat flour and seeds while remaining flaky, light, and small has my immediate attention.

headline: Chemical Weapons Treaty Does Not Apply to Petty Crime, Justices Rule

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that Congress had not meant to authorize prosecutions of minor crimes under a chemical weapons treaty.

headline: A Woman I Regarded as a Hero, and New Doubts

It charged that Somaly Mam, an activist against human trafficking in Cambodia, had fabricated elements of her background. Somaly has been a hero of mine, and I’ve written about her in my column, first in 2008 and most recently in 2011.

headline: Nicholas Kristof Should Give Readers a Full Explanation About Somaly Mam
abstract: The columnist was a high-profile supporter of the Cambodian activist, who has stepped down after fabrication charges.
lead_paragraph: A recent Newsweek cover story calls Somaly Mam the “Holy Saint (and Sinner) of Sex Trafficking.” It details the ways in which the Cambodian activist against sex trafficking fabricated at least some parts of her own story and the dramatic, heartrending stories of girls she said were sold into sex slavery.

headline: It’s Easy to Forget About Risk in a Stable Market
abstract: When we have periods of relative stability, we can forget what normal market risk feels like, and we get comfortable with more and more risk.

headline: Measuring the Apology of Network Rail in Britain

headline: Hospital Charges Surge for Common Ailments, Data Shows
abstract: Hospitals charged more for every single one of 98 common ailments in 2012, and the increase for all but seven exceeded the nation’s 2 percent inflation rate for that year, according to a Times analysis.
lead_paragraph: Charges for some of the most common inpatient procedures surged at hospitals across the country in 2012 from a year earlier, some at more than four times the national rate of inflation, according to data released by Medicare officials on Monday.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s release, the Tiananmen Square crackdown, and the Koch brothers’ influence in Detroit.
lead_paragraph: Republican candidates are continuing to run against Obamacare, but will it work? The vast majority of Americans want the law improved, but not repealed, The New York Times editorial board says: “That sentiment conflicts with the Republican playbook, which party leaders are suddenly trying to rewrite. The result has been an incoherent mishmash of positions, as candidates try to straddle a widening gap between blind hatred of health reform and the public’s growing recognition that much of it is working.”

headline: The Perils of a Circumstantial Insider Trading Case
abstract: Moving from suspicion of insider trading to proving a violation requires much more than just timely trading and vague connections, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Insider trading is all about propitious timing. And trades by the golfer Phil Mickelson and William T. Walters, a high-rolling gambler, just before the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn made an unsolicited offer to buy Clorox in 2011 have all the signs of a potential violation: a quick increase in the stock price that made their risky call options worth millions of dollars. But timing alone is not enough to establish insider trading. So moving from suspicion to proving a violation requires much more than just timely trading and vague connections between a potential source and profitable trades.

headline: Cause Marketing Effort Is Centered on the Negroni
abstract: Campari America and Imbibe Media are joining forces for Negroni Week, with the goal of raising $100,000 for charities nationwide.
lead_paragraph: The designation of weeks or months for cause-related marketing purposes has become so familiar that they now seem, in most instances, to fade into the woodwork. When almost every week or month is a “Week” or “Month,” they can lose their power to motivate consumers to become donors or lend a helping hand.

headline: What’s Black and White and Travels 310 Miles?
abstract: It’s a newly discovered annual migration of several thousand zebra in Botswana and Namibia, one of the longest animal journeys in Africa.
lead_paragraph: Given all the attention that has been paid to migrations of wildlife in Africa it’s a surprise to find a new one, not to mention one that is the longest of any on that continent.

headline: The Right and Misogyny
abstract: Why the cultural right shouldn’t reflexively disagree with the feminist left.
lead_paragraph: My column yesterday joined the crowded debate over the cultural significance (if any) of the Santa Barbara killer’s radioactive, misogynistic, sexually-frustrated rage. That debate has gone in any number of directions, but it’s often slipped into some well-worn right-left grooves, with writers on the feminist left tilting at capital-p Patriarchy and “traditional masculinity” and conservative commentators dismissing their arguments as victimology and ideological overreach. And as in another recent controversy, on rape and campus life, I’m a little dissatisfied with my own side’s approach: In their haste to critique too-sweeping indictments of masculinity/male privilege/”rape culture”/etc., it seems to me, some conservatives risk foreclosing the possibility that misogyny might be a real cultural problem, to which a certain amount of moral outrage and a certain kind of structural critique might both be healthy, legitimate responses.

headline: Spain’s King Juan Carlos Abdicates
abstract: King Juan Carlos of Spain said that he would abdicate the throne after nearly 40 years, and that his son, Crown Prince Felipe, would succeed him.
lead_paragraph: King Juan Carlos of Spain said that he would abdicate the throne after nearly 40 years, and that his son, Crown Prince Felipe, would succeed him.

headline: Apple Unveils iOS 8 and OS X Yosemite at Developer Conference
keywords: ['Mac OS (Operating System)', 'iOS (Operating System)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The company announced a series of changes intended to help juggle content across Macs and iPhones and iPads.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple on Monday introduced new operating systems for its Mac computers and mobile devices, including a series of changes intended to help Macs work more seamlessly with iPhones and iPads.

headline: Key Details of E.P.A. Carbon Emissions Proposal
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Coal', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency’s announcement to limit carbon pollution is just the starting gun to a rule that critics say will drive up the cost of electricity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A rule proposed by the Enivironmental Protection Agency would cut carbon pollution from power plants 30 percent from 2005 levels by 2030 – the equivalent, according to the agency, of taking two-thirds of all cars and trucks in America off the road. Here are some things to know about the rule:

headline: A Luxe Update on a Classic Pilot’s Timepiece
abstract: In this series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. This week: Breitling celebrates the 30th anniversary of its Chronomat Airborne with a special commemorative edition.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the photographer Rob Kulisek captures a timepiece from Breitling.

headline: Blair Urges E.U. Leaders to Heed Lessons of Elections
abstract: Former Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain called on European Union leaders to heed the “wake-up call” of the recent European elections by delivering better living standards.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Entering Europe’s debate over the rise of populist parties, former Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain on Monday called on European Union leaders to heed a “wake-up call” by delivering better living standards, but he insisted that immigration from Eastern Europe had benefited Britain.

headline: Chris Brown Released From Jail
abstract: Mr. Brown was released from a Los Angeles jail early Monday morning.
lead_paragraph: The singer Chris Brown, who had been in a Los Angeles jail since the middle of March, was released just after midnight on Monday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: The Sexy Golf Angle to the Latest Insider Trading Scandal
abstract: William T. Walters, the Las Vegas gambler at the center of the insider trading inquiry involving Carl Icahn and Phil Mickelson, runs a caddy service featuring “extremely attractive” women.
lead_paragraph: Last week was an eventful one for the Las Vegas gambler William T. Walters.

headline: Lupita Nyong’o to Join ‘Star Wars: Episode VII’

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Lupita Nyong’o just added another broadly commercial film to her post-Oscar dance card. As in, the broadest: “Star Wars: Episode VII.”

headline: Dorchester Cancels Fashion Prize In Wake of Protests
abstract: The Dorchester Collection has canceled its fashion prize for emerging designers this year in the wake of protests.
lead_paragraph: The Dorchester Collection has canceled its fashion prize for emerging designers this year in the wake of protests against its luxury hotels from leading figures in the fashion industry and Hollywood.

Handwriting is being dropped in public schools — that could be bad for young minds. Google’s new hands-free computer is finding its way into operating rooms. Breast cancer survivors find the start of their new lives in a tattoo artist’s work.

headline: Too Extreme for the N.R.A.
abstract: The gun association’s lobbying wing said it was “downright weird” to bring a 7.62 rifle to lunch.
lead_paragraph: The National Rifle Association’s lobbying wing, the Institute for Legislative Action, has officially recognized that guns, whether they’re toted by good guys or bad guys, are frightening—at least if they’re long guns and they’re in public places.

headline: Valeant and Ackman Departing From Usual Playbook in Pursuit of Allergan
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: In the last week, a joint bid for Allergan, the maker of Botox, has evolved from an already unusual deal into one of the most confounding takeover attempts in recent memory.
lead_paragraph: From the moment it was announced, the $53 billion joint bid for Allergan, the maker of Botox, made by Valeant Pharmaceuticals and the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman, was highly unconventional.

headline: Neighbors Protest 33-Foot Statue
abstract: Aby Rosen, the real estate titan and art collector, has upset his neighbors in Old Westbury, N.Y., with a 33-foot-tall statue of a naked woman ripped open to reveal a fetus.
lead_paragraph: Residents of wealthy Old Westbury, N.Y., do not have to worry about living downwind of a pig farm or next to a fraternity house.

headline: Valeant’s Achilles’ Heel
abstract: The premium and increased cash may help bring Allergan to the negotiating table. But questions over Valeant’s own stock remain its weakness, says Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals is pushing its $54 billion deal with the help of a carrot and two sticks.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | May 27-June 2, 2014
abstract: See how much you know about the 10 news stories in this quiz. To find the answers, click each blank and you’ll be taken to the original Times article from which the excerpt came.
lead_paragraph: Apple plays catch-up, a plan to cut carbon emissions, the death of an icon and more: How many of the topics in this week’s news quiz have you been following?

headline: What’s Lost as Handwriting Fades
abstract: Even as the emphasis shifts to the keyboard, experts say that learning to write by hand improves motor skills, memory and creativity.
lead_paragraph: Does handwriting matter?

headline: Barbro Lindgren Wins Children’s Literature Prize
abstract: The Swedish author won the Astrid Lindgren Memorial Prize, which includes a cash award of about $748,000.
lead_paragraph: The Swedish author Barbro Lindgren was awarded the 2014 Astrid Lindgren Memorial Prize, the literary world’s largest award for children’s literature, at a ceremony at the Stockholm Concert Hall on Monday. The prize, which is named for the Swedish author and editor, who died in 2002, has been given annually since 2003, and is meant to honor a writer, illustrator or storyteller for a lifetime’s work. It includes a cash award of five million Swedish krona (about $748,000).

headline: Oliver Stone Plans a Film About Edward Snowden
abstract: The director says he will adapt a book by Luke Harding, a Guardian journalist.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Oliver Stone, one of Hollywood’s most provocative directors, will make a movie about one of the world’s most divisive figures: Edward Snowden.

headline: The Scene | Holland’s Opus
abstract: The city of The Hague in South Holland is rich with gems of all sorts, culturally, culinarily and architecturally.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to its quaint streets and picturesque canals, The Hague, a jewel of a city in South Holland, has long attracted a discerning international crowd. And with this month’s reopening of the renovated Royal Picture Gallery Mauritshuis, home to Vermeer’s “Girl With a Pearl Earring,” there’s more reason than ever to go. At the exuberantly packed antique store Il Mondo Stijl, tulipieres are transformed into lamps with oversize red shades, next to an Italian cachepot in the style of a Persian warrior and Capodimonte porcelain parrots. Rich with jewels of a different sort, Herman Romberg makes Tahitian pearl necklaces and turquoise drop earrings for a clientele that includes Queen Maxima and other members of the Dutch royal family. For those in search of culinary indulgence, there’s South of Houston, a French-American restaurant that serves dry-aged beef and elegant desserts. But perhaps The Hague’s grandest attraction is the Hotel Des Indes. Built as a palace in 1858, it has retained its Old World glamour — mirrored walls and marble columns — and it’s an ideal place to savor the city’s Dutch strawberries and Austrian sacher tortes.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Milestones Fall at Englishtown Drag Races
abstract: Speed records were set at N.H.R.A.’s Summernationals in New Jersey; three spectators were killed and several injured at the Jim Clark Rally in Scotland.
lead_paragraph: Weather conditions were perfect for record high speeds and close racing at the National Hot Rod Association’s Summernationals drag races at Englishtown, N.J., on Sunday. Richie Crampton achieved a milestone for himself and the sport with his Top Fuel victory. Crampton, an Australian competing in his ninth N.H.R.A. event, defeated the points leader, Doug Kalitta, in the final. In the process, he scored his first career Top Fuel victory. The N.H.R.A. said he became the 100th different driver to win in the Top Fuel category, in an official history that dates to 1963.

headline: The Sweet Surprise of Dry Riesling
abstract: Three bottles of dry riesling that may be hard to find but are worth the effort display a combination of strength and delicacy, finesse and elegance.
lead_paragraph: Updated | July 8, 2014

headline: Book Covers: Before and After
abstract: Designers discuss their work on recent book covers.
lead_paragraph: Designers discuss their work on recent book covers.

headline: No Nation Has Lowered Obesity Rate in 33 Years
abstract: A study of data from 188 countries finds that obesity abounds in rich and poor countries alike, and sometimes neighbors have quite different levels.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 30 percent of the world’s population is overweight or obese, and not one country has reduced its obesity rate in 33 years, according to a new study combining three decades of data from 188 countries, published in The Lancet last month.

headline: On the Move Because of Global Warming
abstract: Climate change is changing the distribution of light-and dark-colored butterflies and dragonflies in Europe, researchers report.
lead_paragraph: Light-colored species of butterflies and dragonflies in Europe like the heat, while dark-colored ones retreat northward to cooler areas. Because of climate change, lighter species are taking over areas once dominated by their darker counterparts, researchers report in the journal Nature Communications. Lighter insects can reflect sunlight more easily and prevent their bodies from overheating.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: May 30-June 1, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: • Elliot Rodger’s parents struggled for years to engage their troubled son with the world, the Times reported yesterday. The perpetrator of the May 23 rampage in Isla Vista, Calif., was described as a high-functioning autistic child prone to depression and anxiety who once had a panic attack so severe he had to be permanently withdrawn from school. “He wasn’t just a little withdrawn,” a family friend and spokesman said. “He was as withdrawn as any person I ever met in my life.”

headline: Podcast: Tattoos for Healing
abstract: Breast cancer survivors find the start of their new lives in a tattoo artist’s work.
lead_paragraph: Breast cancer survivors find the start of their new lives in a tattoo artist’s work.

headline: A Way With Words and a Spice Rack
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Food', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: “I remember the first time I was in the kitchen with Maya Angelou.”
lead_paragraph: I remember the first time I was in the kitchen with Maya Angelou. It happened in Sonoma, Calif., some 40 years ago. A mutual friend had been invited to spend a week, and I trailed along. Ms. Angelou maintained a home in that Mediterranean-looking town of red tile roofs in the wine country, complete with a guest suite in which we were comfortably ensconced. At dinnertime we walked up to the main house.

headline: Businesses May Have to Wait to Offer Employees a Choice of Health Plans
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: Insurers suggest two reasons why allowing small businesses to offer employees a choice of plans might not be in the best interests of those businesses and their employees.
lead_paragraph: For small businesses that want to offer employees health insurance, there aren’t a lot of reasons to buy that coverage on the new Small Business Health Options, or SHOP, exchanges created by the Affordable Care Act. In fact, there are only two.

headline: After Nadal and Ferrer, Spanish Tennis Talent Pool Looks Thin
abstract: Garbiñe Muguruza is the only rising Spanish (or Venezuelan) woman with clear top-10 potential, and nearly all of Spain’s top-100 men’s players are well-established veterans.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The future of Spanish tennis may not be Spanish in the future.

headline: Growing Up on Raw Foods
abstract: A growing cadre of families who are raising their children on entirely uncooked fare, but many doctors caution against the trend.
lead_paragraph: Meals for Levi Bowland are pretty much the same every day. For breakfast, it’s melon. For lunch, a heaping bowl of coleslaw and three bananas. Dinner involves more fruit, and a salad.

headline: Hopes for Impact of Carbon Rules in U.S. Are Modest
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Coal', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Global Warming', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: Reductions in coal use will come from relying more on other power sources and making structures more efficient, but both are already happening.
lead_paragraph: The new carbon pollution rules the Obama administration announced on Monday will help spur the natural gas industry and renewable energy like wind and solar power, but executives and analysts said they did not see the nation’s reliance on coal disappearing anytime soon.

headline: Music Camp for Kids, Vacation for Parents
abstract: Children can immerse themselves in Jamaica Music Camp while their parents get a reduced-price stay at a nearby resort.
lead_paragraph: For parents potentially worried about sending their kids away to camp, one newcomer is simultaneous vacations – in Jamaica.

headline: A Favor for Grandpa? But This Is America
abstract: The restless, thwarted immigrant hero of Boris Fishman’s “A Replacement Life” wants to become a truly American writer but his family keeps dragging him back to its Soviet Jewish past.
lead_paragraph: Now that he has landed a junior position at the prestigious Century magazine in New York, Slava Gelman, the restless, thwarted hero of Boris Fishman’s “A Replacement Life,” decides it is time to become an American.

headline: The Forests of the Ocean
abstract: Josie Iselin celebrates seaweeds, saying she hopes to “reveal the largely unseen forms of ocean flora as a nexus where art and science converge.”
lead_paragraph: The secret to finding unsuspected beauty, artists and naturalists will tell you, is in knowing how to slow down and really look. The writer and photographer Josie Iselin certainly knows how to do that, as she shows in her beguiling new book, “An Ocean Garden.”

headline: On Separate Islands, Crickets Go Silent
abstract: Crickets on two Hawaiian islands have independently mutated to not chirp, gaining them protection from a parasitic fly, but hindering their ability to find a mate.
lead_paragraph: In 2003, a number of male field crickets on the Hawaiian island of Kauai were born without the ability to chirp.  Two years later, the same thing happened on Oahu.

headline: Justices Enter Into Dispute Over Districts Alabama Set
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Democratic lawmakers contend that the state Legislature packed minority voters into a few districts, diluting their voting power.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to consider challenges from Democratic lawmakers who say the Alabama Legislature packed minority voters into a few districts, diluting their voting power.

headline: The Winners of Our Fifth Annual Found Poetry Contest
abstract: Eleven winners, 14 runners up, and 25 honorable mentions: the best found poems of the nearly 2,000 we received. Congratulations, poets, and thank you, teachers!
lead_paragraph: The bar for winning our annual found poetry contest just keeps getting higher.

headline: Lurking Just Beneath This Surface ...
abstract: “Next Time on Lonny,” a Web series from 2011, is back for a second season.
lead_paragraph: “Next Time on Lonny” is a Web series — a first season of six episodes appeared in 2011, and a second season begins on Tuesday. There was every reason for “Lonny” to be lost in the slush pile of short comedy videos online, but for one thing: Ben Stiller liked it. So if you want to know what Mr. Stiller thinks is funny, you can see for yourself over the next four weeks at maker.tv and on YouTube.

headline: Gallery | Julian Wasser’s Photographs of the California Dream, and its Underbelly
abstract: The legendary lensman’s first monograph, “The Way We Were,” captures the nostalgia — and darkness — of Hollywood in the ’60s, ’70s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: On the cover of “The Way We Were” (Damiani Books, $60) — the first monograph by the legendary lensman Julian Wasser — a vast cloud of smoke issues from Steve McQueen’s pursed lips. Coming from a veneer so tough — collar starched, eyes concealed behind dark glasses — it’s the single note of expression, the breath the only proof the man is man and not made of wax. Herein lies the unreal reality of Wasser’s California: in this exhalation is all the nostalgia of a dream once dreamed. And despite the misty-eyed title of his book capturing the heyday of L.A. celebrity and counterculture, “the fact is, everything you heard about living in Los Angeles in the early ’60s was really true,” the photographer says. “It was a golden age and a hopeful time.”

headline: How Cats See in the Dark
abstract: Does the slit shape of a cat’s pupil confer any advantages over the more rounded pupils of other animals?
lead_paragraph: Q. Does the slit shape of a cat’s pupil confer any advantages over the more rounded pupils of other animals?

headline: Is Andrew Cuomo Liberal?
abstract: The left-leaning Working Families Party nearly endorsed someone else.
lead_paragraph: New York’s Gov. Andrew Cuomo has spent almost four years trying to carve out a comfortable central spot in the state’s political spectrum. He is now known as a fiscal conservative who lowers taxes (even on the rich) and cuts costs (even for struggling communities), and as a social progressive who supports gun control and gay marriage

headline: E.P.A. Unveils Plan to Slash Pollution
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency administrator, Gina McCarthy, announced a plan that aims to cut carbon pollution from the nation’s power plants 30 percent from 2005 levels by 2030.
lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency administrator, Gina McCarthy, announced a plan that aims to cut carbon pollution from the nation’s power plants 30 percent from 2005 levels by 2030.

headline: Isabel Toledo’s Beauty and Fitness Regimen
abstract: The designer’s beauty regimen also includes makeup and fragrance for a bit of fantasy.
lead_paragraph: Born in Cuba and raised in West New York, N.J., Isabel Toledo, 54, has been designing a namesake women’s wear line since 1984. Aside from dressing Michelle Obama on occasion and collaborating with Lane Bryant, Ms. Toledo designed the costumes for the Broadway musical “After Midnight,” for which she’s been nominated for her first Tony Award (the ceremony is Sunday). She lives and works with her husband, the illustrator Ruben Toledo, in Manhattan. BEE SHAPIRO

headline: Doctors Aren’t Strongly Republican Anymore
abstract: A study attributed the partisan shift in campaign donations partly to an increase in female physicians.
lead_paragraph: American doctors have shifted their political support away from Republicans toward Democrats, according to a study released on Monday.

headline: The Serious Playfulness of a Rising Composer, and How It Has Spread
abstract: The Orchestra of St. Luke’s played two early works by George Benjamin and explored links to them in pieces by three other composers in an NY Phil Biennial event.
lead_paragraph: Few composers have seen their American reputations rise as swiftly in recent years as George Benjamin’s. Buoyed by the ecstatic international reaction to his 2012 opera, “Written on Skin,” which is to have its New York stage premiere next year, his newfound status is such that it was perfectly reasonable for him to be one of just two composers whose influence was celebrated by the Orchestra of St. Luke’s over the weekend as part of the NY Phil Biennial.

headline: The Nipple Artist
abstract: A tattoo parlor in Finksburg, Md., has become an unlikely destination for breast cancer survivors.
lead_paragraph: A tattoo parlor in Finksburg, Md., has become an unlikely destination for breast cancer survivors.

headline: A Tattoo That Completes a New Breast
abstract: Tattoo artist Vinnie Myers has developed a unique specialty in nipple tattoos for women who have undergone treatment for breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: FINKSBURG, MD. — A tattoo parlor here has become a mecca for an unlikely crowd: women with breast cancer.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Two Royal Ballet Dancers to Skip Russian Tour in Protest
abstract: Two unidentified dancers have decided not to join the Ballet’s tour of Russia as a protest against the country’s antigay legislation.
lead_paragraph: Two Royal Ballet dancers have decided not to join the Royal Ballet’s upcoming tour to Russia, as a protest against the antigay legislation supported by President Vladimir V. Putin. The company would not name the dancers or give their rank, although The Independent described them as “senior” company members.

headline: May the World Be Their Oyster
abstract: Three actresses in the Broadway run of “The Cripple of Inishmaan” are jointly making the most of their downtime in New York City.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday afternoon, the Broadway actresses Ingrid Craigie, Gillian Hanna and June Watson took a car to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to view Kara Walker’s “A Subtlety.” They stepped into the shuttered Domino Sugar Factory, pausing to view the enormous central figure, with its African features and Aunt Jemima kerchief, crouched sphinxlike at the far end of the floor.

headline: Exploring the Photographic Spirit
abstract: Raised on family tales of an old haunted farmhouse, Elizabeth Moran grew up to join relatives turned ghost-hunters in Memphis.
lead_paragraph: Raised on family tales of an old haunted farmhouse, Elizabeth Moran grew up to join relatives turned ghost-hunters in Memphis.

headline: Ciro de Quadros, 74, Dies; Leader in Ridding Latin America of Polio
abstract: Dr. de Quadros navigated war zones to lead a successful immunization campaign in Latin America and the Caribbean.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Ciro de Quadros, a Brazilian epidemiologist who navigated war zones and reimagined outmoded public health practices to lead an immunization campaign that eradicated polio in Latin America and the Caribbean, died on Wednesday in Washington. He was 74.

headline: Strong Sales for ‘Gentleman’s Guide’ Ahead of Tony Awards
abstract: Ticket sales for “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” have been strong since it was nominated for 10 Tonys.
lead_paragraph: After the Tony Award winners are announced on Sunday night, what will happen to ticket sales for two of Broadway’s most-nominated musicals, “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” and “After Midnight”?

headline: When Coral Reefs Thrive, So Does Variety in Fish
abstract: Research from the off the Malay Archipelago draws a connection between the stability of reefs and the diversity of the fish living there.
lead_paragraph: The fish that live off the Malay Archipelago, between Southeast Asia and Australia, are among the most diverse in the world. Now researchers are reporting that the area owes its diversity to the stability of coral reefs over the past three million years.

headline: Brave, New and Lifted by Magic
abstract: Shakespeare’s late romance “The Tempest” itself undergoes a sea change in the inventive production of the play at American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Shakespeare’s late romance “The Tempest” itself undergoes a sea change in the inventive production of the play at American Repertory Theater here. The magic of Prospero has a razzle-dazzle allure in this freshly reimagined, steampunk-stylish production, directed and adapted by Aaron Posner and Teller (of the magic-meisters Penn and Teller) and featuring songs judiciously culled from the Tom Waits catalog.

headline: Filing by Computer: A Pillow Helped
abstract: A longtime sports journalist reminisces about the day in 1974 when he first lugged a 15-pound computer he called “the blue monster” to file a story from the road.
lead_paragraph: I was in a $6-an-hour motel in Oakdale, on Long Island, about 50 miles from Times Square. It was going to be my first time.

headline: Complicated Brains, Walking Well Into Old Age, To Teleport Data
abstract: Letters to the editor and online comments.
lead_paragraph: Bowel Disorders

headline: Velocity, Vulnerability and Youth
abstract: At the School of American Ballet’s annual workshop showings, young dancers performed “Serenade” and parts of George Balanchine’s “Swan Lake,” “Coppélia” and “Western Symphony.”
lead_paragraph: The School of American Ballet, founded by George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein, is 80 years old this year. Inevitably, the anniversary calls for a staging of “Serenade,”  the first ballet choreographed by Balanchine on American soil, for the school’s annual workshop showings. There are three performances; I caught the second, on Saturday evening. “Serenade” began the program of Balanchine dances; excerpts from his one-act “Swan Lake” and the third act of “Coppélia” followed; the finale was the last movement of “Western Symphony.”

headline: Facing Jail: Highlights From a Reporter’s Career
abstract: The Times reporter James Risen is facing a jail term for refusing to name a confidential source. We look at some of his work from the past decade.
lead_paragraph: James Risen, a Times reporter, is facing a jail term for refusing to name a confidential source.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Spain, Afghanistan and Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Spain, Afghanistan and Turkey.

headline: Filtering Out Unwanted Gmail Messages
abstract: Plus, how to move photos from a cellphone to a Kindle Fire.
lead_paragraph: Moving Photos

headline: Drones on Movie Sets? Lights, Camera, Takeoff
abstract: Seven film production companies have asked the Federal Aviation Administration for permission to use drones in making movies.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Don’t panic, that unmanned aircraft peering over your shoulder might soon belong to Steven Spielberg or one of his functional equivalents.

headline: Salesforce Bottom Line Is Put at Risk by a Slide in the Company’s Stock
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Enterprise Computing', 'Executive Compensation', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Some analysts say the cloud-computing juggernaut is overly reliant on stock-based pay and that a prolonged slump in its share price could harm the health of its core operations.
lead_paragraph: Nearly everything about Salesforce.com is remarkable.

headline: A Star-Gazing Palace’s Hazy Future
keywords: ['Telescopes and Observatories', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Research']
abstract: As attentions turn to newer telescopes, Lick Observatory is fighting to stay relevant.
lead_paragraph: James Lick, a piano manufacturer and land baron in 19th-century California, wanted to build himself a pyramid, but a friend persuaded him to leave his money to science. And so it came to be that Lick was buried under a telescope on Mount Hamilton, 30 miles south of San Francisco.

headline: New Costumes for a Balanchine Classic
abstract: New York City Ballet recreates costumes for its new production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.”
lead_paragraph: New York City Ballet recreates costumes for its new production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.”

headline: A ‘Midsummer’ Costume Redo
abstract: For its latest “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” New York City Ballet did detective work to make sure the period costumes were accurate.
lead_paragraph: Figuring out how to remake 104 of the costumes that the designer Barbara Karinska created more than a half-century ago for the fairies and foolish mortals of George Balanchine’s ballet “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” for Tuesday night’s opening performance required detective work, millinery archaeology and a scavenger hunt for material that eventually led to three continents.

headline: Automating Cybersecurity
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Contests and Prizes', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A Defense Department agency is holding a contest to encourage programmers to create automation tools to find flaws in computer systems, like ones that make data vulnerable to theft.
lead_paragraph: If only computers themselves were smart enough to fight off malevolent hackers.

headline: Less Carbon, More Energy
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency’s new rule sets a goal for each state based on its carbon dioxide emissions divided by its electricity generation. A chart showing where each state stands.
lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency’s new rule sets a goal for each state based on its carbon dioxide emissions divided by its electricity generation. A chart showing where each state stands.

headline: Q. and A.: Liu Heung Shing on Photographing Tiananmen
abstract: The most intense moments of the Hong Kong-based photojournalist Liu Heung Shing’s career came when he was a witness to the Tiananmen Square protests in 1989.
lead_paragraph: The Hong Kong-born photojournalist Liu Heung Shing, who shared a 1992 Pulitzer Prize for documenting an attempted coup in Russia, now lives in Beijing, where he devotes most of his time to organizing photo exhibitions and editing books on historical photos of China. His own photos from China are themselves an archive of the country’s astounding changes since the death of Mao Zedong. His images for Time magazine and The Associated Press in China in the late 1970s and early 1980s have been collected in “China After Mao.”

headline: Listen Up | Hercules and Love Affair Makes a Case for House Music
abstract: Andy Butler has just released the third album from his dance-music project. Here, he previews the first single — and curates an exclusive playlist for T.
lead_paragraph: “America has never fully had its house music moment,” says Andy Butler — better known by his moniker Hercules and Love Affair — via Skype while vacationing in Brussels. “In Europe, it’s another story. I feel it’s a rite of passage for people to go to the discotheque.” Butler is an American through and through (he got his start D.J.ing around Denver and attended Sarah Lawrence College), but you wouldn’t know it from Hercules and Love Affair’s distinctly Continental sound. “Audiences there have a tradition of integrating dance music in pop culture,” he explains. Indeed, Butler’s breakout hit, 2008’s “Blind,” had its biggest reception in Italy, and was received warmly in Britain as well. If there’s anyone in a position to get statesiders dancing, though, it’s Butler — thanks especially to his energetic third album, “The Feast of the Broken Heart,” just released on Big Beat/Atlantic Records.

headline: The Overwhelming Maleness of “Silicon Valley”
abstract: The show’s season finale highlights the male-dominated nature of tech more starkly than ever — but does it do enough to critique it?
lead_paragraph: Since its premiere, “Silicon Valley” has prompted discussion of sexism in the actual Silicon Valley. The show’s season finale offers perhaps its best illustration yet of the male-dominated nature of the tech industry — but whether that illustration will rise to the level of critique remains an open question.

headline: The Crossroads at Cold Harbor
abstract: In a Virginia field, some 7,000 Union soldiers were killed or wounded in an hour – and the fighting raged for another week.
lead_paragraph: By late spring 1864, Lt. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant was relentlessly pursuing his advance on the Confederate capital at Richmond, Va. With his recent appointment as commander of the Union armies, Grant had brought a new approach to the war – one of absolute and brutal attrition. Knowing that he could replace as many men as he lost, even as the rebel army suffered from a desperate shortage of manpower, he had bulldozed his way across Virginia in what was named the Overland Campaign, throwing tens of thousands of men against the Confederate wall.

headline: Cano Is Quiet in Mariners’ Rout of Yankees, but Fans in Bronx Aren’t
abstract: Robinson Cano was booed unmercifully at Yankee Stadium, but he did not factor much in the Mariners’ 10-2 victory.
lead_paragraph: A rainout at the end of April allowed Robinson Cano a temporary reprieve from the jeers he had heard upon his previous return to Yankee Stadium. By the time Cano came back to the Bronx with the Seattle Mariners to make up the postponed game, he would have been more integrated onto his new team, and perhaps Yankee fans would have softened their stance on a player who had been a critical part of the team’s success in the last decade.

headline: Mets Overcome Leadoff Concerns to Win in Nine
abstract: The Mets and the Phillies managed to play a nine-inning game for a change, and the Mets scored 11 runs to make sure.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Mets had a handful of flaws at the start of the season. For one, they lacked a leadoff hitter. Eric Young Jr. had not established himself as an everyday player. And Juan Lagares was not exactly a true leadoff hitter.

headline: Fearing Converts to Terrorism, France Intercepts Citizens Bound for Syria
abstract: Amid worries about a threat from radicalized Europeans who fight in Syria and then return, France is arresting would-be jihadis even before they leave the country.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The three young Frenchmen were arrested as they tried to make their way to Syria to wage jihad. They had not harmed anyone in France or made plans to do so, according to the evidence at their trial in January, but in France these days, seeking to fight in Syria is enough to bring a charge of plotting terrorism — and in this case sentences of three to five years in prison.

headline: The Supreme Court Blunder That Liberals Tend to Make
abstract: Democrats and Republicans have split the last 14 presidential elections, but Republicans have appointed 12 of the last 20 Supreme Court justices
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the waning months of his presidency, Lyndon Johnson took a tremendous risk. He nominated Supreme Court Justice Abe Fortas, who had once been Johnson’s personal lawyer and remained a confidant, to become chief justice.

headline: How Much Hospitals Charged Medicare for the Same Types of Cases
abstract: Data released by the federal government shows that hospitals across the country charge Medicare differing amounts for the same procedure.
lead_paragraph: Data released by the federal government shows that hospitals across the country charge Medicare differing amounts for the same procedure.

headline: Bowe Bergdahl’s Vanishing Before Capture Angered His Unit
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The release of the U.S. soldier has created political problems for both parties amid allegations that he had left his base without permission.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sometime after midnight on June 30, 2009, Pfc. Bowe Bergdahl left behind a note in his tent saying he had become disillusioned with the Army, did not support the American mission in Afghanistan and was leaving to start a new life. He slipped off the remote military outpost in Paktika Province on the border with Pakistan and took with him a soft backpack, water, knives, a notebook and writing materials, but left behind his body armor and weapons — startling, given the hostile environment around his outpost.

headline: The Playlist | The Best of Queen Bey
abstract: T’s critic at large Jody Rosen tracks the most essential tunes from the colossal pop star and culture issue cover girl.
lead_paragraph: Jody Rosen, T’s critic at large, wrote about Beyoncé Knowles for the cover of T’s culture issue, which hits newsstands June 15. “The way she sings, her approach to rhythm and harmony, her dancing — it’s all very strange and sui generis,” he says of the singer. “She’s an avant-gardist masquerading as the world’s biggest pop diva.” Here, Rosen tracks the most essential tunes from the woman on top of the world.

headline: Personal Statement
abstract: The humble T-shirt becomes a stylish message board thanks to flashy type and aggressive graphics.
lead_paragraph: The humble T-shirt becomes a stylish message board thanks to flashy type and aggressive graphics.

headline: Beyoncé: The Woman on Top of the World
abstract: A few years ago, Beyoncé Knowles was like any other record-breaking pop star in an already crowded field. Then something changed.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Beyoncé Knowles was like any other record-breaking pop star in an already crowded field. Then something changed.

headline: Everything Must Go
abstract: The poet Tom Healy and his pal, the sculptor Tom Sachs, orbit a world of consumption so conspicuous it can be seen from outer space.
lead_paragraph: The poet Tom Healy and his pal, the sculptor Tom Sachs, orbit a world of consumption so conspicuous it can be seen from outer space.

headline: Edward Finkelstein, 89, Dies; Took Macy’s to Its Highs and Lows
abstract: Mr. Finkelstein turned Macy’s into one of the nation’s smartest, fastest-growing department store chains, only to see it wind up in bankruptcy court.
lead_paragraph: Edward S. Finkelstein, a master merchandiser who turned Macy’s into one of the nation’s smartest, fastest-growing department store chains, only to see it wind up in bankruptcy court, died on Saturday at his home in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 89.

headline: Word of the Day | pliable
abstract: This word has appeared in 42 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: pliable •\ˈpli-ə-bəl\• adjective

headline: Rangers and Kings Share a Cast of High-Pressure Achievers
abstract: Players on both sides have been on the winning end of numerous Game 7s and other playoff-deciding games.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals is set for June 18 in Los Angeles. If it gets that far, if the Rangers and the Kings battle to one last game, there will be a Cup at stake and a lot of streaks on the line. Something will have to give.

headline: Amid Sense of Incompletion, Petkovic Trudges Ahead in Paris
abstract: The 28th-seeded woman at the French Open, Andrea Petkovic has overcome injuries and reached the quarterfinals with a three-set win over Kiki Bertens, but she expects more from herself.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Andrea Petkovic prepared for her French Open fourth-round match against Kiki Bertens by spending some time on one of her favorite websites: YouTube.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 3, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 3, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “Who would think that you would send a child upstairs and they never came back?”

headline: Corrections: June 3, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on June 3, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (CW) FAMOUS IN 12 An ordinary family, above, moves to Los Angeles to seek fame while being filmed around the clock for 12 weeks in activities guided by Harvey Levin and his TMZ crew. Family members will wage individual fame campaigns on social media while each week a “star power meter” will analyze the information to determine who has a shot at a Kardashian-like existence — and who should return to anonymity.

headline: Marilyn Beck, Hollywood Columnist Without the Gush, Dies at 85
abstract: Ms. Beck was a widely read newspaper columnist and broadcast figure who helped bring an impartial style to the world of celebrity gossip.
lead_paragraph: Marilyn Beck, a widely read newspaper columnist and broadcast figure who helped introduce a style of impartial journalism to the celebrity gossip beat, died on Saturday at her home in Oceanside, Calif. She was 85.

headline: A Chic Idea for China’s Green-Minded Set
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: A Hong Kong-based environmental movement to clean up the textile and apparel industry is recruiting young talent to make the concept of eco fashion more attractive to the urban middle class in China.
lead_paragraph: A Hong Kong-based environmental movement to clean up the textile and apparel industry, one of the world’s largest polluters, is recruiting young talent to make the concept of eco fashion more attractive to the urban middle class in China.

headline: Ukraine Pushes Back as Rebels Attack in the East
abstract: Ukraine’s interior minister said that separatist fighters had attacked government vehicles but that the attack had been repulsed.
lead_paragraph: LUHANSK, Ukraine — Ukraine’s minister of internal affairs said Tuesday that the central government’s security forces had begun a new phase of the campaign against separatist fighters in the city of Slovyansk, destroying rebel checkpoints and equipment and engaging in firefights.

headline: Test Yourself | History, June 3
abstract: Answer this question about Spanish history.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Unveiling New Carbon Plan, E.P.A. Focuses on Flexibility
abstract: What are some of the policy options that states will have to achieve the pollution cuts required by this regulation?
lead_paragraph: In “Unveiling New Carbon Plan, E.P.A. Focuses on Flexibility,” Coral Davenport writes about the Obama administration’s proposal to cut greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Assad’s Win Is Assured, but Limits Are Exposed
abstract: The election is certain to confirm Bashar al-Assad’s hold on power amid a civil war that has killed an estimated 160,000 Syrians.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As Syrians went to the polls on Tuesday in an election virtually certain to give President Bashar al-Assad a new term, buses ferried government workers from their offices to cast ballots. Security checkpoints blocked some people from leaving neighborhoods if they did not have inked fingers proving they had taken part. And a few citizens pronounced themselves so enthusiastic that they had voted several times.

headline: How to Succeed in Washington Without Really Trying
abstract: Become a cause célèbre. There’s never been a smoother path from anonymity to Wolf Blitzer’s greenroom.
lead_paragraph: We seem to be in the midst of several national conversations. Every day, in fact, on MSNBC or Fox News or NPR or Sarah Palin’s Facebook page or my brother in-law’s Twitter feed, new national conversations are being set aloft over something or other of great importance — cyberbullying, digital diets, “slut-shaming,” Benghazi and all that. But the only way to have your national conversation rise above the others is to have a “face” of that conversation — your very own Pussy Riot, Edward Snowden, Sandra Fluke, New York City carriage horses or “Duck Dynasty” guys. Or that cattle rancher from Nevada, what’s his name?

headline: Do You Like School?
abstract: Do you look forward to going to school in the morning?
lead_paragraph: A recent Op-Ed essay topping The Times’s most-emailed list argues that the majority of employees in America do not feel engaged at work. They feel underappreciated by their supervisors, overwhelmed by how much they have to do, and don’t feel that what they are doing even matters. Is school any different?

headline: Exploring the Photographic Spirit
abstract: Raised on family tales of an old haunted farmhouse, Elizabeth Moran grew up to join relatives turned ghost-hunters in Memphis.
lead_paragraph: An amazing little camera caught Elizabeth Moran’s attention at a family reunion. It was as tiny as a spy camera, cartoonishly so.

headline: Living on Purpose
abstract: A sense of purpose helps sustain people in old age, new studies show.
lead_paragraph: My late father had a longtime friend, a retired kosher butcher, who lived down the hall in their South Jersey apartment building. Past 90, Manny was older and frailer than my father; he leaned on a cane and could barely see well enough to recognize faces. But every morning, and again in late afternoon, he walked through my dad’s unlocked front door to be sure he was all right and to kibitz a bit.

headline: California Chrome’s Quest for the Triple Crown, and the Lives He Transformed
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Belmont Stakes', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers']
abstract: The connections behind California Chrome’s run at the Triple Crown have one thing in common: They all fell hard for him in their own way.
lead_paragraph: LOS ALAMITOS, Calif. — Art Sherman is not a complicated man. He is 77 and proud of a life that is longer on memories than it is on bankroll. Sixty years ago, he was a Brooklyn kid in California learning about horses from a crew of cowboys.

headline: Euro Zone Edges Closer to Dreaded Deflation
abstract: Consumer prices in the 18 nations of the euro zone rose at an annual rate of just 0.5 percent in May, further pressuring the European Central Bank to ease monetary policy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Consumer prices in the euro zone ticked ever closer to outright deflation, official data showed Tuesday, making it almost certain that the European Central Bank will move to ease monetary policy this week.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Andreessen Horowitz Increases Bet on Zenefits, a Human Resources Firm
abstract: Zenefits, which delivers its software to businesses over the cloud, is said to be valued at $500 million after the latest financing round.
lead_paragraph: Just months after investing in Zenefits, a human resources software company, Andreessen Horowitz has increased its investment.

headline: New York Today: Summons Season
abstract: What you need to know for Tuesday: summer’s smaller crimes, possible rain, and the first family moves into Gracie Mansion.
lead_paragraph: Happy pleasant Tuesday morning.

headline: Elections in Syria
abstract: The ballot is expected to give Bashar al-Assad another term as president.
lead_paragraph: The ballot is expected to give Bashar al-Assad another term as president.

headline: New King or, Spaniards Ask, Is It Time for No King?
abstract: Just under 50 percent said they supported it, according to an opinion poll published in January.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — There is no doubt that King Juan Carlos played an essential role in ushering Spain toward democracy, and later remained a respected voice that could speak for his nation abroad while also providing a necessary balm at critical moments to heal old wounds and mediate disputes at home from above the political fray.

headline: Obama, in Poland, Renews Commitment to Security
abstract: A $1 billion program to bolster defenses for American allies in Eastern and Central Europe is announced, but nerves are still rattled by the crisis in neighboring Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — President Obama flew here Tuesday to unveil a $1 billion security plan intended to demonstrate the United States’ “rock-solid commitment” to stand with Central and Eastern Europe against Russian aggression, but it did not settle nerves rattled by the crisis in neighboring Ukraine.

headline: Fewer Hong Kongers Support 1989 Tiananmen Protests, Survey Finds
abstract: Sympathy for the protests in Tiananmen Square has ebbed somewhat in Hong Kong, although a clear majority still believes that the Chinese government was wrong in suppressing them, the latest annual poll found.
lead_paragraph: Sympathy and support for the student-led protests in Tiananmen Square a quarter-century ago have ebbed somewhat in Hong Kong this year, although a clear majority still believes that the Chinese government was wrong in suppressing the protests, according to an annual survey released on Tuesday.

headline: K.K.R. to Buy Internet Brands for $1.1 Billion
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity']
abstract: Internet Brands, which owns websites like Lawyers.com, CarsDirect.com and ApartmentRatings.com, is being sold by Hellman & Friedman and JMI Equity.
lead_paragraph: The private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has agreed to buy Internet Brands, which operates a portfolio of websites and software, in a bet that it can help the company expand its services.

headline: 1975: Juan Carlos to be Sworn In As King of Spain
abstract: The death of Gen. Francisco Franco ended 36 years of dictatorship in Spain and restored the monarchy under Juan Carlos I, as the International Herald Tribune reported in 1975.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — With the death of Generalissimo Francisco Franco early this morning, Spain today calmly prepared for a new era under Prince Juan Carlos as its first king since 1931.

headline: Tiananmen, Forgotten
abstract: My generation of young Chinese can’t afford to look back or consider the larger issues that bedevil our society.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — I don’t remember the first time I heard the term liu si — June 4 — which is how the Tiananmen protests, the widespread demonstrations in 1989 that ended in bloodshed, are referred to in China. It was perhaps sometime around 2003, when I was 15 or 16. The term was probably uttered at the dinner table by one of my parents, both of whom were on the Avenue of Eternal Peace, the street in front of Tiananmen Square, on that night. They bore witness to the senseless killing, a memory that has haunted them ever since.

headline: Mixed Reaction to the Bergdahl Deal
abstract: Prisoner swap or negotiations with terrorists? Questions arise after the freeing of five senior Taliban figures in exchange for the American soldier Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl.
lead_paragraph: Prisoner swap or negotiations with terrorists? Questions arise after the freeing of five senior Taliban figures in exchange for the American soldier Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl.

headline: A Start-Up That Helps Businesses Assess Customer Service
abstract: StellaService’s staff members shop companies to “stress-test” their customer-service processes.
lead_paragraph: Start-Up: StellaService.

headline: Q. and A.: Louisa Lim on the Pivot Point for China’s Contemporary History
abstract: The author of a new book on the Tiananmen massacre argues that it was crucial to understanding today’s China.
lead_paragraph: Louisa Lim’s new book, “The People’s Republic of Amnesia: Tiananmen Revisited,” describes how government policy and fast economic growth have conspired to make most Chinese ignorant about the June 4, 1989, massacre in Beijing and crackdowns in scores of cities across China. But in an interview, Ms. Lim, a former Beijing correspondent for National Public Radio who recently completed a fellowship in the United States, argued that the massacre was crucial to understanding today’s China. Excerpts follow:

headline: Intersection | El Raval, Barcelona
abstract: In Barcelona’s Raval neighborhood, locals draw inspiration from rock stars and the city’s history.
lead_paragraph: In Barcelona’s Raval neighborhood, locals draw inspiration from rock stars and the city’s history.

headline: In Debate Over Coal, Looking to Lessons of ’90s Tobacco Fight
keywords: ['Coal', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: The so-called War on Coal is reminiscent of the War on Tobacco, in which a truce took hold in large part because the states dependent on the product were compensated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency’s proposed regulation of power plant emissions signals the beginning of a fight over coal and climate change. Any chance of a resolution is likely to depend on the combatants agreeing to a reduction in emissions in exchange for help to coal-dependent regions and assistance to workers struggling with higher energy costs.

headline: Morning Agenda: France’s Direct Appeal on Bank
abstract: French officials are appealing to the United States on behalf of BNP Paribas. | Valeant’s bid for Allergan raises a question about the role of drug companies. | Pilgrim’s Pride raises its bid for Hillshire Brands. | Trouble may be brewing at Salesforce.
lead_paragraph: With the prospect of a guilty plea in the United States looming, the French bank BNP Paribas has enlisted the support of a powerful ally: its own government, including top regulators and the French president, DealBook’s Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write. President François Hollande recently reached out to the White House to raise concerns about a plea deal, injecting a political undercurrent into a law enforcement investigation.

headline: Tony Awards Predictions: Best Musical
abstract: This year’s best musical race is the most wide open since 2005.
lead_paragraph: Will the emotional punch of “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical” send that show soaring to victory on Sunday in the race for the best musical Tony Award? Will cleverness carry the day with a win for “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder”? Or will comic antics – as well as the lack of a clear favorite in this category – be enough for “Aladdin” to land Disney’s first best musical Tony since “The Lion King” in 1998?

headline: The Small Stuff, Again
abstract: Following my recent rant about misused hyphens, here’s a quick look at another much-abused punctuation mark: the comma.
lead_paragraph: Following my recent rant about misused hyphens, here’s a quick look at another much-abused punctuation mark: the comma.

headline: Daily Report: The Search for Computers That Can Spot Their Own Security Flaws
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Contests and Prizes']
abstract: A Defense Department agency is holding a contest to encourage programmers to create automation tools to find flaws in computer systems, like ones that make data vulnerable to theft.
lead_paragraph: If only computers were smart enough to defend themselves against malevolent hackers. Such is the premise of an ambitious two-year contest with a $2 million first prize, posed to the world’s computer programmers by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, better known by the acronym Darpa. It is the blue-sky, big-think organization within the Defense Department that created a precursor of the Internet in the late 1960s and more recently held a contest that spurred development of self-driving cars, Kenneth Chang reports.

headline: Art of Huang Yin Toys With Concept of a Lie
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'ANGER (EMOTION)', 'Art', 'Children and Childhood', 'Fairy Tales', 'Fear (Emotion)', 'Men and Boys', 'Sweating']
abstract: With the figure of the curiously adult child, the artist Huang Yin is saying that people don’t really grow up, they just pretend to. And they lie a lot.
lead_paragraph: Drops of sweat run down the comically exaggerated faces of the little boys in the artist Huang Yin’s oil paintings. With slicked-back hair and red, doll-like cheeks, they smoke, clutching full glasses of wine, their faces creased in laughter.

headline: Stephen Colbert on Thomas Piketty
abstract: What happens when you cross a parody of a blowhard right-wing talk-show host with a French economist who seeks a fight against global inequality?
lead_paragraph: What happens when you cross a parody of a blowhard right-wing talk-show host with an influential French economist who seeks a fight against global inequality? Now we know, after the Thomas Piketty World Tour continued Monday night with a stop at “The Colbert Report.”

headline: Another Man Freed as Brooklyn District Attorney’s Office Reviews Cases
abstract: Roger Logan, found guilty in a 1997 killing, was freed on Tuesday, the result of his own plea for justice and a review of 90 cases by the Brooklyn district attorney’s office.
lead_paragraph: On a rain-drenched night in the summer of 1997, Sherwin Gibbons was shot dead, murdered as he sipped a beer in the vestibule of a building in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

headline: Obama Defends Swap of Taliban for American P.O.W.
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: “The United States has always had a pretty sacred rule, and that is: we don’t leave our men or women in uniform behind,” President Obama said.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — President Obama defended on Tuesday the prisoner swap that freed an American soldier in Afghanistan and vowed to keep watch over the five Taliban figures released from the American prison camp in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, in exchange.

headline: WWDC Dissected: A New Era for Apple, but an End for Some Apps
abstract: On the heels of Apple’s WWDC keynote presentation, New York Times tech columnists Molly Wood and Farhad Manjoo discuss the hits and misses in the big announcements.
lead_paragraph: As it tends to do a few times a year, the technology industry paused on Monday for a day of product news and promises from Apple. Making iOS and the Macintosh operating systems work better? Check. A Snapchat competitor? Check. Better cloud computing capabilities? Check.

headline: Stuck in an Underground Village
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Being stuck on an indefinitely delayed subway train is a good opportunity to learn about one’s fellow riders.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Declassified U.N. Cables Reveal Turning Point in Rwanda Crisis of 1994
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Museums', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: Nearly 300 documents capture the reluctance of the United Nations Security Council to respond to the deepening crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On April 12, 1994, six days after a plane carrying Rwanda’s president was shot down, setting off a wave of killings, Madeleine K. Albright, the American ambassador to the United Nations at the time, sent a cable to the State Department proposing that the United States take the lead in pushing to withdraw most of the United Nations peacekeeping force operating there.

headline: With Choice at Tiananmen, Student Took Road to Riches
abstract: Xiao Jianhua, the leader of the official student union at Peking University in 1989, sided with the government and found wealth and favor.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A few days after the crackdown on the Tiananmen Square protests 25 years ago, the Chinese government filled the airwaves with a list of the 21 most wanted student leaders accused of stirring up an antigovernment rebellion. At the top of the list was a 20-year-old student at Peking University named Wang Dan, who set up an unofficial student union to mobilize his classmates to demand democracy.

headline: How Hillshire Can End Its Deal for Pinnacle
abstract: With Hillshire now choosing to talk to its two unsolicited suitors, Pilgrim’s Pride and Tyson Foods, the company’s deal to buy Pinnacle Foods is in doubt. Here’s how that earlier takeover proposal can end.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders who had protested Hillshire Brands’ takeover of Pinnacle Foods will most likely be heartened by the packaged foods company’s decision to talk to its two unsolicited suitors.

headline: Pakistan Shaken by Faraway Arrest of Political Boss
abstract: The arrest of Altaf Hussain on suspicion of money laundering caused panic in his stronghold of Karachi, Pakistan, where businesses closed and residents rushed home fearing political violence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When British police officers mounted a dawn raid on a calm London suburb on Tuesday, with orders to arrest the powerful Pakistani political boss Altaf Hussain, the reverberations were felt most intensely 4,000 miles away in the port city of Karachi.

headline: Here Are the CFDA Winners...
abstract: Joseph Altuzarra and Rihanna were among the winners from Monday night’s fashion awards show.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Altuzarra and Rihanna were among the winners from Monday night’s fashion awards show.

headline: CFDA Awards: The Verdict
abstract: Four main takeaways from Monday night’s honors.
lead_paragraph: The envelopes have been opened, Rihanna has made the requisite news (via a sheer crystal mesh dress and skull cap; O.M.G., O.M.G., etc.), and the 2014 CFDA awards have come to an end. What do you need to know about the evening?

headline: Tea Party Challenge in Mississippi G.O.P. Primary Goes to the Wire
keywords: ['Elections, State Legislature', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: Senator Thad Cochran appeared headed for a runoff with a Tea Party-backed challenger in Mississippi, while in Iowa, State Senator Joni Ernst cruised to victory.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There was no clear winner early Wednesday in the most hard-fought Republican Senate primary race this year, with the six-term incumbent Thad Cochran of Mississippi and his Tea Party-backed challenger, State Senator Chris McDaniel, running neck and neck after a night of lead changes.

headline: Whose Writing Career Do You Most Envy?
abstract: Zoë Heller and Daniel Mendelsohn discuss writers whose careers they covet.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Zoë Heller and Daniel Mendelsohn discuss writers whose careers they covet.

headline: Converting a Run-Down Power Plant
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Art', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Even if the gallery crowd is slow to arrive, signs of the building’s revival are proving uplifting for residents, local officials and real estate brokers in Yonkers, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A ruin on the banks of the Hudson River, the closed Glenwood power plant site has haunted the city of Yonkers for decades.

headline: Facts & Figures: Female Hurricanes
abstract: People think storms with female names will be less dangerous, and respond accordingly.
lead_paragraph: Researchers from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign have found that powerful hurricanes with female names were deadlier than equally strong hurricanes with male names, apparently because people are less afraid of girls.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Super-ish Tuesday
abstract: Voters will be heading to the polls for primaries in Alabama, California, Iowa, Mississippi, Montana, New Jersey, New Mexico and South Dakota.
lead_paragraph: Good morning from a balmy Washington. It may be only June, but a miniature Super Tuesday is upon us, with primary elections taking place in eight states today.

headline: Sperm Donation is Full of Euphemisms, and an 11-Year-Old is Full of Questions
abstract: When I announced the pregnancy at a family dinner, my father reminded my younger brother that I was “helping out” friends by being their “donor.” “But David’s gay,” he helpfully reminded the table. “How can they make a baby if they’re not having sex?”
lead_paragraph: Since agreeing to become a sperm donor for my good friends, Tori and Kelly, I’ve noticed an impressive variety of euphemisms are used when discussing the subject in polite company. My mother regularly calls to inquire how “that thing” is going “with the girls,” for example, and acquaintances will praise me for my decision to “donate,” as if I’ve just dropped off some gently used housewares at my local Salvation Army.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on Obama’s proposed carbon-emissions rules, the European Union elections, the Veterans Affairs issues and Afghan interpreters.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s proposed emissions restrictions on power plants may be insufficient by themselves to forestall the severest impacts of climate change. But they are ultimately “good for the nation’s health, good for technological innovation, good for President Obama’s credibility abroad, and, in time, good for the health of the planet and future generations,” says  The New York Times editorial board.

headline: Marilyn Monroe’s World War II Drone Program
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Before Hollywood and a name change, Norma Jeane Dougherty worked in a war plant that manufactured an early version of today’s remote-controlled pilotless aircraft.
lead_paragraph: Working 10 hours a day for $20 a week in a World War II defense plant 70 years ago was 18-year-old Norma Jeane Dougherty, wife of a young United States merchant seaman assigned overseas. Her company, called Radioplane, in Burbank, Calif., founded by the British character actor Reginald Denny, made small remote-controlled pilotless aircraft, intended to help United States Army and Navy anti-aircraft gunners refine their targeting skills.

headline: In Escape Rooms, Video Games Meet Real Life
abstract: The video game culture has propelled the creation of escape rooms, immersive events that require audience members to solve puzzles and influence dramatic outcomes.
lead_paragraph: Everything is interactive these days, thanks to video games and the Internet, even Neil Patrick Harris’s forthcoming autobiography, which is being written in the style of a 1980s Choose Your Own Adventure book. One of the most interesting fusions of digital culture with an older form — in this case, theater — is the escape room, which locks people behind a closed door and asks them to find a way out.

headline: Maya Angelou Memorial Service to Be Streamed Online
abstract: The memorial service will be held Saturday morning at Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, N.C.
lead_paragraph: A memorial service will be held for Maya Angelou at the Wait Chapel of Wake Forest University, in Winston-Salem, N.C., on Saturday morning, the university announced. Ms. Angelou, who died on May 28, was the Reynolds Professor of American Studies at the university, a position to which she was appointed in 1982.

headline: Obama Defends Bergdahl Prison Deal
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Prisoners of War']
abstract: The president defended the United States prisoners exchange that freed Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl from Taliban captivity after five years.

headline: With New Government, Analysts Expect Policy Shift for Selling Public Companies
abstract: The expectation for the Narendra Modi-led government is one of strategic sell-downs of the government’s stakes.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — As the National Democratic Alliance government led by the newly elected Prime Minister Narendra Modi begins to fall into place, analysts expect his mantra of “maximum governance, minimum government” to translate to a strategic sale of stakes in ailing publicly owned companies.

headline: Disapproval Is Swift for French Merger Plan
abstract: President François Hollande says reducing the number of regions is a needed step to cut costs, but critics fear a loss of cultural identity and federal jobs.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France is a nation where regional identity is fierce, embodied in the sparkling wine of Champagne or choucroute, the sauerkraut revered in Alsace.

headline: Rangers Like Richards, and May Buy Him Out
abstract: In their drive to the Stanley Cup finals, Brad Richards has emerged as one of the Rangers’ leaders, but they might try to get out from under his expensive contract later this month.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Brad Richards has done exactly what the Rangers asked of him in July 2011 when they signed him to a nine-year, $60 million contract. He has provided playmaking and leadership, ushering the Rangers to their first Stanley Cup finals since 1994. It is unlikely they would have gotten this far without him.

headline: So What?
