lead_paragraph: This spring, those who enjoy arguing about language (and they are many) turned their attention to a perennial but still-unsolved question: Is it O.K. to start a sentence with the word “so”?

headline: The Dubious Campaigns to Fight Overregulation
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Congress is seeking to create an independent commission to repeal outdated rules, but the move would probably just lead to overlapping reform efforts and may prove to be unconstitutional, David Zaring writes in Another View.
lead_paragraph: Most businesses cannot make plans without making predictions about what their regulators will do. Some have argued that this task has been complicated by the fact that old regulations are rarely repealed, even as new ones are added, making for overlapping requirements and outdated regulations.

headline: The Left and Masculinity
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Gender', 'Honor Killings', 'Isla Vista, Calif, Massacre (2014)', 'Men and Boys', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties', 'Violence (Media and Entertainment)']
abstract: Does something called “traditional masculinity” need to die so that modern men can live?
lead_paragraph: My last post tried to pin down what I find troublesome about how conservatives sometimes engage with arguments about sex, violence, misogyny and masculinity — whether the context is rape on college campuses or the Santa Barbara murders. As a complement, let me try to pin down why the left’s framing of these issues often leaves me even colder, using as an example a particularly passionate argument from the left-wing gadfly Fredrik De Boer, in which he reacts to watching the video the killer left behind:

headline: From Exiled Students, Sympathy for One Who Chose Another Path
abstract: Two former protest leaders who spent years in prison expressed understanding about a classmate who chose to sit out the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square — and is now immensely wealthy.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1989, Wang Dan’s image, with his tousled hair and oversized, plastic-framed glasses, became known to millions around the world as he rallied students on Beijing’s Tiananmen Square. A history major at the elite Peking University, he chose the path of protest that led to imprisonment and, eventually, to exile following the crackdown on June 4 of that year.

headline: Israel Condemns Plan in Washington to Work With New Palestinian Alliance
abstract: A disagreement over whether the United States would engage with a Palestinian government formed with Hamas’s consent signals new strains between Israel and the U.S.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Tuesday that he was “deeply troubled” by the Obama administration’s decision to work with the new Palestinian government, signaling new strains in the often rocky relationship between Israel and the United States, two close and critical allies.

headline: Illinois: Six are Shot in Laundromat in Chicago
abstract: Six people were shot in a laundromat on the South Side of Chicago on Monday night, the latest outbreak in a wave of gun violence plaguing the city.
lead_paragraph: Six people were shot in a laundromat on the South Side of Chicago on Monday night, the latest outbreak in a wave of gun violence plaguing the city. The shootings happened shortly after 8 p.m. in a coin laundry in the 7900 block of South Colfax Avenue, a police spokesman said. The victims, described as two teenagers and four adults by police, were taken to hospitals. None of the injuries were believed to be life-threatening, the police said. Although the number of homicides in Chicago had dropped amid increased police efforts — there were more than 500 homicides in 2012 — violence has jumped in recent months.

Fedora’s nearby sister restaurant, Perla, serves a cocktail called National Lampoon’s Wisco Vacation, no explanation needed.

headline: A C.I.A. Mole Hunt In the Era of Hackers
abstract: In David Ignatius’s “The Director,” a freshly installed leader of the Central Intelligence Agency learns that it has been hacked by an unknown enemy.
lead_paragraph: David Ignatius’s fast, sometimes frantic new thriller, “The Director,” is about a mole in the C.I.A., a ghost in the national security machine, a worm in the system.

headline: A Young Photographer’s Fresh View on Fashion
abstract: This month, the buzzy young talent Erik Madigan Heck is debuting a series of fine-art photographs at Bosi Contemporary and curating an issue of Creem magazine.
lead_paragraph: The 30-year-old photographer and filmmaker Erik Madigan Heck has gained acclaim for hyper-real, richly colorful images that elevate fashion portraiture to fine art. A new series of 13 of his large-scale images, “The Absorbed Tradition,” debuts tomorrow at New York’s BOSI Contemporary gallery. They will also be featured as part of a special new Heck-curated and photographed issue of Creem magazine, out this month. “I decided that I needed to make a whole magazine that articulated a sort of remedy to the problem that I had created in my head,” Heck says of the Creem project, “which was that everything” in fashion image culture “resembled everything else.”

headline: An Opera About Little Rock Integration, With Libretto by Henry Louis Gates Jr.
abstract: An opera based on the nine black students who enrolled at Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., is in the works, with music by Tania León and a libretto by Henry Louis Gates Jr.
lead_paragraph: Ever since John Adams had his first operatic hit with “Nixon in China,” operas based on the headlines and recent history rather than mythological tales and literary adaptations have become plentiful. The University of Central Arkansas is hoping to add the story of the Little Rock Nine  — nine black students who enrolled at what had been an all-white high school in Little Rock, Ark., in 1957 – to the operatic annals. The school is in the process of commissioning the composer Tania León and the scholar Henry Louis Gates Jr. to create a work about the incident, and hopes to present the premiere in September 2017, around the 60th anniversary of the events.

headline: Latest Incarnation of King Crimson Plans U.S. Tour
abstract: King Crimson, with its eighth lineup since 1969, plans to tour the United States starting in September.
lead_paragraph: Robert Fripp, the founding guitarist and driving creative force of the British progressive rock band King Crimson, has declared the band dead several times since 1974, but this week he allowed that there was life in it yet. On his online diary Mr. Fripp noted that the group’s latest lineup – its eighth since 1969, first announced in September – had just convened in London for rehearsals, and was planning to tour the United States in the fall. The tour is to begin in Albany on Sept. 9 and end in Seattle on Oct. 6. There will be three performances at the Best Buy Theater in Manhattan, Sept. 18-20.

headline: An Existence So Vanilla, It’s Stifling
abstract: “The Sonic Life of a Giant Tortoise” features characters who admit that their worlds could use more spark.
lead_paragraph: His secret is nothing terrible, just a thought that he’s kept private, but the man tells it bashfully: “I want to live more fully than I do now.” That’s the quiet wish of the restless 30-somethings in the Japanese playwright Toshiki Okada’s “The Sonic Life of a Giant Tortoise,” presented by the Play Company in Dan Rothenberg’s splendidly cast production at Jack, in Brooklyn.

lead_paragraph: VERO BEACH, Fla. — The storefront Islamic center tucked in a nondescript shopping center here has no imam, so the task of leading the small group of men and boys gathered to pray usually falls to the eldest, or the one who knows the Quran the best.

headline: Greenwich Concours: Sunny Days, a Big Turnout and a Record Auction
abstract: Bonhams reports more than $8 million in sales at the auction; a 1935 Duesenberg and a rare Belgian 1930 Minerva 80138 AL convertible win best in show.
lead_paragraph: The Greenwich Concours d'Élégance, now in its 19th year, celebrates classic cars from all over the world, with the spotlight last Sunday on European marques. The day was sunny, and that contributed to a big turnout, for the show and the Bonhams auction held there.

headline: Lessons From the Old School
abstract: The Simone’s lived-in warmth has become rare in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The chef Chip Smith and his wife, Tina Vaughn, moved to New York in 2012 after shutting their restaurant in North Carolina, but the Simone, which they opened in November, doesn’t feel like a transplanted Southern flower. It is a classic Manhattan restaurant that seems to have emerged on East 82nd Street fully formed out of a time capsule sealed in the last century.

headline: First Victim in a Cluster of Stabbings
abstract: Tanaya Copeland, 18, was killed as she walked to a friend’s house days before two children were attacked in an elevator in a nearby building.
lead_paragraph: Whether she was practicing her drumming, riding her bike around her neighborhood in Brooklyn or going to the movies, Tanaya Copeland was often accompanied by friends in purple, fellow members of a community marching band who had known her, in some cases, since middle school.

lead_paragraph: In another symbolic step toward the exit from Afghanistan, the United States on Tuesday formally handed Kyrgyzstan control of Manas Air Base, once a major staging point for personnel and cargo bound for the Afghan war.

lead_paragraph: The protesters had been cleared out of Tiananmen Square for just over a week when the Beijing Public Security Bureau issued a most-wanted circular on June 13, 1989, bearing the names and photographs of 21 student leaders.

headline: Syrians Vote in Presidential Election
abstract: Voting began in areas held by the Syrian government for an election that President Bashar al-Assad is certain to win and that the opposition has called a farce.
lead_paragraph: Voting began in areas held by the Syrian government for an election that President Bashar al-Assad is certain to win and that the opposition has called a farce.

headline: These Chiles? Nothing to Fear
abstract: In the Yucatán, mild, not mind-blowing, chiles are appreciated for their subtle flavor. But even the fierce ones can be tamed.
lead_paragraph: AKUMAL, Mexico — There is no one American cuisine, and I suppose you can say there is no one Bittman cuisine either. The nation developed without respect for what was here before the Europeans flooded in, and what might have been was supplanted by anything goes. This culinary manifest destiny can be fascinating, of course; my block has Turkish, Southwestern, Tex-Mex and Italian, all within 100 feet of one another. (That’s before you cross the avenue.) None are very good, but you can’t complain about variety.

headline: Eli Broad’s Art Showcase in Los Angeles, Still Unfinished, Sues Over Delays
abstract: A museum that the financier Eli Broad is building in Los Angeles is suing a German company over delays in constructing parts of its unusual facade.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The flagship museum of the billionaire financier and art collector Eli Broad, still under construction, has filed a $19.8 million lawsuit against a German company for what it describes as delays in fabricating the building blocks for its unusual latticed facade.

headline: Telling Congress What Families Need, One City, State or Hearing at a Time
keywords: ['Family Leaves', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Paid Time Off', 'Parenting', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: At a Senate committee hearing, a supporter of paid family leave tries to convince legislators on both sides of the aisle that there’s broad bipartisan support for policies that support families.
lead_paragraph: Recently, Ellen Bravo, executive director of Family Values at Work, testified before the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions. The hearing was billed as a roundtable discussion of “Economic Security for Working Women,” but economic security for working women means security for their families, and nearly every policy that would help ease the struggle for working women would improve life in the workplace for men as well.

headline: Potential Sale of Law School Raises Debate Over Who Should Profit
abstract: InfiLaw System is proposing to buy Charleston Law School, but opponents are skeptical of the company’s for-profit business model, writes Steven Davidoff in the Deal Professor column.

headline: San Francisco’s Ice Cream Scene Gets Even Hotter
keywords: ['Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: A city with an ice cream obsession has gotten an infusion of flavor from new purveyors over the last few years.
lead_paragraph: Its perpetual chill be damned, San Francisco is an ice cream lover’s utopia, a city where frozen-dairy shrines like Bi-Rite Creamery, Humphry Slocombe and Mitchell’s court perpetual lines and impassioned debate about their relative merits. The past few years have brought a new batch of scoop shops and trucks whose products are quintessentially Northern Californian, with an emphasis on local, organic ingredients and flavors that range from the slavishly seasonal to the doggedly avant-garde. It’s the kind of ice cream you’d expect, in other words, from one of the most gastronomically fixated cities in the country.

abstract: Nicknamed the “Watermelon” for its playfully unusual shape, this 95-room hotel tries, and mostly succeeds, to be both quirky and luxurious.

headline: Restaurant Report: Thunderbird in Indianapolis
abstract: Housed in a former rockabilly club from the 1950s and ’60s, this new spot pours colorfully named cocktails and dishes up rib-sticking fare.
lead_paragraph: The Indianapolis dining scene has come a long way in a short time. Locals talk about how it’s growing out of its generic roots, gaining a consciousness about non-chain businesses. Take, for example, Thunderbird. In the up-and-coming Fountain Square neighborhood, the 80-seat restaurant, which opened in February, is housed in the former home of a rockabilly nightclub from the 1950s and ’60s.

headline: A Winding, Watery Way to the World Cup
abstract: The goal: Reach Natal, Brazil, in time for the United States’ opening match. The route: That’s a lot less straightforward.
lead_paragraph: In the last few days, I’ve explored a gold mining town, eaten lots of curries and taken a boat down the Essequibo River to visit waterfalls and old Dutch forts — all in Guyana, the English-speaking, Caribbean-influenced country on South America’s north coast. What brings me this virtually tourist-free nation of 750,000?

headline: Live Analysis of the Primaries, County by County

abstract: Gathering and mapping tweets by Nate Cohn and Jonathan Martin as they analyze the results.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, The Upshot and The Times political staff followed the results of the Republican Senate primaries in Mississippi and Iowa in a slightly different way. Nate Cohn, who has been writing about the Senate races, joined Jonathan Martin of The New York Times’s Washington bureau. As the election results rolled in, county by county, their analysis was complemented by county-level mapping.

headline: The Potential Downside of Natural Gas
abstract: President Obama’s climate plan relies on natural gas’s ability to drive down emissions, but it’s unclear whether its net effect helps in the long term.
lead_paragraph: CONVENTIONAL wisdom, strongly promoted by the natural gas industry, is that natural gas drives down American emissions of carbon dioxide, by substituting for carbon-rich coal. The climate stabilization plan announced by the Obama administration on Monday relies on that. But in other ways, cheap natural gas drives emissions up.

abstract: The Commerce Department, ruling in a long-simmering trade dispute, said manufacturers had benefited from unfair subsidies.
lead_paragraph: The Commerce Department on Tuesday imposed steep duties on importers of Chinese solar panels made from certain components, asserting that the manufacturers had benefited from unfair subsidies.

abstract: “Jack Kirby: New Gods — Artist’s Edition” reprints issues of the comic and a gallery of other Fourth World art.

headline: Twitter Chat About New E.P.A. Carbon Pollution Regulations
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Coal', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: Coral Davenport answered questions from readers about President Obama’s announcement of regulations to cut carbon pollution.
lead_paragraph: Coral Davenport, who reports on energy and environment policy from the Washington bureau of The New York Times, answered questions on Tuesday from readers on Twitter. The discussion was spurred by President Obama’s announcement of Environmental Protection Agency regulations to cut emissions rates from the nation’s power plants 30 percent from 2005 levels by 2030. Followers of @TheCaucus Twitter account asked about a variety of issues, including the politics and timing of the rule, its effect on coal-producing states, the implications of the regulations for global negotiations on climate change, and more.

headline: Brazilian President Rejects Criticism Over World Cup
abstract: Facing discontent over her government’s preparations for the World Cup, President Dilma Rousseff defended the funding of new stadiums and said Brazilians planning to shun the event were a “small minority.”
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — The year was 1970. Agents of Brazil’s military dictatorship had arrested Dilma Rousseff, then a member of a fledgling urban guerrilla group, the Palmares Armed Revolutionary Vanguard. Inside the prison where she was being held in São Paulo, a debate raged among the inmates: Should they support Brazil in that year’s World Cup?

headline: Groomed for Greatness | A Men’s Spa Where Discretion is Key
abstract: No women are allowed at JF Men, the hairstylist Julien Farel’s new salon on the Upper East Side, and the services clients receive there (whether a facial or a salt-and-pepper camouflage) are nobody’s business but their own.
lead_paragraph: No man wants a woman to know when he’s gotten what the hairstylist Julien Farel calls a “salt-and-pepper camouflage” — where you blend your gray discreetly to get back to your natural color. And so what happens at JF Men — Farel’s new men’s-only salon, which opened below his new Restore Salon and Spa flagship at the Loews Regency Hotel on the Upper East Side of Manhattan — stays at JF Men. “It’s almost like Vegas,” Farel laughs. Indeed, the intimate space feels akin to a modern-day gentlemen’s club: a lounge for relaxing after a power lunch, a flat-screen TV, a bar cart — “We’re only missing the cigar,” Farel quips in a thick French accent. Need to get your shoes shined while you get a little taken off the back? No problem.

headline: People Lost in Transit, Strangeness Abounding
abstract: The life of the writer Jane Bowles in part forms the basis for Julia Jarcho’s play “Nomads.”
lead_paragraph: The playwright Julia Jarcho and the director Alice Reagan share a fondness for strangeness, for edges that don’t quite line up.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an e-mail. Sign up »

headline: Southern Politicians Try to Hold Back the Tides
abstract: For the moment, but maybe not for long, fossilized language is required of both Republican and Democratic candidates.
lead_paragraph: It’s always taken longer to get to the future in the South, and the region’s social tardiness has been on display in this season’s political races. For the moment, at least, harsh and fossilized language is still required of both Republican and Democratic candidates.

headline: Dinosaur Fossil Smuggler Gets 3-Month Sentence
abstract: A Florida fossil hunter who illegally dug up dinosaur skeletons from the Gobi Desert in Mongolia was sentenced on Tuesday to three months in prison.
lead_paragraph: A Florida fossil hunter who illegally dug up dinosaur skeletons from the Gobi Desert in Mongolia was sentenced on Tuesday to three months in prison on charges that he smuggled the bones into the United States, then used them to reassemble a Tyrannosaurus bataar, above, that he sold for $1 million through a New York auction house.

headline: My Wars Are Ending
abstract: Last week, President Obama, speaking at West Point, made clear that the end of combat in Afghanistan is near. An Air Force officer who deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan struggles to find clarity about what it all meant.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 31, the Air Force shut down rescue operations at Bastion Air Base in Afghanistan. It closed five years of lifesaving in the Helmand Province by “Pedro” and “Guardian,” as the HH-60G Pave Hawks and Pararescue/Combat Rescue officers were known, and became just the latest in the list of places I’ve gone, to which I will go no more. The first ones were Balad Air Base and Camp Victory, in Iraq. Then Kandahar, and most recently, Camp Bastion in Afghanistan.

headline: A Reckless Trajectory: Ingénue to Courtesan to Streetwalker
abstract: American Ballet Theater’s revival of Kenneth MacMillan’s 1974 “Manon” features new sets and costumes and dramatic and delirious dancing.
lead_paragraph: The dramatic fortitude required to pull off a good Manon — the troubled courtesan drawn between greed and love — is fairly attainable. Kenneth MacMillan’s earthy, naturalistic choreography reads like text. But for a great Manon, more is at stake. A ballerina doesn’t so much dance the role as let it consume her body, bit by bit. It’s like a fever.

headline: Childbirth, a Lit Torch and a Trot
abstract: A compulsion to repeat emerged as a common theme as colleagues of the choreographer DD Dorvillier presented solos at Danspace last weekend.
lead_paragraph: “Diary of an Image by DD Dorvillier”: that’s the title of the four-week program currently underway at Danspace Project at St. Mark’s Church. But not all the work is by Ms. Dorvillier. On Friday and Saturday, for the second of two weekends, the choreographer invited colleagues to present solos of their own. Commonalities between the pieces appeared coincidental, except perhaps for purposeful awkwardness and a compulsion to repeat.

headline: Garden Workshops at a Vermont Inn
keywords: ['Flowers and Plants', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Master gardener Ben Pauly will lead workshops at the Woodstock Inn & Resort in Vermont this summer.
lead_paragraph: The Woodstock Inn & Resort in Woodstock, Vt., this summer is sharing the talents of its No. 1 green thumb, the master gardener Ben Pauly, who will lead a series of hands-on sessions exploring the art and technique of gardening.

headline: Busy Comings and Goings, and Tangled Partnerings
abstract: The Daniel Gwirtzman Dance Company, celebrating its 15th anniversary, performed “The Oracle” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Fishman Space.
lead_paragraph: In a program note accompanying his new work, “The Oracle,” Daniel Gwirtzman assures his audience that “there are so many ways into a dance.” Listen to the score, he suggests, or trace the geometries of the movement. Imagine what might happen next, or consider the metaphors embedded in the choreography. Whatever you do, “Create your own frame,” he urges.

headline: Retro Rap That Puts Women Down
abstract: In a rap era characterized by more emotional maturity, “Loyal” by Chris Brown and “Cut Her Off” by K Camp share a retrograde feeling in how they regard women.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night at Hot 97 Summer Jam, Lil Wayne was at the end of his mini-set, in the middle of his protégée Nicki Minaj’s performance, when he gleefully rapped his verse from the Chris Brown hit “Loyal,” concluding with the incessant refrain: “These ho’s ain’t loyal!”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Ukraine, South Africa and Iran.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Ukraine, South Africa and Iran.

headline: Musical Mischief With Dvorak
abstract: Old World elegance for the “New World” composer, as the Budapest Festival Orchestra brought playful touches to its two all-Dvorak concerts at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: The Budapest Festival Orchestra was almost halfway into its performance of Dvorak’s Slavonic Dance No. 8 (Op. 72) on Monday evening when Gaspar Szente, one of its percussionists, ambled through the string section to the front of the stage. Sitting down on the stool that had been placed there for the next concerto’s solo cellist, he calmly reached into his breast pocket and pulled out a tiny brass cymbal. Another leisurely gesture brought forward a mallet. With his head cocked attentively, he waited for his entrance. Then he played, intermittently producing delicate, pealing notes that improbably became the music’s emotional focus.

headline: Any Ghosts Here? A Team Is in Pursuit
abstract: “Spooked” is a four-episode paranormal series available on Hulu and YouTube.
lead_paragraph: Say this for Bryan Singer: He has range. He’s the director and a producer of “X-Men: Days of Future Past,” which has grossed more than $500 million worldwide in less than two weeks. And, at the same time, he’s an executive producer of the new online series “Spooked,” which looks as if it could have been made on the “X-Men” budget for moist towelettes.

headline: Far From Beijing, Jaded Students Inspired to Protest
abstract: The Tiananmen protests of 25 years ago are well documented, but less well known are the protests took place across China, paralyzing cities large and small for nearly two months that spring.
lead_paragraph: They were the children of poor farmers and factory workers, the first in their families to attend college, and for that they were grateful. But in the spring of 1989, the students at Hubei University, a provincial college in the Yangtze River city of Wuhan, were jaded beyond their years.

headline: Off Her High Horse and Back Home
abstract: In “Jennifer Falls,” Jaime Pressly plays a woman who moves back home with her mother after losing her job.
lead_paragraph: Here are some reasons to like, or at least be interested in, the first episode of “Jennifer Falls,” a new sitcom beginning on Wednesday on TV Land. Or not.

headline: A Paltry Start in Curbing Global Warming
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Global Warming', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: World leaders aren’t dealing with the limit of the planet’s carrying capacity when they weigh future growth against the need to deal with climate change.
lead_paragraph: Tim Jackson, professor of sustainable development at the University of Surrey in Britain, uses a nifty back-of-the-envelope calculation to underscore the challenge of giving the world’s poor a shot at prosperity while preventing a global climate disaster.

headline: Spoleto, Known for Its Operas, Has Drama Left Over for the Concert Stage
abstract: Spoleto Festival USA in Charleston, S.C., renowned for opera, is a cornucopia of other offerings as well.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The Spoleto Festival USA has seemed to be in more or less permanent reconstruction mode in recent years, thanks to the renovation of some of its main performance spaces: first the weather-beaten Memminger Auditorium (reopened in 2008), then the College of Charleston’s Sottile Theater (2009) and the historic Dock Street Theater (2010). Now the end is in sight, with work well along on a rebuilding and acoustical upgrade of the Gaillard Auditorium, which is scheduled to reopen next May.

headline: Should We Die?
abstract: Some scientists believe their research could greatly extend human life — but the prospect makes a lot of people queasy, writes ANNA NORTH.
lead_paragraph: If letting a scientist study your child could help stop human aging, would you allow it?

headline: Into the Sanctum With a Master of Awe and Mysticism
abstract: The Estonian Philharmonic Chamber Choir performed Arvo Pärt’s “Kanon Pokajanen,” set to an Orthodox text, at the Metropolitan Museum on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Composers are inspired by myriad sources, including a particular event, emotion, person or landscape. The prime inspiration of the Estonian composer Arvo Pärt, however, was suppressed for a long stretch of his career. Beginning in the 1960s, Mr. Pärt, a convert to the Eastern Orthodox faith, wrote works whose religious character irked the Soviet authorities at a time when the official credo was atheism.

headline: An Affirmation of Faith at Carnegie Hall
abstract: The Tallinn Chamber Orchestra and Estonian Philharmonic Chamber Court presented an all-Arvo Pärt concert on Saturday with the composer on hand at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Orthodox priests in black robes and conical caps rubbed shoulders with pop stars and actors, including Björk, Antony Hegarty and Keanu Reeves, at Carnegie Hall on Saturday at a sold-out concert of music by Arvo Pärt. No other living composer has so fervent a following or such a diverse group of fans. When Mr. Pärt, bearded, frail and smiling shyly, took a bow at the end of the evening — this was his first visit to New York in 30 years — the roar that greeted him seemed unanimous.

headline: Steven Spinola
abstract: Mr. Spinola is the president of the Real Estate Board of New York, or Rebny, the industry’s leading trade association in the city with about 15,000 members.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Spinola, 65, is the president of the Real Estate Board of New York, or Rebny, the industry’s leading trade association in the city with about 15,000 members. He is the longest-serving president of the group, having held the position since 1986. Rebny’s focus lately has been on the city’s recently released affordable housing plan.

headline: European Central Bank Chief Looks for Silver Bullet
keywords: ['Euro (Currency)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Deflation (Economics)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The E.C.B. is expected to start charging banks interest to keep money in its vaults, a so-called negative deposit rate meant to stave off deflation and revive growth.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Mario Draghi might feel like a doctor trying to treat a chronically ill patient with unproven medicines.

headline: Europe Struggles to Avoid Deflation’s Grip
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Deflation (Economics)', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Economists fear that an outbreak of ultralow inflation across the 18-nation euro zone is doing more harm than good to the bloc’s economic recovery.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — In her upscale three-story beauty salon in a middle-class suburb of Athens, Doria Tsirigotis used to charge 30 euros for a haircut. But when a wrenching recession set in, her competitors started cutting their prices, first to 20 euros, then to 10 and even as low as 5 — or less than $7.

headline: Iran Offers a Window to the West
abstract: Given a chance – and a week – to visit Iran, John Moore took to the road in central Iran to see daily life in a place that has opened a bit to the West.
lead_paragraph: Given a chance – and a week – to visit Iran, John Moore took to the road in central Iran to see daily life in a place that has opened a bit to the West.

headline: For Goldman’s New Strategy Officer, Putting the Bank Back in Banker
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: As Goldman Sachs’s new chief strategy officer, Stephen Scherr will have to continue to grow the firm’s businesses like asset management and lending.
lead_paragraph: When Stephen M. Scherr started at Goldman Sachs more than 20 years ago, the firm operated out of the public eye. Run by a consortium of partners, it did not have to disclose much about its financial health to the world.

headline: New York City Teachers Vote for Raise and a Nine-Year Contract
abstract: The contract, agreed to in May by city officials and the teachers’ union, will increase pay but leaves many questions about future health benefits.
lead_paragraph: New York City teachers have approved a nine-year labor contract, their union announced on Tuesday, a deal that raises pay by 18 percent but leaves questions about the future of their health benefits.

headline: Narendra Modi, the Prime Minister of India: A Leader Who Is What He Wears
abstract: India’s new prime minister has succeeded in associating his personal style with his political platform, especially with the Modi Kurta.
lead_paragraph: Even by the standards of a world that has seen blogs devoted to Michelle Obama’s dress sense, the pre-election makeovers of François Hollande and Dilma Rousseff, and the canonization of Nelson Mandela’s shirts, the image-craft of India’s new prime minister, Narendra Modi — and its fashion fallout — has been something of a case study.

headline: Budapest Orchestra Has Bows Seized Over Ivory Concerns
abstract: The Budapest Festival Orchestra had seven of its bows seized at John F. Kennedy International Airport on Saturday over concerns that they contained forbidden African elephant ivory.
lead_paragraph: Updated, June 4, 2:52 p.m. |

headline: Massad Is Confirmed as Chairman of Futures Commission
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Senate confirmed Timothy G. Massad as well as two other commissioners, Sharon Y. Bowen and J. Christopher Giancarlo.
lead_paragraph: The Senate confirmed the nomination of Timothy G. Massad as chairman of the Commodity Futures Commission on Tuesday, as well as two other commissioners to lead the agency, Sharon Y. Bowen and J. Christopher Giancarlo.

headline: Google Offers New Encryption Tool
abstract: On Tuesday, Google announced plans to provide a new way to encrypt information that will make government snooping and hacking more difficult.
lead_paragraph: The National Security Agency’s snooping is about to get more difficult.

headline: Visa Is Preparing a Standard for Prepaid Debit Cards
abstract: The payment processor plans to create a special designation that will alert consumers to cards that meet criteria involving fees and terms.
lead_paragraph: Prepaid debit cards are growing in popularity, but it’s often hard to know whether a card is a good deal or not before you buy one, because there’s no requirement that the cards disclose their fees and terms in a uniform way. To help clue in consumers, Visa Inc. said on Tuesday that it would soon flag prepaid cards that meet a set of consumer-friendly standards, like flat monthly fees.

headline: As Obama Acts on Pollution and Bergdahl, G.O.P. Talks of an Erosion of Trust
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Prisoners of War', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Global Warming']
abstract: President Obama’s moves to swap Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl for five Taliban members and issue restrictions on carbon emissions make it more unlikely that major proposals like an immigration overhaul can advance this year, some lawmakers warned.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s actions in the case of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl and in issuing new power plant emissions restrictions have deepened its rift with congressional Republicans, who see the moves as the latest troubling examples of the White House circumventing Congress.

headline: Coal Pollution and Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers react to proposed regulations for coal-fired power plants.

headline: Semifinal Reunion for Gulbis and Djokovic
abstract: Ernest Gulbis will face Novak Djokovic in a men’s semifinal at the French Open after they each scored victories on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Flower power was no match for Ernests Gulbis at the French Open on Tuesday.

headline: Missing, Captured, Freed: The Case of Bowe Bergdahl
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Prisoners of War']
abstract: Readers discuss the issue of military discipline and the political outcry.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Future for Bike Share
abstract: A reader suggests an expanded system to rival the subway.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A ‘Docu-Ad’ Looks at Hardship of Those Without Bank Access
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A nearly 40-minute commercial by American Express resembles an investigative nonfiction film and reveals the high costs of living outside the traditional financial system.
lead_paragraph: REMEMBER the longtime pitch for Campbell’s Chunky soup, “the soup that eats like a meal”? A project that American Express is to introduce Wednesday can be described as a commercial that watches like a documentary.

headline: Shipping Oil by Rail
abstract: Noah Greenwald of the Center for Biological Diversity responds to an editorial, “Time to Move on Dangerous Tank Cars.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Gail Collins Responds to Readers: ‘Excitement Mounts! Sort of’
abstract: The Op-Ed columnist answers a few questions from readers about her latest column.
lead_paragraph: In her recent column, “Excitement Mounts! Sort Of”, Gail Collins writes about what we’ve learned so far this election season. Readers had these questions for her:

headline: Women’s Colleges
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A rising sophomore at Brown University argues that transgender students should be welcome in a traditionally “safe space.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Medical Marijuana
abstract: Rabbi Joel M. Levenson supports passage of a bill in the New York Senate.

headline: Segregation by Ability
abstract: Should public schools track students into gifted education programs?

headline: Clippers’ Sale Silences a Dialogue on Race
abstract: With the pending $2 billion sale of the Los Angeles Clippers, it appears the discussion about racism in the N.B.A. and beyond has stopped.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, we seemed to be on the verge of having a national conversation about race, racism and prejudice.

headline: Iraq’s Best Hope
abstract: In Kurdistan, democratic ideas in young minds.
lead_paragraph: SULAIMANI, Iraq — I am a sucker for commencements, but this one filled me with many different emotions.

headline: Upscale Dairies Grow in India, Promising Safer Milk
keywords: ['Dairy Products', 'Milk', 'Organic Foods and Products', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: As more middle-class Indians are able to afford costlier products, they drive the demand for organic, fair-trade and artisanal items.
lead_paragraph: GURGAON, India — On a 26-acre farm a couple hours’ drive inland from Mumbai, hundreds of black-and-white Holstein-Friesian cows laze around, dining on seasonal greens and listening to a custom playlist of rap, pop, classical and even devotional music. They are treated to a routine medical checkup before heading to a “rotary milking parlor,” where their udders are gently squeezed, until the cows step away, at will.

headline: In BNP Case and Beyond, Regulators Search for Penalties to Fit the Crimes
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The authorities are considering restrictions on operations that funnel money through the network that connects the world’s largest banks.
lead_paragraph: United States bank regulators are descending deep into the plumbing of the financial system as they seek the most fitting punishment for the giant French bank now in the cross hairs of the law enforcement authorities.

headline: Massachusetts: Details Emerge on Fatal Jet Crash
abstract: The crew of the Gulfstream IV jet that crashed in Bedford on Saturday night made comments about aircraft control before the plane exploded, killing all on board, federal investigators said.
lead_paragraph: The crew of the Gulfstream IV jet that crashed in Bedford on Saturday night made comments about aircraft control before the plane ran off the runway and exploded, according to federal investigators analyzing the cockpit voice recorder and the flight data recorder on Tuesday. An investigator did not specify the nature of the comments. The investigator also said that a crew member had indicated the plane was ready to lift off, but it was unclear why the aircraft failed to do so. All seven people on board were killed. The flight data recorder indicated that the jet reached 165 knots, and that brake pressure rose and the aircraft decelerated before it careered into a gully.

headline: G.M. Officials Say They Expect Mary Barra Will Be Cleared of Wrongdoing
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Officials at General Motors said an internal report on faulty ignition switches tied to 13 deaths would exonerate the company’s chief executive.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The moment captured a new sense of confidence that General Motors has been anxiously awaiting from Mary T. Barra, its embattled chief executive.

headline: Plan to Honor Big Developer in Brooklyn Is Criticized
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Atlantic Yards (Brooklyn)']
abstract: The Municipal Art Society plans to give its Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Medal to Bruce C. Ratner, builder of the Atlantic Yards development.
lead_paragraph: The Municipal Art Society is well known for campaigns to save Grand Central Terminal and Lever House and to stop towers  that would have cast long shadows over Central Park.

headline: Case’s Revolution Fund Invests in Supplier of Children’s Lunches
abstract: The Revolution Growth fund, which Stephen M. Case started with two former AOL colleagues, is investing in Revolution Foods, a company that makes healthy lunch meals for schools and grocery stores.
lead_paragraph: Stephen M. Case, the investor and co-founder of AOL, is taking an increasing interest in the food business.

headline: Tunisian Man Accused Last Year of Terrorism Pleads Guilty to Lesser Counts
abstract: A man who federal prosecutors said last year had wanted to commit acts of terrorism pleaded guilty on two counts of fraud and misuse of visas to facilitate an act of international terrorism.
lead_paragraph: A Tunisian man who federal prosecutors said last year had wanted to commit acts of terrorism pleaded guilty on Tuesday to two charges that did not specifically mention terrorism.

headline: Horse Racing Still Stumbling in Antidrug Push
abstract: Efforts to combat the widespread use of drugs in horse racing have been fragmented and ineffectual. Perhaps it’s time to bring in the United States Antidoping Agency.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — When California Chrome finally made his way back to the stables at Pimlico Race Course after winning the Preakness Stakes more than two weeks ago, fans cheered and rushed toward him, their camera phones held high and clicking.

headline: Smuggling Remembrance Into Tiananmen Square
abstract: The virtual silence around the crackdown in Beijing on June 4, 1989, was pierced again this year by imaginative Chinese Internet activists.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Dan Levin reported from Beijing, the authorities in China appeared to step up their censorship of the Internet to blot out even oblique discussion of the 25th anniversary of the violent crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square on June 3 and 4, 1989.

headline: Dai-ichi to Buy Protective Life for $5.7 Billion
abstract: Dai-ichi Life Insurance joins many other Japanese firms that are seeking growth outside their home country as it buys Protective Life, a publicly held firm based in Birmingham, Ala.
lead_paragraph: Dai-ichi Life Insurance, one of Japan’s biggest life insurers, agreed on Tuesday to buy the Protective Life Corporation for about $5.7 billion, as Japanese companies continue to seek growth outside their home country.

headline: Aiming Financial Weapons From Treasury War Room
abstract: As the financial sanctions that the United States imposes on foreign governments have become vastly more sophisticated, the Obama administration has deployed them more and more often.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a dingy suite of offices in a Treasury Department annex, the troops work into the night, armed with paperwork, computers and a clock on the wall set to Tehran time. They blast out advisories ordering banks to block targeted people, then threaten them with consequences — fines that can range into millions of dollars — if they do not.

headline: HOW THE INDUSTRY FARED IN MAY
abstract: Strong sales were reported as recalls are up industrywide.
lead_paragraph: Strong sales were reported as recalls are up industrywide.

headline: Monarchies, More Useful Than You Think
abstract: As Spain prepares to crown a new king, it seems incredible that a dozen monarchies still survive across Europe.
lead_paragraph: The decision by the 76-year-old King Juan Carlos of Spain to abdicate in favor of his 46-year-old son, Crown Prince Felipe, inevitably revives the question of why so many monarchs still reign across Europe.

headline: A Prosecutor’s Reputation Sinks Lower
abstract: A new report on Charles Hynes, the former Brooklyn district attorney, delivers a damning body of evidence on a shameful tenure.
lead_paragraph: When Kenneth Thompson was campaigning last year to unseat the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles Hynes, his main line of attack was that the office Mr. Hynes had run for nearly 24 years was ethically compromised, badly managed and a discredit to law enforcement.

headline: BNP Paribas Pinned Hopes on Legal Memo, in Vain
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Prosecutors said the memo from the law firm of France’s largest bank applied to only a small fraction of its wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: BNP Paribas, under investigation for doing business with Sudan and other countries that the United States has blacklisted, is hashing out the final details of a criminal guilty plea for its parent company. Several months ago, the giant French bank thought it had a secret weapon to avoid that fate altogether.

headline: Protesters Cite New Details of Albuquerque Police Shooting as Reason for Rally
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Thirteen protesters who were arrested Monday after storming the mayor’s office said they were prompted by an autopsy report showing a homeless man had been shot in the back.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — The 13 protesters who stormed the mayor’s office here and were arrested and jailed Monday said they were spurred by renewed outrage over the latest development in a string of fatal police shootings: An autopsy released last week showed the bullet that killed a homeless man, James Boyd, had been fired into his lower back.

headline: Amazon’s Power Play
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Editorials']
abstract: The company is using bullying tactics to get a good pricing deal on electronic books while squeezing publishers and hurting authors.
lead_paragraph: Amazon, the online retailer, has often described itself as obsessed with making customers happy. But lately the company has been making some of its users extremely unhappy by making it hard or impossible for them to buy books published by the Hachette Book Group  in the United States and delaying the deliveries of titles from the Bonnier Media Group in Germany.

headline: Don’t Harsh Our Mellow, Dude
abstract: Colorado is finding out that it’s not so easy to unleash pot on hordes of tourists seeking a mellow buzz.
lead_paragraph: The caramel-chocolate flavored candy bar looked so innocent, like the Sky Bars I used to love as a child.

headline: How The Industry Fared In May
abstract: Strong sales were reported as recalls are up industrywide.
lead_paragraph: Strong sales were reported as recalls are up industrywide.

headline: Critics Are Questioning American Military Credo of Leaving No One Behind
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Prisoners of War', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Rescues']
abstract: Military and civilian officials rallied to defend the years of effort spent to rescue Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The deadly rescue mission in Afghanistan in 2002 began when Petty Officer First Class Neil C. Roberts, a member of the Navy’s classified SEAL Team Six, fell out of a helicopter that came under enemy fire as it tried to land on the snowy ridge line of an 11,000-foot mountain.

headline: Favorite for Triple Crown Inspires a Run on Betting Tickets
keywords: ['Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Belmont Stakes', 'Horse Racing', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Gambling', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: At the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, California Chrome could become the first Triple Crown winner in 36 years. Fans are preparing by buying unusual amounts of betting tickets, some for potential profit but mostly for souvenirs.
lead_paragraph: For veteran gamblers, the rhythms of victory are familiar, if too elusive, on most afternoons.

headline: Michigan Senate Passes Plan to Ease Detroit Pension Cuts
abstract: The State Senate agreed to Gov. Rick Snyder’s call for spending millions in state money to spare the pensions of Detroit retirees from deeper cuts, a proposal approved last month by the House.
lead_paragraph: The Michigan Senate on Tuesday agreed to Gov. Rick Snyder’s call for spending millions in state funds to spare the pensions of Detroit retirees from deeper cuts and to avoid the sale of artworks from the city’s museum, part of a larger bargain aimed at bringing a swift close to the nation’s largest municipal bankruptcy.

headline: Deal to Free Bowe Bergdahl Puts Obama on Defensive
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'Detainees', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The White House argued that the “unique circumstances” presented by the opportunity to return Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl gave President Obama the authority to lawfully bypass a federal statute.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House argued on Tuesday that the “unique circumstances” presented by the opportunity to return Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl gave President Obama the authority to lawfully bypass a federal statute requiring the Pentagon to notify Congress a month before he transferred the five Taliban detainees necessary to complete the deal.

headline: Corporate Rivalries and Strategies Extend to the Street
abstract: In Corporate Challenge races, the main goal is camaraderie and team building, but in a region like New York full of people who do not like to lose, the team competition can be heated.
lead_paragraph: When his Manhattan hedge fund entered a corporate relay race, a young trader named David Nightingale gained a leadership role: ringer.

headline: Live-Blogging the Tiananmen Square Anniversary
abstract: New York Times reporters live blog the 25th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown from Beijing, Hong Kong and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Today marks the 25th anniversary of the Chinese military’s crackdown on the protests in Tiananmen Square, and The Times reported on how the event was remembered. In Hong Kong, a huge nighttime rally took place in Victoria Park. But in mainland China the situation was starkly different: The authorities were intent on silencing any mention of the anniversary, arresting dissidents and others, and prohibiting social media postings that allude even remotely to the crackdown.

headline: ‘It Will Be Incomparably More Difficult to Rule China’
abstract: Nicholas Kristof reported for The Times on the violent crackdown of pro-democracy protesters in Beijing’s Tiananmen Square in 1989.
lead_paragraph: On June 4, 1989, Chinese troops conducted a bloody crackdown on thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. At the time, Nicholas Kristof, The New York Times’s Beijing bureau chief, reported that “by ordering soldiers to fire on the unarmed crowds, the Chinese leadership has created an incident that almost surely will haunt the government for years to come.”

headline: Judge’s Decision to Hear Inmates’ Case Threatens Practice of Solitary Confinement
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Solitary Confinement', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Eighth Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: A federal judge in Oakland, Calif., agreed to consider whether holding prisoners in isolation for more than a decade violated their rights under the Eighth Amendment.
lead_paragraph: More than 200 inmates at Pelican Bay, California’s toughest prison, have spent over a decade locked in windowless 8-foot-by-12-foot cells for 22 hours or more a day. Dozens more have been in solitary confinement for 15 years — or even longer.

headline: In Stanley Cup Finals, Big Markets Don’t Mean Big Viewership
abstract: As the Rangers and the Kings, teams from the nation’s two largest markets, meet in the Stanley Cup finals, television viewership is not expected to set a record.
lead_paragraph: The Stanley Cup finals between the Rangers and Los Angeles Kings are the ninth being carried by NBC and its cable companion, NBCSN (and its Versus and OLN antecedents), a long period of media stability for the N.H.L. Under NBC, the finals have averaged as many as 5.7 million viewers (last year’s Original Six battle between Boston and Chicago) and as few as 1.8 million (the 2007 Ottawa-Anaheim series). Now, as teams from the nation’s two largest markets meet, some wonder if this is the formula for record viewership.

headline: Let Sleeping Dogs Lie
abstract: Is Jim Hilger playing with us?
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s game night here at Wordplay, and Jim Hilger has gotten out some of his favorites for us.

headline: All the World’s a Stage: One Player’s View of It
abstract: Jim Dale’s one-man show, “Just Jim Dale,” revisits the highs and pratfalls of his long and varied career in show business.
lead_paragraph: In his light-footed and lovable new solo show, “Just Jim Dale,” the man of the hour and a half recalls an early turning point in his path toward a long career in show business. When the young Mr. Dale was taken to his first West End musical, “Me and My Girl,” he watched a comic dazzle the audience with a tumble into the orchestra pit and felt a sudden, churning yearning to be up there, basking in the laughter. He turned to his father and asked how he might make a go of it.

headline: Sam’s Club Plans a Safer Credit Card
abstract: The new credit card will use EMV chip technology, which makes a card much more difficult to duplicate than those that use only a magnetic strip.
lead_paragraph: Sam’s Club plans to announce a new credit card on Wednesday that will make it the first major American retailer to switch to a more secure payment card technology that has been widely discussed since a customer-data breach at Target late last year.

headline: A Growing Challenge for Germans Who Live by Bread Alone
keywords: ['Bread', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: Traditional bakers are fighting to maintain their place in the hearts — and stomachs — of Germans as industrial baking techniques find favor.
lead_paragraph: SCHOPFHEIM, Germany — On Sunday mornings, the line at the backdoor of Fritz Trefzger’s bakery snakes through the courtyard as customers wait for their chance to step into the inner sanctum of his kitchen.

headline: Former Prosecutor in Brooklyn Was Consumed by Campaign, Emails Show
keywords: ['Elections, District Attorneys', 'Campaign Finance', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Emails show a growing preoccupation by Charles J. Hynes, the longtime district attorney, with his re-election as it became clear he would face a serious challenge.
lead_paragraph: As a contentious campaign intensified, the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, was grasping to stay on top.

headline: Sather Is Used to Stanley Cup Finals, if Not With the Rangers
abstract: The presence of Glen Sather, the Rangers’ general manager who won five championship rings with the Oilers, lent a certain kind of old-fashioned hockey star power to media day.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Glen Sather used to be at these things all the time, though not lately — not in 24 years, in fact. But Sather, the guiding force of the Rangers, seemed perfectly at home at the Staples Center on Tuesday, taking part in media day as his team prepared for Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals against the Los Angeles Kings.

headline: On the Line in Governors’ Stanley Cup Bets: Rice Cakes vs. Cupcakes
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York promised to deliver a gift basket and a 2013 hockey puck marking his passage of an on-time budget to Gov. Jerry Brown of California, who countered with a promise of rice cakes.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — California has fine wines. New York has world-class steaks.

headline: Blurred Lines Between Duty and Friendship
abstract: Justice Barry Kamins comes from a political world but is legally bound to stay out of it, despite his friendship with the former District Attorney Charles Hynes of Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Let us eavesdrop on an email exchange between two men who have been friends for 40 years, talking in the way people do when they have known each other for most of their adult lives.

headline: Den Dekker Grabs an Opportunity in Center
abstract: With Juan Lagares on the disabled list, Matt den Dekker will have chances to fill Lagares’s role.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Matt den Dekker turned and sprinted toward the center-field wall, keeping an eye on a ball that Ryan Howard had just clobbered. Den Dekker slowed, searched for the wall with his off hand and, at the last second, launched his body into the air and snatched the ball out of the sky. As he jogged back in, he held out his closed glove, as if any of his teammates had doubted he would make the catch.

headline: Shot Yards Away From Police Station, a Teenager Collapses and Dies
abstract: LaQuan Nelson, 16, was shot near Classon Avenue in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. No arrests had been made as of late Tuesday in connection with the shooting, the police said.
lead_paragraph: After he was shot Monday afternoon in Brooklyn, LaQuan Nelson, 16, staggered toward the 88th Precinct, collapsing on the sidewalk next to the redbrick police station house. But no one could save the teenager.

headline: Relatives of Victims of Drone Strikes Drop Appeal
abstract: The family members of three United States citizens killed in American drone strikes without trial will not appeal a judge’s dismissal of a lawsuit they filed against administration officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The relatives of three United States citizens killed in American drone strikes without trial, including Anwar al-Awlaki, a radical Muslim cleric, have decided not to appeal a federal judge’s dismissal of a lawsuit they filed against Obama administration officials.

headline: Mortimer Matz, a Middleman at the Nexus of Politics and Public Relations
abstract: Mr. Matz, whose payments from the office of former District Attorney Charles Hynes of Brooklyn have been questioned, is a longtime presence in New York politics.
lead_paragraph: In the 1990s, the columnist Jimmy Breslin credited Mortimer Matz as the person who made the raincoat an essential element of the criminal justice system.

headline: Lack of Cameras in Public Housing Outrages Residents and de Blasio
keywords: ['Cameras', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The New York City Housing Authority has come under fire for the lack of security cameras at a housing project where a 6-year-old boy was stabbed to death on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, responding to an outcry over the killing of a 6-year-old boy in Brooklyn, blamed “unacceptable bureaucracy” on Tuesday for delays in installing security cameras in many public housing projects, including the complex in East New York where the boy was stabbed to death on Sunday.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: June 3, 2014

headline: Roy Goodman, Liberal Republican Stalwart in New York, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Goodman was longtime state senator from the Upper East Side whose ambitions for higher office were thwarted.
lead_paragraph: Roy M. Goodman, a longtime New York State senator who was once the heir apparent to the liberal Republicans who dominated state politics in the 1960s and was later a courtly leader of that faction as it was pushed to the party’s margins, died on Tuesday in Danbury, Conn. He was 84.

headline: A’s Donaldson, by Most Measures, Is Atop Game
abstract: Oakland third baseman Josh Donaldson leads the majors in WAR, a stat that attempts to quantify a player’s overall contribution to his team’s success, but that is not his only quantifiable gauge of success.
lead_paragraph: The best player in baseball is not quite sure about the statistic that gives him that title. Josh Donaldson, the third baseman for the Oakland Athletics, arrived at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday as the major league leader in wins above replacement, as calculated by baseball-reference.com. If only he could define it more sharply.

headline: Can Bowe Bergdahl Be Tied to 6 Lost Lives? Facts Are Murky
abstract: Since Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl was freed after years in captivity, a number of the men who served with him have called him a deserter. Some have gone further, blaming him for the deaths of six to eight soldiers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Did the search for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl cost the lives of American soldiers?

headline: Anna Berger, an Actress With a Gift for Matriarchs, Dies at 91
abstract: Woody Allen and producers of “The Sopranos,” among others, cast Ms. Berger for her specialty: the older ethnic woman.
lead_paragraph: Anna Berger, a character actress known for playing matriarchal figures from different ethnic backgrounds in films like Woody Allen’s “Crime and Misdemeanors” and television shows like “The Sopranos,” died on May 26 in Manhattan. She was 91.

headline: The Republican Case Against Republican Economics
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Reformers are beginning to question the party’s free-market orthodoxy.
lead_paragraph: After the 2012 presidential election, key Republicans began to criticize their party’s opposition to immigration reform and gay rights. But now party reformers are questioning something much more central: free-market orthodoxy.

headline: No Vacancy
abstract: In hockey, a goalie is always mindful of the vulnerable areas in front of the net. These days, no one is better at guarding those spots than the Rangers’ Henrik Lundqvist.
lead_paragraph: In hockey, a goalie is always mindful of the vulnerable areas in front of the net. These days, no one is better at guarding those spots than the Rangers’ Henrik Lundqvist.

lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 8: Good Golly, Miss Molly.

lead_paragraph: “Many officials regard China’s growing wealth as fair game. And as a result, corruption has morphed into large-scale looting.”

lead_paragraph: An interactive comparison of two ways to draw teams for the World Cup.

headline: Justice Department Plans to Begin a Review of Music Licensing Rules
keywords: ['Music', 'Royalties', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Billions of dollars in royalties will be at stake as lobbyists for the two major music licensing clearinghouses and those of Silicon Valley rivals battling over the 73-year-old regulations.
lead_paragraph: The music industry has been complaining loudly in recent years about outdated federal regulation. Now it finally has a chance to do something about it.

headline: Losing Weight May Require Some Serious Fun
abstract: Volunteers who were told to exercise by walking a mile consumed more calories afterward than those who were told to have fun while completing the same workout, a provocative new study found.
lead_paragraph: If you are aiming to lose weight by revving up your exercise routine, it may be wise to think of your workouts not as exercise, but as playtime. An unconventional new study suggests that people’s attitudes toward physical activity can influence what they eat afterward and, ultimately, whether they drop pounds.

headline: Banned Books Week to Focus on Comics and Graphic Novels
abstract: Alison Bechdel’s “Fun Home” and Dav Pilkey’s “Captain Underpants” prompted challenges in the last year.
lead_paragraph: This year’s theme for Banned Books Week, the annual celebration of the freedom to read, will concentrate on graphic novels and comic books. The campaign runs from Sept. 21 to Sept. 27.

abstract: This word has appeared in 59 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: mite •\ˈmit\• noun

keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']

lead_paragraph: After a presidential election on Tuesday and continued diplomatic maneuvering, the United States’ approach in the three-year crisis.

headline: The World Cup Draw Is Unfair. Here’s a Better Way.
abstract: The U.S.’s tough group was just one of the hotly debated outcomes of the draw in December. Relying more on world rankings would lead to more balanced groups.
lead_paragraph: The controversy over December’s World Cup draw — in which France’s placement was hotly debated and United States fans were left bemoaning their fate — was symptomatic of the system’s fundamental flaws.

headline: Mets Lose Lead in 8th and Game in the 9th
abstract: The Cubs made it 1-1 in the eighth on a home run, and won the game an inning later on a two-out single.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As the night wore on, and the Mets and the Cubs entered the eighth inning of a one-run game, the fans at Wrigley Field waited quietly. They had no reason to cheer, but no reason to leave. The game was still somehow anyone’s to win, because the Mets were just as inexplicable as their Cubs. Both teams were talented enough to get runners on base, and inept enough to strand most of them there.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6:45 P.M. (Starz) WHITE HOUSE DOWN (2013) A police officer and former soldier (Channing Tatum) interviewing for a job with the Secret Service (he doesn’t get it) finds himself in the White House at the very moment it is overrun by a paramilitary group in this action-adventure directed by Roland Emmerich. Jamie Foxx (above right, with Mr. Tatum) plays the president, who needs saving — from the terrorists, and from big business — if only for his workable peace plan for the Middle East. And Maggie Gyllenhaal, James Woods, Richard Jenkins, Lance Reddick and Jason Clarke portray the administration’s team players. The film “is as demented and entertaining as promised, and a little less idiotic than feared,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Emmerich “makes the opening siege unsettling enough to grab your attention and then, once he has it, begins folding in lighter moments — one-liners, cartoonish bits of business, laughably impossible situations and stunts — that ensure that at least this American collapse doesn’t end up feeling too heavy.” He “gives it the pow,” she added, “while Mr. Tatum provides the pulse.”

headline: Special Parking Rules in New York
abstract: Because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday and Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday and Thursday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: In New Jersey, a Republican Nominee Will Try to Hold On to a Congressional Seat
abstract: A wealthy insurance executive beat a perennial conservative candidate in the Republican primary in New Jersey’s Third Congressional District on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A wealthy insurance executive beat a perennial conservative candidate in the Republican primary in New Jersey’s Third Congressional District Tuesday, a result that may frustrate Democrats hoping to take advantage of its closely divided politics.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on June 4, 2014.

headline: Yankees Still Searching for Runs and Victories
abstract: Mark Teixeira returned to the lineup and drove in two runs, but the rest of the team could not bunch together the hits it has been searching for, and New York lost to Oakland, 5-2.
lead_paragraph: During the first four games of the Yankees’ current homestand, Manager Joe Girardi often referred to the dearth of power hitters in his lineup as the team scored only eight runs and lost three times.

headline: Wave of Minors on Their Own Rush to Cross Southwest Border
abstract: A perception that the United States is treating children of migrants better than in past years is fueling much of the new migration.
lead_paragraph: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — After a decade apart, 13-year-old Robin Tulio was finally heading to the border to be with his mother. A maid, living illegally in Baltimore, she had decided the time was right to smuggle her son into the United States.

headline: Egypt: Sisi Wins With 97 Percent
abstract: Egypt’s elections commission on Tuesday formally declared the former defense chief, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the winner of last week’s pro forma presidential election with nearly 97 percent of the vote.
lead_paragraph: Egypt’s elections commission on Tuesday formally declared the former defense chief, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the winner of last week’s pro forma presidential election with nearly 97 percent of the vote. Turnout was about 47 percent of eligible voters, far short of what he had sought to prove he had a mandate to lead and less than the 52 percent who voted in the 2012 election won by Mohamed Morsi, whom Mr. Sisi overthrew last year. Foreign observers have said the election fell short of international standards.

headline: Yemen: Deadly Fighting Flares
abstract: The most recent flare-up in the long-running fight between the Yemeni Army and Shiite insurgents in the country’s north has killed hundreds of people in the past three weeks, local officials said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The most recent flare-up in the long-running fight between the Yemeni Army and Shiite insurgents in the country’s north has killed hundreds of people in the past three weeks, local officials said Tuesday. The clashes, in Amran Province, began when the rebels sought to claim new territory closer to the capital, said Ahmad al-Bakry, the province’s deputy governor. He said more than 500 people had been killed, including 100 rebels and 20 soldiers in the past two days. The toll could not be independently verified. On Monday, the government sent jets to bomb rebel areas after rebels came close to taking over a government checkpoint, Mr. Bakry said. A Houthi rebel leader, Ali al-Bikhiti, linked the violence to grievances over governmental neglect. “What is happening in Amran is a revolt against injustice,” Mr. Bikhiti said.

headline: Saudi Arabia: MERS Toll Revised
abstract: Saudi Arabia revised sharply upward the number of cases of the new MERS virus within its borders and said it had been fatal in more than 40 percent of the cases.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia revised sharply upward the number of cases of the new MERS virus within its borders and said it had been fatal in more than 40 percent of the cases. After a review of medical records, the country’s total number of cases of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome since the virus was isolated in 2012 is now 688, up from 575; the death toll is 282, not 190. The country has had a surge of cases since March — many apparently originating in hospitals — but they seem to be falling off, an adviser to the Health Ministry said. That surge led to the dismissal of the health minister, and on Monday, his replacement dismissed the deputy health minister who has been the public face of the country’s response. The deputy, Dr. Ziad Memish, was recently  profiled in The Lancet for his preparations for the annual visit to Mecca by up to three million Muslims. Most of the 133 new cases are from March and April, suggesting that many were either not tested or not reported.

headline: Where Bergdahl Disappeared
abstract: Maps of where Bowe Bergdahl was stationed and the initial operations to find him.
lead_paragraph: Maps of where Bowe Bergdahl was stationed and the initial operations to find him.

headline: Growth Has Been Good for Decades. So Why Hasn’t Poverty Declined?
abstract: Low-income workers are putting in more hours on the job than they did a generation ago — and the financial rewards for doing so haven’t increased.
lead_paragraph: The surest way to fight poverty is to achieve stronger economic growth. That, anyway, is a view embedded in the thinking of a lot of politicians and economists.

headline: Jury Announced for Guggenheim Helsinki Museum Design Competition
abstract: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation and Helsinki city officials are set to open an international design competition on Wednesday for a proposed new 130-million-euro museum along the South Harbor of the Finnish capital.
lead_paragraph: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation and Helsinki city officials announced details of an open international design competition on Wednesday for a proposed new 130-million-euro museum along the South Harbor of the Finnish capital.

headline: Democrats Shouldn’t Dream in Mississippi, Where a Runoff Looms
abstract: A win by Chris McDaniel in the Republican primary would give Democrats hope in a polarized state, but the road to victory already seems blocked.
lead_paragraph: After a night of surprising regional shifts in voter turnout Tuesday, neither Thad Cochran, an incumbent Republican senator in Mississippi, nor Chris McDaniel, a state senator backed by Tea Party groups, appeared to reach the 50 percent necessary to avoid a runoff in Mississippi’s Republican Senate primary.

headline: G.O.P. Nominee for Governor Faces an Uphill Climb in California
abstract: The former Treasury Department official Neel Kashkari beat a Tea Party favorite and will face Gov. Jerry Brown in the November election.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Neel Kashkari, the newly named Republican nominee for governor of California, has a big task ahead of him: start remaking a party that does not hold a single statewide office, wields almost no power in the State Legislature and has suffered a seemingly inexorable erosion of its share of the state’s registered voters, now at just over 28 percent.
