abstract: Can you calculate the the approximate vertical distance between the upper and lower mezzanine levels of a New York City subway station?
lead_paragraph: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: Dufry to Buy Duty-Free Rival for About $1.7 Billion
keywords: ['AIRPORTS', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The deal to acquire Nuance Group of Switzerland would create a retailer with shops in 239 airports on five continents. The combined company would have 15 percent of the global airport retail market.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Dufry, the operator of duty-free and other airport retail locations, said on Wednesday that it would pay 1.55 billion Swiss francs, or about $1.73 billion, to acquire its Swiss rival, Nuance Group.

headline: Obama, Seeking Unity on Russia, Meets Obstacles
abstract: President Obama, meeting with the leaders of the Group of 7 powers, faces challenges navigating the complicated waters of European politics.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — President Obama started his day in Warsaw struggling to convince his friends in Central and Eastern Europe that the United States is being tough enough with Russia. He ended his day in Brussels, still struggling, but this time to persuade America’s core Western allies to stay tough with Russia.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | New U.S. Effort to Aid Unaccompanied Child Migrants
abstract: Why has there been a recent surge in children attempting to enter the country illegally?
lead_paragraph: In “New U.S. Effort to Aid Unaccompanied Child Migrants,” Julia Preston writes about problems caused by the numbers of unaccompanied young people crossing the border.

headline: The Big Dig
abstract: Shucked or steamed, clams are easier to enjoy all summer long than you think.
lead_paragraph: Shucked or steamed, clams are easier to enjoy all summer long than you think.

headline: How Jurgen Klinsmann Plans to Make U.S. Soccer Better (and Less American)
abstract: The former German star hopes to keep expectations low for the coming World Cup. For now, Klinsmann will take the long view when it comes to soccer success for the United States.
lead_paragraph: Even before he exiled the most accomplished and iconic player in United States soccer history and before his presumptive top goal scorer went nearly an entire season without scoring goals and before he knew whom, exactly, his team was actually going to play, Jurgen Klinsmann was sure he was going to lose.

headline: Iran Offers a Window to the West
abstract: Given a chance – and a week – to visit Iran, John Moore took to the road in central Iran to see daily life in a place that has opened a bit to the West.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Getty Images asked the photographer John Moore if he wanted to see how open Iran’s new president was to Western news media. Mr. Moore, a senior staff photographer for Getty, was game. He had been there once — 10 years ago — to cover parliamentary elections. This time, Getty encouraged him to follow his own interests and itinerary. He decided on a road trip.

headline: When Do You Write by Hand?
abstract: Has it been your experience that you learn things differently or better when you write by hand? Why or why not?
lead_paragraph: Do you take notes in school, write letters, keep a pen-and-paper diary or do any other kind of regular writing by hand, or do you type almost everything?

headline: Border Guards in Ukraine Abandon Posts
abstract: Separatist fighters had besieged a border guard command center in Luhansk for two days. A nearby internal security base was also overrun.
lead_paragraph: CHERVONOPARTIZANSK, Ukraine — Border guards here, near the Russian border in eastern Ukraine, fled their posts for fear of attacks by separatist militias on Wednesday, helping open a strategic corridor for the transport of goods, contraband and war material from Russia that could lead to a widening of the conflict in eastern Ukraine.

headline: Analysis of President Obama’s Speech
abstract: Peter Baker, the chief White House correspondent for The New York Times, reports on President Obama’s speech in Warsaw.
lead_paragraph: Peter Baker, the chief White House correspondent for The New York Times, was in Warsaw with President Obama reporting on the president’s speech commemorating the 25th anniversary of elections in Poland that led to the end of Communist rule. You can read Mr. Baker’s article on nytimes.com and follow him on Twitter - @peterbakernyt.

headline: Through Miss India and Its Critics, Two Approaches to Women’s Empowerment
abstract: A documentary on beauty pageant contestants and the women who see the contests as an affront to Indian culture will have its theatrical release in India on Friday.
lead_paragraph: When Nisha Pahuja began filming the Miss India pageant in 2008, she envisioned the documentary as a portrait of India careening towards modernity through the lens of the pageant contestants.  But over time, Ms. Pahuja found herself drawn to another side of the story: India’s protest movement against these beauty contests, led largely by conservative religious groups here.

headline: Carlyle in Talks for Majority Stake in French Campsite Operator
abstract: The Carlyle Group is in exclusive talks to acquire Homair Vacances from its French private equity owners, Montefiore Investment and Naxicap Partners.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Homair Vacances, the French operator of campsites and holiday rentals, said on Wednesday that its controlling shareholder, Iliade, was in exclusive talks to sell a majority stake to the Carlyle Group.

headline: Militants Attack Pakistani Army, Killing 6 Soldiers and Setting Back Peace Talks
abstract: Suspected Islamist militants killed six soldiers and three civilians in separate attacks that offered the clearest indication yet that faltering peace talks with the Taliban had effectively collapsed.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Suspected Islamist militants attacked the Pakistani Army near a high-security military complex and along the Afghan border on Wednesday, killing six soldiers and three civilians in separate attacks that offered the clearest indication yet that faltering peace talks with the Taliban had effectively collapsed.

headline: Crowds Gather in Hong Kong for Anniversary of Tiananmen Crackdown
abstract: Tens of thousands turned out in Hong Kong, but in mainland China, a stifling security presence on the streets and online appeared to forestall any protests.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Tens of thousands gathered at a central park in Hong Kong on Wednesday to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown, even as a stifling security presence in Beijing and elsewhere in mainland China appeared to forestall protests.

headline: Sallie Krawcheck Opens an Index Fund Focused on Women
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Sallie Krawcheck’s organization, 85 Broads, is changing its name to Ellevate and will team up with Pax World Management to offer an index fund.
lead_paragraph: When Sallie L. Krawcheck, a former big bank executive, bought a women’s network last year, she said she wanted to “move from advocacy of women to the smart business of real investment in women.”

headline: Taliban Deftly Offer Message in Video of Freed U.S. Soldier
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Prisoners of War', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The video released Wednesday that showed the transfer of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl to American troops provided the Taliban an opportunity to publicize their argument that they are a legitimate state in exile.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban seem loose, almost offhand, on camera as they wait for the American Black Hawk to land. Two fighters walk their hostage, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, out to American troops, greeting their enemies eye to eye as they quickly shake hands. They wave as the Americans retreat back to the chopper.

headline: The Path to Workers, and Their Stories, in Abu Dhabi
keywords: ['Building (Construction)', 'Foreign Workers', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'News and News Media', 'Strikes']
abstract: Ariel Kaminer shares her experiences reporting on the harsh conditions workers faced during the construction of New York University’s Abu Dhabi campus.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Ariel Kaminer wrote about the harsh conditions that construction workers faced during the building of the New York University campus in Abu Dhabi. A reporter on the Metro desk, she usually measures her travel expenses in subway fares. Here she tells of the challenges and rewards of reporting a story that is far from her usual beat.

headline: TV Apps Are Soaring in Popularity, Report Says
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Television', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Are people more interested in taking their cable subscriptions with them than they are in cutting the cord? A new report suggests that TV apps, despite a slow start and a slow trickle of content, may be catching on after all.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to online video, people may not want to cut the cord. Instead, they want to take the cord with them. People are streaming broadcast television on their smartphones in record numbers, according to Adobe’s state-of-the-industry report on digital video viewing.

headline: Kristof Recalls a Bloody Day in Beijing
abstract: Nicholas Kristof wrote on the day of the crackdown in Tiananmen Square 25 years ago.
lead_paragraph: “To be an American on the square this morning was to be the object of fervent hope and inarticulate pleas for help,” Nicholas Kristof wrote on the day of the bloody crackdown in Tiananmen Square 25 years ago today. He and his wife, Sheryl WuDunn, won the Pulitzer Prize for their coverage of the democracy movement in China and its suppression. We asked Nicholas, now a Times Op-Ed columnist, to recall the events of that day. We include some of his articles from that tumultuous time.

headline: Why I’m Rethinking My Investment in E-Commerce
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Commerce', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Small Business']
abstract: I have come to understand that my company is not an e-commerce business; I am a retailer with a good website.
lead_paragraph: I have been selling furniture and accessories online for about six years. Two years ago, we realized that we needed to upgrade our website if we wanted to keep up, so we went out and hired a company to rebuild it from scratch. We went with a developer that works with the popular Magento platform, and the site came out very well. As a matter of fact, it won an award from one of the magazines that give out awards.

headline: Lithuania Moves Closer to Joining Euro Zone
abstract: Of the seven other European Union countries slated to join, none meet all the criteria for economic performance, budget discipline or central bank independence.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The looming deflation. The rising tide of anti-European populism. The near-record unemployment.

headline: Musée Picasso in Paris Names New President
abstract: Laurent Le Bon, who currently heads the Centre Pompidou-Metz, was named president, replacing Anne Baldassari, who was dismissed from the position last month.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – The French government has appointed a new president to the Musée Picasso, bringing what it hopes will be a close to a messy succession of missteps and public embarrassments at the museum, which has been closed for a delayed and over-budget expansion project for nearly five years.

headline: The Department Store Wars Are Heating Up
abstract: The good news is (theoretically anyway), this should work to the benefit of designers and consumers.
lead_paragraph: The war chests are growing in the department store world, in case you hadn’t noticed. Today Richard Baker, the owner of Hudson’s Bay Company, the Canadian department store chain that bought Saks Fifth Avenue last summer (and also owns Lord & Taylor) told WWD he planned to invest “$40 million” in the group’s digital activities this year — this on top of the $1 billion new-ish president Marigay McKee told me earlier has already been allotted to revamping the Saks chain over the next five years.

headline: Morning Agenda: BNP’s Secret Weapon Misfired
abstract: BNP Paribas pinned its hopes on a legal memo. | Regulators may restrict BNP’s dollar-clearing operations. | The notion of legal education is colliding with the profit motive in Charleston, S.C. | Goldman’s new chief strategy officer will continue to expand the bank’s businesses.
lead_paragraph: BNP Paribas, under investigation for doing business with Sudan and other countries that the United States has blacklisted, is weeks away from having its parent company plead guilty to the crime. But several months ago, BNP thought it had a secret weapon to avoid that fate altogether, DealBook’s Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess write. BNP showed prosecutors a memo that the bank thought would explain and possibly mitigate its conduct.

headline: A Tupac for Everyone

Mr. Kreidler was assisting Wilson as he brought his play “King Hedley II” to Broadway, but really he was there to learn whatever Wilson wanted to teach him. And that morning, the subject was Tupac Shakur.

headline: Tony Award Predictions: Leading Actress in a Play

Or do you think LaTanya Richardson Jackson will prevail in the race for best actress in a play, for her star turn as Lena Younger in “A Raisin in the Sun”? And where does the intense competition in this category leave Cherry Jones, who delivered a much-discussed portrayal of Amanda in “The Glass Menagerie”?

headline: Desire in High Gear
abstract: Penelope Skinner’s play “The Village Bike,” with Greta Gerwig, is making its American debut in an MCC Theater production.
lead_paragraph: Here is your Urban Dictionary lesson of the week: A “village bicycle” is slang for a local slut — everyone in town has ridden the bike, you see. The term has a double meaning, though, in Penelope Skinner’s play “The Village Bike,” making its American debut in an MCC Theater production. In the play, Becky (Greta Gerwig) is pregnant and hormonal and her sex drive is healthier than ever, but her husband seems to have completely lost interest in sex. Adventures ensue when she turns to pornography and then buys a used bike (an actual one) from a man known for his promiscuity.

headline: East Northport, L.I.: Good Schools, Good Neighbors
abstract: A hamlet in the Town of Huntington that shares the same highly rated school district of its more expensive neighbor to the north, but with lower taxes.
lead_paragraph: When Erin Chavez, a college history teacher, and her husband, Daniel, a special-education teacher, moved to East Northport with their two young children two years ago, they had chosen their house mainly for its low price, convenient location and good school system. They got warm and friendly neighbors in the bargain.

headline: Venice Mayor Is Arrested on Corruption Charges
abstract: Mayor Giorgio Orsoni is accused of misusing public funds from a multibillion dollar project to build underwater barriers to protect the city from flooding.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The Italian authorities on Wednesday arrested the mayor of Venice and more than 30 others in a political corruption case linked to the city’s multibillion dollar flood-protection project. The arrests came only weeks after investigators revealed an embarrassing corruption scandal involving projects for next year’s Milan Expo.

headline: The Fight Against Fake Drugs
abstract: An ingenious cellphone verification system is just one of the methods being used to combat deadly counterfeit medications in Africa.
lead_paragraph: In November 2008, children in Nigeria taking a medicine called My Pikin Baby Teething Mixture began to die. The syrup was counterfeit, the standard glycerin replaced with cheaper diethylene glycol, which looks, smells and tastes the same. But diethylene glycol is an industrial solvent, which attacks the central nervous system, kidneys and liver. The medicine killed 84 children before it was pulled from pharmacy shelves.

headline: Feeling For | Modern Basics Dyed With Ancient Medicinal Plants
abstract: The sustainable clothing line Baserange debuts a capsule collection of blue pieces naturally colored with woad on Net-a-Porter today.
lead_paragraph: Blandine de Verdelhan and Marie-Louise Mogensen, the France- and Denmark-based designers of Baserange, have made it their mission to produce minimal, functional clothing and underpinnings as sustainably as possible. The duo’s latest offering, debuting exclusively on Net-a-Porter today, is a capsule collection that highlights what de Verdelhan calls “a key part of the environmental footprint of making garments”: dye. The six-piece assortment gets its striking shade from woad, a medicinal plant in the broccoli family that the designers discovered in a workshop in a village near Toulouse, France. The ancient species was a key component of southern France’s economy during the Medieval and Renaissance eras; royalty and high society, including Napoleon, favored it for its distinctive blue hue. It’s also known for the anti-inflammatory and healing properties it provides when applied to the skin, and is unusual in the way that it continues to “live” as a garment ages. “The color grows stronger as you wash the material, and, if left in the closet, it will become irregular,” explains Verdelhan. “It’s such a beautiful, particular blue, and is quite important in Toulouse. There, all the shutters are painted in this color. It’s quite lovely.”

headline: Dozens of Gang Suspects Held in Raids in Manhattan
abstract: In all, 40 people were arrested on charges of conspiracy, assault and weapons offenses in connection with violence in and around two housing projects.
lead_paragraph: Police officers in body armor swooped into two Manhattan housing projects at dawn on Wednesday in simultaneous raids aimed at scores of suspected gang members indicted on charges of planning and carrying out tit-for-tat gun battles stretching back to the 2011 murder of an 18-year-old basketball star.

headline: Channing, Abraham and Mullally to Join ‘It’s Only a Play’ on Broadway
abstract: Stockard Channing, F. Murray Abraham and Megan Mullally will join Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick in a revised version of Terrence McNally’s 1980s comedy.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Award winner Stockard Channing, the Oscar winner F. Murray Abraham and the Emmy winner Megan Mullally will join Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick on Broadway in a newly revised version of Terrence McNally’s 1980s comedy “It’s Only a Play,” the producers said on Wednesday. The show centers on an anxious playwright (Mr. Broderick); his best friend (Mr. Lane), who has left theater for television; the producer (Ms. Mullally) and a diva star (Ms. Channing) of the playwright’s new show; and a hypocritical drama critic (Mr. Abraham). The ensemble will also include Micah Stock as a coat check attendant; casting for the roles of the play’s director and a taxi driver will be announced later. The production, which reunites Mr. Lane and Mr. Broderick years after their starring roles in Broadway’s “The Producers” and the 2005 revival of “The Odd Couple,” will begin performances in late summer at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater and open on Oct. 9. Jack O’Brien will direct.

headline: Decent Draw and Rising Hopes for California Chrome

lead_paragraph: There has always been a sense of destiny surrounding California Chrome — his owners called him their Kentucky Derby horse as soon as he hit the ground. They were right, and after the colt won the Preakness Stakes, too, the air of inevitably has only thickened.

headline: The New Face of ‘Networking’

This, he said, would happen even though such coverage benefits from a big tax break.

headline: Iran’s Leader Says Obama Has Removed Military Option

headline: Exclamation Points for the Ear
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The return of chandelier earrings; shorts suited for the workplace and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: The way the jewelry designer Lisa Salzer of Lulu Frost sees it, the return of chandelier earrings can be credited to the Céline fall runway, where they dangled solo in every single look. “Elongated, sculptural single earrings really signal a move away from delicate and dainty styles,” Ms. Salzer said. “My take is to do one long style with a simple stud on the opposite ear.” The designer Lizzie Fortunato is similarly inclined, citing the oversize earrings in Marni’s spring collection. “I’m a fan of merging the ‘statement’ and ‘delicate’ trends,” she said. These summer-friendly styles can ease you into the trend. They’ll look glamorous worn together, but for an added dose of cool, pair one with a bitty stud — lest you look as if you have lost one earring.

headline: On Tiananmen Anniversary, China’s Military Touts Its Strength
abstract: As thousands elsewhere mark the 25th anniversary of the killings at Tiananmen Square, the the People’s Liberation Army Daily, the Chinese military newspaper, published an editorial calling for a stronger, more robust military posture.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times reported this week that there was discord throughout the People’s Liberation Army — even up to the ranks of the general staff — during the protests of 1989. Officers and soldiers argued over how to handle the demonstrations and what orders to obey. After soldiers carried out the massacre of civilians on June 3 and 4, 1989, killing hundreds, possibly thousands, of people, top military officers sought reassurances from Communist Party leaders that the army would never be deployed again for internal unrest.

headline: In Valeant’s Bid for Allergan, an Opaque Business Model Is Revealed
abstract: Nobody really knows if Valeant Pharmaceuticals is doing anything that makes money, or is just engaged in prestidigitation that never gets anywhere, writes Jesse Eisinger in The Trade.
lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, financial engineering masquerades as vision. When it works, you get to be called the Oracle of somewhere or other. If it works for only a short period, you can still get rich. What a country.

headline: A Curriculum to Strengthen Students Against Cyberbullying
abstract: Students at the Facing History School in New York City try to understand the circumstances and decisions surrounding larger social injustices and then relate that back to their own experience.
lead_paragraph: The Facing History School in New York City takes a unique approach to cyberbullying, based in part on its partnership with Facing History and Ourselves, a professional development organization that integrates the concepts of identity, community, responsibility, decision-making and participation into all aspects of its curriculum. By looking at case studies about social injustices, students try to understand the circumstances and decisions surrounding these events and then relate that back to their own experience and communities.

headline: How Not to Pay the Price for Free Wi-Fi
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Wireless Communications', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Jumping on a network at a coffee shop or park could put your privacy at risk. Here are some ways to stay (reasonably) safe.
lead_paragraph: Part of globe-trotting nowadays is flitting from one free Wi-Fi network to the next. From hotel lobby to coffee shop to subway platform to park, each time we join a public network we put our personal information and privacy at risk. Yet few travelers are concerned enough to turn down free Wi-Fi. Rather, many of us hastily give away an email address in exchange for 15 minutes of free airport Internet access.

headline: Daniel Nardicio: Closing a Gay Generation Gap
abstract: The gay night-life producer mixes 20-something go-go dancers with vintage Broadway legends for a good-naturedly tawdry summertime romp.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon in his Chelsea office, the gay night-life producer Daniel Nardicio turned to a lithe go-go boy wannabe named Lorenzo Ashkenazi, 23, and handed him a colorful jockstrap from the label C-IN2.

headline: Finding Inspiration for a Civil Rights Museum
abstract: David Rockwell talks about how travel played a role in designing exhibition spaces for a civil rights center that opens to the public in Atlanta later this month.
lead_paragraph: The National Center for Civil and Human Rights in Atlanta, which opens to the public on June 23, is one of several new museums in the South dedicated to civil rights.

headline: Nicholas Kristof on Tiananmen Square
abstract: Nicholas Kristof remembers the unlikely heroes of the protests 25 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Kristof remembers the unlikely heroes of the protests 25 years ago.

headline: Tiananmen Square, the Turning Point That Wasn’t: A Q. & A. With Nicholas Kristof
abstract: The Op-Ed columnist looks back on the site of pro-democracy protests in China 25 years ago, and on his own career.
lead_paragraph: Natalie Kitroeff, an editorial assistant, asked Nicholas Kristof to look back at  his reporting from Tiananmen Square, the site of pro-democracy protests in China 25 years ago, to reflect on what he might do differently now and how much has changed, or not changed, in China and in his own  world view.

headline: Bergdahl’s Fellow Soldier Speaks Out
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Prisoners of War']
abstract: In an interview with The Associated Press, Gerald Sutton, a former Army specialist who served with Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in Afghanistan, said Sergeant Bergdahl was a deserter.
lead_paragraph: In an interview with The Associated Press, Gerald Sutton, a former Army specialist who served with Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in Afghanistan, said Sergeant Bergdahl was a deserter.

headline: Data Readings Converge to Show an Economy Regaining Momentum
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Productivity', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Before the Labor Department releases its jobs report for May on Friday, there are already signs that the economy is moving in a better direction.
lead_paragraph: For months, the weather has dominated discourse about the economy. Analysts attributed the dearth of shoppers, the weak employment numbers and the overall decline in economic activity to the cold and snow in the eastern half of the nation, the freakish storms in the South and Midwest, and the drought in the West.

headline: An Unusual van Gogh Work at a German Museum – His Ear
abstract: A replica of Vincent van Gogh’s left ear is on display at a museum in Germany.
lead_paragraph: A model of Vincent van Gogh’s left ear — you know, the ear — is on display at a German museum, with plans to eventually bring it to New York.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Suitcase Entrepreneur
abstract: Facebook’s small-business boot camp. Things to consider before hiring your first employee. And is the rebirth of American manufacturing a myth?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Boehner Calls for More Action on V.A. Scandal
keywords: ['Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Law and Legislation', 'Hospitals']
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner called on President Obama to support legislation offered by House Republicans for changes in the Department of Veterans Affairs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner on Wednesday demanded that President Obama do more to fix what Mr. Boehner called “the abject failure” of the Department of Veterans Affairs to meet the needs of the country’s soldiers returning from battles abroad.

headline: Year-End Roundup, 2013-14 | Math, Science, Health and Technology
abstract: All the Science, Math, Health and Technology lessons we published this year — with links back to our 2010, 2011, 2012 and 2013 collections.
lead_paragraph: One of many short videos in The Times’s Science Take series.

headline: Image of the Day: June 4
abstract: The soccer World Cup tournament will begin in Sao Paulo in Brazil on June 12.

headline: The Anatomy of a Political Direct-Mail Solicitation
abstract: Most solicitations from political parties are much more upfront about the ultimate destination of the money given.
lead_paragraph: The envelope is emblazoned with “Dick Morris” and “Stop Hillary Now” and features a picture of Hillary Clinton with the title “Yes, she’s running.” There is little to suggest that it, or the fund-raising solicitation inside, comes from the Republican Party, let alone the Republican Party in the Virgin Islands.

headline: Watches Win NATO Support
abstract: The band, known as a NATO, is a trend not without controversy.
lead_paragraph: James Bond gets all the glory, but Pussy Galore wore it best. There she stands, in a still from the imperishable “Goldfinger,” atop the wing of a light plane, wearing a taut sleeveless satin waistcoat and snug black pants, her Icy Hot profile framed by a honeyed mane that was the actress Honor Blackman’s glory.

headline: T Toasts Gucci’s Charity with Beyoncé
abstract: A host of big names turned out to toast the Chime for Change initiative to assist women and girls worldwide — and to catch a glimpse of T’s new issue and cover star.
lead_paragraph: WhoFrida Giannini, the creative director of Gucci, and Deborah Needleman, the editor in chief of T, hosted a sharply dressed crowd to fete the first anniversary of Gucci’s Chime for Change charity initiative. James Franco and Blake Lively, two faces of the brand, were in attendance, as were the writers Malcolm Gladwell and Marianne Pearl and the Russian street-style stars Miroslava Duma and Anya Ziourova. Attendees craned their necks and hoisted their smartphones to catch a glimpse of Solange Knowles, who was the D.J. for a portion of the festivities, and the evening’s guest of honor, none other than T’s new cover star, Beyoncé.

headline: Vernon Davis Breaks His Silence Over Fantex I.P.O.
abstract: The San Francisco 49ers tight end said in an interview on Wednesday that the I.P.O. was about more than money. Instead, he said, it’s about helping him build his brand.
lead_paragraph: Vernon Davis, a tight end for the San Francisco 49ers, has enough on his mind already, starting with scoring touchdowns and avoiding injuries.

headline: Are Young People Sheltering in School?
abstract: The bad economy of the past several years has forced more people to skip college or drop out than to stay in longer.
lead_paragraph: The notion that young people can seek and find shelter from a bad economy by staying in school is a myth. The more nuanced reality is that young people can shelter in school — if they can afford it. Most cannot.

headline: After Bribery Scandal, High-Level Departures at Walmart
keywords: ['Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: At least eight senior executives have left the giant retailer since reports of bribery in its international division surfaced two years ago.
lead_paragraph: Thomas A. Mars, formerly the chief administrative officer for Walmart in the United States, stepped down. José Luis Rodríguezmacedo Rivera, once the general counsel at Walmart’s Mexican division, quietly left the company. And H. Lee Scott Jr., who was Walmart’s chief executive, will retire from the board this month.

headline: Hillshire Must Decide Whether to Be Target or Suitor
abstract: Hillshire Brands is facing two competing takeover bids, but its biggest decision may be whether to stick with its own acquisition strategy and remain independent, Steven M. Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: Everyone is asking how Hillshire Brands can get out of its acquisition of Pinnacle Foods in light of two competing bids for Hillshire for more than $6 billion. Instead, perhaps the question should be whether Hillshire even wants to exit the Pinnacle deal, and if so, what is the price it would have to pay Pinnacle for such relief.

headline: Janelle Monáe on Daily Devotionals, Electric Bicycles and Afro-Futurism
abstract: The pop star with the bouffant hairdo and the sci-fi look, who performs a concert tonight in Brooklyn, offers a thoughtful set of creative inspirations.
lead_paragraph: Janelle Monáe is both a major pop star and a bona fide style icon. With her signature bouffant hairdo and mildly androgynous tailored suits in sharp monochrome patterns, she is simultaneously retro and futuristic, a strikingly recognizable (and vaguely alien) figure in the cultural landscape. Originally from Kansas City, Kan., Monáe first gained recognition for her 2007 concept EP “Metropolis: Suite 1 (The Chase)” (loosely inspired by the Fritz Lang film “Metropolis”) and burst into pop stardom in 2010 with “The ArchAndroid,” then followed that up with last year’s “The Electric Lady.” Mixing references with abandon, her music channels the otherworldliness of the funk icons Curtis Mayfield, Parliament and Earth, Wind and Fire and the icy cool of Grace Jones, David Bowie and Prince, while incorporating her contemporary collaborators Big Boi (of Outkast) and Erykah Badu. Yet her influences reveal a warmth and depth beneath her stylized public persona. She shared them in advance of a concert for Celebrate Brooklyn tonight.

headline: The Rangers’ Adventures in the Stanley Cup Finals
abstract: The cartoonist Bob Eckstein takes readers through each of the Rangers’ 10 trips to the Stanley Cup finals, beginning in 1928.
lead_paragraph: The cartoonist Bob Eckstein takes readers through each of the Rangers’ 10 trips to the Stanley Cup finals, beginning in 1928.

headline: Wheelies: The Loose Lug Nuts Edition
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)', 'Organized Labor', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Nissan recalls 334 crossovers for improperly tightened lug nuts. The company also announces pricing for the 2015 Altima.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Cosmos Up Next for Red Bulls in U.S. Open Cup
abstract: The Red Bulls of M.L.S. and the Cosmos of the N.A.S.L. will play each other for the first time, in a fourth-round match of the U.S. Open Cup on June 14.
lead_paragraph: The Red Bulls were idle last weekend in Major League Soccer and the club’s coaches and players thought Sunday’s match at New England would be its last one until the end of June.

headline: The Great Experiment
abstract: TIMOTHY EGAN checks in from Seattle on that city’s recent move to raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour.
lead_paragraph: What if: you gave the poorest workers a raise of 61 percent? Not now, but phased in, starting next spring, over seven years. It would kill the economy, yes? Or maybe it would give so many people at the bottom so much more money that they could buy more stuff and eat out and get beyond the social safety net, raising everybody’s standard of living.

headline: Happenings | Love and Marriage on the Roof of the Wythe Hotel
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Marriages', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Williamsburg stronghold is installing an artistic pop-up church on its sixth floor terrace, where L.G.B.T. couples can come to tie the knot throughout New York’s upcoming Pride Week.
lead_paragraph: Church, like home, is where you find it. During New York’s Pride Week at the end of this month, gay couples looking to get married will find a church in the unlikeliest of places: on the rooftop of the Wythe Hotel in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Andrew Tarlow, one of the hotel’s founders, came up with the idea of putting a pop-up wedding chapel on the sixth-floor terrace as a tribute to the members of the L.G.B.T. community who live in the neighborhood, especially those who had worked with him for many years at his nearby restaurant Diner.

headline: Start the Presses
abstract: A historian traces the desire for information that led eventually to newspapers.
lead_paragraph: It’s a fundamental human impulse to want to know more than you can hear over the back fence. Curiosity about people, places and events that matter but cannot be seen from where you stand has civic, commercial and prurient origins. In his new book, Andrew Pettegree argues that this need to know led to the establishment of postal routes, private back channels and, eventually, newspapers.

headline: New York vs. L.A. in Stanley Cup
abstract: An intense final pits New York against Los Angeles for the first time in hockey as the Rangers and Kings face off in the championship. Three story lines to follow.
lead_paragraph: An intense final pits New York against Los Angeles for the first time in hockey as the Rangers and Kings face off in the championship. Three story lines to follow.

headline: Tiananmen Vigils in Hong Kong and Taiwan
abstract: Outside mainland China, tens of thousands of people gathered to mark the bloody crackdown on pro-democracy protesters 25 years ago in Beijing’s Tiananmen Square.
lead_paragraph: Outside mainland China, tens of thousands of people gathered to mark the bloody crackdown on pro-democracy protesters 25 years ago in Beijing’s Tiananmen Square.

headline: Sara Lee’s Breakup Is Starting to Pay Off
abstract: Add the latest bid in the war for Hillshire Brands to the 2013 sale of a coffee unit and a special dividend, and shareholders may finally make good, says Kevin Allison of Reuters. Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Voracious buyers are finding the meat on Sara Lee’s bones. The old consumer conglomerate broke itself up into the meat-focused Hillshire Brands and the coffee roaster D.E Master Blenders 1753 in 2012 after spurning takeover offers worth about $12 billion, according to news reports at the time. It looked like a raw deal — until now.

headline: No Longer Updating
abstract: This blog is no longer being updated. Please go to nytimes.com/video/the-new-york-times-minute/ for the latest episodes of the Times Minute.
lead_paragraph: This blog is no longer being updated. Please go to nytimes.com/video/the-new-york-times-minute/ for the latest episodes of the Times Minute.

headline: In Elections Across the World, Democracy Is a Matter of Definition
keywords: ['Elections', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Presidential votes in Egypt and Syria have represented a triumph of process and imagery over democracy’s supposed essence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — These have been heady days for those who like to ponder whether there is such a thing as a one-size-fits-all election, whether democracy, in other words, is indivisible.

headline: The Triple Crown Winners, Fit to Print
keywords: ['Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Horse Racing', 'Belmont Stakes', 'Kentucky Derby', 'Preakness Stakes']
abstract: Twelve horses have won the Triple Crown, with American Pharoah’s victory in 2015 the most recent. A look back at how The New York Times covered these rare triumphs.
lead_paragraph: Twelve horses have won the Triple Crown, with American Pharoah’s victory in 2015 the most recent. A look back at how The New York Times covered these rare triumphs.

headline: Appeals Court Ruling in S.E.C. Case Will Curb Judicial Power Over Settlements
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The decision gives the regulator much discretion to settle cases in ways it sees fit while curtailing the power of judges to “search for the truth,” Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: In the tug of war between a few federal district judges and regulators, score one for the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Two Players on the Rise, but Only One Will Make It to the Final
abstract: Simona Halep, who beat Svetlana Kuznetsova, and Andrea Petkovic, who beat Sara Errani, will meet Thursday, with the winner reaching her first Grand Slam final.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When Simona Halep and Andrea Petkovic played in last year’s final of a tournament in Nuremberg, Germany, Halep was ranked 58th and Petkovic 103rd.

headline: Breakdown: Death at the Track
abstract: A 2012 investigation by The New York Times revealed a pervasive culture of drugs and lax regulation in the U.S. horse racing industry.
lead_paragraph: A 2012 investigation by The New York Times revealed a pervasive culture of drugs and lax regulation in the U.S. horse racing industry.

headline: BNP Paribas Faces Capital Hit, but Not a Dire One
abstract: The multibillion-dollar penalties expected to be imposed on BNP Paribas by the United States authorities will not deliver a crushing blow to the bank’s capital, but investors and analysts are still unsettled.
lead_paragraph: As the United States authorities prepare to punish BNP Paribas, the doubts about the French bank’s financial strength are growing.

headline: Via Tablet or Smartphone, Learning With MOOCs
abstract: Thousands of Massive Open Online Courses, covering everything from astrophysics to the arts, are available online.
lead_paragraph: MASSIVE Open Online Courses — or MOOCs — are a snowballing revolution in education.

headline: In Amsterdam, a New Food Tour
abstract: The Jordaan Food Tour in Amsterdam includes tastings, history lessons, and, to conclude, a canal ride.
lead_paragraph: Visit a snoepwinkel (candy shop) to taste several varieties of Dutch liquorice, sample smoked sausages at a slagerij (butcher shop), and eat herring “the Amsterdam way” (served with chopped onions, a pickle and a Dutch flag on a toothpick that doubles as your fork) during the just-launched Jordaan Food Tour from Eating Amsterdam Tours.

headline: Columbia Names Editor and Publisher for Global Reports Series
abstract: Columbia Global Reports will be devoted to book-length reporting projects.
lead_paragraph: Columbia Global Reports, a new Columbia University publication devoted to book-length reporting projects, now has an editor and publisher.

headline: The Rangers’ Adventures in the Stanley Cup Finals
abstract: The cartoonist Bob Eckstein takes readers through each of the Rangers’ 10 trips to the Stanley Cup finals, beginning in 1928.
lead_paragraph: When the Rangers meet the Los Angeles Kings in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals on Wednesday night it will mark the 11th time in the club’s long, and often unsuccessful, history that it has made it to the championship round.

headline: When a Family Gets Away, Its Problems Make the Trip
abstract: In “The Vacationers,” infidelity and other issues mar a family’s vacation in Mallorca, Spain.
lead_paragraph: Emma Straub’s bustling new novel is about a New York family’s two-week idyll in a house on the Spanish island of Mallorca. It’s also about a different kind of break: infidelity. The book is full of couples, and all of them have to cope with some kind of cheating during the course of the story. Even its youngest, most petulant character, a sharp-eyed teenager named Sylvia Post, has been betrayed by her high school boyfriend and rewarded with an Adonis of a Spanish tutor as compensation.

headline: In His Words | The Art of Inscrutability
abstract: On the cusp of a big James Lee Byars show, the artist Anish Kapoor remembers the lamentably unsung American sculptor.
lead_paragraph: On the cusp of a big James Lee Byars show, the artist Anish Kapoor remembers the lamentably unsung American sculptor.

headline: The Gun Report: June 4, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Throughout its 25 years, “The Simpsons” has been revered for its biting social commentary, pointing out the foibles of American society with laser-like accuracy. It’s had its political moments too, taking on gay marriage, immigration, the environment, elections, drug addiction — and, in November 1997, guns.

headline: Coldplay Holds at No. 1
abstract: Coldplay’s latest album, “Ghost Stories,” kept the top spot, holding off the country singer Brantley Gilbert and Mariah Carey’s new album.
lead_paragraph: Coldplay holds the No. 1 spot on Billboard’s album charts for a second time, in a week of poor music sales.

headline: With a Flair for the Dramatic, Doughty Fuels the Stoic Kings
abstract: Despite winning two Olympic gold medals and a Stanley Cup, the demonstrative and outspoken Drew Doughty is not always recognized as one of the N.H.L.’s best defensemen.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Not many players with two Olympic gold medals and a Stanley Cup title are overlooked or misunderstood. But such has been the plight of the Los Angeles Kings’ Drew Doughty.

headline: Eimear McBride, a Debut Novelist, Wins Baileys Fiction Prize
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The Irish author Eimear McBride won the prize, which honors English-language writing by women, for her novel “A Girl Is a Half-Formed Thing.”
lead_paragraph: The Irish author Eimear McBride has won the Baileys Women’s Prize for Fiction for her debut novel, “A Girl Is a Half-Formed Thing.”

headline: Clip: ‘Borgman’
abstract: A scene from the film directed by Alex van Warmerdam.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film directed by Alex van Warmerdam.

headline: Street Style in El Raval, Barcelona
abstract: Deh André, who has lived in Barcelona for six years, has one style rule: always wear colors.
lead_paragraph: El Raval in Barcelona is a district with a worn-in feel, from the secondhand shops to Sant Pau del Camp, one of the city’s oldest churches. Deh André, shown, was recently in El Raval, in a secondhand outfit from head to toe (except Nike hightops bought new). Mr. André, a Brazilian, has lived in Barcelona six years and has one style rule: always wear colors. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Concrete Shoes Are So Last Season
abstract: The Dutch director Alex van Warmerdam wanted to create a surreal and violent film with “Borgman.”
lead_paragraph: The term “sleep with the fishes” is given a surreal visual interpretation in the dark, haunting drama “Borgman.”

headline: Europe Gets Negative Interest Rates. What Does That Even Mean?
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Interest Rates', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Normally the bank pays you to keep your money there. When rates turn negative, you pay the bank.
lead_paragraph: First there was ZIRP. Now get ready for NIRP.

headline: Magical Forest, Comic Mishaps
abstract: Maria Kowroski and Joaquin De Luz of New York City Ballet danced the lead roles in Balanchine’s version of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: George Balanchine’s “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” which New York City Ballet opened on Tuesday at the David H. Koch Theater, is two dances in one. The first half sweeps through Shakespeare’s comic play: Titania fights with Oberon over her page. Butterflies and fairies, many of them adorable children, swirl across the stage. The mischievous Puck wreaks havoc with two pairs of lovers and transforms poor Bottom into a donkey.

headline: An Icon They Clicked On
abstract: Emotions ran high at the 2014 CFDA fashion awards.
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, the fashion world gathered to congratulate itself.

headline: Letting a Mighty Nave Breathe, in Full View of a Neighborhood
abstract: As backhoes make way for two 15-story apartment towers that would block views of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, a critic proposes a solution.
lead_paragraph: Workers are digging the foundation for a twin-towered apartment building that will obscure the great flying buttresses and stained-glass windows of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Morningside Heights.

headline: Zara, Where Insiders Look for an Edge
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)']
abstract: Zara, in remaking itself as a fashion front-runner, is a magnet to tastemakers.
lead_paragraph: When they’re not tending clients or updating inventory at the Albright Fashion Library, a supplier of fresh-from-the-runway looks to stylists, socialites and film companies, Lindsay Carr and Yael Quint like to poke around the Internet for credible approximations of their favorite high-end labels. Their jobs afford them plenty of chances to beg, borrow or buy at a discount any number of lust-worthy items from the likes of Balenciaga, Givenchy or Céline. But on a recent spring morning, Ms. Carr was turned out top to toe in Zara.

headline: Donna Karan: Milestones
abstract: A look at Ms. Karan’s life and career as she steps down as chief designer of Donna Karan International.
lead_paragraph: A look at Ms. Karan’s life and career as she steps down as chief designer of Donna Karan International.

headline: Seek and Ye Shall Find a Hottie
abstract: In “It Takes a Church,” worshipers help one of their own winnow down a list of Christian suitors drawn from the congregation.
lead_paragraph: What good Christian doesn’t love that sublimely spiritual moment on Sunday when the priest or minister says, “And now, let us pray — but first let’s see if we can fix Angela up on a date”?

headline: An Elusive Hand at the Goldman Pairs
abstract: The Goldman Pairs has been contested annually in New York City since 1929, making it the world’s longest-running bridge tournament.
lead_paragraph: The Goldman Pairs has been contested annually in New York City since 1929, making it the world’s longest-running bridge tournament. The winners of the 86th event, held on May 24 and 25, were George Krizel of Feasterville-Trevose, Pa., and Albert Shekhter of New York City. They finished 1.12 match points ahead of Arch McKellar of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and Greg McKellar of Kingston, Ontario. Third were Michael Polowan of New York City and Richard Schwartz of Lords Valley, Pa.

headline: Recollections of Warriors, Redeployed Into Dance
abstract: “Healing Wars,” a new piece by the choreographer Liz Lerman, weaves veterans’ stories from the Civil War and contemporary conflicts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During naval service in the Middle East, Paul Hurley lost a leg. Now he’s joined a dance company.

headline: In a First, Test of DNA Finds Root of Illness
abstract: Researchers report sequencing DNA to identify an elusive pathogen within 48 hours, but experts say it will be years before the method is in widespread use.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Osborn, 14, lay in a coma at American Family Children’s Hospital in Madison, Wis. For weeks his brain had been swelling with fluid, and a battery of tests had failed to reveal the cause.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Single Dose of Antibiotic Found Effective in Quelling MRSA
abstract: A study says that one infusion of oritavancin worked as well as the 10-day regimen now used to treat serious bacterial skin infections.
lead_paragraph: A single infusion of an antibiotic can clear serious bacterial skin infections — including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, or MRSA — just as effectively as the 10-day regimen now used to treat patients, researchers reported Wednesday.

headline: Ex-Convict Arrested in Stabbing of Brooklyn Children
abstract: News of the arrest came less than an hour after police officials publicly identified the suspect, Daniel St. Hubert, in the stabbing of two children, one fatally, in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A man with an extensive criminal record who was released from prison less than two weeks ago was arrested Wednesday night in connection with the stabbing death of a 6-year-old Brooklyn boy, hours after investigators used forensic evidence to identify a suspect, the authorities said.

headline: Germany Begins Inquiry of U.S. in Surveillance Case
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: After pressure from members of Parliament, Germany’s federal prosecutor announced a formal investigation into the tapping of Chancellor Angela Merkel’s cellphone.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s federal prosecutor announced Wednesday that he had begun a formal investigation of what he called “unknown” members of American intelligence agencies on suspicion that they had eavesdropped on one of Chancellor Angela Merkel’s cellphones.

headline: Who Says a Woman Needs a Boyfriend for a Great Shirt?
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Ties (Apparel)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The men’s designer Alexander Olch started with ties. Now he is leaping the gender gap.
lead_paragraph: The demography of Orchard Street circa Canal Street is changing rapidly, but it’s still home to as many Chinese-owned restaurant-supply stores as boutique tie-makers, which may explain the Asian woman peering quizzically through the window of Alexander Olch’s five-month-old shop one recent afternoon.

headline: Two Paths to the Great Outdoors
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Leather and Leather Goods', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: These two new outposts of Pacific Northwest good will capture different but related aspects of their region.
lead_paragraph: Right by the front door of the new Will Leather Goods store in NoLIta are a few bowls full of candies. Reach in. Grab a few. I took some Bit-O-Honeys. They were chewy, a little oily, and lasted long, designed for a stroll.

headline: Donna Karan Exudes Calm in the Chaos
abstract: Her company may not be the powerhouse it once was, but the designer says she has no plans to move aside.
lead_paragraph: When the fashion designer Donna Karan debuted her most recent collection in February, it was a high-voltage affair: a specially commissioned film by Steven Sebring playing in the background as models strutted on stage in negligee-like outfits paired with square-shouldered jackets and tall boots. In the audience, a smattering of boldface names: Katie Holmes, Trudie Styler and Rita Ora, all sheathed head to toe in Donna Karan.

headline: Joni Ernst Fights for Dirty Water in Iowa
abstract: The winner of the Iowa Senate Republican primary opposes the Clean Water Act.
lead_paragraph: Joni Ernst, the winner of the Iowa Senate Republican primary on Tuesday, has a briefcase full of the usual shopworn, hard-right policies: no same-sex marriage, no reform of immigration, no federal minimum wage, no Education Department, no progressive tax code. She still clings to the idea of private accounts for Social Security.

headline: The Fall of Narcissism
abstract: Is narcissism really an incurable plague sweeping America? Maybe not, writes ANNA NORTH.
lead_paragraph: If there’s any psychological diagnosis that has captivated our national imagination over the last five years or so, it’s narcissism — an alleged epidemic that’s supposed to be turning America’s youth into loud-mouthed, hyperentitled, participation-trophy-demanding monsters. But some are starting to question whether it’s really the scourge it’s cracked up to be.

headline: Works by New Talents, Taken to a Power of One
abstract: Musicians from the New York Philharmonic stretched out with a program of solo pieces at SubCulture, as part of the NY Phil Biennial.
lead_paragraph: Part of the pleasure of the inaugural NY Phil Biennial, an 11-day exploration of new work that ends Saturday, has been getting to know the Philharmonic’s players better. Take Sumire Kudo.

headline: A Gas Cache, Now Under Shaky Ground
abstract: The Groningen field in the Netherlands has provided energy for decades, but a series of earthquakes have damaged property and rattled residents.
lead_paragraph: LOPPERSUM, the Netherlands — Deep below the cow pastures and farming villages in this picturesque northeastern corner of the Netherlands lies an extraordinary resource: Europe’s largest source of natural gas, known as the Groningen gas field.

headline: Pharrell Williams at the Apollo Theater
abstract: Mr. Williams performed Tuesday night at the storied Harlem theater.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Williams performed Tuesday night at the storied Harlem theater.

headline: Justices Reject Call to Halt Gay Marriages in Oregon
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The request that the decision be stayed came from the National Organization for Marriage, which opposes the unions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected a request to halt same-sex marriages in Oregon. The court’s one-line order gave no reasons for declining to issue a stay.

headline: Melodrama, Feats of Aerial Daring, and Mom
abstract: The suspense of Daphne du Maurier, the mystique of the circus and the smothering bosom of a meddlesome family, all at the Spoleto Festival USA in Charleston, S.C.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Live theater is one of the few places where creaking can be a pleasant sound. It can come from a door temporarily concealing a bad guy, or it can come from a play content to traffic in plot twists that wouldn’t have shocked your great-grandmother.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Dresses', 'Lingerie and Underwear']
abstract: Chloé reopens its Madison Avenue flagship, the La Perla sample sale and the annual Todd Snyder summer sale.
lead_paragraph: Openings

headline: Behind an N.B.A. Finals Rematch
abstract: A three-peat for LeBron James and the Miami Heat or a shot at redemption for Tim Duncan and the San Antonio Spurs? The sports columnist Harvey Araton on the finals encore.
lead_paragraph: A three-peat for LeBron James and the Miami Heat or a shot at redemption for Tim Duncan and the San Antonio Spurs? The sports columnist Harvey Araton on the finals encore.

headline: Many Answers, Still More Questions
abstract: Ronald K. Brown’s company, Evidence, brings its hybrid of African and modern-dance moves to the Joyce.
lead_paragraph: It can be tempting to say — and some critics have — that Ronald K. Brown creates the same piece over and over. There are undoubtedly common elements, both structural and thematic, running through his work: a fluent, hybrid language of African-based and modern dance; a preference for patchwork musical playlists; an allegiance to the realm of the spiritual. Each of his dances, in one way or another, is an expression of praise.

headline: Young Composers Catch the Philharmonic’s Ear
abstract: Six young composers survive a competition to have their works played by the New York Philharmonic; three get public performances.
lead_paragraph: It was a bit like a reality television show called “The Composer,” or “Philharmonic Idol,” or perhaps just “Survivor.” After more than 400 composers ranging in age from 9 to 84 had submitted their scores, six finalists were chosen to come to Avery Fisher Hall to hear the New York Philharmonic play their pieces.

headline: N.R.A. Backs Away From Article Criticizing Advocates of Carrying Guns in Public
abstract: The group sought to distance itself from an article on its website that called brandishing weapons in public in support of open-carry laws “scary” and “weird.”
lead_paragraph: The National Rifle Association is distancing itself from an article on its website that called demonstrations by gun rights advocates who brandished weapons in public “scary” and “weird,” and that said such advocates had “crossed the line from enthusiasm to downright foolishness.”

headline: Encircling Rome, On and Off the Road
abstract: Gianfranco Rosi’s documentary “Sacro GRA,” the surprise winner last year of the Venice Film Festival’s top prize, is part of the Open Roads: New Italian Cinema festival at the Film Society of Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: When Gianfranco Rosi arrived at the Venice Film Festival in September with his fourth feature-length film, the documentary “Sacro GRA,” he was happy just to be there. It was the first year that Venice, the world’s oldest film festival, had admitted documentaries, and prizes were the furthest thing from his mind.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: Food news from Iowa to Ivory Coast.
lead_paragraph: The parent company of Carl’s Jr. and Hardee’s said the minimum wage in California is so high ($9) that it’s harder to come up with profitable business models. Guess they won’t be expanding into Seattle, where the minimum wage is set to rise to $15. No loss.

headline: A Tea Party Edge in Mississippi
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Political Advertising']

lead_paragraph: Jonathan Martin on the race in Mississippi as G.O.P. Senate candidates prepare for a runoff.

headline: A Satellite Show at the Venice Architecture Biennale, Hosted Through (and Inspired by) Airbnb
abstract: A pop-up exhibition during this year’s biennial is being held not in a palazzo but in an Airbnb-rented flat — which also provided thematic fodder for the works on view.
lead_paragraph: Much of this year’s Rem Koolhaas-curated Architecture Biennale in Venice, which opens this weekend, explores the 20th century. But the Airbnb Pavilion, a satellite three-day pop-up exhibition opening tonight and organized by Fabrizio Ballabio, Alessandro Bava, Luis Ortega Govela and Octave Perrault, a group of students and recent graduates of the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London, investigates a distinctly 21st-century phenomenon: the way people loan out their apartments in the newfangled “sharing economy.”

keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Children and Childhood', 'Condoms', 'Parenting', 'Population', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Sex', 'Sex Education']
abstract: A first ever sex education class at an elite Beijing elementary school produced some drama. But the real challenge may be the convincing the parents, not the children, who enjoyed it after getting over their initial shock.
lead_paragraph: China’s 1.35 billion people have to come from somewhere, so it’s a fair guess that Chinese people have had a lot of sex.

keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Cable Television', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Wireless Communications']

lead_paragraph: Independent music groups, angry with YouTube’s demands over licensing terms, have asked government regulators in Europe and the United States to intervene on their behalf.

abstract: Every day this week we’ll publish a crib sheet on the blog as a primer for watching the World Cup like a pro. Today, this year’s best telenovela fodder.
lead_paragraph: Being a soccer fan in the United States requires more knowledge than it used to. In honor of a special World Cup issue of the magazine on June 8, the 6th Floor blog will publish a series of crib sheets to help readers watch the World Cup like a true fanatic — or at least a European.

abstract: Ms. Logan and a producer had been placed on leave after a discredited report about the attacks on the American compound in Benghazi, Libya.
lead_paragraph: Lara Logan has quietly returned to work at “60 Minutes,” CBS News confirmed on Wednesday.

headline: India’s Feudal Rapists
abstract: You can’t understand sexual violence in India without understanding caste.
lead_paragraph: WHEN a distressed father is reporting his daughter’s disappearance to a policeman in India, there are some questions he doesn’t want to hear. “What is your caste?” is one of them. Yet, the father, Sohan Lal, said this was the first thing the police asked him last Tuesday, when he begged them for help. After revealing his low-caste background as a Shakya, Mr. Lal said the officers mocked him and refused to lift a finger.

headline: Sales at John Derian, Judy Ross Textiles and Sferra
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Textiles', 'Beds and Bedding', 'Pillows']
abstract: Discounts on tabletop items, pillows and more.
lead_paragraph: During John Derian’s annual sale, some decoupage is up to 60 percent off, and select tabletop items, bedding and decorative accessories are up to 50 percent off, through Saturday (John Derian decoupage dome paperweights, originally $60, are $25; John Derian six-inch-square Vide Poche plates, originally $70, are $28); 8 East Second Street (Bowery), 212-677-3917, johnderian.com.

headline: And There Was Light
abstract: When a Dutch couple looked around for a new home, a church was not their first choice. But then they counted the blessings.
lead_paragraph: When Ronald Olthof and his partner, Sofie Suiker, decided to buy a home, their first instinct was to find an old building they could renovate. An abandoned industrial space, maybe.

headline: Coaxing a History from Board and Beam
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: An engineer with a detective’s eye ferrets out the story of his midcentury cottage in Maine.
lead_paragraph: ARROWSIC, Me. — The flourish that most delights Henry Petroski about his handmade house here is the way its builder “eased” the edges of the boards that form the cabinets, lintels, doors and door bracings. These subtle details were among the clues that set Mr. Petroski on a quest to learn about the man who employed them.

headline: Mortars and Pestles: Developing a Crush
abstract: The right pulverizing tools make a difference in the taste and texture of your ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Using a mortar and pestle “isn’t always that practical,” said Marc Meyer, the executive chef and co-owner of Cookshop and several other restaurants in Manhattan. Even so, he said: “I insist on it for certain things, like garlic. I like the way garlic comes out when it is completely smashed: It becomes a purée and seems to dissolve into whatever you’re making.”

headline: Decorator Underground
keywords: ['Photography', 'Basements and Cellars', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A new book illuminates the dwellings of building superintendents.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan building superintendents are rarely asked about how they decorate their subterranean apartments, combining tenants’ castoffs and souvenirs of faraway homelands against backdrops of rusty pipes and industrial gray walls. When the photographer Gesche Würfel set out to interview the workers for a book, “Basement Sanctuaries” (Grey Matters/Schilt Publishing, $20), “They were very happy about the recognition, that somebody was interested in their life,” she said. In her images, houseplants and pet birds survive on little sunlight, and paintings and photos of tropical waterfronts and Paris landmarks are hung alongside trash cans, exercise equipment and laundry machines. The supers told her that the spaces can be tricky to protect. “Every time I maintain it, people steal my paintings from me,” one said. But another super has managed to attract tourists to his well-appointed home. “It brings them to tears to see the basement,” he said. Information: 31-20-528-69-12, schiltpublishing.com.

headline: Not Really an Ocean Apart
abstract: Roche Bobois has added a new designer to its stable. And — sacré bleu! — it is an American.
lead_paragraph: It has been 40 years since the French furniture company Roche Bobois planted a flag in the United States, but only recently did it invite an American to design for its collection. On Thursday, the company is introducing two chairs by Stephen Burks, a New Yorker, that riff on consumer tastes in different parts of the world. Called Traveler, the chairs come in a European version with a canopied tubular metal structure and leather upholstery ($11,800 with canopy) and an American version in wood and fabric ($11,800). Mr. Burks said the first chair expresses a “micro-architectural moment” and celebrates craft, whereas the second signals deep, satisfying comfort: “It’s like a giant pillow,” he said. But don’t take these ideas too literally, he added. “There is so much diversity within cultures, it would be a gross exaggeration to say, ‘I’ve summed up Europe in a chair, or summed up America.’ ” Available in September. Information: roche-bobois.com.

headline: Tea for Two and Visible to All
abstract: This week, the artist Hiroshi Sugimoto unveils a glass teahouse in Venice.
lead_paragraph: Hiroshi Sugimoto is a celebrated chronicler of the monotonous, the frozen and the familiar. He has photographed seascapes, modernist buildings and wax figures of famous people. But the 66-year-old Tokyo artist, who maintains a second studio in Chelsea, where he sat down with a reporter last month, also has a deep feeling for the ritualized performances of his homeland. He has produced and directed his own versions of the traditional Japanese puppet theater called bunraku, and the building he designed for his multidisciplinary Odawara Art Foundation in Japan will have a noh theater stage perched 100 meters above the sea when it opens in 2016.

headline: Raphael Fruhbeck de Burgos, Citing Illness, Withdraws from Conducting
abstract: Spanish conductor Raphael Fruhbeck de Burgos announces retirement from conducting
lead_paragraph: Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos, the veteran Spanish conductor, has cancer and is giving up conducting immediately on the advice of his doctors, the Boston Symphony Orchestra said on Wednesday.

headline: Taking One Room at a Time
abstract: An accessories collection starts with the dining room and promises to move steadily through the house.
lead_paragraph: Department of Decoration made its debut last month at a dinner party at the High Line Hotel. Tables were set with powder-coated flatware and serving trays, smooth slab ceramic plates and printed table linens, all created by the husband-and-wife team of Brian Kaspr and Payton Cosell Turner, who already make wallpaper under the name Flat Vernacular.

headline: Design Treasures Once Destined for Archives Now Can Be Yours
abstract: The new Christopher W. Mount Gallery in Los Angeles specializes in artifacts like models and design drawings.
lead_paragraph: “In architecture,” Christopher W. Mount said, “people always think of the final product.” A longtime museum curator, Mr. Mount is hoping to interest design fans and collectors in the means to that end: The Christopher W. Mount Gallery in Los Angeles, which has opened inside the Pacific Design Center, will offer maquettes, design drawings, photographs and other artifacts by prominent figures related to architecture and design.

headline: When the Landline Is a Lifeline
keywords: ['Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Internet Telephony', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The new Internet-based phones still have some major flaws.
lead_paragraph: AT&T and Verizon are pushing hard to shift traditional landline service, which has mostly operated over copper lines, to a system of Internet-based phones by around 2020. If the Federal Communications Commission approves the switch as is, it could come as a shock to the 96 million Americans who still rely on landlines.

headline: Cooperstown on the Field, Behind the Scenes
abstract: A Tauck trip to Cooperstown, N.Y., will include an after-hours tour of the Baseball Hall of Fame, a pick-up game at Doubleday Field, and good seats for a Paul Simon concert.
lead_paragraph: In Cooperstown, N.Y., while the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum is waving pennants in honor of its 75th anniversary, Tauck will offer virtual behind-home-plate access to sports celebrities and special events in a four-day trip.The Tauck Baseball Event, July 31 to Aug. 3, offers guests third- and fourth-row seating at a 75th anniversary concert featuring Paul Simon as headliner. An after-hours tour and talk at the Baseball Hall of Fame includes a keynote address and question and answer session with the “Baseball” documentary filmmaker Ken Burns, who designed the trip with Tauck.

headline: Missing Japan, Balanced in Brazil
abstract: Among the first generation of Japanese laborers who immigrated to Brazil more than a century ago, Haruo Ohara photographed a world where man sought harmony with tradition and nature.
lead_paragraph: Among the first generation of Japanese laborers who immigrated to Brazil more than a century ago, Haruo Ohara photographed a world where man sought harmony with tradition and nature.

abstract: When the setting’s flamboyant and the view is free, you socialize first and (maybe) pay later.

headline: Dr. Pharmacist
