lead_paragraph: After Asiya Khatu smashed her finger in a door, she was treated by a pharmacist, not a doctor. (This is a clip from a forthcoming short documentary from Nicholas Kristof and Adam B. Ellick.)

headline: The Ambiguities of the Bergdahl Case
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Readers respond to news articles and an Op-Ed essay about the return of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl.

headline: Libya: Swiss Red Cross Worker Is Killed
abstract: Gunmen in the central Libyan city of Surt fatally shot a Swiss man working for the Red Cross on Wednesday, the humanitarian group said in a statement.
lead_paragraph: Gunmen in the central Libyan city of Surt fatally shot a Swiss man working for the Red Cross on Wednesday, the organization said in a statement. The man, Michael Greub, 42, was leaving a meeting with colleagues when their vehicle came under attack, it said. No possible motives were disclosed, but foreign workers and diplomats have come under increasing threat from armed groups that have operated with impunity in Libya since its revolt in 2011. The killing came amid intensifying violence in the eastern city of Benghazi, where a self-proclaimed army leader, Gen. Khalifa Hifter declared war on Islamist militias almost three weeks ago. He was lightly wounded Wednesday when a suicide bomber drove an explosives-laden truck into a base where the general was staying east of Benghazi. Four of his guards died in the attack, according to one of the general’s aides.

headline: Canada: Prostitution Bill Targets Clients
abstract: The government of Canada introduced legislation on Wednesday that would criminalize buying sexual services but would not, in many situations, make selling them illegal.
lead_paragraph: The government of Canada introduced legislation on Wednesday that would criminalize buying sexual services but would not, in many situations, make selling them illegal. The bill follows a Canadian Supreme Court ruling in December that overturned most laws governing the sex trade on the basis that they violated prostitutes’ constitutional right to security. While Justice Minister Peter MacKay said the bill aimed to focus on pimps and the customers of prostitutes, he added that prostitutes who offered their services in public areas where children might be present would, in most cases, be fined. The bill would also make advertising sexual services a crime. Some lawyers for prostitutes argued that the measure did not address the court’s concern about prostitutes’ safety.

headline: Assad’s Soft-Focus Vision for Syria, as Seen on YouTube
abstract: The Syrian president’s opponents mocked his campaign slogan, “Together,” featured in a series of upbeat advertisements posted on his YouTube channel.
lead_paragraph: As unexpected as it might have seemed three summers ago, when hundreds of thousands of Syrians jammed the streets demanding that President Bashar al-Assad just “leave,” his landslide re-election, confirmed shortly after polls closed on Wednesday, surprised no one. Given that his supporters, in regions of the deeply divided nation now under government control, openly boasted of voting early and often, and that his opponents largely ignored the contest, the huge margin of victory was entirely believable.

headline: Collecting Wood for Pennies
abstract: With no jobs available, Anwa Begum dives for driftwood to sell as firewood.
lead_paragraph: With no jobs available, Anwa Begum dives for driftwood to sell as firewood.

headline: Netflix Points at Verizon for Delays in Streaming
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Net Neutrality']
abstract: Netflix said its message was one of many ways it is testing to notify customers about how their viewing experience is affected by their Internet service provider’s network.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Being partners with Netflix does not mean that Netflix is on your side.

headline: The T.M.I. Pregnancy
abstract: The endless stream of prenatal data has changed a joyous experience into something ominous.
lead_paragraph: Becoming a mother was so simple when I became a mother. Pregnancy was treated as a natural experience. You peed in a cup, and then once a month the obstetrician pressed his stethoscope against your belly and you watched his face for a smile.

headline: Sterling Agrees to Sale of Clippers, and to Drop Lawsuit
keywords: ['Basketball', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Donald Sterling made an agreement with the N.B.A. to “resolve all their differences” and gave his consent to a deal negotiated by his wife to sell the team that they co-own, Sterling’s lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: Donald Sterling, the Los Angeles Clippers’ owner who was barred for life by the N.B.A. for racist comments, decided Wednesday to consent to the $2 billion sale of the team engineered by his estranged wife, Rochelle, his lawyer said.

headline: With 2014 World Cup, Soccer Ascends to Role as Premier Ad Platform
abstract: American advertisers are jumping on the World Cup bandwagon, attracted both by changing demographics and by the nature of event programming, where viewers are less likely to skip commercials.
lead_paragraph: THERE is a saying that Brazil is the country of the future, and always will be, and the jest has been reworked to proclaim soccer as the American sport of the future that will also never fulfill its potential.

headline: China Financier Defends Companies’ Deals
abstract: Xiao Jianhua said the company he co-founded was helping the family of China’s president dispose of assets when the company bought a stake that the family held in an investment firm.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — A billionaire Chinese financier, responding to an article in The New York Times about deals that his companies made with the relatives of some of China’s senior leaders, said Wednesday that a company he co-founded was helping the family of China’s president, Xi Jinping, dispose of some of its assets last year when the company bought a stake that the family held in a state-backed investment firm.

headline: G.M. Report on Recalls Is Expected Thursday
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Liability for Products', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The report will recommend changes and provide details about the company’s reaction after discovering faulty auto ignition switches and its failure to seek immediate recalls.
lead_paragraph: General Motors on Thursday will release the results of its three-month internal investigation into the events leading up to this year’s recall of 2.6 million small cars with defective ignition switches.

headline: Scholars’ Bid to Criticize Israel’s Actions Is Rejected
abstract: Most members of the Modern Language Association declined to vote on a measure asking the State Department to pressure Israel not to erect obstacles to Americans’ teaching at Palestinian universities.
lead_paragraph: A resolution critical of Israel failed to win approval from a leading scholarly group, the Modern Language Association, the group said on Wednesday, after an overwhelming majority of its members declined to vote.

headline: At Belmont Park, Savoring the Other Sides of the Track
keywords: ['Belmont Stakes', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Horse Racing']
abstract: Regulars at Belmont Park bemoan the frenzied throngs that are expected to turn out on Saturday for California Chrome’s bid for the Triple Crown, preferring the racetrack’s slower pace.
lead_paragraph: The stalwarts of Belmont Park shuffled toward the front benches some 50 minutes before post time, a procession of walking canes and tinted sunglasses, plastic bags treated as briefcases and jeans pulled high enough to make belly buttons disappear.

headline: A Bonus California Chrome Can’t Win
keywords: ['California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Horse Racing', 'Belmont Stakes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: From 1997 to 2005, Visa USA offered a $5 million reward to any horse that could claim racing’s Triple Crown. But none did.
lead_paragraph: The six horses who could have won the Triple Crown from 1997 to 2005 must not have heard Visa USA executives whisper to them: Win the Belmont Stakes, and we will send a $5 million bonus to your Cayman Islands account. For most athletes, that would have been motivation enough. But these horses run for glory and carrots, not cash. They heed their jockeys, not sponsors.

headline: A Proud Career That Seemed to Curdle
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Politics and Government', 'Elections, District Attorneys', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Charles J. Hynes, the former Brooklyn district attorney, started out with populist promise, defending the poorest and establishing humane prison programs. But his political sensitivities gradually enslaved him.
lead_paragraph: Many moons ago, in the early 1980s, tenant organizers traveled to Downtown Brooklyn to hear the new fire commissioner talk of a plague of arson that had turned so many apartment buildings in so many neighborhoods into bonfires.

headline: Puerto Rico Debates Who Put Out the Lights in Mosquito Bay
keywords: ['Marine Biology', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Environment']
abstract: The bay is normally lit up by microscopic plankton — an important tourist attraction — but in January it abruptly lost its glow, alarming scientists.
lead_paragraph: VIEQUES, P.R. — Sitting on a small boat in Mosquito Bay, a tapestry of stars above him, Mark Martin, a field researcher, scooped water into a canister. He studied the liquid for some sign of why, suddenly and inexplicably, one of the world’s most famous bioluminescent bays had dimmed.

headline: Can the Minimum Wage Be Too High?
abstract: On Monday Seattle raised its minimum wage to $15 an hour. But can the city afford it? Will it lead to job losses, as some predict, or be a model for national reform?

headline: In Race for Rangel’s Seat, Top Rivals Promise Job Growth in Struggling Areas
abstract: Representative Charles B. Rangel and State Senator Adriano Espaillat courted voters in the Bronx and Harlem with promises of job growth.
lead_paragraph: With less than three weeks to go until the Democratic primary for Representative Charles B. Rangel’s seat in Congress, he and his top rival, State Senator Adriano Espaillat, courted voters on Wednesday by promising to bring sorely needed jobs to the struggling Harlem and Bronx neighborhoods that make up much of their district.

headline: Spurs and Heat Are Starting Where the What-Ifs Left Off
abstract: If not for a confluence of improbable events last year, the Spurs would not be on a mission for atonement, and the Heat would not be chasing a third consecutive title.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Now that the Miami Heat and the San Antonio Spurs have arrived here, ready to reprise their riveting seven-game N.B.A. final of a year ago, among the many questions worth considering is one that is perhaps the simplest.

headline: British Bank Regulators Pine to Win a Big Case
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)']
abstract: Stung by missteps and losses, the Serious Fraud Office, which prosecutes and investigates corruption and fraud, is struggling to improve its track record.
lead_paragraph: When Credit Suisse agreed on May 19 to plead guilty and pay $2.6 billion for conspiring to help Americans avoid taxes, it was yet another day of dreary headlines for bankers around the world.

headline: Inquiry Urged on Site Called Mass Grave of Irish Babies
abstract: The burials of up to 796 babies are believed to have taken place from 1925 to 1961 on the site of a home for unwed mothers run by a Roman Catholic religious order.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The government and the police are coming under increasing pressure to open an investigation into allegations that a Roman Catholic religious order secretly buried up to 796 babies and toddlers born to unmarried mothers in a septic tank over several decades.

headline: Let’s Give Mississippi Less
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, Senate', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: Guess who had the most dramatic election of this primary season? And it’s not over!
lead_paragraph: When was the last time the nation turned its attention to Mississippi?

headline: Clarifying, and Tightening, Patent Law
abstract: Two recent Supreme Court decisions should reduce abusive and frivolous patent litigation, which has increased sharply in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Two recent unanimous Supreme Court decisions should reduce abusive and frivolous patent litigation by raising the standards by which judges decide such cases. The number of cases has increased sharply in recent years.

headline: For Rivals, a Rare Aligning of Form and Draw
abstract: Rafael Nadal and Andy Murray found higher gears to close out their opponents, setting up the first match between the two at a Grand Slam event in nearly three years.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In an age of great rivalries in men’s tennis, Rafael Nadal versus Andy Murray has been the one that keeps getting away.

headline: Children on the Run
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Children and Childhood', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Editorials']
abstract: The rising influx of young unauthorized immigrants crossing the border with or without parents has become a humanitarian crisis.
lead_paragraph: Along the southern border, particularly in Texas, a rising influx of young unauthorized migrants crossing the border with their parents — or, more alarmingly, alone — has overwhelmed the Border Patrol and sent the federal government scurrying for a coordinated response. Its first action was the right one: the creation of a top-level task force including the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the Department of Health and Human Services to care for the unaccompanied children.

headline: Bettman Addresses N.H.L. Players’ Efforts to Hide Concussions
abstract: Commissioner Gary Bettman said Wednesday that the N.H.L.’s concussion protocol was working, and that the league was serious about enforcing it.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Commissioner Gary Bettman said Wednesday that the N.H.L.’s concussion protocol was working, and that the league was serious about enforcing it.

headline: Mary Soames, Daughter of Churchill and Chronicler of History, Dies at 91
abstract: After wartime service in uniform and as an aide to her father, Lady Soames became an acclaimed writer of books about her family.
lead_paragraph: Mary Soames, the last surviving child of Winston Churchill, lived a storybook life and chronicled it in her own well-received books. After her family announced her death at 91 on May 31 in London, Prime Minister David Cameron called her “an eyewitness to some of the most important moments in our recent history.”

headline: Standing Up to Mr. Putin
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: President Vladimir Putin of Russia needs to know that continued moves to destabilize Ukraine or aggressively extend Russia’s reach will not go unanswered.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s decision to commit $1 billion to bolster security in Central and Eastern Europe sends important messages to both NATO allies and President Vladimir Putin of Russia. The crisis over Russia’s annexation of Crimea has calmed down a bit, and some Europeans, like France, seem eager to put it behind them. But Mr. Putin has shown he cannot be trusted. The alliance needs to be honest with itself and take full account of his ruthless unpredictability as it plans security arrangements for the future.

headline: Democrats See a Break in a Gain for the Tea Party in Mississippi
abstract: The strong showing of the sometimes-unpredictable Tea Party favorite, Chris McDaniel, in the Republican primary offered Democrats the opportunity to highlight his controversial views.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is a major headache for the national Republican Party and perhaps the biggest break Democrats have been handed in this difficult election year: a three-week runoff campaign in Mississippi between a party elder, Senator Thad Cochran, and the sometimes unpredictable Tea Party favorite, Chris McDaniel.

headline: Recalibrated Finalists Renew Their Rivalry
abstract: After a seven-game showdown in last season’s N.B.A. finals, the Heat and the Spurs left their cores intact, but they have continued adapting on the way to a rematch.
lead_paragraph: For the second straight year, the Miami Heat and the San Antonio Spurs will meet in the N.B.A. finals, and it will again be easy to cast them as polar opposites: the old-school Spurs with their homegrown crop of stars — Tim Duncan, Tony Parker and Manu Ginobili were all drafted by San Antonio — against the modern mercenaries from Miami, including the transplants LeBron James and Chris Bosh.

headline: There’s a Kind of Hush
keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Myanmar government has doubled down on its repression of Muslims and some scholars think it approaches genocide.
lead_paragraph: SITTWE, Myanmar — Few people have fought as courageously for human rights as Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Prize-winning democracy advocate who stood up to the generals here in Myanmar.

headline: Don Zimmer, Who Lived Baseball for 66 Years, Dies at 83
abstract: As player, coach and manager, Zimmer was variously associated with the Brooklyn Dodgers, the Mets, the Red Sox and the Yankees. He was even married on a baseball diamond.
lead_paragraph: Don Zimmer, the stubby, Popeye-muscled baseball lifer with the unforgettable jowls whose passion for the game endured through 66 years as a player, manager, coach and adviser, died on Wednesday in Dunedin, Fla. He was 83.

headline: Ex-Rangers Coach Hailed for His Role in a Success Story
abstract: Tom Renney, who replaced Glen Sather behind the Rangers’ bench in 2004, aided the development of four key players: Henrik Lundqvist, Dan Girardi, Marc Staal and Dominic Moore.
lead_paragraph: Glen Sather, the Rangers’ general manager, clearly made the right call last June when he hired Alain Vigneault to replace John Tortorella behind the bench. Sather made an equally wise decision a decade ago when he tabbed Tom Renney to resurrect the franchise.

headline: To Lure Bostonians, New ‘Pop-Up’ Bus Service Learns Riders’ Rhythms
abstract: The service is the brainchild of a 23-year-old entrepreneur and has routes dictated by millions of bits of data that show where people are and where they need to go.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — Katie Pasciucco, 34, an account manager at a software company, is a typical Boston commuter. Her door-to-door trip to work is just 4.5 miles but takes at least 50 maddening minutes.

headline: Criticism Over Troop Withdrawal Emerges From Beyond G.O.P.
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Former military officers and civilian officials who defended the administration’s strategy in Afghanistan worry efforts to train and advise Afghan security forces will be curtailed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Criticism of President Obama’s announcement that American forces would leave Afghanistan by the end of 2016 has begun to come not just from his Republican adversaries, but also from another quarter: former military officers and civilian officials who worked for years to develop and defend his administration’s strategy in Afghanistan.

headline: Word of the Year
abstract: A tribute to an important novel, by Ed Sessa.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — The book that Ed Sessa commemorates in today’s puzzle was a game changer for me.

headline: A Data-Driven Commute
abstract: The “pop-up” bus service Bridj made its debut in Boston, hoping to offer a quicker alternative for commuters by using algorithms to adapt its routes.
lead_paragraph: The “pop-up” bus service Bridj made its debut in Boston, hoping to offer a quicker alternative for commuters by using algorithms to adapt its routes.

headline: Just Mill About, You Know, as Any Crowd Would Do
abstract: “Arrivals & Departures,” part of a trio of Alan Ayckbourn plays running in rep as part of Brits Off Broadway, is a comedy that delves into counterterrorism.
lead_paragraph: The orders are as impossible as they are imperious: “Do try and merge.”

headline: A Belmont Who Fought for Racing and for Soldiers
abstract: More than 100 years ago, August Belmont Jr. battled an antigambling law that shut down horse racing. He eventually won out by stressing the value of horse.
lead_paragraph: Horse racing fans are eagerly awaiting Saturday’s Belmont Stakes, the race that will decide whether California Chrome will join racing royalty like Seattle Slew, Secretariat and Omaha as a Triple Crown winner. But a little more than a hundred years ago, racing was threatened, and the Jockey Club president, August Belmont Jr., decided to save it.

headline: Yuri Kochiyama, Rights Activist Who Befriended Malcolm X, Dies at 93
abstract: Mrs. Kochiyama, a Harlem activist who was interned with other Japanese-Americans in World War II, cradled a dying Malcolm X after he was shot.
lead_paragraph: Yuri Kochiyama, a civil rights activist who formed an unlikely friendship with Malcolm X when he was still promoting black nationalism and later cradled his head in her hands as he lay dying from gunshot wounds in 1965, died on Sunday in Berkeley, Calif. She was 93.

headline: Maxine Greene, 96, Dies; Education Theorist Saw Arts as Essential
abstract: A public intellectual and author, Dr. Greene was also a kind of Pied Piper at Teachers College, Columbia University, where she taught for a half century.
lead_paragraph: Maxine Greene, a teacher and education theorist who promoted the arts as a fundamental learning tool and in nearly 50 years at Teachers College, Columbia University, became its resident Pied Piper, known for her persuasive scholarship, her vivid writing and her imbuing teaching with a spirit of endless adventure, died on May 29 at her home in Manhattan. She was 96.

headline: Karlheinz Böhm, Actor-Turned-Humanitarian, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Böhm was typecast as heartthrob counts and princes until he starred in “Peeping Tom,” a controversial horror film. He later started an Ethiopian charity.
lead_paragraph: Karlheinz Böhm, an Austrian actor turned humanitarian whose early reputation rested on numerous portrayals of princely heartthrobs and one role as a serial killer who films the agonies of his female victims, died on May 29 in Grödig, Austria, near Salzburg. He was 86.

headline: Mets Are Benefiting From Competition at Shortstop
abstract: Called up by the Mets in May, Wilmer Flores appears to be challenging Ruben Tejada at shortstop the way the team had hoped.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When the Mets called up Wilmer Flores last month, Manager Terry Collins challenged Ruben Tejada to be better. While Tejada had made little progress at shortstop, he had not been pushed by anyone trying to take his job. But now that Flores felt more comfortable at shortstop, he would be Tejada’s competition.

headline: French Open Ball Kids Carry Gear and a Tune
abstract: The tournament’s 250 young workers have a challenging morning ritual that includes a workout and singing.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Spectators arriving early at Roland Garros encounter an unusual sight each morning: more than 200 children singing and chanting as they run down a wide walkway that leads past the empty stadium of Philippe Chatrier Court.

headline: Special Parking Rules in New York
abstract: Because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 4, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: June 4, 2014

headline: Behind P.O.W.’s Release: Urgency and Opportunity
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Prisoners of War', 'Detainees', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: An Obama administration divided over a prisoner swap that would free five Taliban commanders swept those issues aside in the rush to secure Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Weeks before a Black Hawk helicopter lifted off in the dying light of eastern Afghanistan, carrying with it an American soldier who had spent five years in the hands of the Taliban, American officials grew increasingly worried that Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s life might be in jeopardy.

headline: Jets’ Breno Giacomini Walks the Line on Offense
abstract: The new right tackle plays with an aggressiveness that sometimes leads an official to reach for a penalty flag.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Sitting at his locker Wednesday afternoon, Breno Giacomini traced an imaginary line on the inside of his stall. He then placed his index finger on top of that line.

headline: Higher Minimum Wage Gains Support
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said he would support raising the state minimum wage — currently $8 per hour — and he might also support an even greater wage for high cost-of-living areas like New York City.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s about-face on raising the minimum wage in New York has increased hopes among the city’s lowest-paid workers that their pay will soon rise sharply.

headline: In Bribery Trial, Lawyer Says Queens State Senator Was Entrapped
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Elections, Mayors']
abstract: Malcolm A. Smith is accused of trying to influence county leaders with tens of thousands of dollars in cash to certify him as a Republican in the 2013 mayoral race.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. — It was Valentine’s Day 2013 at Sparks Steak House in Midtown Manhattan, and gifts were exchanged.

headline: Senators Show Frustration After Briefing on Ex-P.O.W.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Prisoners of War', 'Detainees']
abstract: Senior officials showed lawmakers a video of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl from January that raised alarms about his health and spurred action, but the meeting failed to quell anger on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — White House officials failed Wednesday night to quell rising anger and frustration in both parties on Capitol Hill after a senators-only classified briefing about President Obama’s decision to free five Taliban prisoners in return for the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who military officials say walked off his base in Afghanistan five years ago.

headline: 25 Years Later, Student Leaders Witness Freedoms Fought for in Tiananmen
abstract: In Taiwan, comrades from the 1989 pro-democracy movement in China see the kind of democratic transformation they had hoped to launch at home.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Wu’er Kaixi took a microphone beneath a portrait of the Chinese revolutionary Sun Yat-sen and began firing up the crowd around him.

headline: For Yankees, a Loss Overshadows Their Defeat
abstract: The Yankees fell to the Athletics, their fifth defeat in six games, as they continued struggling on offense, but the game was eclipsed by the news of Don Zimmer’s death.
lead_paragraph: Around the sixth inning of the Yankees’ loss to the Oakland Athletics on Wednesday, Derek Jeter was told of the death of Don Zimmer. Suddenly, any attempt to come back in the game became much more difficult. There was grief to overcome in the Yankees’ dugout.

headline: State and Local Officials Vow to End Homelessness Among Veterans
abstract: Michelle Obama, an active supporter of service members and their families, emphasized that a goal set by the administration in 2010 to end homelessness among veterans was achievable.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 80 state and local officials committed to try and end the problem of homelessness among veterans by the end of 2015, the Obama administration announced Wednesday, news that comes amid a scandal over medical care for veterans.

headline: U.N. Official Urges Syria to Finish Chemical Arms Disposal
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'International Relations']
abstract: Sigrid Kaag, the official overseeing the destruction of the weapons, said it was “very, very critical” to remove the final 7.2 percent of the arsenal.
lead_paragraph: Acknowledging that Syria will miss the June 30 deadline for eliminating its chemical weapons, the top United Nations official overseeing the arsenal’s eradication said Wednesday it was “very, very critical” for Syria to export the final shipment, which is packed and ready to go but is trapped in an area contested by insurgents in the civil war.

headline: Man Shoots and Kills 3 Canadian Mounties
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Stanley Cup', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Several media reports indicated that the man involved in the shooting was carrying two rifles, a bow and a knife.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A man shot and killed three members of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in Moncton, New Brunswick on Wednesday night and wounded two others.

headline: Hamas Looms Over Latest Israel-U.S. Dispute
abstract: The dispute was over the announcement this week that the United States would work with a new Palestinian government that emerged from reconciliation talks with Hamas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For allies who speak often of their unbreakable bonds and constant communication, this has been a season of static between Jerusalem and Washington. The latest eruption was over the announcement this week that the United States would work with a new Palestinian government that emerged from reconciliation talks with Hamas.

headline: A Familiar Ring for Members of Heat and Spurs
abstract: When the San Antonio Spurs meet the Miami Heat in the N.B.A. finals, Tim Duncan, Dwyane Wade and others will have a chance to add to substantial jewelry collections.
lead_paragraph: Championships can define careers. Bill Russell’s 11 rings are often used as a trump card in arguments about greatness, while Charles Barkley’s and Patrick Ewing’s reputations suffered because those stars never won it all.

headline: In Downtown L.A., a Stylish Design Gallery for Special Guys
abstract: Please Do Not Enter, just opened by two French transplants on the 12th floor of the Pacific Mutual Building, offers a well-curated selection of furniture, objects, leather goods and more.
lead_paragraph: The puzzlingly named Please Do Not Enter is the newest intriguing venture to launch in downtown Los Angeles, that burgeoning mecca of all things cool and compelling. A cross between a gallery and a boutique, Please Do Not Enter offers a collection of contemporary goods that have been carefully curated by its French founders Nicolas Libert and Emmanuel Renoird for an audience of “progressive minds.” Both are art collectors with a special affection for design and architecture, and the space is like an extension of their lives.

headline: Surrealist Photographs of Life’s In-Between Moments
abstract: In an upcoming exhibition, Brea Souders introduces two distinct bodies of work that share the same tone but never the same meanings.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: Two Artists Who Want to Be Your Friends
abstract: FriendsWithYou, purveyors of all things happy and cute, are releasing a monograph with Rizzoli and a cloud-shaped light with Case Studyo and Paul Kasmin Gallery.
lead_paragraph: The first image in the debut monograph of the Los Angeles-based artist duo of Arturo Sandoval III and Samuel Albert Borkson, a.k.a FriendsWithYou — called “We Are FriendsWithYou” (Rizzoli, $55) — is a group of cute little clouds with black beady eyes and tiny red smiles. The characters are from their short film “Cloudy.” “It’s like a very simplistic, reduced form that everybody can relate to,” Borkson explains. “It reminds you of childhood, it reminds you of your creativity, how people can look at the clouds and dream up whatever they want.”

headline: The Great Hamstring Saver
abstract: The powerful Nordic hamstring exercise requires only a partner, a soft surface and a little insouciance about falling on your face.
lead_paragraph: This article appeared in the June 8, 2014 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

headline: The World Cup Is Bad for Brazil, Many Brazilians Say
abstract: Survey respondents see hosting the world’s most popular sporting event as using resources better spent on social issues such as health care, education and unemployment.
lead_paragraph: The World Cup, the championship tournament of the world’s most popular sport, gets underway on June 12 in São Paulo, Brazil. In advance of the tournament, few Brazilians see hosting the event as advantageous for their country, a new survey shows.

headline: Word of the Day | phoenix
abstract: This word has appeared in three New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: phoenix •\ˈfe-niks\• noun

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Arachnophobia
abstract: Can you solve the mystery of a 36-year-old stay at home with debilitating fever, shortness of breath and a strange sore on the back of her leg?
lead_paragraph: The Challenge: Can you solve the medical mystery of a woman who develops a sore on her leg and then fever, nausea and chest pain?

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 5, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 5, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t have any headaches anymore. It’s almost like a rebirth.”

headline: Q. and A.: Wu’er Kaixi on Tiananmen’s Hopes and Taiwan’s Achievements
abstract: The 1989 student leader discusses why he chose to live in Taiwan, how he sees its system surpassing older democracies in the West and the future of relations with Beijing.
lead_paragraph: For the two student leaders most wanted by the Chinese government after the 1989 crackdown on the Tiananmen Square protest movement, Taiwan has become a home in exile. Wu’er Kaixi and Wang Dan now live in a place that has undergone the sort of democratic transition they hoped would happen in mainland China 25 years ago.

headline: In South Korean Voting, No Clear-Cut Victory for Either Party
abstract: Local election results showed the main opposition party winning nine of 17 races for big-city mayors and provincial governors, and candidates from the governing party won the remaining eight races.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Local election results on Thursday showed the main opposition party winning nine of 17 races for big-city mayors and provincial governors in what was seen as a referendum on the leadership of President Park Geun-hye.

headline: Kings Climb Out of Hole as Rangers Fall Into One
abstract: In its latest postseason comeback, Los Angeles overcame a 2-0 deficit, dominating the Rangers over the last 25 minutes and winning Game 1 of the finals on Justin Williams’s overtime goal.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Los Angeles Kings are affectionately called the L.A. Cockroaches by some players and fans because they refuse to die. On Wednesday night at Staples Center, the Kings again showed uncanny resiliency as they overcame a 2-0 deficit and defeated the Rangers, 3-2, in overtime in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: Obama’s Warsaw Workout Finds Its Way to the Internet
abstract: A video showed the president in a dark tracksuit wearing earphones as he lifted weights, did squats and rode a stationary bicycle, occasionally grimacing.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — It may not be the same thing as having his telephone calls tapped by the National Security Agency, but President Obama got a taste of what it is like to have his privacy violated on Wednesday.

headline: A Lifer Who Stood Up for His Players and His Teams
abstract: Don Zimmer, who died Wednesday at 83, seemed to do it all in a baseball career of 60-plus years.
lead_paragraph: Baseball lost a little bit of its soul on Wednesday with the death of Don Zimmer, a character for the ages.

headline: Dismay at Failure of Swap to Rescue More Hostages
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Hostages', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Kidnapping', 'Terrorism', 'Barter']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Elaine Weinstein received a message from the White House on Saturday morning telling her to be ready for a phone call from a senior Obama administration official.

headline: Cubs Blunder, but Not Enough for a Mets Victory
abstract: In a sloppy game between two struggling teams, the Cubs were slightly less dysfunctional.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Curtis Granderson hit a ground ball into the Chicago Cubs’ shift in the fifth inning Wednesday night, and for another team, it would probably have been a routine play.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 4:15 P.M. (Starz Cinema) INCENDIES (2011) The adult children (Mélissa Désormeaux-Poulin and Maxim Gaudette) of an Arab woman, Nawal (Lubna Azabal, above), living in Canada travel to an unnamed country that closely resembles Lebanon to seek out a brother they never knew existed on the instructions of Nawal’s last will and testament. In the process, they learn that their mother, a Christian, had fallen in love with a Muslim and fled her hometown, becoming in succession a student, an activist, a clandestine militant, a political prisoner — and more. The director Denis Villeneuve “tells Nawal’s story in a way that is both subtle and emphatic, and Ms. Azabal, portraying Nawal from hopeful youth to despairing middle age, gives a performance that is all the more powerful for the restrained, unshakable sense of dignity she brings to it,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film, based on a play by Wajdi Mouawad. “The depth and complexity of her anger is both a product and a mirror of her native country’s self-destructive pathology, and as the full horror of her life is disclosed, she becomes, in her children’s eyes and the audience’s, as grand and tragic as the heroine of an opera.”

headline: A More Militant Protest Demands Reforms From Beijing
abstract: Participants in the smaller demonstration set the Communist Party’s flag on fire and pledged to “occupy” the city’s Legislative Council if the Hong Kong government did not grant universal suffrage.
lead_paragraph: While most eyes were on the huge vigil in Hong Kong’s Victoria Park to mark the 25th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown, a separate demonstration by more ardently anti-Communist Party protesters drew several thousand people across the harbor on Wednesday night, highlighting the different approaches to confronting Beijing’s rule of the territory.

headline: Alibaba to Take Stake in Chinese Soccer Team
abstract: The e-commerce giant Alibaba said on Thursday that it would buy 50 percent of Guangzhou Evergrande F.C. from the team’s parent company, the Evergrande Real Estate Group.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The e-commerce giant Alibaba Group agreed on Thursday to pay nearly $200 million for a stake in a Chinese soccer team, its latest in a recent spate of acquisitions.

headline: Indicted German Financier Freed in Italy
abstract: Florian Homm, arrested last year on a United States warrant, was released from prison and returned to Germany, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — A German hedge fund manager wanted on securities fraud charges in Los Angeles has been released from an Italian jail, his lawyer said, in what appeared to be a serious setback for United States prosecutors.

headline: Henkel to Buy French Detergent Maker for $1.3 Billion
abstract: Henkel’s deal to acquire the Spotless Group from the European private equity firm BC Partners is expected to give a boost to the German company’s laundry and home care products unit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Henkel of Germany said on Thursday that it would pay 940 million euros, or about $1.3 billion, for the Spotless Group, a French maker of laundry detergent and other home care products, from funds advised by the European private equity firm BC Partners.

lead_paragraph: In “Crowds Gather in Hong Kong for 25th Anniversary of Tiananmen Killings,” Keith Bradsher reports on commemoration events in China.

headline: ING Moves Ahead With I.P.O. of Insurance Unit
abstract: The Dutch financial services company ING Group said it would hold a long-anticipated initial public offering for the NN Group, its European and Japanese insurance and investment management arm.

lead_paragraph: The music world has been graced by many a pop diva. Whitney Houston, Madonna, Aretha Franklin, Mariah Carey, Jennifer Lopez, Diana Ross, Barbra Streisand and Lady Gaga have all reigned the stage at some point. Is Beyoncé queen now?

headline: Missing Japan, Balanced in Brazil
abstract: Among the first generation of Japanese laborers who immigrated to Brazil more than a century ago, Haruo Ohara photographed a world where man sought harmony with tradition and nature.
lead_paragraph: It doesn’t matter that oceans are vast, deep and imposing. For much of history they have had to be crossed by force or necessity.

headline: Web Editor Detained Over Photo Linking Mao to Fringe Sect
abstract: The editor was held under a charge that has been used to detain those who participated in events to mark the 25th anniversary of the crackdown on the Tiananmen protest movement.
lead_paragraph: A Beijing-based web editor has been detained by the authorities on suspicion of posting a doctored photo that linked Mao Zedong with a fringe religious group accused in a high-profile murder, a lawyer said.

headline: Xinjiang Hospital Asks Staff Not to Fast During Ramadan
abstract: A health department in Yinin, in far western Xinjiang, says a local hospital has asked its Muslim workers, including members of the region’s ethnic Uighur and other groups, not to skip meals during Ramadan, to prevent work accidents.
lead_paragraph: A hospital in a city in the western region of Xinjiang that was the site of deadly ethnic unrest in 1997 has asked its staff members not to skip meals during Ramadan, the Muslim month of fasting that begins on June 28, the local health department said.

keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Zoopla, controlled by the publisher of The Daily Mail, has tapped into Britain’s obsession with rising housing prices, attracting more than 20 million visits a month.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Zoopla Property Group, a British property listings website, could be valued at more than 1 billion pounds when it goes public in London later this month.

headline: New York Today: No School, but Why?
abstract: What you need to know for Thursday: a holiday’s obscure roots, rain until lunchtime, and a New York baseball mainstay dies.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: Teenage Sunburns Raise Melanoma Risk
abstract: Women who had at least five blistering sunburns during their teenage years had a greater likelihood of developing any of the three main forms of skin cancer, but especially melanoma.
lead_paragraph: The risk of developing the deadliest form of skin cancer may be closely tied to sun exposure in youth, a new study suggests.

headline: Two Workouts for the Mayor
abstract: Two personal trainers, Justin Gelband of modelFIT and Will Torres of Willspace, explain workouts designed especially for Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: Two personal trainers, Justin Gelband of modelFIT and Will Torres of Willspace, explain workouts designed especially for Mayor Bill de Blasio.

headline: A de Blasio Workout: New Routine, No Sweat
abstract: Bill de Blasio may govern New York City, but he would not wow anyone with his feats of strength at the Prospect Park Y.M.C.A. in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The very tall man, watched closely by a pair of police officers in business attire, stripped off his sweatshirt and windmilled his arms. He rolled his head in circles, stretching his neck.

headline: As D-Day Tribute Nears, Leaders Maneuver Over Ukraine
abstract: A dwindling band of veterans began gathering for the 70th anniversary of the amphibious landings in Normandy that turned the course of World War II.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Veterans began gathering on Thursday on the Normandy beaches — some of them perhaps for the last time at such a major commemoration — to observe the 70th anniversary of the D-Day landings of World War II, even as their political leaders grappled anew with the conflict’s legacy of East-West division.

headline: Memories From Normandy
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Seventy years later, four veterans of the largest amphibious invasion in history recall their experiences.
lead_paragraph: Beginning on June 6, 1944, more than 150,000 Allied troops landed on a broad stretch of beaches on the coast of Normandy, in German-held France. Entrenched behind concrete walls and bunkers were more than 50,000 German soldiers. Seventy years later, four veterans of the largest amphibious invasion in history recall their experiences.

headline: Goldman Bolsters M.&A. Team in Asia
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: With the reshuffling, Goldman Sachs is repositioning itself to capitalize on a boom in deal-making in Asia.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG – Goldman Sachs is ramping up its mergers and acquisitions team in Asia amid a surge in deal volume in the region, according to an internal memo sent on Thursday.

headline: Exiled Rally Leader Says He Slipped Into China
abstract: The return of Zhou Fengsuo, who helped lead the 1989 protests, came despite China’s intensified security measures on the anniversary of the crackdown.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Despite the ramped-up security for the 25th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown, an exiled former protest organizer whose name and picture are on the Chinese government’s 1989 list of the 21 most-wanted students managed to slip back into the country undetected this week, he said Thursday.

headline: 1914: James Joyce Hears an Army
abstract: On May 24, 1914, The New York Times reported on the publication of a new poetry anthology, “The Imagists,” that featured the works of James Joyce.
lead_paragraph: “First Glimpses” offers a look at the first times famous people or things appeared in the pages of The New York Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: What I’m Looking for in a New Partner
abstract: After the disaster of my first business partnership, I’m setting up processes to ensure I don’t make the wrong decision again.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always been a solo achiever. I’m an only child, and at school I excelled at individual sports like long-distance running.

headline: Why People Hate Taking Surveys
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: With the credibility of survey research in danger because of the deceptive tactics of some pollsters, an industry seeks to police itself.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy to be a pollster these days. As polls have proliferated, the job of legitimate survey researchers has become increasingly difficult. Unfortunately, those of us who are trying to conduct quality surveys are painted with the same brush as those who are not.

headline: Bank of England Keeps Interest Rates Unchanged
abstract: Despite robust economic data, the central bank left its key interest rate at 0.5 percent and continued to hold 375 billion pounds in government bonds.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Bank of England on Thursday decided to leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low, even as Britain’s economy continues to gather strength.

headline: Daily Report: Sprint and T-Mobile Move Closer to Merger
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: With the deal, Sprint, which is majority-owned by Japan’s Softbank, would acquire T-Mobile, creating a more formidable rival to the two largest wireless phone providers in the United States, Verizon and AT&T.
lead_paragraph: Responding to a wave of consolidation in the telecommunications industry, the nation’s third- and fourth-largest wireless phone operators have agreed on the terms of a deal to join forces, David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced report.

headline: Philippines Reports Chinese Ship Movement Around Disputed Reefs
abstract: Philippine officials said Chinese ships were photographed near two areas in the South China Sea that could be used to reclaim land and build structures.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — China is moving ships around disputed reefs in the South China Sea that could be used to reclaim land and build structures, President Benigno S. Aquino III of the Philippines said on Thursday.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Morning Views
lead_paragraph: The number of children crossing the border between Mexico and the United States illegally has doubled each year since 2011, with 60,000 more expected to arrive this year. This — The New York Times editorial board says — is not a security crisis, but a humanitarian one. “Young people are being pushed out of their homes, not pulled,” the board writes, citing increasing civil unrest in Mexico and parts of Central America. “They are fleeing for their lives.”

headline: Accel’s Breyer to Partner With Venture Capital Firm in China
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Start-ups', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: James W. Breyer will advise and invest alongside IDG Capital Partners, which is expected to make early stage investments in Chinese technology, media and telecommunication companies.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI – James W. Breyer, the venture capitalist who made a fortune with an early bet on Facebook, is putting some of his winnings to work in China, partnering with Beijing-based venture capital firm to invest in Chinese technology start-ups.

headline: In Our Pages: June 6
keywords: ['Dogs', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Ships and Shipping']

lead_paragraph: 1914: Giant Warships Not Needed

headline: European Central Bank Breaks New Ground to Press Growth
abstract: The central bank cut its benchmark interest rate to 0.15 percent, a record low.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Banks typically make money on the cash they park at a central bank. Now the European Central Bank wants them to pay for the privilege.

headline: No Time Off for Good Behavior
abstract: The heart of “Orange Is the New Black” is Piper Chapman’s real-world education, in which her hypocrisy and narcissism are constantly challenged.
lead_paragraph: Is it a problem that “Orange Is the New Black” essentially treats prison like a bad day in high school, the kind that includes both a scary walk to the principal’s office and an embarrassing visit to the school nurse?

headline: Young Love, Complicated by Cancer
abstract: In “The Fault in Our Stars,” a film based on the young-adult novel, two teenagers with cancer fall in love and grasp the meaning of their lives earlier than usual.
lead_paragraph: “The world is not a wish-granting factory.” That line, from “The Fault in Our Stars,” is undoubtedly true, and it is also true that the movie, like the book before it, is an expertly built machine for the mass production of tears. Directed by Josh Boone (“Stuck in Love”) with scrupulous respect for John Green’s best-selling young-adult novel, the film sets out to make you weep — not just sniffle or choke up a little, but sob until your nose runs and your face turns blotchy. It succeeds.

headline: Tony Award Predictions: Readers (and Boldface Names) Weigh In
abstract: Celebrities and Times readers offer their Tony Award predictions.
lead_paragraph: So said Anna Wintour, Condé Nast artistic director and editor-in-chief of Vogue, about the race for best actor in a musical as part of our Tony Award predictions series this week. At our invitation, Ms. Wintour, Oscar and Tony winner Liza Minnelli, Emmy Award winner Jim Parsons, and television host Kelly Ripa joined a few dozen of you in offering predictions.

headline: Amazon Boycott Gets a Helping Hand From Stephen Colbert
abstract: The popular comedian lashed out at the e-commerce company on Wednesday night over its dispute with Hachette, a book publisher.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Colbert went after Amazon Wednesday night, literally giving the retailer the finger on his Comedy Central show. Twice.

headline: Talking Rebranding and Logos With Loewe’s Jonathan Anderson
abstract: The brand revealed its new logo and typeface yesterday.
lead_paragraph: Rebranding of heritage names has become something of a fashion trend recently, what with Hedi Slimane’s conversion of Yves Saint Laurent’s ready-to-wear to Saint Laurent Paris; Pinault-Printemps-Redoute’s transformation into Kering, complete with little owl pictogram: Celine’s new minimalism courtesy of Phoebe Philo, and so on. The latest entrant into this group is LVMH’s Loewe, under the creative directorship of Jonathan Anderson (aka J Anderson, iconoclastic Young British designer), which unveiled its new logo and typeface yesterday.

headline: Energy Choices
abstract: An educational intervention from a concern troll.
lead_paragraph: Nate Silver got a lot of grief when he chose Roger Pielke Jr., of all people, to write about environment for the new 538. Pielke is regarded among climate scientists as a concern troll – someone who pretends to be open-minded, but is actually committed to undermining the case for emissions limits any way he can. But is this fair?

headline: China Sentences Scores in Xinjiang for Acts of Terror
abstract: The accused were convicted on charges including intentional murder, arson and participating in terrorist activities, with nine people sentenced to death. Three others received
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese courts in the northwestern region of Xinjiang sentenced 81 people on terrorism and other charges on Thursday, according to the state broadcaster China Central Television. The sentences are part of a widening crackdown in the region after a spate of deadly violence in China for which the authorities have blamed foreign-backed Islamist separatists.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Obama Talks Climate Change at Summit
abstract: President Obama is meeting with foreign leaders at the Group of 7 meetings in Brussels to discuss energy, climate change and, of course, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine that led to Russia’s exclusion from the meetings.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning. Political controversies over a prisoner swap with the Taliban and the scandal at the Department of Veterans Affairs are still swirling in Washington, but on this warm and gloomy day, President Obama has a busy agenda across the pond.

headline: Israel Expands Settlements to Rebuke Palestinians
abstract: Israel said the proposal for about 1,500 units was a response to the creation of a unity Palestinian government.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel says it is moving ahead with the planning and construction of hundreds of Jewish settlement homes as retaliation against the new Palestinian government, which has been accepted by the United States and much of the world even though it is supported by Hamas. The announcement enraged the Palestinians and flouted international opinion.

headline: Where Have All the Couriers Gone?
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A look back at the 1960s, when the delivery messenger, rushing copy in and out, was an important person in the office.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary,

headline: Video and Updates on G.M. Internal Recall Investigation

lead_paragraph: As my colleague Bill Vlasic reports, Mary T. Barra discussed the findings of an internal investigation into why it took General Motors more than a decade to recall about 2.6 million small cars with defective ignition switches. The auto company says the problem has caused at least 13 deaths, but lawyers bringing suits against G.M. say the toll is at least 60.

headline: A Little Something Special
abstract: Small, delicate pieces of jewelry, meant to be mixed and worn every day, are sentimental talismans of a particular moment in time.
lead_paragraph: Small, delicate pieces of jewelry, meant to be mixed and worn every day, are sentimental talismans of a particular moment in time.

headline: G.M. Inquiry Cites Years of Neglect Over Fatal Defect
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: In an internal investigation, the company cited bureaucratic problems and the failure of individual employees to deal with a fatal ignition flaw, and said 15 had been dismissed.
lead_paragraph: WARREN, Mich. — A sweeping internal investigation of General Motors released on Thursday condemned the company for its decade-long failure to fix a deadly safety defect, one that led to “devastating consequences,” including at least 13 deaths.

headline: Morning Agenda: Sprint and T-Mobile Near a Deal of Their Own
abstract: Sprint and T-Mobile have settled on the terms of a $32 billion deal. | A maverick judge leaves his mark. | Valeant’s opaque business model has been revealed. | Assessing the effects of a multibillion-dollar penalty on BNP’s capital.
lead_paragraph: Responding to a wave of consolidation in the telecommunications industry, the nation’s third- and fourth-largest wireless phone operators have agreed to a deal of their own. The operators, Sprint and T-Mobile, which have long contemplated a merger, finally settled on the terms of a $32 billion deal that is likely to be announced this summer, DealBook’s David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced write. The merger would create a more formidable rival to the two largest wireless phone providers in the United States, Verizon and AT&T. Under the terms of the deal, Sprint, which is majority-owned by Japan’s SoftBank, would acquire T-Mobile for about $40 a share in cash and stock, a 17 percent premium to Wednesday’s price. Accounting for regulatory uncertainty, the early terms of the deal also include a breakup fee of more than $1 billion that Sprint would pay to T-Mobile.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘In the Night’
abstract: This poem, by Emma J., is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest. It comes from a Travel article, “A Big Sur Bath by the Light of the Moon.”
lead_paragraph: This poem, by Emma J., is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest. It comes from a Travel article, “A Big Sur Bath by the Light of the Moon.”

headline: Canadian Police Seek Suspect in Killing of Officers
abstract: The authorities in New Brunswick said that they had identified the man who killed three Mounties and wounded two others.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A full day after a heavily armed gunman killed three police officers and wounded two others, Moncton, New Brunswick, largely remained under siege on Thursday night.

headline: If the Serial Killers Don’t Get Him, the Fast Food Will
abstract: John Waters’s memoir “Carsick” describes his fantasies and fears about hitchhiking from Baltimore to San Francisco and then recounts the real journey.
lead_paragraph: Calls to literacy come in many forms, most of them smug and self-defeating. Then there is the cult-film director John Waters’s advice. In his one-man show “This Filthy World,” he instructs audiences, “If you go home with somebody, and they don’t have books,” don’t sleep with them.

headline: A Long-Ago Blackout Burns Brightly
abstract: Michael Mitnick, Kim Rosenstock and Will Connolly shepherd their musical, “Fly by Night,” to New York.
lead_paragraph: When Kim Rosenstock, Michael Mitnick and Will Connolly first staged their musical “Fly by Night” as Yale School of Drama grad students in 2009, it was nothing if not a DIY proposition.

headline: A Brawny Vegetarian Soup Holds Its Own With Meat Lovers
abstract: Martha Rose Shulman, a cookbook author and Times columnist, works with the Ruder family to help them go vegetarian twice a week without even thinking of feeling deprived.
lead_paragraph: Renee Ruder and her meat-loving family (her husband and their three daughters, 7, 9 and 11) have asked for help adding more vegetable-based meals to their weekly menu, and with making the most of their new C.S.A. (community supported agriculture) share. I am leading the way, holding a crash course in creating substantial vegetarian meals using pantry staples, the seasonal vegetables that come every week in the C.S.A. box, and ingredients from nearby supermarkets.

headline: With Group of 7 Backing, Obama Gives Russia One-Month Ukraine Deadline
abstract: The threat of stronger economic sanctions lurks behind the deadline, but the tough talk did little to stifle world leaders’ desire to meet individually with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — With the backing of other world leaders, President Obama effectively set a one-month deadline for Moscow to reverse its intervention in Ukraine and help quash a pro-Russian separatist uprising or else he said it would face international sanctions far more severe than anything it had endured so far.

headline: 36 Hours in Canberra, Australia
abstract: In the country’s capital, situated between Sydney and Melbourne, you’ll find everything from culture to cycling, political history to panoramic views.
lead_paragraph: To stand atop a Canberra hilltop is to contemplate the stark charm of the Australian bush: vast grassy fields, swaths of eucalyptus forest and Instagram-worthy sunsets. This outpost is Australia’s national capital — not, as is commonly thought, the glitzier city of Sydney, three hours’ drive north. In Canberra, there are no beaches or iconic opera houses, and European chic is best sought an hour’s flight away in Melbourne. But what the “bush capital” lacks in big-city tousle, it makes up for in big-sky beauty, breezy civic pride and a decidedly hipster underbelly. Set on an artificial lake and spread across a valley between mountain ranges, Canberra is the Brasilia of Australia, designed by the American architects Walter Burley Griffin and Marion Mahony Griffin, who won a competition in 1911 to create the country’s political heart because Sydney and Melbourne couldn’t stop bickering about their own fabulousness. A year after the city’s centennial celebrations and with a steady influx of artists and gastronomes, Canberra is best appreciated with deep intakes of mountain air and an ear tuned to the calls of sulphur-crested cockatoos and crimson rosellas.

headline: Anatomy | ‘The Fault in Our Stars’
abstract: In Anatomy of a Scene, Josh Boone narrates a sequence from “The Fault in Our Stars” featuring Shailene Woodley, Ansel Elgort and Nat Wolff.
lead_paragraph: In Anatomy of a Scene, Josh Boone narrates a sequence from “The Fault in Our Stars” featuring Shailene Woodley, Ansel Elgort and Nat Wolff.

headline: The Burden of Being Messi
abstract: What does the greatest player in the world have to do to make Argentina love him?
lead_paragraph: In much of Argentina, where Lionel Messi lived until he was 13, native speakers replace the “y” sound with a “sh” sound. Yo, the personal pronoun for “I,” becomes “sho,” and calle, which other Spanish speakers would pronounce “ka-yay,” becomes “ka-shey.” The sound gives Argentine Spanish a slurry softness that resembles aspects of the Portuguese spoken in Brazil. More important to this story, that “sh,” and the fact that Messi has retained it all his life, has at times been the sole lifeline between the greatest soccer player in the world and the country he plays for.

headline: Democrats Are Weary in Wake of Bergdahl Case
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Prisoners of War', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: President Obama’s handling of the prisoner exchange has renewed frustration among congressional Democrats about the administration’s relations with its allies on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s handling of the Bergdahl prisoner exchange has renewed frustration among congressional Democrats about the administration’s relations with its allies on Capitol Hill, and prompted criticism that the White House failed to prepare the lawmakers for the politically explosive case.

headline: Exclusive Clip: Yves Saint Laurent
abstract: Yves Saint Laurent (Pierre Niney) prepares his models backstage for his first show after his well-publicized split from Dior. Yves’ muse Victoire (Charlotte Le Bon) surprises him with a new haircut.
lead_paragraph: Yves Saint Laurent (Pierre Niney) prepares his models backstage for his first show after his well-publicized split from Dior. Yves’ muse Victoire (Charlotte Le Bon) surprises him with a new haircut.

headline: In West Bengal, Communists’ Defeat Signals a Larger Loss
abstract: The Communist Party of India (Marxist) was reduced to just two seats in West Bengal, a state that was formerly the source of its national power.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon in April in Baruipur, a rural expanse on the edge of Kolkata, Sujan Chakraborty, a leader of the Communist Party of India (Marxist), presided over a meeting with party workers before he set out to campaign on foot, days before the parliamentary election vote was held there.

abstract: In an internal investigation, General Motors cited bureaucratic problems and the failure of individual employees to address a safety problem that the company links to 13 deaths and 47 accidents.
lead_paragraph: In an internal investigation, General Motors cited bureaucratic problems and the failure of individual employees to address a safety problem that the company links to 13 deaths and 47 accidents.

headline: Europe’s Central Bank Gets Serious About Fighting Deflation
keywords: ['Deflation (Economics)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The bank’s president signaled on Thursday that he was throwing everything but the kitchen sink at the Continent’s economic malaise.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank has seemed hopelessly behind the curve for ages, its leaders sitting on their hands as their continent seemed to drift inexorably toward Japan-style deflation.

headline: When Plans Go Out the Window
abstract: Finnerty Steeves and Mark Mignone found more space in Midtown West.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, when Finnerty Steeves bought her sunny Greenwich Village studio for $380,000, she thought she would remain there for the rest of her life.

headline: How the Recession Reshaped the Economy, in 255 Charts
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Five years since the end of the Great Recession, the private sector has finally regained the nine million jobs it lost. But not all industries recovered equally.
lead_paragraph: Five years since the end of the Great Recession, the private sector has finally regained the nine million jobs it lost. But not all industries recovered equally.

headline: The Age of Online Memory
abstract: 10,000 Europeans per day are asking Google to honor their newly granted “right to be forgotten.” ANNA NORTH finds that the online omission of public facts could lead to changes in the way humans remember — and forget &mdash themselves and each other.
lead_paragraph: The poetically-named “right to be forgotten” has been much discussed recently, after a European court ruled last month that E.U. residents can force Google to remove certain embarrassing search results about them. Indeed, according to a Time magazine article published yesterday, Google is receiving 10,000 requests per day to be ‘forgotten’ in Europe. Neither the decision nor the volume of interest among Europeans in exercising this new “right” will affect Americans directly, but they may feed into a bigger conversation about memory and forgetting at a time when so much about our lives is recorded online.

headline: Fears for Sergeant’s Life Led to Secrecy About Swap, Obama Official Says
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Prisoners of War']
abstract: The administration worried that splits within the Taliban could lead gun-wielding guards to kill Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl before he was turned over to American forces.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A senior Obama administration official said Thursday that the operation to free Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl was kept a closely held secret because of fear that splits within the Taliban could lead gun-wielding guards to kill the soldier before he was turned over to American forces last weekend.

headline: 1964: D-Day Remembered
abstract: Fifty years ago the European Edition recalled the D-Day landings on its front page.
lead_paragraph: OFFICIAL INVITATION — The engraving above is the frontispiece of an invitation to the commemorative ceremonies of the 20th anniversary of D-Day sent to distinguished persons by the D-Day Commemorative Committee, an official French group which is headed by Minister of Cooperation Raymond Triboulet. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 5, 1964.

headline: Newly Elected Parliamentarians Take Oath in Sanskrit
abstract: An usually high number of lawmakers took their oaths in Sanskrit on the second day of the new Parliament session in New Delhi.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI -— At least two dozen newly elected members of India’s lower house of Parliament, which had its second meeting on Thursday, took their oaths in Sanskrit, India’s traditional language that harkens back to its ancient civilization.

headline: Suspect in Brooklyn Stabbings Is Charged With Murder
abstract: Daniel St. Hubert, who was also charged with attempted murder in an attack on two children, is also a suspect in an attack in Chelsea that left a 53-year-old man severely wounded, an official said.
lead_paragraph: The man arrested on Wednesday night in connection with the stabbing death of a 6-year-old Brooklyn boy was charged on Thursday with murder, the police said.

headline: Putting a Price Tag on Nature’s Defenses
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Coral', 'Reefs', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Wetlands', 'Environment', 'Forests and Forestry']
abstract: A new study estimates the trillions of dollars of protection that ecosystems provide, although not everyone buys the premise.
lead_paragraph: After Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans, the United States Army Corps of Engineers got to work on a massive network of levees and flood walls to protect against future catastrophes. Finally completed in 2012, the project ended up costing $14.5 billion — and that figure didn’t include the upkeep these defenses will require in years to come, not to mention the cost of someday replacing them altogether.

headline: In Store | A Cozy New L.A. Design Nook
abstract: Ouli, a new showroom and store in the rapidly changing Echo Park neighborhood, showcases work from a range of talent in a tiny, homelike storefront.
lead_paragraph: One gets the feeling that Scott Barry and Brooke Intrachat would not be at all upset if you visited their new L.A. store Ouli simply to collapse into the buttery silver leather beanbag pouf (their design) and page through the adjacent copy of The Gentlewoman. In fact, with its exposed wood ceiling and feathery floral arrangements, Ouli is designed to feel more like a cozy, well-appointed living room than a gallery. “People come in and say, ‘what is this, a meditation center?'” says Barry.

headline: Karl Ove Knausgaard Brings His Struggle to Brooklyn
abstract: Readers packed a small bookstore on Wednesday night to hear Mr. Knausgaard discuss his six-volume autobiographical novel.
lead_paragraph: About 30 minutes before the start of Karl Ove Knausgaard’s event at the relatively small and narrow Community Bookstore in Park Slope on Wednesday, people packed the entire space in a scene more reminiscent of the calm before an indie-rock storm than an author appearance. Ezra Goldstein, an owner of the store, approached a microphone. “Don’t get excited,” he said. “This is just a sound check.”

headline: Harper Lee Lawsuit Is Dismissed
abstract: After asking a judge to reinstate a lawsuit against a museum, Harper Lee asks that the suit be withdrawn.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:59 p.m. |

headline: New Access to a Nicaraguan Island
abstract: A new airport may increase tourism on Ometepe Island, a Unesco Biosphere Reserve in Nicaragua.
lead_paragraph: The government of Nicaragua is betting that a new $10 million airport will boost tourism on Ometepe Island, a Unesco Biosphere Reserve known for its towering twin volcanoes.

headline: Three Things Students Wish Teachers Knew
abstract: Students wish teachers would be fair, consider homework assignments carefully and with an eye to utility, and treat students like people.
lead_paragraph: As the school year winds down, I thought it would be helpful to hear from students in the vein of “Five Things Teachers Wish Parents Knew” and “Three Things Parents Wish Teachers Knew.” I spoke with and emailed over a hundred students in grades kindergarten through 12, enrolled in independent and public schools all over the country, and asked them to think back on the past year and come up with just one thing they wished that their teachers knew. The top three:

headline: Josh Boone Narrates a Scene From ‘The Fault in Our Stars’

headline: Ryan Carson of Treehouse, on When Titles Get in the Way
abstract: The chief executive of an online interactive education platform says that eliminating management roles has generally worked well at his company.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Ryan Carson, chief executive of Treehouse, an online interactive education platform, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Facts & Figures: Before and After ‘Obamacare’
keywords: ['Gallup Poll', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The uninsured rate has declined significantly since the law took effect.
lead_paragraph: Although few Americans say the Affordable Care Act has helped them, the uninsured rate has declined significantly since the law took effect, and appears to be leveling off at around 13.4 percent.

headline: Strasbourg Music Festival Closes, Cites Poor Ticket Sales
abstract: France’s oldest classical music festival shuts down just days before opening concert
lead_paragraph: The Strasbourg Music Festival has closed its doors just days before Sunday’s opening concert. France’s oldest classical music festival, the event was scheduled to run through June 15 and feature prominent artists such as the pianist Krystian Zimerman and the conductor Sir John Eliot Gardiner, leading the English Baroque Soloists.

headline: Gannett Would Unlock Value by Splitting Off Publishing Unit
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Television']
abstract: Gannett’s television business is being undervalued when compared with other baskets of TV holdings, Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: A breakup of Gannett is inevitable. Gannett, the owner of USA Today and other newspapers, is not getting much credit for the transformation of its television segment. As Time Warner sets its publishing arm free this week, a Breakingviews analysis suggests Gannett should do the same.

headline: When the Teacher Is Depressed
keywords: ['Depression (Mental)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Parenting', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Teaching can be a stressful occupation, and yet there is comparatively little done to protect teachers’ well-being or consider the effect of a teachers’ emotional health on students.
lead_paragraph: The toll that a mother’s or father’s depression takes on children has been well documented: Children of depressed parents may become anxious or withdrawn, may have trouble regulating their emotions or dealing with challenges, and may develop behavior problems or even become depressed themselves.

headline: DNA Test Indicates Camel-to-Human Transmission of MERS
abstract: The virus in a 44-year-old Saudi man who died in November was the same as that in an ailing camel he was tending, scientists report.
lead_paragraph: In the clearest evidence yet that the MERS virus can be passed directly from camels to humans, genetic sequencing has shown that a 44-year-old Saudi man who died of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome in November had a strain virtually identical to that in one of the camels in his herd, researchers said on Wednesday.

headline: Moving On by Moving Around
abstract: After her husband died, I urged her to move from the house. Instead she rearranged the furniture.
lead_paragraph: Caregiving is a delicate dance, with a gradual shift in who is leading and who is following. One partner is, often, a frail, widowed mother, upended by the loss of her husband and living in the family home, too big, costly and difficult to maintain.

headline: D-Day, 70 Years Later: A Frenchman Says, ‘Merci’
abstract: Words of gratitude on the 70th anniversary of the Allied invasion.
