headline: Lennon Manuscripts Go for Nearly $3 Million in Auction
abstract: Short stories, poems and drawings by John Lennon sell for $2.9 million, more than double the pre-sale estimate.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 John Lennon manuscripts — including short stories, poems and line drawings – have sold for $2.9 million, more than double the pre-sale estimate, at Sotheby’s in New York, Reuters reported.

headline: Clinton’s Hectic Pace Acts as Retort to Health Fears
keywords: ['Presidential Elections (US)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Age, Chronological', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s breakneck schedule allows her to promote her memoir, but also to project that she has the energy and stamina required of a presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: It was roughly 7 a.m. the day after Hillary Rodham Clinton had left her job as secretary of state. She had been up for a while and called a friend. “O.K., I’m rested!” Mrs. Clinton told her friend.

headline: Wheelies: The Audi Flagship Edition
abstract: Audi announces pricing for its A8 sedan; Honda and Mercedes-Benz top the ALG value and quality study.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Living With Cancer: Chronic, Not Cured
abstract: Chronic cancer means you will die from it — unless you are first hit by the proverbial bus — but not now, not necessarily soon.
lead_paragraph: At the end of yoga sessions for cancer patients, we are told to say to ourselves, “I am whole, healed and healthy in this and every moment.” Perversely, since in yoga we express aspirations as if they were already so, the sentence reminds me of people who congratulate me on being “cancer free.” Stable disease often goes unrecognized.

headline: Listen Up | The Smooth, Psychedelic Sounds of Glass Animals
abstract: The Oxford, England-based quartet — anointed by Paul Epworth, Adele’s producer — debuts a remix of “Pools,” the lead single from their new album, here.
lead_paragraph: Dave Bayley, the frontman for the quirky new Oxford, England-based band Glass Animals, says his original life plan was to become a doctor. In fact, Bayley insisted on finishing his degree in medicine at King’s College London before officially forming Glass Animals with three of his high school friends, Drew MacFarlane, Edmund Irwin-Singer and Joe Seaward, in 2012. It was a second beginning of sorts: Bayley had published some of the quartets demos on the Internet in 2010, but had removed them almost immediately when they proved too popular. “People started getting in touch,” says Bayley. “We didn’t know what it was like to be in a band. We didn’t know anyone in a band at all, so we freaked out and took everything off the Internet.”

headline: In Terms of Fans, the Heat Have Already Beaten the Spurs
abstract: Even if more Americans wind up rooting for the Spurs in the N.B.A. finals, the Heat will still have many more committed fans.
lead_paragraph: Some of the commentary around the N.B.A. finals assumes that most Americans are rooting for the Spurs to beat the Heat. That makes sense. The Spurs are a likable group, with an older core of players perhaps chasing a last title. And they’re trying to dethrone a team that was built in large part on big-name free agents, including one who took his “talents to South Beach.”

headline: Abstract Painter’s Afterlife, Reborn
abstract: The Abstract Expressionist Raymond Spillenger was an underrecognized member of the New York School. His later work, which his sons unearthed, may have a second life.
lead_paragraph: Raymond Spillenger, who died in November at the age of 89, was among the very last of the first- and second-generation Abstract Expressionists. There can’t be many others remaining, and few more obscure than Mr. Spillenger, who left scant traces. Some of his paintings hang — or have hung — at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington, at the Contemporary Arts Museum in Houston and at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, and his name is mentioned in a few of the reference books. That’s about it. Mr. Spillenger’s reputation, or lack of one, is a reminder that the great art movements rise and then fall — with Abstract Expressionism eased aside by Pop, in turn overtaken by Super-Realism, Minimalism and all the other isms — and that from any one moment, often only a handful of names survive, some for good reason, some just from luck or self-promotion.

headline: Before Arrest, a Long String of Violent Acts
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Assaults', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Daniel St. Hubert, who is accused of stabbing two children in Brooklyn, has a history of violent crime and, according to his sister, a history of mental illness.
lead_paragraph: Just before dawn on Wednesday, a man thought by the police to be Daniel St. Hubert sat on a bench in a Chelsea subway station. Two weeks before, Mr. St. Hubert had been released from a five-year term in prison for trying to strangle his mother with an electrical cord.

abstract: Dither, an electric-guitar quartet, will perform work by John Zorn and David Lang in Long Island City on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: When the Miser’s not out scouring the city on your behalf for all things cheap, he’s been known to do a little pickin’ on the guitar, an instrument he was inspired to adopt as a teenager, predictably enough, by the great Jimi Hendrix. But the Miser was much less interested than his peers in learning Hendrix’s soulful solos by rote and much more taken with how he made music out of sonic “mistakes” — feedback, static, effects — and a general irreverence toward proper technique.

lead_paragraph: Sprint and T-Mobile have seemingly, inexorably been heading toward a merger agreement for more than a year. And such a deal has had no more outspoken advocate than Masayoshi Son, the Japanese billionaire who controls Sprint.

keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Prisoners of War']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A classified military report detailing the Army’s investigation into the disappearance of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in June 2009 says that he had wandered away from assigned areas before — both at a training range in California and at his remote outpost in Afghanistan — and then returned, according to people briefed on it.

headline: Homecoming Queen
abstract: “Jenny From the Block,” a.k.a. Jennifer Lopez, performed at Orchard Beach on Wednesday night to a hometown crowd.
lead_paragraph: As party tricks go, Jennifer Lopez has the best and most effective one: Regardless of her milieu, she comes off as if she’s slumming. Making records and having songs on the radio? That’s not something she appears interested in doing particularly often, even though she’s welcomed when she does. Making movies? Here and there, sure, but nothing notably great in years. Appearing on television? On “American Idol,” she had twice the wattage of anyone else around her.

headline: Australia Doesn’t Seem So Far Away
abstract: At Flinders Lane in the East Village, the chef grew up in Melbourne, but the most interesting dishes draw on flavors from across the Indian Ocean and the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: Here is the choice: a bottle of brown HP sauce, with London’s Houses of Parliament in sky blue on the label and a secret recipe (tomatoes, tamarind, dates, molasses, malt vinegar, mysterious spices) dating from the late 19th century, or a ramekin of mayonnaise laced with a house-made sambal of bird’s-eye chiles, fish sauce and palm sugar.

headline: The Triple Crown Eleven
keywords: ['Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Horse Racing', 'Belmont Stakes', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)']
abstract: Only 11 horses have won thoroughbred racing’s Triple Crown, the first, in 1919, and the last, in 1978. California Chrome will aim to become the 12th in Saturday’s Belmont Stakes.
lead_paragraph: Horse racing fans are used to the disappointment. Eleven times a horse has come into the Belmont Stakes having won the first two legs of the Triple Crown in the years since Affirmed captured the last one in 1978. Eleven times, it didn’t happen. Each came with such possibility, and each left with heartbreak. When Spectacular Bid was outgunned down the stretch by Coastal in 1979, no one knew the drumbeat of failure that was ahead, that would become the unofficial background music of the Belmont.

headline: Scottish Independence Debate Will Reach Edinburgh Fringe Festival
abstract: The annual event, which runs Aug. 1 to 25, is scheduled to include almost 3,200 shows.
lead_paragraph: When David Bowie was named best British male solo artist at the Brit Awards in February, his acceptance speech, read on his behalf by Kate Moss, included the plea “Scotland, stay with us,” and he thus entered the divisive public debate over Scottish independence, which will come to a vote in September. Mr. Bowie’s phrase is the inspiration for “All Back to Bowie’s,” a freewheeling and decidedly political presentation by a group of Scottish artists, including David Greig and Cora Bissett, that is planned for this summer at the annual Edinburgh Festival Fringe. The show will include poetry, music and more in a variety format that will be different at each performance.

She wondered whether the process is particularly challenging only for smaller companies just starting out.

headline: A Slowly Roasted Fish to Serve With Portuguese White Wines
abstract: After exactly an hour in the oven, a whole fish emerges perfectly cooked, with silken flesh.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes I take the “What if?” approach to cooking and have had more successes than errors. A few weeks ago I decided to roast some stunningly fresh ocean perch whole. But what if, instead of my usual hot-roasting method, I wrapped the fish tightly in parchment and put it in a slow oven? I was risking $18 worth of fish and the prospect of takeout for dinner. I guessed that the fish, about two pounds, might need an hour and reasoned that succulence might define the end result.

abstract: Portugal is setting its own course, avoiding global trends in favor of intriguing local vines.
lead_paragraph: Of all the historical wine-producing countries, Portugal is the most overlooked.

headline: More Fathers Who Stay at Home by Choice
abstract: A shift reveals a structural change in gender roles in family and at work underway in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Otis Johnson said he never fathomed becoming a stay-at-home father. But soon after he was laid off from his factory job in 2009, his first of two children arrived. And even when his job prospects improved, he made the calculation that millions of mothers had made before him: “By the time I get a paycheck, it all goes to day care, or I can stay home and raise my own children.”

lead_paragraph: Susan Spencer-Wendel, a former newspaper reporter who wrote a best-selling memoir about living life to the fullest after learning she had an incurable muscle-wasting disease — and wrote most of it on a smartphone with her right thumb — died on Wednesday at her home in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 47.

lead_paragraph: One of the world’s most precious troves of looted antiquities — brilliantly colored burial shrouds from an Andean civilization that flourished a thousand years before Columbus — is on its way back to Peru for a ceremonial handover in Lima.

lead_paragraph: While on a state visit to Warsaw to mark the 25th anniversary of the end of communism in Poland, President Obama took time out to pump some iron in a hotel gym — though not a lot of it. A leaked video showing him grunting and grimacing under the weight of what appeared to be a modest set of dumbbells drew attention from observers who seemed underwhelmed.

headline: The Gun Report: June 5, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: When most people think of Google Glass, they imagine Sergey Brin bopping around town sporting wiry, futuristic spectacles that make phone calls, go online and record everything you see. A growing number of people equate the new technology with concerns over privacy violation—so much so that Glass pioneers, who are easily identified by their headsets, have been discriminated against in public settings. Few equate the burgeoning technology with guns. But that may change.

headline: The Rush to Demonize Sgt. Bergdahl
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Desertion (Military)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The sergeant is being attacked in the absence of actual facts.
lead_paragraph: Four months ago, Senator John McCain said he would support the exchange of five hard-core Taliban leaders for the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl. “I would support,” he told CNN. “Obviously I’d have to know the details, but I would support ways of bringing him home and if exchange was one of them I think that would be something I think we should seriously consider.”

headline: Hard-Boiled
abstract: With one eye on Philip Marlowe, Stephen King takes a crack at the detective novel.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through “Mr. Mercedes,” billed as Stephen King’s first hard-boiled detective novel, a fedora makes an appearance. It’s a winking gift to the retired cop hero, Bill Hodges, from his first client, Janey Patterson. “Every private dick should have a fedora he can pull down to one eyebrow,” she tells him. Hodges tries it on for size, as do Jerome (his teenage Watson) and even Janey herself. No one seems to hang on to it for long. Then, at a critical point in the story, it disappears in a flash.

headline: Man on a Mission
abstract: From farmer to president to Nobel laureate, Jimmy Carter has been a voice of progressive evangelicalism.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Carter may be the most pious man ever to have occupied the White House. He was “born again” at age 11 and has taught Sunday school for decades. His penchant for godliness has ranged from prophetic — he was most likely the only businessman in 1950s Plains, Ga., to refuse to join the White Citizens’ Council — to priggish: As president, he once told civil servants who were “living in sin” that they ought to get married.

headline: The Poster Child for Menopause
abstract: When Sandra Tsing Loh started her book “The Madwoman in the Volvo,” her aim was to capture the experience of what she calls the “triple-M generation:” the menopausal, middle-aged mother.
lead_paragraph: When Sandra Tsing Loh started her book “The Madwoman in the Volvo,” her aim was to capture the experience of what she calls the “triple-M generation:” the menopausal, middle-aged mother.

headline: Tanaka (9-1) Stops the A’s, and the Yankees’ Slide
abstract: The Yankees scored only two runs, but starter Masahiro Tanaka, who improved to 9-1, was dependable again, winning the final game of a 2-5 homestand.
lead_paragraph: Early in the season, even when the Yankees’ starting rotation was at the vanguard of their success, there was always an extra jolt of excitement when Masahiro Tanaka took the mound.

headline: Mary Anthony, Choreographer and Teacher of Modern Dance, Dies at 97
abstract: Students of Ms. Anthony included some of American dance’s leading figures, like Donald McKayle and Arthur Mitchell.
lead_paragraph: Mary Anthony, a modern dancer celebrated since the 1940s for the lyricism and drama in her choreography but even better known as a teacher of some of American dance’s leading performers and choreographers, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 97.

headline: Peter Glaser, Who Envisioned Space Solar Power, Dies at 90
abstract: Dr. Glaser’s concept for harnessing solar energy was deemed credible enough for the government to spend $20 million studying it, only to conclude it was too expensive.
lead_paragraph: Peter Glaser, who in the late 1960s envisioned a way to harness limitless solar power in space and transmit it for use on Earth via invisible microwaves — a notion so intriguing that the government spent $20 million studying it, only to conclude that it was too complex and expensive — died on May 29 at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 90.

headline: Harvard Confirms Book Is Bound in Human Skin
abstract: A 19th-century French treatise in the university’s libraries is almost surely bound in human skin, according to scientists who tested it.
lead_paragraph: Scientists at Harvard have confirmed that a 19th-century French treatise in the university’s libraries is almost surely bound in human skin, thus ending months of uncertainty and setting off a torrent of online Hannibal Lecter (get it?) jokes.

headline: Accident Prone
abstract: In this story collection, mishap is never far away.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth McCracken knows how loss can melt reality, forever altering a person’s sense of time. In “An Exact Replica of a Figment of My Imagination,” a deeply affecting memoir about the stillbirth of her son, she tells us that she sought to write “a book that acknowledges that life goes on but that death goes on, too, that a person who is dead is a long, long story.” In her new collection, McCracken gives brilliantly splintered life to just that kind of story: These pages are filled with sudden deaths and lingering ghosts, some passings that are imminent, others that are uncertain or inferred.

headline: An Education
abstract: A novel of college life in South Korea’s politically turbulent 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Translated books make up only about 3 percent of titles published in America, so I’m ecstatic to see the Korean writer Kyung-sook Shin’s rising popularity. Her previously translated novel, “Please Look After Mom,” hit the New York Times best-seller list and is now available in more than 20 countries.

headline: An Inner Life
abstract: Kimberly Elkins’s “What Is Visible” is a fictional biography of Laura Bridgman, who lost her sight, hearing, and senses of smell and taste as a baby.
lead_paragraph: “What Is Visible,” a fictional biography, opens with two disparate glimpses of one life. A year before her death, elderly Laura Bridgman meets a busy-handed child named Helen Keller. Next we witness a much earlier historic encounter when Laura, at 12, meets Charles Dickens. The elder Laura is grumpy; the adolescent loops between self-aggrandizement and epic self-doubt. We’re asked to forgive all, because of circumstances more dire than any invented by Dickens or borne by Keller. As a baby, Laura suffered an illness that took her sight, hearing, and senses of smell and taste.

headline: REPLAY
abstract: With an eye on today’s events, looking anew at historical sports photographs from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: With an eye on today’s events, looking anew at historical sports photographs from The New York Times.

headline: Asia Society Museum Director to Lead Hirshhorn
abstract: Melissa Chiu, the Asia Society Museum director, is named the new leader of the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Chiu, the Australian-born, veteran director of Asia Society Museum in New York has been chosen to lead the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, a Smithsonian division that is trying to regain its footing after a series of bruising fights over finances, leadership and direction.

headline: Snatching Atari Back From the Grave, Again
abstract: Atari, the pioneering video game company, emerged from bankruptcy last December and is now developing new products in a bid to make itself relevant to a generation that wasn’t alive during its heyday in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: It’s a fitting symbol for Atari that the most attention it has received in years occurred when one of its products, a notorious flop, was excavated from a landfill in April.

headline: ‘Citizen Koch’ and the Politics of Big Money
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: The limits of what an individual can do in the face of well-financed opposition are shown throughout this documentary, which looks at the effects of the Citizens United Supreme Court case.
lead_paragraph: Part of the impact of “Citizen Koch” comes from juxtaposing average Americans with the moneyed interests that grip today’s political process. When we see a Republican in Wisconsin weighing her dissatisfaction with her party and her stance on abortion, it’s an inspiring sight of a citizen at work, grappling in good faith with the situation at hand. It’s a world away from the documentary’s portrayal of Americans for Prosperity, the conservative advocacy group funded by the billionaires David and Charles Koch.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Burning Woman
abstract: Sandra Tsing Loh’s memoir of her roller-coaster ride through “the change.”
lead_paragraph: If menopause just made you want to kill someone, it wouldn’t be so bad. The problem is, it makes you want to kill someone you love. And then it makes you want to love someone who’s a complete and utter moron. And there you have it: the story of half the divorces in America.

headline: Over There: Daughters of Liberty
abstract: Women’s vivid personal accounts of World War I, from the front lines, are the subject of a show opening next week at the Massachusetts Historical Society in Boston.
lead_paragraph: ON A WAR’S FRONT LINE, FROM A WOMAN’S VIEW

headline: A Passionate Symbol, Even Without the World Cup
abstract: “This Is Not a Ball” is a soccer documentary that focuses primarily on the ball itself.
lead_paragraph: In “Waste Land,” Lucy Walker’s Oscar-nominated 2010 documentary, the Brazilian photographer Vik Muniz trekked around a garbage dump and collaborated with its workers in the name of art. It was topical, revelatory and inspirational. In “This Is Not a Ball,” directed by Mr. Muniz and Juan Rendón, the artist has another project — a piece for the 2014 World Cup (less than a week away!) involving 10,000 balls — but the process of documenting it only bogs down this film.

headline: New Bug Found in Widely Used OpenSSL Encryption
abstract: Just two months after Heartbleed, a new bug in OpenSSL, the widely used encryption protocol, has been discovered. But this bug was exploitable for far longer.
lead_paragraph: Security experts are still trying to plug the hole left by Heartbleed, the bug found in the widely used OpenSSL encryption protocol, with some 12,000 popular domains still vulnerable, according to AVG Virus Labs.

headline: A Taste of Charleston, Old-School and New
abstract: Go on a restaurant crawl through downtown, starting with a new spot that’s spiced with intriguingly weird ideas and ending with a classic place where formality is leavened by a lighthearted spirit.
lead_paragraph: Rain was falling in fits and starts on a late afternoon in downtown Charleston, and sodden azalea blossoms were scattered across the sidewalk along Queen Street.

headline: Chic Stops in the Suburbs of La Paz, Bolivia
abstract: The center of the city’s gentrification is now the Zona Sur, which sits 1,000 feet lower and is noticeably warmer than the far more visited colonial city center.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in a long time, La Paz is having a moment. And the center of the city’s gentrification is now the Zona Sur — made up of four adjoining suburban neighborhoods — which sits 1,000 feet lower and is noticeably warmer than the far more visited colonial city center, a 15-minute taxi ride away. Pushed along by a culinary project from Claus Meyer, co-founder of Noma in Copenhagen, the well-heeled area has seen an influx of modern additions that the Andean city has long lacked.

headline: For Kentile Floors Sign, Star of Brooklyn Skyline, the End Seems Near
abstract: The eight-story-high neon sign will be removed, according to a city permit, but a broker who represents the owners of the building where the sign sits said they have no plans to demolish it.
lead_paragraph: The language of the plans recently approved by the New York City Buildings Department seems unambiguous:

headline: World Cup Crib Sheet: Judging a Fan’s Soccer I.Q. by His Jargon
abstract: Watch the World Cup like a true fanatic — or at least sound like one. Learn the right phrases to yell at the screen while watching the matches.
lead_paragraph: We continue our series of crib sheets designed to help readers watch the World Cup like a true fanatic — or at least sound like one. Learn the right phrases to yell at the screen while watching the matches.

headline: Heaven and Earth, Sized to Grasp
abstract: The Morgan Library & Museum offers exhibitions of Renaissance manuscript illuminations by the Claude Master and Romantic landscapes from Britain and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Paper is the mother lode of the Morgan Library & Museum, and one of the great through lines of civilizations everywhere. Nearly every Morgan exhibition, whether of prints, drawings, rare books or musical scores, enlarges the understanding of paper as a means of expression, both personal and cultural. Right now, windows are being opened there by two delightfully focused exhibitions that center on artists using paper to different ends, in different centuries and parts of Europe.

headline: A Star Client List and a Magic Touch
abstract: The comedian Mike Myers directs the documentary “Supermensch,” about the talent manager Shep Gordon.
lead_paragraph: A valentine from one friend to another, “Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon” is not entirely kidding about that title, or at least its tone. Directed by the comedian Mike Myers, this clubby documentary lauds the swellness and shrewdness of the talent manager Shep Gordon with the help of celebrities and the sunnily mellifluent subject himself.

headline: On View | Henrik Vibskov, Fashion’s Renaissance Man, Showcases His Fine Art
abstract: The Danish multihyphenate — soon to design costumes for Bjork’s opera — has an art show at Ruttkowski;68 in Cologne.
lead_paragraph: With the Paris men’s collections just a few weeks away, the Danish fashion designer Henrik Vibskov is busy at work. But it’s not just clothing that’s on his mind. When he spoke to T, he was busy putting the finishing touches on “Vibskovski;72 II,” his new solo exhibition at the Cologne art space Ruttkowski;68. He’d also submitted the first proposals for a collaboration with his fellow Nordic multihyphenate Björk, a supersize restaging of her album “Medúlla.” And then there’s the fragrance he’s developing, the upcoming art exhibitions in Moscow and Seoul, a set design for this month’s Roskilde Festival and a handful or so of other projects in progress listed on the pink sticky notes on his computer.

headline: At a Wedding, You Are What You Wear
abstract: For the bridal party and family, in particular, the road to fashion is paved with peril.
lead_paragraph: I’m going to a wedding this summer, which means once again I am dealing with the sleeve problem. You ladies of a certain age know what I am talking about. There comes a time in your life, even if you have a personal trainer and are taking your meals in the gym, when the muscles and skin on your inner upper arms give up. It’s as if they’re saying: “Oh, the hell with it. Where’s the bar?” They’re just hanging off the bone, exhausted.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from South Africa, Israel, South Korea and France.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Africa, Israel, South Korea and France.

headline: At Museum Born of Politics, New Chief Faces Economics
abstract: After losing a director and then dismissing another, El Museo del Barrio is hatching ambitious plans to widen its focus to all of Latin America under its new director, Jorge Daniel Veneciano.
lead_paragraph: A little over a year ago, El Museo del Barrio, the oldest museum in the United States devoted to Latino art, had the equivalent of a nervous breakdown in public.

headline: Pining for a Burnished Time, Long Ago and Far Away
abstract: “The Pre-Raphaelite Legacy,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a modest introduction to one of 19th-century Britain’s most interesting backward-looking groups.
lead_paragraph: As in politics, so in art: Some movements want to hasten us into the future, some want to turn back the clocks to a supposedly better time. “The Pre-Raphaelite Legacy: British Art and Design,” a small exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a modest introduction to one of the 19th century’s most interesting backward-looking groups.

headline: A Few Carcasses Here, a Few Landscapes There
abstract: “Life in Death: Still Lifes and Select Masterworks of Chaim Soutine” at the Paul Kasmin Gallery consists of 16 paintings by Soutine, the Belarus-born Expressionist.
lead_paragraph: The lines between museums and galleries have become blurry, with major Chelsea dealers mounting scholarly, historical exhibitions. But it takes more than just great material to achieve a “museum quality” show, as you are reminded at the Paul Kasmin Gallery exhibition of 16 paintings by the Belarus-born Expressionist Chaim Soutine (1893-1943).

headline: The Parent Trap
abstract: Addressing matters of parenting, dishonesty, flings and best-friend breakups.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a long birthday party, my son put his hands around my nephew’s neck. (The boys are 7 and 4.) My brother-in-law yelled at my son before my husband had a chance to address the situation. My husband demanded we leave immediately. My son, who has some special needs, got upset and began screaming that he hated his uncle and called him selfish and stupid. A subsequent talk with my sister did not go well. She downplayed her husband’s yelling and thinks we should have corrected my son for his outburst. I disagree. No one yells at my son but me. Ideas?

headline: ‘Common Spaces’
abstract: The title of this show refers to terrain that should be public property but isn’t, unless political action is taken to make it so.
lead_paragraph: The Kitchen

headline: Jay DeFeo
abstract: This exhibition of drawings, photographs and photocopies finds DeFeo moving past her ponderous masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: Mitchell-Innes & Nash

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: sunburned teenagers, MERS and MRSA. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: sunburned teenagers, MERS and MRSA. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Ibrahim El-Salahi: ‘Selected Works, 1962-2010’
abstract: This is a miniature reprise of a retrospective devoted to the Sudanese artist Ibrahim El-Salahi, a leading figure in African and Arab modernism.
lead_paragraph: Skoto Gallery

headline: Joyce Robins: ‘Paint and Clay’
abstract: Flat reigns here in both circular and rectilinear wall pieces that date from 2002 to the present.
lead_paragraph: Theodore:Art

headline: Fund Manager Sets Goats Grazing in Blighted Detroit
abstract: The financier Mark Spitznagel brought 20 billy goats to graze on overgrown grass among abandoned homes and general detritus.
lead_paragraph: To most of the world, the solution to debt-ridden Detroit is money. But for one hedge fund manager, it’s goats.

headline: What I’m Reading
abstract: A stack of books about soccer, thanks to the coming World Cup, is on her nightstand.
lead_paragraph: On my nightstand right now is a stack of books about soccer. They were part of my plan to write a column called, at least in my own mind, “How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the World Cup.” (Columnists don’t choose the headlines).

headline: Shoo-Ins Are Few in Heated Tony Race
abstract: While most races in this year’s Tony Awards are fiercely competitive, interviews with 40 of 800 voters yield some informed predictions of who will triumph Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: IN a departure from recent Tony Awards seasons, when popular musicals like “The Book of Mormon,” “Once,” and “Kinky Boots” were dominant, voters for Sunday’s prizes are likely to spread them around. But among which shows? Which performers and artists? Making predictions is unusually difficult this year, with few clear-cut favorites, more wild cards than usual and some fierce races involving Hollywood stars, veteran stage actors and past Tony winners.

headline: Clip: ‘Edge of Tomorrow’
abstract: A scene from the film featuring Tom Cruise and Emily Blunt.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film featuring Tom Cruise and Emily Blunt.

headline: Killed in Action by Aliens, Over and Over Again
abstract: In “Edge of Tomorrow,” Tom Cruise plays a military man caught in a time loop, destined to battle invading aliens day after day in a repeating bid to save Earth from Armageddon.
lead_paragraph: Tell me if you’ve heard this one before. A man wakes up and quickly realizes that he’s repeating yesterday, down to the last meal, salutation and conversation. He’s trapped in a kind of time loop. He can’t escape, but, he realizes, he can change. That may not make sense, given the logic of the space-time continuum, but it works just fine in fiction because, well, it’s fiction. To put it another way, “There are no paradoxes in time travel, there can’t be.” Or so says a character in Robert A. Heinlein’s 1964 novel, “Farnham’s Freehold,” about space, time and the apocalypse.

headline: Celebrating in Prospect Park
abstract: Celebrate Brooklyn!, in its 36th year, will put on a series of free concerts by an all-star lineup.
lead_paragraph: Celebrate Brooklyn!, in its 36th year, will put on a series of free concerts by an all-star lineup.

headline: For Father’s Day in London, a Brawnier Tea
abstract: A Father’s Day tea at the Milestone Hotel in London will include ales, Scotch, and Cornish pasties.
lead_paragraph: In honor of Father’s Day on June 15, the Milestone Hotel in London’s Kensington neighborhood is offering “Gentleman’s Afternoon Tea.”

headline: Guggenheim Abu Dhabi Plans a Preview Show
abstract: The Guggenheim Abu Dhabi isn’t going to open for a couple of years, but a fall exhibition will offer a small preview of its collection.
lead_paragraph: The Guggenheim Abu Dhabi, one of three museums being built on the windswept Saadiyat Island in the capital of the United Arab Emirates, has been a quieter presence than the two other institutions there. The Louvre Abu Dhabi, designed by the French architect Jean Nouvel, which is scheduled to open next year, and the Zayed National Museum, created by the British architect Norman Foster and to be completed in two years, have each had exhibitions at Manarat Al Saadiyat, the island’s exhibition and visitor center, offering previews of their institutions. Now it is the Guggenheim’s turn.

headline: The Islands Treasured by Offshore Tax Avoiders
keywords: ['Tax Shelters', 'Corporate Taxes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: United States companies told the I.R.S. that they earned $129 billion in 2010 in Bermuda, the Cayman Islands and the British Virgin Islands, but their real earnings are more complex.
lead_paragraph: Did you know that United States companies earned $129 billion in 2010 in three small groups of islands?

headline: Clip: ‘Obvious Child’
abstract: A scene from the film, featuring Jenny Slate and Jake Lacy.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, featuring Jenny Slate and Jake Lacy.

headline: Right Guy Is Just One in a World of Choices
abstract: The cautious yet funny rom-com “Obvious Child” stars Jenny Slate as a Brooklyn woman who faces an unexpected pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: We first encounter Donna Stern, the 28-ish heroine of Gillian Robespierre’s “Obvious Child,” doing standup in a ratty Brooklyn club, putting her own idiosyncratic spin on the currently popular style of boundaryless, confessional, body-conscious humor. Donna is played by Jenny Slate, whose résumé (“Saturday Night Live,” “Parks and Recreation,” “Bob’s Burgers”) reads like a Google map of the modern comic universe and who easily juggles the sweet and nasty sides of her temperament.

headline: Pro Wrestlers Add Heft to Campaign for Better Parenting by Fathers
abstract: The Advertising Council, World Wrestling Entertainment and three of its wrestlers have teamed up to produce commercials to persuade men with children to be better fathers by becoming more involved with their children.
lead_paragraph: THE Advertising Council is joining forces with World Wrestling Entertainment on a public service campaign promoting the importance of men being better fathers.

headline: A Regent of Retro and Future
abstract: Janelle Monáe held court in her free show of retro-futurist R&B to kick off the 36th Celebrate Brooklyn! series, with an enormous overflow audience.
lead_paragraph: Every narrative needs a tension, and in the kinetic, fantastical saga of Janelle Monáe’s career, it boils down to the tug-of-war between abandon and control. At the Prospect Park Bandshell on Wednesday night, she was wheeled onstage in a straitjacket, her posture and pompadour briefly evoking the Bride of Frankenstein. Breaking free, she headed straight into “Givin Em What They Love,” a prowling funk processional whose title refrain lands somewhere between a boast and a pledge.

headline: A Home Invader, Creepily Charismatic
abstract: In Alex van Warmerdam’s malevolent adult fairy tale, “Borgman,” an enigmatic, beady-eyed drifter intrudes on the lives of a rich suburban family.
lead_paragraph: There is no one who resembles a sleeping princess, a fairy godmother or a dashing romantic savior in the Dutch filmmaker Alex van Warmerdam’s malevolent adult fairy tale, “Borgman.” The story’s magic is black, its perfidy driven by evil spirits.

lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Days After a Federal Seizure, Another Type of Ransomware Gains Ground
abstract: Just days after federal agents seized two computer networks used to distribute ransomware, security researchers said a new exploit kit was being used to distribute ransomware with disturbing success rates.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It has been mere days since federal agents seized control of computer networks used by hackers to infect victims with CryptoLocker, a piece of malware known as “ransomware,” which encrypts the contents of computing devices so hackers can demand a ransom to decrypt it.

headline: Unanswered Questions From G.M.’s Report
abstract: Matthew L. Wald, a Times business reporter, had three unanswered questions after the release of an internal investigation into General Motors’ ignition switch problems.
lead_paragraph: Matthew L. Wald, a Times business reporter, had three unanswered questions after the release of an internal investigation into General Motors’ ignition switch problems.

headline: 70 Years After D-Day, Veterans Return to Normandy
keywords: ['Veterans', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: With the youngest participants in the 1944 storming of five Normandy beaches now 88, these anniversary commemorations may be, for many, the last memorial pilgrimage.
lead_paragraph: With the youngest participants in the 1944 storming of five Normandy beaches now 88, these anniversary commemorations may be, for many, the last memorial pilgrimage.

headline: A Scary Experience With Edible Marijuana
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Maureen Dowd about using legal marijuana in Colorado.

headline: This Week’s Movies | June 6, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Obvious Child,” “The Fault in Our Stars” and “Edge of Tomorrow.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Obvious Child,” “The Fault in Our Stars” and “Edge of Tomorrow.”

headline: European Central Bank on Inflation Fight
abstract: The European Central Bank president, Mario Draghi, announced several measures to fight low inflation and boost the euro zone economy.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank president, Mario Draghi, announced several measures to fight low inflation and boost the euro zone economy.

headline: Fixes After BP Spill Not Enough, Board Says
keywords: ['Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)']
abstract: A report from the federal Chemical Safety Board said another disastrous offshore oil well blowout could happen despite regulatory improvements.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Federal safety regulators warned on Thursday that another disastrous offshore oil well blowout could happen despite regulatory improvements in the four years since a BP well explosion in the Gulf of Mexico killed 11 workers and dumped millions of gallons of oil into the sea.

headline: With Obama and Putin in France for Dinner, Hollande Leaves Room for Seconds
abstract: President François Hollande of France rushed to the presidential palace for a dinner with the Russian leader after hosting one with President Obama at a fancy restaurant in town.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Gourmand though he may be, it seems highly improbable that President François Hollande of France was moved by appetite alone to host two successive dinners here on Thursday night.

headline: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for June 6-12
abstract: A selected guide to pop, rock and cabaret concerts in the New York City area, as well as music festivals.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: In Memoir, Hillary Clinton Discusses Russia, Syria and Iraq
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature', 'United States International Relations', 'News and News Media']
abstract: In her memoir “Hard Choices,” Hillary Rodham Clinton weaves personal and political tales, according to CBS News, which obtained a copy before the book’s scheduled publication next week.
lead_paragraph: In her memoir “Hard Choices,” Hillary Rodham Clinton writes about the United States’ troubled “reset” with Russia, says her vote authorizing the war in Iraq was “wrong,” calls Syria a “wicked problem” and gives a timetable of the raid that led to the death of Osama bin Laden, according to CBS News, which obtained a copy of the book before its publication next week.

headline: Verizon Challenges Netflix’s Warning Messages Blaming It for Slow Streaming Service
abstract: The dust-up comes after the companies agreed that Netflix could pay Verizon to connect directly to its network, creating a faster connection that bypasses the go-between that carries most content through the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Verizon fired back at Netflix on Thursday after it was revealed that Netflix showed its customers an error message blaming Verizon’s network for slowing the streaming of Netflix’s programming.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for June 6-12
abstract: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in New York.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Tea Party Dead-Enders
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A legacy of no significant legislation, no changes for the better in American life, no compromise with the majority of voters. It could have been worse.
lead_paragraph: The Tea Party is five years old this election season, which means it’s done teething and spitting up on itself, but still prone to temper tantrums, irrational outbursts and threats to take its toys and storm off if it doesn’t get its way.

headline: Spare Times for Children for June 6-12
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: SPROUTFEST

headline: In Brazen Strike, Sunni Militants Storm Central Iraqi City
abstract: The offensive provided the latest evidence of the militants’ strength in Iraq, six months after hard-line Islamist fighters seized the western city of Falluja.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Hundreds of Sunni militants stormed the central Iraqi city of Samarra early Thursday, taking control of neighborhoods and government buildings in a siege that provoked a panicked government counteroffensive to prevent the loss of the town.

headline: The Climate Domino
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The E.P.A.’s proposed rules on carbon should start a chain reaction that leads to steps to limit climate change around the world.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s me, but the predictable right-wing cries of outrage over the Environmental Protection Agency’s proposed rules on carbon seem oddly muted and unfocused. I mean, these are the people who managed to create national outrage over nonexistent death panels. Now the Obama administration is doing something that really will impose at least some pain on some people. Where are the eye-catching fake horror stories?

headline: Spare Times for June 6-12
abstract: A guide to street fairs, parades, literary events, performances and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and Sites

headline: The Political War
abstract: How the Union defeat at Cold Harbor reverberated all the way to the White House.
lead_paragraph: Pity Abraham Lincoln. Everything that should have gone right for the Union cause in the spring of 1864 had, in just a few weeks, gone defiantly and disastrously wrong.

headline: Where Bigfoot Roamed
abstract: “Willow Creek” is a work of restraint rarely seen from its writer and director, Bobcat Goldthwait.
lead_paragraph: As a comedian, Bobcat Goldthwait can seem like a colicky baby, spitting punch lines punctuated by random screams. As a filmmaker, however, he’s more focused and less predictable, channeling his choleric style into pointed satires on American society that sometimes hit their marks with uncomfortable directness.

headline: It Takes Some Heat to Create Movie Stars
abstract: “Trust Me,” written and directed by Clark Gregg, stars Mr. Gregg as a scuffling, obsequious agent specializing in child actors.
lead_paragraph: Until it disintegrates in an explosion of sentimentality, “Trust Me” qualifies for what could be called “The Day of the Locust” award. That imaginary honor, named for the Nathanael West novel, would be bestowed on the year’s nastiest, most stomach-turning movie about no-holds-barred Hollywood wheeling and dealing. Such films are usually box office poison, but they still are made, perhaps because they give their creators a chance to vent.

headline: Clip: ‘Ping Pong Summer’
abstract: A scene from the film, directed by Michael Tully.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, directed by Michael Tully.

headline: It’s 1985 All Over Again
abstract: Michael Tully’s “Ping Pong Summer” centers on a teenager and his family’s seaside vacation in Ocean City, Md., three decades ago.
lead_paragraph: From its revenge-of-the-nerd narrative to its soaked-in-nostalgia style, “Ping Pong Summer” revisits the 1980s with such slavish affection that you suspect its writer and director, Michael Tully, of being notably transformed during those boom-box-blighted years. The film fairly beams with the afterglow of lost virginity.

headline: Shifts in Wireless Market May Sway a Sprint Deal
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: The two companies say their merger would add a strong competitor to a market now dominated by AT&T and Verizon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the view of Sprint and T-Mobile USA, less is more.

headline: President Obama Was Right
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: National solidarity is essential to the health of the country. And President Obama’s prisoner swap for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl nurtured that sentiment.
lead_paragraph: Americans don’t have a common ancestry. Therefore, we have to work hard to build national solidarity. We go in for more overt displays of patriotism than in most other countries: politicians wearing flag lapel pins, everybody singing the national anthem before games, saying the Pledge of Allegiance at big meetings, revering sacred creedal statements, like the Gettysburg Address.

headline: Did Colorado Go Too Far With Pot?
abstract: Was the move to legalize marijuana done too quickly? Do changes need to be made to their approach?

headline: Nigerian Sect Kills Villagers Along Border
abstract: That massacre in the village of Attagara was the bloodiest in a series of attacks by Boko Haram this week in Nigeria’s far north, according to officials.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The Boko Haram men, disguised in army uniforms, gathered the villagers together and promised them protection.

headline: Back Where He Belonged: An All-Satchmo Day
abstract: More than 40 years after Louis Armstrong’s death, it’s possible to spend a virtual day with him in New York, including a visit to Armstrong’s longtime home in Queens, now a museum.
lead_paragraph: MAYBE it was the 50th anniversary of “Hello, Dolly” having knocked the Beatles off the top of the pop charts (May 9, 1964), but it occurred to me recently that with a little advance work, I could spend an entire day in New York with Louis Armstrong.

headline: Louis and Lucille Armstrong’s Creole Red Beans and Rice
abstract: A recipe courtesy of Louis Armstrong House Museum.
lead_paragraph: Courtesy of Louis Armstrong House Museum Time: 6 hours

headline: Key Questions in the Release of Bowe Bergdahl
abstract: Sorting out the facts and the controversy surrounding the release of the lone American prisoner of war from the Afghan conflict.
lead_paragraph: Sorting out the facts and the controversy surrounding the release of the lone American prisoner of war from the Afghan conflict.

headline: Steven H. Scheuer Is Dead at 88; He Put the TV Review Before the Show
abstract: Mr. Scheuer provided guidance to viewers with the “TV Key” column and the “TV Movie Almanac & Ratings.”
lead_paragraph: Steven H. Scheuer, a television critic who helped change how newspapers reviewed programs and thus how viewers decided what to watch, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: House Democrats Set Off to Energize the Faithful, With a Focus on Women
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', "Women's Rights", 'Road Trips', 'Women and Girls', 'Buses', 'Elections, State Legislature']
abstract: In a politically gloomy midterm election year for Democrats, Representative Nancy Pelosi and some of her House colleagues revved up small but enthusiastic crowds to turn out the vote.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — It is a politically gloomy midterm election year for Democrats, but Representative Nancy Pelosi and some of her House colleagues were on a roll this week.

headline: Researchers Race to Save Coral in Miami
keywords: ['Reefs', 'Coral', 'Ports', 'Building (Construction)', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: With dredging set to begin this weekend in the Port of Miami, researchers are scrambling to salvage a much larger than expected trove of corals.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — With dredging set to begin this weekend in the Port of Miami, researchers are scrambling to salvage a much larger than expected trove of delicate corals that were not in the original marine life rescue plan for the undersea area.

headline: Belatedly, Europe Takes On Low Inflation
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Credit and Debt', 'Government Bonds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Central Bank has taken some steps, but they need to be matched by government actions if the economy is to recover.
lead_paragraph: After months of doing too little, the European Central Bank on Thursday announced a series of policies to bolster the euro zone’s frail economy and avert deflation, which would weaken it even further.

headline: Where Some May Say No Thanks for the Memories
abstract: A half-built shopping center is slowly being turned into a monument to Boris N. Yeltsin, the ebullient, erratic leader who served as Russia’s first elected president from 1991 to 1999.
lead_paragraph: YEKATERINBURG, Russia — On the embankment of the lake at the heart of this city in the Urals, a half-built shopping center is slowly being turned into a monument to a man and an era that few in Russia remember fondly at all, even in the man’s native region.

headline: A Horror Story Borrows From History
abstract: In “The Sacrament,” written and directed by Ti West, two journalists accompany a man traveling to meet his sister, a recovering addict, at a compound in a foreign country.
lead_paragraph: The director Ti West, whose credits include the very fine horror movie “The House of the Devil,” has a talent for dread. He’s so good at raising the little hairs on your neck and keeping them on alert that you can only feel let down when he doesn’t deliver a movie that makes good on his setup. That’s the case with his latest, “The Sacrament,” a neo-exploitation flick that shifts from the unnerving to the hollow after it becomes evident that Mr. West is more interested in showing how his characters die than how they lived. It doesn’t help that he seems to encourage you to wish the worst on at least some of them, notably a troika that serves as this tale’s metaphoric blind mice.

headline: Clip: ‘The Sacrament’
abstract: A scene from “The Sacrament,” directed by Ti West.
lead_paragraph: A scene from “The Sacrament,” directed by Ti West.

headline: Soaring, and Souring, in Postseason Spotlight
abstract: The Kings’ Justin Williams, a decent offensive producer in the regular season, is a monster during the playoffs. The Rangers’ Rick Nash, a big-ticket goal scorer, has been virtually unable to score in the postseason.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Kings’ Justin Williams, a decent offensive producer in the regular season, is a monster during the playoffs. The Rangers’ Rick Nash, a big-ticket goal scorer in the regular season, has been virtually unable to score in the postseason.

headline: Remembering D-Day With Their Brothers in Arms
abstract: Friday marks the 70th anniversary of the Allied invasion of Normandy — June 6, 1944. Three residents of the Long Island State Veterans Home recall what it was like on the ground.
lead_paragraph: STONY BROOK, N.Y. — Every morning, Lieutenant Michael Settanni wakes up next to his bunkmate, Cpl. Ben Gebbia, in a modest room in a home shared with about 350 other military men.

headline: An Old Warplane’s Do-Over Flight in France
abstract: The New York-based Whiskey 7 plane revisits the skies it last braved during World War II.
lead_paragraph: Revisiting the skies it last braved during World War II, the New York-based war horse known as the Whiskey 7 was back over Normandy on Thursday, once again opening its doors and letting parachutists jump into the frigid air outside, 70 years after its — and the world’s — most famous invasion.

headline: Clip: ‘The Case Against 8’
abstract: A scene from the documentary.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the documentary.

headline: After Heartbreak, Time for Results
keywords: ['Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Cameras', 'Editorials', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: There is no excuse for the absence of surveillance cameras in the city’s housing projects, an absence that was emphasized after the fatal stabbing of a boy in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Rapid, aggressive police work led to the arrest on Wednesday of a suspect in the shocking stabbings of two children in a Brooklyn public-housing elevator on Sunday.

headline: A Tale That Nearly Had No End
keywords: ['Movies', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: “The Case Against 8” documents the same-sex-marriage case that took four years to wind its way to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: As gay men living in California, Ben Cotner and Ryan White were “flabbergasted,” Mr. White recalled, by the passage of Proposition 8, their state’s 2008 ballot measure to deny the right of same-sex couples to marry. They didn’t expect it to win.

headline: On a Team of Stars, Only One Plays Like It
abstract: The Yankees won again on Thursday behind Masahiro Tanaka, who has produced results in line with his reputation, unlike other big names on the team.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, you really can predict baseball — at least when Masahiro Tanaka pitches. Those other days are the troublesome ones for the Yankees.

headline: Chester Nez, 93, Dies; Navajo Words Washed From Mouth Helped Win War
keywords: ['Navajo Indians', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Language and Languages', 'Cryptography, Codes and Ciphers']
abstract: Mr. Nez helped fashion from his Navajo language a military code so impervious that it helped the United States secure victory in the Pacific in the summer of 1945.
lead_paragraph: To the end of his life, Chester Nez recalled the first message he sent over the radio while serving at Guadalcanal: “Enemy machine gun nest on your right. Destroy.”

headline: A Legal Chess Game Leading to ‘I Do’
keywords: ['Movies', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The documentary “The Case Against 8” portrays the harrowing legal battle leading to the reversal of California’s ban on same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Opening in theaters before airing on HBO on June 23, “The Case Against 8” follows the legal challenge to Proposition 8, the 2008 referendum that banned same-sex marriage in California. Because the Supreme Court effectively nullified the ban last year — the decision said the initiative’s supporters lacked the standing to appeal a federal ruling striking it down — this documentary from Ben Cotner and Ryan White is less a work of immediacy than of backstage intrigue.

headline: Some See G.M. Report as Powerful Ammunition for Change
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Mary T. Barra, the head of General Motors, called an internal investigation released on Thursday an occasion for the automaker to clean house.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chief for regulatory affairs is gone. So is a senior lawyer and two midlevel engineers. Two safety executives were also let go. The list is long — at least 20 in all — of those dismissed or disciplined by General Motors for their role in the company’s failure to correct a deadly safety defect in millions of its small cars.

headline: At French Open, Simona Halep Carries the Hopes of Romania
abstract: Halep, the first Romanian woman in more than 30 years to reach a Grand Slam singles final, has continued her quick and steady rise over the last two seasons.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — One of the quirks and delights of the Grand Slam tournaments is that the historical tennis figures are often still here on site, playing in the senior events, watching from the stands or the commentary booths, hobnobbing in the hallways and presidents’ boxes.

headline: Bond Rally Is Squeezing the Trading at Big Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Government Bonds', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Wall Street’s top banks bet on a bear market for Treasuries this year. But with bonds rising, some firms are worried about their bottom lines.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s biggest firms this year made an extraordinary wager that they probably now regret.

headline: Surviving a German Trading Floor, Ruefully
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Marc Bauder directs a German documentary in which a former stock trader divulges his experiences and observations.
lead_paragraph: In “The Wolf of Wall Street,” Jordan Belfort cuts short an explanation of his work, because, he says, we probably couldn’t follow the details. “Master of the Universe” attempts that explanation but offers a sobering antidote to irrational exuberance and a psychological case study in the financier’s mind-set. This indefatigable tell-all documentary from Marc Bauder cedes the floor to Rainer Voss, a German ex-trader who tells us with clarity about how it all works.

headline: How to Meet Cute in France: Whimsical Stabbings, Genial Strokes
abstract: In “2 Autumns, 3 Winters,” a stylistic homage to French New Wave cinema, three young adults come together by chance and stay together because of something more.
lead_paragraph: Life doesn’t proceed as methodically as in the screenplay of a skillfully plotted commercial film. Unforeseen events interrupt the flow and destroy the symmetry. The randomness of life and the capriciousness of human nature were recurrent motifs in French New Wave movies of the 1960s and ’70s. And in “2 Autumns, 3 Winters,” the Gallic filmmaker Sébastien Betbeder’s breezy, lighthearted homage to the films of Jean-Luc Godard and others, fate keeps stepping in to alter the destinies of its three principal characters, Arman (Vincent Macaigne), Benjamin (Bastien Bouillon) and Amélie (Maud Wyler).

headline: Shooting Leaves One Dead at Seattle Pacific University
keywords: ['School Shootings', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: A gunman armed with a shotgun opened fire on the campus of Seattle Pacific University, leaving three people wounded and one dead before being taking into custody, the Seattle police said.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — A man armed with a shotgun opened fire on the campus of Seattle Pacific University on Thursday afternoon, leaving three people wounded and one dead before being taken into custody, the Seattle police said.

headline: Woman in an Endless Coma, Circled by Endless Debate
abstract: The filmmaker Marco Bellocchio’s 2012 drama, “Dormant Beauty,” draws on a famous right-to-die case to perform a kind of CT scan on the Italian republic and some of its citizens.
lead_paragraph: Thought and feeling are never far apart in the films of Marco Bellocchio. From his precocious beginnings in the 1960s with “Fists in the Pocket” and “China Is Near,” Mr. Bellocchio, now 74, has explored weighty ideas — about Italian society and politics, about the struggle between faith and secularism in the modern world, about authority, idealism and sexual desire — with passionate, at times melodramatic, ardor.

headline: The Complex Battle to Achieve the Perfect Dirt
keywords: ['Belmont Stakes', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Horse Racing']
abstract: The mile-and-a-half racetrack at Belmont Park, which has unusual aspects ranging from its length to its running surface, requires a great deal of maintenance.
lead_paragraph: A week before the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes, a tractor with wheels practically the size of horses towed a grader along the track while a worker on the back checked the depth of the dirt’s surface every couple of feet.

headline: For a Decade, G.M. Response to a Fatal Flaw Was to Shrug
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The Valukas report details a decade-long tale of denial, incompetence and tragic nonchalance at General Motors.
lead_paragraph: Just six months ago, a group of senior General Motors executives gathered to review a series of PowerPoint slides concerning a question that had been smoldering inside G.M. for a decade: Should the company recall hundreds of thousands of small cars because of a dangerous defect?

headline: Playing Ball in the Shadow of Warfare
abstract: “The Only Real Game,” directed by Mirra Bank, traces the history of baseball in Manipur, a state in India, where it was introduced during World War II.
lead_paragraph: If nothing else, “The Only Real Game,” a documentary about baseball in Manipur, in northeastern India, serves as an antidote to the Disney film “Million Dollar Arm,” which also involves baseball and India. Here, America’s game is played with armed troops looking on and with very little prospect of a happy ending.

headline: Faces of an Immigration System Overwhelmed by Women and Children
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Children and Childhood', 'Women and Girls', 'Buses']
abstract: In Phoenix, up to four buses a day arrive at the Greyhound station, each filled to capacity with women and children from El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — This is what it looks like when an immigration system is overwhelmed by tens of thousands of women and children from Central America.
