abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Girl, 7, Recovering From Elevator Stabbing
abstract: Mikayla Capers, 7, who survived the elevator attack that killed her 6-year-old friend, has been transferred out of intensive care and has begun eating solid foods again.
lead_paragraph: Her best friend is dead, stabbed to death on Sunday by a strange man who followed them into an elevator in a public housing project in East New York, Brooklyn. A suspect is in custody, his history of violence and mental illness now the subject of intense scrutiny.

headline: Clip: ‘Burt’s Buzz’
abstract: A scene from the documentary.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the documentary.

headline: Syria: Assad Praises Election and Iran
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad brushed off criticism of his re-election and praised Iran’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: A day after his re-election in a disputed vote, President Bashar al-Assad said on Thursday that the 73 percent turnout the government reported in the vote sent a message that Syrians were “determined to manage their own affairs,” brushing off criticism of the vote and calls for an internationally brokered political transition. Syria’s state news agency reported that Mr. Assad, who made the comments during a meeting with a high-ranking Iranian official, Alaeddin Boroujerdi, also praised Iran’s nuclear program, the subject of intense international negotiations. Iran says the program is for civilian purposes, while the United States says it is a military program. Mr. Boroujerdi was part of a delegation of election observers from Iran — a country that has provided considerable support to ensure the survival of Mr. Assad. The Iranian delegation declared that the election, in which the president garnered 89 percent of the vote, was free and fair. Mr. Assad’s opposition has denounced the election as a farce.

headline: Missed Out on Millions, but He’s the Spartan Sort
abstract: The documentary “Burt’s Buzz” profiles the bearded co-founder pictured on the Burt’s Bees line of personal care products.
lead_paragraph: The word “icon” is given quite a workout in “Burt’s Buzz,” a documentary about the man whose likeness adorns Burt’s Bees products. It’s to the film’s detriment. Not only is the word overused these days, but it also has no business being applied to a pitchman for a product line that may have fans but is hardly a dominant cultural force. The film, by Jody Shapiro, seems so hagiographic that when it finally gets around to its 20 minutes’ worth of interesting stuff, you’re not sure whether to trust it.

headline: Saudi Arabia: Camels and Livestock Are to Be Tested for Traces of a Virus
abstract: Alarmed over the rising human death toll from the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus, authorities in Saudi Arabia, said they would start testing the kingdom’s entire population of camels.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Saudi Arabia, alarmed over the rising human death toll from the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus, said they would start testing the kingdom’s entire population of camels and other livestock next week, Saudi newspapers reported Thursday. The Arab News quoted Fahd Balghuneim, the agriculture minister, as saying the tests to determine the extent of infection would be conducted via blood or mucus samples. Saudi Arabia has in the past few days adopted a more aggressive response to the virus, known as MERS, which originated in the country two years ago and has been linked to camels, which spread the virus to humans. On Tuesday, the Health Ministry said a review showed that the death toll was 282, 92 more than reported a day earlier, and it announced that the deputy health minister had been relieved. On Wednesday, in the clearest evidence yet that MERS can be passed directly from camels to humans, research published in The New England Journal of Medicine said genetic sequencing had shown that a Saudi man who died of MERS in November had a strain virtually identical to that in one of the camels in his herd.

headline: Events on Long Island for June 8-14, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Tense Search, Chilling Note and an Arrest in Brooklyn Stabbings
abstract: At nearly every stop in three boroughs, the authorities said, Daniel St. Hubert left evidence that began to be unlocked Wednesday in an eight-hour avalanche of revelations.
lead_paragraph: Around 8 p.m. Wednesday, a man paused at a corner in Ozone Park, Queens, and scrawled letters and symbols on a stop sign:

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 5, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Crossing Borders Through Cinema
abstract: In “Filmistaan,” an aspiring actor tries to bridge political differences when he is mistakenly captured by extremists.
lead_paragraph: “Filmistaan” celebrates the power of cinema to bridge divides, but the mirth doesn’t entirely travel in this Bollywood production about an aspiring actor, Sunny (Sharib Hashmi), who is kidnapped by Pakistani militants. While the film mixes genres in the inimitable Bollywood style, that premise, at least, is played for laughs.

headline: Bringing Blood to the Neighborhood
abstract: The Hong Kong horror film “Rigor Mortis” puts an actor through an exorcism.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, Hong Kong cinema came up with its own version of a comic monster movie. It was no “Ghostbusters,” but “Mr. Vampire,” mixing traditional Chinese folk tales of “hopping vampires” with action and humor, proved successful, spawning numerous sequels.

headline: Witness Says Senator Was ‘Marginalized’
abstract: A colleague of Malcolm A. Smith, the New York state senator on trial on bribery charges, said Mr. Smith believed he was the victim of a “coup.”
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. — Malcolm A. Smith was feeling “marginalized,” as his State Senate colleague put it at his bribery and wire fraud trial on Thursday.

headline: Rushing Headlong Into the Hurly-Burly
abstract: Rob Ashford and Kenneth Branagh’s staging of “Macbeth” at the Park Avenue Armory is a speeding juggernaut for two intermissionless hours.
lead_paragraph: Hearts beat fast in the thrilling new “Macbeth” that has transformed the Park Avenue Armory into a war zone, and every breath starts to feel like a gasp. Rob Ashford and Kenneth Branagh’s galloping British-born production, which opened on Thursday night with Mr. Branagh in the title role, saturates everyone in it in adrenaline. Make that everyone watching it, as well.

headline: Language Originally Known As Mocha
abstract: A crunchy and fun debut by Kameron Austin Collins.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Every now and then, people write to me asking for advice on constructing and, although I sadly no longer have time to actually collaborate with constructors, I always enjoy discussing the aspects of construction. Once in a while, among those who write to me, there emerges a truly nice person with charmingly good manners, who is not only smart but loves the process of learning and furthermore, puts it to good use.

headline: Astros End Trend By Selecting Pitcher Out of High School
abstract: The Houston Astros selected Brady Aiken, a left-handed pitcher, with the first pick in the 2014 draft, the first time in more than two decades a high school pitcher was selected with the top pick.
lead_paragraph: SECAUCUS, N.J. — In 1991, the Yankees selected Brien Taylor, a high school left-hander, with the first overall pick in baseball’s amateur draft. His failure to make the majors scared teams away from showing similar faith in a prep pitcher in the 22 drafts that followed.

headline: A Culture of Child Rape in Liberia
abstract: Jessica Vale’s documentary “Small Small Thing: The Olivia Zinnah Story” offers an unflinching look at the culture of rape in Liberia.
lead_paragraph: Looking for a villain in Jessica Vale’s documentary? There’s competition. Obviously, in “Small Small Thing: The Olivia Zinnah Story,” about a 7-year-old rape victim in Liberia, there is the man who attacked her so brutally that her genitals were mangled and covered in scar tissue. He was a 20-year-old cousin. She was left with a fistula requiring numerous surgeries to repair, if it could be fixed at all.

headline: Navy Pilots Under the Gun
abstract: In D M W Greer’s “Burning Blue,” Navy fighter pilots become the focus of an investigation that exposes a homosexual affair.
lead_paragraph: At last it’s come along: the “Reefer Madness” of gay rights. In D M W Greer’s supposed drama “Burning Blue,” a military official worries aloud that if man-on-man sex among its fighter pilots is not punished severely, the Navy could be perceived as being run by a “perverse cult.”

headline: What Experts Say About the Belmont Stakes
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Belmont Stakes', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)']
abstract: Some respected veterans of the horse racing world were asked to assess Saturday’s Belmont Stakes, in which California Chrome could end the sport’s Triple Crown drought. Some quotations have been condensed.
lead_paragraph: Some respected veterans of the horse racing world were asked to assess Saturday’s Belmont Stakes, in which California Chrome could end the sport’s Triple Crown drought. Some quotations have been condensed.

headline: Shaken, G.I.’s Hometown Waits for All the Facts
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Residents in Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s hometown of Hailey, Idaho, are trying to make sense of the furious backlash against him and the way the reaction to his release has turned so dark so quickly.
lead_paragraph: HAILEY, Idaho — From the time of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s capture five years ago, Zaney’s River Street Coffee House has been ground zero for information about and support for the soldier and his family.

headline: He’s Just Like Her Ex-Boyfriend, Down to the Tattoo
abstract: In the thriller “The Moment,” Jennifer Jason Leigh is a war photographer consigned to a psychiatric hospital who meets a doppelgänger for her ex-boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Hitchcock disliked whodunits; he felt viewers became too bound up in guessing the solution. That principle holds true for the director Jane Weinstock’s “The Moment,” a psychological thriller that shrouds its mysteries in layers of hallucination and unreliable narration.

headline: A Journey for the Soles and the Soul
abstract: “Walking the Camino: Six Ways to Santiago” documents travelers who make the trek to the Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela in Spain.
lead_paragraph: The Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela in Spain, where, legend holds, the Apostle James is buried, has drawn pilgrims since the Middle Ages. So it’s not as if the most popular Camino de Santiago, the 500-mile Camino Francés, which starts at St.-Jean-Pied-de-Port in the Pyrenees, needs any publicity. Still, “The Way,” Emilio Estevez’s 2011 film about four modern-day hikers — one played by his father, Martin Sheen — introduced many to the trek and its meditative pleasures.

headline: Debating the Possibility of Winning by a Nose Patch
abstract: California Chrome’s owners want him to use a nasal strip, but others in the sport doubt its merits.
lead_paragraph: California Chrome’s owners would be ecstatic if a nose — and perhaps a nasal strip — makes the difference in the one-and-a-half-mile Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

headline: What I’ve Been Watching
abstract: The recent television habits of a Times columnist.
lead_paragraph: Now it can be told: All of the recent Times columnist forays into interactivity and transparency — the reader Q&As, the reading lists — have been building up to this week’s launch of our new Op-Ed app, which offers readers an all-access pass to the high-stakes, occasionally drug-fueled world of Times opinion journalism.

headline: War’s Elite Tough Guys, Hesitant to Seek Healing
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Traumatic Brain Injury', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Suicides have increased among the military’s Special Operations forces, prompting concern that brain injuries and stress have not been properly treated. Susan Ullman’s husband, Sgt. First Class Michael B. Lube, committed suicide last summer.
lead_paragraph: After his fourth combat tour, to Afghanistan in 2011, Sgt. First Class Michael B. Lube, a proud member of the Army Special Forces, came home alienated and angry. Once a rock-solid sergeant and devoted husband, he became sullen, took to drinking, got in trouble with his commanders and started beating his wife.

headline: Cracking Down on Illegal Mortgage Referrals
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau goes after companies that violate laws prohibiting payments for customer referrals.
lead_paragraph: A federal agency is aggressively going after mortgage, title and real estate companies that it believes are violating laws prohibiting payments or incentives for customer referrals.

headline: On the Road, and on the Run
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: “Il Sorpasso” and “Stranger on the Prowl,” both available in new DVD editions, offer variations on Italian neorealism.
lead_paragraph: The first stage of Italian neorealism documented wartime destruction and endemic poverty; the second, rosier stage added a touch of fantasy; the third recorded the spiritual emptiness of Italy’s economic miracle. Dino Risi’s “Il Sorpasso” (1962), originally released in the United States as “The Easy Life” and newly out from Criterion in a dual-format edition, is of that third stage.

headline: Billionaire Issues Statement About Times Article
abstract: The billionaire Chinese financier Xiao Jianhua, the subject of a New York Times profile on Wednesday, said he did not make money through his political connections but by following Warren Buffett’s value investing strategy.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire Chinese financier Xiao Jianhua, the subject of a New York Times profile on Wednesday, said he did not make money through his political connections but by following Warren Buffett’s value investing strategy.

headline: Rangers Put Aside Turnover That Led to Overtime Loss in Game 1
abstract: Coach Alain Vigneault said: “Stuff like that happens. You got to turn the page and move on.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Rangers said they had no concerns about Dan Girardi, whose turnover led to Justin Williams’s overtime goal in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: Surrounded by Nature
abstract: An Upper West Side penthouse with a lushly landscaped wraparound terrace enters the market.
lead_paragraph: A petite and picturesque Upper West Side penthouse, with a lush wraparound terrace that replicates the Old World charm of a European garden yet provides forever views of Central Park and the evolving cityscape to the south, is poised to enter the market at $3.995 million. The monthly maintenance for the light-filled two-bedroom two-bath unit, PHC, is $3,468.

headline: Global Times Editor Apologizes to Chinese Veterans Over Online Post
abstract: Hu Xijin had suggested that some soldiers in China’s 1979 war with Vietnam shirked participation in “dare-to-die” squads that carried out risky, suicidal missions. The official newspaper of the military said that was “nonsense.”
lead_paragraph: The editor of a prominent Chinese newspaper has apologized after saying in a tweet suggesting that some soldiers in China’s 1979 war with Vietnam shirked participation in “dare-to-die” squads that carried out risky, suicidal missions.

headline: N.I.H. Seeks $4.5 Billion to Try to Crack the Code of How Brains Function
abstract: The National Institutes of Health’s price tag stamps President Obama’s Brain Initiative as an effort on the scale of the Human Genome Project.
lead_paragraph: The National Institutes of Health set an ambitious $4.5 billion price tag on its part of President Obama’s Brain Initiative on Thursday, stamping it as an effort on the scale of the Human Genome Project.

headline: Lowly Cubs Sweep as Mets Fill Bases but Don’t Clear Them
abstract: The Mets stranded 11 runners Thursday against the Cubs, 31 in the series, and they are batting .148 this season with the bases loaded.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — With the crack of Anthony Rizzo’s bat, there was no doubting what would happen next. No doubt the ball would land in the bleachers in right-center field to put the Chicago Cubs ahead. No doubt the Mets would strand base runners with the game still in reach. And no doubt that the crowd would sing “Go, Cubs, Go,” the team’s anthem.

lead_paragraph: The horses for the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes are listed in order of post position with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Both have also selected their win-place-show horses for the Belmont, which will be run at 6:52 p.m. Saturday, and both are picking California Chrome to become the first Triple Crown winner since 1978. headline: Openness on Israeli Issues Seen in Survey of Iranians
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Some 40 percent were found to support giving up any ability to produce nuclear arms in exchange for lifting sanctions.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An unusual survey of Iranian public opinion indicates that 40 percent of Iranians would be willing to give up any ability to produce nuclear weapons in the future in return for the full removal of sanctions.

headline: Girls’ Night Out With Jamaican Spice
abstract: Miss Lily’s 7A is a hyper-stylized Jamaican restaurant that opened by Tompkins Square Park last month.
lead_paragraph: There is no Lily at Miss Lily’s 7A, a hyper-stylized Jamaican restaurant that opened by Tompkins Square Park last month, namesake of a place on Houston Street. What there is is an exuberantly clashing Caribbean color scheme, some retro reggae album covers, bottled jerk sauces and waitresses in short shorts.

headline: In Thailand, Growing Intolerance for Dissent Drives Many to More Authoritarian Nations
abstract: Since the military coup last month, academics and activists have been driven to flee a nation once considered a liberal haven in Asia.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Thailand, long the liberal bastion of Southeast Asia, has traditionally been a haven for refugees from its less democratic neighbors. Now, in the wake of a recent coup, a small group of Thai intellectuals are making the reverse journey — heading to Cambodia and other more repressive nations as their own country cracks down on dissent.

headline: As in Past, Underdog Goal Is to Exploit Divisive Party
abstract: The story of John Tower, whose 1961 victory began a shift to a Republican-dominated Texas, offers a glimpse at the challenges of Democrats now pursuing statewide office.
lead_paragraph: With a ticket led by State Senators Wendy Davis of Fort Worth and Leticia Van de Putte of San Antonio, Democrats are hoping to break a political drought that has lasted since 1998, the last time a member of their party held statewide office.

headline: Facing the Law, but Running to Uphold It
abstract: Republicans have a habit of winning statewide elections nowadays, so the troubles of a candidate like Ken Paxton, running for attorney general, have not hurt him so far.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Halfway Houses Meet Fraction of Demand for Former Inmates
abstract: Roughly a quarter of former inmates in Texas return to prison within three years, the state Department of Criminal Justice has found. One reason is the shortage of transitional space.
lead_paragraph: When Terry Pelz, a former warden with the Texas Department of Criminal Justice, testified against a prison gang leader, Mark Fronckiewicz, in the 1993 capital murder trial of a fellow inmate, he had choice words.

headline: North Korea Detains 3rd American in New Threat to Relations With U.S.
abstract: The man, a resident of suburban Dayton, Ohio, was accused of unspecified illegal acts while visiting the country as a tourist.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A municipal worker from Ohio on a tour of North Korea has been detained there for unspecified illegal acts, making him the third American known to be currently held in the isolated country and threatening to further aggravate its tense relationship with the United States.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) FRIDAY NIGHT SPOTLIGHT: PIRATE PICTURES The comedian Greg Proops takes his humor to the high seas as host of this monthlong festival, which begins with Frank Lloyd’s silent version of “The Sea Hawk” (1924), about a British noble (Milton Sills) sold into slavery who escapes and turns himself into a pirate king. Henry King’s “The Black Swan” (1942), starring Tyrone Power as a swashbuckler intent on cleaning up the Caribbean after he’s named governor of Jamaica, follows at 10:15; Frank Borzage’s “The Spanish Main” (1945), in which a Dutch ship’s captain (Paul Henreid) turns Caribbean pirate and kidnaps the future bride (Maureen O’Hara) of a corrupt Spanish governor (Walter Slezak), at midnight; Felix Feist’s “Pirates of Tripoli” (1955), with Henreid as a buccaneer trying to help a deposed Arab princess (Patricia Medina) reclaim her throne, at 2 a.m.; Sidney Salkow’s “The Golden Hawk” (1952), with Rhonda Fleming and Sterling Hayden as pirates who join forces against yet another corrupt Caribbean governor, at 3:30; and Lew Landers’s “Hurricane Island” (1951), about a captain (Jon Hall) searching for the fountain of youth alongside Ponce de León (Edgar Barrier), at 5.

headline: Suspect Arrested in Killing of Three Mounties in New Brunswick
abstract: Justin Bourque is accused of shooting the police officers in what witnesses called an ambush in Moncton.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A man suspected of fatally shooting three Canadian Mounties and wounding two others, putting a Canadian city under a virtual siege, was arrested early Friday, the police said.

abstract: Professor Armelagos was one of the founders of paleopathology, a discipline at the nexus of biology, medicine, evolution, archaeology and culture.
lead_paragraph: George J. Armelagos was a reader of bones.

headline: A ‘Modern-Day Knight’ Who Helped Fleeing Tiananmen Activists
abstract: Chan Tat Ching, 70, is a small-business man in Hong Kong. But 25 years ago, he created a lifeline for fugitives escaping the Tiananmen Square crackdown.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — WHEN tens of thousands of people gathered in Hong Kong this week to mourn the military carnage against protesters in Beijing 25 years ago, Chan Tat Ching stood among them, holding a candle and bowing to honor the dead.

headline: Bear Rescue Plan Delayed by Permit Problems
abstract: A plan to transport 28 of the sickest animals from a bear bile farm to a rescue center in Sichuan Province cannot go forward without a government permit for the transfer.
lead_paragraph: When a group of international animal welfare advocates reached an agreement with a Chinese bear bile farm in April to turn it into a sanctuary, they planned to transport 28 of the sickest animals to their rescue center for treatment. That plan has hit a snag because it is taking longer than expected to obtain a government permit for the bear transfer.

keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'News and News Media', 'Writing and Writers']

lead_paragraph: A journalist based in Hong Kong who was arrested last week by the Chinese police is an American citizen, people close to the case said Friday.

headline: Populist Party Fails to Capture Seat in British Parliament
abstract: The right-wing United Kingdom Independence Party failed to capitalize on a strong showing in European elections, but it cut into the Conservatives’ margin of victory.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Despite momentum from a surprisingly strong showing in recent European elections, the populist right-wing United Kingdom Independence Party failed to win its first seat in the British Parliament when it finished second to the Conservative candidate in a special election, according to results announced Friday.

headline: What Was Your Favorite Field Trip?
abstract: Are field trips an important part of the learning experience? Why?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever taken a field trip that broadened your horizons — or taught you something that you would have never learned from a textbook? Perhaps you visited a Buddhist temple, a butterfly conservatory or a historic cemetery? Or maybe you just took a class trip that was really fun?

abstract: Over the last decade, many of Italy’s racetracks have closed, taking with them thousands of jobs and memories of a once-heralded sport.

headline: British Video Game Retailer Raises $203.4 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: The offering by Game Digital, controlled by the hedge fund Elliott Management, priced at the low end of the expected range of £2 to £2.12, another sign of a slight cooling in what has been a red-hot I.P.O market in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Game Digital, the British video game retailer controlled by the hedge fund Elliott Management, said on Friday that it had raised about $203 million in its initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange.

headline: On 70th Anniversary, the Memories of D-Day Are Replayed at Normandy
abstract: June 6, 1944, has long since taken on the aura of myth, and the commemorations retell stories of heroism and sacrifice.
lead_paragraph: VIERVILLE-SUR-MER, France — At Camp Dog Green, recreated just a few miles inland from where combat raged on and around the Normandy beaches in June 1944, soldiers in American uniforms and nurses with the Red Cross insignia on their breast pockets mill among the drab green tents, tuning their tinny radios to the music of Glenn Miller. They appear to be just waiting for orders.

headline: Best of Both Worlds? Northeast Cut Emissions and Enjoyed Growth
abstract: Economic growth and carbon emissions were once closely linked. The results in nine states show they no longer necessarily are.
lead_paragraph: Some critics of the Environmental Protection Agency’s new requirements for power plants argue that forcing emissions reduction will curtail economic growth. But the recent experience of states that already cap carbon emissions reveals that emissions and economic growth are no longer tightly tied together.

headline: Awkward Diplomacy as Leaders Gather
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met with Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine, and Mr. Putin also had an informal conversation with President Obama at the D-Day commemoration ceremony in France.
lead_paragraph: BÉNOUVILLE, France — As President Obama wrapped up a four-day European trip on Friday, the violent conflict over Ukraine seemed to move toward a new phase of diplomacy, but it remained unclear whether the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, was genuinely willing or able to call off a pro-Russian uprising across his border.

headline: Vietnam Says Video Shows Chinese Ship Intentionally Sinking Boat
abstract: Vietnam has released video of a clash at sea last month that it says shows a Chinese vessel in disputed waters intentionally ramming and sinking a smaller Vietnamese fishing boat.
lead_paragraph: Vietnam has released a video that it says shows a Chinese fishing boat intentionally ramming into a smaller Vietnamese fishing boat, causing it to sink.

headline: Suicide Bomb Hits Convoy of an Afghan Candidate
abstract: The candidate, Abdullah Abdullah, escaped unharmed in what was the first attack on a candidate in the Afghan presidential election.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bombing on Friday struck a convoy of vehicles carrying one of the candidates in Afghanistan’s presidential runoff election next week. The candidate, Abdullah Abdullah, escaped unharmed, but at least six other people were killed.

headline: One More Senior Official Reportedly Kills Himself
abstract: The death by hanging of a deputy city mayor of Weifang has highlighted what appears to be a growing number of suicides by officials in China amid an anticorruption campaign.
lead_paragraph: Depression and suicide reportedly claimed another Chinese government official this week, bringing to at least 15 the number of officials said to have committed suicide in the last 18 months, according to Chinese news media.

headline: Daily Report: Changes in Wireless Market May Influence a Sprint Deal

lead_paragraph: In the view of Sprint and T-Mobile USA, less is more, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Plotting the World Cup Coverage
abstract: Andrew Das, an editor in sports, shares some of the plans for covering the World Cup this summer.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Das, an assistant sports editor, will fly to Brazil this weekend to prepare coverage of the World Cup soccer tournament, which begins on Thursday. We asked him what readers can expect.

headline: It’s Not Too Soon to Pay Attention to Senate Polling
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: An analysis of Senate contests suggests polls are as accurate as so-called fundamentals this far into an election cycle.
lead_paragraph: Just five months until November’s midterm elections and already early polling results have countered some expectations. In Arkansas, the Democrat Mark Pryor is showing surprising strength in a red state, and in North Carolina, Kay Hagan is trailing as an incumbent in a battleground state. We won’t know how accurate polling is until after the election, so for now, the very relevant question is, How much should we care about early polls?

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Morning Views
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s opponents have pounced on the decision to trade five Taliban leaders in exchange for the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl. This is yet another example of the hypocrisy which “now pervades the Republican party and the conservative movement,” The New York Times editorial board writes. “The critics seeking political advantage don’t care about the life or mental state of a particular soldier, or of a principle of loyalty that should provide comfort to any soldier in danger of capture. They live only for the attack.”

headline: Morning Agenda: S.E.C. Takes on High-Speed Trading
abstract: The S.E.C. has called for changes to govern fast trading. | Telecommunication bankers are running out of deals to pitch. | A rally in the bond market has banks worried. | A hedge fund manager sets goats grazing in Detroit.
lead_paragraph: S.E.C. TAKES ON HIGH-SPEED TRADING  |  Regulators have been slow to react to changes in the stock market, which in the last decade has evolved into a place dominated by high-speed traders. Now, the Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking to update the market’s rules for the new era, DealBook’s William Alden writes. On Thursday, Mary Jo White, the chairwoman of the S.E.C., unveiled a sweeping package of recommendations for new rules and other changes geared toward strengthening the structure of the market and improving disclosures for investors.

headline: For Some Retirees, a Second Act Is Easier Than Expected
abstract: Skills honed during decades spent in one career can be relevant to strikingly different positions, experts say.
lead_paragraph: NEVER in a million years did Cheryl Delaney expect to spend her retirement working with the elderly. Her entire career had been in the financial sector — as a bank officer and loan administrator, in collections and finally as an office manager at Fidelity Investments in Boston. Changing bedpans was not on her bucket list.

headline: Struggling to Understand ‘Slenderman’
abstract: What, if anything, does it say about us that an Internet character might have driven children to violence?
lead_paragraph: Slenderman, a fictional character said to have inspired two young Wisconsin girls to stab a third, continues to disturb America. Beyond the obviously upsetting nature of the crime, many are asking what — if anything — it says about contemporary society that a figment of the Internet’s imagination might have driven two children to violence.

headline: Soaring Past Low Expectations
abstract: With “22 Jump Street,” Phil Lord and Christopher Miller are poised to cement their status as the go-to Hollywood duo for making good movies out of ideas that seem doomed to fail.
lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — Giant, pallid and fleshy, the faces of Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum are plastered all over Los Angeles. On billboards, buildings and buses, their mirrored-sunglasses-wearing selves seem to be promoting their new movie, “22 Jump Street,” everywhere.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: Season 2 Begins in a More Menacing World
abstract: Piper and Alex joust once again.
lead_paragraph: Episode 1, Season 2: O.K., so maybe The Litch had started to feel too comfortable, its Secret Santa and movie nights making it seem more Smith College common room than women’s minimum-security prison.

headline: Singing Nun Wins Italian TV Talent Show
abstract: Sister Cristina Scuccia became a viral sensation belting out pop hits, but some now wonder whether fame will lead her astray from her first calling.
lead_paragraph: ROME — She trilled and thrilled millions of YouTube viewers with songs by Alicia Keys, Cyndi Lauper and Bon Jovi. She belted out a duet with Kylie Minogue, both of them clad in black, albeit with vastly different approaches to style.

headline: We Are the World (Cup)
abstract: Bringing the world together, one soccer match at a time.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — At dinner recently, one of my 5-year-old twins announced that he intended to learn Croatian.

headline: Vodafone Reveals Direct Access by Governments to Customer Data
abstract: In a privacy report, the British telecommunications company said that the authorities in certain countries had direct access to its networks without having to use legal warrants.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – A number of governments have the ability to tap directly into the communication network run by the British telecommunications company Vodafone, a level of surveillance that elicited outrage from privacy advocates when the company disclosed it on Friday.

headline: Remembering Operation Bluestar on Its 30th Anniversary
abstract: A sampling of stories reflecting on the 30th anniversary of the Indian Army’s storming of the Golden Temple in an attempt to flush out militants.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, on June 6, 1984, the Indian Army open fired on the Akal Takht, the shrine inside the Golden Temple of Amritsar, one of the holiest sites for India’s Sikh community, in the state of Punjab.  Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale, the militant Sikh leader with a popular following in the state, had occupied the temple with armed followers.

headline: 217,000 Jobs Added, Nudging Payrolls to Levels Before the Crisis
abstract: Employers hired 217,000 workers in May and the unemployment rate remained flat at 6.3 percent.
lead_paragraph: After a series of peaks and valleys that confounded optimists and pessimists alike this year, the American economy seems to have settled into a healthy, if not spectacular, pace of job creation.

abstract: The artist, an Australian citizen born in China, was seized after publicizing images of a replica of Tiananmen Square he made out of ground pork.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — An Australian artist born in China who was detained shortly after publicizing images of a replica of Tiananmen Square he made out of ground pork will be deported from China, Australian officials said on Friday.

headline: What’s News in Washington: D-Day Remembrance
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama joined other world leaders at Normandy’s Omaha Beach to commorate the occasion, and many will be watching any interaction between Mr. Obama and President Vladimir Putin of Russia, who was excluded from this week’s Group of 7 meetings.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning from Washington. It has been a week focused on veterans of war and prisoners of war and it concludes with commemorating the beginning of the end of the last World War.

headline: In Jobs Report, Two Milestones
abstract: Good news in an economic report is also a reminder of how long it has taken to recover from the downturn.
lead_paragraph: This morning’s jobs report has two important labor market milestones. First, the total number of nonfarm jobs has finally climbed back above its pre-recession level. This comes fully six years and four months after employment last peaked, meaning that it has taken longer to recover from this recession than in any previous post-World War II downturn.

headline: Vanishing Into the Role
abstract: Guy Pearce stars as a former military man in “The Rover,” which is set in a future Australia.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, the Australian actor Guy Pearce played an unusual but crucial role in “The Hurt Locker,” Kathryn Bigelow’s Academy Award-winning Iraq drama. Appearing at the beginning of the film, Mr. Pearce was a bomb expert who seemed set to be a primary character. As it turned out, his performance was limited to a single scene, but its impact set up the film’s high-stakes authenticity.

lead_paragraph: Writer, actress and Rookie editor in chief Tavi Gevinson talks coming of age, Kanye and her dream interview subject.

headline: Quick Action Kept School Shooting Casualties Down, Police Say
keywords: ['School Shootings', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: For some at Seattle Pacific University, a Christian campus, there was a tone of quiet affirmation of the actions of people who the police said had helped subdue the gunman and save lives.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Students at Seattle Pacific University gathered on campus Friday in small prayer circles and at large candlelight vigils to mourn the violence that exploded in a science and engineering building, when a young man walked in with a shotgun on Thursday afternoon. One student was killed and two others were wounded. One of them remained hospitalized Friday in serious condition after hours of surgery.

headline: Good News on Jobs. Why Aren’t We Happier?
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: A closer look at the numbers shows why, even with months of solid job growth, things don’t feel so great.
lead_paragraph: We did it, America! Six and a half years after the Great Recession began, and five years after it ended, we have now regained all the jobs lost during the downturn. Huzzah!

headline: For Miami Heat and Spurs, Hot Arena Plays Big Role in Game 1
abstract: An air-conditioning failure on Thursday led to sweltering conditions in San Antonio’s arena in Game 1 of the finals, and the Heat’s LeBron James watched the final minutes with leg cramps.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — As the temperature began to climb inside AT&T Arena Thursday night, the failure of the air-conditioning system seemed to be nothing but an annoyance.

headline: Buying a Guaranteed Retirement Income, for Some Peace of Mind
abstract: Many people at or nearing retirement age are purchasing deferred-income annuities that will provide them with an extra monthly income check.
lead_paragraph: Many workers long for the sense of security that only an old-fashioned pension can provide. The big insurers are well aware of this, and that’s why many of them are offering new ways for investors to buy and build a pension on their own.

headline: Found Poetry Favorite | ‘The Elvish Doings in the Forest’
abstract: This poem, by Libbie, is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest. It comes from a dance review, “There’s Brightness When the Fog Clears.”
lead_paragraph: This poem, by Libbie, is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest. It comes from a dance review, “There’s Brightness When the Fog Clears.”

headline: A Four-Month Streak of Sturdy Job Growth
abstract: Another month of adding more than 200,000 jobs continues the longest such run since 2000, but it’s nowhere near a record.
lead_paragraph: The United States economy has added more than 200,000 jobs in each of the past four months, the Labor Department reported Friday.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | May 2014
abstract: In this installment of our monthly collection, we spotlight five articles that use photography and narrative to reveal the texture of teenage life, 11 articles about young people making a splash in the world, and three other articles about teenagers that can provoke discussion.
lead_paragraph: On the first Friday of every month we publish a collection of articles about teenagers featured in The New York Times.

headline: The Politics of the P.O.W. Coverage
abstract: In a highly partisan story, charges of bias from both sides.
lead_paragraph: The story has dominated the headlines for a week — the dramatic swap of an American prisoner of war for five Taliban prisoners.

headline: Trying to Go Legit, Despite the In-Laws
abstract: In the new Starz drama “Power,” guided by the rapper 50 Cent, a criminal chases a more honest second career with a new night spot, called Truth.
lead_paragraph: The first intimation that “Power,” a new series starting Saturday on Starz, is not about the West Wing or the building of the Hoover Dam comes in the opening credits.

headline: Interview With a Torturer
abstract: Eric Abraham, a former South African journalist, commissioned a play about a meeting between a black female psychologist and the convicted former leader of a pro-apartheid death squad.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In 1997, in the newly democratic South Africa, a black female psychologist met a white male convict in Pretoria Central Prison. The psychologist, Pumla Gobodo-Madikizela, had just completed a doctoral fellowship at Harvard and had returned to the country to serve on the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. The man she had asked to meet was Eugene de Kock, a former policeman nicknamed “Prime Evil,” who had led a covert counterterrorism unit dedicated to the torture and killing of anti-apartheid activists.

headline: Private Jobs Have Recovered. Government Jobs Still Lag.
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'Government Employees', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Total employment has returned to its pre-recession peak because the private sector has added more than enough jobs to make up for government cutbacks.
lead_paragraph: The United States economy has finally exceeded its pre-recession employment peak, as many analysts of today’s jobs report have noted. But that milestone obscures two very different stories — in the private and public sectors. The public sector — federal, state and local government — still isn’t close to returning to its pre-recession employment levels.

headline: 5th Batch of Clinton-Era Papers Is Released
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: The roughly 2,000 documents cover subjects including Rwanda, policies toward gays in the military, the Oklahoma City bombing and Vice President Al Gore’s presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Archives unsealed about 2,000 documents from the Clinton administration on Friday, the fifth such release in recent months of memos, transcripts and speeches that had been withheld from public view.

headline: Zlatan Ibrahimovic: ‘I’m Never Satisfied’
abstract: The Swedish soccer star on planning his next move.
lead_paragraph: The Swedish soccer star talks to Wm. Ferguson about growing up an outsider in Sweden, the motivational power of anger and missing the World Cup — despite being the best.

headline: Obama and Putin Meet Briefly Over Ukraine
abstract: The two leaders talked after initially appearing to ignore each other at a gathering in France to mark the 70th anniversary of the D-Day landing.
lead_paragraph: BÉNOUVILLE, France — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia held private talks with President Obama and with the newly elected leader of Ukraine on Friday as both sides in the violent conflict in Eastern Europe tried to ease a geopolitical showdown that has shaken the post-Cold War order.

headline: New Fire Commissioner Returns to a Challenged Department
abstract: Daniel A. Nigro returns to the Fire Department as commissioner 12 years after retirement.
lead_paragraph: In a room deep inside Fire Department headquarters in Downtown Brooklyn, flat screens line the walls, tracking every fire and emergency medical incident in New York City. The last time Daniel A. Nigro was in this operations hub, before his retirement as chief of department a year after the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, the room had all the technological grandness of a broom closet.

headline: The World Cup Hairdo Hall of Fame
abstract: The magazine’s contributing illustrator sees soccer coifs in the scenery.
lead_paragraph: In his travels throughout Brazil in anticipation of the World Cup, Christoph Niemann, the magazine’s contributing illustrator, found soccer fever so intense that he couldn’t help seeing famous footballers — and their hair — wherever he looked.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Letters: ‘My Accidental Jihad’
abstract: Readers react to recent reviews of Krista Bremer’s “My Accidental Jihad,” Daniel Schulman’s “Sons of Wichita” and more.
lead_paragraph: ‘My Accidental Jihad’

headline: Nazism
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: New books by Götz Aly, Elisabeth Sifton and Fritz Stern, Bernard Wasserstein, and Nicholas Kulish and Souad Mekhennet.
lead_paragraph: WHY THE GERMANS? WHY THE JEWS?  Envy, Race Hatred, and the Prehistory of the Holocaust  By Götz Aly  Metropolitan/Holt, $30.

headline: The Top Shelf of Journalism Books
abstract: David Carr and others share their favorite books by and about journalists.
lead_paragraph: This week, David Carr, The Times’s Media Equation columnist and a culture reporter, reviews “The Invention of News,” by Andrew Pettegree. I asked Carr and a few of his colleagues to recommend their favorite books about journalism.

headline: Going Native
abstract: Lily King’s novel “Euphoria,” inspired by the life of Margaret Mead, is about a love triangle in New Guinea.
lead_paragraph: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: Fire on the Mountain
abstract: In Michael Koryta’s “Those Who Wish Me Dead,” two killers start a forest fire to flush out the only witness to their crimes.
lead_paragraph: Michael Koryta is a fearless stylist who has put his hand to ghost stories, historical novels, killer-thrillers, revenge tragedies, morality tales and detective stories. He’s now swinging from the high wire with THOSE WHO WISH ME DEAD (Little, Brown, $26), a heart-thumping backwoods adventure that sends two creatively sadistic killers into Montana’s Beartooth Mountains, where they spark a monster forest fire to flush out the only witness to their crimes: Jace Wilson, a 14-year-old boy. Jace was just trying to escape his reputation as class coward when he dived into a quarry near his Indiana home. But when he swam into a dead man — and spotted the killers flinging a second victim into the water — Jace knew he was going to die. Reborn with a new name, he finds himself among the “bad kids” in a grueling wilderness survival course, parked there when his parents couldn’t be persuaded to put him in a traditional witness protection program. Jace’s hunters, the Blackwell brothers, are heartless sociopaths whose professional detachment is etched in their unnervingly precise grammar and careful diction. (“The way they say things. Like they’re alone in the world. Like it was built for the two of them and they’re lords over it.”) There will be no mercy from that quarter.

headline: Border Crossings
abstract: The women in these stories seek new passions and geographies, from Italy to India.
lead_paragraph: In “The Italian System,” a wry, knowing story in Francesca Marciano’s first collection, “The Other Language,” the unnamed protagonist is planning a lifestyle guide for Americans. Seven years earlier — a period that evokes the scent of a fairy tale — she had moved to New York from Rome on a whim, having secured a place in a creative writing workshop at the New School. She fell in love with the city and so has never left, despite the fact that this place she adores hasn’t exactly opened its arms to welcome her. She found work as a language teacher, initially telling herself this is simply “a way to pay the rent.” But, as is often the way with the quotidian, “teaching became her real job and she forgot about other aspirations.” And yet those aspirations don’t quite disappear. In the fresh new days of spring, she determines to put together a book, “The Italian System,” about how to live a Roman life in New York.

headline: Acting the Brute
abstract: Jeffrey Masson examines the human propensity for violence and cruelty.
lead_paragraph: We humans often like to trumpet our uniqueness among all the world’s biodiversity. We pride ourselves on our exalted, big-brained status and our resulting separation from everything else we lump together as “nature.” For Jeffrey Moussaieff Masson, the salient feature of our distinction is neither the power of language nor the potential for extreme acts of creativity nor even an opposable thumb. It is, rather, our “singular capacity for violence.”

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: NO EASY DAY: The Autobiography of a Navy SEAL — The Firsthand Account of the Mission That Killed Osama bin Laden,  by Mark Owen with Kevin Maurer. (New American Library, $16.) The May 2011 raid on Abbottabad, Pakistan, is the heart of this boots-on-the-ground account, but Owen (a pseudonym for Matt Bissonnette, a former member of the SEALs who served 13 consecutive combat deployments) also details the formation and evolution of one of the military’s most elite units.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: CAN’T WE TALK ABOUT SOMETHING MORE PLEASANT?, written and illustrated by Roz Chast. (Bloomsbury, $28.) This scorchingly honest, achingly wistful graphic memoir looks at the last years of Chast’s nonagenarian parents.

headline: As the World Turns
abstract: Floyd Skloot describes his experience with vertigo.
lead_paragraph: One recent morning, I helped my son search for his misplaced shoes. They were nowhere to be found, so I took a peek under the couch. This was a rash move. The bend and twist required for ­under-couch viewing set off a wicked spin of dizziness, as I feared it would.

headline: B.A.s and I.O.U.s
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Books and Literature', 'For-Profit Schools', 'Student Loans']
abstract: A political scientist assesses the climbing costs of higher education and the rise of for-profit universities.
lead_paragraph: We’re having the wrong conversation about higher education in our country. So argues Suzanne Mettler in her ­provocative new book, “Degrees of Inequality,” based on the eight years she spent studying a college system that she argues works well for those born into well-off families but few others. Tuition rates of $50,000 or more at private four-year colleges? The trillion-plus dollars Americans collectively owe on college loans? In ­Mettler’s ­telling, those should be the least of our worries when considering the “caste system” that is now higher education in the United States.

headline: Publish or Perish
abstract: Seeking inspiration, a blocked novelist embroils himself in an unsolved murder.
lead_paragraph: Let’s be honest, no one likes literary wunderkinder. Twenty-­eight-year-olds are bad enough. Twenty-eight-year-olds whose first books become blockbusters? That’s just irritating. Joel Dicker, the 28-year-old Swiss author behind “The Truth About the Harry Quebert Affair,” doesn’t even have the decency to write dreck. His darkly comic debut thriller (already a blockbuster in Europe!) is unimpeachably terrific.

headline: Talking Talent | An Artist’s Directorial Debut
abstract: Andrew Levitas discusses the process of creating his first picture, “Lullaby,” which stars the likes of Amy Adams and Terrence Howard, and his future in film.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Levitas has the Midas touch. The 36-year-old artist, one of only a handful of American painters to ever study at the prestigious Société Nationale des Beaux-Arts in Paris, had never made a movie before he cast Garrett Hedlund and a whole slew of Oscar darlings (Amy Adams, Jennifer Hudson, Richard Jenkins, Terrence Howard) in his directorial debut, “Lullaby.” On June 13, his semi-autobiographical film about family and mortality will prove that the New York-based multihyphenate can write and direct the way he paints — with the confidence of a seasoned veteran and the vulnerability of a true artist.

headline: Settling Scores
abstract: In Georgian London, a tale of seduction, sex, love, death and the pianoforte.
lead_paragraph: It’s 1794 in London. In the dark Virginia & Baltick coffeehouse, huddling in the pungent shadow of tallow candles, four rich men are hatching a plan to marry off their daughters. Risen from the underbelly of the city, wheeling and dealing, they’ve made their fortunes in cloth, fur and timber. They’re successful and wealthy, but now they want sons-in-law with titles who will produce “grandchildren of a certain kind.”

headline: Conrad in Vietnam
abstract: Ward Just’s novel, set largely before the American escalation in Vietnam, evokes “Lord Jim” and other works.
lead_paragraph: Ward Just is both a writer’s writer and an astute tracker of human souls under duplicity and duress. He writes incisively, with striking imagery and with deep knowledge of how people in power behave, from ambassadors coping with the world’s hot spots to Midwestern community leaders suppressing a local crime. Like many distinguished novelists, Just was a journalist first, covering Washington, London and Saigon before the release of his first novel in 1970. “American Romantic,” his 18th, is one of his finest. It has all the qualities Just’s regular readers look forward to, yet it’s an equally good place to be introduced to his work.

headline: California Pioneers the Court-Aided One-Day Divorce
abstract: Some courts in California offer a program that allows couples without lawyers to dissolve their marriages in hours. The concept could spread to more states.
lead_paragraph: MARISSA YORK, a real estate broker in Manhattan, used a $50 online do-it-yourself divorce kit when she and her husband of more than nine years decided to part ways. Their breakup was relatively amicable, she said, so she figured they could save money by avoiding lawyers. “We didn’t want to drag it out over months or years,” she said.

headline: Bright Young Assistants
abstract: A novelist recalls a post-college year working for an old-fashioned literary agency.
lead_paragraph: “My Salinger Year,” Joanna Rakoff’s breezy memoir of being a “bright young assistant” in the mid-1990s, opens with her decision to leave graduate school, desert her nice college boyfriend and move to New York to write poetry. Almost immediately, she falls for an overbearing aspiring novelist, takes a poorly paid job at a famous literary agency and lands in an unheated apartment in Williamsburg. “I wanted to be extraordinary,” she admits. Instead, she joins a legion of “girls” from comfortable backgrounds determined to live uncomfortably, at least briefly, in vague pursuit of Art.

headline: Leaders Meet to Honor D-Day
abstract: President Obama joined President François Hollande of France and others for a dinner while in Europe.
lead_paragraph: President Obama joined President François Hollande of France and others for a dinner while in Europe.

headline: Young and in Debt in New York City
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Student Loans', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: For the first time in a decade, student borrowers are less likely to take out home mortgages than other young people.
lead_paragraph: For young people, moving to New York City hasn’t made much mathematical sense for decades. The jobs don’t pay enough, the internships don’t pay at all, and the rents are prohibitive by any sane standard.

headline: Jackie Robinson and Nixon: Life and Death of a Political Friendship
keywords: ['Endorsements', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The political journey of the first African-American in major league baseball mirrored the movement of black voters to the Democratic party.
lead_paragraph: Here in Yankee Stadium’s locker room after Game 5 of the 1952 World Series, Senator Richard Nixon of California, Republican nominee for vice president, congratulates Jackie Robinson on the Brooklyn Dodgers’ 6-5 win over the Yankees. (The Dodgers ultimately lost in seven games.)

headline: Inside the List
abstract: The “Glee” star Lea Michele, whose “Brunette Ambition” is No. 13 on the advice, how-to and miscellaneous list, once tried to cover up acne using a strategy she’d seen on “Sex and the City.”
lead_paragraph: Spotted: The actress and singer Lea Michele, who plays Rachel Berry on “Glee,” has a book on the advice, how-to and miscellaneous list: “Brunette Ambition,” her breezily memoiristic style guide and advice manual for women, is No. 13 in its second week. Among other things, Michele reveals she once tried to cover up an outbreak of acne using a strategy she’d seen on TV. It didn’t go well: “Hilariously,” she writes, “I thought I had picked up a great concealing trick from ‘Sex and the City,’ when Carrie uses a black eyeliner to turn a zit into a beauty mark. Brilliant, except my skin was so bad I needed about 16 beauty marks. I went out with my girlfriends with black dots all over my face thinking I had the world fooled. They took one look at me and asked, ‘What . . . did you do to your face?’ ” These days, Michele more often opts for a homemade facial mask and the services of a professional dermatologist to keep her skin clear. She also goes without makeup if possible. “Whenever I can, I give my skin a vacation,” she says. “It’s nice to remember what I actually look like.”

headline: Fashion’s Embrace of Reality TV
abstract: Diane von Furstenberg is in the midst of filming her own series, “The DVF Project” for E!, signifying the first embrace of the pop-culture phenomenon by an establishment name since Michael Kors took on “Project Runway” in 2004.
lead_paragraph: The fashion/reality TV love affair is still going strong

headline: This Is What a Cursed Soccer Stadium Looks Like
abstract: 64 years after the devastating 1950 World Cup, Maracanã stadium will host another final. Can the home team erase the memory of what happened there the last time?
lead_paragraph: The place was built for a coronation, a colossal theater where hundreds of thousands could bear witness and celebrate. When Maracanã opened in 1950, in the heart of Rio, it was the world’s largest stadium, the site of what Brazil was certain would be its first World Cup championship. And things started well enough: The host country breezed through to the final match, where, because of tournament rules at the time, it needed only a draw against Uruguay to win the whole event. With little more than 10 minutes to go, the score was 1-1, and the fans were on edge. Then the Uruguayan winger Alcides Ghiggia put them over with a sudden strike. “Only three people have, with just one motion, silenced the Maracanã,” he famously said later. “Frank Sinatra, Pope John Paul II and me.”

headline: Reply All: The 5. 25.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: CAN THE NERVOUS SYSTEM BE HACKED?

headline: Who Made That Autocorrect?
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Word Processing', 'Software', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Spelling']
abstract: Real-time spell-checkers grow more sophisticated.
lead_paragraph: “How fast will new Word 6.0 fix typos? How fast can you make them?” asked an advertisement in a computer magazine from October 1993. The newest version of Microsoft’s word processor came with a brand-new feature called AutoCorrect. Type in “SHip teh cartons friday,” and the program would correct your text to “Ship the cartons Friday.”

headline: The World Cup Soundtrack
abstract: If you want to find the best funk music in Brazil, you’ll need to stray far from the stadiums.
lead_paragraph: The volume rattles the bones. The gyrations evoke scenes of lustful abandon. In some of funk’s most explicit forms, tracks sprinkled with the prerecorded sounds of machine-gun fire exalt the drug gangs still in control of some of Rio de Janeiro’s favelas. On certain nights, the bass from the amps resonates from the hillside slums into the bastions of the privileged classes, as if to remind them: Rio doesn’t belong just to you.

headline: Sleep Now, Die Later
abstract: The perils of napping; Clay Aiken vs. Henry Clay.
lead_paragraph: The perils of napping; Clay Aiken vs. Henry Clay.

headline: Help! I’ve Fallen, and I Don’t Want Help
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: When to leave people — and trash — where they lie.
lead_paragraph: I was on the subway when another passenger passed out. The train made an emergency stop, and medical responders assisted the person, despite her screaming — after she came to — that she wanted to be left alone. If the woman was saying she did not want to be helped, even if in critical condition, is someone ethically allowed to obey her and let her suffer? Or would it be a crime to let her suffering continue? ELISABETH BUCHWALD, SCARSDALE, N.Y.

headline: Where the View Gets a Standing Ovation
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Theater']
abstract: Barry and Fran Weissler, Broadway producers, chose their high-floor apartment for its killer views.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve got to be where my spirit can run free,” sings the lost-soul title character in the hit Broadway revival of “Pippin.” “Got to find my corner of the sky.”

headline: Pakistan Suspends License of Leading News Channel
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Television', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The 15-day suspension of Geo is seen as a sign of growing tensions between the country’s civilian and military leaders.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Pakistani government on Friday suspended the broadcasting license of Geo News, a popular television channel, in a major escalation of Geo’s dispute with the country’s powerful Inter-Services Intelligence spy agency.

headline: Today in Small Business: Why Burt Was Ousted
abstract: The economy regains the 8.7 million jobs lost in the recession. An owner gives away a coffee shop. And why the co-founder of Burt’s Bees was ousted.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Former Investment Banker Joins Vatican Financial Watchdog
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Marc Odendall, who has worked for JPMorgan Chase, Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse First Boston, is one of four outside experts whom Pope Francis has appointed to oversee the Financial Information Authority at the Vatican.
lead_paragraph: The Vatican has turned to a European banker to help oversee its financial watchdog.

headline: Give Kids Your Undivided Attention — or No Attention At All
abstract: Either shut your phone and laptop down and be present, or grab the gadgets and get to work. It’s the half-measures of attention that don’t work for parents or kids.
lead_paragraph: Here is what I wish I’d known, from 14-some years into this parenting gig: Leave the children alone when you must and then really be with them when you can. Or, to put it slightly differently: Alternate fully engaging with fully ignoring them. There is, of course, an implied “instead of” here — instead of half paying attention to them all the time (cough smartphone cough).

headline: Thoughts on Dark Pools and Michael Lewis
abstract: The new Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into high frequency trading and so-called dark pools is long overdue.
lead_paragraph: The new Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into high frequency trading and so-called dark pools — as announced yesterday by Chairwoman Mary Jo White — is long overdue. As speed has become the most important factor in getting the absolute best price, high-frequency traders have gained advantages over other investors that are undeniable. Some of these firms almost never have down days anymore. More and more, the average investor has to feel that the game is rigged.

headline: Not Just an Easy Commute
abstract: Developers have broken ground on several luxury residential projects in Midtown East in recent months.
lead_paragraph: Midtown East does not usually make an apartment hunter’s shortlist.

headline: Déjà View
abstract: The baroque French chateau of Vaux Le Vicomte, a quieter but equally majestic alternative to Versailles, has undergone a majestic restoration.
lead_paragraph: Vaux Le Vicomte, a quieter but equally majestic alternative to Versailles, has undergone a simple yet spectacular restoration. The wooden doors blocking the view through the north and south arcades of the chateau have been removed, reinstating the original transparency between the interiors and the grounds proposed in the 17th century by the architect Louis Le Vau and the royal gardener André Le Nôtre. vaux-le-vicomte.com

headline: Summer Reads, Courtesy of JPMorgan
abstract: You won’t find any Faulkner on JPMorgan’s summer reading list, but titles by Arianna Huffington and the physicist Michio Kaku made the cut.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase provides advice to clients across the globe on complex financial matters.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘The Fault in Our Stars,’ ‘Edge of Tomorrow’ and ‘Obvious Child’
abstract: Times critics on “Obvious Child,” “The Fault in Our Stars” and “Edge of Tomorrow.”
lead_paragraph: In this video, Times critics offer their thoughts on “Obvious Child,” “The Fault in Our Stars” and “Edge of Tomorrow.” Read all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Gone With Barely a Trace
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'ARCADES']
abstract: The Windsor Arcade went up on the site of a hotel fire that took many lives. The dead were never memorialized.
lead_paragraph: The flamboyantly decorated Windsor Arcade of 1901, on Fifth Avenue from 46th to 47th Street, spread a layer of Beaux-Arts frosting over the site of a gruesome hotel fire, and presents a cautionary tale for anyone wrestling with memory and monuments.

headline: Biking Just Beyond the Big City
abstract: Gotham Bicycle Tours is offering multiple-day camping trips in the Hudson Valley and Long Island.
lead_paragraph: As passionate cyclists and campers, Bronx residents Lukas Herbert and Laura Willis have introduced friends to their avocation and hope to see their fellow city riders discover the joys of multiple-day bicycle touring. But they know an impediment exists.

headline: ‘The Invasion of Europe From the West Has Begun’
abstract: The language of the article that appeared in The New York Times about the D-Day invasion was simple, and the events it described were anything but.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As 160,000 Allied soldiers began to swarm the Normandy beaches on June 6, 1944, an ocean away New York Times editors scrambled to put out a special 6 a.m. edition heralding a seminal moment of World War II.

headline: For Missing Major Crown, Djokovic Must Dethrone a Dominant King
abstract: Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal advanced to the final of the French Open, where Djokovic will seek his first title while Nadal will seek his ninth.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Novak Djokovic knows that the road to his first French Open title goes through Rafael Nadal. It is a road he has not crossed before, but one he knows he can cross.

headline: Family-Friendly Tax Reform and The Poor
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Payroll Tax', 'Poverty', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Does reform conservatism’s proposed child tax credit leave the poor out in the cold?
lead_paragraph: Having promised them some time ago, before a week of travel left me behind on blog posts, I hope to have responses up next week to some of the recent macro-level liberal takes on “reform conservatism” — from E.J. Dionne, William Galston, and my colleague Tom Edsall, among others.

headline: World Leaders Honor D-Day Anniversary
abstract: President François Hollande of France and President Obama spoke to veterans at the Normandy American Cemetery at Omaha Beach on the 70th anniversary of the D-Day landing.
lead_paragraph: President François Hollande of France and President Obama spoke to veterans at the Normandy American Cemetery at Omaha Beach on the 70th anniversary of the D-Day landing.

headline: D-Day’s Wheels Roll Again
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Military Vehicles']
abstract: Thousands of military enthusiasts in trucks, jeeps and other Army vehicles converged on Normandy, France, to mark the 70th anniversary of D-Day.
lead_paragraph: ÉTRÉHAM, FRANCE — Like many families spending part of this summer on the road, Kevin and Brenda Goodwin of Felixstowe, England, are taking their holiday in a big R.V. with two beds, a kitchen, a bathroom with a shower and a pair of bicycles lashed to the front.

headline: Saudi Arabia and Iran Reach Out Tentatively
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: With the Persian Gulf region still in tumult, there have been surprising signs that Tehran and Riyadh are looking to temper their destructive rivalry.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The fevered struggle between Saudi Arabia and Iran for regional dominance has for years aggravated nearly every conflict across the Middle East as the two nations armed, funded and encouraged each other’s adversaries.

headline: Feeling Old on the Internet
abstract: The feeling of oldness has been decoupled from actual biological aging — it may now be an end in itself.
lead_paragraph: Would you like to know how many times the moon has orbited the earth since you were born — or, more soberingly, what percentage of people born on the same day as you have died? Now you can find out this information, along with a great many more depressing facts about your senescence, at the website You’re Getting Old.

headline: Ronaldo, Neymar and Iniesta in (Superslow) Motion
abstract: How three World Cup stars do what they do best.
lead_paragraph: How three World Cup stars do what they do best.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Invention of News’
abstract: This week, David Carr discusses Andrew Pettegree’s “The Invention of News”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the week’s literary news; Molly Worthen talks about new books by and about Jimmy Carter; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, David Carr discusses Andrew Pettegree’s “The Invention of News”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the week’s literary news; Molly Worthen talks about new books by and about Jimmy Carter; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Wheelies: The Z06 Power Edition
abstract: Chevrolet announces specifications for the 2015 Corvette Z06; Mercedes-Benz says it will double its urban sales locations.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Bergdahl Missteps
abstract: The White House could have headed off some of the rather predictable criticism.
lead_paragraph: The right-wing backlash to the prisoner exchange that freed Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl is unseemly, to put it politely, as we said on our editorial page this morning – a jumble of hypocritical flip-flops and hyperbolic statements based on no evident facts, with a nice thick coating of politicizing and propagandizing.

lead_paragraph: As autographed pictures go, there may be none so damning as the one that David Lloyd George, Britain’s prime minister during the latter part of World War I, inscribed on Dec. 1, 1933: “To Chancellor Hitler, with admiration for his brilliant gift of courage.”

headline: Throw FIFA Out of the Game
abstract: People don’t have to be displaced and workers don’t need to die for soccer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — MOST people associate FIFA, the organization that oversees international soccer, with the quadrennial joy of the World Cup. But as the 2014 tournament begins next week in Brazil, FIFA is plagued by levels of corruption, graft and excess that would shame Silvio Berlusconi.

abstract: There are complicated reasons that only a small percentage of employees feel engaged and satisfied at work. There are also simple solutions that managers can introduce at virtually no cost that would make any workplace more humane and desirable.

headline: Bergdahl and Our Distance from the Battlefield
abstract: As we talk about the behavior of soldiers, let’s acknowledge the gaps in our knowledge and investment
lead_paragraph: I have a big, big problem with many of the people who so quickly judge the actions of Bowe Bergdahl, and I have a big, big problem with many of those who jump in to say how the soldiers around him should or shouldn’t feel and how our armed forces should or shouldn’t behave.

headline: For Another Kind of Platform
abstract: An app called Tunnel Vision turns the subway map into a fount of information about both New York and the subway system itself.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is expanding wireless coverage in stations across New York, but for now there’s still a good chance of getting caught on a platform with nothing new to read or see on your phone. If you find that possibility horrifying, you might consider downloading Tunnel Vision, an app that turns the subway map into a fount of information about both New York and the subway system itself.

headline: For de Blasio, Deals, Drama and (Maybe) Progress
abstract: Any political figure like Bill de Blasio, who came to power by the hand of moral authority and in possession of a big agenda for reform, is going to be judged more harshly than one who seems more obviously transactional.
lead_paragraph: If you have been in or around Downtown Brooklyn in recent days, you may have found yourself noticing a darkened haze in the color of the local mood ring. On Tuesday, activists gathered in Borough Hall to grieve over the fate of Long Island College Hospital, which is to be converted into a condominium site with some sort of health care facility, though it is uncertain how much of one. The hospital effectively closed last month, leaving residents in surrounding areas worried about curtailed services, in particular the prospect of waiting a dangerously long time for an ambulance. On May 31, a man in Red Hook did die after what was reported to be a long wait, and though it was unclear whether a direct connection existed, the episode served as a dramatic confirmation of the community’s apprehension.

headline: Classical Playlist: John Adams, Handel, Lewis Spratlan and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: LEWIS SPRATLAN: ‘Apollo and Daphne Variations’; other worksBoston Modern Orchestra Project, Gil Rose, conductorEliot Gattegno, on soprano and alto saxophones(BMOP/Sound)The American composer Lewis Spratlan, born in 1940, gained wide attention in 2000 when a concert version of Act II of his opera “Life Is a Dream,” which was completed in 1978 but had never been staged, won the Pulitzer Prize for Music. This welcome new recording from the impressive Boston Modern Orchestra Project offers three ingeniously written and distinctive Spratlan works. “A Summer’s Day” (2008) uses a simple, dreamy Celtic tune at the start as a jumping-off place for an elusive, complex suite that ruminates on the tensions below the surface of an inviting day. In his Concerto for Saxophone and Orchestra (2006), Mr. Spratlan finds a gripping, fresh approach to what might seem an awkward classical music genre; the music evolves from mystical musings to raw, jazzy vehemence. “Apollo and Daphne Variations” is like a Spratlan version of a Schumann suite, with alternating episodes of whimsy, frenzy and innocence. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Video: The Subaru XV Crosstrek Hybrid Won’t Save Much Green
abstract: A capable, utilitarian crossover with more power than the base model, the XV Crosstrek Hybrid will not turn in impressive fuel-economy numbers.
lead_paragraph: Subaru and Prius owners are fiercely loyal to their rides. Subie drivers (who often dwell in polar vortex regions) pledge their allegiance to the Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive flag. The evangelical hybrid camp is more obsessed with fuel economy than getting places quickly. Conversely, it’s unwise to off-road a Prius, and the only way to guarantee lofty m.p.g.s in a Subaru is coasting from a mountain summit.

headline: A Shift in Locale, but Still Hearty Italian
abstract: Francesca’s Italian Bistro, which has relocated from its former strip-mall quarters to the quaint center of Coventry, presents a curious amalgam of familiar dishes nicely executed and offbeat ones whose novelty at times exceeds their quality.
lead_paragraph: Francesca’s Italian Bistro, to the delight of its ardent fans, has relocated from its former strip-mall quarters to the quaint center of Coventry. The restaurant, while bigger, is still cozy: a dozen tables with a view into the kitchen, where gusts of flame kick up as Salvatore Urso deglazes a pan.
