headline: Liquidnet, a Dark Pool Operator, Is Fined $2 Million Over Customer Data
abstract: Liquidnet violated regulations as well as its own promises to members when it allowed a separate business unit to access confidential data about members’ trades, the S.E.C. said.
lead_paragraph: Liquidnet Holdings, a brokerage firm that operates a secretive trading venue, has agreed to pay a $2 million fine to settle accusations that it improperly used confidential information about its customers in marketing a new product, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Friday.

headline: A Two-in-One Tower
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Condominiums', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Luxury Goods and Services']

lead_paragraph: While a team approach to real estate development is not unusual, a new residential project near Madison Square Park is putting a different spin on the concept. Instead of a single high-rise created by multiple partners, the building is essentially split in half between two partners.

headline: U.S. and European Job Markets Take Different Paths
abstract: Unemployment levels in the United States have dropped back almost to the levels of fall 2008, but Europe has a grimmer story.
lead_paragraph: MORE than five years after the collapse of Lehman Brothers in September intensified a credit crisis, the labor market in the United States has almost recovered — at least as measured by the number of unemployed people. But in most of Europe, the number of jobless workers remains substantially higher than it was then.

headline: Happenings | The Beloved Bangkok Eatery Bo.Lan Pops Up in New York
abstract: This weekend, the restaurant is operating out of a large art studio on Greenwich Street. Last night, the wunderkind artist Korakrit Arunanondchai hosted a party for the art and fashion set there.
lead_paragraph: So many pop-ups happen solely for marketing purposes these days that it’s refreshing to find one that reflects the original intent behind the concept: fleeting, spontaneous pleasure. This weekend, New Yorkers can rejoice in the news that, apropos of nothing, one of Bangkok’s most beloved eateries, Bo.Lan, is operating an outpost in a massive, tumbledown art studio opposite the UPS hangar on Greenwich Street. On Saturday and Sunday, the wife-and-husband chef duo of Bo Songvisava and Dylan Jones (their restaurant’s moniker is a Kimyeification of their names) will dish up a tasting menu of regional Thai specialties for an intimate group of strangers.

headline: Cooking With Nuts and Seeds
abstract: Nuts and seeds like sunflower, pumpkin, chia and sesame are loaded with nutrients and give dishes heft and a satisfying texture.
lead_paragraph: For years, nutritionists have been urging us to eat nuts in place of high-carb and sugary snacks. Regulators allow purveyors of peanuts, almonds, walnuts, pistachios, hazelnuts and pecans to make claims that these nuts, as part of a diet low in saturated fats and cholesterol, may help reduce the risk of heart disease.

headline: So You Want to Watch a Weepie
abstract: If “The Fault in Our Stars” doesn’t satisfy your need for heartbreak, here are a few other candidates.
lead_paragraph: Are you looking for a little bring-me-down? Have you been distraught by reports of Netflix shutdowns in the middle of the night, just when the new season of “Orange Is the New Black” became available? Has someone shamed you for reading young-adult literature?

headline: Who’s Listening to that Vodafone Call?
abstract: Vodafone, the British wireless company, published its first law enforcement disclosure report about the requests for access it gets from governments in 29 countries.
lead_paragraph: Since Edward Snowden’s revelations, many Internet and telecommunications firms have begun telling the world more about the kind and quantity of private information public agencies seek and get from them—a small step toward peeling back the shroud of secrecy over government surveillance.

headline: Taking a Spin: What if the Democrats Won in Appalachia?

headline: Nigerian Television Becomes Front for U.S. in Terrorism Fight
abstract: State Department officials acknowledged that their efforts to directly challenge Boko Haram could prove challenging in a region racked by massacres, bombings and shootings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department is financing a new 24-hour satellite television channel in the turbulent northern region of Nigeria that American officials say is crucial to countering the extremism of radical groups such as Boko Haram. The move signals a ramping up of American counterinsurgency efforts to directly challenge the terrorist group, which abducted nearly 300 Nigerian schoolgirls in April.

lead_paragraph: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, they’ll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: A Toast to Mudslinging: This Drink’s for Mississippi
abstract: A race with so much dirty politics deserves a cocktail to match: a version of the Mississippi Mudslide.
lead_paragraph: No two ways about it: The race for the Mississippi Senate seat long held by Thad Cochran is ugly. A supporter of his challenger, Chris McDaniel, faces charges for breaking into a nursing home and photographing Mr. Cochran’s wife, who is being treated for dementia. The bitter primary race was so close on Tuesday that it is now heading to a runoff election June 24.

lead_paragraph: California Chrome, a shiny chestnut colt with a signature white blaze, has won six consecutive races, including the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes, by a combined 27 1/2 lengths.

keywords: ['Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'Children and Childhood', 'Legal Profession']

abstract: Mr. McMillon, 47, who started at the company at age 17, made an appearance at Walmart’s shareholders’ meeting on Friday.
lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. — Harry Connick Jr., Pharrell Williams, Robin Thicke and Sarah McLachlan all put on a show here Friday at the annual shareholders’ meeting of Walmart Stores.

headline: Fear of Equities Drives More Investors to Cash
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Money Market Accounts', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Millennials are hoarding cash at the same rate as baby boomers, researchers found, suggesting that anxiety about market crashes has yet to subside.
lead_paragraph: IF a lot of your portfolio is still sitting in cash after a five-year bull market in equities, you’re not alone. Investors at all wealth levels around the world are holding substantial amounts of cash that have increased since 2012. What this means for investors and the markets that depend on their money is intriguing.

lead_paragraph: A preview of summer dressing: hula-hoop-size hats with long or short dresses or with shorts, and dashing men.

abstract: Has the gun lobby spawned a movement it can’t control? Open Carry Texas is setting its own rules.
lead_paragraph: Has the National Rifle Association spawned a movement it can’t control, more radical than the radicals and ultimately self-destructive?

headline: Bill Cunningham | A-twirl
abstract: A preview of summer dressing: hula-hoop-size hats with long or short dresses or with shorts, and dashing men.
lead_paragraph: Like a rainbow-colored tornado, a woman on Eighth Avenue was spinning what appeared to be 45 hula hoops. On Wednesday, family night at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, hula hoops were revived for the kindergarten set. Last Saturday, more than 5,000 picnickers boarded ferries at Battery Park for the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic held at Liberty State Park. It was a preview of summer dressing: hula-hoop-size hats with long or short dresses or with shorts, and dashing men.

headline: Move Over, Penguins, Marathon Coming Through
abstract: A marathon in Antarctica makes laps over hills and through mud and ice.
lead_paragraph: At the tail end of the most bone-chilling winter in recent years, I left New York for Antarctica, the coldest and driest place on earth, where the sun never completely sets.

headline: Lost in Time in England’s Northeast
abstract: Peeling back the centuries on a trip to towns that dot this corner of the country along the North Sea.
lead_paragraph: My gateway drug to serious Anglophilia was horses — the British Pony Club Manual of Horsemanship, my English saddle made by Barnsby — but the addiction was truly about words. What, for example, could “Hounds, gentlemen, please” possibly mean? This was a sign along the roadside near the stable where we kept my horse outside St. Louis. I turned it over in my mind for months before I understood that drivers were being asked to slow down if foxhounds were in the vicinity.

headline: In Argentina, Wine, Art and Altitude
abstract: A mountain winery and the only museum in the world solely dedicated to the artist James Turrell combine at Colomé.
lead_paragraph: Our friends love modern art but don’t really drink; my companion and I are closer to the reverse. So as we researched places where we could travel and all come away happy, Colomé, in northwest Argentina, stood out. It’s a mountain winery with a contemporary art museum and sounded like the perfect two-couple compromise — a little bit high culture, a little bit grand cru.

headline: A Starter Kit for Military Collectors
abstract: Jeeps from World War II are ubiquitous at military vehicle shows, and they are a starting point for many people getting into the collecting hobby.
lead_paragraph: To the Army, it was known simply as the G503 or the quarter-ton, but to millions of soldiers it quickly became the jeep, a coinage generally linked to a character from the Popeye cartoon strip, Eugene the Jeep. Today, wartime jeeps are ubiquitous at military vehicle shows, and they are starting point for most people getting into the collecting hobby.

headline: Austrian Journalist Convicted in Holocaust Restitution Case Vows to Appeal
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Stephan Templ, accused of defrauding the state by omitting a relative from a restitution claim for property looted by the Nazis in 1939, was sentenced to one year in prison.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Stephan Templ, an Austrian journalist convicted of defrauding the Austrian state of about $748,000 in a Holocaust restitution case, vowed Friday to appeal to the European Court for Human Rights in Strasbourg, France, after a high court in Vienna sentenced him to one year in prison and two years of probation.

headline: Extravagant Wedding Cakes Rise Again
abstract: Couples are returning to big weddings with show-off cakes.
lead_paragraph: Reports of the demise of the wedding cake have been exaggerated.

headline: Obama Aide Defends Remarks on Bergdahl’s ‘Honor’
abstract: The national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, insisted that she had been right to assert that Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl served with “honor and distinction.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, found herself in a familiar predicament this week: under fire from Republicans for statements she made about a murky sequence of events involving Americans in a distant land.

headline: I Was Promised Flying Cars
abstract: Why don’t they exist? Because nature’s fundamental forces remain a mystery.
lead_paragraph: AS an astronomy-obsessed kid in the 1970s, I subsisted on a steady diet of science fiction. It promised a future filled with technological wonders: talking computers, bionic limbs, flying cars. Forty years later, though much of that future has arrived, it’s still missing what I consider its most important ingredient. Sure, we’ve got the iPhone’s Siri, and the Food and Drug Administration just approved a prosthetic arm controlled by signals from the brain — but where are our smooth-gliding flying machines, our Landspeeders (“Star Wars”) and airborne DeLoreans (“Back to the Future”)?

headline: A Player Who Is Rarely at a Loss for Words
abstract: Gulbis, who lost in the semifinals of the French Open, his best showing at a Slam yet, spoke candidly and entertainingly about his tennis game throughout the tournament.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Ernests Gulbis entertained on and off the court in his run to the semifinals of the French Open, his best showing at a Grand Slam event. Gulbis spoke candidly and memorably throughout the tournament.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring George Takei and Tracey Emin
abstract: Tracey Emin and George Takei get snuggly with a heat-activated handbag while considering a speaker and spacesuits.
lead_paragraph: George Takei, “Star Trek” alum, announcer for “The Howard Stern Show” and gay activist whose documentary, “To Be Takei,” hits theaters in August, takes on Tracey Emin, a rabble-rousing English artist who rose to fame in the 1990s with confessional works like “Everyone I Have Ever Slept With 1963-1995.” A moving series of her digital neons, “I Promise to Love You,” is on view now at the Cosmopolitan Hotel in Las Vegas. A musical inspired by Takei’s childhood incarceration in U.S. internment camps comes to Broadway this fall.

headline: A Splashy and Celestial Affair
abstract: Nick Denton, the publisher and founder of Gawker Media, was married to Derrence Washington at the American Museum of Natural History on May 31.
lead_paragraph: Nick Denton, the publisher and founder of Gawker Media, was married to Derrence Washington at the American Museum of Natural History on May 31.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a West Islip, L.I., six-bedroom and a Pound Ridge, N.Y., farmhouse.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties include co-op lofts in TriBeCa and Greenwich Village, and a Bay Ridge townhouse.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Readers’ Choice: Who’ll Take a Tony?
abstract: New York Times readers predict that “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” Neil Patrick Harris and Audra McDonald will take prizes on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: The deadline for Tony Award voters to turn in ballots was 6 p.m. on Friday, but dozens of ArtsBeat readers have already weighed in with picks and predictions this week ahead of Sunday’s Tony ceremonies. How’d you call the major races?

headline: A Good Man With Pepper Spray
abstract: It wasn’t a ‘good guy with a gun’ that disrupted an attempted mass shooting in the Pacific Northwest yesterday.
lead_paragraph: And the only thing that can stop a bad man with a gun is a good man with…pepper spray! So it went in the attempted mass shooting at Seattle Pacific University Thursday, when a gunman opened fire in a campus hall. One student was killed, several others injured. But it could have been far worse had not a student campus monitor, Jon Meis, pepper-sprayed the shooter and put him a chokehold.

headline: Big Ticket | $30.4 Million for a Midtown Three-Bedroom
abstract: A three-bedroom apartment in the popular A-line of the 90-story One57 tower was the most expensive sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: Another of the glassy three-bedroom aeries in the popular A line at the Extell Development Company’s 90-story Midtown tower, One57, sold for $30,449,175 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. For now, the monthly carrying costs for the 4,483-square-foot condominium, No. 61A, are a mere $7,545, thanks to a tax abatement.

headline: In Britain, Child’s Weight Leads to Parents’ Arrest
abstract: The police called it a rare step when they arrested the parents of a 210-pound, 11-year-old boy on suspicion of neglect and child cruelty.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The parents of an 11-year-old boy were arrested in Britain on suspicion of neglect and child cruelty after authorities grew alarmed about the child’s weight.

headline: Inequality, Fertility and the Rich
abstract: Should egalitarian liberals favor child tax credits for the upper class?
lead_paragraph: In my post earlier today on the distributional impact of a new child tax credit, I noted that the benefits to richer families under a plan like Senator Mike Lee’s would diminish if, in pursuit of revenue neutrality, the plan phased out its expanded tax credit at higher income levels. (The current child tax credit has a phase-out that begins at $110,000 for married joint filings.) But as a coda, it’s worth noting that to the extent that family-friendly policy actually boosts fertility — a highly uncertain question, to be sure — egalitarian liberals might want to think twice about a child tax credit phase-out, because then they wouldn’t reap the potentially egalitarian benefits of higher fertility in the upper class.

headline: Drifting Back to the Real World
abstract: Richard Strauss, born in Munich 150 years ago, gained fame with scandalous works before taking his experimentalism into the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Richard Strauss, born in Munich 150 years ago this Wednesday, must have laughed over the condemnations, even from many critics, of his opera “Salome” after its 1905 premiere in Dresden. Before long, of course, this succès de scandale was playing to eager audiences across Europe. The royalties Strauss earned paid for his bucolic villa in Garmisch.

headline: Booed in the ’60s, but Time Will Tell
abstract: A rigorous composer, clarinetist and tenor saxophonist, Jimmy Giuffre broke from the jazz mainstream in the 1960s, but by today’s standards, his music sounds modern.
lead_paragraph: It’s anyone’s guess what Jimmy Giuffre was thinking when he improvised the stark, intriguing solo clarinet pieces intended for his 1962 Columbia album, “Free Fall.” Along with the five that made the cut, there were five others that saw the light of day some 35 years later, as bonus tracks on an overdue reissue. Small gems of oblique investigation, they bear titles that seem to hint at Giuffre’s state of mind; among them is one with a lonesome air, played in shadowy subtones, that he called “Time Will Tell.”

headline: D-Day Combat Vehicles
abstract: Images from a 70th anniversary D-Day rally of military vehicles in and around Normandy, France.
lead_paragraph: Images from a 70th anniversary D-Day rally of military vehicles in and around Normandy, France.

headline: Double Strawberry Cheesecake
abstract: Melissa Clark makes a stunner of a dessert: a lighter, more flavorful double strawberry cheesecake made with goat cheese and red wine.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes a stunner of a dessert: a lighter, more flavorful double strawberry cheesecake made with goat cheese and red wine.

headline: A Strawberry Cheesecake That Is Red and White and Pink All Over
abstract: This dessert encourages the cream and strawberries to unite in juicy-creamy joy.
lead_paragraph: Picture a strawberry cheesecake: white and creamy cake on the bottom, bright red berries on top. Maybe the berries are fresh and ripe and leak a little of their tart juice onto the dense cake below. More likely, the berries are sealed in shiny, syrupy goop. Either way, you get a separation of strawberries and cream, with the two playing off each other in juicy-creamy succession.

headline: Two Paths to the Same Destination
abstract: A man who lives by logic meets an artist who shows him how much more there is to life.
lead_paragraph: Nick Denton, the publisher and founder of Gawker Media, was approaching a group of his wedding guests who were smoking on a terrace of the American Museum of Natural History. Those familiar with the stern side of Mr. Denton, who was married at the museum on May 31 to Derrence Washington, might have thought they would be reprimanded. Instead he grinned and said: “We’re gathering everyone for a group photo. We have a guy up there.”

headline: Not a Happy Camper
abstract: A mother sending her child to camp reveals the truth: When she was a girl, she couldn’t stand it.
lead_paragraph: I’m about to thrust my child into a four-week-long situation that I know, from experience, to be a total misery. Of course, I’m not going to tell her this. Introducing children to new and potentially life-altering experiences necessarily means trying to convince them that terrible things are just fine, even good.

headline: Smooth Sounds Don’t Always Slide Into Easy Categories
abstract: José James, Gabriel Kahane, Magos & Limón, Jimmy Cobb and Manuel Valera have new albums.
lead_paragraph: José James

headline: Evening Hours | A Breath of Fresh Air
abstract: Stepping out for fun and to do good.
lead_paragraph: Stepping out for fun and to do good.

headline: Code Name Parmigiano
abstract: Behind the scenes at a Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese producer.
lead_paragraph: Behind the scenes at a Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese producer.

headline: The World Through Stewart Rahr’s Neon Glasses
abstract: Mr. Rahr, 68, a billionaire philanthropist and playboy, spends his time with celebrities, whom he calls friends. It’s not clear the feeling is mutual.
lead_paragraph: At a recent lunch at the Trump Grill, Stewart Rahr, a man of unnaturally orange skin who wears bright yellow Ray-Bans wherever he goes, whipped out his iPhone to prove that, despite tabloid reports to the contrary, he’s really a good guy.

headline: Diesels: Not Just for the Big Guys Anymore
abstract: By selling the market’s only half-ton diesel pickup in a time of tightening fuel-economy standards, Ram gives its corporate parent, Fiat Chrysler, a chance to stand out from the competition.
lead_paragraph: TESTED 2014 Ram 1500 EcoDiesel

headline: Electric, but Not Bragging About It
abstract: The 2014 Mercedes-Benz B-Class Electric Drive is the company’s first battery-electric car, but it is not a spartan green vehicle. In terms of its interior fit and finish, the car will feel right at home in a Mercedes showroom.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, CALIF. — Electric cars, by the nature of how their motors function, are capable of dispensing right-now torque in big satisfying jolts.

headline: Hauling Heavy Loads as It Lightens Wallets
abstract: The 2015 GMC Sierra Denali is a big workhorse, but it’s also a luxury vehicle that owners may not want to get dirty. Hauling mulch in a $64,000 vehicle seems extravagant.
lead_paragraph: ABERDEEN, N.C. — I wince as a half-yard of mulch cascades from the bucket of the skid-steer loader into the cargo bed of the 2015 GMC Sierra Denali 2500, a plume of drab dust mushrooming out to coat the Onyx Black body with flecks of bark and sawdust.

headline: A Night Out With Jessica Seinfeld
abstract: Ms. Seinfeld candidly admits that two of her three children barely pay attention to her these days, have an attitude and are sick of her cooking.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Seinfeld took one look at her friend Beth Buccini on Wednesday night at her Baby Buggy charity event and moved in to give her a pat-down. Maybe it had something to do with Ms. Seinfeld’s new short, blond haircut, which she refers to jokingly as “butch lesbian cousin.”

headline: GMC Sierra Denali: The $64,000 Question
abstract: As high-end pickups add the latest luxury appointments, truck prices have continued their steady climb. But is the GMC Sierra Denali — or any pickup — worth $64,575?
lead_paragraph: As high-end pickups add the latest luxury appointments, truck prices have continued their steady climb. But is the GMC Sierra Denali — or any pickup — worth $64,575?

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Arachnophobia Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a 36-year-old mother with fever, diarrhea and a strange sore on the back of her leg.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 36-year-old woman with several weeks of fever, fatigue, diarrhea and chest pain along with an ugly sore on the back of her leg. The correct diagnosis is …

headline: The GT40, Born of Ford’s Feud
abstract: The Ford GT40 has great bloodlines as one of the most successful endurance-racing cars of the 1960s, and it’s rare. Now, one is coming up for sale in California.
lead_paragraph: The Ford GT40 meets all the requirements for a platinum-grade collectible: It’s gorgeous, it has great bloodlines as one of the most successful endurance-racing cars of the 1960s and it’s rare (with just over 100 built).

headline: Shoe Companies Show a Red Card to Black Soccer Cleats
abstract: For the tournament in Brazil, major shoe companies have planned a veritable parade of pigments for cleats.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, soccer has gone through a number of memorable, if often regrettable, fashion trends. There was the alarming popularity of short shorts; the odd fixation on puffy, bloused jerseys; the bumblebee sock phase (not to be confused with the leg-warmer sock craze); and, in what was surely the sport’s couture low point, a brief dabble with the unitard.

headline: Three to Watch
abstract: Neymar, Oscar and Keisuke Honda are the ones to watch in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Name Neymar

headline: A Rare Taste of Vietnam on Long Island
abstract: Pho Maxia in Westbury, owned by Vietnamese brothers, is a new venue that offers inexpensive fare beyond its namesake.
lead_paragraph: It might seem that Pho Maxia, a new Vietnamese restaurant in Westbury, epitomizes the word “no.” There are no reservations, no credit cards, and no liquor license.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Group of Catholic and Orthodox Officials Endorses Marriage for Some Priests
abstract: A high-level group, the North American Orthodox-Catholic Theological Consultation, is calling on the Vatican to allow Eastern Catholic priests serving in North America to marry.
lead_paragraph: In a step that is sure to fuel the debate over mandatory celibacy, a high-level group of Catholic and Orthodox officials is calling on the Vatican to allow married men to serve as Eastern Catholic priests in North America.

headline: A Bridge Deal From the Reisinger Knockout Teams
abstract: The Reisinger Knockout Teams used to be a very popular event. Recently, though, the number of entries has dropped.
lead_paragraph: The Reisinger Knockout Teams used to be a very popular event. Recently, though, the number of entries has dropped noticeably. This year, six teams took part in a round robin on Memorial Day in New York City at the end of the Eastern States Regional.

headline: Prancing Into History of One Golden City
abstract: The American Classical Orchestra, with Bart van Oort on piano, paid tribute to Prague at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: A vibrant performance of Mozart’s “Prague” Symphony capped the concert of the American Classical Orchestra on Thursday at Alice Tully Hall and, with it, the ensemble’s season.

headline: A Composer Beyond His ‘Twilight Zone’
abstract: Marius Constant, who composed the theme to “The Twilight Zone,” had a place on a Riverside Symphony program with works by Bizet, Nielsen and Prokofiev.
lead_paragraph: Even the most obscure composers can have a remarkably large presence on YouTube. While researching the music of Marius Constant, whose works I was admittedly not familiar with before Wednesday evening, I was surprised to find hundreds of results on YouTube. But maybe that’s not unexpected after all, considering he composed the theme to the television classic “The Twilight Zone.”

headline: From a Wistful Queen, Longing and Regret
abstract: Mariella Devia returned to New York for an Opera Orchestra of New York concert performance of “Roberto Devereux” at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Divadom, like the price of gold, thrives on scarcity. The most elaborate mystiques and fervent cults build up around singers one rarely hears live. Any artist sounds better in a mixture of memories and hopes than in life.

headline: Who Will Be the Next David Beckham?
abstract: Every four years, the fashion world sees the World Cup tournament as a fertile hunting ground for its next big star. This year, all eyes will be on Neymar.
lead_paragraph: Really sexy. Super-foxy. I mean, that body.

headline: Wishing His Listeners Luck, a Pianist Dives In
abstract: Marino Formenti led listeners on a Liszt-inspired odyssey at his piano recital as part of the NY Phil Biennial.
lead_paragraph: Speaking to the audience that packed Lincoln Center’s Kaplan Penthouse on Wednesday night for his adventurous recital titled “Liszt Inspections,” the probing Italian pianist Marino Formenti ended his introductory comments with two words of encouragement.

headline: Secular Group, on Eve of Big Meeting, Fires Top Official Who Elevated Its Profile
abstract: Edwina Rogers, a Republican lobbyist, said she was given no warning by the Secular Coalition for America, for which she had worked for two years.
lead_paragraph: Atheists and nonbelievers from across the country will muster on Capitol Hill next week for a summit meeting organized by the Secular Coalition for America, a growing alliance of groups that has been giving the religious right an intensifying case of heartburn by lobbying for the separation of government and religion.

headline: ‘Plane Wreck at Los Gatos’
abstract: The folk singer Barbara Dane released this version of “Plane Wreck at Los Gatos” in 1973.
lead_paragraph: The folk singer Barbara Dane released this version of “Plane Wreck at Los Gatos” in 1973.

headline: A Work Is Rushed to a Debut, by Design
abstract: The New York Philharmonic, as part of its NY Phil Biennial, performed premieres by its composer in residence and an emerging artist on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The work that opened the New York Philharmonic’s concert on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall was selected for performance only two days earlier. There was not even time to list it in the program.

headline: An Artful Stealth Theme, Returning on Padded Feet
abstract: The Jeff Ballard Trio, playing at the Jazz Standard, has artful ways of being understood at a level just beyond what comes easily.
lead_paragraph: The jazz drummer Jeff Ballard tends to close the distance between himself and the other musicians he plays with. His drumming is active, busy, rarely loud and constantly shuffling pattern and timbre: He’s often trying to connect with, illustrate and magnify whatever else is happening around him.

headline: A Country Negotiation in Brooklyn
abstract: The country singer Michaela Anne performed on Thursday at Hill Country, a restaurant and live music venue in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Short of outright heckling, there probably aren’t many more dispiriting things you can shout at a performer from the crowd than “Are you on Spotify?”

headline: James and Air-Conditioning Are Expected to Return for Game 2
abstract: San Antonio’s overheated arena and LeBron James, who missed the final minutes of Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals with leg cramps, were said to be doing better on Friday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — When LeBron James noticed during warm-ups that AT&T Center was warmer than usual Thursday night for the start of the N.B.A. finals, he did something unusual for a creature of habit: He cut his routine short and sat on the scorer’s table, waiting for the game to start.

headline: A Selection of Documents From the National Archives
abstract: Here is a selection of the roughly 2,000 documents released on Friday. Subjects include Rwanda, policies toward gays in the military, the Oklahoma City bombing and Vice President Al Gore’s presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Here is a selection of the roughly 2,000 documents released on Friday. Subjects include Rwanda, policies toward gays in the military, the Oklahoma City bombing and Vice President Al Gore’s presidential campaign.

headline: State Street Financial Literacy Test
abstract: A series of questions was posed to 2,880 investors in the first quarter of 2014 in 16 countries globally.
lead_paragraph: A series of questions was posed to 2,880 investors in the first quarter of 2014 in 16 countries globally.

headline: Q. & A. | Hans-Ulrich Obrist on Curating the Swiss Pavilion at the Venice Architecture Biennale
abstract: The omnivorous curator discusses “A Stroll Through a Fun Palace,” his exhibition that explores the connections between two late-20th-century architectural thinkers: the architect Cedric Price and the political economist Lucius Burckhardt.
lead_paragraph: As if summer travelers needed any more incentive to descend on the sinking city of Venice, tomorrow the 14th International Architecture Exhibition of the Venice Biennale opens to the public. This year’s edition, directed by Rem Koolhaas, gets back to the basics of modern architecture, with dozens of exhibitions at national pavilions that delve into formative moments of the 20th century. The Swiss Pavilion is headed by Hans-Ulrich Obrist, the omnivorous curator and co-director of exhibitions and programs at the Serpentine Galleries in London. In it, Obrist has brought together two 20th-century figures whose research has influenced architectural thinking in their own time and since: the Swiss political economist Lucius Burckhardt and the English architect Cedric Price. Here, Obrist walks through the genesis of the pavilion’s exhibition “A Stroll Through a Fun Palace,” whose title refers to Price’s great unrealized construction, “Fun Palace,” and Burckhardt’s concept of “Strollology.”

headline: Russia Releases Greenpeace Ship
abstract: Russian prosecutors released the ship, the Arctic Sunrise, nearly nine months after seizing it following a protest at the first offshore oil platform in the Arctic, Greenpeace announced.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian prosecutors released a Greenpeace International ship nearly nine months after seizing it following a high-seas protest at the first offshore oil platform in the Arctic, the organization announced Friday.

headline: Hacking Into Prime Time With Attitude
abstract: Mackenzie Davis, 27, of “Halt and Catch Fire” on AMC, has philosophical conviction and a macabre pastime.
lead_paragraph: “I love seeing the insides of things,” Mackenzie Davis said, tucking her bleached bob behind her ears, a giraffe’s neck expanse above her slashed and safety-pinned Bart Simpson T-shirt. “It just fascinates me and always has.”

headline: Dazzling a Prince, Slowly, Gently, on Point
abstract: Frederick Ashton’s “Cinderella,” which enters the repertory of American Ballet Theater on Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House, is the only staging of Prokofiev’s score to stand the test of time.
lead_paragraph: Your world is not the only world: That’s the lesson of Romantic ballet. And when a grown woman moves from one world to another, she herself is transformed. In Prokofiev’s “Cinderella,” not only does the title character’s dream come true, but she becomes her dream version of herself.

headline: Giving a Satirist of the Third Reich the Last Laugh
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'German Language', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The work of Kurt Tucholsky, a left-wing German satirist, is becoming available in English-language editions, thanks to a tiny publishing house.
lead_paragraph: The Nazis kept a long list of writers to settle scores with, but one in particular inflamed them: the left-wing satirist Kurt Tucholsky. In magazine articles and comic poems, he took aim at nationalists, militarists and fat cats. He dipped his pen in a special, distilled venom to describe Hitler and his followers, whom he ridiculed as “little people” in the refrain of “Die Mäuler Auf!” (“Mouths Open!”), one of his most famous poems.

headline: World Cup Crib Sheet: Picking a Winner
abstract: If, as a World Cup viewer, you remain a free agent without any team loyalties, use this chart to help you pick a winning team.
lead_paragraph: We continue our series of crib sheets to help readers watch the World Cup like true fanatics. If, as a World Cup follower, you remain a free agent without any national-team loyalties, use this chart to help you arrive at a winning team.

headline: Eviction Battles Imperil a Queens Art Haven
keywords: ['Art', 'Evictions', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Landlords']
abstract: A conflict at a building housing studios in Ridgewood, Queens, has many worried that artists may be pushed out of the area.
lead_paragraph: Battles between artists and landlords are nearly as plentiful in New York City as galleries themselves.  But a recent spate of attempted evictions and other conflicts in a three-story brick building in Ridgewood, Queens, is buffeting a young outpost of the art world just as the area is earning a reputation for affordable studio space and vibrant openings.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
abstract: This week, Joe discusses G.M. and high-speed trading.
lead_paragraph: An internal investigation at General Motors into a faulty ignition switch concludes that there’s been an 11-year history of failures at the company. But the company’s C.E.O. said there is no proof of a conspiracy to hide the issue. Meanwhile, the faulty ignition switch — which costs less than a dollar to replace — has been blamed for more than a dozen deaths, led to recalls of millions of vehicles and resulted in a multi-million-dollar fine.

headline: Carl Icahn Discloses Stake in Family Dollar
abstract: The billionaire investor disclosed in a filing with regulators on Friday that he has a 9.39 percent stake in Family Dollar, which operates a chain of discount stores and has been under pressure to improve sales.
lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor who has taken on the likes of Apple and eBay, has identified a new target: Family Dollar Stores.

headline: Knausgaard Tour Arrives in Manhattan
abstract: Karl Ove Knausgaard spoke to Zadie Smith on Thursday night at the bookstore McNally Jackson.
lead_paragraph: “So, it’s the Beatles, right?” asked a passer-by on Thursday night to the crowd lined up outside McNally Jackson bookstore in SoHo for a conversation between Zadie Smith and the Norwegian novelist Karl Ove Knausgaard. People started queuing at about 4 p.m., two hours before the scheduled start of Mr. Knausgaard’s second New York City event in three nights to promote his six-part autobiographical novel “My Struggle.” (The third volume to be translated into English was published last week.)

headline: Graduating to Hit Shows
abstract: The short-lived CBS comedy “The Class,” which was recently released on DVD, is worth remembering for a cast filled with actors who have gone on to populate a bumper crop of hits.
lead_paragraph: It was a sitcom about Philadelphia-area third graders who reunited in their late 20s, and it was spun from the fertile minds of David Crane, a creator of “Friends,” and Jeffrey Klarik, a writer-producer of “Mad About You.” In the fall of 2006, “The Class” was the new CBS show with the season’s highest hopes. It was not to be dismissed.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lucius in Kansas
abstract: A little calm amid the storm.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been on the road within Europe for the last couple of days, not much time to seek out new music. So a really nice minimalist performance from one of my standing favorites; I love watching the evident joy of the performers:

headline: A Deadline for Goats to Get Out of Detroit
abstract: The hedge fund manager Mark Spitznagel wants to use his goats to promote urban renewal and farming, but the city has other ideas.
lead_paragraph: The campaign by the hedge fund manager Mark Spitznagel to let goats graze in Detroit has hit a snag.

headline: Bracing Beethoven Interpreter
abstract: Starting Wednesday, the New York Philharmonic presents the first of three programs featuring the distinguished pianist Yefim Bronfman.
lead_paragraph: The inaugural NY Phil Biennial, perhaps the most ambitious and extensive contemporary-music festival yet overseen by an American orchestra, has understandably claimed lots of attention. But starting Wednesday, the New York Philharmonic presents the first of three programs over three weeks featuring the distinguished pianist Yefim Bronfman, artist in residence this season with the orchestra, as soloist in the five Beethoven piano concertos and the “Triple” Concerto for Violin, Cello and Piano.

headline: Texts and Context, at the Modern
abstract: An exhibition opening on Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art has adapted its titled from a phrase in Gertrude Stein’s “Tender Buttons.”
lead_paragraph: Although it was 100 years ago that Gertrude Stein’s “Tender Buttons: Objects, Food, Rooms” was published, her Cubist writings about interior space evoked through light, emotions and memory, keep appearing in different guises, seeming just as contemporary now as when they were written. An exhibition opening on Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art has adapted its titled from a phrase in “Tender Buttons.” Called “Sites of Reason: A Selection of Recent Acquisitions,” it brings together 16 works by 13 artists, all of which have entered MoMA’s collection over the past few years but are only now on view there for the first time.

headline: In Its 10th Year, a Brooklyn Debut
abstract: Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet has developed a reputation for its powerhouse dancing and glamorous repertory.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet has developed a reputation for its powerhouse dancing and glamorous repertory, which skews toward the work of high-profile European choreographers. Its 10th anniversary brings a couple of firsts: first appearance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and first season under both a new artistic director, Alexandra Damiani, and new associate choreographer, Crystal Pite, who will create two new pieces for the troupe over the next three years.

headline: Unflinching View at a Festival
abstract: “Private Violence,” Cynthia Hill’s documentary film about domestic violence against women opens the 25th anniversary of the Human Rights Watch Festival.
lead_paragraph: “Private Violence,” Cynthia Hill’s gripping documentary film about domestic violence against women opens the 25th anniversary of the Human Rights Watch Festival on Friday with the cinematic equivalent of a brass-knuckled punch in the face. The film tells the stories of Deanna Walters, a North Carolina woman trying to escape an abusive husband, and Kit Gruelle, a dedicated advocate for battered women who championed Ms. Walters’s quest for justice after she was kidnapped and relentlessly brutalized in her husband’s truck during a four-and-a-half-day cross-country trip. When a North Carolina prosecutor decided that the severity of her beatings only a qualified as a misdemeanor Ms. Walters, with Ms. Gruelle’s encouragement, filed kidnapping charges.

headline: Northside Festival Booms in Brooklyn
abstract: It’s just another four nights in Brooklyn, only more so.
lead_paragraph: It’s just another four nights in Brooklyn, only more so. Clubs are full of local bands and selected visitors; there’s more music than anyone could possibly attend. The sixth annual Northside Festival, expanding each year, promises some 400 bands playing in Williamsburg and Greenpoint from Thursday through Sunday. There are free but ticketed shows (with an online R.S.V.P. to the festival) at McCarren Park, to be headlined, on Saturday, by Thee Oh Sees, playing typically brief, frenzied sets of manic garage rock, and on Sunday by Chvrches with their gleaming synth-pop conundrums. Music badges, for $80, encourage club hopping, but are subject to capacity limits; strategic fans may want to choose particular shows.

headline: A Rebranded Vice President
abstract: HBO’s dramas are known for throwing surprises at viewers, but the shocker of the year may have come last week on “Veep.”
lead_paragraph: HBO’s dramas are known for throwing surprises at viewers, but the shocker of the year may have come last week on one of its comedies: Selina Meyer got a haircut. Selina, the vice president and title character of “Veep,” walked into the office “rebranded,” as she put it, sporting a new, shorter look. “I never knew you had so much neck,” one member of her inner circle said. Another, out of earshot, was less kind. “It’s the worst use of scissors since my failed vasectomy,” he said.

headline: Tyra’s Next Top Show, Yoko Ono’s Touchy Prints and Altuzarra’s Latest Milestone
abstract: Plus, the waning eau de Abercrombie, RiRi’s banished ad in Britain and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from France, Central African Republic, India and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from France, Central African Republic, India and Afghanistan.

headline: Nazi Art-Looting Case May Proceed, Court Rules
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Art']
abstract: A federal appeals court issued a potentially far-reaching decision Friday that allows the victims of Nazi-related looting to press ahead with efforts to reclaim stolen artwork.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court in California issued a potentially far-reaching decision Friday that allows the victims of Nazi-related looting and their heirs to press ahead with legal efforts to reclaim stolen artwork.  The case involves two large portrayals of Adam and Eve by the 14th-century master Lucas Cranach the Elder that were taken from the prominent Jewish Dutch dealer Jacques Goudstikker in a forced sale and are now in the collection of the Norton Simon Museum in California. Goudstikker’s daughter-in-law, Marei Von Saher, has been trying to reclaim the dyptich for years but has repeatedly run into legal stumbling blocks.  In a 2-to-1 decision, though, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed a lower court’s decision and permitted Ms. Von Saher’s lawsuit to proceed.  The diptych was recovered and returned to the Netherlands after World War II, when the Dutch negotiated a partial settlement with Goudstikker’s widow, which did not cover the work. The Norton Simon bought the paintings in 1971 from a collector. In 2012, a district judge ruled against Ms. Von Saher, saying that the United States had fulfilled its obligations to restitute the art, and that any effort to alter the Dutch resolution of the case would interfere with the federal government’s sole authority over foreign policy. But the appeals panel noted that the United States had signed two international agreements — one in Washington in 1998, and another in Terezin, Czech Republic, in 2009 — intended to remove obstacles to the recovery of possessions stolen by the Nazis.  The Norton Simon released a statement saying it “remains confident that it holds complete and proper title” to the paintings and that it would “continue to pursue, consistent with its fiduciary duties, all appropriate legal options.”

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web.

headline: Taking a Stand, on Stools
abstract: “Los Monólogos de la Vagina,” a version of Eve Ensler’s work in Spanish, is using the typical rotating-cast format in its run at the Westside Theater.
lead_paragraph: “The Vagina Monologues,” Eve Ensler’s classic paean to women and their genitalia, is always a bit of a feminist rally: part humor, part outrage. That spirit of celebration and defiance runs through “Los Monólogos de la Vagina,” the Spanish-language version of the show at the Westside Theater, where the ebullient Daphne Rubin-Vega is bringing an extraordinary warmth and vivacity to the proceedings.

headline: Uber’s True Valuation Will Be About Timing
abstract: Uber’s fund-raising round, announced Friday, made it worth $17 billion — just five years after it started. But that’s all on paper.
lead_paragraph: Talk about getting rich quick. Uber’s fund-raising round, announced Friday, made it worth $17 billion just five years after the car service company started.

headline: Under Cover: Ronaldo, Messi and Neymar: Capturing Soccer’s Biggest Stars
abstract: Dylan Coulter, a photographer based in New York City, talks about the three days he spent in Spain photographing and filming Cristiano Ronaldo, Neymar da Silva Santos Jr. and Lionel Messi.
lead_paragraph: Every four years, people around the world grab their noisemakers, don their team jerseys and gather in stadiums, living rooms and local bars to watch the World Cup. How can such an expansive and consuming event be covered in a 60-page magazine issue? And then how do you boil that into a single cover image?

headline: Nowhere to Turn
keywords: ['Isla Vista, Calif, Massacre (2014)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Have you struggled to help a violent child? The Times would like to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: The killing of six people by a troubled 22-year-old in Isla Vista, Calif., last month is only one of the most recent in a string of shootings by young, disaffected men. Such episodes are a trauma for the communities that are hit, especially the families of the victims and the perpetrator. But they also cause a shiver of dread in certain parents all over the country, particularly those with teenagers and young adult children who seem capable of violence: Could my boy ever do that?

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Facebook said on Friday that it had blocked users in Pakistan from access to the pages of a popular Pakistani rock band and several left-wing political pages, drawing sharp criticism from free-speech activists who accused the American company of caving in to government censors.

headline: Is Softball Sexist?
abstract: Women played baseball before they could vote — and they still should.
lead_paragraph: OVER the next three weeks, baseball players from around the country will compete in three regional tryouts for a chance to make it onto the United States baseball team. These are among the most elite, dedicated and talented athletes in their sport, and the best of them will go on to play against teams from Japan, Australia, Canada, Hong Kong, Venezuela and Taiwan in the World Cup tournament held in September in Miyazaki, Japan. But the team receives almost no attention, and many of its members weren’t even able to play their sport in high school. These baseball players are women.

headline: Syria: Drought Adds to Woes, U.N. Says
abstract: The supply of safe water in Syria is now one-third of the level it was before March 2011 when the civil war began, Unicef officials said.
lead_paragraph: The supply of safe water in Syria is now one-third of the level it was before March 2011 when the civil war began, Unicef said Friday in a report that warns of new levels of suffering because of a worsening regional drought. The report said the 9.6 million Syrians affected by the conflict, half of them children, are at increased risk of disease because the water scarcity has compounded problems caused by damage to water and sewage systems. Parts of Syria have received the lowest levels of rainfall in more than half a century, the report said, and most parts of the country have only received half the average rainfall of a normal year. The drought also threatens to put new pressures on Jordan, Lebanon and Iraq, where Syrian refugees are already straining the water supply.

headline: Where Should You Watch the World Cup in New York City?
abstract: There is no shortage of places to watch soccer games in the city, especially during the World Cup. Tell us your favorite hangout.
lead_paragraph: Outside Brazil, there is probably no better place to watch the World Cup than the world’s city — New York. The usual spots, like The Football Factory, in Manhattan, and Woodwork, in Brooklyn, will be showing the games, of course, but every four years, the list of places to watch grows longer. Tapas bars are transformed into cheering sections for La Roja. Italian spaghetti joints become filled with passionate Azzurri fans. And bars typically crowded with American football loyalists draw fans of that other brand of football.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If the Keystone XL pipeline is not built — and more oil from the Canadian oil sands is moved by rail — there could be hundreds more deaths and thousands more injuries than expected over the course of a decade, according to an updated State Department analysis of the contested project that was released Friday.

lead_paragraph: General Motors is recalling about 105,500 vehicles in two actions – one because a warning chime is inoperative and the other because air bags may not deploy in a crash, the automaker said. So far this year, the automaker has issued 34 recalls covering nearly 15.9 million vehicles across North America, including 13.9 million in the United States.

headline: P.O.W. Deal Gives Qatar a Victory, and a New Test
abstract: There is much on the line for Qatar, which has wagered its already weakened reputation on keeping the five Taliban militants freed from Guantánamo Bay in exchange for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl out of sight and under control.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — The five hardened Taliban militants were quickly whisked in a fleet of cars to the shoulder of a highway on the outskirts of the capital just as they arrived. There, out of the public eye and under the watchful gaze of Qatari security, they exchanged warm hugs with a welcome delegation and then once more were whisked off into hiding.

headline: I Approved This Message; My Family Delivered It

abstract: Some of the latest ads for Senate candidates feature cute children and supportive parents, some of them famous, including former Senator Sam Nunn and Moon Landrieu, a former New Orleans mayor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Still relatively early in the 2014 election cycle, candidates are trying to introduce themselves — or reintroduce, as the case may be — to voters. And amid a panoply of negative spots, image mavens and ad wizards have found a way to try to help their politicians cut through the clutter: family, family, family. A look at some of the latest ads that feature kin (appealing parents, cute children) in supporting roles.

headline: General Motors Recalls 105,500 Vehicles
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: General Motors is recalling vehicles because a warning chime is inoperative and because air bags may not deploy in a crash.
lead_paragraph: General Motors is recalling about 105,500 vehicles in two actions — one because a warning chime is inoperative and the other because air bags may not deploy in a crash, the automaker said. So far this year, the automaker has issued 34 recalls covering nearly 15.9 million vehicles across North America, including 13.9 million in the United States. The largest recall announced on Friday involves the warning-chime issue and includes about 69,500 of the automaker’s newest pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, including 57,500 in the United States. The models affected by the recall are the 2014 Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra light-duty pickups, the 2015 Silverado and Sierra heavy-duty pickups and the 2015 Chevrolet Tahoe, Suburban and GMC Yukon and Yukon XL S.U.V.s. The air bag problem affects 36,000 vehicles in North America, including 31,500 in the United States. The models covered by the recall are the 2012 Buick Verano and the Chevrolet Camaro, Cruze and Sonic.

headline: Day of Reckoning for N.C.A.A.
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'College Athletics', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Basketball (College)']
abstract: An antitrust trial begins Monday that could upend big-time college sports.
lead_paragraph: I began writing about the N.C.A.A. two and a half years ago, more or less by accident. Assigned by The New York Times Magazine to imagine a scheme in which athletes in the revenue sports — football and men’s basketball — get paid, I was awakened for the first time to inequities in the world of big-time college sports. Of course I knew that the coaches were getting rich while the players were getting nothing; everybody knew that. But I didn’t think that much about it. Neither did most fans, I would venture to guess.

headline: Seattle Leads the Way
abstract: Lawmakers on the local level who support a higher minimum wage show Congress where it needs to go.
lead_paragraph: The new $15-an-hour minimum wage approved this week in Seattle does more than guarantee a raise to tens of thousands of workers in the city. As the highest minimum in the nation, it changes the terms of the minimum-wage debate and expands the realm of the possible in setting new minimums.

headline: In Memoir, Hillary Clinton Emphasizes Her Softer Side
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: In her new memoir, “Hard Choices,” she discusses her approach to diplomacy, but also gives a glimpse of her role as mother of the bride.
lead_paragraph: In Hillary Rodham Clinton’s first bid for president in 2008, her campaign seemed determined to make a powerful point: She was strong. She was tough. She was ready to lead.

headline: Wanting to Believe in California Chrome
keywords: ['Belmont Stakes', 'Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Kentucky Derby', 'Preakness Stakes']
abstract: Nearly four decades ago, Richard Migliore saw back-to-back Triple Crowns as a teenage exercise rider. He and many other fans are hoping to feel that magic again at Belmont Park on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-seven years ago, Richard Migliore first felt the magic of a Triple Crown. He was a 13-year-old exercise rider fibbing about his age to work out a filly at Belmont Park. He saw the newspapermen, as they were called then, clamoring around Seattle Slew’s barn.

keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Editorials']
abstract: The decision to skimp on scheduled payments to pension funds for state workers adds another stain to the governor’s résumé.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey already has a famous traffic jam on the George Washington Bridge tarnishing his reputation as a Republican comer and putting a damper on his ambitions for higher office. His latest budget difficulties, which have caused him to backtrack on a promise to repair the state’s pension system, adds one more stain to his résumé.

headline: Stabbing Case Shows Lapses in Treatment for the Mentally Ill
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: When Daniel St. Hubert was released from prison, there was little that correction officials could do to ensure that he received the therapy he needed. Nine days later, he was accused in a killing.
lead_paragraph: During much of his five years of incarceration for choking his mother with an electrical cord, Daniel St. Hubert was prone to aggressive outbursts and violence, assaulting inmates and correctional workers. It took three years before he was even deemed psychologically fit to stand trial.

headline: Plan to Build Ice Center in the Bronx Stalls Amid a Feud
abstract: Principals in a group that recruited Mark Messier and won city approval for a plan to redevelop the Kingsbridge Armory with nine rinks have sued one another.
lead_paragraph: An ambitious effort to convert the Kingsbridge Armory into a national ice sports center has stalled in recent weeks amid a bitter feud and two lawsuits over future profits and control of the development group behind the project.

headline: Israeli-Palestinian Collision Course
abstract: With the recent collapse of peace talks and the reconciliation of the feuding Palestinian factions, it is time for all sides to think hard about where they are headed.
lead_paragraph: The recent collapse of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks has sharpened tensions and put the two sides on a collision course. The feuding Palestinian factions, Fatah and Hamas, formed a government this week, prompting Israel to retaliate with plans for hundreds of new housing units in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. The Palestinians threatened unspecified countermeasures. It is clearly time for all sides to think hard about where this is headed.

headline: Kings Work on Ice, but Most Live on the Beach
abstract: All but one of the Kings players live in either Manhattan Beach or Hermosa Beach, allowing them to trade their skates for boarder shorts and flip-flops in the off-season.
lead_paragraph: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif. — When the Los Angeles Kings won the Stanley Cup two years ago, the trophy’s first postgame trip was to a small bar near the beach, within walking distance of nearly every player’s home.

headline: Gunman Attacks Georgia Courthouse and Dies in Firefight, Authorities Say
abstract: The authorities said the man, facing drug and weapons charges, was attempting a “frontal assault” on the courthouse in Cumming, Ga., using an arsenal that included an assault rifle and tear gas.
lead_paragraph: CUMMING, Ga. — A man was shot to death on Friday by law enforcement officials after he brought an arsenal, including an assault rifle and a large supply of ammunition, to the county courthouse here and tried to mount what the authorities described as a “frontal assault” on the building.

keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Off-Track Betting', 'Belmont Stakes', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Gambling', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: In a city where almost everything disappears — the diners and dry cleaners of yesterday shape-shifting into frozen yogurt shops and Duane Reades — the demise of New York’s Off-Track Betting parlors was particularly cruel to its patrons.
lead_paragraph: For decades, they were outposts for the self-identified degenerate, the moldering province of otherwise antisocial men with crumpled newsboy caps on their heads and racing forms tucked beneath their armpits.

headline: U.N. Chief Picks Jordanian Prince for Rights Post

lead_paragraph: GENEVA — United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Friday nominated a veteran diplomat and relative of Jordan’s royal family to be the agency’s next high commissioner for human rights.

headline: In Some States, Emissions Cuts Defy Skeptics
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'States (US)', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Coal', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: At least 10 states have already met President Obama’s goal of a 30 percent reduction in power plant emissions by 2030, without the economic damage that critics have warned would occur.
lead_paragraph: The cries of protest have been fierce, warning that President Obama’s plan to cut greenhouse gases from power plants will bring soaring electricity bills and even plunge the nation into blackouts. By the time the administration is finished, one prominent critic said, “millions of Americans will be freezing in the dark.”

headline: Egyptian Election Law Helps to Block Opposition
abstract: The new law allows authorities to bar the candidacy of supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist group that dominated Egypt’s free elections after the 2011 uprising.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The military-appointed interim president of Egypt on Friday issued an election law that experts say all but eliminates the chance of parliamentary opposition to his successor, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who installed the interim government.

headline: Sons of Major Leaguers, but Not Always Stars
abstract: At least 205 sons of major leaguers have followed in their fathers’ footsteps, but only one of those — Roberto Alomar — reached the Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: On July 2, 1903, Jack Doscher took the mound for the Chicago Cubs. The son of Herm Doscher, a third baseman and outfielder in the early days of the National League, Jack is believed to have been the first son of a former big leaguer to play in the majors.

headline: For Fans in Bronx, Jennifer Lopez’s Homecoming Was Overdue
abstract: Ms. Lopez’s free concert at Orchard Beach this week was her first-ever show in the Bronx. Some fans wondered why it took her so long to perform in the borough where she grew up.
lead_paragraph: Since releasing her debut studio album, “On the 6,” an ode to the subway line she rode growing up in the Bronx, Jennifer Lopez has leaned on a narrative that has followed her through forays into singing, dancing and acting. And a hit single, “Jenny From the Block,” became a catchy moniker for the performer.

headline: In Fraud Trial, F.B.I. Agent Testifies That Senator Funneled Money to Lawmakers

lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — A real estate developer from Rockland County came to New York City dangling tens of thousands of dollars in cash and checks and slowly began to set a trap. State Senator Malcolm A. Smith, federal prosecutors tried to demonstrate on Friday, took the bait.

lead_paragraph: Representative Charles B. Rangel and his main challenger, State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat, lashed out at each other on Friday during their first televised debate: Mr. Rangel accused Mr. Espaillat of running a racially based campaign and Mr. Espaillat charged that their district had suffered under Mr. Rangel’s leadership.

headline: Warfare’s Never-Ending Story
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Cold War Era', 'United States International Relations', 'Prisoners of War', 'Detainees']
abstract: A World War II commemoration, and echoes of the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: The world looked back to the future last week as 18 national leaders gathered to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the D-Day invasion that triggered the end to World War II’s apocalyptic ravaging of Europe.

headline: California: Tree Trimmer Won’t Be Charged
keywords: ['Trees and Shrubs', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Birds']
abstract: No charges will be brought against Ernesto Pulido, a tree trimmer in Oakland who knocked five baby herons from their nests a month ago while trimming trees for the United States Postal Service.
lead_paragraph: No charges will be brought against Ernesto Pulido, a tree trimmer in Oakland who knocked five baby herons from their nests a month ago while trimming trees for the United States Postal Service. The case was investigated by the federal Fish and Wildlife Service, which said Thursday that “no further action is warranted.” Mr. Pulido could have faced a $15,000 fine and six months in jail for violating the Migratory Bird Treaty Act of 1918. “I’ve never been happier,” Mr. Pulido said. The birds are expected to fully recover. Two will be released on Saturday.

headline: Karen DeCrow Dies at 76; Feminist Lawyer and Author Led NOW
abstract: Ms. DeCrow led the National Organization for Women during the 1970s, fighting for the Equal Rights Amendment and Title IX.
lead_paragraph: Karen DeCrow, who was president of the National Organization for Women during the 1970s, a turbulent period in which she helped lead campaigns for passage of the Equal Rights Amendment and against sex discrimination in education and sports, died on Friday at her home in Jamesville, N.Y., a suburb of Syracuse. She was 76.

headline: Two States Repeal Education Standards
abstract: The governors of Oklahoma and South Carolina signed bills within the past week repealing the Common Core state standards, guidelines for children’s achievement in reading and math between kindergarten and high school graduation.
lead_paragraph: The governors of Oklahoma and South Carolina signed bills within the past week repealing the Common Core state standards, guidelines for children’s achievement in reading and math between kindergarten and high school graduation. Both states had been among the 46 and the District of Columbia that had adopted the standards, written by a group of educators and other experts convened by the National Governors Association and the Council of Chief State School Officers. But as resistance grew in their states, lawmakers moved to replace them with standards developed within the states. Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina signed that state’s bill last week, and Gov. Mary Fallin of Oklahoma signed a bill on Thursday that would require educators in the state to set new standards to replace the Common Core.

headline: Neither Player Nor Bat Was Ready for the Fog
abstract: The broken air-conditioning system in Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals was highly unusual, but it did not compare to the Fog Game during the Stanley Cup finals on May 20, 1975.
lead_paragraph: The broken air-conditioning system at San Antonio’s AT&T Center on Thursday in Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals was highly unusual, but those saunalike conditions did not compare to the Fog Game during the Stanley Cup finals on May 20, 1975, between the Buffalo Sabres and the Philadelphia Flyers.

headline: Newly Pro, and Adding Experience to Mets’ System
abstract: The Mets, who have recently used first-round draft picks on high school prospects, on Thursday selected Michael Conforto, a polished outfielder from Oregon State.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Mets have tried to restock their organization with young, talented positions players, using their first-round picks from 2011 to 2013 on the high school prospects Brandon Nimmo, Gavin Cecchini and Dominic Smith. None have reached Class AA yet.

headline: Andrei N. Mironov, Soviet-Era Political Prisoner and Activist, Dies at 60
abstract: Mr. Mironov caught on early to the absurdities of Soviet life and later became active in the samizdat movement.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — After Andrei N. Mironov was killed in Ukraine by artillery fire on May 24 while working with an Italian photojournalist, news accounts described him as an interpreter for foreign journalists there.

headline: A Rough Guide to Brooklyn for Conventioneers
abstract: With Brooklyn making its bid to host the 2016 Democratic National Convention, borough boosters are already getting set to roll out the red carpet. Here’s a rough draft of the welcoming committee’s visitors’ guide.

headline: Bernard Telsey: The Shows Must Go On
abstract: Sunday is hardly ever a day off for Mr. Telsey, a casting director, who is always fielding requests from producers and directors. But he’s become adept at carving out time for family, too.
lead_paragraph: As one of more than 800 Tony Award voters, the casting director Bernard Telsey gets invited to every new Broadway show that is eligible for an award, so he’s a regular at Sunday matinees — most of them a quick walk from his Hell’s Kitchen brownstone. Indeed, Sunday is hardly ever a day off: He is always fielding requests from producers and directors obsessing over their theater, television and film projects. But Mr. Telsey, 54, has become adept at carving out time for his wife, Anne Marino, an executive with Tommy Hilfiger; their sons Daniel Marino, 25, who lives in Brooklyn, and Felix Telsey, 14; and the family’s Maltese poodles, Wally and Louie.

lead_paragraph: Since 1978, 12 horses who won the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness have failed to capture the Belmont, one missing glory by a nose, others in a landslide.

headline: Russian State Media Focuses Attacks on Kerry’s Spokeswoman

lead_paragraph: The rhetorical sniping between Russian and American officials over the separatist uprisings in Ukraine appeared to escalate a notch this week when state television channels controlled by the Kremlin devoted an unusual amount of time to reporting on, and so amplifying, recent attacks by Russian bloggers on a State Department spokeswoman, Jen Psaki.

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 7, 2014.

headline: U.S.’s Young Players Expected to Contribute Now and Lead Later
abstract: Jurgen Klinsmann included Julian Green, John Brooks and DeAndre Yedlin — three players who did not take part in World Cup qualifying — on his roster for the tournament, keeping an eye on the future.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — When Jurgen Klinsmann was given a contract extension through 2018 by U.S. Soccer in December, it allowed him the luxury of keeping an eye on the long-term future of the national team. His roster for the 2014 World Cup reflects that, introducing a new generation of American players.

headline: A Shaken-Up Lineup Stirs the Yankees’ Offense
abstract: The Yankees showed a little more pop after they moved Jacoby Ellsbury to leadoff, Brett Gardner to the No. 2 spot and Carlos Beltran to No. 3.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Contemplating a week’s worth of offensive feebleness, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi opted for something familiar to try and shake out some hits to begin a 10-game trip.

headline: Your Slightly-Better-Than-a-Dartboard Guide to Choosing a Team in the World Cup
abstract: For those who like the pageantry but couldn’t care less about the tactics, a guide to picking a team in the World Cup and finding a place to cheer among your newfound compatriots.
lead_paragraph: For those who like the pageantry but couldn’t care less about the tactics, a guide to picking a team in the World Cup and finding a place to cheer among your newfound compatriots.

headline: Watching the World’s Game, in the World’s City
abstract: Passion for soccer runs deep in New York City, where immigrants in every ethnic enclave are preparing to cheer on their home countries. Here are some city spots to watch with the faithful.
lead_paragraph: On a gloriously sunny afternoon recently, Lunasa, an East Village pub, was packed seven deep at the bar, as three TVs showed the day’s big games. Soccer games, that is, in Germany, Portugal and England.

headline: Fire Breaks Out at TGI Friday’s Near Rockefeller Center
abstract: The Fire Department said no one was seriously injured in the three-alarm blaze and that the cause is being investigated.
lead_paragraph: A fast-moving fire at a restaurant near Rockefeller Center on Friday night sent flames and smoke shooting into the night sky as diners ran for the exits and dozens of firefighters rushed to extinguish the blaze, the authorities said.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) ENOUGH SAID (2013) Julia Louis-Dreyfus, in a Golden Globe-nominated role, plays Eva, a divorced massage therapist in Los Angeles who finds her life emptying out as her daughter (Tracey Fairaway) prepares to leave for Sarah Lawrence College. Then she meets Albert (James Gandolfini, above, with Ms. Louis-Dreyfus), another divorced parent of a college-bound girl, and although he isn’t her usual type, Eva suddenly finds herself falling for this funny, tender and sexy slob. Enter Marianne (Catherine Keener), a glamorous bohemian poet and Eva’s new client — who, Eva finds out a little too late, also happens to be Albert’s former wife. And so Eva listens to Marianne’s complaints about her ex — he’s a bore and a loser, clumsy in bed and unable to take care of himself — and surreptitiously tries to correct the faults in Albert that caused their marriage to disintegrate. “The real genius of ‘Enough Said’ is that it takes this entirely plausible anecdotal circumstance and unlocks both its farcical potential and its latent profundity,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this “small miracle of a movie” written and directed by Nicole Holofcener. “This movie will make you laugh and leave you in tears. Some of the pathos is the accidental byproduct of seeing Mr. Gandolfini, so playful and alive, in one of his final major movie roles and feeling once again the loss of his remarkable gift. There is also the pang of the empty nest, that mixture of grief and pride that is the special anguish of modern parents. But there is also something deeper. The ache that ‘Enough Said’ leaves behind comes from the blunt force of truth.”

headline: No Pockets, No Problem
abstract: Most tables at Space Billiards in Koreatown are the standard six-pocket variety, but those without holes are for four-ball billiards, a preferred game in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Space Billiards is a pool hall of the sort that feels nocturnal on even a bright day. But it is not a dour place, and it isn’t filled with unsavory hustlers. In its slightly manic, neon-noir way, it exudes a quirky sense of cheer. Simple strobe lights jitter across walls. A seemingly endless string of dance hits plays. The wall behind the red couch is covered with small mirrors. At some tables you’ll find cheap American beer; at other tables, bottles of OB Lager and soju, the beer and liquor of South Korea.

headline: The ‘Oz’ Moment
abstract: “American Odyssey: Photos From the Detroit Photographic Company, 1888-1924,” which opens with a sampling of New York vistas, contains color photochroms, as they were called, that the authors say were “the first color photographs of the North American continent.”
lead_paragraph: I’ll never forget eyeballing Ebbets Field for the first time. I had seen photographs in the sports pages, and grainy images on TV. And I had seen grass before, even growing up in Brooklyn. Still, I was totally unprepared for what the verdant playing field looked like in person in what, in a few years, the NBC peacock would introduce as living color.

headline: Tribal Elder of the Fields
abstract: Jimmy Peters, 55, has been largely homeless since 1995, he said, and for the past four years has slept mostly in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: Lounging on the thick grass in Strawberry Fields, Jimmy Peters gazed up at the penthouse apartment of a new luxury high-rise on West 57th Street.

headline: Posey’s Late Homer Lifts Giants Past Mets
abstract: Jon Niese pitched seven strong innings for the Mets, but their bullpen faltered again as Buster Posey broke an eighth-inning tie and lifted San Francisco to its major-league-leading 40th victory.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Mets and the San Francisco Giants were tied in the eighth inning Friday night. But after San Francisco’s Angel Pagan drew a leadoff walk and moved into scoring position, the Giants were so confident that they had their closer, Sergio Romo, start to warm up.
