headline: Poroshenko Takes Ukraine Helm With Tough Words for Russia
abstract: Petro Poroshenko was sworn in amid a continuing separatist insurrection in eastern Ukraine by pro-Russian fighters.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Petro Oleksiyovych Poroshenko, a pro-European, billionaire confectioner, was sworn in on Saturday as the fifth president of Ukraine, promising to put an end to a separatist insurrection in the east that has divided the country for months.

headline: World Cup Crib Sheet: Know Your Superstars
abstract: For sports fans who want to know who the Lebron James of soccer is, here are world soccer stars and their analogs in American sports.
lead_paragraph: We continue our series of crib sheets to help readers watch the World Cup like true fanatics. For sports fans who want to know who the Lebron James of soccer is, here are world soccer stars and their analogs in American sports.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Morning Views
lead_paragraph: The New York Times cautions American officials dealing with the Palestinian Authority’s new unity government, a coalition of the extremist Hamas and more moderate Fatah factions. “Many experts say that if there is ever to be an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement,” the editorial board writes, “the Palestinians must be united. But the United States has to be careful to somehow distinguish between its support for the new government and an endorsement of Hamas and its violent, hateful behavior.”

headline: Tracy Morgan Critically Hurt in New Jersey Car Crash
abstract: Mr. Morgan, a former “Saturday Night Live” and “30 Rock” cast member, was in an accident on the New Jersey Turnpike early Saturday that killed one person, the police said. A truck driver was charged in the crash.
lead_paragraph: The actor and comedian Tracy Morgan finished a stand-up comedy show in Delaware on Friday night and headed back to New York City with several other comedians. Around 1 a.m., a tractor-trailer slammed into the back of their luxury van, overturning it and setting off a chain reaction that involved four other vehicles.

headline: Five Experts Evaluate E.C.B.'s Policy Shift
abstract: Will Mario Draghi’s “significant package” help finally pull the euro zone out of its slump? A group of experts with a stake in the outcome offer their views.
lead_paragraph: “We think this is a significant package,” Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, said on Thursday. He was describing the measures the bank had announced to combat the euro zone’s crippling combination of slow growth and superlow inflation.

lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

abstract: If the world of campers divides into those people who hated camp and those who loved it, on which side of that divide do you fall?

headline: Two New Legal-Themed Documentaries
abstract: Compelling new films on the fight over the right to same-sex marriage and the sexual abuse scandal at Penn State both deal with the intricacies of the law.
lead_paragraph: I’ve spent the past weekend at the Berkshire International Film Festival in western Massachusetts, and I want to recommend two terrific law-related documentary films I saw there. One is directly law-related: “The Case Against 8,” the story of the federal court case that led to the invalidation of California’s Proposition 8 and to the arrival of marriage equality there. The film, by Ben Cotner and Ryan White, is now playing commercially in New York and Los Angeles, will soon open elsewhere, and will be shown on HBO on June 23 (disclosure: I had a tiny consulting role in the making of the film, actually a discussion of Supreme Court procedure over a cup of coffee with the filmmakers.)

headline: Milwaukee Suburb Tries to Cope With Girl’s Stabbing
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Assaults', 'Education (K-12)', 'Myths', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: An attack on a 12-year-old, brought on, perhaps, by an obsession with the fictional Internet figure Slender Man, has forced an urgent self-examination in Waukesha, Wis.
lead_paragraph: WAUKESHA, Wis. — At Horning Middle School last week, some girls painted cat whiskers on their faces with liquid eyeliner, in tribute to a fellow sixth grader who loved cats but who lay in a hospital recovering from 19 stab wounds that the authorities say were inflicted by two friends who had lured her into a park to kill her.

lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Militants attacked a university in the western city of Ramadi early Saturday, forcing students and professors to flee gunfire and shelling, while in the capital, at least 48 people were killed by car bombs in an apparently coordinated series of explosions.

headline: A Golfer Who Lived Large and Played Larger

lead_paragraph: TUSTIN, Mich. — Near a horse-and-carriage crossing in this small town, the golfing bon vivant Walter Hagen lives on, his memory carefully cultivated by a retired couple who never saw him swing a club.

headline: Variety: A Vowel-less Crossword Puzzle
abstract: The return of Arthur Schulman’s vowel-less crossword.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — We haven’t seen many of these vowel-less crossword puzzles in The New York Times since records have been kept of these things (there have been five since 1997, if you count this one), and we haven’t seen one since 2006. But if you wait long enough, I’m told, everything comes back into style, and Arthur Schulman, who created the first four, has a new vowel-less crossword for us.

headline: Gay Pride Promotions
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: L.G.B.T. pride month is now observed not just with parades and parties, but also with travel promotions.
lead_paragraph: Companies such as Hilton, Kimpton and American Airlines have long marketed to the gay community. This month in a most public display of affection, Marriott International, a company with conservative Mormon roots, is wrapping three of its Washington, D.C., hotels in photo banners, including Jason Collins, the N.B.A.’s first openly gay basketball player, and Geena Rocero, a transgender model. The campaign urges travelers to share photos on Instagram under #LoveTravels @MarriottIntl.

headline: A Vow to End Hollow Nods and Salutes
abstract: The chief executive at General Motors, Mary T. Barra, wants to ensure that deadly failures never happen again, but old habits are hard to change.
lead_paragraph: After the release last Thursday of the internal report on General Motors’ failure to recall thousands of defective cars for more than a decade, Mary T. Barra, the chief executive, addressed the company’s employees. In her remarks, Ms. Barra projected an earnest and urgent desire to reform the company’s culture, which she said was permeated by “bureaucratic processes that avoided accountability.” That culture meant no one took responsibility for faulty ignition switches in Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars that were ultimately responsible for at least 13 deaths.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior American officials plan to meet in Geneva on Monday and Tuesday with an Iranian delegation in an attempt to advance the stalled nuclear talks, the State Department announced Saturday.

headline: When Sources May Have Lied
abstract: Trying to sort out the truth about Somaly Mam, a Cambodian activist against human trafficking
lead_paragraph: Somaly Mam described having been trafficked into a brothel as a young girl in Cambodia, then escaping and helping others—and she came to run a couple of organizations in Cambodia that battled forced prostitution. She wrote an autobiography, was feted at the State Department and Kennedy Center, and celebrated by journalists. Including me. I wrote one column about her life story in 2008 after her autobiography was published in the U.S., and made several references to her after that, most recently in 2011.

headline: Stumped? Invoke the 5-Minute Rule
abstract: The chief executive of Quintiq, a software company, tells employees to go ask someone when stumped at a task for more than five minutes.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Victor Allis, chief executive of Quintiq, a software company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

abstract: Jason Aramburu, who developed a sensor and smartphone app to help plants thrive, looks to use them to fight drought and food shortages.
lead_paragraph: A lemon tree springs from the soil in Jason Aramburu’s backyard in Berkeley, Calif., alongside rose bushes, birds of paradise, strawberry plants and squash blossoms. The garden is thriving, but its upkeep requires almost no effort from Mr. Aramburu. Instead, a foot-high soil sensor does much of the work.

headline: LeBron James Shows a Growing Willingness to Take the Lead on Social Issues

lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — It is easy now, as Donald Sterling has thrown up his hands in surrender, to forget what it was like April 26, in the hours after a bombshell of an audio recording was released. The outrage over the racist rants was instantaneous — except from where it might have been expected to be greatest. The N.B.A., it seemed, was stunned into near silence.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British police on Saturday released the Pakistani political leader Altaf Hussain, four days after he was arrested on suspicion of money laundering, but said that he remained under investigation.

headline: U.S. Crew Is Arrested on Honduras River Job

lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — When Robert Mayne, a marine salvage expert, sailed from Florida to the Mosquito Coast of northeastern Honduras, he carried with him a business plan that would allow him to make some money while helping the poverty-stricken people of the region.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bill Clinton’s speeches as president were notoriously long, exemplified by his State of the Union addresses, which were wordier than any other president’s in the modern era.

lead_paragraph: The passionate rivalries of World Cup soccer will soon be enthralling sports fans across the globe, along with throngs of fanatic gamblers placing untold millions in bets.

headline: Stop Holding Us Back
abstract: There are smarter, more effective ways to lower high school dropout rates.
lead_paragraph: This month, more than three million high school students will receive their diplomas. At more than 80 percent, America’s graduation rate is at a record high. More kids are going to college, too. But one-third of the nation’s African-American and Latino young men will not graduate.

headline: Pot Rules
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Marijuana', 'Labeling and Labels']
abstract: As it moves past the old "Reefer Madness" caricature, the reefer crowd in Colorado gets mad at the prospect of almost any regulations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IN the last chapter, I covered how not to get high. In this one, I will cover how to get high.

headline: Dear Millennials, We’re Sorry
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Environment', 'Global Warming', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Youth', 'Age, Chronological']
abstract: How dare we malign kids or pretend to care about them when our habits and spending endanger their future.
lead_paragraph: AMONG Americans age 40 and older, there’s a pastime more popular than football, Candy Crush or HBO.

headline: Detroit’s Fight Against Blight
abstract: A census of the city’s demise shows how many buildings must be torn down, but that would be just the starting point for a real rescue effort.
lead_paragraph: At one level, a new report about blight in Detroit can be seen as a cartographic inventory of the abandoned homes, vacant lots and rundown industrial sites that have spread through the once-thriving Motor City like a metastasized cancer. But there is another way to look at this important document: as the starting point for fresh conversation about what needs to be done to stabilize and revive Detroit and other declining cities around the country.

headline: Haiti Elections in Doubt as Ex-Presidents Stir Pot
abstract: Political uncertainty reigns as the current president jousts with opponents over the staging of an overdue election, which has brought waves of foreign dignitaries to attempt to defuse the crisis.
lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — When he returned to Haiti from exile three years ago, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the former priest turned president turned deposed president, promised to stay out of politics. Yet the political party he founded and continues to inspire has routinely sent thousands of people into the streets to protest the current government, demanding the resignation of the prime minister.

headline: Stjepan Hauser
abstract: The rock cellist on wearing out bows, collecting cactuses and walking the length of the Thames.
lead_paragraph: Stjepan Hauser is a Croatian cellist and half of the group 2Cellos, which is known for its covers of popular rock songs. A YouTube video of the duo playing AC/DC’s “Thunderstruck” has gotten more than 18 million views so far.

headline: Madam Secretary Made a Difference
abstract: Did Hillary Clinton accomplish much as secretary of state? Yes! She helped change the diplomatic agenda for the better.
lead_paragraph: WHEN politicians have trouble spinning their own glories, that’s a problem.

headline: The Ghosts in the Machine
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Books and Literature', 'Myths', 'Occult Sciences', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Internet urban legends like Slenderman fit neatly into the tradition of American horror folklore.
lead_paragraph: BOWLING GREEN, Ky. — A SURPRISING number of knife attacks on and by teenagers have appeared in the national news in recent weeks, but in terms of sheer tragic weirdness, nothing can match the case of two 12-year-old Wisconsin girls who stabbed a classmate 19 times, nearly killing her — and then said they did it to appease someone called “Slenderman.”

headline: How to Beat Malaria, Once and for All
abstract: We have to shift from controlling the disease to eliminating the parasite.
lead_paragraph: MAE SOT, Thailand — MALARIA is a seasonal disease; with tropical rains come the fevers. In the news media, malaria is also seasonal. Every spring around World Malaria Day we hear about its devastating effects, including deaths in the hundreds of thousands. This year the reports were encouraging: Infections have been reduced and many lives saved. In May, researchers reported in Science that yet another potential malaria vaccine may be around the corner. Malaria seems to be on the retreat.

headline: A View From Gitmo
keywords: ['Detainees', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Hunger Strikes', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Prisoners of War']
abstract: The Bergdahl swap highlights how inmates are hostage to politics.
lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — THE week’s national debate around the exchange of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl for five Afghans imprisoned at Guantánamo Bay found me at the American base in Cuba for meetings with my clients. Here, too, the swap is the talk of the town — among prisoners, among guards and between the two groups.

headline: There Is No Alternative
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Only Hillary Clinton can hold together the Democrats’ political coalition.
lead_paragraph: IF the excerpts currently circulating in the press are any indication, Hillary Clinton’s latest memoir will resemble pretty much every recent political memoir from a potential presidential candidate: That is, it will be chloroform in print.

headline: The Biology of Risk
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Financial Brokers', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hormones', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The Fed has contributed to bubbles by misunderstanding our nature. Too much certainty, we go too far. With too little, we freeze.
lead_paragraph: SIX years after the financial meltdown there is once again talk about market bubbles. Are stocks succumbing to exuberance? Is real estate? We thought we had exorcised these demons. It is therefore with something close to despair that we ask: What is it about risk taking that so eludes our understanding, and our control?

headline: Obama on Obama on Climate
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Weather', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Environment', 'Coal']
abstract: The president explains in an interview why the new E.P.A. rules on carbon are so pivotal.
lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to dealing with the world’s climate and energy challenges I have a simple rule: change America, change the world.

headline: Starting Out Behind
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Youth', 'Editorials', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Today’s young people face limited job opportunities and increasing hardship.
lead_paragraph: Today’s young people, ages 18 to 24, should have been the lucky ones. They were preteens or teenagers when the recession hit in late 2007, with high school and college still ahead. Unlike those who had to enter the work force in the depths of the downturn, they had time, or so it seemed, to wait out the weak economy.

headline: The War on Coal Already Happened
abstract: And technology won.
lead_paragraph: I’m trying to pull together some thoughts about interests and ideology in the fight over climate policies, and found myself wondering what exactly is at stake in the supposed “war on coal”. And the answer is, surprisingly little — at least as far as jobs are concerned. Here’s total employment in coal mining (the earlier numbers are from Historical Statistics of the United States, Millennial Edition; the later from the FRED database):

headline: When a Shared ID Leads to a Grim Predicament
abstract: Apple’s new family sharing program will come too late for those embroiled in disastrous situations because of inadvertently shared private messages.
lead_paragraph: We live, it has been said many times, in the era of oversharing. Sometimes this produces awkward situations. Other times, it produces something much worse.

headline: Watchful Eyes in Booth Certify the Action on the Track
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Belmont Stakes', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Officiating (Sports)', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers']
abstract: For the three placing judges perched high above the Belmont Park clubhouse, their work determining official race results is a delicate dance.
lead_paragraph: The time that elapsed from when the track announcer Tom Durkin, in his signature cadence, declared that “the horses have reached the starting gate” until the “official” sign was posted on the infield video board was a matter of minutes.

headline: Wind? Biofuels? Get Real, a Contrarian Says
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Natural Gas', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A new book by a “climate agnostic” offers contrarian views on energy policies, arguing that the world needs a revival of nuclear power.
lead_paragraph: Every so often we need someone to put in a kind word for the devil, if only to remind us of unpleasant facts. On energy policy, we need someone willing to declare flat out that “if oil didn’t exist, we would have to invent it. No other substance comes close to oil when it comes to energy density, ease of handling, and flexibility.”

headline: In South Sudan, a Ghost of Wars Past: Child Soldiers
keywords: ['Child Soldiers', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The United Nations Children’s Fund (Unicef) estimated last month that 9,000 children had been recruited into armed forces or other groups to fight in the South Sudan conflict.
lead_paragraph: BENTIU, South Sudan — Stretched out on a tarp on the floor of a makeshift hospital on a dirt road outside this town, a soldier in a leg cast was laughing and joking with other wounded fighters. His smile was broad and innocent, his voice not yet changed by puberty.

headline: Child Migrants Strain Makeshift Arizona Shelter
abstract: Immigration officials overwhelmed by a flood of women and children from Central America are housing hundreds of unaccompanied boys and girls in a makeshift detention center.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Immigration officials overwhelmed by a flood of women and children from Central America who illegally crossed the border from Mexico are moving hundreds of unaccompanied boys and girls this weekend to a makeshift detention center in Nogales, Ariz.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 8
abstract: The prisoner swap that brought Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl home has drawn criticism and will be the main focus of the Sunday news shows.
lead_paragraph: The Taliban released a video on Wednesday of their handover of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl to American troops, and it quickly went viral. The exchange — five Taliban prisoners were released from Guantánamo Bay in exchange for Sergeant Bergdahl — drew criticism from some lawmakers, who disagreed with President Obama’s decision. The story was made murkier when soldiers who served with Sergeant Bergdahl called him a deserter and some blamed him for the deaths of six to eight soldiers who were killed in a search mission for him.

headline: The Astros Are on the Verge of Winning for Losing
abstract: While the Astros’ recent top draft picks are still in the minor leagues, several long-term answers are now everyday players in Houston.
lead_paragraph: The Houston Astros picked first in the draft for the third year in a row on Thursday.

headline: With ‘She Knows a Band,’ an Agent Is Born
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'AGENTS (BUSINESS)', 'Music', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: In the 1980s, through a chance encounter, a teenager lands a job booking small town gigs for a rock band.
lead_paragraph: When I was 18 years old, I walked into a nightclub in Highland, Ind., with a woman 10 years my senior who was my teacher at the Barbizon modeling school in Chicago. (“Be a model, or just look like one!”) My grandmother had signed me up for the class. She hoped honing my table-setting skills might land me a suitable husband, and if I learned the Dior turn along the way, that would be nice, too. My Barbizon teacher’s presence matters only inasmuch as her looks allowed me into Club Dimensions sans ID. She bore a passing resemblance to Snow White (alabaster skin, glossy black hair, matte red lips). We were new friends, and I’d driven to her house in Highland for a visit from my apartment in suburban Chicago.

headline: After a Girl’s Accusation, the Questions Pile Up
abstract: “Conviction,” the new play by Carey Crim, which is having its world premiere at Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor, tells the story of a teacher accused of inappropriate behavior with an underage student.
lead_paragraph: The first scene of “Conviction,” the new play by Carey Crim, begins with a celebration, as two couples toast a successful high school production of “Romeo and Juliet” directed by Tom Hodges, one of the husbands. But the scene ends on a dark note, as Tom takes a phone call from the school principal and frowns. Ominous music fills the air, and the play soon turns tense and gripping.

headline: Online Learning Goes to Harvard
keywords: ['E-Learning', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Business Schools']
abstract: Readers respond to “B-School, Disrupted” (June 1).

headline: In Pitching Veggies to Kids, Less Is More
abstract: To persuade children to eat healthy food, new research suggests that giving no message at all trumps any other persuasion.
lead_paragraph: One of the fiercest marketing battles in the world takes place in kitchens and at dining room tables across the world. The sellers are parents, trying everything to persuade their children to eat their vegetables.

headline: ‘As Though the Other Good Horses Weren’t There’
abstract: Steve Wolfson, 73, shared his memories of Affirmed and discussed issues facing the thoroughbred racing industry.
lead_paragraph: Steve Wolfson is the son of Louis Wolfson, the owner of Affirmed, the 1978 Triple Crown champion. He formerly directed the operations at Harbor View Farm in Florida, where Affirmed was bred. Wolfson, 73, shared his memories of Affirmed and discussed issues facing the thoroughbred racing industry with Tom Pedulla.

headline: Affordable Housing That’s Very Costly
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Zoning', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization']
abstract: What is known as inclusionary zoning lets developers build more housing units if they charge much lower rents for some of them.
lead_paragraph: Abington House, at 500 West 30th Street near the High Line in West Chelsea, is a new luxury residential building and, like a lot of new luxury developments in Manhattan, it’s extremely expensive. The cheapest two-bedroom apartment now listed there rents for $5,850 a month. That gets you only one bathroom; a two-bed, two-bath can run as high as $8,695.

headline: Kings’ Resilience Rests, Quietly, With Jonathan Quick
abstract: Quick backstopped the Kings to three Game 7 wins this postseason on the way to the Stanley Cup finals.
lead_paragraph: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — As N.H.L. fans seek a definitive statement on the Los Angeles Kings’ resilience, the best place to look may be the quietest corner of their dressing room.

headline: Playoff Overtime Isn’t the Grueling Slog It Used to Be
abstract: When N.H.L. playoff games go into extra periods, they are being decided more quickly, by fitter players who can maintain their energy levels near 100 percent.
lead_paragraph: Many sports have overtime, extra time or extra innings. But in hockey, extra periods of play have traditionally been a physically grueling ordeal, sometimes stretching into the next morning.

headline: Alexander Shulgin, Psychedelia Researcher, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Shulgin, a chemist who specialized in the creation of mind-altering substances, and who introduced the drug known as Ecstasy for potential therapeutic use, died on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Shulgin, a chemist who specialized in the creation of and experimentation with mind-altering substances, and who introduced the controversial drug popularly known as Ecstasy for potential therapeutic use, died on Monday at his home in Lafayette, Calif., east of Oakland. He was 88.

headline: Bird? Plane? No, but the Same View for Tennis Matches
abstract: At major tennis tournaments, wire-guided aerial cameras leave some players wary but provide distinctive overhead shots of the action.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a gray day at the French Open, thousands of spectators watched Roger Federer sit for a changeover on Philippe Chatrier Court. A moment later, a miniature jet the size of a small automobile appeared over the rim of the stadium.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 5
abstract: Two top players, Franck Ribéry of France and Marco Reus of Germany, will miss the World Cup because of injuries.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Remembering Maya Angelou
abstract: Former President Bill Clinton, Oprah Winfrey and the first lady, Michelle Obama, eulogize Maya Angelou at a memorial service in Winston-Salem, N.C.
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton, Oprah Winfrey and the first lady, Michelle Obama, eulogize Maya Angelou at a memorial service in Winston-Salem, N.C.

headline: More Scrutiny, Still Spectacular
abstract: Executive compensation boards are now more independent and rewards are increasingly tied to results. But C.E.O. pay remains enormous.
lead_paragraph: A 30 percent rise in stocks made 2013 a fruitful year for the owners of American businesses, the shareholders; while the growth in rewards was less generous for top employees, their compensation was still enormous. Average total pay for the 200 most highly paid chief executives tracked by Equilar, an executive compensation data firm, rose 6 percent, to $20.7 million.

headline: What Hillary Rodham Clinton Did
abstract: Readers comment on my column about Clinton’s legacy as Secretary of State
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column takes aim at the commonly heard narrative that Hillary Clinton as Secretary of State was glamorous but didn’t really achieve much or leave any legacy. I think that’s completely wrong, and that she did have a significant impact–just not the usual kind. I think this is an issue that is going to spark more debate this week following publication of Clinton’s book on Tuesday and as the presidential campaign approaches. So let me know if you agree, or where you think she did–or didn’t–have impact.

headline: How the Pay Figures Were Calculated
abstract: To measure the amounts that chief executives were paid last year, Sunday Business asked Equilar Inc., an executive compensation data firm, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings.
lead_paragraph: To measure the amounts that chief executives were paid last year, Sunday Business asked Equilar Inc., an executive compensation data firm, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings.

headline: The Pay at the Top
abstract: 200 of the highest-paid chief executives in American business.
lead_paragraph: 200 of the highest-paid chief executives in American business.

headline: An Elusive Jackpot
abstract: Women have a much harder time becoming a chief executive and hold well under 10 percent of such jobs, but those who do earn the same as men.
lead_paragraph: If you were Marissa Mayer of Yahoo, making nearly $25 million for one year’s worth of work — not to mention getting $50,000 in company-paid personal security — the gender pay gap would probably not be a major concern. Women scaling the heights of corporate America tend to have compensation packages that are as jaw-droppingly gigantic as men at a similar level.

headline: A Hamlet Wrapped in Yarn
abstract: Downtown Oyster Bay is awash in bright crochet as part of “The Hand-Stitched Hamlet,” an exhibition by the artist Carol Hummel.
lead_paragraph: Walk through downtown Oyster Bay these days and you’ll find 48 trees, 34 lampposts and four kiosks wrapped in bands of green, royal blue, purple, light blue and yellow crocheted yarn.

headline: Cruz Fires Up G.O.P. Delegates in Texas
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows']
abstract: To no one’s surprise, Ted Cruz, the United States senator, was a star-spangled celebrity at the three-day Texas Republican Convention, which drew more than 7,000 delegates, alternates and guests.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — After patiently waiting in a line that snaked outside the doorway of a cavernous exhibit hall on Saturday, John Justice was just a few feet from reaching his goal — being photographed with Ted Cruz, the United States senator and Tea Party favorite.

headline: Unfamiliar Name Becomes Hurdle for Hispanic Candidate
abstract: With the chances of Texas Democrats winning a statewide office in November hinging on a higher turnout among Hispanics, the only Hispanic on their statewide ticket goes by the last name Van de Putte.
lead_paragraph: With the chances of Texas Democrats winning a statewide office in November hinging on a higher turnout among Hispanics, the only Hispanic on their statewide ticket goes by the last name Van de Putte.

headline: Belmont Stakes: Tonalist Denies California Chrome the Triple Crown
keywords: ['Belmont Stakes', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)']
abstract: Tonalist rallied down the stretch to capture the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes, while California Chrome failed to become the 12th Triple Crown winner, finishing fourth and extending a drought that has existed since Affirmed swept the series in 1978.
lead_paragraph: Tonalist, ridden by Joel Rosario, won the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday at Belmont Park, denying California Chrome his shot at becoming the 12th Triple Crown winner and the first since Affirmed in 1978.

headline: Concealed Weapons, and the Sanctity of Marriage
abstract: “Luv,” Murray Schisgal’s three-character play about unhappiness set in 1964, the same year it opened on Broadway, provides physical and cultural comedy at the Schoolhouse Theater in Croton Falls.
lead_paragraph: One man is standing on a bridge, poised to jump. Everything has gone wrong in his life. Another man, passing by, recognizes him from his college days and casually calls out his name. Everything in the second man’s life has gone right. Everything except his marriage. Maybe, in Murray Schisgal’s “Luv,” these two old pals can help each other.

headline: Voter Turnout as Big as Texas? Not Really
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Voter turnout puts the state close to the bottom of the nation. One reason is redistricting. Another is dominance of the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: In Paris, the Ultimate Rivalry Begins Its Next Chapter
abstract: If Novak Djokovic beats Rafael Nadal in the French Open final on Sunday, he will join Nadal and six others in the exclusive club of men who have won all four Grand Slam singles titles.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Despite smashing that racket in the semifinals, Novak Djokovic has been determined to keep the mood lighter at this French Open, and he stayed true to his plan on Saturday.

headline: It’s Good to Be a Female C.E.O., if You Can Get There
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Women and Girls', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Though female chief executives earn less than men at the same level, that’s not the whole story.
lead_paragraph: Female executives and their pay have been making headlines lately, from Yahoo to General Motors to The New York Times. We know that women face many obstacles on their way to the corner office (just 4.9 percent of chief executives at the 1,000 biggest companies are women), but do they continue to be treated differently once they arrive there? The answer is yes — but in different ways than the female employees below them.

headline: Willie Nelson Rode on Bus but Called Another Home
abstract: A Craigslist ad listed a vehicle as a former tour bus of Willie Nelson, but it turns out that the bus belonged to Paul English, his drummer, which its buyers knew.
lead_paragraph: The entertainer Willie Nelson has a ranch in Texas and a residence in Hawaii, but the place that he calls home is a bus named Honeysuckle Rose.

headline: Sharpton Warns Against Race-Baiting in New York Contest
abstract: The Rev. Al Sharpton’s warning appeared to be aimed at Representative Charles B. Rangel, who repeatedly discussed race in a debate for the upcoming Democratic primary for Congress.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Al Sharpton sent out a stern warning on Saturday against race-baiting in the contest for the 13th Congressional District in New York.

headline: Charity in Mexico Takes More Than Good Intentions and Cash
abstract: An orphanage in Ciudad Juárez found out just how tricky it could be to navigate the philanthropic world when 40 children with special needs were abruptly taken away last month.
lead_paragraph: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — When 40 children with special needs were removed from an orphanage here last month, officials at the facility said that employees looked on helplessly, unable to get a clear reason.

headline: Deep in the Heart of Prospero
abstract: The current production of “The Tempest” by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey in Madison is less concerned with flashy stagecraft and more intent upon fleshing out the emotions that dwell within Prospero’s heart.
lead_paragraph: The shipwreck that opens Shakespeare’s “Tempest” is often staged with billowing sails, splintering masts and despairing sailors lurching across heaving decks amid blasts of rain and wind. Yet that is not the way the play begins in the current production by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey in Madison.

headline: After Thrill of Triple Crown Bid, Frustration for Delayed Passengers
keywords: ['Belmont Stakes', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Horse Racing', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Transit Systems', 'Railroads', 'Transportation', 'Buses']
abstract: The possibility of seeing a Triple Crown winner brought larger crowds to Belmont Park, testing the infrastructure of the track and the city’s public transportation.
lead_paragraph: The first train arrived an hour before post time for the opening race, pulling into a creaky rail station unaccustomed to the crowd.

headline: Strike One
abstract: Patrick Berry strikes out.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — O.K, here’s the thing: There are times when the creative vision of a puzzle maker outpaces that of some of the technology that exists to support that vision. And because there are many third party programs and apps with which to download The New York Times Crossword — programs and apps that The Times does not control — not everyone will have the same experience. I might have alluded to that yesterday, when I was driving myself crazy trying to think of a way to explain this puzzle. I feel better now, so here we go.

headline: Baby-Boomer Misery Confronts a Funnier Future
abstract: “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” which is at Hartford Stage, is a comic mash-up of Chekhovian themes and characters, with nods to Aeschylus, Shakespeare, Beckett and Walt Disney.
lead_paragraph: What’s so great about licking postage stamps, anyway? Audiences at Hartford Stage will be forgiven if they don’t stop to think this through as Mark Nelson, playing the first of the four title characters in Christopher Durang’s “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” waxes rhapsodic about stamp-licking. His brilliant, showstopping rant about the vanished joys of yesteryear — coonskin caps, Dinah Shore, rotary-dial telephones, Bishop Fulton J. Sheen, handwritten letters and, yes, even the icky, glue-backed stamps for posting them — bursts forth in a torrent that vanquishes any and all cavils.

headline: Seeking National Glory, Clubs Tap Global Talent
abstract: The winners of league championships in Britain and France depended on an international lineup of stars.
lead_paragraph: The champions of premier French and British club leagues defended their titles this year by doing the usual: importing world-class talent.

headline: Urged to Multiply, Iranian Couples Are Dubious
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Population']
abstract: The country’s leadership is offering incentives to begin and enlarge families, but experts say little will change while economic prospects are grim.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — In their early 30s, married, and with prospects for successful careers, Bita and Sherag could be contemplating the logical next step in their lives: becoming parents.

headline: Though Not Quietly, Kentucky Moves to Cut Reliance on Coal
keywords: ['Coal', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: Despite cries of a “war on coal” that echo through mining country in eastern Kentucky, the region is already taking hardheaded steps toward a post-coal economy.
lead_paragraph: BURGIN, Ky. — The E. W. Brown power plant rides like an ocean liner on a rolling ridge in Kentucky, its smokestacks and plumes visible across fields of corn and cattle for miles around.

headline: Giants Series Gives Mets Another Look at What They Lost in Pagan
abstract: Since the Mets traded him in 2011, Angel Pagan has been a driving force for the World Series-winning Giants.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Angel Pagan keeps his World Series ring, the one he won with the San Francisco Giants in 2012, in his house, in a secure location he does not readily divulge. Every now and then, he takes it out and admires it. The ring motivates him.

headline: Behind the ‘Slightly-Better-Than-a-Dartboard Guide to Choosing a Team’
abstract: In the World Cup, you can choose to root for your ancestors or, if you want, a team that speaks to you, and not your patriotic pride. If that’s your chosen course, this is a chart for you.
lead_paragraph: As a nation of immigrants, Americans tend to have more choices than most when it comes to rooting for a team in the World Cup. You get the United States — that’s your safety school, so to speak. Unfortunately, the U.S. national team never figures to go very deep into the tournament. So you can choose to root for your ancestors or, if you want, a team that speaks to you, and not your national or ethnic pride. If that’s your chosen course, this is a chart for you.

headline: Fresh Legs Stamp Out a Coronation
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Belmont Stakes', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers']
abstract: Tonalist won the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, denying California Chrome his shot at becoming the first Triple Crown winner since Affirmed in 1978.
lead_paragraph: The gates popped open Saturday, and 11 horses charged past the grandstand for a mile-and-a-half marathon nicknamed, fittingly, the Test of the Champion. All eyes were on California Chrome, in pursuit of the first Triple Crown since 1978. There appeared to be little to worry about as jockey Victor Espinoza spurted him along the rail and glided him into the first turn almost easier than he had in his six previous races, all victories.

headline: Seeing Squalor and Unconcern in a Mississippi Jail
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Two years after control of the East Mississippi Correctional Facility changed hands amid complaints about squalid conditions, advocates for inmates say little has improved.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — Open fires sometimes burn unheeded in the solitary-confinement units of the East Mississippi Correctional Facility, a privately run state prison in Meridian, 90 miles east of here.

headline: Bergdahl Was in Unit Known for Its Troubles
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Prisoners of War']
abstract: The issues faced by Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s unit in many ways reflected the problems of the Pentagon’s strategy writ large across Afghanistan at that moment of the war.
lead_paragraph: The platoon was, an American military official would assert years later, “raggedy.”

headline: Cleveland Clinic Chief Out of Running for V.A.
abstract: The chief executive of the Cleveland Clinic, Dr. Delos M. Cosgrove, said Saturday that he had been considered for the job of secretary of veterans affairs, but had withdrawn his name.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Dr. Delos M. Cosgrove, the chief executive of the Cleveland Clinic, said Saturday he had been considered by President Obama for the job of secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, but had withdrawn his name and would stay at the clinic.

headline: Outside Money Floods Alaska in Senate Race
abstract: Political ads fill the airwaves in Alaska, which has become a giant receptacle for money from “super PACs” fighting for control of the United States Senate.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — A big part of being an Alaskan is harboring a suspicion of all things Lower 48. It’s an inclination that runs so deep that locals have a proper noun to describe everywhere else — Outside.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Book ‘Hard Choices’ Portrays a Tested Policy Wonk
abstract: “Hard Choices” is a statesmanlike document intended to attest to Mrs. Clinton’s wide-ranging experience on national security and on foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: The rollout of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s new book, “Hard Choices,” as a prelude to a possible 2016 run for the White House, has had all the subtlety of a military operation ramping up to full speed: the leak of the Benghazi chapter to Politico late last month (presumably to get talk about that hot-button topic out of the way early), the cover story in the latest issue of People magazine, the wall-to-wall lineup of television interviews this week, a grueling cross-country book tour.

headline: Portraying Horse as Hero, Soon Fallen
keywords: ['California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Television', 'Belmont Stakes', 'Horse Racing', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers']
abstract: Television networks face the danger of falling in love with potential Triple Crown winners, and not doing enough justice to the rest of the field.
lead_paragraph: Heading into the Belmont Stakes, California Chrome was the undisputed story.

headline: As Bowe Bergdahl Heals, Details Emerge of His Captivity
abstract: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl told medical officials he was locked in a metal cage in total darkness for weeks at a time as punishment for trying to escape, according to officials briefed on his condition.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl has told medical officials that his captors locked him in a metal cage in total darkness for weeks at a time as punishment for trying to escape, and while military doctors say he now is physically able to travel he is not yet emotionally ready for the pressures of reuniting with his family, according to American officials who have been briefed on his condition.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 7, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: June 7, 2014

headline: ‘Orphan Black’ Recap: Meet the New Clone, the One With the Flannel Shirt
abstract: Is Tony going to stick around?
lead_paragraph: Season 2, Episode 8: As I watched Saturday’s installment of “Orphan Black” for the second time, something continued to bother me. The introduction of Tony, a transgendered clone played by Tatiana Maslany, is certainly a surprising development and another intriguing variation on the show’s central themes of individual identity within a select group and nature vs. nurture.

headline: Hope Wilts as Tradition Stays Strong
keywords: ['Belmont Stakes', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Horse Racing', 'Flowers and Plants']
abstract: Tony Green, Belmont’s official florist, felt deep in his bones on Saturday morning that California Chrome would win the Triple Crown and wear the blanket of carnations he had assembled.
lead_paragraph: The traditional blanket of white carnations placed on the winner of the Belmont Stakes was made with 445 flowers painstakingly glued to a seven-foot-long velveteen quilt by Tony Green, who felt deep in his bones on Saturday morning that California Chrome would win the Triple Crown.

headline: Handwriting on Wall for Yankees as Ball Flies Over It
abstract: With the Yankees in a scoring slump, the starting pitcher David Phelps knew what a tiebreaking, three-run homer by the Royals’ Salvador Perez likely meant for his team — another defeat.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The pitch was down, almost at Salvador Perez’s shoe tops, just where Yankees starter David Phelps wanted it. Then Perez swung and drove the ball where Phelps never expected, toward the Kansas City Royals’ bullpen in left field.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 8, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 8, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “Anybody with a lot of children is either very rich or very irresponsible. There is no other way.”

headline: U.S. Displays Improvement Across the Field and a Breakthrough at the Front
abstract: Jozy Altidore hit his stride Saturday with two goals against Nigeria as the United States men’s national team completed a sweep of three exhibitions before the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — After struggling with a scoring slump dating to last year, Jozy Altidore hit his stride Saturday with two goals in a convincing 2-1 win over Nigeria that could give the United States national team momentum for its arrival in Brazil for the World Cup.

headline: The Intimacy of Anonymity
abstract: Thanks to Facebook and Instagram, oversharing one’s personal life feels as authentic as reality TV. Right now anonymous posts hold the key to the truth.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to Facebook and Instagram, oversharing one’s personal life feels as authentic as reality TV. Right now anonymous posts hold the key to the truth.

headline: Stephen Boehmke, Nicholas Koster
abstract: The couple are architects in New York firms.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Paul Boehmke and Nicholas Simon Koster were married Saturday evening at Basilica Hudson, an event and performance space in Hudson, N.Y., by Miguel Escobar, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion.

headline: Sarah Brody, Bradley Cohen
abstract: The bride raises funds for a nonprofit organization; the groom is a lawyer for the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Michele Brody and Bradley Heath Cohen are to be married Sunday at the Temple, a synagogue in Atlanta. Rabbi Peter S. Berg will officiate, with Rabbi Ed Snitkoff, an uncle of the groom, assisting.

headline: Samantha Ladd and Justin Sughrue
abstract: The bride is a vice president at JPMorgan Chase; the groom directs investments at CVC Credit Partners.

abstract: For Tyler Alexandra Ellis, her wedding dress wasn’t fashion, to paraphrase her father, but it was exclusive.
lead_paragraph: To paraphrase her father, the bride didn’t wear fashion, she wore a wedding dress.

lead_paragraph: Joanna Amy Brooks and Marcus Andreas Klostermeyer are to be married Sunday afternoon by Cantor Leslie Friedlander at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

headline: Kings Again Take the Lead Only When Necessary: At the End
abstract: The Kings conjured another unlikely finish to beat the Rangers and gain a 2-0 advantage in the Stanley Cup finals, a series in which Los Angeles has not held a lead before the end of a game.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals was decided in overtime. Game 2 on Saturday night at Staples Center went to double overtime, more than four hours after the first puck was dropped. Eighty-two shots were fired on goal. When the last one eluded the outstretched glove of Henrik Lundqvist, the Los Angeles Kings grabbed a stranglehold on the series.

headline: Steve Coburn Lashes Out at Racing Industry, Capping an Emotional Five Weeks
keywords: ['Belmont Stakes', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Horse Racing', 'Kentucky Derby', 'Preakness Stakes']
abstract: Coburn, an owner of California Chrome, said horses shouldn’t be allowed to skip the Kentucky Derby to stay fresh for the Belmont Stakes.
lead_paragraph: Steve Coburn was afforded five weeks of fame beyond the clichéd 15 minutes, and he made the most of his time in the limelight.

lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

keywords: ['Belmont Stakes', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)']

lead_paragraph: An estimated crowd of 100,000 attended Belmont Park on Saturday to watch California Chrome run for the Triple Crown.

headline: Giants Rally in Ninth to Send Mets to Fifth Straight Loss
abstract: San Francisco took advantage when the ball trickled away on a third strike to Angel Pagan to start a two-run ninth-inning rally to overcome the Mets.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mets catcher Anthony Recker stood still, his hand on his hip, staring blankly into the distance. The Mets were clinging to a 4-3 ninth-inning lead over the San Francisco Giants, the best team in baseball.

headline: World Cup Crib Sheet: Very Important Charts
abstract: We complete our series of crib sheets to help readers watch the World Cup like true fanatics. To see which team asked for a Jacuzzi in every hotel room, and more, check out the charts below.
lead_paragraph: We complete our series of crib sheets to help readers watch the World Cup like true fanatics. To see which team asked for a Jacuzzi in every hotel room, and more, check out the charts below.

headline: 2014 Tony Awards: Hugh Jackman on His Hosting Plans
abstract: Hugh Jackman discusses Sunday’s Tony Awards and explains why Neil Patrick Harris is a tough act to follow.
lead_paragraph: For complete coverage of the Tony Awards, including performance videos, predictions and an interactive ballot, please visit The Times’s Tony Awards special section.

headline: A Plea to the Daughters of Title IX: Why Don’t More Women Coach?
abstract: When I was a child playing soccer, there weren’t that many women who’d grown up playing the game. Now there are, but they’re still not represented on the sidelines, and that’s not the way this is supposed to work.
lead_paragraph: When I first registered my daughter, Lily, for soccer five years ago, I made a conscious decision to take a back seat. I wouldn’t volunteer to be the head coach. Instead, I would take a role as an assistant/orange-slice dispenser. The plan was for me to lend support, but not loom too large over my daughter.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 68TH ANNUAL TONY AWARDS Hugh Jackman, above, will sing and dance his way across the stage of Radio City Music Hall as host of this ceremony honoring excellence on Broadway. Performers include the nominees Neil Patrick Harris and the cast of “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” Sutton Foster and the cast of “Violet,” and Idina Menzel, in a song from “If/Then,” as well as Alan Cumming in a reprisal of his Tony Award-winning role from “Cabaret.” Other highlights include a 10th-anniversary celebration by the cast of “Wicked”; Patti LaBelle, Gladys Knight and Fantasia in performance with the cast of “After Midnight”; Sting in a work from his coming musical, “The Last Ship”; and Jennifer Hudson in a number from “Finding Neverland,” a Harvey Weinstein project.

headline: In Our Pages: June 9
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Plans for a railway in Tonquin are announced in 1889; The British monarch meets President Roosevelt in 1939.
lead_paragraph: 1889: The Tonquin Railway

headline: How Much Should We Pay For Art?
abstract: When so much is free online, ANNA NORTH writes, how do we determine the value of creative work?
lead_paragraph: “How do we decide, as a capitalist society, what creative expression is worth?” That question, posed by Ester Bloom at The Billfold, gets more vexed every day. In a time when more and more art is available for free online, we as a society have to figure out how to value and support it.

headline: At Swearing-In, Ex-General Vows ‘Inclusive’ Egypt
keywords: ['Elections', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, who led the military takeover that ousted President Mohamed Morsi, formalized his grip on power but must now overcome economic dysfunction and political polarization.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who led the military takeover here nearly one year ago, was sworn in as president on Sunday, testing the bet that a new strongman can overcome the economic dysfunction and political polarization that bedeviled Egypt’s three-year experiment with democracy.

headline: 3 Inmates Escape in Quebec in Latest Helicopter Jailbreak
keywords: ['Prison Escapes', 'Helicopters', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The men fled aboard a helicopter that landed in the courtyard of a jail in suburban Quebec City, the second such aerial breakout in the province in 15 months.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Three men escaped from a Quebec jail on Saturday night aboard a helicopter, the second aerial breakout in the province in 15 months.

headline: A Half-Century of Guiding Young Scholars in Harlem
abstract: Since 1964, Edouard E. Plummer has taken promising poor and minority children and, in one intense year, given them the tools to get into — and thrive at — the nation’s leading schools and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Edouard E. Plummer works out of a room inside a Harlem public school that would be spacious — if it were a storage closet. Still, he has found a way to pack its shelves and cover its walls with a growing testament to a half-century of achievements that rival those of headmasters at the swankiest prep schools.

headline: Nadal Denies Djokovic, and Defies Belief, Once Again
abstract: Rafael Nadal won his ninth French Open title Sunday and fifth in a row, defeating his longtime rival Novak Djokovic, 3-6, 7-5, 6-2, 6-4.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After all the consecutive victories and the confidently clenched fists, after the new hires and the new attitude, the 2014 French Open was just another red-clay rerun for Novak Djokovic.

headline: Critics of P.O.W. Swap Question the Absence of a Wider Agreement
abstract: Many in the Afghan government believed that American officials misled them into thinking that the prisoner swap would not be done unless it was connected to a broader peace effort.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the heads of the two major intelligence committees criticized the Obama administration on Sunday for swapping Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl for five members of the Taliban, they homed in on one part of the deal that the White House has struggled for a week, unsuccessfully, to explain. The question is why the five were released without any commitments to a larger agreement, under which the Taliban would renounce international terrorism, and begin a process of reconciliation with the government of Afghanistan.

headline: Sisi Ascends to the Presidency
abstract: Abdel-Fattah el-Sisi was sworn in Sunday as Egypt’s president.
lead_paragraph: Abdel-Fattah el-Sisi was sworn in Sunday as Egypt’s president.

headline: Is It Possible to Be a Male Feminist?
abstract: Some men have proclaimed themselves as feminists. The Isla Vista killings have renewed questions about the authenticity and meaning of that identity, JAKE FLANIGAN writes.
lead_paragraph: Who is the male feminist? Perhaps we should first ask: Does he even exist?

headline: ‘Calvin and Hobbes’ Creator Returns, Briefly
abstract: After nearly two decades, Bill Watterson, the creator of “Calvin and Hobbes,” made a surprising return to comic strips last week.
lead_paragraph: Bill Watterson, the creator of “Calvin and Hobbes” who retired in 1995 and withdrew from the public eye for almost two decades, has finally returned to drawing comic strips, if only for a brief moment. Last week, Mr. Watterson was the ghost artist for a handful of panels on Stephan Pastis’s “Pearls Before Swine” for a storyline in which Mr. Pastis is replaced as the artist of the strip by a second grader named Libby.

headline: Rift Deepens in Britain Over Claims of School Infiltration Plot by Islamic Extremists
abstract: A dispute over how to combat the threat of homegrown Islamic extremism in British schools has provoked a political crisis, prompting a public apology and a resignation.
lead_paragraph: A dispute over how to combat the threat of homegrown Islamic extremism in British schools has provoked a political crisis, prompting the personal intervention of Prime Minister David Cameron, a public apology from one senior minister and the resignation of an adviser to another.

headline: Border Makes China and India Bristle, Even as They Seek Closer Ties in Trade
abstract: As the neighbors try to reinvigorate their economic relationship in meetings this week, India’s support for Tibetan exiles who seek regional autonomy is an abiding source of conflict.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — China’s state news media has welcomed India’s new prime minister, Narendra Modi, as a pragmatic new partner on economic matters, noting that as a regional leader, he made four visits to Beijing seeking investment and even went to the trouble of printing his business cards in Chinese characters, in the auspicious color of red.

headline: In Egypt, Back to Rule By a Strongman
abstract: After the swearing-in of Sisi in Egypt, the reactions from around the world were mixed, JAKE FLANAGIN writes.
lead_paragraph: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who led the military takeover in Egypt nearly one year ago, was sworn in as the country’s president on Sunday. The reactions to Sisi’s election ranged from downright joyous to cautiously optimistic to unapologetically cynical.

headline: Terrorists Attack Airport in Pakistan, Killing 13
abstract: Ten gunmen infiltrated Karachi international airport, engaging in an extended firefight against security forces, killing 13 people before security forces killed the militants and regained control of the airport.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — In a ferocious terrorist assault that stretched into Monday morning, suspected Islamist militants infiltrated Pakistan’s largest international airport in Karachi, waging an extended firefight against security forces that resulted in 23 deaths and shook the country’s already fragile sense of security.

headline: Rangers Fume Over a Tangle in the Crease
abstract: Dwight King’s goal in the third period Saturday started the Kings’ rally and incensed the Rangers’ Henrik Lundqvist, who said he could not move on the play.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Whether a play included goaltender interference, perhaps the most disputed penalty in hockey, is not reviewable by replay officials, despite frequent pleas to make it so. The Rangers’ Henrik Lundqvist became the latest to issue that request, after Game 2 of the Stanley Cup finals Saturday night.

headline: Tonalist’s Owner Savors Victory but Offers Some Criticism of His Own
keywords: ['Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Horse Racing', 'Belmont Stakes', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)']
abstract: For Robert Evans, Tonalist’s win in the Belmont Stakes made up somewhat for a failed Triple Crown by his father’s horse in 1981. But he, like his competition, relayed complaints.
lead_paragraph: Robert Evans was gracious Saturday evening when a reporter relayed the sour-grapes comments from Steve Coburn, one of California Chrome’s owners.

headline: Vanity Fair Ad Gives Life to What Killed the Cat
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Magazines', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Social Media']
abstract: A campaign with the theme “born curious” begins on Monday, with the goal of expanding circulation and generating more ads.
lead_paragraph: SCHWEPPES, for many years, sold tonic water as “curiously refreshing.” Hendrick’s gin staged a “theater of curiosities” and billed its unusual website as a “Curiositorium.” And it is, of course, common knowledge what curiosity did to that cat.

headline: 2014 Tony Awards: ‘Gentleman’s Guide’ and ‘All the Way’ Take Top Honors
abstract: Charles Isherwood and Eric Grode are live-blogging the 68th annual Tony Awards. Stay tuned for their ongoing commentary, photos from the show, reports from the press room and more.
lead_paragraph: Charles Isherwood, a theater critic for The Times, and Eric Grode, a writer and critic for The Times, live-blogged the 68th annual Tony Awards.

headline: Trying to Stop Fight at Staten Island Bar, Man Dies After He Is Punched
abstract: A 46-year-old regular at the Drunken Monkey who was trying to break up a fight was killed when he was struck and fell backward, his head hitting the pavement.
lead_paragraph: Closing time was approaching early Sunday morning at the Drunken Monkey, a Staten Island bar with a reality television claim to fame, when a group of stragglers began fighting.

headline: At Vatican, Day of Prayer With Focus on Uniting
abstract: The Israeli and Palestinian presidents went to the Vatican on Sunday at the invitation of Pope Francis, and Jews, Christians and Muslims offered invocations for peace.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — In a richly symbolic ceremony, Pope Francis oversaw a carefully orchestrated “prayer summit” with the Israeli and Palestinian presidents on Sunday as Jews, Christians and Muslims offered invocations for peace in the Vatican gardens.

headline: Andy Murray Picks Amélie Mauresmo as His New Coach
abstract: Mauresmo immediately became the highest-profile female coach in tennis but otherwise fits a trend in which current champions have hired former champions to join their teams.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was the French Open’s best off-court chess match: Andy Murray versus the news media on the topic of his new coach.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 9
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Municipal Bonds', 'Government Bonds']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: From China, With Pragmatism
abstract: Are the Chinese outdoing Americans at their own philosophical game?
lead_paragraph: As an American Fulbright lecturer living in Beijing, I am regularly confronted with “lost in translation” ethical conversations. At a recent lunch with United States Embassy officers and local Chinese intellectuals, we had a complete cultural breakdown over red envelopes.

headline: Yankees’ Offense Goes Back to Sleep, Squandering a Solid Start by Kuroda
abstract: The Yankees went 1 for 17 with runners in scoring position and even failed to score after loading the bases with no outs in the second.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — On a partly cloudy Sunday morning, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi led more than a dozen reporters down a hallway to the visitors’ dugout at Kauffman Stadium and sat down. Ever optimistic, Girardi then cited run-scoring doubles by Brian McCann and Carlos Beltran the previous two nights as encouraging signs for his club’s struggling offense.

headline: Five Killed in Las Vegas Shootings
abstract: Two people fatally shot two police officers at a restaurant before killing a third victim at a second site and then shooting themselves, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Two police officers and another person were killed in a shooting rampage on Sunday morning in Las Vegas, the authorities said.

headline: Philharmonic’s Contemporary Foray Ends, With a Promise of More
abstract: Alisa Weilerstein was the cello soloist in Friday night’s installment of the NY Phil Biennial contemporary festival.
lead_paragraph: Avery Fisher Hall looked to be about half-full for a concert by the New York Philharmonic on Friday night, the orchestra’s next-to-last program for the inaugural NY Phil Biennial, conducted by the vibrant German-born composer Matthias Pintscher. The Philharmonic, the institutional curator of this bracing festival, may have hoped that every event would attract capacity crowds; some, in smaller halls, did.

headline: A Paragon of Honor, With a Little Time Off for Love
abstract: In remake of 2012 Tamil hit, Akshay Kumar stars as a captain on home leave in “Holiday.”
lead_paragraph: Akshay Kumar has made a career of playing Indian Everymen, sweet goofballs who succeed accidentally while upholding traditional values. He may cut down villains — there’s plenty of fighting in movies like “Chandni Chowk to China” and “Singh Is Kinng” — but he honors mothers and aunties and helps the poor.

headline: For Audience and Young Composers, a Chance to See Works Take Flight
abstract: Seven rising composers had their pieces performed in the first NY Phil Biennial.
lead_paragraph: “I want to clarify the articulation in the oboes in measure four,” George Manahan, the music director of the American Composers Orchestra, announced to his players on Saturday evening, before they began Andy Akiho’s “Tarnished Mirrors.”

headline: Teenage Angst Trumps Sci-Fi at the Box Office
abstract: “The Fault in Our Stars,” a teenage romance starring Shailene Woodley, had a strong opening weekend, forcing the highly publicized Tom Cruise vehicle, “Edge of Tomorrow,” to No. 3.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Social media came of age in Hollywood over the weekend.

headline: Stacked Deck
abstract: Dealing with the Taliban over American P.O.W.’s.
lead_paragraph: Dealing with the Taliban over American P.O.W.'s.

headline: T h r e e  S t r i k e s
abstract: Tom McCoy uses his space well.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — All is forgiven, Tom McCoy. You can come home now.

headline: A Lowly Scorned Shopgirl Takes On the Upper Crust
abstract: A working-class woman unjustly sent to prison plots revenge against well-heeled members of society in “Within the Law,” a Progressive Era melodrama revived at the Metropolitan Playhouse.
lead_paragraph: However current the issues of income inequality, a living wage and an arbitrary criminal justice system may be, “Within the Law” reminds us that they have long been fodder for popular entertainment.

headline: Good With the Scalpel, but Lacks People Skills
abstract: In Herman Koch’s “Summer House With Swimming Pool,” there is lechery, jealousy and filth, and they all come to play during a vacation on the Mediterranean coast.
lead_paragraph: Reading “The Dinner,” by the Dutch author and misanthrope Herman Koch, was rather like being stabbed in the eyeball with a hot needle. The book was such a huge international best seller that Mr. Koch is demonstrably not alone in his fascination with all things loathsome about humanity, and “The Dinner” did tell a propulsive tale. It is a hard act to follow, but say this about his new novel, “Summer House With Swimming Pool”: This is a book in which someone actually does stick a hot needle in his own eyeball. The blood, pus and pain that follow are lovingly described.

headline: Dutilleux and Ravel Mingle With Sir Mix-a-Lot
abstract: As the host ensemble for the annual conference of the League of American Orchestras, Ludovic Morlot led the Seattle Symphony in wildly contrasting programs at the Benaroya Hall.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — It has been quite a spring for the Seattle Symphony.

headline: More Than Just the Father of a Famous Actor
abstract: The actor Robert De Niro pays homage to his father, the painter Robert De Niro Sr., in a short documentary, shown Monday night on HBO.
lead_paragraph: Robert De Niro, one of the most respected and successful actors of his generation, ended up in a very different field from his father, the painter Robert De Niro Sr. But he knows that one thing is true for all artists no matter what the discipline: Talent isn’t enough. What separates someone at the top from countless skilled contemporaries who spend their careers in semi-obscurity has as much to do with serendipity as it does with ability.

headline: A Shoeshine Box, With a Luster All Its Own, Emerges From the Shadows
abstract: The Fenimore Art Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y., has acquired an ornate folk-art shoeshine box that was displayed at the Museum of Modern Art in the 1940s.
lead_paragraph: A 1930s shoeshine stand bedecked with gilded knobs and beaded fringe, which was once exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art — where it played a role in a famous director’s ouster — resurfaced last month and is headed back into the public eye.

headline: Persistence Can Be Its Own Reward, Even for a Confrontational Band
abstract: Eyehategod performs old and new songs in a Brooklyn club.
lead_paragraph: There must be a positive lesson to be extracted from the story of Eyehategod. This band from New Orleans has endured 26 years — through opiates, hurricanes, homelessness, jail and probation. It has survived a name that has never gotten any less puerile; the recent death of a drummer, Joey LaCaze, who helped define its angry and sensuous sound; touring whenever possible; recording a lot less often; and a kind of artfully antisocial behavior.

headline: Tracy Morgan, Still Critical, Is ‘More Responsive’
abstract: The actor and comedian Tracy Morgan remained in critical condition on Sunday after he was injured in a crash in New Jersey over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: The actor and comedian Tracy Morgan remained in critical condition on Sunday after he was injured in a crash in New Jersey over the weekend. Mr. Morgan, 45, a former cast member of “Saturday Night Live” and “30 Rock,” had several serious injuries, including a broken leg, a broken femur, a broken nose and several broken ribs, his publicist Lewis Kay said on Sunday. He was hurt when a tractor-trailer slammed into the back of the luxury van he was riding in as he left a comedy show in Delaware around 1 a.m. on Saturday. Mr. Morgan is expected to remain in the hospital for several weeks, Mr. Kay said.

headline: Focusing on a Mystery, and Their Own Dramas
abstract: “Murder in the First,” a new show from Steven Bochco, has some echoes of a Bochco series from the 1990s but also some telling differences.
lead_paragraph: When a series follows one murder investigation for an entire season, the conceit can sometimes look like a European refinement. “Broadchurch,” “Spiral” and “The Fall” are just a notable few of the many imported shows that proved so broodingly intense that it sometimes seemed as if networks and basic cable here could never catch up.

headline: Biggest Master Point Winner at Eastern States Regional
abstract: John Kranyak of Las Vegas won more master points (78.7) than anyone else at the Eastern States Regional in Manhattan last month.
lead_paragraph: John Kranyak of Las Vegas won more master points (78.7) than anyone else at the Eastern States Regional in Manhattan last month. He had three firsts and one second in four Swiss Team events.

headline: A Work Moves, Even if Some of the Figures Do Not
abstract: Silhouette cutouts of other dancers were part of “Diary of an Image by DD Dorvillier,” at Danspace Project.
lead_paragraph: “Diary of an Image by DD Dorvillier,” the four-week performance series that has been running at Danspace Project in St. Mark’s Church since May 21, has mostly evaded providing a clear, defining image of DD Dorvillier. “A Catalogue of Steps” rearranged fragments from her early works. The “Solo Performances” over two weekends were created and performed by people other than Ms. Dorvillier. And on Friday, when she debuted her own work, also called “Diary of an Image,” she gave over the first part of the piece to stationary silhouettes of other dancers.

headline: Governors Ball
abstract: Scenes from the music festival on Randalls Island.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the music festival on Randalls Island.

headline: A Mix of Fact and Imagination, ‘As Seen on Radio’
abstract: An episode of “This American Life” taped at the Brooklyn Academy of Music included work by Philip Glass and Lin-Manuel Miranda.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Academy of Music’s opera house must have hosted plenty of Valkyries in its time. But Jeanine De Bique is almost certainly the first to stride onstage accessorized with a broom and dishwashing gloves, singing about how much she hates her job.

headline: Jennifer Lopez Bows Out of World Cup Ceremony
abstract: Jennifer Lopez will not perform as planned because of what FIFA officials are calling “production issues,” The Associated Press has reported.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Lopez will not perform as planned at the opening ceremony of the 2014 World Cup in São Paulo, Brazil, on Thursday because of what FIFA officials are calling “production issues,” The Associated Press has reported. Ms. Lopez was scheduled to appear alongside the rapper Pitbull and the Brazilian star Claudia Leitte for a performance of “We Are One (Ole Ola),” the official song of the soccer tournament, before the opening match between Brazil and Croatia. All three artists perform on the recording of the track, which was released in April and written and co-produced by Pitbull. A replacement for Ms. Lopez has not been announced.

headline: ‘Pass It On’
abstract: This short video shows how a Congolese man turns scraps into a soccer ball for village children, so they can play the sport they love.
lead_paragraph: As soon as I saw a photograph of an African soccer ball, stitched together from old rags in the geometric patterns so familiar to us, I wanted to tell its story.

headline: Pass It On
abstract: This short video shows how a Congolese man turns scraps into a soccer ball for village children, so they can play the sport they love.
lead_paragraph: This short video shows how a Congolese man turns scraps into a soccer ball for village children, so they can play the sport they love.

headline: An Invasion of Color at Chelsea Art Gallery
abstract: The famously chromophobic Chelsea got a shock of color on the walls of the Gemini G.E.L. at Joni Moisant Weyl Gallery.
lead_paragraph: The famously chromophobic Chelsea got a shock of color on Thursday night: lime green, sunshine yellow, orange and spring green on the walls of the Gemini G.E.L. at Joni Moisant Weyl Gallery, defying conventional wisdom that galleries must be white. The masterminds were two architects known for shaking up hotels and houses with bold hues: Peter Stamberg (who held court in a fluorescent orange jacket from Joe Fresh) and Paul Aferiat (in pink seersucker), founders of Stamberg Aferiat & Associates.

headline: Aftermath of the Karachi Airport Attack
abstract: The scene at the airport in Karachi, Pakistan, after militants stormed past security, firing automatic weapons and hurling grenades.
lead_paragraph: The scene at the airport in Karachi, Pakistan, after militants stormed past security, firing automatic weapons and hurling grenades.

abstract: Readers respond to an editorial about relieving the penalties imposed on those with a criminal record.

headline: Noncompete Clauses Increasingly Pop Up in Array of Jobs
abstract: Once largely limited to the technology and sales sectors, the agreements are entering a range of fields; even camp counselors and hairstylists are being required to sign.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Colette Buser couldn’t understand why a summer camp withdrew its offer for her to work there this year.

headline: After Period of Turmoil, Riverside Church Elects New Leader
abstract: The Rev. Dr. Amy K. Butler was elected to lead one of the nation’s most prominent liberal Protestant pulpits, making her the first woman to head the church in its 84-year history.
lead_paragraph: Riverside Church, one of the nation’s most prominent liberal Protestant pulpits, on Sunday elected as its new senior minister the Rev. Dr. Amy K. Butler, making her the first woman to head the church in its 84-year history.
