abstract: A hobby that saw its heyday in Victorian Britain is enjoying a revival in London.
lead_paragraph: A hobby that saw its heyday in Victorian Britain is enjoying a revival in London.

headline: As a British Pastime Is Revived, Some Critters Get Second Lives
abstract: A hobby that blends taxidermy with arts and crafts is enjoying a resurgence, with class rosters and course materials that are stuffed.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Now pull the skin up over the skull like a hood,” Margot Magpie instructed her students. They were hunched over wooden tables, each holding a scalpel in one hand and a white mouse, gutted, in the other.

headline: End of Altidore’s Slump Lifts U.S. Hopes
abstract: The United States national team will rely on forward Jozy Altidore at the World Cup, and he may have a newfound confidence after scoring twice against Nigeria on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — As the United States national team prepares for the World Cup in Brazil, it is riding the momentum of a three-game winning streak and perhaps a dose of newfound confidence from its starting striker, Jozy Altidore.

headline: Peaceful Nonreconciliation Now
abstract: Palestinians need not live in abject poverty. They deserve drastic and immediate improvements in their everyday lives.
lead_paragraph: MAALE SHOMRON, West Bank — JOHN KERRY’S failed Middle East peace effort has made it clear that a negotiated political agreement is impossible at the moment. The two-state formula enjoyed decades of exclusive stardom, in which its appeal thwarted all innovative and alternative thought.

headline: Shifts in Charity Health Care
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'Philanthropy', 'Hospitals', 'Editorials']
abstract: There are still too many gaps and quirks in the health care reform law that could prevent the most vulnerable groups from getting insurance.
lead_paragraph: Health care reform was supposed to relieve the financial strain on hospitals that have provided a lot of free charity care to poor and uninsured patients. The reform law, known as the Affordable Care Act, was expected to insure most of those patients either through expanded state Medicaid programs for the poor or through subsidized private insurance for middle-income patients, thereby funneling new revenues to hospitals that had previously absorbed the costs of uncompensated care.

headline: Reconstruction Planned for Infamous Townhouse in Greenwich Village
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The house at 18 West 11th Street has had its share of famous owners and, in 1970, was the site of an accidental bombing by the Weatherman group.
lead_paragraph: The house at 18 West 11th Street is one of Greenwich Village’s most famous. It has been a home to literary and Broadway royalty, the site of a deadly accidental bombing by Weatherman radicals and, once rebuilt, a sweet neighborhood fixture with a stuffed Paddington Bear wearing seasonal outfits in its angled picture window.

headline: Tipped Into Poverty
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Waiters and Waitresses', 'Law and Legislation', 'Tips and Tipping', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Americans who work for tips have not received a raise in 20 years. Congress should give it to them.
lead_paragraph: When Senate Republicans recently blocked a vote to raise the federal minimum wage, they snubbed the estimated 27.8 million people who would earn more if the measure became law. The hardest hit are the roughly 3.3 million Americans who work for tips, nearly three out of four of whom are women. Workers in predominantly tipped jobs — including restaurant servers, bartenders, hairstylists — are twice as likely as other workers to live below the poverty line. They need a raise, and Congress should give it to them.

headline: A Model for Juvenile Detention Reform
keywords: ['Solitary Confinement', 'Children and Childhood', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Editorials', 'Juvenile Delinquency']
abstract: The Justice Department’s recent settlement with Ohio, which will eventually end solitary confinement there, puts all states on notice.
lead_paragraph: States are sending fewer and fewer children to juvenile correctional facilities, partly in response to research showing that locking up young people increases the risk that they will eventually drop out of school and become permanently entangled with the justice system.

headline: A Triple Crown Tradition Prevails at Belmont Stakes Despite Sour Grapes
keywords: ['Belmont Stakes', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Horse Racing', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)']
abstract: The owner and trainer of Tonalist, the Belmont Stakes winner, understood why Steve Coburn, a co-owner of California Chrome, was upset, but the reality was that they put their horse first.
lead_paragraph: California Chrome’s co-owner Steve Coburn was upset, and so were the multitudes who had their hearts set Saturday on a victory by the colt in the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes and the first Triple Crown in 36 years. But, like all of us who at one time or another need to heed the guiding, loving hand of a spouse, the voluble cowboy should have listened to his wife, Carolyn, and just zipped it when the cameras were in his face.

headline: Cyberattack Insurance a Challenge for Business
abstract: More businesses are buying policies, but losses are difficult to quantify because attackers are constantly getting more advanced.
lead_paragraph: Julia Roberts’s smile is insured. So are Heidi Klum’s legs, Daniel Craig’s body and Jennifer Lopez’s derrière. But the fastest-growing niche in the industry today is cyberinsurance.

headline: Ebola Gets Worse in West Africa
abstract: Nations afflicted by the epidemic, as well as their neighbors, will need to redouble efforts to contain the virus.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization warned last Wednesday that the epidemic caused by the deadly Ebola virus in West Africa, which had seemed to be waning, has recently taken a turn for the worse. The afflicted nations and their neighbors will need to redouble their efforts to contain a virus for which there is neither a cure nor a vaccine.

headline: Ready for Spotlight, a Course Is Restored to Its Shaggy Self
keywords: ['Golf', 'PGA Championship', 'United States Open (Golf)', "United States Women's Open (Golf)", 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: The Pinehurst No. 2 course, recently returned to its original appearance with irregular sand and native vegetation, will host the United States Open and the United States Women’s Open in the coming weeks.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — As one of the country’s first golf resorts, Pinehurst has long been viewed as an American cradle of the sport. The resort’s showcase golf course, known as Pinehurst No. 2, hosted its first major event more than 100 years ago and evolved into a masterpiece of the nation’s best-known golf architect, Donald Ross.

headline: In Crown Heights, Once Torn by Race Riots, a Friendly Game of Soccer
abstract: Teams of Hasidic Jews and black immigrants from the Caribbean came together to play soccer in the Crown Heights Cup, in a section of Brooklyn with a history of tension.
lead_paragraph: The World Cup may be days away, but in Brooklyn, the Crown Heights Cup game on Sunday may be almost as important. In some ways, it is more important.

headline: Religious Constriction
keywords: ['Creationism and Intelligent Design', 'Religion and Belief', 'Global Warming', 'Evolution (Biology)']
abstract: We can’t let political leaders cast science and facts out of the culture.
lead_paragraph: I am both shocked and fascinated by Americans’ religious literalism.

headline: Netflix Investors to Vote on C.E.O.-Chairman Split
abstract: Shareholders of the media company are to vote Monday on whether to divide the roles of chief executive and chairman, now held by Reed Hastings.
lead_paragraph: Netflix has had its share of battles of late, including opposing Comcast’s proposed takeover of Time Warner Cable and pointing fingers at Verizon for some instances of its streaming video service’s being slowed. But the online video titan has also quietly faced restiveness among some of its shareholders.

headline: In Texarkana, Uninsured and on the Wrong Side of a State Line
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'States (US)']
abstract: On the Arkansas side of Texarkana, the poor gained access to Medicaid because of the Affordable Care Act. Those across the border in Texas did not.
lead_paragraph: TEXARKANA, Tex. — On a hazy, hot evening here, Janice Marks ate a dinner of turkey and stuffing at a homeless shelter filled with plastic cots before crossing a few blocks to the Arkansas side of town to start her night shift restocking the dairy cases at Walmart.

headline: Tyson Is Said to Win Battle for Hillshire Brands
abstract: Hillshire Brands, the company that makes Jimmy Dean sausages and Ball Park hot dogs, is expected to declare Tyson Foods the victor of a bidding war, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:18 a.m. | In the battle for Jimmy Dean sausages, it appears that Tyson Foods has won.

headline: Interests, Ideology and Climate
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Coal', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Mines and Mining', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Libertarianism (US Politics)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The monetary stakes, it turns out, are not the biggest obstacle to rational action on global warming.
lead_paragraph: There are three things we know about man-made global warming. First, the consequences will be terrible if we don’t take quick action to limit carbon emissions. Second, in pure economic terms the required action shouldn’t be hard to take: emission controls, done right, would probably slow economic growth, but not by much. Third, the politics of action are nonetheless very difficult.

headline: At Rio’s Beaches, Kicks Go Over Net
abstract: Futevolei is a popular Brazilian version of beach volleyball in which players use any move that would be legal in soccer to get the ball back over the net.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The most impressive move in Brazilian sports has nothing to do with soccer, takes place on sand and is known, delightfully, as the Shark Attack.

headline: An American Life, Lived in Shadows
abstract: A strict immigration law did not reduce Oklahoma’s illegal immigrant population. Tens of thousands have stayed put, hiding and striving.
lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — Ignacio, a father of four, bounces along in his pickup truck, driving at exactly the speed limit through an aging suburb. The clock says 6:44 a.m. Religious pendants hang off the mirror. His teenage son sits beside him, chatty if half-awake, as they approach an apartment building for a day of roofing in dire heat.

headline: Brazil’s Other Favorite Sport
abstract: Born on Copacabana Beach in the 1960s, futevolei is a uniquely Brazilian sport.
lead_paragraph: Born on Copacabana Beach in the 1960s, futevolei is a uniquely Brazilian sport.

headline: Are Reparations Due to African-Americans?
abstract: Would they compensate for a history of racial injustice? Would they be fair or practical? How would they be implemented?

headline: Face of the N.C.A.A., Battered Early and Often
abstract: Mark Emmert, the president of the N.C.A.A., is an unapologetic target of detractors as his organization faces legal challenges to its amateurism model.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — A large oil painting hangs in the office of Mark A. Emmert, the president of the N.C.A.A. It depicts a boxer in a gym preparing for a bout, a team of trainers huddled around him.

headline: Port Authority Land Purchase Is Boon to Bayonne, and Christie
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Local Government', 'Bankruptcies', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The Port Authority’s 2010 purchase of land in New Jersey appears to be an early example of how Gov. Chris Christie has used the agency as a financial backstop for his state.
lead_paragraph: When the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced in June 2010 that it had purchased a 131-acre tract of land on the waterfront in the city of Bayonne for $235 million, the deal seemed like an auspicious one for the agency.

headline: Five Dead in Shooting Rampage in Las Vegas
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Two suspects killed two police officers on Sunday at a restaurant and fatally shot a third person at a nearby Walmart before dying in a suicide pact, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: In a shooting rampage that left five people dead, two assailants killed two Las Vegas police officers on Sunday at a pizza restaurant and fatally shot a third person at a nearby Walmart before dying in a suicide pact, the authorities said.

headline: Day After Catcher Is Sent to Minors, Mets Are Swept Again in Trip Finale
abstract: The Mets concluded an 11-day trip with their sixth straight loss, a 6-4 defeat by the Giants. Catcher Travis d’Arnaud was demoted to Class AAA Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It was only the seventh inning, but David Wright was perhaps the Mets’ last hope. He was given a rare day off, but the Mets were a run behind the San Francisco Giants with two outs and the tying run on first base.

headline: Degree? Check. Enthusiasm? Check. Job? Not So Fast.
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Careers and Professions', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Jelani Thomas is entering the work force with a brand-new bachelor’s degree and plenty of hope. The sluggish economic recovery, however, is making it hard for him to see his next move.
lead_paragraph: He pulled the maroon robes over his shoulders and straightened his cap, his body tingling with that nothing-can-kill-this-day kind of vibe. Then he heard his mother calling his name — Jelani! Jelani! — and suddenly he was standing, then shouting, then high-fiving his fellow college graduates.

headline: 3-Pointer No Longer Domain of Small Players in N.B.A.
abstract: The Heat and the Spurs are prime examples of how the game has evolved after the introduction of the long-range shot.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Bob McAdoo, with his graceful, high-arcing jumper, was a rarity for an N.B.A. big man. At 6 feet 9 inches, he could pull shot blockers like Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Artis Gilmore and Bob Lanier out near the top of the key and shoot over them or drive past them. Three times, McAdoo led the league in scoring, and in 1975, he was named the N.B.A.’s most valuable player.

headline: A Proud Swirl of Sound and Spectacle
abstract: This year’s parade wore a slightly more serious attitude thanks to revelations of financial mismanagement and rising concern that the parade’s corporate sponsorships had turned a cherished cultural celebration into a commercial spectacle.
lead_paragraph: The parade could be seen and heard several blocks away from Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, where determined visitors armed with folding chairs and coolers had been lining the route since early Sunday morning. Red, white and blue flags fluttered like capes from the backs of people heading toward Bryant Park. Salsa music pumped from the floats and coursed through the streets. Cheers rose above the roar of Midtown traffic.

headline: A Proud Swirl of Red, White and Blue
abstract: Spectators lined Fifth Avenue to watch the 57th National Puerto Rican Day Parade, a start-of-summer tradition in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Spectators lined Fifth Avenue to watch the 57th National Puerto Rican Day Parade, a start-of-summer tradition in New York City.

headline: For Buffalo, Few Points on the Ice but Plenty in the TV Ratings
abstract: Despite the Sabres’ struggles, Buffalo’s love of hockey is Canadianesque: The game is in the city’s blood.
lead_paragraph: The hockey fans of Buffalo are proving that their passion for the sport does not wane, even when the Sabres have a miserable points percentage — the worst in their history.

headline: Stretching the Limits Seems to Suit the Kings
abstract: Los Angeles has faced a daunting amount of postseason adversity en route to a two-games-to-none lead over the Rangers in the Stanley Cup finals.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Los Angeles Kings’ relentless run this postseason may be the most inexplicable one in the 121 years of the Stanley Cup.

headline: Morris A. Adelman Dies at 96; Saw Oil as Inexhaustible
abstract: He argued that the world’s supply of oil would never be exhausted because the technology to extract it would continue to improve.
lead_paragraph: Morris A. Adelman, an energy economist who marshaled free-market principles and hard data in arguing that the world’s oil supply was not running out, died May 8 at his home in Newton, Mass. He was 96. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he taught and researched for 65 years, announced the death on May 15.

headline: Time Inc. to Set a Lonely Course After a Spinoff
keywords: ['Magazines', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Television', 'News and News Media', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The magazine publisher, once a towering presence in its industry, faces a shifting market with debts to pay as it begins trading Monday as an independent company.
lead_paragraph: Sometime late next year Time Inc., the company that all but created the modern magazine business, will leave its home of more than five decades, the Time & Life Building in Rockefeller Center, and head to new quarters in downtown Manhattan.

headline: Video Gaming’s Big Expo, and G.M.’s Shareholder Meeting
abstract: E3, the Electronic Entertainment Expo, gets underway in Los Angeles, and G.M. is to hold its shareholders’ meeting less than a week after issuing an internal report on its recall of millions of cars.

headline: Free Music, at Least While It Lasts
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Compact Discs', 'Royalties']
abstract: The people who make all that yummy music are actually being loved to death by fans who expect it to be free.
lead_paragraph: Late last Thursday, I stopped at the fruit stand and some big, vivid red grapes caught my eye. The vendor said a two-pound bunch would be $6, which seemed steep. I was about to tell him as much, and then came to my senses and gave him the money.

headline: David Nadien, Philharmonic Concertmaster, Is Dead at 88
abstract: Although Mr. Nadien’s background was as a studio musician and not an orchestral player, Leonard Bernstein appointed him as concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic in 1966.
lead_paragraph: David Nadien, a violinist whose appointment as concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic raised eyebrows because of his thriving career as a studio musician, died on May 28 in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Japan Seeks to Squelch Its Tiny Cars
keywords: ['Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Automobiles']
abstract: Saying the nation’s automakers are too focused on a niche market, the government has sharply raised taxes on the tiny vehicles, prompting an outcry.
lead_paragraph: SHINSHIRO, Japan — Toshie Yamada’s “kei,” with its pint-size engine and tiny wheels, looks more like a Fisher-Price toy car than a regular truck. But don’t underestimate her Nissan NT 100 Clipper microtruck. At a recent farmers’ market, where she sells orchids from her flower farm here in central Japan, she loaded up a mountain of crates, buckets and a folding table before hopping in and zipping away.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: June 8, 2014

headline: The Well-Followed on Social Media Cash In on Their Influence
abstract: Popular stars of social media platforms like Vine and Instagram are making advertising deals with companies trying to reach their audiences.
lead_paragraph: Good thing social media did not exist during the era of “Mad Men.” It might have put Don and Peggy out of business.

headline: Reuniting With Mother at the Zoo
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A woman’s poetic reminiscence about meeting her mother in front of the snowy owl at the Central Park Zoo.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: G.M. Report Illustrates Managers’ Disconnect
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Defective Products', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Columbia (Space Shuttle)', 'Challenger (Space Shuttle)', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Executives and Management (Theory)']
abstract: For academics who study management, the automaker’s organizational failure is all too common.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The report released last week on how General Motors failed for years to recognize a safety defect in millions of small cars contained no new scientific or engineering insights. What it did was reinforce a point about the sociology of management: From cars to space shuttles, from offshore oil wells to nuclear reactors, the people who make the decisions are often out of step with the mechanical details.

headline: Sterling’s Ban and Fine Won’t Change, Silver Says
abstract: The process of removing the Clippers owner Donald Sterling from the N.B.A. is nearing an end, Commissioner Adam Silver said Sunday.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver said Sunday that the process of removing the Clippers owner Donald Sterling from the league was nearing an end, even though Sterling had a lawsuit pending against the league and had not signed a term sheet that his wife, Rochelle, agreed to with Steve Ballmer for a $2 billion sale.

headline: War Gear Flows to Police Departments
keywords: ['Police', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Vehicles', 'ARMOR']
abstract: Former tools of combat — M-16 rifles, grenade launchers, silencers and more — are ending up in the armories of local police departments, often with little public notice.
lead_paragraph: NEENAH, Wis. — Inside the municipal garage of this small lakefront city, parked next to the hefty orange snowplow, sits an even larger truck, this one painted in desert khaki. Weighing 30 tons and built to withstand land mines, the armored combat vehicle is one of hundreds showing up across the country, in police departments big and small.

headline: ‘Penny Dreadful’ Recap: Vanessa’s Sin and Obsession
abstract: We learn the origins of the mutual contempt and attraction that seem to fuel Vanessa and Sir Malcolm.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 5: When Vanessa set out to flirt with Victor Frankenstein earlier in “Penny Dreadful,” she cooed a few lines of Wordsworth at him, from the “Intimations of Immortality,” to be precise. In “Closer Than Sisters,” the first episode to air since Showtime announced that the show has been renewed for a second season, she switches over to another Romantic poet, John Keats – and appears to be setting herself up for the worst kind of immortality.

headline: 2014 Tony Awards: ‘Gentleman’s Guide’ and ‘All the Way’ Are Named Top Shows
abstract: The awards, which honor Broadway’s best plays and performances, included a record win for Audra McDonald and honors for Neil Patrick Harris and Bryan Cranston.
lead_paragraph: Overcoming death-defying odds — modest ticket sales, little-known stars and limited appeal to tourists — “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” won the Tony Award for best musical on Sunday night, in a ceremony that stood out for spreading the wealth among many shows. As for performers, one reigned supreme: Audra McDonald made history by winning her sixth prize for acting, the most ever.

headline: ‘Halt and Catch Fire’ Recap: Joe Reveals a Scar
abstract: Joe reveals something of himself, or maybe not.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 2: Is “Halt and Catch Fire” a mystery, or is it a procedural? The second episode of AMC’s new drama about the dawn of the personal computer industry dances upon this question.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: As government and internal investigations into the ignition-switch defect have built since the February recall of Cobalts and other General Motors models, Cobalt owners have remained loyal to the brand.
lead_paragraph: As government and internal investigations into the ignition-switch defect have built since the February recall of Cobalts and other General Motors models, Cobalt owners have remained loyal to the brand.

headline: Judge Voids Expansion of Discount Drug Program
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: In passing the Affordable Care Act, Congress expanded a program requiring price limits on certain medications sold at clinics in low-income areas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge has struck down a new rule requiring drug companies to offer certain drugs at discounted prices, saying the Obama administration had no authority to issue the rule.

headline: James and the Heat Coolly Even the N.B.A. Finals
abstract: The air-conditioning system at AT&T Center was working Sunday night as LeBron James scored 35 points to help the Heat even the N.B.A. finals at a game apiece.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — The air-conditioning system at AT&T Center was in working order Sunday night, and so was LeBron James.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 4
abstract: Who is the oldest player in the World Cup? The youngest? Which team is the most homegrown? FIFA’s breakdown of World Cup rosters by the numbers answers these questions, and more.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday June 9, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 9, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “It’s impossible to understand what it is to move when you have nothing. To risk everything — losing your bed, your sense of community — for an uncertain benefit? There’s no way you want to risk that.”

headline: World’s Oldest Man, Though Only Briefly, Dies at 111 in New York
abstract: Alexander Imich, who held the title of world’s oldest man, was born in 1903 before the flight of the Wright Brothers.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Imich, a Polish-born psychic researcher who was certified the oldest man on earth, died Sunday morning at a senior residence in Manhattan. He had turned 111 on Feb. 4.

headline: Not the Movies, but Real Theater
abstract: Viewers who were paying close attention to the Tony Awards could occasionally not help but acknowledge that performing live theater is hard work in a way that making movies is not.
lead_paragraph: “You’re asking people to care about something that may not affect their lives, may not even affect their children’s lives,” Anderson Cooper said, introducing the CBS broadcast of the Tony Awards on Sunday night.

(ABC) HILLARY CLINTON: PUBLIC AND PRIVATE — ONE ON ONE WITH DIANE SAWYER In an interview at her home in Washington, Mrs. Clinton (above right with Ms. Sawyer) discusses her new book, “Hard Choices,” as well as the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the aftermath of the concussion she sustained in 2012 and whether she will release her medical records if she runs for president in 2016.

headline: Steve Coburn’s Proposal Aside, Belmont Field Is Traditionally Small
keywords: ['Belmont Stakes', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Horse Racing', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)']
abstract: Steve Coburn spoke out in favor of limiting the race to horses that had run the first two legs of the Triple Crown, but that would change the dynamics of the entire series, making it much easier to complete the trifecta.
lead_paragraph: California Chrome headed back to California after Saturday’s Belmont Stakes, in which he failed to become the first Triple Crown winner since 1978, but the debate about the format of the three-race series continued.

headline: In Communist Party Parlance, Adultery Has Many Names
abstract: China’s top antigraft body actually used the Chinese word for adultery last week while announcing the expulsion of a party member, rather than oft-used euphemisms like “moral corruption.”
lead_paragraph: The Communist Party regularly employs a variety of muffled euphemisms for sexual misdeeds: moral corruption, dissolute lifestyle and the like. But in a rare display of lucidity, China’s top antigraft body actually used the Chinese word for adultery — tongjian (通奸) — last week while announcing the expulsion of a party member.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Morning Views
lead_paragraph: The New York Times editorial board supports a settlement in a lawsuit between the Justice Department and the State of Ohio over care in juvenile correctional facilities. “Ohio will sharply reduce and eventually end solitary confinement,” the board writes, citing statistics indicating higher likelihood of mental problems and suicidal behavior in youngsters forced to endure it. “The Justice Department’s settlement with Ohio puts states on notice that solitary policies need to change. If adopted nationally, the principles in that settlement would go a long way toward humanizing juvenile detention.”

headline: Golf’s Mona Lisa Got a Buzzcut
abstract: The world’s best golfers will compete for the U.S. Open at Pinehurst. The resort’s landmark course recently got a makeover, and its new look is anything but manicured and green.
lead_paragraph: The world’s best golfers will compete for the U.S. Open at Pinehurst. The resort’s landmark course recently got a makeover, and its new look is anything but manicured and green.

headline: Lloyds Sets Price Range for TSB Unit Below Book Value
abstract: The pricing at 2.20 pounds to 2.90 pounds wasn’t a surprise as the white-hot market for initial public offerings in London has appeared to cool somewhat in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Lloyds Banking Group announced on Monday the price range for the initial public offering of its TSB Banking Group unit, one that is below what analysts think is the book value of the business.

abstract: The deal is expected to increase the hedge fund manager’s presence in the United States and boost its fund of funds business, FRM, through new product offerings.

headline: Cinven to Buy Spanish Fiber Optic Network Operator
abstract: The European private equity firm is set to pay about $697 million for Gas Natural Fenosa Telecomunicaciones, which provides high-speed transmission services to telecom operators in Spain and Central and South America.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The European private equity firm Cinven said Monday that it had agreed to pay 510 million euros, or about $696.8 million, for Gas Natural Fenosa’s fiber optic network operator in Spain and Latin America.

headline: China Accuses Vietnam of Ramming Ships to Stop Rig
abstract: China says that Vietnamese ships have rammed Chinese vessels 1,416 times since a dispute over a Chinese oil rig in the South China Sea flared up in May.
lead_paragraph: China says that Vietnamese ships have rammed Chinese vessels 1,416 times since a dispute over a Chinese oil rig in the South China Sea flared up in May and that Vietnam has used “frogmen” to attempt to disrupt China’s controversial exploratory drilling operations.

headline: Photographing a ‘Difficult Love’ in South Africa
keywords: ['Constitutions', 'Hate Crimes', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Photography', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Transgender and Transsexual']
abstract: Zanele Muholi has been an activist using photography to champion the rights of black lesbians and transgender people in South Africa.
lead_paragraph: I first encountered the South African photographer Zanele Muholi two winters ago in her native country. I was so shy and in awe of her work that I half-hoped she wouldn’t remember that last encounter. As the foremost chronicler of black lesbians and transgender people in South Africa, Ms. Muholi is an artist and activist, advocating for rights for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people on a continent where they are under attack.

headline: What Are Your Experiences With Internet-Based Urban Legends?
abstract: How do scary stories and urban legends find audiences online?
lead_paragraph: Do you know any scary or strange stories that are presented on the Internet as true? Do you believe the stories are real or made-up?

abstract: Sam Borden, European sports correspondent for The Times, wrote this week’s cover story on the U.S. national soccer team’s German coach, Jürgen Klinsmann.
lead_paragraph: Sam Borden, European sports correspondent for The Times, wrote this week’s cover story about the German coach of the U.S. men’s national soccer team, Jürgen Klinsmann.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today: Ain’t No Sunshine
abstract: What you need to know for Monday: A whole week of clouds, a new fire commissioner, and the world’s oldest man dies on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: Good dreary Monday morning to you.

headline: Daily Report: Businesses Struggle to Obtain Insurance Against Cyberattacks
abstract: More businesses are buying policies, but losses are difficult to quantify because attackers are constantly getting more advanced.
lead_paragraph: Julia Roberts’s smile is insured. So are Heidi Klum’s legs, Daniel Craig’s body and Jennifer Lopez’s derrière. But the fastest-growing niche in the industry today is cyberinsurance, Nicole Perlroth and Elizabeth A. Harris report.

headline: Assault on Pakistan Airport Signals Taliban’s Reach and Resilience
abstract: A deadly assault on an airport in Karachi showed how, despite the Pakistani Taliban’s challenges and deepening divisions, their reach has extended into Pakistan’s biggest city.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Only a week ago, the Pakistani Taliban appeared to be on the ropes. Violent rivalries had split the insurgency in two. Peace talks with the government had collapsed. Military jets had pounded militant hide-outs in the tribal belt.

headline: Kabul’s City on the Hill
abstract: A mountain neighborhood of the Afghan capital is a microcosm of a country divided, by ethnicity and status.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Just south of the city center is the most famous of Kabul’s many dun-colored mountains. It is called TV Hill, after the telecom and broadcast antennas that crowd its peak like needles in a pincushion. One of the most visible signs of the Western presence in Afghanistan, it is hailed as a symbol of post-Taliban progress.

headline: The Challenges of Enforcing Customer Service Policies
abstract: The challenges become even greater when Western companies try to introduce established customer-service procedures into their Chinese operations.
lead_paragraph: A gate agent stopped me recently as I was boarding a flight to Dallas. After inspecting my carry-on bag, she asked me if it would fit.

headline: How to Pay for Only the Health Care You Want
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Plans could compete based on the types of treatments they cover, which would give consumers a far clearer choice than they have now.
lead_paragraph: One reason health insurance is expensive is that most plans cover just about every medical technology — not just the ones that work, or the ones that are worth the price. This not only drives up costs, but also forces many Americans into purchasing coverage for therapies they may not value. But there’s no reason things couldn’t be different, and better for consumers.

headline: Minimum Wage: Who Makes It?
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Education (K-12)', 'Income Tax', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Most workers who earn the minimum wage are older than they used to be and more educated.
lead_paragraph: Minimum-wage increases could appear on the ballot in as many as 34 states this year. President Obama has also proposed increasing the federal minimum wage to $10.10, from $7.25. Who makes the minimum wage, and who would be affected by any of the proposed increases?

headline: Prison for 5 in Murder of Journalist
abstract: The sentences were the toughest punishment to date in the long-running investigation into Anna Politkovskaya’s death, but it is still unclear who paid for and ordered the killing.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Moscow’s highest criminal court on Monday sentenced five men to prison, including two to life sentences, for the 2006 murder of the investigative journalist Anna Politkovskaya, but left unsolved the question of who ordered the killing, the highest-profile attack on a Russian journalist of the last decade.

headline: Europe’s Age of Diminished Expectations
abstract: This you call recovery?
lead_paragraph: Joe Weisenthal informs us that Spanish bond yields are now about the same as US yields. This is telling us two things, one good, one bad. The good news is that investors no longer have much fear of a euro crackup any time soon. The bad news is that they expect Europe to remain depressed for a long time.

headline: Chinese Ex-General Warns U.S. Over Magazine Article
abstract: Retired Lt. Gen. Wang Hongguang, in the populist Chinese newspaper Global Times, takes issue with “Five American Weapons of War China Should Fear.”
lead_paragraph: “A reminder to the Americans puffed up with pride and arrogance, making threatening gestures: Do not be ultimately defeated by our lethal trump weapon in your absent-mindedness.”

headline: Morning Agenda: Tyson’s Winning Bid for Hillshire
abstract: Hillshire Brands is expected to declare Tyson Foods the victor of a bidding war. | Uber attains an eye-popping valuation. | Insider trading may be a game for risk takers. | A hedge fund manager must remove his goats from Detroit before a Monday deadline.
lead_paragraph: TYSON SAID TO WIN BATTLE FOR HILLSHIRE  |  It appears that Tyson Foods has emerged victorious in the battle for Hillshire Brands, the maker of Ball Park hot dogs and Jimmy Dean sausages, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. Hillshire, which is also home to its namesake lunch meats, is expected to declare Tyson the winner of a bidding war, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday. The decision will conclude a two-week contest between Tyson and Pilgrim’s Pride, both giants in the poultry industry.

headline: Meanwhile, On the Health Front
abstract: The disaster that wasn’t.
lead_paragraph: You still encounter people claiming that Obamacare has been a disaster, that more people have lost insurance than gained it, etc., etc. But the reality is that it has already made a big dent in the number of uninsured; and the quality of insurance has gone up, too, because canceled policies were canceled because they offered little real protection.

headline: Merck Bids $3.8 Billion for an Edge in Hepatitis
abstract: Merck will pay $24.50 a share in cash, or about $3.85 billion, for the biotechnology company Idenix in an effort to bolster its arsenal of potential drugs in the hotly competitive hepatitis C area.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:32 p.m. | Merck will buy the biotechnology company Idenix Pharmaceuticals for $3.85 billion in an effort to bolster its arsenal of potential drugs in the competitive arena of hepatitis C treatments, the companies announced on Monday.

headline: Disappointed Immigration Applicants Sue Canada
abstract: More than 1,400 Chinese plaintiffs have filed a lawsuit against the Canadian immigration authorities after Canada announced it was canceling its immigrant investor program along with tens of thousands of outstanding applications.
lead_paragraph: Lili Feng and her husband first drew up the plan for their family’s future in March 2010. Their goal, like that of thousands of other wealthy Chinese, was to move via the investor immigration program to Canada, which they believed offered the best combination of public safety and education for their three daughters.

lead_paragraph: Paris is for lovers and New York for dreamers, but when you’re a classy canine accustomed to life’s finer things, getting there can be for the dogs.

headline: From DigiFest to the Tonys, Fashion’s Major Missed Opportunities
abstract: Doesn’t anyone want to dress New York’s theater royalty, or tap social media’s celebrities to influence their fans’ future retail choices?
lead_paragraph: For an industry that has made something of an art out of leveraging events — from the World Cup to the Super Bowl, the Oscars to Cannes — this weekend was, it seems to me, a shocking lost opportunity for fashion. The industry missed out on both DigiFest NYC, haven of all things young and up-and-coming, and the Tony Awards, the ultimate high-culture draw. In both cases, it was a striking, and arguably shortsighted, absence.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott

lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

lead_paragraph: Lee Allan joined Gage, Minneapolis, as the agency’s design director. She succeeds Kenny Friedman, who left to join Flor, Chicago, as executive creative director. Ms. Allan had most recently been creative director at Go East Design, St. Paul.

headline: Q. and A.: Yang Yong on Documenting the Damage to China’s Rivers
abstract: A geologist who is documenting the degradation of China’s waterways discusses what he has learned and how rapid development affects people living along these waterways.
lead_paragraph: As a geologist for a state-owned company, Yang Yong saw firsthand both the beauty of China’s rivers and the damage done to them by the country’s rapid development. In 1992, he set out to document the degradation of China’s waterways on his own, and has since widely explored rivers across China, particularly in the south and west of the country. His photographs of the Jinsha River, the Yangtze River’s upper reach, which flows through Qinghai, Sichuan and Yunnan Provinces, show vividly how that critical waterway has been harmed by the development of mining and hydropower. In an interview, he discussed what led him to this line of research, what his exploration of China’s rivers has revealed and how rapid development affects people living along these waterways.

headline: A Remark in France Is Assailed as Racist
abstract: Activists pledged to file a criminal complaint against Jean-Marie Le Pen of the National Front after he used an apparently anti-Semitic pun about ovens to dismiss critics.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Activists vowed on Monday to file a criminal complaint against the founder of the far-right National Front, Jean-Marie Le Pen, after he used an apparently anti-Semitic pun about ovens to dismiss one of his Jewish critics.

headline: No Alarm Before Waters Rose, Say Survivors of Dam Flood

lead_paragraph: On Sunday evening, two busloads of engineering students on a field trip to the hilly northern state of Himachal Pradesh stopped on the national highway between the towns of Shimla and Manali, struck by the beauty of the Beas River, nestled between the hills.

lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — At 5 a.m. five days a week, 15 traditional Indian wrestlers, known as pehlwan, meet at Mahatma Phule Akhara, one of the largest gyms dedicated to the sport left in Mumbai.

lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning from a cloudy Washington.

headline: Foreign Mergers Expand Ranks at Big Law Firms
abstract: The number of lawyers at the country’s largest law firms rose 3.9 percent last year, but the increase was largely because of mergers with foreign firms, not domestic hiring, according to a new survey from The National Law Journal.
lead_paragraph: The number of lawyers at the country’s largest law firms rose last year, but the increase was largely because of mergers with foreign firms, not domestic hiring, according to a new survey from The National Law Journal.

headline: Family Dollar Adopts Plan to Keep Carl Icahn at Bay
abstract: After Mr. Icahn disclosed a 9.39 percent stake in the retail chain on Friday, Family Dollar Stores announced on Monday that it had adopted a one-year shareholder rights plan, also known as a poison pill.
lead_paragraph: Family Dollar Stores has battened down the hatches days after the activist investor Carl C. Icahn declared the discount chain his latest target.

headline: Understanding Ed O’Bannon’s Suit Against the N.C.A.A.
abstract: The former U.C.L.A. basketball star Ed O’Bannon’s antitrust lawsuit against the N.C.A.A. went to trial on Monday, exploring the question of compensation for college athletes.
lead_paragraph: In the court of public opinion, the N.C.A.A. has been on trial for quite some time now.

headline: Analog Devices to Buy Smaller Chip Maker for $2.45 Billion
abstract: The larger chip maker, which supplies technology for cars, wind turbines, medical devices, video surveillance and smartphones, is acquiring Hittite Microwave.
lead_paragraph: Analog Devices, a chip maker that supplies technology for cars, wind turbines, medical devices, video surveillance and smartphones, has agreed to buy the Hittite Microwave Corporation, a smaller rival, for about $2.45 billion in cash.

headline: Ad Age Campaign Offers a Look at Roads Not Taken
abstract: A lighthearted glimpse at industry leaders in jobs they might be in if they hadn’t read Advertising Age.
lead_paragraph: A leading advertising trade publication is promoting itself by enlisting some well-known industry executives to suggest the rewards of readership.

headline: The Life-Hack Bias
abstract: Life hacking is popular enough now to inspire mockery, but allegedly offbeat tips for career success may also reveal entrenched inequalities, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: Life hacking — the practice of optimizing one’s home, time and behavior for maximum efficiency — has been a topic of popular discussion for long enough that it now inspires mockery. Witness a recent LinkedIn article that advocates (facetiously, one assumes) the “interesting lifehack” of using a wooden spoon to block areas of one’s computer screen from view. “While it is too early to talk about the long-term effects of the spoon,” writes Joachim Bauernberger, it is “bound to disrupt our relationship with technology as we know it.”

headline: The Nuts and Bolts of Automotive Photography
abstract: René Staud, a successful automotive photographer, offers a peek behind the polished images that show up in sales brochures and promotional material.
lead_paragraph: Photographs of cars are easy to take for granted. Every time a new model comes out, it is accompanied by a bombardment of images not unlike the wartime dumping of propaganda leaflets. They’re everywhere.

headline: 15 Crazy Facts About BuzzFeed That Will Totally Blow Your Mind
abstract: A listicle about the viral clearing house for cat pics and other click bait. With GIFs!
lead_paragraph: T’s culture issue looks at the numbers behind Jonah Peretti’s empire of cat pics and other click bait. Here, some of the highlights — presented, naturally, in the style of BuzzFeed.

headline: By the Numbers | Thanks for Sharing
abstract: Trolling BuzzFeed’s cats-and-click-bait empire.
lead_paragraph: Even if you’ve never taken its “Which Disney Princess Are You?” quiz or scanned a listicle like “21 Smells ’90s Girls Will Never Forget,” you are likely aware that BuzzFeed is the mother lode of goofy, meme-y click bait. Its nearly 400 daily posts bring in over 130 million unique visitors a month — the kind of traffic coveted by any website, even if the means are often derided. Another enviable asset? BuzzFeed’s $46 million in venture capital. But the eight-year-old site’s founder, the viral-content guru Jonah Peretti, 40, isn’t satisfied with just being the king of workday distractions. With the help of editor in chief Ben Smith, BuzzFeed has been making a play for serious journalism, with political scoops and breaking news stories percolating inside offices named after Internet-famous cats. With its profit margins still a closely guarded secret, it’s hard to know what the payoff will be, but the value is in the clicking.

headline: Lisa Feldman’s Yogurt and White Bean ‘Ranch’ Dressing
abstract: This dressing can be used as a dip for crudités, or on a crisp salad.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Feldman, the director of culinary services atthe schools division of the food services company Sodexo, understands that where there is ranch dressing, there are kids who will eat vegetables. Lisa is working to devise menus for schools that meet or exceed the Department of Agriculture’s Healthier US Schools Challenge requirements. With a deep understanding of the ingredients that school lunch programs have to work with, she developed a white bean and yogurt salad dressing base. The mixture will make a dressing that has much more nutritional value, considerably less sodium, and none of the additives in the long ingredient list on a bottle of commercial ranch dressing.

headline: White Bean and Yogurt Green Goddess
abstract: Fresh tarragon is the key to the flavor of green goddess dressing.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always had a weakness for green goddess dressing. It has that creamy appeal that ranch dressing also has, with the heady flavor and fragrance of fresh tarragon, which is the key to its flavor. The base is modeled on the bean and yogurt salad dressing base that the Sodexo chef Lisa Feldman has introduced to school lunch programs. Serve it as a dip with spring vegetables like artichokes and asparagus or with crispy salads.

headline: Yogurt and Bean Dressing With Thai Flavors
abstract: Sriracha sauce, lately popular with chefs, adds spice and pungency to this dressing.
lead_paragraph: This version of Lisa Feldman’s yogurt and bean dressing is based on her slightly sweet Thai ginger dressing. Sriracha sauce, I’ve noticed, has become the go-to condiment for many chefs. It contributes just enough spice and pungency to the mix (you can add more if you want more heat). I like to serve this with grains, and as a dip or a dressing for crispy salads.

headline: Yogurt and Bean Dressing With Cilantro and Lime
abstract: This is a pale speckled-green dressing, slightly zingy.
lead_paragraph: One of my favorite variations on Lisa Feldman’s bean and yogurt dressing base is her cilantro-lime dressing. Blend cilantro into just about any dressing, purée, sauce or soup, and I’ll be there with a spoon. I use a little more cilantro and lime juice than Lisa calls for, to achieve a pale speckled-green mixture that is slightly zingy; add a small green chile if you want a bit more spice.

headline: Bean and Yogurt Caesar Salad Dressing
abstract: Don’t like a raw egg in your Caesar, but want it creamy? The bean and yogurt base is the solution.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Feldman’s bean and yogurt base is a great solution for a creamy Caesar salad dressing if you don’t like the idea of using a raw egg. Parmesan is added to the mix, and I also use an anchovy fillet, which you can omit if you wish. But the anchovy and the Parmesan are what make this resemble a Caesar dressing.

headline: Time Inc. Stock Falls in Its Debut
abstract: The magazine company was spun off from Time Warner, which gained on Wall Street on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Shares of Time Inc., the magazine company that began trading Monday after being spun off from Time Warner, got off to a rough start, falling nearly 7 percent before recovering somewhat.

headline: Outsmarting Breast Cancer With Evolving Therapies
abstract: Changes in the treatment of breast cancer have amounted to a revolution in patient care.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few decades, changes in the treatment of breast cancer amount to a revolution in patient care. And it’s not over yet. There was a time when the standard approach was a radical mastectomy, which involved removal of not just the breast, but all the lymph nodes in the armpit and underlying muscles in the chest wall. This approach has been replaced by less extensive surgery that, through decades of clinical trials, has proved to be equally effective at treating patients, as well as safer and less disfiguring. Even simple mastectomies, in which most nodes and the muscles were left intact, have become far less common. Dr. J. Dirk Iglehart, director of the Susan F. Smith Center for Women’s Cancers at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, estimated that he now performs a tenth of the number of mastectomies than when he entered the field in the 1970s.

headline: Food Curated | The Mandarin’s Tea Room
abstract: At the Mandarin’s Tea Room, Timothy Hsu walks tea novices through the ancient Chinese art of tea appreciation.
lead_paragraph: At the Mandarin’s Tea Room, Timothy Hsu walks tea novices through the ancient Chinese art of tea appreciation.

headline: The Mandarin’s Tea Room
abstract: Timothy Hsu, the founder of this underground tearoom in SoHo, introduces guests to real tea leaves.
lead_paragraph: Liza de Guia is a video journalist whose blog, Food. Curated., profiles people who produce interesting food in New York and beyond.

headline: Photographing a ‘Difficult Love’ in South Africa
abstract: Zanele Muholi has been an activist using photography to champion the rights of black lesbians and transgender people in South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Zanele Muholi has been an activist using photography to champion the rights of black lesbians and transgender people in South Africa.

headline: What a Merged Sprint and T-Mobile Would Look Like
abstract: Antitrust regulators in Washington will have to assess whether a combined wireless company would be good for consumers.
lead_paragraph: With Sprint and T-Mobile having agreed in principle on the terms of a deal that would see the third- and fourth-largest wireless carriers in the United States join forces, eyes are already turning to Washington, where regulators will have to assess whether a combined company would be good for consumers.

headline: Today in Small Business: Should Your Data Be in the Cloud?
abstract: Credit is expanding. What start-ups need to know about the I.R.S. Are venture capitalists an endangered species?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: James Reigns, Despite Unrelenting Siege
abstract: James’s defection from Cleveland can no longer explain why fans continue to assail him, often beyond reason. Is there something deeper in play?
lead_paragraph: It was a good day to be king, from a sun-drenched clay court at Roland Garros in Paris to a restoratively air-conditioned hard court in San Antonio. About 11 hours apart, Rafael Nadal and LeBron James demonstrated why they are the ruling monarchs of their time and possibly all time.

headline: Ping-Pong Redux
abstract: Try your hand at this ping-pong scoring puzzle by Dan Bennett.
lead_paragraph: Our challenge this week was proposed by Dan Bennett and Avery Pickford, who teach math at The Nueva School near San Francisco. Dan Bennett came up with the idea way back when he was a grade school student, and both Mr. Bennett and Mr. Pickford worked on developing it further for use in their classrooms.

headline: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria Declares ‘General Amnesty’ for Prisoners
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Terrorism', 'Detainees']
abstract: A decree from Syrian leader granted amnesty for all crimes except “acts of terrorism,” raising hopes among Syrians with relatives in detention.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria issued a decree on Monday granting “a general amnesty” for all crimes except “acts of terrorism,” Syrian state television reported, raising tentative hopes among Syrians with relatives in detention.

headline: Russians Find Few Barriers to Joining Ukraine Battle
abstract: A border that was already considered porous at best does little to stop a flow of men, war matériel and contraband.
lead_paragraph: ROSTOV-ON-DON, Russia — It was at a barbecue outside a city in southern Russia, this Russian war veteran recalled, that he and some friends met an envoy for the separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine. They were fighting for their families, the envoy said, against the “neo-Nazis and ultranationalists” who had seized power in Kiev in a February coup.

headline: California Chrome’s Co-Owner Apologizes for His Outbursts
abstract: Steve Coburn returned to ABC’s “Good Morning America” on Monday to apologize for remarks that diminished the achievement of Tonalist, the Belmont Stakes winner.
lead_paragraph: Two days after a nationally televised outburst about how fresh horses had deprived horse racing of a Triple Crown champion, Steve Coburn, a co-owner of California Chrome, apologized to those affiliated with the Belmont Stakes winner, Tonalist, and to the horse racing world.

headline: Brazil on Edge as World Cup Exposes Rifts
abstract: While some Brazilians are excited that their country is hosting the World Cup, others resent the event’s ballooning costs and a sluggish post-boom economy.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s list of feats since ending authoritarian rule in the 1980s is as long as it is varied, including antipoverty programs pulling millions into the middle class, the democratic election of presidents who suffered indignities under the dictatorship and the surging growth of tropical agriculture to help feed the world.

headline: Bang on a Can Teams Up With the Jewish Museum
abstract: The new-music collective Bang on a Can will present concerts linked to exhibitions at the Jewish Museum.
lead_paragraph: The new-music collective Bang on a Can will begin a yearlong relationship with the Jewish Museum, the museum announced Monday, and neither institution is wasting time getting started.The first concert is a free performance on Tuesday by the Asphalt Orchestra, Bang on a Can’s idiosyncratic marching band, as part of the Museum Mile Festival. The performance, outside the Jewish Museum on Fifth Avenue at 92nd Street, begins at 6 p.m.

headline: Laundry App Start-Up Gets New Financing
abstract: The venture capital firm Canaan Partners led a $10.5 million round in Washio, which makes an app for on-demand laundry and dry cleaning services.
lead_paragraph: The venture capital firm Canaan Partners has led a $10.5 million round in Washio, which makes an app for on-demand laundry and dry cleaning services, both companies said on Monday.

headline: How G.M.’s Lawyers Failed in Their Duties
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Legal Profession', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: G.M.’s lawyers were squarely at the center of the ineptitude for letting problems with the faulty ignition fester for years, Peter J. Henning writes in White Collar Watch.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the savings and loan scandal, Judge Stanley Sporkin asked how a once-prominent financial institution could engage in a pattern of misconduct. “Where were the professionals when these clearly improper transactions were being consummated?” he asked.

headline: Image of the Day: June 9
abstract: A man taking a bath at a railway station in Jammu, Jammu and Kashmir, as a heat wave swept across northern India.

headline: Talk of a Kinks Reunion Heats Up
abstract: The Davies brothers are discussing joint projects, apparently including an album and a tour, but the prospect is still tentative.
lead_paragraph: The signals are mixed, but talk of a Kinks reunion, first hinted at in the British press in December, heated up over the weekend when Ray Davies, the group’s singer and principal songwriter, told The Sunday Times of London that he had been discussing the possibility with his brother, Dave Davies. “I met Dave only last week to talk about getting back together again,” he told the paper. Although the two generally composed separately during the Kinks’ heyday, Ray Davies said that he would like to write some new songs with his brother.

headline: Video of Mass Sexual Assault Taints Egypt Inauguration
abstract: A grainy video of a crowd of men assaulting a woman that circulated on the Internet presented the new Egyptian president with an immediate test on assault and harassment of women.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A video showing a mass sexual assault on a nearly naked woman in the midst of inaugural celebrations for Egypt’s new president is testing his pledge to curb an epidemic of such attacks, with captured scenes of a police officer with a gun in his hand struggling against a crowd of men to extricate the victim.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Recap: The Battle at Castle Black
abstract: On Sunday, the long-anticipated clash came to pass in “The Watchers on the Wall.”
lead_paragraph: Here be spoilers … and the world’s softest anvil.

headline: Entertainment | The Dreamer
abstract: Richard Linklater had an idea to make a film about boyhood. All it would take was 12 years and a whole lot of thought about the meaning of time.
lead_paragraph: Richard Linklater had an idea to make a film about boyhood. All it would take was 12 years and a whole lot of thought about the meaning of time.

headline: N.C.A.A. Settles One Video Game Suit for $20 Million as a Second Begins
abstract: As the Ed O’Bannon case began on Monday, the N.C.A.A. settled another suit involving the use of college athletes’ likenesses in video games.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The N.C.A.A. has reached a settlement to pay $20 million to current and former college athletes who sued over the use of their likenesses in video games, the league said Monday. The announcement came as a higher-profile video game lawsuit, filed by the former U.C.L.A. basketball star Ed O’Bannon, began in federal court here.

headline: Detroit Automakers Pledge $26 Million to Help Save City’s Art
abstract: Ford, General Motors and Chrysler committed to donating a combined $26 million to help save the city’s art collection, part of a “grand bargain” to ease pension cuts for city retirees.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Detroit Institute of Arts announced Monday that the nation’s three major automakers would donate a combined $26 million to help save the city’s art collection, bringing the city a step closer to completing a deal aimed at coming out of bankruptcy by fall.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Ricciardo Breaks Through in Formula One
abstract: Daniel Ricciardo won the Canadian Grand Prix for his first Formula One victory; Ed Carpenter held off Will Power to take the IndyCar event at the Texas Motor Speedway.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Ricciardo scored his first career victory in Formula One, passing Nico Rosberg with three laps to go in the Canadian Grand Prix in Montreal on Sunday. Ricciardo’s win was also the first this season for the Red Bull Infiniti team. His teammate, Sebastian Vettel, the defending series champion, collected third place behind Rosberg.

headline: Audit Shows Extensive Medical Delays for Tens of Thousands of Veterans
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Hospitals', 'Falsification of Data', 'Doctors']
abstract: More than 57,000 patients have been waiting more than three months for medical appointments at V.A. facilities, and nearly 64,000 others have been in the system for a decade but have still not been seen by doctors.
lead_paragraph: More than 57,000 patients have been waiting more than three months for medical appointments at hospitals and clinics run by the Department of Veterans Affairs, and nearly 64,000 others have been enrolled in the system for a decade but have still not been seen by doctors despite their requests, according to a nationwide audit released Monday.

headline: Greece Replaces Finance Minister in Cabinet Shuffle
abstract: The new finance minister, Gikas Hardouvelis, a professor and former government adviser, will try to enact a tough economic reform program imposed by Greece’s international creditors.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Prime Minister Antonis Samaras of Greece on Monday replaced his finance minister as part of a sweeping government shuffle intended to re-energize his coalition after its weak performance in European Parliament elections last month.

headline: How Black Turnout Could Decide Senate Control
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections']
abstract: An increase in the black share of the electorate isn’t the likeliest outcome, but it has happened before.
lead_paragraph: Black voters will play an outsize role in this year’s fight for control of the Senate. Mississippi, Louisiana and Georgia are the three states where African-Americans represent the largest share of the population, and North Carolina isn’t too far behind, at seventh on the list.

headline: Listen Up | Sofia Coppola’s Music Man Strikes Out on his Own
abstract: Brian Reitzell — the force behind many of the film world’s most innovative soundtracks and scores — premieres his first-ever solo album, “Auto Music,” streaming here exclusively for T.
lead_paragraph: “That’s the ‘Blade Runner synth,'” Brian Reitzell notes, pointing to the hulking ’70s-era Yamaha CS-80 keyboard in a corner of his L.A. recording studio. “And this is the ‘Terry Riley organ,'” he continues, brushing the keys on another vintage Yamaha, the YC-45-D, before moving on to a sleek ’80s-era PPG Wave 2.2. “I remember being 12 years old and playing a chord on this at Guitar Center in San Francisco, and feeling like I was being transported to heaven on Mars,” he says. These three machines are but a few of the vintage instruments crammed into the room where Reitzell – one of today’s pre-eminent film and TV soundtrack composers and music supervisors – creates his evocative scores. “This is only a fraction of the things that I have,” Reitzell adds. “And there’s nothing in here that’s new!”

headline: Driver Charged in Crash Involving Tracy Morgan Had Not Slept in 24 Hours, Prosecutors Say
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Sleep', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue']
abstract: In a statement issued on Monday, a Walmart spokeswoman emphasized that the company believed their driver “was operating within the federal hours of service regulations.”
lead_paragraph: The Walmart driver whose truck collided with a van carrying the comedian Tracy Morgan and other performers had not slept for more than 24 hours before the crash, New Jersey prosecutors said on Monday.

headline: Merger Market Shows Signs of Froth
abstract: Drug and food deals are being done at huge premiums. And still shareholders are bidding up the shares of buyers. They may regret it, contend Robert Cyran and Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The merger market is showing symptoms of overheating. Global deal volume is up sharply this year – up 63 percent according to Bernstein research and 71 percent by Thomson Reuters’ tally. Monday’s announcements, meanwhile, hint at “toppiness.”

headline: Bobby Jindal’s Bergdahl Questions, Answered
abstract: “Do you think it makes sense for the president of the United States to be negotiating with terrorists?” he asked.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana, one of a long list of Republican politicians who yearn for national office and who grab the national spotlight by pandering to the far right, received applause from fellow Republicans on Friday by attacking President Obama over the decision to trade five Taliban prisoners for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl.

headline: How Audra McDonald Won Six Tony Awards
abstract: Reading The New York Times’s reviews of Ms. McDonald, who has won a Tony in each of the four performing categories.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, Audra McDonald won her sixth Tony Award for acting, more than any other performer. Her achievement is all the more remarkable in that she has worked in just nine Broadway productions since she first appeared in “The Secret Garden” two decades ago.

headline: With ‘Stay Lit,’ Writers Persevere in a Hostile World
abstract: In a time when the writing life feels more precarious than ever, just sticking with it is becoming its own art form, writes ANNA NORTH.
lead_paragraph: Writing is scary. It is especially scary now, as advances shrink, publishers fight with Amazon, and the death of the novel is forecast with ever-increasing frequency. It’s a time when it would make a lot of sense to quit — and a time when simply not quitting is becoming its own art form.

headline: Antigovernment Obsession Preceded Las Vegas Shootings
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Attacks on Police', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Amanda and Jerad Miller made sure their cats were cared for, and then headed off to start an antigovernment revolution. The two died after shooting to death three people in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Before 6 on Sunday morning, just hours before they killed two police officers and a civilian in a display of antigovernment violence, Jerad and Amanda Miller left their two beloved cats with Kelley Fielder, the next-door neighbor with whom they had been staying. Ms. Miller, 22, promised to return later. Mr. Miller, 31, did not. He gave Ms. Fielder a tearful hug, and said, “I got to do what I got to do.”

headline: Russia and Ukraine Meet on Natural Gas Pricing Dispute
abstract: Talks are intended to push the two sides to reach an agreement on costs and to end concerns about cutoffs of natural gas to the European Union.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Russian and Ukrainian officials failed to reach a solution early Tuesday to a dispute over energy that has exacerbated tensions and led to concerns about cutoffs of natural gas to the European Union.

headline: 1972 Grateful Dead Film to Be Screened in Theaters
abstract: Footage from a German television performance will be shown at theaters around the country in July.
lead_paragraph: This year’s installment of an annual Meet-Up event for fans of the Grateful Dead will be a big-screen showing of a rare television recording the group made during its European tour in the spring of 1972. Fathom Events and Rhino Entertainment will present “Grateful Dead Meet-Up at the Movies: Beat Club 4/21/72” at more than 360 movie theaters around the country on July 17.

headline: Raw Food Families Provoke Powerful Reactions. Why?
abstract: Families who feed their children a raw diet consisting solely of fresh fruits, vegetables, seeds, nuts, and sprouted grains feel judged for their choices.
lead_paragraph: In this era of organic, farm-to-table eating, it’s not surprising that raw food diets — that is, meals consisting solely of fresh fruits, vegetables, seeds, nuts and sprouted grains — would gain an ardent following among some families. I wrote about this trend, and children who subsist on entirely raw fare, in Growing Up on Raw Foods for the Well.

headline: Using iPhoto’s Contact Sheet Feature to Save Paper
abstract: Plus, making movies with Microsoft products.
lead_paragraph: Q. In iPhoto ’11 on OS X Mavericks, is there a way to print certain pictures in an album with their names and dates showing and have it print several photos per page, to save paper?

headline: Malnutrition: Starving Children Lack Crucial Gut Bacteria
abstract: Even when fed nutritious food, malnourished children in Bangladesh were not able to acquire the beneficial bacteria, and remained stunted, a study found.
lead_paragraph: When children are starving, the bacteria that live in their intestines may determine whether they can be saved, scientists working in Bangladesh are reporting. And they say it may become imperative to find a way to give children bacteria as well as food.

headline: Christie’s Chief of Staff Says He Knew Nothing About Idea to Close Lanes to Bridge
abstract: In testimony, Kevin O’Dowd said he had believed the assurances of his deputy, Bridget Anne Kelly, that she was not involved in the closing of lanes to the George Washington Bridge.
lead_paragraph: The chief of staff for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey testified on Monday that he had no knowledge in September of the decision to close several traffic lanes to the George Washington Bridge.

headline: Catfish Whiskers, pH Detectors, Help Track Prey
abstract: Japanese sea catfish are able to detect minute changes in seawater acidity, helping them find their favored food.
lead_paragraph: Japanese sea catfish have an unusual advantage when hunting in pitch-dark waters, a new study reports: Their whiskers can detect minute changes in the water’s acidity.

headline: Corruption Claims Cast Cloud on Qatar’s World Cup Bid
abstract: FIFA was expected to complete a review of whether Qatar’s successful 2022 World Cup bid was awarded honestly, after complaints led by the British.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — As far as the soccer-mad rulers of this wealthy emirate are concerned, the British are just being sore losers and bad sports with all their complaints about corruption, slave labor, an epidemic of worker deaths and, let’s not forget, the extreme heat associated with Qatar’s successful 2022 World Cup bid.

headline: Remixing the Two Dots Soundtrack
abstract: The makers of the Two Dots game have invited members of the public to remix its theme song.
lead_paragraph: The makers of the Two Dots game have invited members of the public to remix its theme song.

headline: The Male Disappearing Act
abstract: How three generations of women are surviving long after the men they married have left town.
lead_paragraph: “My husband disappeared 18 days ago.”

keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Assaults', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'News and News Media']

lead_paragraph: Lawyers and the family of Anna Politkovskaya reacted to the court sentencing of five men convicted of killing the Russian journalist in 2006.

headline: Do-Nothing Congress? These Members Did Something (Annual Reports)
abstract: The annual report, a familiar product for corporations and nonprofits, is starting to find favor among members of Congress.
lead_paragraph: Public approval of Congress has fallen to record lows. Members have introduced little legislation and passed even less. But a small but growing number of lawmakers have taken to explaining to constituents, in great detail, that they have indeed been doing something.

headline: The Vulnerable Democratic Coalition
keywords: ['Iran-Contra Affair', 'Minimum Wage', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An expanded take on why the party needs Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Responding to my Sunday column, which compared the Democratic Party’s diverse presidential-level majority to fin-de-siecle Austria-Hungary and cast Hillary Clinton as the lone political figure capable of playing Emperor Franz Josef and holding the fractious imperium together, Jonathan Chait tweeted that the argument “needed 3000 words to be remotely persuasive.” Consider this post, then, an attempt to add some of the missing words, with a focus on the Democratic coalition’s potential 2016 weaknesses more than Hillary Clinton’s unique role within the party (which I’ll mention below, but think is mostly self-evident).

headline: Rosetta Getty’s Art-Inspired Sophomore Collection
abstract: The designer shares behind-the-scenes shots of the making of her Resort 2015 look book at the Pollock-Krasner House and Studio in the Hamptons.
lead_paragraph: Today, Rosetta Getty will present her sophomore collection to a host of fashion editors at the Chelsea Arts Tower in Manhattan. It’s fitting that the designer chose the art gallery condominium to set the scene for her resort 2015 outing: this season, like last, she sourced inspiration from one artist and one artistic muse. The personal style of Betty Parsons — the gallerist, artist and proponent of the Abstract Expressionist movement — infuses the set of sensible and effortless separates. And the palette of Jackson Pollock — specifically, his “Mural” painting, originally commissioned by Peggy Guggenheim in 1943 — informed Getty’s mostly chartreuse, black and white color choices for the season. Even Pollock’s relaxed, fluid brush strokes come into play in the L.A.-based designer’s laid-back silhouettes.

headline: Next-Best Thing to Living Next Door to Your Idol
abstract: For some, buying a burial space near the final resting place of a person they admire is a different kind of hero worship, and puts a new twist on the real estate cliché “location, location, location.”
lead_paragraph: During a break in a concert in the Bronx, Victor Goines, a jazz saxophonist and clarinetist, realized that he wanted to spend more time in that very place — a lot more time. Being there would put him close to people he idolized, like Duke Ellington, so he decided to spend $25,000 to buy the land behind the stage.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | June 3-June 9, 2014
abstract: How many of these news stories did you follow this week? How well can you do against others taking the quiz? Test yourself and see.
lead_paragraph: How many of the news stories below did you follow this week? How well can you do against others taking the quiz?

headline: Back Home, Rangers Seem Lost
abstract: The fans were expectant of victory at the start of what Coach Alain Vigneault called the biggest hockey game in New York in 20 years, but the Rangers were dominated by the Los Angeles Kings.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers played their first home game in the Stanley Cup finals in two decades, but the magic of 1994 did not fill Madison Square Garden on Monday night. Mark Messier sent encouraging words before the game, but there was no Messier on the ice, no Mike Richter in the nets, no Brian Leetch bursting down the ice on a rush.

lead_paragraph: Can viral media success be engineered? Good question.

lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Trauma patients arriving at an emergency room here after sustaining a gunshot or knife wound may find themselves enrolled in a startling medical experiment.

headline: A Possible Way to Save a Disappearing Leonardo
abstract: A technique for tracking paper degradation may help preserve a vanishing portrait from the 1500s.
lead_paragraph: A new technique for tracking paper degradation could help save a fading Leonardo da Vinci masterpiece from the early 1500s.

headline: Spiders’ Webs Hum With Information
abstract: Spider silks can vibrate along a wide range of frequencies, conveying crucial information about prey.
lead_paragraph: Like strings on a guitar, spider silks can vibrate along a wide range of frequencies, transmitting information about prey, other spiders and even the condition of the web itself, researchers say.

headline: Best Selling Science Books
abstract: Titles, fundamentally based on the sciences, as selected by the science editors from all adult nonfiction books reported to The New York Times for the month.
