headline: Riddle by Riddle, a Murder Confession Unspools
abstract: In “The Antiquarian,” the narrator’s best friend, confined to a psychiatric ward after the murder of his fiancée, admits to the deed yet drops hints that the truth might be more complex.
lead_paragraph: The news from college friends tends to be the stuff of weddings, children and jobs. In “The Antiquarian,” the delightfully macabre first novel by the Peruvian writer Gustavo Faverón Patriau, the narrator, Gustavo, receives a rather more alarming update: His closest friend from his university days, Daniel, has murdered his fiancée, Juliana, by stabbing her 36 times, attempting to burn her body and leaving her in the trunk of his car while trying to kill himself with a gunshot to the head. He fails and lands in a psychiatric ward.

headline: Proposal to Split Netflix’s Chairman and C.E.O. Roles Fails
abstract: Investors in Netflix voted down a proposal to split the two roles on Monday, with a preliminary tally showing double the amount of opposition to the idea this year from last year.
lead_paragraph: New York City Comptroller Scott M. Stringer had hoped that huge support for a proposal last year to split Netflix‘s chairman and chief executive roles would have carried over to this year’s shareholder election.

headline: Making the Best Iced Latte
abstract: The secret to the iced latte served at Go Get Em Tiger and G&B Coffee in Los Angeles, one of the finest coffee drinks in the country: homemade almond-macadamia milk.
lead_paragraph: The secret to the iced latte served at Go Get Em Tiger and G&B Coffee in Los Angeles, one of the finest coffee drinks in the country: homemade almond-macadamia milk.

headline: 6 Innovative Iced Coffees
abstract: A handful of some of America’s most inventive, refreshing and delicious cold coffees.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s the heat, but coffee professionals who never put sugar in their espresso and believe milk is for cereal will loosen up when it comes to summer drinks. Here, in no particular order, are six iced coffees (actually, five iced coffees and one from a chilled keg) that are inventive, refreshing and delicious.

headline: The Best Iced Latte in America?
abstract: This exquisite latte from Los Angeles is just one of the nation’s creative new versions of a summer staple.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — If coffee were a religion, Charles Babinski and Kyle Glanville would be two of its high priests.

headline: Ask Well: Do Monogamous Women Still Need a Pap Smear?
abstract: Most cases of cervical cancer are linked with the sexually transmitted HPV virus. So why are monogamous women who test negative for HPV still given pap smears?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: American Held in North Korea Described as Family Man
abstract: A statement distributed by the lawyer for the American, Jeffrey Edward Fowle, was his family’s first comment on the detention, first reported on Friday.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio municipal worker seized by the authorities in North Korea while he was visiting on a tourist visa last month was described by his lawyer on Monday as an avid traveler, devoted husband and father to three young children, who was anxiously missed by his family.

headline: At E3 Gaming Convention, Microsoft Shifts Emphasis of Xbox One Console to Games
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)', 'PlayStation 4 (Video Game System)']
abstract: The company is selling a less expensive console and creating new games to increase sales, which trail those of Sony’s PlayStation 4.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The latest video game consoles can play Internet radio, Netflix movies and YouTube video clips. But Sony and Microsoft, gearing up for a blistering battle in retail stores this holiday season, are reassuring consumers that their consoles are very much about games, too.

headline: G.M. Suits Will Proceed as One Case in New York

abstract: The consolidation of more than 80 lawsuits against General Motors into a single proceeding in Manhattan represents a small but meaningful victory for the automaker.

lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The man from the goal-line-technology company left no margin for error, which was probably a good thing given his line of work.

headline: Revolving Doors at Hospitals
abstract: Hospitals face mounting pressure to reduce readmission rates, but many factors, including the support available at home, can upend the best of efforts.
lead_paragraph: Everyone on the ward fell hard for the patient in the room at the end of the hall. Her roommate was loud, demanding and a complete nuisance — nobody spent more time in that part of the room than was absolutely necessary. But the gently smiling, impeccably mannered little 90-year-old, admitted to the window bed with a touch of pneumonia, was a big favorite.

headline: Leaving Searchlight Behind, Reid Is Moving to Las Vegas
abstract: Senator Harry Reid sold his home in Searchlight to Nevada Mining and Milling and is moving to Las Vegas to be closer to his children and grandchildren.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Searchlight, Nev., has been synonymous with Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic leader whose birthplace has fueled scores of elegiac floor speeches, campaign events and even a book, “The Camp That Didn’t Fail,” a history of the tiny mining town where he was raised.

headline: Cocktail Culture | One Negroni for Every Month of the Year
abstract: In Portland, Ore., the restaurant Nostrana hosts its fourth annual Negroni Social, complete with 12 recipes concocted by leading lady chefs like Nancy Silverton, recent winner of the most prestigious James Beard award.
lead_paragraph: For the fourth annual Negroni Social at the Rooster Bar at the rustic Italian restaurant Nostrana in Portland, Ore., the chef Cathy Whims recruited 11 of her female chef friends to contribute riffs on the quintessentially Italian cocktail. “I don’t know a chef that doesn’t adore a perfect Negroni,” explained Whims about her decision to recruit talent from the kitchen side of the house to dream up cocktail recipes. “As an aperitivo, the Negroni opens up your palate, kick-starts your digestion and prepares you for the meal ahead of you. It actually makes you think about all the flavors your are experiencing, and I think that’s part of why it lends itself to being so relevant to chefs developing their own versions.”

In Albany in 2009, for example, a politician now on trial for bribery (Malcolm Smith) was briefly deposed as Senate president by two other senators who were later convicted of crimes (Hiram Monserrate and Pedro Espada Jr.) as party control of the chamber hung in the balance.

lead_paragraph: Mobile phone games have come a long way since the late 1990s. Back then, the No.1 game — and maybe the only game on a device — was the ultrabasic monochrome maze puzzle, Snake.

abstract: This past weekend, a particularly busy day in sports news made producing the section a bit of a nightmare.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Hoffman has designed Times sports pages since 2004. Here, he talks about the unique challenge of producing the Sunday section, using this past weekend’s as an example.Deadlines were blown, tempers flared and compromises were made.

headline: A Reporter Fits Cancer Into Her Busy Schedule
abstract: In “Chasing Life,” a new series on ABC Family, Italia Ricci plays a young reporter who learns she has leukemia while covering a story.
lead_paragraph: Purveyors of pop culture have a way of discovering a subject simultaneously. This is apparently the moment for the realization that young people can get cancer just like older ones. The top film at the box office over the weekend was “The Fault in Our Stars,” a weeper about two teenagers with cancer, and on Tuesday night ABC Family introduces “Chasing Life.”

lead_paragraph: The emotional weather is as volatile as the changeable skies in “When January Feels Like Summer,” an engaging, buoyantly acted romantic comedy by Cori Thomas at Ensemble Studio Theater. In Ms. Thomas’s sweet-tempered play, the lives of a handful of problem-plagued New Yorkers intersect in surprising but satisfying ways, leading to unexpected alliances.

lead_paragraph: AKOL, CAMBODIA — As the sun rises on Tonle Sap Lake, fishermen head out from floating villages like this one, past half-submerged mangroves and flooded shrub land, to check their nets, much as they have for centuries.

abstract: The Tonle Sap, one of the world’s most productive freshwater ecosystems, is in trouble. A group of researchers is working with local fishermen to figure out how to save it.

headline: GoDaddy to Tap Public Markets With I.P.O.

headline: A Boy and Girl Meet Face to Face, Even When They’re Not in the Same Room
abstract: “Blink,” written by Phil Porter, finds two characters in a story of love in the age of indirect, device-assisted communication.
lead_paragraph: “Blink” is everything you want in a relationship play: funny, painful, affecting. This is all the more remarkable when you consider that its two characters, young social misfits named Sophie (Lizzy Watts) and Jonah (Thomas Pickles), rarely address each other. It’s a risky mode of storytelling, but the playwright, Phil Porter, makes it pay off beautifully.

headline: Seeing Obstacle-Filled Path to Mars
abstract: A review of the human spaceflight program found no viable strategy and too little funding to get astronauts on Mars by the 2030s as President Obama pledged they would.
lead_paragraph: Since the triumph of the moon landings more than four decades ago, presidents have made grand pronouncements about the next adventure for NASA astronauts, one that would culminate with humans on Mars. But each time, those ambitions faded, unfulfilled.

headline: The Governors Ball Music Festival 2014
abstract: New York’s music-loving finest descended upon Randall’s Island for three days of shows and nonstop people-watching opportunities.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Governors Ball photo diary of Aurelie Pellissier.

headline: Taking Her Tony Home
abstract: Jessie Mueller came to New York with fears that she would never get desirable roles again, but she made a splash in “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical” and won a Tony.
lead_paragraph: Jessie Mueller never expected to outgrow the Chicago theater scene. She grew up in a family of actors in Evanston, Ill., and loved nothing more than watching her parents dress up for local awards banquets when they were nominees. She went on to win acclaim there for roles in “Carousel” and “She Loves Me,” once even borrowing a dress for a prize ceremony that her mother had worn years earlier.

headline: A Festival With a New York Heart
abstract: This year’s Governors Ball was about hometown New York City pride, but also about guitar heat versus electronic cool, strong female songwriters and the many ways to make people dance.
lead_paragraph: Every well-planned festival holds a skein of tangled story lines. This year’s Governors Ball — the fourth annual event, presented Friday through Sunday with 68 acts on four stages on Randalls Island — was, first of all, about hometown New York City pride. It had a headlining set on Sunday by Vampire Weekend and a much-anticipated, fully rewarding set on Saturday by the Strokes, as well as a lineup dotted with other New York City bands, notably a recharged TV on the Radio.

lead_paragraph: Plastic first became widespread in the mid-20th century. Since then, about six billion tons have been manufactured. Much of that has ended up as trash, and nobody knows what will become of it.

He has gone so far as to underscore the importance of his “inner circle,” although it might make more sense to refer to his inner triangle.

Defending your unit has been shown to exceed a willingness to die for family, cause or country, and even the fear of capture. Yet unit cohesion in battle is a tricky thing to measure, let alone compare.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — After months of cleaning and painstaking scientific investigation, art specialists in Britain have apparently concluded a decadeslong debate over the authenticity of a self-portrait by Rembrandt, saying on Tuesday that it was genuine.

headline: Facts Are Murky on Location of Dead Babies in Ireland
abstract: A historian stands by her conclusion that 796 Irish children who died at a home for unwed mothers in Tuam are in a mass grave, but some of her ideas are being challenged.
lead_paragraph: TUAM, Ireland — That 796 children, mainly babies, died at St. Mary’s Mother and Baby Home between 1925 and its closing in 1961 is not disputed. A local historian, Catherine Corless, says she researched the death certificates. What troubled her was that she could find burial records for only one child and wanted a plaque to commemorate the lives of the others.

headline: More Airports Adopt Free Wi-Fi
abstract: Of the nation’s 30 busiest airports, 12 offer all-free Internet, while a dozen others opt for a plan with some free access.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Steve Parker, sitting in the atrium at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport last week, was about to dig into his bag for a hot spot device when he noticed a poster nearby.

headline: Controlling the Narrative
abstract: Writing can be an artificial arena where we mash the world into a shape we can stand to look at.
lead_paragraph: I used to be a polemicist. I was an editorial cartoonist, and wrote what I called “artist’s statements” to accompany my cartoons each week, which over the two terms of the George W. Bush administration lengthened and sharpened from rants into something more like essays. I became practiced at using language as a weapon. My role models were hilarious, elegant and brutal humorists from Mark Twain and H.L. Mencken through Hunter S. Thompson and Matt Taibbi, who raised American invective to an art form. This is a fine and honorable tradition when practiced with a certain amour-propre and panache, but in the last couple of decades it’s become our dominant mode of public discourse, degraded by hacks and amateurs who ape its cruelty but are rhetorically illiterate and tone-deaf to humor. They’re just parroting talking points with profanity.

lead_paragraph: CÓRDOBA, Spain — The Mosque-Cathedral of Córdoba, considered one of the world’s architectural wonders, is often portrayed as a symbol of coexistence between Muslims and Catholics.

headline: Introduced to Monty Python, on the Concorde
abstract: A lawyer working in London and New York was a regular on the supersonic jet, where noise and discomfort were offset by elegant, entertaining seatmates.
lead_paragraph: MY parents made the mistake of getting me a Eurail pass when I was 19 years old. I haven’t stopped traveling since. I’ve been flying for work for about 40 years. I’m an attorney, specializing in protecting trademarks and designs and ideas. That means I have to meet with my clients face to face.

headline: Competition Is Stiff to Manage Tech Billions
abstract: Wealthy entrepreneurs represent a potential gold mine for financial advisers.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft went public in 1986, its chief executive and largest shareholder, Bill Gates, wound up with a broker at Goldman Sachs, the Wall Street firm that had led the company’s initial public offering.

headline: North Korea: U.N. Attracts Threats for Plan to Monitor Human Rights
abstract: North Korea threatened “ruthless punishment” against South Korea for playing host to a United Nations office that will monitor the human rights situation in the North.
lead_paragraph: North Korea on Monday threatened “ruthless punishment” against South Korea for playing host to a United Nations office that will monitor the human rights situation in the North. In May, South Korea accepted a request from the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights to open a field office in Seoul. On Monday, North Korea said that raising a “racket” over a “nonexistent human rights issue” was a politically motivated campaign to defame its government. It said the United Nations office and its staff would “not be excepted from being targets” of its punishment. In March, a panel of United Nations investigators published a report documenting what it called systematic and widespread human rights violations against political prisoners and others in the North. The United Nations has said it hopes that a field office in South Korea, where a large number of North Korean refugees have settled, will aid its investigation of human rights abuses in the North.

headline: Making Holidays of Brazil’s World Cup Games
keywords: ['World Cup 2014 (Soccer)', 'Soccer', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Holidays and Special Occasions']
abstract: In Brazil, the soccer-obsessed country hosting the World Cup, game days for the home team will not be national holidays, but they will probably seem as if they are.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — To work or not to work? Regardless of where anyone here stands on the logic of Brazil’s spending billions of dollars in preparation for hosting this year’s World Cup, the question as opening day approaches is hugely pertinent.

headline: Israel: General Has Hopeful View About the Nuclear Talks With Iran
abstract: As Iran and the United States began talks in Geneva to advance negotiations over Iran’s disputed nuclear activities, a top Israeli intelligence official said he believed that Iran was serious about ensuring the success of the negotiations.
lead_paragraph: As Iran and the United States began two days of talks in Geneva on Monday to advance the stalled negotiations over Iran’s disputed nuclear activities, a top Israeli intelligence official said he believed that Iran was serious about ensuring the success of the negotiations. The assessment of the official, Brig. Gen. Itai Brun, the chief analyst of Israeli military intelligence, appeared more optimistic than that of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, who has persistently warned against what he has called a bad nuclear deal with Iran. General Brun, speaking at Israel’s annual Herzliya Conference on policy and security, said that Iran was abiding by a temporary agreement with major powers, and that economic pressures on the country “are leading it toward a dialogue, which we view as serious, on a permanent agreement.” The temporary accord expires on July 20, and diplomats have said significant obstacles remain in achieving a permanent agreement to guarantee that Iran’s nuclear program is for peaceful purposes.

headline: T.S.A. Charts a Rise in Guns at Checkpoints
abstract: This year, the Transportation Security Administration has found 892 guns at airport checkpoints, 19 percent more than in the same period of 2013.
lead_paragraph: LOTS more of our fellow travelers are packing for the airport, so to speak. So far this year (as of the end of last week), the Transportation Security Administration has found 892 guns in passengers’ carry-on bags at security checkpoints. That’s a 19 percent increase from the comparable period of last year, when the total was 750 guns.

headline: Argentina: Vice President in Court for Questioning in Corruption Case
abstract: A simmering political scandal took a dramatic turn when a judge forced Vice President Amado Boudou to appear in a Buenos Aires court to answer questions.
lead_paragraph: A simmering political scandal took a dramatic turn on Monday when a judge forced Vice President Amado Boudou to appear in a Buenos Aires court to answer questions about whether he had used his influence as economy minister to take ownership of a company that printed the nation’s currency. Mr. Boudou, 51, is accused of using a frontman to purchase shares in the printing company, which was awarded a government contract and later nationalized. He has denied the allegations and has accused news organizations of conspiring against him. The judge, Ariel Lijo, rejected Mr. Boudou’s call for the session to be broadcast live on television. The judge is expected to announce his decision later this month on whether to file criminal charges against Mr. Boudou.

headline: Time Warner Said to Seek a Big Stake in Vice Media
abstract: Time Warner and Vice Media are said to be in negotiations that could lead to a $1 billion deal and give Vice a television network.
lead_paragraph: Time Warner is in talks to buy a large stake in Vice Media for as much as $1 billion, a deal that could include providing Vice with the television network HLN, people with knowledge of the negotiations said on Monday.

headline: Pope Francis Meets With Peres and Abbas
abstract: Pope Francis, the Israeli president Shimon Peres and the Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas spoke after a peace prayer meeting in the Vatican gardens.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis, the Israeli president Shimon Peres and the Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas spoke after a peace prayer meeting in the Vatican gardens.

headline: A Museum Devoted to Movies Is Still Writing Its Own Script
abstract: The Academy Museum of Motion Pictures, scheduled to open in 2017, is still figuring out its mission.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the dim light of a gutted department store, through the dust of nearby construction, Kerry Brougher sees a flickering movie future filled with “hundreds of different cinemas.” For tiny screens. Vast ones. Theaters yet to be conceived.

headline: After a Short, Furious Battle, a Rich Offer for Hillshire
abstract: A bidding war for the maker of Jimmy Dean sausages ended in a $7.7 billion offer by Tyson Foods, reflecting a trend of consolidation among food producers.
lead_paragraph: Just over three weeks ago, Hillshire Brands was focusing on shoring up support for its planned takeover of Pinnacle Foods despite vocal shareholder opposition.

headline: Progress on Transgender Rights and Health
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexual', 'Discrimination', 'Medicare', 'Editorials', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Birth Certificates', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Advancements include Medicare covering gender reassignment surgery, an evaluation of the military’s senseless ban on transgender service and Maryland’s law extending civil rights protections.
lead_paragraph: Progress on civil rights typically comes in incremental steps that discard old policies for new approaches advancing fair treatment. The Obama administration recently took such a step by reversing a 1981 policy that excluded gender reassignment surgery from coverage under Medicare.

headline: Mona Freeman, First ‘Miss Subways,’ Dies at 87
abstract: Ms. Freeman was just 14 when she was named Miss Subways, a title bestowed on about 200 young women before the competition was retired 35 years later.
lead_paragraph: Mona Freeman, who had never ridden a subway when she was crowned New York City’s first Miss Subways in 1941 — an appointment that led to a modest career as a film and television actress — died on May 23 at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 87.

headline: Pakistan’s Latest Crisis
abstract: Will the attack over the weekend persuade Pakistan’s government to acknowledge the Taliban’s pernicious threat and confront it in a comprehensive way?
lead_paragraph: In its increasingly violent effort to destroy the Pakistani state, the Pakistani Taliban have attacked, among other targets, army headquarters in Rawalpindi, a naval base in Karachi, an air base in Kamra and an airport in Peshawar. The brazen assault over the weekend on the international airport in Karachi takes the campaign to a new level, striking at the country’s largest city and one of its most important commercial centers. Though militants and gangs operate freely there, Karachi is home to Pakistan’s central bank, a stock exchange and its hopes for desperately needed economic resurgence.

headline: Peres, at 90, Is Ready to Leave the Israeli Presidency, but Not to Retire
abstract: The sole survivor of Israel’s founding generation in public office, Shimon Peres stretched the bounds of a largely ceremonial office.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Reaching the end of a red carpet after landing here for the latest of his more than 60 trips abroad as Israel’s president, Shimon Peres faced the group of journalists awaiting him.

headline: More Voting Games in Ohio
abstract: By cutting back on early voting, the state has taken another egregious step to impose barriers for citizens who tend to vote Democratic.
lead_paragraph: Someday, after they figure out how to appeal to a broader swath of the electorate, Republicans will probably be embarrassed by how much time they have spent making it harder for Americans to vote. For now, though, the beat just goes on. In a misguided effort to hold on to power despite an ever-shrinking base of older white voters, Republican lawmakers around the country continue to impose all sorts of barriers to the ballot box.

headline: Why Uber Might Well Be Worth $18 Billion
abstract: Though some call the taxi app’s valuation of $18.2 billion “insane,” it’s worth doing the basic math and taking a closer look.
lead_paragraph: It was described as “nuts,” “insane” and “idiocy.”

headline: The New Right
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: A new manifesto from a group of reform conservatives is the most coherent and compelling policy agenda the American right has produced this century.
lead_paragraph: Conservatives generally believe that capitalism is a machine that cures itself. Therefore, people on the right have been slow to recognize the deep structural problems that are making life harder in the new economy — that are leading to stagnant social mobility, widening inequality and pervasive insecurity.

headline: Walmart Reorganizes E-commerce Personnel
abstract: The staff changes, including the departure of the president of Walmart.com, come as the company shifts toward a stronger online presence.
lead_paragraph: Walmart announced two high-level changes to its e-commerce team on Monday, as it pushes to ramp up its online business and compete with its archrival Amazon.

headline: Battle Over Fracking Poses Threat to Colorado Democrats
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Referendums', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: An array of ballot proposals would ask Colorado voters to sharply limit energy development, but the Democratic governor and other party leaders are seeking an alternative.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — An impassioned national debate over the oil-production technique known as fracking is edging toward the ballot box in Colorado, opening an election-year rift between moderate, energy-friendly Democrats and environmentalists who want to rein in drilling or give local communities the power to outlaw it altogether.

headline: As World Cup Nears, American ‘Football’ Fans Adapt Foreign Traditions
abstract: Professional soccer is reaching new heights of popularity in the United States, and fans are trying to incorporate foreign traditions without seeming pretentious.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Even if the fans known as the American Outlaws had not been clumped noisily together at one end of the stadium at the United States-Nigeria soccer match here Saturday, they would have been impossible to miss.

headline: The Latest Tea Party Piñata
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: How is it that even a useful, job-creating government agency like the Export-Import Bank is ripe for attacking by the right?
lead_paragraph: About three weeks ago, Representative Jeb Hensarling, a Republican from Texas who is chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, gave a speech to the Heritage Foundation. Hensarling is a Tea Party favorite. His core view is that better government is less government, and that there is nothing government can do that the private sector can’t do better.

headline: Does Soccer Need FIFA?
abstract: How can the world's most popular sport avoid the traps of corruption?

headline: Cup Chase Puts Gaborik Back on the Garden’s Ice
abstract: Marian Gaborik, a man of few words and many goals, is playing in Madison Square Garden for the first time since the Rangers traded him in April 2013.
lead_paragraph: Marian Gaborik is a man of few words and many goals.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 9, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: June 9, 2014

headline: Frick Seeks to Expand Beyond Jewel-Box Spaces
abstract: The Frick Collection will announce on Tuesday plans for a new six-story wing, a project that will require the approval of city landmark officials and is likely to draw scrutiny from some of the museum’s neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Joining a trend toward major expansions, the Frick Collection, known for its intimate, jewel-box galleries, will announce on Tuesday plans for a new six-story wing that will increase its exhibition space, open private upstairs rooms, and offer views of Central Park from a new roof garden on East 70th Street.

headline: In Britain, School Report Cites Division Over Islam
abstract: An inquiry found a culture of “fear and intimidation” of staff members and blamed fundamentalist Islamic school board governors.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A report released on Monday concluded that pressure from fundamentalist Islamic school board governors had created a culture of “fear and intimidation” among senior staff members in a number of British schools said to have been the targets of a campaign to impose Islamist views on parts of the educational system.

headline: Plan to Refill Highway Fund Stokes Conflict in Congress
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Roads and Traffic', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Money to replenish the Highway Trust Fund is also being sought by Finance Committee leaders to help smooth the passage of a broad rewrite of the tax code.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With federal highway funds just weeks from depletion, the struggle to replenish the Highway Trust Fund has linked Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, the majority leader, with one of the Republicans’ brightest stars, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky — and pushed against the bipartisan leadership of the Finance Committee — with the clock ticking.

headline: For Western Oil Companies, Expanding in Russia Is a Dance Around Sanctions
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Shale']
abstract: BP, Exxon Mobil, Shell, Total and other big Western oil companies are striking deals and plowing money into Russia even as more sanctions loom.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Like many chief executives of American companies, Rex W. Tillerson of Exxon Mobil didn’t attend the major business forum in Russia last month, at the urging of White House officials. But the company’s exploration chief, Neil W. Duffin, did.

headline: Stuyvesant Town, Former Middle-Class Bastion, Awaits Mayoral Help
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Stuyvesant Town (NYC)', 'Peter Cooper Village (NYC)', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: For years, tenants in Stuyvesant Town and its cousin, Peter Cooper Village, sat preserved behind a dam of rent regulations. Those days are gone. A sale could come soon.
lead_paragraph: To discover a vaguely affordable apartment in Manhattan is like falling down a fire escape into a bed of clover.

headline: Scant Support for Elite New York High Schools’ Admissions Options
abstract: The bills would allow New York City’s most selective high schools to allow multiple factors in deciding whom to admit, rather than one long test.
lead_paragraph: Civil rights advocates have long complained about the relatively small number of black and Hispanic students in New York City’s most selective high schools. Mayor Bill de Blasio, during his campaign last year, complained about it, too.

headline: Plan B Eased Clippers Deal: Sterling’s Diagnosis
abstract: Rochelle Sterling and her lawyer used a clause in the Clippers trust documents to cut her husband, Donald, out of the deal after doctors found him to be affected by cognitive impairment.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At 7 on a Saturday morning, four weeks after her life had erupted in scandal, Rochelle Sterling was awakened by a ringing phone.

headline: Secretive Classroom Activity
abstract: A punny Tuesday puzzle by Pamela Klawitter.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle by Pamela Klawitter has a theme that originally confused me, but it turned out to be a lot simpler and more elegant in execution than I thought, mainly because I am the queen of overthinking things. Not only that, but Ms. Klawitter’s theme takes advantage of one of the meaner tricks in crossword constructing, which actually made the “Aha!” moment even more fun than usual.

headline: Supreme Court Rules in Favor of Electronics Plant in Poisoned Water Case
keywords: ['Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Statutes of Limitations', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: The decision found that North Carolina landowners who sued CTS Corporation over the poisoning of their drinking water had missed a filing deadline.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Landowners who say a North Carolina electronics plant poisoned their drinking water missed a filing deadline, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday.

headline: Democrats See Winning Issue in Carbon Plan
keywords: ['Coal', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Several Democrats in competitive Senate races have supported an E.P.A. proposal to curb power-plant emissions, citing growing public support for action and perceptions that Republicans are anti-science.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He is a Democrat in a marquee Senate race, pressed by a strong Republican in a state with a challenging political environment. So when a new proposal to limit power plant emissions was seen as posing a threat to allies of the Obama administration, Senator Mark Udall of Colorado acted quickly: He embraced the plan.

headline: Facebook Hires From PayPal to Focus on Messaging
abstract: The company announced that it had hired David Marcus, PayPal’s president, to lead the expansion of messaging products — and eventually, to figure out how to make money from them.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It couldn’t be any plainer if it were in a post by Mark Zuckerberg himself: Facebook, which was built on the idea that people want to share information with dozens of friends and acquaintances, is getting serious about more private communications.

headline: Colleges and Evangelicals Collide on Bias Policy
keywords: ['Evangelical Movement', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Discrimination', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: The Bowdoin Christian Fellowship group will cease to be recognized on campus after refusing to adhere to rules barring discrimination based on a person’s religious beliefs.
lead_paragraph: BRUNSWICK, Me. — For 40 years, evangelicals at Bowdoin College have gathered periodically to study the Bible together, to pray and to worship. They are a tiny minority on the liberal arts college campus, but they have been a part of the school’s community, gathering in the chapel, the dining center, the dorms.

headline: For Virginia’s Don Beyer, Obama Is Still a Positive
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: In an election season when many congressional Democrats are avoiding President Obama like a quirky relative at a family reunion, Don Beyer has cast himself as an unrepentant advocate.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — In an election season when many congressional Democrats are avoiding President Obama as if he were a quirky relative at a family reunion, Don Beyer has cast himself as an unrepentant advocate.

headline: Tapes in State Senator’s Trial Reveal Quid Pro Quo Arrangements
abstract: At Malcolm A. Smith’s bribery and wire fraud trial, jurors hear recordings of the state senator and others discussing incentives to support his mayoral campaign.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. — State Senator Malcolm A. Smith had a Plan A and a Plan B.

headline: Selling With Nostalgia, Post-Boomer
abstract: With boomers no longer in the 18-to-49 demographic group, nostalgia ads are harking back to the 1970s, ’80s and ’90s.
lead_paragraph: NOSTALGIA, according to the saying, isn’t what it used to be. That is increasingly true on Madison Avenue, as advertisers — seeking to evoke warm feelings and fond memories in consumers — adjust the timelines for how far they look back.

headline: Mickelson Takes Heart in a Change of Course
abstract: Phil Mickelson has run into many problems at the United States Open, but a change at Pinehurst No. 2 that relies on short game has him optimistic.
lead_paragraph: Two missed eight-foot putts, a drive into the left rough that created a double bogey, a 6-iron plunked into a greenside bunker and three putts from five feet above the cup for a double bogey, another drive off a hospitality tent followed by a 3-iron into a tree branch and a double bogey, two 3-wood tee shots into thick, heavy rough that led to two double bogeys, untimely three-putts and a missed green with a wedge on a 121-yard hole.

headline: The Captain Is in the House, but It’s Not 1994
abstract: Mark Messier, the leader of the last Rangers team to win the Stanley Cup in 1994, was at the Garden for Game 3 on Monday.
lead_paragraph: At the airport gate Monday, there was a man wearing a pilot’s hat and a blue No. 11 Rangers jersey who was boarding passengers and playing air hockey and posing for iPhone photographs, oh, please, just one more. His head was shaved like Mark Messier’s, and he sounded like Mark Messier and he squinted when he smiled just like Mark Messier — wait, it really was him, wasn’t it?

headline: State Senator’s Resignation Deepens Political Turmoil in Virginia
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'State Legislatures', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Questions about Republican influence and the fate of the Virginia state budget and Medicaid expansion surround State Senator Phillip P. Puckett’s sudden resignation.
lead_paragraph: The resignation of a Democratic state senator in Virginia that flipped control of the Senate to Republicans set off charges on Monday of an unseemly deal and threatened Gov. Terry McAuliffe’s chances of expanding Medicaid under the president’s health care law.

headline: Tanaka’s Matchup Against Ex-Teammate Falls Through
abstract: A rainout for the Yankees at Kansas City on Monday means Tanaka will not start as planned Tuesday against Seattle’s Hisashi Iwakuma, because Manager Joe Girardi is pushing his entire rotation back.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Masahiro Tanaka could not have known it when he boarded his flight to Seattle on Monday afternoon: His pitching matchup on Tuesday night with Hisashi Iwakuma, his former teammate with Tohoku Rakuten in Japan’s Pacific League, was not going to happen.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 3
abstract: France has momentum coming off its drubbing of Jamaica in a warmup match, a nice confidence boost after the loss of Franck Ribéry to injury.
lead_paragraph: Momentum is possibly one of the most coveted commodities entering a major tournament like the World Cup — that and a healthy roster.

headline: At Junior’s Site, Bidders See Brooklyn, Too, as a City of Spires
abstract: Brooklyn partisans may someday extol building heights rare even in Manhattan, in the form of a 1,000-foot tower.
lead_paragraph: Strolling the bluffs of Brooklyn Heights in the 1850s, Walt Whitman would gaze out at the metropolis growing across the river.

headline: Border Agency Replaces Head of Internal Affairs
abstract: The agency replaced James F. Tomsheck, citing an effort to strengthen investigations, particularly into episodes involving shootings and other use of force by border agents.
lead_paragraph: The federal Customs and Border Protection agency has replaced its top official in charge of internal affairs, James F. Tomsheck, citing an effort to strengthen investigations, particularly into episodes involving shootings and other use of force by border agents.

headline: Mets’ Murphy Discusses Fatherhood at White House Meeting
abstract: Criticized on sports talk radio for going on paternity leave for the birth of his son, he said it was the right choice and that he had the backing of his team.
lead_paragraph: Mets second baseman Daniel Murphy, who earlier this year was criticized on New York sports talk radio for going on paternity leave, spoke about being a father at the White House on Monday as part of the Working Families Summit.

headline: New Safety Standards Set for Baby Food
keywords: ['Infant Formulas', 'Salmonella (Bacteria)', 'Baby Foods', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration announced Monday that it had set new safety standards for infant formula.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration announced Monday that it had set new safety standards for infant formula. The rules require manufacturers to screen products for salmonella, which can cause fever and diarrhea, and cronobacter, a potentially lethal germ that thrives in very dry places, like powdered milk and baby formula. The F.D.A. said that companies must also test products for nutrient content and demonstrate that they support “normal physical growth.”

headline: Oklahoma: Another Base to House Young Immigrants
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Immigration and health authorities will open a shelter at Fort Sill, an Army base in Lawton, for unaccompanied minors caught crossing the border illegally.
lead_paragraph: Immigration and health authorities will open a shelter at Fort Sill, an Army base in Lawton, for unaccompanied minors caught crossing the southwest border illegally, Obama administration officials said Monday. About 600 youths will be sent there in the coming days, with the number expected to grow to 1,200. About 1,200 minors who were apprehended without parents are in a shelter at Lackland Air Force Base in San Antonio, and 575 are at Naval Base Ventura County near Oxnard, Calif. The authorities also set up temporary holding cells in Nogales, Ariz., to process the youths for deportation proceedings.

headline: Myles J. Ambrose, Nixon Drug Czar, D.E.A. Midwife, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Ambrose was President Richard M. Nixon’s first drug czar, but resigned before he could take the helm of the new government arm he had helped shepherd into being, the Drug Enforcement Administration.
lead_paragraph: Myles J. Ambrose, who was President Richard M. Nixon’s first drug czar, but who resigned before he could take the helm of the new government arm he had helped shepherd into being, the Drug Enforcement Administration, died on June 3 in Leesburg, Va. He was 87.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 10, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 10, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “People are worried about how much has been spent. But once we see the first game, the parties will start.”

headline: Answering Readers’ Questions About Immigration
abstract: New York Times journalists covering immigration are answering readers’ questions about the Obama administration’s plan to cope with a surge of unaccompanied minors crossing the border.
lead_paragraph: As Americans continue to debate border security, deportation policies and the possible path to citizenship for people living in the country illegally, the Obama administration is facing a political crossroads as it tries to cope with an immigration system that is overwhelmed.

headline: USA Hockey Permits Use of Safety Feature Resembling Warning Track
abstract: The Look-Up Line is a 40-inch-wide orange strip around the perimeter of the rink that is designed to reduce paralyzing neck injuries.
lead_paragraph: USA Hockey, the sport’s governing body in the United States, announced Monday that it had permitted use of the Look-Up Line, an orange warning track painted on the ice designed to reduce paralyzing neck injuries that could result from collisions into the boards. However, the measure fell short of mandating its use in American ice rinks.

headline: U.S. Team Hits Practice Field Soon After Touching Down in Brazil
abstract: The Americans are making themselves at home at a São Paulo facility in preparation for their opening match with Ghana.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The United States national team arrived in Brazil early Monday morning, and the players were on the field for their first training session by that afternoon. If that seems like a quick turnaround after a 12-hour, two-leg, overnight travel itinerary that began in Jacksonville, Fla., consider that Tim Howard, the starting goalkeeper, actually was surprised at how long it took for the team to get to work. “With Jurgen, I’m surprised we weren’t out here earlier,” Howard said.

headline: I Am Someone, Look at Me
abstract: Hailed as the 21st century’s answer to Proust for his controversial six-volume autobiographical work, “My Struggle,” Karl Ove Knausgaard responds to his sudden celebrity with this essay on his tortured relationship with fame — its intense lure, its perils and the Scandinavian culture that condemns its pursuit.
lead_paragraph: Hailed as the 21st century’s answer to Proust for his controversial six-volume autobiographical work, “My Struggle,” Karl Ove Knausgaard responds to his sudden celebrity with this essay on his tortured relationship with fame — its intense lure, its perils and the Scandinavian culture that condemns its pursuit. Translated by Ingvild Burkey.

headline: On One Kings Lane, a Trove of Treasures from Venice Curated by Fortuny
abstract: The brothers who run the textile house Fortuny have curated a massive home-accessories sale debuting tomorrow on the flash-sale site.
lead_paragraph: Design enthusiasts who weren’t fortunate enough to visit Venice this week for the opening of the Architecture Biennale (and might be suffering from a touch of Instagram envy), can at least fake the experience via an upcoming sale on One Kings Lane. Mickey and Maury Riad, the two brothers who run the century-old Venetian textile house Fortuny, were invited by the site to shop the town’s various islands to assemble a massive home-accessories sale of over 200 items, which begins tomorrow. A tag sale of the brothers’ own personal collection will also debut on the same day.

headline: Raf & Ruby
abstract: At the top of their creative fields, the fashion designer Raf Simons and the artist Sterling Ruby have succeeded at something almost more elusive and unexpected: a true, collaborative brotherhood.
lead_paragraph: At the top of their creative fields, the fashion designer Raf Simons and the artist Sterling Ruby have succeeded at something almost more elusive and unexpected: a true, collaborative brotherhood.

headline: Google Adds Graffiti to Its Art Portfolio
keywords: ['Art', 'Graffiti', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Vandalism']
abstract: The new Street Art Project includes graffiti and other works from around the globe, including some that no longer exist.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — There’s a portrait of an anonymous Chinese man chiseled into a wall in Shanghai, a colorful mural in Atlanta and black-and-white photographs of eyes that the French artist JR affixed to the houses of a hillside favela in Rio de Janeiro. These are among the images of more than 4,000 works included in a vast new online gallery of street art that Google is unveiling here on Tuesday.

headline: Poll Shows Path to Citizenship Is Favored
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Law and Legislation', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Deportation']
abstract: Pressure is mounting on House Republicans and on President Obama to take action on immigration before the fall elections.
lead_paragraph: While 62 percent of Americans favor a path to citizenship for immigrants living in the United States illegally, Republican voters are sharply split on the issue going into the November elections, according to a nationwide poll published Tuesday by the Public Religion Research Institute and the Brookings Institution, nonpartisan research groups in Washington.

headline: L.A. Kings Led by Top Players Once Again
abstract: The Kings’ Marian Gaborik, who had an up-and-down but largely productive four-season tenure with the Rangers, had an assist in his first return to Madison Square Garden since his trade in 2013.
lead_paragraph: The Garden was ready. The capacity crowd — wearing special blue Stanley Cup finals T-shirts — was loud and prepared for the Rangers’ first home game in the finals since 1994. But the experienced Los Angeles Kings, who had never won a playoff game at Madison Square Garden, spoiled the party.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9:15 A.M. (HBO Signature) CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY (2005) Tim Burton’s sugar rush, based on Roald Dahl’s book, stars Johnny Depp as an oddly sinister candy maker and Freddie Highmore (above, with Mr. Depp, left, and David Kelly) as a boy who wants nothing more than to swim in chocolate. Well, who wouldn’t? Despite burdening Willy Wonka with a psychological back story, “there is simply too much pleasure to be found in Wonka’s world to get too hung up about his relationship with his dad,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The real lesson of ‘Charlie and the Chocolate Factory’ is — or should be — that pleasure and curiosity are their own rewards.”

headline: Taliban Hit Airport Again After Pakistani Airstrikes
abstract: Gunmen attacked Karachi’s airport on Tuesday for the second time this week, and the death toll from the first attack rose to at least 36 as seven additional bodies were found.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Retaliating against a new wave of military airstrikes, Pakistani Taliban gunmen on Tuesday attacked security forces at Karachi’s international airport for the second time this week, underscoring their capacity to create mayhem in the country’s largest city.

headline: China Complains About Plutonium in Japan
abstract: China has complained that Japan has 640 kilograms of plutonium that it has not reported to the International Atomic Energy Agency.
lead_paragraph: China has complained that Japan has 640 kilograms of plutonium that it did not report to the International Atomic Energy Agency.

keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Industrial Espionage', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Delivering his biggest speech on science and technology, President Xi Jinping demands that China master and control the new technologies that, he said, will decide global economic and political winners and losers.
lead_paragraph: Even when President Xi Jinping of China urges his country’s scientists to blaze a trail into the future, he dwells on the defeats and humiliations of the past.
