headline: Euronext Value Could Reach About $2.4 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: The IntercontinentalExchange unit, which operates stock exchanges across Europe, plans to initially list its shares in Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels. It also plans to list in Lisbon later this year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON –IntercontinentalExchange, owner of the New York Stock Exchange, said on Tuesday that it expected the initial public offering of its Euronext unit to value the business at up to 1.75 billion euros, or $2.38 billion.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A Bold Counterpunch Shows Taliban’s Lasting Strength
abstract: How should the Pakistani government deal with the Taliban?
lead_paragraph: In “A Bold Counterpunch Shows Taliban’s Lasting Strength,” Declan Walsh reports on an attack at Pakistan’s largest international airport.

headline: Despite Critics, China Asserts Democratic Progress in Hong Kong
abstract: As tensions mount in Hong Kong, the Chinese government lays out its argument for how Hong Kong has gotten better under its rule.
lead_paragraph: A week after roughly 100,000 people turned out in Hong Kong in a protest directed at China’s Communist leadership, Beijing has issued a ringing defense of its oversight of the territory, crediting the central government with everything from combating the SARS epidemic to promoting democratic reforms and ensuring Hong Kong’s economic success.

headline: ‘Friendly Fire’ Strike Kills 5 Special Operations Soldiers in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Americans and at least one Afghan soldier were killed when a coalition aircraft accidentally struck their position, Afghan and American officials said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Five American Special Operations service members and at least one Afghan soldier were killed when a United States Air Force B-1 bomber unleashed an airstrike on their position in southern Afghanistan, in one of the deadliest instances of friendly fire in more than a decade of war, Afghan and American officials said Tuesday.

headline: Imperial Tobacco Plans I.P.O. of Logista Distribution Unit
abstract: The British company intends to retain a majority stake following the offering, in which a minority of shares held by its Altadis unit would be sold to institutional investors.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British tobacco manufacturer Imperial Tobacco Group said on Tuesday that it planned to spin off its Compañía de Distribución Integral Logista Holdings distribution unit in an initial public offering in Spain.

headline: Does Live Theater Offer Something You Just Can’t Get Watching Movies or TV?
abstract: Do you like going to the theater? When was the last time you saw a play or musical? What did you see, and how was it?
lead_paragraph: Do you ever go to the theater to see live performances? Do you enjoy watching plays or musicals? Have you ever seen a Broadway or Off-Broadway show?

headline: A Photographer’s Summer of Luck in San Francisco
abstract: Fifty years ago, San Francisco was the setting for cultural and political upheaval. And Arthur Tress was the lucky young photographer who captured it.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Tress was one lucky young photographer. Mr. Tress, a 23-year-old New Yorker, happened to visit his sister in San Francisco in the summer of 1964, when big news kept breaking.

headline: High-Profile Conference to Draw Attention to Sexual Violence in War
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The initiative has drawn support from the movie star Angelina Jolie, Secretary of State John Kerry and the British foreign secretary William Hague.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Hollywood star Angelina Jolie and the British foreign secretary, William Hague, opened a high-profile gathering here on Tuesday intended to combat the increasing prevalence of sexual violence in war zones, with Ms. Jolie calling for an end to a “culture of impunity” among perpetrators.

headline: Silicon Valley Tries to Remake the Idea Machine
abstract: Hoping to invent the future, the tech industry is looking to recreate its past.
lead_paragraph: Like any supersecret lab that’s supposedly trying to invent the future, Google X looks rather nondescript from the street. Besides the occasional hot pink driverless car parked out front, the facility is an archipelago of unmarked, low-slung, redbrick buildings, more Sunset Park than Silicon Valley. Inside, however, whiteboards offer clues about what exactly the future — at least as Google sees it — might look like. And while some diagrams — including one with parts labeled “snooze” and “set time” — suggest more mundane inventions, others, like one outlining a “space elevator,” seem a bit more ambitious.

headline: Support for Blind University Aspirant Turns to Censure
abstract: When Li Jinsheng became among the first Chinese blind people to take the regular university entrance examination, he made history. Now he says he failed, and he’s being pilloried.
lead_paragraph: Li Jinsheng, a massage center owner, was among the first blind people to take the “gaokao,” or nationwide university entrance examinations, after the government, in a major turnaround in April, allowed blind people to do so. But Mr. Li says he failed.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today: Head Trip
abstract: What you need to know in New York for Tuesday: a mind-reading bike helmet, murky weather, and a runaway carriage horse.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:19 a.m.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: Taystee Gets Her Moment
abstract: Taystee knows pi to 56 digits, but winning a job? That’s not easy.
lead_paragraph: Season 2, Episode 2: Could it be that we’ve found the most compelling storyline – and it’s not Piper?

headline: In South Carolina, Graham Prevails Without a Runoff
abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, once thought to be among the Republicans most vulnerable to a Tea Party challenge this year, easily dispatched six primary opponents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, once thought to be among the Republican incumbents most vulnerable to a Tea Party challenge this year, easily dispatched six primary opponents on Tuesday, capturing well over 50 percent of the vote and avoiding a runoff.

headline: Finally, a Pollution Index Beijing Can Love
abstract: A new survey seeks to gauge how open officials are about levels of pollution at the sources of the problem.
lead_paragraph: Transparency is a popular catchphrase these days in China, with ordinary people demanding more of it from their officials. In this regard, pollution is one area in which there has been some progress, even if the polluting activities themselves remain a chronic problem across the country.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Important opinions on the Pakistan bombing, protecting journalists, safe roads, Arizona water and Andy Murray’s coach.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times editorial board condemns the “brazen assault” carried out by Taliban militants on the international airport in Karachi, Pakistan, this weekend. “One has to assume the militants will stop at nothing until the state is utterly destabilized and they have taken control,” the board writes, calling on Pakistani political and military leaders to recognize the Taliban threat and quickly devise a strategy to protect the nation’s people. “Time to find a solution is fast running out.”

headline: Daily Report: Report Implicates 2nd Chinese Army Unit in Online Spying
abstract: The report, by CrowdStrike, a security company, ties a hacker group in Shanghai to attacks on governments, contractors and research companies.
lead_paragraph: Just weeks after the Justice Department indicted five members of the Chinese army, accusing them of online attacks on United States corporations, a report released on Monday offers more evidence of the breadth and ambition of China’s campaign to steal trade and military secrets from foreign victims, Nicole Perlroth reports.

headline: Bergdahl Prisoner Swap Stirs Concern
abstract: Two new polls reveal many Americans have concerns about a deal with the Taliban that was done without notifying Congress, as the law requires.
lead_paragraph: Americans have serious misgivings about the prisoner swap that freed Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl from captivity in Afghanistan, and most disapprove of President Obama’s failure to inform Congress ahead of the exchange with the Taliban, according to two new national surveys.

headline: Applying the Lessons of ‘Moneyball’ and ‘Golden Motions’ to Your Business
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Small Business', 'Statistics']
abstract: Studying data on customers, partners, employees and prospects can help businesses find ways to grow smarter, faster and more efficiently.
lead_paragraph: As the founder of a business intelligence software company, it can be hard to explain my job to those outside my industry. Whenever I catch up with friends or family members, I can see the question coming a mile away: “What exactly does your company do again?”

headline: Sunni Militants Drive Iraqi Army Out of Mosul
abstract: Militants spilling over the border from Syria seized control of Iraq’s second-largest city in the most stunning success yet of a rapidly widening insurgency that threatens to drag the region into war.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Sunni militants spilling over the border from Syria on Tuesday seized control of the northern city of Mosul, Iraq’s second largest, in the most stunning success yet in a rapidly widening insurgency that threatens to drag the region into war.

headline: If Robots Drove, How Much Safer Would Roads Be?
keywords: ['Robots and Robotics', 'Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Two studies find that cars that automate some of the riskier aspects of driving have the potential to improve safety as much as seatbelts did.
lead_paragraph: Human error is the culprit in 93 percent of automobile crashes — including the pileup last weekend that left Tracy Morgan in critical condition, caused, prosecutors say, by a truck driver who had been awake for 24 hours.

headline: A Case Study in Lifting College Attendance
abstract: Nearly every qualified high school senior in Delaware is on track to enroll in college. A year ago, almost 20 percent did not.
lead_paragraph: Sydney Nye was a straight-A student with an SAT score high enough to apply to any college in the country. When her senior year of high school in Wilmington, Del., started about nine months ago, she had dreams of becoming a chemical engineer.

headline: Arm Syria’s Opposition
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: American interests demand that we support the moderate fighters against both Assad and the jihadists.
lead_paragraph: Washington — In February, I resigned as the American ambassador to Syria, after 30 years’ foreign service in Africa and the Middle East. As the situation in Syria deteriorated, I found it ever harder to justify our policy. It was time for me to leave.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Closer Look at Uber’s Valuation
abstract: Uber might well be worth its whopping valuation. | Time Warner is said to be seeking a big stake in Vice Media. | How Tyson won a short but furious bidding war for Hillshire. | Wealthy entrepreneurs represent a potential gold mine for financial advisers.
lead_paragraph: A CLOSER LOOK AT UBER’S VALUATION  |  When the car ride service Uber was valued on Friday at $18.2 billion, some called the figure “nuts” and “insane.” After all, it was hard to believe that a four-year-old company that exists on an iPhone could be worth more than longstanding institutions like Alcoa and Tiffany, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. But a look at the basic math suggests that Uber’s valuation might still be too low.

headline: In Our Pages: June 11
keywords: ['Eiffel Tower (Paris)', 'Royal Family', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: the Prince of Wales visited the Eiffel Tower in 1889; The first woman in space had a baby in 1964.
lead_paragraph: 1889: His Royal Highness on High

headline: Intersection | Detroit’s Industrial Chic
abstract: In the historic Eastern Market neighborhood of Detroit, local style is inspired by the industrial surroundings.
lead_paragraph: In the historic Eastern Market neighborhood of Detroit, local style is inspired by the industrial surroundings.

headline: Who Ordered Politkovskaya’s Murder?
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Editorials', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: A few hired hands have been sentenced. The mastermind is still unknown.
lead_paragraph: Almost eight years after the gruesome murder of Anna Politkovskaya, one of Russia’s most respected investigative journalists, Moscow’s highest criminal court has finally sentenced five men to prison, two of them for life. The court ruled Monday that these men were part of a conspiracy to assassinate Ms. Politkovskaya in her apartment block on Oct. 7, 2006. These convictions signal some progress in Russia’s glacial investigations of the murder, but the case is not closed.

headline: In Performance: Tony Award Winners
abstract: Performances by the Tony Award-winning actors Jessie Mueller and James Monroe Iglehart.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night Tony Awards were given to two actors who recently participated in a small concert produced by The New York Times as part of a special Tony Awards edition of the In Performance series.

headline: When Spell-Check Can’t Help
abstract: Here’s the latest batch of sound-alike mix-ups, including a couple I don’t recall seeing before. Add these to your watch list.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the latest batch of sound-alike mix-ups, including a couple I don’t recall seeing before. Add these to your watch list.

headline: New And Not Improved
abstract: Conservatives look for new ideas consistent with old prejudices.
lead_paragraph: OK, we’re obviously in for a lot of breathless hype about the new conservatism, as supposedly exemplified by Room to Grow, which self-consciously lays out what are supposed to be bold new conservative policy ideas. One thing you don’t find amid the hype, however, is much actual description of the new ideas in question. That’s because the ideas don’t bear too much scrutiny.

headline: What’s News in Washington: In Six States, It’s Primary Day
abstract: Six states are holding primary elections, with the most interesting action taking place in South Carolina and Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday morning from Washington. Hillary Rodham Clinton’s book “Hard Choices” comes out today, kicking off her much-anticipated book tour, furthering speculation about her intentions for 2016 and consuming a whole lot of political oxygen. But on the ground it remains midterm season, and it is primary day.

headline: The Release of Bowe Bergdahl
abstract: President Obama makes a controversial prisoner swap.
lead_paragraph: President Obama makes a controversial prisoner swap.

headline: Madame Tussauds Fits Maya Angelou
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A cameraman recalled the chaos at Ms. Angelou’s apartment, especially the glass eyeballs, as a crew from the wax museum measured her for her likeness.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Allergan, Maker of Botox, Rejects Valeant’s $53 Billion Offer
abstract: The latest cash-and-stock bid “substantially undervalues” Allergan and “creates significant risks and uncertainties” for its shareholders, the chief executive said in a letter.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:42 p.m. |

headline: Fashion Awards: Beyond Vogue and Up With Men’s Wear
abstract: A new award for men’s wear designers increases the attention on this booming sector in fashion.
lead_paragraph: For the last few years, Vogue has had something of a lock on the fashion awards market — ever since American Vogue introduced its fashion fund award with the Council of Fashion Designers of America in 2003, which was followed by “Who Is on Next?,” the Italian Vogue/AltaRoma prize established in 2005; the British Vogue and the British Fashion Council designer award in 2008; and the Fashion Design Council of India and Indian Vogue award in 2012. Well, now GQ is getting in on the act.

headline: Who’s Your Mommy? We Don’t Know — Yet
abstract: Although Kelly is carrying their daughter, we won’t know until she arrives who the biological mother is. For now, it’s father’s baby; mother’s maybe.
lead_paragraph: Over a year ago, despite my many doubts, I agreed to become a sperm donor for my good friends, Tori and Kelly. Saying yes, it turns out, was the easy part. It took nearly a year of failed attempts before Kelly conceived. For the round of I.V.F. that finally worked, moreover, both of my friends decided to harvest eggs. The clinic then transferred the two best resulting embryos, one from each woman, to increase Kelly’s odds of conceiving.

headline: Israel Parliament Elects Ex-Speaker as President to Succeed Peres
abstract: The selection of Reuven Rivlin, a veteran Likud Party politician, ends what was seen as an unseemly race for a largely ceremonial post.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli Parliament on Tuesday elected Reuven Rivlin, a veteran Likud Party politician and former minister and Parliament speaker, as the country’s next president, ending what many here described as the most unseemly race in Israel’s history for what is largely a ceremonial post.

headline: The Pundits and the President
abstract: What’s their problem with success?
lead_paragraph: This seems to be the season for centrist Obama-bashing. He’s ineffectual, we’re told, a drag on his party, Democrats are complaining (although none on the record), and so on.

headline: How Has Parenthood Informed Your Writing Life?
abstract: James Parker and Mohsin Hamid discuss how fatherhood has influenced their work.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Mohsin Hamid discuss how fatherhood has influenced their work.

headline: Police Statements Cloud Alleged Rape and Murder Case, Analysts Say
abstract: Police reform advocates have criticized the contradictory police statements about the alleged rape of two cousins in Uttar Pradesh in May.
lead_paragraph: In the span of two weeks, the Indian police have offered different versions of the alleged rape and murder of two cousins in Uttar Pradesh State who were found hanging from a tree on May 28, in an event that invited widespread censure of the state government and a rebuke from the United Nations in India, as well as a statement from its secretary general, Ban Ki-moon.

headline: Despite Clash in Ukraine, Cease-Fire Talks Advance
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The foreign ministers of Russia, Germany and Poland said they were optimistic while President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine proposed setting up a corridor to help people flee the violence.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — The foreign ministers of Russia, Poland and Germany on Tuesday signaled progress toward a cease-fire in Ukraine, even as up to 40 separatists were reported to have been killed in a fierce battle for control of an airport in the east of the country.

headline: The Rabbi Cardinal O’Connor Never Knew: His Grandfather
abstract: The sister of Cardinal John Joseph O’Connor, the Catholic Church’s top official in New York for 16 years, made a surprising discovery: Their mother had converted from Judaism to Catholicism.
lead_paragraph: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — In his 16 years as the Catholic Church’s top official in New York, Cardinal John Joseph O’Connor was a staunch friend and defender of the Jewish people.

headline: Bosnia’s Cup Debut Turns Part of St. Louis Into Sarajevo West
abstract: A neighborhood that seems more European than Midwestern is bracing for Bosnia’s first appearance in the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The whiteboard propped on the sidewalk read “Sretno Zmajevi,” or Good Luck Dragons, referring to the nickname for the Bosnian national soccer team. And the message rippled down the street.

headline: Banksy Confesses: He Made the Eavesdropping Mural
abstract: Banksy, in a rare exchange with the public, acknowledges making a mural in a city in England where an intelligence agency has its headquarters.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a rare exchange with the public, the elusive graffiti artist Banksy has acknowledged painting a mural depicting secret agents eavesdropping on a telephone booth, which appeared in April in the city of Cheltenham, where one of Britain’s intelligence agencies has its headquarters.

headline: Walkabout: Transit Strike Threatens to Disrupt World Cup
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Cup Half-Full With the World Cup set to start in São Paulo on Thursday, Brazil is facing the latest in a series of obstacles and frustrations in hosting the games: a transit strike in the city that threatens to disrupt the opening. (BBC)

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Born Alive’
abstract: This poem, by Joanna Gerber, is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest. It comes from a Science article, “Space Ripples Reveal Big Bang’s Smoking Gun.”
lead_paragraph: This poem, by Joanna Gerber, is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest. It comes from a Science article, “Space Ripples Reveal Big Bang’s Smoking Gun.”

headline: In Shareholder Address, G.M. Chief Vows Safety
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Defective Products', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Before a shareholders meeting, Mary T. Barra of General Motors said a compensation expert would determine how many died from the faulty switch.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors’ chief executive, Mary T. Barra, told shareholders on Tuesday that the company was making major changes in its operations in the wake of an internal investigation of its recall of defective small cars.

headline: After 7 Months, British Hacking Case Heads to the Jury
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson — tabloid editors and former lovers — are accused of condoning the intercepting of voice mail messages and other practices.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With one of Britain’s most riveting trials — a seven-month courtroom marathon that exposed the inner workings of the tabloid news media and the personal lives of two friends of the prime minister — nearing its conclusion, the judge gave this reminder to the jury: “No one is so powerful they can ignore the law.”

headline: New Works and Programming by Laurie Anderson to Highlight New York Live Arts Season
abstract: The New York Live Arts season will include 71 performances by more than 22 artists and ensembles.
lead_paragraph: Commissioned works by Kyle Abraham and RoseAnne Spradlin, among others, as well as the third annual Live Ideas mini-festival, to be programmed by the composer Laurie Anderson, are among the highlights of the 2014-15 season at New York Live Arts, the Chelsea dance theater directed by the choreographer Bill T. Jones. The season, which Mr. Jones announced Tuesday, will include 71 performances by more than 22 artists and ensembles, including the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company.

headline: Does Obama’s Unpopularity Matter?
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Unemployment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why Democrats shouldn’t assume that the president’s poll numbers won’t weigh them down in 2016.
lead_paragraph: My last post offered 1400 words in response to a Jonathan Chait tweet; now let me offer a few more in response to his actual rebuttal to my recent column on why the Democrats need Hillary Clinton to hold their presidential majority together. Here, from his latest post, is a two-part argument that I’m overstating the significance of President Obama’s stuck-in-the-40s approval ratings for his party’s fortunes in 2016. First, because of the Republicans:

headline: Chobani’s Science Lesson
abstract: A controversial message on yogurt lids has people talking about anti-science sentiment in America, and the power of social media to change it, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: The Greek yogurt company Chobani raised hackles last week with a message under some of its lids that read, “Nature got us to 100 calories, not scientists. #howmatters.” The company has apologized, but some scientists say the controversy suggests something bigger about anti-science sentiment in America.

headline: Ukrainians Find Jobs and a Slice of Russia in Arctic Norway
abstract: Tumult in Ukraine has ensured that there is no shortage of labor on Spitsbergen, a Norwegian island where a Russian company mines coal and Moscow heavily subsidizes aspects of daily life.
lead_paragraph: BARENTSBURG, Norway — While scientists up here in the high Arctic monitor global warming by studying the movement of polar bears, ice floes and glaciers, Nikolai Mikitenko tracks the meltdown in Ukraine, the land of his birth more than 2,000 miles away, through the migration of desperate coal miners.

headline: Hong Kong Rebel Loses His Trademark Long Hair
abstract: Leung Kwok-hung’s unkempt mane had been a constant in his decade as one of the city’s most animated legislators. That was, until his hair was cut short on Monday.
lead_paragraph: No matter what he did to the laws — making them as a legislator in the somber wooden chamber of Hong Kong’s Legislative Council, or breaking them when he burst into a room to disrupt a public forum — Leung Kwok-hung’s long unkempt hair had been a constant in his decade as one of the city’s most animated legislators. That was, until his hair was cut short on Monday.

headline: In Store | At Rachel Comey’s New SoHo Flagship, Form Follows Fashion
abstract: This Thursday, the downtown designer with a cult following opens the doors to her first brick and mortar outpost, a cheeky yet refined shop located just under her own apartment.
lead_paragraph: It is fitting that Rachel Comey, who hosts intimate dinner parties rather than runway shows during fashion week, has chosen to open her first brick-and-mortar outpost just downstairs from her own SoHo apartment next door. The downtown designer with a cult following has a knack for keeping things personal — and for not taking fashion too seriously. “It’s important for the store to be a tad funny,” she says. Indeed, the buzz surrounding the shop — which her most ardent followers have been hoping and wishing for for the past 13 years — has been on overdrive since Comey released a photo of a cheeky flag, painted with the help of her good friend Leanne Shapton, hanging outside the then-raw space on Crosby Street. It poked fun at the storefront’s mainstream-Manhattan neighbors: SoulCycle, Jamba Juice and Duane Reade.

headline: Rangers Create Bounces; L.A. Kings’ Jonathan Quick Swats Them Away
abstract: With 32 saves, the Kings’ goalie unveiled the wand on Monday night in Game 3 that has been a part of his arsenal in recent seasons.
lead_paragraph: As the puck bounced tantalizingly near what seemed like an open net and a sure chance at a goal in Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals Monday, Rangers forward Mats Zuccarello’s stick took an extra microsecond to make contact with it. He was in perfect position, poised to make all the overwrought pregame buildup seem valid, primed to make Madison Square Garden erupt, ready to determine both teams’ fortunes.

headline: Trial of South Korean Ferry Crew Begins
abstract: Angry relatives of the victims gathered at the courthouse, shouting “Murderer!” as the captain and other senior crew members entered not guilty pleas.
lead_paragraph: GWANGJU, South Korea — The captain and 14 other crew members of the South Korean ferry that sank in April, leaving 304 people dead or missing, went on trial here on Tuesday. The defendants faced the anger of victims’ relatives at the courthouse, where senior crew members denied the homicide charges against them.

headline: Appreciating the Flavors of West Bank
abstract: At a recent dinner at the United States consulate in Jerusalem, a Swiss-born chef was given a challenge of making a menu derived from West Bank food purveyors.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Michael Ratney, the United States consul general here, is a fan of the television show “Chopped,” in which cooks must whip up an appetizer, entrée and dessert from baskets of disparate, often unpalatable, ingredients. So for a dinner party last week, Mr. Ratney gave the consulate’s Swiss-born chef, Ursula Imran al Sous, a challenge: Make a menu out of items from West Bank purveyors that Washington underwrites.

headline: Reporter’s Notebook: Palestinian Feast
abstract: To celebrate the diversity of Palestinian products grown on the West Bank, America’s top diplomat to the region prepared a feast inspired by the “Chopped” television Series.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate the diversity of Palestinian products grown on the West Bank, America’s top diplomat to the region prepared a feast inspired by the “Chopped” television Series.

headline: ‘Baby Got Back’ Story: Sir Mix-a-Lot Was an Early Interactive Success
abstract: “Baby Got Back” took off in part because of an early effort at interactive media.
lead_paragraph: Before Sir Mix-a-Lot broke through to the pop charts in 1992, he’d found some success on the rap charts with his first two albums, “Swass” and “Seminar.” But his label, Def American, struggled to get widespread airplay in promoting his third album, “Mack Daddy.” The first single they released, “One Time’s Got No Case,” went nowhere. Increasing their efforts for the second single, “Baby Got Back,” the label reached out to the Box, a cable network that played music videos based on viewer requests on the telephone. As Sheila Rule wrote in The New York Times:

headline: Children at the Border
abstract: Readers respond to a recent editorial on the surge of young immigrants at the southern border.
lead_paragraph: More than a few online commenters were annoyed, angered or exasperated by an editorial last week, “Children on the Run,” which told of the recent surge of tens of thousands young migrants being caught at the southern border. These children, many of them traveling alone, are straining the Border Patrol’s resources and prompting the Obama administration to take urgent steps to ease what looks to us  like a refugee crisis, but to others like an invasion.

headline: Recording the Polar Bear’s View of its Changing Arctic Environment
abstract: The polar bear’s view of its Arctic domain is captured by a novel camera.
lead_paragraph: I first encountered the wildlife filmmaker Adam Ravetch in 2007 when writing about “Arctic Tale,” a film on polar bears and walruses that he co-directed for National Geographic in 2007 and which meshed fictional storytelling and astonishing imagery.

headline: Incentives and Technology
abstract: Yes, we have choices.
lead_paragraph: The invaluable Mark Thoma leads me to this post attacking what I thought was a totally obvious takedown of Roger Pielke Jr.. In general, reading attacks on oneself should be done in very limited doses, but in this case I learned something — namely, that what I assumed was obvious apparently isn’t to everyone.

headline: Voter Fraud Is Rare, but Myth Is Widespread
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Many people believe voter impersonation and other kinds of election fraud are much more widespread than they really are.
lead_paragraph: Is vote fraud common in American politics? Not according to United States District Judge Lynn Adelman, who examined the evidence from Wisconsin and ruled in late April that “virtually no voter impersonation occurs” in the state and that “no evidence suggests that voter-impersonation fraud will become a problem at any time in the foreseeable future.”

headline: Image of the Day: June 10
abstract: A woman at a protest in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, seeking the whereabouts of her family member who went missing since a separatist rebellion broke out in the state in 1989.

headline: Czech Pawns In a System That Stifled
abstract: “Burning Bush” uses the case of a martyr to help depict life under totalitarianism in Czechoslovakia after the 1968 Soviet invasion.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 20, 1968, Warsaw Pact troops led by the Soviet Union invaded Czechoslovakia, putting a violent end to the reformist socialist experiment known as the Prague Spring. The following winter, a student named Jan Palach set himself on fire in Wenceslas Square, an act of protest that is the starting point of “Burning Bush,” Agnieszka Holland’s thoughtful, gripping, crisply acted new film.

headline: Today in Small Business: Managing People Who Hate Each Other
abstract: The Bodyguard Blanket. Economists predict robust growth. And is Uber undervalued?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Bergdahl Briefing Fails to Allay Senators’ Doubts
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A closed-door briefing by military officials seemed to do little to defuse the festering political controversy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senators emerged Tuesday from a classified, closed-door briefing on the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl seemingly less convinced than ever about the wisdom of swapping five high-level Taliban prisoners for the Army soldier after he spent years in captivity.

headline: Sex in Assisted Living: Intimacy Without Privacy
abstract: Assisted living facilities are just beginning to grapple with the questions raised by intimate relations among residents, including those with cognitive impairment.
lead_paragraph: Trulah Goin Mills had developed dementia and couldn’t be left alone in the house, but when she and her husband, Lewis, moved into an assisted living facility in Boise, Idaho, in 2012, one lifelong quality remained intact.

headline: Euronext’s I.P.O. Will Be a Tough Sell
abstract: Anchor investors have a vested interest in backing Euronext’s planned I.P.O. but some of the group’s target growth goals look to be a stretch, writes Swaha Pattanaik in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Euronext’s initial public offering looks like a tough sell. The firm is seeking a valuation of 1.3 billion euros to 1.8 billion euros when it floats later this month. Anchor investors have a vested interest in backing the issue. But for other buyers, it is a leap of faith.

headline: Gail Collins Responds to Readers: Congress Versus Hobbit
abstract: The Op-Ed columnist answered a few questions posed by commenters about her latest column, Congress Versus Hobbit.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins, Op-Ed columnist, answered a few questions posed by commenters about her latest column, Congress Versus Hobbit.

headline: You Can Skip the Fitting, Mom
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Stone Fox Bride offers erotic, evocative wedding wear for millennial brides.
lead_paragraph: IN THE DECADE-PLUS since the psychologist Barry Schwartz published his oft-cited book “The Paradox of Choice: Why More is Less,” the options available to the American bride have increased beyond measure. She can legally marry another woman in many states. She can skip the whole wedding racket entirely, in protest or preoccupation or boredom, and suffer no social stigma whatsoever. Or — and this is a hedge I have observed among many urban millennials — she can sort of back up slowly, shruggingly, consciously down the aisle: save the blood-diamond money for a down payment on a Clinton Hill condominium; hire friends to do the organic catering; and buy her frock, perhaps in electric-blue, from Etsy or similar.

headline: Commodities Regulator Names New Enforcement Chief
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has hired the former prosecutor and defense lawyer Aitan D. Goelman as head its of enforcement division.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:45 p.m. | Wall Street’s smallest regulator has hired a big-name enforcement director.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Just Jim Dale’
abstract: A scene from the actor’s one-man show, at the Laura Pels Theater, about his varied career in show business.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the actor’s one-man show, at the Laura Pels Theater, about his varied career in show business.

headline: ‘Disgraced’ Will Reach Broadway, Though Without Aasif Mandvi
abstract: Ayad Akhtar’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play will open at the Lyceum Theater on Oct. 23.
lead_paragraph: Ayad Akhtar’s blistering play “Disgraced,” which had a critically acclaimed Off Broadway run in 2012 and won the Pulitzer Prize for drama the next year, will open on Broadway this fall at the Lyceum Theater, one of the lead producers, Matthew Rego, confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Wheelies: The Average Age Edition
abstract: IHS Automotive reports that the average age of autos in the United States is still 11.4 years; Bill Hoglund, a former G.M. executive, dies at 79.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Fans Wait Hours to See Hillary Clinton at Book Signing
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Hundreds of Mrs. Clinton’s fans, eager to see her run for president in 2016, turned out in Manhattan to get their copies of her memoir, “Hard Choices,” signed.
lead_paragraph: Andre Morales, a 36-year-old from Brooklyn, arrived before 3 a.m. Tuesday and planned to ask Hillary Rodham Clinton how it felt to work for President Obama after he had defeated her in the 2008 Democratic primary.

headline: Arms Windfall for Insurgents as Iraq City Falls
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Weapons provided by the United States to help Iraqi forces battle militants are now in the hands of the militants.
lead_paragraph: The insurgent fighters who routed the Iraqi army out of Mosul on Tuesday did not just capture much of Iraq’s second-largest city. They also gained a windfall of arms, munitions and equipment abandoned by the soldiers as they fled — arms that were supplied by the United States and intended to give the troops an edge over the insurgents.

headline: European Antitrust Authorities Contend That ICAP Colluded to Rig Rates
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The top antitrust enforcer for the European Commission says that the British financial firm ICAP colluded to try to fix a benchmark interest rate tied to the yen.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Commission is accusing the British financial firm ICAP of collusion, saying it tried to fix a benchmark interest rate tied to the yen.

headline: Health Officials Call for More Fish in Diets of Children and Pregnant Women
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mercury (Metal)', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Seafood']
abstract: Federal officials on Tuesday announced that women who are pregnant or breast-feeding should eat at least eight ounces of fish per week, but still no more than 12.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials on Tuesday announced that they would recommend for the first time that women who are pregnant or breast-feeding and young children eat a minimum of two servings of low-mercury seafood every week for their health.

headline: City Settles Occupy Protesters’ False-Arrest Lawsuit
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: The city agreed to pay nearly $600,000 to resolve the lawsuit, which accused police officers of falsely arresting people who were walking on a sidewalk in a 2012 demonstration.
lead_paragraph: The City of New York has agreed to pay nearly $600,000 to resolve a lawsuit accusing police officers of falsely arresting Occupy Wall Street participants who were walking on a sidewalk in the East Village on New Year’s Day 2012.

headline: Tracy Morgan’s New Series Is Still a Go Whenever He Recovers, FX Says
abstract: An untitled series was to begin production in August, but the injured comedian is still hospitalized.
lead_paragraph: The FX cable networks affirmed their commitment on Tuesday to the injured comedian Tracy Morgan, saying that a new series announced earlier in the spring to star Mr. Morgan would still be “waiting for him” when he recovers from his injuries.

headline: Markets Are Less Volatile. Should We Worry?
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)']
abstract: Wild swings in the market have become uncommon, signalling there is less fear among investors. That should be good. Unless it’s not.
lead_paragraph: If the stock market was a person, right now it would be a supremely easygoing retiree on the beach in Key West drinking a piña colada. Mr. Market is very, very relaxed.

headline: Judge Rejects Teacher Tenure for California
keywords: ['Tenure', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Education (K-12)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Organized Labor', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The decision handed teachers’ unions a major defeat in a landmark case to overturn laws governing how teachers are hired and fired and is expected to set off similar fights across the nation.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A California judge ruled Tuesday that teacher tenure laws deprived students of their right to an education under the State Constitution and violated their civil rights. The decision hands teachers’ unions a major defeat in a landmark case, one that could radically alter how California teachers are hired and fired and prompt challenges to tenure laws in other states.

headline: Cherche Midi Opens
abstract: Keith McNally’s French comfort zone now includes this restaurant named for a Left Bank street where he once lived.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Turning to National Front, but Keeping a Distance
abstract: Many voters in Bohain-en-Vermandois, a struggling community in the north of France, backed the far-right party in European Parliament elections, but few are ready to herald a switch.
lead_paragraph: BOHAIN-EN-VERMANDOIS, France — Armand Pollet, the representative of the far-right National Front in this struggling, largely rural town in the north, sat back in his leather easy chair recently and smiled with satisfaction, declaring that his party was now locked in place as France’s third mainstream party.

headline: A Bouillabaisse Dinner, Halvah Spreads and More
abstract: Recommendations for the week of June 10.
lead_paragraph: To Share: A Bouillabaisse Dinner Is Quite a Catch

headline: Knicks, in Selecting Fisher, Take a Different Approach
abstract: The Knicks introduced Derek Fisher as their coach Tuesday in a low-key news conference that played down concern over Fisher’s lack of coaching experience.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Derek Fisher conceded Tuesday, as he was introduced as the new coach of the Knicks, that he had no experience as a coach at any level. He did not dismiss the empty lines on his résumé, but then again it hardly seemed to matter to the man who hired him, the Knicks’ new president, Phil Jackson, who won 11 N.B.A. titles as a coach.

headline: Google to Buy Skybox Imaging for $500 Million
abstract: Though Google will initially use Skybox’s satellite offerings to improve its mapping service, the technology giant will likely use its latest acquisition to help expand its Internet access services — joining balloons and drones.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:57 p.m. | Google agreed on Tuesday to buy Skybox Imaging, a provider of high-quality satellite images, for $500 million, as the technology giant continues to work on fulfilling its lofty ambitions for its Internet offerings.

headline: A Legislative Assault on the Financial Stability Oversight Council
abstract: Two bills proposed in the House clearly show a political motivation to obstruct the work of the panel responsible for identifying potential threats to the financial system, Stephen J. Lubben writes in the In Debt column.
lead_paragraph: Two new bills are pending in the House that relate to the Financial Stability Oversight Council and its ability to designate which parts of the financial system are “too big to fail” and thus in need of greater regulatory scrutiny. Both show how political the entire issue has become.

headline: Ireland Investigating Complaints Against Unwed Mother Homes
abstract: The decision to mount an inquiry followed the suggestion that for decades, the remains of 796 children may have been secretly buried at a home.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The Irish government said Tuesday it would begin an investigation into allegations of neglect and criminality at so-called mother-and-baby homes over several decades.

headline: Disapproval of Obama Doesn’t Mean Long-Term Trouble for Democrats
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Low approval ratings point to increasing polarization, not necessarily a deeper problem for the party’s presidential candidate in 2016.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic coalition is thought to have an advantage in national elections, but President Obama’s approval ratings have sagged into the low-to-mid 40s. It’s possible that his weak approval ratings are a sign of weakness in the Democratic coalition, as Ross Douthat, a New York Times columnist, argued on Sunday. Low presidential approval ratings can presage the collapse of a political coalition, like the fall of the Republican coalition in the last years of the George W. Bush administration.

headline: 1956: Elvis Is Introduced to the Nation
abstract: The big band era collided head-on with rock ’n’ roll when Elvis Presley made his first nationwide television appearance on “Stage Show,” a CBS variety series hosted by Tommy and Jimmy Dorsey.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 2
abstract: Soccer fans at the World Cup are known for flashy outfits, face painting and searching for a good time.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times have counted down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Oregon Shooting Draws Obama’s Outrage on Gun Laws
keywords: ['School Shootings', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Gun Control', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: On a day when the nation’s attention was drawn to another school shooting, President Obama expressed frustration with the inability to pass laws on background checks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, speaking hours after a gunman killed a student and wounded a teacher at an Oregon high school, said Tuesday that his failure to push through stricter gun laws was the greatest frustration of his presidency, declaring, “We’re the only developed country on earth where this happens.”

headline: From the I.R.S., a Taxpayer Bill of Rights
abstract: Responding to a torrent of complaints, the Internal Revenue Service on Tuesday unveiled a Taxpayer Bill of Rights.
lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service has been accused of a lot of things, but being user-friendly is not usually one of them.

headline: E.U. Official Criticizes U.S. Move Against Norwegian Air
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Slim Kallas, the E.U.'s top transport official, hinted at legal action if Washington did not grant the license to the budget carrier's American subsidiary.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s top transport official expressed deep disappointment on Tuesday with an attempt by American lawmakers to block plans by Norwegian Air Shuttle to offer new cut-rate flights across the Atlantic, and hinted at possible legal action if Washington failed to grant an operating license to the budget carrier’s long-distance subsidiary.

headline: Alabama and Mississippi Voted Last Week. No Official Results Yet.
abstract: Two Southern states haven’t posted official primary vote totals yet, because the elections are run by the parties, not the state.
lead_paragraph: A week after primary elections in eight states, two of them — Alabama and Mississippi — have not posted any results on an official state government website. The two stand alone among states that held primaries on June 3 in not publishing any results in a central location. California, Iowa, Montana, South Dakota, New Mexico and New Jersey had unofficial election-night results sites, in many cases updated live on election night.

headline: Trickle-Down Fragrances
keywords: ['Perfumes and Fragrances', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: There has been a shift in the mass fragrance market toward a higher sophistication in both aroma and packaging.
lead_paragraph: Perfume lovers can now buy a deeply scented bottle of a new eau de toilette, blended with natural oils of sandalwood and jasmine absolute sambac, both imported from India, formulated by the French-trained perfumer who has worked on scents from luxurious niche brands like Atelier Cologne, which last year introduced a pair of fragrances in sleek glass bottles infused with either gold or silver, retailing at $195.

headline: Chris Christie Spares No Legal Expense
abstract: The state has been billed over $3 million in legal fees for Bridgegate work.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who slogged through the 344-page report on Bridgegate from New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie’s lawyers in March understood that this old fashioned whitewash would be extremely expensive.The governor hired one of the nation’s  big time law firms, Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, which dutifully declared that Gov. Christie was not to blame for the massive traffic jams last year. Those problems were the work of others, the report insisted. The governor’s hands were clean.

headline: A Glimpse (and a Taste) of Celebrity
abstract: Bobby Flay’s first new restaurant in New York City in nearly a decade, Gato is many things, often all at the same time, but it is rarely shy.
lead_paragraph: Gato galloped into town in March, pursued by the food media and Bobby Flay fans in a thundering cloud of hoofbeats. The first new restaurant Mr. Flay and his business partner, Laurence Kretchmer, have opened in New York City in nearly a decade, Gato is nominally Mediterranean, but the chef rides herd on pastas and pizzas and romesco sauces with a go-for-broke intensity that’s 100 percent American. Mr. Flay brushes flavor on his ingredients in thick impasto strokes, making each plate a three-dimensional aggregation of char, smoke, capsicum, sugar, acid and fat. The cooking at Gato is many things, often all at the same time, but it is rarely shy.

headline: 2014: Clinton Fans at a Book Signing
abstract: Supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton waited in line at the Barnes & Noble in Union Square for Mrs. Clinton’s first book signing on a nationwide tour to promote her new memoir.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton waited in line at the Barnes & Noble in Union Square for Mrs. Clinton’s first book signing on a nationwide tour to promote her new memoir.

headline: Unexpected Love Stories
abstract: Lucas Kavner’s surprising and very funny new play, “Carnival Kids,” directed by Stephen Brackett, is part a reckoning of a father-son relationship.
lead_paragraph: Like his hero, Johnny Cash, he’s a man in black: weathered Levi’s, motorcycle boots, a T-shirt with a box of cigarettes straining the chest pocket. A long-ago rock star who toured the world but never managed to get rich, Dale arrives to crash at his son’s Morningside Heights apartment like a leftover from a more analog time. Broke and unemployed, he has no idea how to navigate a world ruled by technology.

headline: Tony Awards Face Criticism Over ‘In Memoriam’ Segment
abstract: The segment honoring those who died was cut from the television broadcast this year.
lead_paragraph: What happened to the In Memoriam segment of the Tony Awards?

headline: Delay Urged on Actions Tied to Tests by Schools
abstract: In an open letter, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation — a strong backer of the new academic guidelines — said more time was needed to make the standards work.
lead_paragraph: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, one of the country’s largest donors to educational causes and a strong backer of the academic guidelines known as the Common Core, has called for a two-year moratorium on states or school districts making any high-stakes decisions based on tests aligned with the new standards.

headline: Q. and A. | Banks on Tapping Into Her Inner Goddess
abstract: The smoky-voiced chanteuse sounds off on her festival style, taking calls from inmates and her Fiona Apple obsession.
lead_paragraph: Early press on Jillian Banks, the 25-year-old songstress who goes simply by Banks, focused largely on how little was actually known about her. The Los Angeles native seemed to appear out of nowhere, dropping a song, “Before I Ever Met You,” on Soundcloud in early 2013 to huge acclaim, and appearing in only a handful of photos in which her dark, searching eyes and model-like cheekbones were hidden in shadow or behind her long brown hair. At a time when many of her peers were blasting out songs about their famous exes and tipping off TMZ to their whereabouts, Banks was — quite literally — shrouded in obscurity. (Appropriately, the singer showed up for her interview with T clad in head-to-toe black, hair hanging over her face.)

headline: Beach Volleyball for All at a California Hotel
abstract: The Fairmont Miramar Hotel & Bungalows in Santa Monica, Calif., is holding weekly beach volleyball games open to guests and the general public.
lead_paragraph: Fairmont Miramar Hotel & Bungalows, a 302-room property in Santa Monica, Calif., is holding its third annual Vilebrequin Beach Volleyball Games.

headline: To Aid the Blind, an Assist From Cameras
abstract: Two devices developed in Israel — a smart contact lens and an iPhone app that turns sights into sounds — aim to give users a kind of sight.
lead_paragraph: In two labs some 50 miles apart in Israel, computer scientists and engineers are refining devices that employ tiny cameras as translators of sorts. For both teams, the goal is to give blind people a form of sight — or at least an experience analogous to sight.

headline: Obama’s Moments of Freedom Send His Aides Scrambling
abstract: Twice in two days, President Obama has veered from his official schedule and shaken off the confines of White House security to get a taste of life on the outside.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The bear was loose again on Tuesday.

headline: Egypt’s Inaction on Sexual Attacks Stirs Fury
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Sex Crimes', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: A video showing a mass assault on a woman during a Tahrir Square celebration has stirred new outrage among rape victims and women’s rights advocates.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Rape victims and women’s rights advocates lashed out on Tuesday at the escalating attempts by the Egyptian government and news media to dismiss a plague of sexual assaults more than three years after the Arab Spring uprising began to expose the scale of the problem.

headline: Families Flee Mosul Amid Gunfire
abstract: Thousands of residents fled Mosul in northern Iraq after the city was seized by militants belonging to the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, an extremist group.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of residents fled Mosul in northern Iraq after the city was seized by militants belonging to the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, an extremist group.

headline: A.I.G. Names Successor to Benmosche, Who Nursed It Through Fiscal Crisis
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Insurance', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Peter D. Hancock’s appointment signals the end of Robert H. Benmosche’s tenure atop the insurer, a five-year rebuilding period.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:29 p.m. | The American International Group on Tuesday named a successor to Robert H. Benmosche, the insurer’s chief executive and the voluble leader who oversaw its recovery from the financial crisis.

headline: Keep Your Government Hands Off My Cheese
abstract: Bureaucrats are banning cheese that is ripened or aged on wooden boards.
lead_paragraph: Cheese, or at least all good cheese, arises out of the mysterious mating of milk, enzymes and bacteria, and federal bureaucrats do not take kindly to either mysteries or germs. This week, a few of those bureaucrats horrified cheese-eaters across the country by banning cheese that is ripened or aged on wooden boards, apparently unaware that they are upsetting the natural rhythms of the universe.

headline: The ‘Grandfather’ Gets Busted
abstract: The D.E.A. spent months investigating the Sinaloa cartel’s operation in the Detroit area and tracking their most prolific drug mule: Leo Sharp, a World War II veteran with no criminal record.
lead_paragraph: The D.E.A. spent months investigating the Sinaloa cartel’s operation in the Detroit area and tracking their most prolific drug mule: Leo Sharp, a World War II veteran with no criminal record.

headline: A Health Insurer Calls, With Questions
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Insurers are calling people new to the Affordable Care Act asking health questions. The companies say the calls are beneficial to consumers, but some experts aren’t so sure.
lead_paragraph: Not long after she signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, Judy Shoemaker received a phone call that puzzled her.

headline: Do You Speak Tech?
abstract: Silicon Valley buzzwords may be invading everyday speech — and not everyone is pleased with the results, writes ANNA NORTH.
lead_paragraph: The tech industry’s influence on where people can live and how they spend their time is well documented. Now it may be influencing the way we talk as well.

headline: Marketing Domino’s in the Lunchroom
keywords: ['Lunch and Breakfast Programs', 'Pizza', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Companies like Domino’s are making more healthful versions of their food to sell in schools, prompting concerns about the use of brands in the school lunch line.
lead_paragraph: Companies like Domino’s are making more healthful versions of their food to sell in schools, prompting concerns about the use of brands in the school lunch line.

headline: Appeals Court Rules Bloomberg Plan for ‘Taxi of Tomorrow’ Is Legal
abstract: The court reversed a lower-court ruling, resuscitating a program passed under the Bloomberg administration for a nearly uniform taxi fleet of Nissan NV200s.
lead_paragraph: A state appeals court on Tuesday ruled that a plan for a nearly uniform fleet of yellow taxis in New York City was legal, reversing a lower-court ruling and resuscitating a program initially enacted under the Bloomberg administration but opposed by Mayor Bill de Blasio.

headline: The Domino’s Smart Slice Goes to School
keywords: ['Pizza', 'Lunch and Breakfast Programs', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Education (K-12)', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: These pies contain fewer worrisome ingredients, but they also give students a hefty dose of marketing in the lunchroom.
lead_paragraph: Given the current uproar over new federal rules aimed at getting schoolchildren to eat more healthfully, you might think fast food was an endangered species on the cafeteria line. But Domino’s is delivering a pizza it calls the Smart Slice to more than 3,000 lunchrooms in 38 states, up from 3 states in 2010. And one force driving those sales is the new rules themselves. These pies contain fewer of the worrisome ingredients found in regular pizzas. But they also give the students a hefty dose of marketing for the Domino’s brand, and many other companies are following the same path to the lunchroom.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: G.M. Chief on Ignition Switch Problems
abstract: Mary T. Barra, General Motors’ chief executive, spoke at a news conference ahead of the annual shareholders meeting.
lead_paragraph: Mary T. Barra, General Motors’ chief executive, spoke at a news conference ahead of the annual shareholders meeting.

headline: In Ireland, 10 Years of Fresh Air
abstract: A decade after the country banned workplace smoking, reflections on how it has changed pubs, hotels and lives.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of March 29, 2004, global television crews gathered outside a Dublin restaurant stocked with celebrating lawmakers to witness what few thought possible in this welcoming land of brilliant but noxious pubs.

headline: Restaurant Review: The Rest in Salt Lake City
abstract: “The Rest is the last 10 years of my life — thrown into one space,” says the owner of this subterranean speakeasy that serves a "campfire gourmet" menu.
lead_paragraph: Along a once humdrum stretch of Main Street in Salt Lake City, tucked behind a storefront called Bodega — a half ramshackle corner store, half taco-peddling beer tavern — is this subterranean speakeasy, the Rest.

headline: Reading List  | The Top 100 Best-Selling Education Books of 2014 (So Far)
abstract: Inspiration for summer reading, compiled by Deborah Hofmann, senior editor of the New York Times best-seller lists.
lead_paragraph: The book trailer for “The End of Your Life Book Club,” No. 67 on our list.

headline: From Cocktails to Kimchi in Los Angeles’s Koreatown
abstract: New businesses have added flavor to the neighborhood’s energetic night life in recent years.
lead_paragraph: With Koreans making up more than a quarter of the immigrants who live in Los Angeles’s Koreatown, that cultural flavor is palpable in the neighborhood’s remarkable concentration of late-night restaurants, bars and clubs. Thanks to the recent arrival of the Line Hotel in Koreatown — a design-minded homage to all things Korean, and to the street-cool sensibilities of K-town — a whole new audience is getting an introduction to city greats that have long been under the radar: croon-worthy karaoke joints, meticulously frothed cappuccinos, fiery grocery kimchi, some of the best Korean barbecue anywhere. A spate of new businesses (a speakeasy here, a microbrewery there) has only added to the area’s energetic night life.

headline: Hotel Review: Heywood Hotel in Austin, Tex.
abstract: Opened in December 2012, this property offers seven one-of-a-kind rooms and perks like free bicycles in newly revitalized East Austin.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: At E3, Nintendo Unveils a Mario World Designed by You
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'E3 Media and Business Summit', 'Wii (Video Game System)']
abstract: About 30 years after the Super Mario franchise began, Nintendo will allow people to create and play unique courses on the Wii U.
lead_paragraph: If you have ever played the first Super Mario Bros., the influential video game from the ’80s, you have probably also ventured into the many subsequent games and levels for Mario created by Nintendo.

headline: Beethoven That’s Not for Bruisers
abstract: Yefim Bronfman, who will play all five of Beethoven’s piano concertos with the New York Philharmonic, explains how he approaches the work, starting with the Fourth Concerto.
lead_paragraph: The fourth of Beethoven’s five piano concertos is the only one that begins with the soloist playing alone. The melody is a statement with the nobility of a Greek temple, a quiet expanse broken only by a playful little burst of a scale, like a giggle atop the Acropolis at sunrise.

headline: Beatles Sing in German, and a Nazi Flag Waves
abstract: Nothing that has been announced this week at the Electronic Entertainment Expo has been as surprising or delightful as the recent emergence of a new Wolfenstein game.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Nazis, those perpetual video game villains who seemed to have been felled in recent years by a virulent zombie contagion, are back. Nothing that has been announced here this week at the Electronic Entertainment Expo, the annual video game trade show better known as E3, has been as surprising or delightful — granted, an odd word to apply to the return of National Socialism — as the recent emergence of a new Wolfenstein game as one of the very best releases of the year.

headline: The Last Gun Report
abstract: Why I am ending The Gun Report.
lead_paragraph: Last Thursday, Jennifer Mascia and I posted our last Gun Report. It was my feeling that although it had been a useful tool — a daily statement about gun violence in America — The Gun Report had run its course. During the year and change that we published it, readers got a close-up look at the many forms gun violence takes — the horrifying incidents involving children shooting other children; the drive-by shootings; the shootings that result from a moment’s rage; and so on. There weren’t just one or two shootings each day; there were 30 or more. On weekends, the carnage was horrific. The Gun Report also became a place where gun proponents and gun opponents could voice their views in the comment section.

headline: O. J. and the White Bronco Ride Again
abstract: This has been a year for anniversaries solemn and sublime in American history and culture. But where does O. J. Simpson and his murder case fit in?
lead_paragraph: Beginning last fall, we seem to have entered a 12-month period heavy with anniversaries, which allows us to pause and ask: Why observe them? Perhaps to note a traumatic moment in history (the 50th of President John F. Kennedy’s assassination) or a turning point (the 50th of the Civil Rights Act and Freedom Summer). Perhaps to commemorate heroism (the 70th of D-Day). Perhaps to relish a cultural sea change (the 50th of the Beatles on “The Ed Sullivan Show”; the 45th of Woodstock).

headline: A Justice Alone, Even if Surrounded
abstract: “Scalia: A Court of One,” a biography of the Supreme Court justice by Bruce Allen Murphy, finds a man driven by nearly operatic qualities.
lead_paragraph: Last fall the pugilistic Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia gave an interview to Jennifer Senior in New York Magazine so playful and revealing that the transcript could nearly be made into a stage play and movie, in the manner of “Frost/Nixon.”

headline: Cold War Spy or Just Wife?
abstract: Tracy Michailidis plays a 1950s wife and mother on her way to the electric chair in “Ethel Sings: The Unsung Song of Ethel Rosenberg.”
lead_paragraph: In “Ethel Sings: The Unsung Song of Ethel Rosenberg,” the playwright Joan Beber issues a posthumous pardon to Ethel Rosenberg, executed for conspiring to commit espionage in 1953.

headline: Seeing Red in the Gene Pool
abstract: Redhead deposits aren’t wanted at the world’s largest sperm bank, leading a photographer to document gingers in all their blazing, freckled varieties.
lead_paragraph: Redhead deposits aren’t wanted at the world’s largest sperm bank, leading a photographer to document gingers in all their blazing, freckled varieties.

headline: A Symphony’s Viral Video
abstract: A YouTube video depicting audience members dancing onstage with Sir Mix-A-Lot at a Seattle Symphony concert has brought the orchestra unparalleled attention and some debate.
lead_paragraph: The Seattle Symphony commissioned the piece that won this year’s Pulitzer Prize for music, “Become Ocean,” by John Luther Adams. But it is a late-20th-century work that is bringing the orchestra broader fame this week: its performance with Sir Mix-A-Lot of his bawdy song “Baby Got Back,” which by Tuesday had been seen more than 1.5 million times on YouTube.

headline: Colombia Says It Has Begun Peace Talks With Rebels
abstract: The government of President Juan Manuel Santos said preliminary negotiations were underway with the National Liberation Army, a guerrilla group.
lead_paragraph: The government of Colombia announced on Tuesday that it had begun exploratory peace talks with a second rebel group, just days ahead of a hotly contested presidential election that could hinge on how voters perceive the efforts of President Juan Manuel Santos to end decades of guerrilla warfare.

headline: Hong Kong Regulators Tense About China Loans
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A surge in lending to Chinese companies is leading Hong Kong regulators to impose strict financial rules four years before they are required under new global standards.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:25 p.m. | A surge in business loans to the slowing mainland Chinese economy has prompted Hong Kong regulators to impose strict financial rules four years before they are required under new global standards.

headline: The Heroine’s Retinue as a Magical Force Field
abstract: The great moments in Frederick Ashton’s “Cinderella,” which joined American Ballet Theater’s repertory on Monday, were the ensembles.
lead_paragraph: Frederick Ashton’s three-act “Cinderella” (1948) is a story of hope fulfilled, a comedy of contrasting characters and a classical ballet dense with sensuous movement. Though New York has been having a Cinderellathon in 2014 — the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical on Broadway, and Rossini’s “La Cenerentola” at the Metropolitan Opera and Massenet’s “Cendrillon” at Juilliard Opera, both in April — this treatment of the old fairy tale takes the prize for dramatic poetry. Still, it looked a pale echo of itself on Monday when it joined American Ballet Theater’s repertory.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Germany and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Germany, New York, Pakistan and Italy.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Germany, New York, Pakistan and Italy.

headline: A Season for the Blossoming of Hopes and Talents
abstract: New York City Ballet was at its most exciting and enthusiastic this spring.
lead_paragraph: Infectious passion for dancing has been the special thrill of New York City Ballet since the start of this year, and during the spring season that ended on Sunday the level kept rising. The sheer danciness of Alexei Ratmansky’s “Namouna: A Grand Divertissement” on opening night was irresistible. Justin Peck’s new “Everywhere We Go,” the season’s big premiere, had weak aspects, yet just look at how its cast was dancing its heart out! No wonder it won ovations.

headline: Oracle’s Database of Youth
abstract: Lawrence J. Ellison, a master salesman, has positioned the new version of his flagship database as a product that continually changes to meet the cutting edge of tech, while staying familiar to its corporate clientele. It’s a great marriage of stability and change from a company now worth more than IBM.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence J. Ellison may have figured out a secret to seeming young: Ignore getting older, and act cutting-edge.

headline: Pentagon on ‘Friendly Fire’ Strike
abstract: The Pentagon press secretary, Rear Adm. John Kirby, said five American troops were killed during a security operation in southern Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon press secretary, Rear Adm. John Kirby, said five American troops were killed during a security operation in southern Afghanistan.

headline: Hillary Rodham Clinton and the Power of Style
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton is an example of a woman who has presumably had to think through how her image affects perception and relationships in traditionally all-male environments.
lead_paragraph: THIS WEEK’S PUBLICATION of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s “Hard Choices” has proved a predictably exciting opportunity for Clintonologists, 2016 election obsessives and pundits everywhere to revisit all sorts of issues that otherwise may have been considered, if not resolved, at least over — from the questions surrounding the couple’s marriage to Mrs. Clinton’s relationship with President Obama to the whole hair brouhaha.

headline: A Genre Dabbler Gets His Accolades
abstract: Donovan Leitch, the singer-songwriter who came to fame in the mid-1960s, discusses his career as he joins the Songwriters Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: Donovan Leitch — or just Donovan, as he became known — might have become a painter instead of a musician. As he tells it, he was considering arts school when he decided, instead, to take his guitar and hitchhike to London, where he began performing as a folk singer. By 1965 he had won a following, as well as recording and publishing contracts, with ballads like “Catch the Wind” and “Colors,” guitar-accompanied folk songs similar to one Bob Dylan was writing — not surprisingly since they were both drawing from the large well of English, Irish, Scottish and American folk melodies.

headline: Art Matters | The Second Life of Performance
abstract: Once left behind by the competitive market, live art is now everywhere — thanks in large part to its staunchest advocate, RoseLee Goldberg.
lead_paragraph: Once left behind by the competitive market, live art is now everywhere — thanks in large part to its staunchest advocate, RoseLee Goldberg.

headline: Why So Many World Cup Fans Dislike Argentina
abstract: The country’s soccer traditions, its past affluence and its European ties all play a role.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Argentina has one of the most successful national soccer teams in the world, and the country has won the World Cup twice, in 1978 and 1986. In this year’s tournament, the team ranks among the most formidable competitors, with Brazil’s coach, Luiz Felipe Scolari, even predicting a final showdown with Argentina.

headline: World Cup’s Most Pessimistic Country: England?
abstract: A mere 4 percent of English respondents predicted their team would win the tournament.
lead_paragraph: The most downcast soccer fans in the world — relative to the quality of their national team — are the citizens of England.

headline: Australia’s Odd World Cup Optimism
abstract: Australians’ predictions befit a country with a higher-ranked team and an easier draw. What’s going on?
lead_paragraph: The Socceroos, as the Australian national soccer team are known, enter the World Cup ranked by FIFA as the 62nd-best team in the world, the lowest standing of any of the 32 teams that earned a slot. They’ve also been dealt the toughest possible draw, facing not only the reigning champions and runners-up in their group, but also highly rated Chile. No wonder oddsmakers give the Aussies less than a 1-in-2,500 chance of winning the tournament.

headline: Morgan Stanley Sees Itself as Two Firms in One
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Company Reports', 'Income', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: As revenue from traditional lines of business like trading has slowed, banks have had to look elsewhere for more stable, less risky lines of business. For Morgan Stanley, the answer has come from wealth management.
lead_paragraph: The more risk-averse Morgan Stanley that has emerged since the financial crisis may tell a tale of two Wall Streets. But it may also tell a tale of two businesses within the bank.

headline: World Cup Opinions in 19 Countries: Likes, Dislikes, Predictions
abstract: Argentina, the United States and Iran appear to be the most disliked World Cup teams. Brazilian supporters enter the tournament as the most confident fans.
lead_paragraph: Argentina, the United States and Iran appear to be the most disliked World Cup teams. Brazilian fans enter the World Cup as the most confident, though Argentines and Spaniards aren’t far behind in their home-country optimism. And fans across many countries agree that the Brazilians play the most attractive form of soccer.

headline: Methodology of World Cup Study
abstract: YouGov conducted a study of public opinion in 19 countries participating in the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: The study of public opinion about the World Cup is based on 19,780 interviews conducted by YouGov in 19 countries between May 19 and June 2. YouGov conducted the interviews online, after selecting respondents from opt-in panels recruited by YouGov or its partners.

headline: European Tech Start-Ups Pay Off for Index Ventures
abstract: Buoyed by big payoffs from backing tech firms, the European venture capital firm Index Ventures has raised a new $542 million fund to focus on mobile, financial services and online marketplaces.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European venture capital firm Index Ventures has been on a roll.

headline: Endowment Chief to Exit at Harvard
abstract: Jane L. Mendillo will exit from her role as manager of the $32.7 billion nest egg by the end of the year; its performance has fallen behind those of other Ivy leagues.
lead_paragraph: Jane L. Mendillo, the manager of Harvard’s $32.7 billion endowment, plans to step down by the end of the year, the university said on Tuesday.

headline: Detroit Denies Last-Minute Reprieve for Goats
abstract: A hedge fund manager will sell baby goats to butchers sooner than expected, now that Detroit officials have failed to grant any reprieve to let them to graze in the city.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund manager Mark Spitznagel has been denied a last-minute reprieve for his guerrilla urban farming project.

headline: More Lands of Fantasy
abstract: While “Game of Thrones” fans wait for the series to return and for George R. R. Martin’s next novel, there are other fantasy book series to explore.
lead_paragraph: As “Game of Thrones” obsessives grimace and wait for George R. R. Martin’s next novel, “The Winds of Winter,” he and his publisher, the Bantam imprint of Random House, are tossing fans a couple of dragon bones.

headline: A Lethal Culture of Secrecy at G.M.
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Legal experts respond to front-page articles.

abstract: Professors of history and politics respond to an Upshot column.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Glimpses of Mosul in Islamist Hands on YouTube
abstract: Video uploaded to YouTube appeared to offer images of Iraq’s second-largest city, Mosul, under the control of Islamist militants.
lead_paragraph: Video uploaded to YouTube on Tuesday appeared to offer glimpses of Iraq’s second-largest city, Mosul, in the hands of Islamist militants after the sudden retreat of Iraqi Army soldiers.
