abstract: A history teacher laments the return of warfare in South Sudan and the young fighters taking part.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cold Winter and Ukraine Lead to Lower Global Growth Forecast
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The World Bank now anticipates global growth of just 2.8 percent in 2014, down from its January estimate of a 3.2 percent expansion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The World Bank has downgraded its estimate of the world’s economic expansion in a new forecast released Tuesday, with developing economies posting disappointing growth rates and the frigid winter in the United States and the crisis in Ukraine weighing on growth, too.

headline: Change at Housing Agency
abstract: Shola Olatoye, chairwoman of the New York City Housing Authority, responds to an editorial.

headline: Colleges Focus on Alcohol and Drugs as Serious Crime Dips
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Crime and Criminals', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Sex Crimes', 'Education (K-12)', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Colleges and universities have become more aggressive about punishing alcohol and drug offenses, even as the rate of serious crime on campus has dropped, according to a government report.
lead_paragraph: Colleges have become more aggressive about punishing alcohol and drug offenses, even as the rate of serious crime on campuses has dropped, according to a government report released Tuesday.

headline: Knicks Name Derek Fisher as Coach
abstract: Phil Jackson, the New York Knicks’ president, and Derek Fisher, their new coach, spoke after Mr. Fisher was hired to replace Mike Woodson.
lead_paragraph: Phil Jackson, the New York Knicks’ president, and Derek Fisher, their new coach, spoke after Mr. Fisher was hired to replace Mike Woodson.

abstract: A Human Rights Watch official says Mississippi remains responsible for the conditions of jails run by private companies.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Chinese Shoppers Change Hong Kong Border Area
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Vast numbers of mainland Chinese traders and shoppers are pumping money into Hong Kong, leading to rapid development of the territory’s border area.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Smoking a cigarette outside a mall in the border town of Sheung Shui, a man who gave his name only as Chen stands next to a wheeled cart filled with purchases. He is visiting from the Chinese city of Shantou, 177 miles away, a trip he makes several times a year.

headline: A V.A. Doctor’s View
abstract: Dr. Victoria A. Seligman of the Denver V.A. Medical Center writes that V.A. medical professionals can offer advice for improving veterans’ health care.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Target Hires an Outsider as Its Data Watchdog
abstract: Brad Maiorino, formerly head of information security at General Motors, will join Target to bolster its efforts to stop security threats like the hacker intrusion last year that compromised data on millions of its customers.
lead_paragraph: Target named a seasoned security expert as its new chief information security officer on Tuesday, on the eve of its annual shareholders’ meeting, as the retailer sought to bolster its data defenses and calm investor chagrin after the extensive hacking it experienced last year.

headline: Amazon Stops Taking Advance Orders for ‘Lego’ and Other Warner Videos
abstract: Amazon, embroiled in a standoff with a book publisher, is using the same hardball techniques with new movies from Warner Home Video.
lead_paragraph: The Everything Store is shrinking again. Amazon customers who want to order forthcoming Warner Home Video features, including “The Lego Movie,” “300: Rise of an Empire,” “Winter’s Tale” and “Transcendence,” are finding it impossible to do so.

abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: RECENT LEASE

keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,311 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,311 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: A Bellwether for London Realty
abstract: As the HSBC tower has changed hands in recent years, it has become an emblem of the boom-bust-boom cycle of London’s commercial property market.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When the global bank HSBC sold its London headquarters tower to a Spanish buyer in spring 2007, at the height of the credit and property boom, the deal was the single largest real estate transaction in British history.

headline: Holder Criticizes Ban on Gay Boy Scout Leaders
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Tuesday sharply criticized the Boy Scouts of America’s policy as “a relic of an age of prejudice and insufficient understanding.”
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Tuesday sharply criticized the Boy Scouts of America’s policy that bans gay scout leaders, calling it “a relic of an age of prejudice and insufficient understanding.” In remarks to the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, a gay-rights group, Mr. Holder said, “The continuation of a policy that discriminates against gay adult leaders, by an iconic American institution, only preserves and perpetuates the worst kind of stereotypes.” There is little Mr. Holder can do to oppose the policy. The Supreme Court ruled in 2000 that the Boy Scouts have a constitutional right to ban gay members.

headline: Sports Should Be Child’s Play
abstract: To turn kids into elite and healthy athletes, avoid specialization.
lead_paragraph: THE national furor over concussions misses the primary scourge that is harming kids and damaging youth sports in America.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: What Causes Weight Gain
abstract: Real food is more likely to promote health than hyperprocessed food.
lead_paragraph: If I ask you what constitutes “bad” eating, the kind that leads to obesity and a variety of connected diseases, you’re likely to answer, “Salt, fat and sugar.” This trilogy of evil has been drilled into us for decades, yet that’s not an adequate answer.

headline: Bloomberg Hires Jacki Kelley, Ad Executive, for Media Business
abstract: Ms. Kelley, previously chief executive of IPG Media Brands North America, is the latest hire from outside journalism as Bloomberg seeks to transform its business under new leadership.
lead_paragraph: Bloomberg has hired a senior advertising executive, Jacki Kelley, as chief operating officer of its media business, the company announced on Tuesday, its latest hire from outside journalism as it seeks to transform its business under new leadership.

headline: Official Backs Marines’ Move to Classify Photos of Forces With Taliban Bodies
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Photography', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Whistle-Blowers', 'Freedom of Information Act', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: An administration official cited troops’ safety in rejecting a whistle-blower’s complaint that photos showing American forces with the corpses of Taliban fighters had violated an executive order.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an apparent expansion of the government’s secrecy powers, the top official in charge of the classification system has decided that it was legitimate for the Marines to classify photographs that showed American forces posing with corpses of Taliban fighters in Afghanistan.

headline: Eric Cantor Defeated by David Brat, Tea Party Challenger, in G.O.P. Primary Upset
abstract: In one of the most stunning primary election upsets in congressional history, Mr. Cantor, the House majority leader, was soundly defeated by David Brat, a Tea Party-backed candidate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In one of the most stunning primary election upsets in congressional history, the House majority leader, Eric Cantor, was soundly defeated on Tuesday by a Tea Party-backed economics professor who had hammered him for being insufficiently conservative.

headline: Erez Itzhaki
abstract: Mr. Itzhaki is a principal of Itzhaki Acquisitions, a real estate development company formerly known as the Keystone Group.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Itzhaki, 44, is a principal of Itzhaki Acquisitions, a real estate development company formerly known as the Keystone Group. His company is involved in boutique condominium projects, including Modern 19 in Chelsea, and is a partner with the developer Michael Shvo and others on a development planned in SoHo.

headline: F.C.C. Chief Plans Action on Wi-Fi in Schools
abstract: The F.C.C. fund that subsidizes the installation of high-speed Internet connections at schools prioritizes bringing connections to a school or library over improving networks inside a school.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Visiting a middle school in Oakland earlier this year, Tom Wheeler, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, got a glimpse of just how badly American schools need better high-speed Internet connections.

headline: Music Industry Officials Agree on Need for Licensing Rule Changes, but Little Else
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Royalties']
abstract: The House Judiciary committee heard testimony on how to fix the outdated federal regulation of the business.
lead_paragraph: The complex system of music licensing came under attack in a congressional hearing on Tuesday, as entertainment and media executives pleaded for changes to how music rights were acquired and paid for online and by radio and television stations.

headline: One Key to Success: A Belief in a Future
abstract: A program for teenage boys in Chicago makes a contribution to the battle against entrenched income inequality.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Tim Jackson’s job is to convince young people that they have a stake in the future.

headline: Officials Assigned for World Cup Opener
abstract: Yuichi Nishimura, 42, of Japan, will be the referee for the World Cup’s opening match on Thursday night, when Brazil plays Croatia in São Paolo.
lead_paragraph: Yuichi Nishimura, 42, of Japan, will be the referee for the World Cup’s opening match on Thursday night, when Brazil plays Croatia in São Paolo. Toru Sagara and Toshiyuki Nagi, also of Japan, will be the linesmen, and Alireza Faghani of Iran was assigned to be the fourth official.

headline: Merkel Cites ‘Threats’ in Warning to Cameron
abstract: Fissures are forming as Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain expresses increasing skepticism of the value of European Union inclusion.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — German-British tensions over who should next lead the European Union appeared to heighten on Tuesday as Chancellor Angela Merkel delivered a scarcely veiled rebuke to Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, warning that “threats” will not work as the 28 members struggle to mend new fissures in their unity aggravated by European Parliament elections last month.

headline: Getting a Kiehl’s Product Into a Man’s Orbit
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Men and Boys', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The personal care company is trying to attract male customers by devising a campaign that features space.
lead_paragraph: THE market for men’s personal care products grew 15 percent from 2008 to 2013, according to Mintel, a market research firm. But while a makeup brand introducing a new mascara can seek publicity from countless beauty publications and bloggers, men’s brands face a hurdle: Although men are buying products like face scrub and anti-aging cream, they are not reading extensively about the items or trading grooming tips on the golf course.

headline: After Rough-Hewed Restoration, Experience at Pinehurst Is Devalued
abstract: The course’s recent restoration, which replaced the rough with coarse sand and native vegetation, has devalued course knowledge, and it has been suggested that the golfers with the least experience playing the course might fare the best.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — The Pinehurst 12, headlined by Phil Mickelson, are those players in this week’s United States Open field who participated in the tournament the last two times it was held here, in 1999 and 2005.

headline: Microsoft Protests Order to Disclose Email Stored Abroad
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'E-Mail', 'Privacy', 'Electronic Communications Privacy Act']
abstract: The objection to hand over email stored in an Irish data center is believed to be the first time a corporation has challenged a domestic search warrant seeking digital information overseas.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft is challenging the authority of federal prosecutors to force the giant technology company to hand over a customer’s email stored in a data center in Ireland.

headline: On Trial’s Tapes, Talk of New York Politics, Secret Cash and Strip Clubs
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: State Senator Malcolm A. Smith is charged with taking part in a conspiracy to pass $60,000 in bribes to Daniel J. Halloran III, then a city councilman, and two Republican county leaders.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — The picture of New York City politicians emerging from secretly recorded conversations at the bribery trial of State Senator Malcolm A. Smith is not one likely to be found in high-school civics textbooks.

headline: P.F. Chang’s Investigating Possible Data Breach
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Credit Cards', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The restaurant chain said Tuesday that it was investigating a possible data breach. If confirmed, it will the fifth major retail chain to have suffered a cyberattack in recent months.
lead_paragraph: P.F. Chang’s China Bistro said Tuesday that it is investigating a potential security breach that may have led to the theft of information from thousands of customer credit cards.

headline: Martha Hyer, Oscar-Nominated Actress, Dies at 89
abstract: Ms. Hyer, who married the producer Hal B. Wallis, played supporting roles but still enjoyed Hollywood’s high life.
lead_paragraph: Martha Hyer, an Oscar-nominated movie actress who starred alongside Humphrey Bogart, Dean Martin, Frank Sinatra and Shirley MacLaine in the 1950s and 1960s, died on May 31 at her home in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 89.

headline: I.R.S. Publishes Guide It Says Will Help Ensure Taxpayer Rights
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service on Tuesday unveiled a Taxpayer Bill of Rights that is intended to ensure the rights to privacy, confidentiality and a fair appeals process with the agency.
lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service on Tuesday unveiled a Taxpayer Bill of Rights that is intended to ensure the rights to privacy, confidentiality and a fair appeals process in dealings with the agency. “This reinforces for the average taxpayer the fairness of the system,” the agency’s commissioner, John Koskinen, said. He said the timing had nothing to do with the investigations that the I.R.S. is facing after being accused of giving improper scrutiny to conservative groups while reviewing their applications for tax-exempt status. He said that the decision was meant to “help taxpayers’ comfort level with the I.R.S.”

headline: Virginia Governor May Try to Expand Medicaid on His Own
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'State Legislatures', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: After Gov. Terry McAuliffe lost his battle with the legislature over Medicaid expansion, he is thought to be studying how to press the issue by executive action — a legally and politically uncertain course.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Gov. Terry McAuliffe has lost his battle with the legislature over Medicaid expansion, an enormous retreat from the high expectations he set for a liberal agenda. However, he is thought to be studying how to press the issue by executive action — a legally and politically uncertain course.

headline: Open Winner Savors Title, and Friendships
abstract: The yearlong celebration of Justin Rose’s United States Open victory, the high mark of which was his recent return to Britain with the trophy, has been sweeter because of the decade of disappointments that preceded it.
lead_paragraph: FLEET, England — Circulars announcing “The Boy Is Back in Town” hung throughout the North Hants clubhouse, where Justin Rose spent an afternoon last month signing autographs, answering questions and posing for photographs with the United States Open trophy he won last June.

headline: F.D.A. Rule May Alter Cheese-Aging Process
keywords: ['Cheese', 'Wood and Wood Products', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: A decision by the Food and Drug Administration to question the use of wooden planks to age some cheeses has prompted an uproar among artisanal cheese makers and some consumers.
lead_paragraph: A decision by the Food and Drug Administration to question the use of wooden planks to age some cheeses has produced a stink that rivals Limburger, prompting an uproar among the artisanal cheese makers and consumers who fear they might lose access to products like obscure blue cheeses from Vermont and imported Parmigiano-Reggiano.

headline: Why Did Cantor Lose? Not Easy to Explain
abstract: The House majority leader outspent his opponent, had defeated a challenger in a more favorable year for the Tea Party and was said to have led in polls. But he lost anyway.
lead_paragraph: Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, lost his primary on Tuesday night in one of the most stunning electoral upsets in recent memory. It is not easy to explain his defeat, or the extent to which his campaign apparently underestimated the severity of the threat posed by David Brat, a Tea Party-backed economics professor.

headline: Campaigning for Environment, Seminary to Divest Some Holdings
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Endowments', 'Global Warming', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The trustees of Union Theological Seminary, a liberal Protestant organization in New York City, voted on Tuesday to divest the school’s $108.4 million endowment from fossil fuel companies.
lead_paragraph: The trustees of Union Theological Seminary, a historic cradle of liberal Protestantism in New York City, voted unanimously on Tuesday to divest the school’s $108.4 million endowment from fossil fuel companies. Union is said to be the first seminary to take up the divestment tactic in a campaign by environmentalists to combat climate change. Last month, Stanford University announced it would divest, but only from coal companies. The president of Union, Serene Jones, said, “Climate change poses a catastrophic threat, and as stewards of God’s creation we simply must act.” The seminary had already divested from tobacco and liquor companies.

headline: Smart Growth on the East Side
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio is reviving a rezoning plan around Grand Central Terminal with a wiser approach.
lead_paragraph: With the sun setting on his final term, Mayor Michael Bloomberg tried last fall to push through a grand rezoning plan for East Midtown that would have brought many more office towers and a flood of workers to a 73-block area around Grand Central Terminal. He said it met an urgent need to keep the city competitive, with up-to-date buildings and improved transportation above and below ground. The plan died in the City Council, under criticism from community members and elected officials who said it was too drastic and too complicated to wave through.

headline: Student Borrowers and the Economy
keywords: ['Student Loans', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials']
abstract: President Obama’s order providing relief to millions with loans and a pending loan refinancing bill speak to a grave problem.
lead_paragraph: President Obama took an important step this week when he signed an executive order providing relief to millions of struggling student loan borrowers and urged Congress to pass a student loan refinancing bill that is scheduled for a vote in the Senate on Wednesday. Both the executive order and the refinancing bill speak to a grave problem that has trapped recent college graduates and threatens the long-term health of the economy.

headline: Bank of America Mortgage Settlement Is Said to Be Deadlocked
abstract: The bank made its final multibillion-dollar settlement offer Monday, but it was said to be short of what the Justice Department wants it to pay for its role in the mortgage crisis.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America and the Justice Department have reached an impasse in negotiations over a multibillion-dollar settlement deal, raising the stakes in an investigation into the bank’s role at the center of the mortgage crisis.

headline: Wylie Dufresne Says He Is Forced to Close WD-50
abstract: The chef, an acclaimed experimenter in the kitchen, announced on Twitter that the restaurant will shut down in November.
lead_paragraph: Updated | June 11, 2014

headline: Clauses That Hurt Workers
abstract: The indiscriminate use of noncompete clauses hurts workers by limiting their ability to seek better jobs in their chosen professions.
lead_paragraph: Many businesses have long required that executives and other important employees agree not to work for a competitor for a year or two after they leave. Now some employers are unfairly imposing that requirement on all kinds of workers, including lower-wage employees like camp counselors, interns and yoga instructors, The Times has found.

headline: The Real War of Ideas
abstract: The religious extremists and the committed environmentalists both want a Middle East without borders, but for very different reasons.
lead_paragraph: The takeover Tuesday of the Iraqi city of Mosul by Sunni extremists who spilled over the Syrian border underscores the clash of world views that is underway in the whole Eastern Mediterranean, which I saw close up during my visit to Kurdistan a few days ago. And it’s not what you think.

headline: In Tough Market, Investment Banks Seek Shelter or Get Out
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Stricter regulations and low volatility are transforming the banking industry, driving banks to find additional, more stable sources of revenue or even to shift away from the business entirely, Steven M. Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: The world of Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and the rest of the investment banks is being remade, squeezed by new regulations and record low volatility in the markets.

headline: Montana: Prosecutors Agree to Improve Sex Assault Response
abstract: A standoff between the Justice Department and an elected county attorney in Montana ended with an agreement under which local prosecutors promised to improve their response to sexual assault cases.
lead_paragraph: A standoff between the Justice Department and an elected county attorney in western Montana ended on Tuesday with an agreement under which local prosecutors promised to improve their response to sexual assault cases. The agreement came months after a lacerating report by federal authorities accused the Missoula County attorney’s office of gender bias in handling sexual assault cases. The county attorney, Fred Van Valkenburg, sued federal judiciary officials, arguing they had no right to investigate his office. Under the deal, that challenge is being dropped, and the attorney’s office has promised to set up new policies and training for sexual assault cases and to communicate better with victims and the police.

headline: Championship Experience, if Not a Championship Roster
abstract: Derek Fisher is the best choice by far if Phil Jackson wants to coach without coaching, mentor a former player and, if all goes exceedingly well, cement a legacy as a championship coach who became a championship executive.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — From the time I left home Tuesday morning and walked down Edgecombe Avenue in the Sugar Hill neighborhood of Harlem, Knicks fans up and down the block were torn between buzzing and fretting over the news that Derek Fisher would be the Knicks’ new coach.

headline: Rangel’s Top Rival Stirs Up Deportation Debate
abstract: The congressman’s camp denies allegations made by his challenger that Mr. Rangel endorsed the deportation of immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Signs that a congressional race has entered its final two weeks: dueling statements, accusations of outrageous behavior and liberal use of the words “desperate” and “unconscionable.”

headline: When Companies Close Doors to the Future
abstract: Should businesses be allowed to have new employees agree to sign noncompete deals? Is it unfair to workers or good for business?

headline: Order for Microsoft to Disclose Data Stored Outside of U.S.
abstract: Microsoft is challenging the authority of federal prosecutors to force it to hand over a customer’s e-mail stored in one of its overseas data centers.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft is challenging the authority of federal prosecutors to force it to hand over a customer’s e-mail stored in one of its overseas data centers.

headline: Another Voice Joins Chorus for Fair Pay
abstract: As of August, a total of 17,191 cases involving wage theft claims were being handled by New York State’s Labor Department, an increase of about 150 percent from 2008, according to a state audit.
lead_paragraph: The rent is $1,187 for the walk-up apartment on East 117th Street in Manhattan where Solomon Perez, 30, lives with his wife and their 2-year-old daughter. He delivers food for Indus Valley, an Indian restaurant on the Upper West Side, making $5.25 an hour plus tips. Mr. Perez said the restaurant takes a cut of about 10 percent of the tips in online orders, like ones that come through Seamless, the Internet food-delivery hub.

headline: A Fight as U.S. Girls Face Genital Cutting Abroad
keywords: ['Female Genital Mutilation', 'Women and Girls', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Female genital cutting has been banned in the United States since 1996, and now it is also illegal to transport girls for “vacation cutting.” But some are concerned that such cutting is on the rise.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Last summer, an American-born teenager of Somali descent fled her parents’ home in a suburb here after she discovered that a coming vacation to Somalia would include a sacred rite of passage: the cutting of her genitalia. In Guinea, a New Yorker escaped to the American Embassy after an aunt told her that her family trip would involve genital cutting. And in Seattle, at least one physician said parents had sent girls back to Somalia to undergo cutting.

headline: New York City Hotel Workers’ Contract May Grow More Lucrative
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: Unionized hotel employees have just been offered an additional series of raises that would lift a maid’s annual pay to nearly $70,000 in 10 years.
lead_paragraph: Workers may be protesting against low wages all around the country, but unionized hotel employees in New York City are not sharing the pain. They have just been offered an additional series of raises that would lift a maid’s annual pay to nearly $70,000 in 10 years.

headline: 3-0 Hole Rangers Inhabit? Only 5 of 320 Teams Have Overcome It
abstract: While just 1.6 percent of teams from the four major sports have rallied from a 3-0 deficit to win a series, the N.H.L. has experienced a slightly better victory rate of 2.3 percent.
lead_paragraph: Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault was subdued and downcast Tuesday, like most of his players, standing on the brink of elimination, peering grimly into the abyss.

headline: L.I.R.R. Popularity Led to Crush After the Belmont
abstract: Far more fans took the train to the Belmont than railroad officials had predicted, prompting the railroad to summon extra service for the crush at the typically little-used station.
lead_paragraph: A little over three weeks ago, the Long Island Rail Road had a lot of money riding on a horse race in Baltimore.

headline: Exhausted and Bereft, Iraqi Soldiers Quit Fight
abstract: More soldiers are deserting the Iraqi Army, turning the tide of the war and fragmenting an institution that was supposed to provide a common sense of citizenship.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The infantryman and his colleagues were already worn down after six months of fighting militants in western Iraq, men flush with weapons and zeal. Army commanders had no answer for the daily deadly ambushes and no broader strategy for prevailing in the longer war.

headline: Help for Referees, in a Can
abstract: A referee can spray what looks like shaving cream at the spot where a free kick should be taken before pacing off the 10 yards where a wall will form.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Even casual soccer fans may already be familiar with the sport’s infamous “magic spray,” the ubiquitous mist that team trainers use on seemingly every type of injury to help stricken — or, as they are occasionally known, faking — players recover from grave maladies without missing a single kick.

headline: Eric Cantor Aside, Immigration Is Unlikely to Dominate Politics
abstract: There is a long history of immigration affecting primaries and local elections without dictating national ones.
lead_paragraph: Eric Cantor’s defeat will most likely lead to a round of speculation about the dominant role that immigration may play in the midterm elections and the 2016 presidential campaign. But you should view that speculation with a somewhat skeptical eye, because immigration has rarely determined the outcome of national elections.

headline: Netflix Orders New Children’s Show Based on ‘Magic School Bus’
abstract: “The Magic School Bus 360°” is part of the company’s expansion in children’s programming. The new show will begin streaming in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Continuing the expansion of its original content for children, Netflix has ordered a new series based on Scholastic Media’s “Magic School Bus,” the long-running television series that encouraged young people to pursue science.

headline: A Troubled Son (or Is He Wicked?) Is Just the Start of a Family’s Trouble
abstract: Nancy Harris’s “Our New Girl,” presented by the Atlantic Theater Company, is about a well-off London family with many domestic pressures.
lead_paragraph: Your sympathies are constantly shifting as you watch “Our New Girl,” a drama by the Irish-born writer Nancy Harris that cross-pollinates two very different genres. On the one hand, Ms. Harris’s London-set play, which opened at the Atlantic Theater Company’s smaller stage on Tuesday night, is a serious study of a well-heeled but harassed contemporary woman trying to keep her marriage and family from fraying. At the same time, Ms. Harris stocks her play with the classic elements of a thriller: a sullen child who may harbor violent impulses, a comely nanny who may not be as innocent as she appears.

headline: Athena’s Counterpart
abstract: Ian Livengood waves proudly at us.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — There is absolutely nothing wrong with this puzzle. It is a light-hearted and amusing tribute to June 14’s Flag Day holiday, and Ian Livengood’s puzzle offers us a chance to identify the prominent features of the flags of four countries. So far, so good.

headline: Former Ambassador to Syria Urges Increasing Arms Supply to Moderate Rebels
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Robert S. Ford, who resigned in February, said more weapons to the moderate Syrian rebels would increase the opposition’s leverage in peace talks and combat the rise of extremist groups.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Robert S. Ford’s misgivings about the Obama administration’s policy toward Syria became so great last summer that he sought to leave his post as the senior United States envoy for Syria.

headline: Careening Into a Bottomless Vortex
abstract: “The Village Bike,” Penelope Skinner’s play at the Lucille Lortel Theater, centers on a lonely pregnant woman whose growing obsession with sex takes her and other characters to dark places.
lead_paragraph: Greta Gerwig turns out to be the perfect person to ride right over the edge of a cliff with. Now don’t say you haven’t been warned. Because over the cliff is where this surprising actress will have taken you by the end of “The Village Bike,” the genuinely daring new play by Penelope Skinner that opened on Tuesday night at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

headline: Eric Cantor’s Voting Record: Angering Allies Is Part of the Job
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Although generally taking a conservative line, as a member of the House leadership he has sometimes cast votes that made his party’s right wing unhappy.
lead_paragraph: As majority leader, Eric Cantor was charged with running the House and electing his Republican colleagues. The tension between the two caused him to schedule, and to vote for, some legislation that angered the conservative base.

headline: No Body Is Found, but a Man Is Charged With Murder
abstract: In an unusual case like that of Etan Patz, Bronx authorities accuse Nasean Bonie of killing Ramona Moore, his wife’s tenant, who vanished in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Ramona Moore chatted with a neighbor outside their Bronx homes one July day in 2012. As the story goes, she was eating a mango, and when she saw that her neighbor wanted one, too, she went inside to get one. The neighbor never saw her again.

headline: Coast Cleared by Others, W.N.B.A. Finally Finds Its Gay Pride
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Basketball', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Transgender and Transsexual']
abstract: Now that the coast is clear, the W.N.B.A., which has been around for nearly two decades, has decided to publicly embrace its gay fans. The gesture deserves two slow claps, considering how long it took.
lead_paragraph: When Brittney Griner, the No. 1 pick in the 2013 W.N.B.A. draft, heard about her league’s new campaign to market games to people who are lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender, she said, “What are we going to have, T-shirts, shoes?”

headline: Emergency Housing Unit Is Unveiled in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Mobile Homes and Trailers', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: In an attempt to improve its disaster assistance services, the City of New York unveiled a prototype for temporary living structures. The units will be studied by the city’s Office of Emergency Management for the next year.
lead_paragraph: In the months after Hurricane Sandy, thousands of New Yorkers faced a daunting search for temporary housing. The supply of vacant apartments ran dry. Cramped hotel rooms prolonged a sense of limbo. Many people just stayed put in dank, waterlogged houses.

headline: Elodie Lauten, Who Wove Opera From Allen Ginsberg’s Poetry, Dies at 63
abstract: Ms. Lauter’s compositions defied handy categorization but were performed widely in New York and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Elodie Lauten, an American composer known for her operatic setting of the work of Allen Ginsberg, died on June 3 in Manhattan. She was 63.

headline: Success Academy Seeks 14 More Charter Schools in New York City
abstract: The city may have to house the new schools or help pay for their space.
lead_paragraph: A charter school network that recently clashed with Mayor Bill de Blasio over the use of public school space is seeking to vastly expand its footprint in New York City, announcing on Tuesday that it wants to open 14 more schools over the next two years.

headline: Kidd and Fisher Carve New Niche for Veterans: Coach’s Office
abstract: Why would any veteran player known for leadership qualities and a strong understanding of the game not at least consider the accelerated path to coaching now that Jason Kidd and Derek Fisher have landed lucrative contracts?
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — In the middle of a championship series that has featured several senior N.B.A. citizens, including San Antonio’s 38-year-old spiritual and strategic centerpiece, Tim Duncan, the hiring on Tuesday of Derek Fisher, 39, to coach the Knicks did not go unnoticed.

headline: Bob Welch, Pitching Ace and Prototype for Today’s Power Arms, Dies at 57
abstract: Welch overcame alcoholism in becoming one the hardest throwers of his era, winning a Cy Young Award and pitching in four World Series for the Dodgers and the A’s.
lead_paragraph: Bob Welch, a flame-throwing right-hander for the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Oakland A’s who overcame alcoholism to win 211 games, including 27 in 1990, a single-season total no other pitcher has reached in the past 40 years, died on Monday in Seal Beach, Calif. He was 57.

headline: The Circus That Doesn’t Leave Town
keywords: ['Circuses', 'ACROBATS AND ACROBATICS', 'Theater', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Juggling and Jugglers']
abstract: Circus acts have infused almost every kind of entertainment option in the city, and demand for circus-related services is surging.
lead_paragraph: The circus is in town, but this big tent has nothing to do with Ringling Brothers or trained lions and elephants. Instead it is the carnival theme popping up across New York City in unexpected ways and in unexpected places: acrobats twirling over patrons in downtown nightclubs, men in leotards juggling mud at $475 dinner theater shows in Midtown, gyms offering “circus yoga,” school children learning about clowning in different cultures, and fire breathers spitting flames onto tin ceilings at bars in Brooklyn.

headline: Michael Schmidt, 68, Maker of Photographic Narratives, Dies
abstract: Mr. Schmidt worked in black and white and made painstaking studies of subjects like the food industry and the life of his native city, Berlin.
lead_paragraph: The German photographer Michael Schmidt was known for presenting stark black-and-white images in dramatic sequence, to powerful emotional effect. A recent project was a penetrating tour of the global food industry that included arresting images of factory farms, a cow’s bulging udder, supermarkets and a single apple. It won an international award just days before Mr. Schmidt’s death on May 24 in Berlin. He was 68.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 10, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Overlooked in Mets’ Focus on the Future, a Nice Victory
abstract: While a 6-2 win against the Brewers might have been an important measuring point during a more successful season, pregame chatter on team personnel was the dominant storyline.
lead_paragraph: A certain inevitability hangs over the Mets. Once the season begins to crumble, the future rapidly becomes the present. When the Mets arrived home Sunday after an 11-game trip, in the middle of a six-game losing streak, they appeared to have reached that point more quickly than they had expected.

headline: Bank of America and the Financial Crisis
abstract: Bank of America, including Countrywide, issued about $640 billion in mortgage-backed securities before the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America, including Countrywide, issued about $640 billion in mortgage-backed securities before the financial crisis.

headline: ISIS: Behind the Group Overrunning Iraq
abstract: Background on the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the Islamist group that gained control of the second-largest city in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Background on the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the Islamist group that gained control of the second-largest city in Iraq.

headline: Cantor’s Loss a Bad Omen for Moderates
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Conservatives who have fueled showdowns on issues like immigration and raising the federal debt ceiling are likely to be emboldened by Eric Cantor’s shocking defeat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Republican leadership, so solid in its opposition to President Obama, was torn apart Tuesday by the defeat of its most influential conservative voice, Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader. His demise will reverberate all the way to the speaker’s chair, pull the top echelons of the House even further to the right and most likely doom any ambitious legislation, possibly through the next presidential election.

headline: Tanaka Follows Iwakuma, Then Sets Himself Apart
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka, the Yankees rookie starter, soaked up anything he could gather from the Mariners’ veteran Hisashi Iwakuma, eight years his elder, when they were teammates in Japan.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When Masahiro Tanaka went from high school into the Japanese professional leagues with the Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles in 2007, his mentor was the team’s ace and best player, Hisashi Iwakuma.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Recap: It’s a Turducken
abstract: Lester has learned a thing or two from his tormenter.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 9: Gasp. Lester Nygaard’s transformation is stunningly complete.

headline: The Downward Ramp
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The jobs crisis has begun to affect even highly skilled college graduates, who are taking jobs that once went to people with fewer skills.
lead_paragraph: With the bursting of the tech bubble at the start of the 21st century, two decades of growth at the high end of the job market — once the province of college graduates with strong cognitive abilities — came to an abrupt halt, according to detailed studies of employment and investment patterns by three Canadian economists. We are still feeling the ramifications.

headline: The Franchising of Architecture
abstract: As leading architects race to put their visual signatures on every nook and cranny of the world, one critic wonders whether globalization is really such a good thing.
lead_paragraph: As leading architects race to put their visual signatures on every nook and cranny of the world, one critic wonders whether globalization is really such a good thing.

headline: Overestimating How Hard We Exercise
abstract: What counts as “moderate” exercise? Many of us think we’re doing more of it than we really are..
lead_paragraph: Most of us know that moderate exercise is good for us. But surprisingly few of us know what moderate exercise means, research shows. An instructive new study found that many of us underestimate how hard we should exercise to achieve maximum health benefits, and overestimate how vigorously we are actually working out.

headline: New York Comic Con Branching Out From Javits Center
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'Comic-Con (Convention)', 'Javits, Jacob K, Convention Center (NYC)']
abstract: A city-wide festival, “New York Super Week,” will be held in conjunction with New York Comic Con in October.
lead_paragraph: Its name may emphasize comic books, but New York Comic Con at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in October also celebrates film, television and video games. ReedPop, which organizes the show, is making that appreciation of all things pop culture more official by declaring Oct. 3-12 “New York Super Week,” a citywide festival that will include gaming events, lectures, concerts, comedy shows and more.

headline: Word of the Day | transition
abstract: This word has appeared in 9,040 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: transition •\tran(t)-ˈsi-shən, tran-ˈzi-\• noun and verb

headline: The Old Is New Again at E3 for Sony and Microsoft
abstract: The games business is increasingly experimenting with how to get its customers to pay for a game, and then to pay again later for what is essentially the same title with some additional perks
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Many music and movie fans of a certain age are accustomed to buying the same works again and again as technologies change.

headline: Spurs Set Blazing Pace and Hang On Late
abstract: San Antonio, which took a 2-1 series lead, set finals records by shooting 86.7 percent in the first quarter and 75.8 percent in the first half.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Within minutes of taking the court at American Airlines Arena on Tuesday night, the San Antonio Spurs demolished a 23-year-old record for offensive efficiency.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Spike TV) GUYS CHOICE 2014 This awards ceremony, taped on Saturday at Sony Pictures Studios in Culver City, Calif., honors the things men like most, as voted by viewers. Sandra Bullock (above left) is celebrated for a Decade of Hotness; Matthew McConaughey (above right) is Guy of the Year; Kevin Hart is King of Comedy; and Rihanna is the Most Desirable Woman.

headline: Members of Congress React to Cantor’s Defeat Via Twitter
abstract: Among those reacting on Twitter to the defeat of Representative Eric Cantor were a number of his colleagues in the House of Representatives and Senate.
lead_paragraph: Representative Eric Cantor’s defeat in Tuesday night’s primary election in Virginia was a major jolt to congressional politics. Among those reacting on Twitter to the defeat of the House majority leader were a number of his colleagues in the House of Representatives and Senate.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 11, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 11, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “The results tonight will move the party further to the right, which will marginalize us further as a national party.”

headline: Gabriel Kolko, Left-Leaning Historian of U.S. Policy, Dies at 81
abstract: Professor Kolko, a prolific author, argued that business interests, rather than public priorities, have long been the essential driver of government action.
lead_paragraph: Gabriel Kolko, an influential left-leaning historian who argued that American domestic and international policies have long been driven more by the interests of big business than by the interests of the people, died on May 19 at his home in Amsterdam. He was 81.

headline: Jeter Starts Two Rallies and Ellsbury Caps a Victory
abstract: Jacoby Ellsbury’s run-scoring single on an 0-2 pitch in the eighth drove in Derek Jeter — who also singled and scored in the first — to lift the Yankees in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Derek Jeter played his first major league game just a few hundred yards outside the walls of Safeco Field, in the long since demolished Kingdome.

headline: Fall of an Apparatchik
abstract: Eric Cantor, retire in peace.
lead_paragraph: Wow — Eric Cantor lost his primary, by a large margin. Amazing.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Morning Views
lead_paragraph: Noncompete clauses are harmful to both employees and “the economy as a whole,” writes The New York Times editorial board. While the board recognizes these policies have reasonable utility in deterring upper management from defecting to competitors, the restrictions can be needlessly hampering to lower-wage employees who statistically earn more money over the years the more professional freedom they enjoy. More broadly, The Times points to studies showing that gratuitously stringent noncompete policies stifle entrepreneurship.

headline: Beijing Police Detain Student Over Tiananmen Tweet
abstract: The student was arrested after she posted a Twitter message suggesting that a method for sending spam text messages might also be used to rally public awareness of the Tiananmen anniversary.
lead_paragraph: The Beijing authorities have detained a woman linked with a Twitter posting suggesting that a method for sending spam text messages might also be used to rally public awareness of the 25th anniversary of the deadly crackdown on the Tiananmen protest movement.

headline: Paul Takes On Clinton Over Her ‘Dead Broke’ Comments
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'Books and Literature', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky invited Hillary Rodham Clinton to see what poverty is like for the people of Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – Senator Rand Paul dismissed comments from Hillary Rodham Clinton that she and her husband were struggling to make ends meet after they left the White House, saying they were “disconnected.”

headline: Traffic Snarls in Europe as Taxi Drivers Protest Against Uber
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: The start-up that digitally links passengers and freelance drivers has expanded beyond the United States to cities including London, Paris and Berlin — all of them the sites of Wednesday’s protests.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Europe’s taxi drivers on Wednesday picked a fight with Uber, an increasingly popular smartphone car-paging service, and dared consumers to choose sides.

abstract: Map of the results and charts of his margins in previous elections.
lead_paragraph: Map of the results and charts of his margins in previous elections.

headline: In American Journalist’s Photographs, Rare Glimpse of India’s First Prime Minister
abstract: Photographs taken by an American journalist in 1952 offer a rare glimpse of then-prime minister Jawaharlal Nehru and his daughter Indira Gandhi on vacation in Kashmir.
lead_paragraph: In January 1952, Margaret Lee Weil, a 30-year-old journalist and photographer, arrived in India to pursue her dream of catching a glimpse of the man whom she had “hero-worshipped from 10,000 miles away all these years,” according to a particularly effusive diary entry.

headline: Emirates Cancels Major Order From Airbus
abstract: The Persian Gulf carrier decided not to purchase 70 of the European plane maker’s A350 jets, currently valued at more than $21 billion.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Airbus suffered a major blow on Wednesday to its latest commercial jet program after one of its largest customers, Emirates Airline, said it had decided to cancel a multibillion-dollar order for 70 long-range planes.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 11, 2014
abstract: Can you calculate how long it will take for student loan debt to reach $10 trillion?
lead_paragraph: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Sunni Militants Drive Iraqi Army Out of Mosul
abstract: How does the conflict in Iraq connect to the civil war raging in Syria?
lead_paragraph: In “Sunni Militants Drive Iraqi Army Out of Mosul,” Suadad Al-Salhy, Kareem Fahim and Rick Gladstone report on how Iraq’s second-biggest city was seized in a rapid assault by insurgents.

headline: Iraq Militants, Pushing South, Aim at Capital
abstract: After seizing control of Mosul, Sunni militants occupied the key oil refining town of Baiji and seized the city of Tikrit, security officials and residents said.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Sunni militants consolidated and extended their control over northern Iraq on Wednesday, seizing Tikrit, the hometown of Saddam Hussein, threatening the strategic oil refining town of Baiji and pushing south toward Baghdad, their ultimate target, Iraqi sources said.

headline: Mac and Cheese for Fancy People
abstract: Lamb gets a pasta garnish straight out of Escoffier.
lead_paragraph: An old hardcover copy of “The Escoffier Cook Book” sits in the library of The New York Times, battered and dog-eared, classified on its front endpaper by someone with exquisite penmanship as a book to be shelved amid titles dedicated to “Foreign Foods.”

headline: There’s a True Story Behind ‘The Mule’: The Sinaloa Cartel’s 90-Year-Old Drug Mule
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Drug Cartels', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine']
abstract: Is Leo Sharp a senile day-lily farmer who was taken advantage of by drug smugglers? Or did he know exactly what he was getting into?
lead_paragraph: The Lincoln pickup truck with Iowa plates was hurtling down Interstate 94, headed for Detroit. A dozen D.E.A. officers in unmarked cars were scattered along a 70-mile stretch, from Kalamazoo to Jackson, Mich. From on-ramps and overpasses, they watched traffic flash by as they tried to spot the truck. They believed it was carrying a major shipment of cocaine.

headline: Seeing Red in the Gene Pool
abstract: Redhead deposits aren’t wanted at the world’s largest sperm bank, leading a photographer to document gingers in all their blazing, freckled varieties.
lead_paragraph: When I was young, and my little sister a bit younger, we went on a trip to China. We were visiting its famous Great Wall when, to our puzzlement, Chinese tourists began queuing up — ignoring the thousands-miles-long wonder of the world to photograph two arguably lesser wonders of the world: my sister and me.

headline: Does the Way Your Classroom Is Decorated Affect Your Learning?
abstract: If you were a teacher trying to create a positive learning environment for students, how would you decorate your classroom?
lead_paragraph: A new study tries to determine whether there might be a correlation between how a room is decorated and kindergartners’ learning. The researchers wanted to know if too many decorations could actually be distracting or overstimulating for young minds. But similar questions could be asked about how classroom environment might influence older students’ academic performance as well.

headline: Where ISIS Is Gaining Control in Iraq and Syria
abstract: The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria — an organization once part of Al Qaeda — has effectively gained control of large swaths of Iraq and Syria over the past year.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria — an organization once part of Al Qaeda — has effectively gained control of large swaths of Iraq and Syria over the past year.

headline: Lufthansa Trims Profit Forecast for 2 Years
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Company Reports']
abstract: As carriers across Europe face more competition, the airline also has to cope with the effect of a three-day strike in April.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Lufthansa on Wednesday sharply reduced its profit forecasts for the next two years, citing slower than expected recovery in demand for its passenger and cargo services, as well as the fallout from widespread strikes earlier this year.

headline: Hagel Defends Bergdahl Trade as a Part of Waging War
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Prisoners of War']
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel was the first high-level official to publicly face lawmakers about a prisoner swap that has angered many in both parties.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A defiant Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Wednesday defended the prisoner exchange that freed Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl after years of captivity with the Taliban, telling skeptical lawmakers that the decision had been kept secret from Congress because leaks could have scuttled the deal or increased risks to the soldier before the swap.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today: Not on My Home Ice
abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: Do or die for the Rangers, more gloomy weather, and no-kill day in animal shelters.
lead_paragraph: Good morning to you on this dreary Wednesday.

headline: Beijing’s ‘White Paper’ Sets Off a Firestorm in Hong Kong
abstract: As China asserts its authority over Hong Kong, local democracy groups cry foul and warn of protests if universal suffrage is not allowed.
lead_paragraph: In December 1984, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China signed a document in Beijing pledging to restore Hong Kong to Chinese control. One of the basic policies laid out in the declaration was that while Hong Kong would be “directly under the authority of” Beijing, it would “enjoy a high degree of autonomy except in foreign and defense affairs.”

headline: Beacon, N.Y.: Quaint City Rediscovered
abstract: A small city hugging the Hudson in southwestern Dutchess County is catching the attention of budget-minded New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Hats, carpets, baby carriages, shower doors, cookie cartons: These are among the many products made, at one point or another, in Beacon, a small city hugging the Hudson in southwestern Dutchess County. Because of them, said Clara Lou Gould, who was the mayor from 1990 to 2007, “people with expertise in different categories would come to do different jobs” and stay on, resulting in a population representing as many as 50 nationalities.

headline: Campaign to Crack Down on Fringe Sects in China Worries Mainstream Churches
keywords: ['Religious Cults', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: The campaign was prompted by the murder of a woman at a McDonald’s that horrified the nation and was attributed to adherents of a religious group.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Last month, as she waited for her husband and 7-year-old son at a McDonald’s in the eastern Chinese province of Shandong, Wu Shuoyan was approached by members of a Christian sect who were on an aggressive recruitment drive.

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft Challenges Federal Warrant for Data Stored Overseas
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Data Storage', 'Privacy', 'Search and Seizure']
abstract: The objection is believed to be the first time a corporation has challenged a domestic search warrant seeking digital information abroad, and it has attracted the concern of privacy groups.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft is challenging the authority of federal prosecutors to force the giant technology company to hand over a customer’s email stored in a data center in Ireland, Steve Lohr reports.

headline: Tax Breaks for Apple and Starbucks Investigated by E.U.
abstract: The European Union has begun an investigation into how low-tax nations like Ireland have helped large multinationals like Apple and Starbucks reduce their tax bills by billions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union officials have been pushing some countries to plug corporate tax loopholes for years to help bolster government coffers in an era of shrinking public budgets and weak economic growth.

headline: An Artist Fills Galleries With Emptiness
abstract: In Marina Abramovic’s latest show, at the Serpentine Gallery in London, nothing is everything.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “You look suspicious,” Marina Abramovic said to an older couple standing to the side of a room in the Serpentine Gallery here on Thursday. The couple looked, well, suspicious, as around them people contemplated panels of bright primary colors, or lay on the floor, eyes closed. Ms. Abramovic took them by the hand, gently asked them to close their eyes, and led them away, walking with a slow, measured tread.

headline: Banks Fear Missing Collateral in China
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Commodities', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The authorities are investigating loans based on collateral of metals at a Chinese port, with implications for Western banks and the Chinese credit market.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:45 p.m. | Large banks and trading firms are frantically trying to determine whether they have fallen victim to a suspected commodities fraud emanating from the giant Qingdao Port in northeast China.

headline: The Father’s Day Audit
abstract: Trying to build a business and raise a family is not about balance. It’s a tug of war in the mud, with all the screaming and grunting and sweating and injuries.
lead_paragraph: At the end of each year, I get my financial statements so I can assess how my business did. And each Father’s Day I take a moment to think about how I did over the previous year as a father.

headline: Your Personality Type, Defined by the Internet
abstract: We know that we are watched online, our feelings scanned by Google and Facebook to figure out what next to sell us. Now we can get a feel for what that looks like, thanks to a linguistic analysis tool released by a start-up. The results, at least in one writer’s case, are bemusing.
lead_paragraph: In some ways, the Internet has become a game of “type and be typed.” Now you can play it at home, too.

headline: Report Links Wen Family to Cambridge Professorship
abstract: The daughter of the former Chinese prime minister Wen Jiabao is behind a charity that endowed a university post in Chinese development studies, according to a report in the British newspaper The Daily Telegraph.
lead_paragraph: A foundation that endowed a professorship at the University of Cambridge is linked to the family of the former Chinese prime minister Wen Jiabao, according to a report in The Daily Telegraph.

headline: Weighing the Risks of Investing in Energy Companies
abstract: Some fund managers are skeptical about fossil fuel companies as long-term investments as nations move toward tougher rules on emissions.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Norway’s economy is highly dependent on oil and gas production, yet the Nordic country’s largest private pension fund manager, Storebrand, worries about the risks of investing in companies that extract fossil fuels. Figuring that tighter regulations on carbon emissions will emerge in the coming years in an effort to combat climate change, Storebrand has decided not to invest in businesses that it believes will be hurt most by those new rules: coal companies and large producers of oil from tar sands.

headline: Once Snubbed, David Brat Turns the Tables

abstract: Mr. Brat’s ability to connect with voters and the perception that Eric Cantor was not engaged in his district combined to deliver one of the most stunning upsets in modern political history.

headline: Is America’s Economy Stuck in the Doldrums? The Case for Optimism
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Corporate Taxes']

headline: Morning Agenda: An Impasse in Bank of America Settlement
abstract: Bank of America’s mortgage settlement is said to be deadlocked. | The manager of Harvard’s endowment plans to step down. | A.I.G. has named its next chief executive. | The banking industry is trying to adapt to stricter regulations and low market volatility.
lead_paragraph: BANK OF AMERICA SETTLEMENT DEADLOCKED  |  Bank of America and the Justice Department have reached an impasse in negotiations over a multibillion-dollar settlement, raising the stakes in an investigation into the bank’s role at the center of the mortgage crisis, DealBook’s Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Ben Protess and Michael Corkery write. The talks stalled on Monday after the bank’s latest offer, at more than $12 billion, was said to be far short of prosecutors’ demands. The Justice Department has sought a settlement worth roughly $17 billion, which would be the largest payout by any bank to date.

headline: Broadway ‘Raisin’ Recoups
abstract: The revival of “A Raisin in the Sun,” which won three Tony Awards, has recouped its entire $4.25 million capitalization.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway revival of “A Raisin in the Sun,” the biggest box-office hit play of the spring theater season, has recouped its entire $4.25 million capitalization. The producers made the announcement on Tuesday, two days after Lorraine Hansberry’s classic reaped success at the 2014 Tony Awards. “Raisin” won for best play revival, best director of a play (Kenny Leon), and best featured actress in a play (Sophie Okonedo); its three Tonys were the most for any play in the 2013-14 season. The critically acclaimed production, which stars Denzel Washington and LaTanya Richardson Jackson, is scheduled to end its run on Sunday.

headline: Bringing Women to the Table to Address Sexual Violence

lead_paragraph: In war zones, rape is a weapon. We cannot claim to be serious about stopping war crimes if we do nothing to prevent and punish these heinous acts – and if women are not part of the solution every step of the way.

headline: In G.O.P., Far Right Is Too Moderate
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Having unleashed the most destructive political impulses of his party, Eric Cantor finally fell victim to them.
lead_paragraph: The forces of political nihilism not only remain alive and well within the Republican Party, but they are on the rise. Witness the way they shook Washington on Tuesday by removing from power Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, who had been one of the most implacable opponents to the reform of immigration, health care and taxation. His crime (in addition to complacent campaigning)? He was occasionally obliged, as a leader, to take a few minimalist steps toward governing, like raising the debt ceiling and ending a ruinous shutdown.

headline: After Eric Cantor
abstract: On the possible implications of a shocking primary defeat.
lead_paragraph: During the government shutdown last year, I wrote a series of posts trying to explain why anyone interested in a healthy conservatism, a viable and serious Republican Party, should be somewhat ambivalent about the fight between the party’s insurgents and its congressional leadership. The insurgents pushed for the shutdown and the establishment resisted it, which meant that on the major question of the moment that establishment was right and the insurgents were not only wrong but utterly disconnected from reality. But in the bigger picture, the insurgents’ critique of the establishment’s lazy, K Street-oriented, “repeal the Medical device tax!” approach to policymaking was quite frequently correct, and it was noteworthy that some of the most prominent figures supporting the shutdown (Mike Lee, most notably, but also Marco Rubio and Rand Paul) were also sources of much of the party’s post-2012 policy innovation. So the post-shutdown scenario favored by many centrist observers in the media, in which John Boehner and Mitch McConnell just found a way to crush the grassroots and bring their base to heel, was not really a long-term solution to the G.O.P.’s lack of vision and seriousness. Instead — somehow, somewhere — the party would need to find leadership that could channel grassroots populism into a constructive agenda, without being captured by that populism’s follies and excesses.

headline: 5 Accused of Luring Men to Strip Clubs for a Night They Wouldn’t Remember

lead_paragraph: It seemed, at the time, to be an unlikely story.

headline: An Honest Answer From David Brat
abstract: The Republican outsider who unseated Eric Cantor did not take a position on the minimum wage Wednesday. Then again, most economists can’t find a consensus on the issue.
lead_paragraph: When an MSNBC interviewer asked David Brat, the economics professor at Randolph-Macon College who toppled Eric Cantor in a primary challenge Tuesday, whether he opposed the minimum wage, he responded on Wednesday, “Um, I don’t have a well-crafted response on that one.”

headline: So, Who, Exactly, Is David Brat, the Guy Who Beat Eric Cantor?
abstract: “God acted through people on my behalf,” David Brat told Fox News after his primary upset.
lead_paragraph: I’m not the only one asking that question this morning after David Brat, an economics professor from Randolph-Macon College, defeated the House Majority Leader, Eric Cantor, in the primary in the 7th District of Virginia — with a tiny campaign budget and an unlimited willingness to represent Mr. Cantor’s record as too moderate for the Republican Party.

headline: In Kyoto, Tradition Meets Today
abstract: Machiya, traditional Japanese townhouses, are resurfacing as places for travelers to shop and sleep.
lead_paragraph: Accommodations rarely get more atmospheric than this: a 100-plus-year-old Kyoto townhouse that once housed maiko, or apprentice geisha, now thoroughly renovated to 21st-century standards trimmed in 1,000-year-old temple beams, antique art and tatami mats. On the banks of the Kamogawa River, the two-bedroom named  Kamogawa-tei (Kiyamachi Street; 81-75-354-7770) is one of six traditional townhouses known as machiya renovated by Aoi Kyoto Stay.

headline: Peter Mayle's Marseille
abstract: The writer talks about where he first went to learn about the Mediterranean city and names some of his favorite spots.
lead_paragraph: Provence, that languid, lavender-covered stretch of France along the Mediterranean, is the region most fans associate with Peter Mayle. His 1989 memoir, “A Year in Provence,” about restoring an 18th-century farmhouse in the Luberon, became such a blockbuster it spawned a veritable franchise of Provençal travelogues, food guides and novels. Indeed, Mr. Mayle said he and his wife had to leave the region for several years just to take a break from eager fans turning up at his doorstep (and from his detractors grumbling about those tourists disturbing the area’s tranquillity).

headline: Britain at the 2014 Venice Architecture Biennale
abstract: Organizers of the exhibition “A Clockwork Jerusalem” discuss the historic influences that shaped their presentation of modern British architecture. The Biennale opened on June 7 and will run until November 23.
lead_paragraph: Organizers of the exhibition “A Clockwork Jerusalem” discuss the historic influences that shaped their presentation of modern British architecture. The Biennale opened on June 7 and will run until November 23.

headline: Lasagna with Red Chard Satisfies a Meat-Loving Family
abstract: As they enter their second week of adding two vegetarian meals weekly, a meat-loving family finds a lasagna they love, and prepares to try a Big Bowl with black beans, greens, avocado and salsa fresca.
lead_paragraph: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist and cookbook author, is working with the Ruder family (Renee, her husband Chris, and their three daughters, ages 11, 9 and 7) to help these meat lovers adopt a plan of eating two vegetarian meals a week without feeling deprived — and to take advantage of a C.S.A. — a community-supported agriculture program — basket often filled with foods to which they are unaccustomed. This week, the family was traveling, so they took their new plan with them.

headline: The World’s Game
abstract: A collection of images of fans and amateur players from around the world illustrates how everyday people embrace the spirit of soccer.
lead_paragraph: A collection of images of fans and amateur players from around the world illustrates how everyday people embrace the spirit of soccer.

headline: Chappelle Clears Up the Mystery — Sort Of
abstract: The comedian had an answer for those who wondered why he left his Comedy Central show in 2005.
lead_paragraph: Corporate bullying. Drugs. The illuminati. They have all played roles in the multitude of wild theories to explain why Dave Chappelle left his hit sketch show on Comedy Central in 2005. But on “Late Show With David Letterman” on Tuesday night, Mr. Chappelle offered grist for a new take on the controversy. “Technically, I never quit,” he joked. “I am seven years late for work.”

headline: Hagel on Bergdahl Trade at House Hearing
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel testified on the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl before the House Armed Services Committee.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel testified on the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl before the House Armed Services Committee.

headline: Egyptian Leader Apologizes to Victim of Sexual Assault in Tahrir Square
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: In a televised visit to the hospital bed of a woman assaulted in Tahrir Square, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi declared his commitment to combat sexual violence against women in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt apologized on Wednesday to the victim of a mass sexual assault that took place in a crowd celebrating his election, declaring in a televised visit to her hospital bed that he urged every soldier, police officer and “chivalrous man” to eradicate such abuse.

headline: Google Streamlines Its Tools for Small Businesses
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Small Business', 'Social Media']
abstract: The company said that many of the tools included in Google Pages and Google Places were consolidated and simplified.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Google announced the introduction of Google My Business, a streamlined platform for small businesses to use its tools. The platform allows businesses to update their information, add photos, share news and see reviews, all in one place.

headline: Alibaba Buys Rest of the Mobile Browser UCWeb
abstract: The Chinese e-commerce giant, continuing an acquisition spree before its initial public offering, forms closer ties to a potentially important partner in the mobile sector.
lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group’s coming initial public offering has done little to dent its appetite for acquisitions. The Chinese e-commerce giant announced yet another takeover on Wednesday.

headline: Image of the Day: June 11
abstract: Parupalli Kashyap, an Indian badminton player, hitting a return shot while playing against Riichi Takeshita of Japan during a first round match in Tokyo, Japan.
