headline: Potent Voices of Conservative Media Propelled Cantor Opponent
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'News and News Media']
abstract: David Brat’s out-of-nowhere victory in the Virginia Republican primary was due in large part to an unusual alignment of media figures like the radio host Laura Ingraham.
lead_paragraph: If Eric Cantor needed evidence that his political career was in real trouble, all he had to do was look outside his living room window one night last week. At a stately country club about half a mile from his home in the affluent Richmond suburb of Glen Allen, so many people had come to see the radio talk show host Laura Ingraham stump for Mr. Cantor’s opponent in the Republican primary, David Brat, that the overflow parking nearly reached his driveway.

headline: Chrissie Hynde, Minus the Pretenders
abstract: The singer on the death of rock ’n’ roll and finally going solo.
lead_paragraph: The Pretenders’ frontwoman talks to Dave Itzkoff about inadvertently going solo for her new album, “Stockholm,” John McEnroe’s chops on guitar and her disgust with award shows.

headline: Versailles Revisited
abstract: Landscape architect Louis Benech and artist Jean-Michel Othoniel discuss the inspiration for their redesign of the Water Theater at Versailles and how trees have memories.
lead_paragraph: Landscape architect Louis Benech and artist Jean-Michel Othoniel discuss the inspiration for their redesign of the Water Theater at Versailles and how trees have memories.

headline: In Our Pages: June 12
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A trio which smuggled goods between Belgium and France is caught in 1939; Mandela is arrested in 1964.

headline: An Ancient Fish
abstract: Metaspriggina swam the oceans more than 500 million years ago. Now its fossils are helping scientists understand how our own biology developed.
lead_paragraph: Metaspriggina swam the oceans more than 500 million years ago. Now its fossils are helping scientists understand how our own biology developed.

headline: In Bid for Botox Maker, Valeant Defends Its Record on Research
abstract: In rejecting Valeant’s latest offer, Allergan trumpeted its research. Valeant, responding on Wednesday, said that most successful pharmaceutical innovation comes from smaller, more nimble competitors.
lead_paragraph: As it pursues a hostile takeover of Allergan, Valeant has reiterated time and again its belief that most pharmaceutical research and development doesn’t pay off.

headline: Goldman’s Blankfein Talks Energy and Politics
abstract: Goldman’s chief executive discussed the opportunities in natural gas drilling and pondered the political climate in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In a round of interviews this week, Lloyd Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, was eager to talk about natural gas drilling in advance of the bank’s energy summit, which began on Wednesday. But he was hesitant to throw his weight behind one of the most politically divisive issues in energy independence: the Keystone XL pipeline.

headline: Militants Storm Turkish Consulate in Iraqi City, Taking 49 People as Hostages
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Hostages']
abstract: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey held an emergency meeting with top security officials amid a diplomatic effort to free the hostages in Mosul.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish government reacted with alarm on Wednesday to the seizure of the country’s consul general and his staff by militants in Mosul, Iraq, vowing to retaliate if any of its citizens are wounded.

headline: The Cantor Upset | The Upshot Countdown
abstract: The Upshot’s Nate Cohn explains just why Eric Cantor’s primary defeat was such a surprise, and why Republicans can expect to hold on to that district in November.
lead_paragraph: The Upshot’s Nate Cohn explains just why Eric Cantor’s primary defeat was such a surprise, and why Republicans can expect to hold on to that district in November.

headline: Creating for Children, Without the Cutesy
abstract: The Scottish writer-performer Andy Manley returns to the New Victory Theater with a show aimed at the 8-and-older set about a close schoolyard friendship shattered by peer pressure.
lead_paragraph: The first show the Scottish theater artist Andy Manley brought to the New Victory Theater in Manhattan was “My House,” a mostly wordless solo piece co-starring a cardboard box and a wayward melon, designed for children 18 months to 3 years old. Next, he brought “White,” a beguiling, still largely nonverbal show about color and disorder, created for 2- to 4-year-olds.

headline: In Nature | The Gardener of Versailles
abstract: André Le Nôtre’s 17th-century masterpiece for Louis XIV has not been altered for centuries — until now. The renowned yet humble French landscape designer Louis Benech is reimagining the four-acre Water Theater, the Sun King’s favorite grove.
lead_paragraph: André Le Nôtre’s 17th-century masterpiece for Louis XIV has not been altered for centuries — until now. The renowned yet humble French landscape designer Louis Benech is reimagining the four-acre Water Theater, the Sun King’s favorite grove.

lead_paragraph: In 2002, Sherry Stewart Deutschmann quit her six-figure sales job at a Nashville company, cashed in her 401(k) and started a competing business.

headline: Before Army, P.O.W. Failed at Coast Guard Training
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Prisoners of War']
abstract: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl spent just short of a month in basic training with the United States Coast Guard in early 2006 before he was given an administrative discharge, military officials said.
lead_paragraph: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl spent four weeks in basic training with the United States Coast Guard in early 2006 before he was given an administrative discharge, military officials said Wednesday. The disclosure raised new questions about whether Sergeant Bergdahl should have been allowed to enlist in the Army two years later, and whether he had to be given a waiver to join either because he had previously washed out of boot camp or because of concerns about his emotional fitness.

headline: How Eric Cantor’s Defeat Could Hurt Republican Fund-Raising
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'Jews and Judaism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: He has been a prolific fund-raiser who has relationships with some donors other Republicans do not.
lead_paragraph: Eric Cantor’s primary defeat against David Brat on Tuesday means that House Republicans will lose one of their best fund-raisers, and a crucial link to some major donors the party is otherwise not close to.

headline: A Long-Ago Ancestor: A Little Fish, With Jaws to Come
abstract: Metaspriggina is two inches long and 505 million years old, and scientists recently uncovered an extraordinary cache of its fossils.
lead_paragraph: Half a billion years ago, a new study suggests, your ancestors may have looked like this:

abstract: Fighters of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, a magnet for militants from around the world, have a religious conviction and canny business sense.
lead_paragraph: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — The fighters with the Free Syrian Army were expecting an attack any day from the jihadists besieging the city of Minbej in war-torn Syria, fortifying their base, once a carpet factory, with concrete bomb-blast barriers.

abstract: And a study suggests that business owners may be better off not taking venture capital.

abstract: Ride-sharing services have the potential to change the way people get around cities — and could help lower emissions and free up space for housing.
lead_paragraph: With a near record-setting investment announced last week, the ride-sharing service Uber is the hottest, most valuable technology start-up on the planet. It is also one of the most controversial.

headline: F.B.I. Begins Criminal Inquiry in V.A. Scandal
abstract: The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said the bureau was looking into accusations that Department of Veterans Affairs officials had manipulated medical waiting lists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. has opened a criminal investigation into accusations that Department of Veterans Affairs officials manipulated medical waiting lists and delayed care for thousands of veterans, the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said Wednesday.

headline: G.M. Chief to Appear Before House Panel Once Again
abstract: Mary T. Barra of General Motors will testify next week along with the outsider who led the company’s inquiry into a fatal ignition-switch flaw.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of General Motors and the former prosecutor hired by the company to investigate why it failed to recognize a fatal defect in Chevrolet Cobalts and other small cars will testify before a House subcommittee next Wednesday.

headline: Morrissey Cancels American Tour, Citing Infection
abstract: Comments on a fan site linked to Morrissey suggested he was infected by a performer who was his opening act.
lead_paragraph: Morrissey has canceled the rest of his current American tour, including a performance scheduled for Barclays Center on June 21, because of a respiratory infection. The other canceled dates on the tour include concerts in Chicago; Flint, Mich.; Hershey, Pa.; Atlantic City and Baltimore.

headline: Ukraine and Russia Still Far Apart on Gas Deal
abstract: As the second day of talks broke down, President Vladimir V. Putin urged officials in Kiev to accept Moscow’s latest price offer for natural gas imports.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Russia and Ukraine failed on Wednesday to end an acrimonious standoff over the price of natural gas supplied by the Russian energy giant Gazprom, dashing hopes that the election of a new Ukrainian president might ease a dispute that has long poisoned relations between Moscow and Kiev. The failure to reach a deal also raised concern in Europe that its own supplies of energy from Russia could be interrupted.

headline: Amazon Music Streaming Service Is Expected Soon
abstract: The feature will give Amazon Prime subscribers access to thousands of songs but omit most new releases, people briefed on the company’s plans said.
lead_paragraph: Amazon plans to introduce a limited music streaming feature as early as Thursday, according to several people briefed on its plans.

headline: For Father and Son, a Creative Tug of War
abstract: R.O. and Nicholas Blechman discuss working together on art for The Times.
lead_paragraph: R.O. Blechman, an author and illustrator, has drawn for The Times for more than four decades. Today, he often works closely with his son Nicholas Blechman, the art director for the Book Review and an illustrator and designer himself, who came to The Times in 1997 as art director of the Op-Ed pages. Father’s Day is this weekend, so we asked the Blechmans to talk about their collaboration. Nicholas calls his father Bob. The R in his initials stands for Robert.

headline: Did Democratic Voters Defeat Eric Cantor? Probably Not
abstract: Turnout was heavy in some Democratic areas, but David Brat’s margin of victory came primarily from the more Republican parts of the district.
lead_paragraph: House Majority Leader Eric Cantor’s unexpected defeat has left many looking for equally unexpected answers. One suggestion is that his opponent, David Brat, was bolstered by Democratic crossover voters, who might have contributed to an increase in turnout from 2012. Mr. Cantor’s pollster, John McLaughlin, said the race was decided by Democratic voters.

headline: Blind Soccer in Brazil
abstract: Brazil’s visually disabled defy the odds by taking part in their country’s favorite pastime, soccer.
lead_paragraph: Brazil’s visually disabled defy the odds by taking part in their country’s favorite pastime, soccer.

headline: Senate Race in Mississippi Exposes a Cultural Rift
abstract: The enthusiastic amateurs, Christian conservatives and Tea Party activists supporting Chris McDaniel stand in contrast to his rival Senator Thad Cochran’s establishment backing.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — It is still not entirely clear what three supporters of the Tea Party favorite Chris McDaniel were doing locked in at 3 a.m. in a darkened courthouse where votes had been tabulated on the night of the state’s contentious primary election last week.

headline: Stabbing Suspect Indicted on Murder Charges
abstract: The hearing for Daniel St. Hubert was largely a procedural affair, but Mr. St. Hubert caused a stir when he asked the judge if he could address the court.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of the elevator stabbings that left a 6-year-boy dead and a 7-year-old girl critically wounded in Brooklyn was formally indicted on Wednesday on charges of murder, attempted murder, assault and weapons possession.

headline: The Democrats Still Have a Problem
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Notwithstanding Eric Cantor’s fate, that is.
lead_paragraph: So … I am aware that having the Republican House Majority Leader defeated by a no-name insurgent tends to cut against my ongoing argument, hotly contested by Jonathan Chait and others on the left, that the Democrats should be worried about their coalition holding together in the next presidential cycle. But because I’m stubborn, I’m going to celebrate Cantorgeddon by going one more round on the subject of whether President Obama’s approval ratings should be a cause of concern for his party, by responding to my colleague Nate Cohn’s contention that for now, at least, they shouldn’t be.

headline: Why Didn’t the Data-Driven Media See Eric Cantor’s Defeat Coming?
abstract: With coverage of Hillary Clinton continuing nonstop, The Times was among those who missed the clues on Cantor.
lead_paragraph: Was the coverage – or lack thereof – of Eric Cantor’s doomed campaign an epic fail by the media? Or was Mr. Cantor’s defeat just one of those inevitable surprises that keeps political junkies coming back for more?

headline: Would These Strategies Work With Your Employees?
abstract: Sherry Deutschmann started LetterLogic with the idea that she could build a better company with a better company culture.
lead_paragraph: In 2002, when Sherry Stewart Deutschmann quit her six-figure sales job at a Nashville company to start a competing business, she was convinced that her company would thrive if she could keep her employees engaged and committed. Today, that business, LetterLogic, which specializes in printing and mailing statements, invoices and letters, has $30 million in annual revenue and no debt.

headline: Italian Bank Hits Market Turbulence With Share Sale
abstract: Shares of Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena fell just more than 20 percent on the Milan exchange. The downturn came after an extraordinary run-up as the bank undertook a stock sale.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – Shares of Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the troubled Italian bank, plunged on Wednesday after going essentially untraded for two days as it undertook a stock sale that seeks to raise nearly $7 billion in new capital.

headline: Classical Playlist: Handel, George Benjamin, David Lang and Others
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: HANDEL: ‘Orlando’Bejun Mehta and other singers; René Jacobs, conductor; B’Rock Orchestra Ghent(Archiv Produktion; two CDs)For me, “Orlando” is Handel’s most innovative and psychologically astute opera, and one of his richest scores. The evocative story tells of Orlando, a renowned knight and crusader, who, weary of finding glory through combat, seeks meaning through love. He comes afoul of a magician who, determined to lead Orlando back to a life of valor, entices him into an enchanted forest where romantic involvements drive Orlando mad. Handel even gives us a mad scene in this opera. René Jacobs, the countertenor turned brilliant conductor, leads a crisp, stylish and immediate performance with the B’Rock Orchestra Ghent and an appealing cast, starring the countertenor Bejun Mehta in the title role, Sophie Karthäuser as his love interest Angelica, and Konstantin Wolff as the magician Zoroastro. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Feeling For | Sustainable Surfboards Made in Maine, or in Your Own Garage
abstract: The craftsmen behind Grain Surfboards hand-carve their covetable old-school planks on a rural farm, and offer a range of D.I.Y. options for surfers who want to build their own boards.
lead_paragraph: Before the advent of mass-produced polyurethane foam and fiberglass surfboards in the 1950s, the industry’s material of choice was durable, hand-hewn wood. Now, a pair of Maine-based craftsmen are seeking to bring the sport back to its roots. Armed with traditional wooden boat-building and fine cabinetry backgrounds, the Grain Surfboards founder Mike LaVecchia and his partner Brad Anderson have created an aesthetically pleasing range of boards that blend old-school materials and craftsmanship with modern shapes and techniques.

headline: Old Industry, Eclectic Styles in Eastern Market, Detroit
abstract: Lauren Stovall prefers comfortable, out-of-the-ordinary items for her retro style.
lead_paragraph: Sporting a vintage jumpsuit and her dad’s throwback frames, Lauren Stovall was channeling an era when Motown music ruled Detroit. Ms. Stovall was recently passing time in the city’s Eastern Market neighborhood, a diverse area with rich history that she finds inspirational. She is a self-proclaimed ’70s girl, a hippie at heart, and says comfort is her main approach to style. “Heels, I mean, yeah, they’re cool, but I just love like some unique flats,” Ms. Stovall said.

headline: How We Left Iraq

headline: Intelligence Too Big for a Single Machine

lead_paragraph: Ever since the computer scientist John McCarthy coined the term artificial intelligence in 1955, the field has gone through cycles of boundless optimism and sobering disillusion. Yet until recently, the supercomputer was the go-to operator of machine intelligence — both in science fiction (HAL, in Stanley Kubrick’s “2001: A Space Odyssey”) and in reality (Watson, IBM’s “Jeopardy!” champ).

lead_paragraph: Mr. Lauren showed a collection of navy-and-white polka-dot and striped classics with eye-poppingly unabashed accents of gold.

headline: Michael Kors Resort 2015
abstract: Mr. Kors showed sweet white eyelet dresses, sable-lined anoraks and tie-dyed suede flares.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Kors showed sweet white eyelet dresses, sable-lined anoraks and tie-dyed suede flares.

headline: Lanvin Resort 2015
abstract: The collection included a studded suede tank and not-quite-matching leather skirt.
lead_paragraph: The collection included a studded suede tank and not-quite-matching leather skirt.

headline: Diane von Furstenberg Resort 2015
abstract: The collection included a multitude of flared trousers.
lead_paragraph: The collection included a multitude of flared trousers.

headline: Louis Vuitton Resort 2015
abstract: Louis Vuitton’s inaugural resort presentation of neat silhouettes with look-at-me prints.
lead_paragraph: Louis Vuitton’s inaugural resort presentation of neat silhouettes with look-at-me prints.

headline: Think Big. Build Big. Sell Big.
abstract: The coming Jeff Koons survey at the Whitney Museum of American Art will consume more space than the museum has ever devoted to a single artist.
lead_paragraph: On a spring afternoon with his first major retrospective in New York looming, the artist Jeff Koons, nattily dressed in navy blue from head to toe, calmly boarded a helicopter heading for a foundry in upstate New York. His mission was to check up on his “Play-Doh,” a monumental sculpture depicting the squidgy material ubiquitous in American playrooms.

headline: Zeppelin Hits the Top 10; Miranda Lambert at No. 1
abstract: Ms. Lambert’s new album, “Platinum,” opened with strong sales, while three Led Zeppelin reissues made the Top 10.
lead_paragraph: Miranda Lambert’s acclaimed new album, “Platinum” (RCA Nashville), opened at No. 1 this week with 180,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Gucci Resort 2015
abstract: The collection included pastel cashmeres and oversize sailor bottoms.
lead_paragraph: The collection included pastel cashmeres and oversize sailor bottoms.

headline: Chanel Resort 2015
abstract: The collection included bouquets of bouclés and florals.
lead_paragraph: The collection included bouquets of bouclés and florals.

headline: The Weight of the World Rests on Brazil
abstract: Brazil, the country that has become synonymous with soccer, has no choice but to win the World Cup. But Argentina looms.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — For all its ability to excite and surprise, the World Cup has a tendency to be a conservative affair. The early group matches usually fulfill the heightened expectation — allowing the minnows of the tournament to have access to a world stage usually denied them — but the knockout phases are where a certain soccer order is restored.

headline: Does Marriage Protect Women Against Violence?
abstract: An op-ed incited outrage this week with the argument that marriage protects women from rape. Now some researchers are saying it misinterprets the data, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: W. Bradford Wilcox and Robin Fretwell Wilson started a social-media firestorm Tuesday when they offered a prescription for lessening violence against women: marriage.

headline: Let the Soccer Drama Begin
abstract: Here is a group-by-group analysis examining countries seen as contenders, and countries that would be overjoyed to make it out of their group.
lead_paragraph: The top players are here (mostly), the stadiums are ready (sort of) and preparation time is up: The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday. After Brazil takes center stage in São Paulo (yes, Croatia will be there, too, but all eyes will be on the host), the two biggest heavyweight fights of the first round arrive in short order: Spain versus the Netherlands on Friday and England versus Italy on Saturday. So settle in for the next month and enjoy.

headline: Truck Driver Pleads Not Guilty in Tracy Morgan Car Crash
abstract: Kevin Roper, whose tractor-trailer hit a van carrying the comedian Tracy Morgan, is charged with one count of vehicular homicide and several counts of assault by auto.
lead_paragraph: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — The Walmart truck driver whose tractor-trailer slammed into a van carrying the comedian Tracy Morgan, critically injuring Mr. Morgan and killing another passenger, pleaded not guilty on Wednesday in a New Jersey courtroom.

headline: RoseLee Goldberg Shares Her Favorite Moments From Performa
abstract: The premier evangelist of live art relates her top experiences at the New York biennial she founded a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: The article “The Second Life of Performance,” from T’s culture issue, explores the increasing ubiquity of live art and the role of RoseLee Goldberg in its growing popularity. Ten years ago, the curator and art historian founded Performa, the New York biennial dedicated to the practice, which has influenced museums around the world. Here, Goldberg shares her favorite moments from Performa’s decade-long history.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Fly by Night’
abstract: Michael McCormick and Adam Chanler-Berat in a scene from the new musical at Playwrights Horizons.
lead_paragraph: Michael McCormick and Adam Chanler-Berat in a scene from the new musical at Playwrights Horizons.

headline: San Jose Repertory Theater Closes Down
abstract: The 34-year-old company had a $5 million budget.
lead_paragraph: The San Jose Repertory Theater, one of the biggest theaters in Silicon Valley, announced on Wednesday that it had shut down.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Women Who Belong in the Kitchen
abstract: Jody Adams is sole owner of Rialto, a 20-year fixture on Harvard Square in Boston’s Charles Hotel.
lead_paragraph: Jody Adams is sole owner of Rialto, a 20-year fixture on Harvard Square in Boston’s Charles Hotel.

headline: An Astute Waif Hopscotching Through Time
abstract: Tom Rachman’s new novel zigzags from 1988 to 1999 to 2011, charting the experiences of a girl with a mysterious past.
lead_paragraph: Tom Rachman’s ingenious second novel, “The Rise and Fall of Great Powers,” is harder to describe than “The Imperfectionists,” his sensational first. So here is some sample dialogue, by way of introduction. Humphrey, an older man with a heavy Russian accent, is explaining Russian history to Tooly, an eager 10-year-old girl who will grow up to become the book’s tough, quick-witted main character and the most important person in Humphrey’s life.

headline: Investors Wary of Putting Money Where the Cloud Is
abstract: In recent months, some investors have pulled back from their bullish support for cloud companies.
lead_paragraph: Box, the Silicon Valley cloud storage company run by 29-year-old Aaron Levie, was on the cusp of going public earlier this year. Until it wasn’t.

headline: Work Sheds Mythic Aura as It Dons New Clothes
abstract: A staging of Peter Boal’s “Giselle” by the Pacific Northwest Ballet has new designs by Jérôme Kaplan.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Peter Boal, artistic director of Pacific Northwest Ballet, staged a revelatory “Giselle” for that company here in 2011. Yet “Giselle” is danced everywhere. So what needed to be revealed?  In truth, the basic text of this central work is in a terrible state all ’round the world. (The same is true for most 19th-century ballet classics, alas. No classic play, opera or concert work is presented today laden with anachronistic and showy changes that are standard for the 19th-century ballets.)

headline: A Season That Defies Its Own Description
abstract: Designers cannot agree on what the five-week pre-spring season is, or even what to call it. Resort? Cruise? Pre-Collection?
lead_paragraph: So we come to the end of that interminable, puzzling, ill-defined women’s wear season that is known as pre-spring — or almost the end, to be absolutely accurate; there are a few more shows dribbling out after the men’s wear spring 2015 collections begin in London this weekend. But you have to draw a line somewhere. And having drawn it, we are left with ... what exactly?

headline: A Mesh of Sounds
abstract: An alluring array of sounds with a German-Brazilian theme filled St. Paul’s German Lutheran Church in Manhattan as part of the Chelsea Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: An alluring array of sounds filled St. Paul’s German Lutheran Church in Manhattan on Tuesday evening during a performance of the Brazilian-born composer Felipe Lara’s “Voz de Ventos” (“Voices of the Winds”), part of the imaginative Chelsea Music Festival. Mr. Lara advised the audience not to turn around and watch the clarinetist Danny Goldman, the flutist Caitlyn Phillips and the bassoonist Brad Balliett as they played in a balcony at the back of the church, but to focus instead on how the music traveled in space.

headline: Sutter, Given Plenty of Reasons to Boast by Kings, Deflects Praise Instead
abstract: Darryl Sutter is one of six brothers to play in the N.H.L. and four to coach in the league, but the only Sutter sibling with a championship ring earned behind the bench.
lead_paragraph: News conferences featuring Los Angeles Kings Coach Darryl Sutter are works of art.

headline: Experts Say a Matisse in a Munich Art Trove Should Go to Its Owner’s Heirs
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: An international group examining Cornelius Gurlitt’s cache of paintings in Germany has determined that a Matisse should be returned to a French art collector’s heirs.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A 1921 portrait by Matisse found in the private collection of the reclusive Cornelius Gurlitt was looted by the Nazis from a prominent French art collector and should be returned to his heirs, a team of international experts said on Wednesday.

headline: G.E. May Still Hold Upper Hand in Alstom Bid
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The decision by Siemens to team up with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in a potential bid for Alstom’s power assets probably won’t be enough to overcome rival interest from General Electric, Olaf Storbeck writes in a Reuters Breakingviews column.
lead_paragraph: Siemens is smart to team up with its Japanese engineering peer Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in a potential bid for Alstom’s power assets. But this probably won’t be enough for Siemens to overcome rival interest from General Electric.

headline: Hotels Get in the World Cup Spirit
abstract: Hotels in Miami Beach, Las Vegas and New York are offering World Cup-themed packages.
lead_paragraph: A number of United States hotels are offering themed packages to coincide with the FIFA World Cup, held in Brazil from June 12 to July 13 this year.

headline: Even Early Adopters See Major Flaws in the Cloud
abstract: Adoption of cloud computing has been slowed by service disruptions, security concerns and regulatory issues.
lead_paragraph: The C.I.A. isn’t afraid of the cloud.

headline: New Yorkers Chosen for Grand National Teams
abstract: Each district of the American Contract Bridge League qualifies one team to play in the final stage of the Grand National Teams.
lead_paragraph: Each district of the American Contract Bridge League qualifies one team to play in the final stage of the Grand National Teams. This is held at the beginning of the Summer North American Championships, taking place this year in Las Vegas next month..

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: 1 Day
abstract: On Wednesday, Belgium backed out of Thursday’s scrimmage with the United States after its coach, Marc Wilmots, grew concerned about gridlock traffic.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. This is the final installment of the World Cup countdown.

headline: In Fela’s Spirit, His Son Keeps Afrobeat Bristling
abstract: The tattoo across Seun Kuti’s shoulders reads “Fela Lives.” Mr. Kuti, a son of Fela Anikulapo Kuti, has emerged as far more than a caretaker for his father’s style.
lead_paragraph: When Seun Kuti had his shirt off, dancing through the end of a sweaty, magnificently funky set at the Highline Ballroom on Tuesday night, the tattoo across his muscular shoulders was visible: “Fela Lives.”

headline: A World of Hurt, and Films Still Able to Share Its Pain
abstract: Women directed 16 of the 22 films in this year’s Human Rights Watch Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: Images of the horrors of war are so ubiquitous in the age of the camera phone that they threaten to overwhelm and desensitize us. For movie critics who are exposed more than many people to this barrage of carnage, the impulse after a while is to withdraw into a protective shell of world-weary cynicism.

headline: A Colonial Inn Adds a Piece of Victoriana
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The Inn at Little Washington, in Virginia, opens an annex called the Parsonage.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Patrick O’Connell, the chef and proprietor of the Inn at Little Washington, a clutch of historic buildings in Washington, Va., added the Parsonage to his complex. He did not restore this two-story house, with its six guest rooms, to its original 1850 décor. Instead, he recreated “the feeling of a grand old family home so that a guest room doesn’t feel like a hotel room,” he said. Built in the Colonial style, the building (across the street from the inn) later was “Victorianized,” to borrow Mr. O’Connell’s verb. And its décor has remained that way, though the palette was lighter than one usually finds in Victorians. The exterior and the porch facing a courtyard are painted green with cream accents. Interior walls are pale or papered in light colors, including the walls flanking a window seat in a second-floor guest room. Rooms start at $575 a night. Information: 540-675-3800 or theinnatlittlewashington.com.

headline: Is a Steam Shower Worth the Expense When It’s Time to Sell?
keywords: ['Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Yes, but don’t underestimate the complexity of installing one.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is a steam shower worth the expense when it’s time to sell?

headline: Note to Forgers: Don’t Forget the Spell Check
abstract: Newly released court documents show that one of the paintings sold by Knoedler and attributed to Jackson Pollock was signed with the artist’s name misspelled.
lead_paragraph: When angry collectors started suing Knoedler & Company for selling dozens of multimillion-dollar forgeries, the gallery’s former president, Ann Freedman, insisted that she and her colleagues had had no reason to think that any of the paintings were counterfeit.

headline: And the Rhubarb Is Easy
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Design']
abstract: A pair floats over some high domestic hurdles to enjoy their laid-back summer house in the Hamptons.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to decorating, entertaining and parenting, David Duplantis and Christopher Nordquist make everything look so effortless and appealing, it’s hard not to feel inadequate in comparison.

headline: Sales at Broadway Panhandler, Company C and OLighting
abstract: Discounts on cookware, furnishings and more.
lead_paragraph: Broadway Panhandler is discounting some knives, cookware and kitchen tools by up to 70 percent, through Sunday (a Cuisinart Vintage 3-quart copper mixing bowl, originally $100, is about $30; a Wüsthof Classic forged fork-tip serrated tomato knife, originally $100, is about $40; a Le Creuset 4.25-quart cast-iron soup pot in select colors, originally $360, is about $140); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway); 212-966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: Sky’s the Limit on Game Videos Online
keywords: ['Cloud Computing', 'College Athletics', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Hudl, a company from Lincoln, Neb., is using cloud computing to help sports teams upload and review films of their games.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to cloud computing, your local youth soccer league may someday play a 12-and-under version of “Moneyball.”

headline: Feeling For | The Adorable Daughter of Hugo Guinness, and Her Bunnies
abstract: In anticipation of Father’s Day, T exclusively shares this video of the artist and 12-year-old Violet at home in the Boerum Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Most know Hugo Guinness as the British artist whose whimsical drawings, paintings and linocut prints — of everything from inky florals to a playful pair of men’s undies — line the walls of John Derian’s dreamland-like shops in downtown Manhattan, not to mention some of the city’s best-appointed homes. But to his 12-year-old daughter Violet, he is simply dad. And though he doesn’t enjoy the company of his younger daughter’s two pet rabbits, Blackie and Odette, as much as she does — he laments that one bites, while both “pee everywhere and poop everywhere and they never stop eating, and we’ve got them for another 12 years” — he adores Violet’s fondness for them.

headline: ‘Bridesmaids’ Writers Team Up for New Comedy
abstract: Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumolo will write and star in a comedy about two best friends, with Ms. Wiig expected to direct.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Since 2011, when “Bridesmaids” became a global hit and expanded the range of female-driven comedy, Hollywood has been desperate for its screenwriters, Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumolo, to team again on another big movie.

headline: The Great Digital-Friendly Outdoors
abstract: A campstove that can charge a phone, a bottle that can purify water, a portable solar array — camping amenities are moving at the pace of tech.
lead_paragraph: Time was when people took to the forest for the weekend with dreams of solitude.

headline: Glass Accessories: Showing Their Strength
abstract: The material can be surprisingly tough, and thus suited to many purposes.
lead_paragraph: Sebastian Herkner uses lots of different materials in the furnishings he makes for companies like ClassiCon, Moroso and Rosenthal. But glass has always held a special appeal for him.

headline: With a Bit of Planning, Keep the Cloud With You Always — Even Offline
abstract: The key to using your cloud services without an Internet connection is preparation.
lead_paragraph: Cloud computing may seem incompatible with being offline, but there are ways to live in the cloud even when you don’t have an Internet connection. The most common situation occurs when you are actually in the clouds — stuck on a plane with no Wi-Fi, or, more likely, Wi-Fi so slow it might as well be nonexistent.

headline: Cynics Need Love, Too
abstract: The singer and comedian Emily Bergl applies a sarcastic edge to some happy standards during her show at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: Sarcasm is the weapon of choice for the singer and comedian Emily Bergl, who opened at 54 Below on Tuesday evening. And oh, how bracing it feels! Just listen to this supersmart, platinum-haired spitfire sing tainted renditions of the Rodgers and Hammerstein standards “People Will Say We’re in Love” and “I Have Confidence.” Inflected with notes of doubt, cynicism and contempt, they curdle from happy, life-affirming ditties into objects of suspicion.

headline: A Detective Who Is More Softy Than Hard-Boiled
abstract: “Breakthrough Weekend” is a New York shaggy-dog story that involves an unusual private detective and his protégé, who take on three increasingly bizarre cases.
lead_paragraph: The closing credits of “Breakthrough Weekend” list a technical crew of five. That figure doesn’t count the producing team, which consists of two of the actors and the director, or the composer, whose personal website is advertised below his name. This New York shaggy-dog story from Sujewa Ekanayake is an example of extreme-makeshift filmmaking — but not, unfortunately, a successful one.

headline: Moving Beyond Clothing With Collections for the Home
abstract: In Southampton, Club Monaco adds vintage and contemporary housewares to its mix.
lead_paragraph: Club Monaco’s shop in Southampton, N.Y., which opened Memorial Day weekend, has the expected clothing and accessories. But it also has home furnishings, and mostly vintage ones at that. Crossing the threshold, one comes upon a table full of hotel silver to the right and old-fashioned mirrors. Other collections throughout the 3,000-square-foot space include vintage glass bottles, silver cocktail shakers and ironstone dishes.

headline: Pictures of the Day: London and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from London, Portugal, Israel and Washington.
lead_paragraph: Photos from London, Portugal, Israel and Washington.

headline: Where the Cool Things Are
abstract: The New York design gallery Mondo Cane has a new name and address.
lead_paragraph: When his lease was set to expire and his rent to triple, Patrick Parrish considered closing his TriBeCa design gallery, Mondo Cane, after almost 15 years and going online only. But in addition to selling vintage furniture and lighting, Mr. Parrish also holds contemporary art and design exhibits several times a year. “I like having openings, interacting with people,” he said.

headline: Modernist Birds Can Roost Here
abstract: The birdhouse’s resemblance to to a certain Olympics stadium was not intentional, its designer said.
lead_paragraph: This artisanal birdhouse looks like a homage to Herzog & de Meuron’s “bird’s nest” Olympic Stadium in Beijing. But the resemblance “probably was subconscious,” said Joe Mansfield, a founder, with Ken Tomita, of Grovemade, a five-year-old woodworking company in Portland, Ore., that produces it. Mr. Mansfield said he started with an Adobe Illustrator plug-in, and then realized, “Oh, that’s like a bunch of branches in a tree.” Made of walnut and what Mr. Mansfield described as “responsibly harvested, domestic Eastern hard-rock maple,” the small birdhouse comes with a solid brass perch and costs $200. Grovemade’s wood iPhone case has already appeared in the cult TV series “Portlandia.” If that show were to do a full-bore Grovemade parody, what product would be required? “I guess they’d have us make a high-end bike-polo stick,” Mr. Mansfield said. “It’s all the rage in Portland.” Information: grovemade.com.

headline: Italian Décor Rooted in Pottery
abstract: Joseph Sciorra, a folklorist, scours Brooklyn neighborhoods for pebbled pottery that stems from his own Italian heritage.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Sciorra, 59, has spent three decades studying how Italian-Americans adapt traditions from their ancestral homelands. The folklorist has looked at, among other topics, the Americanized versions of Italian embroidery, Neapolitan music, ephemeral architecture built for street processions and lawn shrines with saint statues in grottoes. A director of the John D. Calandra Italian American Institute at Queens College, he has been roaming Brooklyn streets lately, documenting 1950s planters covered in beach pebbles and blogging about his finds at i-italy.org.

headline: Losing the Key
keywords: ['Locks and Keys', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: There are smart new ways to lock your front door, but are they really better than that old lump of brass?
lead_paragraph: In this age of rapid transformation, the house key has been surprisingly resistant to change. Cars have mostly switched to key fobs. Hotels and office buildings favor the pass card. And yet the little metal keys we carry around — part security device, part domestic totem — aren’t that different from the ones carried by our parents, their parents or their parents, going back to the Civil War, when Linus Yale Jr. invented the cylinder lock, modifying an ancient Egyptian design.

headline: What Ferris Bueller Hath Wrought
abstract: In “Where We Started,” a man and woman meet while staying at a West Texas motel and consider leaving their respective married lives for each other.
lead_paragraph: The premise of “Where We Started” seems torn from an indie-script textbook: Will (Matthew Brumlow) and Nora (Cora Vander Broek), two lonely strangers locked in unhappy marriages, happen to run into each other on a night that might change their lives.

headline: Seattle, the New Center of a Tech Boom
abstract: With a convergence of tech companies large and small, Seattle is attracting money and talent, eager to grow in the cloud and become a hub akin to Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — From his ninth-floor office in downtown Seattle, Hewlett-Packard’s cloud computing outpost, Bill Hilf can see the Space Needle, the Pike Street Market and the future of computing.

headline: Summer Fashion: Small Canvases for Big Prints
abstract: Loud prints work well on bikinis; a global fashion website focuses on Brazil during the World Cup; a tote features a rescue dog helping other pups in need; and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: Given the season’s giddy profusion of prints — the tribal patterns, the splashy botanicals, the retro blooms — it follows that they would feel right for swimwear as well. Gabby Sabharwal, the designer of the swimwear label Giejo, a collection made with vintage fabrics, worked with a brush-stroke print after seeing the painterly inspirations on the spring runways. Yodit Eklund, who designs the African surf and beach label Bantu, developed the prints for her collaboration with J. Crew from traditional West African wax cloth patterns. Her color palette was based on 1970s funk and high-life album covers from Africa. Kenzo swimsuits echo the popular fish motifs in its spring collection. And as Ms. Eklund points out, a swimsuit is an easy way to pull off ... well, loud prints. “The surface area of a swimsuit is naturally small, so swimwear is a great opportunity to play with print without a head-to-toe look that might be overwhelming.”

headline: The V.A.’s Problems, by the Numbers
abstract: Facts and figures behind the troubled Department of Veterans Affairs.
lead_paragraph: Facts and figures behind the troubled Department of Veterans Affairs.

headline: Tools for Troubleshooting
abstract: What you need to inspect your home.
lead_paragraph: What you need to inspect your home.

headline: Hillshire Stuck Between the Terms of 2 Deal Offers
abstract: Hillshire Brands is being forced into an intricate dance as it weighs a buyout offer from Tyson Foods, Steven M. Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor.
lead_paragraph: Hillshire Brands is in deal limbo.

headline: At the Tonys, a D.I.Y. Fashion Aesthetic Prevails
abstract: A red carpet where almost no one seems to ask, “Who are you wearing?”
lead_paragraph: Just before midnight last Sunday, Mark Rylance, a Tony winner for “Twelfth Night,” was standing in the lobby of the Plaza Hotel, clutching his award and discussing his black top hat.

headline: Processing Power, Delivered by the Truckload
abstract: Demand for server racks is growing, but only a few handlers in the United States specialize in transporting high-value computer equipment and the associated supply chain security and coordination.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Hidden off an unmarked, winding road near the George Bush Intercontinental Airport here is a 40,000-square-foot warehouse filled with boxes, most about the size of a tall chest of drawers. As soon as handlers load one truck, it seems as if they are unloading another.

headline: Costuming Imelda Marcos in ‘Here Lies Love’
abstract: Clint Ramos costumed “Here Lies Love,” about a first lady drunk on politics.
lead_paragraph: Clint Ramos was a boy of 13 when he first encountered Imelda Marcos. She alighted fairylike at his high school in Cebu in the Philippines, a beacon of munificence pinning medals on deserving lads.

headline: Lady Gaga Becomes a Live Nation Client
abstract: Live Nation, the concert promoter, announced a management deal with the performer’s new manager, Bobby Campbell, on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after a public split with her former manager, Lady Gaga has become a client of Live Nation Entertainment’s management division.

headline: Looking for Trouble at Home Can Pay Off
keywords: ['Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Muster your courage (and your binoculars) and inspect your house, inside and out.
lead_paragraph: I know that preventive home maintenance is the grown-up way to save money in the long term and keep rats out of my pantry in the short term. All my friends from Shangri-La tell me so. And let’s face it, they’re the only people on the planet who practice preventive home maintenance.

headline: Bending the Rules to Offer Yoga With a Beer Chaser
abstract: The social aspect of drinking after class makes these group exercises at breweries a popular option.
lead_paragraph: A chef, 24 yogis and a dog walk into an Art Deco bar. It’s 10:30 a.m. on a recent Sunday, and most of the yogis have just completed a 2.3-mile run through downtown Los Angeles, led by a chef, Rob Rice, who is a certified yoga instructor.

headline: Tony Awards Committee Eases Limits on Promotional Swag
abstract: The panel also eliminated prizes for sound design in a play and a musical.
lead_paragraph: Get ready, Tony Award insiders – a whole lot of swag could be coming your way next spring.

headline: A Breakdown of Six Sneakers and Their Wearers
abstract: What do your sneakers say about you? Here’s a cultural breakdown.
lead_paragraph: What do your sneakers say about you? Here’s a cultural breakdown.

headline: U.S. Said to Rebuff Iraqi Request to Strike Militants
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Obama administration declined last month’s request by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki because it was reluctant to open a new chapter in a conflict that the White House has insisted was closed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the threat from Sunni militants in western Iraq escalated last month, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki secretly asked the Obama administration to consider carrying out airstrikes against extremist staging areas, according to Iraqi and American officials.

headline: A Rubber-Soled Revolution
abstract: The once ungentlemanly sneaker has undergone a fashion baptism, showing up in offices as well as cafe society.
lead_paragraph: The once ungentlemanly sneaker has undergone a fashion baptism, showing up in offices as well as cafe society.

headline: Tips From Fashion Insiders on How to Wear Sneakers With a Suit
abstract: Men’s wear experts offer their fashion tips for getting it right.
lead_paragraph: Sneakers with a suit? Of course. Men’s wear experts offer their fashion tips for getting it right.

headline: Security Needs Evolve as Computing Leaves the Office
abstract: As cloud computing grows, and security still lags far behind the layers of physical and network security of computer rooms down the hall, many start-ups are offering ways to encrypt information.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Five years ago, people still spoke of cloud adoption as if they had a choice.

headline: The Sneaker Comes of Age
abstract: The distinction between dress and athletic shoes is on the verge of collapse for fashion-forward men.
lead_paragraph: When Christopher Tennant, the editor of the magazine Man of the World, met up with his future in-laws a few months ago at JoJo, an Upper East Side restaurant, he wore a navy blazer from Barneys New York, olive slacks and — what else? — a pair of sneakers by Common Projects.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,312 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,312 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Goldman and Bain Settle Suit on Collusion
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Goldman Sachs and Bain Capital have agreed to pay a combined $121 million to settle a lawsuit that accused them and other firms of colluding to drive down the prices of takeovers before the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs and Bain Capital have agreed to pay a combined $121 million to settle a lawsuit that accused them and other firms of colluding to drive down the prices of takeovers before the financial crisis, according to a court filing on Wednesday.

headline: Danish Composer Wins $200,000 Prize From Philharmonic
abstract: Per Norgard wins the Marie-Josée Kravis Prize for New Music.
lead_paragraph: Per Norgard, a Danish composer known for kaleidoscopic works with shimmering, seamlessly evolving textures, has been awarded the Marie-Josée Kravis Prize for New Music, presented every two years by the New York Philharmonic. The award carries a $200,000 cash prize as well as a commission to compose a work for the orchestra.

Thanks to cloud computing, the start-up in Lexington, Mass., does it with 22 people, a few laptops and an Internet connection.

headline: A Lesson in Injustice
abstract: I was a master. He was a servant. This was what I’d been taught.
lead_paragraph: When I was 6, I saw my uncle slap, punch and kick the young boy who lived in his house. This wasn’t unusual in the India of the early ’90s, and it isn’t unusual even now. Parents routinely beat up kids, convinced that it is the best way to discipline them. A friend of mine in Gangtok, my hometown, came to school with stick marks tattooed on his arms every other week. This, though, was the first time that I had actually seen my uncle beating up a child.

abstract: The RTB 500 is meant to provide the real-time price of media on 500 leading publishers’ sites.

headline: Undecided

headline: Plan Will Change on Young Migrants
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Women and Girls', 'Detainees', 'Immigration Detention']
abstract: The authorities will no longer send female adult migrants with children to a makeshift detention center in Nogales and then release them in Arizona, the Homeland security secretary said.
lead_paragraph: The border authorities will no longer send female migrants with children to a makeshift detention center in Nogales, Ariz., and then release them in the state, Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson said Wednesday at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing.  As of June 1, Mr. Johnson said, unaccompanied children caught crossing the border illegally are being sent to the Nogales center for initial immigration processing, and they will not be released in the state. Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona had said that she was “disturbed and outraged” when hundreds of women and children were sent by immigration officials on buses to Phoenix and released with no assistance.

headline: Target Seeks to Reassure Its Investors at Meeting

headline: CNN Covers Cantor, Shifts to Simpson
abstract: As its cable news rivals flooded the airwaves with coverage of the Cantor primary race upset, CNN aired a documentary about O.J. Simpson.

lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — Everyday golfers know about footprints in the sand. The scourge of recreational golf is that many players neglect to rake bunkers after hitting out of them. As a result, many weekend duffers are left playing shots from the imprints of shoes.

headline: A Family That Plays Together Reconvenes at Pinehurst

Standing off the 10th hole at Pinehurst No. 2 on Wednesday, McNealy smiled and said, “It feels like a typical McNealy family golf vacation.”

headline: When the Trophy Is the Biggest Star
abstract: The Stanley Cup is the most singular of trophies, a 35-pound hunk of silver recognizable instantly even by those who do not watch a second of the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: While hockey may have struggled to keep its footing among the most popular sports in the United States in recent years, it has held tight to the status of having the coolest championship trophy. The Stanley Cup is the most singular of trophies, a 35-pound hunk of silver recognizable instantly even by those who do not watch a second of the playoffs.

headline: Michigan: Another Retiree Group Agrees to Pension Cuts
abstract: The board of Detroit’s general retirement system voted Wednesday to endorse the city’s bankruptcy plan, becoming the latest retiree group to support a so-called grand bargain.
lead_paragraph: The board of Detroit’s general retirement system voted Wednesday to endorse the city’s bankruptcy plan, becoming the latest retiree group to support a so-called grand bargain that includes outside funding and base pension cuts of 4.5 percent for former municipal workers. Pensioners must vote on the proposal by July 11 and could face steeper reductions if they reject the debt-slimming plan, which is subject to a federal judge’s approval. As part of the bargain, which would also keep a city-owned art collection off the auction block, two national foundations committed a combined $13 million to the Detroit Institute of Arts, the museum announced Wednesday. This week, automakers made a $26 million pledge. The artwork has been targeted by some creditors as a source of cash.

headline: Court Requires Warrants for Tracking Locations by Cellphone
keywords: ['Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Privacy', 'Search and Seizure']
abstract: A federal appeals court in Atlanta on Wednesday ruled that the Fourth Amendment protects information about people’s locations based on the cell towers their mobile phones are using.
lead_paragraph: In a groundbreaking case, a federal appeals court in Atlanta on Wednesday ruled that the Fourth Amendment protects information about people’s locations based on the cell towers their mobile phones are using. The ruling means investigators must get judicial warrants to obtain cell site data about someone. It builds on a ruling by the Supreme Court in 2012 finding that the police needed a warrant to attach a GPS device to a suspect’s car. While the court held that investigators should have obtained a warrant to get his locational data, it declined to overturn his conviction because the legal principle was not yet clear at the time of the investigation.

headline: White House Outlines Steps to Protect Covert Identities
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: The moves are in reaction to the accidental revelation last month of the Central Intelligence Agency’s top spy in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: The White House on Wednesday outlined the steps it would take to prevent the disclosure of covert officials’ identities when the president is traveling abroad. The moves are in reaction to the accidental revelation last month of the Central Intelligence Agency’s top spy in Afghanistan.

headline: Massachusetts: Venue Change Is Sought in Marathon Case
abstract: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who is accused in last year’s marathon bombings, filed court documents on Wednesday saying that they want their client’s trial moved out of Boston.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who is accused in last year’s marathon bombings, filed court documents on Wednesday saying that they want their client’s trial moved out of Boston. The lawyers did not say why they were seeking a new location, but indicated that they were trying to spare Mr. Tsarnaev the death penalty. In early court filings, Mr. Tsarnaev’s lawyers have referred to Boston’s news media coverage of the bombings, suggesting that the pretrial publicity there would prevent Mr. Tsarnaev from receiving a fair trial. If the court grants the move, the trial could still be held in Massachusetts, avoiding the intense feelings in Boston while benefiting from the state’s general anti-death-penalty tilt.

headline: Familiar Course to Defeat for deGrom
abstract: Jacob deGrom, the Mets’ rookie starting pitcher, pitched six innings in his third loss of the season, with the Mets managing just two hits over the final four innings against the Brewers.
lead_paragraph: Last season, when Matt Harvey pitched a brilliant game and was ultimately let down by his offense, he often recited the same message. He said that his job was to pitch as well as he could, to give his offense a chance, and that he could do nothing more than that.

headline: For Rangel and Challengers, a Subdued Debate
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Representative Charles B. Rangel discarded his props and toned down the racial language during the first live televised debate that pitted him against State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat and the Rev. Michael A. Walrond.
lead_paragraph: Representative Charles B. Rangel discarded his props and toned down the racial language during the first live televised debate that pitted him against State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat and the Rev. Michael A. Walrond as he seeks a 23rd term to represent the 13th Congressional District.

headline: Ugandan Official to Be Next General Assembly Chief
abstract: The United Nations General Assembly chose Sam Kutesa, Uganda’s foreign minister, as its next president, bypassing concerns of rights advocates and Western officials over Uganda’s law criminalizing homosexuality.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations General Assembly chose Sam Kutesa, Uganda’s foreign minister, as its next president on Wednesday, bypassing concerns of rights advocates and Western officials over Uganda’s  law criminalizing homosexuality, which took effect four months ago. Mr. Kutesa was selected by acclamation, without a vote. The one-year post is largely ceremonial but carries significance because the president leads General Assembly meetings. Mr. Kutesa said nothing about gay rights in his acceptance speech but vowed to promote gender equality and women’s rights. Asked by reporters afterward about his views on gays, he said, “As long as they respect privacy, I have no problem with it at all.” Philippe Bolopion, the United Nations director at Human Rights Watch, said the Uganda law “makes him a questionable choice.” Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general, supported Mr. Kutesa’s presidency but has expressed concern about the law, urging its repeal.

headline: Pakistan: Brothers Sentenced Again for Cannibalism
abstract: An antiterrorism court in Punjab Province on Wednesday sentenced two brothers accused of cannibalism each to 11 years and four months in prison.
lead_paragraph: An antiterrorism court in Punjab Province on Wednesday sentenced two brothers accused of cannibalism each to 11 years and four months in prison. The brothers, Muhammad Arif and Farman Ali, were arrested in April after the police found a baby’s head at their home in remote Bhakkar. They were convicted after a similar discovery in 2011 but were released after 18 months because, lawyers said, Pakistani law has no specific provisions against cannibalism. This time they were convicted of terrorism, desecrating a corpse and concealing evidence, said Mian Muhammad Rizwan, the public prosecutor in the case. Mr. Arif said that his older brother had disinterred a baby’s body and that the two had cooked and eaten the remains.

headline: Brazil: With World Cup Near, Airport Staff Plans Strike
abstract: The workers at Rio de Janeiro’s airports said they would go on a 24-hour strike on Thursday, the opening day of the World Cup soccer tournament.
lead_paragraph: The workers at Rio de Janeiro’s airports said they would go on a 24-hour strike on Thursday, the opening day of the World Cup soccer tournament. Other strikes have recently affected Brazilian cities as unions exert leverage at a time when the government is trying to avert major problems. The workers at Rio’s international airport and two domestic airports said they were seeking better conditions and a new collective bargaining agreement. It was not clear how the strike would affect the thousands of visitors flowing into Rio, which will host several games, including the World Cup final. Union officials said that as much as 80 percent of the airport work force would keep working during the strike, Brazilian news organizations reported. In São Paulo, subway workers voted not to resume their strike.

headline: Mets Reach Intersection of Expectation and Patience
abstract: The Mets’ prospects have shown enough to at least be intriguing, but the team, once again, is lagging below .500.
lead_paragraph: The Mets’ most dependable starting pitcher was a seventh-round draft choice from an Ohio high school who was not considered a top prospect as he clawed through the minor leagues. That pitcher, Jon Niese, cannot relate to the expectations that stalk so many others in the organization.

headline: Phyllis Patterson, Who Revived 16th Century, Dies at 82
abstract: Ms. Patterson, with her husband, Ron, created the first modern Renaissance fair in an effort “to bring history to life.”
lead_paragraph: Phyllis Patterson, who brought 16th-century Europe to Southern California in the 1960s when she helped found the first contemporary Renaissance fair, died on May 18 in a hospital in San Rafael, Calif. She was 82 and lived in a log cabin nearby, in Novato.

headline: Glenn Britt, Cable Chief Who Saw Broadband’s Future, Dies at 65
abstract: He was a longtime executive with Time Warner Cable, eventually earning the titles of chairman and chief executive before he retired in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Glenn A. Britt, the longtime chief executive of Time Warner Cable, whose career encompassed the shift from televisions with rabbit ears to streaming video, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 65.

headline: Yankees’ Ellsbury Has Reputation as ‘Dirt Rat’ (It’s Praise)
abstract: Jacoby Ellsbury has proved versatile for the Yankees, with opponents calling him a grinder and lauding his relentlessness.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Jacoby Ellsbury has earned some earthy nicknames over the years, mostly stemming from his six seasons with the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Security of Sites Storing Small Radioactive Material Is Found to Be Lacking
keywords: ['Nuclear Energy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Radiation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A report by the Government Accountability Office said that some “radiological sources” were secured by nothing more than an ordinary padlock.
lead_paragraph: Radioactive chunks of industrial metal that could be used in terrorist attacks are sometimes secured at sites around the country with no more than ordinary padlocks, according to congressional auditors. Also, auditors called ineffective the procedures for doing background checks of employers handling the materials.

headline: The Eloquence of Silence
abstract: In her final interview, the intensely private heiress Rachel ‘Bunny’ Mellon opened the doors to her legendary Virginia estate and the unparalleled treasures of her lifetime.
lead_paragraph: In her final interview, the intensely private heiress Rachel ‘Bunny’ Mellon opened the doors to her legendary Virginia estate and the unparalleled treasures of her lifetime.

headline: A Series of Indecisive Moments
abstract: In this installment of a series from the photo editors of T, we gather a group of images from Mark Steinmetz’s “American South” and “Paris in My Time” series.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: Selected Poems by Charles Wright
abstract: Poems by Mr. Wright, the newly named poet laureate.
lead_paragraph: Poems by Charles Wright, the newly named poet laureate.

headline: Charles Wright Named America’s Poet Laureate
abstract: Mr. Wright’s work fuses the legacy of European modernism with mystical evocations of the landscape of the American South.
lead_paragraph: The Library of Congress is to announce on Thursday that the next poet laureate will be Charles Wright, the author of nearly two dozen collections of verse that fuse the legacy of European modernism with mystical evocations of the landscape of the American South.

headline: Should Runners Get Pedicures?
abstract: Lost or discolored toenails are part of being a dedicated runner. Can anything be done to prevent this?
lead_paragraph: Jackie Cartier of Boulder, Colo., has been running for 10 years. That has left her feet beaten up and bruised, with thick calluses and the occasional missing toenail. But she won’t step foot in a salon to have a pedicure.

headline: Anchor of Rangers Buoys Them Just in Time
abstract: Stopping 40 of 41 Los Angeles shots, including all 15 in the third period, Lundqvist rescued the Rangers again in Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals.
lead_paragraph: After practice one afternoon, Henrik Lundqvist discussed his hockey mortality. “You don’t know how many chances you get in the playoffs,” Lundqvist said. “Before you know it, it might be over.”

headline: Lundqvist’s 40 Saves Give Rangers a Shot
abstract: Henrik Lundqvist, who made 15 saves in the third period alone, helped the Rangers force a Game 5 and avoid the indignation of seeing Los Angeles lift the Stanley Cup on their home ice.
lead_paragraph: Madison Square Garden once again served as the Rangers’ fortress Wednesday night. They held off the Los Angeles Kings, 2-1, refusing to allow the indignation of seeing them lift the Stanley Cup on home ice.

headline: Rafael Frühbeck, 80, Dies; Conductor Made the World a Podium
abstract: A life that began in Franco’s Spain led Mr. Frühbeck to a career conducting dozens of major orchestras.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos, a Spanish conductor known for his frequent guest appearances with the world’s foremost symphony orchestras, died on Wednesday in Pamplona, Spain. He was 80.

headline: Polarization Is Dividing American Society, Not Just Politics
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A new study suggests that people in general, not just politicians, have grown more divided, geographically and socially, by ideology.
lead_paragraph: It is common for Americans to lament the polarization and dysfunction of Washington, but Congress might be doing a better job of representing the public than voters care to admit.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 12, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 12, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “The days of just going to Washington and things happening in a vacuum are over.”

headline: What’s On Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (FX) WANDERLUST (2012) Jennifer Aniston and Paul Rudd star as Linda and George, out-of-work Manhattanites unable to sell their “microloft” in the West Village. Then they stumble onto Elysium, an “intentional community” in rural Georgia, where good vibrations — and not a little smoke — fill the air, and the only blackberries grow on trees. Established decades earlier by Carvin (Alan Alda), now in a wheelchair and battling memory loss, and his hippie friends, the commune is home to a touchy-feely guitar-strumming collage led by Seth (Justin Theroux), a creepy Lothario; and a novelist and nudist (Joe Lo Truglio) who wears the occasional sanitary pouch (like a hairnet, but lower) when he’s crushing grapes for homemade wine. “Part of what gives this movie unexpected resonance is that Linda and George have joined only somewhat voluntarily,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this “mostly funny comedy” from David Wain. “Like other Americans seeking simplicity and maybe a chicken coop out back, they want off the road, at least for a while. There’s something touching about this desire, though Mr. Wain doesn’t let Linda and George fly their freak flags for long.”

headline: Rookie Jets Cornerback Gets the Green Light to Bump and Run
abstract: Dexter McDougle, who was injured in September, early in his senior season at Maryland, has been cleared for contact drills.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Dexter McDougle, a rookie cornerback, was ecstatic when the Jets’ training staff allowed him to trade the red jersey he had worn since he joined the team as a third-round draft choice for a green one that signified he was free to engage in contact drills.

headline: Stout Performance Extends the Finals
abstract: A stellar game by goaltender Henrik Lundqvist and goals from Martin St. Louis and Benoit Pouliot helped the Rangers cut the Kings’ lead in the Stanley Cup finals to 3-1.
lead_paragraph: A stellar game by goaltender Henrik Lundqvist and goals from Martin St. Louis and Benoit Pouliot helped the Rangers cut the Kings’ lead in the Stanley Cup finals to 3-1.

headline: Kings Head Home Empty-Handed but Hoping for Redemption
abstract: Despite its relentless attack on Wednesday, Los Angeles was denied the Stanley Cup in its first opportunity to close out the Rangers.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Kings entered Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night needing one victory to clinch their second Stanley Cup in three years.

headline: Xi of Two Minds: Be a Good Neighbor, or Assert China’s Power?
abstract: A new report says that President Xi Jinping is torn between ambitions to have China exert power over Asia and a desire for peace in the region so he can focus on domestic priorities.
lead_paragraph: If you’re sometimes discombobulated by China’s foreign policy gyrations, there may be some consolation in knowing that so, apparently, is President Xi Jinping. A new report argues that China’s external strategy under him remains an unstable compound of impulses: swelling ambitions that China will use its growing economic and military power to subdue rivals versus a longstanding desire for a stable, benign regional setting so that the ruling Communist Party can tend to domestic priorities.

headline: Synthesis Lost
abstract: The instability of moderation, redux.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong has some notes on the evident trouble we’ve been having maintaining the “neoclassical synthesis” — the doctrine, made famous by Paul Samuelson but actually there in Keynes too, that macroeconomic policy is needed for full employment but once you have that a relatively free-market policy works.

headline: In Testimony Against N.C.A.A., Economics Professor Suggests Players Should Be Paid
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Football (College)']
abstract: The key witness in a federal antitrust trial involving the athletic association has been an economics professor who has suggested that universities would be better off compensating players financially.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Three days into a federal antitrust trial involving the N.C.A.A., the key witness has been Roger Noll, a 74-year-old economics professor emeritus at Stanford. His studies and theories form much of the basis for the allegation that the N.C.A.A. has engaged in price fixing by systematically depriving players a piece of lucrative broadcast and video-game contracts.

headline: Tanaka Earns Win No. 10 as Yankees Beat Mariners
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka pitched a complete game, lowering his earned run average to 2.02, the fourth-best mark in the majors, and Mark Teixeira supported him with a three-run homer.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Masahiro Tanaka is putting together the type of rookie season that even longtime baseball fans cannot remember seeing.

headline: Greenpeace and Other Advocates Fear Clampdown After Leaked Report
abstract: An intelligence report leaked to the local media charged foreign-funded nongovernmental organizations with stalling economic progress.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A confidential intelligence report submitted to the prime minister’s office and leaked to the local media criticizing foreign-funded nongovernmental organizations, including Greenpeace India, for their detrimental effect on the Indian economy has caused many social activists to worry about the security of their operations.

headline: European Court Upholds $1.44 Billion Fine Against Intel
abstract: The case, which dates back to 2000, is about a competitive edge the chip maker may no longer have. But the ruling has legal implications for other tech giants.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — An appeals court on Thursday upheld an antitrust fine of 1.06 billion euros against the computer chip giant Intel, giving more teeth to the European Union’s power to hold multinational technology giants accountable — even if the case is years old and Intel no longer wields the sort of power over consumers that got it into trouble in the first place.

abstract: Can you choose the words that best complete the sentence from the article?
