abstract: Why might so-called therapeutic hypothermia help to save lives?
lead_paragraph: In “Killing a Patient to Save His Life,” Kate Murphy reports on an experimental medical procedure.

headline: BNP Paribas Executive Leaves as Trade Investigation Grows
abstract: Georges Chodron de Courcel is stepping down in the face of an investigation into whether the bank did business with countries blacklisted by the United States.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:13 p.m. | A senior BNP Paribas executive is stepping down in the face of an investigation into whether the bank did business with countries blacklisted by the United States.

headline: An Interview With Xi, Long Before He Was China’s Leader
abstract: In a 2004 interview, Xi Jinping talks about his hard years on a farm when his family was out of political favor.
lead_paragraph: China’s president, Xi Jinping, belongs to the “sent-down” generation of urban youths assigned to labor in the countryside during the radical fervor of the Cultural Revolution, and while many of his peers rue that era as a lost decade, in a newly unearthed interview, Mr. Xi describes his seven rural years as a life-transforming immersion in poverty, hard work, spartan eating and bed fleas.

headline: British Discount Retailer B&M Raises $1.81 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: The company will receive about $126 million, while the rest will be divided between the Arora family and the United States private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – B&M European Value Retail, the British discount retailer, said on Thursday that it had raised 1.08 billion pounds, or about $1.81 billion, in its initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange.

headline: Prison Sentence Feared for Detained Rights Lawyer
abstract: The prospect of the imminent release of Pu Zhiqiang, a human rights lawyer who was detained after a meeting in Beijing to mark the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown, is growing dim.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer who met with Pu Zhiqiang, a crusading human rights lawyer who was detained after a meeting in Beijing to mark the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown, has expressed pessimism about the prospect of his speedy release.

headline: On the Road to a Photo of America
abstract: A road trip from Laredo, Tex., to Duluth, Minn., in search of how immigration has changed America in real lives demands a balance between plotted paths and serendipity.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the New York Times staff photographer Todd Heisler and a reporter, Damien Cave, set off on an ambitious journey to travel up Interstate 35, chronicling how the middle of America is being changed by immigration. With two weeks left on their assignment, Mr. Heisler took a moment to record a brief yet personal account for Lens regarding his experiences on the road.

headline: Will You Be Watching the World Cup?
abstract: Do you think soccer will ever become the most popular sport in the United States, as it is in much of the rest of the world? Why?
lead_paragraph: The World Cup, which is held every four years, begins on Thursday in Brazil and will last until mid-July. Thirty-two countries are contending for the title of world champion. The last time around, Spain won — but who will win this year? And will you be watching?

headline: U.S. Drone Hits Pakistan for 2nd Time in 12 Hours
abstract: The strikes were apparently aimed at the Haqqani network, a Taliban-allied faction that until last month held the American soldier Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl hostage.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An American drone struck a militant compound in Pakistan’s tribal belt for the second time in 12 hours on Thursday, killing at least 10 suspected members of the Haqqani network in a suddenly intense resurgence of the C.I.A. offensive in Pakistan.

headline: Kurdish Fighters Take a Key Oil City as Militants Advance on Baghdad
abstract: As the Kurds seized Kirkuk, Sunni militants threatened to advance into the heavily Shiite south and destroy shrines there.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — Kurdish forces exploited the mayhem convulsing Iraq on Thursday to seize complete control of the strategic northern oil city of Kirkuk as government troops fled in the face of advancing Sunni militants. The insurgents pressed their advance southward toward Baghdad, warned officials of occupied Mosul to renounce allegiance to the central government and threatened to destroy religious shrines sacred to Shiites.

headline: New York Today: Brazil vs. Croatia, in Queens
abstract: What you need to know for Thursday: watching the World Cup, even more lousy weather, and good polling news for the mayor.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning to you.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: First Year May Be Critical for Lowering Asthma and Allergy Risk
abstract: Childhood exposure to allergens and germs may be protective against the development of asthma and allergy, but a new study suggests that the beneficial effect happens only with exposure in the first year of life.
lead_paragraph: Childhood exposure to allergens and germs is generally believed to protect against the development of asthma and allergy, but a new study suggests that this effect happens only with exposure in the first year of life.

headline: Facebook to Let Users Alter Their Ad Profiles
abstract: The social network will allow users to see dossiers of their likes and dislikes, as well as give them the means to change, add to or delete the data.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If you have ever wondered why Facebook showed you that advertisement for a new iPhone game or a cheap flight to Bermuda, you will soon be able to find out.

headline: Q. and A.: Anson Chan on Beijing’s Pressure Tactics in Hong Kong
abstract: A former Hong Kong leader says the city needs to be tougher in dealing with Beijing, or else face the consequences sooner rather than later.
lead_paragraph: Anson Chan served as the No. 2 official in Hong Kong in the last years of the British colonial administration as well as in the first four years of the government following the territory’s return to China in 1997. During her time in office she was often referred to as Hong Kong’s “Iron Lady” and regarded as one of Asia’s most powerful women.

headline: Oil Rig Operator Shelf Drilling to List in London
abstract: The Dubai-based company, which operates in the Middle East, Southeast Asia, India and parts of Africa, said it hoped to issue shares valued at a minimum of $500 million later this year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Shelf Drilling, a Dubai-based operator of oil rigs, is looking to become the latest company to cash in on a buoyant market for London stock offerings.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook to Give Users More Control Over Marketing Data
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Online Advertising', 'Social Media']
abstract: The service plans to announce that it is going to give its users the ability to see the marketing files that it keeps on them and change, add or delete data from them.
lead_paragraph: If you have ever wondered why Facebook showed you that ad for a new iPhone game or a cheap flight to Bermuda, you will soon be able to find out, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on Republican nihilism, inmate phone calls, taxpayer-funded campaigns, sex-trafficking laws and Middle East militants.
lead_paragraph: “The forces of political nihilism not only remain alive and well within the Republican Party, but they are on the rise,” writes The New York Times editorial board. The Times finds the defeat of Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, by David Brat, an upstart “of the distant extremes,” to be both regrettable and disconcerting. For the Republicans of Virginia’s Seventh Congressional District, even Mr. Cantor, “who had been one of the most implacable opponents to the reform of immigration, health care and taxation,” was apparently too moderate. “His crime (in addition to complacent campaigning)? He was occasionally obliged, as a leader, to take a few minimalist steps toward governing, like raising the debt ceiling and ending a ruinous shutdown.”

headline: Women Who Belong in the Kitchen: Jody Adams
abstract: Ms. Adams talks about her life in the restaurant business and the impact of meeting Julia Child.
lead_paragraph: Jody Adams remembers her first job as a 25-year-old cook, working directly on the hot line. “I cut myself. I burned myself. I was a mess; I cried,” she said. “But I survived.”

headline: The Economic Damage of Recession News
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: Consumers often put too much stock in arbitrary thresholds like zero growth, and sometimes adjust their spending accordingly.
lead_paragraph: Real gross domestic product (G.D.P.) in the United States shrank by 1 percent in the first quarter of the year. What made this announcement seem so significant?

headline: Freshdesk Raises $31 Million for Customer Support Software
abstract: The financing round in the start-up, which offers cloud-based software on a subscription basis, is being led by Tiger Global Management and includes Google Capital and Accel Partners.
lead_paragraph: Stock market investors have rallied around Zendesk, a customer service software company that went public last month.

headline: How Thad Cochran Is Trying to Avoid Eric Cantor’s Fate
abstract: No matter how much attention will be shifted to the Mississippi runoff election, the intractable inertia of the typical voter will play a big role.
lead_paragraph: In winning his state senate seat in 2007, Chris McDaniel drew just over 10,000 votes. In winning a sixth United States Senate term a year later, Thad Cochran drew 766,000.

headline: In Our Pages: June 13
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: a spying scandal broke out between Switzerland and Germany in 1889 and a famous painting was stolen from the Louvre in 1939.

headline: Cantor Resigns as House Majority Leader
abstract: Representative Eric Cantor, Republican of Virginia, announced he would resign from his position as House majority leader within weeks of a stunning defeat in the primary election.
lead_paragraph: Representative Eric Cantor, Republican of Virginia, announced he would resign from his position as House majority leader within weeks of a stunning defeat in the primary election.

headline: Morning Agenda: Mickelson Not Linked to Clorox
abstract: Phil Mickelson did not trade in shares of Clorox as Carl C. Icahn was mounting a takeover bid for the company in 2011. | For Goldman, Alibaba is a symbol of what could have been. | Goldman and Bain Capital agreed to end a lawsuit involving the “club deal.” | Hillshire’s conundrum.
lead_paragraph: MICKELSON’S ROLE OVERSTATED IN INSIDER INQUIRY  |  The golfer Phil Mickelson did not trade in the shares of Clorox as the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn was mounting a takeover bid for the company in 2011, according to people briefed on the matter, Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess write in DealBook. Recent news reports said that Clorox was among the stocks that federal authorities were examining as part of a two-year investigation into well-timed trades made by Mr. Mickelson and the gambler William T. Walters.

headline: Russian Absurdism, With Floating Furniture
abstract: Mikhail Baryshnikov and Willem Dafoe collaborate with Robert Wilson in adapting Daniil Kharms’s story “The Old Woman,” soon coming to the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Robert Wilson was sketching. Circles within circles, horizontal lines punctuating them, numbers and words alongside. The diagram was a visual rendition of the structure of one of his early works, “The Life and Times of Joseph Stalin,” but he could doubtless do exactly the same thing for any of the numerous theater and opera pieces he has created and directed in the course of a 45-year career.

headline: Finding Her Future Looking to the Past
abstract: In her new album, “Ultraviolence,” Lana Del Rey sets herself further outside whatever passes for current pop mainstream.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In October, before starting an international theater tour, the songwriter Lana Del Rey consulted a clairvoyant. She was instructed to write down four questions in advance and sleep on them. The first question on the list, Ms. Del Rey said in an interview in May at her house here, was “Am I meant for this world?”

headline: Sex, Violence and Power, With a Feminist Slant
abstract: Penelope Skinner and Sarah Treem write plays and characters that reflect on the complicated and often contradictory legacy of the various waves of feminism.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the British playwright Penelope Skinner found herself in an editing suite, staring at a woman’s breasts. She had written an episode of “Fresh Meat,” a sitcom about college students, which contained a sex scene. The woman in it had just a few lines, and Ms. Skinner didn’t want her to serve as merely a source of titillation. So in the script she’d stated, “She does not take her top off.”

headline: A Conversation With Andrew Wilson, Chief Executive of Electronic Arts

headline: An Uncomfortable Moment With Nathan Fielder

headline: Nathan Fielder’s Ingenious Dumb Humor
abstract: How the star of Comedy Central’s “Nathan for You” makes the most of uncomfortable moments.
lead_paragraph: The new cafe at 1802 Hillhurst Avenue looked familiar, but something was off. It was nestled into a strip mall in Los Feliz, on the east side of Los Angeles, and its logo was a double-tailed mermaid, rendered in black and green, wearing a crown and a smile. Its name, spelled out in blocky white letters, was recognizable, too, except for a blunt détournement up top: DUMB STARBUCKS COFFEE. The store was the creation of Nathan Fielder, a Canadian-born comedian, and he designed it to look exactly like an outpost of the ubiquitous coffee chain — that is, until you realized that the word “dumb” was everywhere. The menu listed 27 beverages with names like Dumb Iced Caramel Macchiato and Dumb Chai Tea Latte. Cups came in sizes from Dumb Tall to Dumb Venti. Two baristas manned the counter, with DUMB STARBUCKS COFFEE emblazoned on their green aprons. “I hired them on Craigslist,” Fielder told me recently. “The ad actually asked for people who worked at Starbucks before, so we wouldn’t have to train them.” A rack of easy-listening CDs kept to the theme: “Dumb Jazz Standards,” “Dumb Norah Jones Duets.” The cafe quietly opened for business on a Friday last February. “I didn’t expect things to get as crazy as they did,” Fielder said.

headline: Parental Collusion on Spending and Rules: Harder Than It Sounds
abstract: Here’s the tricky part about trying to form a cabal to stomp the seeds of perceived materialism: It’s awfully hard to be the first person who speaks up.
lead_paragraph: Parenting would be a little easier if everyone set the same rules for their children. No iPhone until kids can pay for one themselves. No sneakers over $100. No birthday parties with elaborate presents, or at least a declaration of a goody-bag truce. Some restraint on giving fancy new vehicles to teenagers.

abstract: The rules are a large component of Michelle Obama’s campaign to reduce the number of overweight children through exercise and better nutrition.

headline: Captive Audience, Mad Interrogator
abstract: In Dave Eggers’s new novel, a serial kidnapper seeks answers from an astronaut and other hostages in a tale told entirely in dialogue.
lead_paragraph: Dave Eggers’s short new novel has a long, awkward title: “Your Fathers, Where Are They? And the Prophets, Do They Live Forever?” And it turns out to be a labored, predictable and tiresome piece of fiction lacking the emotional wisdom and dazzling prose that have distinguished so much of this author’s earlier work.

headline: He’s a Great Pet, Even if He Does Singe Your Hair
abstract: “How to Train Your Dragon 2,” the sequel to the 2010 blockbuster from DreamWorks Animation, is considerably darker and more self-aware than its forerunner.
lead_paragraph: War and peace. Humans and animals. Contemplation of our bestial versus our spiritual sides. These may be too much heavy baggage to attach to a corporate product like “How to Train Your Dragon 2.” But such matters are there for you to ponder in this sequel to the 2010 blockbuster that recertified DreamWorks Animation, after a fallow period, as a major player in Hollywood’s cartoon sweepstakes. And pop mythology nowadays has a way of seeping into the culture and sending far-reaching undercurrents.

headline: Maazel to Slow Down, on Doctors’ Orders

He also said he would not take any professional engagements during the 2014-15 season.

headline: Now Booking | A Techno-Utopian Bar in San Francisco for Those Who Like to Think While They Drink
abstract: The Interval, opening this month in the Fort Mason Center, features a library, an ambient soundtrack created by Brian Eno and, later this year, two robots.
lead_paragraph: Since merriment sometimes just isn’t enough, the Interval, a Mensa-courting bar that opens this month in the Fort Mason Center, also offers a library stacked with 1,000 literary masterworks and reference books, an ambient soundtrack created by Brian Eno and, later this year, two robots: One will make drinks, while the other will write predictions about the future on the space’s massive chalkboard. Conceived by the San Francisco-based collective the Long Now Foundation — whose board of directors includes Eno and the Whole Earth Catalog creator Stewart Brand — the Interval will also host regular salons for cerebral scenesters.

headline: Efforts by Colleges to Curb Assaults Focus on Fraternities

lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — At the University of Tennessee this year, some fraternity pledges had hot sauce poured on their genitals. At Emory in Atlanta, pledges were required to consume items “not typical for eating” and to engage in fistfights. And at Wesleyan in Connecticut, a few months after the university reached a settlement with a woman who said she was raped at a fraternity house, another woman said that she was raped at a different fraternity house.

headline: Missing Collateral a Sign of Weakness in China’s Financing Chains
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The direct damage looks manageable, but confidence in the country’s giant credit system has eroded, writes John Foley of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Faith in metal-backed lending in China is corroding – and so is confidence in the country’s giant credit system. Authorities and banks, including Standard Chartered and Citic, are investigating whether traders at Qingdao port used the same lot of copper and aluminum to back multiple loans. Vanishing collateral isn’t a new problem, but could prove to be China’s weakest link.

headline: Coke Can Be Sued by Rival Over Juice Claim, Court Says

headline: In Her Words | Elizabeth Hawes on Fashion and Style
abstract: A selection of the 10 funniest, cleverest, most caustic zingers written by the late fashion icon during her lifetime.
lead_paragraph: For T’s culture issue, out this Sunday, Alice Gregory wrote about “The Most Brilliant American Fashion Designer”: Elizabeth Hawes, the writer, designer and feminist who passed away in 1971. Throughout her career, Hawes offered an honest, often funny appraisal of the fashion world as it was and as she thought it should be. She was a proponent of using style to get what you want (and, essentially, to become who you want to be), and a wicked critic. While researching the piece, Gregory amassed a collection of Hawes’s wittiest one-liners from her nine books. Here, she lists her 10 favorite quips from the most important woman in fashion you’ve never heard of.

headline: The Most Brilliant American Fashion Designer

headline: Bolinas, Calif., the Town That Didn't Want Company
abstract: This small township 20 miles northwest of San Francisco is isolated by temperament as well as geography — but for how long?
lead_paragraph: The Grand Hotel is neither, really. Forty-five years ago — before the poets Robert Creeley and Lawrence Ferlinghetti bought houses nearby; before a food co-op and a naturopathic store opened down the street; before the rustic surfing town of Bolinas, Calif., was the sort of place where a tourist would consider spending the night — the Grand Hotel was merely Vic Amoroso’s house, with a garage that doubled as a bric-a-brac shop.

headline: Rangers Will Need More Luck to Come Back Against the Kings
abstract: The Rangers needed two shots by Los Angeles to somehow sputter short of the goal to avoid being eliminated from the finals on home ice, but the Kings seem undaunted.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers needed a supernatural force field over their goal line Wednesday night to keep from being unceremoniously swept out of the Stanley Cup finals by the Los Angeles Kings. While that made for a thrilling moment for the Madison Square Garden faithful, it came with the knowledge that the Rangers might need similar otherworldly happenings to intervene in three more games.

headline: Palestinian Premier Says New Government Lacks Power in Gaza
abstract: Rami Hamdallah said that not much had changed since the new government took over and that reconciliation between the West Bank and Gaza Strip would take time.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — The Palestinian Authority has had a new government for 10 days now, but the prime minister, Rami Hamdallah, acknowledged on Thursday that he still lacked any authority in the Hamas-dominated Gaza Strip and that nothing had yet changed on the ground.

headline: Tony Committee Decision to Drop Sound Design Awards Prompts Noisy Outcry

headline: Just Like the Last One, Only Different
abstract: In “22 Jump Street,” Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum reprise their role as police partners, this time going undercover on a college campus.
lead_paragraph: More is more and is, at times, just right in “22 Jump Street,” an exploding piñata of gags, pratfalls, winking asides, throwaway one-liners and self-reflexive waggery. This is, of course, the sequel to “21 Jump Street,” the 2012 hit that borrowed its title and undercover brother shtick from the old television show best known for its hair-gel hottie, Johnny Depp. For a second time, Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum play lovable undercover cops who — in between dodging danger and jokes that fly almost as fast as they do on “The Simpsons” — insinuate themselves into a juvenile population, whose resistance to these charmers has been rendered completely futile, much like that of the movie’s audience.

headline: Checking In With the International Desk on Iraq
abstract: An international editor explains how the desk is handling coverage as insurgents push toward Baghdad.

headline: When a Stressful Hospital Stay Makes You Sick
abstract: It’s long been known that hospitals can be the source of illness. But post-hospital syndrome is something different and more ominous.

headline: Primary Voters, Maybe Not So Extreme After All
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: It’s conventional wisdom that the most fervidly conservative or liberal voters tend to dominate primaries, but this assumption needs another look.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:01 p.m. | The Indian Point nuclear power plant, 30 miles from New York City (and 8 miles from my house), has been run safely and reliably for the most part. But it’s at a critical juncture, with New York Governor Andrew Cuomo having vowed to shut it down and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission weighing relicensing for the two operating reactors.

headline: World Cup Comes to Governors Island, via the Big Screen

In addition to the bars and saloons where soccer fans gather on a regular basis, hotels are opening rooftops for viewings; big screens are being erected in Dumbo, Brooklyn, and on 46th Street in Manhattan’s Little Brazil; and normally staid restaurants are being converted into arenas for the faithful.

headline: Juan Gabriel Vásquez Wins International Impac Dublin Literary Award

headline: Ruby Dee, a Ringing Voice for Civil Rights, Onstage and Off, Dies at 91
keywords: ['Theater', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Movies']
abstract: Ms. Dee, who earned acclaim in “A Raisin in the Sun” and “American Gangster,” sought roles that addressed racial issues and campaigned for civil rights with her husband, Ossie Davis.

abstract: We asked readers to submit Instagram photos of wedding invitations that were given or received that are meaningful and eschews all norms.
lead_paragraph: We asked readers to submit Instagram photos of wedding invitations that were given or received that are meaningful and eschews all norms.

headline: U.S. Scrambles to Help Iraq Fight Off Militants as Baghdad Is Threatened
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The White House hurried Thursday to reassure Iraq that it would help its beleaguered army fend off militants who have overrun much of the country and now threaten Baghdad.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House, confronted by an unexpected crisis on a battlefield it thought it had left behind, scrambled Thursday to reassure Iraq that it would help its beleaguered army fend off militants who have overrun much of the country and now threaten Baghdad.

headline: Soccer and Internal Discord, on Display for World to See
abstract: Brazil reaffirmed its reputation as a powerhouse of global soccer in the opening match of the World Cup, but its widening political fissures were also on display for an international audience.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Brazil reaffirmed its reputation as a powerhouse of global soccer in the opening match here of the World Cup on Thursday, setting off street parties around the country, but its widening political fissures were also on display for an international audience.

headline: The Privacy Paradox, a Challenge for Business
abstract: A new global survey of consumers found that businesses — more than hackers or government — are seen as a threat to the privacy of personal information.
lead_paragraph: People around the world are thrilled by the ease and convenience of their smartphones and Internet services, but they aren’t willing to trade their privacy to get more of it.

headline: With Eric Cantor’s Loss, Is Immigration Reform Dead?
abstract: Hard-liners certainly hope it is.
lead_paragraph: People who say immigration reform is good and dead, now that House majority leader Eric Cantor lost his primary to an immigration hard-liner, include those who really want it to be dead. These are the ones shoving the pillow into immigration reform’s face.

headline: A Chef in the Field | Littleneck Clams
abstract: The briny flavor of these little hard-shelled mollusks pairs well with the smokiness of Spanish chorizo in a summery dish that comes together with wine, parsley, lemon — and butter.
lead_paragraph: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Award Categories for Grammys Are Tweaked
abstract: One change in the music awards allows use of sampling and “interpolation” in all songwriting categories; another redefines “alternative.”
lead_paragraph: The continually moving target of Grammy Award categories has shifted once again, with a handful of tweaks announced on Thursday that affect about 20 categories.

headline: Spare Times for June 13-19
abstract: A guide to street fairs, parades, literary events, performances and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Jazz Age Lawn Party (Saturday and Sunday) Hosted and conceived by the musician Michael Arenella, this annual event on Governors Island transports guests to the Roaring Twenties with hot jazz, vaudeville, tap dancing and vintage automobiles.

headline: Ex-Leader of Ivory Coast Is Ordered to Stand Trial
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The International Criminal Court said former President Laurent Gbagbo would be tried on charges of crimes against humanity in connection with violence after 2010 elections in Ivory Coast.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Laurent Gbagbo, the former Ivory Coast strongman whose refusal to accept electoral defeat in 2010 set off a brief but bloody civil war, was ordered to stand trial Thursday by the International Criminal Court in The Hague.

headline: How Obama Can Increase Taxes on Carried Interest
keywords: ['Capital Gains Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Law and Legislation', 'Private Equity', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: The White House has the legal authority to change the carried interest tax treatment of fund managers without consulting Congress, Victor Fleischer writes in the Standard Deduction column.
lead_paragraph: President Obama could change the tax treatment of carried interest with a phone call to the Treasury Department. But the White House will need a precise understanding of the regulatory landscape to make a change that is fair, easy to administer, and will hold up in court.

headline: Deconstructing the Illusion
abstract: Houdini Kitchen Laboratory is a pizzeria with good food and earnest intent that just happens to be in one of the coolest spaces in the city.
lead_paragraph: To the trophy-hunting diner, the more difficult a restaurant is to find, the more alluring it is. Consider, then, the checklist for Houdini Kitchen Laboratory: No sign. Unmarked entrance at the back of a former brewery. (Better yet, through a fence to the back “yard,” a.k.a. loading dock.) On a bleak block of industrial buildings with graffiti palimpsests and rusted drips from what pass for windows.

headline: What to Do When Crawdad Grows Anxious
keywords: ['Evolution (Biology)', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: In an experiment that indicates anxiety exists far down the food chain, scientists made crayfish nervous and then calmed them with drugs.
lead_paragraph: Crazed commuters, fretful parents and overwrought executives are not the only ones to suffer from anxiety — or to benefit from medication for it. The simple crayfish has officially entered the age of anxiety, too.

headline: Bergdahl Departs Germany for Treatment in Texas
abstract: The American prisoner of war, who was freed in exchange for Taliban detainees, will receive specialized treatment the military has designed for soldiers who have endured long periods in captivity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the American prisoner of war freed on May 31 in exchange for five senior members of the Taliban, left Ramstein Air Base in Germany on Thursday afternoon and will arrive in the United States early Friday to begin treatment at a Texas military medical facility, the Pentagon said.

headline: Boehner Slams Obama’s Response to Iraq
abstract: House Speaker John A. Boehner commented on the crisis in Iraq on Thursday and attacked President Obama’s response to the escalating violence, saying the president was “taking a nap.”
lead_paragraph: House Speaker John A. Boehner commented on the crisis in Iraq on Thursday and attacked President Obama’s response to the escalating violence, saying the president was “taking a nap.”

headline: Countries Weigh In on Iraq’s Unrest
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Terrorism', 'International Relations']
abstract: Britain, the United States, the United Nations and countries in the region react to the intense fighting in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Britain, the United States, the United Nations and countries in the region react to the intense fighting in Iraq.

headline: Teenage Endurance Driver Takes Exams While Preparing for Le Mans
abstract: For Alessandro Latif, the choice between taking his college exams and competing in his first Le Mans 24-Hour race was impossible. So he’s doing both.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Alessandro Latif didn’t betray any emotion while waiting for his exams to begin on the campus of the British School of Paris in Le Vésinet, a suburb of the French capital. But you could sense his excitement, nervousness and fatigue.

headline: Treasury’s Domestic Finance Chief to Leave
abstract: The Treasury Department’s top official for domestic finance, Mary J. Miller, plans to step down this fall after having helped to oversee the rollout of the Dodd-Frank overhaul of financial regulations.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department’s top official for domestic finance, Mary J. Miller, plans to step down this fall after having helped to oversee the rollout of the Dodd-Frank overhaul of financial regulations.

headline: After Police Dog Is Injured, Partner Responds Quickly
abstract: Officer Anthony Compitello and Caesar were training in Brooklyn when the dog had a seizure after being shocked.
lead_paragraph: For the past eight years, Officer Anthony Compitello and Caesar left for work every morning together, came home every evening together and spent nearly every hour in between working together.

headline: A Wedding and a Funeral
abstract: The most uplifting moment in one woman’s life collides with the most wrenching time in another family’s history.
lead_paragraph: Tears spill from the eyes of Maung Tin May. This is supposed to be the happiest day of her life.

headline: Kids and Parents: Happy to Move Up, Sad to Say Goodbye
abstract: I think of summer as a happy time of year—which is why I’m annually blindsided by the small sorrows of graduations and change.
lead_paragraph: This morning was the “step-up” ceremony at my children’s school. It’s the fifth time I’ve attended this same event (it’s a K-8 school) and it always follows the same leisurely pattern: acknowledging the teachers; various presentations; songs from each of the different music classes; speeches from the fifth graders who are moving on to middle school; and a class gift from the graduating eighth grade (that had a separate graduation ceremony the day before). There is no pomp and circumstance, there are no flat hats. It’s a pleasant, charming way of acknowledging the passing of another year and the inevitable forward movement of children. And the first time I attended, I felt like chewing my own arm off to escape.

headline: Brazil vs. Croatia: Live Blog
abstract: In the end, it’s the result that everyone expected, but not before Croatia scared Brazilian fans everywhere with a shock 1-0 lead.
lead_paragraph: In the end, it’s the result that everyone expected, but not before Croatia scared Brazilian fans everywhere with a shock 1-0 lead.

headline: Life in the Fast Lane
abstract: Advice about fathers and their children.
lead_paragraph: My widowed father is 80 and has begun dating a woman close to his age. She has tremendous joie de vivre, but my siblings and I worry that she is wearing our father out, scheduling social events nearly every night of the week. We want our father to enjoy his life, but not at the expense of his health, which seems to be failing. We have raised our concerns with our father, who has not taken them to heart. But we disagree about whether to speak with his new partner. Should we?

headline: We Didn’t Have a Plan, but the Baby Did
abstract: Becoming a father took me on an unpredictable and sometimes embarrassing journey.
lead_paragraph: About a year into our marriage, my wife and I decided we were ready for the adventure of having a child. Despite our best efforts, it wasn’t happening. We didn’t know why. One night as we were watching television, my wife turned to me and said, “I think you’re the problem.”

headline: Wheelies: The Made for Europeans by Tennesseans Edition
abstract: Nissan to build engines for European-market Infiniti Q50 sedans in Tennessee; Roll-Royce opens a showroom in Cambodia.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Stepan’s Sweep (of a Glove) Helps His Team Avoid One
abstract: Unlike in soccer, saving a goal with his hand was a legal move by Rangers center Derek Stepan in the Stanley Cup finals against the Kings.
lead_paragraph: Soccer has its Hand of God. Now hockey has its Hand of Stepan.

headline: UBS Hires Veteran Bank of America Executive
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: UBS has hired Jerry Marcus, a former head of Bank of America Merrill Lynch’s retail investment banking group, as a vice chairman for its Americas investment bank, the Swiss firm said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: UBS has hired Jerry Marcus, a former head of Bank of America Merrill Lynch‘s retail investment banking group, as a vice chairman for its Americas investment bank, the Swiss firm said on Thursday.

headline: Casino Owner Caesars Redefines Itself, but Still Has Mountain of Debt
abstract: Caesars Entertainment has sliced and diced its assets in a way that will save something for shareholders, but it still has a lot of debt, writes Stephen J. Lubben, the In Debt columnist.
lead_paragraph: Caesars Entertainment, the owner of several casinos, is taking a page from the Dynegy playbook. That is not meant as a compliment.

headline: Bain Capital’s Mark Nunnelly Retires
abstract: Mark Nunnelly, 55, a longtime managing director of Bain Capital, will continue to serve on the boards of a number of Bain’s portfolio companies.
lead_paragraph: Mark Nunnelly, a longtime managing director of Bain Capital, has retired from the Boston-based private equity firm, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

headline: Haitian Art and Dance in Brooklyn
abstract: A “Selebrasyon” of Haitian culture, which runs through June, features two free events this weekend in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Haitian art — a rich blend of African and European, Christian and Voodoo influences — impresses all the more when you remember that it emerges from a swirl of poverty, political violence and natural disasters.

headline: Q. and A. | Wild Belle Spreads Its Island Vibes
abstract: The stylish sibling duo talk reggae influences, keeping it in the family and dressing like rock stars.
lead_paragraph: Reggae-based pop music has unlikely torchbearers in Elliot and Natalie Bergman, a.k.a. Wild Belle. The brother-sister duo grew up around Chicago, a city that’s more Buddy Guy than Bob Marley, and spent much of their childhood like modern-day Von Trapps, singing songs around the piano with their parents and two other siblings. Elliot, who plays keyboard and saxophone and, at 32, is seven years Natalie’s senior, would go on to study jazz and play in an Afrobeat band, Nomo, at the University of Michigan. And the siblings’ travels, both literal and sonic, helped expand their musical purview. The resulting mix of sounds — indie pop tinged with reggae and ’70s soul — can be heard throughout Wild Belle’s debut album, “Isles,” released last year. And though they insist the title is more about the album’s structure than its influences (“each song is its own island,” Natalie has said), it might just as easily be a nod to Chris Blackwell’s Island Records, whose catalogue of ska and reggae hits surely left an impression.

headline: ‘A Logo for America’
abstract: A video of the work by Alfredo Jaar.
lead_paragraph: A video of the work by Alfredo Jaar.

headline: Anatomy | ‘How to Train Your Dragon 2’
abstract: Dean DeBlois narrates a sequence from “How to Train Your Dragon 2.”
lead_paragraph: Dean DeBlois narrates a sequence from “How to Train Your Dragon 2.”

headline: Drug Merger Discussion Leaves Out a Key Risk
abstract: The merger proxy for Mallinckrodt’s $5.6 billion bid for Questcor Pharmaceuticals does not include reports of incidents involving Acthar, Questcor’s immune-system drug and its biggest product.
lead_paragraph: As shareholders of the global pharmaceutical giant Mallinckrodt consider approving its $5.6 billion bid for Questcor Pharmaceuticals, a small but fast-growing California company, they must try to assess the risks associated with the deal.

headline: Mallinckrodt, Questcor and Questions About Acthar
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Acthar (Drug)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Mallinckrodt announced in April that it intended to merge with Questcor Pharmaceuticals, which makes the immune system drug Acthar. But a key filing last month did not disclose adverse effects from the drug that were reported to regulators.
lead_paragraph: Mallinckrodt announced in April that it intended to merge with Questcor Pharmaceuticals, which makes the immune system drug Acthar. But a key filing last month did not disclose adverse effects from the drug that were reported to regulators.

headline: Clip: ‘The Rover’
abstract: A scene from “The Rover,” directed by David Michod and featuring Guy Pearce and Robert Pattinson.
lead_paragraph: A scene from “The Rover,” directed by David Michod and featuring Guy Pearce and Robert Pattinson.

headline: Jump-Start Your Workday With an 8 A.M. Rave
abstract: Two morning dance-party series are gaining popularity in New York, with live music, yoga and a bar serving coffee and juice.
lead_paragraph: THREE tall, glowing jellyfish puppets swept around the club floor, illuminating the broad grins and sweat-soaked brows of the wildly hopping dancers. Thumping house remixes of Tears for Fears’ “Everybody Wants to Rule the World” and Missy Elliott’s “Work It” rattled the balcony railings. Two D.J.s pumped their fists as a small pack of brass players appeared on the balcony, bleating along to the electronic soundtrack under stark strobe lights.

headline: European Film Directors Issue Appeal for Imprisoned Ukrainian Colleague
abstract: Directors including Pedro Almodóvar and Wim Wenders express concern over the fate of Oleg Sentsov, a Ukrainian filmmaker who was arrested last month.
lead_paragraph: Top European film directors, including Pedro Almodóvar, Mike Leigh, Andrzej Wajda and Wim Wenders, have appealed to President Vladimir V. Putin and other Russian officials about the fate of Oleg Sentsov, a Ukrainian filmmaker who was arrested in Crimea last month on suspicion of plotting terrorist acts.

headline: Dean DeBlois Narrates a Scene From ‘How to Train Your Dragon 2’
abstract: The director Dean DeBlois discusses an early sequence from the film.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Dean DeBlois discusses a sequence from “How to Train Your Dragon 2,” a sequel to the 2010 blockbuster. This scene features the lead character Hiccup (voiced by Jay Baruchel) flying through the clouds with his dragon companion, Toothless.

headline: Low Vitamin D Tied to Premature Death
abstract: People with low blood levels of vitamin D are more likely to die prematurely than those with normal levels, a new analysis has found.
lead_paragraph: People with low blood levels of vitamin D are more likely to die prematurely than those with normal levels, a new analysis has found.

headline: ‘Homeless Lamp, the Juice Sucker’
abstract: Excerpt from a video of a performance by the artist Iván Navarro and his flourescent light bulb sculpture on the streets of Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Excerpt from a video of a performance by the artist Iván Navarro and his flourescent light bulb sculpture on the streets of Chelsea.

headline: In World Cup, Mexico Believes Anything Can Happen After Rough Road to Brazil
abstract: After cycling through 4 coaches and nearly 50 players and barely surviving qualifying, Mexico will begin the World Cup on Friday with a match in Group A against Cameroon.
lead_paragraph: NATAL, Brazil — In the eyes of the Mexican writer Juan Villoro, a frequent commentator on soccer and, thus, a person with a keen sense of narrative structure, the Mexico national team’s undulant path to this city unfolded much like the plot of a telenovela.

headline: Training at the Top of the World
abstract: To train for the largest descent of his life, Jeremy Jones partnered with the legendary climber Conrad Anker.
lead_paragraph: “Higher Unplugged” looks at the making of the film “Higher,” which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

headline: Clip: ‘Witching & Bitching’
abstract: A scene from the film, directed by Alex de la Iglesia.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, directed by Alex de la Iglesia.

headline: Clip: ‘Lullaby’
abstract: A scene from the film directed by Andrew Levitas.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film directed by Andrew Levitas.

headline: Three Confirmations to Fed Board May Strengthen Yellen’s Hand
abstract: The Senate confirmed two new appointees to the Federal Reserve Board, moves expected to bolster the position of Janet Yellen on key policy decisions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday brought the Federal Reserve Board a little closer to full strength, confirming Lael Brainard, a former Treasury Department official, to one of the three open seats by a vote of 61 to 31.

headline: New Flights to Colombia
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Avianca and JetBlue Airways are adding direct flights to Cartagena, reflecting increased interest in traveling to Colombia.
lead_paragraph: Two airlines have announced plans to add flights to Cartagena this year, reflecting the growth in American tourism demand in Colombia.

headline: Police Tactics Under Increased Scrutiny at World Cup
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'World Cup 2014 (Soccer)']
abstract: Protesters in Brazil accused the police of using excessive force against a demonstration in São Paulo on Thursday, ahead of the World Cup kickoff.
lead_paragraph: Protesters in Brazil accused the police of using excessive force to prevent a small group of demonstrators opposed to what they call lavish spending on the World Cup from reaching the stadium in São Paulo where the tournament began on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Defending ‘Guilty Pleasures’
abstract: Some readers argue that calling some books good and others merely fun oversimplifies the joys of reading, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: Should we feel bad about reading for fun? A Slate critique of young-adult fiction last week had readers answering mostly in the negative. But beyond any specific genre, there may be a larger conversation to be had about which books are good, which books are fun, and whether there needs to be a difference.

headline: In Store | Everlane Pops Up in SoHo
abstract: The online-only basics brand is opening a temporary store, which will host food-oriented events and provide detailed information about the origins of its products.
lead_paragraph: Since 2011, the online-only basics brand Everlane has, with its motto of “radical transparency,” encouraged consumers to ask where and how their clothes are made — and how much they are marked up (which in Everlane’s case is a fraction of the usual amount). Starting tomorrow, shoppers will have the chance to sample the brand’s understated (and, compared to similar offerings, underpriced) staples in person at a SoHo pop-up. And though it’s not Everlane’s first appearance in New York, it’s by far its largest and most social outing. Called “Open House,” the space, which operates through June 28, will host catered events with other transparency-minded organizations from the food world, such as Gather Journal and Edible Schoolyard NYC. Every garment and accessory sold in the store — whose perforated-plywood interiors come courtesy of the Isa restauranteur Taavo Somer’s creative agency, Friends and Family — will be sold alongside an infographic detailing its origin story.

headline: Getting to the Heart of Suriname
abstract: As he winds his way to the World Cup, the Frugal Traveler stops in Suriname, where he travels in the interior by boat, and experiences a chaotic slice of the capital.
lead_paragraph: Nelson Tiapoe pointed out two mature trees just a few feet apart amid the dense jungle vegetation. “When you see a mango tree and a cacao tree together, you know people used to live here,” he said. He was leading me and a 62-year-old Dutch man named Ton through the dense Amazonian rain forest of central Suriname just across the Upper Suriname River from his eco-resort, Knini Paati.

headline: Friulano, an Italian White Wine That Makes Friends Easily
abstract: Though its popularity has decreased, this flagship wine of the Friuli-Venezia Giulia region of Italy is worth rediscovering.
lead_paragraph: CIVIDALE DEL FRIULI, Italy — You may have sipped a pleasant pinot grigio from Friuli, a region in the far northeast of Italy known for its white wines and more properly called Friuli-Venezia Giulia. But you are less likely to have had a glass of friulano, a more distinguished wine that is worth discovering.

headline: Built on Historic Foundations
abstract: “Exposed: A History of Lingerie” presents 80 examples of European and American undergarments and accessories dating from the 18th century to the present.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes there’s too much theory. Sometimes too little. There’s not enough animating “Exposed: A History of Lingerie,” an otherwise nicely produced exhibition at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology. Organized by Colleen Hill, the museum’s associate curator of accessories, it presents 80 examples of European and American undergarments and accessories dating from the 18th century to the present, all from the museum’s permanent collection.

headline: Woman Is Found Hanged in Indian State
abstract: The body of a 19-year-old woman was found hanging from a eucalyptus tree, the third similar discovery in the state of Uttar Pradesh in two weeks.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The body of a 19-year-old woman was found hanging by her scarf from a eucalyptus tree in a village in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh on Thursday morning, the police said. It was the third similar gruesome discovery in the state in two weeks.

headline: Living With Cancer: ‘The Fault in Our Stars’
abstract: “Cancer kids are essentially side effects of the relentless mutation that made the diversity of life on earth possible,” says the 16-year-old narrator of John Green’s book and movie.
lead_paragraph: “Cancer books suck,” says 16-year-old Hazel Grace Lancaster. But she has a favorite and so do I. Mine is the novel John Green wrote about her.

headline: Harris’s Run in ‘Angry Inch’ Won’t Get Any Longer
abstract: Despite a strong ticket demand, Neil Patrick Harris will not say in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” beyond his scheduled Aug. 17 departure.
lead_paragraph: Neil Patrick Harris, who won the Tony Award for best actor in a musical for  “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” will not extend his run in the show beyond his scheduled departure date of Aug. 17 in spite of strong ticket demand, the show’s lead producer said on Thursday. Taking over for Mr. Harris will be Andrew Rannells, a Tony nominee as Elder Price in “The Book of Mormon” and a cast member of the HBO series “Girls,” according to the producer, David Binder.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Remember the Problems With Mortgage Defaults? They’re Coming Back With Student Loans
keywords: ['Student Loans', 'Consumer Protection', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Personal Bankruptcies']
abstract: Companies managing the loans have little incentive to devise forgiveness plans for borrowers who run into trouble.
lead_paragraph: Student loans, along with mortgages and car loans, have become one of the three largest sources of credit, exceeding credit-card debt. This growth in student debt appears to have caught regulators unprepared. Compared with mortgages, auto loans and credit cards, student loans are loosely regulated, and that regulatory weakness is particularly threatening to consumers because they can’t discharge their debts through bankruptcy and escape lenders who are causing them harm.

headline: James Jebusa Shannon’s Portraits Rescued From Obscurity
abstract: Part of a little-remembered artist’s collection is on display at Debra Force Fine Art in Manhattan through the rest of the month.
lead_paragraph: ONCE FORGOTTEN PAST, NOW RECALLED IN PAINTING

headline: Marijuana’s Journey to Legitimacy
abstract: “Evergreen: The Road to Legalization” examines the battle surrounding an initiative to permit possession of small amounts of recreational marijuana in Washington State.
lead_paragraph: “Great social policy changes are not an easy sell,” says Jonathan Martin, a reporter for The Seattle Times, in Riley Morton’s assured documentary “Evergreen.” He’s not kidding: This record of Washington State’s battle over Initiative 502, which legalized possession of small amounts of recreational marijuana in 2012, is predictably loaded with rancor. The battle isn’t over whether pot should be legalized, but to what extent.

headline: Questioning the Unimaginable: A Fifth FIFA Term for Sepp Blatter
abstract: Global soccer needs to move on from Blatter, the president of FIFA, who has shown no willingness to confront corruption in his sport.
lead_paragraph: RIO dE JANEIRO — There was that face again.

headline: Iraqi Army Retakes Government Complex in Central Ramadi
abstract: Efforts to stem the rise of the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Efforts to stem the rise of the Islamic State.

headline: A History of Awesome in One Room
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature', 'Art', 'Libraries and Librarians']
abstract: There is much, maybe too much, to revere at “Marks of Genius: Treasures From the Bodleian Library” at the Morgan Library & Museum.
lead_paragraph: THE MORGAN LIBRARY & MUSEUM does not usually put trash on the wall, but there are exceptions. Among the nearly 60 rare books, manuscripts and objects on exhibit in “Marks of Genius: Treasures From the Bodleian Library” is a constellation of khaki-colored papyrus scraps retrieved about a century ago from an ancient dump outside the vanished Egyptian city of Oxyrhynchus. Over the years, excavations at the site have yielded census forms, invoices, bureaucratic correspondence and the occasional literary find — in this instance, a fragment of verse by Sappho, inscribed in Greek in the second century A.D., from the first of the nine books of poems she is known to have written.

headline: A German Rebel in South Africa
abstract: Jürgen Schadeberg left Nazi Germany to pursue photography in South Africa, where he documented the black struggle and trained a generation of photographers.
lead_paragraph: Jürgen Schadeberg left Nazi Germany to pursue photography in South Africa, where he documented the black struggle and trained a generation of photographers.

headline: A Photographer Recalls Her Life Within a Demimonde
abstract: This documentary follows Nan Goldin from Paris to Berlin, and interviews her subjects as well as the artist herself.
lead_paragraph: A long time ago, a doctor told the photographer Nan Goldin that she had the genes of an Olympic athlete. Just as well: Even while eliding the details of her colorful, adventurous past, “Nan Goldin: I Remember Your Face” contains enough throwaway references to bodily harm to make her and her admirers grateful for the gifts of biology.

headline: Movies Listings for June 13-19
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Arriving Late to the Party, but Dancing on All the Clichés
abstract: “Under the Same Sun: Art From Latin America Today” is the second phase of the Guggenheim Museum’s three-part UBS MAP Global Art Initiative.
lead_paragraph: Our big museums were built by businessmen, and significant changes are usually about making money. In these days of international markets and a cosmopolitan tourist flow, it pays for Western Modernist strongholds to look culturally embracing. This helps explain the Guggenheim’s UBS MAP Global Art Initiative, a three-phase collecting venture that finds the museum buying and showing the kinds of work it has paid little attention to in the past.

headline: Letters: Summer Reading Issue
abstract: Readers respond to a recent cover illustration, a review of Laline Paull’s “The Bees” and more.
lead_paragraph: Summer Reading Issue

headline: Navigating Persistence and Despair
abstract: Ben Watt, formerly of Everything but the Girl, performed at Joe’s Pub on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A line Ben Watt sang at Joe’s Pub on Wednesday night — “Who am I fooling when I say I have no regrets?” — could encapsulate his songwriting. It’s modest, pensive, backhanded, self-questioning, emotional yet elegantly restrained.

headline: Antics Pierced by Angst
abstract: “Ayckburn Ensemble,” a medley of plays by Alan Ayckbourn at 59E59 Theaters, offers a rich opportunity to explore the sadness of his antic consumerist characters.
lead_paragraph: Emily Dickinson, a very American poet, may have called hope “the thing with feathers.” But for the British playwright Alan Ayckbourn, hope is largely a flightless creature. It flaps its wings from time to time, but it seldom gets far off the ground.

headline: The Battle Money Couldn’t Win
abstract: The Vanderbilts tried to keep their section of Fifth Avenue residential, but commercial interests won out.
lead_paragraph: The dowdy loft building at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 52nd Street is about as blank as a building can get, just limestone and windows. But it sent the Vanderbilt family over the edge, the symbol of their defeat after years of attempts to preserve the residential sanctity of this stretch of New York’s most famous address.

headline: Schomburg to Create Center to Study Slave Trade
abstract: The Schomburg Center is establishing a new center for the analysis of the trans-Atlantic slave trade, thanks to a $2.5 million private gift.
lead_paragraph: The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture is establishing a major new center for the analysis of the trans-Atlantic slave trade, the only such center based in a public research library, Schomburg officials said on Thursday.

headline: Jayson Musson: ‘Exhibit of Abstract Art’
abstract: This exhibition’s works are based on images satirizing Modern art that occasionally appeared in Ernie Bushmiller’s great comic strip, “Nancy.”
lead_paragraph: Salon 94 Bowery

headline: Ken Price: ‘Specimen Rocks’
abstract: Exhibitions of Price’s large painted bronze sculptures in two Matthew Marks Gallery spaces show him pushing his work into new territory to the end.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Marks Gallery

headline: A Car Is Stolen, Setting Off an Angry Pursuit
abstract: In “The Rover,” set in a bleak Australia, a man sets out for revenge after thugs take his vehicle.
lead_paragraph: “The Rover,” David Michôd’s new film, takes place in Australia 10 years after an unspecified event called the Collapse, which has left everyone in a bad mood and catastrophically short of shaving supplies. This is not quite the apocalyptic ground zero of “The Road” or “The Road Warrior” (speaking of Down Under dystopias). Roving bands of armed men drive around shooting, but some of them wear uniforms and fill out government paperwork when they catch someone. Money still works (American dollars are preferred over Australian), and there seems to be enough food, gasoline and ammunition to keep everybody alert, mobile and angry.

headline: ‘A Painter and His Poets’: ‘The Art of George Schneeman’
abstract: Artists’s artists make up a highly select category. Poets’ artists occupy an even narrower niche, and George Schneeman filled it completely.
lead_paragraph: Poets House

headline: Barely Moving, but Communicating Volumes
abstract: The Performance Mix Festival featured the Canadian artist Dana Michel, who remains wholly original and hard to classify.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian performance artist Dana Michel is a real original, peculiar to the nth degree and remarkably compelling onstage. She scarcely dances; she scarcely speaks; her manner is oblique. It would be easy to make what she does sound ridiculous. Yet no sooner does she take the stage than she creates a complex world. She’s doing a singular form of acting, and we’re caught up by the strangeness of both her outward behavior and her character’s private thoughts. For me and others, she was the one important discovery of the American Realness Festival at the Abrons Arts Center in January.

headline: Events in Westchester for June 15-21, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: A Show That Really Gets Into Your Head
abstract: The Franklin Institute’s new permanent exhibition, “Your Brain,” immerses visitors in the human body’s most complicated and astounding part.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Clambering upward in dim violet light, stepping from one glass platform to another, you trigger flashes of light and polyps of sound. You climb through protective tubes of metallic mesh as you make your way through a maze of pathways. You are an electrical signal coursing through a neural network. You are immersed in the human brain.

headline: Mark Rothko: ‘The Watercolors 1941-47’
abstract: Watercolor was the perfect medium for the transitional period of Rothko’s career.
lead_paragraph: Pace Gallery

headline: The Antidote to Sweet
abstract: Kara Walker makes ingenious connections in “Ruffneck Constructivists,” which showcases 11 international artists at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — With her site-specific sphinx-goddess on view at the former Domino Sugar Factory in Brooklyn, Kara Walker is making a bold leap from two dimensions into three. And she has many more thoughts brewing on the subjects of sculpture and architecture, to judge from “Ruffneck Constructivists,” a smart, gripping and confrontational show she organized for the Institute of Contemporary Art here.

headline: Conversation Served With Cocktails
abstract: Under new ownership, Big Bar is a place where quick drinks willingly turn into long chats in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: IT was at some point between mixing caipirinhas and doing a little dance to Ann-Margret’s rendition of “Thirteen Men” (“Last night I was dreaming/I dreamed about the H-bomb”) that Bryan Richgruber, a bartender at Big Bar in the East Village, quietly said, “Isn’t this a great bar?”

headline: Sycamore Takes 10% Stake in Express and Seeks a Deal
abstract: It is the latest acquisition attempt by Sycamore, which has fashioned itself as a specialist in retailers having acquired the Jones Group, Talbots and Hot Topic.
lead_paragraph: The investment firm Sycamore Partners disclosed on Thursday that it had acquired a 9.9 percent stake in Express Inc., the fashionable retailer that has hit a slump of late, and is interested in buying the rest of the company.

headline: Missed Connections
abstract: In Boris Fishman’s first novel, a frustrated writer forges applications for Holocaust reparations for his grandfather and other members of Brooklyn’s Soviet émigré community.
lead_paragraph: Is there room in American fiction for another brilliant young émigré writer? There had better be, because here he is. Boris Fishman’s first novel, “A Replacement Life,” is bold, ambitious and wickedly smart.

headline: A Difficult Woman, With a Past Worth Writing About
abstract: A biographical portrait of the author Violette Leduc, Martin Provost’s “Violette” traces a life that included humble beginnings.
lead_paragraph: In “Violette,” Emmanuelle Devos plays one of those impossible women who can’t give anyone, most of all herself, a break. For Violette Leduc, a black marketeer turned celebrated writer, life is a series of crushing disappointments, from the mother who never took her hand to the friends who never stay. Early in the film when a friend leaves the home they share, he sneaks out like a thief. He knows her too well. She doesn’t let him go; rather, she chases him down a road, frantically pulling at him and howling. This is a woman who doesn’t feed on misery: She gorges on it.

headline: Man Without a Country
abstract: For the celebrated Austrian writer Stefan Zweig, Europe’s descent into war in the 1930s was too much to bear.
lead_paragraph: The last full-length book Stefan Zweig wrote was a memoir called “The World of Yesterday,” an elegy for the Viennese culture that had nurtured his literary talent and was, in 1941, in the process of being wiped out by fascism and world war. The book was completed in Brazil, where Zweig and his second wife, Lotte, had settled after years of expatriate hopscotching and where they would commit suicide on Feb. 22, 1942.

headline: Out of Berlin, the Heart of an Artist
abstract: An exhibition at the Neue Nationalgalerie in Berlin should thrill and surprise even the most devoted Marsden Hartley fan.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Before Jasper Johns or Jackson Pollock, there was Marsden Hartley, America’s first great modern painter of the 20th century. He achieved this distinction in Paris and most of all in Berlin between early 1912 and late 1915. There he produced a stream of paintings that synthesized Cubism and other European modernisms, mixed in non-Western motifs and mysterious symbols and culminated in his lusty, elegiac German Officer paintings.

headline: In Serious Pursuit, Even in Clown Shoes
abstract: The saxophonist Charles Gayle, honored for lifetime achievement, played many roles at the Vision Festival Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: In a musician’s work, you often hear a position or an effect or a big idea: humor, revision, argument, discipline, cynicism, romance. It’s just something extra to engage, a filter or transformer between the creative force inside him and the expectations of his listeners. Not so much, though, in the work of Charles Gayle, who played through opening night of this year’s Vision Festival on Wednesday night at Roulette, as bandleader and duet partner and conductor; playing saxophone, piano and bass; and in and out of clown clothes. He seems almost transparent: Your hearing cuts right through to what animates him.

headline: Hellfighters, High Finance and an Heiress
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: One book gives the history of the 15th New York National Guard Regiment; another traces the trajectory of high finance in New York City; and another is on Huguette Clark, a reclusive copper heiress who died in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Before the 15th New York National Guard Regiment was formed, black Americans who wanted to enlist against the Germans in World War I had to join the French or Canadian Army. By the end of the war, this all-black regiment was famous on both sides of the Atlantic for never losing an inch of ground to the enemy, or a single man to capture.

headline: F.D.A. Issues Clarification, but Cheese Makers Are Wary
keywords: ['Cheese', 'Wood and Wood Products', 'Listeria Monocytogenes', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning']
abstract: Cheese makers remain suspicious even after the Food and Drug Administration said late Wednesday that it had erred.
lead_paragraph: The panic over what appeared to be a change in the federal rules that govern the craft of artisan cheese making seems to be dying down, but cheese makers remain suspicious, even after the Food and Drug Administration said late Wednesday that it had erred.

headline: Agnes Varda in Chris Marker’s Studio
abstract: The French filmmaker Agnès Varda visits with Chris Marker at his home.
lead_paragraph: The French filmmaker Agnès Varda visits with Chris Marker at his home.

headline: An Extended Family Puts on a Big Recital
abstract: For the inaugural Ailey Spirit Gala, at Lincoln Center, the main company shared the stage with members of Ailey II, the Ailey School and AileyCamp.
lead_paragraph: Alvin Ailey died almost 25 years ago at the too-young age of 58, yet his company, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, remains undeniably robust, unlike many that have lost their founders. So much so that it’s no longer just a company. The institution has tiers, as showcased Wednesday during the inaugural Ailey Spirit Gala at the David H. Koch Theater, where the main company shared the stage with members of Ailey II, the Ailey School and AileyCamp.

headline: Orpheus Descending and Arising
abstract: The indomitable Yefim Bronfman starred in the New York Philharmonic’s minifestival of Beethoven’s piano concertos.
lead_paragraph: The indomitable Yefim Bronfman stars in the New York Philharmonic’s minifestival of Beethoven’s piano concertos unveiled on Wednesday at Avery Fisher Hall with glowing performances of the first and fourth concertos.

headline: Who Was Gyp the Blood?
abstract: A reader asked about Gyp the Blood, the leader of the feared Lenox Avenue Gang in the early 1900s in New York.
lead_paragraph: Q.My father used to tell me that when he was a little boy, he was scared to death at hearing stories about a gangster known as Gyp the Blood. Can you tell me something about this person?

headline: Clip: ‘Hellion’
abstract: A scene from the film, directed by Kat Candler.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, directed by Kat Candler.

headline: Mosul Residents Flee as Unrest Spreads
abstract: Thousands of Mosul residents continued to flee the violence in Iraq’s second-largest city after Al Qaeda-inspired militants seized the area.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Mosul residents continued to flee the violence in Iraq’s second-largest city after Al Qaeda-inspired militants seized the area.

headline: Protests Spread Across Brazil
abstract: Demonstrators clashed with the police in São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro a few hours before the opening game of the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators clashed with the police in São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro a few hours before the opening game of the World Cup.

headline: Player Tumbles; Opposition Falls
abstract: Brazil, the host country and favorite for the World Cup, was awarded a penalty kick despite Croatia’s protests, leading to the decisive goal in the tournament opener.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — It was Dia dos Namorados on Thursday, the Brazilian equivalent of Valentine’s Day, which meant there were chocolates and flowers and couples holding hands tucked among the sea of yellow jerseys that stretched from the Itaquera neighborhood over to Jardins. From sunrise all the way until the shimmering moon peeked above the skyline, Brazilians showed their passion for one another, and for soccer, as the World Cup began.

headline: Brides Gather Outside Court to Jeer Restaurateur Who Dashed Wedding Plans
abstract: The half-dozen women had once pinned their wedding-day hopes on Jason Stevens, the owner of the now-closed event space reBar, who pleaded guilty to charges of tax fraud.
lead_paragraph: The balding man dressed in black knew plenty of the people in the Brooklyn courtroom, watching on Thursday morning as he pleaded guilty to charges of tax fraud. But as he hurried out of the courthouse and into a waiting car, he did not lift his eyes to acknowledge a single one of them.

headline: Celebrating a Salsa Legacy
abstract: The SummerStage concert series will include a focus on Fania Records’ 50th anniversary and the roots of salsa.
lead_paragraph: FROM the beginning, the kinetically danceable Latin music style known as salsa had deep New York roots. It was created by musicians who, though mostly of Caribbean origins, lived here, played in clubs here for audiences trying to find their footing here and recorded in studios here for a label that was also born here: Fania Records.

headline: When Teenage Anger Spirals Like a Texas Tornado
abstract: “Hellion,” by Kat Candler, explores the back story of a 13-year-old vandal.
lead_paragraph: Going nowhere slowly and with great deliberation, “Hellion” presents a fractured family locked in a closed loop of adolescent misbehavior and adult retaliation. The instigator is Jacob (Josh Wiggins), a troubled 13-year-old whose father, Hollis (Aaron Paul), has withdrawn into boozy depression after the death of his wife. Now a distant parent and indifferent housekeeper, Hollis provides little for Jacob and his younger brother (Deke Garner), aside from junk food and remonstrations.

headline: Oy Gevalt! Untranslated Yiddish Recordings Stall State Senator’s Trial
abstract: Prosecutors in the trial of Malcolm A. Smith did not promptly turn over thousands of taped conversations, which could cause a delay or a mistrial.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — In an odd twist in a courtroom saga dense with allegations of political corruption, the fate of State Senator Malcolm A. Smith and two other defendants may be put on hold because, of all things, Yiddish.

headline: Two Bands of True Believers Hurtling Toward a Collision
abstract: In the Israeli drama “Policeman,” an elite counterterrorism squad faces off with a band of youthful revolutionaries.
lead_paragraph: There are moments in “Policeman” when it feels as if the director Nadav Lapid is drawing one very large noose around his characters. That’s especially true early in this hypnotic, slow-building shocker from Israel, before the narrative pieces have slid into place, revealing Mr. Lapid’s intentions. Certainly, nothing looks out of the ordinary in the opening images of five men bicycling up a steep country road. That is until one, Yaron (Yiftach Klein), breaks away and begins riding so hard and fast toward the camera that he looks as if he might break through the screen.

headline: Abandon the Two-State Solution?
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed article by Dani Dayan, a former leader of West Bank settlers.

headline: Now Screening | Travels With Agnès Varda
abstract: The doyenne of French New Wave cinema, now in her 80s, has just released an enchanting five-part travel series in which she visits old friends like Chris Marker and Anouk Aimée, and makes some new ones too.
lead_paragraph: In her new five-part travel series “From Here to There” (available through SundanceNOW’s subscription program, Doc Club), the French filmmaker Agnès Varda, now 86, sometimes referred to as “The Grandmother of New Wave,” attends art and film festivals, visits old friends, interviews favorite artists and makes new acquaintances. Most of the time, a camera is in her hand. Occasionally, someone else is filming and she enters the scene. Whether in front of the lens or behind it, her curiosity is boundless and rooted in a desire to share her friendships and pleasures. “The main subject is ‘the other,'” she says. “I’m present in my films, I’m among the others.”

headline: Keeping Troubled Youths Out of Solitary
abstract: Experts in juvenile services respond to an editorial, “A Model for Juvenile Detention Reform”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
