keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Women and Girls', 'Waiters and Waitresses', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Dawn Sweeney of the National Restaurant Association takes issue with an editorial, “Tipped Into Poverty.”

headline: From the Friedman Forum: ‘What Is a Job Today, and Who Is Getting Hired?’
abstract: Remarks delivered by Thomas L. Friedman at the start of his second Next New World conference, in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: From the Editor: Below are the prepared remarks Thomas L. Friedman delivered today at the start of his second annual Next New World forum. This year’s conference, held in San Francisco, focused on the question, “What is a job today, and who is getting hired?” Speakers included Andrew McAfee, co-founder of the M.I.T. Initiative on the Digital Economy; Sebastian Thrun, chief executive of Udacity; Laszlo Bock, head of human resources at Google; David Coleman, president and chief executive of the College Board; and Jeff Weiner, chief executive of LinkedIn.

headline: The Cathedral and the Towers
abstract: Laura Friedman of the Morningside Heights Historic District Committee responds to a Critic’s Notebook about the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Helping Students Succeed
abstract: A former high school teacher urges that educators focus on the early school years to lower dropout rates.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Brokers Fight Rule to Favor Best Interests of Customers
keywords: ['Financial Brokers', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Personal Finances', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: The financial industry is fiercely fighting a change in a pension law that would require more finance professionals to act as fiduciaries for their customers.
lead_paragraph: David O’Brien, a certified financial planner, has tried to repair the retirement portfolios of several victims over the years. There was the high school science teacher who didn’t realize she had been sold a variable annuity, where layers of incomprehensible fees devoured nearly 2.5 percent of her retirement savings each year. Then there was the woman fighting cancer, who was also sold a high-cost annuity, but whose underlying investments were tied up in a money-market type fund — one that cost 1.5 percent annually.

headline: Jazz Listings for June 13-19
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: This Week’s Movies | June 13, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “22 Jump Street,” “How to Train Your Dragon 2” and “The Rover.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “22 Jump Street,” “How to Train Your Dragon 2” and “The Rover.”

headline: Tenure Decision Draws Sharp Debate
abstract: A California judge’s rejection of teacher tenure almost edged out surprising election results in the number of comments it drew on our site.
lead_paragraph: Timothy R. Williams is a community moderator, monitoring comments submitted to the website.

headline: Events in New Jersey for June 15-21, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Iraq, Greece, Ukraine and France.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Iraq, Greece, Ukraine and France.

headline: Clip: ‘Test’
abstract: A scene from the film, directed by Chris Mason Johnson.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, directed by Chris Mason Johnson.

headline: 36 Hours in Venice
abstract: Sip and snack canalside, indulge in gelato for breakfast and forage for not-so-touristy souvenirs during a weekend in northern Italy.
lead_paragraph: As frustrating as it is fascinating, Venice is not an easy city to get to know. Getting lost is a given. The crowds can be beastly. And yes, the whole place is sinking — literally under rising sea levels, and figuratively beneath the weight of day-tripping tourists. But these obstacles have not hindered this beguiling city from establishing itself over the past decade as the pre-eminent place in Italy for contemporary art. More recently, a wave of high-end hotels has opened along the Grand Canal, and back alleys have been set abuzz with new nightspots and a revived restaurant scene. So leave the famous sights to the crowds and instead drink up the less overt charms of this watery wonderland.

headline: Grimly Staring in the Mirror, a Dancer in ’85
abstract: “Test,” a drama centering on a dancer in San Francisco, recalls a period of intense anxiety in the mid-1980s as gay men waited to learn whether they were H.I.V. positive.
lead_paragraph: “Test,” set in San Francisco in 1985, captures with extraordinary precision and sensitivity the moment when an H.I.V. test became available, and the city’s gay men faced the daunting prospect of finding out their status. In those scary days, there was no pharmaceutical regimen that could arrest the disease. And as one man, looking ahead to a future of sexual self-discipline, puts it, “Monogamy seems so unnatural.” In the golden era of promiscuity and unprotected sex, the notion of suddenly having to use condoms seemed almost an affront, not to mention inconvenient.

headline: Events on Long Island for June 15-21, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut for June 15-21, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Ford Lowers Gas Mileage on 6 Models, All 2013-14s
abstract: Six new Ford models, including the 2014 Ford Fiesta, as well as some hybrid and plug-in hybrid versions, are involved.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in less than a year, the Ford Motor Company is lowering the fuel-economy ratings for some of its vehicles.

headline: Kentile Floors Sign, a Stalwart Remnant of a Grittier Brooklyn, Will Get a New Home
abstract: The owner of the warehouse building beneath the sign has agreed to donate it to a neighborhood nonprofit group, the Gowanus Alliance, which will find a place to re-install it.
lead_paragraph: It is confirmed: The Kentile Floors sign in Brooklyn is coming down.

headline: An Insurer and an Ad Agency Join Forces, Again
abstract: The advertising is to appear, beginning in late summer, during televised coverage of National Football League games as well as in print, digital and outdoor media.
lead_paragraph: A WALK down memory lane for a major marketer and one of its former advertising agencies, inspired by “Mad Men,” is ending with a reunion.

headline: When Chaos Trumps Civility
abstract: A young Mexican factory worker faces a world ruled by cruelty in “Heli.”
lead_paragraph: The opening scenes of Amat Escalante’s “Heli” establish the terrible contradiction that ensnares its main character, a young Mexican factory worker. First, we see a brazen but also unnervingly businesslike act of brutality, in which a group of men drag two bound-and-battered hostages from the bed of a pickup truck and hang one of them, stripped to his underwear, from a highway overpass. Then we meet Heli (Armando Espitia) as he answers a knock on the door and chats with a friendly census worker in a bright yellow polo shirt. Her questions sound reasonable enough at first: How many people in the household? What is your profession? Later they will seem grotesquely irrelevant to the facts of Heli’s life.

headline: Global Rules for Auditors? Don’t Hold Your Breath
keywords: ['ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Though a complete conversion to international rules by the United States is highly unlikely, it seems possible that some domestic companies will be allowed to convert to international rules if they wish.
lead_paragraph: Chris Cox, who as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission tried to bring international accounting rules to the United States, has now done an about-face.

headline: One Generation Passes; Another One Grumbles
abstract: An obnoxious young man learns life lessons as his father nears death in “Lullaby,” the directorial debut of Andrew Levitas.
lead_paragraph: Am I a hardhearted meanie because I watched “Lullaby,” a solemn, triple-hankie sobfest about assisted suicide, in a state of dry-eyed impatience? Maybe so. But “Lullaby,” the directorial debut of Andrew Levitas, a jack of all artistic trades, is the kind of manipulative, cliché-infested hokum that alienates moviegoers by its insistence on hogging all the tears. Its subliminal message — “I’m more sensitive than you could possibly be” — is exclusionary, and much of its stilted dialogue (“It’s hard to love someone who’s got an expiration date stamped on their forehead”) is cringe worthy.

headline: The Fix Isn’t In
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: The surprise primary defeat of Eric Cantor is the unraveling of an ideological movement.
lead_paragraph: How big a deal is the surprise primary defeat of Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader? Very. Movement conservatism, which dominated American politics from the election of Ronald Reagan to the election of Barack Obama — and which many pundits thought could make a comeback this year — is unraveling before our eyes.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: Jesus, You’ll Be the Stick-Up Guy. SpongeBob, You’re a Lookout.
abstract: “Witching & Bitching” centers on a gold heist in Spain that goes awry when the criminals flee to a border town that is known for its occult contingent.
lead_paragraph: Not counting a prologue right out of “Macbeth,” the Spanish comedy “Witching & Bitching” begins as a madcap heist picture. In Madrid, a group of hapless would-be criminals — dressed as a silver Christ, a soldier, Minnie Mouse, the Invisible Man and SpongeBob SquarePants — steals gold from a pawnshop.

headline: Taking On Teacher Tenure Backfires
abstract: Firing bad educators won’t close the achievement gap.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — IN his decision on Tuesday to strike down California’s teacher-tenure system, Judge Rolf M. Treu of Los Angeles Superior Court ruled that laws protecting teachers from dismissal violated the state’s constitutional commitment to provide “a basically equal opportunity to achieve a quality education” and drew parallels with prior cases concerning school desegregation and funding levels.

headline: Cy Twombly Works Donated to Tate Modern
abstract: Following the wishes of Cy Twombly, his foundation has donated paintings and sculptures to the Tate Modern in London.
lead_paragraph: Since 2010, the Tate Modern in London has devoted a gallery to Cy Twombly, the postwar American painter who died in 2011. In it are three large paintings from his “Bacchus” series — enormous abstract canvases of drippy red spirals dating from 2006-8 — along with five bronze sculptures and assemblages of found objects, such as the top of an olive barrel, that were made between 1979 and 1991.

headline: Secrets of the Ordinary Dad
abstract: On Father’s Day, I would try to give him something practical, like a drill or an electric carving knife. But a few weeks later, he’d give it back.
lead_paragraph: His gut was a jellyroll or two over the belt line and he smoked these discount cigarettes he bought by the carton, but that didn’t keep him from showing me one of his more nimble tricks. We’d wait till just after kickoff at the football game, the Cougars of Washington State. Then he’d lead me around the side where we could sneak in by crawling under a small opening in a big chain-link fence. I was 6 or 7.

headline: Private Toll Road Considered to Counter Population Boom
abstract: The Texas Turnpike Corporation of Dallas has proposed a private toll road to connect Greenville and Wylie.
lead_paragraph: Facing traffic congestion that is only expected to get worse, officials in North Texas are weighing a proposal to build a toll road for commuters into Dallas. The Texas Turnpike Corporation of Dallas has proposed a private toll road, the only of its kind in the state, connecting Greenville and Wylie, and local transportation officials say they are keeping an open mind.

headline: Truth as a Tinderbox That Must Disappear
abstract: The Iranian director Mohammad Rasoulof’s thriller “Manuscripts Don’t Burn” depicts a hunt by state assassins for a manuscript recounting an attempt to kill intellectuals.
lead_paragraph: Depicting his combustible material with a cool head and a steady hand, the Iranian filmmaker Mohammad Rasoulof — defying a 20-year government ban on his work — makes “Manuscripts Don’t Burn” a slow-motion explosion of anti-authoritarian rage.

headline: Save the Frick Collection
abstract: The new expansion plan isn’t right for the small museum in a mansion.
lead_paragraph: AMERICA has few mansions built by a family with an art collection they meant to share with the public. So when word came this week that the Frick Collection, on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, was planning to expand and build a six-story addition where there is now a discreet garden and a splashing fountain with lily pads — one of those few places in the cityscape where we are allowed to stop and breathe — I felt blunt disappointment, as well as betrayal.

headline: Under the Skin
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexual', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation', 'Depression (Mental)']
abstract: The next fight for transgender insurance equality will happen in the states.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — TRANSGENDER Americans scored a major victory for equality last month, when the Department of Health and Human Services overturned a decades-old ban on Medicare coverage for gender-confirming surgeries.

headline: A Young Man’s Dark-Roasted Day
abstract: “A Coffee in Berlin,” Jan Ole Gerster’s feature film debut, follows a young man’s twisting path.
lead_paragraph: A day-in-the-life story, “A Coffee in Berlin” follows the downward-sloping fortunes of Niko, a scruffily poetic slacker who loses his girlfriend, his driver’s license and his financial support from Daddy. And that’s before night falls.

headline: New York Attorney General Supports a Bill Regulating Payroll Cards
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Debit Cards', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Eric T. Schneiderman is supporting a bill that will regulate payroll cards, A.T.M.-style cards that some employers are using to pay employees.
lead_paragraph: After firing a warning shot last July, New York’s attorney general has stepped up his battle against the A.T.M.-style cards that some of the state’s largest employers use to pay their workers.

headline: Democrats Hope for Shift in Their Favor
abstract: Texas Democrats seek to close the margin between Republican and Democratic votes to better prepare for the 2016 election season.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Those Offensive Linemen Make a Filling Meal
abstract: Outliers in the high school social strata take their witch-enabled revenge on the popular kids in “All Cheerleaders Die.”
lead_paragraph: One witch and four cheerleaders enact savage revenge on the stars of a high school football team in “All Cheerleaders Die,” a trashy horror caper oozing blood and pheromones.

headline: Hostile Takeover Bids for Big Firms Across Industries Make a Comeback
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Boards of Directors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Hostile and unsolicited deal activity is up sharply this year, according to Thomson Reuters, with nearly $100 billion in hostile activity.
lead_paragraph: Endurance Specialty Holdings’ offer for Aspen Insurance Holdings in April did not get much attention from the broader business world.

headline: A Move to Get Youths to Take Tuition Aid After Foster Care
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Children and Childhood', 'Tuition', 'Foster Care', 'Community Colleges', 'Youth']
abstract: Legislators are examining whether a new approach is needed to get former foster youth in Texas to take advantage of an exemption from college tuition.
lead_paragraph: By the time Corey Vollette decided to go to college — after years spent adrift after dropping out of high school — it was too late to take advantage of an exemption from tuition and fees at a public college or university in Texas.

headline: In Emerging Markets, What Scares Most Investors Entices Oppenheimer
abstract: Justin M. Leverenz’s emerging market fund has outperformed most of his peers since 2010.
lead_paragraph: The day has been long for Justin M. Leverenz, who runs America’s largest emerging markets mutual fund at Oppenheimer Funds.

headline: Westchester Adopts a New Plan to Save Rye Playland
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Ice Skating', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS']
abstract: The new direction for the money-losing amusement park scraps a blueprint for a revenue-producing field house and focuses instead on upgrading its ice rink.
lead_paragraph: How to save Rye Playland, the old-timey amusement park in Rye, N.Y., owned by Westchester County, has been a conundrum, and a source of local tension, for years.

headline: Winding Journeys to the N.B.A.’s Summit
abstract: Reigning superstars claim much of the attention at the N.B.A. finals, but also fascinating are the veteran role players with an opportunity to win the prize that eluded some of the very best.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Fortune is not often discriminatory when it chooses those it will ultimately smile upon. Eleven years ago, before he became the ink-swathed and enigmatic Birdman, Chris Andersen was merely a very tall tag-along, uncomfortably folded into the way back of my Volvo station wagon.

headline: From Invalid to Nanny, in a Twinkling of an Eye
abstract: In “The Amazing Catfish,” an ailing young woman finds herself thrust into the family of a woman with whom she just shared a hospital room.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican director Claudia Sainte-Luce orchestrates the beginning of “The Amazing Catfish” to show her sluggish main character — a young supermarket clerk, also named Claudia — finally waking up, in a manner of speaking. First she literally awakens, in an ineffably eerie, dimly lighted scene. But it’s during a sudden hospital visit, in a room with an older woman named Martha (Lisa Owen), that she feels the unfamiliar tug of family.

headline: Clothes Make the Player
abstract: Eric Tosky, 58, wears a full baseball uniform in his softball league, drawing teasing from players dressed in shorts and T-shirts.
lead_paragraph: The Great Neck Weekend Softball league — with its modest slogan: “The Greatest Pickup Game on Earth” — does not take itself too seriously.

headline: Methodists to Sell Shares as a Protest Over Israel
abstract: The pension board of the United Methodist Church has decided to divest its shares in a British company that supplies security equipment to Israel.
lead_paragraph: The pension board of the nation’s largest mainline Protestant denomination, the United Methodist Church, has decided to divest its shares in a British company that supplies security equipment to Israel for use in prisons and in the occupied West Bank.

headline: U.S. Bishops Seek to Match Vatican in Shifting Tone
abstract: Fifteen months into the pontificate of Pope Francis, the Roman Catholic bishops of the United States find themselves unsettled in ways large and small.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — They are rethinking what kinds of houses they live in, and what kinds of cars they drive. They are wondering whether, in anticipation of the 2016 presidential election, they need to rewrite their advice to parishioners to make sure that poverty, and not just abortion, is discussed as a high-priority issue. And they are trying to get better about returning phone calls, reaching out to the disenchanted and the disenfranchised, and showing up at events.

headline: U.S. Denies Talk on 2022 World Cup
abstract: The president of the United States soccer federation, Sunil Gulati, denied a report that FIFA had asked it to form an organizing committee that could take over preparations for the 2022 World Cup if it is taken away from Qatar.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The president of the United States Soccer Federation, Sunil Gulati, denied a report that FIFA had asked it to form an organizing committee that could take over preparations for the 2022 World Cup if it is taken away from Qatar.

headline: A Good Ruling on Privacy
keywords: ['Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Wireless Communications', 'Privacy', 'Editorials', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Search and Seizure', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Cellphone tracking cannot be allowed to trample the Fourth Amendment.
lead_paragraph: The capacity of cellphones to track people’s movements and provide a vivid picture of their private lives poses a substantial and growing threat to privacy.

headline: The Port Authority Is Fooled Again
abstract: A deal to save the struggling city of Bayonne, N.J., was a good deal for Gov. Chris Christie, but not for the bistate authority.
lead_paragraph: The purchase of 131 acres along the waterfront of Bayonne, N.J., in 2010 was a fabulous bargain for the seller, the struggling city of Bayonne, and a windfall for New Jersey’s governor, Chris Christie. It was not such a good deal for the buyer — the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

headline: Iraq in Peril
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: It is up to Iraq to show leadership in the face of recent insurgent victories. The United States cannot be sucked into another round of war.
lead_paragraph: What’s happening in Iraq is a disaster and it is astonishing that the Iraqis and the Americans, who have been sharing intelligence, seem to have been caught flat-footed by the speed of the insurgent victories and the army defections.

headline: ‘A Lot of Oops Moments,’ but the Scores at the U.S. Open Aren’t Too Shabby
abstract: Unpredictability was expected at Pinehurst, which had been restored to look as it did in the 1930s, but some of the results of Thursday’s first round looked overly retro.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — Matt Kuchar’s second shot at the 18th hole rolled through the green, sped down an embankment and did not stop until it was in the clubhouse. A Brandt Snedeker bunker shot ricocheted behind him and settled in the woods. Justin Rose came within an inch of a hole in one, but after his ball flirted with the cup, it ended up so far from the hole Rose chose a wood to play his next shot. In a flash, a near ace became a bogey.

headline: A Woman Is Courted, but the Suitor Is Her Father
abstract: The daughter of the screenwriter Roger Towne directs, writes and stars in her own film, “I Am I.”
lead_paragraph: To the mini-trend in films about aging parents in decline (“Amour,” “Away From Her,” the recent “Grand Départ”), add “I Am I,” a wispy vanity project for the writer-director-actress Jocelyn Towne. Rachael (Ms. Towne) is at her mother’s funeral when she encounters Gene (Kevin Tighe), her father, who left shortly after Rachael was born. Gene, his memory dimming, has been in a retirement home. When he meets Rachael, he falls under the delusion that she is her mother, for whom he still carries a torch. Rachael, to know him better, eventually decides to play along.

headline: Obama’s Odds With Congress: Bad to Worse
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Representative Eric Cantor and President Obama never got along, but Mr. Cantor’s primary defeat this week may also mean the defeat for what remains of Mr. Obama’s legislative agenda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One day in April, President Obama called Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, to wish him a happy Passover. However the call started, it went downhill from there. By day’s end, both sides were arguing about what was said and taking shots at the other for not getting along.

headline: The Big Burn
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: After neglect from the United States, the Sunni-Shiite conflict explodes in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: When the United States invaded Iraq in 2003, it effectively destroyed the Iraqi government. Slowly learning from that mistake, the U.S. spent the next eight years in a costly round of state-building. As Dexter Filkins, who covered the war for The Times, wrote in a blog post this week for The New Yorker, “By 2011, by any reasonable measure, the Americans had made a lot of headway but were not finished with the job.”

headline: Stewart Tributes Fill Day 1 of U.S. Open as Mickelson Feels the Crowd’s Support
abstract: Fans at the U.S. Open paid tribute to Payne Stewart, the 1999 winner, who died in a plane crash four months after his victory, and they also heaped their love onto Phil Mickelson.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — The United States Open course and the fans who lined it showed their softer side on Thursday. How could a mushy sentimentality not prevail given that wherever you looked on Pinehurst No. 2 on a leaden morning, the ghost of Payne Stewart lurked?

headline: Reaction to Brazil’s First Goal
abstract: From across the country, Brazilian fans react to their team’s first goal of the 2014 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: From across the country, Brazilian fans react to their team’s first goal of the 2014 World Cup.

headline: The Iraqi Army Was Crumbling Long Before Its Collapse, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: American military and intelligence officials told a Senate hearing that the Iraqi military had been in decline since the last American advisers left the country in 2011.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The stunning collapse of Iraq’s army in a string of cities across the north reflects poor leadership, declining troop morale, broken equipment and a sharp decline in training since the last American advisers left the country in 2011, American military and intelligence officials said Thursday.

headline: Brazil’s First Goal
abstract: Across the country, Brazilian fans react to their team’s first goal of the 2014 World Cup, in what would be a 3-1 victory against Croatia.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, Brazilian fans react to their team’s first goal of the 2014 World Cup, in what would be a 3-1 victory against Croatia.

headline: In Weapons Case, Prosecutors Press 2 Brothers to Urge 3rd to Come to U.S. to Plead Guilty
abstract: The brothers — one a former New York City police officer, another a former Customs and Border Protection officer — worked with another brother to sell military-grade guns to customers in the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: It was an unusual example of family pressure, exerted by federal prosecutors against two brothers.

headline: After Florida State Rape Case, Police Will Revise Procedures
abstract: The police department in Tallahassee, Fla., which handled a rape accusation against Florida State’s Jameis Winston, is now working to rewrite its sexual assault complaint policy.
lead_paragraph: The police department in Tallahassee, Fla., the target of stinging criticism and national attention for its handling of a rape accusation against Florida State University’s Heisman Trophy winner, Jameis Winston, has begun working with a respected women’s advocacy group to rewrite its sexual assault complaint policy.

headline: Spain Enters as a Favorite That’s Forgotten
abstract: The Spaniards have been the kings of soccer over the last half-dozen years, winning the last World Cup and the last two European championships, but they have arrived in Brazil relatively unnoticed.
lead_paragraph: SALVADOR, Brazil — For the first time in more than 60 years, the World Cup is back in the spiritual home of soccer, and it is only natural that the pretournament spotlight has been overwhelmingly focused on the hosts and their enormously popular players.

headline: Job Losses in Need of Interpreting
abstract: The federal government abruptly stopped using seven small translation agencies in New York City that provided interpretation at hearings for people trying to prove they were entitled to Social Security disability payments.
lead_paragraph: New York is the city of tongues, a metropolis where language has about 800 separate tributaries, the babbling global capital of human speech.

headline: Iraqis Who Fled Mosul Say They Prefer Militants to Government
abstract: As many as 500,000 Iraqis fled Mosul after a militant group swarmed the city, many of them Sunnis who seemed less fearful of the group than their own government.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — After Islamic extremists swarmed his city this week, Saad Hussein fled here with his wife and six children. But after one night, he was on his way back home to Mosul, hearing that things were quiet there.

headline: Clip: ‘The Signal’
abstract: A scene from William Eubank’s film featuring Brenton Thwaites and Laurence Fishburne.
lead_paragraph: A scene from William Eubank’s film featuring Brenton Thwaites and Laurence Fishburne.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 12, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Tip of the Iceberg: Rethinking Life After High School
abstract: “Ivory Tower,” a documentary from Andrew Rossi, explores the problems facing higher education today.
lead_paragraph: “Ivory Tower,” a documentary about soaring costs and other problems confronting higher education, can’t seem to decide what points it wants to make and ends up making none. Parts of it seem like free advertising for the institutions it visits, which include Harvard, Arizona State University and experimental institutions like Deep Springs College. Other parts sound the already familiar lament that students come out of college with crushing debts and no prospects for the kinds of jobs that would enable them to pay off those debts. There are suggestions that colleges do a poor job of actually educating students, and that the cost issue is a result of bloated administrative salaries and a rush to build showpiece campuses.

headline: The World’s Ball
abstract: An evolution, from 1930 to today.
lead_paragraph: An evolution, from 1930 to today.

headline: Hackers Take a Road Trip, With a Sci-Fi Detour
abstract: The director William Eubank reimagines reality and defies logic in “The Signal.”
lead_paragraph: William Eubank’s “The Signal” demonstrates the fine line between paranoid science-fiction fantasy and demo reel. Both involve impressive visions of reality reimagined, and both defy logic extravagantly and yet somehow casually, too. Mr. Eubank’s diverting but disconnected film might fairly be described as a little bit of each.

headline: Vermont G.O.P. Finds Candidates in Short Supply
abstract: Vermont’s Republican Party, once a major power, is alienated from the national brand, troubled by infighting and unable to offer a full slate of candidates for the primaries.
lead_paragraph: MONTPELIER, Vt. — The Vermont Republican Party website makes a plain-spoken appeal: “CANDIDATES WANTED.”

headline: Family Guy
abstract: David Steinberg slips in a somewhat timely minitheme.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — We have a big day coming up this weekend, and if you are a dad or have ever been important in the life of a child, Wordplay wishes you a happy Father’s Day.

abstract: A game you can play while the footballers are playing theirs.
lead_paragraph: A game you can play while the footballers are playing theirs.

headline: With Data and Resolve, Tacoma Fights Pollution
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Clean Water Act', 'Science and Technology', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'PCB (Polychlorinated Biphenyls)', 'Rain']
abstract: Tacoma, Wash., is using science, persistence and enforcement to take on rain-borne pollution, which has been a largely ignored environmental problem.
lead_paragraph: TACOMA, Wash. — Last year, environmental engineers working for this city had an unnerving worry. After a decade and tens of millions of dollars devoted to a fastidious cleanup of its corner of Puget Sound, Tacoma’s shore front was in danger of being contaminated with a highly toxic chemical.

headline: Former BP Engineer Wins New Trial in Case on Gulf Spill
abstract: A federal judge threw out an earlier verdict, saying a forewoman had “polluted” the jury with remarks she overheard outside the courtroom.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in New Orleans has ordered a new trial for a former BP engineer convicted of deleting text messages relevant to an investigation of the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill, concluding that outside information influenced the jury’s verdict.

headline: A Dominatrix Who Hates Heels
abstract: Emmanuelle Seigner dislikes high heels but found a perfect fit playing the sultry Vanda in the film version of “Venus in Fur,” directed by her husband, Roman Polanski.
lead_paragraph: Emmanuelle Seigner hates high heels and avoids wearing them at all costs. When the designer Tom Ford asked her to walk in a fashion show, she successfully pleaded with him to put her in flats. But there was no avoiding them in her latest film, “Venus in Fur,” directed by her husband, Roman Polanski, in which she plays a dominatrix of sorts whose sartorial centerpiece is a pair of thigh-high kinky boots.

headline: Tanks, of Unknown Origin, Roll Into Ukraine
abstract: Ukraine’s interior minister claimed that an armored column from Russia had crossed the border into eastern Ukraine overnight.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Ukraine’s interior minister claimed on Thursday that an armored column from Russia had crossed the border into eastern Ukraine overnight and had fought with Ukrainian troops during the day.

headline: As Sunni Militants Threaten Its Allies in Baghdad, Iran Weighs Options
abstract: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria fighters pose a direct threat to the pro-Iranian government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, vowing to massacre Shiites and destroy their shrines.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — In years past, Iranian officials would smirk when recalling how the United States had done the dirty work for them by removing the Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein, a Sunni who led an eight-year war against Shiite Iran.

headline: Officials to Investigate Reports of Mistreatment of Minors Caught Crossing Border
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Children and Childhood', 'Deportation', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Border officials opened an investigation on Thursday into claims by legal aid groups that border agents were mistreating unaccompanied minors caught crossing the Southwest border illegally.

headline: The Goal Heard Round Brazil
abstract: When Neymar drove the ball into the back of the net for Brazil’s first goal, pandemonium ensued around the host country.
lead_paragraph: When Neymar drove the ball into the back of the net for Brazil’s first goal, pandemonium ensued around the host country.

headline: Dino? Ol’ Blue Eyes? All the Above, by Jerry
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']

lead_paragraph: The movie widely regarded as Jerry Lewis’s masterpiece, “The Nutty Professor” (1963), arrives with a swagger on the occasion of its 51st anniversary in a deluxe “50th Anniversary Collectors Edition,” from Warner Bros. Home Entertainment.

headline: Building Nuclear Weapon Would Take Years, Not Months, Iran Says in Report
abstract: The estimate contradicts both classified assessments by the United States government and many outside experts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Iranian government this week published its first detailed study of how long it estimates it would take its scientists and engineers to assemble a nuclear weapon, saying that with its current infrastructure, “the required time span is in years.”

headline: Giant Seeks Return to Pre-Injury Success
abstract: After tearing his A.C.L. last preseason, Giants safety Stevie Brown is determined to recapture his playmaking spark.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants safety Stevie Brown intercepted a pass against the Jets in a preseason game on Aug. 24 and was racing down the left side when he spotted an opening toward the middle of the field. He pushed off on his left leg — and it buckled.

headline: Chicago Winces After a Jewel Is Stamped ‘Trump’
abstract: Donald Trump’s name is lighting up the Chicago skyline on his hotel tower, much to the chagrin of Chicagoans, including Mayor Rahm Emanuel.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — There was a collective sigh of relief when Donald Trump opened his 92-story hotel and condominium tower here six years ago.

headline: In Bitterly Contested House Primary, a State Legislator Defends His Record
keywords: ['Dominican-Americans', 'State Legislatures', 'Endorsements', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Adriano D. Espaillat’s record in Albany, where he is now a state senator, has been played down by Representative Charles B. Rangel, but Mr. Espaillat said he is an effective leader for minorities and immigrants in the senate.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, Hispanic lawmakers saw a crisis brewing on eastern Long Island: Under the direction of the Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, the police were raiding rooming houses full of immigrants and arresting drivers, many of them Hispanic, who lacked licenses or identification. The county jail was running checks to catch inmates in the country illegally.

headline: Campus Colleagues, Basketball Teammates, and Now, Political Rivals
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: David Brat, who beat Eric Cantor, and Jack Trammell, the academic colleague Mr. Brat faces in the election, have found themselves unprepared for the political fishbowl.
lead_paragraph: ASHLAND, Va. — Before the two professors became overnight political rivals in one of the most improbable, high-profile races in memory, they knew each other best as basketball teammates.

keywords: ['Mad Cow Disease (Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy)', 'Beef', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Meat', 'Cattle', 'Livestock Diseases', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']

lead_paragraph: Dozens of Whole Foods stores in the Northeast and a restaurant in New York received beef over an eight-month period that may not have been properly slaughtered to reduce the threat of mad cow disease, federal officials said on Thursday.

headline: Greece Wars With Courts Over Ways to Slash Budget
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Greek judges continue to contest the government’s attempts to cut salaries, pensions and jobs of public workers to reduce the country’s debt.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The Greek government has made a range of painful cuts to salaries, pensions and jobs for public workers over the last four years, saying they were needed to satisfy the demands of the international creditors that bailed the country out. But the Greeks hurt by those steps, and the nation’s courts, have a different idea.

abstract: If Representative Kevin McCarthy rises to Mr. Cantor’s majority leader spot, the result would elevate a Californian with a less conservative voting record than the man he would replace.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For all the talk of a lurch to the right after the primary election defeat this week of the House majority leader, Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the race to remake the Republican leadership may actually leave its top ranks more moderate.

headline: Despite Upheavals, NBC Extends Lauer’s Contract
abstract: As recent ratings have improved for NBC’s “Today,” Matt Lauer will remain on the morning show for more than two years, according to NBC executives.
lead_paragraph: NBC’s “Today” show issued a new endorsement of its longtime anchor Matt Lauer on Thursday, signing the veteran newsman to a contract extension that will keep him in place on the morning show for what NBC described as multiple more years.

headline: Heat’s Crash Course Can’t Prevent Another Wreck Against the Spurs
abstract: The Heat put in plenty of study time after their debacle in Game 3, but it didn’t do any good as the Spurs took a 3-1 series lead and moved to the cusp of a championship.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It was no fun. Before meeting the San Antonio Spurs on Thursday night in Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals, the Heat spent a substantial portion of Wednesday huddled in a darkened room watching film of their well-publicized debacle in Game 3.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie’s appearance on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon” on Thursday resembled a spurned suitor’s return to the site of his humiliation.

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Masahiro Tanaka is neither impressed nor surprised that a little more than two months into his first major league season, he is one of only two pitchers with 10 victories.

(Showtime) DAVID BECKHAM INTO THE UNKNOWN Just in time for the World Cup, the director Anthony Mandler follows Mr. Beckham, above, the retired soccer superstar, and his friends Derek White and Dave Gardner into the heart of the Amazon in Brazil, where they travel by motorcycle and boat from Manaus to Angelin, across the Negro and Cuieras Rivers, and deep into the rain forest to mingle with the remote Yanomami tribe.

headline: In Trying to Halt the Mets’ Slide, Wright Is Enduring His Own Struggles
abstract: David Wright quietly went 1 for 5 with a walk as the Mets lost to the Brewers, their eighth defeat in their last nine games.
lead_paragraph: Often this season, when the Mets have started to slide, David Wright has stressed the importance of stopping it before it gets worse. He has sounded urgent and a tad desperate, perhaps because in each of the previous five seasons, he felt a sense of inevitability set in, like a man standing atop a leaky dam staring down a flood.

headline: At Rangers’ Practice, Mood Is Light but Focused
abstract: The Rangers will try to extend the finals against the Kings with a victory Friday in Game 5 at Staples Center, where they lost two overtime contests to begin the series.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Rangers have reached the point of the Stanley Cup finals where mileage in the air and wear on their bodies provide yet another test of mettle for them and their opponents, the Los Angeles Kings.

headline: Cameroon Players Say Protest and Late Arrival Have Not Affected Morale
abstract: In an unexpected discussion, Coach Volker Finke and his players played down the effect of the team’s dispute over pay four days earlier.
lead_paragraph: NATAL, Brazil — Four days after Cameroon players refused to board a flight to Brazil in a dispute over World Cup pay, Coach Volker Finke attributed the disagreement to cultural norms in Africa and played down its significance to the team’s preparations.

headline: Chase Whitley, Under Control Again, Guides Yankees to Sweep of Mariners
abstract: Whitley, a rookie right-hander, issued no walks for the fourth straight start, and Derek Jeter had three hits and two R.B.I. in his final regular-season game against Seattle.

headline: Iraqi Shiite Cleric Issues Call to Arms

lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The specter of sectarian war and partition of Iraq grew on Friday as the country’s top Shiite cleric implored his followers to take up arms against an insurgent army of marauding Sunni extremist militants who have captured broad stretches of northern territory this week in a sweep toward Baghdad.

headline: A German Rebel in South Africa
keywords: ['Apartheid (Policy)', 'Discrimination', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Photography', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Jürgen Schadeberg left the ruins of Nazi Germany to pursue photography in South Africa, where he documented the black struggle and trained a generation of photographers.
lead_paragraph: When Jürgen Schadeberg was forced to join the Hitler Youth, he knew wearing brown shirts, marching in step and singing the glories of the Führer and the Fatherland were not for him. Even before his teens, he abhorred what they stood for.

abstract: Reaction to a court ruling against death sentences for two men for crimes committed against an 11-year-old girl has highlighted broader issues including corruption, prejudice and justice.
lead_paragraph: Should a person be executed for raping or prostituting a child? That question — which lay behind an explosion of comments as Chinese responded on Friday to a Supreme People’s Court decision overturning the death sentences of two men for crimes committed against an 11-year-old girl — seemed hardly the point.

headline: Daily Report: Scrutinizing Silicon Valley’s Response to Obama’s Climate Goals
abstract: In an interview, Vinod Khosla addresses how he and other venture capitalists might react to the call for new technology on clean energy.
lead_paragraph: If the United States is going to achieve President Obama’s new climate change goals, an X factor is how Silicon Valley will respond, Claire Cain Miller reports. Success will depend, many analysts think, on whether the policy will spur entrepreneurs to come up with new technologies and create a clean energy economy.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – The investment company Atlas Mara Co-Nvest, backed by a former Barclays chief executive, Robert E. Diamond Jr., is likely to fall short of the $400 million it was seeking in a second round of fund-raising to back investments in the African financial sector, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: No Ceremony for Bowe Bergdahl Upon Return to U.S. Soil
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: Exactly 1,809 days after he was captured, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl returned to a homecoming void of any relatives and dampened by a controversy over his capture and release.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Exactly 1,809 days after he was captured by Taliban fighters who kept him in a metal cage for weeks and possibly months during nearly five years in captivity, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl returned to the United States early Friday to a homecoming void of any of his relatives and dampened by a swirling controversy over his capture and release.

headline: Tableau Software Helping Data Become More Visual
abstract: When data stops being slowly written into rows and columns and starts moving quickly online from sensors, Internet browsers and smartphones, other things change too. We are starting to see the information in more dynamic ways.
lead_paragraph: Data point, meet data stream.

headline: States Choose to Defer Employee Choice for Health Plans
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: Longtime backers of the Affordable Care Act said that the government was too generous in granting delays to the states.
lead_paragraph: When it set the final rules implementing small-business health insurance exchanges for next year, the federal government gave states the option of taking a one-year pass on one of the exchanges’ most attractive features: the opportunity for small-business employees to choose among a variety of health plans. This week, the Department of Health and Human Services announced that 18 states would in fact defer employee choice until 2016.

headline: Eric Cantor Is Not a Reform Conservative
abstract: The outgoing House majority leader viewed reform conservatism as a political strategy, not a policy agenda.
lead_paragraph: One thing we’re hearing about Eric Cantor’s primary defeat is that it’s bad for “reform conservatism.” That’s a term that means different things to different people, but for these purposes I’m talking about a different domestic agenda from the one the Republican Party has been pursuing in recent years and one that centers on middle-class economic concerns.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on gun violence, the Common Core, N.G.O.s in India and Eric Cantor.
lead_paragraph: “What’s happening in Iraq is a disaster and it is astonishing that the Iraqis and the Americans, who have been sharing intelligence, seem to have been caught flat-footed by the speed of the insurgent victories and the army defections.” The New York Times editorial board comments on the sudden capture of Mosul by Sunni militants, and the greater threat to Iraq and the Middle East region, noting there are few good options in resolving the crisis with ease or speed.

headline: Morning Agenda: Univision’s Sale Talks
abstract: Univision’s owners are considering a sale. | Hostile deal-making is back. | Oppenheimer’s emerging markets fund has outperformed its peers since 2010. | Sycamore takes aim at Express.
lead_paragraph: UNIVISION OWNERS SAID TO WEIGH A SALE  |  The owners of Univision Communications, the biggest Spanish-language broadcaster in the United States, are said to have held preliminary talks about a potential sale with media companies in recent weeks, including CBS, Time Warner and Viacom, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. The talks were at a very early stage and no sales process is underway at the moment. Should Univision’s owners ‒ a consortium led by the billionaire Haim Saban ‒ pursue a sale, they will probably expect bids to top at least $20 billion.

headline: Swedish Auteur Takes On a Brave Loner
abstract: Jan Troell’s latest film, “The Last Sentence,” is a portrait of Torgny Segerstedt, a Swedish newspaper editor who was an early, ferocious and persistent critic of Hitler.
lead_paragraph: From “High Noon” to “Silkwood” and “The Insider,” the courageous loner who stands up to evil at great personal risk is a familiar film figure. Now the Swedish master Jan Troell has added to that gallery with “The Last Sentence,” his portrait of Torgny Segerstedt, a Swedish newspaper editor who was an early, ferocious and persistent critic of Hitler, defying both Nazi threats and his own government’s pleas not to undermine its neutral stance.

headline: The Lack of Major Wars May Be Hurting Economic Growth
abstract: It’s not because war spending itself is so good. It’s because the threat of war can inspire countries to do great things.
lead_paragraph: The continuing slowness of economic growth in high-income economies has prompted soul-searching among economists. They have looked to weak demand, rising inequality, Chinese competition, over-regulation, inadequate infrastructure and an exhaustion of new technological ideas as possible culprits.

headline: Indications of Growth in U.S. Job Market
abstract: For the first time since 2009, the number of short-term unemployed workers has surpassed the number of long-term unemployed workers — a sign of demand in the job market.
lead_paragraph: FOR more than 60 years, unemployment in the United States was largely a short-term problem. The level of unemployment went up and down, but most of the unemployed found work relatively quickly. Few remained out of work for as long as 15 weeks. Long-term unemployment was always a lesser problem.

headline: British Regulator Osborne Takes a Step Forward for Foreign Exchange Oversight
abstract: Remarks by Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, on addressing market manipulation in currency trading gives greater clarity to the banking sector, write two Nasdaq OMX executives.
lead_paragraph: Michael O’Brien and Bill Nosal are senior executives with Nasdaq OMX’s SMARTS market surveillance.

headline: And a Choir Shall Heal Them
abstract: David Greig’s play about the aftermath of a mass shooting, “The Events,” will use local choirs in its American debut this month in New Haven.
lead_paragraph: The Scottish playwright David Greig was hard to pin down while traveling in the highlands of his homeland recently, so it turned out to be eerily coincidental that we finally spoke the day after Elliot O. Rodger went on a murderous rampage in Isla Vista, Calif. Efforts to understand what motivated the young man were popping up all over the Internet as Mr. Greig discussed “The Events,” his 2013 play about the anguished aftermath of a deadly shooting.

headline: Keep Fighting For Sane Gun Restrictions. Only Harder.
abstract: President Obama has to keep trying to get the changes he wants, just like the gun lobby did.
lead_paragraph: Like many Americans — most, actually, I venture — I feel the same sense of frustration and anger over Congress’s failure to approve stricter gun laws that President Obama expressed following this week’s fatal school shooting in Oregon.

lead_paragraph: ELLISVILLE, Miss. — Moments after a little-known economics professor in Virginia became a conservative sensation by toppling Eric Cantor, the House Republican leader, Chris McDaniel, the Tea Party’s best hope for a Senate seat this year, got a text message from his best friend in Mississippi’s capital.

headline: Selling TOMS: The Questions, and a Few Answers

lead_paragraph: The fashion/philanthropy world was surprised by the news in The Financial Times this week that TOMS — the shoe brand started by Blake Mycoskie in 2006 and based on the One-to-One model (for every pair sold, a pair is given away) — was up for sale.

headline: U.N. Warns of Rights Abuses and Hundreds Dead in Iraq Fighting
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: The top human rights official at the United Nations expressed “extreme alarm” over extrajudicial killings, rape and the shelling of civilians.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — As Sunni insurgents pursued an offensive toward Baghdad on Friday, Navi Pillay, the top United Nations human rights official, expressed “extreme alarm” over what she termed summary executions, rape, reprisal killings and shelling of civilians, putting the first estimate of casualties in the hundreds.

headline: Comcast Seeking to Replace G.E.’s Initials Atop 30 Rock
abstract: NBCUniversal’s new owner has asked New York City’s Landmarks Preservation Commission to let it replace the neon sign atop the 70-story Manhattan tower.
lead_paragraph: Comcast is known for its low-key corporate culture. At its 58-story headquarters, the tallest building in Philadelphia, a boxy glass crown gleams conspicuously but anonymously.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘22 Jump Street,’ ‘How to Train Your Dragon 2’ and ‘The Rover’

lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics look at “22 Jump Street,” “The Rover” and “How to Train Your Dragon 2.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: In Fashion | The Return of Alice Roi
abstract: The New York-born-and-bred designer — a patron saint for stylish downtown girls of the aughts — is officially relaunching her brand.
lead_paragraph: For girls-about-downtown in the late ’90s and early aughts, Alice Roi was a patron saint. The lower-Manhattan-born-and-bred designer with the cool-kid persona created clothes that tempered a girlish sensibility with a subtle sense of humor. There were the “La Caricature” dresses, covered in an Honoré Daumier print of two snobs turning their noses at each other. There were the Yeti-like mohair jackets and the bare-shouldered tops with cutouts meant to resemble crewneck openings. The line was a cult hit until 2008, when Roi became a mom and not only shuttered her business but withdrew completely from the fashion world.

headline: A Lost Father, and a Daughter Who’s Not Ready to Let Him Go
abstract: The Friday before Father’s Day last year, my dad, an Alzheimer’s patient, wandered off from my mother at the grocery store. I’d been saying goodbye to him for almost a decade, but I wasn’t ready to lose him.
lead_paragraph: While preparing my daughter for her preschool graduation ceremony last year, a text message buzzed my phone from my brother: “Dad has been missing for two hours.”

headline: 2 Private Equity Settlements Followed Failure of Broader Talks on Collusion Lawsuit
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Private Equity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: After collective settlement talks on collusion broke down, Bain Capital and Goldman Sachs broke ranks and struck their own deals, ratcheting up the pressure on the other firms.
lead_paragraph: For six years, the biggest private equity firms fought a lawsuit that accused them of illegal collusion during the buyout boom. Their strategy, through rounds of difficult settlement talks, was to stick together.

headline: Former Goldman Director Gupta’s Last Days of Freedom
abstract: Rajat K. Gupta is scheduled to report to a prison camp in Massachusetts, spending the next two years not far from his onetime friend, Raj Rajaratnam.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Rajat K. Gupta, the former managing director of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company who was convicted of insider trading, is scheduled to report to a minimum-security prison camp in Massachusetts, spending the next two years not far from his onetime friend and partner in crime, Raj Rajaratnam.

headline: For Cantor, Loss of Leadership Role Means Far Fewer Perks
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Life is about to get very different for Eric Cantor, who is going from being the No. 2 Republican in the House to just another congressman.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As House majority leader, Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia has enjoyed a bump in salary, a large political staff, an elegant office suite on the second floor of the Capitol and a security detail that drove him to and from his suburban Richmond home.

headline: Critique of Narendra Modi in College Magazine Leads to Arrest of Seven
abstract: Six students and a college principal were arrested at a Kerala college after a student-run magazine published a negative article on Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
lead_paragraph: A college magazine that published an implied, strident critique of Narendra Modi, the newly elected prime minister, incited enough ill will that six students on the magazine’s editorial staff were arrested Wednesday and accused of printing defamatory material and of provocation with the intent of causing riots, among other crimes.

headline: If a Teenager Lands a Summer Job, the Value Is Lasting
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Shortages', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Only 25 percent of American teenagers were employed last summer, but the long-term payoffs from a summer job are hard to beat, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: HUNTER-JOHN HURST, 16, of Raleigh, N.C., is a living example of a modern-day conundrum. Like many others his age, he needs to earn money this summer. But finding a job is tougher than ever, with the number of teenagers employed nationwide at a near-historical low.

headline: Russia Sent Tanks to Separatists in Ukraine, U.S. Says
abstract: After the State Department said that Russia had sent weapons to rebels in Ukraine, separatists using antiaircraft and heavy machine guns fired on a military transport plane in Luhansk, the Ukrainian Defense Ministry said.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — The State Department said Friday that Russia had sent tanks and other heavy weapons to separatists in Ukraine, supporting accusations Thursday by the Ukrainian government.

headline: Who Made That Inflatable Noisemaker?
abstract: How stadiums got a whole lot louder.
lead_paragraph: As soccer fans arrived at Portland’s Civic Stadium on Sept. 7, 1997, they were handed an unfamiliar implement: a pair of long balloons, sponsored by Nike, designed to make their cheering louder. “That was the first time I saw those inflatable things that people bang together,” says Tab Ramos, a starting player on that U.S. men’s soccer team and now an assistant coach. The sellout crowd for the World Cup qualifier, among the noisiest that Ramos had ever heard, reached maximum cacophony when he scored the winning goal. “The stadium sounded like it was going to fall down,” he says.

headline: Reply All: The 6.1.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: LIFE IN THE VALLEY OF DEATH

headline: Highly, Highly Recommended
keywords: ['Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: Charity, once removed; rogue editing.
lead_paragraph: As part of a typical hiring process, I asked a job applicant for a reference. It turned out that I already knew the reference, who was very supportive of the candidate. The man got the job. After I extended the offer, I heard through the grapevine that the applicant and the reference were romantically linked. The hire has performed very well, but I felt that they both should have been more forthright about their relationship. Should they have been? JEFF H., SAN DIEGO

headline: Before Learning to Crawl, You Must Learn to Swim
abstract: Underwater photographs of infants learning to swim.
lead_paragraph: Rachael Ubiera, a 25-year-old in Kissimmee, Fla., considers herself “one of the relaxed moms.” But the first time she saw her 5-month-old daughter, Zoe, carefully dropped underwater in a pool for infant survival swim training, it was nerve-racking. “She looked surprised,” Ubiera says. “Like, ‘What are you doing to me?’ ” Zoe was being introduced to “self-rescue,” in which babies are taught to hold their breath underwater, kick their feet, turn over to float on their backs and rest until help arrives. The technique, photographed here by Seth Casteel, who is working on a related book that will come out next spring, was pioneered in the late ’60s by Harvey Barnett, who at 18 became determined to teach infants to swim after the drowning of a neighbor’s child. His methods have spread around the world — taught in clinics and imitated widely. “It gives the baby the best possible chance,” he says. Julie Bosman

headline: The Breakup List
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Text Messaging']
abstract: There were a few things about me that my girlfriend liked. And plenty she didn’t.
lead_paragraph: It was summertime in Brooklyn, so hot that the trees were shedding leaves and the Realtors were sweating through their starched shirts and stopping on street corners to wipe down their Bluetooth earpieces. My girlfriend — we’d been together, more or less, since our first date in February — was staying with me for a couple of weeks while she sublet her apartment. She was between trips abroad. She was always traveling for work. I’d set her up at my kitchen table with the wireless password. I got her a partner membership at my gym. We cranked up the air-conditioner in the bedroom at night and lay across the comforter to let our sweat dry. In the mornings, the tired air-conditioner wheezed out a spray of mist.

headline: Love, Kuwaiti Style
abstract: Way out of Eden: Adam and Eve, with fangs; pneumonia in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: Way out of Eden: Adam and Eve, with fangs; pneumonia in Arizona.

headline: Can General Linder’s Special Operations Forces Stop the Next Terrorist Threat?
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: As the fight against terrorism broadens to Africa, the United States faces a tricky balance: how to fight an enemy without actually doing the fighting.
lead_paragraph: On a searing morning this spring, Brig. Gen. James B. Linder leaned against the red-webbing seats of a C-130 as it flew over the Sahara. On his camouflaged knee, he balanced two dog-eared Moleskine notebooks and a map of Africa. Linder, who is in his early 50s, commands the United States Special Operations forces in Africa. He was on his way to visit a detachment of 12 Army Green Berets training with African troops to fight Al Qaeda and its affiliates in Niger. Through the plane’s scratched plexiglass portholes, dunes crested like waves in an ocean of sand, and hot blasts of wind buffeted the fuselage. An hour’s flight to the south, his team of Special Forces was deployed along the Nigerian border, where the militant group Boko Haram was targeting children in its bid to establish an Islamic state.

headline: World Cup Is Huge on Twitter … in Japan
abstract: The Japanese are among the world’s most active social media users. They are also posting more on Twitter about the World Cup than typical soccer powerhouses like England and Brazil.
lead_paragraph: The World Cup buzz is building on social media – in Brazil, in England and, most of all, in Japan.

headline: Washington’s Gyms Want a Tax Break. That’s a Problem.
keywords: ['Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: As the economy has shifted away from goods and toward services, sales tax revenue has shrunk. But it’s politically hard to raise taxes on services.
lead_paragraph: When I went to the gym in Washington on Thursday, I was urged to get on Twitter and tell local leaders members “#donttaxfitness.” That’s because next Tuesday, the Council of the District of Columbia will vote on expanding the sales tax to include gym memberships and related services, like yoga and personal training; currently, those kinds of services aren’t taxed.

headline: Charity Golf Events Have Courses Filling Up

headline: The Killer Assessment
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Cooperatives', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Home Repairs and Improvements']
abstract: Few co-ops have faced as catastrophic an assessment as 2 Fifth Avenue, where a facade fix came in at over $30 million.
lead_paragraph: Nothing inflicts fear and loathing on the heart of a co-op resident like the specter of a major assessment. The A-word has to be the most unpopular notification a co-op board ever drops on shareholders, the verbal equivalent of a stink bomb. Trouble, anxiety and intramural back-stabbing inevitably ensue.

headline: Arachnid Phobia
abstract: What looks like a spider bite and acts like a spider bite but isn’t a spider bite?
lead_paragraph: What looks like a spider bite and acts like a spider bite but isn’t a spider bite?

headline: Should We Learn to Live With Debt?
abstract: As politicians debate what to do about student-loan debt, some say what borrowers need is advice not for paying it off quickly but for managing decades of payments, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: The country’s $1.1 trillion of student loan debt continues to inspire plans for relief. But as these are debated, some borrowers are dealing with a more personal issue: what to do, and how to live, while they pay.

headline: DiMaggio and Sinatra: The Feud Between Two Italian-American Pathbreakers
abstract: These two men probably did more than anyone else of their time to bring Italian-Americans into the mainstream of the nation’s popular culture.
lead_paragraph: In March 1949, Joe DiMaggio posed in Yankee Stadium, smiling, with another famous Italian-American of his era — each in his professional uniform — but their friendship would not endure.

headline: Using Artists to Sell Condos in Miami and New York
abstract: In markets where amenities are expected, developers are using well known artists to help their projects stand out.
lead_paragraph: With cities like New York and Miami in the midst of another luxury condominium boom, developers seem to be tripping over one another in the scramble to announce their latest projects, and to stand out from the pack, they are locked in an escalating game of one-upmanship.

headline: In Store | A New Multibrand Concept Boutique in Detroit
abstract: Willys, a new lifestyle store featuring four U.S.-based, made-largely-in-America brands — Steven Alan, Filson, Clare V. and Mollusk — opens Saturday in the city’s Midtown district.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most visible new success story in the ongoing effort to revitalize Detroit’s economy is Shinola — the three-year-old leather goods and lifestyle brand which employs more than 130 people at its bicycle and watch manufacturing facilities there (and some 130 more in its offices and retail operations). Now, a couple of doors down from its store in the city’s emerging Midtown district, the company is spawning what might be Detroit’s first multibrand concept boutique. Willys, which opens to the public on Saturday, takes its name from the Willys Overland Motor Company, which invented the first jeep in 1941 and was for a time during the 1910s the second-largest car manufacturer in the U.S.; the 2,900-square-foot space is housed in the former service bay of the company’s old headquarters.

headline: Discovering What Defeat Looks Like
abstract: In Thursday’s Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals, the Heat’s offense was dispirited and disorganized, and their defense invariably left open a member of the Spurs.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Toward the end of the third quarter of Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals Thursday, an intensely generic D.J. began exhorting the crowd in the Miami Heat’s arena to get loud. In the stands, a few women with bare midriffs stood up and randomly started shaking.

headline: A Literary Expert on Driving in the Dark
abstract: Neil Gaiman discusses the stuff of nightmares and his upcoming appearance at Carnegie Hall, where on June 27 he will give a reading with a live score by the FourPlay string quartet.
lead_paragraph: Stirring his pot of nightmares, legends, fairy tales and human folly into stories, the British-born fantasy writer Neil Gaiman has produced more than 20 books for children and adults, most of them scary and strange. The multitasking Mr. Gaiman is the author of the best-selling adult fairy tale “The Ocean at the End of the Lane” and the children’s books “Coraline” and “Stardust,” which have been made into films. He has written episodes for the sci-fi TV show “Dr. Who,” and is the author of the popular “Sandman”  series of graphic novels. And then there are his 1.9 million Twitter followers.

headline: Nathan Fielder, In Short
abstract: Long before his Comedy Central show, Nathan Fielder practiced his craft by writing, directing and acting in short films that he screened at comedy nights in Toronto and uploaded to YouTube. Here’s a look at some of his best.
lead_paragraph: For this week’s magazine I profiled Nathan Fielder, whose excellent Comedy Central series, “Nathan for You,” begins its second season on July 1. The starting premise of his series is that Fielder — who is Canadian and studied marketing and entrepreneurship at college before turning in earnest to his comedy career — presents himself to actual business owners as a reality-TV business consultant, pitching them preposterously elaborate, compellingly off-kilter marketing schemes and then documenting the unpredictable results. (The entire first season of “Nathan for You” is currently available to watch free.)

headline: Today in Small Business: House Approves Small-Business Tax Break
abstract: Oil prices soar. Why Apple doesn’t tweet. How Starbucks is using bad smartphone batteries to boost its business.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Behold the Fall Harvest
abstract: Authors with books scheduled to be released later this year include Haruki Murakami, Marilynne Robinson and David Mitchell.
lead_paragraph: When BookExpo America, the annual trade convention, took place in Manhattan two weeks ago, the publishing industry turned its gaze to the traditionally heavy-hitting fall season.

headline: Motherhood
abstract: New books by Jowita Bydlowska, Eleanor Henderson and Anna Solomon, Daisy Waugh, and Caroline Clarke.
lead_paragraph: DRUNK MOM  A Memoir  By Jowita Bydlowska  Penguin, paper, $16.

headline: Flying Start
abstract: Two picture books recount the adventures of a mouse and of a writer who uncover the secrets of aviation.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the last of the great rugged individualists were the early pilots. Their dangerous solo missions made heroes of them all as they paved the way for modern aviation. None was more beloved than “Lucky Lindy” himself, Charles A. Lindbergh, who completed the first lone nonstop flight across the Atlantic Ocean on May 21, 1927. In a way reminiscent of Robert Lawson’s 1939 children’s book “Ben and Me,” which suggested that Benjamin Franklin’s brilliant ideas came from a Philadelphia mouse named Amos, the young German artist Torben Kuhlmann has reimagined the Lindbergh legend through the character of an inventive rodent.

headline: Cameroon vs. Mexico: Live Blog
abstract: Live coverage and analysis of the Mexico-Cameroon match. Mexico needs to win to put pressure on Croatia, its rival for the second qualifying spot. (Brazil will very likely get the first.) For Cameroon, this game is probably the best chance for a point in group play.
lead_paragraph: Live coverage and analysis of the Mexico-Cameroon match. Mexico needs to win to put pressure on Croatia, its rival for the second qualifying spot. (Brazil will very likely get the first.) For Cameroon, this game is probably the best chance for a point in group play.

headline: Dragon Seed
abstract: For the heroine of this dreamlike first novel for young adults, finding herself involves a surprising discovery.
lead_paragraph: Certain fairy tales are so ingrained in our consciousness that we have no memory of when we first heard them; there’s a sense we always knew them. I had that feeling when reading Rebecca Hahn’s debut novel, “A Creature of Moonlight.” Though Hahn’s story is new and wholly original, I immediately felt I had fallen into a dark and beautiful fairy tale, one that resonated like something important but long forgotten.

headline: Drawn to the Shore
abstract: In a comfortingly familiar vacation community, a girl is now mature enough to understand what’s been kept from her before.
lead_paragraph: In the first frames of “This One Summer,” a graphic novel written by Mariko Tamaki and illustrated by her cousin Jillian Tamaki, a father carries his sleeping daughter down a driveway to a cottage in the dark. This is Awago Beach, where Rose Wallace’s family has been coming “since . . . like . . . forever.” Or, more precisely, since Rose, who is now either an old tween or a young teenager (we don’t learn her exact age), was 5.

headline: Global Repositioning
abstract: A teenage girl searches for her kidnapped uncle in a world where time and geography have been shuffled.
lead_paragraph: The publishers of S. E. Grove’s novel, an ambitious and quixotic high fantasy called “The Glass Sentence,” smartly slapped upon the dust jacket an assessment by Megan Whalen Turner: “Not since Philip Pullman’s ‘The Golden Compass’ have I seen such an original and compelling world built inside a book.” A sensible precaution; it’s easy to suppose that “The Glass Sentence” was written in reaction to Pullman’s magisterial “His Dark Materials.” I am hardly one to lodge a complaint about that. Great works create their own gravitational field; Pullman wrote under the influence of Milton. The question ­remains: Does this admirer pull off something worthwhile of her own?

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Neil Gaiman, whose “Ocean at the End of the Lane” is No. 8 on the paperback fiction list, wrote his first published book — “solely for the money,” he says — about Duran Duran.
lead_paragraph: Notorious: After spending two and a half months on the hardcover fiction list last year, Neil Gaiman’s fantasy novel “The Ocean at the End of the Lane” slips onto the trade paperback list this week at No. 8. The paperback follows on the heels of another book that should appeal to Gaiman’s fans — Hayley Campbell’s winningly scrapbookish tribute, “The Art of Neil Gaiman,” which Audrey Niffenegger describes in the foreword as “a sort of midcareer retrospective.” The book recounts Gaiman’s early days as a hungry arts journalist and his rise to cult success as a writer of comic books, notably the “Sandman” series, before he turned his hand to novels. It also reminds readers that Neil himself (as he’s known on Twitter) once wrote a scrapbookish tribute of his own: His first published book — “written solely for the money,” he says — was “Duran Duran: The First Four Years of the Fab Five” (1984). “I got a phone call from a lady,” Gaiman explains in an interview cited in the book, “and she said would you like to write a rock ’n’ roll book for us? A rock ’n’ roll biography? And I thought, ‘Oh God, yes! I’m in!’ ” Gaiman suggested a handful of subjects, including the Velvet Underground, David Bowie and Elvis Costello, before the editor interrupted: “Do you want to write the Duran Duran book, the Barry Manilow book or the Def Leppard book?” Pragmatism led him to choose the relative newcomers Duran Duran. “With Barry Manilow,” he said, “I figured I was going to have to listen to, you know, 40 Barry Manilow albums.”

headline: Office Max
abstract: An account of office design and technology since the Civil War offers insights into the changing nature of work.
lead_paragraph: How you work depends in large part on the spaces in which you work. This big theme is taken up by Nikil Saval in “Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace.” There is in fact nothing “secret” about this history; from the Civil War on, as the white-collar world grew, managers and designers thought out loud about where workers should sit, the furniture they should use, the walls and windows that should surround them. Instead of a secret history, Saval, an editor of n+1, has written something more interesting. He has infused a straightforward factual account with all sorts of literary, cultural and political insights; these make the story he tells more dark than dry.

headline: Isolation Unit
abstract: A novel traces a solitary farmer’s attempt to escape her past on a remote British island.
lead_paragraph: Evie Wyld’s second novel opens with its narrator, a woman named Jake Whyte, discovering one of her sheep killed and gutted. Carrion birds are feasting: “Crows, their beaks shining, strutting and rasping, and when I waved my stick they flew to the trees and watched, flaring out their wings, singing, if you could call it that.” Jake shouts, “What are you laughing at?” and throws a rock at them.

headline: It Was a Dark and Stormy Night
abstract: Val McDermid reworks Jane Austen’s Gothic satire “Northanger Abbey.”
