lead_paragraph: Val McDermid’s “Northanger Abbey” is the second book to emerge from the Austen Project, in which Jane Austen’s published oeuvre is reimagined by 21st-­century authors. But early on her heroine, Cat Morland, encounters, via audiobook, the Gothic work of another 19th-century novelist — Bram Stoker’s “Dracula.” “For Cat,” we are told, “schooled only in contemporary vampire romance, it was a curious and unsettling experience. It reminded her of the first time she’d tasted an olive. It was unlike everything that had crossed her palate before; strange and not quite pleasant, yet gilded with the promise of sophistication.”

headline: Puritans’ Progress
abstract: A memoir centers on life in Concord, Mass., its cultural legacy and changing ways.
lead_paragraph: Concord, Mass., is a sacred spot in the mythology of New England Protestants, once the Brahmins of American society, now fast becoming just another ethnic group. With this change comes new material for our venerable tradition of ethnic comedy. The territory is not altogether virgin, of course, but Sarah Payne Stuart comes to it with freshness and flair in this memoir.

headline: Abdullah Abdullah Moves Toward Center of Afghan Power
abstract: The front-runner in Afghanistan’s presidential election, Mr. Abdullah has pushed ahead by excelling at the central skill of Afghan political leadership: making deals.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — AFTER decades roaming the margins of power — as a close aide to the revered resistance leader Ahmed Shah Massoud, as a foreign minister and later as Afghanistan’s perennial opposition leader — Abdullah Abdullah may finally be arriving at the center of it all.

headline: Southern Living
abstract: The author of “Under the Tuscan Sun” reflects on her early life in a small Georgia town.
lead_paragraph: Throughout Frances Mayes’s idylls about “the sweet life in Italy” — the subtitle of one of her best-selling memoirs — there are glimpses of a childhood, far less blissful, in the American South. In “Bella Tuscany,” she mentions her “tyrant” grandfather, Daddy Jack. In “Under the Tuscan Sun,” she touches on her “resigned disappointed ancestors” back home. Even as she enjoys a “pure surge of pleasure” while restoring Bramasole, a villa near Cortona, Italy, and discovering what it means to “surprise your own life,” she must keep the shadows cast by the town of Fitzgerald, Ga., at bay. “To put it mildly,” she remarks in passing of her father, Garbert, “he was a difficult man and to complicate that, he died at 47.”

headline: Nothing to Hide
abstract: Coming-of-age tales about girls and their fraught relationships.
lead_paragraph: Paula Bomer writes the kind of women’s fiction that critics like to call “raw.” Her stark portrayals of biological womanhood have been described as raw and angry, raw and darkly funny, brutally raw and urgent. The word is meant literally, to a degree: Her earlier books, “Nine Months” and “Baby,” feature birth scenes that spare no anatomical detail. But “raw” has also come to mean something specific in blurb-speak about quasi-confessional writing by women, and it’s not always fitting or fair. Half praise, half dis, it commends the struggle to embrace female ugliness while finding the work unsatisfactory. “Raw” work is visceral but also hard to digest — a kind term, in other words, for something half-baked.

headline: Late Bloomer
abstract: A married immigrant Londoner in his 70s is ready to come out.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, at the age of 82, the indomitable stage and screen actor Christopher Plummer won his first Academy Award for his energetic portrayal of Hal Fields, a 75-year-old who comes out of the closet shortly after his wife’s death, in Mike Mills’s structurally complex romantic comedy “Beginners.” In the film, Hal’s full-throttled, last-call embrace of life inspires his son, Oliver, to fully embrace his own, while asking what exactly it takes to start life anew, and when, if ever, it’s too late.

headline: European Pastoral
abstract: In Michel Déon’s 1975 bildungsroman, a young Frenchman sets off to discover the Continent between the two world wars.
lead_paragraph: Michel Déon’s 1975 novel “The Foundling Boy” (in French “Le Jeune Homme Vert,” or “The Green Young Man”) is a bildungsroman, an account of a naïve young person’s education and the formation of his character, in this case inspired by Henry Fielding’s 18th-century novel “Tom Jones,” about a similarly clueless but likable character making his way on the road of life. As witty as its English forebear but with French savoir-faire, “The Foundling Boy” may win new readers for books translated from French, of which too few are published. English PEN and Arts Council England have supported Julian Evans’s translation, evidently in hopes of broadening our reading of these classics.

headline: G.M. Recalls Camaros to Replace Faulty Keys
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The action covers half a million 2010 to 2014 Camaros, which can stall if their key fobs are jostled.
lead_paragraph: General Motors is recalling more than half a million Chevrolet Camaros because of the danger that a bump to the keys could suddenly turn off the ignition — a problem similar to the defect that led the automaker to recall millions of small cars this year.

headline: Here’s How
abstract: One book about child rearing recommends unconditional love; another calls for paternal involvement.
lead_paragraph: It is entirely possible, if you sit down on a comfy couch with a plump pillow, a good reading light and a crack pipe, that you can read a bunch of parenting books and not feel terrible.

headline: All in the Famiglia
abstract: A British historian examines the past of Italy’s three major regional crime organizations, and finds unity.
lead_paragraph: In “Blood Brotherhoods,” the British scholar John Dickie sets himself the wildly ambitious task of writing the histories of Italy’s three major criminal organizations from their origins in the mid-19th century to the present. The result is a book that is alternately impressive and infuriating. Dickie has amassed and digested an astonishing mass of material (tens of thousands of pages of trial documents, newspaper accounts and secondary literature) and followed scores of different characters (bandits, crime bosses, policemen, judges, politicians) in disparate places across a 150-year span. And yet he has managed, despite the girth and diversity, to sustain an argument and a story. He entertains the reader with dozens of fascinating figures — both noble and blood-chilling — while making frequently shrewd judgments that place this story in context, as a central feature of Italian life.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: BELIEVING IS SEEING: Observations on the Mysteries of Photography,  by Errol Morris. (Penguin, $25.) Morris brings his great talent as a filmmaker to this investigation of the contested reality behind an eclectic range of documentary photographs — from the Crimean War, the Depression, Abu Ghraib and elsewhere. Intercutting his essays with maps, letters, timelines and interview excerpts, Morris “refines our most basic way of understanding the world,” Kathryn Schulz wrote here.

headline: A Second Chance to Help Families Save Their Homes
keywords: ['Foreclosures', 'Homeowner Affordability and Stability Plan', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Federal housing agencies have an opportunity to reconsider policies that prevent nonprofits from helping troubled borrowers keep their homes, writes Jennifer Taub, the author of “Other People’s Houses.”
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Taub is professor at Vermont Law School. Her book “Other People’s Houses” was published in May by Yale University Press.

headline: Obama Says He Will Decide on Military Support for Iraq in ‘Days Ahead’
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: With Iraq in crisis, President Obama made a statement about the situation on Friday before leaving on a trip to North Dakota and California.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Friday that he would make a decision “in the days ahead” about whether to use American military power to help the besieged Iraqi government stave off collapse at the hands of Islamist insurgents, but he ruled out using ground forces.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WHAT IS VISIBLE,  by Kimberly Elkins. (Twelve, $25.) While contemplating the bare requisites of being human, this historical novel about the Helen Keller-like Laura Bridgman also dishes dirt on a pantheon of 19th-century heroes of civil reform.

headline: Heavy Lifting From the Vaults: Lots of Allmans and Elvis on the Way
abstract: A six-CD set of the Allman Brothers Band at the Fillmore East in 1971, and and eight-CD, two-DVD set of Elvis Presley performances will released this summer.
lead_paragraph: Classic albums by the Allman Brothers Band and Elvis Presley are to be given expanded reissues that, depending on your level of fascination with these musicians, are either textbook examples of bloated archival sprawl or something like perfection.

headline: A Reagan or a Blair?
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Farm Bill (US)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: What kind of leader does the G.O.P. need now?
lead_paragraph: I wrote a little on Wednesday about what I described as the uncertain implications of David Brat’s primary victory for the future of a more reform-minded conservatism. For a less uncertain take on the matter, here is David Frum, arguing that the only way to reform the Republican Party is for figures like Eric Cantor – or, I suppose, his successors in the leadership — to take the fight more ruthlessly to the party’s insurgents:

headline: Thad Cochran’s Unlikely Donor Lineup
abstract: Michael Bloomberg, Mitch McConnell and Sean Parker don’t share many political views, but they all gave money to the Mississippi senator.
lead_paragraph: The adage that politics makes for strange bedfellows may have few better examples than the Senate race in Mississippi, where Senator Thad Cochran faces Chris McDaniel, a state senator, in a June 24 runoff.

headline: A Trip That Will Assist the Rhino
abstract: A portion of the fee for a new safari by Extraordinary Journeys will go to an initiative intended to help the rhinoceros.
lead_paragraph: Extraordinary Journeys, the New York City-based safari outfitter, recently announced a new 10-day safari to Botswana and Zambia that is intended to benefit the Great Plains Foundation’s Zeros for Rhinos initiative.

headline: Portraits From Kiev
abstract: Photos of the protesters and the mourners at Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine, in February.
lead_paragraph: Photos of the protesters and the mourners at Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine, in February.

headline: Strike a Pose
abstract: The actress imitates the poses from fashion catalogs and magazines for Leanne Shapton’s forthcoming book, “Women In Clothes.”
lead_paragraph: The actress imitates the poses from fashion catalogs and magazines for Leanne Shapton’s forthcoming book, “Women In Clothes.”

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Nikil Saval’s ‘Cubed’
abstract: This week, Nikil Saval talks about “Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the week’s literary news; Lenore Skenazy discusses two new books about parenting; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Nikil Saval talks about “Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the week’s literary news; Lenore Skenazy discusses two new books about parenting; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Five Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Entertainment options for almost everyone.
lead_paragraph: There are a lot of cultural options out there. Too many to choose from? Perhaps. So below we’ve winnowed them all down to a few, for brows of all kinds.

headline: Document | Act Natural
abstract: The actress Zosia Mamet strikes a pose – a whole lot of them, in fact – while recreating images from fashion catalogs and magazines.
lead_paragraph: Soon after the Canadian-born artist Leanne Shapton ordered a nightgown from the Vermont Country Store last year, she began to receive mail-order catalogs from National (their tagline: “Living the comfortable life since 1952″) and Woman Within. Struck by the models’ demure stances, she cut out certain images, before turning to her own fashion magazines and other periodicals. Last September, she asked Zosia Mamet to imitate the poses she had collected; the photographer Gus Powell shot. “Posturing” — inspired by the grids of the German artist Hans-Peter Feldmann, illustrated workouts and 1970s yoga manuals (hence the unitard) — is one of the many projects in “Women in Clothes,” out this fall. Edited by Sheila Heti, Heidi Julavits and Shapton, the book explores the issues women face when they get dressed. According to Shapton, the photo series evokes the energetic, experimental spirit of the publication, which features over 600 contributors. “We wanted the reader to do exercises,” Shapton said. “Exercises for the critical eye.”

headline: Kevin McCarthy Won’t Enjoy Being Majority Leader
abstract: It’s no fun leading a caucus that resembles a raucous playground.
lead_paragraph: Kevin McCarthy of California, the House Republican Whip, is running hard to win Eric Cantor’s post as Majority Leader, and claims he has the votes locked up. But except for the big office — and the security detail, and the power and the glory — it’s hard to know why he really wants the job.

headline: Winning a Real Estate Bidding War
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Because of low inventory in many markets, buyers will need to be strategic in how they present their offers.
lead_paragraph: The low supply of homes for sale in many markets means buyers must be prepared for bidding wars. Buyers should be strategic in how they present their offers, and avoid paying too high a premium for their “perfect” property.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Nikil Saval’s ‘Cubed’
abstract: This week, Nikil Saval and Lenore Skenazy.
lead_paragraph: This week, Nikil Saval and Lenore Skenazy.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
abstract: This week, Joe revisits his economic predictions and Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: After a severe winter that sent the economy into negative territory at the start of the year, have things turned around? Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar review their predictions on economic growth for the year ahead. Are the stock market’s recent record highs trickling down to everyone? Plus, whatever happened to Bitcoin?

headline: Back From the Brink, Minnesota Orchestra Announces New Season
abstract: After a lockout and administrative upheaval, the Minnesota Orchestra will open its 2014-15 season with Mahler’s “Resurrection” Symphony.
lead_paragraph: For anyone still waiting for assurances that the Minnesota Orchestra is settling back into its routine after a 16-month lockout and subsequent administrative drama, the orchestra has announced its 2014-15 season. And if that alone is not a clear enough sign, the orchestra and Osmo Vanska, its highly regarded music director – newly restored to his post after resigning during the dispute – plan to open its subscription season on Sept. 26 with Mahler’s “Resurrection” Symphony. (An opening gala with Renée Fleming, and a pair of performances outside the orchestra’s hall precede the Mahler, but surely Mr. Vanska and company want the symbolism to be clear.)

headline: Movie Review: ‘22 Jump Street’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “22 Jump Street.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “22 Jump Street.”

headline: On Our Walls
abstract: In this Insider series, On Our Walls, we’ll take you inside the building to see the photographs that hang on our walls.
lead_paragraph: The walls of The New York Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue are decorated with news images from the past. Prints by photojournalists hang throughout the building. In this Insider series, On Our Walls, we’ll take you inside the building to see the photographs — many of them rich in history — and the stories behind them.

headline: Son of David Rockefeller Dies in Small-Plane Crash
abstract: Dr. Richard Rockefeller, the son of the philanthropist David Rockefeller, was piloting a small plane that crashed shortly after he took off from Westchester County Airport.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Richard Rockefeller, son of the billionaire and prominent philanthropist David Rockefeller, was killed Friday morning when the small plane he was piloting crashed shortly after takeoff, according to a spokesman for the family.

headline: Driven | 2015 Audi A3 2.0T quattro
abstract: Don’t confuse small with inexpensive.
lead_paragraph: Don’t confuse small with inexpensive.

headline: Wheelies: The World Cup Nissan Edition
keywords: ['World Cup 2014 (Soccer)', 'Le Mans Auto Race', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: Nissan begins a Spanish-language ad campaign to aim at World Cup fans; Honda enters the music business to reach the young.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Rover’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Rover.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Rover.”

headline: Israeli Teenagers Said to Be Kidnapped in West Bank
abstract: Initial reports said the three teenagers, one with American citizenship, were last heard from on Thursday on their way to a hitchhiking area south of Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Three Israeli teenagers were missing in the West Bank and were presumed to have been kidnapped, Israeli military officials said on Friday. The episode tested Israel’s already strained ties with the Palestinians and prompted the involvement of the State Department amid reports that one of the youngsters held United States citizenship.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Nikil Saval’s ‘Cubed’
abstract: Mr. Saval discusses “Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace,” and Lenore Skenazy discusses two new books about parenting.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Richard Sennett reviews Nikil Saval’s “Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace.” Mr. Sennett writes:

headline: Video: The Audi A3 Is a Small Car With a Big Price
abstract: Audi’s A3 offers the high style and inspired driving characteristics for which the marque is known, and at a characteristically Audi price.
lead_paragraph: There are a few key things to know about the new Audi A3 compact car, which for 2015 is being offered in the United States for the first time as a sedan, not a hatchback.

headline: A ‘Money Pit’ No More
abstract: A mansion used for the 1986 comedy film “The Money Pit” is poised to go on the market.
lead_paragraph: The Long Island mansion used for “The Money Pit,” the 1986 comedy starring Tom Hanks and Shelley Long about the ultimate fixer-upper fiasco, is poised to go on the market for $12.5 million. The annual property taxes on the home are $65,992.

headline: Bookshelf: Baby Talk
abstract: New picture books include Sara Gillingham’s “Snuggle the Baby” and Lori Nichols’s “Maple.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include Sara Gillingham’s “Snuggle the Baby” and Lori Nichols’s “Maple.”

headline: John Kerry on Obama’s Iraq Thinking
abstract: At the Global Summit to End Sexual Violence in Conflict, Secretary of State John Kerry spoke about the “timely decisions” on the violence in Iraq that he expects from President Obama.
lead_paragraph: At the Global Summit to End Sexual Violence in Conflict, Secretary of State John Kerry spoke about the “timely decisions” on the violence in Iraq that he expects from President Obama.

headline: Image of the Day: June 13
abstract: People at the Gateway of India in Mumbai, Maharashtra, during a high tide.

headline: Tactician Will Try to Take a Title From a Brawler
abstract: Ruslan Provodnikov, the World Boxing Organization’s junior welterweight champion, could not be any more different from Chris Algieri, the undefeated challenger.
lead_paragraph: Backgrounds often help shape boxing styles, and contrasting styles are said to make fights.

headline: Fathers' Rights and Women's Equality
abstract: Is the father's rights movement a legitimate claim for equality, or a backlash against feminism?

headline: Assessing the Benefits of Becoming a Benefit Corporation
abstract: Companies that adhere to a triple bottom line approach to business — profit, people and planet — are finding value in registering as a Benefit Corporation and seeking a designation that recognizes their commitment.
lead_paragraph: When business owners incorporate, they typically do so for one of two reasons: Their accountant told them it’s a good idea, or they want to be taxed in a particular manner. Now there’s a third reason to consider.

headline: Can Uber Live Up to Its $40 Billion Valuation?
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: Will the ride-sharing service succeed because of network effects, or merely clear out regulatory obstacles to the ultimate benefit of others?
lead_paragraph: Dec. 4, 2014: Uber, the mobile-phone-based car service, is getting bigger. The company said today that it had raised another $1.2 billion in funding in a round that values the firm at a remarkable $40 billion (thus post-funding the firm is worth $41.2 billion). At 5 years old, the company now has a valuation on par with that of giants like Time Warner Cable and Prudential Insurance.

headline: The End of Cuisine
abstract: Nathan Myhrvold, the Mad Hatter of modernist cooking, invited the movement’s leading chef, Ferran Adrià, over for a 50-course, lab-prepared meal. It was a lot to digest, sure, but what does a feast like this mean for the future of eating?
lead_paragraph: Nathan Myhrvold, the Mad Hatter of modernist cooking, invited the movement’s leading chef, Ferran Adrià, over for a 50-course, lab-prepared meal. It was a lot to digest, sure, but what does a feast like this mean for the future of eating?

headline: F.C.C. Begins Investigation Into Quality of Internet Download Speeds
abstract: The commission has begun an investigation of Internet service providers at the same time that it is trying to define whether it has jurisdiction over their businesses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission has opened an investigation into recent deals where entertainment companies like Netflix have agreed to pay Internet service providers like Comcast and Verizon for faster video delivery, a practice that critics contend will divide Internet service into fast and slow lanes.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Dragon 2’
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “How to Train Your Dragon 2.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “How to Train Your Dragon 2.”

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: fish during pregnancy, tools to combat blindness and sex after 60. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: fish during pregnancy, tools to combat blindness and sex after 60. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: An Intense Chef, and His Commandments
abstract: At Tomo’s Cuisine in East Hanover, the chef Tomonori Tanaka offers a menu of more than 100 items.
lead_paragraph: The first thing you should know about Tomonori Tanaka, the owner, chef and one-man band calling the tunes at Tomo’s Cuisine in East Hanover, is that he’s not as stern as he looks.

headline: The Rebirth of the Wedding
abstract: The wedding industry has come in for intense critique over the past few years, but wedding traditions still hold cultural sway.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, it seemed like America might reject the wedding. Feminist criticisms of various wedding traditions gained steam; a New Yorker writer released a book on the ceremonies’ ballooning costs; the recession made couples scale back. The phrase “wedding-industrial complex” entered common parlance.

headline: John Seymour: Home for Tuck-In Time
abstract: The restaurateur John Seymour is committed to city life, even if these days he finds the vibe he loves in Brooklyn rather than his native Yorkville.
lead_paragraph: When the restaurateur John Seymour moved 12 years ago from Manhattan to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, he was drawn by the raw lofts with low rents. “The first place I lived was on Kent Avenue, with a revolving door of roommates and 20-foot ceilings,” he said. “We could throw a football inside.”

headline: The Halal Guys: Cashing In on Street Cred
keywords: ['Street Vendors', 'Halal Foods and Products', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Food Trucks']
abstract: More than a decade after three Egyptian men switched from selling hot dogs from their Midtown cart to serving halal food to Muslim cabdrivers, the Halal Guys are about to become a fast-food chain.
lead_paragraph: Some empires are managed from a distance: in corner offices, from cellphones on beaches, under palm fronds while being fanned by servants.

headline: The Times Critics’ Guide to the ‘Friday the 13th’ Movies
abstract: Critics for The New York Times review every movie in the “Friday the 13th” franchise. Mostly — spoiler ahead — they disapprove.
lead_paragraph: There’s only one actual Friday the 13th in 2014 — good news for paraskevidekatriaphobics. But if you wanted to complete a marathon viewing of all eleven movies in the “Friday the 13th” franchise on the actual date, you’ve probably missed your chance for this year. (If you want to go ahead anyway, note that most of the films are available for digital rental.)

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Season Finale: 6 Questions That Need Answers
abstract: The final episode of Season 4 of “Game of Thrones” will run on Sunday on HBO.
lead_paragraph: This post contains spoilers.

headline: Kerry Joins Envoys to Deplore Sexual Violence in War
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The secretary of state spoke at a conference in London featuring Angelina Jolie that sought ways to bring perpetrators to justice.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Secretary of State John Kerry said on Friday that sexual violence in conflict zones should be banished “to the dark ages and the history books,” as he joined dozens of ministers and the actress Angelina Jolie to promote efforts to bring perpetrators of such crimes to justice.

headline: Stayin’ Alive
abstract: Meryl Meisler wasn’t interested in capturing the urban decay of Bushwick, Brooklyn, in the 1980s so much as she was the signs of normal life happening despite it.
lead_paragraph: Meryl Meisler couldn’t believe the sight that greeted her when she emerged from the subway in Bushwick, Brooklyn, for the first time, in 1981. “It looked like the photographs that I had seen of Beirut,” she recalled of the cityscape of bombed-out buildings.

headline: It Never Happened, but It’s Still True
abstract: “Third Person,” a new film written and directed by Paul Haggis, follows several relationships as the examine questions of trust.
lead_paragraph: At the conclusion of a 2011 New Yorker article on the Church of Scientology, the writer-director Paul Haggis made a prediction regarding his very public break with that institution.

headline: King’s College in New York to Accept Bitcoin
abstract: The four-year evangelical school based in Lower Manhattan said that it would become the first accredited college to allow students to pay their tuition in Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin can already be used to purchase a plane ticket, donate to a political campaign and pay a satellite TV bill. Beginning this fall, it can also be used to pay for a college education.

headline: Enter the World Cup
abstract: The Op-Ed columnist handicaps the national teams as the world will now “pause for a month,” to follow the action in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: The world will now pause for a month. It’s the World Cup. Coups and annexations, meltdowns and earthquakes will have to take a back seat to the beautiful game. No other global obsession even comes close. I have been at the last two in South Africa and Germany and came away with glorious memories. Love of the game usually wins out in the end whatever the pretournament grumbling and ugly moments (like Zinedine Zidane’s head butt in the 2006 final).

headline: Whom to Watch in the G.O.P. Shuffle
abstract: As Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, exits the scene, several candidates are vying for leadership positions, which may force a change in Republican party politics.
lead_paragraph: As Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, exits the scene, several candidates are vying for leadership positions, which may force a change in Republican party politics.

headline: Art Matters | A Biennial in, and About, Los Angeles
abstract: The second edition of “Made in L.A.” at the Hammer Museum reflects the diverse yet interconnected nature of the city’s art world.
lead_paragraph: In his infamous Artforum review of the first “Made in L.A.” biennial in 2012, the critic and curator Michael Ned Holte used some choice language: the survey of nascent L.A. artists at the Hammer Museum had a “boosterish tone,” he wrote. He even name-checked every Angeleno’s favorite “Saturday Night Live” sketch, “The Californians,” with its memorable recurring finale in which all the characters crowd in front of a single mirror.

headline: President Obama’s Statement on Iraq
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: President Obama announced that he would not be sending United States troops back into combat in Iraq, but said he had asked his national security team to prepare a range of options.
lead_paragraph: President Obama announced that he would not be sending United States troops back into combat in Iraq, but said he had asked his national security team to prepare a range of options.

headline: Hillary Clinton Talks Same-Sex Marriage on ‘Fresh Air’
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: She explained her positions over time—but not clearly.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has been getting some heat in the media for being evasive about her views on gay marriage during an interview with Terry Gross, host of NPR’s Fresh Air program, and for snapping at Ms. Gross when she pressed her on the subject.

headline: A Train to Nowhere in a New Ice Age
abstract: The sci-fi thriller “Snowpiercer” is the South Korean director Bong Joon-ho’s English-language debut.
lead_paragraph: In the sci-fi thriller “Snowpiercer,” class warfare goes express.

headline: Reassessing Reversal of Adversary to S.E.C.
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The Court of Appeals’ reversal of Judge Jed Rakoff’s decision to reject an S.E.C. deal with Citigroup has troubled many lawyers who specialize in securities law.
lead_paragraph: Judge Jed S. Rakoff of the Federal District Court in Manhattan sent shock waves through the legal and financial establishments in November 2011 when he rejected a proposed $285 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Citigroup. Judge Rakoff said it was impossible for him to say whether it was “fair and reasonable,” let alone in the public interest, after the bank “neither admitted nor denied” the S.E.C.’s accusations nor otherwise revealed any of the facts in a complex mortgage fraud case.

headline: Evidence Is Still Thin That Democratic Voters Ousted Eric Cantor
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: The simplest explanation is that there was a surge of conservatives who voted to unseat the House majority leader.
lead_paragraph: The theory that Democrats cost Eric Cantor his re-election continues to fester. It’s not impossible; it’s just highly unlikely. Mr. Cantor lost by 11 points, which is a significant margin in what was a congressional primary with fairly high turnout. I’ve not seen any evidence that there was a surge of 15,000 Democratic votes.

headline: Skillet Chicken With Rhubarb
abstract: Rhubarb is just as good in savory dishes as it is in dessert. Here, Melissa Clark uses it in a bright, fresh and seasonal dish with chicken and green garlic.
lead_paragraph: Rhubarb is just as good in savory dishes as it is in dessert. Here, Melissa Clark uses it in a bright, fresh and seasonal dish with chicken and green garlic.

headline: Drinks and Food, in That Order
abstract: Baró New World Cantina is a festive place where cocktails and wine are the headliners, and the casual, tasty Latin American dishes serve more as accompanying acts.
lead_paragraph: A place that bills itself as a cantina, as this nearly year-old spot does, calls to mind a few assumptions. First, that a good time will be had there. Second, that drinking — of the lively, boisterous variety — will factor heavily into that good time. And third, that food can be enjoyed there, even if it is not quite the main point.

headline: Rhubarb Flaunts Its Savory Side
abstract: Join the revolution. Tart rhubarb does not have to be sugared into submission to be delicious.
lead_paragraph: Are you ready for the rhubarb revolution?

headline: This Weekend: The Northside Festival
abstract: The sixth annual Northside Festival in Brooklyn kicks off Thursday and will run through the weekend. There will be hundreds of bands showcasing their latest music. Here are three to check out.
lead_paragraph: The sixth annual Northside Festival in Brooklyn kicks off Thursday and will run through the weekend. There will be hundreds of bands showcasing their latest music. Here are three to check out.

headline: Early Gershwin Musical to Open City Center’s Encores Season
abstract: “Lady, Be Good,” the first full musical from George and Ira Gershwin, will run again, with a new orchestration, in February.
lead_paragraph: The Gershwin brothers’ first full musical, “Lady, Be Good” – which yielded, apart from the title song, “Fascinating Rhythm” and “So Am I” (and from which “The Man I Love” was unaccountably dropped during an out-of-town run) – will open City Center’s Encores! season on Feb. 4. The musical, which has a book by Guy Bolton and Fred Thompson as well as Ira Gershwin’s lyrics and George Gershwin’s music, ran for 330 performances on Broadway in 1924 and 1925.

headline: Love, Fear and Anxiety in Suite 719
abstract: In Neil Simon’s 1968 “Plaza Suite,” now at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport, three vignettes examine marriages in trouble, or at least the trouble with marriages.
lead_paragraph: For most of his career, Neil Simon explored family relationships in plays that were either comedies or bittersweet dramas tinged with humor. Even his funniest work, though, was often built on pain. Where would “The Odd Couple” be without the marital difficulties that brought Oscar and Felix together as mismatched roommates?

headline: Iraq May Turn to Iran for Help, Maliki Aide Says
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The aide also criticized what he called the Obama administration’s failure to better prepare the Iraqi military for an emergency.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A senior Iraqi official on Friday warned that his country might be forced to turn to Iran for military help if none were forthcoming from the United States, but he insisted he was unaware of any Iranian military units in his country so far.

headline: The Snakes May Not Bite, but the Humidity Devours
abstract: England was among the teams less than enthusiastic to play World Cup games in Manaus, this hot, humid city in the Amazon, even with no snakes in sight.
lead_paragraph: MANAUS, Brazil — It is the one place all 32 teams probably wanted to avoid in the World Cup, this Amazon city where the heat and humidity feel like a dryer full of damp clothes.

headline: Spain vs. Netherlands: Live Blog
abstract: Welcome to our live coverage of Friday’s Group B clash between Spain and the Netherlands, a rematch of the 2010 World Cup final.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to our live coverage of Friday’s Group B clash between Spain and the Netherlands, a rematch of the 2010 World Cup final.

headline: High Cost to Focusing on Student Loans Over Saving
keywords: ['Student Loans', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Taking on debt to pay for college leads many young people to forgo saving money for years — potentially sacrificing hundreds of thousands of dollars.
lead_paragraph: This week, President Obama ordered changes to the federal student loan program that could help millions of borrowers make their payments more affordable starting in December 2015.

headline: Malfunction Seen in Jet Crash That Killed Co-owner of Philadelphia Inquirer
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board issued a report on the crash on May 31 near Boston that killed seven people, including Lewis Katz, co-owner of The Philadelphia Inquirer.
lead_paragraph: The wreckage of an executive jet that crashed on takeoff at an airport north of Boston on May 31 shows signs of a mechanical malfunction, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Friday in a preliminary report.

headline: A First Great Love Plots the Course for the Second
abstract: After losing their spouses, two longtime friends find a new beginning with each other.
lead_paragraph: The night before she died, Diane Gamble helped plan her husband’s life without her.

headline: Training at the Top of the World
abstract: To train for the largest descent of his life, Jeremy Jones partnered with the legendary climber Conrad Anker for an ascent of Denali.
lead_paragraph: To train for the largest descent of his life, Jeremy Jones partnered with the legendary climber Conrad Anker for an ascent of Denali.

headline: Unraveling in Iraq, and Beyond
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Readers respond to news articles and a column about the crisis.

headline: China to Prosecute Pu Zhiqiang for Activism
abstract: The decision to prosecute Pu Zhiqiang, a widely respected figure, provides more evidence of the Chinese government’s determination to silence reform advocates.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities on Friday announced the formal arrest of a well-known rights defender who last month took part in a private seminar where participants discussed the army’s violent suppression of the student-led protests of 1989 in Tiananmen Square.

headline: Iraq’s Uncertain Future
abstract: As President Obama weighs intervention in Iraq, analysts debate the country’s options.
lead_paragraph: As President Obama weighs whether to help defend the Iraqi government against insurgents, analysts around the world are offering their prescriptions (and their sometimes-dire predictions) for a country in the throes of worsening conflict.

headline: Talking Talent | Jenny Mollen’s New Book of Laughs
abstract: “I Like You Just The Way I Am: Stories About Me and Some Other People,” the actor’s collection of hilarious autobiographical tales, all started with a handful of online essays that she wrote for Playboy.
lead_paragraph: Honest and often painfully embarrassing, Jenny Mollen’s debut book, “I Like You Just The Way I Am: Stories About Me and Some Other People” (St. Martin’s Press), hits bookstores on Tuesday and is poised to be one of the season’s funniest reads. The 35-year-old wife of the actor Jason Biggs and mother to their newborn son, Sid, spent over a decade appearing in barely-there parts on film and television, but found her true calling when she decided to put pen to paper to chronicle her every phobia, sexual encounter and misadventure while stalking her future husband’s exes. With over 125,000 Twitter followers who hang on her acerbic pearls of wisdom — “It’s 10:40, He’s not calling to make plans!” — Mollen, who looks more like a Maxim pinup than a raunchy comedienne, is amassing a devoted legion of fans, one selfie at a time.

headline: 30-Year-Old Decision Could Serve as Template for N.C.A.A. Antitrust Case
abstract: The O’Bannon case says that the N.C.A.A. violated the law by price-fixing. In another case, two universities argued that the N.C.A.A. restrained trade by controlling television contracts.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — William Isaacson has only a few items in his trial binder at federal court here every day. There are both sides’ pretrial briefs filed in the antitrust suit brought against the N.C.A.A. by his client, the former U.C.L.A. basketball star Ed O’Bannon. There are the major decisions by the presiding judge, Claudia Wilken. And there is the full text of a 30-year-old Supreme Court case.

headline: A Better Ranch Dressing
abstract: Here’s a salad dressing base made with yogurt and white beans that can be the foundation of a healthful ranch dressing as well as a few variants.
lead_paragraph: Ranch dressing for dipping makes almost any vegetable more appealing to children, but commercially prepared ranch dressings have nutritional drawbacks. So here’s a salad dressing base made with yogurt and white beans that can be the foundation of a healthful ranch dressing as well as a few variants.

headline: A Little Assistance on the Path to ‘I Do’
abstract: A number of consultants, or concierges, help the lovelorn on their road to wedded bliss, and beyond.
lead_paragraph: It takes a village, the saying goes, to raise a child. And in today’s world, it may take an army of consultants, and the cash to pay for them, to bring two lonely souls from bar stools through bended knee and into a glittering wedding celebration. Here is just a partial rundown of the consultants, or concierges, if you will, that the lovelorn may encounter on their road to wedded bliss, and beyond.

headline: Big Ticket | At $70 Million, a Manhattan Co-op Sales Record
abstract: The sale of a palatial Fifth Avenue penthouse that was the longtime home of Edgar M. Bronfman was the most expensive of the week.
lead_paragraph: A palatial Fifth Avenue penthouse embraced to the west and south by a wraparound terrace with 100 feet of panoramic Central Park frontage sold for $70 million and, along with breaking a sales record for Manhattan co-ops, was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Iraq Reportedly Blocks Social Networks
abstract: Seeking to stem the flow of militant propaganda, Iraq on Friday reportedly cut off access to social networks, including Facebook, Twitter and YouTube.
lead_paragraph: As officials in Baghdad searched for ways to blunt the momentum of Islamist militants who have seized large stretches of Iraq in recent days, the government blocked access to social media sites including Facebook, Twitter and YouTube, bloggers and journalists inside the country reported on Friday.

headline: New York City vs. Street Peddlers, a Brief History
abstract: A selection of articles from The New York Times’s archives chronicling the battle.
lead_paragraph: A selection of articles from The New York Times’s archives chronicling the battle.

headline: The Beautiful Data Set
abstract: To an economist, soccer is also an experiment.
lead_paragraph: THE World Cup is finally underway. At long last, soccer fans can don their team colors, head down to the local pub — and begin collecting data to test economic theories.

headline: Weekend Autos Calendar: Henry Ford Museum’s Motor Muster Celebrates the Mustang
abstract: The event in Dearborn’s Greenfield Village marks 50 years of the Ford pony car; World War II Jeep aficionados gather in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: Cara Delevingne’s Acting Debut, Karlie Kloss’s Designs and Jeff Koons’s Storefront Show
abstract: Plus, Prince Charles unleashes his inner pyro, Rachel Comey sets up shop in SoHo and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: In China, Negotiating Peaks and Police
abstract: A trekking adventure in a Tibetan area of China draws some official attention.
lead_paragraph: The black sport-utility vehicle stopped about 300 feet behind us at a bend in the road. Its occupants were hidden behind its tinted windows. Inside, we assumed, were police officers assigned to follow our group of five foreign men and a local driver up the narrow mountain road. A metal bar across the road had brought us to a halt. It was a police checkpoint, and a man posted at a booth said no outsiders were allowed farther.

headline: Finding Mexico City, and Luis Barragán, Again
abstract: After an absence, the author returns to the capital and renews his appreciation of the great Mexican architect.
lead_paragraph: Memory, in its random way, erased the reasons I stopped going to Mexico City.

headline: The Sister of Second Chances
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Women and Girls', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Teresa Fitzgerald, known as Sister Tesa, has an expanding empire of apartment buildings, thrift stores and special programs in Queens for women who have been in prison, and their children.
lead_paragraph: Venita Pinckney grew up around Catholic schools and churches, and she thought she knew about nuns. Then a small, gray-haired sister named Teresa Fitzgerald came to fish her out of a Harlem crack house. Ms. Pinckney had been a drug addict for 23 years, a dealer and a prostitute, and had lost both of her children to foster care. She was high at the time.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Giants’ Beason Sustains Foot Injury
abstract: Linebacker Jon Beason, one of the Giants’ defensive leaders, sustained a ligament tear and a small fracture in his right foot that may jeopardize his availability for the season opener.
lead_paragraph: Jon Beason, the Giants’ middle linebacker and one of their defensive leaders, sustained a foot injury that may jeopardize his availability for the season opener against the Lions in Detroit on Sept. 8.

headline: Priceline Will Need to Expand OpenTable Overseas to Justify the Splurge
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Reservations (Airlines, Hotels, Etc.)', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The $2.6 billion in cash that Priceline is paying makes sense only if can find a way to expand OpenTable’s overseas presence, writes Robert Cyran of Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The Priceline Group picked an expensive option in its search for expansion.

headline: Giving a Semi-Hearty Cheer for Semi-Staged Opera
abstract: In an operatic performance, does paring a work down to the bare score make it more potent, or do theatrical trappings enrich the experience?
lead_paragraph: When the vengeful husband enters his wife’s bedroom to kill her in the final act of Verdi’s “Otello,” he is accompanied by the muted snarl of a sepulchral E natural in the double basses. For several measures, the violins have been sustaining a heaven-high A flat, and the low tone suddenly replaces it, as if a candle had been snuffed out.

headline: Selling Baubles on the Street: License Required
abstract: Chun Yin, a street vendor, became the family breadwinner after her husband had a stroke, but she was not allowed to sell under his city-issued license.
lead_paragraph: On March 14, Chun Yin took the subway from her apartment in East Harlem to get a good spot on Canal Street to sell jade bracelets, pearl earrings and carved figurines on red silky thread she braids by hand.

headline: Weekend Reading: London Bankers May Be Slow to Return Your Calls
abstract: Who has time to advise a deal or underwrite an initial public offering when important events are taking place in one of the BRIC countries?
lead_paragraph: Who has time to advise a deal or underwrite an initial public offering when important events are taking place in one of the BRIC countries?

headline: Taking a Spin: Republicans Have It Their Way
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Midterm Elections (2014)']
abstract: In this week’s example of a simulation of our Senate election forecasting model, Republicans win just about ever contested seat except North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Just about everything broke right for Republicans today in my spin of Leo’s Senate wheels, our weekly demonstration of how much uncertainty remains in this year’s elections.

headline: Avoiding Another Iraq Quagmire
abstract: President Obama on Friday ruled out sending American ground troops back into the country.
lead_paragraph: Given that he built a political career on opposition to the Iraq war, it was a relief but no surprise when President Obama on Friday ruled out sending American ground troops back into the country.

headline: At Bonnie Slotnick Cookbooks, Recipes to Feed Your Mind and Body
abstract: The store’s books — 4,000, perhaps — are organized by subject: bread, sauce, breakfast, etiquette. But Ms. Slotnick also stocks biographies, memoirs and even manuscripts.
lead_paragraph: There’s always a slight sense of dread as you approach West 10th Street, just off Seventh Avenue, that you might find Bonnie Slotnick’s vintage cookbook shop closed that day. But if the chipped wooden “Open” sign (she painted it herself) peeks out from the brownstone’s stoop, you’re in luck. Shove open the rickety door and a string of bells will herald your arrival.

headline: Mick Jones: A Quiet Day, for a Juke Box Hero
abstract: For Mr. Jones, 69, original lead guitarist of the band Foreigner, Sundays can be for soccer, family and probably some shopping.
lead_paragraph: It is an amusement of New York life that rock stars live among us, picking up dry cleaning or going to the dentist just like everybody else. And it is a quirk of contemporary rock stardom that its constituents now come in all vintages, with hairstyles and heydays stretching back for decades. So it is that Mick Jones, 69, original lead guitarist of the band Foreigner, has been living near Central Park since the ’70s, long enough that he can say, in the accent of Somerset, England, “I’m really a native New Yorker.” These days he is sometimes eclipsed by his stepchildren and children, who include: the D.J., singer and producer Mark Ronson, 38; the fashion designer Charlotte Ronson, 36; the singer and D.J. Samantha Ronson, 36; and the actress Annabelle Dexter-Jones, 27. Foreigner will perform with Styx and Don Felder at Jones Beach on Long Island on June 28.

headline: The Mediterranean Seafood Salad of Your Dreams
abstract: Frutti di mare rice salad is summer cooking at its best, meant to be enjoyed outside with friends and a bottle of wine.
lead_paragraph: Summer appetites are different, and so is summer cooking. In the morning one craves fresh fruit and little more, but by midday a voracious hunger is upon us. We want garlic and lemon and olive oil, and olives, and tomatoes with salt. Maybe a little pizza to tide us over until lunch.

headline: A Ride Across America | Greenmarkets and Off-the-Grid Living in the Heart of Kentucky Coal Country
abstract: Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, is biking across the U.S. talking to people about food. His second dispatch comes from Berea, Ky., where after four days of Dairy Queen and deep-fried Oreos, he found a tasty, healthy meal.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, they’ll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

headline: Senegal to the Caribbean, With a Stop at the Church of Funk and Soul
abstract: An overview of releases covers a 1969 Senegal recording; romantic bachata songs; soul- and funk-influenced gospel; and jazz spotlighting electric and acoustic guitar and electronics.
lead_paragraph: Dexter Johnson

headline: Have You Shopped for a ’70 Ford Lately?
abstract: The Marti Auto Works complex in Arizona is a monument to the owner’s long relationship with Fords. He has created a database of details about individual vehicles from the day they appeared on the assembly line.
lead_paragraph: EL MIRAGE, ARIZ. — To step into Kevin Marti’s garage here is to travel back in time, to reset the dial on the WABAC Machine for 1970 and the destination for the Ford dealership in Anytown, America.

headline: A Full-Service Time Machine
abstract: Kevin Marti’s garage and museum in El Mirage, Ariz., is a reproduction of a circa-1970 Ford dealership.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Marti’s garage and museum in El Mirage, Ariz., is a reproduction of a circa-1970 Ford dealership.

headline: 24-Hour Race Could Lure Huge Crowd at Le Mans
keywords: ['Le Mans Auto Race', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: Attendance is expected to hit 300,000 for the 82nd running of the race on Saturday in France.
lead_paragraph: LE MANS, France — Authorities here are expecting a potential record crowd — possibly approaching 300,000 people — for the start Saturday of the 82nd running of the 24 Hours of Le Mans endurance race.

headline: Mayor of Venice Resigns Amid Corruption Scandal
abstract: Mayor Giorgio Orsoni had been arrested last week and charged with receiving illegal campaign donations believed to be linked to a project intended to save Venice from flooding.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Venice’s mayor, Giorgio Orsoni, resigned on Friday amid a mounting corruption scandal connected with the construction of a colossal flood-barrier system designed to save the lagoon city from flooding.

headline: Finding Cracks in a Perfect Life
abstract: Annette O’Toole takes the lead in a production of Wendy Wasserstein’s “Third,” staged at Two River Theater in Red Bank.
lead_paragraph: Wendy Wasserstein is best remembered for writing thoughtful, witty plays about smart women of her baby boom generation.

headline: Tradition Will Play On at Clearwater Festival
abstract: The mood is expected to be celebratory as a musical memorial unfolds at the first iteration of the festival since the founder, Pete Seeger, and his wife, Toshi Seeger, died.
lead_paragraph: The Clearwater Festival, which has grown from a counterculture-era folk picnic into a sprawling event featuring nearly 100 acts on seven stages, remains at heart a modest affair, free of corporate logos and nurtured by a handful of artist-activists who shared a smaller-is-better ethos with the festival’s founder, Pete Seeger.

headline: On the Market in Hilton Head, S.C.
abstract: A look at traditional and contemporary homes ranging in price from $599,000 to $3,495,000.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: At E3, Virtual Reality Goggles Don’t  Fit Into Reality
abstract: Virtual reality headsets were the hot topic at the 2014 E3 gaming conference. But seeing groups of people wearing black goggles in a room together looked stranger than fiction.
lead_paragraph: It’s tough to stand out at E3, the annual gaming conference. People wander around dressed as orks, gangsters, prehistoric humans, and no one really bats an eye. As one person put it to me, “E3 is nerdier than the cantina scene in Star Wars.”

headline: Futebol para Cegos no Brasil
abstract: Os deficientes visuais brasileiros desafiam o destino ao jogarem o esporte favorito do seu país, o futebol.
lead_paragraph: Os deficientes visuais brasileiros desafiam o destino ao jogarem o esporte favorito do seu país, o futebol.

headline: Where the Z/28 Legacy Began
abstract: The Z/28 designation came from Chevy’s production option code, Z28, for the Special Performance Package. The car’s special qualities were in the engine that anchored the package.
lead_paragraph: Carmakers often resurrect popular model names, but only rarely do they reinstate the character that made the original so memorable. It does happen — the 2014 Corvette Stingray seems to have it — and early reports say that Chevrolet’s Camaro Z/28 revival is faithful to its take-no-prisoners ancestor.

headline: Inside the Frog, a Prince Awaits
abstract: The frumpy Honda Fit has exceeded customer expectations for a budget-friendly subcompact, and the company has kept it that way with the redesigned 2015 model.
lead_paragraph: If a building contractor arrived on time, performed heroically and charged a fair price — this is a New York fantasy, stay with me — would you complain that he wasn’t good-looking? Would you refuse to hire him if he didn’t come with a fashionable tool belt?

headline: A Legend Revived, Its Spirit Intact
abstract: The Camaro Z/28, a model reincarnated from the heyday of pony cars, is all beefcake, powered by the 505-horsepower 7-liter V8 last seen in the Corvette Z06.
lead_paragraph: MONTICELLO, N.Y. — For the Chevrolet Camaro, burning rubber in a straight line has rarely been a problem. Turning and stopping? Not always a top priority.

headline: Taliban Run Into Trouble on Battlefield, but Money Flows Just the Same
abstract: Rising revenues from opium trafficking and other such ventures could increase the longevity of the insurgency, Afghan and Western officials say.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Despite years of efforts by Western officials to cut off the Taliban’s financial lifelines, the militants are as rich as ever, bringing in so much cash from opium trafficking, illegal mining, extortion rackets and other ventures that the money itself appears to be a reason for many insurgents to keep fighting, Afghan and Western officials say.

headline: World Cup 2014: Switzerland Stuns Ecuador, 2-1, in Added Time
abstract: Haris Seferovic’s goal with 20 seconds left in added time capped a wild finish and gave Switzerland a stunning 2-1 victory over Ecuador in a first-round match.
lead_paragraph: Haris Seferovic’s goal with 20 seconds left in added time capped a wild finish and gave Switzerland a stunning 2-1 victory over Ecuador in a first-round match.

headline: A Vieques Hotel With Contemporary Design–and Cuisine
abstract: El Blok, a new inn in Vieques, Puerto Rico, designed by the firm Fuster + Architects, will feature the cuisine of the chef José Enrique.
lead_paragraph: The small island of Vieques, just off the eastern coast of Puerto Rico, will soon harbor one of the most architecturally significant hotels in the Caribbean.

headline: World Cup 2014: France Easily Beats Honduras, 3-0
abstract: France rolled past Honduras in its opening match, helped by a red card to Honduran midfielder Wilson Palacios and two goals from forward Karim Benzema.
lead_paragraph: France rolled past Honduras in its opening match, helped by a red card to Honduran midfielder Wilson Palacios and two goals from forward Karim Benzema.

headline: 2015 Camaro Z/28
abstract: A look at the latest Camaro Z/28.
lead_paragraph: A look at the latest Camaro Z/28.

headline: Russia Sent Tanks to Separatists in Ukraine, U.S. Says
abstract: A State Department spokesman said that claims of heavy weapons crossing the border into Ukraine were correct.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department confirmed on Friday that Russia had sent tanks and other heavy weapons to separatists in Ukraine.

headline: World Cup 2014: Italy Defeats England, 2-1
abstract: With goals by Claudio Marchisio and Mario Balotelli, Italy outlasted England in the punishing heat and humidity of Manaus to win the first match in the Amazon rainforest.
lead_paragraph: With goals by Claudio Marchisio and Mario Balotelli, Italy outlasted England in the punishing heat and humidity of Manaus to win the first match in the Amazon rainforest.

headline: In Baghdad, Where ‘Hello’ Means Goodbye, Hellos Abound at Travel Agencies
keywords: ['Travel Agencies and Agents', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Travel agencies, normally closed on Fridays, were open and busy, and even with extra flights there was often not a seat to be had.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqis say “hello” when they mean goodbye. This can get a little confusing to visitors who do not speak the local dialect of Arabic and think they are hearing English, instead of a borrowed word that has been inverted in meaning.

headline: World Cup 2014: Colombia Defeats Greece, 3-0
abstract: Colombia more than made up for the absence of Radamel Falcao, its star striker, in its victory against Greece on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Colombia more than made up for the absence of Radamel Falcao, its star striker, in its victory against Greece on Saturday.

headline: World Cup 2014: Costa Rica Defeats Uruguay, 3-1
abstract: After falling behind 1-0, Costa Rica scored three goals in the second half to defeat Uruguay in one of the first upsets of the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: After falling behind 1-0, Costa Rica scored three goals in the second half to defeat Uruguay in one of the first upsets of the World Cup.

headline: The 2015 Honda Fit: More Than Skin Deep
abstract: Honda’s well-mannered hatchback gets an update, proving that beauty is as beauty does.
lead_paragraph: Honda’s well-mannered hatchback gets an update, proving that beauty is as beauty does.

headline: Settlement Talks Stall for Citigroup and Justice Department
abstract: Talks to settle a civil inquiry into the sale of shoddy mortgage investments have deteriorated, as the sides are deadlocked on how much money the bank should pay.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:21 p.m. | Talks between the Justice Department and Citigroup to settle a civil investigation into its sale of shoddy mortgage investments have deteriorated in recent days, as the sides are deadlocked on how much money the bank should pay.

headline: World Cup 2014: Ivory Coast Defeats Japan, 2-1
abstract: The Ivory Coast recovered from an early setback, scoring two second-half goals in the space of 100 seconds Saturday night to earn a 2-1 win over Japan in Group C.
lead_paragraph: The Ivory Coast recovered from an early setback, scoring two second-half goals in the space of 100 seconds Saturday night to earn a 2-1 win over Japan in Group C.

headline: Revealing Art, Bursting at the Seams of Control
abstract: Georg Friedrich Haas’s “Atthis,” a monodrama based on texts by Sappho, had its staged premiere at the Kitchen on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The soprano Ariadne Greif stepped out of her gown and ripped off the strips of silver duct tape that crisscrossed her torso like a girdle until she stood naked at the front of the stage, flushed and defiant. “Under my skin gruesome fire smolders,” she sang in a German translation of verses by Sappho. “A high roaring buzzes in my ears, and from every pore seep pearls of sweat.”

headline: World Cup 2014: Argentina Defeats Bosnia-Herzegovina, 2-1
abstract: Lionel Messi scored a goal to the delight of his fans, and Argentina received the gift of an own goal in scoring a 2-1 victory over Bosnia-Herzegovina.
lead_paragraph: Lionel Messi scored a goal to the delight of his fans, and Argentina received the gift of an own goal in scoring a 2-1 victory over Bosnia-Herzegovina.

headline: World Cup 2014: Germany Defeats Portugal, 4-0
abstract: Thomas Müller scored three goals to power Germany to a commanding 4-0 victory and solidified his country’s place at the top of the list of teams that will challenge for the title.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Müller scored three goals to power Germany to a commanding 4-0 victory and solidified his country’s place at the top of the list of teams that will challenge for the title.

headline: Electricity Reporting for Duty
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: The Zero SR is a pumped-up version of the company’s Zero S and a promising indicator that electric motorcycles are closing in on daily-use practicality.
lead_paragraph: TESTED 2014 Zero SR

headline: Bumpy Road to Bright New Days
abstract: The gospel-influenced Melissa Manchester, with her smoky lower register, performed at Café Carlyle on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: “Time has left us older/but wiser, I know I am.” “Come in From the Rain,” the welcoming hymn to a solid longtime friendship from which those lyrics come, was written in the 1970s by Melissa Manchester and Carole Bayer Sager. Although Ms. Manchester’s original recording was not a big hit, the song nevertheless became a nightclub staple until it slowly faded out of fashion.

headline: Are You a ‘Fun Dad’?
abstract: Are you a fun dad? We’re asking readers to share their stories about fun dads who may or may not have also been embarrassing dads.
lead_paragraph: This week, President Obama described himself as a “fun dad” who “teeters on the edge of being embarrassing sometimes.”

headline: World Cup 2014: Iran and Nigeria Play to 0-0 Draw
abstract: Iran and Nigeria tied, 0-0, in a match that was low on goalscoring opportunities and became the first draw of the 2014 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: Iran and Nigeria tied, 0-0, in a match that was low on goalscoring opportunities and became the first draw of the 2014 World Cup.

headline: London’s Legacy in the Slave Trade
abstract: Learning about the city’s role in the slave trade through its monuments, museums and historic houses.
lead_paragraph: It was a bright Saturday morning, and the City of London, the financial district of the British capital, was empty. I was wandering its narrow side lanes seeking a sculpture. I kept getting lost, and found myself going forward and then backtracking. Finally, in a courtyard between office buildings I came upon it: “The Gilt of Cain,” by Michael Visocchi and Lemn Sissay.

headline: U.S.O.C. Narrows Bids to Four Cities
abstract: The United States Olympic Committee said Boston, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington were candidates to host the Summer Games.
lead_paragraph: The United States Olympic Committee announced Friday that it had narrowed its list of potential American cities to host the 2024 Summer Games to four finalists — Boston, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington.

headline: The Z/28 Generations
abstract: The Camaro Z/28 through the years.
lead_paragraph: The Camaro Z/28 through the years.

headline: A Balanced Flavor for the Modern Father
abstract: Men are more stressed about work-life harmony than their fathers or grandfathers were. This week’s cocktail recipe stresses a nice balance.
lead_paragraph: Fatherhood used to be so simple. Wake up, grab your briefcase, kiss your wife and kids goodbye, work all day and come home to find a clean house, kids tucked into bed and a cocktail awaiting your arrival.

headline: Under an Unblinking Gaze, a Farewell to Privacy
abstract: “Surveillance,” performed by ZviDance at New York Live Arts, considers what remains of intimacy in the age of omnipresent monitoring.
lead_paragraph: Who’s watching whom and to what purpose? “Surveillance” — a new 60-minute piece by ZviDance at New York Live Arts this week — is a shrewd collage, both appealing and disconcerting, of the Orwellian Big Brother society, aspects of sexuality and dancing to rock music. It’s the urban world we know, deconstructed and reassembled. In a society in which people need to film or photograph everything, what intimacy is left? Zvi Gotheiner’s choreography suggests that he is as much sociologist as dance-maker.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Iraq, Afghanistan, Syria and Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Iraq, Afghanistan, Syria and Mexico.

headline: The Duet Between the Right Brain and the Left
abstract: For its 10th anniversary, Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet is sampling five works recently choreographed for it in three programs at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: In 2003, when the Walmart heiress Nancy Laurie founded Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet, it sounded like a whim. Yet, over time, the troupe earned respect by filling a hole in the market, commissioning work by rising European choreographers gaining buzz abroad but little seen here. This is a valuable service, even if the effect so far has been to make New York dance audiences feel that they haven’t been missing much.

headline: The Barrister Has 2 Faces
abstract: “The Escape Artist” stars David Tennant and Sophie Okonedo as rival barristers, and Toby Kebbell as a suspected killer, on “Masterpiece Mystery!”
lead_paragraph: In one area, at least, America has a severe trade imbalance with the British. They keep sending us their brainy, urbane leading men — Colin Firth, Benedict Cumberbatch, Kenneth Branagh, Daniel Day-Lewis — and receive very little in return.

headline: The World Wide Bridge Contest Results
abstract: The World Wide Bridge Contests were held in clubs around the world on June 6 and 7.
lead_paragraph: The World Wide Bridge Contests were held in clubs around the world on June 6 and 7. They were organized by Ecats Bridge, which is run by Anna Gudge and Mark Newton (ecatsbridge.com).

headline: Stephane Cremieux of the French Brand Cremieux Shares Father’s Day Gift Ideas Any Dad Will Love (Including His)
abstract: The venerable preppy sportswear line, now run by two generations of Cremieux men, recently opened its first U.S. location in SoHo.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the venerable French brand Cremieux, a purveyor of preppy tailored sportswear since 1976, opened its first American store in SoHo. These days, Cremieux is a family business, jointly operated by its founder, Daniel Cremieux, and his son, Stephane. Here, Stephane offers his list of 10 great Father’s Day treats (many of which can be picked up at locations around New York City for you last-minute shoppers) that his dad and any other would appreciate.

headline: Under Cover: Photographing Frontline Operations in Africa
abstract: The June 15 cover story about confronting terrorism in Africa is accompanied by photographs from Michael Christopher Brown. Here, he discusses his recent assignment for the magazine.
lead_paragraph: The June 15 cover story about confronting terrorism in Africa is accompanied by photographs from Michael Christopher Brown. For the past several years, Brown has primarily covered North and Central Africa, particularly Libya and the Democratic Republic of Congo. Here, he discusses his recent assignment for the magazine.

headline: Chile vs. Australia: Live Blog
abstract: Chile scored two quick goals to jump out to an early lead and held on against Australia for the victory in the teams’ opening Group B match.
lead_paragraph: Chile scored two quick goals to jump out to an early lead and held on against Australia for the victory in the teams’ opening Group B match.

headline: Publishing a Novel to Preserve a Legacy
abstract: Elise Jordan, the widow of the investigative war journalist Michael Hastings, talks about her decision to publish “The Last Magazine,” a satirical novel he wrote about his internship at Newsweek.
lead_paragraph: Elise Jordan curled her petite frame into the sofa in her sunny apartment in TriBeCa and kept her voice steady as she explained why she pushed to publish the unfinished novel of her husband, Michael Hastings, on the first anniversary of his death.

headline: Judge to Consider Retrial or Dismissal in Malcolm Smith Case
keywords: ['Yiddish Language', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'State Legislatures', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: Kenneth Karas indicated that he might end the current trial of a New York state senator and two others because Yiddish translators are scarce.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — As prosecutors hurriedly assembled a team of translators to transcribe 28 hours of Yiddish conversation, a federal judge said on Friday that he would entertain written arguments to help him determine whether the untranslated material might warrant a mistrial or a dismissal of the bribery indictments against State Senator Malcolm A. Smith and two other defendants.

headline: Scoring Onslaught Does In Defending Champions
abstract: Spain, winners of the last World Cup, limped off in defeat as the Dutch triumphed in the remake of the 2010 final as a horror film.
lead_paragraph: SALVADOR, Brazil — Sitting on the bench, worrying that history might be repeated at his team’s expense, Dirk Kuyt, the Dutch reserve forward, had a perfect view of a goal that energized a nation and a tournament with its daring and flair.

headline: High-End Hermès Handbags at Center of Suit Against Christie’s
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Auctions']
abstract: The venerable auction house has been sued by a rival, Heritage Auctions, after it hired several employees in Heritage’s highly lucrative accessories department.
lead_paragraph: Locked behind glass, illuminated like a jewel, lies an Hermès Birkin — totem of wealth, bestower of status, and one seriously expensive handbag.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Tunes From the Great Shakespearean Songbook
abstract: Karen Akers both stands out from and blends in with an ensemble cast in “Sing for Your Shakespeare,” a high-concept musical revue.
lead_paragraph: In the olden days (2011 or so), if you wanted to see and hear Karen Akers doing the exquisite songs of masters like Cole Porter and Stephen Sondheim, you had to make reservations at one of Manhattan’s chic cabarets. But here she is in all her splendor, onstage at the Westport Country Playhouse, in “Sing for Your Shakespeare,” both standing out from and blending in with an ensemble cast.

headline: The Honoree Wanted to Play, Too
abstract: “Celebrate Ornette,” a Celebrate Brooklyn! concert, paid tribute to the 84-year-old Ornette Coleman, who decided to join the band for a while.
lead_paragraph: The evening’s honoree on Thursday at the Prospect Park Bandshell in Brooklyn was Ornette Coleman, and the first to pay respects was Sonny Rollins, wearing a stylish black raincoat.

headline: Nostalgia’s Blurring Glow
abstract: Among urbanists, there has been a growing and rather emotional fascination with old corporate signage: mammoth emblems to industries whose methods are anathema to a prevailing value system.
lead_paragraph: In “Mythologies,” Roland Barthes’s classic collection of essays on the roots and consequences of interpretation, the theorist examines the ways in which consensus understanding evolves around cultural phenomena, typically — or, perhaps almost always — at the expense of layered or contested meaning.

headline: After Four Decades, a School Program Still Shows Youth and Energy
abstract: Performances this week by Kids Dance at the Joyce Theater are celebrating the 40th anniversary of Eliot Feld’s Ballet Tech Foundation.
lead_paragraph: As Eliot Feld has said, ballet is not for a class of people, but for everyone with talent. Discovering dancers through auditions at New York City public schools is his mission. On Thursday night, that talent was on display at the Joyce Theater when Mr. Feld’s Kids Dance revealed exactly what a student showcase should be: fresh and unpretentious, with just enough rigor to make it easy on the eye.

headline: Obama Finds He Can’t Put Iraq War Behind Him
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Iraq continues to shape President Obama’s tenure, as he concludes that American interests there prevent him from fully leaving the country to the Iraqis themselves.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a high-profile speech to Army cadets last month, President Obama tried to move beyond America’s tumultuous adventures in Iraq and Afghanistan with a new doctrine all but forswearing the use of military power except in the most dire of circumstances.

headline: Reactions to the Turmoil in Iraq From Those Who Served
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The New York Times asked veterans of the war in Iraq to share their reactions to the news this week that Sunni extremist militants had seized broad stretches of the country.
lead_paragraph: Many of the American servicemen and women who served in Iraq had strong reactions this week when Sunni extremist militants seized broad stretches of the country. The New York Times asked some of the contributors to At War to share their feelings about events there.

headline: Alitalia’s Board Agrees to Cash Infusion From Etihad of Abu Dhabi
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Rescues']
abstract: Etihad Airways will invest $1.6 billion in Alitalia for a 49 percent stake in the Italian airline.
lead_paragraph: Facing the prospect of bankruptcy for the second time in five years, the board of Italy’s troubled flagship airline, Alitalia, agreed on Friday to a strategic partnership that would give a stake of up to 49 percent to the state-owned Abu Dhabi carrier Etihad Airways.

headline: Eastern Tent Caterpillar: Warm, Fuzzy and Icky
abstract: Eastern tent caterpillars, frequently mistaken for more destructive animals, nest together at night in large webby tents and emerge during the day ready to feed.
lead_paragraph: The eastern tent caterpillar (Malacosoma americanum) ranks high on the “ick” scale for many New Yorkers. Vilified by gardeners, and frequently mistaken for other more destructive caterpillars like those of the nonnative gypsy moth, it is unfairly cast as a woodlands plague. Children seem to instinctively want to squish them. But beauty can sometimes be found in unlikely places. A close examination of the eastern tent caterpillar reveals a handsome native, well adapted to life in the northeast.

headline: Kevin McCarthy’s New Challenge
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Kevin McCarthy, the House majority whip, faces a new challenge in the wake of Eric Cantor’s primary defeat.

headline: Natasha Lyonne Is the Character Who Came for Dinner
