abstract: Ms. Lyonne, of “Orange Is the New Black,” sometimes feels she has become her character, Nicky.
lead_paragraph: Natasha Lyonne had come from taping NBC’s “Late Night With Seth Meyers” on Wednesday, and was waiting for the cable guy in her lofty SoHo apartment.

headline: With Pop-Up Salons, Art Is Demystified
abstract: The start-up Gertrude, named after the writer and art collector Gertrude Stein, has pop-up art salons in New York and other cities.
lead_paragraph: On a Saturday afternoon in Chelsea, a group of a few dozen people milled around the International Print Center New York, drinking Champagne and making small talk about the show New Prints 2014/Winter. But this wasn’t a gallery opening, nor was it an artist’s talk. Rather it was a salon by Gertrude, a new company organizing events to discuss art.

headline: At the Tone, Leave a What?
keywords: ['Text Messaging', 'Voice Mail', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Despite a constant connection to their phones, Generation Y tend to text in lieu of vocal interaction.
lead_paragraph: In a memorable scene from the 1996 comedy “Swingers,” Jon Favreau’s romantically inept protagonist, Mike, deluges the answering machine of a woman he’s just met at a bar with a spate of excruciatingly self-sabotaging messages.

headline: Ayahuasca: A Strong Cup of Tea
keywords: ['Alternative and Complementary Medicine', 'Hallucinations', 'Tea', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Ayahuasca has fans among those who value its power to produce personal insights through hallucinations.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday night, a dozen seekers in loosefitting attire, most in their 20s and 30s, climbed a flight of steps of a mixed-used community space in Bushwick, Brooklyn. After arranging yoga mats and blankets on the floor, they each paid $150, listened to a Colombian shaman and his assistant welcome them in Spanish and English, signed a disclaimer, and accepted large plastic takeout-style containers for vomiting.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 13
abstract: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes the Puerto Rican Day Parade, fire breathers, and a soccer game that helps unite a community.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes the Puerto Rican Day Parade, fire breathers, and a soccer game that helps unite a community.

headline: Defense Reports Puncture Led to Botched Execution
abstract: An independent autopsy of Clayton D. Lockett’s body contradicts Oklahoma prison officials’ account of events.
lead_paragraph: Oklahoma executioners failed to place an injection line properly in a vein in the groin of Clayton D. Lockett, according to an independent autopsy commissioned by Mr. Lockett’s defense lawyers after his bungled execution drew wide attention to the problems of lethal injection.

headline: George Takei Is Still Guiding the Ship
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Television', 'Movies', 'Theater']
abstract: War internment and “Star Trek” behind him, Mr. Takei advocates gay rights, leading with a wink and a grin.
lead_paragraph: George Takei sat in a V.I.P. room at the Waldorf-Astoria as a young makeup artist named Eryk Datura dabbed foundation on his brow.

headline: Orchestrated Conflict
abstract: Russian television has been whipping up anti-Kiev sentiment with unsettling effectiveness.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — IN the lush green fields here in Ukraine’s troubled east, I attended a funeral and a wedding over two days earlier this month. They presented vivid tableaux of contrasting emotions — one of fury, the other of fatalism — but each contained clues to the direction of things in this country on the edge of Europe whose eastern flank has risen up in open rebellion against the central government.

headline: Proving Their Chops in the ‘Real World’
abstract: Culinary students prepare meals and serve diners at restaurants-cum-classrooms in Hyde Park and New Rochelle.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever taken a chance on a haircut at a beauty academy or let high school football players wash your car, you might be a candidate for eating at the hands of culinary students. At the newly refurbished Bocuse Restaurant at the Culinary Institute of America, in Hyde Park, and at the year-old Dining Lab at Monroe College, in New Rochelle, diners who aren’t risk-averse can open themselves up to an enormously fun — and rewarding — experience.

headline: Evening Hours | So Happy Together
abstract: With summer approaching, many celebrated outdoors.
lead_paragraph: With summer approaching, many celebrated outdoors.

headline: First Briefing on Bergdahl’s Condition
abstract: Maj. Gen. Joseph DiSalvo of the Army said the freed Taliban prisoner Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl was in stable condition.
lead_paragraph: Maj. Gen. Joseph DiSalvo of the Army said the freed Taliban prisoner Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl was in stable condition.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Strutting
abstract: Signs of a new peacock men’s wear revolution are in evidence.
lead_paragraph: Signs of a new peacock men’s wear revolution are in evidence.

headline: In the Air | Paper Revolution
abstract: Objects made from paper, or inspired by it, are being elevated to artistic heights. Whether crinkled or cut out, print’s age-old medium is a material of modern design.
lead_paragraph: Objects made from paper, or inspired by it, are being elevated to artistic heights. Whether crinkled or cut out, print’s age-old medium is a material of modern design.

headline: For Early Birds and Late Risers Alike
abstract: All-day breakfasts have been making a comeback on Long Island, with several new cafes upgrading traditional diner offerings with locally sourced ingredients and made-from-scratch recipes.
lead_paragraph: After years of catering to night owls with pub offerings like the Good Life in Massapequa Park and the Phoenix in Seaford, Peter Mangouranes, 38, and Paul Oliva, 35, decided to introduce themselves to customers who like to socialize before the sun sets with an all-day breakfast spot called Jam. The cheerful, eight-month-old country cafe, just down the block from the Good Life, has been serving breakfast standards with a twist since October.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Men’s Wear Revolution
abstract: Signs of a new peacock revolution are in evidence.
lead_paragraph: Signs of a new peacock revolution are in evidence. It features keen attention to detail, including the lapel flower, real or fake. Further evidence are the spectacular windows at Saks Fifth Avenue. A star of the movement, Domenico Spano, known to the world of custom tailoring and fastidious style as Mimmo, outside the Bowery atelier Against Nature. His style has drawn the focus of a group of young men. Also, a gentleman carries the same bright briefcase but pairs it with a different jacket each day.

headline: Among the Rediscovered: Jimmy Giuffre and Eric Dolphy
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss two underappreciated jazz artists.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss two underappreciated jazz artists.

headline: Beinecke Library Gets Sackville-West Papers
abstract: The Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library at Yale has acquired the papers of the writer and gardener Vita Sackville-West and her husband, Harold Nicolson.
lead_paragraph: The Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library at Yale has acquired the papers of the writer and gardener Vita Sackville-West and her husband, Harold Nicolson, a diplomat, novelist and historian. The couple featured prominently in Britain’s literary and political life in the first half of the 20th century and provided their son, Nigel Nicolson, with the subject of his best-selling 1973 biography, “Portrait of a Marriage.” The archives include drafts of lectures, broadcasts and articles (including a manuscript of her 1942 novel, “Grand Canyon”); letters from her parents; letters from close friends and lovers, including Rosamund Grosvenor, Pat Dansey, Geoffrey Scott, Hilda Matheson, Christopher St. John and Gwen St. Aubyn; and diaries and garden journals dating from 1930 to 1962.

headline: Ruth Simmons at Smith College
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Commencement Speeches']
abstract: Ruth Simmons, former president of Smith College and Brown University, addresses the 2014 graduating class of Smith College.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Simmons, former president of Smith College and Brown University, addresses the 2014 graduating class of Smith College.

headline: Bob Garfield at Albright College
abstract: Bob Garfield, journalist, addresses the 2014 graduating class of Albright College.
lead_paragraph: Bob Garfield, journalist, addresses the 2014 graduating class of Albright College.

headline: Oil Industry in Iraq Faces Setback to Revival
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: “The collapse of Iraq would bring an international oil crisis,” an expert says, but so far the oil markets are taking the growing unrest in stride.
lead_paragraph: After a long history of wars and sanctions, Iraq re-emerged as a critical source of oil in recent years. Mounting Iraqi production helped to ease world oil prices despite the tightening restrictions on Iran and tanking exports from Libya. And Western and Chinese oil companies rushed back, revitalizing long-neglected oil fields in the north and south.

headline: No Money, No Time
abstract: The poor are under a deadline that never lifts.
lead_paragraph: THE absurdity of having had to ask for an extension to write this article isn’t lost on me: It is, after all, a piece on time and poverty, or, rather, time poverty — about what happens when we find ourselves working against the clock to finish something. In the case of someone who isn’t otherwise poor, poverty of time is an unpleasant inconvenience. But for someone whose lack of time is just one of many pressing concerns, the effects compound quickly.

headline: Alexis Ohanian at Carthage College
abstract: Alexis Ohanian, co-founder of Reddit, addresses the 2014 graduating class of Carthage College.
lead_paragraph: Alexis Ohanian, co-founder of Reddit, addresses the 2014 graduating class of Carthage College.

abstract: Atul Gawande, doctor and writer, addresses the 2014 graduating class of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
lead_paragraph: Atul Gawande, doctor and writer, addresses the 2014 graduating class of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

headline: In ‘Two Gentlemen,’ Shakespeare’s One Dog
abstract: Oliver, a 65-pound mutt, plays Crab, who has a scene in “The Two Gentlemen of Verona,” in Pinkney Park, Rowayton.
lead_paragraph: You don’t see a lot of dogs in Shakespeare’s plays. Actually, you don’t see any — except Crab.

headline: Echoes of Africa Along the Carolina Coast
abstract: Pete Marovich has been documenting the Gullah communities in South Carolina, which maintain traditions despite the challenges of encroaching development.
lead_paragraph: Pete Marovich has been documenting the Gullah communities in South Carolina, which maintain traditions despite the challenges of encroaching development.

headline: Making Sense
abstract: This month, we decided to focus on the deeper meanings behind some of the most influential people (living and dead) and ideas shaping how we live right now.
lead_paragraph: I like to think that T is a magazine about all the things in life that you don’t really need, but that make every day seem that much more beautiful and interesting. It’s why, in every issue, we try to bring you a mix of the most compelling cultural ideas percolating in fashion, art, design, food, travel. This month, we decided to focus on the deeper meanings behind some of the most influential people (living and dead) and ideas shaping how we live right now.

headline: Jimmy Scott, Singer Whose Star Rose Late, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Scott, whose plaintive delivery earned him a following that included other vocalists like Madonna, Marvin Gaye and Frankie Valli, spent most of his career in relative obscurity before gaining wider appreciation in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Scott, a jazz singer whose distinctively plaintive delivery and unusually high-pitched voice earned him a loyal following and, late in life, a taste of bona fide stardom, died on Thursday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 88.

headline: Massachusetts Democrat Wins Over Voters; Her Party Is a Different Story
abstract: Polls show that Martha Coakley, the state attorney general, is leading in the race for governor. But party delegates, remembering her failed Senate campaign in 2010, may not endorse her.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — It was a cringe-worthy moment for Massachusetts Democrats.

headline: Botox: A Drug With Many (Potential) Uses
abstract: Botox is currently approved for nearly 30 uses worldwide, including 10 in the United States. But Allergan, the manufacturer, has applied for or received patents on many more uses for the drug, a move made partly to discourage competitors while it pursues further research.
lead_paragraph: Botox is currently approved for nearly 30 uses worldwide, including 10 in the United States. But Allergan, the manufacturer, has applied for or received patents on many more uses for the drug, a move made partly to discourage competitors while it pursues further research.

abstract: Martha Coakley, the attorney general of Massachusetts, is running as a Democrat for governor, after a failed run for Senate in 2010.

lead_paragraph: John A. Hamilton, a host and producer of public affairs television programs beginning in the 1970s, died on June 7 in Fairfax, Va. He was 84 and lived in nearby McLean.

headline: T Culture Issue
abstract: The latest issue of T peels back the layers on some of the most influential figures in our culture, past and present.
lead_paragraph: The latest issue of T peels back the layers on some of the most influential figures in our culture, past and present. In our cover story, Jody Rosen explores the meaning of music’s biggest superstar, Beyoncé – from her teenage days with Destiny’s Child to her current standing as pop’s most glorified (and scrutinized) V.I.P. In the Seattle laboratory of Nathan Myhrvold, Dwight Garner ponders the future of food over a 50-course meal the Mad Hatter-like culinarian cooked for his hero, Ferran Adrià. And in suburban Chicago, Emily Witt catches up with the teen blogger turned budding media mogul Tavi Gevinson, whose greatest act — after she takes on Broadway, that is — may be yet to come. Elsewhere, the outspoken critic and forward-thinking American fashion designer Elizabeth Hawes finally gets her due, more than four decades after her death; lit’s reigning bad boy and memoirist of the moment Karl Ove Knausgaard grapples with fame in a soul-searching essay; Charlotte Moss looks back on an interview with the late heiress and horticulturist Bunny Mellon, whose fabled Virginia estate is testament to her extraordinary life; BuzzFeed’s click-bait empire gets the “By the Numbers” treatment; and the director Richard Linklater, whose 1970s-set stoner dramedy “Dazed and Confused” helped define a generation (albeit almost two decades after the fact), tackles time once again in his most ambitious project to date. See all stories from the issue >>

abstract: The goals of of the three main groups in Iraq — Sunni, Shiite and Kurdish — as the country threatens to split apart along sectarian lines.

headline: Blocking Any Medicaid Expansion, Virginia Legislature Passes Budget Bill
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'State Legislatures', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The resignation this week of a Democratic senator turned the tide against Gov. Terry McAuliffe and expanded health coverage for the poor into a flood.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Empowered by their new majority in the State Senate, Republicans have moved to checkmate Gov. Terry McAuliffe in a monthslong contest over Medicaid, passing a budget that does not include the Medicaid expansion the governor sought and forbidding him from unilaterally expanding the health care program for the poor.

headline: Eric Hill, 86, Dies; Created Spot, a Pup Beloved by Toddlers
abstract: Mr. Hill’s children’s books have sold 60 million copies in 60 languages and inspired a TV cartoon show.
lead_paragraph: Eric Hill, an illustrator and writer whose picture books featuring a puppy named Spot enchanted toddlers and sold tens of millions of copies, died on June 6 at his home in Templeton, Calif. He was 86.

headline: The Battle Over Dress Codes
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Education (K-12)', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Why are we focusing so much on what girls are wearing?
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — IN the Bay Area, the last week of school is a time to dig out cozy jackets and socks, but this year our natural air-conditioning (that’s “fog” to you) failed, giving us a few sweltering June days.

headline: World Cup 2014: USA Defeats Ghana, 2-1, on John Brooks Goal
abstract: An early goal by Clint Dempsey and an improbable late score by John Brooks helped the United States stave off Ghana and avoid a third straight World Cup loss to the small African nation.
lead_paragraph: An early goal by Clint Dempsey and an improbable late score by John Brooks helped the United States stave off Ghana and avoid a third straight World Cup loss to the small African nation.

headline: The Father’s Example
keywords: ["Father's Day", 'Labor and Jobs', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: It’s important to show my son that work is the epicenter of a good life.
lead_paragraph: RECENTLY, my 14-year-old son, Carlos, accompanied me on a trip to give a speech alongside a group of politicians. In the large holding room backstage, the speakers milled about, making small talk before our speeches. Working as my assistant, Carlos handed me a bottle of root beer, which, unbeknown to me, he had been shaking. (Behold the mysteries of the 14-year-old mind.) Upon opening it, I sprayed a copious amount onto a distinguished member of Congress.

headline: Bringing Back Europe’s Bison
abstract: A German prince is leading an effort to bring back the European bison, Europe’s largest land mammal, in Bad Berleburg. The animal almost went extinct in the early 20th century.
lead_paragraph: A German prince is leading an effort to bring back the European bison, Europe’s largest land mammal, in Bad Berleburg. The animal almost went extinct in the early 20th century.

headline: Obama Visits Sioux Lands on a Trip Shadowed by Iraq
abstract: In his first visit to an American Indian reservation as president, Mr. Obama told the crowd that he had delivered on a campaign promise to improve relations between the government and the nation’s tribes.
lead_paragraph: CANNON BALL, N.D. — Hours after adjourning a tense Oval Office meeting about the Iraq crisis, President Obama found himself on the ancestral lands of Chief Sitting Bull, taking part in a powwow to honor American Indians who have served in America’s foreign wars.

headline: New Chairman of Board at N.Y.U. Is Announced
abstract: William R. Berkley will have the title of chair-designate until October 2015, when he will officially succeed Martin Lipton.
lead_paragraph: New York University has announced a new leader for its board of trustees, one of the largest and most powerful in American academia: William R. Berkley, an insurance industry executive currently serving as a board vice chairman.

headline: In Iraq Crisis, a Tangle of Alliances and Enmities
abstract: The major players in the Iraq and Syria crisis are often both allies and antagonists, working together on one front on one day and at cross-purposes the next.
lead_paragraph: The major players in the Iraq and Syria crisis are often both allies and antagonists, working together on one front on one day and at cross-purposes the next.

headline: Eyesore and Landmark in One
keywords: ['World Cup 2014 (Soccer)', 'Soccer', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: In the shadow of the newly renovated Maracanã Stadium, where the World Cup final will be played, stands a crumbling building that was once devoted to the indigenous people of Brazil.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Rotting, crumbling, covered in graffiti, overrun by weeds, the hulking wreck of a building known as the Aldeia Maracanã would make an unsightly addition to any neighborhood.

headline: A Muslim Entrepreneur Follows a Kosher Model to Mainstream Success
keywords: ['Halal Foods and Products', 'Muslim Americans', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Food']
abstract: Adnan A. Durrani’s Saffron Road food company has moved beyond a core audience of American Muslims and into the commercial mainstream, with annual sales approaching $35 million.
lead_paragraph: During the early months of 2010, Adnan A. Durrani found himself frequently thinking of kosher hot dogs. To be more precise, he was thinking of an ad campaign for them created decades earlier by the Hebrew National company. Its well-known slogan went, “We answer to a higher authority.”

headline: S.E.C. Conducting Investigation of Port Authority Projects
abstract: The investigation will focus in part on the agency’s handling of roadway construction projects, according to several people briefed on the matter.
lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said this week that it is under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, adding to the series of inquiries that have been ordered since the lane-closing scandal at the George Washington Bridge last year.

headline: Chicago Competes Against Itself for Site of Obama Presidential Library
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: Three universities, several community groups and others in Chicago are expected to submit proposals to the Barack Obama Foundation for the presidential library site.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The tussle over the location of President Obama’s future presidential library seems to have come down to a debate over various places he has lived, including this city, New York City and Hawaii. Leaders from all three have been boasting lately of their relative assets as they lobby for the site, which they see as an honor, not to mention an economic driver.

headline: Beleaguered Iraqis Court Iranian Mastermind of the Shiites Who Fought the U.S.
abstract: Iraq may see the possibility of significant aid from Iran as a means of pressuring the United States to come to Iraq’s defense with aid of its own.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gen. Qassim Suleimani, the shadowy commander of Iran’s paramilitary Quds Force, flew to Iraq this week with dozens of his officers to advise the country’s beleaguered leadership about how to blunt the advance of militant forces on Baghdad, American officials said Friday.

headline: A Better Approach to School Discipline
abstract: A new report lays out a clear road map for preserving order without suspending or expelling students under “zero tolerance” policies.
lead_paragraph: The “zero tolerance” disciplinary policies that swept through the country’s schools beginning in the 1990s have led to millions of children each year being suspended, expelled and even arrested, mainly for minor misbehavior that would once have been dealt with at the principal’s office. Federal civil rights officials warned this year that these tactics are often used in a discriminatory fashion against black and Latino children, who are at greater risk of being thrown out of school and denied an education.

headline: Obama, McCain and Maliki
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: All sides bear some of the responsibility for the deteriorating crisis in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: THE debacle in Iraq isn’t President Obama’s fault. It’s not the Republicans’ fault. Both bear some responsibility, but, overwhelmingly, it’s the fault of the Iraqi prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

headline: With Attention Elsewhere, Kaymer Is in Midst of Run of Distinction at U.S. Open
abstract: His fellow Germans are focused on the World Cup, but Martin Kaymer is having a record-setting United States Open.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — With a second straight round of 65, Martin Kaymer set the United States Open record for the lowest score at the halfway mark and became the first player in any of the four major golf championships to open with back-to-back 65s.

headline: Getting a Good Table by Flicking an App, Not Greasing a Palm
abstract: Restaurateurs are uncomfortable with a wave of mobile apps that secure and resell coveted tables at popular establishments, sometimes covertly.
lead_paragraph: Who owns a restaurant reservation?

headline: Veterans Watch as Gains Their Friends Died for Are Erased by Insurgents
abstract: Hundreds of Americans lost their lives battling for control of parts of Iraq that are falling to militants with breathtaking speed.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks before their battalion was to get new mine-resistant vehicles, Capt. Adam P. Snyder, Pvt. Dewayne L. White and Sgt. Eric J. Hernandez were speeding toward a mission in Baiji, Iraq, when a roadside bomb engulfed their Humvee in flames, killing the two enlisted men. Captain Snyder, 26, died the next day, Dec. 5, 2007.

headline: Seeing Their Gains at Risk, Shiites Flock to Join Militias
abstract: Skills honed on behalf of President Bashar al-Assad will be used for militia groups battling the Sunnis who are driving toward Baghdad.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — When he heard on Tuesday that Mosul, Iraq’s second-largest city, had fallen to Sunni militants, Abu Ali Alakabaie knew what he had to do.

headline: With No Body, Police Sought Murder Clues Elsewhere
abstract: Detectives shared details of the mysterious case of Ramona Moore, after she made the rare transition from missing person to suspected murder victim without ever turning up.
lead_paragraph: Detectives entered a basement in the Bronx and recoiled at the stench and the scene.

headline: Next Steps in Iraq
abstract: Readers comment on my column about who bears responsibility for the mess in Iraq
lead_paragraph: As a bit of an experiment we’re publishing my Sunday column on line tonight, Friday, because it’s newsy and based on today’s events. My deadline for the Sunday column is Friday afternoon, because of early printings for the Sunday Review section, and the Sunday columns normally go on line roughly when the Sunday paper comes out. But we’re all trying not to hamper our digital product with our print constraints, so we decided to put this column up early. Let me know what you think of the idea. And don’t be confused if you read it now on line and then encounter it Sunday in print.

headline: Decorating and Design Meet Taxation and Politics Where Cuomo Lives
abstract: A home in Westchester County, owned by the governor’s companion, Sandra Lee, was reassessed and assigned higher property taxes after improvements.
lead_paragraph: NEW CASTLE, N.Y. — The white clapboard colonial-style house at 4 Bittersweet Lane in this exclusive town is special for two reasons.

headline: Pastor New to Harlem Takes Rangel On
abstract: The Rev. Michael A. Walrond Jr.’s candidacy has raised questions about his aims in the race to unseat Representative Charles B. Rangel.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Michael A. Walrond Jr. knows he is the outsider. In the Democratic primary for the congressional seat carved out of Harlem that now stretches into parts of the Bronx, Mr. Walrond trails far behind the longtime incumbent, Representative Charles B. Rangel, and State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat in the polls.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 13, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In a Downpour, Mexico Keeps Calm to Edge Cameroon
abstract: Neither the relentless rain nor the contentious officiating rattled the Mexican players, who dismantled Cameroon in a performance that belied the final scoreline.
lead_paragraph: NATAL, Brazil — The rain was relentless, descending in thick sheets to turn this city’s glistening new soccer stadium into an overstuffed water park. The officiating was contentious, as two apparent goals were canceled within a 20-minute span in the first half.

headline: The Koch Cycle of Endless Cash
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Political Action Committees', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Wind Power', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The wealthiest Americans are using their fortunes to lobby Congress against any limits on their ability to buy elections.
lead_paragraph: It’s not enough, apparently, that some of the wealthiest Americans spend millions to elect their candidates to Congress. Now they are using their fortunes to lobby Congress against any limits on their ability to buy elections.

headline: Sign at the End of a Freeway
abstract: A wide open and crunchy puzzle by Alex Vratsanos. Just the way we like it.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — If you’re going to attempt to solve the Saturday New York Times Crossword — and why wouldn’t you? — it helps to try one that has lots of white space in which to roam, plenty of fun, crunchy entries, some tricky cluing to keep you interested and some high-scoring Scrabble letters in the mix. Alex Vratsanos’s puzzle pretty much achieves all of these. He’s also hit for the cycle — published a puzzle for each day of the week — with this one, so congratulations are in order.

headline: Spain Was Asking for Trouble Against the Netherlands
abstract: Spain played a high defensive line, positioning themselves well forward, near midfield. It left them vulnerable, giving the Netherlands multiple opportunities for long passes to streaking forwards, resulting in many high-quality chances — and many goals.
lead_paragraph: Spain played a high defensive line, positioning themselves well forward, near midfield. It left them vulnerable, giving the Netherlands multiple opportunities for long passes to streaking forwards, resulting in many high-quality chances — and many goals.

headline: Recreating Wilderness in Spain
abstract: A reserve in the country’s west seeks to transform unused farmland into the type of wild area that disappeared from Europe centuries ago.
lead_paragraph: A reserve in the country’s west seeks to transform unused farmland into the type of wild area that disappeared from Europe centuries ago.

headline: From Untended Farmland, Reserve Tries to Recreate Wilderness From Long Ago
abstract: A reserve in western Spain is at the forefront of Europe’s “rewilding” effort, which seeks to restore species and ecosystems that vanished centuries ago.
lead_paragraph: LA ALAMEDILLA, Spain — The forces of nature were getting more than a little prodding recently on the grassy 1,200-acre reserve outside this village near Spain’s border with Portugal.

headline: So Triple Crown Is Tough? Try Sweeping Golf’s Majors
abstract: Since 1930, no golfer has swept the majors, and in the last three decades, only Tiger Woods has won the first two legs. The difficulty is that there are different horses for different courses.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — Thirteen horses have won the first two legs of the Triple Crown since 1978, when Affirmed completed the feat with a victory in the Belmont. In the same span, only one man, Tiger Woods, has won the first two legs of golf’s holy grail.

headline: Threat Grows From Liver Illness Tied to Obesity
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Liver', 'Medicine and Health', 'Obesity', 'Transplants']
abstract: Despite major gains in fighting hepatitis C and other chronic liver conditions, public health officials are now faced with a growing epidemic of liver disease that is tightly linked to the obesity crisis.
lead_paragraph: Despite major gains in fighting hepatitis C and other chronic liver conditions, public health officials are now faced with a growing epidemic of liver disease that is tightly linked to the obesity crisis.

headline: A Game of Groans
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: Pick a route, any route, on the road to replenishing the Highway Trust Fund! Ready to go, people?
lead_paragraph: Today let’s find fun ways to talk about the Highway Trust Fund.

headline: Walking in a Graduation Procession, 50 Years Late
abstract: Richard Zirpolo, 67, joined the class of 2014 at Xavier High School in Manhattan, so that his mother could finally watch him be handed a diploma.
lead_paragraph: Richard Zirpolo’s heart pumped. His hands sweated. It was his high school graduation ceremony in 1964, and he was ready to receive his diploma.

headline: Peace Corps Volunteers Deserve Fairness
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Women and Girls', 'ABORTION', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Members of the government’s volunteer corps should receive the same coverage as other federal workers.
lead_paragraph: Women make up more than 60 percent of the Peace Corps, volunteers who are often put in situations where safe and reliable medical care is difficult to find and where they face the risk of sexual assault. Yet federal law does not allow abortion coverage in the volunteers’ health care program, even in cases of rape or incest, or when a pregnancy endangers a woman’s life. Next week, subcommittees in both the House and the Senate will begin work on a Peace Corps budget for the next fiscal year. The lawmakers should repeal this unfair prohibition.

headline: Reprisal Killings Reported in Iraq’s Militant-Held Areas
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Sunni militants in Iraq are rounding up former government workers, allowing some to repent and live while executing others, residents and a United Nations official said.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — While still largely refraining from terrorizing the population inside Mosul, militants, working from a list they have obtained, have begun seeking out citizens who worked for the government, offering some a chance to repent and live under their authority, and in other cases executing them on the spot, according to accounts of residents and a top United Nations official.

headline: Friday Night Music: Sylvan Esso
abstract: Also, Chris Christie.
lead_paragraph: My wife, who hates you all, suggested this as today’s music selection:

headline: Immigration Is Key, Not Top, Issue in South Carolina County
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: People who live and work in Greenville County, S.C., say that immigration, while important, is not the central concern that some commentators have seen.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Dripping with sweat while working in his front yard here, Kevin Bailey had sharp words about President Obama’s health law and what he sees as runaway spending on Capitol Hill. Those issues, he said, were those that mattered most.

headline: After Heat’s Humbling Loss, Future Is Uncertain
abstract: Miami’s Big Three can all opt out of their contracts, and at least two of them — LeBron James and Chris Bosh — might be considering it.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — His numbers were solid, nothing out of the ordinary for LeBron James. He finished Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals with 28 points and 8 rebounds, plying his trade against a convoy of defenders that included the San Antonio Spurs’ Kawhi Leonard, who, at a precocious 22, somehow plays with both energy and polish.

headline: Franz Beckenbauer Barred by FIFA for 90 Days
abstract: Franz Beckenbauer, who won World Cups with Germany as a player and coach, was suspended for refusing to cooperate with an investigation over bidding for the 2018 and 2022 tournaments.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — FIFA’s ethics committee on Friday suspended Franz Beckenbauer from all soccer activity for 90 days, saying he had refused requests to cooperate with an investigation into the bidding for the 2018 and 2022 World Cups.

headline: Spurs Have Made N.B.A. Finals Anything but Close
abstract: The N.B.A. finals have been shockingly one-sided, with the Spurs relying on lethal shooting and talented role players to put the defending champion Heat on the verge of being dethroned.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. finals were billed as a repeat of one of the most competitive series in history. The defending champion Miami Heat may have won their 2012-13 series against the Spurs, but you had to really squint to see the difference between the two teams. At the end of seven intense games, the San Antonio Spurs had actually outscored the Miami Heat by five points.

headline: Drowsy Drivers, Dangerous Highways
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: The fatal accident that left the actor Tracy Morgan injured brings attention to the lobbying efforts of the trucking industry.
lead_paragraph: Days before an accident in which an allegedly drowsy truck driver crashed into a van carrying the actor Tracy Morgan, critically injuring him and killing another passenger, a Senate committee voted to roll back regulations meant to keep fatigued truckers off the nation’s highways.

headline: Try a Little Common Sense
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Search Engines']
abstract: Should free speech always trump the right to privacy?
lead_paragraph: Last month, around the same time the European High Court ruled that Europeans had a “right to be forgotten” by the search engine Google, a man named Tim Barefield approached me with the following story:

headline: Idaho Republican, Appealing to Right, Enters Race to Replace Cantor
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: Representative Raúl R. Labrador has positioned himself as a more conservative alternative to Representative Kevin McCarthy as majority leader.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Raúl R. Labrador, a Republican of Idaho who has barely served two terms in Congress, jumped into the race for House majority leader on Friday, offering himself as the more conservative alternative who could pull the House rightward in the wake of Representative Eric Cantor’s loss in a primary.

headline: Jeter’s Return to Oakland Recalls a Defensive Gem
abstract: The Yankees shortstop’s backhand flip to nail Jeremy Giambi at home plate during Game 3 of the 2001 American League division series helped turn the tide after two home losses.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Unless the Yankees and the Oakland Athletics meet in the playoffs, shortstop Derek Jeter will make his final stop this weekend at the O.co Coliseum, the site of perhaps the most memorable defensive play in his 20-year major league career.

headline: Strategies in the Political and Athletic Arenas
abstract: This week Iraq plunged into sectarian war, the World Cup began, and Eric Cantor was defeated in a House primary race.
lead_paragraph: The opening game of the World Cup had everything the advance hype promised — battles between the police and protesters outside the São Paulo stadium; boos for the leaders of Brazil and FIFA, the governing body of world soccer; dodgy refereeing; and a beautiful game between Brazil and Croatia.

headline: U.S. Airstrikes Could Help in Reversing Insurgent Offensive, Experts Say
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Sunni Muslims']
abstract: Advisers and better intelligence could improve United States air power in an effort to assist the Nuri Kamal al-Maliki government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American air power could play an important role in reversing the Sunni insurgent offensive in Iraq, current and former American military officials said on Friday, but it would be most effective with improved intelligence about insurgent targets and if the United States were willing to deploy small teams of advisers to call in airstrikes.

headline: Kings Beat Rangers for Cup, Ending Short Series of Long Games
abstract: The Los Angeles Kings won their second Stanley Cup in three years with a four games to one series win over the Rangers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Bad omens stared at Henrik Lundqvist at the start of Game 5 of the Stanley Cup finals. It was the 666th game of his Rangers career. A full moon — the first on Friday the 13th since 2000 — hung over Staples Center.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE CONJURING (2013) Patrick Wilson and Vera Farmiga, above, play Ed and Lorraine Warren, the real-life paranormal investigators who declared an infamous Dutch colonial-style house on Long Island haunted, leading to more than a dozen “Amityville” movies. Their target this time is a Rhode Island farmhouse, where the blissful dreams of Carolyn and Roger Perron (Lili Tayor and Ron Livingston) and their five daughters become a moaning, creaking nightmare when they find themselves playing cat-and-mouse with an evil force. The director, James Wan, “smartly keeps enough distance from the Warrens that you can see that these true believers are also hovering at the edge of dangerous fanaticism,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “That gives the movie a shiver of political currency, even if a greater, more sustaining pleasure of this particular haunted-house fantasy is how it works as a metaphor for moviegoing itself. When the Perrons first settle into their house, they’re facing the future with bright, anxious smiles that aren’t much different from those of the horror-film faithful who are waiting nervously, hopefully, to be jolted by the next great shocker. It’s here.”

headline: Kings Capture Cup at Home
abstract: The Kings rallied in the third period to force overtime and scored in the second extra period to beat the Rangers in Game 5 and win the Stanley Cup.
lead_paragraph: The Kings rallied in the third period to force overtime and scored in the second extra period to beat the Rangers in Game 5 and win the Stanley Cup.

headline: Talk of Puck Luck Bounces Both Ways for Both Teams
abstract: The Stanley Cup finals saw its share of weird bounces and deflections. While the Rangers believed “the hockey gods” may have played a part in the series, the Kings did not buy it.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s called puck luck, and it would seem to be an appropriate phrase for some of the bounces, deflections and goal-line theatrics that threaded their way through the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: Chuck Noll, Coach of Steelers’ 1970s Dynasty, Dies at 82
abstract: Noll took a Pittsburgh team that had been a perennial doormat and turned it into a powerhouse.
lead_paragraph: Chuck Noll, who built the “Steel Curtain” Pittsburgh Steelers of the 1970s into one of the most dominant teams in pro football history, becoming the only N.F.L. coach to win four Super Bowl championships, died on Friday at his home in Sewickley, Pa., outside Pittsburgh. He was 82.

headline: Mets Choosing Sides in World Cup
abstract: On the second day of soccer’s biggest tournament, the Mets, faced with a rain delay, temporarily diverted their attention to the games in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Mets reliever Carlos Torres was sitting at his locker Wednesday, speaking into his phone in a hushed tone and a hurried manner. Torres sounded desperate, almost as if he were begging.

headline: Republicans at Romney Retreat Search for Focus
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mitt Romney’s third annual conference in Utah serves to help find a focus for the divided, and largely leaderless, party.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — The official topic of the conference, emblazoned on materials handed out to guests gathered here at a luxury Norwegian-inspired resort, was “The Future of American Leadership.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 14, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 14, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “The equivalent of this is foie gras. You have to force feed ducks to get fatty liver, but people seem to be able to develop it on their own.”

headline: Phelps Shuts Down Athletics as He Gets Support From Yankees’ Offense
abstract: The Yankees starter did not allow a hit until the fifth inning, while Jacoby Ellsbury, Mark Teixeira and Brett Gardner each drove in a run.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — No one saw this coming Friday night from Yankees right-hander David Phelps against the Oakland Athletics.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on June 14, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Afghans, Looking Ahead to U.S. Withdrawal, Vote With Guarded Optimism
abstract: As voters chose Saturday between an ex-finance minister and an opposition politician, the Taliban appeared not to have launched any major attacks, at least in urban areas.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghans lined up on Saturday to vote in the second and final round of the country’s presidential election, choosing a new leader to steer Afghanistan through the coming withdrawal of American-led military forces. Despite reports of numerous attacks in rural parts of the country, the Taliban appear to have failed to disrupt the voting.

headline: Separatists Down Military Transport Jet, Killing 49 in Eastern Ukraine
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Military Aircraft', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: The attack was the deadliest episode for the Ukrainian military since the unrest began in the country’s east.
lead_paragraph: LUHANSK, Ukraine — Separatists in Ukraine used a shoulder-fired missile to shoot down a large Ukrainian military transport jet as it was trying to land at an airport in this eastern city on Saturday, killing all 49 people on board, the military said. The attack was the deadliest episode for the Ukrainian military since the unrest began in the country’s east.

headline: Analytics: Poem by Committee
abstract: People sent out more than 1,000 tweets using the hashtag #NYTpoem during our poetry-writing session with Patricia Lockwood on May 30. Here’s how the tweets broke down, with examples.
lead_paragraph: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the June 15 issue of the magazine.

headline: Iraq Rebels Stall North of Baghdad as Residents Brace for a Siege
abstract: An insurgent juggernaut that captured Iraq’s second-largest city and raced nearly 200 miles south in three days stalled on Saturday, leaving residents in Baghdad bracing for a siege that so far has not happened.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A rebel juggernaut that captured Iraq’s second-largest city and raced nearly 200 miles south in three days, raising fears of an imminent assault on Baghdad, stalled for a second day on Saturday about 60 miles north of the capital, leaving residents bracing for a siege that so far has not happened.

headline: Why That Phone Charger Took Two Years to Arrive
abstract: What can go wrong in turning a bold idea into a business? A start-up company’s creative team counts the speed bumps.
lead_paragraph: I first heard about the JuiceTank, a slim iPhone case that doubles as a wall charger, when my friends started raving about it two years ago on Twitter. There was one catch, though it didn’t bother them: The JuiceTank didn’t yet exist.

headline: We Will Be Welcomed As Liberators
abstract: And Ahmed Chalabi is George Washington.
lead_paragraph: I’ve often noted that to a first approximation, nobody ever admits having been wrong about anything. My usual prime example is all the people who issued dire warnings five years ago that runaway inflation was imminent — and are issuing identical warnings to this day. But all of that is nothing as compared with the way the same people who assured us that the invasion of Iraq would be a splendid little war — remember “Everyone wants to go to Baghdad, real mean want to go to Tehran”? — are now insisting that we should go all in on behalf of a corrupt, incompetent regime that is basically Iran’s ally, not ours.

headline: At De Beers, Collecting Images and Inspiration
abstract: Hollie Bonneville Barden, head designer at De Beers Diamond Jewelers, draws inspiration from a wall full of images in her London office.
lead_paragraph: Above the buzz

headline: On the Steamboat, and Striking Up the Calliope
abstract: Travis Vasconcelos, a historian and lecturer with the American Queen Steamboat Company, started working on riverboats at the age of 12.

headline: You Can’t Have A Wage-Price Spiral Without Wages
abstract: And wages are going nowhere.
lead_paragraph: There was a fairly characteristic argument over dinner last night about when the Fed should tighten. I’m in the camp that says it should wait until we see wages rising at least at pre-crisis rates. The other side says that wages are a lagging indicator, and if it waits that long the Fed will be behind the curve.

headline: Bernard Schwartz, on the Philosophy of ‘Just Say Yes’
abstract: Loral’s former chief executive says he looked for optimism in the people he would hire — “the sense that we’re going to win, and that we’re going to have a successful answer to whatever the problem is.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Bernard L. Schwartz, an investor who is the former chairman and C.E.O. of the Loral Corporation, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Finding Shock Absorbers for Student Debt
abstract: How to insure against the risks of investing in a college education? Allow student loan payments to rise and fall with the borrower’s income.
lead_paragraph: President Obama last week signed an executive order aimed at easing the debt burden on millions of people who borrowed money for college. Soaring loan costs, he said, have put “too big a debt load on too many people,” and it’s time to do something about it.

headline: Pension Funds, Dancing a Two-Step With Ratings Firms
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Some government pension funds are suing ratings agencies — but are still relying on them to grade investments.
lead_paragraph: Pension fund investors lost billions of dollars trusting the rosy credit ratings stamped on troubled mortgage securities before the 2008 crisis. In its aftermath, they have spent years and many dollars suing Moody’s and Standard & Poor’s, the main purveyors of those dubious grades.

headline: Allergan, Defending Its Fort Botox
abstract: The feisty chief of Allergan, Botox’s maker, says a takeover would imperil the company’s drug-discovery mission.
lead_paragraph: David E. I. Pyott spent a couple of hectic days in Manhattan last week, paying calls on institutional investors and Wall Street analysts, trying to persuade them that his company is worth much more than $54 billion.

headline: The Nation’s Economy, This Side of the Recession
abstract: In the five years since the United States began its slow climb out of the deepest recession since the 1930s, the job market has undergone a substantial makeover.
lead_paragraph: In the five years since the United States began its slow climb out of the deepest recession since the 1930s, the job market has undergone a substantial makeover.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, June 15
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “Noncompetes are a dampener on innovation and economic development.”

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Elevators and Escalators', 'Balconies and Terraces', 'Condominiums']
