lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Colombia vs. Greece: Live Blog
abstract: Live coverage and analysis of the match between Colombia and Greece. Colombia, the seeded team and a sleeper pick by many to make a deep run, lost its star striker Radamel Falcao to a knee injury, but the team still has plenty of talent.
lead_paragraph: Live coverage and analysis of the match between Colombia and Greece. Colombia, the seeded team and a sleeper pick by many to make a deep run, lost its star striker Radamel Falcao to a knee injury, but the team still has plenty of talent.

headline: Room Service, I’ll Have a Massage
abstract: Luxury properties are increasingly giving their guests a chance to enjoy more elaborate spa treatments en-suite.
lead_paragraph: In-room massages are a standard amenity at most upscale hotels, but luxury properties are increasingly giving their guests a chance to enjoy more elaborate spa treatments en-suite. The Chatwal in New York City, for example, has a package through its Elizabeth Arden spa that includes reflexology, a warm cream manicure and a blow dry and style for women and hair trim and neck cleanup for men ($534).

headline: Carrying Fragile Hopes, England Stumbles in Opener
abstract: England has disappointed its fans since winning the World Cup in 1966, and the national pessimism was confirmed in a loss to Italy in their first match.
lead_paragraph: MANAUS, Brazil — England had just counterattacked and counterpunched, quickly responding to a goal by Italy with one of its own. But this is the World Cup, and England never seems to escape the bizarre.

headline: Variety: A Somewhat Hostile Acrostic
abstract: An acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon that reveals a writer’s sadness.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Samuel Butler had a complicated relationship with his parents, but particularly his father, which could explain the underlying hostility in today’s acrostic quote. In the 1932 book “Samuel Butler: A Mid-Victorian Modern,” he wrote: “He never liked me, nor I him; from my earliest recollections I can call to mind no time when I did not fear him and dislike him … I have never passed a day without thinking of him many times over as the man who was sure to be against me.”

headline: E3 Still Dazzles, Even as Video Game Sales Go Digital
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3)', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: It is unclear what the role of events like E3 will be as more of the games business shifts to digital distribution, away from physical stores.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Electronic Entertainment Expo, or E3, the video game industry’s annual convention, is very good at a certain ritual: building hype for big-budget games — more often than not for consoles — just before summer starts, so publishers can maximize their sales when games land on store shelves for the holidays.

headline: The End of Iraq
abstract: The facts on the ground are shredding the official maps of Iraq and the region.
lead_paragraph: EVERY so often, in the post-9/11 era, an enterprising observer circulates a map of what the Middle East might look like, well, after: after America’s wars in the region, after the various revolutions and counterrevolutions, after the Arab Spring and the subsequent springtime for jihadists, after the Sunni-Shiite struggle for mastery. At some point, these cartographers suggest, the wave of post-9/11 conflict will necessarily redraw borders, reshape nation-states, and rub out some of the lines drawn by Sir Mark Sykes and François Georges-Picot in a secret Anglo-French treaty almost 100 years ago.

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Latest Updates on the Insurgency in Iraq
abstract: Follow the latest developments in Iraq on Saturday, as the government in Baghdad attempts to regroup following a string of victories by Islamist militants.
lead_paragraph: Open Source is collecting reports from bloggers and journalists in Iraq on Saturday, as the government in Baghdad attempts to regroup following a string of victories by Islamist militants.

headline: 21 Flat-Screen TVs, 18 Holes, One Pair of Eyes
abstract: Tommy Roy, the lead producer for NBC and the Golf Channel, is at his 20th U.S. Open, an event he has covered like a conductor orchestrating a symphony of words and pictures.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — It was the first round of his 20th United States Open telecast, and the Golf Channel and NBC producer Tommy Roy had a meaty morsel of information for the on-air host Dan Hicks, who could not decipher what Roy was shouting into his earpiece.

headline: ‘After Midnight’ to Close After 8 Months
abstract: The Broadway musical “After Midnight,” a revue of song-and-dance numbers from the Cotton Club era of the 1920s, will close on June 29 after more than eight months of performances, a spokesman for the show confirmed on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway musical “After Midnight,” a revue of song-and-dance numbers from the Cotton Club era of the 1920s, will close on June 29 after more than eight months of performances, a spokesman for the show confirmed on Saturday. The producers of “After Midnight” were hoping to boost their modest ticket sales by winning the Tony Award for best musical last Sunday, but another nominee, “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” took the prize. “After Midnight,” which was capitalized at about $7 million, will close at a financial loss. Investors may recoup some money if a national tour of the show – now in discussions – comes together and proves successful.

headline: Medical Device Maker Medtronic Is Said to Be Near a Deal for Covidien
abstract: Medtronic is looking to buy a competitor, Covidien, for more than $45 billion. If a deal is completed, it would help cut Medtronic’s corporate tax rate.
lead_paragraph: Medtronic Medtronic is nearing a deal to buy a competitor, Covidien, for more than $45 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Saturday, in a deal that would combine two major medical device makers.

headline: Ukrainian Military Plane Shot Down
abstract: A Ukrainian military plane was shot down by Pro-Russia separatists in Novohannivka, Ukraine. All 49 people aboard were killed.
lead_paragraph: A Ukrainian military plane was shot down by Pro-Russia separatists in Novohannivka, Ukraine. All 49 people aboard were killed.

headline: Flying 3 Flags and Seeking One Banner
abstract: Patty Mills of the San Antonio Spurs flies three flags: of Australia, the Aboriginals and the Torres Strait Islands, and like many Australians he continues to wrestle with complex questions of culture and heritage.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Benny Mills, it appears, is the type of man who is incapable of speaking without a smile, one that instantly gives his cherubic face an impish glint. His wife, Yvonne, is a more serious study, a woman who chooses her words carefully, as if they are irrevocable, and speaks them with a quiet force.

headline: A Cantor Effect for Businesses and the G.O.P.
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Corporations', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Eric Cantor’s defeat last week in a primary to David Brat, who campaigned against Wall Street, led industry to mobilize to preserve its clout in Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day after Representative Eric Cantor became the first congressional leader in modern times to lose his seat in a primary, one of the biggest aftershocks occurred not on Capitol Hill or in the sprawling Richmond suburbs he has represented for more than a decade but on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Kings’ Second Stanley Cup in Three Seasons Defies Cap Logic
abstract: Los Angeles defeated the Rangers in the Stanley Cup finals to lift the Cup for the second time in three years, an achievement that comes despite the current salary-capped era of parity in the N.H.L.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One team winning two Stanley Cups in three seasons during this salary-capped era of parity in the N.H.L. defies logic. But the Los Angeles Kings have never paid mind to the expectations of others.

headline: New Position for Angels: Contention
abstract: After stumbling early in the season the last two years, the Los Angeles Angels are entering the summer in the thick of the race in the A.L. West.
lead_paragraph: In his first two seasons as general manager of the Los Angeles Angels, Jerry Dipoto watched his team all but disappear from contention in the early-season quicksand. In 2012, the Angels doomed themselves with a 6-14 start. Last year, they lost 22 of their first 33.

headline: Minority Gun Owners Face Balancing Act, Weighing Isolation and Stigma of Violence
abstract: At a time when gun issues are volatile nationally and sales are increasing, many minority gun owners are trying to balance the pros and cons of ownership with the N.R.A.’s unyielding stances.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Standing in a small booth surrounded by displays for rifles, pistols, holsters and other firearm accouterments, the Rev. Kenn Blanchard signed copies of his book “Black Man With a Gun: Reloaded.” Amid the sea of thousands of white faces that descended on this city for the National Rifle Association convention in late April, Mr. Blanchard, an N.R.A. member since 1991, offered his reasoning for why he was one of the few black visitors.

headline: Big City Book Club
abstract: The Big City Book Club’s hot-summer reading selection is Richard Price’s best-selling 2008 novel, “Lush Life.” Join us for the live discussion of the book on Tuesday, July 15, at 6:30 p.m.
lead_paragraph: The Big City Book Club’s hot-summer reading selection is Richard Price’s best-selling 2008 novel, “Lush Life.” The book is both an evocation of decades of life on the Lower East Side of Manhattan and the tale of a violent crime whose effects ripple. One of the witnesses of the murder is initially considered a suspect, and even when he is exonerated, the trauma of the event stays long with him. Join us for the live discussion of the book on Tuesday, July 15, at 6:30 p.m.

headline: Uruguay vs. Costa Rica: Live Blog
abstract: After falling behind 1-0, Costa Rica scores three goals to defeat Uruguay in one of the first upsets of the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: After falling behind 1-0, Costa Rica scores three goals to defeat Uruguay in one of the first upsets of the World Cup.

headline: A Conflict on Campus
abstract: Readers discuss whether college groups should be allowed to exclude students.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss whether college groups should be allowed to exclude students.

headline: Notes From the Plasticene Epoch
keywords: ['Plastics', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Water Pollution', 'Editorials']
abstract: In Hawaii, the effort to pick up tons of plastic that washes ashore may seem futile, but it is better than doing nothing.
lead_paragraph: Like diamonds, plastics are forever. The tons dumped into the ocean float around, swirling on currents, breaking into smaller bits, never going away. Scientists have identified huge gyres of plastic in the Pacific. There is an Eastern Garbage Patch, between Hawaii and California; a Western Garbage Patch, off Japan, and a patch between them called the Subtropical Convergence Zone, north of Hawaii.

headline: Highways Need Help, but Not This Way
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Editorials', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: A corporate tax holiday was disastrous in 2005. It would be disastrous again.
lead_paragraph: It should surprise no one that the federal Highway Trust Fund is on the brink of insolvency. The 18.4 cents a gallon federal gas tax that is the fund’s main source of revenue has not been raised since 1993. Since then, the population has grown by 55 million people. Roads, bridges, tunnels and public transit have not been maintained or upgraded to meet the increased demand.

headline: Peggy Smith
abstract: The cheesemaker on mysteries, vintage roadsters and listening to music on vinyl.
lead_paragraph: Peggy Smith was a chef at Chez Panisse in Berkeley for 17 years before co-founding Cowgirl Creamery, which makes award-winning artisan cheeses. The company, in Point Reyes Station, Calif., was among the first American cheesemakers inducted into France’s prestigious Guilde Internationale des Fromagers.

headline: 5 Principles for Iraq
abstract: There are many questions that need answering before the U.S. considers intervening.
lead_paragraph: THE disintegration of Iraq and Syria is upending an order that has defined the Middle East for a century. It is a huge event, and we as a country need to think very carefully about how to respond. Having just returned from Iraq two weeks ago, my own thinking is guided by five principles, and the first is that, in Iraq today, my enemy’s enemy is my enemy. Other than the Kurds, we have no friends in this fight. Neither Sunni nor Shiite leaders spearheading the war in Iraq today share our values.

headline: My Father, Body and Soul
keywords: ["Father's Day", 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: Seeing Dad for the last time was both a blessing and a curse.
lead_paragraph: IT’S been eight years since I last saw my father, lying in his reclining chair in his living room, as perfectly still as the half-filled coffee cups on the side table.

headline: A Paper Boat Navigating a Digital Sea
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Newspapers', 'Public Editor (Times Column)']
abstract: Times editors are scrambling to adapt to the changing media landscape, but are they going fast enough?
lead_paragraph: IT’S Wednesday morning and 39 editors have filed in to the 10 a.m. meeting in The Times’s third-floor conference room, some carrying laptops and smartphones, others with pens and notepads.

headline: Naked Confessions of the College-Bound
abstract: The raw and revelatory admissions essay reflects the blinding competition to get into elite schools.
lead_paragraph: THE Yale applicant had terrific test scores. She had fantastic grades. As one of Yale’s admissions officers, Michael Motto, leafed through her application, he found himself more and more impressed.

headline: When Will Hillary Let It Go?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Movies']
abstract: America is entranced with the frozen kingdoms of two polarizing queens.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — NO one wrote about blondes like Raymond Chandler.

headline: The Fog Machine of War
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'News and News Media', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: I saw firsthand how the United States military rationed what the American public knew about its operations in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan. — WHEN I chose to disclose classified information in 2010, I did so out of a love for my country and a sense of duty to others. I’m now serving a sentence of 35 years in prison for these unauthorized disclosures. I understand that my actions violated the law.

headline: Abortion and Birth, Together
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Midwives']
abstract: Single facilities that treat patients with wanted and unwanted pregnancies are part of an effort to reframe reproductive care.
lead_paragraph: SOME of the pregnant women who arrive at Buffalo Womenservices in upstate New York are there for checkups or tours of the birth center, with its pool and homey delivery room. Others arrive to talk to a doctor, nurse or counselor. But they are not waiting for prenatal tests. They are there to get abortions.

headline: Poetry: Who Needs It?
abstract: It’s long been a major art with a minor audience.
lead_paragraph: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — WE live in the age of grace and the age of futility, the age of speed and the age of dullness. The way we live now is not poetic. We live prose, we breathe prose, and we drink, alas, prose. There is prose that does us no great harm, and that may even, in small doses, prove medicinal, the way snake oil cured everything by curing nothing. But to live continually in the natter of ill-written and ill-spoken prose is to become deaf to what language can do.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 15
abstract: Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, lost his primary race, setting off a political frenzy. Militants in Iraq have also retaken areas of the country that Americans once held. Both events will dominate the conversation on the Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: A primary race in Virginia rocked the political world when Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, lost to his Tea Party-backed opponent David Brat, an economics professor. By the following day, Mr. Cantor announced that he would resign his leadership position by July 31. Mr. Cantor will appear on both ABC’s “This Week and CNN’s “State of the Union,” to give his opinion on why he lost his congressional seat and what went wrong with his campaign.

headline: The Milk Carton Guy
keywords: ['Detainees', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Prisoners of War']
abstract: Detainees have been released from Guantánamo for years. Why were Republicans outraged only with the prisoner swap for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl?
lead_paragraph: In early 2003, military investigators traveled to Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to interview one of the prison camp’s most valuable detainees, a Qaeda loyalist from Morocco named Abdullah Tabarak. According to multiple reports, Mr. Tabarak had been Osama bin Laden’s chief bodyguard and longtime confidant, and he gave himself up to help bin Laden elude capture shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: The Ultimate Underdog
abstract: The University of Tokyo, which produces many of Japan’s top politicians, doctors and even baseball team owners, is a lightweight when it comes to the nation’s most popular sport, baseball.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Itaru Kobayashi remembers what his baseball coach at the University of Tokyo used to tell the team before games, and he remembers what the coach said after the team inevitably lost.

headline: A Stigma of Black Gun Ownership
abstract: In recent decades, gun ownership has been taboo among many African-Americans, but that may be changing.
lead_paragraph: In recent decades, gun ownership has been taboo among many African-Americans, but that may be changing.

headline: Teams Win N.B.A. Titles, but Superstars Sell the Sizzle, and Themselves
abstract: Some may prefer breathtaking teamwork, but the N.B.A. has grown and is popular because of its star system. Get used to it.
lead_paragraph: I get nervous whenever people begin pining for “the good old days.” There has been a lot of this over the last few days as the San Antonio Spurs have mopped the floor with the Miami Heat during the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Extremist Video Appears to Show American
abstract: Intelligence analysts believe that a video released by a Syrian rebel group last month shows Moner Mohammad Abusalha, the American who blew himself up in the conflict recently.
lead_paragraph: Intelligence analysts believe that a video released by a Syrian rebel group last month shows Moner Mohammad Abusalha, the American who blew himself up in the conflict recently.

headline: Syria Suicide Bombing Puts U.S. Face on Jihad Video
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Terrorism', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: American officials believe a recruitment video circulating in extremist circles shows the American who killed dozens in a recent attack, and they are concerned that others will follow in his path.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Like a trailer for a summer blockbuster, the video begins with loud music and the words “Coming Soon.”

headline: Rift Bared as Palestinians Aid Israel in Search for Teenagers Missing in West Bank
abstract: The crisis underscored the complexity of Israel’s relations with the Palestinian Authority and the authority’s deep differences with Hamas despite a recent reconciliation pact.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — As the search continued on Saturday for three Israeli teenagers who were missing in the West Bank and were presumed to have been abducted by Palestinian militants, the crisis underscored the complexity of Israel’s relations with the Palestinian Authority and the authority’s deep differences with Hamas despite a recent reconciliation pact.

headline: A Piece of the Game Beyond the Walls
abstract: Dozens of inmates manufacture soccer balls at a Brazilian prison near one of the 12 cities hosting the World Cup games.
lead_paragraph: CONTAGEM, Brazil — Hugo Alves used to play professional soccer for a living. He remains connected to the sport, but not in the way he intended. Now his uniform consists of a red T-shirt and pants, and he makes soccer balls at a factory in prison.

headline: A Baseball Binge Woven From Dreams
abstract: A journey through five cities in five days had one goal: to see five major league baseball games.
lead_paragraph: This would be a week from my dreams: five major league baseball games in five cities in five days.

headline: Palace of Squatters Is a Symbol of Refugee Crisis
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Squatters', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: The overcrowding of Salaam Palace is a crisis within a larger, nationwide emergency set off by a fresh surge of more than 50,000 migrants to Italy since the beginning of the year.
lead_paragraph: ROME — On a recent evening, two volunteer doctors and a handful of medical students moved gingerly around a dimly lit room, examining dozens of newly arrived migrants from the Horn of Africa. The medics treated blotchy arms, legs and feet — symptoms of scabies — lighting the infected areas with a smartphone app. Nearby, a pediatrician listened to the chests of newborns and toddlers.

headline: Obama Moves to End Rail Workers Strike in Philadelphia
abstract: Gov. Tom Corbett asked President Obama to establish an emergency board to help resolve a dispute that halted service on 13 lines, including the one to Philadelphia International Airport.
lead_paragraph: A transit strike in Philadelphia ended late Saturday after President Obama signed an executive order creating a presidential emergency board to help resolve the labor dispute.

headline: Graduates Cautioned: Don’t Shut Out Opposing Views
abstract: Several commencement speakers this spring advocated tolerance in the wake of protests that drummed away others who had been invited.
lead_paragraph: Commencement speakers made news this year mostly by their absence. Protesters on the left assailed speakers who had been invited by colleges and universities, and in some cases, they got their wish, driving away the intended guests.

headline: The Fight Over New Standards
abstract: Backlash reigns in schools nationwide after the introduction of Common Core standards. Critics say they are overly difficult, but others say they challenge students to become better thinkers.
lead_paragraph: Backlash reigns in schools nationwide after the introduction of Common Core standards. Critics say they are overly difficult, but others say they challenge students to become better thinkers.

headline: Tears of Joy and Heartbreak After an Enthralling Series
abstract: There has never been a five-game series as supremely gripping as the Stanley Cup finals between the Los Angeles Kings and the Rangers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Long passages of breathless excitement and almost unbearable anxiety, and then, in an instant, utter joy and utter despair. Alec Martinez leaps once, his arms aloft in joy; a second time, and tosses away his stick; a third time, and throws off his gloves. He turns to embrace his teammates — he has just scored to win the Stanley Cup for the Los Angeles Kings.

headline: Common Core, in 9-Year-Old Eyes
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)']
abstract: Chrispin Alcindor, a Brooklyn fourth grader, was once a top student. But rigorous new academic standards — and the exams that accompany them — have frayed his confidence.
lead_paragraph: He could have written about the green toy truck he kept hidden in his room, a reminder of Haiti, a place he did not yet fully understand.

headline: England vs. Italy: Live Blog
abstract: With goals by Claudio Marchisio and Mario Balotelli, Italy outlasted England in the punishing heat and humidity of Manaus in the first match in the Amazon rainforest.
lead_paragraph: With goals by Claudio Marchisio and Mario Balotelli, Italy outlasted England in the punishing heat and humidity of Manaus in the first match in the Amazon rainforest.

headline: At Commencement, Obama Mocks Lawmakers Who Deny Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Commencement Speeches', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Colleges and Universities', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Speaking at the University of California, Irvine, President Obama likened those who deny climate change to people who would have told John F. Kennedy, at the dawn of the space program, that the moon “was made of cheese.”
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — President Obama, appearing emboldened after his recent move to cut carbon emissions from coal-fired power plants, on Saturday ridiculed members of Congress who deny climate change or plead scientific ignorance as an alibi for avoiding an uncomfortable truth.

headline: Enrich
abstract: In which Tony Orbach enriches our Sunday.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — O.K., so it’s not really a Father’s Day puzzle, unless, of course, you really like the letter ‘N,’ in which case, surprise! Happy Father’s Day!

headline: Korea’s Fish Special: A Delicate Mix of Outhouse and Ammonia
abstract: Served most often as chewy pink slabs of sashimi, hongeo, or fermented skate, is prized in South Korea for fumes so strong they sometimes cause people’s mouths to peel.
lead_paragraph: HEUKSAN ISLAND, South Korea — South Korea has a generous list of foods some find hard to swallow, among them boiled silkworm pupae and live baby octopuses, which have been known to attach their suction cups to the roofs of diners’ mouths in what appear to be desperate bids to escape.

headline: Cambodia’s Scam Orphanages
abstract: In Cambodia, less than a quarter of children in orphanages are actual orphans.
lead_paragraph: In Cambodia, less than a quarter of children in orphanages are actual orphans.

headline: Property Taxes and the Urge to Tinker
abstract: It is possible for a government that does not levy property taxes to lower them, but it can be complicated.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Cambodian Activist’s Fall Exposes Broad Deception
keywords: ['Orphans and Orphanages', 'Children and Childhood', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Human Trafficking', 'Prostitution']
abstract: Activists say the story of Somaly Mam is part of a larger tale of deception meant to attract foreign money into impoverished Cambodia.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — The fall from grace of one of Cambodia’s most prominent social activists and the unraveling of her sad tale of being an orphan sold into sex slavery has highlighted what aid workers here say is widespread embellishment and in some cases outright deception in fund-raising, especially among the country’s orphanages.

headline: Trying to Limit Outside Influence in Prescribing Drugs
abstract: Throughout Texas and across the nation, medical facilities are imposing bans on drug representatives visiting with doctors.
lead_paragraph: As sales representatives for pharmaceutical companies brought doughnuts and lunch over the years to physicians at the 20 Kelsey-Seybold medical clinics in the Houston area, Patrick Carter worked to limit the representatives’ presence.

headline: Lee Hyla, 61, Who Mixed Rock and Jazz Into Classical Works, Dies
abstract: Critics said that Mr. Hylas’s works captivated audiences with its eclectic originality, propulsive rhythmic force, companionable combination of dissonance and consonance.
lead_paragraph: Lee Hyla, an American composer whose work married the formal rigor of classical music with the driving energy of rock and the improvisational abandon of jazz, died on June 6 in Chicago. He was 61.

headline: Recognizing a Hurdle and Finding Her Voice
abstract: With its mostly male cast, Kat Candler’s “Hellion,” a coming-of-age story, defies traditional notions of what female-directed movies are supposed to look like.
lead_paragraph: Kat Candler, the writer and director, fell in with an ambitious group of filmmakers when she first moved to Austin from Florida in 1997.

headline: Alan Douglas, Who Mined Hendrix Archive, Dies at 82
abstract: Whether Mr. Douglas’s decision to add new material to posthumous releases of Jimi Hendrix’s music was right or wrong is a matter of debate.
lead_paragraph: Alan Douglas, a music producer and packager who worked with jazz greats like Duke Ellington, recorded the prerap stylings of the Last Poets and published a book of monologues by Lenny Bruce — but who is best known as a controversial steward of the legacy of Jimi Hendrix — died on June 7 at his home in Paris. He was 82.

headline: In Democratic Stronghold, a Republican Fights Back
abstract: In a border district that includes almost 25 percent of Texas’ land, the competition is for a congressional seat that has changed hands twice in two general elections.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — A San Antonio native and former C.I.A. agent is trying to break through in the only region in this Republican state where congressional Democrats hold a steady grip: Texas’ border with Mexico.

headline: Frank Schirrmacher, German Newspaper Publisher, Dies at 54
abstract: Mr. Schirrmacher was co-publisher of the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, one of Germany’s most respected publications.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Frank Schirrmacher, a co-publisher of the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung and one of Germany’s most prominent and forceful intellectuals, died on Thursday after a heart attack. He was 54.

headline: After Annexing Crimea, Euphoric Russia Turns Thoughts to Ukraine
abstract: Ukraine continues to dominate public discourse in Russia, and nothing else — not housing concerns, political issues or even an indoor smoking ban — really competes.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The event in Moscow last week was billed as an expert discussion, not a political one, on Ukraine’s future. But Sergei Y. Glazyev, an economic adviser to President Vladimir V. Putin with a distinctive Stalinist bent, unleashed some rather overtly political remarks.

headline: University of Tokyo’s Favorite Disappointment
abstract: The university, locally known as Todai, churns out success in almost every field, except baseball. The team has lost 76 straight games.
lead_paragraph: The university, locally known as Todai, churns out success in almost every field, except baseball. The team has lost 76 straight games.

headline: As the Demand for Court Interpreters Climbs, State Budget Conflicts Grow as Well
keywords: ['Translation and Interpreters', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Jury System', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'States (US)']
abstract: New Mexico and other states with increasingly diverse populations have strained to meet the rising cost of providing court interpreters for non-English speakers.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — Judge David Segura of Santa Fe County Magistrate Court called his first housing case of the day, a disagreement between Gabriela Herrera and her landlord over a rental payment. In Spanish, Ms. Herrera — born in California, raised in Mexico and a resident of this city for six years — recounted her side of the story, fixing her eyes on the judge, whose eyes, in turn, kept shifting to the interpreter translating her words into English in a booming baritone.

headline: Ivory Coast vs. Japan: Live Blog
abstract: This is Ivory Coast’s moment after two cycles of bad luck and bad draws at the World Cup. While Japan is looking to atone for some spotty pre-World Cup performances.
lead_paragraph: This is Ivory Coast’s moment after two cycles of bad luck and bad draws at the World Cup. While Japan is looking to atone for some spotty pre-World Cup performances.

headline: With Spurs’ Minds on a Title, the Heat Give Theirs a Break
abstract: Miami Coach Erik Spoelstra urged his team to take a mental rest from basketball before trying to make an unprecedented comeback from a 3-1 deficit in the N.B.A. finals.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — After the San Antonio Spurs dealt his team two straight losses in Miami, Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra took an unconventional approach, advising his players to avoid even thinking about basketball. That was his prescription for Friday: no practice, no second-guessing themselves, no stress.

headline: Massachusetts Democrats Hand Coakley a Setback
abstract: The state treasurer, Steve Grossman, finished well ahead of Ms. Coakley, who barely beat the third-place candidate for the gubernatorial nomination.
lead_paragraph: WORCESTER, Mass. — Massachusetts Democrats on Saturday endorsed for governor Steve Grossman, the state treasurer, passing over Martha Coakley, the attorney general, and setting up an intense fight for the party nomination in the September primary.

headline: Calling Back a Zombie Ship From the Graveyard of Space
abstract: After 36 years in space, the International Sun-Earth Explorer-3 appears to be in good working order, and a shoestring group of civilian engineers is trying to bring it back into Earth’s orbit.
lead_paragraph: For 17 years, it has been drifting on a lonely course through space. Launched during the disco era and shuttered by NASA in 1997, the spacecraft is now returning to the civilization that abandoned it.

headline: A Nation Teased by a Stale Promise of Supremacy
abstract: Supporting Uruguay seems to be a mix of masochism and nostalgia, and the country’s 3-1 loss to Costa Rica on Saturday will reinforce its fans’ cultured skepticism.
lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay — Few in Uruguay will have heard of the English man of letters Cyril Connolly. Yet his most famous phrase — “Whom the gods wish to destroy they first call promising” — would not be lost on a country used to auspicious starts.

headline: Rebels’ Fast Strike in Iraq Was Years in the Making
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: The group’s sweep into Mosul and farther south appeared to catch many Iraqi and U.S. officials by surprise, but the gains were the realization of a yearslong strategy of state-building.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — When Islamic militants rampaged through the Iraqi city of Mosul last week, robbing banks of hundreds of millions of dollars, opening the gates of prisons and burning army vehicles, some residents greeted them as if they were liberators and threw rocks at retreating Iraqi soldiers.

headline: Despite Five Bogeys, Kaymer Calmly Holds On to a Five-Shot Lead
abstract: A difficult day at Pinehurst was not enough to rattle Martin Kaymer, who is seeking his second major title.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — No one plays the United States Open without hitting a shot that ends up somewhere unforeseen or, worse, somewhere unbelievably unlucky. What happens after that often defines the golfer’s competitive journey.

headline: In Second Career Start, Harvey’s Former Teammate Blanks the Mets
abstract: Once Matt Harvey’s high school teammate, the Padres rookie Jesse Hahn silenced the Mets on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: After the finest pitching performance of his young career, in front of about two dozen friends and family members at Citi Field, Jesse Hahn returned to his locker in the visiting clubhouse and checked his phone. He found a simple text message: “Good job.” It was from Matt Harvey.

headline: Yankees Aren’t Exactly Bombers, but Their Bats Are Showing Signs of Life
abstract: The Yankees’ offense still has work to do, but in the last two games the team had 22 hits and 13 runs.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Yankees went 12 straight games without scoring more than four runs before beating the Seattle Mariners, 6-3, on Thursday night to sweep their three-game series.

headline: High School Stars Mix With Pros at Grand Prix
abstract: Some of the best high school track runners in the country got a chance to compete with professional counterparts at the Adidas Grand Prix on Randalls Island.
lead_paragraph: After the women’s 1,500 meters Saturday at the Adidas Grand Prix on Randalls Island in New York, Alexa Efraimson had to put her hands on her knees, with beads of sweat dripping down her forehead as she tried to catch her breath. She had finished the race in 4 minutes 7.05 seconds, the second-fastest time in the event by a high school runner in the United States.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 14, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Worry Under the Big Top as Mexico City Moves to Ban Circus Animals
abstract: After Mexico City’s legislative assembly approved a ban on circus animals, the country’s tight-knit community of family-owned circuses is on the defensive.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — It is a weekday evening under the circus tent, and Bebeto Fuentes does it all effortlessly. He soars on the trapeze, vaults on and off a cantering horse, keeps an eye on the tigers, spins off the trampoline and takes a turn as a melancholy clown.

headline: Pinehurst Scary? Not After Heart Surgery
abstract: After undergoing two heart transplants, Erik Compton said “hitting a tee shot on 18” at the United States Open is not that big of a deal.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — While Erik Compton rested for his Saturday afternoon round at the United States Open, his mother, Eli, monitored the morning wave of players at Pinehurst No. 2. It was like watching a man-made disaster unfold. The first 33 golfers to tee off averaged 75.06 strokes, and four did not break 80.

headline: Young, Former Titans Quarterback, Retires
abstract: Quarterback Vince Young, who has not played in the N.F.L. since 2011, told NFL.com that he had retired.
lead_paragraph: Quarterback Vince Young, who has not played in the N.F.L. since 2011, told NFL.com that he had retired. Young, the No. 3 overall pick in 2006 by the Tennessee Titans, was released in 2011 after a falling-out with Jeff Fisher, then the Titans’ coach. Young participated in the Cleveland Browns’ minicamp before signing with the team May 1, but the team cut him four days after drafting Johnny Manziel.

headline: Massacre Claim Shakes Iraq

abstract: Insurgents from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria posted photos on the web to support the claim that they had executed 1,700 people. If true, it would be the region’s worst mass atrocity in recent years.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Wielding the threat of sectarian slaughter, Sunni Islamist militants claimed on Sunday that they had massacred hundreds of captive Shiite members of Iraq’s security forces, posting grisly pictures of a mass execution in Tikrit as evidence and warning of more killing to come.

headline: The World’s Best Father Gets a Close Shave
abstract: Daughter Alice Bee has some special pampering planned for the World’s Best Father.
lead_paragraph: Today is Father’s Day! Whether it’s cooking breakfast in bed or playing superheroes together, my daughter Alice Bee always has something fun planned for the two of us. And it’s sounding like today is going to be no exception: She just informed me that she has scheduled my first-ever straight razor shave down at the local barbershop.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on prisoner swaps, the Iraq turmoil, the I.R.S. scandal and Hong Kong freedom.
lead_paragraph: “Republicans continue to rail against President Obama’s trade of five Taliban detainees for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl on May 31,” writes The New York Times editorial board. “But prisoner releases in wartime are never simple or clean.” The board cites President George W. Bush’s release of a Moroccan Al Qaeda operative by the name of Abdullah Tabarak, chief bodyguard to Osama bin Laden, in 2004 as precedent for President Obama’s decision. The Times believes opposition to the swap derives not from concerns for national security but for partisanship: “Perhaps Republicans were not troubled by such releases — and the more than 500 others that occurred during the Bush administration — because they were not then blinded by hatred of the White House occupant.”

headline: The Corporates and the Crazies
abstract: Pining for Mitt Romney, too.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Peters and Shaila Dewan write about corporate shock over the sudden fall of Eric Cantor; it’s further confirmation of the story I told in my last column. Corporations and plutocrats had a good deal going: they bankrolled politicians who talked cultural populism during campaigns, but more or less ignored all that and focused on tax cuts and deregulation after the polls closed. And Cantor fit that profile perfectly.

headline: Where Dishonesty Is Best Policy, U.S. Soccer Falls Short
abstract: American players do not fake injuries or exaggerate contact nearly as much as others do, perhaps putting the squad at a strategic disadvantage.
lead_paragraph: NATAL, Brazil — The list of improvements that the United States men’s soccer team needs to make is considerable. Coach Jurgen Klinsmann would like to see a more consistent back line, better touch from his midfielders and plenty more production from the attackers.

headline: Bombings Kill Up to 21 People in Baghdad
abstract: Two attacks that rattled central Baghdad were the first major bombings there since Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Insurgents set off two bombs in separate incidents in central Baghdad on Sunday, killing as many as 21 people, witnesses said, and breaking a recent although brief lull in attacks in Iraq’s capital city.

headline: Disciplined Democrats

lead_paragraph: Matt Yglesias pushes back against claims, by Ross Douthat among others, that the Democratic Party is a fragile coalition held together only by Hillary Clinton’s personal popularity. He’s right; I’d just like to add a few thoughts.

headline: Double-Duty Dads
abstract: Many dads are far more involved at home than their fathers were. But a new study suggests workplaces may not have caught up, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: Anne-Marie Slaughter has noted that while everybody asks expectant moms how they’re going to balance work and family, few think to ask the same of dads. But now that may be changing — and dads’ answers reveal a lot about American culture at home and at the office.

headline: Netanyahu Says Three Were Taken by Hamas
abstract: The remarks Sunday by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel followed the arrests overnight of 80 people, most of them Hamas activists, and the closing of parts of the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Sunday that Israel knew “for a fact” that the kidnapping of three Israeli teenagers was the work of the militant Islamic movement Hamas but held the Palestinian Authority responsible, arguing that the abduction proved that the world was wrong to accept the Palestinian government formed this month with Hamas’s consent.

headline: Casey Kasem, Wholesome Voice of Pop Radio, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Kasem, the longtime host of “American Top 40,” was known for his homey sentiment and an optimism that ran headlong into the prevailing spirit of rebellion in 1970s music culture.
lead_paragraph: Casey Kasem, a disc jockey who never claimed to love rock ’n’ roll but who built a long and lucrative career from it, creating and hosting one of radio’s most popular syndicated pop music shows, “American Top 40,” died on Sunday in a hospital in Gig Harbor, Wash. He was 82.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Smithsonian) SHARK GIRL “My family and morals have made me the person I am today,” Madison Stewart, above, says, before adding what might give some viewers pause: “When I speak of family, I speak of sharks.” The 20-year-old Ms. Stewart, who was 2 when she began crisscrossing the Great Barrier Reef off the coast of Australia on a boat with her parents, goes where few others dare. Since the age of 12, she has been diving with sharks, without the protection of a cage but armed with the video camera she uses as a media weapon to fight the misconceptions circling these creatures. This documentary follows Ms. Stewart as she travels from Australia to Mexico, Palau and the Bahamas to commune with tiger sharks, Caribbean reef sharks and silky sharks — and in the process debunks myths and alleviates fears by demonstrating how these predators help keep the entire ocean ecosystem in balance.

headline: Host in a Big-Tent Era of Pop Music
abstract: Casey Kasem, the longtime host of the syndicated radio show “American Top 40,” homogenized pop, playing the same tunes coast to coast.
lead_paragraph: The music didn’t matter that much on “American Top 40,” the syndicated radio countdown show devised by Casey Kasem and a handful of Los Angeles radio colleagues. Individual songs might advance steadily toward No. 1, stall out along the way, suddenly leapfrog into the Top 10 or peak early and plummet. They would come and go: rock or pop, soul or country, hip-hop or synth-pop. The format would hold them all.

headline: Pakistan Military Wages Assault Against Militants
abstract: After fighter jets pounded militant targets in North Waziristan, the military announced that it had launched a “comprehensive operation” against militants in the region.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Ending years of hesitation, Pakistan’s military on Sunday said it was launching a major military operation against the Pakistani Taliban and allied foreign militants at their main base in the tribal belt along the Afghan border.

headline: Obama Discusses Climate Change
abstract: At a commencement ceremony at the University of California, Irvine, President Obama called for action on climate change.
lead_paragraph: At a commencement ceremony at the University of California, Irvine, President Obama called for action on climate change.

headline: Up at a Villa, Down in a Temple
abstract: The annual summer festivities at Caramoor, a genteel estate and pleasant getaway from the city, kick off on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The annual summer festivities at Caramoor, a genteel estate and pleasant getaway from the city, kick off on Saturday with an opening-night gala featuring Joshua Bell playing Sibelius’s soulful Violin Concerto with the Orchestra of St. Luke’s.

headline: Side by Side by Riverside
abstract: Two female choreographers — both integral to postmodern dance in New York — make the River to River Festival lineup even brighter.
lead_paragraph: The River to River Festival, presented by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, gets better every year, and this summer, two female choreographers — both integral to postmodern dance in New York — make the lineup even brighter. Eiko, the extraordinary Japanese dancer revered for her haunting collaborations with Koma, her usual male counterpart, shakes up her creative process in “Two Women,” a new duet featuring the young Japanese dancer Tomoe Aihara.

headline: Senior-Year Blues in 1950s Texas
abstract: Peter Bogdanovich’s film “The Last Picture Show” comes to the Museum of Modern Art this week.
lead_paragraph: It is 1951 at the start of Peter Bogdanovich’s “The Last Picture Show” (1971), and a bleak winter wind whips through the dusty small town of Anarene, Tex., as high school students (played by Cybill Shepherd, in her screen debut; Jeff Bridges; and Timothy Bottoms) prepare for graduation and the rigors of adulthood. From what they encounter — marital infidelity, class struggle, economic and cultural decline — the future doesn’t look promising.

headline: Peace, Love and Mayhem
abstract: Hardcore can be a closed circle, with dogmas attacking from every side, which is why it’s refreshing to see the nonlinear path Trash Talk has taken to its career.
lead_paragraph: Hardcore can be a closed circle, with dogmas attacking from every side, which is why it’s refreshing to see the nonlinear path Trash Talk has taken to its career.

headline: When Barristers Do Battle
abstract: “The Escape Artist,” a two-part “Masterpiece Mystery!” thriller, begins Sunday night on PBS.
lead_paragraph: “If you’re chained up in a safe at the bottom of a shark tank,” a colleague advises early in “The Escape Artist,” what you do is “call for Houdini.” The Houdini he means is Will Burton (David Tennant, expressive as ever), London’s top-ranked junior criminal defense barrister, according to a recent poll, and well up the ladder toward queen’s counsel because of his ability to win any case. But his invincible legal acrobatics backfire when a handshake denied sends his latest client, the reclusive bird lover, sadist and psychopath Liam Foyle (Toby Kebbell), into a rage — leaving Will, his wife (Ashley Jensen) and their son (Gus Barry) targets of his revenge. Enter Will’s professional nemesis, Maggie Gardner (Sophie Okonedo, fresh off a Tony victory for best supporting actress in a play for “A Raisin in the Sun”), frothing to overtake her rival. David Wolstencroft, the mastermind behind the BBC spy series “MI-5,” wrote this two-part “Masterpiece Mystery!” thriller, beginning Sunday night on PBS, which plumbs Will’s justification for his job in all its ramifications. “Everyone deserves a defense,” he maintains. Even he.

headline: Moving Together, if Not in Unison
abstract: A young choreographer, Preston Miller, is the force behind the film “Enemy Within,” a project that brings together dancers from different disciplines to tell a story.
lead_paragraph: One evening in 2007, Preston Miller found himself at a birthday party full of “crazy talented people.” A freshman in Fordham University’s B.F.A. program with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, he was surrounded by the likes of Wynton Marsalis, Desmond Richardson and a mentor, the Ailey dancer Matthew Rushing. At one point, Mr. Miller recalled, “Matthew leaned over to me and said, ‘Man, if we wanted to, we could go out tonight and turn New York out, if we all got together.’ ”

headline: James Franco to Direct Play
abstract: Mr. Franco will make his theatrical directorial debut as part of the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater’s coming 20th anniversary season.
lead_paragraph: James Franco, below, will soon add another occupation to his extensive cultural résumé when he makes his theatrical directorial debut for the premiere of “The Long Shrift” by the author Robert Boswell, presented as part of the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater’s coming 20th anniversary season. The play tells the story of a convict just released from jail who was accused of rape as a teenager. Performances at the Rattlestick are scheduled from July 7 to Aug. 23. Other world premieres in the 2014-15 season are “Pitbulls” by Keith Josef Adkins (“The Last Saint on Sugar Hill”), which is to run from Nov. 6 to Dec. 13, and “Shesh Yak” by Laith Nakli, scheduled for Jan. 15 to Feb. 19. The Rattlestick also announced that “Juárez: A Mythology Documentary” by Rubén Polendo, would be part of the second annual Theater: Village festival, in which a number of new works at West Village locations share a playwright or theme.

headline: Batting Leadoff, Granderson Helps Mets Beat Padres
abstract: With a home run, two walks and a single, Curtis Granderson helped the Mets bounce back from a two-hit shutout loss, even as Daisuke Matsuzaka had to leave after an inning.
lead_paragraph: During Saturday’s game, Mets Manager Terry Collins approached Curtis Granderson on the bench in the dugout and began asking him questions, like “Have you hit well out the leadoff spot before?” and “How have you felt up there?”

headline: Tony for Best Musical Is Nice, but a Profitable Hit Is Better
abstract: Since “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” won the Tony for best musical, its producers are changing their marketing strategy in the hope of turning an acclaimed show into a long-running hit.
lead_paragraph: All winter and spring, the Broadway producer Joey Parnes wore his game face to the advertising meetings at 11:30 a.m. Wednesdays for his $7.5 million musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder.” The show was losing money most weeks, and his big bet — that the June 8 Tony Awards could be a game changer — was a ways off and hardly a sure thing.

headline: Subs
abstract: In which we are befuddled and bemused by Bruce Haight.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — There’s a revealer here in Bruce Haight’s grid, but you might have to look for it. It’s at 11 Down, not a place where you might normally expect to find the punchline of the puzzle.

headline: Out of Desert Dust, a Miracle on a Shoestring
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Mobile Homes and Trailers']
abstract: A farmworkers’ trailer park east of Palm Springs celebrates a precious amenity, a community focal point and public space.
lead_paragraph: MECCA, Calif. — About an hour east of Palm Springs, past the Tesla and Maserati dealers and the poodle and labradoodle walkers, lies St. Anthony’s Trailer Park, in the eastern Coachella Valley. It is a vast psychic and economic distance from the annual spring hipster music festival. This Coachella is a place where farmworkers live in dilapidated mobile home parks improbably named after saints. These are communities where clean drinking water and reliable electricity are never givens, and where, during the rainy season, children wrap plastic bags around their sneakers to stay dry while parched desert turns to mud.

headline: Some New Games to Sink Your Claws Into
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'E3 Media and Business Summit', 'PlayStation 4 (Video Game System)', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)', 'Wii (Video Game System)']
abstract: At the E3 gaming convention, it’s more exciting to try a new game yourself than watch someone else play.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One of the hardest things to do at the Electronic Entertainment Expo, the annual video game trade show here, is actually to play video games. Even if you possess a media badge that lets you skip the long lines at the Los Angeles Convention Center, you’re often allowed only to watch a developer play a forthcoming game — or worse, watch a video pitch that highlights the concepts that the makers will try to execute over the next year or two. At times, it can feel like a book expo where you read only proposals or a film festival for screenplay treatments.

headline: The Other Veterans Scandal
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The way we fund their benefits makes it too easy to go to war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE Department of Veterans Affairs is mired in scandal. More than 57,000 veterans have been waiting at least three months for a doctor’s appointment. Another 64,000 never even made it onto a waiting list. There are allegations that waits for care either caused or contributed to veterans’ deaths.

headline: Among a Troupe’s New Works, a Battle ...
abstract: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performed the premiere of Robert Moses’s “The Pleasure of the Lesson.”
lead_paragraph: In the three years since Robert Battle became artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, he has shown remarkable poise in balancing between boldness and cool calculation as he revamps a repertory long in need of renovation.

headline: ... And an Ostrich That Spreads Its Wings
abstract: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s newest addition to its repertory reprises an important chapter in modern dance history.
lead_paragraph: One of the newest additions to Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s repertory is, in another sense, the oldest. Asadata Dafora choreographed “Awassa Astrige/Ostrich” in 1932, soon after moving to New York from his native Sierra Leone. On Friday at the David H. Koch Theater, Ailey became one of a handful of troupes to present this three-and-a-half-minute gem, with Antonio Douthit-Boyd as its majestic interpreter: part prowling warrior, part resplendent bird.

headline: Museum Power Squabble Borders on the Surreal
abstract: A court-ordered mediation meeting on Monday could determine the future of the Museum of Contemporary Art in North Miami.
lead_paragraph: NORTH MIAMI, Fla. — In a somewhat bizarre arrangement, scholars gathered at the Museum of Contemporary Art here this weekend for a symposium led by a man whom city officials view as the museum’s director and who museum officials regard as an impostor. It was scheduled despite objections from the museum’s board, which ultimately gave up its effort to cancel the event inside the museum’s city-owned building.

headline: Racing by Snowmobile for Economic Survival in Michigan
abstract: The documentary “Northern Light” is a sneakily compelling, endlessly patient observation of three working-class families in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.
lead_paragraph: Cool in tone and temperature, Nick Bentgen’s “Northern Light” turns white vistas and blue language into a sneakily compelling, endlessly patient observation of three working-class families in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.

headline: France Leaves Scoring Struggles Behind in Its Opener
abstract: Scoring twice and creating a third goal that was confirmed by goal-line technology, Karim Benzema provided a dominant win that was a relief for France.

headline: For Katie Couric, Shift to Web From TV Is Complete
keywords: ['Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The former host of NBC’s “Today” show, who recently taped the last episode of her syndicated talk show, looks to continue exploring substantive topics for Yahoo.
lead_paragraph: After three decades of continuous work in television, Katie Couric has now officially moved on to what she is calling “my new chapter.”

headline: A Theme Park for Thomas Trains
abstract: A theme park based on the adventures of the popular children’s character is to begin construction at Edaville USA Railroad in Carver, Mass., The Associated Press reported.
lead_paragraph: A theme park based on the adventures of the popular children’s character Thomas the Tank Engine is to begin construction at Edaville USA Railroad in Carver, Mass., The Associated Press reported. The park, called Thomas Land, will have 14 rides inspired by characters in the British television show “Thomas & Friends,” which is broadcast on PBS in the United States. A 20-minute train ride on a life-size Thomas the Tank Engine is to be the park’s centerpiece when it opens in the summer of 2015.

headline: How We Play the Game
abstract: Every team plays in distinct ways. To understand their style, one must learn a bit about each country’s history.

headline: A Long Day’s Bach Journey, by Train, Foot and Ferry, With Cello
abstract: The Five Boroughs Music Festival and Early Music Festival: NYC combined to produce “A Suite Ride Through NYC.”
lead_paragraph: When two festivals combine to produce an event, you might expect it to be a big deal. And “A Suite Ride Through NYC,” which was presented on Friday by the Five Boroughs Music Festival but was also the opening program in the new Early Music Festival: NYC, was indeed big in many ways.

headline: London Welcomes the Tech Set and Its Money
abstract: The city is hosting a number of events this week as continues efforts to diversify the local economy and embrace the technology industry.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – From hipster hangouts in East London to corporate headquarters in West London, the British capital will roll out the red carpet this week for many of the world’s leading tech entrepreneurs and investors.

abstract: New research suggests that tax evasion deepens inequality.
lead_paragraph: GABRIEL ZUCMAN is a 27-year-old French economist who decided to solve a puzzle: Why do international balance sheets each year show more liabilities than assets, as if the world is in debt to itself?

headline: High-Scoring A’s Punish Yankees in a Matchup of Fill-In Starters
abstract: Oakland bruised Vidal Nuno for eight runs in three innings in a 10-5 rout, to improve to 42-27. The Yankees, who are only two games over .500, scored once in six innings against Jesse Chavez.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Yankees and the Oakland Athletics have both lost multiple starting pitchers to injury this season. In a matchup of replacements at the Coliseum on Sunday, the A’s gave another reason they have the best record in the American League.

headline: Kaymer, Leading All the Way, Wins by 8 for His First U.S. Open Title
abstract: Martin Kaymer, who opened the tournament with a course-record 65, closed with a 69 at Pinehurst No. 2 for a 72-hole total of nine-under-par 271. He finished eight strokes ahead of Erik Compton and Rickie Fowler.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — Martin Kaymer arrived at the first tee Sunday dressed appropriately for a methodical man with a modest, logical plan for the day.

headline: Device Maker Medtronic Agrees to Merger and Will Move to Ireland
abstract: In combining with Covidien, Medtronic would relocate its headquarters to Ireland from Minneapolis, but argued that its tax rate would remain roughly the same.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:13 p.m. | Medtronic agreed on Sunday to buy Covidien for $42.9 billion, combining two of the world’s biggest medical device makers and helping Medtronic lower some taxes by gaining access to cash held overseas.

headline: Starbucks to Provide Free College Education to Thousands of Workers
abstract: Through an unusual arrangement with Arizona State University, the company will pay for its workers to earn college degrees.
lead_paragraph: Starbucks will provide a free online college education to thousands of its workers, without requiring that they remain with the company, through an unusual arrangement with Arizona State University, the company and the university will announce on Monday.

headline: Out of Power Almost 7 Years, Blair Is Still Haunted by a Legacy of War
abstract: Tony Blair, the former British prime minister, remains defined by many for his steadfast support of President George W. Bush and the invasion of Iraq.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Twiggy Garcia, a part-time bartender, had talked with friends about making a citizen’s arrest if he ever got near Tony Blair, the former prime minister who led Britain into war in Iraq. But he never seriously imagined it happening.

headline: It’s Privacy vs. the People in the Battle for Martin’s Beach
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Land Use Policies', 'Eminent Domain', 'Beaches', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The future of a hidden beach on the San Francisco Peninsula is being fought in a case that has become the latest class-charged standoff involving a wealthy entrepreneur in Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: HALF MOON BAY, Calif. — The Pacific Ocean glistens in the distance, past the rolling bluffs that rise beyond the electric gate that blocks off Martin’s Beach Road. The road leads to Martin’s Beach, once a revered hideaway for surfers, fishers and beachgoers drawn by its isolation, dramatic cliffs and sweep of soft sand.

headline: Modern Cosmology Versus God’s Creation
abstract: Does our completely random location in the universe mean that it wasn’t intentionally made for us?
lead_paragraph: This is the seventh in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Tim Maudlin, a professor of philosophy at New York University and the author of “Philosophy of Physics: Space and Time.”

headline: Eric Cantor’s Defeat Exposed a Beltway Journalism Blind Spot
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Newspapers', 'News and News Media', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: The provincialism of Washington, D.C., is now multiplied by the diminution of nonnational newspapers.
lead_paragraph: It’s now clear why the primary defeat of the House majority leader, Eric Cantor, came so completely out of the blue last week: Beltway blindness that put a focus on fund-raising, power-brokering and partisan back-and-forth created a reality distortion field that obscured the will of the people.

headline: A Curious List of People Who Donated to the Central Park Zoo
abstract: Almost from the time Central Park opened in the late 1850s, prominent citizens pushed for the inclusion of an animal menagerie like those in London and Paris. Unsolicited donations quickly followed, from powerful men like the secretary of state for Abraham Lincoln and a 10-year-old boy with no ties to power or fame. Each animal and donor was listed in the park’s annual reports, including the report from 1866:

abstract: A weekend of activity serves as an indication that a crackdown continues under the new president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi.

headline: Giving Life to Central Park Zoo, One Donation at a Time
abstract: With the zoo population about to change yet again, a look back at how Central Park became the repository for animals cast off or donated by New York citizens and visitors.

keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is contacting hundreds of thousands of people with subsidized health insurance to resolve questions about their eligibility, as consumer advocates express concern that many will be required to repay some or all of the subsidies.

headline: Breaking Up Is Hard to Do for the Rangers

headline: With an Amazon Smartphone, the Retailer Seeks a Tether to Consumers
abstract: Amazon is set to give the brutal phone business a shot. On the one hand, analysts say, it has no choice; on the other, the rewards could be tremendous.
lead_paragraph: Hold the phone: Amazon wants to burrow even deeper into your life.

headline: Events in Iraq Open Door for Interventionist Revival, Historian Says
abstract: Robert Kagan has called for the president to resist a popular pull toward making the United States a nation without larger responsibilities.
lead_paragraph: McLEAN, Va. — In a much-discussed essay, the historian Robert Kagan recently depicted President Obama as presiding over an inward turn by the United States that threatened the global order and broke with more than 70 years of American presidents and precedence. He called for Mr. Obama to resist a popular pull toward making the United States a nation without larger responsibilities, and to reassume the more muscular approach to the world out of vogue in Washington since the war in Iraq drained the country of its appetite for intervention.

headline: William M. Roth, Shipping Heir Who Became Lifelong Public Servant, Dies at 97
abstract: Mr. Roth was the scion of the Matson Navigation Company but served as the chief negotiator for the U.S. in a historic trade pact; ran for governor of California; and restored Ghirardelli Square in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: As the scion of a shipping empire, William Matson Roth grew up in a 43-room home with 16 acres of formal gardens. When his twin sisters made their debut at a ball there in 1939, The San Francisco Chronicle said they were “launched like luxury liners.”

headline: Yes He Could
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Global Warming', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: This is the Barack Obama we’ve been waiting for.
lead_paragraph: Several times in recent weeks I’ve found myself in conversations with liberals who shake their heads sadly and express their disappointment with President Obama. Why? I suspect that they’re being influenced, often without realizing it, by the prevailing media narrative.

headline: Evacuating Children Along a Dangerous Ukraine Route
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']
abstract: Volunteer-run minivans are evacuating children from the besieged eastern city of Slovyansk, taking them beyond the reach of artillery fire and twitchy gunmen.
lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — It was a trip no mother would wish to take. But faced with few options, a group of women and children piled into a blue minivan on a recent day to take to the dangerous road out of town on the way to a safer place.

headline: Dangerous Divisiveness
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: At a peak moment of partisanship, we should stop to do a self-audit of our allegiances and assumptions.

headline: Worries Over Access to Free Public TV
abstract: A planned spectrum auction has caused concern that universities and states that hold public station licenses but are not primarily broadcasters may give up spectrum and use the proceeds for other needs.
lead_paragraph: Public television officials are raising the concern that the Federal Communications Commission’s planned spectrum incentive auction, intended to free airwaves for use by wireless broadband companies, could leave parts of the country without over-the-air public television access.

headline: Bank Tool Is Expanding Unbanked Households, Regulators Say
abstract: New York’s attorney general is taking aim at databases that have been criticized for limiting access to banking services.
lead_paragraph: In her early college years, when Charlette Williams started routinely mismanaging her finances and pushing her checking account balance into the red, she never thought the mistakes would haunt her five years later, she said. Now, she is paying a steep price.

headline: Corporate Confidence Likely to Bring Pricier Deals
abstract: Merger transactions are expected to become more expensive this year and next, according to a new American Appraisal study.
