keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Editorials']
abstract: A deeply flawed appeals court ruling could severely limit enforcement against foreign cartels.
lead_paragraph: American antitrust laws have protected consumers against monopolies and cartels for more than a century. But a recent appeals court decision could severely limit the enforcement of those laws against foreign cartels that supply critical components used in cellphones, computers and other products Americans buy.

headline: Ultra Violet, Warhol Superstar, Dies at 78
abstract: Isabelle Collin Dufresne, the French-born artist, actress and author known as Ultra Violet, was the beauty among the superstars of Andy Warhol’s glory days at his studio, the Factory.
lead_paragraph: Isabelle Collin Dufresne, the French-born artist, actress and author known as Ultra Violet, the beauty among the superstars of Andy Warhol’s glory days at his studio, the Factory, died on Saturday at a Manhattan hospital. She was 78 and lived in Manhattan and in Nice, France.

headline: Despite a Shadow, Messi Shimmers in Argentina’s Cup Opener
abstract: Eager to match the legacy of Diego Maradona, Lionel Messi led Argentina to a 2-1 victory over Bosnia and Herzegovina on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Lionel Messi can never be the man Argentina wants him to be, since that man is Diego Maradona, and in their eyes not even Messi — no matter what genius he conjures — will ever measure up to Maradona.

headline: How to Stabilize Iraq and Stop the March of ISIS
abstract: What can be done to stabilize Iraq and stop the gains from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria?

headline: Fighting Terrorism With More Money
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Investing $5 billion in the fight against extremists sounds sensible, but the new program seems too heavily dependent on military responses.
lead_paragraph: If all goes according to President Obama’s plan, the United States will soon be making a major new investment of $5 billion so that other countries can help in the fight against extremists. Regardless of how sensible such a proposal might sound, many things can go wrong, and the new program already seems too heavily dependent on military responses.

headline: Agency Aims to Regulate Map Aids in Vehicles
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Maps', 'Mobile Applications', 'Navigation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Smartphones', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Global Positioning System']
abstract: In an effort to curb distracted driving, a measure in a proposed bill would specify that Transportation Department could regulate smartphone map apps and systems built into cars.
lead_paragraph: Getting directions on the road from Google Maps and other smartphone apps is a popular alternative to the expensive navigation aids included in some cars. The apps are also a gray area when it comes to laws banning the use of cellphones or texting while driving.

headline: Why Hispanics Don’t Have a Larger Political Voice
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Voting and Voters', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Although they make up about 17 percent of the country’s population, they will most likely constitute 3 percent of voters in the 2014 Senate battlegrounds.
lead_paragraph: Hispanic-Americans are growing in number, coveted by the nation’s political parties and deeply in favor of an overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws. Given this combination, why does such an overhaul still seem to be such a long shot in Washington?

headline: In History-Making Event, Men and Women Share the Stage
keywords: ['Golf', 'United States Open (Golf)', "United States Women's Open (Golf)", 'PGA Championship']
abstract: The United States Women’s Open begins Thursday at Pinehurst as, for the first time, the women are sharing a major course with the men.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — On the Pinehurst No. 2 driving range Sunday, a teenage girl shyly approached Sergio García, who greeted her with a warm embrace. She walked away as if there were clouds beneath her feet.

headline: An Explosion in Washington
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: What a deadly blast at a federal arsenal revealed about women laborers during the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: The timing could not have been more eerily ironic. On June 17, 1864, an official read a letter thanking the girls and women who worked at Washington’s federal arsenal for a donation to a monument for the 78 victims of a deadly 1862 arsenal blast in Pittsburgh. Then, just hours later, an explosion – like “a sudden flash of lightning,” in the words of one survivor – went off inside the arsenal’s 100-foot-long wooden laboratory.

headline: Never Boring, Always Beautiful
abstract: In soccer as in life, we Italians tend to do best when our backs are against the wall.
lead_paragraph: Some people party too soon. I was in Brazil in spring 2006, and Brazil was in a festive mood. The World Cup in Germany was on the way, and Brazilians, rightly convinced they had the best team, were already celebrating their triumph. At one public event, I said: “Just calm down, please. Italy is going to win this one.” The audience chortled, saying: “Come on. Italian soccer is in the midst of its biggest scandal ever. Two championship titles have been revoked. The players are in shock, and the clubs are in disgrace!” That’s why, I said.

headline: Where Prose Turned to Poetry
abstract: Brazilian soccer style transformed the “British and Apollonian” game into “Dionysian dance.”
lead_paragraph: In Brazil, soccer was initially played among elite clubs behind closed doors. Blacks were excluded. Outside the confines of formal championships, however, the sport was quickly taken up as a game played in abandoned lots, meadows and urban gaps. Balls were improvised, fields were improvised, and the game was fertile ground for the spirit of improvisation.

headline: Life Sentences for 2 Sex Traffickers Who Preyed on Mexican Immigrants
abstract: Isaias and Bonifacio Flores-Mendez were each sentenced to life in prison last month for smuggling hundreds of Mexican women across the border and forcing them into prostitution in and around New York City.
lead_paragraph: It was a sprawling family business, employing drivers, dispatchers and doormen. There were “steerers” who passed out “chica” cards on the street to solicit customers. There was even a mechanic who swept vehicles for tracking devices that might have been surreptitiously placed by federal agents, prosecutors said.

headline: How We Play the Game
abstract: Every team is simply trying to score goals while preventing its opponent from doing the same. But they all seem to go about it in distinct ways.
lead_paragraph: Every team is simply trying to score goals while preventing its opponent from doing the same. But they all seem to go about it in distinct ways. To understand what is happening on the fields in Brazil at the World Cup, one must learn a bit about each country’s history, and literature, and music, and regionalism, and economy — not to mention bicycles and pottery.

headline: A Boy’s Execution, 70 Years Later
abstract: South Carolina once sent a 14-year-old to the electric chair after a hasty prosecution that was riddled with misconduct. Now there is a push for exoneration.
lead_paragraph: On the first page of the official sentencing report for George Stinney Jr., the outline of a boy is visible in a short string of numbers. Age: 14. Height: 5-1. Weight: 95. His complexion is listed as Black, his religion as Baptist, his occupation as None. Next to Build one word is typed: Small.

headline: A Smartphone Keyboard App That Anticipates What You Want to Type
abstract: SwiftKey’s app for Android, which the London start-up made available free last week, is used on almost 250 million handsets. Now the company hopes to develop a relationship with Apple.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Typing on the glass of a smartphone can be a headache. The keyboards are tiny. Errors are easy to make, even on the simplest of words. And autocorrect, the function meant to fix typing mistakes, often introduces errors, switching words that have little to do with what people actually mean.

headline: V.A. Punished Critics on Staff, Doctors Assert
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Whistle-Blowers', 'Doctors', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans', 'Hospitals', 'Falsification of Data']
abstract: In response to employee whistle-blowers, the Department of Veterans Affairs has made clear over the years that it would not hesitate to retaliate, disciplining and even firing those who spoke up.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Staff members at dozens of Department of Veterans Affairs hospitals across the country have objected for years to falsified patient appointment schedules and other improper practices, only to be rebuffed, disciplined or even fired after speaking up, according to interviews with current and former staff members and internal documents.

headline: Artificial Pancreas Shows Promise in Diabetes Test
abstract: A system built with a modified iPhone successfully regulated blood sugar levels in a trial with people who have Type 1 diabetes, researchers reported Sunday.

headline: A Nemesis in the Black Stars
abstract: The United States will face off on Monday against Ghana, in a matchup that over the last decade has turned into an unexpected rivalry. Victory for the Americans would be a long time coming.
lead_paragraph: NATAL, Brazil — For more than two days straight here in this beach town in northeastern Brazil, the rain came down with the strength of an open fire hose. It shook the cashew trees and bent the palm trees so that their fronds nearly kissed the ground. It turned roads into rivers, caused mudslides and turned some neighborhood soccer fields into ponds.

headline: New York Adoptees Fight for Access to Birth Certificates
abstract: The recent passage of laws in New Jersey and Connecticut that give adopted children more rights to their files is fueling hope that New York will follow suit.
lead_paragraph: Maureen Sheridan’s search for her biological mother began in the late 1990s, after she had a precancerous mole removed and her doctor suggested she look into her medical history. That research led her to the New York Public Library, where in 2001, sifting through a vast trove of vital records, Ms. Sheridan discovered the name she had been given at birth: Beth Lyons.

abstract: Pitchers Nick Burdi and Kyle Funkhouser are two of the principal reasons the Cardinals are given a chance to win the College World Series, despite being in the loser’s bracket.

headline: Methodist Church Pension Board Links Divestment to Firm’s Role in Israeli Prisons
abstract: Members have been debating divestment to pressure Israel to stop building settlements and to take steps toward a peaceful resolution with the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: A decision by the pension board of the United Methodist Church to sell its stock in a company that provides security equipment to Israel has set off a backlash from supporters of Israel, who are gearing up for another fight over divestment this week at the convention of another mainline Protestant denomination, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.).

headline: The United Nations of the Hardwood
abstract: With eight players on the current roster born outside the United States, the Spurs have made a complicated game look easy by speaking a common language: top-flight basketball.

headline: Her Heart Didn’t Belong to Daddy (or the Prince)
abstract: Despite the teeth-baring title, the tone is mostly cool and considered in “Pat Kirkwood Is Angry,” a spellbinding cabaret show written by and starring the gifted singer Jessica Walker.
lead_paragraph: Despite the teeth-baring title, the tone is mostly cool and considered in “Pat Kirkwood Is Angry,” a spellbinding cabaret show at the 59E59 Theaters written by and starring the gifted singer Jessica Walker. The titular actress, portrayed by Ms. Walker, was a British star probably unknown to most Americans. Her up-and-down career included glittery stints in the West End, steep plunges into the panto circuit when things got tough, a brief stay in Hollywood that sent her to a sanitarium and, most spectacularly, a festive night with a royal that made her a figure of scandal for decades.

headline: New York City Street Treasure

headline: With Offensive Bonanza, Spurs Force the Heat to Consider Taking Fewer Gambles
abstract: On the verge of elimination, Miami entered Game 5 on Sunday night with a decision to make on defense: Play with greater activity or back off.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: “Frozen,” released last November, is the second-highest-grossing 2013 film after adjusting for inflation, surpassed only by “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire” — and it is still in theaters. “Despicable Me 2,” even without a hit song, was No. 4, and “Monsters University” ranked sixth.
lead_paragraph: “Frozen,” released last November, is the second-highest-grossing 2013 film after adjusting for inflation, surpassed only by “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire” — and it is still in theaters. “Despicable Me 2,” even without a hit song, was No. 4, and “Monsters University” ranked sixth.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Finale: Sibel Kekilli Takes Home an Odd Souvenir
abstract: Sibel Kekilli is still coming to terms with leaving the series, but she has a keepsake to remember it by: the weapon that killed her character.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this post contains spoilers about Sunday’s season finale of “Game of Thrones.”

headline: Success Academy’s Expansion Plans Put de Blasio in a Tough Spot
abstract: The Success Academy Charters Schools group’s aim to double in size by 2016 forces Mayor Bill de Blasio to choose between two troublesome options.
lead_paragraph: A charter school network’s plan   to double in size over the next few years could reignite a war over classroom space in New York City, only this time with the ground rules already tilted against the mayor.

headline: Dispute Over Judges Leaves Family Courts in Limbo
keywords: ['Family Courts', 'State Legislatures', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: In New York, the state budget has provided funding to add 20 family court judges, but regional squabbling is holding up the assignments.
lead_paragraph: In a drab waiting area on the fifth floor of Manhattan Family Court, a 6-year-old boy danced among the wooden benches and two strangers wrangled over custody schedules as Natasha, 39, stared plaintively at a closed courtroom door.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 15, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Spurs Win Fifth Title, Cementing Dynasty Across Decades
abstract: San Antonio erased an early 16-point deficit to capture its fifth championship in 16 seasons and avenge a finals loss against Miami last year.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — The arena rumbled. It was only the first half on Sunday night, but there was already a growing sense of inevitability with each passing possession. Having withstood the best that LeBron James could offer, the Spurs were closing in on another championship.

headline: ‘Halt and Catch Fire’ Recap: Please, Hurry Up and Kill the Bird
abstract: Joe does a surprising thing, all to kill a business deal.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 3: This show has lost the plot. In the span of a single episode, “Halt And Catch Fire” has descended from a fairly enjoyable melodrama about the dawn of the personal computing industry into a writhing mess. This third episode was a tossed-salad of seeming arbitrary stabs at character development; everyone does something a little weird, shocking, or apparently deep, but little of it adds to a sense of who these people are or what on earth they’re trying to do.

headline: ‘Penny Dreadful’ Recap: It’s a Bloody Father’s Day
abstract: A death and a visitation move the plot toward its conclusion.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 6: Happy bloody Father’s Day here on “Penny Dreadful.” The episode picks up with Vanessa and Sir Malcolm surveying the carnage left by their demonic visitor in Episode 4. But it’s impossible not to view what happens in “What Death Can Join Together” – and what led up to it – through the prism of the full-length flashback that made up the previous episode. (As with previous weeks, spoilers are sprinkled throughout.)

headline: Unexpected, Unplanned and Unwanted
abstract: When her second son was born, six weeks premature, Emily Guillermo recalled thinking, “You’re not supposed to be mine. You were not supposed to be made.”
lead_paragraph: When her second son was born, six weeks premature, Emily Guillermo recalled thinking, “You’re not supposed to be mine. You were not supposed to be made.”

headline: ‘Thinking of Ways to Harm Her’
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Women and Girls', 'Parenting', 'Series', 'Anxiety and Stress']
abstract: Studies are revealing a more complex view of maternal mental illness, including that what is known as postpartum depression often begins during pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: Postpartum depression isn’t always postpartum. It isn’t even always depression. A fast-growing body of research is changing the very definition of maternal mental illness, showing that it is more common and varied than previously thought.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 16, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 16, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t know if you call it a problem or a weakness, but it’s clear that the American nature is to try and make everything fair, to try and be fair to the game.”

headline: In Fez, a Restaurant Starring the Finest Chefs in the World
abstract: Designed by the creative director of the Jardin Majorelle, Restaurant Numero 7 recently reopened with a chef-in-residence program that is bringing in noteworthy talent like Jerome Waag of Chez Panisse.
lead_paragraph: Deep in the hive-like medina (old city) of Fez, Morocco, one of the world’s most beautiful restaurants has just reopened as a venue for an intriguing new visiting-chef-in-residence project that casts the kitchen as an incubator for both cultural exchange and culinary innovation.

headline: Steering Clear of Poison Ivy
abstract: Simple precautions can prevent a nasty reaction from contact with poison ivy and related plants, which can harm even those who have had previous uneventful exposures.
lead_paragraph: I was once among those who claim, “I could walk through a field of poison ivy and not get it.” One day I learned otherwise: On a hike, I needed to relieve myself in the great outdoors and ended up with an impossibly itchy, blistering rash on a most delicate body part.

headline: Word of the Day | irretrievable
abstract: This word has appeared in 12 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: irretrievable •\ˌir-i-ˈtre-və-bəl\• adjective

headline: What’s On Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (FXX) THE GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO (2011) Daniel Craig stars as a crusading Swedish journalist hired by a wealthy industrialist (Christopher Plummer) to investigate the disappearance of his niece 40 years earlier. Rooney Mara, above, in an Oscar-nominated performance, is Lisbeth Salander, the vulnerable yet ruthlessly competent computer hacker who helps him solve the mystery in this adaptation of the Stieg Larsson novel, directed by David Fincher. “She is a marvelous pop-culture character, stranger and more complex than the average superhero and more intriguing than the usual boy wizards and vampire brides,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about Lisbeth, first played by Noomi Rapace in the 2010 Swedish adaptation. “It has been her fate, unfortunately, to make her furious, uninspiring way through a series of plodding and ungainly stories.” And “despite the slick intensity of Mr. Fincher’s style, his movie is not immune to the same lumbering proceduralism,” Mr. Scott said. Still, he added, “Mr. Fincher’s impressive skill is evident.”

headline: First True Test, and a Noticeable Gaffe, for Goal-Line Technology
abstract: The technology, new to the World Cup, confirmed a goal by France in the 48th minute, but not before the system first showed a replay of the ball just after it struck the post and indicating “no goal.”
lead_paragraph: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil — Goal-line technology was put to its first serious use at the World Cup on Sunday in the 48th minute of France’s match with Honduras.

headline: Outrage After Pencil-Chewing Is Blamed for Lead Poisoning
abstract: Parents of children who showed high levels of lead in their blood believe that a local chemical plant is to blame, but a government official caused an uproar by suggesting that chewing pencils was the cause.
lead_paragraph: The dangerous levels of pollution in a village in Hunan Province have been well known for some time, but after a Chinese state television investigation and a particularly callous remark by one local official, the authorities have begun taking action.

headline: James, Even at His Best, Can’t Carry the Heat to the Finish
abstract: LeBron James had a game-high 31 points to go with 10 rebounds, 5 assists and 2 blocks, and he helped limit Tony Parker. But without help, he could not stop the Spurs.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Miami’s LeBron James sat on a trainer’s table an hour before tipoff, his eyes closed, his headphones on as he sang to himself, his back rested squarely against a wall.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on June 16, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Three Sentenced to Death Over Tiananmen Attack
abstract: A Chinese court sentenced three men to death on Monday for their roles in carrying out an attack near the entrance to Beijing’s Forbidden City in October that left six people dead and 39 injured.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese court sentenced three men to death on Monday for their roles in carrying out an attack near the entrance to Beijing’s Forbidden City in October that left six people dead and 39 injured, in what the police said was a terrorist act carried out by Islamic jihadists belonging to the Uighur ethnic minority.

headline: China Surpasses U.S. as Largest Corporate Debt Issuer
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A study by Standard & Poor’s found that China’s nonfinancial companies had total outstanding bank loans and bonds worth $14.2 trillion at the end of last year, compared with $13.1 trillion in the United States.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China has overtaken the United States as the world’s biggest issuer of corporate debt, despite worsening cash flow at Chinese companies since the financial crisis, according to a report released Monday by Standard & Poor’s.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Wind and dust, not flame and steel’
abstract: This poem, by Ibante S., is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest.
lead_paragraph: This poem, by Ibante S., is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest.

headline: Father’s Day Plea to Educate China’s ‘Illegal’ Children
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Children and Childhood', 'Education (K-12)', "Father's Day", 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Parenting', 'Rural Areas', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: The suicide of a father of four in Guizhou Province in March aroused national debate on the practice, common in some areas, of “the kidnapping of education by family planning.”
lead_paragraph: Father’s Day is an imported concept that not all Chinese are comfortable with, but the news media celebrated on Sunday with photographs of new fathers and, in a display of filial piety, children thanking dads by scrubbing their feet.

headline: Mota-Engil Africa Plans I.P.O. Amid Flurry of London Offerings
keywords: ['Building (Construction)', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The engineering and construction company, which is based in Johannesburg, intends to float at least 25 percent of its share capital in the offer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mota-Engil Africa, a subsidiary of the Portuguese conglomerate Mota-Engil, said on Monday that it planned to list an initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange, the latest in what has been a rush of offerings in London.

headline: Coast Town Is Attacked in Kenya; Dozens Die
abstract: The authorities said the attack on a police station and two hotels in the coastal town of Mpeketoni was carried out by the Somali militant group Shabab.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — At least 48 people were killed when dozens of militants attacked a Kenyan coastal town overnight, targeting a police station and two hotels, officials said Monday.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Unrest in Iraq
abstract: How has the escalating violence in Iraq provoked reactions from world leaders like President Obama?
lead_paragraph: In “Obama Pushes Iraqis to Mend Sectarian Rifts,” Mark Landler and Michael R. Gordon write about the U.S. reaction to recent events in Iraq and the unrest there.

headline: Student Crossword | Ancient Egypt
abstract: Test your knowledge of ancient Egypt by playing our crossword, then exploring related Times and Learning Network resources.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of ancient Egypt by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Echoes of Africa Along the Carolina Coast
abstract: Pete Marovich has been documenting the Gullah communities he first encountered as a teenager in South Carolina, which maintain traditions despite the challenges of encroaching development.
lead_paragraph: Africa endures in the language and customs of the Gullah people, descendants of slaves who have lived along the Carolina coast for generations, sustaining themselves through the land and water.  Pete Marovich, who grew up in South Carolina aware of this distinctive culture, wanted to photograph these communities, so about a decade ago he pitched the idea to a magazine editor.

headline: Atos of France to Spin Off Its Payments Unit in I.P.O.
keywords: ['Cloud Computing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Initial Public Offerings']
abstract: Worldline, an Atos subsidiary that provides electronic payment products, said it would price its shares at 16.40 euros to 20 euros, valuing the unit at up to €2.4 billion, or $3.2 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The French computer services provider Atos announced on Monday that it was spinning off its electronic payments unit in an initial public offering that could value the business at up to 2.4 billion euros, or $3.2 billion.

headline: Gazprom Cuts Russia’s Natural Gas Supply to Ukraine
abstract: The energy company said it would no longer provide gas on credit, prompting worry that supplies to the European Union could be disrupted.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Further aggravating already tense relations between Russia and Ukraine, the Russian energy giant Gazprom cut off natural gas supplies to its neighbor on Monday, warning that the reduction could diminish the amount of gas flowing to Europe.

headline: Britain’s Mitchells & Butlers to Acquire 173 Pubs
abstract: The $451.5 million deal for the bulk of Orchid Group is expected to expand the market share of Britain’s largest operator of managed pubs and restaurants.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Mitchells & Butlers, Britain’s largest operator of managed pubs and restaurants, said on Monday that it would acquire the bulk of Orchid Group, including 173 pubs, for about $451 million.

headline: Israel Demands Palestinian Leader’s Help After Abductions
abstract: The request came in a telephone conversation begun by President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority after Israeli troops killed a Palestinian man overnight.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Monday that he expected his help in finding three kidnapped Israeli teenagers and capturing their abductors. The telephone conversation, initiated by Mr. Abbas, came after Israeli troops killed a Palestinian man overnight as they continued an aggressive campaign across the West Bank, arresting a total of 150 people, most of them leaders of the militant Islamic movement Hamas.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: New York Today: Test Time
abstract: What you need to know in New York for Monday: the Regents return, sunshine continues, and a crackdown on the roads.
lead_paragraph: Good sunny Monday morning to you.

headline: Buddhist-Muslim Unrest Boils Over in Sri Lanka
abstract: Three people were killed and scores injured in riots in a southwestern coastal town.
lead_paragraph: ALUTHGAMA, Sri Lanka — In some of the worst religious violence in Sri Lanka in decades, three people have been killed and 78 injured in riots between Buddhists and Muslims in this southwestern coastal town after months of rising tensions, officials said Monday.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Recap: Season 4 Finale
abstract: With a sweeping, violent episode titled “The Children,” the epic HBO series wrapped up its fourth season.
lead_paragraph: Here be spoilers, and the end of our watch … for now.

headline: Daily Report: Amazon Seeks Tighter Hold on Shoppers Through a Phone
abstract: Amazon is set to give the brutal phone business a shot. On the one hand, analysts say, it has no choice; on the other, the rewards could be tremendous.
lead_paragraph: Amazon is expected to introduce a smartphone on Wednesday at an event in Seattle, a long-rumored project that aims to close any remaining gap between the impulse to buy and the completed act, David Streitfeld reports.

headline: In London, the Men’s Wear Revels Begin
abstract: For spring 2015, the London Collections: Men is showcasing everything from traditional English suiting to the most extravagantly luxurious fur-and-silk sportswear.
lead_paragraph: That green juice, the sip choice in New York, has reached London was only one of the takeaways of a late lunch on Saturday, held in honor of the London men’s wear designer Craig Green. A fruit-and-veg concoction was passed around at Hoi Polloi, the restaurant at the Ace Hotel in the designer-heavy Shoreditch, but it was only one green offering of many: The theme of the lunch (and its official hashtag) was “Eat Your Craig Greens,” and each course — soup, salad and supper — was a rhapsody in that color.

headline: Alibaba Clarifies Leadership Structure as I.P.O. Approaches
abstract: An amended prospectus by the Chinese e-commerce giant publicly disclosed the names of all 27 individuals in its controlling partnership for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:00 p.m. | The Alibaba Group, China’s biggest e-commerce company, is continuing to slowly reveal more about its operations.

headline: The Trouble With Apple’s Health App
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Electronic Health Records', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The new app faces two major challenges: health records systems’ inability to share information, and people’s unwillingness to do so.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Apple made news with the introduction of Health, an iPhone app that will allow users to collect biometric information like heart rate and blood pressure and send it automatically to doctors or hospitals. The company also announced a partnership with Epic Systems, one of the largest suppliers of electronic medical record systems in the United States. This has led many to speculate that a new age is upon us, with patients having much greater access to health information, as well as the ability to share it with their doctors.

headline: Definition of ‘Rich’ Changes With Income
abstract: What annual income would it take for you to consider yourself rich? Is it possible you are rich already?
lead_paragraph: “Congratulations, Joe! You’re rich!” John McCain said to Joe Wurzelbacher in the 2008 presidential campaign. Joe was thinking of buying a small plumbing business. He was dismayed to learn from Barack Obama that the candidate’s plan to raise marginal tax rates on individuals earning more than $200,000 a year was described as “taxing the rich.”

abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: UGL of Australia to Sell Property Management Arm for $1.15 Billion
abstract: Investors including the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan and the private equity firms TPG Capital and PAG Asia Capital have agreed to buy DTZ, a property management business.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Australian engineering services company UGL said on Monday that it had agreed to sell the property management business DTZ to a consortium of investors, including the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan and the private equity firms TPG Capital and PAG Asia Capital, in a deal that values the business at 1.22 billion Australian dollars, or about $1.15 billion.

headline: What Makes a Great Editor? Part I.
abstract: Insider asks Times reporters and photographers, “What makes a great editor?”
lead_paragraph: “I am not the editor of a newspaper and shall always try to do right and be good so that God will not make me one.”

headline: Grocery Delivery Service Instacart Raises $44 Million
abstract: Instacart, a company based in San Francisco that has expanded to 10 cities, announced a round of financing led by Andreessen Horowitz.
lead_paragraph: Companies like Uber and Airbnb have prospered by allowing people to sell their services to strangers on a smartphone-powered network.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on global counterterrorism, Saudi health safety, Wisconsin equality and British biodiversity.
lead_paragraph: “If all goes according to President Obama’s plan, the United States will soon be making a major new investment of $5 billion so that other countries can help in the fight against extremists,” writes The New York Times editorial board. The goal is to scale back American involvement in combatting terrorism by funding and equipping foreign counterterrorism operations. The Times is skeptical: “As Iraq demonstrates, just training troops to shoot and providing generals with expensive weapons will not address the threat.”

headline: Start-Up WeLab Raises $14 Million From Sequoia Capital and Hong Kong Tycoon
abstract: The investment in WeLab Holdings, an Internet finance start-up in Hong Kong, highlights the strong demand among investors for the Chinese Internet sector.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG – WeLab Holdings, an Internet finance start-up in Hong Kong, said on Monday that it had raised $14 million from Li Ka-shing, Asia’s richest man, and Sequoia Capital, a stalwart of Silicon Valley.

headline: PAI Partners Plans Joint Venture to Control Labeyrie Fine Foods
abstract: Under a deal, PAI Partners and the French food cooperative Lur Berri would hold equal stakes in Labeyrie, the producer of foie gras, smoked salmon and other gourmet foods.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European private equity firm PAI Partners said on Monday that it was moving forward in its effort to acquire a stake in the gourmet food producer Labeyrie Fine Foods.

headline: Hillshire Lays Out Path to End Its Deal With Pinnacle Foods
abstract: Hillshire Brands said that its board would no longer back its planned takeover of Pinnacle Foods, paving the way for the company to sell itself to Tyson Foods.
lead_paragraph: Hillshire Brands said on Monday that its board would no longer back its planned $4.3 billion takeover of Pinnacle Foods, paving the way for the company to sell itself to Tyson Foods for $7.7 billion.

headline: My Biggest Failure? Failing to Recognize Failure
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Small Business']
abstract: After all of the hard work, it can be very hard to walk away from a failing business.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has picked up a business book, attended a panel discussion or read an entrepreneurship blog in the past several years has probably learned about the virtues of “failing fast.”

headline: Morning Agenda: Alibaba’s Inner Circle Revealed
abstract: Alibaba unveils the 27 individuals in its controlling partnership. | A rival offer is expected to challenge G.E.’s bid for Alstom. | A bank account screening tool is under regulatory scrutiny. | Medtronic has agreed to buy Covidien.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group on Monday publicly disclosed the names of all 27 individuals who will make up the company’s select inner circle in an amended initial public offering prospectus, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. The individuals, led by a company founder, Jack Ma, will essentially control the online market operator through their ability to nominate a majority of directors.

headline: Level 3 to Buy TW Telecom for $5.7 Billion
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Fiber Optics', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: The takeover would add to the size of Level 3 Communications, already one of the country’s biggest providers of back-end Internet services.
lead_paragraph: Level 3 Communications said on Monday that it had agreed to buy TW Telecom, a provider of business Internet connections, for about $5.68 billion, as consolidation continues in the telecommunications industry.

headline: Airbus and Safran Plan to Merge Satellite Launch Activity
abstract: The move is a response to mounting pressure from the region’s biggest commercial satellite companies for more affordable launches.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Airbus Group and Safran of France plan to merge their satellite launching activities into a new company that aims to better compete against lower-cost rivals from Russia and the United States.

keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Data Centers', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Fusion-io, which makes flash memory hardware and software used in data centers, went public in 2011.
lead_paragraph: The SanDisk Corporation said on Monday that it would buy the data storage provider Fusion-io for $1.1 billion.

headline: Executive Editor of The New York Times Is Treated for Cancer
abstract: Dean Baquet, 57, the new executive editor, had a malignant tumor removed from his kidney and plans to return to work in about a week.
lead_paragraph: Dean Baquet, the executive editor of The New York Times, had a malignant tumor removed from his kidney on Saturday and will spend about a week away from the office while recovering, he said in an email to the newspaper’s staff on Monday morning.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Situation in Iraq Worsens
abstract: The weekend brought no calm to the violent situation in Iraq. Instead, it got worse, with reports of 1,700 Iraqi soldiers being executed by Sunni Islamist militants and two bombs going off in Baghdad.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning. President Obama is returning from Southern California today to a Washington heat wave and a Middle East crisis.

headline: Modi Underscores Ties to Bhutan in First Foreign Visit
abstract: The newly elected prime minister concluded his first foreign visit to the neighboring country of Bhutan on Monday.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian prime minister Narendra Modi concluded a two-day visit to Bhutan on Monday afternoon, making the tiny landlocked country nestled toward the eastern end of the Himalayas his first stop on his foreign policy tour.

headline: Insurgents in North Ambush Militia Volunteers and Seize Another City
abstract: The insurgents were an alliance of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria and the vestiges of loyalists to the Saddam Hussein government that was ousted by the Americans a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The Sunni extremist militants threatening Iraq seized another northern city on Monday in a battle with the Iraqi Army after having ambushed a convoy of untrained Shiite volunteers in the first lethal encounter between Sunni and Shiite combatants since the government began mobilizing thousands of Shiites.

headline: In Battle Over Allergan, Morgan Stanley Gets in the Crossfire
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'E-Mail', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: In its quest to defend against a hostile takeover, Allergan has pulled back the veil on the usually secretive world of mergers and acquisitions banking, publishing excerpts from emails written by senior Morgan Stanley investment bankers.
lead_paragraph: In its quest to defend against a $53 billion hostile takeover, Allergan pulled back the veil on the usually secretive world of mergers and acquisitions banking on Monday.

headline: Should Modeling Be Treated Like Driving, or Drinking?
abstract: Modeling hits young girls at their most emotionally vulnerable, when their self-esteem is the most uncertain and their judgment, certainly about themselves, the least informed.
lead_paragraph: There’s a very good piece on the Terry Richardson is-he-a-sexual-predator-or-not scandal in this week’s New York magazine. I think it’s worth reading not simply because it lays out a very hot-button issue fairly dispassionately, but because it also highlights one of the problems with modeling that is related to the recent skinny-models controversy, yet may actually be more essential than both: namely, the young-models problem.

headline: Argentina’s Debt Appeal Is Rejected by Supreme Court
abstract: The developments are likely to add to the turmoil in Argentina’s already unsettled bond market.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:57 p.m. | The Supreme Court handed Argentina two major defeats on Monday in cases brought by bondholders who refused to accept reduced payments after the country’s 2001 default.

headline: Opening Ceremony Collaborates with Fashion’s Favorite Florist
abstract: Thierry Boutemy’s darkly romantic arrangements are popping up on a limited-edition collection of clothing, accessories and a fragrance.
lead_paragraph: The Brussels-based florist Thierry Boutemy has decorated the runways of Lanvin and Dries Van Noten and the halls of Versailles for Sofia Coppola’s “Marie Antoinette.” Now he’s lending his darkly romantic aesthetic to Opening Ceremony for a range of capsule collections — including Opening Ceremony clothing, Manolo Blahnik shoes and a fragrance made in conjunction with Le Labo — which go on sale today at the brand’s stores and online. Working with the Opening Ceremony founders Humberto Leon and Carol Lim, Boutemy created still lifes — from artfully smashed petals to lavish arrangements of blue roses, dahlias and delphiniums — which were then photographed and translated into a vibrant series of digital prints. The scent, meanwhile, was formulated to capture what Boutemy calls “the permanent feeling of walking in a perfectly arranged mad and wild garden.”

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg later said, “such a delightful surprise.”

headline: In Drive Against Militants, Pakistani Airstrikes Hit Strongholds
abstract: The Pakistani military command said it had attacked six targets in the Shawal Valley of North Waziristan and killed 27 militant fighters.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As a full Pakistani military offensive in the tribal district of North Waziristan took shape on Monday, commanders promised a crushing blow to the jihadi groups that have flourished there in the past decade, spreading chaos in the region and posing a security threat to the West.

headline: Pop Music to Get Its Due on BBC Awards Show
abstract: The inaugural BBC Music Awards will be presented in a live broadcast from London on Dec. 11.
lead_paragraph: Evidently in the belief that the entertainment industry does not have sufficient opportunity to pat itself on the back, the BBC announced on Monday that it would present the inaugural BBC Music Awards at a live ceremony at Earl’s Court, in London, on Dec. 11.

lead_paragraph: Inside Zucker Bakery in the East Village, where Zohar Zohar, the owner and head baker, creates cookies and pastries that incorporate the flavors of Israel and other countries.

lead_paragraph: Liza de Guia is a video journalist whose blog, Food. Curated., profiles people who produce interesting food in New York and beyond.

headline: Cruises With Unesco Sites as Destinations
abstract: Seabourn’s new partnership with Unesco will give passengers increased access to World Heritage Sites.
lead_paragraph: The small-ship cruise line Seabourn has tied virtual mooring lines to Unesco in a new program that offers increased access to the organization’s diverse World Heritage sites such as Avignon, France, the Giant’s Causeway in Northern Ireland and Peterhof Palace in St. Petersburg.

headline: A Long Way From Wonder Bread
abstract: Ponsford’s Place, a bakery in Northern California, is part of a movement emphasizing locally grown, minimally processed whole grains.
lead_paragraph: SAN RAFAEL, Calif. — Pam Ross showed up at Ponsford’s Place Bakery & Innovation Center at 5 p.m. sharp, just minutes after the owner, Craig Ponsford, put out the sidewalk “bread man” sculpture that alerts customers: Pizza night is on.

headline: Germany vs. Portugal: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Both these teams are expecting to advance regardless of today’s result. But the losers will be nervously looking over their shoulders at the United States and Ghana.
lead_paragraph: Loaded with talent, Germany is a contender to win it all, as it is at almost every World Cup. Portugal is increasingly regarded as a one-man team. But that man is Cristiano Ronaldo, who is the reigning world player of the year. Expect Germany to swarm him with defenders.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

headline: Measuring Recovery? Count the Employed, Not the Unemployed
abstract: The employment rate shows that the economy is improving. It also shows that it has a long way to go.
lead_paragraph: South Carolina’s unemployment rate dropped to 5.3 percent in April, lower than in December 2007, when it stood at 5.5 percent on the eve of the Great Recession.

headline: Rise of the Internet Hate Machine
abstract: The Internet has made it easier than ever before for foul-mouthed, often sexist haters to air their grievances without consequence, writes JAKE FLANAGIN.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the age of Internet hate, when “it’s never been easier to send an anonymous death threat,” writes Jack Shafer for Reuters. “As with so many of life’s labors, advanced technology has removed most of the work and hazard from sending cowardly messages to people to frighten them.”

headline: Stir-fried Broccoli Stalks and Flowers, Red Peppers, Peanuts and Tofu
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Vegetables', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Broccoli', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Cutting broccoli stalks into two-inch julienne is almost like adding yet another vegetable to this quick stir-fry.
lead_paragraph: Probably most of you have used broccoli time and again in stir-fries. In this version I cut the stalks into 2-inch julienne, which is almost like adding a separate vegetable to the mix of broccoli flowers and red pepper (also cut in julienne). There’s a lot of texture at play here – crisp-tender vegetables, crunchy peanuts and soft tofu. You can add a little spice if you want, but I’ve made the chili flakes optional.

headline: Pan-Fried Broccoli Stems
abstract: A swift way to turn broccoli into an irresistible snack or side dish.
lead_paragraph: This was an experiment and now it is a keeper. Peel broccoli stems, slice them thin, and pan-fry in hot oil just until the slices are charred on the edges, then flip over and brown for just a little bit of time on the other side. If you do this just right, the medallions will have edges that are slightly crispy with that wonderful fried flavor, and tender interiors. With a little salt (or even without) they are irresistible. One stem’s worth of medallions will disappear quickly, so count on 1 per person (at least!). Although you will use a fair amount of oil for frying, it doesn’t all get absorbed by the broccoli stems.

headline: Pre-Summer Greek Salad With Shaved Broccoli and Peppers or Beets
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Vegetables', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Broccoli', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Uncooked, paper-thin broccoli keeps its shape and color, but absorbs a dressing.
lead_paragraph: Classic Greek salad is a summer dish in my house; impossible to make if tomatoes are not in season and wonderful. But other vegetables take to the same treatment – a simple dressing with a high ratio of acid (in this case a combination of lemon juice and vinegar with olive oil), feta cheese and lots of mint and parsley.

headline: Pasta With Mushrooms and Broccoli
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Vegetables', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Broccoli', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Cooked separately, broccoli stems and flowers have different textures and shades of green.
lead_paragraph: Broccoli stems and flowers can be prepared and cooked separately, like two different vegetables. For this pasta I used a vegetable peeler to shred the broccoli stems into thin ribbons, which I cooked briefly with the mushrooms. I sliced the crowns very thin and blanched them briefly with the pasta. The result is a dish with different textures and shades of green: the stems should be crisp-tender, their color faded. The crowns will be bright green, and 2 to 2 1/2 minutes cooking will render them tender but not mushy.

headline: ScienceTake | Secrets of the Bat Wing
abstract: The spectacular flight of bats may be aided by long, thin muscles in the skin of their wings.
lead_paragraph: The spectacular flight of bats may be aided by long, thin muscles in the skin of their wings.

headline: Spring Rolls With Shredded Broccoli Stems, Vermicelli and Red Pepper
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Vegetables', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Broccoli', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: You can save time on these light, pungent spring rolls by using the already shredded broccoli stems available in some supermarkets.
lead_paragraph: Lately I’ve been finding bags of shredded broccoli stems or broccoli stem slaw in supermarkets. I used just such a bag for this. You can grate the stems that come with your bunch broccoli for these, or you can save a bit of time and effort by buying the bagged product.

headline: New Insight Into How Bats Conquer the Air
abstract: Scientists at Brown University used Botox to discover evidence that bats’ muscles help shape their wings in flight.
lead_paragraph: Bats are an extraordinary evolutionary success, the only mammals to conquer the air. Their flying ability has long attracted the attention of engineers and biologists, and it comes through soft, flexible wings unlike those of birds or insects.

headline: Medtronic-Covidien Deal Is a Marriage of Convenience
abstract: Stents and sutures are not an obvious fit, Jeffrey Goldfarb and Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews write, and the savings and benefits from such a merger do not appear to justify a premium of nearly $10 billion.
lead_paragraph: The marriage of Medtronic and Covidien looks to be one of convenience. The $42.9 billion deal includes a premium that exceeds the estimated cost savings. Stents and sutures are not an obvious fit. And moving Medtronic’s headquarters from Minneapolis to Covidien’s Dublin base will not obviously cut the American company’s tax bill. Freeing up overseas cash is too shallow a reason to tie the knot.

headline: Tony Gwynn, Hall of Fame Batting Champion, Dies at 54 of Cancer
abstract: In his 20-year major league career, all with the San Diego Padres, Gwynn had a batting average of .338, including .394 in 1994. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 2007.
lead_paragraph: Tony Gwynn, who won a record eight National League batting championships, amassed 3,141 hits and gained acclaim as one of baseball’s most passionate students of the art of hitting, died on Monday in Poway, Calif. He was 54.

headline: Aftermath of a Militant Attack in Kenya
abstract: Scenes from Mpeketoni, where militants attacked a police station and two hotels, according to officials.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from Mpeketoni, where militants attacked a police station and two hotels, according to officials.

headline: Microsoft Unveils Machine Learning for the Masses
abstract: Microsoft plans to make predictive data analysis, now an arcane field, a standard part of business. The company says that a product due out in July will simplify what are now expensive, difficult processes.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft has a new strategy to win cloud business: A supposedly comprehensive predictive analysis service — and all you have to do is store your data in Azure, the Microsoft cloud.

headline: Col. George Sicherman’s Dice
abstract: How can you make a pair of Sicherman Dice — that is, renumber a pair of dice so that they give you the same odds as a pair of standard dice?
lead_paragraph: Our challenge this week is a classic by recreational mathematician Col. George Sicherman, who hit upon the insight in 1977. The resulting Sicherman Dice are a curiosity known to pretty much anyone who’s spent some time with recreational math. I reached Col. Sicherman by phone and asked him — How did he even think to look for something no one else had even considered?

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Webrooming’ Versus ‘Showrooming’
abstract: Food trucks are found to be as safe as restaurants. Tech start-ups head to Berlin. Are business plans over-rated?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Former Medtronic C.E.O. Defends Inversion Deal
abstract: Bill George, a former chief executive of Medtronic, opposed Pfizer’s proposed deal to acquire an overseas competitor and reincorporate abroad, but he is all in favor of his former employer making a similar deal.
lead_paragraph: Bill George, a former chief executive of the medical device maker Medtronic, came out last month against Pfizer’s proposed inversion – a deal to acquire an overseas competitor and reincorporate abroad, lowering tax rates and freeing up overseas cash.

headline: Alibaba Drops In to Say Hi to Institutional Investors in U.S.
abstract: Members of Alibaba’s management team are scheduled to hold a series of informal meetings with investors in several American cities, according to people briefed on the matter.
lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group is not expected to begin a formal road show with prospective investors in its upcoming initial public offering for at least a month.

headline: True Appreciation of These Spurs Will Come
abstract: The Spurs were never more respected than after the excruciating way they lost to the Heat last year and perhaps never more appreciated than after this year’s N.B.A. title.
lead_paragraph: Suffering is good. It reinforces character, resolve and commitment. Experienced in public, it exposes vulnerability. Handled with class, it heightens likability.

headline: Schumacher, Out of Coma, Leaves French Hospital
abstract: The former Formula One champion has left the hospital in France where he was admitted with brain injuries nearly six months ago to “continue his long phase of rehabilitation.”
lead_paragraph: Michael Schumacher, the former Formula One champion, has left the hospital in Grenoble, France, where he was admitted with brain injuries nearly six months ago, to “continue his long phase of rehabilitation.” He is “no longer in a coma,” his family announced in a statement Monday.

headline: China Executes 13 in Xinjiang Region After Attacks
abstract: The 13 people had been found guilty of organizing and leading terrorist groups, as well as murder, arson, theft and other crimes.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese government executed 13 people in the Xinjiang region on Monday, part of an intensifying response to growing violence in the region that is spreading to other parts of the country.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Penalties for Gay Themes
abstract: Two South Carolina universities will have to spend $70,000 teaching U.S. founding documents—because they assigned gay-themed books last year.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina upheld a budget item requiring two universities to spend $70,000 to teach United States founding documents — as punishment for having assigned gay-themed books to freshmen last year.

lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is taking a hard look at who should be held accountable when it comes to the General Motors debacle.

headline: Crafts Retailer Michaels Stores Aims to Raise $500 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: The crafts retailer, which originally filed two years ago for an initial public offering, aims to price its shares from $17 to $19 each, a sign that the long-awaited offering is drawing near.
lead_paragraph: The crafts retailer Michaels Stores may be nearing the end of its long journey to the public markets.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Audi Works Hard for 13th Le Mans Win
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Le Mans Auto Race', 'Automobile Racing', 'Nascar Sprint Cup Series']
abstract: Audi survived mechanical problems and a strong performance from Toyota for the victory; Marc Marquez won his seventh consecutive MotoGP race.
lead_paragraph: Audi won the 24 Hours of Le Mans on Sunday for the 13th time in the last 15 years, with its diesel-electric hybrid R18 e-tron quattros finishing one-two ahead of a field of exhausted rivals. The winning Audi entry, for the third time in four years, was shared by Benoît Tréluyer of France, André Lotterer of Germany and Marcel Fässler of Switzerland.

headline: A Faster Way to Find the Origin of Malaria
abstract: A DNA “bar code” of 23 snips from the genes of parasites that cause malaria can help scientists quickly determine where they originated, British researchers report.
lead_paragraph: By using a DNA “bar code” of 23 short snips from the genes of parasites that cause malaria, scientists can now often quickly determine where they originated, British researchers report.

headline: Siemens and Mitsubishi Counteroffer for Alstom Is Less Than G.E.’s Bid
abstract: Siemens and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries formally presented a counteroffer for Alstom, but their combined bid was less than what General Electric was offering.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:12 p.m. | PARIS — Siemens and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries formally presented a counteroffer for Alstom on Monday in an attempt to assuage French fears about losing one of its most important companies, even as their combined bid was less than what General Electric had proposed.

headline: A Merger in a Race With Congress
abstract: The fate of the Medtronic-Covidien deal hinges on Congress and whether it will doing anything about tax inversions, writes Steven M. Davidoff in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: Why does Medtronic want Covidien?

headline: At the London Men’s Wear Shows, Exuberance Reigns
abstract: At the London men’s shows, it’s hard not to be struck by three things that almost every show so far has shared in common.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the men’s wear shows here finish up their second day, it’s hard not to be struck by three things that almost every show so far has shared in common: the size of the crowds, the energy in the rooms and the youthfulness of the attendees who jam into their seats or line the back walls, craning for a look at the fashion on exuberant display.

abstract: The fund-raising points to the growth of a cottage industry aimed at making the virtual currency easier and safer to use, thereby bringing it further into the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: The Bitcoin security platform BitGo announced on Monday that it had raised $12 million, the latest example of how investors see opportunity in a growing industry aimed at making virtual currency easier and safer to use.

headline: U.S. Is Exploring Talks With Iran on Crisis in Iraq
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: The United States sees potential meetings with Iran as an opportunity to discuss the threat posed by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the Sunni extremist group.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A senior American diplomat met with his Iranian counterpart in Vienna on Monday to explore whether the United States and Iran could work together to create a more stable Iraqi government and ease the threat from Sunni militants.

lead_paragraph: Daniel Ahiakpor joined the New York office of Vdopia in a new post, vice president for business development. He had been senior director and head of publisher platform sales at Adap.tv, New York, part of AOL.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: The song in a commercial for Apple brings back memories, but the company and its agency are not divulging the name of the singer.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: S.E.C. Fines Hedge Fund in Demotion of Whistle-Blowing Employee
abstract: Paradigm Capital Management agreed to pay $2.2 million to settle the civil charges, becoming the first investment fund to pay a fine for retaliating against an employee who reported his firm’s misdeeds to the S.E.C.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:37 p.m. | The Securities and Exchange Commission has sounded a warning to Wall Street and corporate America, taking aim at a hedge fund not only for improper trading but for punishing the employee who blew the whistle on the wrongdoing.

headline: The Wisdom of Breaking Away
abstract: It’s easy and instinctive for investors to follow the herd, but they are better off pursuing their own goals.
lead_paragraph: In February 2012, a group of experienced skiers headed into the backcountry near the Stevens Pass resort in Washington State to look for untracked powder. It was a beautiful day, and everyone expected to have a great time skiing the popular Tunnel Creek section.

headline: For the ‘Fargo’ Finale, Many Unanswered Questions
abstract: Heading into Tuesday night’s finale, we’re faced with jumbled plot lines that may or may not be cleared up.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, a very pregnant Molly Solverson and her sleepy postman husband, Gus Grimly, cozied up in bed, a sublime scene of domestic tranquillity amid all the violence and trouble that has coursed through the episodes of FX’s “Fargo.”

headline: A Mother’s Anguish, a History of Violent Crime and Rocks That Ring
keywords: ['Stonehenge (England)', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Women and Girls', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: A woman’s suicide sheds light on maternal mental illness; a vast database of trial transcripts from the Old Bailey Courthouse in London helps historians figure out when British justice shifted from brutal to civilized; researchers discover the hidden musical qualities of Stonehenge.
lead_paragraph: A woman’s suicide sheds light on maternal mental illness; a vast database of trial transcripts from the Old Bailey Courthouse in London helps historians figure out when British justice shifted from brutal to civilized; researchers discover the hidden musical qualities of Stonehenge.

headline: ‘Frida Kahlo’s Garden’ to Sprout in New York City
abstract: The New York Botanical Garden will present “Frida Kahlo’s Garden” starting next May.
lead_paragraph: “I paint flowers so they will not die,” Frida Kahlo once said, and in her paintings as well as her life, flora of many varieties – flowers, trees, roots, tendrils, watermelon, cactus fruit – took on an almost supernatural presence. Next year the New York Botanical Garden will explore her obsession with the vegetable world in “Frida Kahlo’s Garden,” an exhibition that will include not only rarely seen paintings by Kahlo but also a re-creation of her studio and garden at Casa Azul in the Coyoacán neighborhood of Mexico City, where she lived for many years and where she died in 1954.

headline: Thanks to Ad Agency, You’re in the Picture at Museum Exhibition
abstract: The installation by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners explores Salvador Dalí‘s fascination with double imagery and optical illusions.
lead_paragraph: An agency known for its creativity has developed an interactive installation for an exhibition at a museum that is devoted to an artist known for his creativity.

headline: Gazprom Cuts Gas to Ukraine
abstract: A Gazprom spokesman, Sergei Kupriyanov, explained the Russian gas giant’s action to stop supplying natural gas to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A Gazprom spokesman, Sergei Kupriyanov, explained the Russian gas giant’s action to stop supplying natural gas to Ukraine.

headline: Blast From the Past: No Digital Technology for Beatles LPs in Mono
abstract: The reissue of the Beatles’ albums in mono on vinyl will use the original analog master tapes for the pressings.
lead_paragraph: Many fans of the Beatles, including the group’s producer, George Martin, and the band members themselves, have long argued that the most authentic way to hear the group’s music is in the original mono mixes. Those were the band’s principal focus during recording and mixing sessions, and they sometimes differ strikingly from the now more familiar stereo versions.

headline: Sex, Drugs and G.D.P.
abstract: Some countries will start counting prostitution and illegal drug sales in their gross domestic product, raising the question of what it really measures.
lead_paragraph: Help me out here.

keywords: ['Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling', 'E-Mail', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The I.R.S. told investigators looking into accusations of politically motivated misconduct that two years’ worth of emails sent and received by an official, Lois Lerner, had been destroyed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service commissioner will testify before two House committees next week about the agency’s disclosure that it lost thousands of emails sought by investigators looking into accusations of politically motivated misconduct by the agency, the committees said Monday.

headline: Met Opera Tax Filing Reveals Pay For Gelb
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera, in the middle of labor talks with its unions, reports that its general manager, Peter Gelb, earned a total of $1.8 million in pay and benefits in 2012, and has since taken a pay cut.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera, which is seeking concessions from its workers amid tough labor talks, reported in a tax filing on Monday that its general manager, Peter Gelb, had earned a total of $1.8 million in pay and benefits in 2012 — but said that he had since taken a pay cut.

headline: MyCopter Simulator
abstract: This video from the University of Liverpool demonstrates the myCopter, a personal helicopter being developed in the United Kingdom.
lead_paragraph: This video from the University of Liverpool demonstrates the myCopter, a personal helicopter being developed in the United Kingdom.

headline: Popcast: Jimmy Giuffre and Eric Dolphy, Rediscovered Jazz Innovators
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss two jazz players who were perhaps underappreciated in their own time but are again attracting attention.
lead_paragraph: The saxophonist Jimmy Giuffre, who died in 2008 at the age of 86, was often out of step with jazz, even after he wrote the swing anthem “Four Brothers” for Woody Herman’s band in 1947 and led the Jimmy Giuffre 3, a late-’50s, drummer-less group that created cultural weight out of light-toned music. He started new groups that got away from swing rhythm and other conventions of jazz; his searches made him fall out of favor with audiences, and after the 1962 album “Free Fall,” he released no new records for 10 years.

headline: Whose Dress Code Is It, and Why?
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Education (K-12)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The best school dress codes aren’t about students and sexuality, but about placing school on the list of places where there are standards, and where the freedom to do whatever we want, whenever we want shouldn’t and doesn’t apply.
lead_paragraph: The dress code — for girls, at least — has become a complicated issue. Is it intended to protect the girls against unwanted advances, or the boys against temptation? If the intent is to foster an atmosphere conducive to learning, why would spaghetti straps interfere with an understanding of algebraic equations? Does demanding that young women disregard the siren song of advertising and the media and leave the midriff-baring tops on the racks teach them that they are worth more than their appearance, or that their appearance is the measure of who they are? Is sexy strong, or is sexy dangerous?

headline: A Helicopter of One’s Own
abstract: European researchers are testing designs for a small, easily piloted helicopter that could one day help shorten commutes and ease traffic congestion.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — You know what would be cool?

headline: Exploring Academia’s Role in Charting Paths to a ‘Good’ Anthropocene
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Earth', 'Education (K-12)', 'Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Philosophy', 'Social Media', 'Sustainable Living', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Enterprising journalists and communicators report on humanity’s growth spurt, urban rush and innovations in family planning.
lead_paragraph: I spent the tail end of last week at the annual conference of the Association for Environmental Studies and Sciences, a young network of scholars and students aiming to foster collaborations among disciplines — from ecology to ethics — in studying, and improving, the human relationship to the environment.

headline: Gluten-Free Eating Appears to Be Here to Stay
abstract: Diet trends come and go, but the demand for products without gluten seems to be on the rise.
lead_paragraph: In the luxe dining room of Del Posto, one of New York’s most heralded and expensive Italian restaurants, one-third of the tables on any given night will have at least one gluten-free diner.

headline: Iran vs. Nigeria: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Iran and Nigeria tied, 0-0, in a match that was low on goalscoring opportunities and became the first draw of the 2014 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: Nigeria won the African Nations Cup last year, but it lacks a star striker. Iran is solid defensively, so goals could be hard to come by.

headline: Supreme Court Rules Against ‘Straw’ Purchases of Guns
keywords: ['First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Religion-State Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Firearms', 'Gun Control', 'Political Advertising', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: The justices also allowed a challenge to a law banning lies in political campaigns to move forward and refused to hear a case about holding school graduations in churches.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday allowed a challenge to an Ohio law banning lies in political campaigns to move forward, turned back a challenge to a law concerning gun purchases and refused to hear a case about holding high school graduations in churches.

headline: Afghan Candidate Alleges Voting Fraud by Karzai and Aides
abstract: Less than 48 hours after a runoff election, signs of a political crisis emerged with the campaign of Abdullah Abdullah claiming there had been widespread ballot stuffing.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Less than 48 hours after a runoff election to choose the next president of Afghanistan, the first signs of a looming political crisis emerged on Monday, with the campaign of Abdullah Abdullah claiming there had been widespread ballot stuffing and suggesting he was being set up for a defeat he would not accept.
