headline: Syrian Government Making Aid Delivery More Difficult, U.N. Official Says
abstract: The United Nations chief aid coordinator said the delivery of aid had become harder since President Bashar al-Assad claimed re-election on June 3.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The government of President Bashar al-Assad is making it harder to deliver humanitarian aid to millions of war-battered civilians in Syria, the United Nations chief aid coordinator, Valerie Amos, said on Monday.

headline: Producers Aim to Bring ‘Love Letters’ to Broadway This Fall
abstract: Broadway producers want to revive A.R. Gurney’s play at the Vivian Beaumont Theater; casting is not yet set.
lead_paragraph: A Broadway revival is in the works for A.R. Gurney’s “Love Letters,” a two-character epistolary play that has long been a favorite of famous actors, with producers aiming to mount the show at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in the fall. The director would be the Tony nominee Gregory Mosher (Broadway’s “A View from the Bridge” in 2009-10) and the lead producers include Nelle Nugent (“The Trip to Bountiful” in 2013), Barbara Broccoli (the James Bond movie series) and Fred Zollo (“Once”), according to two Broadway producers who are not involved with the show but are familiar with the plans.

headline: Two Kids Still Hopelessly Devoted to Each Other
abstract: This version of “Grease” at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn features four tracks that were composed for the film and years later grafted onto the stage show.
lead_paragraph: There’s certainly some heart in the serviceable production of “Grease” at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn. But the show’s pulse can be overwhelmed by percussion. Here, the big tunes are belted out, then underscored in fear you might miss a beat. That leaves only the modest, quiet numbers to give those peppy characters some much-needed depth.

headline: Festival Style: Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival
abstract: Music fans gather in Manchester, Tenn., for the music and to don their favorite festival-style interpretations.
lead_paragraph: Music fans gather in Manchester, Tenn., for the music and to don their favorite festival-style interpretations.

headline: Pterosaurs, Flying Reptiles, Were a Social Lot
abstract: The discovery of intact eggs and pterosaur fossils in China suggests that the creatures nested in large groups.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered the first intact eggs from pterosaurs, the flying reptiles that lived alongside the dinosaurs. The eggs, along with dozens of pterosaur fossils, are from a site discovered in 2005 in northwestern China. In a new study in the journal Current Biology, the scientists report that the pterosaurs belong to a new genus and species, Hamipterus tianshanensis, dating to the Early Cretaceous, 145 million to 100 million years ago. They had wingspans of five to 11 feet.

headline: Sounds of Frog Lust, Made Even Sexier
abstract: Male Mientien tree frogs are using storm drains to enhance their mating calls, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Tiny frogs in Taiwan are making the most of urban development by using storm drains to amplify their mating calls and impress females, researchers say. Open concrete drains are common in Taiwan, and male  Mientien tree frogs (above, one in its more usual setting) like to perch inside when courting. Writing in The Journal of Zoology, researchers reported that the drains enhanced the volume and duration of calls.

headline: The Mother Who Jumped
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: A few months after Cindy Wachenheim gave birth to the child she had long dreamed of, she became convinced that she had caused her son irrevocable brain damage. It was a certainty she couldn’t shake.
lead_paragraph: A few months after Cindy Wachenheim gave birth to the child she had long dreamed of, she became convinced that she had caused her son irrevocable brain damage. It was a certainty she couldn’t shake.

headline: In Defeat, Portugal Shows Its Ugly Side
abstract: A penalty kick and two goals off defensive rebounds gave Thomas Müller of Germany the first hat trick of the 2014 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: SALVADOR, Brazil — The goals came in volume for Cristiano Ronaldo this year, as he stretched nets in towns across Europe at a stunning rate. While playing for Real Madrid, Ronaldo scored 51 times in 47 games, earning him the Ballon d’Or for best player in the world.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | June 10-16, 2014
abstract: How well did you follow the news this week? How well can you do against others taking our ten-question quiz? Test yourself and find out.
lead_paragraph: How well did you follow the news this week? How well can you do against others taking our 10-question quiz?

headline: Green Space So Exclusive It’s Off Limits Even to Residents
abstract: At a growing number of upmarket buildings in New York, the ultimate amenity is an outdoor oasis so exclusive that no one but the gardener is allowed in.
lead_paragraph: Deborah Nevins is one of the most sought-after landscape designers in the world. She has seeded and sodded estates for the likes of the entertainment mogul David Geffen, the Greek shipping magnate Stavros Niarchos and the media tycoon Rupert Murdoch, and her haute habitats dot townhouse backyards and prewar rooftops from Greenwich Village to Park Avenue.

headline: After Baby, an Unraveling
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Series']
abstract: One woman’s wrenching struggle illuminates recent findings that postpartum mental disorders can emerge later than expected and include a broader range of symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Cindy Wachenheim was someone people didn’t think they had to worry about. She was a levelheaded lawyer working for the State Supreme Court, a favorite aunt who got down on the floor to play with her nieces and nephews, and, finally, in her 40s, the mother she had long dreamed of becoming.

headline: Spurs’ Title Is a Testament to Persistence
abstract: A Jacob Riis quotation in the San Antonio Spurs’ locker room not only motivated the players, but also summed up their resolve.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — In a corner of the San Antonio Spurs’ locker room, there is a framed quotation from the muckraking social reformer Jacob Riis.

headline: A Chain Reaction of Change Behind Dams
keywords: ['Levees and Dams', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: Researchers found that evolutionary change in alewife herrings since the 18th century had a ripple effect on bluegill.
lead_paragraph: When settlers in 18th-century New England dammed their lakes, they unwittingly set off evolutionary changes in the herring species called the alewife. Now researchers have discovered that those changes rippled across the food web.

headline: Ticketless Fans Breach Security Gate at World Cup
abstract: FIFA and World Cup officials faced questions about security Monday after two incidents kept ticketed fans out of one match until after it had begun and nearly allowed fans without tickets to force their way into another.
lead_paragraph: FIFA and World Cup officials faced questions about security Monday after two incidents Sunday kept ticketed fans out of one match until after it had begun and nearly allowed fans without tickets to force their way into another.

headline: Voice by Eternal Lips
abstract: A premiere of the band’s latest music video features the dancer Alex Sotomayor as Michael Jackson.
lead_paragraph: A premiere of the band’s latest music video features the dancer Alex Sotomayor as Michael Jackson.

headline: Creating a Supply Chain of Work by Female Playwrights
abstract: Female writers and producers have put together a list of 46 recommended plays by women.
lead_paragraph: All but daring American theaters to put on more new plays by women, an advocacy group of female writers and producers released a list of 46 such works on Monday that have been recommended for production by dozens of other playwrights, dramaturges and artistic directors.

headline: Middle School Never Ends
abstract: A new study finds that what’s cool in eight grade may cause problems in adulthood — and brings back a lot of middle-school memories, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: Do “cool kids” suffer for their status later in life? A new study suggests they may — and its reception shows how much power childhood hierarchies seem to have over us, even decades later.

headline: Computing Crime and Punishment
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: A trove of London trial data over more than two centuries, digitized and analyzed by algorithm, is yielding clues in the evolution of the British justice system.
lead_paragraph: In 1765, John Ward was hanged for stealing a watch and a hat.

headline: Bill de Blasio Loves L.A. (We Love It!)
abstract: The New York mayor lost a bet with the Los Angeles mayor, and has to sing Randy Newman’s “I Love L.A.” tonight on “Jimmy Kimmel Live.”
lead_paragraph: Sports wagers by politicians are boring and not worth your time. But this one could have been interesting.

headline: United States vs. Ghana: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: An early goal by Clint Dempsey and an improbable late score by John Brooks helped the United States stave off Ghana and avoid a third straight World Cup loss to the small African nation.
lead_paragraph: The pressure to mount an attack for the Americans will be on Clint Dempsey, Jozy Altidore and Michael Bradley. Ghana will look to the stalwart captain, Asamoah Gyan, and the young Jordan Ayew, starting instead of Kevin-Prince Boateng.

headline: Merrill Lynch to Pay More than $32 Million for Overcharging Clients
abstract: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ordered Merrill Lynch to pay a fine and restitution for overcharging about 41,000 small businesses and 6,800 charities over upfront sales fees on certain mutual funds.
lead_paragraph: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority has ordered Merrill Lynch to pay more than $32 million over sales fees it charged on certain mutual funds.

headline: Diplomacy and Soccer for Biden in Brazil
keywords: ['World Cup 2014 (Soccer)', 'United States International Relations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Soccer']
abstract: The vice president said he hoped to “rebuild trust” with President Dilma Rousseff, who was angered by reports that the N.S.A. had spied on her.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Seeking an opening during the World Cup soccer tournament to thaw relations with Brazil, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived in Latin America’s largest country on Monday, expressing a desire to “rebuild trust” after the souring of ties over revelations of the National Security Agency’s surveillance practices.

headline: Jonathan Ive on Apple’s Design Process and Product Philosophy
abstract: Apple’s design chief, who rarely speaks publicly, said in a recent interview that the company’s design processes remained unchanged, vibrant and healthy.
lead_paragraph: When Steven P. Jobs led Apple, he created a core principle for the company’s designers and engineers: stay fully focused on making great products.

headline: Poetry Profiles: Octopus Press
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Editors from Octopus Books answer questions about the press’s history and future.
lead_paragraph: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by editors at Octopus Books, Hajara Quinn, Zachary Schomburg, Mathias Svalina and Alisa Heinzman, and book designer Drew Swenhaugen.

lead_paragraph: London

abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: The Earth’s Hidden Ocean
abstract: An ocean of water appears to be tied up in minerals of the mantle 400 miles below the surface, according to an analysis of seismic waves passing through the deep earth.
lead_paragraph: An analysis of seismic waves passing through the deep earth appears to confirm what laboratory experiments have suggested was possible: that an ocean of water is tied up in the mantle, 400 miles below the surface.

headline: The Making of a Male Model
abstract: In January, we followed Tomas Gajdos during his first season — from London to Paris and from castings to fittings — as he tried to break into the fashion business.
lead_paragraph: During Men’s Fashion Week, hundreds of young men head to Europe, hoping it will be the start of their modeling careers. “I think that most people think that when you become a model, you don’t have to worry anymore about money,” said Tomas Gajdos, a 17-year-old high school student from Slovakia who was discovered by a modeling agent while riding the London Tube. “But, it isn’t so easy as it maybe looks.”

headline: American Tower Expands Cellphone Tower Holdings in Brazil
abstract: The $978 million acquisition of BR Towers, backed by the private equity firm GP Investments, follows American Tower’s purchase last year of 2,800 cellphone towers in Brazil from NII Holdings.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The American Tower Corporation has agreed to acquire a Brazilian cellphone tower company, BR Towers, backed by the private equity firm GP Investments, for about $978 million, the companies said in regulatory filings on Sunday.

headline: Listen Up | A Brooklyn Experimental Musician Gets in Touch With His Inner Michael Jackson
abstract: With his new project, Eternal Lips, the veteran artist Grey Gersten surrenders to the joys of pop music, as seen in the video for “Voice,” which stars a diminutive Michael Jackson impersonator and premieres here.
lead_paragraph: “I avoided pop music for a long time,” says Grey Gersten, a veteran of the Brooklyn indie music scene, of his new pop-minded solo project Eternal Lips. “I thought pop was all about consumerism. Then I realized pop was about dreams and fantasy.”

headline: Father, Doctor, Role Model
abstract: “The Good Doctor” is more than a son’s search to understand his father’s actions, but an evaluation of a generation that practiced medicine differently.
lead_paragraph: In a career that spanned more than five decades, from the 1950s into the 21st century, Dr. Phillip I. Lerner witnessed vast transformations in medicine. But as his son, Dr. Barron H. Lerner, writes in this exquisitely insightful new memoir, none of the changes was more profound than the evolution of the doctor-patient relationship.

headline: In Another Blow, G.M. Recalls 3 Million More Defective Cars
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Keys with extra weight could cause the vehicles to switch off in a “jarring event,” and will need modification on several models, the automaker says.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Monday that it would recall 3.36 million defective cars worldwide, another low point in the seemingly endless safety crisis that has engulfed the nation’s largest automaker.

headline: Dense Breasts May Obscure Mammogram Results
abstract: In many states, doctors are notifying women who are found to have dense breast tissue. But there is no clear medical guidance on what they should do next.
lead_paragraph: The doctors were pleased to inform me, the letter said, that the results of the mammogram were normal. Early detection of cancer is important, a report was sent to my referring physician, I should report any lumps, see my health provider, have a physical.

headline: Ask Well: Feeding Heavy and Thin Kids Together
abstract: How do you feed two children in a family when one is overweight and one is underweight?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Delay in Translating Recordings May Affect Jury Availability at State Senator’s Trial
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Yiddish Language', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: Jurors in the bribery trial of Malcolm A. Smith are being polled to find out if they can serve longer while the defense team translates 28 hours of Yiddish conversations.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — A mistrial in the federal government’s bribery case against State Senator Malcolm A. Smith and two other defendants seemed highly possible on Monday after the judge said he would ask jurors whether they could serve into mid-July so defense lawyers could digest dozens of hours of conversation in Yiddish and English.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Senate Hearing on Fairness of High-Speed Stock Trading Could Get Heated
keywords: ['Financial Brokers', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The Senate’s Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations plans to zero in Tuesday on the question of fairness in split-second trading and on the money paid by brokerages to firms actually handling the trades.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:14 p.m. To the average investor with a brokerage account, the process of buying and selling shares of stock seems straightforward. But the back end of these systems, governing how billions of shares are traded, remains opaque to many customers.

headline: Best Week Yet for ‘Gentleman’s Guide’ After Tony Win
abstract: “A Gentleman’s Guide for Love & Murder,” which won the Tony Award for best musical, hit a new high in ticket sales last week.
lead_paragraph: Last week was the best yet at the box office for the Broadway musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” following the show winning the Tony Award for best musical on June 8. “Gentleman’s Guide,” one of the most modest-selling musicals of the 2013-14 season until it became a front-runner for the Tony last month, grossed $851,262 for eight performances last week; its previous high was $816,932 for nine performances during Christmas week last year. The average paid ticket price was $121.89, up nearly $22 from the week before – a big jump that reflects theatergoers’ buying more premium-price tickets, a goal of the show’s producers as they try to leverage the Tony into making the show a commercial hit.

headline: Despite a Wayward Journey, Márquez Is a Rock for Mexico
abstract: Rafael Márquez is the first player in World Cup history to have worn a captain’s armband at four straight tournaments, a giant achievement given how unlikely it seemed just a short while ago.
lead_paragraph: NATAL, Brazil — With one arm folded across his chest, Rafael Márquez of Mexico stood in the pouring rain and belted out his country’s national anthem. Moments later, he was cruising around the drenched field, influencing play in his typical subtle ways, helping lead his team to a  1-0 victory over Cameroon.

headline: A Superspy Races to Halt Armaggedon
abstract: In “I Am Pilgrim,” a globe-trotting thriller by Terry Hayes, a master spy is enlisted to thwart a biological attack on the United States by an Arab bent on vengeance.
lead_paragraph: Neither its plot nor its provenance do much to recommend Terry Hayes’s “I Am Pilgrim.” So it’s all the more surprising that this first novel by a screenwriter of films not renowned for their dialogue turns out to be the most exciting desert island read of the season.

headline: With His Best Finish in a Major, Fowler Displays Substance and Style
abstract: Rickie Fowler, who tied for second at the United States Open, has often been more a commodity than a competitor, but he is committed to getting better.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — As befits the perfect pitchman, Rickie Fowler met with the news media Sunday wearing a cap with “Puma” spelled in large writing and a shirt bearing a Puma logo so large the eye was reflexively drawn to it.

headline: Rocks With Resonance
abstract: The sounds of ringing rocks at Preseli Hills in West Wales, the source area of some of the Stonehenge bluestones.
lead_paragraph: The sounds of ringing rocks at Preseli Hills in West Wales, the source area of some of the Stonehenge bluestones.

headline: Older Than the Rolling Stones
abstract: A project aimed at recapturing the soundtrack of history suggests that the rocks at Stonehenge were chosen, and hauled from a long distance, for their ability to produce hollow, bell-like noises.
lead_paragraph: Before dawn Saturday, thousands of revelers will again gather among the monoliths at Stonehenge to sing, bang drums and frolic beneath a solstice sunrise.

headline: Relatives of Missing Teenager Speak Out
abstract: Relatives of Naftali Fraenkel, an Israeli-American teenager who is believed to have been kidnapped by Palestinian militants, expressed hope that he would be found soon.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of Naftali Fraenkel, an Israeli-American teenager who is believed to have been kidnapped by Palestinian militants, expressed hope that he would be found soon.

headline: As Robotics Advances, Worries of Killer Robots Rise
keywords: ['Robots and Robotics', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Newer machines will have more autonomy, and experts are concerned about the humans toiling alongside them.
lead_paragraph: From driverless cars to delivery drones, a new generation of robots is about to revolutionize the way people work, drive and shop. But there is one area where robots are already entrenched and spreading fast: the industrial sector, especially manufacturing and storage.

headline: A Hublot Timepiece Specially Designed for World Cup Fans
abstract: With two sets of hands — including one for keeping time in soccer matches — the Big Bang Unico Bi-Retrograde Chrono is the official watch of the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the photographer Rob Kulisek captures a timepiece from Hublot.

headline: A Delay at La Guardia Becomes ‘The French Connection’
abstract: Delays at La Guardia led to a last-minute decision to drive to a meeting in Montreal. What happened next was like a car chase scene from a movie.
lead_paragraph: I HAVE been flying for most of my 35-year career. As the chairman and chief investment officer at Saguenay Strathmore Capital, I’m constantly traveling for business. I was on a plane two and a half weeks after rotator cuff surgery. The doctor thought I was nuts.

headline: Hoping the Tale of a Glass Slipper Fits Into a Troupe’s Repertory
abstract: American Ballet Theater performs Frederick Ashton’s “Cinderella” with four casts.
lead_paragraph: The stylistic versatility offered by American Ballet Theater at its best is a marvel. During this spring season, it has been dancing choreography by four thoroughly unalike 20th-century masters — Leonide Massine, George Balanchine, Kenneth MacMillan and Frederick Ashton — and, often enough, the standards it has set in each have been world class.

headline: Squeezing the Life Out of Airline Travel
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Frequent Flier Programs', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Business Travel']
abstract: It can be hard to get enthusiastic about flying when planes are packed, fees are everywhere and frequent-flier programs are getting tighter.
lead_paragraph: SUMMER is coming, airplanes are fuller than ever, and the airlines are squeezing every penny they can from passengers. Even stalwart fliers like my friend Heather Poole, a flight attendant and author of a humorous memoir about her career (“Cruising Altitude: Tales of Crash Pads, Crew Drama and Crazy Passengers at 35,000 Feet”), are taking a deep breath.

headline: Efforts to Inspire Students Have Borne Little Fruit
abstract: The Obama administration began private-public partnerships to encourage students to pursue studies in science and technology, but that goal has been an elusive one.
lead_paragraph: An occasional column on developments in what educators call STEM — for science, technology, engineering and math.

headline: Keeping Health in Stock at New York City’s Bodegas
keywords: ['Convenience Stores', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Food']
abstract: Jetro Cash and Carry, a wholesale warehouse, is expanding its fresh produce offerings and sponsoring health fairs to encourage bodegas to stock healthy options in poor neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: At Sandy Ortiz’s bodega in the Bronx, no platanos means no business.

headline: Did George W. Bush Foresee What’s Happening in Iraq?
abstract: Fox News claimed he “pretty much laid this out as it is happening.”
lead_paragraph: In their rush to blame the escalating violence in Iraq on President Obama, Republican critics brush off any suggestion that his predecessor may also be to blame, offering up some version of “Oh yeah, Democrats always want to blame Bush, but Obama has been in office for more than five years.”

headline: A Newsroom Tradition Comes to an End, Sort Of
abstract: The coffee cart, which had been wheeled into the third-floor newsroom to provide a free caffeine fix every weekday afternoon around 4:30 for more than 20 years, is being replaced.
lead_paragraph: A Times tradition ended on Monday: the coffee cart, which had been wheeled into the third-floor newsroom to provide a free caffeine fix every weekday afternoon around 4:30 for more than 20 years. The company told newsroom employees in an email that it would be replaced by an offering of “fruits and other healthy snacks.”

headline: Transforming Phone Video Into Publicity and a Film
abstract: Images from YouTube videos capturing filming of “Transformers: Age of Extinction” fed a documentary.
lead_paragraph: Chicago was blowing up. There were explosions at the convention center, cars cartwheeling down South Wacker Drive, pandemonium in Millennium Park and helicopters swooping down the river, ducking under drawbridges.

headline: What Olivier Theyskens’s Departure From Theory May Really Mean
abstract: Theory announced that its artistic director, Olivier Theyskens, was leaving the brand to “pursue other design projects.”
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Theory announced that its artistic director, Olivier Theyskens, was leaving the brand to “pursue other design projects.” The recent pre-spring 2015 collection was his last.

headline: ‘Ring’ Cycle With Digital Orchestra Is Postponed
abstract: Professionals committed to a Wagner festival in Connecticut with digital samples of music pulled out, leading to postponement.
lead_paragraph: The effort to bring Wagner’s “Ring” cycle to Connecticut with digital samples instead of a traditional orchestra has been postponed. Organizers announced Monday that they were canceling their first offering, a production of “Das Rheingold” planned for August, saying that several artists had withdrawn, citing threats to their careers.

headline: Bonnaroo 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Bonnaroo 2014 photo diary of Tamara Reynolds.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Bonnaroo 2014 photo diary of Tamara Reynolds.

headline: Tell Us What You Love About Your Bodega
abstract: The Times wants to know why you love your bodega. Is it what you buy, or the people who work there? Why do you prefer it over the convenience stores you can find elsewhere?
lead_paragraph: Bodegas, the trusty neighborhood shops that carry the bare essentials and are never far away when you need them, have long been a point of pride for New Yorkers.

lead_paragraph: Greta Gerwig and Scott Shepherd in a scene from Penelope Skinner’s dark comedy at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

headline: The Redesign of a Design Museum
abstract: The Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, offers a preview of the total renovation it is completing this year, adding exhibition space, an “immersion room” and an electronic pen with a memory.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Carnegie used the third floor of his Fifth Avenue mansion as a gymnasium where he practiced his putting. The current owner, the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, plans to put a small mini-golf green there on Tuesday when the news media gets a preview of the mansion’s nearly completed $91 million renovation.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Iraq, Palestine and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Iraq, Palestine and Spain.

headline: As Brazil Cheers, Protesters Struggle to Be Heard
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'World Cup 2014 (Soccer)']
abstract: With Brazilians loudly rallying behind their national team in the World Cup, activists concerned about social issues have struggled to make their voices heard.
lead_paragraph: Twelve months after hundreds of thousands of protesters took to Brazil’s streets to complain of lavish public spending on stadiums for the World Cup, the tournament organizers have been relieved to see just hundreds attend scattered demonstrations as the first round of games got underway.

headline: Creative Destruction Yada Yada
abstract: Disrupt this!
lead_paragraph: Jill Lepore has a great article in the New Yorker debunking the hyping of “disruptive innovation” as the key to success in business and everything else. It’s not a bah-humbug piece; it is instead a careful takedown, in which she goes back to the case studies supposedly showing the overwhelming importance of upstart innovators, and shows that what actually happened didn’t fit the script. Specifically, many of the “upstarts” were actually long-established firms, and more often than not the big payoffs went not to disruptive innovators but to firms that focused on incremental change and ordinary forms of efficiency and quality.

headline: Spanish-Language ‘Vagina Monologues’ Closes After Short Run
abstract: The creative team had described the production as the first open commercial run of a Spanish-language play Off Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Spanish-speaking audiences didn’t turn out for “Los Monólogos de la Vagina,” forcing the quick closure of Eve Ensler’s play after 15 previews and 33 regular performances.

headline: At Home, a Dramatic Organist
abstract: Boston’s early music festival last year called on a New York-based choral director and organist, John Scott. New York’s new festival has done the same.
lead_paragraph: A well-remembered highlight of the Boston Early Music Festival a year ago was a Bach organ recital by John Scott. Mr. Scott, the organist and director of music at St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue in New York, is better known here for his work with the splendid St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys than as an organist.

headline: Drifters Look for Work; One of Them Finds Love
abstract: The Chelsea Opera revives “The Tender Land,” a rarely seen work by Aaron Copland.
lead_paragraph: For all of the dearly departed New York City Opera’s contributions to American culture, the 30 or so new operas it presented were never really among them. Seen Gian Carlo Menotti’s “The Most Important Man” or Thea Musgrave’s “The Voice of Ariadne” lately? Neither have I.

headline: A Red Carpet for Young Guests
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Business Travel', 'Age, Chronological', 'Youth']
abstract: Select hotels are updating design, services and technology, to attract younger customers, who command as much as $1.7 trillion in spending power.
lead_paragraph: Travis Evans could meet his friends in just about any bar around Washington, but he is drawn to the Dignitary Bar at the Marriott Marquis, where he takes time to enjoy his favorite drink, an Old-Fashioned.

headline: Questions and Answers About the Crisis in Iraq
abstract: New York Times correspondents in Iraq respond to questions about the insurgency, sectarian strife and United States policy options.
lead_paragraph: The conflict in Syria has escalated into a wider regional crisis, edging neighboring Iraq closer to all-out sectarian warfare, as Sunni militants led by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, have  declared a caliphate that stretches across eastern Syria and much of northern and western Iraq.

headline: Mariano Rivera and JPMorgan’s James Lee Honored by Sports Charity
abstract: The Bids for Kids Gala will honor the recently retired Yankees pitcher Mariano Rivera and James B. Lee Jr., vice chairman of JPMorgan Chase at an event expected to raise nearly $3 million.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t quite a merger of pinstripes, but one of Wall Street’s top deal makers is taking the stage with a New York Yankees legend to raise money for a sports-focused children’s nonprofit.

headline: Reclaim the Firefox Search Box
abstract: Plus, how to remove books from the Kindle screen.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do I restore the Google search box and its search engines list to Firefox version 29.0.1?

abstract: Lily Rabe and members of the cast of the Shakespeare in the Park production at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: Lily Rabe and members of the cast of the Shakespeare in the Park production at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

headline: Moelis Creates Private Equity Fund-Raising Team by Hiring From a Rival
abstract: In joining Moelis, the four bankers from Greenhill & Company will focus on services like fund-raising and helping institutional investors sell their stakes in leveraged buyout funds.
lead_paragraph: Moelis & Company said on Monday that it has hired four executives from a rival boutique investment bank, Greenhill & Company, to start up a group specializing in raising money for private equity firms.

headline: Iraq’s Current Conflict Foretold
abstract: As rebel forces capture Iraqi cities, veteran photojournalists look at the lessons learned and the obstacles that lie ahead for independent coverage in the region.
lead_paragraph: As rebel forces capture Iraqi cities, veteran photojournalists look at the lessons learned and the obstacles that lie ahead for independent coverage in the region.

headline: Who Will Win in Iraq?
abstract: The insurgency will burn out, to the benefit of its sworn Shiite enemies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — TO go by much of the commentary about Iraq in recent days, the country is already past the breaking point under the lightning campaign by Sunni insurgents. Reinforced by hardened fighters from Syria and sympathetic communities in northern and western Iraq, the insurgents control much of Mosul, the most important city in northern Iraq, and Tikrit, the home of Saddam Hussein’s clan, and they have laid siege to Samarra, the site of one of Shiism’s most storied shrines. It would be no surprise if the next few weeks brought them to the gates of Baghdad.

headline: With ‘SmartBinge,’ WNYC Wants Listeners to Load Up on Its Podcasts
abstract: Though some of its shows are among the most downloaded podcasts on iTunes, WNYC needs listeners to connect those tastes to the radio station, and hopefully, contribute.
lead_paragraph: DURING pledge drives, public radio hosts often highlight what they call driveway moments, those instances when, upon arriving home, motorists are so captivated by a radio segment that they remain behind the wheel until it concludes. Now a new campaign from WNYC promotes the notion that in the era of smartphones and podcasts, far from being confined to their cars, listeners can tune in wherever and whenever they want.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,317 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,317 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: A New Video of Modern-Day Concentration Camps
abstract: Readers are invited to comment on searing footage of the Myanmar government’s persecution of a Muslim minority.
lead_paragraph: On my recent trip to Myanmar, I was accompanied by a Times video journalist, Adam Ellick, who just published a searing video of the modern-day concentration camps for Rohingya in that country. I must say that sometimes as a scribbler, I find it a hassle to make videos on trips. There’s more equipment, and we’re always fussing over microphones and capturing sunsets, and the cameras make us more obvious to the authorities. I like nimble, and videos aren’t nimble. But then I see the finished results, and I’m so impressed.

headline: Egypt to Free Ill Journalist Who Staged Hunger Strike
abstract: Abdullah Elshamy, an Al Jazeera reporter, had been detained without charges since last August.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Prosecutors will release a hunger-striking journalist, Abdullah Elshamy, because of his deteriorating health, the Egyptian state news media said on Monday, offering a concession on the treatment of one of more than 16,000 prisoners detained since the military takeover last summer.

headline: Suze Orman’s Approved Prepaid Debit Cards Are Quietly Discontinued
abstract: No announcement was made, though cardholders received a letter with the news. Observers speculated that her very low $3 monthly fee may have undercut the business.
lead_paragraph: Suze Orman is quietly getting out of the payments business.

headline: A Church-PAC Link Raises Questions in Mississippi
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Political Action Committees', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: If a church’s resources were used to help Senator Thad Cochran, the church could lose its tax-exempt status.
lead_paragraph: The full-page advertisement in Mississippi Link, a weekly newspaper aimed at black residents of Jackson, the state’s capital, urged readers to vote for Senator Thad Cochran in the June 3 Republican primary.

headline: General to Lead Bergdahl Inquiry
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Army has appointed a two-star general to conduct an investigation into the disappearance of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl from his outpost in Afghanistan in 2009.
lead_paragraph: The Army has appointed a two-star general on Monday to conduct an investigation into the disappearance of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl from his outpost in Afghanistan in 2009. The officer, Maj. Gen. Kenneth R. Dahl, who has combat experience in Afghanistan, will conduct the inquiry into Sergeant Bergdahl, who returned to the United States from an Army hospital in Germany last Friday, two weeks after being released in exchange for five senior Taliban detainees. Sergeant Bergdahl is undergoing therapy and counseling at an Army hospital in San Antonio.

headline: Marriage by Force Is Addressed in Britain
abstract: A new law in England and Wales is seen as part of the government’s effort to fight religious extremism.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — England and Wales made it a criminal offense as of Monday to force anyone into marriage, an effort to persuade victims to come forward and to emphasize secular legal values.

headline: Can the Port Authority Save the Planet?
abstract: We need agencies that cross borders to protect coastal environments.
lead_paragraph: THIS has been a bad year for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, with scandals over a bridge closure and, most recently, a shady real estate deal. But the authority has a chance at redemption, if it is willing to move beyond its traditional mandate. Its model of interstate cooperation could do much more than prevent traffic jams; it could also play the leading role in managing the ecological health of the Hudson River estuary, and serve as an example for other coastal cities around the world facing complex environmental problems in a time of climate change.

headline: Writing in the Here and Now
abstract: How travel writers observe and report on the meanderings of their minds.
lead_paragraph: There may be no literary genre that, at its best, evokes sense of place more than travel writing. The whole point is to make the reader feel there, not here, to transport proverbial armchair travelers from their dull, quiet living rooms to a cacophony of scarlet macaws clearing their throats deep in a tropical rain forest in Costa Rica.

headline: Obama to Send Armed Support to U.S. Embassy in Baghdad
abstract: In a letter to the speaker of the House, the president explained that United States soldiers will be sent to Baghdad to protect American citizens.
lead_paragraph: In a letter to the speaker of the House, the president explained that United States soldiers will be sent to Baghdad to protect American citizens.

headline: World Cup 2014: Belgium Defeats Algeria, 2-1
abstract: Two second-half goals enabled Belgium to rally for a 2-1 victory against Algeria and keep alive its hopes of winning the group.
lead_paragraph: Two second-half goals enabled Belgium to rally for a 2-1 victory against Algeria and keep alive its hopes of winning the group.

headline: British Spy Agencies Assert Power to Intercept Web Traffic
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Privacy', 'Social Media', 'E-Mail']
abstract: A government document cites the right to intercept communications that go through services like Facebook, even if they are between people in Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a broad legal rationale for collecting information from Internet use by its citizens, the British government has asserted the right to intercept communications that go through services like Facebook, Google and Twitter that are based in the United States or other foreign nations, even if they are between people in Britain.

headline: In Medtronic’s Deal for Covidien, an Emphasis on Tax Savings
abstract: The medical device company will reincorporate in Ireland as part of its merger with Covidien.
lead_paragraph: To invest in the United States, Medtronic says it needs to move to Ireland.

headline: Ruling on Argentina’s Debt May Give Creditors More Power
abstract: In years past, countries could cut a deal to satisfy creditors. But the Supreme Court’s ruling could make that more difficult.
lead_paragraph: For decades, a country in deep financial trouble could, as a last resort, cut a deal with its creditors to slash its debt load, perhaps gaining relief for its economy and its people.

headline: In Two Michigan Villages, a Higher Calling Is Often Heard
abstract: Neighboring Fowler and Westphalia have each produced 22 priests, defying the trend of a shrinking Roman Catholic clergy.
lead_paragraph: FOWLER, Mich. — Aside for the mole grazing his right eyebrow, it is difficult to distinguish Gary Koenigsknecht from his identical twin, Todd, four minutes the elder.

headline: Climbing Out of the Darkness of Maternal Mental Illness
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A community and an event for women experiencing maternal mental illness, those who have passed through it, and their family and friends.
lead_paragraph: Two articles in the Health section, “Thinking of Ways to Harm Her” and “After Baby, an Unraveling,” shed new light on the timing and range of maternal mental Illness. New studies and research suggest that maternal mental illness can appear during pregnancy, or can appear not only in the first few weeks after birth but in later months. In the year after giving birth, studies suggest, as many as one in five and at least one in eight women develop symptoms of mental illness, including not just depression, but anxiety, bipolar disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder or a combination as well.

headline: A Dream Start
abstract: The substitute John Brooks, who was playing in his first World Cup game, powered a fierce header into the net to give the United States a 2-1 victory over Ghana.
lead_paragraph: NATAL, Brazil — It began with the magical. It ended with the miraculous.

headline: Court Rulings on Voter Restrictions Create Limbo as Midterms Near
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Identification Devices', 'Minorities', 'Discrimination', 'States (US)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The decisions have gone both ways, but several have provided a new round of judicial rebukes to the recent wave of photo ID requirements and efforts to shorten early voting.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — With the midterm elections only months away, efforts to carry out some of the country’s strictest photo ID requirements and shorten early voting in several politically pivotal states have been thrown into limbo by a series of court decisions concluding that the measures infringe on the right to vote.

headline: The Structures of Growth
abstract: What do you need to do to get better at something after you have gone through the early stages of making a lot of progress really quickly?
lead_paragraph: Most of us are trying to get better at something. And when we think about our future progress, we tend to imagine we will improve linearly. We’ll work hard at mastering some skill; we’ll steadily get better and better.

headline: Frances Foster, Children’s Book Editor With an Imprint, Dies at 83
abstract: Ms. Foster published award-winning authors like Roald Dahl, Peter Sis, Philip Pullman and Louis Sachar.
lead_paragraph: Frances Foster, a children’s book editor who published authors like Roald Dahl, Peter Sís and Philip Pullman, and who had her own imprint, died on June 8 in Manhattan. She was 83.

headline: Truckers Resist Rules on Sleep, Despite Risks of Drowsy Driving
keywords: ['Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Trucks and Trucking']
abstract: Drowsy driving, a leading cause of crashes and highway fatalities, has come to the fore after an accident involving the comedian Tracy Morgan on a stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike.
lead_paragraph: The tractor-trailer set off at 2:30 a.m. from Springfield, Mo., the usual time and place. Nearly 11 hours later, along the Will Rogers Turnpike in Oklahoma, fatigue caught up.

headline: Ruling Against J.C. Penney in Dispute With Macy’s Over Martha Stewart Products
abstract: The ruling that J.C. Penney unlawfully interfered with a merchandising agreement may be the penultimate chapter of a long-running dispute among three famous names in retailing.
lead_paragraph: A New York judge on Monday ruled that J. C. Penney unlawfully interfered with an exclusive merchandising agreement between Macy’s and Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia.

headline: Study Asserts Startling Numbers of Insider Trading Rogues
keywords: ['Insider Trading', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Stock Options and Purchase Plans']
abstract: Two professors have evidence of what we’ve long suspected: Insider trading is far more common than the number of prosecutions would suggest, arising from perhaps a quarter of all public company deals.
lead_paragraph: There is often a tip.

headline: How Health Care Systems Stack Up
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: In a study, the United States finished last out of 11 advanced nations, despite having the most costly system in the world.
lead_paragraph: Britain and Switzerland were top scorers in a study examining the quality and efficiency of health care systems in 11 advanced nations by a leading American research organization. As usual, the United States finished last over all and last on several important measures of cost and health outcomes, despite having the most costly system in the world.

headline: Legislating Ignorance About Guns
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Research', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials']
abstract: If pro-gun members of Congress have their way, they will continue to bar federally financed research on the roots of gun violence and how to prevent it.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen months and dozens of school shootings after the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., public-health experts still lack basic information on the roots of gun violence and how best to prevent it.

headline: Innocents at the Border
abstract: President Obama needs to mount a surge of humanitarian care to handle the explosion of young migrants fleeing violence in their home countries.
lead_paragraph: The surge of desperate young migrants across the southwest border has the Obama administration scrambling to respond. It was clearly ill-prepared for a problem that grew steadily for years before exploding this year, with more than 47,000 unaccompanied children caught at the border since October.

headline: In a .338 Lifetime Average, Every Day Counted
abstract: Tony Gwynn, who died of cancer, said proudly that he learned something new at the ballpark every day, a simple, powerful lesson in a sport with a punishing schedule.
lead_paragraph: Tony Gwynn may have embodied the game of baseball better than anyone else who has played. It was not because Gwynn, who died of cancer on Monday at age 54, was among its greatest hitters. It was because of the wonder he found in the game and the joy he took in applying his daily discoveries.

headline: Sunnis and Kurds on Sidelines of Iraqi Leader’s Military Plans
abstract: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has resisted calls to work with Sunni Arabs and Kurds, instead spending most of his time running his country’s military strategy and trying to recruit Shiites to battle separatists.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has presented himself as the man who could bring Iraqis together, but with the collapse of his army before a Sunni militant assault, he has taken on only one role — that of commander in chief of Iraq.

headline: A New College Model
abstract: Has Arizona State found a new way to educate students? Starbucks employees may soon find out.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Howard Schultz, the chief executive of Starbucks, unveiled his company’s newest — and possibly most important — perquisite for its employees: a free college education. He announced this new program on a stage in The Times Center in Midtown Manhattan, alongside his partner in the new venture, Michael Crow of Arizona State University.

headline: Sharpton’s Coolness to Rangel Marks Waning of a Political Generation
keywords: ['Endorsements', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Tensions have grown in recent years between the Rev. Al Sharpton and Representative Charles B. Rangel, adding further uncertainty to the congressman’s bid for re-election.
lead_paragraph: When the Rev. Al Sharpton abruptly summoned the candidates in the Democratic primary for Representative Charles B. Rangel’s seat to the headquarters of Mr. Sharpton’s organization, the National Action Network, this month, the incumbent showed up an hour late.

headline: Guantánamo Detainees’ Lawyers Seek Further Delays
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Detainees', 'Terrorism', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The lawyers said that until they knew more about scrutiny of defense teams by the F.B.I., they could not know whether they had a conflict of interest and needed to step aside.
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — Defense lawyers on Monday sought further delays in the war crimes case against five Guantánamo Bay detainees accused of aiding the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, telling a military judge that there had been greater scrutiny of defense teams by the F.B.I. than had previously come to light.

headline: U.S. Judge Denies Stay of Execution in Georgia
abstract: The Georgia State Board of Pardons and Paroles and a federal judge denied Marcus Wellons’s clemency request Monday afternoon. He is scheduled to be executed Tuesday at 7 p.m.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A federal judge on Monday rejected a Georgia inmate’s argument that his execution, scheduled for Tuesday evening, should be stayed because the state had refused to disclose details about the drug to be used in his lethal injection.

headline: To Bolster Its Claims, China Plants Islands in Disputed Waters
abstract: China is moving sand onto reefs and shoals to add new islands to the contested Spratly archipelago, alarming Vietnam, the Philippines and other Southeast Asian nations that claim sovereignty over it.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The islands have all that one could ask of a tropical resort destination: white sand, turquoise waters and sea winds.

headline: Chicago Is Freed From Oversight on Graft
abstract: A federal judge ended the oversight intended to prevent politically motivated hirings, firings and harassment of government employees.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The city that was once known as the patronage capital of the world may no longer live up to the title.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 16, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Tensions Mount as Troops Scour Hebron in Search for Missing Youths
abstract: Israel arrested 150 people, most of them leaders of the militant Islamic movement Hamas, and Aziz Dweik, a Hebron resident who is speaker of the Palestinian Parliament.
lead_paragraph: HEBRON, West Bank — Kayed and Hassan Jaber, brothers who drive trucks loaded with marble from this city’s quarries into Israel each day, stood in the doorway of their Star of the South company here Monday afternoon watching pretty much nothing happen on the street.

headline: Abduction of Young Israeli Hitchhikers Spurs Debate on Conduct
abstract: Some said they were angry over what they called the youths’ seemingly cavalier behavior in the West Bank, but others said the infrequent bus service left people no option but to hitch a ride.
lead_paragraph: NOF AYALON, Israel — The three Israeli teenagers kidnapped by Palestinian militants while hitching a ride in the West Bank last week have provoked an outpouring of sympathy in Israel’s ordinarily fractious society, with nonstop news coverage and gatherings of thousands who have recited psalms for the safe return of the hostages, all students at yeshivas in West Bank settlements.

headline: Bratton Still Sees Challenges in a New York He Made Safer
abstract: In his second tour as police commissioner, William J. Bratton is using many of the same techniques he developed in the high-crime early 1990s, though the city is far calmer now.
lead_paragraph: In his office on the 14th floor of Police Headquarters, William J. Bratton displays copies of his memoir, “Turnaround,” his account of taming New York’s crime-filled streets and subways in the 1990s. On a mostly empty wall hangs a framed Time magazine cover from 1996, declaring over a steely photo of Mr. Bratton: “Finally, We’re Winning the War Against Crime. Here’s Why.”

headline: Big Retailers Agree to List Unit Prices on Websites
abstract: Six major stores, including Walmart and Costco, joined in the deal with New York’s attorney general. But there was one holdout, Amazon.
lead_paragraph: Is that television-size box of graham crackers at Costco really a better deal than a standard box at Walmart? Soon, online customers won’t have to do the math to figure it out.

headline: The Shadow of the Patriarch
abstract: Religious beliefs and contemporary life rub up against each other in Ayad Akhtar’s new play, “The Who & The What.”
lead_paragraph: Matters of faith and family, gender and culture are stirred together into a fiery-flavored stew in “The Who & the What,” the probing new play by Ayad Akhtar that opened on Monday at the Claire Tow Theater at Lincoln Center. Like Mr. Akhtar’s “Disgraced,” which won the 2013 Pulitzer Prize and will be seen on Broadway this fall, this new work considers the itchy frictions that emerge when religious belief and contemporary life rub up against each other, as they do for the family at the center of the play, a Pakistani immigrant and his two grown daughters.

headline: Dancing Between Battles
abstract: Jack O’Brien’s pleasure-filled production of “Much Ado About Nothing” in Central Park pits Lily Rabe and Hamish Linklater as Shakespeare’s sparring partners Beatrice and Benedick.
lead_paragraph: Fair weather never lasts forever, not even in the Eden-like patch of Sicily that has popped up in Central Park. That’s the setting for Jack O’Brien’s pleasure-filled production of “Much Ado About Nothing,” which opened on Monday night at the Delacorte Theater. Though skies and temperaments are sunny when the show begins, you’re always conscious of brooding storms waiting to make their angry entrances.

headline: Pop the Question
abstract: A very quiet puzzle from Zhouqin Burnikel.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — It took me a long time to figure out what the theme was for Zhouqin Burnikel’s puzzle. That’s not a bad thing, mind you; There’s a revealer at 69 Across that explains everything, albeit in a very quiet way (pun intended).

headline: Migrants Flow in South Texas, as Do Rumors
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Women and Girls', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Talk of “permits” allowing migrants who crossed the border illegally to stay temporarily in the United States has added to a surge of families arriving from Central America.
lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Tex. — Exhausted and dazed, hundreds of Central American migrants, mainly women with small children, come to the bus station of this border city every day now, spilling into a church next door that has opened its doors. Having crossed into the United States illegally, the new arrivals are often grimy and famished. In the church, they eat, bathe and sleep, changing into donated shoes and clothes.

headline: How the United States Scored Against Ghana
abstract: An annotated diagram of the United States’ goal against Ghana in the 2014 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: An annotated diagram of the United States’ goal against Ghana in the 2014 World Cup.

headline: Critics Point to Drawbacks in Starbucks Tuition Program
abstract: According to the fine print, students might have to pay thousands of dollars out of pocket, and wait months or years before being reimbursed.
lead_paragraph: Within hours on Monday of unveiling, with much fanfare, a program to pay employees’ college tuition, Starbucks faced criticism for drawbacks in the fine print — notably that students could have to pay thousands of dollars out of pocket, and wait months or years before being reimbursed.

headline: Spanish Police Target Cells Recruiting War Volunteers
abstract: The Spanish authorities have arrested several men accused of recruiting volunteers for insurgencies from Western Africa to Syria and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: MELILLA, Spain — Starting in this tiny North African enclave, the Spanish police have cracked down in recent weeks on a network of Islamic militants with footholds in Spain and Morocco that they say has recruited and dispatched young volunteers to join insurgencies from Mali to Libya to Syria.

headline: Mets’ Experiment Doesn’t Yield Positive Result
abstract: Batting the starting pitcher in the No. 8 spot for the first time in team history made little difference against the defending National League champions.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Manager Terry Collins has worked all season to find the right lineup to try to ignite the Mets’ offense. It can be a fundamentally flawed and draining process that has seemed to grow more difficult each day.

headline: Teenagers Arrested After Videotaped Attacks
keywords: ['Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Assaults', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Seven teenagers were arrested after a string of assaults against fellow teens in Hudson Falls, N.Y. Police continue to search for a motive in the attacks, which were recorded on cellphones and shown to friends.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON FALLS, N.Y. — They were beatings meted out with seemingly no motive other than capturing a moment of small-town adolescent fame. And, in a bizarre way, they succeeded.

headline: Intersection | Clinton Hill, Brooklyn
abstract: In the diverse Clinton Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn, Kenard Bunkley, an educator and longtime resident, says his “urban-prep” style is easy and comfortable.
lead_paragraph: In the diverse Clinton Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn, Kenard Bunkley, an educator and longtime resident, says his “urban-prep” style is easy and comfortable.

headline: Secret Tapes of Politicians Cause a Stir in Poland
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Transcripts released by a Warsaw newspaper are proof that the government should be dismissed, an opposition leader said.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Mysterious tapes of high-level officials discussing what seem to be unsavory deals, recorded in the back room of a restaurant popular with the political elite, are threatening the careers of some of Poland’s most prominent leaders and perhaps even the survival of the current government.

headline: Ready to Fight for a Drink That Tastes Like a Slap in the Face
abstract: To the gentle palate of a white wine drinker, palinka tastes like rubbing alcohol with a hint of fruit. It is best consumed far from an open flame.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Zoltan Hajas learned to make palinka from a neighbor who lives on the other side of his backyard fence.

headline: Moise Safra, Banker and Philanthropist, Dies at 79
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A member of the prominent banking family, Mr. Safra recently invested in several real estate ventures in New York and London.
lead_paragraph: Moise Y. Safra, a member of a prominent Brazilian banking family who last year bought a stake in the General Motors Building on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, died on Friday in São Paulo, Brazil. He was 79.

headline: Shell to Sell Large Stake in Australian Gas Company
abstract: Royal Dutch Shell said on Tuesday that it would offload the majority of its stake in Woodside Petroleum, Australia’s biggest independent oil and natural gas producer, in a deal worth $5.7 billion.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Royal Dutch Shell said on Tuesday that it would offload the majority of its stake in Woodside Petroleum, Australia’s biggest independent oil and natural gas producer, in a deal worth $5.7 billion.

headline: Tracy Morgan’s Condition After Crash Is Upgraded to Fair
abstract: The comedian was said to have made “great improvement” since a six-vehicle accident on June 7.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Tracy Morgan, who was gravely injured in a crash more than a week ago, has been upgraded to fair condition, his publicist said on Monday, calling it a “great improvement.”

headline: Richards Silent, but Others Address Future
abstract: On breakup day, center Brad Richards refused to address whether he will be part of the team next season, while four others who will become unrestricted free agents said they hoped to remain in New York.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Brad Richards did not speak to reporters on the Rangers’ breakup day on Monday, an unusual step for a player who spoke practically every day this season.

headline: Dark Clouds Hover Over a Funny Man
abstract: The fourth season of Louis C. K.’s “Louie” on FX was more serious and sober than in the past, and although the topics were familiar, they were treated more solemnly.
lead_paragraph: During the 20-month hiatus between Seasons 3 and 4 of “Louie,” the show’s creator, writer, director and star, Louis C. K., said he needed “a little breathing room” to gather his ideas and take the series — one of the smartest and funniest comedies on television — in a new direction.

headline: Quiet About Adversary, U.S. Posts a Victory That Speaks Volumes
abstract: Though U.S. players refused to say that beating Ghana would be a huge accomplishment, the team simply would not allow a third straight World Cup loss to the Black Stars.
lead_paragraph: NATAL, Brazil — In the days leading up to the United States national team’s game against Ghana on Monday, not one American player said a word about the past.

headline: Deadly Tornadoes Sweep Across Northeast Nebraska
abstract: The town of Pilger sustained serious damage, with the county sheriff estimating that 50 to 75 percent of it was heavily damaged or destroyed.
lead_paragraph: Tornadoes ripped through northeastern Nebraska on Monday afternoon, killing at least one person and causing serious damage in the town of Pilger, the authorities said.

headline: A Bolder Effort by Big Tobacco on E-Cigarettes
abstract: Big Tobacco is moving to turn the e-cigarette market to its advantage, with subsidiaries of the companies that make Marlboro and Camel set to announce nationwide marketing plans.
lead_paragraph: Electronic cigarettes, promoted as a healthier alternative to tobacco, are getting powerful new backers with an unhealthy reputation: big tobacco companies.

abstract: This word has appeared in 322 New York Times articles in the past year.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 17, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 17, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I heard in Guatemala that people were caught by immigration, but then they let them go and gave them a permit. The word got around, and that’s why so many people are coming.”

headline: Player Ratings: United States (2) vs. Ghana (1)
abstract: The United States got critical individual performances in winning its first World Cup match and taking a promising step toward advancing out of its group.
lead_paragraph: It was not pretty, and it was not perfect, but the United States defeated Ghana for a promising start in its uphill climb to advance out of a challenging Group G.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) HELLO I MUST BE GOING (2012) A divorced 30-something (Melanie Lynskey) finds a haven from her adult problems in the suburban Connecticut home of her critical mother (Blythe Danner) and indulgent father (John Rubinstein) in this comedy written by Sarah Koskoff and directed by Todd Louiso. There, she finds sex and romance with the 19-year-old stepson (Christopher Abbott, above with Ms. Lynskey) of a potential client her father is desperate to impress, who has allowed his doting mother (Julie White) to believe he is gay. “Needless to say, there are complications, some farcical, some belonging more to the realm of therapeutic melodrama,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “This is ultimately a tale of affirmation, self-acceptance and second chances, and its lessons, while not unwelcome, are a bit too forced and neatly packaged to make it fully satisfying. But when Ms. Lynskey and Mr. Abbott are together, there are inklings of a wilder, riskier, less predictable movie — one you may wish the characters could escape into, even though you know they never will.”

headline: If Affirmative Action Is Doomed, What’s Next?
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Two new books offer ideas on how to achieve diversity in higher education without using race-based systems.
lead_paragraph: Affirmative action as we know it is probably doomed.

headline: Nest’s Smoke Alarm Returns, With Price Cut
abstract: Nest’s smart smoke and carbon monoxide alarm is coming back to store shelves two months after safety concerns prompted a recall of the devices. Nest, which is owned by Google, is also cutting the price on the product to $99 to $129 to sell more of them.
lead_paragraph: Nest’s smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are coming back to store shelves two months after safety concerns prompted a recall of the devices.

headline: Big Voice, Defying Gravity
abstract: Idina Menzel, who gained a young following through “Frozen,” emphasized her grown-up side on Monday evening in a concert at Radio City Music Hall.
lead_paragraph: Midway through her Radio City Music Hall concert on Monday evening, Idina Menzel expressed her displeasure at reading a description of her voice as “screechy.” That’s not a word any soprano could appreciate, and in Ms. Menzel’s case, it isn’t even accurate.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on June 17, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Female Activist in Haryana Works Within System for Change
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Honor Killings', 'Marriages', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Santosh Dahiya, a professor and the head of the women’s wing of a group of all-male village councils, speaks up against so-called honor killings and other atrocities against women.
lead_paragraph: Over a cup of milky tea some months ago in a nondescript hotel in Rohtak, a dusty town of steel and oil mills, colleges and auto repair shops, Santosh Dahiya reflected on the slow-moving pace of change in the mostly rural state of Haryana.

headline: City Aims to Play Down Its Dog Meat Festival
abstract: The feasting is expected to go ahead as scheduled in the southern city of Yulin, but officials have taken steps to deflect outside attention from the annual event, at which thousands of dogs are consumed.
lead_paragraph: Animal rights advocates say they have seen signs that the southern city of Yulin is trying to lower the profile of its much-criticized dog-eating festival. The feasting is expected to go ahead as scheduled this weekend, but local officials have taken steps to deflect outside attention from the annual event, at which thousands of dogs are consumed.

headline: European Auto Sales Continue to Climb
abstract: Registrations of new passenger cars in May in the European Union rose by 4.5 percent from a year earlier, the ninth straight month of gains.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Europe’s car market has continued to slowly regain the ground lost since the financial crisis, industry data showed on Tuesday, with sales in May posting a ninth straight month of advances.

headline: Kenyan Leader Blames Domestic Foes, Not Shabab, for Attacks
abstract: President Uhuru Kenyatta said the killing of at least 57 people in two raids was the work of local “political networks,” not Islamic militants.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — As Kenyan officials reported a second lethal attack on a coastal village, Kenya’s president said Tuesday that the violence, which has left at least 57 people dead, was the work of “local political networks” and was not carried out by the Shabab, a Muslim extremist group that has claimed responsibility.

headline: Rick Perry’s ‘Groundhog Day’
abstract: Can the Texas governor bear to run for president again?
lead_paragraph: “Boys, I am going to bless this meal,” Rick Perry said, ducking his head and folding his hands under his chin. We were sitting at Nate ’n Al, the Jewish Deli in Beverly Hills, and the governor of Texas was looking every bit the regular customer in a tight black polo shirt and designer glasses. His face was nicely tanned; his hair, as ever, was coifed and TV-ready. He had just ordered a corned-beef Reuben (“I worked out this morning”) and a Diet Dr Pepper (“you got those critters?” he asked the waiter). But before diving in, Perry took a moment to appreciate his surroundings. “I’m more Jewish than you think I am,” he told me. “I read the part of the Bible that said the Jews are God’s chosen people.” He boasted that he has been going to Israel since 1992. Then Perry got down to business, thanking the Lord for His many blessings, and asking Him to be with “our men and women who defend our freedom, bring ’em home safe, be with the president, give him wisdom.”

headline: Iraq’s Current Conflict Foretold
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Photography', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: As rebel forces capture Iraqi cities, veteran photojournalists look at the lessons learned and the obstacles that lie ahead for independent coverage in the region.
lead_paragraph: With Sunni rebel extremists increasing their attacks on Iraqi government forces, the conflict has drawn in Shiite civilians who had been mobilized in defense. The rebels of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, who claim to have executed hundreds of Iraqi troops, have overtaken cities in the northern and western parts of the country.

headline: Britain Says It Is Ready to Reopen Iran Embassy
abstract: The pace of a thaw between the two countries appears to have been intensified significantly by a shared interest in containing Sunni militants in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Underscoring its warming relations with Iran, Britain announced Tuesday that the “circumstances are right” to reopen the British Embassy in Tehran and that it would establish a small presence there as soon as possible.

headline: As Sunnis Die in Iraq, a Cycle Is Restarting
abstract: Many Iraqis said they feared a resumption of the sectarian violence that occurred during the height of the 2006-08 war.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — As Sunni militants rampaged across northern Iraq last week, executing Iraqi soldiers and government workers and threatening to demolish Shiism’s most sacred shrines, Iraq’s Shiites suffered mostly in silence, maintaining a patience urged on them by their religious leaders through months of deadly bombings.

headline: Military to Let Enlistees Be Shorter and Stouter
abstract: The People’s Liberation Army will relax the physical restrictions for recruits in an effort to expand the pool of eligible enlistees and attract more highly educated candidates, a state-run newspaper reported.
lead_paragraph: China has spent years trying to streamline its military, the world’s largest by personnel count, but its latest modernization may see it swell a little. The People’s Liberation Army will be admitting new recruits who are slightly shorter and pudgier than their predecessors, the state-run China Daily reported on Tuesday.

headline: Daily Report: British Spy Agencies Are Said to Claim Right to Intercept Web Communications
abstract: Privacy groups say the government contends that data transmitted through foreign-based services like Facebook lacks the legal protection of domestic communication.
lead_paragraph: In a broad legal rationale for collecting information from Internet use by its citizens, the British government has reportedly asserted the right to intercept communications that go through services like Facebook, Google and Twitter that are based in the United States or other foreign nations, even if they are between people in Britain, Mark Scott reports.

headline: Lindsay Lohan Cheerleads for Jeremy Scott
abstract: Unlike Mr. Scott’s usual fan base, the actress was in place and on time for his Moschino show in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jeremy Scott’s fashion shows are infamous for their celebrity contingents, an audience bloc with a history of delaying proceedings past even the fashion world’s usual loose interpretation of timeliness. (At his Moschino debut in Milan in February, Rita Ora and Katy Perry were so delayed that their arrivals were greeted by boos from the photographers’ pit.) So it was all the more a surprise to see, at his debut men’s show for Moschino here Monday, a famous friend perched quietly — and punctually — front row.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on gun-violence research, workplace equality, genetically modified bananas, Iraqi compromise and casual-rents rules.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times reports dozens of school shootings have occurred in the 18 months since the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., and the public-health community still lacks necessary information on how to prevent gun violence. “And if pro-gun members of Congress have their way, it will stay that way,” the editorial board writes. Representative Jack Kingston, Republican of Georgia and head of the House subcommittee that sets the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention budget, has labeled efforts to understand the socio-psychological causes of gun violence as “propaganda” for “gun-grabbing initiatives.” The price of ignorance “is measured in tens of thousands of preventable deaths and avoidable injuries from guns, year in and year out,” the board notes. “Compared with that, $10 million for the C.D.C. to study the problem and propose solutions would be a small price to pay.”

abstract: It’s different the second time around, when you have money in your pocket and a win under your belt. How? For one thing, you go home for dinner.
lead_paragraph: There is a whopper of a myth that exists about so-called serial entrepreneurs. It is widely accepted that those who have built and sold a company once have a better chance of succeeding with their next venture.

headline: Morning Agenda: Argentina’s Court Loss Buoys Creditors
abstract: The Supreme Court hands Argentina two defeats. | A study puts insider trading suspicions into hard numbers. | Medtronic’s deal for Covidien has reignited the debate over inversions. | Alibaba reveals more information in an amended I.P.O. prospectus.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday handed two major defeats to the government of Argentina, which has been fighting with New York hedge funds over bonds that the country defaulted on in 2001. Along with putting Argentina at risk of another default, the setbacks could also make it harder in the future for a financially troubled country to cut a deal with its creditors to reduce its debt load, DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes. Argentina had asked the Supreme Court to overturn a lower court’s ruling that had required the country to pay back defaulted bonds held by the litigating hedge funds, known as holdouts.

headline: A Bookstore Owner Taps a Wound to Write a First Novel
abstract: Lisa Howorth, an owner of the beloved Square Books in Oxford, Miss., draws from a family tragedy to write her first novel, “Flying Shoes.”
lead_paragraph: In the opening pages of Lisa Howorth’s novel, “Flying Shoes,” her heroine, Mary Byrd Thornton, gets a phone call from a police detective. He has news: The unsolved 30-year-old murder of her brother is being reinvestigated. She picks up a glass-laminate dish, advertised as indestructible, and shatters it on the kitchen floor.

headline: In Performance: Greta Gerwig and Scott Shepherd of ‘The Village Bike’
abstract: The actors perform a scene from Penelope Skinner’s play at the Lucille Lortel Theater.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features the actors Greta Gerwig and Scott Shepherd in a scene from Penelope Skinner’s dark comedy “The Village Bike.”  The play centers on Becky (Ms. Gerwig), a pregnant young woman who moves to a small English town with her husband, only to embark on an adventurous but troubled affair with a local lothario, Oliver (Mr. Shepherd). In this scene, Becky and Oliver get acquainted, and there’s some awkward flirtation. The show, directed by Sam Gold for MCC Theater, continues through July 13 at the Lucille Lortel Theater.
