headline: Feeling For | Illesteva Shades You Design Yourself
abstract: The cult downtown eyewear brand is launching a customize-it-yourself option for three of its frames today.
lead_paragraph: In the four years of its existence, the New York-based eyewear and accessories brand Illesteva has made some noise with its collaborations, including House of Waris, the Webster boutique and Lou Reed. Lou Reed! How to follow up a partnership with the man who helped invent punk? Perhaps the only thing more punk than punk is the ethos of D.I.Y., and so today, the line — whose colorful, unisex shades have been sported by Beyoncé, Lady Gaga and Cara Delevingne — is unveiling a new custom sunglasses service. Using Illesteva’s website, users can select one of three frame styles, then choose from up to eight colors for the fronts and sides and match them up with one of up to nine lens varieties, including a polarized option. Like all of the brand’s offerings, the shades will be made in Italy or France. “I’ve never seen this offered in sunglasses before. I’m interested to see what color ways people will come up with,” says Daniel Silberman, the brand’s co-owner and designer. His decision to hand control over to his customers comes down to one of punk’s main tenets: self-expression. “Everyone wants to feel like they have something unique,” he says, “something that someone else doesn’t have.”

Estée Lauder, the American beauty behemoth that owns the likes of Clinique, Bobbi Brown and La Mer, has just created a new stand-alone men’s skin care group. It’s the first time the company has treated the segment as its own category.

headline: From Bach to Mavis Staples: The White Light Festival
abstract: Lincoln Center announces the lineup of its 2014 White Light Festival.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 edition of the White Light Festival, Lincoln Center’s annual exploration of spirituality in the arts, will include Peter Sellars’s staging of Bach’s “St. Matthew Passion,” a performance of Islamic and Sufi devotional music by the Rizwan-Muazzam Qawwali ensemble from Pakistan, a screening of Krzysztof Kieslowski’s 10-part film “The Decalogue” and a concert by Mavis Staples among its 28 presentations. The festival will run from Oct. 7 through Nov. 11.

headline: At the Cutting Edge of Gay Family Law
keywords: ['ADOPTIONS', 'ARTIFICIAL INSEMINATION', 'Families and Family Life', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Parenting', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Sperm']
abstract: In the past, second-parent adoptions have been standard in the gay community. But a court recently ruled that such adoptions were neither “necessary nor available” for gay married couples since a “presumption of parenthood” exists.
lead_paragraph: We always thought our story would be pretty typical: Boy meets girl; girl asks boy for sperm to impregnate her wife; boy relinquishes parental rights so girl can second-parent adopt. You know, just a run-of-the-mill beginning to your average American family.

headline: 7 Killed as Pakistan Police Clash With Preacher’s Followers
abstract: The deaths occurred after officers demanded the removal of blockades from roads leading to the headquarters of the preacher, Muhammad Tahir-ul-Qadri.

headline: Surge in Child Migrants Reaches New York, Overwhelming Advocates
abstract: Newly arrived children who illegally crossed the border with Mexico on their own are flooding community groups and shelters seeking help.
lead_paragraph: For more than a month, 16-year-old Cristian threaded his way from his home in rural Guatemala to the United States, hoping to reunite with his father, whom he had not seen in nearly four years. Guided by smugglers, he rode in cars, buses and trains, walked countless miles, dodged the authorities in three countries, hid out in dreary safe houses and went days at a time without food.

headline: Twin Tornadoes Leave Behind a Devastated Nebraska Town
abstract: While double tornadoes are not rare, the two that touched down around Pilger, Neb., were unusual in that both were large, meteorologists said.
lead_paragraph: PILGER, Neb. — The employees of the bank here in this small village in northeast Nebraska watched the skies darken late Monday as they handled the deposits and withdrawals. They felt the air thicken and get sticky as the humidity rose. Moments later, after reports of a funnel cloud southwest of town, they found themselves huddling in the bank vault.

headline: Should We All Learn to Code?
abstract: Some argue that understanding how to solve problems with computers is more important than learning any particular programming language, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: The idea that Americans must all learn to code or risk being left behind by the world economy has become so ubiquitous that it’s inspired a significant backlash. But some are saying what we need most isn’t coding proficiency per se but a broader understanding of how to use computers to approach problems.

headline: U.S. Seizure of Suspect in 2012 Benghazi Assault Ends Long Manhunt
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Commandos and F.B.I. agents descended on the outskirts of Benghazi just after midnight local time on Monday; grabbed Ahmed Abu Khattala, the suspect; and raced away, said those briefed on the operation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American commandos operating under the cover of night seized the man suspected of leading the deadly attack on the United States Mission in Benghazi, Libya, the government announced on Tuesday, ending a manhunt that had dragged on for nearly two years and inflamed domestic and international politics.

headline: Microsoft’s Surface Pro 3 Isn’t for Everybody
abstract: Users who mainly want a tablet that can sometimes be used a computer may be fine, but if you want to do intensive work, the Surface Pro isn’t the best.
lead_paragraph: FOR the better part of a month, I’ve been trying to replace the laptop that I use for my daily work, an Apple MacBook Pro, with Microsoft’s new tablet computer, the Surface Pro 3. I say “trying” because that’s what it has felt like; this is a machine that I’ve had to put a lot of work into adjusting to, in the hope that, at some point, I’d get used to it and see some kind of payoff.

headline: Drug Suspect Who Took Control of Police Car and Fled Is Found
abstract: Bryan McMenamin of Ridgewood, Queens, was rearrested nearly a day after escaping from two plainclothes narcotics detectives; one of them was injured.
lead_paragraph: The two men had been arrested, handcuffed and stuffed in the back seat of an unmarked police vehicle, a seemingly routine part of a drug investigation on Monday evening in Queens.

headline: As Justice Department Scrutinizes Local Police, Cleveland Is Latest Focus
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: A wide-ranging civil rights investigation into the Cleveland police is the latest in a series of federal interventions in police departments across the United States.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — As cries of “shots fired” shrieked from police radios, a caravan that grew to 62 patrol cars chased an old blue Malibu through 20 miles of this city’s streets and highways. The vehicle and its two occupants were surrounded in a school lot, and in a disorienting jumble of sirens and strobes, officers fired 137 rounds at close range.

headline: World Cup 2014: Mexico and Brazil Play to a 0-0 Draw
abstract: Brazil dominated much of the match against Mexico, but with four points each, both teams are in good position to advance from the group.
lead_paragraph: Brazil dominated much of the match against Mexico, but with four points each, both teams are in good position to advance from the group.

headline: Burberry Gives a Garden Party
abstract: It was the final afternoon of the men’s wear shows here in London and, as usual, Burberry would yield the biggest celebrity haul of any of the designers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Give us a smile please, Tom,” one of the paparazzi shouted at the actor Tom Felton (“Harry Potter”) as he stood awkwardly in the bright afternoon sunshine on Tuesday, waiting to go into the Burberry show in Kensington Gardens.

headline: World Cup 2014: Russia and South Korea Play to 1-1 Draw After Keeper's Blunder
abstract: Russia could not overcome a costly error by its goalkeeper and wound up settling for a 1-1 draw with South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Russia could not overcome a costly error by its goalkeeper and wound up settling for a 1-1 draw with South Korea.

headline: Northside Festival 2014
abstract: Scenes from the 2014 Northside Festival photo diary of Sandy Kim.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Northside Festival 2014 photo diary of Sandy Kim.

headline: China Sends Top Diplomat to Begin Talks With Vietnam
abstract: A senior Chinese official will meet with Vietnam’s deputy prime minister in the first high-level discussions since tensions between the countries escalated in May.
lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — A senior Chinese official will hold talks here on Wednesday with Vietnam about the contentious deep-sea oil rig stationed by China in disputed waters, the two countries announced Tuesday.

headline: Today in Small Business: Why Innovation Is Overrated
abstract: When brick-and-mortar businesses act like start-ups. When middle schoolers act like Avon ladies. And why deregulation doesn’t help entrepreneurs.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: ‘You’ve Done Everything You Can’
abstract: In the past, I’d never understood people who said they were done, who gave up on their dream of having their own genetic children. But as I thought of the future, I could not imagine going on.
lead_paragraph: We were sitting in the new French pastry shop in the souk waiting for The Call.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Aiming Beyond Film
abstract: The entertainment company is moving into YouTube, Netflix and even shopping malls, with a new take on the classic visit to Santa Claus.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Calif. — For months, DreamWorks Animation has been working on a prototype for a product it hopes will change how the world’s children meet Santa each Christmas. Code name: DreamHouse.

headline: Mistrial Is Declared in Malcolm Smith Corruption Trial
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Yiddish Language', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Several jurors said they could not extend their service to accommodate the translation of wiretapped conversations in Yiddish that prosecutors had failed to turn over promptly to the defense.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — Malcolm A. Smith, at times one of New York’s most powerful political officials as the majority leader and the minority leader of the State Senate, was granted a mistrial on Tuesday by a federal judge in his trial for bribery and wire fraud.

headline: Medtronic-Covidien Deal Rewards Just 2 Advisory Firms
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Complex mergers in recent years often have been an excuse to bring in extra investment bankers but the $43 billion Medtronic-Covidien deal bucked the trend, Antony Currie writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Investment bankers had a rude awakening over the weekend. A megamerger like the $43 billion cash and stock deal Medtronic and Covidien announced on Sunday often provides a feast for a raft of advisory firms. Not this time. The two medical devices companies are only using one each.

headline: Uber, American Express Partner for Loyalty Points
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Credit Cards', 'Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Mobile Applications', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The car service Uber is offering American Express Membership Rewards card holders the opportunity to earn points.
lead_paragraph: Much like our universe, options to earn loyalty points through travel are ever-expanding.

headline: China Keeps a Close Eye on Oil Interests in Iraq
abstract: As militants threaten to drag Iraq back into civil war, China National Petroleum Corporation, the largest state-owned energy company, anxiously monitors its substantial investments in the country.
lead_paragraph: As the violence of the American-led invasion of Iraq and the ensuing civil war ebbed after 2008, some analysts said that China had emerged as the big winner from the strife, at least in terms of oil interests. China National Petroleum Corporation, the largest state-owned energy company, had become the biggest foreign investor in the Iraqi oil industry. With a tolerance for risk and willingness to accept lower profits, C.N.P.C., as it is commonly called, won major government contracts and invested billions of dollars in Iraq.

headline: Image of the Day: June 17
abstract: A boy at Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, at the confluence of the Ganges River and Yamuna River fishing out coins offered by Hindu devotees using magnets.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week in 140 Characters
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: Highlights of our staff’s tweets from the spring 2015 men’s shows.
lead_paragraph: Here are highlights of our staff’s tweets from the spring 2015 men’s shows.

headline: Facebook Releases Slingshot for Self-Destructing Selfies
abstract: On Tuesday, Facebook rolled out Slingshot, a stand-alone app that lets users share photo and video messages that are then meant to disappear.
lead_paragraph: When Facebook ended negotiations to buy Snapchat last year, that did not mean the company stopped thinking about the disappearing photo messages that have made Snapchat so popular for casual conversations, especially among younger users.

headline: Valeant Tries New Tactics to Woo Shareholders of Botox Maker Allergan
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: Valeant Pharmaceuticals is planning to take a cash-and-stock exchange offer to Allergan shareholders, a move aimed at easing the path toward a merger deal.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals is planning to take an exchange offer to Allergan shareholders, as it moves ahead with its $53 billion hostile takeover attempt for the maker of Botox.

headline: Learning to Fly
abstract: The choreographer David Parsons’s signature work, “Caught,” has a soloist soaring through the air as if caught in a photograph.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer David Parsons’s signature work, “Caught,” has a soloist soaring through the air as if caught in a photograph.

headline: Bowe Bergdahl the Subject of Rival Films
abstract: The team that made “Zero Dark Thirty” — Kathryn Bigelow, Mark Boal and Megan Ellison — are competing with a Fox Searchlight project.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – To the competing films in development about Edward Snowden add another pair of projects on a hot-button political subject: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the recently freed Taliban prisoner of war.

headline: Car Owners Criticize Pace of G.M. Recall Repairs
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Demand has far surpassed production of parts, a concern that lawmakers are likely to bring up with the automaker’s chief this week at a hearing.
lead_paragraph: Four months after Melissa Miller’s car was recalled by General Motors for a deadly defect, she is still waiting for it to be fixed — and still driving it.

headline: He Can Fly, in a Flash, Right Before Your Eyes
abstract: “Caught,” a five-minute piece by David Parsons that stars a soloist soaring through the air and features lighting effects, is being presented by Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.
lead_paragraph: In 1982, David Parsons made his greatest choreographic discovery: He invented a way for a dancer to fly.

headline: Bathhouse ‘Dutchman’ Heads to Chicago
abstract: Rashid Johnson’s production first ran last year as part of the Performa 13 Biennial in an East Village bathhouse.
lead_paragraph: The artist Rashid Johnson’s production of “Dutchman,” which was staged last year as part of the Performa 13 Biennial in a true hothouse environment – the Russian and Turkish Baths on 10th Street in the East Village – is heading out on the road to another storied urban bathhouse.

headline: Vans and Ace Hotel Team Up for a Sleek Take on the Skateboarding Shoe
abstract: A new pair of all-black kicks, created exclusively for the hotel’s doormen and front-desk team, is now poised to hit the streets.
lead_paragraph: At the Ace Hotel Downtown Los Angeles, which opened earlier this year in what was once the United Artists building, the doormen and front-desk team have been outfitted with a fresh new set of kicks: a leather-and-canvas men’s lace-up designed in collaboration with Vans, the skate-shoe company which has previously teamed up with everyone from Hello Kitty to Kenzo. The black-on-black version of the classic Era model is the ultimate grown-up sneaker, equally at home in the hipster-chic, movie-set-like hotel or on the SoCal streets. Starting this weekend, the shoes are also available in limited quantities in the gift shop; next Monday, they’ll be sold online.

headline: Knicks Changing, With or Without Anthony
abstract: Phil Jackson’s message to Carmelo Anthony, who is deciding whether to opt out of his Knicks contract, has been that the team collective will take precedence over the individual.
lead_paragraph: Phil Jackson is not one to deal in absolutism. He is pragmatic but whimsical. Basketball is his honored career, not his spiritual calling.

headline: At the Fragrance Foundation Awards, the Sweet Smell of Success
abstract: Wtih Coco Rocha and Carine Roitfeld as co-chairwomen for the evening, there was glamour in the air.
lead_paragraph: Wtih Coco Rocha and Carine Roitfeld as co-chairwomen for the evening, there was glamour in the air.

headline: Live Video from State Department Briefing on Suspect Arrested in Attack on Benghazi Compound
abstract: Officials from the State Department answer questions about the arrest of a suspect in the attack on the compound in Benghazi on Sept. 11, 2012.
lead_paragraph: State Department officials answer questions about the arrest of a suspect in the attack on the compound in Benghazi on Sept. 11, 2012.

headline: How to Choose a Hospice
abstract: The president of the American Hospice Foundation offers some questions to ask when selecting hospice care.
lead_paragraph: The American Hospice Foundation, an advocacy group that has worked to improve care for the dying and bereaved since 1995, will close its doors at the end of this month. The foundation has lost too much funding to continue, its founding president and chief executive Naomi Naierman told me in an interview. As a parting gift, however, Ms. Naierman — a hospice executive for more than 30 years — has passed along some consumer advice.

headline: Hearing Indicates Easy Path for Obama’s Housing Nominee
abstract: President Obama’s nominee for housing secretary, Mayor Julián Castro of San Antonio, fielded a series of mostly friendly questions from members of the Senate Banking Committee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s nominee for housing secretary, Mayor Julián Castro of San Antonio, fielded a series of mostly friendly questions on Tuesday from members of the Senate Banking Committee, signaling a smooth path to confirmation in the coming weeks.

headline: A World Premiere From Patti Smith and Her Daughter at Crossing the Line Festival
abstract: The Crossing the Line festvial, presented by the French Institute Alliance Française, is to open on Sept. 8.
lead_paragraph: “Killer Road,” a work by the rock iconoclast Patti Smith, her daughter Jesse Smith and the ambient composer-performers of Soundwalk Collective, is one of three productions that will have their world premieres as part of Crossing the Line, the multidisciplinary festival presented by the French Institute Alliance Française (FIAF).

headline: Finally, an Executive Order on LGBT Workplace Discrimination
abstract: The president is preparing to bar federal contractors from discriminating on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity.
lead_paragraph: Workplace discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity “needs to stop,” President Obama said last November, “because in the United States of America, who you are and who you love should never be a fireable offense.” But November came and went, as did 2013, and the first quarter of 2014, without the president heeding the rising calls for executive action.

headline: U.S. Calls on Europe to Ease Limits on Gene-Altered Food
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Genetic Engineering']
abstract: But there continues to be deep resistance to bioengineered products in the European Union — or to easing various other agricultural trade protections.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The top American agriculture official on Tuesday called on the European Union to do more to ease restrictions on gene-altered food and feed crops if it hoped to reach a trans-Atlantic trade pact.

headline: Obama Plans Protected Marine Area in Pacific Ocean
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: The president says he will use his executive authority to create the world’s largest protected marine area to defend diverse habitats from harmful activities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an effort to protect diverse habitats of coral reefs, whales, dolphins, sharks, sea turtles and numerous fish species from commercial fishing and other activities, President Obama announced Tuesday that he intended to use his executive authority to create the world’s largest marine protected area in the south-central Pacific Ocean.

headline: Scoop: A Glimpse Into the NYTimes CMS
abstract: A look at Scoop, the CMS that powers NYTimes.com and its mobile apps.
lead_paragraph: You know the importance of technology to the future of journalism has become a widely accepted fact when a prominent editor decides to join a new company because of its content management system. That’s what Ezra Klein told The New York Times about his decision to leave The Washington Post for Vox Media, a digital publisher with a fancy, custom-built CMS. Klein couldn’t quite describe what made the Vox system so special, but the fact that a journalist said he loved, let alone even tolerated, his CMS was all you needed to know that the world has changed.

headline: Defensive Shift Finds Some Believers in College Baseball
abstract: Texas Tech’s Tim Tadlock, the national coach of the year, is a rarity in the college game: He trusts his young arms to pitch to a defense.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — It is not that big a deal, Texas Tech Coach Tim Tadlock said. Sometimes he overshifts his infield against left-handed pull hitters, putting three players on the right side of second base like major league teams do for David Ortiz of the Boston Red Sox. Sometimes he moves defenders a few feet, subtly, all in the hope of getting an out.

headline: Brazil vs. Mexico: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Both teams won their first games, so a win is not vital. Brazil will expect one nonetheless, while Mexico would be ecstatic with a draw.
lead_paragraph: Both teams won their first games, so a win is not vital. Brazil will expect one nonetheless, while Mexico would be ecstatic with a draw.

headline: Stepping Into the Role of the Ringmaster
abstract: At A Voce Madison and BLT Fish, daring acts to follow.
lead_paragraph: When a restaurant is founded by a chef whose kitchen acrobatics make us sit up and notice, it can be confusing for everybody when that chef moves on. Will the replacement be a caretaker cook mimicking the style that made the place exciting? Or will the successor be a creative whiz who can make the menu jump through a new set of hoops?

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week Street Style
abstract: Looks range from dapper to experimental.
lead_paragraph: Looks range from dapper to experimental.

headline: An ’80s Warhol Brings $30 Million at Art Basel
abstract: The 1986 Warhol “fright wig” silkscreen painting was sold to an unnamed private American buyer.
lead_paragraph: BASEL, Switzerland — An Andy Warhol self-portrait priced at more than $30 million led the rush of early sales at the V.I.P. preview of Art Basel, the world’s pre-eminent fair devoted to modern and contemporary art. The 45th edition of this event, held at a time when auction prices of contemporary art are booming, features hundreds of international galleries.

headline: Spy Photographers Capture Camouflaged Mini F-150
abstract: A Ford source confirms that the toy truck seen at the Dearborn Development Center is a Power Wheels interpretation of the next-generation F-150 pickup.
lead_paragraph: It’s not unusual for automotive spy photographers to pop up with images of heavily camouflaged prototype vehicles, typically taken from the other side of a fence. This week, though, the photographers shot something a bit smaller: a tot-size F-150 pickup.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week Spring 2015 Accessories
abstract: Statement pieces and staples from the men’s collections in London.
lead_paragraph: Statement pieces and staples from the men’s collections in London.

headline: Roma Boy, 16, Is Comatose After Beating Outside Paris
abstract: The teenager was abducted from a shantytown and beaten last week by as many as a dozen people in an attack that drew condemnation from politicians and rights groups.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A teenage Roma boy lay in a coma in a hospital here on Tuesday after being abducted from a shantytown and beaten last week, apparently in retaliation for what his assailants thought were thefts he committed in a nearby housing project, the French authorities said.

headline: The 9th Annual Jazz Age Lawn Party
abstract: The photographer Christina Paige captured images of New Yorkers sporting Gatsby-era duds on Governor’s Island last weekend.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the photo diary of Christina Paige.

lead_paragraph: To Graze: A Culinary Fleet Reaches an Island

headline: In Competing Offers for Alstom, France’s Government Holds Sway
abstract: Rival bids for Alstom seem fated to be decided less on business merits and more on attractiveness to President François Hollande’s government, which fears losing one of France’s industrial crown jewels.
lead_paragraph: In business, there is a right way and a wrong way. But as General Electric has been learning, there is also a French way.

headline: Met Opera Cancels Simulcast of ‘Klinghoffer’
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera has said that it decided that a simulcast of John Adams’s “The Death of Klinghoffer” could stir up anti-Semitism.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera announced on Tuesday that it was canceling plans to simulcast John Adams’s “The Death of Klinghoffer” this fall to cinemas around the world, drawing praise from some Jewish groups who object to the opera, but laments from the work’s fans and a warning from its composer that the decision promotes “intolerance.”

headline: Koch Group Forms ‘Super PAC’ as 2014 Races Near
abstract: The Freedom Partners Action Fund provides an outlet for money the Kochs and other donors are preparing to funnel into the 2014 election.
lead_paragraph: A political nonprofit group at the center of the philanthropic and political network overseen by Charles and David Koch has formed a new “super PAC,” according to documents filed earlier this month with the Federal Election Commission, providing a new outlet for the hundreds of millions of dollars the Kochs and their fellow donors are preparing to funnel into the 2014 election.

headline: Brazen Figure May Hold Key to Mysteries
abstract: The apprehension of Ahmed Abu Khattala may finally begin to address some of the persistent questions about who carried out the Libya attack and why.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Ahmed Abu Khattala was always open about his animosity toward the United States, and even about his conviction that Muslims and Christians were locked in an intractable religious war. “There is always hostility between the religions,” he said in an interview. “That is the nature of religions.”

headline: AnonyWatch: When Unnamed Sources Are Flat Wrong
abstract: Assessing what happened in a story about Phil Mickelson.
lead_paragraph: In a blistering column this week, the Reuters media critic Jack Shafer takes The Times to task for using a particular kind of anonymous source — the kind who turn out to be wrong.

headline: How to Help Myanmar’s Muslim Minority
abstract: For people who want to do something to aid the Rohingya people living in 21st century concentration camps, here are a few ideas.
lead_paragraph: It’s a question I’ve heard over and over again from readers who learn about the persecuted Rohingya Muslim minority in Myanmar. For a couple of weeks now, I’ve been asking myself the same thing: “What can we do to help?”

headline: The Wonking Dead
abstract: Arguments that eat your brains.
lead_paragraph: The Commonwealth Fund is out with a new report comparing advanced-country health care systems, and the (mostly pre-Obamacare) US system looks very bad indeed: vastly higher spending per capita than anyone else, with worse results.

lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago, the news raced through the newsroom.

lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: A Scrapped Aphex Twin Album Finds New Life on YouTube
abstract: Fans of Richard D. James, who release his music as Aphex Twin, take a test pressing of a 1994 album, raise some money and put it on YouTube.
lead_paragraph: Fans of the electronic music composer Richard D. James, who releases his music under the name Aphex Twin, have come up with an elaborate plan to get some of his unreleased music out there. When members of We Are the Music Makers, an online electronica forum, learned that a collector was selling one of five known acetate test pressings of “Caustic Window” – an Aphex Twin album that Mr. James produced in 1994 but scrapped – they sprang into action.

headline: Doublethink in Punditry
abstract: On being cynically self-righteous.
lead_paragraph: A belated reaction to Mark Thoma’s comments on Barry Ritholtz and the issue of pundit accountability. Mark writes:

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: SolarCity Is Acquiring a Start-Up, Silevo, to Build Panels
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Solar Energy', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: SolarCity, Elon Musk’s fast-growing provider of rooftop systems, is buying Silevo for at least $200 million in stock and plans a Buffalo factory.
lead_paragraph: SolarCity, the fast-growing provider of rooftop solar electricity systems, is moving into the panel manufacturing business, acquiring a start-up and planning to build one of the world’s largest module factories in Buffalo, executives said on Tuesday.

headline: David Henry Hwang and Lynn Nottage Joining Columbia Playwriting Faculty
abstract: The playwrights David Henry Hwang and Lynn Nottage are joining the faculty of Columbia University’s School of the Arts.
lead_paragraph: The playwrights David Henry Hwang and Lynn Nottage will join the faculty of Columbia University’s School of the Arts, the school’s dean, Carol Becker, has announced, thus raising the profile of an M.F.A. program in playwriting that has existed since 1965 but in recent years has had only two professional playwrights, Charles L. Mee and Kelly Stuart, on its full-time faculty.

headline: Ramen: A Quick Fix for the Soul
abstract: Egg, butter and American cheese take Roy Choi’s ramen to the next level.
lead_paragraph: It tells you something about the philosophy of Roy Choi that one of the recipes in his 2013 book, “L.A. Son,” doesn’t seem at first glance like a recipe at all. You make some instant ramen. Slide an egg into the hot broth, then some butter.

headline: Putting Fun in Fatherhood
abstract: What does being a fun dad really mean? From moonwalks to early-morning sandwich-making, our readers share their stories of dads who put the fun in fatherhood.
lead_paragraph: As every dad knows, fatherhood isn’t all fun and games. But our recent Father’s Day question, “Are you a fun dad?” did prompt a number of amusing stories. We heard about dads who moonwalk, sing ZZ Top songs, play “name that potato,” dress up as the Grim Reaper on holidays and find various other ways to connect with their sons and daughters.

headline: Does TV Ignore Female Sexuality?
abstract: Many have criticized “Game of Thrones” for its depictions of female pain, but one writer says the show and others like it neglect female pleasure, too, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: Much criticism of “Game of Thrones” — and, indeed, of cable TV in general — has focused around its depictions of violence against women. But at Salon, Lili Loofbourow points to another problem: Much of television may offer not just too many scenes of brutality toward women but also too few designed to make them feel good.

headline: Israelis Start #BringBackOurBoys Campaign
abstract: Israelis trained to promote their country’s image online started a campaign last week, using a hashtag inspired by Nigerian activists, after three teenagers disappeared on their way home from religious schools in the occupied West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Wednesday, 5:44 p.m. | Inspired by the success of Nigerian activists who used a simple hashtag to trigger a global outpouring of sympathy for schoolgirls kidnapped by Islamist militants, a group of Israelis trained to promote their country online started a #BringBackOurBoys campaign last week after three teenagers disappeared on their way home from religious schools in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Roy Choi, King of L.A. Food Trucks, Moves On to a Hotel
abstract: A star in his own right, Mr. Choi went from slinging tacos in traffic to helping conceptualize a new hotel in Koreatown.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Roy Choi stood on the roof of the Line, a new hotel in the same Koreatown neighborhood he used to roam around as a child, and surveyed the surrounding blocks like a ship’s captain scanning the ocean waves.

headline: A Smart Way to Skip College in Pursuit of a Job
keywords: ['E-Learning', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Vocational Training', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The “NanoDegree,” an online collaboration of AT&T and Udacity, may offer a reasonable shot at using the web to democratize higher education.
lead_paragraph: Could an online degree earned in six to 12 months bring a revolution to higher education?

headline: Russia vs. South Korea: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Russia could not overcome a costly error by its goalkeeper and wound up settling for a 1-1 draw with South Korea.
lead_paragraph: With Belgium as the favorite to win this group and Algeria a longshot to advance, the winner of this match should be in good position to qualify for the knockout round.

headline: On View | Lee Ufan’s Contemplative Sculptural Installations at Versailles
abstract: The South Korean-born, Japan-based artist has installed a series of large-scale sculptures and land art pieces that create a dialogue with the palace’s legendary gardens.
lead_paragraph: For the past several years, the Chateau de Versailles has invited different contemporary artists to exhibit works on its grounds, including Takashi Murakami and, controversially, Jeff Koons. Starting today, the palace will be hosting 10 new pieces by the South Korean-born, Japan-based artist Lee Ufan, nine of which have been installed outdoors in the vast gardens designed by André Le Nôtre for Louis XIV.

headline: Torn Between Competing Perspectives on Iraq
abstract: The collapse of Iraq reveals some ugly truths about the real emotional stakes the United States had in the wars there and in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Is this what 1975 felt like?

headline: With Business Initiative, Obama Aims to Show He Can Act Without Congress
abstract: The White House unveiled a program that will provide entrepreneurs access to more than $5 billion in advanced manufacturing equipment.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — President Obama acted as a pitchman for entrepreneurs on Tuesday afternoon, fielding questions from small-business owners in an attempt to highlight creative ways to bolster manufacturing.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: At the World Cup, Doomsday Predictions Give Way to Smaller Hiccups in Brazil
abstract: With each of the 12 host cities now having hosted at least one game, it seems that organizers are toeing the line between normal logistical problems and a more irritating lack of preparedness.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — One stadium would not be ready on time. Another would not be ready at all. Violent street protests would threaten fans and upstage everything. Airport and subway strikes would strand tens of thousands of visitors.

headline: Kids’ Activities, Sonoma Style (New Museum Included)
keywords: ['Museums', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Attractions for children in Sonoma County include a new museum, the county fair, and activities at several wineries.
lead_paragraph: With more than 400 wineries, Sonoma County, Calif., might be known as an oenophile destination, but the region is making a big push to also draw in families with several attractions and events.The Children’s Museum of Sonoma County, for example, opened in March and has an outdoor nature education area that’s representative of the local landscape with a redwood grove, a mini version of the Russian River, and wetlands.

headline: War’s Hell, Especially for Editors
abstract: Michael Hastings’s posthumous novel focuses on the American news media’s complicity in the rush to war in Iraq and on the withering of venerable brands like Time and Newsweek.
lead_paragraph: What was meant to be Michael Hastings’s first novel, “The Last Magazine,” is his final and only one. This talented young journalist and war correspondent died last year in a car crash at 33. This book, which he’d apparently told few people about, was rescued from his laptop.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Iraq, Cambodia, India and France.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Iraq, Cambodia, India and France.

headline: Appeals Court Affirms Sherlock Holmes Is in Public Domain
abstract: A judge’s ruling harshly rejected arguments from the estate of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has rejected a copyright appeal brought by the estate of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, opening the way for writers, filmmakers and other creators to make free use of Sherlock Holmes, his sidekick Watson and any elements of their story that appeared in Conan Doyle works published prior to Jan. 1, 1923.

headline: Giants’ Beason Avoids Surgery, but Status for Opener Is in Doubt
abstract: Jon Beason, who became one of the Giants’ defensive leaders late last season, will not need surgery to correct the ligament tear and small fracture in his right foot sustained last week.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants middle linebacker Jon Beason will not need surgery to correct the ligament tear and small fracture in his right foot sustained last week in an off-season practice, the team announced Tuesday. But Beason’s foot will be immobilized for six weeks, which will precede an additional, undetermined period of recovery. His availability for the season opener Sept. 8 in Detroit remains in doubt.

headline: Put Language Aside, Then Let the Music Take Time to Speak
abstract: The bands Poor Rich Boy and DakhaBrakha performed at the Global Beat Festival on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: Nina Garenetska makes an unlikely rapper. Along with the two other women in the Ukrainian band DakhaBrakha, which performed on Monday night at Brookfield Place’s Winter Garden, she was wearing a white lace wedding dress, a tall black lamb-fur hat and half a dozen beaded necklaces. Ms. Garenetska was also holding her cello, painted with bright geometric designs.

headline: Lawmakers Introduce Bill to Ban Paid Prioritization

headline: Putting Duct Tape to Yet Another Use: Opera
abstract: The soprano Ariadne Greif ripped off strips of duct tape that bound her naked torso as part of Opera Cabal’s powerful production of “Atthis” at the Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: The Kitchen in Chelsea is not a big performance space. So when Ariadne Greif, the soprano starring in Opera Cabal’s production of Georg Friedrich Haas’s “Atthis,” came to the front of the stage on Thursday evening, stepped out of her dress and began to tear off the metallic-looking strips of duct tape that girded her naked torso, even the last row of audience members got a close-up of what must be one of the most searingly painful and revealing operatic performances in recent times.

Besides the terrible suffering inflicted on these animals, there is a growing fear that they could soon become extinct.  The best way to stop this killing is to stop the market.

lead_paragraph: The coronation of Crown Prince Felipe de Borbón as the new Spanish king and his wife, Letizia, as queen consort on Thursday is generally being greeted, anti-monarchists aside, as a new start for Spain; a smart move on the part of Felipe’s father, King Juan Carlos; and the introduction of a new royal “fashion icon” — this last even though the event itself is billed as an austere affair, without the usual pomp and elaborate gowns a coronation implies.

headline: Saving, and Splurging, in Guyana
abstract: With basic costs low, the Frugal Traveler indulges in a rare bit of liberal spending, going on a boat tour and taking a flight to the country’s most celebrated destination.
lead_paragraph: Where I come from, we don’t put ice in our Guinness. Or Red Bull. But in the gold-mining frontier town of Bartica, Guyana, I became a (temporary) convert.

headline: A Gleam of Renewal in Struggling Detroit
abstract: Corktown, once a desolate strip just west of downtown, is regarded by locals as a bright example of what rebuilding can do.
lead_paragraph: Corktown, once a desolate strip just west of downtown Detroit, is a serious hotbed of new restaurants, bars, hotels and more, all sitting in the shadow of one of the most glaring icons of Detroit’s demise, the skeleton of the old train depot, Michigan Central Station. In this ailing city, people look at Corktown as a bright example of what rebuilding can do. The resurgence of Corktown, originally an Irish enclave, began with the 2005 opening of Slows Bar B Q. These days, thanks to low rents and a consumer base hungry for things to do, the area is now a vibrant community of passionate restaurateurs, stylish shopkeepers, meticulous coffee connoisseurs and craft cocktailers.

headline: Restaurant Report: Opposite Mess Hall in Bangkok
abstract: With its signature cocktails and small inventive plates, Opposite has become a stylish spot for those looking for an unpretentious but excellent meal.
lead_paragraph: If you spot a Bangkok chef or two dining at Opposite Mess Hall, don’t be surprised. With its signature cocktails and small inventive plates inspired by cuisine from all over Asia and beyond, this ingredient-focused restaurant and bar has become a popular post-service spot, a kind of stylish mess hall for those looking for an unpretentious but excellent meal.

headline: Don’t Fight in Iraq and Ignore Syria
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Obama’s thinking on ISIS is confused and will lead to more problems.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — FOR the last two years, many people in the foreign policy community, myself included, have argued repeatedly for the use of force in Syria — to no avail. We have been pilloried as warmongers and targeted, by none other than President Obama, as people who do not understand that force is not the solution to every question. A wiser course, he argued at West Point, is to use force only in defense of America’s vital interests.

Then came the blow of the economic downturn and rising gas prices, with units plummeting 58 percent over the next three years, to 165,700 in 2009.

They have become the new reality in the Western United States.

headline: F.D.A. Proposes Rules for Listing Risks on Social Media
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday proposed new rules that would require drug and medical device makers to disclose risks of products on social media platforms.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday proposed new rules that would require drug and medical device makers to disclose risks, along with benefits, of products on social media platforms, even when the allowable length of messages is very limited as on Twitter. Until now, many medical product makers have refrained from using Facebook and Twitter to talk about their products because they were unsure of the rules or whether the F.D.A. would censure them, said Lori Leskin, a lawyer at Kaye Scholer. The rules would also permit, but not require, companies to correct misleading information posted by third parties about their products.

headline: As LED Industry Evolves, China Elbows Ahead

Hundreds of factories built all over eastern China, often with lavish clean energy subsidies from state-owned banks and local governments, were operating at half capacity. The share prices of LED manufacturers were plunging.

He was supposed to be marking off yardage in anticipation of his caddying duties for the 69th United States Women’s Open, which will get underway on Thursday.

headline: Daniel Keyes, Author of ‘Flowers for Algernon,’ Dies at 86

lead_paragraph: Daniel Keyes, the author of “Flowers for Algernon,” the story of a man with an I.Q. of 68 who temporarily becomes a genius after surgery — a book that inspired the film “Charly,” starring Cliff Robertson — died on Sunday at his home in South Florida.  He was 86.

headline: Nature, Opaque and Mysterious, in All Its Seasons

lead_paragraph: Four of the five sections of “From a Firefly’s Eye,” a suite of dances presented by Zendora Dance Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Fishman Space over the weekend, took their titles from the seasons. But the show was no pastoral, no pretty nature calendar, and the music was definitely not Vivaldi.

headline: City’s Love Affair With the Summer Sprinkler Bursts Forth
abstract: Sprinklers, perhaps more ubiquitous in New York than in any other city, are often gussied up in fanciful designs: a sea turtle, a ship, even a subway token.
lead_paragraph: Just after 2 p.m. Tuesday, with the temperature bursting 90 degrees, Sariya Rodriguez, age 20 months, stepped into the sprinkler section of Printer’s Park in the Longwood section of the Bronx. The water jets — set in the ground in a circle — were resting at the moment, but there were ample puddles for her to stamp with her pink plastic sandals. Suddenly, the water sprung from the jets. Sariya, who had never been in that part of the playground before, now was encircled with dancing streams of water. Her eyes and mouth opened in surprise. She looked up at her mother, Yajaira Rodriguez. Then they both laughed.

headline: A Balancing Act on Iraq
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: As President Obama considers his options, he has struck just the right cautious note so far.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has, so far, struck the right note on Iraq, where Sunni extremist militants are seizing territory and threatening the existence of the state. He has been cautious — emphasizing the need for political reform in Iraq and reaching out to other countries that could have an impact on its fate.

headline: Lawmakers Skeptical on Emails and I.R.S.
keywords: ['Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'E-Mail']
abstract: Republicans investigating the possible targeting of Tea Party groups ridiculed reports of computer crashes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Six additional Internal Revenue Service workers lost emails sought by congressional investigators when their computers crashed, investigators announced Tuesday, escalating Republican suspicions that the employees may have been trying to cover up political targeting of Tea Party organizations.

headline: Bill to Reduce Speed Limit to 25 M.P.H. Gains Favor
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Speed Limits and Speeding']
abstract: The bill would deliver perhaps the most significant change yet under Mayor Bill de Blasio’s Vision Zero plan to eliminate traffic deaths in the city by 2024.
lead_paragraph: A proposal to lower the New York City speed limit to 25 miles per hour cleared a critical hurdle on Tuesday, as a bill in the State Senate won the support of the de Blasio administration and some, though not all, traffic safety advocates.

headline: The Limits of the Fed
abstract: The slow and steady withdrawal of stimulus has not been accompanied by a slow and steady improvement in economic conditions.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is expected to conclude its two-day meeting on Wednesday afternoon with another $10 billion scale-back of its monthly bond purchases. At that pace, the bond-buying program — an effort to stimulate the economy by lowering long-term interest rates — will be over by December at the latest.

headline: Following in a Writer’s Rhythms
abstract: “Gertrude Stein Saints!” sets some of this author’s characters, real and invented, to music at Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: In “Everybody’s Autobiography,” Gertrude Stein explained why she preferred saints to martyrs. “A really good saint does nothing,” she wrote. “Anybody is more interesting doing nothing than doing something.”

headline: A Woman’s Place at a Pivotal Moment
abstract: Cherry Jones plays a character who runs a bed-and-breakfast that becomes an early shelter for battered women in the earnest, thoughtful drama “When We Were Young and Unafraid.”
lead_paragraph: The year is 1972, and a new age of feminism is dawning as women grope to find voices to match their evolving identities. Well, some of them are groping. The female characters in “When We Were Young and Unafraid,” Sarah Treem’s debate-driven new play at City Center Stage 1, appear to have little difficulty articulating their viewpoints or making sure that we know exactly where to place them on a shifting scale of political consciousness.

headline: What You’d Need To Play
abstract: Amy Johnson racks up points with us.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — In 1938, an architect named Alfred Mosher Butts created a word game that evolved from an earlier one he called “Lexiko.” The new game, which criss-crossed letter tiles to form words, used a distribution and points system that he developed after doing a letter-frequency analysis of various sources, including The New York Times.

headline: Talks on Medical Marijuana Bill as Time Starts to Run Out in Albany
abstract: With only days left on the legislative calendar, state lawmakers and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo are ensconced in negotiations over a new medical marijuana program.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — For a drug known for tranquillity, marijuana has become a very tense issue here.

headline: Woman Sentenced to 41 Months for Fake Water Park Plan
abstract: Liliana Trafficante stole more than $1 million from investors through a fictional proposal to build a water park in Goshen, N.Y., for foster children.
lead_paragraph: An Orange County, N.Y., woman who duped investors out of more than $1 million through a fictional proposal to build a water park for foster children was sentenced on Tuesday to 41 months in prison.

headline: What to Do With the Twins?
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Weighing all the options and the complicated dynamics at play in Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: There is much talk right now about America teaming up with Iran to push back the coalition of Sunni militias that has taken over Mosul and other Sunni towns in western Iraq and Syria. For now, I’d say stay out of this fight — not because it’s the best option, but because it’s the least bad.

headline: With War at Doorstep, Iran Sees Its Revolutionary Guards in a Kinder Light
abstract: The well-documented mass killings by Sunni militants in Iraq have caused ordinary Iranians to rethink their views of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — They came to celebrate the short life of Ali Reza Moshajjari, a local boy from a south Tehran neighborhood and apparently the latest Iranian victim of the escalating sectarian conflict in neighboring Iraq and in Syria.

headline: Stamp Sells for a Record $9.5 Million
abstract: An 1856 stamp known as the One-Cent Magenta from British Guiana sold at Sotheby’s for the highest price ever paid for a stamp at auction.
lead_paragraph: A tiny square of very old red paper with cut corners — a one-cent postage stamp from the 19th century — sold for $9.5 million on Tuesday, the most ever paid for a stamp at auction, but $500,000 short of the auction house’s $10 million to $20 million presale estimate.

abstract: President Obama is considering a targeted, highly selective campaign of airstrikes against Sunni militants in Iraq, similar to counterterrorism operations in Yemen, rather than an aerial bombardment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is considering a targeted, highly selective campaign of airstrikes against Sunni militants in Iraq similar to counterterrorism operations in Yemen, rather than the widespread bombardment of an air war, a senior administration official said on Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Suggests Getting Tougher With Syria on Chemical Weapons Deadline
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The U.S. representative to the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons said a simple condemnation of Syria wasn’t enough as the country is about to miss a deadline for the destruction of its chemical munitions.
lead_paragraph: The United States suggested on Tuesday that the global organization responsible for overseeing the ban on chemical weapons would have to take more assertive action than a simple condemnation concerning Syria, which will miss a June 30 deadline for the destruction of its chemical munitions and has been accused of using chlorine-gas bombs in its civil war.

headline: Tanaka’s Bold Brushstrokes Paint Blue Jays Into Corner
abstract: Though Masahiro Tanaka lasted only six innings, he allowed just two runners to reach scoring position after the first, struck out 10, and gave the Yankee offense time to find its rhythm.
lead_paragraph: Masahiro Tanaka’s latest gem, on Tuesday against the Toronto Blue Jays, materialized a little differently from most of his other performances. It seemed to develop slowly, like a mosaic. It was not until the later innings that the full form of his mastery took shape.

headline: Cutting the Poor Out of Welfare
keywords: ['Welfare (US)', 'Poverty', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Reform and restructuring have left more than 600,000 households living in extreme poverty.
lead_paragraph: Over the past three decades, Congress has conducted a major experiment in anti-poverty policy. Legislators have restructured benefits and tax breaks intended for the poor so that they penalize unmarried, unemployed parents — the modern-day version of the “undeserving poor.” At the same time, working parents, the aged and the disabled are getting larger benefits.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Reversing a potentially groundbreaking ruling, a federal appeals court this week said the government need not show a defense lawyer classified materials related to the national-security surveillance of his client.

abstract: The White House pushed back against criticism from conservative lawmakers who said the suspected leader of the 2012 Benghazi attack should be tried by the military.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Conservative lawmakers on Tuesday sharply criticized the Obama administration’s decision to prosecute the suspected leader of the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya, in the civilian criminal justice system, arguing that he should be questioned and tried by the military.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Finale Recap: Morton’s Fork: They’ve Come Undone
abstract: “Fargo” denizens meet their fates.
lead_paragraph: In the criminal wilderness, invading “Fargo,” people align themselves with good or evil, as protector or predator. Few fall in between.

headline: Sudan: Attack Ravages Hospital
abstract: A hospital run by the humanitarian group Doctors Without Borders was heavily damaged by the Sudanese Air Force in an attack on the village of Farandalla in the South Kordofan region, the group said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A hospital run by the humanitarian group Doctors Without Borders was heavily damaged by the Sudanese Air Force in an attack on the village of Farandalla in the South Kordofan region, the group said Tuesday. The group’s head of mission, Brian Moller, expressed shock, “especially since it was clearly identified with a flag and a cross on the roof.” One hospital staff member was hurt, as were five villagers, the group said. Rebels in the region have been fighting the government in Khartoum since 2011.  In recent weeks, the Sudanese government has stepped up its offensive in the region. The Sudanese Army’s press officer could not be reached for comment.

headline: Exercise and the ‘Good’ Bugs in Our Gut
abstract: Frequent exercise may influence our weight and overall health by altering the kinds of organisms that live inside of us, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Being physically active may encourage beneficial germs to thrive in your gut, while inactivity could do the reverse, according to an innovative new study. The findings suggest that, in addition to its other health benefits, frequent exercise may influence our weight and overall health by altering the kinds of organisms that live inside of us.

headline: Brazil: Biden and Rousseff Meet
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Dilma Rousseff met Tuesday with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. as Brazil and the United States moved to improve relations.
lead_paragraph: President Dilma Rousseff met Tuesday with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. as Brazil and the United States moved to improve relations. Ties were strained last year by revelations of surveillance of Ms. Rousseff and other Brazilian officials by the National Security Agency. Mr. Biden told reporters in Brasília that their conversation about the spying was “candid,” while emphasizing the potential for improving ties. He also handed over to Ms. Rousseff declassified documents related to Brazil’s military dictatorship, which seized power in a 1964 coup supported by the United States. Ms. Rousseff is a former Marxist guerrilla who was tortured by agents of the dictatorship. She said this month in an interview that she was prepared for a thaw in ties with Washington.

headline: Canada: Carbon Monoxide Affects Scores at Day Care
keywords: ['Day Care Centers', 'Carbon Monoxide', 'Child Care', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: About 70 children and 10 adults were overcome by carbon monoxide at a day care northwest of Montreal on Tuesday and were rushed to the hospital by ambulances and school buses.
lead_paragraph: About 70 children and 10 adults were overcome by carbon monoxide at a day care northwest of Montreal on Tuesday and were rushed to the hospital by ambulances and school buses. Health and fire officials said at a news conference that no one had lost consciousness during the episode in St.-Eustache, Quebec. But the five children with the most severe symptoms were transferred to a larger hospital for further examination. The source of the gas was unclear, but fire officials are investigating the cleaning machinery used in the day care center the previous night.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 18, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 18, 2014.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 3:05 P.M. (Cinemax) SAVAGES (2012) Two Southern California marijuana dealers — Chon (Taylor Kitsch), a cynical combat veteran, and Ben (Aaron Johnson, above right, with Mr. Kitsch and Blake Lively), a soulful Berkeley graduate — and their gorgeous significant other, O (Ms. Lively), take on Mexican traffickers in what A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called “Oliver Stone’s feverish, fully baked, half-great adaptation of Don Winslow’s ferocious and funny drug-war novel of the same name.” The film, he added, “is a daylight noir, a western, a stoner buddy movie and a love story, which is to say that it is a bit of a mess. But also a lot of fun, especially as its pulp elements rub up against some gritty geopolitical and economic themes.”

headline: N.C.A.A. Begins Its Turn in Antitrust Case Brought by Athletes
abstract: The director of women’s athletics at the University of Texas testified that paying athletes for the use of their likenesses or allowing them to share in revenue was “incongruous” with the university’s approach to amateur sports.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Christine Plonsky, the director of women’s athletics at the University of Texas, took the stand Tuesday morning in federal court here in an effort to persuade a judge that the N.C.A.A. and its biggest athletics programs are not the commercialized profit centers they have been accused of being by a string of witnesses during the past week and a half.

headline: Georgia Inmate Is Put to Death in First U.S. Execution Since Botched Procedure
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Marcus A. Wellons, convicted in the 1989 rape and murder of a teenage girl, was the first inmate put to death in the United States since a botched execution in Oklahoma seven weeks ago.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Ga. — Marcus A. Wellons, who was convicted in the 1989 rape and murder of a teenage girl, was executed at a Georgia prison on Tuesday, becoming the first inmate put to death in the United States since a botched execution in Oklahoma seven weeks ago prompted renewed questions about capital punishment.

headline: Mets, Stifled by Cardinals, Waste Solid Start by Niese
abstract: Jon Niese allowed three earned runs or fewer for an 18th consecutive start, but a struggling Mets offense and two questionable plays in the field by Daniel Murphy muddied Niese’s night.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The way he pitches, Jon Niese is often overlooked. He is not imposing. He does not throw particularly hard. His strikeout rate is not high. And pitching for the Mets, because of their low-octane offense, he is often deprived of wins.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Citic Resources, a Chinese state-owned commodities trader, said on Wednesday that it had been unable to locate more than 100,000 tons of alumina at a port in northeast China that is the focus of a commodities fraud investigation.

headline: Malaysia Searches for Survivors After Boat Sinks
abstract: An official said the vessel was believed to have been carrying 97 Indonesian migrants back to their home country — 60 people were rescued, five bodies found and 32 remain missing.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Five people died when an overloaded wooden passenger ship carrying 97 Indonesians back to their home country sank off the west coast of Malaysia early Wednesday, Malaysian officials said, and search-and-rescue teams were working into the night looking for 32 others who remained missing.

headline: 1939: France’s Last Public Guillotining

headline: Betrayal in Charlie Rangel’s Harlem?
abstract: Rangel has been the face of the district for four decades. Then an ambitious preacher named Michael Walrond came along. Now they’re fighting over the future of America’s most symbolic black neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: St. John’s Baptist Church, in the Sugar Hill section of Harlem, is a modest redbrick building, discernible from the buildings on its block by two white Corinthian columns and a large, illuminated plastic cross hanging from the second story. Back in the civil rights era, the church housed a thriving congregation, many of them African-Americans who had fled the South. Its rolls have since dwindled to about 250, but Harlem is a neighborhood eternally preoccupied with its past, and St. John’s remains a place where local power brokers — and former power brokers and aspiring ones, too — gather to debate issues and anoint leaders.

headline: Taking Care of People and Pictures in Hong Kong
abstract: A Hong Kong nanny adept at street photography prompts comparisons to Vivian Maier. But Xyza Cruz Bacani wants to be known on her own merits.
lead_paragraph: A stream of images from Hong Kong caught Rick Rocamora’s attention on Facebook: black and white street scenes, with dramatic light and compositions that ranged from kinetic to serene. The fact that the photographer, Xyza Cruz Bacani, was from the Philippines — like Mr. Rocamora — intrigued him, though he was reluctant to contact her.

headline: Setting Sour Words Aside, Li Keqiang Begins Visit to Britain
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Royal Family']
abstract: The prime minister’s visit comes after a period of cool political relations between China and Britain.
lead_paragraph: After an exchange of unflattering comments between the Chinese and British sides threatened to overshadow Prime Minister Li Keqiang’s trip to Britain, sunny skies greeted him on Tuesday, the first full day of his visit. Following a meeting with Queen Elizabeth II in the morning, the second-ranking Chinese leader met with Prime Minister David Cameron at 10 Downing Street for talks and lunch with business leaders.

headline: Japan Outlaws Possession of Child Pornography, but Comic Book Depictions Survive
keywords: ['Child Pornography', 'Law and Legislation', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: The move brought Japan in line with the rest of the developed world, but Parliament left a loophole for the nation’s sometimes sexually explicit manga comics.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Yielding to years of pressure to fall in line with the rest of the developed world, Japan’s Parliament outlawed the possession of child pornography on Wednesday. But the new law left untouched the nation’s popular and sometimes sexually explicit manga comics as well as other portrayals of young girls as objects of sexual desire.

headline: Insurgency in Iraq Widens Rivals’ Rift
keywords: ['Sunni Muslims', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: After President Hassan Rouhani of Iran declared readiness to defend Iraq’s Shiite holy sites, Saudi leaders issued a barely veiled admonishment not to intervene.
lead_paragraph: Tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia, Islamic rivals of the Middle East, appeared to escalate on Wednesday over the Sunni extremist insurgency convulsing Iraq, as President Hassan Rouhani of Iran declared readiness to defend Iraq’s Shiite holy sites with force and Saudi leaders issued a barely veiled admonishment not to intervene.

headline: Daily Report: AT&T and Udacity Create Online ‘NanoDegree’ Program
abstract: The degree, offered after six to 12 months of online study, may provide a reasonable shot at using the web to democratize higher education.
lead_paragraph: This week, AT&T and Udacity, an online education company founded by the Stanford professor and former Google engineering whiz Sebastian Thrun, announced something meant to be very small, Eduardo Porter reports: the “NanoDegree.”

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on ocean conservation, the Brownback amendment, Middle East cooperation, public records and digital dispatch markets.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times welcomes the news that President Obama will double the area of protected waters in the Pacific Ocean. “The United States does not have an Amazon basin,” the editorial board writes, “but it has the watery equivalent, a paradise of turtles and sharks, seals and dolphins, coral reefs and giant clams, frigate birds and boobies.” Mr. Obama is expanding on the legacy of his predecessor, George W. Bush — a fact The Times finds heartening: “Environmental conservation has a long bipartisan history in this country. These remote waters are a part of America most citizens may never see, but they should be thankful that presidents, of both parties, had the foresight to protect them.”

headline: Extremists Attack Iraq’s Biggest Oil Refinery
abstract: Witnesses said the refinery in Baiji had fallen to attackers from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, but some Iraqi officials asserted that fighting was still going on in the facility.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Refinery workers, witnesses and an Iraqi Army officer reported the seizure of Iraq’s biggest oil refinery by Sunni extremists on Wednesday after army helicopter gunships failed to repel their attack. But other Iraqi officials, including the commander of the garrison defending the refinery in Baiji, asserted that fighting was still going on inside the extensive facility, shut down by the violence.

headline: Ackman’s S.E.C. Filing on Bid for Botox Maker Allergan Contains an Error

lead_paragraph: When it comes to technology, Washington needs to learn how to fail smaller.

headline: Push Polls, Defined
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Asking negative questions about an issue or candidate does not, in itself, make it a push poll.
lead_paragraph: “Push polls” — which are not really polls at all — are often criticized as a particularly sleazy form of negative political campaigning. Voters pick up the phone to hear what sounds like a research poll. But there is no effort to collect information, which is what a legitimate poll does.

headline: U.N. Report Details Casualties in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: A total of 356 people were known to have been killed since mid-April and thousands have fled their homes amid rising violence, insecurity and crime, the report said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Hundreds of people have been killed and thousands have fled their homes amid rising violence, insecurity and crime in areas of eastern Ukraine that are under the control of pro-Russia armed groups, the United Nations said on Wednesday.

headline: Wrestling With Heartache in a Birthplace of Soul
abstract: The performance by the British soul singer Sam Smith was a showcase for his vocal calisthenics and achingly beautiful songs.
lead_paragraph: At this point, the Apollo Theater exists largely in totemic form, a repository of credibility available for loan to those seeking to cloak themselves in its legacy, whether out of homage or insecurity. Its meaning is fungible, whatever its occupant for the night needs it to be.

lead_paragraph: The Federal government reached a $968 million settlement on Tuesday with SunTrust Banks over questionable mortgage practices, underscoring how state and federal authorities have been targeting banks beyond Wall Street, Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. But even as the government reached one settlement, its talks to resolve mortgage issues with one of the nation’s largest banks, Citigroup, grew increasingly tense and veered toward a lawsuit.
