headline: Palestinian Leader Pledges to Hold Abductors of Israeli Teenagers to Account
abstract: Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, said he was working with the Israelis to find the youths and punish their captors.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Wednesday strongly denounced the kidnappers of three Israeli teenagers who went missing in the West Bank six days ago and said he would hold the perpetrators accountable.

headline: Soft Money’s Squishy Political Influence
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Political Action Committees', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: A report looks at how outside spending can transform a campaign in subtle and not-so-subtle ways.
lead_paragraph: To congressional campaign workers, the groups that can raise and spend unlimited donations can seem like unpredictable wedding guests: You don’t know when they’ll show up, what they’ll bring or whether their presence will prove a welcome distraction or a disaster.

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Spring/Summer 2015 London Men’s Shows
abstract: A peek at what some of the peacocks in London were wearing.
lead_paragraph: A peek at what some of the peacocks in London were wearing.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Situation in Iraq Worsening
abstract: With the situation in Iraq getting more tense by the day, President Obama appears closer to a decision about how to respond.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning from Washington.

headline: Obama and Lawmakers Meet to Discuss Iraq Action
abstract: White House officials said the president did not rule out the possibility of coming to Congress for a vote to support his actions, depending on what he decides to do.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and congressional leaders on Wednesday privately confronted the politically delicate question of whether Mr. Obama would be required to ask Congress for permission to take military action against Sunni fighters in Iraq, but emerged from an hourlong Oval Office meeting with different views of what was said.

headline: Europe May Be in a Recession (Still)
abstract: The economists charged with making the determination say it’s unclear if the economy is expanding or merely taking a pause.
lead_paragraph: Is the European economy expanding, or is it in recession? Turns out, even the people whose job it is to decide aren’t sure. And their reasoning shows why the economic situation seems so perilous in Europe, even though its economy isn’t clearly shrinking. In fact, part of their hesitation to call the end of the recession stems from their fear that policy makers may not be sufficiently concerned about the state of the economy.

headline: It’s So Immersive, You Even Get Wet
abstract: If you’re looking for high-energy fun, head to Union Square, where the high-flying acrobats from “Fuerza Bruta: Wayra” will splash around in giant pools over your head.
lead_paragraph: Theater doesn’t really have an equivalent of the summer blockbuster. If anything, the home of the biggest, showiest spectacles — Broadway — is usually quiet during the hot months, with few new openings. But if you’re looking for high-energy fun and empty-headed action accessible to anyone, head to Union Square, where the high-flying acrobats from “Fuerza Bruta: Wayra” will splash around in giant pools over your head. From the makers of “De la Guarda,” this show, which opens at the Daryl Roth Theater on Friday, is an expanded version of a production that ran in New York from 2007 until January, with 20 new minutes added.

headline: Boston Bombing Suspect Seeking Change of Trial Venue
abstract: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev argue that he will not get a fair trial in Boston in the attack on the Boston Marathon that killed three people and wounded more than 260.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, accused in last year’s marathon bombings, said Wednesday that their client could not receive a fair trial in Boston or elsewhere in the state, and asked for the trial to be moved to Washington.

headline: Spain’s Incoming King Takes Over a Throne Heavy With Political Tension
abstract: A lengthy recession has heightened demands for an overhaul of political parties and institutions tainted by corruption, including the monarchy.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — This year, while visiting a telecom conference in Barcelona, Crown Prince Felipe worked the room as the heir apparent to the Spanish throne, smiling and glad-handing the crowd, until he ran into a Catalan businessman who refused to shake his hand because of the Spanish monarchy’s opposition to a planned independence referendum in Catalonia this fall.

headline: In the Euro Zone, Recession Is Not Quite Over, Economists Say
abstract: Growth is still too weak and unemployment is too high, leading economists say, adding that at best, the recession that began in 2011 is hibernating.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Many people probably thought the euro zone recession ended about a year ago when output began growing again. Not so, a group of leading economists argued this week.

headline: The Democrats United?
abstract: Why party unity doesn’t necessarily protect presidential coalitions.
lead_paragraph: Vox’s Matthew Yglesias, seconded by my colleague Paul Krugman, has written a seven-point response to my argument that the Democratic coalition is more fragile, and more dependent on Hillary Clinton’s unique strengths, than many people (mostly liberals) tend to think. Yglesias’s rebuttal focuses on the Democratic Party’s apparent lack of deep policy divisions, which he regards as the main reason why there’s so little opposition to Clinton at the moment. “It is impossible,” he writes, “to mount a coherent anti-Clinton campaign because there is no issue that divides the mass of Democrats.” There’s no equivalent of the intra-Democrat war over the Iraq War that gave us Dean v. Kerry and than Obama v. Clinton; the neoliberal/populist debate over Wall Street is muddled and complicated; there’s unanimity on the need to tackle inequality; the education reform debate is real but doesn’t matter enough at the federal level to shape presidential politics; and the party’s demographic diversity coexists with increasing ideological conformity. Then as his parting point, he notes that polarization and partisan rancor make it hard to imagine either political coalition truly dissolving any time soon: The collapses of the past, “where one party’s candidate gets utterly blown away … simply can’t happen under modern conditions.”

headline: Pro-Democracy Media Company’s Websites Attacked
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The websites of Next Media, which publishes Apple Daily, an independent Hong Kong newspaper often critical of the Chinese government, were offline for hours in the largest Internet attack the company has experienced.
lead_paragraph: Next Media, which publishes Apple Daily, an independent Hong Kong newspaper often critical of the Chinese government, saw the largest attack ever against the company’s websites on Wednesday, taking the group’s websites offline for hours.

headline: What’s on Your New York City Reverse Bucket List?
abstract: New York can be a city with as many gripes as highlights. Tell us what you don’t want to do in New York City before you die.
lead_paragraph: Future comments on this post have been closed. We have published a selection of our favorite reverse bucket list items from readers here.

headline: A Darker View of the Age of Us – the Anthropocene
keywords: ['Earth', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Optimism', 'Pessimism', 'Sustainable Living', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Divergent views on prospects for a “good” Anthropocene — this era of a human-dominated planet.
lead_paragraph: I alerted a batch of scholars and scientists focused on climate change and sustainable development to my taped talk on “Paths to a ‘Good’ Anthropocene” at the annual meeting of the Association for Environmental Studies and Sciences.

headline: Barra Faces Scrutiny in House Over G.M. Recalls
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Mary T. Barra, before a House panel for a second time, faced sharp questioning from members skeptical of the carmaker’s internal investigation into recall delays.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mary T. Barra, chief executive of General Motors, walked into a crowded House hearing on Wednesday with her high-powered lawyer at her side, confident that his exhaustive internal investigation about a deadly defect would convince lawmakers that G.M. is taking safety seriously.

headline: Just How Were Those Underwater Babies Photographed?
abstract: The June 15 Look features children from 4 months to 22 months during infant survival swim training in Kissimmee, Fla. They were photographed by Seth Casteel, who specializes in animal photography and is publishing a book called “Underwater Puppies” in September.
lead_paragraph: What better way to welcome summer’s arrival than with pictures of happy babies underwater? The June 15 Look features children from 4 months to 22 months during infant survival swim training in Kissimmee, Fla. They were photographed by Seth Casteel, who specializes in animal photography and is publishing a book called “Underwater Puppies” in September. Here, Casteel talks about what babies and dogs have in common when they’re all wet.

headline: Valeant Takes New Step to Pressure Botox Maker Into Sale
abstract: Valeant Pharmaceuticals officially opened up its exchange offer to Allergan shareholders, offering $72 and 0.83 of a share of Valeant stock for each Allergan share. The offer is now worth about $51 billion.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:07 p.m. |

headline: A Glimpse of Syrian Lives Ravaged by War in Homs
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Social Media']
abstract: The New York Times bureau chief in Beirut, Anne Barnard, shared some of her experiences during a recent visit to Homs, Syria, via Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Anne Barnard, the Beirut bureau chief for The New York Times, traveled to Syria recently and reported her experiences in Damascus and Homs via Twitter. Her social media dispatches provided a rare view into the dire circumstances in Syria where the three-year conflict has killed an estimated 160,000 Syrians and left millions displaced. And she shared some poignant reactions to the devastation there.

headline: Right Out of Hollywood, a Witness to History
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Movies', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Television']
abstract: The actor Richard Beymer campaigned for civil rights and shot film in Mississippi in 1964 that appears in the documentary “Freedom Summer.”
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1964, Richard Beymer — the actor who a few years earlier had made a splash playing Tony in the film of “West Side Story” — furiously drove his Austin-Healy from Los Angeles to rural Mississippi. He was going to join the hundreds of young people heading there, mostly white students from the North, who would become part of the audacious civil-rights campaign known as Freedom Summer.

headline: St. George, S.I.: Framed by the Harbor
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The historic neighborhood of St. George, Staten Island, offers a wide variety of homes and views of New York Harbor.
lead_paragraph: In praise of St. George, a historic neighborhood on Staten Island that gazes on New York Harbor, residents invariably mention the free ferry to Manhattan. They often cite the affordability of a place where one-bedroom apartments can cost less than half of what they go for in pricier parts of the city. And they might even point out the wondrously out-of-place look of some blocks, with fanciful Victorians on steep hills that can feel cut-and-pasted from San Francisco.

headline: Jay Leno to Receive Mark Twain Prize for Humor
abstract: The former “Tonight” show host is the 17th recipient of the annual prize.
lead_paragraph: Have you heard about this? Have you seen this? Jay Leno, the doggedly populist comedy monologist and former host of the “Tonight” show, will be the next recipient of the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, the prize’s organizers said Wednesday.

headline: Daring Deeds
abstract: Nick Bertozzi’s graphic novel “Shackleton” follows the explorer and his crew on his third attempt to reach the South Pole.
lead_paragraph: In Nick Bertozzi’s graphic novel “Shackleton,” the great man who between 1901 and 1921 embarked on four attempts to reach the South Pole is first depicted in a moment of total failure. So sick with scurvy that he can scarcely lift his head from his pillow — let alone pull a loaded sledge — Shackleton is ordered back to England, forced to abandon Robert Falcon Scott’s Discovery expedition. But he is determined to return to the Antarctic, despite his wife’s entreaties (“The children are growing so quickly”!) and the claims of common sense. Though it’s easy to miss in Bertozzi’s telling, Shackleton went back about 5 years later, leading the Nimrod expedition, which came within 97 miles of reaching the South Pole. He managed to secure funding for a third attempt in August 1914, on the eve of the First World War. It is this famed adventure that is the focus of “Shackleton.”

headline: Charges Against Simon and Brickell Are Dropped
abstract: Disorderly conduct charges against Paul Simon and Edie Brickell were dropped by prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: The disorderly conduct charges that were brought against Paul Simon and Edie Brickell after a domestic dispute in late April were dropped by prosecutors in a Norwalk, Conn., courtroom on Tuesday. Mr. Simon and Ms. Brickell, who had made a court appearance when the charges were brought, did not appear to hear them dismissed, The Associated Press reported.

headline: HelloFresh, a Meal Delivery Start-Up, Raises $50 Million
abstract: The new round of financing, led by Insight Venture Partners and a Russian firm, comes as more competitors aim to tap the popularity of home cooking by delivering fresh ingredients to consumers.
lead_paragraph: The race for dominance in the dinner-kit delivery business — where companies ship out packages of fresh ingredients for specific recipes, ready for customers to turn into home-cooked meals — is intensifying.

headline: Latinos Onscreen, Conspicuously Few
abstract: Although Latinos constitute 17 percent of the United States population, their cultural presence is limited, and where present, is often stereotyped.
lead_paragraph: If you went to the movies in 1946, when Latinos constituted barely 3 percent of the American population, you might have caught Carmen Miranda, reportedly the highest-paid woman in the world at the time, dancing with her improbably tall fruit hat. By the 1950s, Desi Arnaz graced network TV as a star of “I Love Lucy.”

headline: Redskins Lose Ruling on Trademarks, but Fight Isn’t Over
abstract: The United States Patent and Trademark Office said “a substantial composite of Native Americans found the term Redskins to be disparaging.”
lead_paragraph: For years, the N.F.L. and the Washington Redskins have defended the team’s name by claiming that it is a sign of honor and bravery, not a slur. When critics disagreed, the team pointed to a survey showing that a majority of Native Americans supported the name.

headline: Cherries Go Savory, Sweet and Boozy
abstract: They can be in every part of a meal, including a cocktail.
lead_paragraph: They can be in every part of a meal, including a cocktail.

abstract: The Netherlands is virtually assured to make the knockout stage, although that would change should Australia somehow pull off a shocker here. For the Socceroos, a point in any of their matches would be a triumph.
lead_paragraph: The Netherlands is virtually assured to make the knockout stage, although that would change should Australia somehow pull off a shocker here. For the Socceroos, a point in any of their matches would be a triumph.

lead_paragraph: WETA, the Washington, D.C., public broadcaster, is expected to take over ownership and control of “PBS NewsHour” on July 1 from the program’s longtime owner, MacNeil/Lehrer Productions, the station announced Wednesday. The plates, which were originally issued from 1963-69, will be made with a reflective finish that complies with state laws. The plates will be available in nine to 12 months. (Hemmings Daily)

headline: How to Build a Better Neighborhood
abstract: The group Better Block is proving that improvised, cheap D.I.Y. weekend block parties can jump-start transformations to more people-centered urban areas.
lead_paragraph: A great public place gives residents of a neighborhood a sense of belonging, pride, connection and beauty. But too many neighborhoods have no such place. Some have been destroyed by recession, with shuttered businesses and boarded-up buildings. Others are simply soulless, built for cars, not people, featuring strip malls that require driving instead of places for residents to walk, bike, play or gather.

headline: A Retailer and Vintner Recalls Her Bohemian Hamptons Upbringing
abstract: Joey Wölffer, founder of the Styleliner and co-owner of Wölffer Estate Vineyard, remembers the good old days on the South Fork and shares her favorite places to shop and eat there today.
lead_paragraph: Joey Wölffer, 32, the founder of the mobile shopping truck the Styleliner and co-owner of Wölffer Estate Vineyard, recalls the Hamptons of her childhood as a very different place: “miles and miles of potato fields” and “a low-key vibe inspired by artists, poets and writers.”

headline: Is This the Beginning of the End of the Redskins’ Team Name?
abstract: A new trademark ruling undermines the Washington owner Daniel Snyder’s stated case for not making a change.
lead_paragraph: We can only guess the exact volume and color of the steam coming out of Daniel Snyder’s ears right about now. Wednesday morning, the United States Patent and Trademark Office canceled the trademark for the Washington Redskins, the pro football team that Mr. Snyder owns — and that he has steadfastly refused to rename, amid accusations that its mascot is racist.

headline: Candidate’s Protest Clouds Afghan Vote-Counting for President
abstract: Abdullah Abdullah accused his opponent, Ashraf Ghani, and President Hamid Karzai of fraud in the runoff vote, but the next steps are unclear.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan’s presidential election was cast into crisis on Wednesday as the candidate Abdullah Abdullah announced a boycott of the electoral process, accusing his opponent and President Hamid Karzai of engineering huge fraud in the runoff vote on Saturday.

keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Concentration Camps', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Extradition', 'Guards']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The 89-year-old Johann Breyer shuffled unsteadily into a federal courtroom in Philadelphia on Wednesday morning, using a cane for support as he sank slowly into a chair at the defense table.

headline: The ISIS Advance Provokes the West and Arab States
abstract: The incursion of militants into Northern Iraq has instigated arguments on military action and governance in Washington and the Middle East, JAKE FLANAGIN writes.
lead_paragraph: As the Islamic State of Syria and Iraq, or ISIS, advances in Iraq, many eyes are trained on Washington and on the governments of Mesopotamia. Two questions are being hotly debated: First, will the United States take military action to prop up a fragile government it left in place after a decade of battle and more than 4,000 casualties? And, at a higher level, what does ISIS’s rise say about the prospects of an effective governance ever being established in the region?

headline: Detroit Rolls Out New Model: A Hybrid Pension Plan
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Government Employees', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: If it succeeds, the city’s cost-cutting hybrid pension plan could be a model for solving government budget crises across the country.
lead_paragraph: In the face of Detroit’s tumultuous bankruptcy proceedings, in which multiple parties are quarreling to protect their interests, the city and its unions have quietly negotiated a scaled-back pension plan that could serve as a model for other troubled governments.

headline: Arguing About the Truth of Disruption
abstract: “Disruption,” a shorthand that supposedly explains technology’s cheaper, faster, downmarket effect on our world, has been like a gospel for Silicon Valley. But suddenly, writes ANNA NORTH, critics divided over whether the business theory holds up at all.
lead_paragraph: “Most big ideas have loud critics,” writes Jill Lepore in The New Yorker. “Not disruption.”
