abstract: Abdullah Abdullah, a candidate for Afghanistan’s presidency, said he suspended work with the country’s electoral bodies and asked officials to stop counting votes because of widespread fraud.
lead_paragraph: Abdullah Abdullah, a candidate for Afghanistan’s presidency, said he suspended work with the country’s electoral bodies and asked officials to stop counting votes because of widespread fraud.

headline: A Gilded Monument Is Mysteriously Shedding Its Brand-New Gold
abstract: The William Tecumseh Sherman statue in Central Park, which began peeling only a few months after it was regilded, will undergo further repair this fall.
lead_paragraph: Crazing. You know what it is if you’ve ever looked at your grandparents’ chinaware and discerned a web of hairline cracks fracturing the glaze.

headline: App Smart | Going Green
abstract: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that can help you adopt environmentally sensible habits in your daily life.
lead_paragraph: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that can help you adopt environmentally sensible habits in your daily life.

headline: For Ideas on How to Live Greener, Think Mobile
abstract: Environmentally aware apps can help a user with tasks like recycling, making a home more energy-efficient and purchasing everyday items.
lead_paragraph: SMARTPHONES and tablets may not seem to be designed with the environment in mind, being made of complex layers of plastics, metals and electronics, with chemical batteries. But apps may help you adopt environmentally sensible habits in your daily life.

headline: BBC Anchor Who Delighted in Blistering Politicians Steps Down
abstract: The “Newsnight” anchor, one of Britain’s best-known broadcasters, was not exactly known for deferring to the lawmakers who appeared on his TV program.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Famed for his combative questions, disdainful delivery and lack of deference, Jeremy Paxman, one of Britain’s best-known broadcasters, on Wednesday made his last appearance on the TV program he has dominated for a quarter of a century.

headline: MoMA to Host Bjork Retrospective Next Year
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art is planning a full-scale exhibition of Bjork’s own work and her collaborations with artists, photographers and designers.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art will present what it is calling a full-scale retrospective of the Icelandic rock composer, singer and otherworldly fashion-plate Bjork next year. The exhibition, which the museum announced on Wednesday, is being organized by Klaus Biesenbach, the museum’s chief curator at large. The retrospective will run from March 7 to June 7, 2015.

headline: France Sees Double Standard in U.S. Prosecution of BNP, but Justice Is Weak
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The randomness and lack of transparency in its prosecution of corporations opens the Justice Department up to legitimate criticism and conspiracy theories, Jesse Eisinger writes in The Trade column.
lead_paragraph: Events in the Middle East and Ukraine demonstrate that the United States can’t always be the world’s policeman. But there is one arena where it is still the top cop on the block: corporate law enforcement.

headline: Amid the Tombstones, a Look Back at Life
abstract: Green-Wood Cemetery is the setting for a production of Thornton Wilder’s “Our Town.”
lead_paragraph: Given Thornton Wilder’s specification that “Our Town” be presented in minimalist fashion, you wonder what he would have made of Brooklyn’s majestic Green-Wood Cemetery as a theatrical setting. There is no curtain, of course, in this presentation by the Green-Wood Historic Fund of Wilder’s drama, only the wind rushing through the tall trees and the jets streaking overhead and the glittering spires of Manhattan in the distance. It doesn’t get more urban Americana than this.

headline: YouTube to Block Videos From Some Indie Labels
abstract: The move comes as the company plans to start up a new subscription service that will compete with streaming music services like Spotify and Beats.
lead_paragraph: Soon to disappear from YouTube: videos by Vampire Weekend, the Arctic Monkeys and perhaps hundreds of other independent musicians.

headline: Report on New York City’s Underground Infrastructure
abstract: The office of Mayor Bill de Blasio issued a report on the city’s underground infrastructure on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The office of Mayor Bill de Blasio issued a report on the city’s underground infrastructure on Wednesday.

headline: Fire Dept. Is Now Responding to All Gas-Odor Calls
abstract: New York City residents that smell natural gas should now call the Fire Department, not Consolidated Edison. The city believes that the Fire Department will provide faster responses, thereby averting potential disasters.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s Fire Department has started responding to all reports of gas odors that the city receives, a significant change in policy put into effect in the wake of an explosion in East Harlem in March that killed eight people.

headline: Google Ready to Comply With ‘Right to Be Forgotten’ Rules in Europe
abstract: By the end of June, a team, led by the search company’s legal department, will start removing web links in Europe for some users that have made online requests.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Your right to be forgotten on the Internet is almost here.

headline: Bachfest Celebrates Monteverdi Choir’s 50th Anniversary
abstract: The Father’s Day timing of the concert by John Eliot Gardiner and his Monteverdi Choir and English Baroque Soloists was fitting but coincidental.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — If ever there was a composer to be celebrated on Father’s Day, it is Bach. Of his 20 children, 10 died in infancy or early childhood, but that still left his hands full. And though inhumanly busy with composition, performance and teaching, he took an active hand in the children’s upbringing and education.

headline: Can’t Fake the Funk
abstract: Kenard Bunkley has an instinct for comfort and his eye on Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In its small confines between the Fort Greene and Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhoods in Brooklyn, Clinton Hill is home to multimillion-dollar historic brownstones and towering housing projects. The area is a mix of young professionals, Pratt Institute art students and locals whose families have lived in the area for generations.

headline: Porsche Tops J.D. Power Initial Quality Study for Second Consecutive Year
abstract: In a survey of more than 86,000 new vehicle owners, J.D. Power found the number of problems this year to be higher.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 J.D. Power Initial Quality Study found that new vehicle owners experienced more problems with their vehicles than the previous year’s respondents, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: Image of the Day: June 18
abstract: Dmitry Rogozin, deputy prime minister of Russia, is on a two-day official visit to India.

headline: Today in Small Business: Banking on Belts
abstract: A successor to the Cronut. How to turn a Facebook page into an online store. Outsourcing mistakes to avoid.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Iraq Under a Colder Eye
abstract: Looking for a solid ground in a quagmire.
lead_paragraph: Let me be clear, as the president would say: Like many better-informed people, I have no definite idea what our current strategy should be in Iraq, and unlike some of them I’m willing to admit it. In the same lukewarm/conflicted way that I supported the 2007 surge, I’m semi-persuaded by the Dexter Filkins argument (amplified here by Reihan Salam) that a residual American force might have made a difference in the current mess — constraining the Maliki government’s sectarian impulses, stiffening up the Iraqi Army’s backbone, giving us better intelligence about ISIS’s development. But that’s pure hindsight, and looking forward most of the strategic options being discussed look somewhat fantastical, from the invasion 2.0 favored by the editors of The Weekly Standard (in which “special operators, and perhaps regular U.S. military units” would rout ISIS, and then somehow re-join together what Maliki has very deliberately put asunder) to the ally-with-Tehran option advanced as the thinking internationalist’s alternative (which even its advocates acknowledge requires lending U.S. resources to the cause of a “strengthened expansionary Iran”), to the “targeted” air strikes reportedly being contemplated by the administration (which, as a certain general with some in-theater experience just pointed out, would risk turning the U.S. military into “the air force for Shia militias”).

headline: In Israel, Masks With a Past
abstract: Masks in an exhibit at the Israel Museum in Jerusalem are more than 9,000 years old.
lead_paragraph: It is a tiny yet haunting exhibit: just 12 stone masks, primitive faces with only holes for eyes, small gaping mouths without lips and uneven, spiky teeth.

headline: With Blood Pressure, Lower Is Not Always Better
abstract: In treating people with high blood pressure, most experts believe that “the lower the better.” But a new study suggests that there are limits beyond which there is no benefit.
lead_paragraph: In treating people with high blood pressure, most experts believe that the lower the better. But a new study suggests that that there are limits beyond which there is no benefit.

headline: Vegetarian Meals Are a Success, But the Real Win Is Learning to Plan Ahead
abstract: The meat-loving Ruder family loved the lasagna, the Big Bowl with Greens, and the beans. The family’s primary cooked loved planning ahead for leftovers.
lead_paragraph: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist and cookbook author, is working with the Ruder family (Renee, her husband, Chris, and their three daughters, ages 11, 9 and 7) to help these meat lovers adopt a plan of eating two vegetarian meals a week without feeling deprived; and to take advantage of a C.S.A., a community-supported agriculture program basket often filled with foods to which they are unaccustomed. This week, they tried a Big Bowl with Black Beans, Greens, Avocado and Salsa Fresca.

headline: Select Home Care Weighs New Wage and Labor Regulations
abstract: A California-based home care company is pondering three choices in meeting new state and federal work rules regarding its caregivers.
lead_paragraph: SELECT HOME CARE, based in Westlake Village, Calif., offers 24-hour nonmedical care to elderly clients in California, Nevada, Utah, Colorado, Oregon and Texas. It has nine offices, 500 employees and more than $10 million in annual revenue.

headline: Listen Up | A Danish Duo Gets Moody With Ukuleles
abstract: Acoustic rockers Death Has No Dominion explore the rooftops of Paris in a new video.
lead_paragraph: In their early 20s, Rasmus Bak and Bjarke Niemann bonded over a shared love of ambient music. Nearly 10 years later, on a whim, the Danish pals embarked on a journey from Copenhagen to upstate New York, where they spent seven days with 20 bottles of wine and two ukuleles in the Rubber House, a desolate black building covered with neoprene sheeting once owned by the actor Willem Dafoe. There, isolated from the outside world and surrounded by woods, their new musical project, Death Has No Dominion, was born.

headline: Delaware Museum Faces Sanctions From Directors’ Group
abstract: One painting from the museum’s collection was sold Tuesday at auction for $4.89 million. Others may be offered on the private market.
lead_paragraph: The Delaware Art Museum, which recently began to sell works of art to help dig its way out of debt incurred by a 2005 expansion and renovation, has been sanctioned by the Association of Art Museum Directors, which said the museum’s actions “violated one of the most basic and important” principles of a collecting institution.

headline: Britain’s Thaw With Iran, Coming at a Crucial Juncture, Could Be Useful to Allies
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: London has been gradually moving to restore full diplomatic relations with Iran, whose role in the region is crucial amid the violence in Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With the election of a relatively moderate president in Iran and the rise of radical Sunni fighters in Syria and Iraq, Britain is pressing ahead to improve relations with Iran and reopen its embassy in Tehran.

headline: How Should Select Home Care Adjust to New Wage and Labor Regulations?
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Home Health Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Small Business', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The company’s chief executive has been rethinking his business model. Entering 2014, he believed he had three options.
lead_paragraph: We’ve just published a case study about Select Home Care, based in Westlake Village, Calif., which offers 24-hour nonmedical care to elderly clients in California, Nevada, Utah, Colorado, Oregon and Texas. As the article explains, Select is confronting an array of regulatory changes that will necessitate shorter shifts, more employees and higher wages.

headline: BlackBerry to Add Amazon App Store to Phones
abstract: John S. Chen, BlackBerry’s chairman and chief executive, has repeatedly acknowledged that an absence of popular apps has hampered the BlackBerry 10 line of phones.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — In a side story to Amazon’s expected move into the smartphone business, the ailing handset maker BlackBerry said on Wednesday that it would include Amazon’s app store on its phones.

headline: Thirteen in Years, but 10 or 15 in Thoughts and Action
abstract: Some 13-year-olds are deep into teen culture, others little changed from the kids they were at a younger age. Subjective age varies, and that variation can raise a red flag for some young teens.
lead_paragraph: Gather together a random assortment of 13-year-olds, and you’ll likely find yourself looking at a group of people who have only their age in common. Some will be way into teenage culture, into hanging out and hooking up, even into alcohol and drugs; others will be little changed from the children they were at 12, 11, even 10 years of age, still singing the songs and playing the games of children.

headline: For Vietnam and China, No Easing of Tensions
abstract: The two countries exchanged sharp views at a session in Hanoi to discuss a Chinese oil rig deployed in contested waters in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China and Vietnam exchanged sharp views Wednesday in their dispute over a Chinese oil rig deployed in contested waters in the South China Sea near Vietnam’s coast and appear to have made little headway in cooling tensions, according to accounts by both governments summarizing a top-level meeting in Hanoi.

headline: Street Style at Florence’s Pitti Uomo
abstract: Fashion from outside the international men’s trade show at Pitti Uomo.
lead_paragraph: Fashion from outside the international men’s trade show at Pitti Uomo.

headline: Federal Reserve Sees Slower Growth, but Maintains Plans to Trim Stimulus
abstract: The central bank will reduce its monthly bond purchases by $10 billion a month and still expects to stop expanding its holdings this year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve on Wednesday sharply cut its economic forecast for 2014 even as it said the economy had bounced back after a nasty winter, allowing the central bank, in its view, to continue to retreat from its stimulus campaign.

headline: Ban on Gun ‘Straw Purchases’ Survives, But Only Just
abstract: Four justices were ready to eviscerate a law meant to keep firearms out of the wrong hands.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court came alarmingly close this week to eviscerating one of the most important gun safety rules on the books — the federal ban on “straw purchases.”

headline: Spain vs. Chile: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Spain must win or their title defense will be over. Chile can probably afford a loss, but would much rather get a point or three to make their final game less crucial.
lead_paragraph: Spain must win or their title defense will be over. Chile can probably afford a loss, but would much rather get a point or three to make their final game less crucial.

headline: Messaging App Gets People Talking With One Word: Yo
abstract: Tap a name on the app’s list of contacts, and a text notification saying “Yo” pops up on the recipient’s smartphone, along with a recorded voice shouting the syllable. The app’s creators have raised $1 million.
lead_paragraph: Some technology start-ups want to cure the world’s ills. Others want to disrupt major industries. One app has a strategy that amounts to a single word.

headline: Fire Phone Immerses Users in Amazon’s World
abstract: If Amazon entices even a fraction of its 250 million customers, it could accelerate already intense competition with retailers and tech companies.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon on Wednesday announced a device that tries to fulfill the retailer’s dream of being integrated into consumers’ lives at every possible waking moment — whether they are deciding where to eat, realizing they need more toilet paper or intrigued by a snatch of overheard music.

headline: G.E. to Propose Sweeteners to Its Alstom Offer
abstract: Jeffrey R. Immelt, the G.E. chairman and chief executive, will meet with French officials on Thursday and Friday to offer additional measures in hopes of persuading them to back G.E.’s deal for Alstom’s energy assets.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Jeffrey R. Immelt, the General Electric chairman and chief executive, is heading back to France with sweeteners for his $13.5 billion bid for Alstom, hoping to lure the government away from a rival offer from Siemens and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries.

headline: Readers Mourn the Loss of ‘The Gun Report’
abstract: The feature of Joe Nocera’s blog began shortly after the Newtown shootings.
lead_paragraph: Gun violence has rarely been more relevant in America than it is right now, so a recent decision to discontinue “The Gun Report” on Joe Nocera’s blog struck many readers as a simply terrible idea. My office has received more than 100 complaints or laments that it has been discontinued; they don’t seem to be a part of a writing campaign but an outpouring from individuals with strong feelings.

headline: Elon Musk’s Halo Effect
abstract: A $350 million acquisition of the solar panel maker Silevo added $900 million to SolarCity’s market value. It’s an investment in an efficient technology and a hedge against rising import tariffs, notes Christopher Swann of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk is applying his magic touch to mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Rail Strike Strands French and Tests Their President
abstract: A work stoppage has entered its second week, challenging François Hollande’s attempt to steer his Socialist Party on a more centrist path.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Now entering its second week, the national railway strike here has stranded thousands and exasperated millions more. It has brought on even more stress for high school students trying to reach their nationwide graduation test sites; upended business trips, hospital visits, vacations and daily commutes; and cost the state rail system upward of $250 million (about 184.2 million euros).

headline: Mother Charged With Fatal Poisoning of 5-Year-Old Boy
keywords: ["Munchausen's Syndrome", 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Lacey Spears, 26, was arrested in the death of her son Garnett, whom investigators say she intentionally made sick for years and chronicled his illnesses on social media.
lead_paragraph: Lacey Spears’s struggle seemed like every mother’s worst nightmare. From the moment her son was born, she said, he was afflicted with never-ending illnesses.

headline: ‘Soul Doctor’ Will Return, Off Broadway
abstract: The musical about Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach had a short-lived Broadway run in 2013.
lead_paragraph: “Soul Doctor,” the musical about the guitar-strumming, folksong-composing rabbi Shlomo Carlebach that had a brief Broadway run at Circle in the Square in 2013, will return in an off-Broadway production at the Actors Temple Theater. Previews begin on Nov. 25; the show opens on Dec. 13. Jeremy Chess is producing. Casting details for the production have not been announced.

headline: Indictment of Lacey Spears
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Ms. Spears, 26, was arrested and charged with murder in the death of her 5-year-old son on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Spears, 26, was arrested and charged with murder in the death of her 5-year-old son on Tuesday.

headline: Redskins Trademark: A Primer on the Cancellation
abstract: The United States Patent and Trademark Office canceled the Redskins trademark registration Wednesday. What comes next?
lead_paragraph: The United States Patent and Trademark Office’s decision Wednesday to cancel the Washington Redskins’ trademark registration will probably increase calls for the N.F.L. team to change its name.

headline: The Scene at Pitti Uomo
abstract: At the international men’s trade show at Pitti Uomo in Florence, a thousand or more exhibitors set up in a chaotic cluster of pavilions scattered throughout fairgrounds inside the 16th century Fortezza da Basso.
lead_paragraph: At the international men’s trade show at Pitti Uomo in Florence, a thousand or more exhibitors set up in a chaotic cluster of pavilions scattered throughout fairgrounds inside the 16th century Fortezza da Basso.

headline: Intel Introduces Custom Cloud Chip
abstract: As cloud computing gets bigger, some applications have to run on thousands of computer servers at once. Intel on Wednesday offered a way to tailor its server chip for this work.
lead_paragraph: Intel is solving a tough business problem, using a little technical innovation.

headline: G.M.’s Chief on Staff and Restructuring
abstract: Mary T. Barra, the chief executive of General Motors, returned before a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee and said the implementation of new safety reviews and procedures are underway.
lead_paragraph: Mary T. Barra, the chief executive of General Motors, returned before a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee and said the implementation of new safety reviews and procedures are underway.

headline: A Retro-Flavored Playlist from the Spring/Summer 2015 London Men’s Shows
abstract: The music that accompanied the collections and played at the parties ranged from late ’90s hip-hop to nostalgic tracks from current bands like Temples and Tame Impala.
lead_paragraph: During a typical show season, there is usually one genre-crossing Top 40 track that gets played ad nauseam — on the runways, during presentations, at parties — until it has been beaten into the brains of showgoers. Thankfully, the spring/summer 2015 London men’s shows offered a diverse and unexpected soundtrack. There was late ’90s and early ’00s R&B and hip-hop at Astrid Andersen, which used “Affirmative Action” by the short-lived super group the Firm, and at MAN, where the finale, “Freak Me” by Silk, was like bedroom music for the collection of duvet-worthy linens and pillowcase-shaped bags. At the Agi & Sam after-party, Black Rob’s 2000 track “Whoa” got everyone (including fellow designer Matthew Miller) onto the dance floor. At the other end of the sonic spectrum, Topman presented a trio of nostalgic songs by contemporary bands — Temples, Saint Etienne and Tame Impala — that fit the retro-inspired collection without making it feel dated.

headline: The Next-Generation Fitness Bands
abstract: Molly Wood reviews the LG Lifeband Touch and the Samsung Gear Fit, two wearable devices that marry fitness bands with smartwatches.
lead_paragraph: Molly Wood reviews the LG Lifeband Touch and the Samsung Gear Fit, two wearable devices that marry fitness bands with smartwatches.

headline: Fitness Devices That Do (Just) a Bit More
abstract: New wearable devices track activities, vital statistics and then some, in combination with apps. But is it enough to justify their price?
lead_paragraph: WEARABLE technology is having an identity crisis.

headline: Jack White Hits No. 1, With Strong Vinyl Sales
abstract: Mr. White’s album “Lazaretto” sold 138,000 copies — 40,000 of them for an “ultra” vinyl edition.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to the music charts, a victory for Jack White is a victory for vinyl.

headline: When Mysterious Symptoms Strike a Small Town
abstract: Eroticism and hysteria run wild in “The Fever,” inspired by a widely publicized outbreak of tics and twitching among girls in Le Roy, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Megan Abbott is a seasoned, Edgar Award-winning author with exceptional gifts for making nerves jangle and skin crawl. She is also skilled at turning teenage sexuality into cause for squirming, “like watching a movie with her dad and suddenly there’s a scene you don’t want to watch with your dad,” as Deenie, the heroine of her latest, “The Fever,” nicely puts it.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': John Lithgow’s Shakespeare in the Park Diary
abstract: A report on the long days — and the long beard — that go along with “King Lear.”
lead_paragraph: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park. His first report follows.

headline: Shift Emerges in Europe on Focus on Austerity
abstract: Left-leaning governments and leaders who are skeptical about austerity efforts are hoping to revisit the European Union’s policies.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — France and Italy, still struggling to meet the euro zone’s tough budget targets, may be gaining support for an effort to relax the rules.

headline: Ivory Coast’s Cornerstone Becomes a Catalyst
abstract: Ivory Coast feels that Didier Drogba’s impact is best used when he comes on as a substitute — as against Japan on Saturday, and maybe also against Colombia on Thursday and Greece.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — Perhaps it was the moment when Didier Drogba rose from the bench to warm up, drawing the attention of almost everyone at Arena Pernambuco in Recife, Brazil. Or maybe it was when he stood poised to enter the game, inspiring his teammates with just his nearing presence.

headline: Times Square Spider-Man Found Not Guilty of Assault
abstract: Philip Williams, an aspiring actor, was accused of hitting a woman who did not tip him for posing for a photo in his costume last year.
lead_paragraph: Extra! Extra! Read all about it: Spider-Man Is Not Guilty!

headline: What Janet Yellen Is Trying to Tell Us
abstract: Reading between the lines, the Fed will keep flowing cheap money into the economy and is in no hurry to raise interest rates.
lead_paragraph: One huge question was hanging over the Federal Reserve before Wednesday’s Fed-a-palooza. And in the course of a statement after the central bank’s policy meeting; new forecasts for the economy and interest rates; and a Q. and A. from Janet Yellen, the Fed chairwoman, it got at least a semblance of an answer.

headline: City Ballet to Add a Week to Its Saratoga Residency
abstract: The New York City Ballet will go back to a two-week season at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in 2015.
lead_paragraph: The Saratoga Performing Arts Center has found a way to stop the New York City Ballet’s slow disappearing act. Having seen the company’s residency dwindle from four weeks to three in 1978, then from three weeks to two in 2009 and then to a single week in 2013 and this year, mainly because the cost of presenting the company was outstripping the center’s ability to raise money to pay for it, the center’s board of directors announced on Tuesday that it would reverse that trend: when the City Ballet returns to Saratoga in 2015, it will be for a two-week season.

headline: An Evening of Sonic Exploration on Keyboards, Electronic and Otherwise
abstract: The Talea Ensemble is exploring sound through modern and contemporary music during its residency at the Stone.
lead_paragraph: All composers are interested in sound, but Anthony Cheung more than most. His orchestral work “Fog Mobiles” (2010) has its horn soloist create tones that suggest foghorns heard from various distances. “Lyra,” first performed last week by the New York Philharmonic, calls for shimmering transitions between a live ensemble and taped music.

headline: In House G.O.P.’s Leadership Fight, the Main Event Is Still to Come
abstract: After the shocking primary loss of Representative Eric Cantor, House Republicans will vote on their leadership on Thursday, but a bigger contest is months if not years away.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans will vote on their leadership on Thursday, but the outcome will essentially keep them in a holding pattern, with the real contest months if not years away.

headline: Pop-Up Restaurants on the Rails
abstract: British Pullman, a luxury train operated by Belmond, will feature high-profile chefs in very limited engagements.
lead_paragraph: Stars of London’s restaurant scene will be periodically hopping aboard the vintage Art Deco cars of the British Pullman, one of several luxury trains operated by Belmond, the former Orient Express Hotels Group, to serve as one-night-only pop-up chefs.

headline: Watch for Low-Flying Angels
abstract: In “Dominion,” angels come to earth, and that’s not a good thing.
lead_paragraph: “Dominion,” beginning Thursday night on Syfy, is a television series spun off from a movie. But we’re not talking about something like “The Avengers” or even, say, “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.” The source in this case is the little-noticed 2010 film “Legion,” in which a motley crew of humans, holed up in a desert diner, fight off a crew of malevolent angels with the help of the archangel Michael, who takes our side for one reason or another. Maybe pity? Hey, it’s been a while.

headline: Families of G.M. Victims Speak Out
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Relatives at a news conference provided accounts of accidents that they say involved General Motors’ ignition defect.
lead_paragraph: Relatives at a news conference provided accounts of accidents that they say involved General Motors’ ignition defect.

headline: Summer Fashion for the Sandal Averse
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Bathing Suits and Swimwear']
abstract: Demure pumps have their place in summer wardrobes; Steven Alan celebrates his 20th anniversary with a special collection and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: Summertime footwear can be extreme: too-high strappy sandals that are simply painful; or, on the trendier front, all of those Birkenstocks and Teva styles. And maybe you’re just not a woman who is crazy about showing off her feet. In the face of all that, demure closed-toe pumps are now looking right, and nicely refined, for the office and for evening hours. At the recent CFDA awards, Marion Cotillard, left, glorious as always, wore a Dior pair with her haute couture dress. Few of us will be wearing couture, but we can pull off the elegant statement with any of these closed-toe options and, perhaps, a pencil skirt and mannish button-down or a smart cocktail dress.

headline: A School Is a Jungle Where Teeth Are Bared
abstract: “The Ballad of Pondlife McGurk,” at the New Victory Theater, explores the fragility of friendship and of our better selves.
lead_paragraph: Funny thing about the Neanderthals. Although scientists tell us that these cave men cousins of ours became extinct about 30,000 years ago, they have a way of reappearing in contemporary society, especially classrooms.

headline: Giants’ Jason Pierre-Paul Says He Is Healthy
abstract: Jason Pierre-Paul, who was unproductive last season after back surgery, said people had been too quick to declare his days as a Pro Bowl-caliber defensive end over.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul knows he had an unproductive season last year as he recovered from back surgery. But he feels some people around the N.F.L. have been too quick to declare that his days as a Pro Bowl-caliber player are over.

headline: Amazon’s Phone: It’s Not About the Phone, Really
abstract: In a much-anticipated announcement, a peek at what the company thinks the next wave of computing will be: the Internet of things.
lead_paragraph: You’ve probably heard that Amazon introduced a phone today, called the Fire. But are phones already so yesterday?

headline: A Rare Double, Even by the Mets’ Standards, Helps Prevent a Sweep
abstract: Bartolo Colon recorded his first hit in nine years, scored his first run in 12 years, and pitched eight innings to lead the Mets past the Cardinals.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — There is an old baseball saying that goes something like this: Every day at the ballpark, you might see something new.

headline: ‘No Body Talk’ Summer Camps
keywords: ['Camps and Camping', 'Women and Girls', 'Children and Childhood', 'Weight', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Beauty (Concept)']
abstract: Some summer camps ban all talk of physical appearance, even compliments.
lead_paragraph: Last August, on a clear summer day, Tom and Maura Gould were driving their 12-year-old daughter from Eden Village, an organic farming camp in Putnam Valley, N.Y., to their home in Cambridge, Mass., when they started talking about family members who were particularly hairy.

headline: Farewells, and Some More Questions, for Press Secretary
abstract: In his final briefing, Jay Carney, the president’s chief spokesman, praised reporters, saying that it was “always a pleasure” and that he had always sought to help the news media do their job.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the top of his last briefing as White House press secretary on Wednesday, Jay Carney acknowledged to his adversaries in the news media “how hard it can get in here, how hot it can sometimes be.”

headline: Curating the Décor
abstract: The Grey Area co-founder Kyle DeWoody is making a name for herself in the art world.
lead_paragraph: AGE 29

headline: Amazon’s Fire and the Real Cost of Switching Phones
abstract: Putting a price on the pain of losing text messages, migrating contact lists and bidding farewell to favorite apps.
lead_paragraph: Amazon’s new phone has loads of features: the ability to recognize thousands of products in stores, supposedly tangle-free earbud cords and a screen that gives images the illusion of depth.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Going Past the Grave to Gain His Love
abstract: Diana Vishneva danced the title role in American Ballet Theater’s “Giselle.”
lead_paragraph: Playing the character of Giselle, a great ballerina can put herself through astonishing changes: A village girl falls in love with a count (named Albrecht) who is pretending to be a peasant, and when she learns he is betrothed to someone else, she goes mad, dies of shock and returns as an ethereal spirit. But a great ballerina often has to play Giselle again and again; and over time, a radiant performance can settle into habit.

headline: In Single Gene, a Path to Fight Heart Attacks
abstract: Two major studies identified mutations in a single gene that keep down levels of triglycerides, a discovery that prompted hopes for a new class of drugs.
lead_paragraph: Two major studies by leading research groups published on Wednesday independently identified mutations in a single gene that protect against heart attacks by keeping levels of triglycerides — a kind of fat in the blood — very low for a lifetime.

headline: Pulling Back the Veil, or Keeping It On
abstract: A Yemeni photographer worked both sides of the camera as she and her daughter – and a doll – posed for a visual mediation on the increasing covering of women.
lead_paragraph: A Yemeni photographer worked both sides of the camera as she and her daughter – and a doll – posed for a visual mediation on the increasing covering of women.

headline: No ‘Fat Talk’ and No Skinny Talk, Either, at Some Camps
abstract: Some camps, in an effort to end not just the “fat talk,” but the mindset that leads to it, have put in place rules banning all body talk: positive, negative or in between.
lead_paragraph: Many children figure out young that one road to conversation with peers, older children and even parents is to talk appearance — theirs, or someone else’s. “She really shouldn’t wear those pants,” or even just “Did you notice his beard?” spark conversations (not always kind), and can lead, eventually, to the dubious bonding ritual that is negative self-talk: “No cookies for me! Not with these thighs!” “Oh, I know, my jeans are getting so tight!” Ninety-three percent of college women told one researcher they had engaged in such “fat talk,” and such talk comes with a cost, putting the focus on weight and appearance, and not in a positive way.

headline: Rappers’ Lyrics and Lifestyles Scrutinized in Murder Case
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Music', 'Racketeering and Racketeers', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Leonard Grant, a.k.a. Uncle Murda, chronicled his life as a Brooklyn rap performer as a colleague, Ronald Herron, known as Ra Diggs, stands trial for three killings.
lead_paragraph: Studio time until 5 a.m., $400 bottles at nightclubs, taking a bullet to the head: Such is the life of a modern-day rapper.

headline: Croatia vs. Cameroon: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Losing a World Cup opener as these teams both did, is bad, but not fatal. Losing Game 2 as well is the end of the line. Both teams must win to have a shot at the second berth behind Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Losing a World Cup opener as these teams both did, is bad, but not fatal. Losing Game 2 as well is the end of the line. Both teams must win to have a shot at the second berth behind Brazil.

headline: Exploiting Circus Animals
abstract: A writer for the PETA Foundation urges the United States to follow the lead of other countries that have banned the use of circus animals.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Iraq, Albania, Kenya and England.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Iraq, Albania, Kenya and England.

headline: A Charter Leader’s View
abstract: Eva Moskowitz, founder of Success Academy Charter Schools, objects to an article describing her as “picking fights.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: There’s Pride in Embracing the Past
abstract: The Orchestra of the League of Composers gave its final concert of the season on Monday at Miller Theater.
lead_paragraph: The Orchestra of the League of Composers gave its final concert of the season on Monday at Miller Theater at Columbia University, under the baton of Louis Karchin.

headline: Pull Over, It’s John Waters
abstract: The film director and author hitchhiked across the United States and lived to tell the tale.
lead_paragraph: The film director and author hitchhiked across the United States and lived to tell the tale.

headline: The Controversy Over ‘The Death of Klinghoffer’
abstract: Readers respond to the Metropolitan Opera’s decision to cancel the simulcast.

headline: The Value of a ‘NanoDegree’
abstract: Jeffrey H. Toney of Kean University likens it to Twitter.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cocktail Culture | A Flight of Top-Shelf Books About Drinking
abstract: If you’re looking for enjoyable new ways to get soused this summer, these four sumptuous, in-depth volumes are just your ticket.
lead_paragraph: This season a number of excellent books about spirits come to market, covering every corner of drinking culture. Pick one up if you’re thinking about new ways of serving drinks this summer.

headline: John Waters on Hitchhiking Across America
abstract: The cult filmmaker’s new book, “Carsick,” recounts his journey from Baltimore to San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: John Waters was safely ensconced in his Greenwich Village apartment, which is unexpectedly tasteful — Oriental rugs, carefully arranged books — for the filmmaker known as the “Pope of Trash,” thanks to movies like “Hairspray” and “Pink Flamingos” that traffic in camp, gore and, ahem, bodily functions.

headline: Boy, 14, Fatally Stabs Schoolmate in Bronx, Police Say
abstract: A 14-year-old, who investigators said may have been teased by the boy who was stabbed, was arrested in the attack at Intermediate School 117.
lead_paragraph: A 14-year-old Bronx boy who may have been teased and robbed by a 14-year-old schoolmate stabbed him to death on Wednesday afternoon outside the school they attended, the police said.

headline: With Wind Calm, Serenity in Slovenia
abstract: The Vipava Valley, near the Italian border, offers low-intensity pleasure — as long as the ferocious Bora wind isn’t blowing.
lead_paragraph: The subject was the Bora — the ferocious northern wind that wreaks seasonal havoc on the western Slovenian region known as the Vipava Valley, where we had just arrived — and my friend expressed disappointment that we had just missed out on the chance to experience it. “It sounds so impressive,” she said.

headline: At London Men’s Fashion Week, Designers Fly the Flag for Individuality
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: At the men’s shows, labels brand-new and centuries-old shared the scene. Some followed tradition while others strayed far from the classical path.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One of the standout shows of London Collections: Men, the city’s three-day men’s fashion “week,” was by a 27-year-old novice named Craig Green. It was all the more astonishing because it was, technically, his first.

headline: Cupid Flitted About Briskly, While the TV Stars Just Stood There
abstract: On Site Opera performed Rameau’s “Pygmalion” at Madame Tussauds, enrolling the likenesses of Julia Roberts and Kim Kardashian in the tale of the sculptor who falls in love with his creation.
lead_paragraph: Julia Roberts couldn’t stop smiling during Tuesday’s On Site Opera performance of Rameau’s “Pygmalion.” Kim Kardashian maintained a more skeptical pose, hands on peplum-frilled hips, a hint of a pout on her closed lips. Of course, neither of them was a reliable measure of the show’s success. Their facial expressions, like everything else about them, were perpetually frozen in wax.

headline: Yellen Delivers Remarks on Fed Policy
abstract: The Federal Reserve chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, said the Fed would maintain its plan to trim its stimulus campaign by reducing its monthly bond purchases to $35 billion beginning in July.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, said the Fed would maintain its plan to trim its stimulus campaign by reducing its monthly bond purchases to $35 billion beginning in July.

headline: When Time Isn’t Free
abstract: A new survey measures American leisure time — but for some, that time may not feel very leisurely, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: How much free time do you have? On a basic level, you could answer that question by tallying up the hours you spend working, sleeping and doing chores, and figuring out what’s left over. But some argue that the real answer is a lot more complicated — and that the way you experience time might have a lot to do with money.

headline: Facebook Makes Its Own Computer Networking Switch
abstract: The social media giant announced that it had created a new kind of computer networking switch, potentially capable of shifting data rapidly through the largest data centers.
lead_paragraph: In pretty short order, Facebook is out to shake up big parts of what makes the Internet go.

headline: Openings and Sales for the Week of June 19
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Handbags and Purses']
abstract: The Transience, a new collection of travel bags; for Alice & Olivia by Stacey Bendet, a new store on the Upper East Side; sales at Veda and Rag & Bone.
lead_paragraph: Openings

headline: Careful Defense in a World Wide Bridge Contest Heat
abstract: In the World Wide Bridge Contest held on June 7, Corey Krantz and Bruce Lang came in second, playing at the Bridge Club of Center City in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: In the World Wide Bridge Contest held on June 7, Corey Krantz and Bruce Lang came in second, playing at the Bridge Club of Center City in Philadelphia. They had a 73.14 percent game, finishing 1.48 percent behind George Criparacos and John Vergitsakis from Greece.

headline: ‘Klinghoffer’ Composer Responds to Met’s Decision
abstract: John Adams said he feared that without international exposure via the Met’s cinema program, “The Death of Klinghoffer” might be greeted by a “Wikipedia opinion.”
lead_paragraph: John Adams said he learned that the Metropolitan Opera was scrapping plans to transmit his opera “The Death of Klinghoffer” to movie theaters around the world when the Met’s general manager, Peter Gelb, told him on Sunday by telephone that he had gotten “unimaginable pressure” from some Jewish groups that oppose the work.

headline: New York’s Film Czar Preserves Indie Spirit
abstract: Cynthia López, Mayor Bill de Blasio’s newly appointed film commissioner, brings to the job an unusual background in independent documentary films.
lead_paragraph: When Cynthia López was 9 years old, her mother told her, “Make sure you hold the door for those who come behind you.”

headline: Protection Sought for Vast and Ancient Incan Road
abstract: The Qhapaq Ñan, which winds thousands of miles down the Pacific Coast of South America, has been recommended for recognition as a World Heritage site.
lead_paragraph: It is an engineering marvel of antiquity, comparable, experts say, to the Roman road system, but more remarkable for the rugged terrain it has traversed for more than 3,000 years.

headline: At Beijing School, Some Parents Take a Sex Education Class
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Education (K-12)', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Sex Education']
abstract: China’s Education Ministry says schools should teach sex education, but for a number of reasons, including widespread embarrassment, it’s usually passed over.
lead_paragraph: If life were a movie, the meeting of 50 mothers and a doctor would have been called ‘‘Sex Ed 2: The Parents.’’

headline: Gyms Add More Obstacles to Fitness Training
abstract: Specialized training programs prove popular at gyms.
lead_paragraph: Steven Beckwith was desperate. A friend had convinced him to sign up for a Spartan Beast, a notoriously tough obstacle course race stretching more than 12 miles, and he knew lifting weights and running on a treadmill at his regular gym wouldn’t prepare him to, say, spider-man across the flat face of a wall or climb a 20-foot rope.

headline: Twitter Restores Access to ‘Blasphemous’ Tweets in Pakistan
abstract: Twitter reversed a decision it made last month to block content in Pakistan deemed “blasphemous” or “unethical” by a government regulator.
lead_paragraph: Pakistanis disappointed by Twitter’s decision last month to block content deemed “blasphemous” or “unethical” by their government expressed satisfaction when the company restored access to the blocked text and images early Wednesday.

headline: Do Children’s Backyard Play Areas Turn Off Buyers?
abstract: When it comes to selling a house, a backyard play area should appeal to people of all ages.
lead_paragraph: Q. Will children’s outdoor play structures make the yard look junky to buyers?

headline: William Maclay’s Road Map to Get Off the Grid
abstract: A new book from the green architect offers strategies and examples for designing “net-zero” buildings.
lead_paragraph: Books by architectural firms are often vainglorious marketing efforts that keep the content glossy and light. But an ambitious new book from William Maclay, an architect in Waitsfield, Vt., and his associates, challenges the genre.

headline: Sales at Kikkerland, ABC Carpet & Home and MoMA Design Store
abstract: Discounts on kitchen essentials and more.
lead_paragraph: Some items are up to 65 percent off at Kikkerland, from Saturday through June 25 (a Mona Lisa wall clock by Constantin Boym, originally $35, will be $25; a Gator grater, $3.50, down from $10); 493 Sixth Avenue (West 12th Street), 212-262-5000, kikkerlandnyc.com.

headline: Furnishing an Outdoor Room
keywords: ['Furniture', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Gardens and Gardening']
abstract: Accessorizing exterior spaces requires the same attention to detail given to interiors.
lead_paragraph: After a longer and more-brutal winter than usual, many outdoor spaces are in need of a little sprucing up.

headline: From Ma Bell to Design Central
abstract: Ameico, an importer of contemporary design, opens an unusual shop in New Milford, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Ameico, an importer of contemporary design, has turned an abandoned telephone exchange building in New Milford, Conn., into an unlikely showcase. The 1917 structure, which had been boarded up for two decades, has been renovated and filled with a retail shop, called 29 Church. It sells clocks and watches from Braun, flatware by Konstantin Grcic for Serafino Zani, and classic posters by Bruno Munari and Enzo Mari for Danese. Upstairs, shoppers will find furniture and lighting from &Tradition, Santa & Cole, Max Bill and the Josef Albers Foundation. The 6,000-square-foot complex includes a library stocked with books on industrial design and will be open to the public for research. Plans are afoot to host industrial design conferences and exhibitions. “We have always felt that one of our missions is to educate consumers about what is good design,” said Peter Kahane, Ameico’s founder. Information: 888-350-8765 or ameico.com.

headline: Breaking Free of Boundaries
abstract: A new feature of Design Miami/Basel is a show of intriguing objects that fall between art and design.
lead_paragraph: Design Miami/Basel, a part of the semiannual Art Basel fair, opened on Tuesday in Switzerland with a new feature called “Design at Large.” Curated by Dennis Freedman, the creative director of Barneys New York, the program displays six large-scale installations stationed under an oculus. The works, a few of which have interactive or performance-based elements, aren’t intended to be commercial, Mr. Freedman said, adding, “None of these pieces could ever have been shown in a booth.” The group includes a tiny biomorphic plastic house, designed in 1965 by the French architect Jean Maneval, and Sheila Hicks’s interactive color lab, “Séance,” which consists of colorful fiber bundles that look like boulders Information: designmiami.com.

headline: He Found His Corner of the Sky
abstract: The adventure writer and novelist Peter Heller discovers happiness in his Colorado dirt-brick cabin.
lead_paragraph: As a boy growing up in Brooklyn Heights, Peter Heller was fascinated by the mythic West, in particular the cowboy novels of Louis L’Amour. “I remember the cover of this one L’Amour book showed a guy on horseback, leading a pack horse across a creek in the snow,” Mr. Heller, 55, said. “Something about that cover — all I wanted to do was drift the high lonesome on horseback.”

headline: Mastering a Collision Course Called Home
abstract: By the time her son was nine months old, the writer Nicole C. Kear had baby-proofed her apartment. Blind-proofing it proved more difficult.
lead_paragraph: By the time my son was 9 months old, I had fully baby-proofed our tiny Brooklyn walk-up. Cabinets containing toxic chemicals were locked. Doorknobs and stove dials had been disabled. All four corners of the coffee table were padded. Easy. Effective. The process of blind-proofing the apartment, for myself, was far more complicated.

headline: Bringing Rio a Bit Closer
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Balconies and Terraces']
abstract: How does a Brazilian family satisfy a longing for the outdoors? With a giant Manhattan terrace.
lead_paragraph: Cristiane Peixoto, a floral designer, and her husband, Marcus Silberman, an investment banker, are from Rio de Janeiro, and as Ms. Peixoto said, “Life in Rio is all about being on the beach and outdoors.” So when the couple bought an apartment for their family in Manhattan, they chose one with as much space outdoors as there is indoors.

headline: Descend Into Giddiness
abstract: Carsten Höller’s latest slide is on the campus of the furniture company Vitra.
lead_paragraph: “I think it would change our lives if we could slide more,” said the Belgian artist Carsten Höller, who has been building slides on and off since 1998. The structures not only carry you efficiently from place to place, he believes, but they also create a special state of mind that, borrowing a phrase from the French sociologist Roger Caillois, he likes to describe as “voluptuous panic.” On Wednesday, Mr. Holler unveiled his first free-standing slide on the campus of the furniture company Vitra in Weil am Rhein, Germany. It is a steel spiral descending from a 100-foot-high tower with a platform that offers a rare elevated view of the architectural masterworks around it. (Among the neighbors are buildings by Álvaro Siza, Tadao Ando and Zaha Hadid.) Topping the structure is a large, numberless clock that is positioned askew so that viewers must tilt their heads and guess the correct time. Mr. Holler prefers that idea to consulting a cellphone, a gesture that can be construed as rude. “People think you could be checking your email,” he said. Information: vitra.com.

headline: What Good Taste Smells Like
keywords: ['Smells and Odors', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Perfumes and Fragrances']
abstract: It’s no longer enough to look nice. A well-designed interior now needs an interesting scent built into it.
lead_paragraph: Meredith Melling’s duplex loft in NoHo features the polished decorating of Ariel Ashe — lots of neutrals with some standout pieces like a tufted royal-blue velvet sofa and a burl-wood-and-chrome dining table — set against its bleached wood floors and gutsy exposed beams and columns. Tying it all together is an invisible, but palpable, element: a sandalwood, vanilla and pepper fragrance, designed especially for Ms. Melling and her apartment, wafting from a sleek metal machine the size of a tablet hidden behind the blue sofa.

headline: Another Blow to the ‘Redskins’ Name
abstract: The trademark board ruled that the Washington football team’s name is “disparaging.” ANNA NORTH writes that many had already come to that conclusion — and stopped using it.
lead_paragraph: When it canceled the trademark on the Washington Redskins name on Wednesday, the Trademark Trial and Appeal Board ruled that the word was “disparaging.” But many came to that conclusion — and stopped using the name — a long time ago.

headline: Assembly Is Not Required
abstract: New Yorkers now can turn to the Container Store for help in organizing their belongings.
lead_paragraph: Instead of trying to make sense of the dizzying array of boxes and shelving options at the Container Store, you can now hire somebody to figure it out for you. After successful runs in Texas, the company just started At Home in its two Manhattan locations. Twelve orderly professionals are ready to lend a hand, said Eva Gordon, vice president for stores. “They’ll come to your home, look at your space to understand your style, assess your needs and come back with an organizational plan.” The cost to get started is $50, which covers the visit and creation of the plan. The organizer recommends Container Store products to carry it out, and returns — at $50 an hour — to oversee the installation of shelving systems and the like, help with staging and styling, and even paint the space. Information: 855-827-4663 or containerstore.com/athome.

headline: Aston Martin Racing to Explore Solar Technology
abstract: Aston Martin Racing has joined with a Chinese company to develop solar-powered air-conditioning for its GT racecars.
lead_paragraph: Aston Martin Racing announced last week that it would join with the Hong Kong-based Hanergy Global Solar Power & Applications Group to find ways to apply solar energy to racecars.

headline: List of Potential Bitcoin Bidders Is Accidentally Released
abstract: A musician, a college professor and the head of public policy for Yelp could all bid on 30,000 Bitcoins being auctioned by United States Marshals Service this month, according to a list that was accidentally leaked.
lead_paragraph: A musician, a college professor and the head of public policy for Yelp could all bid on 30,000 Bitcoins being auctioned by United States Marshals Service this month, according to a list that was accidentally leaked by the office on Wednesday.

headline: Bits of Brooklyn, Everywhere
abstract: BAMcinemaFest at the Brooklyn Academy of Music will feature films from Richard Linklater, Joe Swanberg and Bong Joon-Ho
lead_paragraph: For decades, the Brooklyn Academy of Music flourished comfortably at the edge of New York’s cultural life. Residents of the borough found it a well-tended and accessible garden of sometimes exotic delights, while Manhattanites could congratulate themselves for their adventurousness, and for finding a taxi willing to take them across the East River.

headline: SAC Capital’s Deal With S.E.C. Gets Final Court Approval
abstract: A federal district court judge in Manhattan gave final approval to a $602 million settlement that does not require Steven A. Cohen’s former firm to admit any wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission‘s insider trading lawsuit against Steven A. Cohen’s former hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is finally over.

headline: Markit, a Big Financial Data Provider, Raises Nearly $1.3 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: Markit priced its offering at $24 a share. The price was in the middle of its expected range, and selling shareholders agreed to sell more of their holdings than expected.
lead_paragraph: One of the most important names in the world of debt trading, Markit, is poised to join the public stock markets — and generate a payday for the banks that are both owners and customers of the financial data firm.

headline: As the U.S. Ponders What to Do in Iraq
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Shiite Muslims']
abstract: Readers react to the crisis in Iraq and the debate over whether the United States should take some action.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Amazon Measures Phone Success
abstract: A winning strategy will not necessarily involve overtaking iPhones or Samsung phones, but wringing more money from its most loyal shoppers.
lead_paragraph: Amazon’s new Fire phone might be less about the phone and more about what its computing power can do in a few years, when it is built into futuristic devices like Internet-connected contact lenses, as I wrote today on the Upshot.

headline: Abdullah Elshamy Released From Prison
abstract: Abdullah Elshamy, an Al Jazeera correspondent who had been on a hunger strike for more than 100 days, was released late Tuesday from an Egyptian prison.
lead_paragraph: Abdullah Elshamy, an Al Jazeera correspondent who had been on a hunger strike for more than 100 days, was released late Tuesday from an Egyptian prison.

headline: New York City’s Emergency Management Chief Resigns
abstract: Joseph F. Bruno, who helped organize the response to Hurricane Sandy in 2012, had stayed on at the request of aides to Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: Joseph F. Bruno, the commissioner of New York City’s Office of Emergency Management for a decade, has resigned, after remaining in office for several months at the request of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s aides.

headline: The Gall of Dick Cheney
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Bush may have been a disastrous president, but at least he isn’t chiding the current administration as it tries to right his wrong in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: The situation in Iraq is truly worrisome, as militants threaten to tear the country asunder and disrupt the fragile, short-lived period absent all-out war there.

headline: Popular at Easter, Peeps Candy Extends to the Quirky Holidays
abstract: A new marketing and advertising campaign plays off the brand’s association with big holidays by highlighting those that are more obscure.
lead_paragraph: PEEPS, the 61-year-old brand of marshmallow candies, is wildly popular for Easter, but the brand has struggled to expand beyond the holiday.

headline: Battle Between Argentina and Hedge Funds Continues in New York
abstract: A dispute between Argentina and several New York hedge funds is returning to Federal District Court in Manhattan for negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:46 p.m. | A fierce legal battle between Argentina and New York hedge funds took a new twist on Wednesday when the country offered to negotiate with the funds just hours after announcing measures that would help it avoid a settlement.

headline: College to No Longer Consider Test Scores in Its Decisions
abstract: Hampshire College, in Amherst, Mass., said Wednesday it would no longer consider SAT or ACT scores in admissions or financial aid decisions.
lead_paragraph: Hampshire College, in Amherst, Mass., said on Wednesday that it would no longer consider SAT or ACT scores in admissions or financial aid decisions. Meredith Twombly, the dean of admissions, said Hampshire had been “test optional” since it opened in 1970 but would become “test blind,” both for greater fairness and because Hampshire favors assessment through written work, projects and discussions, not test scores. Robert Schaeffer, public education director of FairTest, said Hampshire would be the only test-blind college: Sarah Lawrence College was test-blind for several years, but it reverted to test-optional two years ago after U.S. News and World Report stopped ranking it because of the lack of test scores.

headline: 2 Million Tune In to See Hillary Rodham Clinton on Fox News
abstract: The former secretary of state, who is promoting her new memoir, gave a boost of 23 percent to the usual audience on the network.
lead_paragraph: Apparently the Fox News audience was intensely interested in what Hillary Rodham Clinton had to say about her latest book.

headline: J.K. Rowling’s ‘The Silkworm’ a Boon for Other Booksellers as Hachette and Amazon Brawl
abstract: With the book expected to be a big hit, retailers are looking to exploit the dispute to win back customers who may be frustrated by Amazon’s lack of inventory.
lead_paragraph: Like any mystery novel expected to be a summer blockbuster, Robert Galbraith’s “The Silkworm,” set for release on Thursday, features shadowy subtext and crafty machinations — but in this book’s case the maneuverings are both on and off the page.

headline: What to Call Iraq Fighters? Experts Vary on S’s and L’s
abstract: There is no consensus on how to define the region denoted by the classical Arabic term “al-Sham,” which is part of the name of the group called the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria by many news outlets.
lead_paragraph: Everyone seems to agree that the Sunni extremists who are striving to carve out a caliphate in Syria and Iraq have upended the region, but there is no consensus on what to call the militant group, in English at least.

headline: An Answer on a Postcard
keywords: ['Financial Aid (Education)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Fafsa’s complicated application form discourages many from going to college. Our bill proposes replacing it with just two simple questions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THIS year, more than 20 million college students will complete the dreaded 108-question Free Application for Federal Student Aid, commonly known as the Fafsa. Most do it again every year they’re in school. Some pay someone to help them. Colleges hire thousands of staff members to assist. Too many students are so intimidated by the form that they don’t bother to apply.

headline: The Not-So-Beautiful Game
abstract: As it becomes trendy, soccer is losing its old frisson of hooliganism.
lead_paragraph: IT’S wonderful that America has fallen in love with World Cup soccer, as it plays out across the greenswards of Brazilian host cities like Natal, Manaus and Curitiba. To walk through New York City on Monday night and hear the restaurant crowds’ whooping at John Brooks’s late-game goal, which propelled the United States over Ghana, was to experience soccer as it is experienced in the rest of the world: collective, noisy and cathartic.

headline: Leader’s Words About Women Jolt Morocco
abstract: Prime Minister Abdelilah Benkirane of Morocco told Parliament this week that women would be better off at home than in the workplace.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Abdelilah Benkirane of Morocco told Parliament this week that women would be better off at home than in the workplace, setting off alarm in a country that has seen slow but steady gains in women’s rights.

headline: Drones Kill 5 as Pakistan and U.S. Target Tribal Belt
abstract: Those killed were in North Waziristan on Wednesday as the Pakistani military continued to fight terrorists there. It is unclear how much, if any, cooperation exists between American and Pakistani officials there.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — An American drone strike killed at least five people in North Waziristan on Wednesday, Pakistani officials said, as the Pakistani military continued its offensive against militants in that tribal district.

headline: Jeff Bezos Shows Off Amazon Fire Phone
abstract: Mr. Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, demonstrated the company’s new phone at a presentation on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, demonstrated the company’s new phone at a presentation on Wednesday.

headline: Parity Could Be a Plus for the So-So Yankees
abstract: Most major league teams are having an identity crisis this season, hovering just a few games above or below .500, and that may give the Yankees hope.
lead_paragraph: The Toronto Blue Jays hold first place in the American League East, but their grip on it is slipping. They have lost 8 of 11 games and, as usual, fell again to the Yankees in the Bronx on Wednesday. It was their 15th loss in a row at the new Yankee Stadium.

headline: After 10 Months in Jail, Freed Egyptian Journalist Says, ‘I Have Won’
abstract: By the time he was finally set free late Tuesday, Abdullah Elshamy, 25, had been held without charge for 10 months.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reported from Cairo on Monday, prosecutors decided to release a hunger-striking journalist, Abdullah Elshamy, because of his deteriorating health.

headline: Pressure Grows in Hunt for Kidnapped Israelis
abstract: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority vowed to help catch whoever kidnapped three Israeli teenagers as mounting pressure threatened his reconciliation pact with Hamas.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Wednesday denounced the abduction of three Israeli teenagers and vowed to help catch the kidnappers, as pressure mounted on him and threatened to collapse his fraying reconciliation pact with the militant Islamic movement Hamas.

headline: Guantánamo Detainee Arraigned in Case That Could Help Decide Fate of Tribunals
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Military Tribunals', 'Detainees', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The arraignment of Abd al-Hadi al-Iraqi set in motion a case that could help determine whether the tribunals system will continue to be used to prosecute terrorism suspects.
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — An Iraqi detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, was arraigned Wednesday on war-crimes charges before a military commission, setting in motion a case that could help determine whether the tribunals system will be used extensively in the future or wither away after the handful of cases before it are completed.

headline: Thomas B. Morgan, Writer, Editor and Lindsay Press Aide, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Morgan combined writing and a passion for public affairs to shape a career that also included top roles at The Village Voice and in public radio.
lead_paragraph: Thomas B. Morgan, who combined a knack for writing and passion for public affairs to shape a heterogeneous career that included being press secretary to Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York, editor of The Village Voice and chief of the city’s broadcasting operations, died on Tuesday in Westmoreland, N.H. He was 87.

headline: Dubai, Once a Humble Refueling Stop, Is Crossroad to the Globe
abstract: Dubai’s rise as a modern crossroads connecting East and West is a tale of globalization, ambition, and an audacious bet on the future of air travel that proved prescient.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — The gimmicks to attract attention and passengers — a $1 million raffle, a chance to win a Porsche 911, or a monthlong shopping festival — are still there but are hardly needed anymore. Travelers from around the world no longer need to be lured to this parched former trading post on the edge of the Persian Gulf.

headline: TCI Hedge Fund in Britain Ends Ties to Charitable Arm
abstract: According to regulatory filings in Britain, the Children’s Investment Fund, known as TCI, will no longer donate money to the foundation on a contractual basis, though it may do so on a discretionary basis.
lead_paragraph: When Christopher Hohn, the founder of one of Britain’s largest and most successful hedge funds, chose to structure his fund to automatically donate a portion of its fees to charity — specifically his wife’s charity — people took notice.

headline: Governor Plans to Cut Ties to Common Core in Louisiana
abstract: Louisiana’s governor said on Wednesday that his state would end its enactment of the educational guidelines, but other officials immediately said that he had overstepped his authority.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana said Wednesday that he would seek to end his state’s enactment of the Common Core educational guidelines and plans to administer a test tied to them, but other officials immediately said that the governor had overstepped his authority and vowed to resist his moves.

headline: Was This Student Dangerous?
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'School Shootings']
abstract: There was nothing I could do about an undergrad who frightened his classmates — and me.
lead_paragraph: The undergraduate who had been writing poems about killing people showed up for his appointment in my office carrying a black canvas backpack. He was slim and dark-haired, his mouth torqued into an uneasy smile. I had spoken several times about his violent ramblings to the campus police and to the university’s office of mental health, and this was what they came up with: I should invite the student to my office and calmly begin a conversation with the following question: “Do you have a plan to harm yourself or anyone else?”

headline: John Devens, Valdez Mayor During Exxon Spill, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Devens was the mayor of Valdez, an obscure coastal town in Alaska, when it was rocked by the wreck of the Exxon Valdez oil tanker in Prince William Sound.
lead_paragraph: John Devens, whose tenure as the mayor of an obscure coastal town in Alaska was rocked by a stunning disaster on its shores — the wreck of the Exxon Valdez oil tanker in Prince William Sound — died last week at his home in Copper Center, Alaska. He was 74.

headline: Up in Arms Over ‘Soccer’ vs. ‘Football’
abstract: A new academic paper suggests that the word soccer began in Britain and was used there happily until at least the 1970s, even as a spirited debate over the sport’s name endures.
lead_paragraph: The letter writer was incensed, as so many people so often are, by America’s insistence on using its own special word to describe the game that almost everyone else calls football.

headline: Should Restaurant Reservations Be for Sale?
abstract: Do reservation apps usefully provide a way for people to  get into popular restaurants, or are they just another way to sell what was once free?

headline: Espaillat for Congress
abstract: It is time for a change in New York’s 13th Congressional District. The Times recommends Adriano Espaillat, a state senator, for the House seat.
lead_paragraph: After a humiliating censure by Congress four years ago for failing to pay taxes and other ethical lapses, Representative Charles Rangel has steadily lost power in Washington. After nearly 44 years in office, it is now time for him to yield to the next generation. In Tuesday’s Democratic primary for New York’s 13th Congressional District, we recommend Adriano Espaillat, a New York State senator, who will be a better representative of this district stretching from Upper Manhattan into parts of the Bronx.

headline: Guns at the Airport
abstract: States should change their laws to classify bringing a gun into security checkpoints as a felony.
lead_paragraph: On June 4, a 32-year-old woman tried to get through security at San Antonio International Airport with a loaded .380 caliber Diamondback in her carry-on bag. This wasn’t a freak occurrence. Transportation Security Administration officials intercepted 18 guns on that day alone — a single-day record in what looks to be a record-setting year. The T.S.A. found 1,320 guns in 2011, 1,556 in 2012, 1,813 in 2013 — and has found roughly 900 so far in 2014.

headline: Mighty Spain Goes Out of the World Cup Meekly
abstract: There was a sense of pity in seeing a legend fall so unexpectedly, and appear so helpless, in Spain’s loss to Chile, in which a death knell clanged for most of the game.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The chants at the game between Spain and Chile began slowly, first from one side of Estádio do Maracanã, then from the other. By the time the final minutes had ticked off the clock Wednesday, tens of thousands of fans had joined in.

headline: Maine Court Fight Pits Farmers Against State and One Another
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Milk', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Local Food', 'Law and Legislation', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'States (US)']
abstract: Maine farmers are fighting state regulations that require them to obtain licenses to sell food products directly to consumers.
lead_paragraph: BLUE HILL, Me. — When Dan Brown quit his job driving trucks and began to work on his wife’s family homestead here about a decade ago, he was looking forward to a quiet life of farming. He began raising chickens and growing vegetables, and watched happily as a calf named Sprocket thrived. The Browns built a farm stand and began selling unpasteurized milk and eventually other products, like jam and salsa.

headline: Amazon Fire Phone’s Missed Opportunities
abstract: The world needed a great, cheap smartphone, and Amazon seems uniquely capable of delivering such a device. But the Fire instead aims at a saturated high end.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When Amazon invited the media and hundreds of its most loyal customers to witness the unveiling of a new device on Wednesday, everyone thought the company would introduce a smartphone made in the mold of its line of tablet computers: pretty good and really cheap.

headline: ‘This Isn’t About Farmer Brown Anymore’
abstract: Dan Brown is a Maine farmer who was sued by the state for selling milk without a license. On Tuesday, Mr. Brown lost an appeal he had made to the state’s highest court.
lead_paragraph: Dan Brown is a Maine farmer who was sued by the state for selling milk without a license. On Tuesday, Mr. Brown lost an appeal he had made to the state’s highest court.

headline: Courting Swing Vote in Harlem District: Whites
keywords: ['Gentrification', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Population']
abstract: The jousting over white residents underscores how gentrification and redistricting have altered the battle lines in a district long seen as a stronghold of black political power.
lead_paragraph: There was never a question that race would play a key role in Representative Charles B. Rangel’s re-election fight, a battle for a seat held by two black men since the 1940s, in a district where Hispanics recently became the majority.

headline: Slurs Don’t Deserve Trademark Protection
abstract: A ruling to cancel the trademark registration of the name of the Washington Redskins because it is disparaging to American Indians was right.
lead_paragraph: There is no question that the term “redskin” has been used as a racial slur for American Indians for hundreds of years and is on par with offensive terms used to denigrate blacks and Hispanics. And it is also clear that federal law prohibits the Patent and Trademark Office from registering trademarks that disparage people or bring them “into contempt, or disrepute.”

headline: Roaring on the Seas
abstract: China’s mounting campaign to control the South China Sea has generated fear and anger among its neighbors, and tensions with Washington.

On Wednesday, at a high-level meeting in Hanoi, China’s top diplomat scolded his Vietnamese hosts for complaining about an oil rig that Beijing planted in early May in waters that Vietnam claims, as its own.

headline: Mexico: Governor of Michoacán Resigns
abstract: The governor of Michoacán, one of the country’s most violent states, where people have taken up arms to fight drug and organized crime gangs, has resigned because of poor health
lead_paragraph: The governor of Michoacán, one of the country’s most violent states, where people have taken up arms to fight drug and organized crime gangs, has resigned because of poor health. The resignation on Wednesday of the governor, Fausto Vallejo, 65, injects political uncertainty in a state where officials’ failure to quell surging violence, giving rise to vigilante groups, led the federal government to take over security this year. Mr. Vallejo, whose four-year term expires in 2016, did not disclose his health problem, but he underwent a liver transplant last year. He returned Tuesday night from a checkup in the United States and informed President Enrique Peña Nieto of his decision Wednesday morning. The State Legislature will choose a successor to serve the remainder of the term.

headline: Stuart Vaughan, Director and Shakespeare Expert, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Vaughan, who got his start directing the first productions of the New York Shakespeare Festival in 1956, professed a loyalty to the text and an aversion to “revisionist approaches.”
lead_paragraph: Stuart Vaughan, who directed the first productions of the New York Shakespeare Festival and later seeded several regions of the country with classic works, starting repertory theaters in Seattle and New Orleans and another that toured community centers and colleges, died on June 10 at his home in High Bridge, N.J. He was 88.
