headline: Who Can Speak for the Patient?
abstract: Our patient was never going to wake up, and no decision should ever be made without consulting the spouse. But I hadn’t known she existed.
lead_paragraph: Our patient was never going to wake up. He had an unrecoverable brain injury. The prognosis had become clear over time. As the patient’s attending physician in the intensive care unit, I arranged a meeting with his sister, the only visitor we’d seen for days, and explained. She was resolute. “He’ll wake up,” she said. “He’s a fighter. Do everything you can to keep him alive.”

headline: The Slumdog Millionaire Architect
abstract: Hafeez Contractor’s wildly prolific (and flamboyant) architecture has come to define Mumbai. But have his projects helped improve life in the city’s slums?
lead_paragraph: The offices of Hafeez Contractor, India’s most commercially successful architect, are on Bank Street, just around the corner from the Mumbai Stock Exchange. The prestige of the address, however, is undermined by the beleaguered state of the Raj-era building. In the reception area, a flat-screen displaying a loop of Contractor’s futuristic projects is mounted on a cracked, stained plaster wall. Upstairs, hundreds of designers sit shoulder to shoulder at long rows of computer monitors, packed in almost as mercilessly as on the commuter trains that ferry them to work each day. The office has struggled to keep up with the firm’s expanding work force and is perpetually under construction. Staff members were known to walk 15 minutes to the five-star Taj Mahal Palace Hotel rather than brave the employee-restroom line. Contractor has vastly increased his square footage by building a loft, but a day at the office now entails ducking through archways, dodging stray wires and ignoring the wail of power saws.

lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Having caught his first big break on radio 50 years ago, José Carlos Araújo, who had honed his sportscasting skills by calling button soccer games in a neighbor’s backyard, figured he would have to tame his changing voice to avoid losing his pitch halfway through the effusively long cries of “goooooool” that are the hallmark and necessity of a Brazilian play-by-play announcer’s routine.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on airport safety, the Redskins’ trademark, nuclear waste, Argentine debt and Columbian peace.
lead_paragraph: “On June 4, a 32-year-old woman tried to get through security at San Antonio International Airport with a loaded .380 caliber Diamondback in her carry-on bag,” The New York Times reports. “This wasn’t a freak occurrence. Transportation Security Administration officials intercepted 18 guns on that day alone — a single-day record in what looks to be a record-setting year.” The editorial calls on state governments to introduce measures that would make any attempt to bring a firearm into an airport a felony. “Unless states decide to classify bringing a gun into security as a felony, though, forgetful people will almost certainly continue to have the right to own, carry and misplace firearms because basic responsibility hasn’t been made a prerequisite for gun ownership.”

headline: Keeping a Cash-Starved Start-Up on Track
abstract: The goal is to sustain team enthusiasm when people are working hard, often late at night and on weekends, to release a product they will probably have to redo repeatedly until it’s right.
lead_paragraph: In a start-up, there’s always too much to do and not enough time or money to do it. There are never enough people to fix what’s broken and never enough resources to develop the next strategic phase. For the first 12 months of Posse, I felt as if I was swimming as hard as I could, trying to avoid drowning. But I knew that if we were going to succeed I had to develop a rhythm to our development.

headline: Why We’re All Crony Capitalists, Like It or Not
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Big business and big government are inextricably linked in ways that fans of free markets may not like but can’t really avoid.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one thing that populists on the left and right can agree upon, it is disdain for crony capitalism. It is a distaste for the cesspool of Washington influence, in which big-business lobbyists canoodle with lawmakers to get their way. It is anger at corporate welfare enriching America’s biggest companies at the expense of the little guy.

lead_paragraph: In the face of Detroit’s tumultuous bankruptcy proceedings, the city and its unions have quietly negotiated a scaled-back pension plan that could serve as a model for other troubled governments, Mary Williams Walsh writes in DealBook. One of the most closely watched issues of the case is whether government pensions can be legally cut in bankruptcy. Now, Detroit has introduced a new plan with the cooperation of its unions, which have been among the most vocal opponents of cutbacks.

headline: For Dov Charney of American Apparel, an Abrupt Fall From Grace
abstract: After years of negative press, the board of American Apparel ousted Mr. Charney as chairman and chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Dov Charney was no one’s idea of a button-down executive.

headline: Q. and A. | Max Silvestri, Funnyman and Foodie
abstract: The Brooklyn-based comedian, who has just released his first stand-up album, “King Piglet,” talks about his favorite dining haunts and his hypothetical last meal on earth.
lead_paragraph: Is Brooklyn the epicenter of new comedy? To make such a claim would be to bait Internet controversy. But it’s safe to say that in 2008 a very good and very influential weekly comedy show, Big Terrific — hosted by Jenny Slate, Gabe Liedman and Max Silvestri — began on Wednesday nights in Williamsburg, eventually settling at Cameo gallery. Since then, it’s become a destination for pros to work out new material (famous names like Aziz Ansari, Zach Galifianakis, John Mulaney and Sarah Silverman have been known to drop by) and for up-and-comers to earn their stripes.

headline: Analysts Say China May Try to Use Manmade Islands to Bolster Bid for Economic Development
abstract: Analysts say China could try to assert that new islands in disputed waters entitle the country to exclusive economic zones just off the coastlines.
lead_paragraph: China has been moving sand onto some reefs and rocks in the Spratly archipelago of the South China Sea to create islands that can support buildings, equipment and human habitation. The construction is stirring anxiety in the Philippines and Vietnam, which compete with China over territorial claims in the Spratly Islands, and raising alarms in the United States, which sees China’s actions in the South China Sea as destabilizing.

headline: Rouhani Vows to Protect Shiite Shrines
abstract: Speaking on Iranian television, President Hassan Rouhani said Tehran would defend Shiite holy sites in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Speaking on Iranian television, President Hassan Rouhani said Tehran would defend Shiite holy sites in Iraq.

headline: China Uses ‘House of Cards’ as Illustration of West’s Corruption
abstract: The Communist Party’s top graft investigation group has published an article using the series “House of Cards” as evidence of the extent of influence-peddling in the West and argue that China is fundamentally different.
lead_paragraph: Money, sex, power and scandal. Netflix’s political thriller “House of Cards,” about a ruthlessly ambitious American politician, has drawn millions of Chinese viewers with these themes, which are largely prohibited on state television.

headline: How Do You Take the Measure of a School Year?
abstract: Was the 2013-14 school year, with its Common Core, its policy debates and its snow days, a success for education, for schools, or for students?
lead_paragraph: As the school year draws to a close, teachers and parents are left wondering how to take its measure, to identify their successes, failures and lessons learned. For those who follow education news, 2013-14 has been The Year of Big Data, and conclusions from recently published studies and surveys have been released in the media like so many rubber balls from a dump truck. The resulting bouncy chaos has been difficult to subdue, let alone organize and interpret.

headline: Colum McCann: By the Book
abstract: The author of “TransAtlantic” and “Let the Great World Spin” says choosing a favorite living novelist is like walking the plank: “Inevitably you end up drowning, but at least it’s in a sea of heroes.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “TransAtlantic” and “Let the Great World Spin” says choosing a favorite living novelist is like walking the plank: “Inevitably you end up drowning, but at least it’s in a sea of heroes.”

headline: A Holy Space in More Ways Than One
abstract: Theater artists look back at their experiences in the second-floor space at St. Mark’s Church, a home for experimental theater for decades.
lead_paragraph: Since 1964, a former Sunday school classroom on the second floor of St. Mark’s Church in the East Village has housed a theater. To find it, walk through a rusty gate, past a graveyard, up a narrow flight of stairs, across a cramped lobby and into new worlds.

lead_paragraph: The brother of a top aide to Hu Jintao, the former Chinese president, has been put under investigation by the ruling Communist Party, its internal discipline agency said on Thursday.

headline: Richard Linklater’s Leading Boy
abstract: The movie “Boyhood” was filmed over the course of a dozen years. Its star, Ellar Coltrane, practically grew up on film.
lead_paragraph: In his new film, “Boyhood,” the director Richard Linklater takes a novel approach to the classic coming-of-age story — one that’s both strikingly radical and entirely logical. Filmed in short installments over a period of 12 years, “Boyhood” details the journey from boyhood to adolescence of one Mason Jr., played by Ellar Coltrane, above, who blossoms on screen before our eyes from a pensive, tentative 6-year-old to a sensitive, freethinking young man of 18.

lead_paragraph: The original plan Jeff Bobula and Caitlin Mennen-Bobula had was to buy a multifamily Brooklyn brownstone.

headline: Challengers Emerge to Replace Divisive Maliki
abstract: Iraqi leaders, alarmed over the Sunni insurgency, are actively seeking to replace Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki with someone supported by all Iraqi sects.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi officials said Thursday that political leaders had started intensive jockeying to replace Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki and create a government that would span the country’s deepening sectarian and ethnic divisions, spurred by what they called encouraging meetings with American officials signaling support for a leadership change.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Striped Knits on the London Runways
abstract: The look, presented in retro colorways, had a kind of ’70s-by-way-of-the-’90s vibe.
lead_paragraph: Instead of the now ubiquitous nautical stripes, designers at the spring/summer 2015 London men’s shows presented variegated striped knits in retro colorways, with a ’70s-by-way-of-the-’90s feeling. They’re the kind of sweaters that the Blur frontman Damon Albarn might have worn circa “Parklife,” or Harmony Korine might have slipped into while he was writing “Kids.” At Topman, a mockneck was paired with bell bottoms (and alternately layered under a short-sleeve daisy-printed shirt). Pringle of Scotland offered a tailored version of the retro golf sweater, worn with suit pants. Meanwhile, continuing his exploration of gender boundaries, J.W. Anderson presented the throwback striped look in the form of a knotted boatneck.

headline: When Getting Laughs Annoys the Neighbors
abstract: The “Live @ the Apt” stand-up comedy shows really are at somebody’s apartment, which makes for a close if crowded camaraderie.
lead_paragraph: “THIS is the kind of show you’re really going to appreciate if comedy is ever illegal,” the comedian Sam Morril said, looking around a small basement in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It was a rainy night, and about three dozen people were gathered in the downstairs of a duplex for “Live @ the Apt,” a regular stand-up show held in the home of its producers. “It’s a very Prohibition-era vibe,” Mr. Morril added.

keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ruling out combat forces, President Obama said the United States will send up to 300 advisers to help Iraq repel Sunni militants who have captured several cities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Thursday that he would deploy up to 300 military advisers to Iraq to help its struggling security forces fend off a wave of Sunni militants who have overrun large parts of the country, edging the United States back into a conflict that Mr. Obama once thought he had left behind.

headline: 40 Indian Workers Kidnapped in Iraq Are Said to Have Been  Located
abstract: The Indian government announced on Thursday that the 40 Indian construction workers kidnapped in Mosul have been located, though the government declined to give further details.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI – After an hours-long journey in a private bus from villages near the city of Amritsar, in Punjab State, the families of 13 of the 40 construction workers whom the Indian government announced had been kidnapped in the northern Iraqi city of Mosul arrived at the Gurdwara Rakab Ganj, a centuries-old Sikh shrine, on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Astronomers Hedge on Big Bang Detection Claim
abstract: Astronomers who said they had detected remnants of the Big Bang’s origins now concede that dust from the Milky Way may have skewed their findings.
lead_paragraph: A group of astronomers who announced in March that they had detected space-time disturbances — gravitational waves — from the beginning of the Big Bang reaffirmed their claim on Thursday but conceded that dust from the Milky Way galaxy might have interfered with their observations.

headline: The Unsettled Politics of Foreign Policy
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: What recent events might mean for Hillary Clinton, Rand Paul and 2016.
lead_paragraph: The conventional wisdom, such as it is, on the political impact of events in Iraq, Ukraine and elsewhere seems to be that they will empower the Republican Party’s hawkish establishment at the expense of the party’s libertarian/anti-interventionist wing — strengthening the hawks’ critique of the Obama White House, bringing Bush-era voices back to the fore, and throwing new obstacles in Rand Paul’s already-difficult path to the nomination. And when you combine this scenario with Hillary Clinton’s none-too-subtle positioning of herself as a more interventionist figure than the current president, you have the possibility of the return of a kind of 2004-style hawkish center in American presidential politics, in which both Clinton and her eventual G.O.P. rival (be it a Cruz, a Rubio, a Bush, a Christie, whomever) would compete to out-tough the other on terrorism, Syria, Iran, ISIS, Putin, and so forth.

headline: Chelsea Handler Will Host a Late-Night Talk Show on Netflix
abstract: The show is a departure for the streaming service in that it will be topical and not follow the previous pattern of all episodes being posted at once.
lead_paragraph: A late-night talk show on Netflix? That is what the company announced on Thursday as part of a deal with Chelsea Handler, the soon-to-exit star from the E! cable network.

headline: Raise Minimum Wage Past $10? Been Here Before

headline: Drawing a Line Between Art and Abuse
abstract: A profile asks if Terry Richardson is an artist or a predator, but many are arguing he can be both, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: “Is Terry Richardson an Artist or a Predator?” asks the headline of a recent New York Magazine profile of the fashion photographer. That question is getting nearly as much discussion as the article itself. Many argue that Mr. Richardson is able to get away with predatory behavior precisely because he’s a male artist in a society that valorizes them.

headline: You’re Just Too Good to Be True
abstract: Clint Eastwood’s “Jersey Boys,” the adaptation of the Broadway musical, is a redemption narrative that’s got a good beat.
lead_paragraph: At the end of “Jersey Boys,” Clint Eastwood’s likable, resolutely laid-back adaptation of the Broadway musical, the actors all freeze. They’ve just performed their last song on a set that looks so artificial that you half-expect the Sharks and the Jets to leap into the frame. Instead, that Jersey music man Frankie Valli and the other Seasons, along with a crowd of central-casting types, gather one last time and together warble and fancy-foot down a back-lot street. They finish big and then they all stop, staring straight ahead as sweat pops and bodies tremble under the now harsh lighting. That’s entertainment, baby, and it is hard work.

headline: Image of the Day: June 19
abstract: India receives annual rainfall from June to September.

headline: Listen Up | A New Indie Label With an Old Soul
abstract: London’s Movement Records, started by pals Christian Gregory and Michael Kiwanuka, gives a voice to emerging soul artists in Britain. Gregory’s new video premieres here.
lead_paragraph: Few record label bosses have the distinction of also being their own first signee. But that’s the case with the British soul artist Christian Gregory, who started Movement Records in London last year as a platform for emerging soul artists in the U.K. “There were a few labels doing kind of throwback stuff,” he says, “but none that really cater to soul as an art form in itself.” The child of classical musicians, Gregory started looking for his own musical direction at an early age. “My parents’ record collection is mostly orchestral stuff, so I would hunt through and look for anything that was different,” he says. “The closest thing I could usually find was either jazz or swing.” By his teens, his love for soul had taken hold.

headline: Nick Wooster, One-Man Brand
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Social Media', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: Mr. Wooster’s capsule collection, to debut at the Pitti men’s fair in Italy, is just one of the products of his web fame.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — He is an Instagram idol, an object of veneration across social media platforms, the sole focus of blogs consecrated to charting his individual style. That style, which the fashion retailer and savant Nickelson Wooster spent decades retooling, has lately become influential enough in the age of image obsession that a cadre of street photographers tracks him wherever he goes.

headline: Book of Comedy Interviews Coming From Judd Apatow
abstract: “Sick in the Head,” due out next year, is a compilation of interviews Judd Apatow has conduced with comedy heroes and colleagues.
lead_paragraph: The producer, director and screenwriter Judd Apatow’s expansive ideas about comedy and how it works are evident in his films and television series, which include “The 40-Year-Old Virgin,” “Knocked Up,” “Freaks and Geeks” and “Girls.” But Mr. Apatow has always liked talking about comedy with others who practice it, and now Random House has signed him to produce “Sick in the Head,” a compilation of interviews he has conducted with many of his comedy heroes and colleagues over the last three decades. The book is due in 2015. Proceeds will go to 826LA, a nonprofit organization that teaches creative writing to students between 6 and 18.

headline: Dining Without Borders
abstract: Baoburg’s idiosyncratic menu owes as much to classical European technique as it does to the chef’s cross-cultural upbringing.
lead_paragraph: Here come the devils on horseback, that relic of dinner parties past: prunes and dates cowled in bacon and thrust onto skewers, chewy, crunchy, sweet and salty at once. Except that these devils are in Japanese garb, adorned with nitsume, the dark, sticky sauce that traditionally accompanies eel; squiggles of extra-tangy Kewpie mayonnaise; and translucent bonito flakes like blanched confetti.

headline: ‘Tick, Tick … Boom!’
abstract: Lin-Manuel Miranda and Karen Olivo rehearse the number “Therapy” from the Encores! Off-Center production of the Jonathan Larson musical.
lead_paragraph: Lin-Manuel Miranda and Karen Olivo rehearse the number “Therapy” from the Encores! Off-Center production of the Jonathan Larson musical.

headline: Colombia and Its Coach Bring Joy to Fans by Advancing
abstract: Colombia struck within four minutes of Didier Drogba’s entry, scoring on James Rodríguez’s header in the 64th minute and on Juan Quintero’s goal six minutes later.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — After their first World Cup victory in 16 years last Saturday, Colombia fans expressed their appreciation by giving Coach José Pékerman more than 400,000 write-in votes in Sunday’s presidential election.

headline: Redskins Isn’t the Only Name the Patent Office Has Blocked
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Native Americans', 'Discrimination', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity']
abstract: Questions regarding what constitutes a slur against Asian-Americans, Italian-Americans and Jews have come before the office in recent years.
lead_paragraph: The United States Patent and Trademark Office blocked the trademark registration for the Washington Redskins on Wednesday on grounds that it disparaged an ethnic group, American Indians. While such cases are not common, they do pop up, reflecting the turbulent mixing bowl of American ethnicity.

headline: Obama on New Military Advisers to Iraq
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The president said the United States would send up to 300 military advisers to Iraq to train that country’s security forces, but he emphasized that America would not be returning to combat.
lead_paragraph: The president said the United States would send up to 300 military advisers to Iraq to train that country’s security forces, but he emphasized that America would not be returning to combat.

headline: Wheelies: The Price of Fuel Edition
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Senators propose raising the federal gas and diesel tax for the first time since 1993; Acura will support the Tiger Woods Foundation.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Command Performance
abstract: Jeffery Renard Allen’s novel “Song of the Shank” draws on the real life of Thomas Wiggins, a blind piano prodigy and autistic savant born a slave in 19th-century Georgia.
lead_paragraph: Before the Chitlin’ Circuit, before the Cotton Club and eons before “Soul Train” or Black Entertainment Television (BET) put black talent on display, there was Congo Square in New Orleans. During Louisiana’s 18th-century French and Spanish colonial era, slaves were allowed to convene near the square on their Sundays off from work to sing, dance and play music — a practice that continued beyond the Louisiana Purchase. Word spread of the spectacle, and soon the slaves began to draw crowds of whites. Later the attempted suppression of “savage” African music by the Protestants helped transform Congo Square into a phenomenon sought by visitors from far and wide. You could argue that in that square, located in what is now Louis Armstrong Park, the American black as an entertainer was born.

headline: Italian Businessman Paolo Scaroni to Join Rothschild
abstract: Mr. Scaroni is expected to join the British financial advisory firm Rothschild Group as deputy chairman on July 1. He was ousted in May as chief executive of Eni, the partially state-owned oil company in Italy.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British financial advisory firm Rothschild Group has hired Paolo Scaroni, an influential Italian businessman who was pushed out as chief executive of the oil company Eni this year by Italy’s prime minister, Matteo Renzi.

headline: Food Networks
abstract: Two books report on culinary trends, and offer a vision for sustainable farming and eating.
lead_paragraph: To start a food trend from agriculture is “one of the riskiest” things an entrepreneur can do, David Sax writes in “The Tastemakers,” his entertaining new excursion into, as his subtitle has it, “Why We’re Crazy for Cupcakes but Fed Up With Fondue.” “Yet every day,” he adds, “there are countless farmers, scientists and gardening dreamers with a trowel in their hand, digging in the dirt and planting the seed that they hope will one day change the way we eat.”

headline: New York Leaders Reach Deal on Medical Marijuana
abstract: The agreement includes a major demand of the Cuomo administration: that no smoking of the drug would be permitted, though other options would be.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders announced an agreement on Thursday for a pilot program to provide access to marijuana to sick New Yorkers, making the state one of the largest to embrace the drug’s use as medicine.

headline: Arms and the Men
abstract: Two new books describe the history of the Second Amendment and the tradition of self-defense among Southern blacks.
lead_paragraph: “The right of the people to keep and bear arms” has been enshrined in the Second Amendment to the Constitution since 1792. In our day, the National Rifle Association and batteries of conservative jurists have fought so successfully to persuade people that the amendment guarantees Americans an individual right of self-­defense that in 2008 the Supreme Court declared unconstitutional an outright ban on handguns for residents of the District of Columbia. Two years later, the court ruled that Chicago could not ban handguns, either — the right to own handguns applied all over the United States.

headline: House Republicans Name McCarthy as Cantor’s Replacement
abstract: The vote that placed a conservative Louisiana with Tea Party support in the No. 3 leadership spot was an effort to quell some unease among party hard-liners.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans reached for continuity and stability on Thursday in electing a new leadership team, promoting a Californian of moderate temperament to No. 2 and a more conservative Louisianian who has the loyalty of the Tea Party as No. 3 in an effort to quell dissent in their restive ranks.

headline: A Deal-Making Touch Honed in the Minority
abstract: Politically obsessed and manically social, Representative Kevin McCarthy is likely to be more focused on brokering deals and winning elections than on pushing policy from on high.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When he was the leader of Republicans in the California State Assembly — an ideologically diverse group of lawmakers often choleric toward both Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and the Democrats who controlled the Legislature — Kevin Owen McCarthy was known as the guy who could help bring a bill across the finish line. Gently, almost as if no one could see it.

headline: Obama on What Iraq’s Leadership Must Do
abstract: President Obama said the fate of Iraq hangs in the balance and discussed whether Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki could unify his country given the sectarian divisions.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said the fate of Iraq hangs in the balance and discussed whether Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki could unify his country given the sectarian divisions.

headline: Disenchantment in France With Fickle National Team
abstract: Public opinion about Les Bleus, the 1998 World Cup champions, has soured since their mutiny at the 2010 World Cup, and the French have yet to re-embrace the team.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Les Bleus, the French national soccer team, went on strike in South Africa. The incident capped the team’s self-destruction in the 2010 World Cup. In the aftermath, the players were called undereducated “PlayStation junkies” who were too individualistic to serve the nation.

headline: Domino Sugar, Brooklyn’s Sweet Story, Makes History
abstract: An exhibition about the sugar industry in Brooklyn is at the Brooklyn Historical Society.
lead_paragraph: Almost 20 years ago, the Miser stood on the Brooklyn waterfront in Williamsburg, wondering how long it would take the city’s savvier real estate developers to salvage the considerable stock of forsaken lots and warehouses, perched perfectly between a rapidly gentrifying neighborhood and sweeping river views.

headline: Five Plead Guilty to Beating a Motorist in Detroit
abstract: Pleas to reduced charges end a case that had raised concerns about racial tension and vigilantism in the bankrupt city.
lead_paragraph: Five people involved in the severe beating of a Detroit motorist after his truck hit a 10-year-old boy pleaded guilty this week to reduced charges, ending a case that had raised concerns about racial tension and vigilantism in the bankrupt city.

headline: Obama on Engaging Iran in Iraq Crisis
abstract: The president discussed Iran’s declaration to intervene in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: The president discussed Iran’s declaration to intervene in Iraq.

headline: Neruda Poems Found
abstract: Twenty previously unknown poems by Neruda, a Nobel laureate, were discovered by researchers cataloging his manuscripts at the Pablo Neruda Foundation in Santiago, Chile.
lead_paragraph: Twenty previously unknown poems by Pablo Neruda have been discovered by the Pablo Neruda Foundation in Santiago, Chile. Seix Barral, Neruda’s Barcelona-based publisher, announced the news on Wednesday. Elena Ramirez, the company’s editorial director, called it “”the biggest find in Spanish literature in recent years,” and emphasized “the extremely high quality” of several of the poems.

headline: Video of Man Rescued From German Cave
abstract: Rescuers from Bavaria’s Mountain Rescue Service carefully extracted an injured explorer through a series of shafts and tunnels after he was trapped for more than 11 days.
lead_paragraph: Rescuers from Bavaria’s Mountain Rescue Service carefully extracted an injured explorer through a series of shafts and tunnels after he was trapped for more than 11 days.

headline: Wisconsin Governor at Center of a Vast Fund-Raising Case
abstract: Prosecutors in Wisconsin say Gov. Scott Walker was part of an effort to illegally coordinate fund-raising and spending between his campaign and outside groups, according to unsealed court filings.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Prosecutors in Wisconsin assert that Gov. Scott Walker was part of an elaborate effort to illegally coordinate fund-raising and spending between his campaign and conservative groups during efforts to recall him and several state senators two years ago, according to court filings unsealed Thursday.

headline: Baptism by Fire
abstract: Coming soon, by N.R. Kleinfield: Jordan Sullivan’s decade-long dream of joining the Fire Department had come true. Now he had to prove himself.
lead_paragraph: Coming soon, by N.R. Kleinfield: Jordan Sullivan’s decade-long dream of joining the Fire Department had come true. Now he had to prove himself.

headline: At Art Basel, Works With a Museum Presence
abstract: With 285 galleries from 34 countries participating, the Art Basel fair in Switzerland is still a magnet for the contemporary art world.
lead_paragraph: BASEL, Switzerland — In an old market hall adjacent to the cavernous center where Art Basel, the gold standard of contemporary art fairs, is taking place, there is a happening unlike anything ever staged here. Called “14 Rooms,” it consists of 14 mini-performances created by artists including Marina Abramovic, Damien Hirst and Yoko Ono, each secreted in a small space behind mirrored doors. Open one door, and there’s a Marina Abramovic look-alike naked and astride a bicycle seat, arms outstretched. In another, identical twins sit in front of identical spot paintings by Mr. Hirst.

headline: Public Worker Testimony Is Protected, Justices Rule
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously in the case of an Alabama college official who was fired after testifying in a public corruption trial.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The First Amendment protects government employees from retaliation for giving truthful testimony that was not part of their job responsibilities, a unanimous Supreme Court ruled Thursday.

headline: A German Voice, Hans-Olaf Henkel, Calls for Euro’s Abolition
abstract: Mr. Henkel, a former business chief who was recently elected to the European Parliament, has joined a wave of popular discontent with the European Union.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — He was once one of Germany’s most prominent business leaders, head of a major industry lobby and IBM’s top executive in Europe. But recently Hans-Olaf Henkel has embarked on a new career, one that puts him radically at odds with most of his European business peers.

headline: As Demand for Education Rises in Brazil, For-Profit Colleges Fill the Gap
abstract: Despite concerns about an emphasis on the business of education, private equity funds and investment banks are buying and merging educational institutions at a rapid pace.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Higher education in Brazil is increasingly in the hands of profit-seeking entrepreneurs.

headline: Ask Well | Game On, Weekend Warrior
abstract: A reader asked Well if occasional cardiovascular exercise is better or worse than regular workouts.
lead_paragraph: A reader asked Well if occasional cardiovascular exercise is better or worse than regular workouts.

headline: Money Remains Crime-Fighting Tool for New York Police
abstract: In the last six years, the Police Department and programs like Crime Stoppers have paid at least $18 million for information, though overall payments have declined.
lead_paragraph: Amid advances in data-driven policing and forensic science, one traditional crime-solving tool has remained a constant for the New York Police Department: money.

headline: Sunday Night Dinner | At Il Buco, Platefuls of Pasta Seem Made to be Lingered Over
abstract: At this classic NoHo restaurant, the laziest day of the week is arguably the most appropriate for enjoying bowls of scallop crudo, olive oil tastings and off-the-menu rib-eye by candlelight.
lead_paragraph: The writer Charlotte Druckman and the photographer Melanie Dunea spend Sunday evenings at New York City dining establishments to find out what’s new with the people behind them.

headline: What’s a Tiara Like You Doing on Reality TV?
abstract: Donors raised $43,000 to buy a diamond tiara once owned by President William McKinley’s wife from the Las Vegas shop on “Pawn Stars.”
lead_paragraph: A first lady’s diamond tiara will head “home” to Ohio soon.

headline: Ask Well: Weekend Warriors
abstract: A reader asks: Is infrequent cardiovascular exercise (like jogging once in a while) better, or worse, than not exercising at all?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Support From the Left Helps Keep a Right-Wing President in Power in Colombia
abstract: By declaring a vote for Juan Manuel Santos as a vote in favor of peace negotiations with rebel groups, Clara López made the country’s left politically relevant again.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Going into Sunday’s presidential election here, many people expected that the right-wing former president, Álvaro Uribe, would be the one whose outsize influence might tip the balance in favor of his preferred candidate, Óscar Iván Zuluaga.

headline: Iraqi Youth Orchestra Cancels American Trip
abstract: Instability in Iraq means the National Youth Orchestra of Iraq will not be able to make a planned trip to perform in the United States.
lead_paragraph: For the 43 teenage musicians of the National Youth Orchestra of Iraq, it was a dream about to come true: the ensemble, formed by the Iraqi pianist Zuhal Sultan in 2008, was planning to visit the United States this summer to work a similarly constituted American group, the Elgin Youth Symphony Orchestra, of Elgin, Ill., and then to perform in Elgin, Washington, D.C., Chicago and possibly New York (a concert was in the planning stages).

headline: 36 Hours in Madrid
abstract: Shop for handmade shoes and edible souvenirs, sample cocktails and cuisine and go on a cultural crawl during a weekend in the Spanish capital.
lead_paragraph: In the five years since Spain’s economy took a nose-dive, madrileños never stopped going out, but they did become more judicious in their spending. While not easy on businesses, this has ultimately been good for consumers, as retailers and restaurateurs dug deep in the treasure chest of Spanish talents and traditions — not to mention agricultural bounty — to weather the economic storm. Before that storm, Madrid seemed frantic to become a copy of any other European metropolis, but now the city feels more Spanish again. Resourcefulness, creativity and reinvention are bubbling up in art galleries, designer ateliers and restaurants. The city’s symbol may be a bear, but for style, culture, history and sybaritic delights, there are plenty of reasons to be bullish on Madrid.

headline: Valencia’s Newest Sounds of Music
abstract: In recent years, a whole new music scene has developed in this Spanish city, merging local musicians with students from all over the world.
lead_paragraph: Music is at the heart of Valencia, Spain’s third largest city. For hundreds of years, people in and around the city have formed symphonic brass bands. Children grow up learning to dance the jota and boleros and to play works by Mozart and Stravinsky, with flamenco coursing through their veins as well. Bordering the Mediterranean on Spain’s east coast, Valencia has long been the nexus of Western, African, Hispanic and South American cultures, the various musical traditions blending with the local.

headline: A Mother-Daughter Test: London, Together
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Books and Literature', 'Children and Childhood', 'Theater', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: What’s it like to explore the city, through books and theater, history and art, with your 8-year-old?
lead_paragraph: Traveling with children seems to operate on a continuum that begins with plane discomfort for the gravely pregnant and ends with teenagers taking ski trips without you. It’s the various in-between stages that currently occupy me: the necessary Children-as-Extra-Luggage travel, as I once did on a book tour with a 5-month-old, coordinating feeds between readings; followed by attempts at Traveling Despite the Child, which my husband and I once did in Japan, hoisting our 10-month-old in a backpack and dining in our hotel bathroom while she slept. And then there is the interminable Where Else Could We Possibly Go? stage, a yearslong stretch of visits to the in-laws, house rentals in places where you won’t bother other people, forays into Disneyland. Into this category fall the whiling away of two-week breaks, babysitter vacations and four-day weekends that constitute the academic calendar.

headline: Moments in Iraq Reporters Will Never Forget
abstract: As the country once again teeters toward sectarian warfare, we asked reporters from The New York Times — now on other beats, in other parts of the world — which of their stories from their time in Iraq have been resurfacing in their minds.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of the United States’ long entanglement in Iraq, many reporters from The New York Times have cycled through the bureau in Baghdad. As the country once again teeters toward sectarian warfare, we asked these reporters — now on other beats, in other parts of the world — which stories from their time in Iraq have been resurfacing in their minds. Several recalled ominous hints of what was to come, while others described the moment that pushed them to see just how deep-seated Iraq’s problems are.

headline: Unplugging in the Unofficial Capital of Yoga
abstract: With her cellphone turned off, the author journeys to Rishikesh, India, where some people think yoga was born.
lead_paragraph: It was a hot and dusty afternoon, about 30 hours into my Indian journey, when the bus driver dropped me off in a small town that he said was near my destination: Rishikesh, regarded as the unofficial world capital of yoga. Only a short rickshaw ride, it seemed, separated my fatigued self from inner Zen. Nearly two weeks of life with monks at an ashram awaited.

headline: Congressional Panel Subpoenaed in Insider Trading Inquiry
keywords: ['Insider Trading', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Federal prosecutors and financial regulators are seeking records from the panel as part of an inquiry into a surge in stock prices of health insurers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors and financial regulators have subpoenaed Congress in an investigation that could test the limits of federal insider trading laws.

headline: Picnic Tables for Dancing, Bookcases for Naps
abstract: The Third Rail Projects dance and performance company has set up shop for the summer on Governors Island, offering the public a window into the troupe’s creative process.
lead_paragraph: FROM a distance, the yellow clapboard house on Governors Island looks normal, with its pretty pink flowers, white gingerbread porch railing and wide side yard. But move a little closer, and you start to wonder.

headline: Our Robot Nightmares
abstract: The more sophisticated robots become, the more, ANNA NORTH writes, we are freaked out by them.
lead_paragraph: As robotics technology grows ever more surprising, its developers and users face a difficult problem: Robots are kind of scary.

headline: Congress and Us: A Hate-Love Relationship
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Only 7 percent of Americans say they are confident in Congress, a new low, but that won’t keep us from re-electing our local representatives.
lead_paragraph: Dear Congress: Our relationship has soured. I no longer have confidence in you. I’ve asked my friends, and they all agree. Only 7 percent of my fellow Americans now tell Gallup they have either a “great deal” or “quite of lot” of confidence in you. A mere 15 percent approve of the way you’re handling your job. They never really liked your friends — big business, organized labor and the banks — but now they tell me they have more confidence in each of them than they have in you.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: postpartum depression, celiac disease and mammograms. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: postpartum depression, celiac disease and mammograms. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: A Reporter Unplugs and Still Finds Connection
abstract: Mary Pilon, a sports reporter for The Times, spent three weeks in Russia covering the Olympics in Sochi earlier this year. After the games, she spent a vacation in Rishikesh, India, and wrote about it for the Travel section.
lead_paragraph: After spending three weeks in Russia covering the Olympics in Sochi, sports reporter Mary Pilon took a vacation in Rishikesh, India. This weekend, the Travel section will publish a story that she wrote about her time there. Here she shares how the trip, inspired by her desire to unplug, and the travel piece came to be.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Spain, Iraq, Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Spain, Ukraine, Afghanistan and More – Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Spain, Ukraine, Afghanistan and More – Pictures of the Day

headline: Greece vs. Japan: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Japan worked hard against Ivory Coast and might have won in slightly different circumstances. Greece was simply woeful; a complete offensive rethink is necessary, and it’s unlikely one was made in the past few days.
lead_paragraph: Japan worked hard against Ivory Coast and might have won in slightly different circumstances. Greece was simply woeful; a complete offensive rethink is necessary, and it’s unlikely one was made in the past few days.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Spain and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Spain, Iraq, Afghanistan and Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Spain, Iraq, Afghanistan and Ukraine.

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Spring/Summer 2015 Pitti Uomo Shows
abstract: A peek at what some of the peacocks at Pitti were wearing.
lead_paragraph: A peek at what some of the peacocks at Pitti were wearing.

headline: With Pine and Ambrose Out, Rockwell and Arianda Step Into ‘Fool for Love’
abstract: The actors cite “scheduling difficulties” in departing the Williamstown Theater Festival revival of Sam Shepard’s 1983 play.
lead_paragraph: Tony winner Nina Arianda and film and stage actor Sam Rockwell will play a battling couple in “Fool For Love” at the Williamstown Theater Festival this summer, replacing Lauren Ambrose and Chris Pine, who dropped out citing “scheduling difficulties.”

headline: A New Guide to the Grand Canyon by Wheelchair
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The writer Cindy Harrington has a new guide to visiting the Grand Canyon for travelers with mobility limitations.
lead_paragraph: Wheelchair users might not think of the Grand Canyon as a place to visit comfortably, but the accessible-travel writer Candy Harrington says it can be done in “Barrier-Free Travel: The Grand Canyon for Wheelers and Slow Walkers.”

headline: Icahn Urges Family Dollar to Sell Itself
abstract: If the company does not cooperate, the activist investor says he will go directly to shareholders with an effort to throw out the entire board.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:38 p.m. | The activist investor Carl C. Icahn has turned up the heat on Family Dollar Stores, the discount retailer in which he holds a 9.39 percent stake.

headline: Auditor Moore Stephens Said Not at Fault; Puda Coal Investor Suit Is Dismissed
keywords: ['ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A federal judge in New York dismissed a shareholder class-action lawsuit against Moore Stephens, which failed to notice that Puda Coal’s managers had transferred company assets to themselves.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, Puda Coal, a Chinese company traded on the New York Stock Exchange, raised $116 million from American investors in two public offerings. It presented audited financial statements showing that it had assets of $111 million and a net worth of $84 million at the end of 2009.

headline: C.D.C. Details Anthrax Scare for Scientists at Facilities
abstract: As many as 75 scientists may have been exposed to live anthrax bacteria after potentially infectious samples were sent to laboratories unequipped to handle dangerous pathogens, an agency spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: As many as 75 scientists from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention may have been exposed to live anthrax bacteria after potentially infectious samples were sent to laboratories unequipped to handle dangerous pathogens, a spokesman for the federal health agency said Thursday.

headline: Praise to Make a Californian Blush
abstract: Expanding the notion of what California rosés can achieve.
lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, the stereotype of California rosés included all the characteristics you would never want in a pink wine: heaviness, sweetness, high alcohol.

headline: A Summer Dinner With Echoes of Paella
abstract: A bottle or two of rosé alongside makes for a happy occasion.
lead_paragraph: Do not lose any sleep over what to serve with a rosé, be it from California or elsewhere. Mia Van de Water, one of our panelists, said that people tend to order rosé the way they do Champagne, because that’s what they want to drink, and it has nothing to do with the food. Jerusha Frost, the other guest panelist, agreed. “It’s rare when you get an opportunity to pair food with a rosé,” she said.

headline: Unsealed Court Order and Exhibits From ‘John Doe’ Investigation
abstract: These court documents detail a secret investigation into whether Gov. Scott Walker and his campaign illegally coordinated fund-raising with 12 conservative groups during efforts to recall him in 2012.
lead_paragraph: These court documents detail a secret investigation into whether Gov. Scott Walker and his campaign illegally coordinated fund-raising with 12 conservative groups during efforts to recall him in 2012.

headline: Cybercriminals Zero In on a Lucrative New Target: Hedge Funds
abstract: As hedge fund capital soars, so too has the number of cyberattacks on their systems.
lead_paragraph: They say crime follows opportunity.

headline: F.C.C. Plans to Fine C.T.S. Technology of China for Selling Signal Jammers
abstract: Over the last decade, the commission has issued dozens of fines and citations against individuals and companies both for using jammers and for offering them for sale. But the F.C.C. took an especially hard line in the current case.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday proposed a $34.9 million fine, its largest ever, against a Chinese electronics company for illegally marketing cellphone and radio jamming equipment online in the United States.

headline: Promoting Mortgage Preapprovals in Competitive Markets
abstract: Smaller lenders use preapprovals to attract borrowers in markets where competition for homes is fierce.
lead_paragraph: Smaller lenders are using preapprovals to attract borrowers in markets where competition for homes is fierce.

headline: Turkish Officers Convicted in 2012 Coup Case Are Released
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The officers were among 330 convicted in the “Sledgehammer” case, so called because of the code name of an alleged plot to destabilize the government.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s highest criminal court on Thursday ordered the release and retrial of 230 military officers who were convicted in 2012 of trying to overthrow the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The decision came one day after the country’s constitutional court delivered a landmark ruling saying that the defendants’ rights had been violated.

headline: Torn by Three Loves and Styles of Jousting
abstract: Eric Rohmer’s languid 1996 film, “A Summer’s Tale,” finally released in the United States, focuses on a young man vacationing in Brittany who feels torn among three women.
lead_paragraph: Eric Rohmer, the French New Wave master, was in his mid-70s when “A Summer’s Tale,” the third installment of his “Tales of the Four Seasons” cycle, was released abroad in 1996. The only one of the cycle’s four films not distributed in the United States, it is finally having an American release, and it was worth the wait.

headline: Eye of the Beholder
abstract: Advice on a friend’s rudeness, forgetting a significant other’s birthday, having the “talk” with a teenage daughter and handshakes.
lead_paragraph: My friend’s wife is an amateur painter. She gave me a painting as a housewarming gift a few years ago. I don’t like her work, so I stashed it in my office. Recently, she borrowed it for a charity exhibition, and later told me proudly that the painting sold for $10,000. She offered me another as replacement. I think selling the picture without asking was tacky. I also think I should receive the tax deduction for the donation because the painting belonged to me. Do you agree? And may I tell her I don’t want a replacement?

headline: Indie Rock Reflections on a Place and Time
abstract: The rock critic Gina Arnold’s “Exile in Guyville” takes its name from, and chews over, Liz Phair’s wise, weird, lo-fi, high-concept 1993 debut album.
lead_paragraph: Frank Zappa made a hobby out of tilting at rock journalists. He called the lot of them, in a tidy summary, “people who can’t write interviewing people who can’t talk for people who can’t read.”

headline: Globe Wiped Out? Tips From the Vault
abstract: Luckily for the crew in TNT’s new series “The Last Ship,” television has been ending the world almost since the medium was invented. Here are some survival tips.
lead_paragraph: You know the feeling. You emerge from a nap in your wine cellar or from a month in a submarine to find that during your absence, civilization has been destroyed, and only you, and perhaps a few other people, are left alive. You’re panicky. Grief stricken. Bummed. Full of impotent rage. Perhaps even a little gleeful.

headline: Jamie Sneider: Thierry Goldberg
abstract: Curiously, you rarely hear artists called witches. Could it be because witches are usually thought of as “female”?
lead_paragraph: 103 Norfolk Street,

headline: A Family Man (Daddy’s a Dictator)
abstract: Adam Rayner talks about playing a Middle East dictator’s son living incognito as a Beverly Hills pediatrician on FX’s “Tyrant.”
lead_paragraph: This boy toy’s all grown up. To play Bassam Al Fayeed, a Middle Eastern dictator’s son living incognito as a Beverly Hills pediatrician named Barry on FX’s new “Tyrant,” Adam Rayner traded the callow sexual maneuverings he optimized in British series like “Mistresses” and “At Home With the Braithwaites” for the gravitas befitting a family man.

headline: Kahn & Selesnick: ‘Truppe Fledermaus & the Carnival at the End of the World’
abstract: In Kahn & Selesnick’s photographic fable, the Truppe Fledermaus travels to abandoned sites to perform for nobody.
lead_paragraph: Yancey Richardson Gallery

headline: Sterling Ruby: ‘Sunrise Sunset’
abstract: Mr. Ruby’s show is a knockout in the best and worst senses of the word.
lead_paragraph: Hauser & Wirth

headline: ‘The Shaped Canvas’: Luxembourg & Dayan
abstract: This group show takes a lively but ultimately lightweight look at a postwar painting trend making a comeback.
lead_paragraph: 64 East 77th Street

headline: Vincent Fecteau: Matthew Marks
abstract: The opposite of showy, the six wall-mounted reliefs in this show look like formal exercises in old-fashioned Cubist aesthetics.
lead_paragraph: 523 West 24th Street

headline: A Calligraphic Answer to ‘I Like This’
abstract: In the accessible Met exhibition “Out of Character: Decoding Chinese Calligraphy,” this art form is presented as a social art, and even a form of social network.
lead_paragraph: Chinese calligraphy can seem daunting to viewers who are unfamiliar with the characters of this ancient art form. Some, stymied by the language barrier, tend to think about the physical act of the brushwork in the more familiar terms of dance or choreography, or to see the characters as abstract shapes (which, of course, they are not, although they have inspired abstract painters like Brice Marden and Franz Kline).

headline: Leaping Away From Success
abstract: The Trey McIntyre Project, a contemporary ballet company in Idaho, is ending, as Mr. McIntyre plans to explore “expanded artistic pursuits.”
lead_paragraph: In the last nine years, the contemporary ballet company Trey McIntyre Project became something almost unheard-of in the often beleaguered cultural landscape: a small, independent dance troupe that was a familiar name both at home in Boise, Idaho, and nationwide. A darling of festivals, the company traveled to up to 40 cities a year, finished each season in the black, gave its dancers full health insurance and offered them over 30 weeks of work each year.

headline: One Century’s Breathing Room Is Another’s Hiccup
keywords: ['Building (Construction)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: N.Y.U.’s proposed sunken walkway comes up against an old easement and a contemporary condominium.
lead_paragraph: The old network of easements and rights of way beside and behind the mansions on Fifth Avenue between East 78th and 79th Streets made life more comfortable for millionaires, but in 2014 is creating a headache for New York University.

headline: A Sadist and a Masochist Walk Into a Theater
abstract: Roman Polanski’s film adaptation of “Venus in Fur,” stars his wife, Emmanuelle Seigner.
lead_paragraph: “Venus in Fur,” Roman Polanski’s nimble film adaptation of the play by David Ives, might provoke a lively post-viewing argument. Is it about sex or power? Art or life? The nature of theater or the logic of desire?

headline: Presbyterians Vote to Allow Same-Sex Marriages
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Presbyterian Church']
abstract: The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) voted to change the definition of marriage from “a man and a woman” to “two people,” and to allow ministers to perform same-sex marriages where it is legal.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) voted at its General Assembly on Thursday to change its constitution’s definition of marriage from “a man and a woman” to “two people,” and to allow its ministers to perform same-sex marriages where it is legal.

headline: An Empty Heart Is One That Can Be Filled
keywords: ['Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: I had loved and lost plenty of times, but I had never let myself feel it. I numbed up.
lead_paragraph: I was 31 before I got my heart broken.

headline: The Man in the Gold Lamé Suit
abstract: A retrospective of James Lee Byars at MoMA PS1 highlights his persona as an artist-philosopher.
lead_paragraph: James Lee Byars (1932-97) was one of the more intriguing characters to stir international art waters during the 20th century’s second half. An American playing the role of artist-as-shaman, he was lionized in Europe but not so well known in the United States. “James Lee Byars: ½ an Autobiography,” a retrospective at MoMA PS1, offers a valuable opportunity to assess his career. Was he the real deal, a true mystic sage? Or was he a canny, charismatic showman who knew how to exploit a modern hunger for timeless wisdom? The question hangs in the air throughout the exhibition, which was organized by Peter Eleey, the museum’s curator and associate director of exhibitions and programs, and Magalí Arriola, curator at Fundación Jumex Arte Contemporáneo in Mexico City, where it had its debut last November.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Third Person’
abstract: Paul Haggis narrates a sequence from “Third Person,” with Adrien Brody and Moran Atias.
lead_paragraph: Paul Haggis narrates a sequence from “Third Person,” with Adrien Brody and Moran Atias.

headline: ‘The Birth of a Theatrical Comet’
abstract: The musical “Rent” was featured on the cover of the Arts & Leisure section of The New York Times on Sunday, March 17, 1996.
lead_paragraph: The musical “Rent” was featured on the cover of the Arts & Leisure section of The New York Times on Sunday, March 17, 1996.

headline: Steve Scalise, Obstructionist, Joins the House Leadership
abstract: The new majority whip voted against the debt ceiling increase.
lead_paragraph: Interest groups love keeping scorecards measuring the fidelity of lawmakers, but to judge the new leaders that House Republicans elected today all you really need to know is how they’d answer the question: Do you believe in governing by consensus or by destruction? Republicans today elected one of each type, which will probably lead to more tension, more obstruction, and less progress.

headline: If Seeing Is Believing, a Panorama of Truth
abstract: The Queens Museum uses its “Panorama” of New York as a launching point for “Bringing the World Into the World,” a playful look at ways to see reality.
lead_paragraph: The Queens Museum has a big advantage when it comes to the familiar curatorial tactic of using older works from its permanent collection to inspire an exhibition of contemporary art. At the museum’s figurative and actual heart lies one of the great visual wonders of New York: “The Panorama of the City of New York,” a nearly 10,000-square-foot miniaturization of every building, street, park and bridge in the five boroughs, complete with day-night lighting cycles and tiny planes zipping in and out of La Guardia and Kennedy along almost-invisible wires.

headline: Events That Ponder a Grim Anniversary
abstract: Hundreds of cultural events are planned across Europe and the United States to mark the 100th anniversary of World War I.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A century ago this month, the great powers of an earlier order began to unravel. World War I redrew the world map, ending the Hapsburg Empire and the Ottoman Empire and shifting the tectonic plates beneath Europe and the Middle East in ways that still resonate. From June 28, the date in 1914 when a young radical assassinated Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in Sarajevo, setting off a chain of events that started the war, to Nov. 11, the date that the Allies and Germany signed a first armistice ending the war in 1918, hundreds of cultural events are planned across Europe and the United States to observe the war’s 100th anniversary. Here are a few of them.

headline: I.R.S. Eases Some Rules for Taxpayers Overseas
abstract: The agency said it would lower or eliminate some fines for failing to disclose offshore accounts, while tightening other requirements.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing criticism that its crackdown on overseas tax cheats had disproportionately hurt small taxpayers guilty of innocent oversights, the Internal Revenue Service said it would revise its rules, lowering or eliminating some fines while tightening other requirements.

headline: The Sadness of Bugles as Soldiers Head Home
abstract: Ralph Vaughan Williams’s “A Pastoral Symphony,” written after his service in France and Greece, is rarely performed but has been recorded with particular warmth.
lead_paragraph: Ralph Vaughan Williams, the British composer long pigeonholed as a purveyor of bucolic calm, knew war, though he didn’t have to. When World War I began, he was 41, old enough to have avoided military service.

headline: In an Ironic Lens, a Latin Myth Evaporates
abstract: Two shows at the International Center of Photography counter some traditional stereotypes of Latin America.
lead_paragraph: A Latin American spring is about to turn into a Latin American summer in New York City art museums. Purely, it seems, by chance, a record number of institutions have recently opened significant shows of work from South America and the Caribbean. The International Center of Photography, as usual one step ahead of the curve, has two.

headline: Dissimilar Figures, Revolted by Carnage
abstract: The painter John Singer Sargent and the political thinker Randolph Bourne shared a revulsion toward World War I, which had gripped the nation like a fever.
lead_paragraph: World War I made for strange bedfellows. One such pair, who never met, haunt me.

headline: Paul Haggis Narrates a Scene From ‘Third Person’
abstract: The writer and director discusses a sequence from his latest film.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the writer and director Paul Haggis discusses a sequence from his drama “Third Person” featuring Adrien Brody and Moran Atias.

headline: Visceral Reality vs. the Big Picture
abstract: An exhibition of World War I artifacts at the Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin spurs reflection on what is gained and lost by distilling a war through personal experience.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — In the century since the First World War began, there have been bloodier conflicts and more barbaric ones. There have been wars that seem more pointless and wars that seem less conclusive. But the First World War remains distinctively stupefying.

headline: Future Shock: Whispering Harleys
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: Harley-Davidson, known for its rumbling motorcycles, is introducing its Project LiveWire Experience, an event that will offer licensed riders a chance to try, of all things, an electric Harley.
lead_paragraph: Sales of electric motorcycles are just a tiny slice of a market that totals about 370,000 road-legal motorcycles a year in the United States, but Harley-Davidson, the proudly American maker of rumbling, brawny heavyweights, is hinting that it would like to change that.

headline: A Test for the Early Detection of Alzheimer’s Disease
abstract: Doctors in Ohio have developed a simple four-page quiz that can help reveal dementia early on, allowing patients to get their lives in order.
lead_paragraph: Liz Arledge is all too familiar with the ravages of dementia. Her mother died of Alzheimer’s, and one of her brothers has been found to have the progressive brain disease as well.

headline: Q. and A.: Michael C. Davis on the Battle Over Hong Kong’s Future
abstract: The law professor explains what is at stake for Hong Kong as the Chinese Communist Party attempts to consolidate its influence over the city. “The coming few months could be very rough,” Mr. Davis says.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong is undergoing deepening tensions over its political future as a self-governed territory under Chinese sovereignty. Democratic activists have demanded that residents win the right to elect Hong Kong’s top leader, called the chief executive, without procedures that would ensure that only candidates approved by Beijing appear on the ballot. Many of the activists have endorsed Occupy Central with Love and Peace, a movement whose members have said they will stage civil disobedience protests in the city’s financial heart if electoral reform plans proposed by the Hong Kong government and Beijing, possibly later this year, do not meet their criteria for universal suffrage.

headline: A Venn Diagram of Love and Its Mutations
abstract: Three unrelated personal dramas revolving around passion, love and betrayal play out in three countries. Inevitably they intersect.
lead_paragraph: In Paul Haggis’s film “Third Person,” Liam Neeson plays Michael, a Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist who has lost his creative mojo and is holed up in a Paris hotel, completing his latest opus. Accompanying him but staying in a separate suite is his girlfriend, Anna (Olivia Wilde), a wacko celebrity journalist who has literary pretensions that Michael is quick to shoot down. They go at each other with the merciless cruelty of two egotists whose only harmonious moments are bouts of frantic sex.

headline: Pitti Uomo: Z Zegna Spring/Summer 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Adam Katz Sinding.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Adam Katz Sinding.

headline: Simple Fare, Bursting With Flavors
abstract: Jay Lippin, who ran the kitchen of Crabtree’s Kittle House two decades ago, returned about a year ago and has brought a new excitement to the 1790 building in Chappaqua.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, when I told friends I was reviewing Crabtree’s Kittle House, I received a consistent response along the lines of: “That used to be my favorite place. I haven’t been in quite a while.” It wasn’t a terrible experience that had turned them off; there was just a general feeling that the longtime Chappaqua star had lost its zing.

headline: Good Feelings About McCarthy and Scalise Elections on Twitter
abstract: If any Republicans were disappointed with the leadership elections in the House, they weren’t taking to Twitter to express their feelings.
lead_paragraph: Republicans elected two members of their caucus to the No. 2 and No. 3 leadership positions in the House of Representatives today.

headline: Waiting in Existential Ennui
abstract: R. C. Sherriff’s 1928 play “Journey’s End,” based on his memories of life in the trenches, anticipates the absurdism and existentialism of Beckett.
lead_paragraph: Many and contradictory are the claims that have been made for “Journey’s End,” the British playwright R. C. Sherriff’s 1928 portrait of life in the trenches and probably still the greatest of 20th-century English-language war dramas. It has been extolled and reviled as an impassioned plea for pacifism, a jingoistic celebration of homegrown heroes and an indictment of shortsighted military blundering.

headline: Suárez Staggers England With Finesse and Ferocity
abstract: Suárez scored both of Uruguay’s goals in a desperately needed 2-1 victory over England, which now requires plenty of help to advance out of the group round.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Luis Suárez’s first goal on Thursday was a delicate touch of class, a deft header nodded in with precision and purpose and placement. Suárez’s second goal, however — the one that was a death blow for England — was something closer to a savage blast.

headline: A ‘Rent’ Duo, Now Reunited
abstract: The first in a new series of never-before-seen theater photographs features a 1996 image of Idina Menzel and Anthony Rapp in the musical “Rent.”
lead_paragraph: Scene Unseen is a new occasional series in which Sara Krulwich, a staff photographer for The New York Times, digs into her archives to talk about a theater photo that has never before been published. In this first installment, Ms. Krulwich takes a look at an image, taken in March 1996, of the original production of the musical “Rent” that features the actors Idina Menzel and Anthony Rapp. The two are now starring together in the new Broadway musical “If/Then.”

headline: A Chef Takes Time to Work the Crowd
abstract: In his hometown, Jonas Gold’s menu includes nods to Korean, Thai, Moroccan, Italian, Mexican, French and Japanese cooking.
lead_paragraph: “The hamburger or the pulled pork sandwich?” I wondered aloud one lunchtime at 55 Main, failing to notice that a wide-mouth bottle of ketchup on each table pointed the way. Jonas Gold, 43, the owner and chef, stopped by my table with the answer. That he is a “burger man,” as he told my party, shows in the quality of the hamburgers here — strip steak and filet mignon trimmings ground in-house, char-grilled as rare as you like, served with a brioche bun and crisp, fresh lettuce, onion and ripe tomato. French fries on the side are hand-cut in the kitchen. The only thing better would be a burger and a beer, Mr. Gold joked. It was true, though with liquor licenses so few and far between, good times take planning in New Jersey. Bring your own cold one, and follow the ketchup to this burger.

headline: The Clerk at Checkout Has Reasons to Be Happy
abstract: Theater Breaking Through Barriers’ “Power Plays” consists of five short works about physical disabilities and the people who cope with them.
lead_paragraph: In Neil LaBute’s “I Dare You,” part of Theater Breaking Through Barriers’ “Power Plays,” a woman in a wheelchair dismisses another woman’s romantic overtures. “I’m not. ...” she says, gesturing reluctantly toward her legs, unable to complete the sentence. “I don’t care what you’re not,” the other woman answers. “I want you to find out what you are. Who you are.”

headline: Clip: ‘Venus in Fur’
abstract: A scene from the film directed by Roman Polanski.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film directed by Roman Polanski.

headline: A Familiar Taste of the Mediterranean
abstract: At Yevma Authentic Greek Cuisine in East Meadow, a chef tested in Athens and New York City presides.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Tuesday night at Yevma Authentic Greek Cuisine in East Meadow, a young man approached the takeout counter and complained that the gyro he had just purchased lacked lettuce and was studded with French fries. Peter Messaris, 48, the owner and chef, offered to add lettuce but also explained to the customer that gyros in Greece sometimes have French fries — not lettuce — tucked into the pita. The patron left with a smile on his face and we (seated nearby) learned why “authentic” is part of the restaurant’s name.

abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: For Your Alfresco Friends
abstract: Gift ideas for an easy day trip based on lightweight, portable equipment for transporting food, cooking and lounging.
lead_paragraph: Gift ideas for an easy day trip based on lightweight, portable equipment for transporting food, cooking and lounging.

headline: Canadian Judge Says Google Must Remove Links Worldwide
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Search Engines']
abstract: The temporary order, granted last Friday by the Supreme Court of British Columbia, emerged from protracted litigation between two companies that were once closely connected.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Google will appeal a decision by a court in British Columbia that requires the company to remove specific search results worldwide. While the case stems from an intellectual property dispute between two small industrial equipment companies, some legal experts say that if the decision is upheld it could have far-reaching consequences for the Internet.

headline: Staying Afloat in End Times
abstract: The TNT series “The Last Ship,” beginning Sunday night, centers on a Navy destroyer crew that returns from an expedition to discover that most of the world’s population has been wiped out.
lead_paragraph: Premium cable hasn’t just influenced television, it has mated with it and spawned hybrids. “The Last Ship,” a maritime drama that begins on Sunday on TNT, is one of the better results of crossbreeding.

headline: Movie Listings for June 20-26
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: A Familiar Name Looks for Consistency on a Women’s Tour
abstract: Cheyenne Woods, Tiger Woods’s niece, is ranked No. 37 on the L.P.G.A.’s developmental Symetra Tour and is playing in her second United States Women’s Open.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — Walking along the fairways of Pinehurst No. 2 at the United States Women’s Open, Cheyenne Woods could not help but smile when fans yelled “Go Deacs!” as she passed by.

headline: For Clam and Lobster Lovers, They’re Palaces
abstract: Seafood is a summer tradition, and these three shacks in Connecticut help diners address their seasonal cravings.
lead_paragraph: Cruising the coast, a summertime tradition, has more purpose when one of Connecticut’s many clam and lobster shacks is the destination. Picnic-table views of the water are the rule, plastic-cutlery casual is the norm, and a sense of urgency is imposed because these spots are open only for the season. The three seafood shacks listed below deliver quality food in unsurpassed waterside settings.

headline: Kevin McCarthy’s Tea Party Bona Fides
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: How the moderate Republican from California got elected House majority leader with overwhelming Tea Party support.
lead_paragraph: How the moderate Republican from California got elected House majority leader with overwhelming Tea Party support.

headline: Carla Laemmle, Actress Since the 1920s, Dies at 104
abstract: Ms. Laemmle, who was reared on the Universal Studios lot, became a fan favorite at autograph shows and horror-film conventions in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Carla Laemmle, a dancer and actress whose screen career began in the silent era and ended with newfound celebrity in the Internet age, died on June 12 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 104.

headline: McCarthy on House Majority Leader Role
abstract: The newly elected House majority leader, Representative Kevin McCarthy, spoke after he was chosen to replace Eric Cantor who unexpectedly lost a primary election last week.
lead_paragraph: The newly elected House majority leader, Representative Kevin McCarthy, spoke after he was chosen to replace Eric Cantor who unexpectedly lost a primary election last week.

headline: Garbage In, Art Out
abstract: For his “Found in Nature” series, Barry Rosenthal searches for discarded items — Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn is his favorite hunting ground — to arrange and photograph.
lead_paragraph: Plastic spoons, bullet shells, tennis balls.

headline: Questions on Treatment of Mentally Ill by State
abstract: A recent Texas review described the state’s mental health system as a mess requiring action, “starting now.” Not even the department itself really disagree.
lead_paragraph: The sheriff of the state’s largest county is peeved with the Texas Department of State Health Services, the agency that runs the state’s mental health hospitals.

headline: Women of Congress and the Press Battle Breast Cancer, and for Bragging Rights
abstract: A close look at an annual showdown to benefit young women fighting breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There are two foes capable of bringing together members of Congress: breast cancer and the press.

headline: McDaniel Drawn Into a Shouting Match at Campaign Event
abstract: Chris McDaniel, the primary challenger to Senator Thad Cochran, told a critic to “get your finger out of my face” during a campaign event.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — State Senator Chris McDaniel, who is in a runoff with Senator Thad Cochran for the Republican nomination in Mississippi, was drawn into a shouting match with a critic on Thursday as he met with a dozen retirees over cranberry and carrot cakes at a grocery store.

headline: Witness to Fatal Shooting of Palestinians Reports Threats From Israeli Soldiers
abstract: Human Rights Watch reported that a Palestinian whose security cameras recorded the fatal shooting of two teenagers last month said he was threatened by Israeli soldiers this week.
lead_paragraph: A Palestinian carpenter whose security cameras recorded the fatal shooting of two Palestinian teenagers at a protest in the West Bank last month told Human Rights Watch that he was threatened by Israeli soldiers this week during an hourlong interrogation.

headline: This Week’s Movies | June 20, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Venus in Fur,” “Norte, the End of History” and “Jersey Boys.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Venus in Fur,” “Norte, the End of History” and “Jersey Boys.”
