abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘Sharks’

headline: Tally of Cyber Extortion Attacks on Tech Companies Grows
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: A flood of extortion attempts against web start-ups that began earlier this year appears to be getting worse. Evernote, Feedly, Moz and, this week, Move, an online real estate service, have been targeted in the last month.
lead_paragraph: Tech start-ups continue to get hit by extortion attempts from cybercriminals who aim to shut down their systems until companies pay their ransom.

headline: Carley Roney: Picnics in the Park, and Selfies With Brides
abstract: Sundays in June mean weddings. But for Carley Roney, 46, a founder of the wedding resource website The Knot, Sundays are for family recreation in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Carley Roney nearly wore black at her wedding in 1993, but decided at the last minute to wear her mother’s wedding dress. She planned the reception in three weeks; it turned out to be on a sweltering July evening. “I was the anti-bride and now I’m the queen of weddings,” she said. Ms. Roney, 46, and her husband, David Liu, 48, were among the founders of the wedding resource company The Knot in 1996. It has since become the XO Group, a media company that includes sites for new and pregnant couples. Ms. Roney and Mr. Liu and their children, Havana, 16, Cairo, 10, and Dublin, 6, live in Dumbo, which Ms. Roney calls “wedding central,” especially in June. Every bride in the city, she said, seems to take pictures beneath the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: Spare Times for June 20-26
abstract: A guide to fairs and cultural festivals, parades, literary events, walking tours and more in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Adventures NYC (Saturday and Sunday) A bit of the great outdoors can be experienced in the city during this free, two-day celebration of rock climbing, kayaking, fly casting, slacklining and other activities in Central Park (on Saturday) and Marine Park, Brooklyn (on Sunday).

headline: I Was a Digital Best Seller!
keywords: ['E-Books and Readers', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Writing and Writers', 'News and News Media']
abstract: And yet I earned little money, and even fewer readers.
lead_paragraph: WEST TISBURY, Mass. — FIVE months ago I published a short book called “Boom.” Commercially it was a bust. No news in that: Most books lose money and are quickly forgotten by all but their wounded authors.

headline: Gerry Goffin, Hitmaking Songwriter With Carole King, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Goffin collaborated with Carole King to write some of the biggest hits of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Gerry Goffin, who collaborated with Carole King to write some of the biggest hits of the 1960s, songs that endured through generations and became classics, including “Will You Love Me Tomorrow?,” “Up on the Roof,” “One Fine Day” and “The Loco-Motion,” died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 75.

headline: Lucy Li, 11, Tops a 78 With Ice Cream at the U.S. Women’s Open
abstract: Li, the youngest player to qualify for the United States Women’s Open, overcame two double bogeys and a triple bogey to finish the first round at eight over par.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — Lucy Li’s historic United States Women’s Open debut was marred by two double bogeys and a triple bogey, which she handled with equanimity. The most disappointment Li showed all day was after her round of eight-over-par 78, when she had to hand over her pink ice-cream bar to her aunt to answer a videographer’s interview questions.

abstract: Responses to an Op-Ed article by Anne-Marie Slaughter, “Don’t Fight in Iraq and Ignore Syria.”

abstract: A circus official says Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey is committed to the best care of their animals.

headline: Suit by Protest Groups on Spying Is Dismissed
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Industrial Espionage', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A judge finds that a civilian analyst did not thwart free speech rights when he infiltrated organizations and passed information to government agencies.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Washington State has dismissed a lawsuit that accused a civilian intelligence analyst working for the military of breaking the law by using a fake name to infiltrate antiwar groups and trying to thwart protests by sharing information he collected with the Army, law enforcement agencies and private security firms.

abstract: The director of the Frick Collection in Manhattan describes how the expansion will benefit visitors.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Just Another Little Dysfunctional Dinner Party
abstract: In “Coherence,” directed by James Ward Byrkit, a party deteriorates when a comet passes over the Earth.
lead_paragraph: It’s a commonplace that speculative fiction speaks to the anxieties percolating in its age. Such seems the case with the likes of “Edge of Tomorrow,” which kinks up its narrative by repeatedly cycling back to the past, suggesting that complex theories about space-time are now so mainstream that they’re the stuff of mass entertainment. The same might be said of the far more modest “Coherence,” although it’s also true that digital tools, which allow directors to shoot fast, cheap and sometimes sloppily, are also helping pry loose linear narrative’s hold on movies.

headline: The Maze of Homelessness
abstract: Barbara Knecht of Care for the Homeless responds to a Sunday Review article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: After a Fire, a Dusty Town Hopes Not to Evaporate
abstract: Fritch, Tex., population 2,000, was already reeling from years of drought when a fire devastated the Panhandle community in May. Now residents are wondering whether it can be rebuilt.
lead_paragraph: FRITCH, Tex. — A month after a fire roared through this Panhandle town, all that remains of Sam Jones’s house is its concrete foundation, a row of charred pine trees and the underground storm shelter where he now lives.

headline: A Push for New Look into Tainted Water’s Source
abstract: In a report, the Railroad Commission of Texas rejected the idea that nearby drilling was the cause of a high content of methane in wells along the Brazos River.
lead_paragraph: WEATHERFORD, Tex. — Steve Lipsky has nearly everything he needs on his 14-acre estate along the Brazos River, west of Fort Worth. The estate includes a guesthouse, a resort-style swimming pool and a seven-bathroom, 15,000-square-foot home where he lives with his wife and three children.

headline: Luxury Apartments? Later. For Now, They Burn Sage.
keywords: ['Tepees', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: The former Domino Sugar refinery site in Brooklyn will be turned into luxury housing after this summer, but until then, a 30-foot-tall white tepee occupies a bit of grass there, offering music, dance and yoga classes.
lead_paragraph: The increasingly glassy Williamsburg waterfront seems an unlikely place for a sacred site. Yet among mirrored high-rises and a manicured shoreline, near the decaying remains of the Domino Sugar refinery in Brooklyn, there sits on a shaggy patch of grass a 30-foot-tall white tepee, the smoke flap open to the sky, the door positioned east (toward the rising sun) and the poles lashed together, stretching out to infinity.

headline: Portrait of a Marriage, With a Star Turn for a Townhouse
abstract: The real star of “Exhibition,” the third feature by the British filmmaker Joanna Hogg, is an austere but elegant, ultramodern townhouse in West London.
lead_paragraph: The real star of “Exhibition,” the third feature by the British filmmaker Joanna Hogg, is an austere but elegant, ultramodern townhouse in West London. Within its chilly spaces, the principal characters have lived and worked for 20 years. Married, childless artists in their 50s, the couple — identified only as D (Viv Albertine, an alumna of the rock group the Slits) and H (Liam Gillick, a well-regarded Conceptual artist) — work on separate floors connected by an elevator and a spiral staircase, and communicate via intercom.

headline: Chinese Government Tightens Constraints on Press Freedom
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media']
abstract: China announced restrictions Wednesday requiring reporters to receive permission from employers for investigative work and banning personal websites.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China introduced new restrictions on what the government has called “critical” news articles and barred Chinese journalists from doing work outside their beats or regions, putting further restraints on reporters in one of the world’s most controlled news media environments.

headline: Tablet Geared Toward Children Underscores Power of Imagination
abstract: The first commercial for the Nabi DreamTab, a computer tablet for children, is expected to be introduced on July 7.
lead_paragraph: TO introduce the Nabi DreamTab, a computer tablet for children from a partnership between DreamWorks Animation and Fuhu, the companies are not initially focusing much on the device’s technical specifications, like its operating system and parental control features. Instead, advertising, marketing and promotional events are going out on a limb, in every sense, and prominently featuring treehouses.

headline: No to Guantánamo for Ahmed Abu Khattala
abstract: The best way to find out what happened in Benghazi and get a clean conviction is to try the terror suspect in federal court.
lead_paragraph: NEARLY eight years ago, 14 men arrived at Guantánamo after years in Central Intelligence Agency custody. Since then, only one has been tried and convicted with the case upheld on appeal. That was Ahmed Ghailani, a Tanzanian national who received a life sentence for his role in the 1998 bombings of the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania that killed 223 people. Mr. Ghailani was tried in federal court in New York, and he is serving his sentence in a federal prison in the United States. His 13 comrades from the C.I.A. detention and interrogation program are still in limbo at Guantánamo, where justice for them and the families of their victims remains elusive.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Clip: ‘The Last Sentence’
abstract: A scene from Jan Troell’s film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from Jan Troell’s film.

headline: International Monetary Fund Says Europe Should Weigh Bond-Buying
abstract: If inflation continues to drag, the suggestion would in effect have the European Central Bank emulate the Fed’s quantitative-easing program, a strategy many economists have been urging.
lead_paragraph: LUXEMBOURG — The International Monetary Fund on Thursday said that if inflation continued to drag, the euro zone’s central bank could do more to invigorate the economy by buying government bonds and other financial assets.

headline: Gay G.O.P. Candidates Feature Partners in Ads
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Advertising', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Three gay Republicans running for Congress are featuring their significant others in campaign ads, a sign of how quickly views are changing on same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Richard Tisei’s new campaign ad offers a scene of domestic bliss.

headline: After Challenging Hitler, It All Goes to the Dogs
abstract: “The Last Sentence” is a fictionalization of how the Swedish journalist Torgny Segerstedt positioned himself on the right side of history by writing an editorial that declared “Herr Hitler is an insult.”
lead_paragraph: It’s plausible that Torgny Segerstedt, a crusading Swedish journalist, was every bit as heroic, freethinking and sexually irresistible to women as he is portrayed in “The Last Sentence.” But you will need to take it on faith even after seeing this stultifying movie, a fictionalization of how Segerstedt (1876-1945) positioned himself on the right side of history by writing an editorial that declared “Herr Hitler is an insult.” Hermann Göring sent a telegram objecting to this boldly tossed gauntlet, one of many such complaints that challenged Segerstedt’s lonely fight.

headline: Health Exchange Enrollees Had Mostly Been Uninsured
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: A survey finds that six in 10 people joining the new health plans had no insurance before, many are worried about affording premiums, and opinions about benefits are a mixed bag.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four in 10 people enrolling in health plans through the new insurance exchanges already had insurance, but six in 10 were previously uninsured, according to a Kaiser Family Foundation survey released Thursday.

headline: ‘We Should Be Further,’ Dominicans Say
abstract: Adriano D. Espaillat, a state senator who was born in the Dominican Republic and is challenging Charles B. Rangel for his Manhattan congressional seat, may help Dominicans cement a growing political influence in the city.
lead_paragraph: The manager of Best Barbers in the Bronx offers free political advice to his fellow Dominicans sitting for $12 haircuts: Vote for Adriano D. Espaillat.

headline: The Corporate Daddy
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Corporations', 'Minimum Wage', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Walmart, the world’s largest public corporation, is a big part of the income-gap problem. It could be a big part of the solution.
lead_paragraph: For some time now, Republicans in Congress have given up the pretense of doing anything to improve the lot of most Americans. Raising the minimum wage? They won’t even allow a vote to happen. Cleaner air for all? They may partially shut down the government in a coming fight on behalf of major polluters. Add to that the continuing obstruction of student loan relief efforts, and numerous attempts to defund health care, and you have a party actively working to make life miserable for millions.

headline: Rays of Humanity in a Vile World
abstract: “Norte, the End of History,” Lav Diaz’s reimagining of “Crime and Punishment,” explores the nature of evil through a double murder and wrongful imprisonment.
lead_paragraph: More than four hours long, filmed in expansive takes with almost no close-ups and very few camera movements, Lav Diaz’s “Norte, the End of History” is a tour de force of slow cinema. The movie, something of a sensation at Cannes last year, is not difficult or obscure — there is a clear, dramatic story involving characters who solicit both empathy and curiosity — but it does require an adjustment of the usual viewing metabolism.

headline: Looking After New Mothers
abstract: Should screening for postpartum depression be mandatory? How can those suffering be assured of treatment?

headline: What Happens in Vegas ...
abstract: Things turn loud and desperate in “Think Like a Man Too,” the sequel to the Steve Harvey-inspired movie.
lead_paragraph: Well, you can’t fault “Think Like a Man Too” for being a sequel too much like the original. The first film, inspired by Steve Harvey’s how-to-get-your-guy best seller, “Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man,” was a blatant product promotion, complete with bookstore signings and author appearances.

headline: Federal Reserve’s Bond-Buying Fades, but Stimulus Doesn’t End There
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Interest Rates', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Government Bonds']
abstract: As the Fed curtails the expansion of its enormous portfolio, its reinvesting of maturing securities may continue to help the economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE Federal Reserve is poised to keep purchasing large volumes of mortgage bonds, and potentially Treasury securities too, even after the likely conclusion of its prominent bond-buying program later this year.

headline: Those Who Took the Veil vs. Neighbors Who Take It All Off
keywords: ['Nuns', 'Strip Clubs and Strippers', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Noise']
abstract: The Sisters of St. Charles outside Chicago are suing the owners of a strip club next to their convent, saying the noise interrupts their prayers and the location violates state law.
lead_paragraph: STONE PARK, Ill. — It was a muggy afternoon, but the Sisters of St. Charles were wearing turtlenecks, long-sleeved habits and stockings as they gathered next to a microphone and an unsavory stretch of four-lane highway. They stood on the sidewalk below a billboard picturing a blonde who appeared to be wearing only eyeliner and a come-hither look: a jumbo-size invitation to Club Allure, a 20,000-square-foot strip club that is a newcomer to the neighborhood.

headline: Candidate Says He Can’t Trust Officials’ Tally of Afghan Vote
abstract: Essentially turning his back on the entire election process, Abdullah Abdullah said he could no longer trust the system to address his accusations of widespread fraud and collusion.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah intensified his political brinkmanship on Thursday, insisting that he would not accept any result put forth by the country’s election commission as his supporters appeared to be gearing up for street protests.

headline: Even Among No-Hitters, Clayton Kershaw’s Was a Standout
abstract: While it’s difficult to compare baseball’s greatest pitching performances, Clayton Kershaw’s no-hitter on Wednesday deserves a spot on the list.
lead_paragraph: Years from now, Charley Steiner said, when he recalls one of the greatest pitching performances in major league history, he will first remember Clayton Kershaw the hitter. In the bottom of the eighth inning Wednesday night, when he came to bat with an eight-run lead, Kershaw, the ace of the Los Angeles Dodgers, competed with everything he had.

headline: When Packing Up Unfurls a Hidden Past
abstract: Following their mother’s death, a brother and sister spend the weekend at her house in “A Picture of You.”
lead_paragraph: “A Picture of You,” the feature debut from J. P. Chan, who wrote and directed, looks at one of the less cinematic aspects of grieving: packing up a house after a parent has died. A brother and sister, Kyle (Andrew Pang) and Jen (Jo Mei), spend the weekend at their mother’s Pennsylvania home. Purging her computer, they discover evidence of a romantic life neither wishes to ponder.

headline: Lessons for Dethroned Spain From Italy, a Rival Who’s Been There
abstract: Since its 2010 Cup debacle, Italy has undergone an impressive rebranding and renaissance and is once again among the top teams in the world.
lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — It was a shocking about-face: Four years after lifting the World Cup trophy and charming fans around the world with its attractive brand of soccer, Spain fizzled unceremoniously out of the tournament’s opening round, losing its first two games. It was cast as the sudden end of an era.

headline: Clip: ‘A Picture of You’
abstract: A scene from the film, directed by J. P. Chan.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, directed by J. P. Chan.

headline: Buying Into Solar Power, No Roof Access Needed
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Solar Energy']
abstract: The so-called community solar garden was pioneered in Colorado, and is appealing to people who have no roof space, like renters and apartment owners, or homeowners with shady roofs.
lead_paragraph: Like many consumers, David Polstein had already done much to reduce energy use in his large Victorian home in Newton, Mass. He replaced his appliances with energy-efficient models, installed better heating and put in new insulation. But he was unable to get a solar system to reduce his utility bill, he said, because his roof is too small and shady to make it worthwhile.

headline: Obama Awards Medal of Honor
keywords: ['Medal of Honor (US)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The president presented the Medal of Honor to Lance Cpl. William Kyle Carpenter, who took the brunt of a grenade blast to save a fellow Marine while serving in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: The president presented the Medal of Honor to Lance Cpl. William Kyle Carpenter, who took the brunt of a grenade blast to save a fellow Marine while serving in Afghanistan.

headline: Marine Cpl. William Kyle Carpenter Receives Medal of Honor
abstract: President Obama presented the Medal of Honor to Cpl. William Kyle Carpenter, who threw himself on a grenade in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Cpl. William Kyle Carpenter, an automatic rifleman who shielded a fellow Marine from a grenade thrown at them during a firefight in Afghanistan in 2010, received the Medal of Honor from President Obama on Thursday.

headline: Turning It on, After a Long Drought
abstract: Center forward Karim Benzema failed to make France’s squad in 2010, and later went through a long scoreless stretch with the team. But he had two goals Sunday in his first World Cup match.
lead_paragraph: SALVADOR, Brazil — The opportunities and the goals came in rapid succession for Karim Benzema in his first World Cup match.

headline: Every Dish Is a Plat du Jour
abstract: “Le Chef” is an odd-couple farce about a stern celebrity chef and the authority-flouting understudy who cooks his own way.
lead_paragraph: Like the culinary geniuses of “Le Chef,” French cinema may need a new seasonal menu. This light, disposable soufflé from Daniel Cohen at times suggests “Ratatouille” with humans. For a film about mouthwatering cuisine, it offers only fleeting delectable sensations.

headline: 5 Exonerated in Central Park Jogger Case Agree to Settle Suit for $40 Million
keywords: ['Central Park Jogger Case (1989)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The five men whose convictions in the brutal 1989 beating and rape of a female jogger in Central Park were later overturned have agreed to a settlement of about $40 million from New York City.
lead_paragraph: The five men whose convictions in the brutal 1989 beating and rape of a female jogger in Central Park were later overturned have agreed to a settlement of about $40 million from New York City to resolve a bitterly fought civil rights lawsuit over their arrests and imprisonment in the sensational crime.

headline: In Chaos, Iraq’s Kurds See a Chance to Gain Ground
abstract: As the advance of Sunni militants shakes Iraq’s government, Kurds see an opportunity to move closer to their long-sought goal of independence.
lead_paragraph: KIRKUK, Iraq — The chair Col. Imad Muhammad sat in belonged to a commander in the Iraqi Army. So did the tiny cup from which he was drinking his tea, the ashtray where he snuffed out his cigarettes and the Ping-Pong table and treadmill outside his office.

headline: World Cup 2014: How Teams Can Advance to the Next Round
abstract: Analysis and graphics show what needs to happen for teams in the 2014 World Cup to advance to the Round of 16.
lead_paragraph: Analysis and graphics show what needs to happen for teams in the 2014 World Cup to advance to the Round of 16.

headline: A Hit Man Repents, With Barrels Blazing
abstract: In Lee Jeong-beom’s action film, a Seoul assassin (Jang Dong-gun) accidentally kills a little girl, then is determined to protect her mother.
lead_paragraph: In “No Tears for the Dead,” the writer and director Lee Jeong-beom’s convoluted and stylish new action film, a South Korean-born, American-raised hit man with abandonment issues is assigned to assassinate the mother of a little girl he accidentally killed during an earlier hit. (We see this incident in a prologue, scored to a jazz club rendition of “Smooth Operator.”)

headline: Keeping Track: A Patent Decision, Overtime Pay
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Overtime', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Some updates on issues we’ve been following.
lead_paragraph: A Good Patent Decision

headline: Gay G.O.P. Candidate Begins Ad Campaign
abstract: Dan Innis, a gay Republican from New Hampshire, announced his candidacy for the House of Representatives in an advertisement.
lead_paragraph: Dan Innis, a gay Republican from New Hampshire, announced his candidacy for the House of Representatives in an advertisement.

headline: After Years of Solitude, Spanish Literary Champion Takes Partner
abstract: Carmen Balcells, who for half a century represented many top names in Spanish and Latin American literature, is forming a joint venture with Andrew Wylie.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA — Carmen Balcells was never just a literary agent. Nicknamed La Mamá Grande, after a story by Gabriel García Márquez, she served as a confidante and coach, someone who paid her writers’ dentist bills and deftly resolved their domestic problems while promoting the greatest Latin American and Spanish authors across the globe, including Mr. García Márquez, Mario Vargas Llosa and many more.

headline: Mark Emmert Plays Down Claims of Hypocrisy by N.C.A.A.
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The N.C.A.A.’s president, Mark Emmert was on the stand to defend the organization in an antitrust case that alleges it violated the law by refusing to allow players to profit from their images.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — In the months before he took over as N.C.A.A. president in 2010, Mark Emmert received two important documents. One was a briefing email from his senior aide Wallace Renfro that referred to the “great hypocrisy of college athletics.” Renfro described it as a growing public perception that unpaid athletes were driving a multibillion-dollar industry.

headline: If Health Care Is a War, Here’s the Front Line
abstract: The documentary “Code Black” takes place in the emergency room of Los Angeles County General Hospital.
lead_paragraph: Idealism and reality collide in “Code Black,” Dr. Ryan McGarry’s impassioned record of his training in the embattled emergency room of the Los Angeles County General Hospital.

headline: Trial Secondary as U.S. Questions a Libyan Suspect
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'Interrogations', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Miranda v Arizona (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: The Libyan suspected of playing a key role in the deadly attack on the United States Mission in Benghazi is talking freely with American interrogators.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Libyan suspected of playing a key role in the deadly attack on the United States Mission in Benghazi is talking freely with American interrogators aboard a Navy ship in the Mediterranean Sea, according to senior American officials.

headline: Suárez Sends Rooney and England to the Brink
abstract: Luis Suárez gave Uruguay the lead with a header in the 39th minute. Wayne Rooney kept England's hopes alive with a goal in the second half, but Suárez struck again in the 85th minute to give Uruguay the victory.
lead_paragraph: Luis Suárez gave Uruguay the lead with a header in the 39th minute. Wayne Rooney kept England's hopes alive with a goal in the second half, but Suárez struck again in the 85th minute to give Uruguay the victory.

headline: The Ugly Side of Bollywood
abstract: In “Miss Lovely,” Ashim Ahluwalia shoves us into a 1980s demimonde of quick-and-dirty Indian exploitation movies, run by gangsters and sweatily intertwined with the sex trade.
lead_paragraph: In “Miss Lovely,” Ashim Ahluwalia shoves us into a 1980s demimonde of quick-and-dirty Indian exploitation movies, run by gangsters and sweatily intertwined with the sex trade. It’s the flip side, or backside, of Bollywood’s sparkle, a place of intimidation, titillation and cash-for-reels deals, with only glimpses of cut-rate glamour.

headline: Signs of Trouble Preceded Fatal Stabbing at Bronx School
abstract: The lawyer for a 14-year-old boy charged with killing another student said the boy suffered months of antagonism and bullying before the deadly fight.
lead_paragraph: When Noel Estevez and Timothy Crump were friends, they did the things that 14-year-old boys everywhere like to do. They played video games, shared dirty jokes on Facebook and had at least one sleepover.

headline: Colombia: U.S. Ends Cali Gang Blacklist
abstract: The United States Treasury on Thursday removed 308 names from a sanctions blacklist that helped cripple the Cali drug gang in Colombia, once considered the most powerful drug trafficking organization in the world.
lead_paragraph: The United States Treasury on Thursday removed 308 names from a sanctions blacklist that helped cripple the Cali drug gang in Colombia, once considered the most powerful drug trafficking organization in the world. The delisting, the largest in the history of the Treasury’s economic sanctions operations, lifted penalties against 78 individuals and 230 entities, mostly based in Colombia. The move left only the two leaders of the organization, which has collapsed financially, on the list. The leaders — the brothers Miguel and Gilberto Rodríguez Orejuela — were sentenced to 30-year prison terms in the United States after their capture and extradition in 2006. The brothers also agreed to forfeit $2.1 billion in assets worldwide, which the Colombian authorities are in the process of collecting.

headline: Yours, Mine and All That Other Mine
abstract: In “Fonzy,” a French film directed by Isabelle Doval, a man who donated sperm for a research project discovers that he fathered 533 children — 142 of whom want to meet him.
lead_paragraph: Diego Costa (José Garcia) is a feckless if amiable 42-year-old who regularly donated his sperm for research purposes 20 years ago, using the name Fonzy (no relation to Fonzie, Henry Winkler’s “Happy Days” character). A pothead with a vintage pinball machine at home, he is a variation on the movies’ overfamiliar man-child template. Now Diego learns he has sired 533 children, 142 of whom are looking for him. Oh, and his no-nonsense girlfriend (Audrey Fleurot) is pregnant by him, too. But by customary means.

headline: With Canoes of Concrete, Engineers at City College Paddle Merrily Onward
keywords: ['Canoes and Canoeing', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Concrete canoeing has a rich tradition among civil engineers, and at City College the teams go back to at least the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: It might sound like an idea that would go over like the proverbial lead balloon, but in September, a group of engineering students at City College of New York began meeting and devising a way to build a concrete canoe.

headline: Gaza: Tunnel Blast Kills 5 Militants
abstract: Five militants affiliated with the Hamas movement were killed Thursday in what appeared to be an accident when an explosion ripped through a tunnel they had dug on the east side of Gaza City.
lead_paragraph: Five militants affiliated with the Hamas movement were killed Thursday in what appeared to be an accident when an explosion ripped through a tunnel they had dug on the east side of Gaza City. An emergency worker also died, of smoke inhalation, while responding to the blast. Hamas, the militant faction that has ruled Gaza from 2007 until the formation of a Palestinian unity government this month, has long stored weapons in tunnels. Israel has carried out airstrikes in Gaza over the past week in response to rockets fired from Gaza into Israel, but Hamas did not blame it for Thursday’s explosion. Instead, the party’s armed wing said that the men were killed “while carrying out their jihadist duty in one of the resistance tunnels.”

headline: To Be Young, Besieged and Black
abstract: The rapper Tupac Shakur inspired “Holler if Ya Hear Me,” a new Broadway musical with a vision of black life in urban America.
lead_paragraph: The beats are sweet, and the words often have an electric charge in “Holler if Ya Hear Me,” a new Broadway musical inspired by the lyrics of the popular but troubled rapper Tupac Shakur, who was shot and killed at 25 in Las Vegas in 1996. Unfortunately, much else about this ambitious show, which opened on Thursday at the Palace Theater, feels heartfelt but heavy-handed, as it punches home its message with a relentlessness that may soon leave you numb to the tragic story it’s trying to tell.

headline: In the Land of Mass Graves
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Rwanda’s remarkable recovery from the 1994 genocide provides clues to a path forward in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Just over two decades ago, Rwanda was swept up in a murderous wave of ethnic violence that was as bad or worse as anything happening today in Iraq and Syria. The conflict was between a historically dominant ethnic minority and a historically oppressed majority, as in Iraq. Yet, today, Rwanda is a relatively successful country.

headline: Veterans and Zombies
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Veterans', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The health care scandal at Veterans Affairs is real, but it’s being hyped out of proportion in an attempt to block reform of the larger national system.
lead_paragraph: You’ve surely heard about the scandal at the Department of Veterans Affairs. A number of veterans found themselves waiting a long time for care, some of them died before they were seen, and some of the agency’s employees falsified records to cover up the extent of the problem. It’s a real scandal; some heads have already rolled, but there’s surely more to clean up.

headline: Egypt: Court Calls for Death Sentences for Top Muslim Brotherhood Members
abstract: An Egyptian court on Thursday began the process of imposing death sentences on the top leader and other members of the Muslim Brotherhood.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian court on Thursday began the process of imposing death sentences on the top leader and other members of the Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist political movement swept from power by the military nearly a year ago, in the latest sign of judicial support for the government’s crackdown on the Brotherhood. In the past few months, Egyptian courts have drawn international condemnation by issuing hundreds of death sentences against Brotherhood members and supporters after rushed trials that have relied on questionable evidence. On Thursday, the court referred the cases of Mohamed Badie, above, the Brotherhood’s spiritual leader, and 13 other people to Egypt’s highest religious authority, in what is seen as the first step in confirming the death sentences. Mr. Badie was also sentenced to death in April, in an unrelated case, but he is entitled to a retrial because the sentence was passed in absentia. In the latest trial, Mr. Badie and other senior leaders, including Essam el-Erian and Mohamed el-Beltagy, faced charges that included inciting murder during violence in Cairo last August.

headline: The Klinghoffer Tragedy
abstract: The decision to cancel plans to broadcast the opera in movie theaters because of pressure from critics is an artistic step backward for the Met.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera, which has scheduled “The Death of Klinghoffer” in the next season, has canceled plans to broadcast the opera live in movie theaters around the world. Peter Gelb, the Met’s general manager, defended the decision this week, saying that the broadcasts “would be inappropriate at this time of rising anti-Semitism, particularly in Europe.”

headline: Good Progress on Affordable Health Care
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: Two new reports suggest that Americans are finding bargains and a wide choice of insurance plans thanks to the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Americans are finding very affordable health insurance and a wide choice of plans on the exchanges operated by the federal government, according to a report issued Wednesday by the Department of Health and Human Services. The report was based on data from the 36 states in which the federal government is operating health insurance exchanges this year. Comparable data from states operating their own exchanges is not yet available.

headline: Playing With Fire in Afghanistan
abstract: The presidential election is in crisis with accusations of balloting-box stuffing and one candidate withdrawing from the process.
lead_paragraph: At this pivotal moment for Afghanistan, one of the two candidates for president, Abdullah Abdullah, is creating a political crisis by trying to interrupt the vote-counting in Saturday’s runoff. On Wednesday, he demanded that the election commission stop counting ballots and withdrew his election observers from the process.

headline: Uganda: Anti-Gay Law Draws Sanctions
abstract: The Obama administration announced additional punitive steps against Uganda on Thursday in response to the country’s new law criminalizing homosexuality.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration announced additional punitive steps against Uganda on Thursday in response to the country’s new law criminalizing homosexuality. Certain Ugandan officials will be barred from entering the United States, and some aid money for Ugandan police and health agencies will be cut off or redirected, the administration said. In addition, the Obama administration canceled plans to hold a military aviation exercise in Uganda. But administration officials said the moves would not diminish the American partnership with Uganda against the Lord’s Resistance Army, a rebel force known for its brutality. And the new travel ban is not expected to prevent Uganda’s foreign minister, Sam Kutesa, from traveling to New York, where he has just been elected president of the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: Weathering the Deluge of 1927
keywords: ['Movies', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)']
abstract: Bill Morrison’s wordless film “The Great Flood” depicts the Mississippi River flood of 1927; Godfrey Reggio’s “Visitors” presents portraits of the human animal.
lead_paragraph: “The Great Flood” and “Visitors,” two monochromatic, wordless, nonnarrative features that opened theatrically this year and are now available for home viewing, aren’t so much avant-garde as anachronistic — although it is that anachronism, the notion of a silent cinematic symphony, that makes them seem avant-garde.

headline: Puts Somebody Out
abstract: In which Martin Ashwood-Smith apologizes.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — UPDATE: Sorry for the delay. Back to your regularly scheduled blog.

headline: A Freelance Career, Found in Translation
abstract: In an industry that handles theatrical releases, festival screenings and more, translation is a freelancer’s profession that faces the common difficulties of quality control.
lead_paragraph: The opening of “Monty Python and the Holy Grail” memorably features credits translated by an overzealous subtitler. Tired of listing the cast, the unseen translator abruptly goes rogue with a tourism pitch: “Wi not trei a holiday in Sweden this yer?”

headline: U.S. Authorities Step In to Charge 2 After Deaths From Extra-Lethal Heroin
abstract: Federal narcotics conspiracy charges have been brought in three deaths from overdoses of fentanyl-laced heroin sold in Dutchess County, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: The first death came in late December. A 20-year-old man and his girlfriend bought $100 worth of heroin from a man named Dennis at an apartment complex in Hopewell Junction, N.Y. It was a new brand for them: The glassine envelopes were labeled “Breaking Bad” and bore the distinctive logo of the television show of that name.

headline: Owner of Revel Casino in Atlantic City Files for Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: The move came as the $2.4 billion Revel Casino Hotel was formally put on the auction block.
lead_paragraph: The $2.4 billion Revel Casino Hotel, whose opening two years ago on the Atlantic City boardwalk was hailed as a revival of the city’s gambling industry, filed for protection from creditors in federal bankruptcy court on Thursday as the owner formally put the property on the auction block.

headline: New Contract for Teachers Is Altering Schools’ Hours
abstract: Because of changes in the new teachers’ contract, a number of schools are moving up the start of the school day, and more than a few parents are not happy about it.
lead_paragraph: For New York City public school students and their parents, the trek to school can often seem like a race to the finish line, with the constant fear of stalled subways or unexpected squalls disrupting a carefully orchestrated routine.

headline: Rapper Denies Murder, but Testifies About a Life Studded With Criminal Acts
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Gangs', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: Ronald Herron, a rapper from Brooklyn also known as Ra Diggs, spent the day on the witness stand describing his “chaotic” life in the Gowanus Houses housing project.
lead_paragraph: Ronald Herron’s youth unfolded in Apartment 4E at 423 Baltic Street in Brooklyn. That was where, he testified on Thursday, he saw his mother using cocaine and heroin; where his sisters, who were “professional shoplifters,” also lived; and where he resided when he was arrested for his first crime at age 13.

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Last month, before a Dodgers-Mets game at Citi Field, Clayton Kershaw happened upon Mets Manager Terry Collins in center field. They had known each other since 2006, when Collins was the Dodgers’ director of player development and Kershaw was drafted in the first round, seventh over all.

headline: Dr. Lorna Wing, Who Broadened Views of Autism, Dies at 85
abstract: Dr. Wing, a British psychiatrist, recognized autism as a mental disorder of many gradations, and she coined the term Asperger’s syndrome for its mildest form.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Lorna Wing, a British psychiatrist who was instrumental in identifying autism as a mental disorder of many gradations, affecting people across the spectrum of intelligence — and who gave autism in its mildest form the name Asperger’s syndrome — died on June 6 in Kent, England. She was 85.

headline: Moroccan Flair in Late-Season Summer Finds
abstract: Beneath the autumn/winter 2014 clothes that have begun to pile up in stores lies an exotic set of separates and accessories rich in pattern and texture.
lead_paragraph: Though summer doesn’t officially begin until tomorrow, stores have already begun to stock autumn/winter 2014 collections. But beneath the onslaught of warm outerwear and cozy sweaters, you can still find some seasonally appropriate spring/summer pieces. There are separates and accessories inspired by both the fashion and architecture of Morocco. The exotic prints embraced by designers like Isabel Marant, Tod’s and Emamò are as colorful as the country’s inhabitants, evoking the graphic tiles that line the riads and the vivid shades that pop throughout the spicy perfumed souks of Marrakesh. Whether worn together in some far off corner of the world or as part of an otherwise minimalist outfit, these bohemian accents are worth the hunt. (And soon, they could end up on sale!)

headline: Obama Extends Marriage Benefits to Gay Couples
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Government Employees']
abstract: After decades of blocking gay married couples from receiving the same benefits as their heterosexual counterparts, most federal agencies will now treat married couples alike, regardless of gender.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government on Friday announced regulatory changes to extend a wide range of marriage benefits to same-sex couples, making good on a promise by President Obama after the Supreme Court struck down the Defense of Marriage Act last year.

headline: Yankees Cap Sweep With Speed, Not Slugging
abstract: In extending a 16-game home winning streak against Toronto, the Yankees relied on the baserunning abilities of Jacoby Ellsbury, Brian Roberts and Brett Gardner, all of whom helped manufacture runs.
lead_paragraph: There are nights when the Yankees, long known for their power hitting, look meek at the plate and must find ways other than the long ball to score runs. The off-season additions of Jacoby Ellsbury and Brian Roberts to complement Brett Gardner have made these Yankees, uncharacteristically, more runners than bombers.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) TANAQUIL LE CLERCQ: AFTERNOON OF A FAUN In 1944, as a 15-year-old dancer at the School of American Ballet, Ms. Le Clercq (above, with Edward Bigalow) appeared in “Resurgence,” a short piece created by George Balanchine for a March of Dimes benefit. Portraying the evil Polio, Balanchine enveloped Ms. Le Clercq in a black cape, rendering her character paralyzed. After children tossed dimes at her character, she arose. In 1956, by then the wife of Balanchine and a muse to Jerome Robbins, Ms. Le Clercq, 27, contracted polio while touring with the New York City Ballet in Copenhagen. Paralyzed from the waist down, she never danced again. Through interviews with her colleagues Jacques d’Amboise and Arthur Mitchell and others, this “American Masters” documentary, directed by Nancy Buirski, chronicles the life of Ms. Le Clercq (1929-2000), the inspiration behind Balanchine’s “Symphonie Concertante,” “Symphony in C,” “Bourrée Fantasque” and “La Valse” and Robbins’s “Afternoon of a Faun.”

headline: Family, Corruption and Sage Words From a News Agency
abstract: A commentary by the state-run news agency Xinhua laced with revealing Chinese idioms is likely to be worrisome reading for Ling Jihua, once the powerful gatekeeper to the Communist Party’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese language is revealingly rich in mordant sayings about the nexus of family, officialdom and corruption. When a man becomes an official, one saying goes, even his “chickens and dogs become immortals.” And a commentary by the state news agency Xinhua that appeared Friday, laced with similar phrases, was likely to be worrisome reading for Ling Jihua, once the powerful gatekeeper to the Communist Party’s leadership.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — The top executives of Siemens and General Electric on Friday made what were likely to be their final pitches to the French government in their battle for Alstom, the French industrial company at the center of a high-stakes political battle.

headline: U.N. Reports Sharp Increase in Refugees as Civil Wars Cripple Nations
abstract: More than 51 million people have been displaced by violence around the world, according to the head of the United Nations refugee agency.
lead_paragraph: In Central African Republic, they ran from home and slept under the trees. In Colombia, they dared not return to their villages. From Syria, they fled by the hundreds of thousands, escaping barrel bombs and summary executions.

abstract: Trey Ratcliff, a travel photographer, took glorious videos of Beijing with a camera attached to a tiny helicopter drone. But he got slapped on the wrist for getting close to Zhongnanhai, which is more forbidden than the Forbidden City.
lead_paragraph: On all-too-rare clear days, Beijing can be a remarkably beautiful city, with elegant imperial buildings, ramshackle courtyard homes, shimmering skyscrapers and jagged hills rising in the distance.

headline: It’s Official: The Boomerang Kids Won’t Leave
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Families and Family Life', 'Youth', 'Student Loans', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Careers and Professions', 'Age, Chronological']
abstract: One in five young adults lives with his or her parents. It might be a recessionary blip — or the dawn of a whole new economic age.
lead_paragraph: Annie Kasinecz has two different ways of explaining why, at age 27, she still lives with her mom. In the first version — the optimistic one — she says that she is doing the sensible thing by living rent-free as she plans her next career move. After graduating from Loyola University Chicago, Kasinecz struggled to support herself in the midst of the recession, working a series of unsatisfying jobs — selling ads at the soon-to-be bankrupt Sun-Times, bagging groceries at Whole Foods, bartending — in order to pay down her student loans. But she inevitably grew frustrated with each job and found herself stuck in one financial mess after another. Now that she’s back in her high-school bedroom, perhaps she can finally focus on her long-term goals.

headline: French Summer Castles in the Sand
abstract: Every spring, French campers stake out a stretch of shoreline where they can still build makeshift beach houses that sustain a community of thousands through the summer.
lead_paragraph: At Piémanson, a Mediterranean beach in southern France, summer starts early. On April 30, families wait for the clock to strike midnight, ready to build makeshift beach houses on the same shoreline spot from previous years.

The Chinese government promptly responded by denouncing the entire exercise in bottom-up democracy as “illegal and invalid.”

headline: Morning Agenda: Icahn Takes Aim at Family Dollar
abstract: Carl C. Icahn is urging Family Dollar to sell itself. | What the Supreme Court’s ruling on Argentina means. | The bidding war for Alstom appears to be in its final stages. | Markit’s shares ended up 11.3 percent on their first day of trading.
lead_paragraph: ICAHN TAKES AIM AT FAMILY DOLLAR  |  The activist investor Carl C. Icahn, who has a long record of aggressively lobbying corporate boards and management, has turned his attention to Family Dollar Stores, the discount retailer in which he holds a 9.39 percent stake, DealBook’s William Alden writes. In a letter to Howard R. Levine, Family Dollar’s chief executive, Mr. Icahn urged the company to self itself “immediately.” He also demanded that three of his representatives be added to Family Dollar’s board. If the company does not cooperate, Mr. Icahn said he plans to go directly to shareholders with an effort to throw out the entire board.

abstract: The government forces were carrying out searches and arrests in a campaign to find three Israeli youths abducted a week ago.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli troops killed a Palestinian youth before dawn Friday and seriously wounded several adults as their sweeping West Bank arrest campaign following last week’s disappearance of three Israeli teenagers both slowed and encountered more resistance.

headline: A Second Career, Happily in the Weeds
abstract: A 2013 federal report showed that one-third of beginning farmers are over 55, and seem to take up the task after leaving a different career.
lead_paragraph: MARBLETOWN, N.Y. — STANDING at the edge of an overgrown field, Charles Noble, 65, cups his hands around his mouth and yells, “Mooowaaaahhh.” He hopes his bovine impression will motivate 68 cattle to follow him to a nearby creek. His herd is apparently not thirsty, preferring to munch on tall grass.

headline: Egypt Has a Sexual Violence Problem
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Female Genital Mutilation', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: It doesn’t matter where you stand on the political spectrum — if you are a woman, your body is not safe.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — There is a fierce battle raging in Egypt, and it’s not the one between Islamists and military rulers — the two factions that dominate most coverage of my country these days. The real battle, the one that will determine whether Egypt frees itself of authoritarianism, is between the patriarchy — established and upheld by the state, the street and at home — and women, who will no longer accept this status quo.

headline: In a Comedic Grab Bag, Many Welcome Surprises
abstract: Jane Lynch refuses to play by the rules during her cabaret appearance at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: Jane Lynch signaled in the opening moments of her smart, witty show at 54 Below on Wednesday evening that this was not going to be your typical cabaret evening of songs built around a theme, with a carefully plotted narrative arc. It was the opposite. In its free-form goofiness, it was what you might call “anti-cabaret.” That’s my term, not hers.

headline: Facing Cuts, Musicians Criticize Met’s Leadership
abstract: A committee representing the Met’s orchestra joins its union in telling the opera’s board that the struggles of recent revivals were “evidence of a failed artistic vision.”
lead_paragraph: The bitter labor talks at the Metropolitan Opera took a new turn this week with a blast from the pit: Musicians in the orchestra, who are being asked to accept pay and benefit cuts, sent letters to the company’s board questioning the Met’s artistic and financial stewardship.

headline: Beethoven, Bronfman and Soaring Sparks
abstract: Yefim Bronfman set fire to the Third Concerto in the Beethoven Festival of the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Twice now, in the course of a week, a New York Philharmonic concert has begun, uninspiringly, with a Beethoven piano concerto and has ended, powerfully, with a Beethoven piano concerto.

headline: After Accolades, Trio Injects a Little Folk Melody and Switches Gears Often
abstract: Children of the Light accepted awards for work in a quartet, then dived into its show on Tuesday at the Blue Note.
lead_paragraph: Before playing a note in its sold-out first set at the Blue Note on Tuesday night, the trio known as Children of the Light paused to receive some accolades. Together, its members — the pianist Danilo Pérez, the bassist John Patitucci and the drummer Brian Blade — make up the rhythm section in the Wayne Shorter Quartet. As such, they were presented with awards from the Jazz Journalists Association: midsize ensemble of the year and record of the year, for Mr. Shorter’s most recent album, “Without a Net.”

headline: Some Playful Touches in a Serious Approach
abstract: Rioult Dance New York presented two programs this week at the Joyce that included works by Martha Graham and May O’Donnell.
lead_paragraph: It takes grit to run a modern-dance company for 20 years, and Pascal Rioult has succeeded, driven partly by a desire to churn out works meant to pack an emotional wallop. Like his mentor Martha Graham, in whose troupe he danced, he creates efficiently structured choreography that is meant to stir and even unsettle the soul. Yet while Mr. Rioult’s passion for pairing dance and music is obvious, passion isn’t everything, and a missing ingredient blurs his efforts: a choreographic voice of his own.

headline: ‘The Goldfinch’ Alights in a Repolished Jewel Box
abstract: The Mauritshuis reopens next week in The Hague, its treasures re-ensconced after a subtle renovation and expansion.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — Since it opened to the public in 1822, the Royal Picture Gallery Mauritshuis has been one of those quiet gems, set in a 17th-century classical townhouse in the center of this patrician city and frequented by lovers of Dutch Golden Age painting. But when it closed for a renovation and expansion two years ago, and a selection from its collection went on tour, Mauritshuis gained an instant celebrity it had never had before.
