headline: Does Sex No Longer Sell T-Shirts? The Lessons of American Apparel and Abercrombie & Fitch
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Suddenly, marketing based on exuberant, stereotypically American sexuality doesn’t seem to be relevant any more.
lead_paragraph: O.K., I know that is a big question. But I’ve been thinking about it ever since the ouster on Wednesday of the American Apparel founder and chief executive Dov Charney.

headline: Listen Up | Andrea Balency Takes the Long Road to Electronica
abstract: The emotive half-French, half-Mexican balladeer puts 20 years of musical training to use on her debut EP.
lead_paragraph: The singer and producer Andrea Balency takes an unconventional tact when it comes to making electronic music. Rather than adding to what has become the echo chamber of EDM (electronic dance music), Balency’s ethereal voice and soft structures instead aim to mimic the movements of contemporary dance. “I’ve always loved dancing,” she says. “Those movements are something I try to translate with music.”

headline: U.S. Gives Thailand and Malaysia Lowest Grade on Human Trafficking
abstract: A State Department report released Friday ranks the two Southeast Asian countries with North Korea, Iran and Zimbabwe.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Thailand and Malaysia are among the two dozen countries doing the least to fight human trafficking, according to a State Department report released Friday, a finding that could lead to economic and diplomatic penalties.

headline: Telling Folk Heroes From Monsters
abstract: The trickster character has seen better days. As the documentary “The Internet’s Own Boy” demonstrates, it’s not always possible to think of the high-tech incarnation of this type as a folk hero.
lead_paragraph: Woe to the once-hallowed trickster. In ancient mythologies, the riddler-thief and agent of change held a position of prestige. Now, we don’t know what to do with him. In our two Americas, we do black and white, either/or, with us or against us. The trickster is in between, both and neither, a character on the fringes.

headline: America As A Lousy Exporter
abstract: Low costs, high productivity, but not that competitive.
lead_paragraph: Sorry about two-day silence — busy with real life and various obligations.

headline: New York City Leaders Reach Accord on $75 Billion Budget
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said the budget signaled a more compassionate era for New York, with investments in public housing and expanded prekindergarten programs.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio and the City Council speaker, Melissa Mark-Viverito, have announced an agreement on a $75 billion budget that Mr. de Blasio said signaled a more compassionate era for New York City, with investments in public housing, expanded prekindergarten programs and summer jobs for youths, but with no tax increases or major cuts.

headline: Chinese Workers in Iraq Staying Put, for the Moment
abstract: Chinese citizens based in the country’s south, which is less affected by the violence and where Chinese investment is concentrated, said that they felt safe for now and had no immediate plans to leave.
lead_paragraph: As sectarian fighting continues to roil Iraq, Chinese companies say they are preparing contingency plans to evacuate their workers from the country. But Chinese citizens based in the country’s south, which is less affected by the violence and where Chinese investment is concentrated, said in interviews that they felt safe for now and had no immediate plans to leave.

headline: In Our Pages: June 21
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Baron Henri de Rothschild is shot in Paris in 1914; Nationalist Spain says it will be neutral in the event of a European war in 1939.

headline: What Does It Mean to Be American?
abstract: Highlight a story or observation that expresses what being American means to you in the comment section of this article.
lead_paragraph: Throughout our journey up Interstate 35 — we’re at 3,500 miles, and counting — Todd Heisler and I have chronicled the process of cultural transformation in Middle America. Once-homogeneous towns and cities from Texas to Minnesota are now heavily influenced by the world; by immigrants with different customs, languages and ideas.

headline: Austerity and Hysteresis
abstract: It’s even worse than we thought.
lead_paragraph: Larry Ball has an important paper documenting, on a consistent basis, a very disturbing point: if you believe official estimates of potential output, the Great Recession and its aftermath have done incredible damage, not just to short-run output and employment, but to long-run prospects.

headline: 6 New Ways to Measure Your Financial Goals
abstract: Some metrics that we cling to in our financial lives can end up being wildly counterproductive. But what should we replace them with?
lead_paragraph: Most of us want goals to shoot for, but all too often we pick the wrong ones.

headline: As Child Migrants Flood to Border, U.S. Presses Latin America to Act
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Children and Childhood', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., on a visit to Guatemala, plans to highlight the dangers facing the children and the futility of their quest.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Faced with an unprecedented surge of child migrants from Central America that is overwhelming shelters and jails in Texas and Arizona, the United States has begun pushing for stronger regional cooperation to arrest the flow and enable the children’s safe return.

headline: The Unwanted Rites of Summer Phone Service
abstract: A doctor asks the Haggler for help with a perennial problem: How to have her phone service reconnected properly for a summer on Martha’s Vineyard?
lead_paragraph: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: Of Shower Scenes and Santeria
abstract: The black and Hispanic inmates circle each other in the stalls.
lead_paragraph: Season 2, Episode 5 Strap in. Just as the last four episodes were starting to feel a bit too linear, this one moves fast in a lot of different directions — both in the past and present stories. (Spoilers below.)

headline: U.S. Moves to Stop Surge in Illegal Immigration
abstract: The Obama administration, increasing efforts to reduce the influx of migrants crossing the Southwest border illegally, will detain more of those migrants and accelerate their cases so they can be deported more quickly, officials said.
lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Tex. — White House officials, saying that misinformation about administration policies helped drive a surge of illegal migrants from Central America across the South Texas border, on Friday announced plans to detain more of them and to accelerate their court cases so as to deport them more quickly.

headline: Letters: ‘No Place to Hide’
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Glenn Greenwald’s “No Place to Hide,” Paul Stanley’s “Face the Music” and more.
lead_paragraph: ‘No Place to Hide’

headline: The Great Y.A. Debate of 2014
abstract: A recent essay on Slate argued that adults should be embarrassed to read young adult books.
lead_paragraph: When the journalist Ruth Graham finished reading John Green’s tear-jerker of a best seller “The Fault in Our Stars,” her eyes were dry, and she wondered: “Does this make me heartless? Or does it make me a grown-up?”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: A REPLACEMENT LIFE,  by Boris Fishman. (Harper, $25.99.) In Fishman’s bold, ambitious and wickedly smart first novel, a Soviet émigré writer in New York becomes disturbingly adept at forging applications for Holocaust reparations.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WE NEED NEW NAMES,  by NoViolet Bulawayo. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $15.) Ten-year-old Darling, the narrator of Bulawayo’s striking first novel, a Man Booker Prize finalist, ekes out a bare-bones existence in a Zimbabwe shantytown. When she’s sent to live with relatives in Detroit, Darling discovers that, far from the comforts of her childhood community, much of America’s abundance is out of reach, and she is forced to reckon with the sacrifices and mixed rewards of assimilating.

headline: The Living and the Undead
abstract: A vampire novel set in Victorian London is told from multiple perspectives.
lead_paragraph: Reading the blurbs on the dust jacket of Lauren Owen’s first novel — from such luminaries as Kate Atkinson, Hilary Mantel and Tana French — readers might think they’re about to embark on a highhanded version of the Gothic novel, full of metafictions and literary allusions. These do appear, along with some beautiful language, but by Page 100, when the first neck is about to be bitten, “The Quick” drops its cloak and becomes a good old-fashioned vampire novel.

headline: The Descent
abstract: Learning to freedive affords a journalist access to a range of underwater worlds.
lead_paragraph: How, in this age of surveillance, can we lose a 210-foot airplane? With its known initial flight path and fuel load, investigators can restrict the last possible position of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 to a sliver of the globe. Trouble is, most of that sliver — like 71 percent of Earth’s surface — is covered by water.

headline: Down Under
abstract: A history of our desire to conquer, understand, embrace and ultimately save the Great Barrier Reef.
lead_paragraph: Our planet’s coral reefs offer nourishment and sanctuary to as many as nine million species, running the gamut of life, from single-cell organisms to whales. The Great Barrier Reef, shimmering beneath the turquoise shallows of Australia’s east coast, surpasses all other coral ecosystems in scale and fame. This colossal spine of life stretches for 1,400 miles, roughly the distance from Boston to Havana. Today the Great Barrier Reef seems obviously spectacular: a World Heritage Site visible to astronauts in outer space and acclaimed as one of the earth’s greatest natural wonders. Yet as Iain ­McCalman reveals in his enthralling book, “The Reef,” little more than 200 years ago no human had any inkling of its dimensions, far less any inkling of the complex science of its precarious vitality.

headline: Secret Lives
abstract: New books by Lauren Francis-Sharma, Claire Kendal, Lisa See, Jennifer Weiner and Lauren Willig.
lead_paragraph: ’TIL THE WELL RUNS DRY  By Lauren Francis-Sharma  Holt, $27.

headline: For Whom the Bell Tolled
abstract: A collective portrait of three couples, including Ernest Hemingway and Martha Gellhorn, caught up in the Spanish Civil War.
lead_paragraph: While many ran in terror from the mounting monstrosities of Spain’s civil war in the late 1930s, three couples — the bright young photographers Robert Capa and Gerda Taro, the writers Ernest Hemingway and Martha Gellhorn, and the devoted press officers Arturo Barea and Ilsa Kulcsar — jumped into the fray. As Amanda Vaill writes in “Hotel Florida,” they risked their lives to shape public opinion and sharpen political will, daring their way toward a new destiny.

headline: Late Reinforcements
abstract: In Aharon Appelfeld’s novel, a sick and aging man in Jerusalem hires a young caretaker.
lead_paragraph: Of the many challenges confronting the contemporary writer of fiction, among the most vexing is the problem of goodness. How does one convincingly portray goodness in an age when the twin presiding deities are irony and violence, when the most feared transgression is the sin of sentimentality? Can there be a place for a character who seems genuinely selfless, motivated by benevolence, decency, the desire to be of help?

headline: Who Made That Pacifier?
abstract: An obvious improvement on knotted rags dipped in honey.
lead_paragraph: By the time Christian W. Meinecke applied for a patent for “a new and original Design for a Baby Comforter” in 1901, people had been giving babies soothing objects to suck on for centuries: knotted rags dipped in water or honey, wooden beads or “gum sticks” made of stone, bone or coral. But nothing would ever be quite as popular as the pacifier.

headline: So You Think You Can Steal?
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Reality Television', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Automobiles']
abstract: Taking the bait car.
lead_paragraph: I witnessed an odd incident: Two cars stopped, and the drivers began arguing. After a few moments of yelling, one driver got into the other’s car, and they drove off, leaving the second car unlocked with the engine running. I saw this very situation on a reality TV show called “Bait Car”: a vehicle is left for someone to steal while the police and cameramen wait. I yelled: “Bait car! Bait car!” as a warning for people nearby. When I told this story later, I was criticized for helping would-be thieves. But I am not comfortable with the show’s premise. Should I have said nothing? STEVEN FONG, SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Kevin Hart: ‘I Don’t Need Therapy’
abstract: The comedian works it out on stage.
lead_paragraph: The comedian talks to Jessica Gross about his first night onstage, growing up in North Philadelphia and learning about the existence of tall people.

headline: Reply All: The 6.8.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: KLINSMANN’S PLAN TO MAKE U.S. SOCCER BETTER

headline: How to Give an Outdoor Cocktail Party
abstract: Advice from an event planner, plus the dangers of the Dow, sunscreen brands by S.P.F. and more.
lead_paragraph: Advice from an event planner, plus the dangers of the Dow, sunscreen brands by S.P.F. and more.

headline: What I Didn’t Understand That Summer in Mexico
abstract: The warning signs were there, but I was too young to make sense of them.
lead_paragraph: I had never been to Mexico before. It was the summer after eighth grade, and my best friend’s parents invited me to their condo in the Yucatán Peninsula, about an hour by car from Cancun. My mother dropped me at Newark Airport. She told me to behave.

headline: Moving Forward
abstract: Gail Caldwell revisits a turning point in her life, one that opened up a world of new possibilities and connections.
lead_paragraph: On the cusp of turning 50, the artist Tracey Emin told the BBC: “I always thought that love was about desire, being with someone, holding someone, feeling someone. But it isn’t necessarily. Love can be different and come in lots of different ways and lots of different guises.” Her interviewer was suitably intrigued. England’s notorious “bad girl” no longer cared about shagging.

headline: Early Frost
abstract: The poet’s letters reveal a dedicated writer and ambitious man.
lead_paragraph: In the early fall of 1912, a blandly handsome, tousle-headed American schoolteacher arrived in London. Nearing 40, coming without introduction or much of a plan — except, as he later confessed, “to write and be poor” — he was making a last attempt to write himself into poetry. It would have taken mad willfulness to drag his wife and four children out of their ­settled New Hampshire life in a quixotic assault on the London literary scene. Still, he was soon spending a candlelit evening with Yeats in the poet’s curtained rooms, having come to the attention of that “stormy petrel” Ezra Pound, who lauded him in reviews back home. Little more than two years later, the schoolteacher sailed back, having published his first two books, “A Boy’s Will” (1913) and “North of Boston” (1914). He had become Robert Frost.

headline: The Wordy Shipmate
abstract: From his fiction and cultural criticism to his latest adventure on an aircraft carrier, Geoff Dyer has defied genres for decades.
lead_paragraph: When Geoff Dyer came aboard the U.S.S. George H. W. Bush for his 14-day stay, he had his Ping-Pong paddle securely stowed but had misplaced his notebook. Too tall, spindly, self-described as “a leftover from a novel Graham Greene had decided not to write,” he had managed through a stubbornness born of sheer neurotic panic to wheedle his way, despite considerable and justified resistance from the United States Navy, into private quarters on the giant but very crowded vessel: the Vice-Presidential Room, no less. His report of his first day on board is a nonstop string of complaints: The noise is unbearable, he keeps knocking his head on the low ceilings and hatches, the spaghetti is cold and the lettuce inedible, the oil fumes are overwhelming, the temperature is like a blast furnace, the air is toxic, the ocean glitters but is spoiled by a sky greased with jet fuel. Dyer admits he is constitutionally incapable of adjusting to new environments; in fact, the only thing he’s grown accustomed to, over the years, is that he never gets used to things. This is the same man who, when asked by a friend (Alain de Botton) if he would like to spend some time writing in an interesting and relaxing environment, immediately replied: Put me on an American aircraft carrier.

headline: Exile’s End
abstract: A couple return to Poland, 40 years after the war and their escape from the Warsaw ghetto.
lead_paragraph: In September 1939, more than 350,000 Jews lived in Warsaw. Six years later, only 11,500 were left. Most of Warsaw itself had been wiped from the face of the earth.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Diana Gabaldon’s “Written in My Own Heart’s Blood” — the eighth entry in her Outlander series of time-traveling romances — is No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, with a new TV show based on the series coming in August.
lead_paragraph: Turkey Stuffing: Diana Gabaldon’s hefty new novel, “Written in My Own Heart’s Blood” — the eighth entry in her Outlander series of time-traveling romances — enters the hardcover fiction list right at No. 1. These books describe the escapades of an 18th-century Scotsman and the World War II-era English nurse who fell into his world courtesy of a witches’ coven; writing in Salon in 1999, the critic Gavin McNett called it “the smartest historical sci-fi adventure-romance story ever written by a science Ph.D. with a background in scripting ‘Scrooge McDuck’ comics.” It’s been five years since the last Outlander title hit stores, and with a new Starz TV show based on the series coming in August, fans are primed for the latest installment. Gabaldon answered their questions recently on the website Goodreads. “People often say to me, ‘You write such strong female characters,’ ” she told one reader who praised the depiction of her heroine, “and I say, ‘Well, I don’t like stupid women.’ ” Gabaldon also cited her belief that fiction has three kinds of characters: mushrooms, hard nuts and onions. It’s a theory she’s expanded on at her official website. Onions, she explains, “develop slowly through the addition of multiple layers of personality, rather than popping up full-fledged as the ‘mushrooms’ do.” Hard nuts, meanwhile, play a merely functional role, making them difficult to animate. “Onions, mushrooms and nuts,” Gabaldon writes; “this is beginning to sound like an exotic recipe for turkey stuffing.”

headline: This Is Your Brain on Writing
abstract: For the first time, researchers have used fMRI scanners to track the brain activity of writers as they created fiction. The results have drawn strong reactions from other scientists.
lead_paragraph: A novelist scrawling away in a notebook in seclusion may not seem to have much in common with an NBA player doing a reverse layup on a basketball court before a screaming crowd. But if you could peer inside their heads, you might see some striking similarities in how their brains were churning.

headline: Events in New Jersey for June 22-28, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: House Votes to Curb N.S.A. Scrutiny of Americans’ Communications
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Lawmakers say the National Security Agency should need a warrant to look for Americans emails and phone calls it gathers while targeting foreigners.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives late on Thursday voted to bar the National Security Agency from looking for Americans’ communications without a warrant within a database of emails and phone calls it gathers while targeting foreigners, a technique critics have labeled a “backdoor search loophole.”

headline: Notable Fires in the New York City Area
abstract: A brief history of the major fires in the New York City region since 1776.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times published an in-depth article about a probationary New York City firefighter this weekend.

headline: For Incarcerated Japanese-Americans, Baseball Was ‘Wearing the American Flag’
abstract: Amid their humiliations during World War II, the inmates defiantly asserted their Americanism through the national pastime.
lead_paragraph: After the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor in December 1941, some Americans expected Major League Baseball to be suspended until World War II was won. Many of the players would want to enlist, they argued, and letting baseball go on as usual might be frivolously disrespectful of the nation’s war effort.

headline: My Lower East Side
abstract: A young transplant is drawn to the lively and fast-changing New York neighborhood a great-great-grandfather left behind.
lead_paragraph: The way we heard it, the rabbi’s wife died on a Tuesday. That left just enough time for seven days of sitting shiva, and after that, a speedy white paint job and a Sunday open house that ended with our successful offer for a spacious and sunny two-bedroom co-op apartment.

headline: Dispatches From the Culture Front
abstract: How The Times reacted to art around the time of World War I.
lead_paragraph: Modernism in the arts can be traced to the late 19th century, but it was the years during and after World War I when the movement matured and produced some of its most startling work. Here are excerpts from The New York Times that show how it covered a few key figures and developments.

headline: Costa Rica vs. Italy: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: When Costa Rica headed to halftime down by 1-0 to Uruguay, few expected what came next: three unanswered goals and a team-defining win. But will this long shot be simply a one-hit wonder? Italy will be better organized and more professional than Uruguay.
lead_paragraph: When Costa Rica headed to halftime down by 1-0 to Uruguay, few expected what came next: three unanswered goals and a team-defining win. But will this long shot be simply a one-hit wonder? Italy will be better organized and more professional than Uruguay.

headline: Sky Diving as a Birthday Gift? Maybe a Nice Sweater Instead
abstract: How did old people jumping out of airplanes get to be a good idea?
lead_paragraph: Everyone was so excited about George H. W. Bush’s jumping out of a plane for his 90th birthday last week, it has inspired me to publicly make a vow: I will not be jumping out of a plane when I turn 90. I won’t do it when I turn 80, either.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Dan Barber’s ‘The Third Plate’
abstract: This week, Dan Barber talks about “The Third Plate”; John Williams on the week’s literary news; James Nestor discusses “Deep”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Dan Barber talks about “The Third Plate”; John Williams on the week’s literary news; James Nestor discusses “Deep”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Court Allows Coca-Cola Plant to Reopen in Uttar Pradesh
abstract: A Coca-Cola production facility in Uttar Pradesh State that was forced to close earlier this month due to concerns over pollution will reopen after an environmental court ruled in the company’s favor on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The National Green Tribunal, an environmental court, on Friday ruled to allow a Coca-Cola production facility in the state of Uttar Pradesh to reopen after it had been closed in early June because of concerns over waste disposal and water usage.

headline: Events in Connecticut for June 22-28, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Dan Barber’s ‘The Third Plate’
abstract: This week, Dan Barber and James Nestor.
lead_paragraph: This week, Dan Barber and James Nestor.

headline: In Los Angeles, Old-Fashioned Glamour or Hip Mixology
abstract: In this restaurant-conscious city, bars are joining the scene.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles is not what you would call a bar town, and for all the obvious reasons. The region covers almost 5,000 square miles. While public transit does exist there — and taxis and Uber are thriving — it is not New York: If you stumble out of a bar on the way home, there’s not a subway on the corner.

headline: A Guide Who Knows the Turf
keywords: ['Real Estate Brokers', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Tama Robertson is among the brokers who specialize in lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender clients.
lead_paragraph: Tama Robertson, a real estate broker, was warming up to a landlord on the Lower East Side of Manhattan recently when he casually asked for her help in breaking the law. Ms. Robertson had heard landlords make crude requests before, but this one stopped her cold.

headline: Eight Hours of Free Music at Sunday’s Bang on a Can Marathon
abstract: This year’s installment of the new-music celebration runs Sunday from 2 p.m. to 10 p.m. at the Winter Garden at Brookfield Place.
lead_paragraph: The Bang on a Can Marathon has been one of the central events of the new-music calendar since 1987, when the composers who founded the organization – Michael Gordon, Julia Wolfe and David Lang – invited composers and performers to present the first of them at a SoHo gallery. In recent years, the marathon has been part of the River to River Festival, and has been held in the vast Winter Garden at Brookfield Place (formerly the World Financial Center), where listeners can take it in with varying degrees of casualness, coming and going as they see fit.

headline: Three’s a Trend | The Return of Wide-Legged Jeans
abstract: In London, the spring/summer 2015 men’s shows favored this throwback silhouette in a series of minimal looks.
lead_paragraph: Tight-fitting denim will always have its place on the runway, thanks to designers like Hedi Slimane for Saint Laurent. But in the spring/summer 2015 collections so far, looser, longer jeans silhouettes are on the rise. Unlike the baggy low-riders of the hip-hop ’90’s, the new crop of wide-legged jeans is surprisingly understated. At the E.Tautz show in London, the designer Patrick Grant offered a version that was dark-washed, cuffed and slightly high waisted. (He sported a pair for his bow.) Worn monochromatically with a tucked shirt and long mac coat, the runway look was put-together but relaxed. Margaret Howell, who continues to show strong collections of covetable basics, also introduced a loose-fitting pair of jeans, which was topped with a simple shirt and coat. And Marta Marques and Paulo Almeida, the duo behind Marques’Almeida, took a more youthful approach, fraying the pants’ hems and pairing them with an equally frayed top and coat that evoked a similarly laid-back minimalism, but with an edge.

headline: Surprisingly Good at Talking About Sex
abstract: When my son first asked me a question about sex, I was surprised by how fundamentally unembarrassed I was, because it didn’t occur to him that it was something to be embarrassed about.
lead_paragraph: “I hate the word ‘moist.’”

headline: Michael Shannon Finds Balance on the Waterfront
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: In Red Hook, Brooklyn, the actor Michael Shannon and his family find a middle ground between the city and suburbs.
lead_paragraph: Throughout history men have made quixotic and impressive sacrifices for the women they loved — started wars, committed murder, swallowed poison, abdicated.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Venus in Fur,’ ‘Norte, the End of History’ and ‘Jersey Boys’
abstract: Times critics on “Venus in Fur,” “Norte, the End of History” and “Jersey Boys.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics review “Venus in Fur,” “Norte, the End of History” and “Jersey Boys.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Tracy Morgan Is Moved to Rehab Center
abstract: The comedian who was badly injured in a crash earlier this month was released from the hospital.
lead_paragraph: Tracy Morgan was released from the New Jersey hospital where he was being treated for critical injuries from a car accident and “transferred to an undisclosed rehab center,” his press representatives said Friday.

headline: Broccoli, Stems and All
abstract: Broccoli stems often play second fiddle to the more popular crowns, and are sometimes even shunned altogether. That’s a shame, because stems have a charm all their own. These recipes highlight the differences in texture and flavor of two parts of the same vegetable.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, when you bought broccoli you bought the whole vegetable, stems and crowns. Then it became customary for grocery store produce departments to separate the crowns from the stems and to sell the crowns at a premium.

headline: TV’s Messy Women
abstract: A new slate of less-than-perfect women have taken TV and film by storm, and, ANNA NORTH writes, some critics are happier about it than others.
lead_paragraph: “Trainwreck.” “Burnout.” “Poster child for IDGAF.” Whatever you call her, a new female archetype has made its way to film and TV, and some viewers are more excited than others.

headline: Today in Small Business: Google My Business
abstract: Will Google’s new portal help small businesses? Is it time to stop paying attention to click-through rates? And why you should give your sales force a checkup.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: R.I.P. Gerry Goffin, a Master Songwriter
abstract: He knew how to convey complicated emotions with the plainest of words.
lead_paragraph: I used to give a class for New York Times interns on writing and editing. I would start by playing the Gerry Goffin and Carole King song “Will You Love Me Tomorrow?” (I used Ms. King’s version.) I wanted to make a point about brevity and beauty: to show how it’s possible to convey complicated emotions, deep feeling and intricate meanings with the tiniest and plainest of words. You can be short and sweet. You can also be short and heartbreaking.

headline: France vs. Switzerland: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Switzerland was much buzzed-about coming into the Cup, and after an initial struggle, it rallied to beat Ecuador.
lead_paragraph: Switzerland was much buzzed-about coming into the Cup, and after an initial struggle, it rallied to beat Ecuador.

headline: A Survivor, Inspired by Love and Loss
abstract: Michael Hersch’s new opera, “On the Threshold of Winter,” was inspired by a friend’s lost battle with ovarian cancer and a dying Romanian poet’s diary.
lead_paragraph: HAVERTOWN, Pa. — The visual artist Christopher Cairns’s sprawling studio near Philadelphia is filled with installations that include piles of skulls and forlorn figures slumped despairingly in chairs. Sculptures that evoke the victims of Pompeii are strewn across the floor near the white wall, which is made of crumbling bricks and shards of glass and will be replicated in the sets for “On the Threshold of Winter,” Michael Hersch’s new opera. Mr. Cairns’s eerie art seems an aptly somber pairing for the dark-hued monodrama, which will receive its premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday, Mr. Hersch’s birthday, with Tito Muñoz conducting the ensemble Nunc.

headline: A War to End All Innocence
abstract: Cast in its day as “the war to end all wars,” World War I has instead become the war to which all subsequent wars and much else in modern life seem to refer, consciously or not.
lead_paragraph: “I feel like a soldier on the morning after the Somme.” This line of dialogue, from an episode in the second season of the BBC series “Call the Midwife,” caught my ear recently as an especially piquant morsel of period detail. It is uttered by a doctor to a nurse after they have just assisted in a grueling home birth, an experience that is compared to the four-month battle in a muddy stretch of Picardy beginning on July 1, 1916, that was, at the time, the bloodiest episode of combat in human history, generating 60,000 casualties in a single day of fighting on the British side alone. The doctor’s comparison is surely metaphorical overkill, but it also represents a familiar style of wit, a habit of linking the challenges we regularly endure with calamities we can scarcely imagine.

headline: Venture Capital Firm Settles S.E.C. Charges Over ‘Pay-to-Play’
abstract: TL Ventures improperly accepted fees from two public pension funds after a senior employee of the firm made campaign contributions in Pennsylvania, the S.E.C. said.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:35 p.m. |

headline: Jumping Through Hoops for a Better Health Plan
abstract: Insurers are moving toward tiered offerings, with rewards in the form of better or cheaper coverage for healthier behavior.
lead_paragraph: To get an idea of what your employer’s health plan may look like in the near future, consider the options the government of Manatee County, Fla., offers to its workers.

headline: When a Will Divides an Estate, and Also Divides a Family
abstract: When an estate is parceled out in unequal shares, family members can turn on one another and no one benefits except the lawyers.
lead_paragraph: KATE’S father died when she was in college, but she stayed close to his side of the family. Although she moved to North Carolina after graduation, she and her three siblings returned to New Jersey a couple of times a year to visit her grandmother, aunts and cousins. She called her grandmother frequently until dementia made it impossible for them to communicate.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Dan Barber’s ‘Third Plate’
abstract: Mr. Barber talks about his new book, and James Nestor discusses “Deep: Freediving, Renegade Science, and What the Ocean Tells Us About Ourselves.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Corby Kummer reviews Dan Barber’s “The Third Plate.” Mr. Kummer writes:

headline: G.E.’s Bid for Alstom Is Blessed by France

abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Revisiting Jazz Roots
abstract: Decades after two jazz lofts in Lower Manhattan succumbed to rising real estate values, a benefit concert at New York University will bring back many veterans of that scene.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-five years ago, the trumpeter and impresario Mark Morganelli opened the first of two jazz lofts in Lower Manhattan. Nineteen years later, he began presenting a series of free summer concerts in Westchester County.

headline: A Soft-Shell Crab to Top Your Toast
abstract: A charred crust heightens the crunch of the crabs, while the soft center crumb sucks up their juices, not a drop lost to the plate.
lead_paragraph: Of all the things you may put on toast, one of the best has claws. The soft-shell crab isn’t as classic as, say, butter and jam. But when the crabs are in season, there are few better ways to savor them.

headline: This Weekend: The BAMcinemaFest
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott offers his must-see list of films from BAMcinemafest.
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott offers his must-see list of films from BAMcinemafest.

headline: Chasing Fires in the Dark
abstract: Over a summer of solitude and personal upheaval in 1996, the photographer Gregory Crewdson spent each night documenting fireflies and will put the images on display this summer at Wave Hill.
lead_paragraph: In 1996, Gregory Crewdson left New York to spend the summer living alone in his family’s cabin in the Berkshires. Upon his arrival, he devised a plan: He would go outside nightly to photograph fireflies.

headline: Iraq’s Hold on Border Crossings Weakening as at Least 34 Are Killed in Battle
abstract: Sunni militants overran one of the last government-held crossings on the Syrian border on Friday after a fierce battle that left at least 34 Iraqi soldiers dead.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Sunni militants overran one of the last government-held crossings on the Syrian border on Friday after a fierce battle that left at least 34 Iraqi soldiers dead.

headline: Image of the Day: June 20
abstract: Students in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, praying for the safety of Indians kidnapped by militants in Iraq.

headline: Afghan Leader Backs U.N. Election Role
abstract: President Hamid Karzai’s comments revived the possibility that the international community might once more have a hand in the selection of a new leader for Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Seeking to quell a political crisis surrounding the June 14 election to choose his successor, President Hamid Karzai reversed course on Friday and suggested that the United Nations get involved in helping Afghanistan settle disputes over the voting.

headline: There Is a Simpler Way for Students to Apply for Financial Aid
abstract: The complicated college financing process is discouraging people from applying for aid and going to college.
lead_paragraph: Any college student who wants a federal loan or Pell grant has to file a Free Application for Federal Student Aid. With well over 100 questions about income, assets and expenses, the Fafsa approaches the IRS Form 1040 in length, and is longer and more complicated than the 1040A and 1040EZ, the tax forms filed by a majority of taxpayers.

headline: The Latest Icon in Artistic Rebellion: A Cabbage
abstract: There’s a reason the Chinese authorities are not known for their sense of humor. They even stopped the artist Han Bing when he went to Tiananmen Square with the latest trendy object in the Chinese art world — a pet cabbage.
lead_paragraph: Every so often, the artist Han Bing likes to play a little prank with a white cabbage — that iconic, rectangular vegetable synonymous in China with full bellies and good fortune. Impaled on a wheeled frame and tied to a length of rope, the cabbage resembles a miniature parade float trailing along behind him through streets around the globe. In Beijing, Los Angeles, New York, Tokyo and other cities, the spectacle has triggered laughter, finger-pointing and questions from bemused passersby. But Mr. Han, 40, gives no answers.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Jersey Boys’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Jersey Boys.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Jersey Boys.”

headline: Asked, Maybe Answered
abstract: Enquire and Pyne, two apps recently introduced in New York, illustrate the challenges developers face when trying to make useful question-and-answer platforms.
lead_paragraph: Two apps recently introduced in New York illustrate the challenges developers face when trying to make useful question-and-answer platforms. Enquire, which connects users with locals who can answer questions about the city’s neighborhoods, and Pyne, which allows users to create and respond to polls, both rely on groups of people willing to ask — and answer — questions.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Norte’

lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Norte, the End of History.”

headline: When the Korean Team Plays, Eat Korean
abstract: During the World Cup, especially when South Korea is playing, Hahm Ji Bach restaurant in Flushing, Queens, is bustling with diners and soccer fans.
lead_paragraph: Hahm Ji Bach is a robust Korean family-style barbecue on 149th Place in Flushing, Queens, with room for 150 diners and tables with built-in grills. But during the World Cup, especially when South Korea is playing, Ham Ji Bach bustles with people indulging together, as well as single eaters with giant portions at tables for one.

lead_paragraph: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the young English singers.

headline: ‘In C,’ and Many Other Keys
abstract: To honor Terry Riley’s classic work “In C,” 11 composers wrote works for all the other notes of the chromatic scale.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate the 50th anniversary of Terry Riley’s “In C,” the seminal Minimalist score that has become virtually a standard repertory work, at least in New York – hardly a season goes by without at least one performance – 11 composers have joined forces to write companion works built around the other notes of the chromatic scale.

headline: Charles Barsotti, Cartoonist With Humor Both Simple and Absurd, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Barsotti made New Yorker readers laugh for more than 40 years with imaginative drawings that often had no punch line.
lead_paragraph: Charles Barsotti, a cartoonist for The New Yorker whose jaded canines, outlaw snails and obtuse monarchs made readers laugh for more than 40 years, died on Monday at his home in Kansas City, Mo. He was 80.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:49 p.m. | The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking to shine a light on trades in the relatively opaque markets for corporate and municipal bonds.

headline: The House Actually Did Something About Warrantless Surveillance
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: A bill would bar intelligence agencies from snooping on American communications that have been swept into databases created to target foreigners.
lead_paragraph: In an unusual display of unity from the divided, do-nothing House, a bipartisan group of lawmakers pushed through a bill that basically says, yes, the Fourth Amendment applies to electronic communications, too.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: General in Sex Case to Retire With a 2-Rank Demotion
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair, who was charged with sexual assault before the case crumbled earlier this year, will be eligible for retirement benefits, including pay, but at a lower level.
lead_paragraph: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair, whose extramarital relationship with a subordinate officer led to charges of sexual assault and a prosecution that ultimately collapsed and embarrassed the military, will retire as a lieutenant colonel, two grades lower than his current rank, the Army said Friday.

headline: Popcast: Ed Sheeran and Sam Smith, British Pop Imports
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the young English singers.
lead_paragraph: Two young English pop singers, Ed Sheeran and Sam Smith, both enthusiastically welcomed in the United States, have ambitious new records.

headline: Calculated Risks: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s ‘Hard Choices’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In “Hard Choices,” Hillary Clinton takes the reader along on her journey representing the United States as President Obama’s top diplomat.
lead_paragraph: In 1969, the night before a Wellesley College senior named Hillary Rodham gave a commencement address that would draw national attention, she was introduced to Dean Acheson, the legendary former secretary of state who had come to campus for his granddaughter’s graduation. “I’m looking forward to hearing what you have to say,” Acheson told Rodham. At the time, many in the country were looking forward to hearing what Acheson had to say. He had just put the finishing touches on “Present at the Creation,” his landmark memoir that would come out a few months after his encounter with the young Rodham, providing a seminal portrait of his role in helping Harry S. Truman forge a new national security architecture at the outset of the Cold War.

headline: Number of French Jews Emigrating to Israel Rises
abstract: The number of French émigrés was four times higher in the first three months of the year than in the same period a year earlier, in part because of a weak economy and anti-Semitism.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For Tiffany Taieb Nizard, the decision to abandon France for Israel came this month when a French-born man was accused of gunning down four people at the Jewish Museum in Brussels in an anti-Semitic attack.

headline: Trumping the First Choice
abstract: The story behind the cover of this week’s Book Review.
lead_paragraph: The cover review this week wasn’t our original choice — we had an entirely different plan at the ready, a review of something else, already edited with the illustration assigned — and then the review of the novel “Song of the Shank” by Jeffery Renard Allen came in, less than a week before we had to go to press.Mitchell S. Jackson, whose first novel, “The Residue Years,” came out last year, had written a total rave, calling Allen’s book “the kind of imaginative work only a prodigiously gifted risk-taker could produce.” It was an interesting match between reviewer and author because, as the assigning editor Gregory Cowles explained, “Their novels are very different — Jackson’s was contemporary and seemingly autobiographical, while Allen’s is on the face of it neither of those. But both are voice-driven and beautifully written, and both play with contemporary ideas about family, race, class and the long legacy of slavery.”

headline: Hoofbeats and Ocean Views in Brooklyn
abstract: On the edge of a highway, the Jamaica Bay Riding Academy sits on 500 surprisingly peaceful acres of rugged coastline and unspoiled forest paths.
lead_paragraph: In a city where dogs are carried around in purses, it seems amazing to find that Susan Gallahue, 64, keeps a horse. Not in her apartment on the Upper West Side, of course, but at the bucolic Jamaica Bay Riding Academy in Bergen Beach, Brooklyn, where she visits Silver Palace, her Thoroughbred-warmblood mix, about four times a week. Ms. Gallahue, a full-time psychiatric nurse, looks forward to every visit with Silver, a retired show-jumping mare she says has “the best personality.”

headline: N.F.L. Collusion Case Reinstated on Appeal
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Football', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: The case stems from the 2010 season, when there was no salary cap and, the players union claims, teams worked together to keep salaries artificially low.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court reinstated a case brought by the N.F.L. Players Association, which has accused N.F.L. owners of collusion by creating a secret salary cap in the 2010 season.

headline: Palestinians Hold Funeral for Boy Killed
abstract: Hundreds attended a funeral procession in the village of Dura for a Palestinian teenager killed by Israeli troops in the West Bank during search operations for three missing Israeli teens.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds attended a funeral procession in the village of Dura for a Palestinian teenager killed by Israeli troops in the West Bank during search operations for three missing Israeli teens.

headline: A Revue of Pop Songs as Catchy as Poison Ivy
abstract: “Smokey Joe’s Cafe,” a musical revue with 39 Lieber and Stoller classics, is scheduled to hit the road in October in a 20th anniversary national tour.
lead_paragraph: Creating a Broadway revue around a songwriting duo who specialized in pop music was a novel idea back in 1995, when “Smokey Joe’s Cafe: The Songs of Leiber and Stoller” made its debut. But it worked. The musical, based on the work of Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller, ran for nearly five years, showcasing such beloved tunes as “Dance With Me,” “Kansas City,” “Hound Dog” and “There Goes My Baby.”

headline: Letting Go of Sykes-Picot
abstract: Is there still a one-state solution for Iraq?
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week I quoted David Frum, usually more hawkish than I, on the theme that American interests in Iraq might be better pursued by looking for solid ground in, say, Kurdistan than by trying to help Iran stabilize the Sunni Triangle or replaying the Diem drama with our new batch of military advisers and Nouri al-Maliki. Now Jeffrey Goldberg, also usually more hawkish than I, has written a follow-up to the 2008 essay I cited in my Sunday column, on the Middle East’s potential post-Iraq War map, which circles around to a similar conclusion:

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $11.75 Million, With a Tycoon for a Neighbor
abstract: A full-floor apartment at the bronze-and-glass tower One Madison is the most expensive sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A full-floor residence at One Madison, the sylphlike bronze-and-glass tower at 23 East 22nd Street that has inspired a defection of high-rollers, including the media mogul Rupert Murdoch, from less avant-garde locales uptown, sold for $11.75 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Polar Exploration Inside an Insurance Office
abstract: At the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, Split Knuckle Theater mashes up the financial crisis and the tale of the intrepid Sir Ernest Shackleton.
lead_paragraph: There was Kevin Spacey. There was a weird dream about an out-of-control copy machine. And there was the unraveling of the economy in 2008. All played a part in the creation of “Endurance,” a 90-minute theatrical mash-up in which grumbling insurance workers morph into chantey-singing polar explorers, office furniture subs for a doughty wooden icebreaker, and a light switch conveys audiences at the Long Wharf Theater from a standard-issue Hartford workplace to the shifting ice floes of Antarctica and back again.

headline: Driven | 2014 Buick Regal Turbo
abstract: The old slogan “Wouldn’t you really rather have a Buick” means something again.
lead_paragraph: The old slogan “Wouldn’t you really rather have a Buick” means something again.

headline: Video: The 2014 Buick Regal Turbo Is Fun for All Ages
abstract: Once lumped with Oldsmobile and Mercury as retiree-friendly brands, Buick may be shedding that long-held stigma.
lead_paragraph: Baby boomers know Buick as an automotive brand favored by their parents (or grandparents). Jingles that purred “Wouldn’t you really rather have a Buick?” during “The Ed Sullivan Show” didn’t work on the generation raised on Barbie, Hot Wheels and the Beatles. They ended up preferring to have a Lexus. Or an Audi. Or a BMW.

headline: I.R.S. Head Testifies on Tea Party Query
abstract: John Koskinen, the Internal Revenue Service commissioner, clashed with lawmakers over missing emails during a heated House hearing on the tax agency’s scrutiny of Tea Party-aligned political groups.
lead_paragraph: John Koskinen, the Internal Revenue Service commissioner, clashed with lawmakers over missing emails during a heated House hearing on the tax agency’s scrutiny of Tea Party-aligned political groups.

headline: Japanese Report Casts Doubt on Admission of Wartime Sexual Coercion
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Apologies', 'Prostitution', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: A new report questioned the factual accuracy of a landmark apology to women forced to work in military brothels in World War II, a finding that could worsen tensions with South Korea.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A group of government-appointed Japanese scholars seemed to raise doubts about the accuracy of a landmark 1993 apology to women forced to work in military brothels during World War II, in a finding that could worsen tensions between Japan and South Korea over wartime history.

headline: America, Online: Love for Hopper’s ‘Nighthawks’
abstract: Online voters chose Edward Hopper’s “Nighthawks” and other works to be displayed on billboards across the country.
lead_paragraph: The plan to fill 50,000 billboards, in all 50 states, with American art works this summer is moving closer to completion. Starting in April, art fans voted for their favorites from among 100 works posted on the ArtEverywhereUS.org website. Voting was closed in early May, and the museums announced the 58 winning works on Friday.

headline: New York Senate Passes Bill on Medical Marijuana
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is expected to sign the bill, which would be effective immediately, though the bill’s regulations and implementation could take up to 18 months.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The New York Senate passed a bill legalizing access to medical marijuana on Friday, a day after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders announced the agreement on a seven-year pilot program to provide the drug to sick New Yorkers.

headline: A New, Eclectic Tour of Reykjavik
abstract: A new walking tour of Reykjavik, Iceland, may include well-known landmarks–and a coffee shop run out a man’s kitchen window.
lead_paragraph: Have a layover in Iceland, but not sure what to do? There’s a new walking tour aimed at introducing travelers — particularly those on stopovers in Iceland — to the locals’ side of Reykjavik.

headline: Affordable Island in the Sun
keywords: ['Elections, State Legislature', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Roosevelt Island was famously conceived as a utopia for working- and middle-class New Yorkers, and, despite several luxury developments, its character has been preserved.
lead_paragraph: Gus Christensen was, until six months ago, a managing director at Evercore Partners, the boutique investment bank, a position preceded by stints at JP Morgan and Goldman Sachs and an education at Wharton. Some years ago, befitting that profile, he was a Republican; but eventually the religion of the free market lost its hold on him, so much so that his politics migrated aggressively to the left. Last week he posted on Twitter a link to a tabloid piece about a billionaire who was buying a $70 million pied-à-terre for his children at 740 Park Avenue, with the hashtag #Signoftheapocalypse.

headline: Health Insurers Pressing Down on Drug Prices
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: More health prescription plans are refusing to cover certain drugs unless the companies charge less for them.
lead_paragraph: In dealing with health plans, drug companies are facing a new imperative — bargain or be banned.

headline: Wall Street’s Latest Must-Have? A Volcker Helper
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A year from now, Wall Street firms have to comply with the Volcker Rule — regulations that aim to restrict the type of trading that banks can do. Two law firms have come up with products to keep up with the rule’s demands.
lead_paragraph: The next accessory desired by top Wall Street traders may not be swanky cufflinks or a Swiss watch.

headline: Rangers Buy Out Richards’s Contract
abstract: Brad Richards will earn more than $20 million over the next 12 years under the Rangers’ buyout.
lead_paragraph: Brad Richards was admired by everyone on the Rangers, including the man who decided to let him go, General Manager Glen Sather.

headline: Wheelies: The Sonata Eco Edition
keywords: ['Vans', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Guarantees and Warranties', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']

lead_paragraph: A roundup of motor news from the web:

headline: Clothes That Made the Man’s Mark
abstract: The life of Yves Saint Laurent, the subject of a biopic by Jalil Lespert, can be traced through the narrative of the clothes he designed.
lead_paragraph: The tormented yet indissoluble relationship between Yves Saint Laurent and his life and business partner, Pierre Bergé, is the governing narrative of Jalil Lespert’s “Yves Saint Laurent,” a biopic about that French fashion designer that opens in New York on June 25. But the life of Saint Laurent, who died in 2008, can also be traced through a parallel narrative: that of the clothes he designed. Between his first collection in 1957 and his retirement in 2002, he changed the way modern women dressed, often prefiguring social change by bringing street and exotic influences to conventional wear, and showing women as newly powerful figures in trousers, trench coats and tuxedos.

headline: U.N. Leader Deplores Syria War’s Spread to Iraq
abstract: In an expansive speech, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon also hinted at his frustration with all those who have fueled the Syrian conflict.
lead_paragraph: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Friday drew attention to perhaps the bleakest chapter of his tenure at the United Nations: the three-year-old war in Syria, and now the prospective unraveling of the region along sectarian lines.

headline: Grand Central Food Hall Proposal Nears Approval
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which operates the terminal, unveiled a plan for Vanderbilt Hall to add a Nordic-themed food space and fine-dining restaurant.
lead_paragraph: The cavernous and elegant Vanderbilt Hall, in Grand Central Terminal, has recently been home to many temporary displays, holiday retail shops and private events. Now it is moving one step closer to housing its first permanent installation, a food hall and a fine-dining restaurant that would be run by Claus Meyer, the founder of Noma in Copenhagen, considered one of the world’s best.

headline: After the Storm, 20 Months in Limbo
abstract: Some households damaged by Hurricane Sandy are just now beginning to recover with the help of faith-based, community and nongovernmental organizations.
lead_paragraph: One after another, caseworkers entered the small, stuffy Downtown Brooklyn conference room — the court of last resort.

headline: A Bicoastal Romance That Got a Big Kickstart
abstract: The groom’s spontaneous email results in a wedding at a zoo.
lead_paragraph: One would think that someone creative enough to write jokes for television shows would have no trouble finding ways to fill his spare time.

headline: A Grandeur That Eclipses the Grotesque
abstract: Unlike the Broadway original, a vivid new production of “Side Show” at the Kennedy Center endows the performers with stark physical deformities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fellow with a third leg really appears to have that extra appendage, the lizard man sports scary scales, and the hermaphrodite seems to be split down the middle in the new production of “Side Show” at the Kennedy Center here. As they lumber, slither or caper forth in the opening number of this 1997 musical, creating a macabre pageant of human oddity, it becomes clear that what we will be seeing is less a revival than a full-scale reimagining of this show, which drew mixed reviews and closed after a few months on Broadway in its first incarnation, while quickly acquiring a cult following among, er, musical-theater freaks.

headline: Drugs Not Covered by Express Scripts and CVS Caremark
abstract: A list of drugs that the two largest pharmacy benefits companies are excluding from payment, and their preferred alternatives for various conditions.
lead_paragraph: Express Scripts (E.S.I.) and CVS Caremark, the nation’s two largest pharmacy benefits companies, have gotten drug manufacturers to offer greater discounts and rebates by refusing to pay for certain drugs, forcing companies to bid against one another.

headline: A Central American Mouse Roars
abstract: Using a high-pressure defensive style, Costa Rica, ranked 34th in the world, stunned Italy and secured a place in the second round of the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — There was less than 20 minutes left to play here on Friday when a bundle of three balloons — red, white and green, the colors of Italy’s flag — floated down from the stands and onto the field.

headline: Booksellers Score Some Points in Amazon’s Spat With Hachette
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Publishers may lose the skirmish with Amazon, but the fight hasn’t gone unnoticed by independent bookstores, or book buyers.
lead_paragraph: Robert Sindelar, the bearded, redheaded managing partner at the Seattle independent bookseller Third Place Books — definitely a David to Amazon’s Goliath — got the idea to take on Amazon while attending BookExpo America in New York a few weeks ago.

headline: G.E.’s Pyrrhic Victory
abstract: This is is a clearer victory for Paris and Alstom than it is for General Electric itself, writes Quentin Webb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: There’s a paradox in General Electric’s French triumph. The  conglomerate is finally getting Alstom’s energy businesses, having seen off German nemesis Siemens and reached an accommodation with a hostile French government. Yet some other players won clearer victories.

headline: Fifty Million Displaced People
abstract: For the first time since World War II, more than 50 million people have been forced out of their homes, their towns, their countries.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to Iraq, the international focus is largely on the Islamic militants who have seized a huge swath of the country and are moving toward Baghdad.

headline: Events in Westchester for June 22-28, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Olivier Theyskens Leaves Theory, Gisele Replaces Kate Moss and Kendall Jenner Is Here to Stay
abstract: Plus, the men’s fashion show in London that moved the front row to tears, the model cast in Sofia Coppola’s next film and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Whither Yo?
abstract: ANNA NORTH writes that the new app drew criticism for saying only “Yo,” but now hackers have widened its repertoire.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to talk about Yo. The app is so simple (it lets users send the word “Yo” to each other) that even to mock it feels like taking it too seriously — come on guys, it’s just Yo! Luckily, hackers have made things easier on all of us by making Yo do some new tricks.

headline: Odd and Original, Yes. Appetizing? Maybe Not.
abstract: On “Frankenfood,” which begins on Sunday on Spike, judges size up hybrid dishes invented by amateur cooks.
lead_paragraph: A certain barbecued blandness can infest food programs at this time of year. “Frankenfood,” a spunky series that begins on Sunday night on Spike, puts variety back on the plate, with ridiculous, sometimes gag-inducing results.

headline: House Ethics Panel Orders Alaska Republican to Pay Fine
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Representative Don Young was required to pay a fine of almost $60,000 for using campaign money for personal purposes and for accepting “impermissible gifts.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Ethics Committee on Friday ordered Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska, to pay a fine of almost $60,000 for using campaign money for personal purposes and for accepting “impermissible gifts.”

headline: Chinese Company Demands Edits to New ‘Transformers’ Movie
abstract: The Beijing Pangu Investment Company says says scenes with its logo or buildings must be removed from “Transformers: Age of Extinction.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The China woes are not over yet for Michael Bay’s latest “Transformers” film, “Age of Extinction.”

headline: Raising a Glass to Chile
abstract: An unexpectedly strong contender in the World Cup deserves a drink. Although the pisco sour is often associated with Peru, Chile has its own version.
lead_paragraph: One of the great pleasures of the World Cup every four years is in the underdogs. When a smaller, poorer country vanquishes a larger, richer one, it is something to cheer, perhaps even when you happen to live in that larger, richer country.
