headline: Agricultural Output Climbed in 2013, Recovering From Drought
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Agriculture was the best part of the American economy in 2013, but it appears to be less strong this year.
lead_paragraph: AGRICULTURE is a small part of the United States economy, but last year it was the best part.

headline: Clinton’s Cough Was Really a Gasp
abstract: In 2011, Hillary Clinton blamed a pollen-induced cough for the hand dramatically raised to her mouth as she and other national security team members watched the mission that killed Osama bin Laden. But she has a different explanation now.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has apparently gotten over her allergies.

headline: Saying No to Austerity, Spain Unveils Tax Cuts
abstract: The government has approved plans to cut company and income taxes in 2015 and 2016 in a bid to bolster spending and investment.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Turning its back on fiscal austerity, the Spanish government presented a broad package of income and corporate tax cuts on Friday that are scheduled to begin before next year’s general election.

headline: Harley’s Electric Prototype
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: A look at the Harley-Davidson electric motorcycle prototype.
lead_paragraph: A look at the Harley-Davidson electric motorcycle prototype.

headline: ‘Hi, Mom, I’m Home!’
abstract: One in five young adults lives with his or her parents. Is this a recessionary blip or the dawn of a whole new economic age?
lead_paragraph: One in five young adults lives with his or her parents. Is this a recessionary blip or the dawn of a whole new economic age?

headline: Ecuador vs. Honduras: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: After taking a lead on Switzerland, Ecuador was disappointed to lose. Based on its downright bad performance against France, Honduras may be just the cure.
lead_paragraph: After taking a lead on Switzerland, Ecuador was disappointed to lose. Based on its downright bad performance against France, Honduras may be just the cure.

headline: The Case for ISIS, Made in a British Accent
abstract: A new recruitment video for the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria features English-speaking militants who say they left Britain and Australia for jihad.
lead_paragraph: Apparently seeking to capitalize on the wave of news coverage that has accompanied their recent gains on the battlefield in Iraq, militants from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, released a recruitment video online late Thursday aimed at persuading Muslims in the West to abandon their comfortable lives and embrace jihad.

headline: Lullabies by Caruso Ignited a Love of Opera in Brooklyn
abstract: Nina DiGregorio coaches the Italian Opera Company in Brooklyn, which she helped found in 1957.
lead_paragraph: When Nina DiGregorio was a baby in the 1920s, her mother would wind up the phonograph and play opera records.

headline: Our Moral Tongue
abstract: How we judge right and wrong depends on what language we’re speaking.
lead_paragraph: ON June 20, 2003, employees of the Union Pacific Railroad faced a difficult decision as a runaway train headed toward downtown Los Angeles: Should they divert the train to a side track, knowing it would derail and hit homes in the less populated city of Commerce, Calif.? Did the moral imperative to minimize overall harm outweigh the moral imperative not to intentionally harm an innocent suburb?

headline: Using Microsoft OneDrive for Photo Backup
abstract: Plus, sharing DVD/CD drives among your network.
lead_paragraph: Q. The Microsoft OneDrive app on my Android phone once asked if I wanted to back up my photos automatically and I said no, but now I’ve reconsidered. How can I get back to that screen again?

headline: Deep in the Amazon, an Isolated Village Tunes In to the World Cup
abstract: The fevered grip of the world’s largest sporting event can be felt even in some of the most isolated areas of the rain forest, where outsiders seldom visit.
lead_paragraph: MANAUS, Brazil — The PP Maués would not set sail for an hour, but its long and narrow decks were already crisscrossed with hammocks for an overnight trip down the Amazon.

headline: In Colorado, a Brewers’ Festival Toasts an Anniversary
abstract: The Colorado Brewers’ Festival will offer a roster of close to 120 beers and hard ciders at its 25th anniversary event this month in Fort Collins.
lead_paragraph: The Colorado Brewers’ Festival will celebrate its 25th anniversary this month in Fort Collins, Colo., a place where the thirst for craft beer is alive, kicking and growing. This year’s festival brings 13 new breweries to the tasting tables, offering a total of close to 120 different brews, including its first group of hard ciders.

headline: The Collections | The Top Five Spring/Summer 2015 Men’s Wear Shows in London
abstract: T’s senior fashion editor shares his favorites from the runways of London Collections: Men.
lead_paragraph: In a city where anything goes, at least in terms of fashion, the most impressive shows in London Collections: Men were the ones that proposed new silhouettes and ideas, yet were still grounded in reality. These five designers accomplished that delicate balance and introduced wearable spring/summer 2015 collections that would look as at home on the street as on the runway.

headline: Josh Earnest’s First Briefing: A Few Observations
abstract: Josh Earnest’s first briefing as White House press secretary was part lesson, party comedy show.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After striding to the famous lectern for his highly anticipated first briefing as the White House press secretary on Friday, Josh Earnest quickly did what his predecessors have turned into an art form: He lowered expectations.

headline: Packed With Technology, Prepped for Hyperbole
abstract: The 2014 Mercedes-Benz S550 isn’t merely a new version of the company’s largest sedan, but a technological leap beyond its ancestors.
lead_paragraph: Pull up to the 7-Eleven in this car and you feel like Leonard Bernstein arriving at Lincoln Center. Ride in the back and you’re escorting Julie Andrews to the Oscars. The doors are substantial enough to repel anything Occupy Wall Street throws at them, and it’s effortlessly powerful enough to outrun any S.E.C. subpoena. The 2014 Mercedes-Benz S550 4Matic sedan is so advanced it should be in geosynchronous orbit over Gstaad.

headline: Hi, I’m a Tablet. I’ll Be Your Waiter Tonight.
abstract: Chains like Panera Bread and Chili’s are using apps and tablets to improve food preparation, ordering and payment, and to entertain customers.
lead_paragraph: BRAINTREE, Mass. — An idea came to Ronald M. Shaich, the chief executive of Panera Bread, as he was driving his children to school about four years ago: What if everyone could order lunch the way he did?

headline: Taking a Spin: Republicans Win Despite Some Disappointment
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: In this week’s example of a simulation of our Senate election forecasting model, the G.O.P. wins in Iowa and Colorado but loses in some friendly territory.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans retake control of the Senate in this week’s spin of Leo’s Senate wheels, our weekly illustration of the uncertainty that remains with so much time until November’s elections. But two red-state Democrats defy the Republican sweep.

headline: Next Stop, India: Full Steam Ahead
abstract: Dhokla is an irresistible street-food snack that is essentially a fluffy, savory bread, and is no more difficult to make than baking a cake.
lead_paragraph: If you are a lover of street food, India is the place to be. Outrageously delicious snacks, of which there are countless thousands, beckon from every corner.

headline: How to Translate Döppelgangers Into Hindi: Just Keep Adding Characters
abstract: “Humshakals” means doubles or döppelgangers, and this slapstick Bollywood offering can’t get enough of them.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of the awful Bollywood comedy “Humshakals,” our handsome billionaire hero pursues his passion: stand-up. He’s awful. His jokes are infantile, his style eager to please but clueless.

headline: Commander in Chief With Idealism Untarnished
abstract: Kid President, the 10-year-0ld YouTube star also known as Robby Novak, stars in his own series on the Hub Network.
lead_paragraph: Ideally, the president should be relatively smart. In the premiere of his new series on the Hub Network, Kid President proves himself smart enough to know that no one can take an unbroken half-hour of the chirpy observations that have brought him Internet fame.

headline: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the West Bank, Iraq, Ukraine and Yemen.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the West Bank, Iraq, Ukraine and Yemen.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 20
abstract: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes a memorial in the Bronx and more than one hot day.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes a memorial in the Bronx and more than one hot day.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Woods Set to Return From Surgery
abstract: Woods’s return seems timed at making a run at the last two majors of the season, the British Open and the P.G.A. Championship.
lead_paragraph: So much for the speculation that Tiger Woods would be sidelined the rest of the year after having back surgery in March. Woods announced Friday on his Facebook page that he would make his first competitive start in nearly four months at next week’s Quicken Loans National, which benefits the foundation that bears his name.

headline: Patrick Huang Introduces a Bridge Deal
abstract: The Longevity Valley 2nd Asia Cup Bridge Championships in Wuyi Qingshuiwan, China, will end on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The Longevity Valley 2nd Asia Cup Bridge Championships in Wuyi Qingshuiwan, China, will end on Sunday.

headline: New York’s Not-So-Perfect Medical Marijuana Law
abstract: The new legislation is too limited.
lead_paragraph: New York is finally joining the ranks of states that allow the use of marijuana for medical purposes, becoming the 23rd in the nation to do so. Too bad Governor Cuomo, who held the upper hand in bargaining because of his veto power, forced legislators to accept so many restrictions that the law will be a lot less useful than it could have been. The legislation has passed both chambers and is awaiting the governor’s signature.

headline: A Ride Across America | Soccer, Bourbon and a Very Special Farm in Missouri
abstract: Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, is biking across the U.S. talking to people about food. In his third dispatch, he shares stories of kindly Kentuckians, an epic lunch in Illinois and a welcome alternative to factory farming in Missouri.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, they’ll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

headline: Reinventing Emily Gould
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A former serpent-tongued devil behind Gawker and a proponent of oversharing now disdains the kind of attention that once defined her.
lead_paragraph: Emily Gould stood posing for a photograph on West 29th Street in front of the building where she works, wearing a stone-colored cardigan, her hair scraped back into a messy ponytail, her only concession to vanity a slash of red lipstick applied with apparent indifference.

headline: A Civil War Skirmish, Fought With Badinage
abstract: “Butler,” a new play staged by the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch, addresses the thorny topics of slavery and duty with wit and wordplay.
lead_paragraph: IT’S HARD TO CATEGORIZE “Butler,” a new play being staged by the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch. It’s part comedy, part historical drama and part biography, often all at once, and sometimes none of those. Yet the show is easy enough to review. Just call it splendid.

headline: Law to Impose Tough Limits on Sales of Ivory Art
abstract: Governor Cuomo is expected to sign a bill outlawing the sale of virtually all items with more than small amounts of elephant ivory or rhinoceros horn.
lead_paragraph: To the chagrin of New York antiques dealers, lawmakers in Albany have voted to outlaw the sale of virtually all items containing more than small amounts of elephant ivory, mammoth ivory or rhinoceros horn. The legislation, which is backed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, will essentially eliminate New York’s central role in a well-established, nationwide trade with an estimated annual value of $500 million.

headline: A Night Out With Jenny Slate of ‘Obvious Child’
abstract: In “Obvious Child,” Ms. Slate is still courting controversy.
lead_paragraph: The actress Jenny Slate arrived at a panel discussion for her new film, “Obvious Child,” Tuesday night, where the first person she saw was a woman who reminded her of her grandmother.

headline: But Can They Write Fashion Code?
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Design', 'Men and Boys', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Start-ups', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: A number of tech-savvy guys starting their own clothing labels see themselves as entrepreneurs, not designers.
lead_paragraph: On a brisk Thursday afternoon, Peter Semple strode purposefully through Google’s Chelsea offices looking for a quiet place to discuss his latest project. “I haven’t slept in the last four days,” Mr. Semple said, bypassing the cafeteria, which was blasting En Vogue, in favor of a curtained-off conference room with a large lime-green armchair at the head of its table.

headline: Swim in Bronx River Kills Boy, 13; Another Is Hospitalized
abstract: One 13-year-boy died and another was in critical condition on Friday after they went swimming in the Bronx River and had to be pulled from the water by emergency divers, according to the Police Department.
lead_paragraph: One 13-year-boy died and another was in critical condition on Friday after they went swimming in the Bronx River and had to be pulled from the water by emergency divers, according to the Police Department.

headline: Amy Alkon’s Crusade Against Rudeness
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: An interview with the author, known as Emily Postal, of a syndicated advice column and two books on manners.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Please let me be on time for the maniacal manners lady. I don’t want her to scold me. Please, pretty please, don’t let me be late.

headline: To the Sea in Ships, as Naughty as Ever
abstract: “All These Darlings and Now Us,” a waterborne installation in San Francisco, is a response to the closing of two beloved local sex clubs, Esta Noche and the Lusty Lady.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The drag queen Persia, in full bejeweled regalia, went out on one of the first rafts, sloping down the launch ramp in thigh-high red stiletto boots.

headline: Translating English Protocol for a Wider Audience
abstract: Proper protocol is good business for a British company.
lead_paragraph: It was a breach of protocol few of the two billion viewers of the royal wedding would have spotted, but the etiquette expert Alexandra Messervy noticed the faux pas immediately.

headline: Four Guys With Swords and Morals
abstract: “The Musketeers” ride again on BBC America in a reinterpretation that explores issues like slavery and terrorism.
lead_paragraph: Certain stories never get old, and certain people never tire of rewriting them.

headline: Marilyn Monroe’s Photo Caper in Poland
abstract: A trove of Marilyn Monroe photos by Milton H. Greene is being auctioned in Poland this week. How the photos got there – and how they will be sold – is worthy of a madcap caper.
lead_paragraph: A trove of Marilyn Monroe photos by Milton H. Greene is being auctioned in Poland this week. How the photos got there – and how they will be sold – is worthy of a madcap caper.

headline: Evening Hours | Warming Up
abstract: Opening doors for celebration and whimsy in gardens.
lead_paragraph: Opening doors for celebration and whimsy in gardens.

headline: Flight Prep: The 2014 Mercedes-Benz S550
abstract: Mercedes-Benz’s big luxury sedan glides into the future with high ambitions that are seamlessly executed.
lead_paragraph: Mercedes-Benz’s big luxury sedan glides into the future with high ambitions that are seamlessly executed.

headline: For His Second Act, a Hot Rod Builder Turns Back the Clock
abstract: A Connecticut man has turned his garage into a showplace. In addition to his two customized Fords and 81 trophies, the garage holds enough machinery for several body shops.
lead_paragraph: STAMFORD, CONN. — “So this is it,” Dennis Wuchiski says as he opens the door to what is possibly the cleanest garage this side of the McLaren Formula One racecar operation in Britain.

headline: Hot Rod Hideaway
abstract: Dennis Wuchiski’s home garage in Stamford, Conn., is both a dream shop and a display case for a lover of Ford hot rods.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Wuchiski’s home garage in Stamford, Conn., is both a dream shop and a display case for a lover of Ford hot rods.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Great, Gatsby
abstract: Nearly 10,000 people attended the Jazz Age Lawn Party on Governors Island, many in costume.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 10,000 people attended the Jazz Age Lawn Party on Governors Island, many in costume.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Jazz Age Lawn Party
abstract: Nearly 10,000 people attended the Jazz Age Lawn Party on Governors Island, many in costume.
lead_paragraph: The ninth annual Jazz Age Lawn Party took place last weekend on Governors Island with Michael Arenella and his Dreamland Orchestra. Mr. Arenella, founder of the event, paid for it himself at first, and the earliest parties drew a few hundred people. Last weekend, nearly 10,000 attended, many in costume.

headline: Readers Respond: Love and Hate for Guns and Video Games
abstract: Readers respond to a column about violence in video games and violence in real life. Some say there is a link, while others say there is no correlation at all.
lead_paragraph: Discussions about the right to own a gun in real life can become quite a debate. It turns out that talking about the right to bear arms in video games can be an equally hot topic.

headline: Not Your Average Garage
abstract: A peek at Dennis Wuchiski’s custom 1932 Ford, which took him 18 years to build.
lead_paragraph: A peek at Dennis Wuchiski’s custom 1932 Ford, which took him 18 years to build.

headline: Under Cover: A ‘Boomerang Kid’ Documents His Generation
abstract: The June 22 cover story about “boomerang kids” features photographs taken by Damon Casarez, who graduated from the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, Calif., with $120,000 in student debt. He recently discussed how his circumstances influenced his portrait-taking.
lead_paragraph: The June 22 cover story about “boomerang kids” features photographs taken by Damon Casarez, who graduated from the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, Calif., with $120,000 in student debt. Eventually, his loan payments became unmanageable, and he moved in with his parents. The discomfort of sleeping on the living-room couch and readjusting to his parents’ house rules inspired Casarez to reach out to others like him. “I did this project because it was something that I knew and something that I thought needed to be talked about,” Casarez says. He recently discussed how his circumstances influenced his portrait-taking.

headline: They Are the World: A Psychedelic Rock Ritual
abstract: The Swedish band Goat’s show was a psychedelic rock ritual of rhythm, motion, hypnotic repetition and ecstatic drive.
lead_paragraph: The Swedish band Goat calls its concerts rituals, and that’s how it performed on Wednesday night at Webster Hall: as a psychedelic rock ritual of rhythm, motion, hypnotic repetition and ecstatic drive. The men in the band were masked or hooded, in a mélange of ethnic clothes. The two female singers up front, dancing and shaking assorted percussion instruments, were post-hippie celebrants in colorful dresses, wearing feathered headdresses above their own glittery masks. No one spoke to the audience: The songs arrived on their own, droning and pounding, wailing with guitar solos and churning with funk.

headline: Pickups Wearing Camo, but Not to Blend In
abstract: Competition among pickup trucks has inspired automakers to seek every possible edge. Now they are using camouflage.
lead_paragraph: Hot competition among pickups has inspired automakers to seek every possible edge, in style as well as technology. So like such disparate trendsetters as downtown club kids and “Duck Dynasty” fans, trucks are now stepping out in camouflage.

headline: ‘All These Darlings and Now Us’
abstract: A waterborne installation in San Francisco combines performance art, urban resistance and a sex-positive philosophy.
lead_paragraph: A waterborne installation in San Francisco combines performance art, urban resistance and a sex-positive philosophy.

headline: The Clubs That Connect The World Cup
abstract: The global tournament is mostly a remix of the professional leagues that are in season most of the time. See which professional clubs have the most players on the most World Cup teams.
lead_paragraph: The global tournament is mostly a remix of the professional leagues that are in season most of the time. See which professional clubs have the most players on the most World Cup teams.

headline: Why Are We Importing Our Own Fish?
keywords: ['Fish Farming', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Oysters', 'Scallops', 'Fishing, Commercial']
abstract: The seafood industry is a great example of the delete-and-replace maneuvers that define the outsourced American economy.
lead_paragraph: IN 1982 a Chinese aquaculture scientist named Fusui Zhang journeyed to Martha’s Vineyard in search of scallops. The New England bay scallop had recently been domesticated, and Dr. Zhang thought the Vineyard-grown shellfish might do well in China. After a visit to Lagoon Pond in Tisbury, he boxed up 120 scallops and spirited them away to his lab in Qingdao. During the journey 94 died. But 26 thrived. Thanks to them, today China now grows millions of dollars of New England bay scallops, a significant portion of which are exported back to the United States.

headline: Toughest Issues Still Unresolved in Iran Nuclear Talks
abstract: A month from the deadline for a final accord, negotiators have a tentative draft, but the United States and Iran remain far apart on difficult issues.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Negotiations with Iran over its disputed nuclear program entered their brinkmanship phase on Friday, with the toughest issues still unresolved a month before the deadline for a final agreement.

headline: Beautiful Game Played With a Gaúcho Flair in Southern Brazil
abstract: The two main clubs in Porto Alegre have a reputation for playing the Uruguayan and Argentine way: tough, and without restraint.
lead_paragraph: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil — “Tell me how you play, and I will tell you who you are.”

headline: Streaming Eagles
keywords: ['ANIMALS', 'Bald Eagles', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: A drama in a Minnesota nest reached millions online. Then things got really wild.
lead_paragraph: THERE was a situation with some bald eagles on the Internet the other day. The drama played out in a large, disheveled nest somewhere in Minnesota, in front of a camera that had been streaming the lives of those birds onto the Internet for the last two years.

headline: You’re Not Really Wearing That to School?
abstract: Readers react to an Op-Ed writer’s discussion of what’s appropriate garb for the classroom.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Biden Adviser Leaving Washington, but It May Not Be for Long
abstract: Jake Sullivan plans to teach at Yale Law School, but he is already being seen as a potential national security adviser in a Hillary Rodham Clinton administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Jake Sullivan leaves Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s staff in August to teach at Yale Law School this fall, he will join a familiar Washington subculture: the battle-scarred White House alumnus, desperate to sample a normal life before deciding whether to jump back into the maelstrom of the next political cycle.

headline: ‘Klinghoffer’: The Opera and the Furor
abstract: Readers respond to an editorial and an Arts pages article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A New Kind of Church, Led by Pope Francis
abstract: The president of Catholics for Choice and a professor of church history respond to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Solstice Blues
abstract: Don’t be afraid of the dark.
lead_paragraph: IN mid-June, the twilight seems to go on forever, the sky awash with translucent shades of rose, pearl, gray. These are evenings of enchantment — but also of apprehension. The moment the sun reaches its farthest point north of the Equator today is the moment the light starts to fade, waning more each day for the following six months. If the summer solstice doesn’t signal the arrival of winter, surely it heralds the gradual lessening of light, and with that, often, an incremental decline in disposition.

headline: Candy’s Dandy, but Pot’s Scary
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Schizophrenia', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: As laws are eased, some users find that the high leads only to a cliff.
lead_paragraph: WE know that occasionally people react badly to marijuana. Some withdraw into anxious, glassy silence. Some responses are more horrifying. In a recent, much discussed case, a Denver man bought cannabis-infused Karma Kandy and hours later — perhaps after also taking prescription pain medication — began raving about the end of the world and killed his wife.

headline: Cavaliers Are Said to Hire Israeli Coach David Blatt
abstract: Cleveland’s signing of a successful European coach to a four-year deal continues a globalizing trend in the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: A month after leading Maccabi Tel Aviv to the Euroleague championship, David Blatt agreed to a four-year deal to become the head coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers on Friday, according to a person with direct knowledge of the negotiations.

headline: Missing Israeli Teenagers Revive a Mother’s Hard-Earned Intimacy With Loss
abstract: For Sherri Mandell, whose son was killed in the West Bank more than a decade ago, the kidnapping of three Israeli teenagers feels all too familiar.
lead_paragraph: TEKOA, West Bank — Sherri Mandell was toasting her daughter’s engagement with her future in-laws at her home in this Jewish settlement south of Jerusalem last Friday morning when she heard the news. After the first sip of sparkling white wine, the groom-to-be put down his glass. “I’m sorry, but we have to stop the party,” Ms. Mandell recalled him saying. “Something terrible has happened.”

headline: Stephanie L. Kwolek, Inventor of Kevlar, Is Dead at 90
abstract: Ms. Kwolek, a DuPont chemist who invented the technology behind Kevlar, a virtually bulletproof fiber that has saved thousands of lives, spent 15 years in the laboratory without a promotion before her breakthrough.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie L. Kwolek, a DuPont chemist who invented the technology behind Kevlar, a virtually bulletproof fiber that has saved thousands of lives, died on Wednesday in Wilmington, Del. She was 90.

headline: The Computer Will Now Take Your Order
abstract: Restaurants have been late to the tech revolution, and many are now scrambling to incorporate tablets, apps, computerized kitchen equipment and data analysis capabilities.
lead_paragraph: Restaurants have been late to the tech revolution, and many are now scrambling to incorporate tablets, apps, computerized kitchen equipment and data analysis capabilities.

headline: Collecting Catholics’ Everyday Stories as an Antidote to Scandals in the News
abstract: Paul Elie, a writer and editor, is working with the oral history project StoryCorps to find and catalog religious stories — tales that have nothing to do with the sexual abuse scandal.
lead_paragraph: The sexual abuse scandal in the Roman Catholic Church broke into the news around 2000, just as Paul Elie was writing his book “The Life You Save May Be Your Own.” His topic was the intertwining friendships of four great Catholic thinkers and writers, some of the best people in his tradition: Dorothy Day, Walker Percy, Flannery O’Connor and Thomas Merton.

headline: Fighting Off the Coast of France
abstract: The most reviled and celebrated ship in the Confederate Navy met its match far from any Southern port.
lead_paragraph: Sunday, June 19, 1864, the C.S.S. Alabama, a swift commerce raider carrying eight guns, steamed out of Cherbourg harbor, prepared to battle the U.S.S. Kearsarge, a sloop of war of similar size and firepower.

headline: Nürburgring 24-Hour Race Draws Huge Entry
abstract: More than 150 cars to compete at the legendary German track; more than 100,000 spectators anticipated.
lead_paragraph: Nürburg, Germany — An automotive clambake of enormous proportions has assembled here this weekend for the 42nd running of the Nürburgring 24-hour race, an endurance contest whose demanding course includes the fabled section known as Nordschleife.

headline: Royalties and Teaching Help Fill Bank Accounts of Justices, Report Says
abstract: Justice Antonin Scalia earned more from book royalties and traveled more than any of his colleagues in 2013, financial disclosure reports released by the Supreme Court showed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Financial disclosure reports released by the Supreme Court on Friday showed that book royalties continued to fill the bank accounts of certain justices, while most bolstered their incomes with teaching assignments.

headline: After a Career Peak at Wimbledon, a Long Fall and a Clouded Future
abstract: Steve Darcis defeated Rafael Nadal in a stunning upset in the first round of Wimbledon last year, but an injury sustained during the match caused him to struggle for the next year.
lead_paragraph: ROEHAMPTON, England — A year ago, Steve Darcis, a Belgian who was ranked 135th, stunned Rafael Nadal in the first round of Wimbledon, ending the 22-match winning streak of Nadal, the two-time champion from Spain. Darcis sealed the 7-6 (4), 7-6 (8), 6-4 victory with an ace, bringing the crowd of 11,429 at No. 1 Court to its feet.

headline: Hackers Take Down World Cup Site in Brazil
abstract: Hackers from Anonymous successfully took down the World Cup site in Brazil, which was still down Friday evening.
lead_paragraph: Hackers on Friday made good on their threat to take down the 2014 World Cup site in Brazil.

headline: FIFA Looking Into Possible Use of Gay Slur by Mexican Fans
abstract: Mexican fans taunted the opposing goalkeepers in their first two World Cup games with a cheer that ends by shouting a word widely regarded as a derogatory term used against gays.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — FIFA has opened disciplinary proceedings against the Mexico team for what it has called the “improper conduct of spectators” at the World Cup.

headline: Judge Blocks Evidence in Goldman Code Theft Case
abstract: The tumultuous case of Sergey Aleynikov has taken another turn as a New York judge throws out most of the evidence against him.
lead_paragraph: The curious case of Sergey Aleynikov — the former Goldman Sachs programmer who was criminally convicted, then acquitted and then charged again — has taken yet another surprising turn.

headline: Presbyterians Vote to Divest Holdings to Pressure Israel
abstract: The church voted at its general convention to divest from three companies that it says supply Israel with equipment used in the occupation of Palestinian territory.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — After passionate debate over how best to help break the deadlock between Israel and the Palestinians, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) voted on Friday at its general convention to divest from three companies that it says supply Israel with equipment used in the occupation of Palestinian territory.

headline: U.N. Chief Served Papers in Suit by Haitian Victims, Lawyers Say
abstract: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon’s spokesman denied that the official had been served.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations has been resisting, successfully so far, lawsuits from Haiti cholera victims who assert that United Nations peacekeepers caused the 2010 epidemic still ravaging the country. But on Friday, lawyers for the plaintiffs said, something new happened: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon was personally served with court papers ordering him to appear, an assertion that his spokesman denied.

headline: Administration Takes Steps to Aid Bees
abstract: The White House announced new initiatives on Friday to promote the health of honeybees and other pollinators, which have suffered enormous losses in recent years.
lead_paragraph: The White House announced new initiatives on Friday to promote the health of honeybees and other pollinators, which have suffered enormous losses in recent years. The memorandum, signed by President Obama, called for research into the causes of the severe decline and the role of pesticides, and formed a “pollinator health task force” of more than 14 federal agencies, saying, “It is critical to expand federal efforts and take new steps to reverse pollinator losses and help restore populations to healthy levels.” Erich Pica, president of the environmental group Friends of the Earth, said the administration “does not go far enough” to address pesticide issues.

headline: Weekend Auto Calendar: Camaros of the World Unite, in Maryland
abstract: The Camaro Nationals, featuring Chevrolet Camaros and Pontiac Firebirds, come to Maryland; the Classic at Pismo Beach to feature a beach town cruise.
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

headline: Report Calls for Tracking Data on Stress Disorder
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Department of Defense and the Veterans Affairs Department should track their efforts to treat post-traumatic stress more carefully, to see how effective those efforts are, a report released Friday said.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense and the Veterans Affairs Department should track their efforts to treat post-traumatic stress more carefully, to see how effective those efforts are, a government-sponsored report released Friday said. The report, from an expert panel assembled by the Institute of Medicine, noted that the agencies spend more than $3.3 billion annually on treatment of the disorder, which affects more than 500,000 veterans, including 8 percent of those who served in Iraq or Afghanistan — who are twice as likely to seek help as veterans of previous wars. It affirms the findings of a report published in 2012 that called for more careful tracking. The V.A. has tracked symptoms in some members given treatment, but it is not clear how many and whether those veterans are in fact improving, experts said. “Given that the D.O.D. and V.A. are responsible for serving millions of service members, families and veterans, we found it surprising that no PTSD outcome measures are used consistently to know if these treatments are working or not,” the chairman of the panel, Sandro Galea of Columbia University, said in a statement.

headline: China: Police Kill 13 in Attack in Xinjiang Region
keywords: ['Police', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Attacks on Police', 'Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)']
abstract: Police officers shot dead 13 attackers on Saturday who rammed a vehicle into the main police station in the region of Xinjiang, according to media reports.
lead_paragraph: Police officers shot dead 13 attackers on Saturday who rammed a vehicle into the main police station of Yecheng County, in the region of Xinjiang in far western China, according to state news media reports. Three police officers were lightly wounded in the attack, which also involved the detonation of explosive devices, the reports said. Violent episodes in Xinjiang have become more frequent in the last couple years, and attacks on police stations appear to be on the rise. Yecheng County is an area that is heavily populated by Uighurs, a Turkic-speaking ethnic group who in in recent years have often clashed in Xinjiang with ethnic Han, the dominant group in China. Many Uighurs say they face discrimination, and some call for an independent Uighur state to be carved from in Xinjiang and called East Turkestan. In recent months, there have been attacks across China that state news media reports have attributed to Uighur militants.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE WOLVERINE (2013) This sixth installment in the X-Men film franchise finds Logan (Hugh Jackman) living as a hermit in the great white north and tormented by the memory of being forced to kill Jean Grey (Famke Janssen). Then the warrior pixie Yukio (Rila Fukushima) spirits him back to Tokyo to meet with Yashida (Haruhiko Yamanouchi), who is intent on repaying his life debt to Logan, who saved him during the bombing of Nagasaki — and alleviate Logan of his immortality, which he now considers a curse. “Mr. Jackman, for all his growling, flexing and macho wisecracking, keeps our attention focused on Logan’s feelings,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. So does the director James Mangold, he said, adding, “A modest superhero picture may sound like a contradiction in terms, but really it is a welcome respite.”

headline: Urban Hurly-Burly of a Bumptious Era
abstract: The great street photographer Garry Winogrand once said, “I photograph to find out what something will look like photographed.”
lead_paragraph: The great street photographer Garry Winogrand once said, “I photograph to find out what something will look like photographed.” That curiosity led him to make some of the most indelible photographs of life in the United States during one of its most turbulent decades, the Sixties, with extraordinary avidity. In crowded off-kilter pictures that seemed haphazard and badly composed to critics at the time, he captured urban pedestrian traffic, people and animals at zoos and political demonstrations and altercations.

headline: He’s an Old Soul, In a Young Way
abstract: In jazz, there are young people who sound old, old people who sound young and, very occasionally, young people who sound like old people who sound young.
lead_paragraph: In jazz, there are young people who sound old, old people who sound young and, very occasionally, young people who sound like old people who sound young. Pay attention to those people. The tenor saxophonist Bill McHenry has been such a person, with a full tone, slow and songlike phrasing and a totally in-the-present disposition equally indebted to free jazz and, say, Lester Young. He’s unpredictable, open to the ideas of his band members and to creating benign mischief.

headline: Tyrannical Captor of Under-Age Wives
abstract: In “Outlaw Prophet: Warren Jeffs,” on Saturday night at 8 on Lifetime, Tony Goldwyn channels Mr. Jeffs, of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints.
lead_paragraph: Talk about scandalous. In “Outlaw Prophet: Warren Jeffs,” on Saturday night at 8 on Lifetime, Tony Goldwyn channels Mr. Jeffs, the president and prophet, seer and revelator, of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints — who in 2006 joined Osama bin Laden on the F.B.I.’s 10 Most Wanted list for having arranged illegal marriages between his adult male followers and under-age girls. “He’s a far cry worse than playing President Fitz,” Mr. Goldwyn said in a phone interview, alluding to his role in the ABC drama “Scandal.” “You have a guy who was essentially disenfranchised in this very strange community, and who usurped power and became a complete dictator in his world.”

headline: A Verdant Treat, and a Period Viola
abstract: Fresh air, proud history: The Naumburg Orchestral Concerts in Central Park has both.
lead_paragraph: Fresh air, proud history: The Naumburg Orchestral Concerts in Central Park has both. A perfect setting, then, for the Knights, a collective that brings equal doses of meticulous musicianship and fun to its performances. In the opening concert of the series on Tuesday, the conductor Eric Jacobsen leads the Knights in a typically eclectic program, including an arrangement of Boccherini’s Quintet in C (Op. 30), set in nighttime Madrid, alongside two newer works by composers with a strong sense of place: Andrew Norman’s “Light Screens” and Ives’s “Three Places in New England.” The composer-pianist Timo Andres joins in for his own take on Mozart’s “Coronation” Concerto. (7:30 p.m.; naumburgconcerts.org.)

headline: A Job Seeker’s Desperate Choice
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Child Care', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The story of Shanesha Taylor, a mother who had a job interview but was unable to find child care, shows the harsh realities of today’s economy.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of March 20, Shanesha Taylor had a job interview. It was for a good job, one that could support her three children, unlike the many positions she’d applied for that paid only $10 an hour. The interview, at an insurance agency in Scottsdale, Ariz., went well. “Walking out of the office, you know that little skip thing people do?” she said, clicking her heels together in a corny expression of glee. “I wanted to do that.”

headline: A Leadership Lesson for Goodell, From Goodell
abstract: Roger Goodell helped integrate his high school football team. Now he has a chance to again come down on the right side of history in the debate over the Washington Redskins’ nickname.
lead_paragraph: In late 2011, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell paid a visit to my barbershop in Harlem, where we enjoyed an informal conversation about a variety of issues centering mainly on player safety and whether the game was becoming too soft.

headline: Variety: A Delicious Diagramless
abstract: A yummy diagramless puzzle from Fred Piscop.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — It’s summer and grilling season is here, as far as Fred Piscop is concerned. Today, we’re not only going to build a puzzle with him, but we’re also going to build the ultimate burger.

headline: A Misguided Departure From the Serve-and-Volley
abstract: From the professional game to youth academies, players are remaining at the baseline more. But statistics still support rushing the net as an effective tactic.
lead_paragraph: The art of the serve-and-volley, many tennis experts argue, has no place in today’s game. It is a common refrain that the speed of the courts, modern string technology and even the size of the athletes have made that style of play obselete.

headline: Unblinking Eyes Track Employees
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Productivity', 'Workplace Environment', 'Science and Technology', 'Privacy', 'Sensors']
abstract: Abundant data, smart software and cheap sensors are beginning to make it possible to measure and monitor employees as never before.
lead_paragraph: A digital Big Brother is coming to work, for better or worse.

headline: The Anchor on an Evolving Team
abstract: As Coach Jurgen Klinsmann reshaped the U.S. team, Tim Howard, the longtime goalkeeper, remained a steady hand and supportive teammate.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Tim Howard did not always like what Jurgen Klinsmann was doing to Howard’s closest friends. He actually hated it. One by one, all of the veteran players on the United States national team had their moments with Klinsmann, the coach from Germany, who had made clear since the moment he was hired in 2011 that history and past performance meant nothing to him.

headline: Workplace Surveillance and the ‘Transparency Paradox’
abstract: Software, sensors and data make it possible to monitor and measure work as never before. But research suggests that privacy can increase worker productivity.
lead_paragraph: Jim Sullivan, general manager of a Dallas restaurant, embraces digital monitoring in the workplace. Software, sensors and data make it increasingly possible, and Mr. Sullivan, as noted in an article I wrote, is a beneficiary of the improved measurement techniques. His data showed he was a highly productive worker, a prime candidate for the promotions he received.

headline: ‘You Can Do It, Shirley’
abstract: The fitness trainer: 44 years old. The client: 90.
lead_paragraph: Martin Luther King Addo, a 44-year-old bodybuilder who was twice crowned Mr. Ghana, opened a storefront gym in a N.O.R.C. — a naturally occurring retirement community — in Lower Manhattan. His clients, many of them older women, are glad he did. Read the full story, and watch the video, above.

headline: Juli Inkster Leaves a Legacy as a Master Multitasker
abstract: After 35 starts, Juli Inkster will play what is likely to be her final round in the United States Women’s Open on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — Take a long look at Juli Inkster, who carded a four-under-par 66, the lowest round of the week, on Saturday. Admire her the way you might the Yankees’ consummate contact hitter, Ichiro Suzuki, or any other favorite relic. She is easy to spot on the driving range, with her short hair and her skirt so long the hem nearly reaches her knees.

headline: South Korea Hunts for Army Shooter
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Korean War', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A South Korean Army sergeant killed five of his fellow soldiers and wounded five others on Saturday when he opened fire along the border with North Korea, military officials said.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean Army sergeant killed five of his fellow soldiers and wounded five others on Saturday when he opened fire along the border with North Korea, military officials said. A hunt for the soldier was underway late Saturday.

headline: Baptism by Fire: A New York Firefighter Confronts His First Test
abstract: Jordan Sullivan’s decade-long dream of joining the Fire Department had come true. Now he had to prove himself.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Sullivan’s decade-long dream of joining the Fire Department had come true. Now he had to prove himself.

headline: Are You a Firefighter? Tell Us About Your First Fire
abstract: Are you a firefighter? If so, Times reporters and editors want to hear about your first fire.
lead_paragraph: “To a firefighter, the first fire is like a police officer’s first collar, a lawyer’s first jury trial, a fisherman’s first tuna. It becomes chiseled into your memory in big block letters, rolled out and dusted off for reminiscence over a lifetime,” N.R. Kleinfield wrote in an article about Jordan Sullivan, a New York City firefighter with Ladder Company 105 in Brooklyn.

headline: In Today’s Power Game, Shorter Players Thrive With Quick Wits and Feet
abstract: As Wimbledon begins Monday, the common perception that height makes right in modern tennis is not always the case.
lead_paragraph: The women’s final of the 2014 French Open was about to begin, and Maria Sharapova and Simona Halep posed for pictures at the net.

headline: Making Headlines With Their Vows
abstract: Katie Couric and John P. Molner were married at the anchor’s home in East Hampton, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Katie Couric and John P. Molner were married Saturday at Ms. Couric’s home in East Hampton, N.Y. John Ellis, a friend of the couple who is a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Rite of the Sitting Dead: Funeral Poses Mimic Life
abstract: Funeral services in New Orleans and Puerto Rico pose the dead to play host at their own wakes, propped up in a familiar tableau.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — All last week, people were calling Louis Charbonnet to find out how they might avoid lying down at their funerals. Funeral directors have called; so have people with their own requests, such as the woman who wanted to be seen for the last time standing over her cooking pot.

headline: Iraqi Shiites Mobilize Against Extremists
abstract: A mass popular mobilization, spurred by a cleric’s urging, is sweeping through large sections of Baghdad and southern Iraq’s Shiite heartland.
lead_paragraph: A mass popular mobilization, spurred by a cleric’s urging, is sweeping through large sections of Baghdad and southern Iraq’s Shiite heartland.

headline: Six Who Have a Chance to Figure Prominently in London
abstract: A capsule look at some of the players to keep a close eye on when Wimbledon starts on Monday.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the players to keep a close eye on when Wimbledon starts on Monday.

headline: Ballot Counting Continues as Some Afghans Protest
abstract: Supporters of Abdullah Abdullah protested across Kabul demanding that the government address accusations that ballot counting in the runoff election was fraudulent.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A day after the United Nations agreed to play a role in settling disputes over the vote for a new Afghan president, protesters demonstrated across Kabul, blocking streets in parts of the city and demanding that the government address their accusations of ballot stuffing.

headline: Answering a Cleric’s Call, Iraqi Shiites Take Up Arms
abstract: Large sections of Baghdad and southern Iraq’s Shiite heartland have been swept up in a mass mobilization, energized by a fatwa urging able-bodied Iraqis to take up arms against Sunni extremists.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The long lines of Shiite fighters began marching through the capital early Saturday morning. Some wore masks. One group had yellow and green suicide explosives, which they said were live, strapped to their chests.

headline: Can U.S. Contain Ronaldo? Germany Found a Way
abstract: How Germany shut down Ronaldo and what the U.S. needs to do when they face him on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: How Germany shut down Ronaldo and what the U.S. needs to do when they face him on Sunday.

headline: Ghana vs. Germany: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Ghana probably has to win, but at the bare, bare minimum must draw. That will be a tall order against a German team that has one foot in the second round already.
lead_paragraph: Ghana probably has to win, but at the bare, bare minimum must draw. That will be a tall order against a German team that has one foot in the second round already.

headline: The Scene | Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Ermenegildo Zegna Spring/Summer 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: Brazil’s Other Team, or So Portugal Hopes
abstract: Longstanding cultural ties may make Portugal the second favorite among Brazilian fans at their country’s World Cup, but many remain ambivalent.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — In 1500, Portuguese explorers arrived on the shores of what is now Brazil seeking, among other things, gold. Today, Portuguese adventurers have come here seeking merely goals.

headline: My Mother, My Writing Student
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Families and Family Life', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: My mother’s novel was an odd reading experience for me, and not just because it contained sex scenes.
lead_paragraph: On the first day of a weeklong creative-writing workshop, I sit across from a group of serious-minded first-time novelists, people who have come to me, their teacher, to make their books better. I’ve just been going over the schedule, a series of craft talks, workshops and one-on-one conferences. “Are there any questions?” I ask.

headline: In Shiite Heartland of Iraq, Volunteers Get Set for a ‘Defensive Jihad’
abstract: In Iraq’s Shiite heartland, volunteers have revived battalions of the Mahdi Army, one of the dominant groups preparing for battle after a call for a “defensive jihad” by a high-ranking ayatollah.
lead_paragraph: NAJAF, Iraq — It had been quite the morning for Jamli Umm Saif, a mother of four. After morning prayers on Saturday, she sent off her husband and eldest son to join a military parade by the Mahdi Army, a Shiite militia run by the populist cleric Moktada al-Sadr.

headline: Immigration Reform’s Open Invitation to Children
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Deportation', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Asylum, Right of', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons']
abstract: The mere promise of amnesty in the future has played a role in the surge of children trying to cross the border.
lead_paragraph: FOR years now, one side of the immigration debate — the side of billionaires, professional bipartisans, and all the great and good — has argued that an amnesty of some kind for illegal immigrants isn’t just a sensible policy choice but a crushingly obvious one: self-evidently wise, morally farseeing and a win for almost everyone, from corporations to labor unions to Republican politicians to the immigrants themselves.

headline: Postpartum Depression
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Women and Girls', 'Parenting', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: Readers react to articles on the various ways that mental disorders can afflict new moms.
lead_paragraph: Readers react to articles on the various ways that mental disorders can afflict new moms.

headline: Ed Lu
abstract: The former astronaut on wrestling, Godzilla and airplane dreams.
lead_paragraph: Ed Lu is a physicist and former NASA astronaut who is currently the chief executive of the B612 Foundation, a nonprofit organization on a mission to save the world from a possible asteroid apocalypse. The group is in the process of building an infrared telescope that, once launched into space, will search the solar system for monster asteroids on a collision course with Earth.

headline: So Similar, So Different
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Education (K-12)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Foreign Aid', 'United States International Relations', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: Two women, both 20 and talented, have lives that are miles apart. Literally and otherwise, thanks to the lottery of birth.
lead_paragraph: READERS often ask: Why do I travel to places like Sudan or Myanmar when we Americans have so many challenges at home to worry about?

headline: Inside Firefighter School
abstract: Jordan Sullivan, a rookie New York City firefighter, recalls his training at the Fire Academy on Randalls Island, known as the Rock, where one of the most challenging exercises is search and rescue.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Sullivan, a rookie New York City firefighter, recalls his training at the Fire Academy on Randalls Island, known as the Rock, where one of the most challenging exercises is search and rescue.

headline: The Coming Climate Crash
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Economy', 'Global Warming', 'Carbon Dioxide']
abstract: We need to tax carbon dioxide emissions to protect our economy.
lead_paragraph: THERE is a time for weighing evidence and a time for acting. And if there’s one thing I’ve learned throughout my work in finance, government and conservation, it is to act before problems become too big to manage.

headline: Neil Barrett: Spring 2015 Menswear
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: How My Wine Turned to Water
abstract: I hadn’t realized my life revolved around booze.
lead_paragraph: TRURO, Mass. — MY email inbox startled me with the subject line: A Voice from the Past. The last email I received with that heading was from Peanuts LoBianco, a deranged former high school classmate who claimed he had learned to walk on water, change water into wine and then walk on the wine. For all that, he still needed money from me.

headline: An Ace Agent Finally Has a Hall of Famer
abstract: Greg Maddux will be inducted into the Hall of Fame this year, the first longtime client of the agent Scott Boras to be enshrined in Cooperstown, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: For most of the last three decades, few people have had more influence on baseball, or been more ubiquitous, than the agent Scott Boras. When you flip on a game taking place in Anaheim, Calif., chances are he is looking back at you from his suite behind home plate. When you wonder whether your team will sign, or retain, a prominent star, quite often it is Boras handling the negotiations.

headline: Baltimore Joins Cities Toughening Curfews, Citing Safety but Eliciting Concern
abstract: Some call a curfew law, to be enforced this summer, an attempt to keep juveniles safe. Others say it opens the door to selective enforcement.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — To beat the summer heat, Isaiah Jackson waits until the sun goes down to play basketball in an alley near his home.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 22
abstract: President Obama announced this week that he would send 300 military advisers to Iraq to aid them in resisting Sunni militants. Lawmakers will weigh in on the president’s foreign policy decisions on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: As unrest and violence continues in Iraq, President Obama announced Thursday that he would send 300 military advisers to the country to aid struggling security forces to fight off Sunni militants. Insurgents with the Sunni militant group Islamic State in Iraq and Syria have swept through northern cities, often seizing money from banks along the way.

headline: Death Threats, Then Red Tape
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Threats and Threatening Messages', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Journalists from Mexico seeking asylum in the United States enter a bureaucratic nightmare.
lead_paragraph: ON June 20, 2011, in Veracruz, Mexico, Miguel Ángel López Solana arrived home to find that his brother, mother and father had been murdered. Both sons were photojournalists at the newspaper where their father was a columnist, writing about crime and political corruption. Within a month, another journalist at the paper was decapitated. A year later, four more journalists were murdered there in a single week. It’s not clear why they were killed, but Mr. López wasn’t going to wait around to find out.

headline: Two-Parent Households Can Be Lethal
keywords: ['Domestic Violence', 'Families and Family Life', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Parenting']
abstract: Having a dad around is great, unless he’s a violent abuser.
lead_paragraph: AFTER spending two years studying services for domestic violence survivors, I was surprised to realize that one of the most common barriers to women’s safety was something I had never considered before: the high value our culture places on two-parent families.

headline: Hacker Tactic: Holding Data Hostage
abstract: Cybercriminals are finding new ways to breach firewalls and hold data hostage.
lead_paragraph: THE perpetual cat-and-mouse game between computer hackers and their targets is getting nastier. Cybercriminals are getting better at circumventing firewalls and antivirus programs. More of them are resorting to ransomware, which encrypts computer data and holds it hostage until a fee is paid. Some hackers plant virus-loaded ads on legitimate websites, enabling them to remotely wipe a hard drive clean or cause it to overheat. Meanwhile, companies are being routinely targeted by attacks sponsored by the governments of Iran and China. Even small start-ups are suffering from denial-of-service extortion attacks, in which hackers threaten to disable their websites unless money is paid.

headline: Superstitious Soccer Fans
abstract: Some Brazilian soccer fans say their personal rituals have a direct impact on their team’s success.
lead_paragraph: Some Brazilian soccer fans say their personal rituals have a direct impact on their team’s success.

headline: With Salary Choice, Anthony Will Show How Much Value He Places on Winning
abstract: Carmelo Anthony has until Monday to decide if he wants to opt out of his contract with the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony will soon be making a choice on how much he is willing to sacrifice, in terms of salary, to be part of a winning team.

headline: Fear Not the Coming of the Robots
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Productivity', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Historically, technology lifted us all by creating new jobs and greater efficiency.
lead_paragraph: JUST over 50 years ago, the cover of Life magazine breathlessly declared the “point of no return for everybody.” Above that stark warning, a smaller headline proclaimed, “Automation’s really here; jobs go scarce.”

headline: Atlanta Summons the Past to Showcase the Present
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: Supporters hope the National Center for Civil and Human Rights, opening Monday in Atlanta, will fuel tourism, broaden the city’s reputation and host international human rights events.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Far from his typical Broadway haunts, the director George C. Wolfe was walking through a construction site here this spring when, amid a cacophony of saws and drills, he stopped and stood before what was to become a replica of a lunch counter that he said would claw visitors back into history.

headline: Gaming the Poor
abstract: Modern slot machine parlors have sophisticated methods of milking less affluent gamblers.
lead_paragraph: In a referendum in November, voters approved as many as seven new casinos to join New York State’s existing nine gambling facilities. And New York is hardly alone. In recent years, 23 other states have legalized and licensed commercial (as opposed to Native American) gambling facilities. In the casino-dense Northeast and mid-Atlantic regions, where 26 casinos have opened since 2004 and at least a dozen more are under development, most adults now live within a short drive of one.

headline: But I Want to Do Your Homework
keywords: ['Homework', 'Parenting', 'Education (K-12)', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Helping my son was about my ego. In the end, all this help does nothing but hurt.
lead_paragraph: MY son and I are shouting at each other, and crying. He is holding his essay between his fingertips as if it’s a dead cockroach. “I’m sorry,” I said. “I just made a few corrections...”

headline: Mass Surveillance in Britain
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Privacy', 'Consumer Protection', 'Editorials']
abstract: Public hearings in a legal case over bulk data collection by British intelligence agencies will provide an important forum for the issue.
lead_paragraph: European officials have often acted as though excessive government surveillance was solely an American problem. The recent release of a  legal statement from a senior British counterterrorism official, Charles Farr, shows that the United States government is certainly not alone in justifying such practices.

headline: Sentencing Reform Runs Aground
keywords: ['Mandatory Sentencing', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Editorials']
abstract: Bills that would reform the criminal justice system have stalled in Congress.
lead_paragraph: Criminal justice reform is one of the rare issues on which there has been bipartisan support in Congress and significant progress toward a legislative solution. Until recently, anyway.

headline: Slavery and the Shrimp on Your Plate
keywords: ['Human Trafficking', 'Forced Labor', 'Seafood', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: Seafood fishing is big business in Thailand, but the government has done little to combat human trafficking and forced labor.
lead_paragraph: Shrimp and other seafood fishing is a big business in Thailand. The industry employs more than 650,000 people and annually produces more than $7 billion in exports that show up on dinner tables all over the world, including in the United States. It also has a horrific dark side. Its reliance on slave labor is so pervasive and ugly that the State Department now lists Thailand as one of the worst violators among 188 countries judged every year on how they deal with human trafficking.

headline: Despite Recent Early Exits, Federer and Williams Like Their Chances
abstract: Serena Williams and Roger Federer said they were ready to compete at Wimbledon, which begins Monday.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — A couple of 32-year-olds who have each won 17 Grand Slam titles weighed in Saturday on the prospects of reaching No. 18 by the end of the Wimbledon tournament, which begins Monday. While Roger Federer was talkative, Serena Williams was terse.

headline: A Largely Indian Victory in World War II, Mostly Forgotten in India
abstract: The memory of the bloodiest battle of the war there, a 1944 encounter that cost the Japanese much of their best army in Burma, is complicated by India’s colonial past.
lead_paragraph: KOHIMA, India — Soldiers died by the dozens, by the hundreds and then by the thousands in a battle here 70 years ago. Two bloody weeks of fighting came down to just a few yards across an asphalt tennis court.

headline: Iraqi-Americans Watch Chaos in Alarm
abstract: About a fifth of the Iraqis in the United States have come since 2000, meaning many are watching the news with an eye out for at least one family member who might be in harm’s way.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Every mile Iraqi militants log on their warpath toward Baghdad is another reason for Majid al-Bahadli to worry.

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: With Job in Peril, Yankees’ Nuno Wobbles Through a Start
abstract: The struggling Yankees starter Vidal Nuno, who gave up three home runs in a loss to the Orioles, is pitching for his job “every time, every outing, every inning.”
lead_paragraph: Vidal Nuno had only a tenuous hold on his spot in the Yankees’ pitching rotation when he took the mound Saturday against the Baltimore Orioles. He hardly strengthened his position in the Yankees’ 6-1 loss, allowing five runs, four of them earned, in six and a third innings while giving up three home runs.

headline: Should America Solve its Own Problems First?
abstract: Readers comment on my column about two 20-year-olds living worlds apart–and why we can address humanitarian problems both at home and abroad.
lead_paragraph: Whenever I write about international issues, I always get pushback from readers who say that we should solve our own domestic problems before worrying about the rest of the world. As House Majority Leader Tom DeLay put it years ago, international humanitarianism puts “Ghana over Grandma.” I don’t buy that, and my Sunday column is a response to that way of thinking. But as my column notes, I think there’s sometimes also the opposite tendency, especially among university students–that is to think that it’s glamorous to fight illiteracy in Tanzania, but not to mentor at-risk students on the wrong side of the tracks in one’s own city. As far as I’m concerned, there are important needs both at home and abroad, and we needn’t solve one before beginning to tackle the other. The story I tell in this column is why I think that. So read the column and post your thoughts below.

headline: Big Ten Commissioner Testifies for a Simpler Time
abstract: Testifying at a closely followed antitrust trial, Jim Delany, the commissioner of the Big Ten, said the business of college sports places undue demands on college athletes.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Mark Emmert, the N.C.A.A. president, drew a crowd to federal court here last week, as journalists and lawyers packed a courtroom and a second overflow room to witness his defense of amateur college sports. When Emmert finished his testimony early Friday, much of the crowd was gone.

headline: American Apparel Ousts Its Founder, Dov Charney, Over Nude Photos
abstract: An internal investigation found that the company’s chief executive had allowed the posting of naked pictures of a female employee who had sued him.
lead_paragraph: The founder and chief executive of American Apparel, Dov Charney, was fired this week because an internal investigation found that he had misused company money and had allowed an employee to post naked photographs of a former female employee who had sued him, according to a person with knowledge of the investigation.

headline: Bosnia-Herzegovina vs. Nigeria: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Vedad Ibisevic of Bosnia did manage to score against Argentina, but it was largely because of keeper error. Bosnia will be looking to do better, with forward Senad Lulic a key man.
lead_paragraph: Vedad Ibisevic of Bosnia did manage to score against Argentina, but it was largely because of keeper error. Bosnia will be looking to do better, with forward Senad Lulic a key man.

headline: Alstom Board Backs Offer From G.E., Ending Battle
abstract: The approval of the $13.5 billion deal essentially brings the long acquisition negotiations to an end, though a final deal hinges on the French state buying Alstom shares.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The board of the French industrial conglomerate Alstom said Saturday that it had unanimously backed General Electric’s offer to acquire most of its energy business for $13.5 billion, essentially ending the battle for the company. A final deal was still awaiting the successful outcome of negotiations between the government and Alstom’s largest shareholder over the sale of a stake to the state.

headline: Dime Store
abstract: Elizabeth C. Gorski’s puzzle adds up to a lot of fun.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, this was just brilliant on a few levels. We saw something like this nearly a year ago, by Daniel Finan, but even so, this is a delicious “Aha!” moment.

headline: Carlton A. Sherwood, Reporter Behind 2004 Kerry Film, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Sherwood was an investigative journalist and former Marine who made “Stolen Honor,” a 2004 film about Vietnam War veterans’ opposition to John Kerry.
lead_paragraph: Carlton A. Sherwood, an investigative journalist and former Marine who lurched between accolades and controversy, most prominently with a 2004 film about the chagrin of Vietnam War veterans over John Kerry’s turning against the war as a naval officer, died on June 11 in Philadelphia. He was 67.

headline: Vows | When the Beat Works
abstract: As musicians, Rachel Elmer and Gabriel Hernandez know when they have a song right. That has not always been the case in their relationship. (Correction: An earlier version of a capsule summary with this video misstated the given name of the groom. He is Gabriel Hernandez, not George.)

headline: Seeing Sons’ Violent Potential, but Finding Little Help or Hope

headline: A Christian Convert, on the Run in Afghanistan

abstract: After an unsuccessful cross-continental journey seeking religious freedom, an apostate Muslim hides near Kabul while family members seek to kill him.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a dank basement on the outskirts of Kabul, Josef read his worn blue Bible by the light of a propane lantern, as he had done for weeks since he fled from his family in Pakistan.

headline: Dr. Arnold Relman, 91, Journal Editor and Health System Critic, Dies
abstract: A longtime editor of The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Relman used it to warn of a “new medical-industrial complex.”
lead_paragraph: Dr. Arnold S. Relman, who abandoned the study of philosophy to rise to the top of the medical profession as a researcher, administrator and longtime editor of The New England Journal of Medicine, which became a platform for his early and influential attacks on the profit-driven health care system, died at his home in Cambridge, Mass., on Tuesday, his 91st birthday.

headline: Political Upstarts Work to Propel Change in an Indonesia Tired of Corruption
abstract: A small but growing group of political upstarts is emerging and its members seem united in a belief that the Indonesian public is fed up with the level of corruption in the nation.
lead_paragraph: BOGOR, Indonesia — Even as a young man, Bima Arya Sugiarto seemed a sure bet to gain membership into the exclusive club of Indonesia’s political elite.

headline: Ukrainian Church Faces Obscure Pro-Russia Revolt in Its Own Ranks
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Russian Orthodox Church', 'Priests', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Many in western Ukraine suspect that the breakaway church represents a Russian-backed maneuver to destroy a vital wellspring of Ukrainian nationalism.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — In a zealously nationalist region of Ukraine that clamors to join Europe and bubbles with suspicion toward Russia, Father Andriy, a preacher at Our Lady of Everlasting Succor church, was defiantly out of step with the mood of his flock.

headline: Film Delves Into Lives of Strippers in Dallas
keywords: ['Strip Clubs and Strippers', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: An actor in “Magic Mike,” Joe Manganiello thought the film scratched only the surface of the world of male stripping, so he made a documentary about performers.
lead_paragraph: When Joe Manganiello first visited LaBare, the Dallas male strip club, in 2012, most of the dancers had no idea who he was.

headline: Dempsey and Ronaldo Are Set for U.S.-Portugal Matchup Despite Injuries
abstract: Clint Dempsey, the American captain, has a broken nose, while Cristiano Ronaldo of Portugal has been battling knee problems.
lead_paragraph: MANAUS, Brazil — Injuries have been the dominant subplot in the buildup to Sunday’s World Cup game between the United States and Portugal, but while both teams will be without important players, each squad’s leader is expected to play.

headline: Traffic Control at Junction of Football and Business
abstract: To regulate contact between college players and agents, Texas has one of the nation’s oldest laws. But the new football coach at the University of Texas at Austin intends to go further to restrict access.
lead_paragraph: For some Texas university football programs, summer means the approach of Agent Day, an invitation-only speed-dating exercise that offers sports agents access to senior players before their final season.

headline: Wie, a Prodigy of the Past, Has a Fresh Outlook in Seeking Her First Major Win
abstract: Players like 11-year-old Lucy Li have received more attention at the United States Women’s Open, but Michelle Wie is tied for the lead heading into the final round.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — People flocked to Lucy Li like children to the neighborhood ice cream truck during the first two rounds of the United States Women’s Open. Michelle Wie, the 36-hole leader, was fine with that.

headline: For Yankees, the Immortalization Process Is Worth Rethinking
abstract: Tino Martinez joined the Yankees’ crowded Monument Park on Saturday, and more from his era are on their way.
lead_paragraph: Tino Martinez had always wanted to attend the Masters, and this spring, he finally did. After the Wednesday practice round in Augusta, Ga., Martinez got a phone call from Deborah Tymon, the Yankees’ senior vice president for marketing. She told him he would get his own plaque in Monument Park on June 21.

headline: A Young Marlin With a Rocket Arm Works to Grow Into an All-Around Threat
abstract: The talk was all about Marcell Ozuna after he made some spectacular throws in Friday’s game, but the Mets proved too much for the Marlins in Saturday’s 4-0 win.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Marcell Ozuna paced around left field during batting practice Saturday afternoon. It was the same spot where he had made the decisive play the night before, and he re-enacted it for his Miami Marlins teammates in slow motion. He retreated a few steps, came forward under an imaginary ball, reached out his glove and wound his arm.

headline: Project Tests New Storage for Energy
abstract: Oncor is installing batteries that will provide backup power in a South Dallas neighborhood, a move that is part of a larger trend of investing in energy from sources like wind and the sun.
lead_paragraph: LANCASTER, Tex. — No one at the equipment lot here would blame you for failing to notice the drab green box sitting across from the spare transformers. But the lithium ions inside that refrigerator-size container are part of a wave of energy storage technology that could help Texas revolutionize its electric grid.

headline: An Enduring Touch Proves as Essential as Ever
abstract: Even as an injury-prone, 36-year-old substitute, Germany’s Miroslav Klose has shown his ability to score goals, as he did against Ghana on Saturday to give the Germans a 2-2 draw and tie the World Cup scoring record.
lead_paragraph: The shaky front flip was not vintage Miroslav Klose, but the critical goal that led to it was definitely a classic Klose poach.

lead_paragraph: Belgium vs. Russia, 12 p.m.: Belgium hopes to get its offense cranked up a bit earlier in this game, before the substitutes start coming in late in the second half. Two of them, Marouane Fellaini and Dries Merten, provided the goals that lifted Belgium over Algeria. Russia also got its only goal in a draw against South Korea from a sub, Alan Dzagoev. A draw may be enough for these two teams to advance.

His unit took his parents to the scene, asking them to persuade their son to surrender.

headline: 17-Year-Old Boy Is Killed in a Shooting at a Bronx Party
