headline: Are Royals Worth the Money?
abstract: Critics of monarchy say it is an antiquated institution too extravagant for cash-strapped countries to maintain, writes JAKE FLANAGIN. Yet many people throughout the world are reluctant to let it go.
lead_paragraph: When Spain’s King Juan Carlos abdicated his throne in June, he received resounding praise for his leadership through the country’s troubled transition to democracy in the 20th century. But many critics in constitutional monarchies throughout the world continue to ask the question: Is the tradition of royalty too luxurious and costly to maintain?

headline: Mastering the Art of Three-Dimensional Graffiti
abstract: Carlos Mare has spent the past three decades transforming graffiti by sculpting and welding stainless steel into art for exhibition in galleries here and abroad.
lead_paragraph: Clanging metal, whirring drills and strains of Chet Baker wafted through the air, nine stories above the busy intersection of St. Nicholas Avenue and West 155th Street in Harlem. Carlos Mare sweated and huffed as he bent a stainless steel arrow over his knee. He tucked it into a mirror-shiny tangle of curves and lines that hung from a wall, stepped back and waved his arms, as if he were conducting an orchestra.

headline: Fooling Mexican Fans
abstract: Mexico’s politicians are pushing through unpopular legislation, while its people are glued to the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: The day before the Mexican soccer team’s thrilling underdog tie with the World Cup favorite, Brazil, last week, the lead editorial of the news site SinEmbargo was titled, “Ready for your Clamato and Gatorade?” — common hangover remedies. “In about three weeks, when you wake from your World Cup dreams,” the editors wrote, “remember that when the soccer fest began, the country was on the verge of monumental decisions. If upon waking, you realize that the country’s energy reserves have been cheaply sold off or whatever else, don’t bother protesting because this is a chronicle foretold.”

headline: ‘Newsies’ to Close in August
abstract: The hit Broadway musical will close on Aug. 24 after two-and-half years of performances, Disney Theatrical Productions announced on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The hit Broadway musical “Newsies” will close on Aug. 24 after two and a half years of performances, Disney Theatrical Productions announced on Sunday. The profitable run has far exceeded Disney’s expectations and helped the company bounce back on Broadway after two critical and commercial disappointments, “Tarzan” and “The Little Mermaid.”

headline: Understanding the Land Where ‘Kafkaesque’ Was Born
abstract: “Gottland,” Mariusz Szczygiel’s book about Czechoslovakia before and after Communism finds both the surreal and the real.
lead_paragraph: One thing worth remembering while reading Mariusz Szczygiel’s mordant “Gottland: Mostly True Stories From Half of Czechoslovakia” is that Franz Kafka was a Czech, and Mr. Szczygiel is not. He’s a Polish writer and journalist, looking with a kind of appalled fascination at his country’s southern neighbor and finding that life there can often be, well, Kafkaesque.

headline: Kevin Hart Sequel No. 1 In a Slow Popcorn Season
abstract: Sony’s “Think Like a Man Too,” a comedy sequel featuring the comedian Kevin Hart, took in $30 million over the weekend, enough for first place.
lead_paragraph: As Hollywood’s version of summer hits its midway mark, North American ticket sales for the movie industry’s 18-weekend “popcorn season” are running 15 percent behind the same period last year, according to Rentrak, a box office data firm.

lead_paragraph: The tranquil, soaring space in the Metropolitan Museum of Art that has housed the Temple of Dendur since 1978 is so beloved that New Yorkers could be forgiven for thinking that the temple itself is beside the point, merely an excuse for the glamorous room, with its sweeping wall of glass.

With the shot clock winding down, Anthony would be operating in an isolation set, the crowd at Madison Square Garden awaiting his next move.

headline: The Harmony of Liberty
keywords: ['Museums', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The new National Center for Civil and Human Rights in Atlanta, does not focus solely on civil rights history but also highlights present-day human rights struggles.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — It isn’t that great a distance from the birthplace of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on Auburn Avenue here to the $68 million, 42,000 square-foot National Center for Civil and Human Rights that is opening on Monday near Centennial Olympic Park. The two sites, though, seem as if they’ve emerged not just from different time periods, but from different and incompatible universes.

headline: A Hybrid Star Expresses the Currents and Crosscurrents in the Europe of Today
abstract: Stromae, a.k.a. the Belgian singer-songwriter Paul Van Haver, delivers French-language songs garnished with deft dance moves.
lead_paragraph: Stromae dances to a continent’s disquiet. He’s a Belgian songwriter who performed on Friday night for an adoring full house at the Best Buy Theater. He’s also a pop-star embodiment of a contemporary Europe that’s smart, increasingly heterogeneous, historically aware, anxious about the future, sleekly charming and unfailingly stylish.

headline: Digging Deep, a Singer Gives Signature Songs Her Own Stamp
abstract: Billie Holiday classics were among the numbers Vivian Reed performed at a recent show.
lead_paragraph: Conventional cultural wisdom has it that Billie Holiday, who wrote “God Bless the Child” with Arthur Herzog Jr. in 1939 and first recorded it two years later, is the ultimate interpreter of this devastating reflection on poverty and humiliation. In Holiday’s performances, her voice curled around the song and enfolded it as though she were trying to comfort a wounded stray animal she found on the street and brought home to care for: perhaps her own inner child.

lead_paragraph: Some choreographers seem to know exactly what they want to say before they say it. Why express through movement what you can articulate just as clearly, if not more, in a program note?

lead_paragraph: In a news conference with Egypt’s foreign minister, Secretary of State John Kerry said that Islamist militants seizing control of parts of Iraq were a threat to the entire region.

headline: The Amazing Adventures of Pencil Man
abstract: “King Kirby” traces the creative and business ups and down of a great comic book artist, Jack Kirby.
lead_paragraph: “King Kirby,” now at the Brick in Brooklyn as part of the Comic Book Theater Festival, opens with a scene that prompts knowing eye rolls to those familiar with the show’s subject: In 1994, a Sotheby’s auctioneer, hawking work by the comic book artist Jack Kirby, dismissively confuses Spider-Man with Iron Man. Of course she does; after all, this is comic book art, not “fine” art, and the cultural elite, like countless parents, have sneered at comics since time immemorial. Even comic publishers, as this show demonstrates, were once happy to shortchange their own creators.

lead_paragraph: It was lovely to be out and around in New York on Saturday, the first day of summer, warm, sunny and dry. And if you were out, you may well have tripped on a concert or two.

lead_paragraph: The bandleader Vince Giordano said that when he dialed the number, he figured it was little more than a Hail Mary pass. But that simple phone call solved the mystery.

headline: Man Dies in Las Vegas at Electric Daisy Carnival
abstract: A 24-year-old California man died after attending opening night of the Electric Daisy Carnival in Las Vegas on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A 24-year-old California man died after attending opening night of the Electric Daisy Carnival in Las Vegas on Friday. The Las Vegas Sun reported that the man, Montgomery Tsang of San Leandro, collapsed in the parking lot of the Las Vegas Motor Speedway, where the festival was being held. He was taken to a hospital, where he died early Saturday morning. No cause of death had been determined as of Sunday afternoon, Jennifer Jacobs, senior coroner investigator at the Clark County Coroner’s Office, said. The festival’s organizers, Insomniac Events, estimate that approximately 134,000 people attended on Friday. About 250 medical calls were made that night, five of which resulted in trips to the hospital, according to the Las Vegas police. A spokeswoman for Insomniac, Jennifer Forkish, said in a statement on Saturday that “one death is one too many,” and asked festivalgoers to help keep one another safe on the remaining two nights. Saturday’s was not the first death tied to an Electric Daisy event. In 2010, a 15-year-old girl died of a drug overdose at the festival in Los Angeles. The next year, a 19-year-old man died at an Electric Daisy event in Dallas, and in 2012 two people died off site after attending the festival in Las Vegas.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13) THE ESCAPE ARTIST “Everyone deserves a defense,” says Will Burton (David Tennant, above), who is London’s top-ranked junior barrister, according to a recent poll, and well up the ladder toward Queen’s Counsel because of his ability to win any case. But his invincible legal acrobatics backfire when a handshake denied sends his latest client, the reclusive bird lover and psychopath Liam Foyle (Toby Kebbell), into a rage — leaving Will, his wife (Ashley Jensen) and their son (Gus Barry) the targets of revenge. Enter Will’s nemesis, Maggie Gardner (Sophie Okonedo), frothing to overtake her rival. David Wolstencroft, the mastermind behind the BBC spy series “MI-5,” wrote this two-part “Masterpiece Mystery!” thriller, shown here in its entirety. (Part 2 will be broadcast on Channel 49 at 9.) “For the Tennant completist, it’s mandatory viewing,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Is Real Inclusiveness Possible?
abstract: Philosophy’s project to more fully represent the diversity of human history and culture faces serious challenges.
lead_paragraph: Like many institutions that have become more concerned with equality in the past few decades, academic philosophy today aims to be more inclusive. In general, university departments are now striving to consider the experiences and concerns of a broader range of people than have traditionally played the social and professional role of the philosopher. This makes sense. In an increasingly global intellectual landscape, the removal of barriers to entry for previously excluded groups of people and schools of thought is productive and fair.

lead_paragraph: Sunday afternoon at Yankee Stadium began with the traditional Old-Timers’ game. With each hit, each strikeout and each introduction, the former Yankees stars earned thunderous applause.

headline: Mayors Put Focus on How to Raise Wages for Lowest-Paid Workers in Cities
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Mayors', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Living Wage', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: At the annual meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors, the subject of income inequality seemed to be on almost everyone’s lips.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — About one in five people in Hallandale Beach, Fla., live below the poverty line. Though it is a small city — 37,000 people, a horse track and a greyhound track — its mayor, Joy Cooper, bellied up to the table during a jobs committee discussion on Saturday among the nation’s mayors and fired off a few questions about raising the minimum wage, if not for the whole city, at least for businesses with city contracts.

lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — As the temperature dipped to a stultifying 106 degrees one recent evening, members of the Coyotes Curling Club showed up at their clubhouse in a factory district near the airport ready to unwind, work out and cool off.

headline: Late Shock Interrupts U.S. Party

headline: Creating Unexpected Opportunities in a Recovering Economy

headline: African Teams Band Together in Spoiler Role
abstract: With the possibility of clearing the tournament’s final hurdle remote, they find solidarity in trying to derail the plans of certain European and Latin American teams.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — It is Sunday in Brasília. The nation’s capital has the air of a city that was out of date even as it was being built. This may have been the city of the future, but now it looks as if it belongs to the past. In the afternoon sun, many of the older, concrete high-rises look shabby compared with their new, glass-fronted neighbors.

headline: 3 Who Escaped Prison by Helicopter Are Caught in Montreal

headline: Honolulu Shores Up Tourism With Crackdown on Homeless

lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — It was just before 7 a.m. and the streets of Waikiki were filled with tourists, surfers, early morning joggers — and Ronnie Cruz, a 34-year-old homeless man getting a ticket from a Honolulu police officer for pushing a shopping cart piled high with his belongings along the sidewalk.

headline: What the U.S. Must Do Now to Advance
abstract: The United States would move on with a win or a draw against Germany or with a Ghana-Portugal tie. Failing that, things get complicated.
lead_paragraph: After a brutally disappointing tie Sunday night, the United States faces a dizzying array of possibilities heading into its final match in the World Cup’s group stage. Here are the basic facts to keep in mind:

headline: Brasília, a Capital City That’s a Place Apart
abstract: The city, a planned showcase for modernistic design, has a distinctly un-Brazilian nature, standing in jarring contrast to the nation’s unpredictability.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — The Brazilian flag reads, “Ordem e Progresso” — “Order and Progress” — which is somewhat curious in this wonderfully jumbled and beautiful country. For an outsider who has visited the samba-infused nightclubs of Rio de Janeiro, the Amazonian jungle or São Paulo, with its ramshackle favelas and snarled traffic, order is not what springs to mind.

headline: Elite, Separate, Unequal
abstract: New York City’s top public schools must become more diverse.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — NEW YORK CITY’S elite public high schools were always meant to provide a quintessentially American blend of academic excellence and democratic accessibility. Unlike the city’s expensive private schools, they would be free and open to all who were academically qualified, irrespective of pedigree.

headline: Here Lies Progress: Asian Actors Fill the Playbill
abstract: “Here Lies Love” and several upcoming revivals have increased the demand for Asian-American actors, and Asians are landing roles that traditionally go to non-Asians.
lead_paragraph: After decades of inching toward center stage, Asian-American theater actors are facing something that they’ve rarely enjoyed in New York: demand.

headline: Fate of 3 Kidnapped Israelis Raises Tensions on Many Fronts
abstract: A kidnapping highlights the huge gulf, political and psychological, between long-warring neighbors and is raising fears of a third intifada in the Palestinian territories.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Three Israeli teenagers kidnapped from the West Bank have been missing for more than 10 days now, their names — Naftali, Gilad, Eyal — becoming staples of synagogue prayers and cafe chatter across this tiny country. Four Palestinians, one of them 15, have been killed by Israeli troops, their photos hoisted at mass funerals as martyrs in the liberation struggle.

headline: The Frustration Doctrine

lead_paragraph: Americans’ confidence in American leadership is flagging to such a degree that it poses a critical threat to our democracy, particularly as moneyed interests seek to manipulate the malaise and stir policy and politician away from principle and toward profit.

headline: Despite a Hex, Ronaldo Works Magic

headline: Conservatives Plan to Use Poll Watchers in Mississippi

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Senator Thad Cochran, the veteran Republican, fights for his political life in Mississippi by taking the unexpected step of courting black Democrats, conservative organizations working to defeat him are planning to deploy poll watchers to monitor his campaign’s turnout operation in Tuesday’s runoff election.

headline: Yahoo Hires Michael Isikoff as Chief Investigative Correspondent

headline: The Big Green Test
abstract: Are conservatives willing to settle for “second best” solutions for global warming?
lead_paragraph: On Sunday Henry Paulson, the former Treasury secretary and a lifelong Republican, had an Op-Ed article about climate policy in The New York Times. In the article, he declared that man-made climate change is “the challenge of our time,” and called for a national tax on carbon emissions to encourage conservation and the adoption of green technologies. Considering the prevalence of climate denial within today’s G.O.P., and the absolute opposition to any kind of tax increase, this was a brave stand to take.

headline: Iraq’s Military Seen as Unlikely to Turn the Tide
abstract: Recent assessments by Western officials and military experts indicate that about a quarter of Iraq’s military forces are “combat ineffective.”
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — As Iraqi Army forces try to rally on the outskirts of Baghdad after two weeks of retreat, it has become increasingly clear to Western officials that the army will continue to suffer losses in its fight with Sunni militants and will not soon retake the ground it has ceded.

headline: Fouad Ajami, Commentator and Expert in Arab History, Dies at 68
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Arabs', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Muslims and Islam']

lead_paragraph: Fouad Ajami, an academic, author and broadcast commentator on Middle East affairs who helped rally support for the United States invasion of Iraq in 2003 — partly by personally advising top policy makers — died on Sunday. He was 68.

headline: The Real Drama at the Met
abstract: If the opera house is to survive, those who work onstage and off will have to take a breath and compromise.
lead_paragraph: Over its 131 years, the Metropolitan Opera has drawn virtually all the major stars onto its massive stage — from the days of Enrico Caruso to the time of Anna Netrebko. The company presents more than 20 operas each season, drawing about 800,000 people to more than 200 performances. Its live broadcasts in movie theaters around the world give 2.5 million people a chance to enjoy opera up close and in real time.

headline: Diapers.com Co-Founder Launches Online Publication

Unfortunately, that seems unlikely to change soon given the release on Friday of a Japanese report on World War II sex slaves.

headline: A Novel Lays Bare Media Ills
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Magazines', 'News and News Media', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: At first glance, “The Last Magazine: A Novel” by Michael Hastings would appear to lack relevance in the current media age, but even from the grave Mr. Hastings has demonstrated anew an ability to reframe the debate.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, “The Last Magazine: A Novel” by Michael Hastings would appear to lack relevance in the current media age. A fictional account of life inside a failed magazine — Newsweek — in a dying industry — print — written by a now-dead journalist, the book seems very much beside the point. And the march of history aside, does the world need another roman à clef from inside the world of Manhattan media, whose bottomless interest in itself is not generally shared by the public?

headline: The Iraq Crisis is Worse Than it Seems for the Kurds
abstract: The Iraqi army weakness is not good for Kurds, who want independence. Now Kurdistan has lost its greatest asset, which isn’t oil, but security.
lead_paragraph: It seems that some who support the Kurdish cause see an opportunity in the mayhem in Iraq. Commentators from abroad see the Iraqi army’s meltdown and retreat from the Sunni Arab heartland north of Baghdad as a sign that things might finally fall into place for the Kurds. Here in Erbil, people were positively elated when the Kurdish armed forces, called pesh merga (meaning “those who face death”), consolidated their grip on oil-rich Kirkuk, after the Iraqi army gave up on the region this week.

Then a couple of months later, he was among nine people who received a new physics prize — and $3 million each — from Yuri Milner, a Russian who dropped out of graduate studies in physics and became a successful investor in Internet companies like Facebook.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on a rigged market, Syrian rebels, safety in the skies, the I.R.S. curiosity and Irish recovery.
lead_paragraph: “There’s no escaping the conclusion that the stock market is not a level playing field where all investors, large and small, have an equal shot at a fair deal,” writes The New York Times editorial board. “The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations recently held a hearing on “maker-taker” pricing in which stock exchanges pay rebates to brokers for sending them buy-and-sell orders. The practice has been around for years, as a growing number of exchanges — there are now 11 public exchanges in the United States — have battled for business. What is new is the compelling evidence that the rebates are corrupting.” Brokers are technically supposed to find the best stock prices for their clients, but new research shows that they are “routinely sending orders to venues that paid the highest rebates.” The board calls on financial regulators to monitor executions, for the good of the American economy and maintaining fair competition: “Securities regulators clearly need to better enforce the best execution requirements on brokers, combined with better disclosure on brokers’ routing decisions and the rebates they earn. If Congress won’t provide more resources for enforcement, rebates need either to be passed along to the customer or eliminated altogether.”

abstract: Former President Bill Clinton, in a video message, says he was “honored and grateful to be among the voices urging” the overturning of the Defense of Marriage Act.
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton, in a video message to be broadcast this week, says he was “honored and grateful to be among the voices urging” the overturning of the Defense of Marriage Act, the measure he signed into law in 1996 that barred federal recognition of same-sex marriages.

headline: Knicks’ Raymond Felton Avoids Jail in Gun Possession Case
abstract: Felton agreed to plead guilty to a felony gun possession charge in return for a $5,000 fine and 500 hours of community service, his lawyer, Jim Walden, said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Raymond Felton has reached a plea bargain with prosecutors that allows him to avoid jail, agreeing to plead guilty to a felony gun possession charge in return for a $5,000 fine and 500 hours of community service, his lawyer, Jim Walden, said.

headline: Monday Quandary: When a Child’s First Friends Fade Away
abstract: Looking for advice for parents, from parents: how do you help a child transition from the friends and playmates you produce for her to friends of her own making, and what do you do when your child is the one who is growing away?
lead_paragraph: This post kicks off a new Motherlode feature: the weekly quandary. We’ll pull a question from the comments, the weekly open thread, or email that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than just that one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family?

headline: Image of the Day: June 23
abstract: A widow attending an event in New Delhi to mark International Widows Day.

headline: Stephens Loses Match, and Could Lose Ground to Other U.S. Phenoms
abstract: In an unfortunate draw against a former top-10 player, the American Sloane Stephens fell to Maria Kirilenko in the first round at Wimbledon.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — The pity of it all for Sloane Stephens is that for one seemingly momentum-changing game, she played like a fierce and resolute survivor. Dangling on the edge of elimination, she saved five match points against Maria Kirilenko to force a second-set tiebreaker, where she proceeded to hold double set point.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Rosberg Wins Another Mercedes Duel
abstract: Nico Rosberg held off his teammate, Lewis Hamilton, for a Formula One win in Austria; Carl Edwards scored his first Nascar road course victory.
lead_paragraph: Nico Rosberg scored his third victory of the year, winning the Austrian Grand Prix on Sunday and holding off his teammate, Lewis Hamilton.

headline: Spicy Quinoa Salad With Broccoli, Cilantro and Lime
abstract: The grassy flavor of quinoa works well with cilantro in this main-dish salad.
lead_paragraph: I love the versatility of quinoa. It can be the building-block ingredient for a salad, as it is in this main-dish salad, or it can be added to salads in smaller amounts, almost as a garnish. Its grassy flavor marries well with cilantro, itself an herb with a grassy, though more pungent, taste. I added sieved hard-boiled eggs for protein – though you could leave them out if you want to make a vegan version of this dish, and toasted pumpkin seeds for crunch.

headline: Long Unarmed, 2 Generals Will Be Reunited With Their Swords
abstract: The Citywide Monuments Conservation Program is replacing swords stolen from monumental bronze statues in the Bronx and in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The pen might be mightier than the sword for a politician or a journalist, but, except for when it ends a war, not for a general — even for two solitary Civil War sentinels who have been left unarmed in New York City parks for decades.

headline: Chickpea, Quinoa and Celery Salad With Middle Eastern Flavors
abstract: Chickpeas make this salad a substantial and comforting dish for a light supper.
lead_paragraph: It’s the sumac (available in Middle Eastern markets) and the herbs – dill, mint, chives – that give this salad its Middle Eastern accents. I love the texture and flavor of the chickpeas, which make for a substantial and comforting dish. It’s all you need for lunch and makes a delicious light supper. I love abundant, thinly sliced celery in just about any lemony salad; you will appreciate it for its texture as well as its flavor.  Of course, you can use canned chickpeas, but if you have the time, try cooking some dried chickpeas to see how good they taste.

headline: Jazz-and-Constitution Diet Can Keep a Mind Sharp
abstract: Nat Hentoff, who turned 89 this month, is the subject of a new documentary and a book.
lead_paragraph: Early in “The Pleasures of Being Out of Step,” a documentary about the writer, critic and record producer Nat Hentoff that opens on Wednesday, Mr. Hentoff declares that “the Constitution and jazz are my main reasons for being.” That may seem an odd pairing to anyone unfamiliar with the man or his work, but Mr. Hentoff has nurtured those twin passions since the 1940s.

headline: Red Quinoa Salad With Walnuts, Asparagus and Dukkah
abstract: This salad is garnished with steamed asparagus and the Middle Eastern nut and spice mix called dukkah.
lead_paragraph: I had initially envisioned a salad in which the asparagus was cut into short lengths and tossed with the quinoa. But the colorful asparagus got lost in the quinoa, and since I love the look of the bright green asparagus against the red grain (O.K., “pseudograin”), I remade this and  garnished it with the steamed asparagus. The quinoa, tossed with chives, parsley, walnuts and a lemony vinaigrette, is sprinkled with dukkah before serving, a surprising touch.

headline: New Hurdle in Investors’ Class Actions
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: A Supreme Court decision will let corporate defendants defeat some securities fraud claims at the outset, but it didn’t go as far as some business groups hoped.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday made it harder for investors to band together to pursue claims that they were misled when they bought or sold securities. But the justices did not accept a broader challenge, one that could have put an end to most class actions for securities fraud.

headline: Sketching Superman’s Power
abstract: The illustrator John Romita Jr., a decades-long veteran of Marvel Comics, is now making his DC Comics debut. His first assignment: Drawing Superman.
lead_paragraph: The illustrator John Romita Jr., a decades-long veteran of Marvel Comics, is now making his DC Comics debut. His first assignment: Drawing Superman.

headline: Unesco Panel Taps Incan Road, Other Sites, as Worthy of Protection
abstract: The World Heritage Committee under the United Nations has designated 29 new sites as being natural or cultural wonders worthy of protection, including an ancient road that runs through the Andes.
lead_paragraph: At its annual meeting, the World Heritage Committee under the United Nations has so far designated 29 new sites as being natural or cultural wonders worthy of special protection, including the Qhapaq Ñan, or the Andean road system of the Incas.

headline: In Japan, Hundreds of Shareholder Meetings on Same Day
abstract: This year, more than one in three companies traded on the Tokyo Stock Exchange will hold their meetings on Friday. Experts say the practice underscores Japanese companies’ dismissive attitude toward shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Investors who own shares in Japanese corporations might want to clear their calendars next Friday.

headline: A Candidate for Governor Has Both Parties on Alert
abstract: Some Republicans in Colorado say the views of Mr. Tancredo, a former congressman, could energize the state’s Democrats while alienating moderate Republicans and unaffiliated voters.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Tom Tancredo, the firebrand former congressman, Harley-Davidson biker and perennial headache for Colorado’s Republican leaders, was taking fire from all sides last week in the final days of his primary campaign for governor. His rivals were slamming him on the airwaves. Moderate Republicans were warning that Mr. Tancredo’s name on the ballot could doom their chances in crucial races across this swing state.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week Street Style
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: Looks from Milan Men’s Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Looks from Milan Men’s Fashion Week.

headline: ‘We’re actually a unique race of people. And if you go down about the third definition, that’s a people that are bound together that have a common sense of unity, a common sense of history, a common language.’
abstract: TK
lead_paragraph: TK

headline: Wie’s Win Advances Surge by American Women
abstract: Coupled with the recent success of No. 1-ranked Stacy Lewis, Michelle Wie reaching her long-awaited potential at the United States Women’s Open further heightened the profile of American women in the sport.
lead_paragraph: PINEHURST, N.C. — The men’s and women’s United States Opens, held in consecutive weeks at Pinehurst No. 2, could not have produced a more fitting finale. After Martin Kaymer won the men’s title June 15, the last woman standing Sunday was Michelle Wie, the only player in the field to have competed in multiple professional men’s events.

headline: Missoni’s Summer Surf Safari
abstract: Angela Missoni, who started her infatuation with surfers last fall, continued the theme with knit suits and lightweight coats.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Mamma mia, cowabunga. Angela Missoni is in the grips of surf mania. Following the surfer stylings of her fall Missoni collection, the designer continued the theme for spring. ‘‘We started in winter, why not follow him in summer?’’ she asked.

headline: Pro-Russian Rebels in Ukraine Match Government Cease-Fire
abstract: The leader of the self-declared Donetsk People’s Republic said the rebels in eastern Ukraine would match the government’s commitment.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Pro-Russian separatists declared a cease-fire Monday in a surprise move that they said they hoped would lead to a settlement of the conflict in eastern Ukraine.

headline: Stanley Marsh, Cadillac Rancher, Dies at 76, Shadowed by Charges
abstract: Mr. Marsh was known as an eccentric millionaire who commissioned the Cadillac Ranch outside Amarillo, Tex., until he was accused of sexually abusing teenage boys.
lead_paragraph: Stanley Marsh, the proudly eccentric and locally prominent millionaire who was best known for commissioning the public art project known as the Cadillac Ranch outside his hometown, the Texas Panhandle city of Amarillo, but whose reputation was badly tarnished by accusations that he had sexually abused teenage boys, died on June 17 in Amarillo. He was 76.

headline: Homer Happiness Lives Only in Memory
abstract: Since switching to less lively bats and a different ballpark in 2011, offense in college baseball is down, and changes are being considered for the sport’s premier event in Omaha.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — At the College World Series, where home runs are nearing extinction, the soft clink of baseballs bunted off metal bats is again the predominant sound. And that sound is wearing on coaches, players, fans and N.C.A.A. officials.

headline: When Advertising on Facebook Can Be a Waste of Money
abstract: If a business buys ads from Facebook and the ads generate likes from people or accounts who aren’t really interested in the business, advertising dollars have been wasted.
lead_paragraph: In January, we published an interview with a social media marketer, Jeff Gibbard, asking him to assess Facebook’s revamped ad platform. While Mr. Gibbard questioned the value of advertising on Facebook, a reader went even further, commenting: “Until Facebook allows independent third-party auditing of its ads and takes the necessary technical procedures to block ‘ad bots,’ the Facebook platform is valueless and we are staying away from it.”

headline: Official on Korean Soldier Who Killed 5
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Firearms', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Kim Min-Seok, the South Korean defense ministry spokesman, said the armed soldier attempted suicide as his family pleaded with him to surrender after he killed five colleagues.
lead_paragraph: Kim Min-Seok, the South Korean defense ministry spokesman, said the armed soldier attempted suicide as his family pleaded with him to surrender after he killed five colleagues.

headline: Poland’s Prime Minister Says He Won’t Dismiss Officials Caught on Leaked Tapes
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Prime Minister Donald Tusk said the government would focus on uncovering the “criminal gang” that made illegal recordings of ministers having blunt and profane conversations.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland said Monday that he would not dismiss any of the ministers whose bluntly political and occasionally profane conversations were caught on tape in the back rooms of expensive Warsaw restaurants, unless they are caught engaging in illegal behavior.

headline: American Indians in Confederate Territory
abstract: How a company of Odawa, Chippewa and Potawatomi men ended up in the horrific Andersonville prison camp.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of June 18, 1864, Pvt. Payson Wolf trudged through the streets of Petersburg, Va., with other battered and bloodied Union prisoners of war. The captives were herded into an old tobacco barn with hundreds of other bluecoats to await their fate in the hands of Confederate military authorities.

headline: Finding Old Posts on the Facebook Timeline
abstract: Plus, how to paste text from a web page without also getting all the strange formatting.
lead_paragraph: Q. I was scrolling back through my Facebook Timeline in my web browser and noticed some of my previous posts and photos weren’t there. How do I get them all back?

headline: Oracle’s Deal Won’t Do Much for Its Cloud Computing Efforts
abstract: Micros still gets the vast majority of its revenue from sales of less sexy hardware and services, making the deal more of an add-on for Oracle rather than a supercharged foray into cloud computing, Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Oracle’s $5.3 billion deal for Micros Systems provides an uncertain forecast for shareholders in the database giant. Even if it’s the start of a new deal binge by Oracle’s chief, Lawrence J. Ellison, it’s not at a crazy valuation. But Mircos, a longtime partner, is more of an add-on than a way to supercharge Oracle’s effort in cloud computing.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Canali Spring/Summer 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: A Mystery Character in the Story
abstract: Thomas Goetz on an 1890 announcement of a cure for tuberculosis, proclaimed by Robert Koch and covered by Arthur Conan Doyle.
lead_paragraph: As the immortal Sherlock Holmes remarks to Dr. Watson in “A Scandal in Bohemia,” it is a mistake to theorize from incomplete data: “Insensibly one begins to twist facts to suit theories, instead of theories to suit facts.” This wise caution applies equally to world-class scientists and ambitious writers hoping to trim a complicated historical era to fit the standard-issue best-seller mold.

headline: Heartbroken, but Hardly Hopeless
abstract: While the faces of the United States soccer players — and their fans — did not have much color after Sunday’s tie, there is still much life left in this team.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Forget about that last goal. Pretend it never happened, as if that soccer ball never ricocheted off the head of a perfectly positioned Portuguese player and into the United States’ net. Do not dwell on those last 30 seconds of that game on Sunday night in the Amazon that stomped on the throat of an otherwise sublime night.

headline: Scaring Away Black Voters in Mississippi
abstract: Right-wing groups have formed a “voter integrity project’ in response to the news that Thad Cochran is courting black Democratic voters in his runoff with Chris McDaniel.
lead_paragraph: Several right-wing groups have banded together to form a “voter integrity project’ in response to the news that Republican Senator Thad Cochran is courting black Democratic voters in his runoff with the Tea partier Chris McDaniel.

headline: Kerry on Iraq Crisis
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke at a news conference in Baghdad about the future of Iraq, imploring its leaders to unite against ISIS.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke at a news conference in Baghdad about the future of Iraq, imploring its leaders to unite against ISIS.

headline: How to Make Perfect Burgers Indoors
abstract: Sam Sifton shows you how to make juicy hamburgers by cooking in rendered fat in a cast-iron pan.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton shows you how to make juicy hamburgers by cooking in rendered fat in a cast-iron pan.

headline: Deconstructing the Perfect Burger
abstract: How to make a great hamburger? Cook on cast-iron pans and griddles, use an 80-20 ratio of meat to fat, sandwich it on a soft bun and don’t overdress.
lead_paragraph: How to make a great hamburger is a question that has bedeviled the nation for generations, for as long as Americans have had griddles and broilers, for as long as summertime shorts-wearing cooks have gone into the yard to grill.

headline: Brazil vs. Cameroon: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Neymar scored a pair of goals to send Brazil to a 4-1 victory over Cameroon and to the Round of 16 as the winner of Group A.
lead_paragraph: To get first place in the group, Brazil must win, preferably by a few goals to be absolutely certain.

headline: Mosquito Bait
abstract: Is there anything people can eat or drink to cut the odds of mosquito bites?
lead_paragraph: Q. Is there anything people can eat or drink to cut the odds of mosquito bites?

headline: Criticism for Detroit Article With No Black Presence
abstract: The Travel editor will discuss it with her staff.
lead_paragraph: Since Monica Drake became The Times’s travel editor about a year ago, she has tried to broaden and diversify the section’s offerings.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | June 17-23, 2014
abstract: How well did you follow the news this week? Test yourself to see how you do against others taking the quiz.
lead_paragraph: How well did you follow the news this week?

headline: Mexico vs. Croatia: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Mexico wore down Croatia, scored three goals in a 10-minute span and moved on to the Round of 16 with a 3-1 victory.
lead_paragraph: Mexico needs a win or draw to be sure to advance. Croatia must win.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: Food news from Kentucky to Asia.
lead_paragraph: A new painkiller is about to hit the market that the F.D.A. approved despite the recommendations of an agency panel, and doctors are afraid it will be the latest gateway to doctor-sanctioned opioid abuse.

headline: Gallery | An Exhibit of Instagram Photos of Kimye with LiLo, Lorde, Damien Hirst and More
abstract: A new exhibition at W Hotels’ Living Room space in Midtown aims to explore a media landscape where a picture is worth a thousand likes.
lead_paragraph: In this new era, in which a picture is worth a thousand likes (or in the case of Kim Kardashian and Kanye West’s wedding photo, more than two million), it’s easier than ever to peer into the lives of others, even those in the public realm. Now, Liberatum, the self-described “cultural diplomacy organization,” has invited a few big names from the world of New York nightlife to contribute exclusive personal snaps to a monthlong exhibition that opens this Thursday at the recently renovated salon at the W New York, the Living Room. Titled “Tagged,” the show “sets out to explore the new cultural etiquettes that technology has put on the New York scene,” according to Liberatum founder Pablo Ganguli. “With some venues banning photos and others encouraging it, people are still treading the water lightly to determine what is and isn’t appropriate when it comes to mixing social life, photography and technology.”

headline: A High-Living Idealist, Running Guns in 1938
abstract: “Midnight in Europe,” Alan Furst’s latest historical thriller, centers on a Spanish agent in Paris who is trying to route arms to Republican forces.
lead_paragraph: The title of Alan Furst’s latest World War II novel, “Midnight in Europe,” could apply to any of them. But don’t be fooled by its generic sound: Mr. Furst, who has by now approached that era and the dread preceding it from so many different cultural and geographical perspectives, remains at the top of his game. This is another fine addition to his elegant, gripping, interwoven set of novels that will someday form a kaleidoscopic map of European powers forced into desperate alliances as they fight for their lives.

headline: Examining a Scandal Within a Scandal About Emails at the I.R.S.
abstract: With investigations taking another turn, it seems a good time to answer some questions about a developing scandal within a scandal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, John Koskinen, testified before the House Oversight Committee on Monday to answer questions about how two years’ worth of emails sent and received by Lois Lerner, the former official at the center of a growing I.R.S. scandal, could have been destroyed, and why the agency waited until just recently to tell Congress.

headline: In G.E.’s Deal for Alstom, French Interventionism Wins Out
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: After much posturing, the French government and G.E. are both declaring victory.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After nearly two months of battle, both the French government and General Electric can finally declare victory.

headline: Review of Handling of Sandusky Case
abstract: The Pennsylvania special deputy attorney general, H. Geoffrey Moulton Jr., said a review of the handling of the Jerry Sandusky sex abuse case found no evidence that politics had affected the inquiry.
lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvania special deputy attorney general, H. Geoffrey Moulton Jr., said a review of the handling of the Jerry Sandusky sex abuse case found no evidence that politics had affected the inquiry.

headline: Preacher Challenges Pakistani Leaders
abstract: Thousands in Islamabad awaited the return of Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri on Monday, ready to reignite a protest movement, but the Pakistani authorities diverted his plane.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — All the makings of a grand entrance were in place when the preacher and political dramatist Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri boarded an Emirates jet bound for Islamabad: Thousands of his followers awaited his return on Monday, ready to reignite a protest movement that riveted Pakistan for weeks last year.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Gucci Spring/Summer 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Bigger Than Baseball: 25 Million Watch U.S.-Portugal World Cup Match
abstract: The World Cup game drew 18.2 million viewers Sunday evening on ESPN, while another 6.5 million watched on Univision.
lead_paragraph: With an audience of 25 million viewers for Sunday’s game between the United States and Portugal, the World Cup is moving into elite territory as a sports property on American television. Ratings for the game were the highest for any soccer game telecast in America and reached more viewers than events like the N.B.A. finals or the World Series.

headline: Cool at 13, Adrift at 23
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Medicine and Health', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: A study finds that after early adolescence the social status of socially precocious teenagers often plummeted.
lead_paragraph: At 13, they were viewed by classmates with envy, admiration and not a little awe. The girls wore makeup, had boyfriends and went to parties held by older students. The boys boasted about sneaking beers on a Saturday night and swiping condoms from the local convenience store.

headline: Dov Charney, American Apparel Founder, Fights to Get His Job Back
abstract: Mr. Charney, the company’s founder, filed notice with the S.E.C. stating that he would make an effort to seek reinstatement.
lead_paragraph: Dov Charney, the founder and longtime chief executive of American Apparel who was ousted last week by the company’s board, filed a formal notice on Monday indicating that he did not plan to leave quietly.

headline: Stunning New Video View of Swimming Polar Bears
abstract: New video footage reveals polar bears in their watery element.
lead_paragraph: Lest you wonder why federal wildlife conservation agencies include polar bears under the Marine Mammal Protection Act, have a look at this video.

headline: Box Office Boom For ‘All the Way’ as Closing Nears
abstract: The play, starring Bryan Cranston, had its best sales week yet, one week before it is scheduled to close on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: “All the Way,” the Broadway drama about President Lyndon Baines Johnson that won Tony Awards this month for best play and best actor for its star, Bryan Cranston, set an all-time record last week for gross ticket sales by a new play.

headline: Barack Obama in 2001
abstract: In a 2001 interview, a young Barack Obama considers his legacy.
lead_paragraph: In a 2001 interview, a young Barack Obama considers his legacy.

headline: When Ruby Dee met Ossie Davis
abstract: In an interview from 2002, Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee reflect on how they first met acting in a play together.
lead_paragraph: In an interview from 2002, Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee reflect on how they first met acting in a play together.

headline: Maya Angelou’s Earliest Memory
abstract: In an interview from 2010, Maya Angelou describes her earliest childhood memory and how her older brother, Bailey, was her greatest hero.
lead_paragraph: In an interview from 2010, Maya Angelou describes her earliest childhood memory and how her older brother, Bailey, was her greatest hero.

headline: Library of Congress to Display Interviews With Blacks, Noted and Unsung
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Archives and Records', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The huge video archive documents the memories of 2,600 interviewees, including Maya Angelou, Isaac Hayes and Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: Maya Angelou’s earliest childhood memory took place on a train when she was 3 years old. When her brother, Bailey, whom she described as “my black kingdom come,” went to the bathroom, Ms. Angelou thought he had been taken away by a porter. “It scared me to death,” she recounted in a video interview recorded in 2010. “I wasn’t afraid that my mother wouldn’t come back or my father or anyone else. It was always Bailey.”

headline: JetBlue Adds Flat-Bed Seats
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Beds and Bedding']
abstract: JetBlue’s new premium service between New York and Los Angeles, called Mint, is a departure from its egalitarian image.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For the well-heeled traveler flying between New York and Los Angeles, for whom onboard Wi-Fi, roomy leather seats, a Zagat-approved meal and a piping hot washcloth are not enough, airlines have an announcement.

headline: Annoyed With Flying? Don’t Get Mad, Get Advice
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Business Travel']
abstract: Two authors suggest ways to deal with the delays, cancellations and frustrations that are part of being an airline passenger.
lead_paragraph: THE list of things that annoy me when traveling is lengthy.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Iraq, Afghanistan and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Iraq, Afghanistan and India.

headline: Challenged to Tetris by Pint-Size Rivals, and Sparing None
abstract: To pass the time during a flight delay, a TV producer accepts a challenge from a group of children to play Tetris.
lead_paragraph: I’M the guy you want to meet at the airport, since I get all kinds of free drink coupons. I get so many of these things I just give them to fellow passengers. I’m a friendly person, but that’s about all I do to connect with other fliers.

headline: U.S. Tie Leaves Emotions Unsettled
abstract: The United States soccer team and its fans were still sorting through their emotions after a stunning last-second draw with Portugal on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: MANAUS, Brazil — Andy Smith stood among a throng of American fans Sunday night, checking the stopwatch on his smartphone, thinking surely this game would end in ecstatic victory.

headline: Reform Conservatism and Immigration
abstract: A response to William Galston on the right’s reformers and immigration policy.
lead_paragraph: This will hopefully be the week in which I settle all family business — by which I mean that I intend to write the responses to liberal critics of “reform conservatism” than I’ve been promising since long before World Cup season. Having discussed immigration policy in yesterday’s column, I’ll start with that issue, and with William Galston’s Wall Street Journal essay from late last month, which offered praise for the recent reformocon manifesto “Room to Grow” but also suggested that reform conservatives were too often coloring “within the lines” — and in particular, that “if immigration is to today’s Republicans as welfare was to the Democrats of the early 1990s, someone will have to go further.”

headline: Church Rethinks Development Plan; Legal Fight Ensues
abstract: St. Michael’s Episcopal Church in Manhattan had been working with developers since 2008 to build condominium building, but new leadership at the church decided the project was too risky.
lead_paragraph: Seven stained-glass windows more than a story high surround the apse of St. Michael’s Episcopal Church at the corner of Amsterdam Avenue and 99th Street in Manhattan. The panels, created a century ago by Louis Comfort Tiffany, depict in vivid hues the celestial triumph of the archangel for whom the 206-year-old church is named.

headline: Mormons Expel Founder of Group Seeking Priesthood for Women
keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Kate Kelly had gained national attention for pushing the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints to open the male-only priesthood to women.
lead_paragraph: Kate Kelly, who unsettled the Mormon Church by founding a movement to advocate opening the male-only priesthood to women, was excommunicated by her bishop and his two counselors in Virginia on Monday.

headline: I Had Alice in Wonderland Syndrome
abstract: A daughter’s admission that during a bad headache things around her looked smaller led to a discovery of a rare syndrome in one family.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, my 10-year-old daughter, Paulina, was suffering from a bad headache right before bedtime. She went to lie down and I sat beside her, stroking her head. After a few minutes, she looked up at me and said, “Everything in the room looks really small.”

headline: In Performance | Margo Seibert
abstract: Margo Seibert, with Chris Fenwick on piano, sings “Raining” from the Broadway musical “Rocky,” at the Winter Garden Theater.
lead_paragraph: Margo Seibert, with Chris Fenwick on piano, sings “Raining” from the Broadway musical “Rocky,” at the Winter Garden Theater.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Happenings | A Secret Chalet Off Hollywood Boulevard Where the L.A. Art World Gathers
abstract: Just off the Walk of Fame there’s an airy new space, conceived by the artist Piero Golia, for the L.A. art community to let its hair down.
lead_paragraph: Around the corner from a blighted stretch of the Hollywood Walk of Fame, through a back entrance that opens onto a seedy parking lot, there’s a space that feels rather like an alpine chalet. Created by the artist Piero Golia, the unlikely oasis is a salon for those in the know located in the storage of L.A.C.E. (Los Angeles Contemporary Exhibitions), an artist-run space that has been operating since the late 1970s.

headline: Vitamin D Screening Not Backed by Expert Panel
abstract: The United States Preventive Services Task Force decided not to recommend routine testing for vitamin D levels in part because it was not clear whether otherwise healthy adults with low levels actually benefit from taking supplements of the vitamin.
lead_paragraph: A government health panel on Monday chose not to endorse widespread screening for vitamin D levels in healthy adults, despite research suggesting that a majority of Americans may be deficient in the vitamin.

headline: A Win for Latin America’s Middle Class
abstract: The arrival in Brazil of more than 200,000 fans from Latin America exemplifies one of the region’s most profound shifts: the rise of the middle class.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — To fulfill his dream of watching Colombia play in the World Cup, Marco Triana Lozada, an engineer from Bogotá, cobbled together savings to travel to Brazil this month. But to avoid spending money on hotels, he and his friends have traversed the country at night on buses to watch Colombia play, even opting to stay in tents at campsites.

headline: Oral Vaccine for Cholera Found Effective in Africa
abstract: A study found that two doses of an oral vaccine provided 86 percent protection against cholera in Guinea.
lead_paragraph: A new, inexpensive, easy-to-use cholera vaccine that is stockpiled for emergencies worked very well during a cholera outbreak in Africa, Doctors Without Borders reported recently.

But more than anything about these youths themselves, the latest foray into generational forecasting shows that generations are often essentially marketing opportunities.

lead_paragraph: And now let’s raise a cold one — a double vodka, I think — to the wackiest bromance in summer comedy. No, not Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum in “22 Jump Street.” That’s kid stuff. I mean Mikhail Baryshnikov and Willem Dafoe.

abstract: For better or worse, the Supreme Court’s decision means that securities litigation is here to say, says Steven M. Davidoff in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: The plaintiffs’ lawyers will live to sue another day.

headline: The Collections | The Top 10 Attractions at Design Miami/Basel
abstract: These noteworthy projects from up-and-coming talent, introduced at this year’s fair, are worth a closer look.
lead_paragraph: The Design Miami/Basel fair — the annual European companion to Design Miami in Basel, Switzerland — has a single objective: facilitating the sale of expensive design objects to wealthy collectors. Yet much like its neighbor, Art Basel, the show can also serve as a resource for enthusiasts and curious window shoppers, who come to see and enjoy the works on view, or survey what’s happening in design now (lots of experimentation with everyday materials, apparently). Without the placards or checklists one would normally find in a gallery or museum, though, it would have been entirely possible for non-experts to meander in and out of the fair’s 50-something booths this year without knowing for sure what’s old and what’s new, or which pieces represent real breakthroughs in materials and process. There were many more novel contemporary works on view than ever before, balancing out the usual glut of 20th-century icons, but it wasn’t necessarily obvious unless you scoured the $30 show catalog.

headline: From Roars to Rhythmic Mallets, a Day for Savoring Exploration
abstract: The Bang on a Can Marathon at the Winter Garden focused on recent work that has yet to settle into the cultural bloodstream.
lead_paragraph: Displaced last year by construction, the annual Bang on a Can Marathon was back at the glass-enclosed Winter Garden at Brookfield Place on Sunday. This meant the event’s singular vibe was back, too: both attentive and easygoing, art and commerce.

headline: Microsoft Makes Bet Quantum Computing Is Next Breakthrough
abstract: A Microsoft-funded venture is aimed at designing computers that can solve problems in fields as diverse as chemistry, material science, artificial intelligence and code-breaking.
lead_paragraph: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — Modern computers are not unlike the looms of the industrial revolution: They follow programmed instructions to weave intricate patterns. With a loom, you see the result in a cloth or carpet. With a computer, you see it on an electronic display.

headline: Longing Far Above Her Station, Simply but Achingly
abstract: Different ballerinas performed the “Giselle” title role in distinctive ways in performances last week at the Metropolitan Opera House.
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater’s performances of “Giselle” at the Metropolitan Opera House last week featured several debuts in the title role and saved the best for last, with Saturday’s return of Alina Cojocaru (who stars in “Swan Lake” this week at the Met). In every case, the interpretation was simpler than the ornate, fervent, virtuosic rendition of Diana Vishneva on opening night. But there are different ways of being simple.

headline: If It’s Broke, Reality TV Can Fix It
abstract: With the debuts of the E! series “Botched” and the Lifetime series “Abby’s Studio Rescue,” the Fix-It TV genre is growing.
lead_paragraph: Watch enough reality television, and one conclusion is inescapable: We can’t do anything right. Run a restaurant. Operate a bar. Manage a hotel.

lead_paragraph: The new Early Music Festival: NYC, which ended last week, gives reason for cautious hope. You can’t be categorical about its prospects one way or the other, because several more or less similar ventures have come and gone in recent years.

headline: At These Hospitals, Recovery Is Rare, but Comfort Is Not
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health', 'Long-Term Care Insurance']
abstract: At long-term acute care facilities, the point is rarely recovery. It’s to keep going, regardless of the cost. But misery doesn’t define such places.
lead_paragraph: NEW BRITAIN, CONN. — Propped up in a hospital bed, a 75-year-old man with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig’s disease, must make an agonizing decision. Should he keep struggling until the illness inevitably kills him, dependent on a ventilator, unable to walk or eat or move? Or should he choose a day and a time to have the ventilator disconnected, and die?

headline: A Few Hot Months of Solidarity and Violence
abstract: Stanley Nelson’s “Freedom Summer,” on the PBS “American Experience” series, looks back at the 1964 campaign for voter registration and education in Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: The PBS documentary “Freedom Summer” won’t make many lists of the top television programs of the year, but it’s hard to imagine two hours better spent in front of a screen.

headline: A Sunken Kingdom Re-emerges
abstract: The floods and storms that battered Britain earlier this year radically changed the way archaeologists interpret the landscape.
lead_paragraph: BORTH, WALES — There is a poem children in Wales learn about the sunken kingdom of Cantre’r Gwaelod, swallowed by the sea and drowned forever after. On a quiet night, legend has it, one can hear the kingdom’s church bells ringing.

headline: Diplomatic Note Promises Immunity From Iraqi Law for U.S. Advisory Troops
keywords: ['Diplomatic Immunity', 'United States International Relations', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The immunity, granted in a diplomatic note from the Iraqi government, is similar to a guarantee rejected by the Obama administration in 2011.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said on Monday that it has accepted from the Iraqi government the same sort of immunity agreement for newly dispatched Special Operations troops that it refused to accept in 2011, when it opted to withdraw all American troops from Iraq rather than keep a residual force behind.

headline: Herpes Infected ‘Since Before We Were Human’
abstract: New research says that both oral and genital herpes have been infecting humans and our ancestors for longer than previously thought.
lead_paragraph: About two-thirds of people are infected with one of two herpes simplex viruses, oral (HSV-1) or genital (HSV-2). New research says both viruses have been infecting humans and our ancestors for longer than previously thought. HSV-1 has been infecting hominids since before they split from the chimpanzee lineage six million years ago, a new study says. HSV-2 was introduced more recently, the researchers said, making the jump from chimpanzees to human ancestors about 1.6 million years ago.

headline: Brazil Romps Past Cameroon and Into Knockout Rounds
abstract: Brazil, which has not played with the precision and dominance that many had hoped for, nevertheless moved on to the next round with a convincing win.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — An anxious nation and its capital exhaled on Monday. Their beloved national soccer team, which has not played with the precision and dominance that many had hoped for in the World Cup, nevertheless moved on to the next round with a convincing win.

headline: Girl, 14, Is Stabbed Near a Bronx School
abstract: The stabbing, near the Richard R. Green Educational Campus in Williamsbridge, was the second close to a Bronx school in less than a week.
lead_paragraph: A 14-year-old girl was stabbed and seriously wounded on Monday afternoon near a junior high school in the Bronx, the authorities said.

headline: Still Exerting a Hold on Science
abstract: A businessman who was interested in a solution to gravity ended up contributing significantly to better understanding it. But it remains a force that confounds scientists.
lead_paragraph: Not long after the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, while the world was reckoning with the specter of nuclear energy, a businessman named Roger Babson was worrying about another of nature’s forces: gravity.

headline: Where Personal Memories Take Root
abstract: A new study lends weight to the notion that every memory of a personal experience is spread out across many neurons in the hippocampus, not stored in a single neuron in that region of the brain.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to forming memories that involve recalling a personal experience, neuroscientists are of two minds. Some say that each memory is stored in a single neuron in a region of the brain called the hippocampus. But a new study is lending weight to the theory of neuroscientists who believe that every memory is spread out, or distributed, across many neurons in that part of the brain.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — One of Monet’s dreamy paintings depicting the water lily pond in his fabled garden at Giverny that failed to sell at Christie’s four years ago, caused a bidding war at Sotheby’s here on Monday night.

headline: Sounds of Danger Disrupt Crabs’ Dinner
abstract: When exposed to the sounds of preying fish, mud crabs are less likely to eat, a study finds.
lead_paragraph: Mud crabs don’t have ears, but they can still detect and react to noises. When exposed to sounds made by preying fish, the crabs were less likely to feed on their own meals, researchers at Northeastern University reported last week in The Proceedings of the Royal Society B. Listening for danger is a critical part of the crab’s survival strategy that could be hindered by increasing ocean noise, the scientists concluded.

headline: Don’t Turn Up Your Nose at the City in Summer
abstract: Sure, New York reeks in the heat. But it’s all useful data — so breathe.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK CITY has always had a challenging relationship with odor, which given its density, could hardly be otherwise. And as summer gets going, so does the season of smell.

abstract: Dissatisfaction with the president’s conduct of foreign policy has shot up among members of both parties in the last month, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
lead_paragraph: Dissatisfaction with President Obama’s conduct of foreign policy has shot up among both Republicans and Democrats in the past month, even though a slim majority supports his recent decision to send military advisers to Iraq to confront the growing threat from militants there, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: College Group Run for Profit Reaches Deal for U.S. Cash
keywords: ['For-Profit Schools', 'Student Loans', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Grants (Corporate and Foundation)', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: Corinthian Colleges, long under government scrutiny, will receive $16 million and produce a transitional operating plan, outlining which schools it will sell and which it will phase out.
lead_paragraph: Moving to head off a cash shortfall that would disrupt classes for its 72,000 students, Corinthian Colleges announced on Monday that it had reached an agreement with the federal Department of Education that would allow it to continue operating, at least temporarily.

headline: Palestinian Freed in 2011 Is Charged by Israel in a Killing
abstract: Ziad Awad and his son were charged in the death of an Israeli police commander in the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian man who was among the prisoners released in 2011 in exchange for an abducted Israeli soldier was charged Monday along with his son in the April killing of an Israeli police commander as he drove to a Passover Seder in a West Bank settlement.

headline: In Wimbledon Lottery, Lucky Losers Win a Second Chance
abstract: The six highest seeds who lost in the final round of qualifying were put in a random draw for four spots that became available in men’s singles.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Luck in tennis is most commonly associated with balls that hit the net cord and dribble over, or shots that hit the racket frame and land square on the line. But there is no luck in tennis quite as important as the luck of the draw.

headline: A Fired Banker and Monroe Capital’s Public Suit
abstract: Monroe Capital claims that Warren Woo, a former executive at the company, stole sensitive information to help start Breakaway Capital, a new private investment firm.
lead_paragraph: When Warren Woo, a deal maker at UBS, left the Swiss bank in 2007 to start his own firm, he named his family office Breakaway Capital.

headline: Mavericks Could Fracture a G.O.P. Senate Majority
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: The election of Tea Party loyalists could expand the ranks of Republican senators who are willing to defy the party leadership.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fear of losing a seat to a Democrat because of a Tea Party upset is one reason congressional Republicans are warily watching Tuesday’s Mississippi Senate runoff and other primary challenges to incumbents. But it is not the sole reason, and perhaps not the most important one, for Republicans this election cycle.

headline: Felix Dennis, 67, Flamboyant Builder of Magazine Empire, Dies
abstract: A roaring lover of money, women, drugs, trees, cars and later in life, poetry, Mr. Dennis built a magazine empire and fortune on being able to spot and exploit budding trends.
lead_paragraph: Felix Dennis, a flamboyant, boastfully profligate, immensely successful British businessman who built a publishing empire that included Maxim, America’s most successful young men’s lifestyle magazine, died on Sunday at his home in Dorsington, Stratford-upon-Avon, England. He was 67.

headline: F.B.I. Cracks Down on Sex Trafficking
abstract: The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said that in the past week law enforcement authorities had arrested 281 pimps and recovered 168 child prostitutes in a sex trafficking sting.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, on Monday said that in the past week law enforcement authorities had arrested 281 pimps and recovered 168 child prostitutes in a nationwide sex trafficking sting. The arrests and recoveries were made in 106 cities, and roughly 10 percent of the prostitutes had been missing from child protective services, the authorities said. In Phoenix, 21 pimps were apprehended, and in Denver 18 prostitutes were recovered, the highest numbers in the operation. More than a dozen children were recovered in other cities, including Chicago and Cleveland.

headline: A Rockefeller Known Not for Wealth but for His Efforts to Help
abstract: Richard Rockefeller, who died on June 13, devoted himself to a half-dozen causes, among them healing the wounds of post-traumatic stress disorder, curing sleeping sickness in Africa and saving the seas.
lead_paragraph: POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y. — As a late afternoon sun tinted the room in gold, the children and grandchildren of David Rockefeller, the banker and philanthropist, gathered around a long table this month for a dinner of scallops and vegetables and toasted his 99th birthday.

headline: Massachusetts: Men Get 3 Years for Theft From Marathon Fund
abstract: Two brothers convicted of filing a false $2 million claim to the Boston Marathon victims’ compensation fund using the name of a long-dead aunt were sentenced Monday.
lead_paragraph: Two brothers convicted of filing a false $2 million claim to the Boston Marathon victims’ compensation fund were sentenced Monday to three years in jail plus 468 hours of community service to help amputees and people with brain injuries. Judge Jeffrey A. Locke of Suffolk County Superior Court gave Branden Mattier, 23, and Domunique Grice, 28, a choice of six years in jail or three years in jail, after which they would serve six hours of community service every other Saturday for three years. The judge said the service could include building ramps for people who are handicapped, serving as an aide in a rehabilitation facility or changing bedpans.

headline: On Balance, a Good Ruling on Emissions
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Clean Air Act', 'Editorials', 'Global Warming', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: The Supreme Court preserved the government’s ability to confront global warming, and pointed out that the Clean Air Act doesn’t meet modern needs.
lead_paragraph: The Clean Air Act is a complex and often confusing piece of legislation, especially when it comes to confronting the challenges of global warming, which were not fully understood when the original law was passed in 1970.

headline: Dean Foods Receives a Subpoena in an Investigation Into Mickelson’s Trades
abstract: The food company has been asked to supply documents to the investigation involving the golfer Phil Mickelson and the gambler William T. Walters, according to people briefed on the matter.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities are seeking information from Dean Foods as part of an investigation into well-timed trades placed by the championship golfer Phil Mickelson and the well-known sports gambler William T. Walters.

headline: Bedouin Trackers Hunting for Clues to Kidnapped Boys
abstract: A specialized team of 50 is among some 1,000 soldiers conducting a sweeping search for three missing Israeli teenagers.
lead_paragraph: BEIT KAHIL, WEST BANK — Maj. Mohammed Mazarib of the Israel Defense Forces ducked into an old stone hut on a hillside above a riverbed here Monday afternoon, quickly determining that footprints inside belonged to soldiers who had beat him there. He nonetheless drew his rifle and shone its spotlight into a hole on the far side of the hut, then grabbed a stick to poke around.

lead_paragraph: This short film celebrates the “Pink Helmet Posse,” three 6-year-old girls who share an unusual passion: skateboarding.

headline: Mississippi Race Points to Appeal of Partisanship
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Midterm Elections (2014)']
abstract: Tuesday’s Republican Senate runoff in Mississippi has sent a message to incumbents in Congress: It is no longer enough to quietly represent your constituents. You have to join the partisan fray.
lead_paragraph: FLOWOOD, Miss. — Regardless of who wins Tuesday’s unpredictable Republican Senate runoff in Mississippi, the fracas has sent a message to incumbents in Congress: It is no longer enough to be a diligent member, quietly representing your constituents’ interests. You have to join the partisan fray.

headline: ‘Gnarly in Pink’
abstract: This short film celebrates the “Pink Helmet Posse,” three 6-year-old girls who share an unusual passion: skateboarding.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, when passing by a skate park in Encinitas, Calif., near San Diego, we were delighted to find three little girls skateboarding in pink tutus and helmets. We immediately decided to tell their story – in a documentary style as playful and eclectic as our subjects.

headline: In Iraq’s Sectarian Violence, a Show of Each Side’s Worst
abstract: Iraqi police were said to have killed scores of Sunni insurgents, while militants turned over the bodies of Shiite civilians they had killed, only to bomb the cemetery during their funerals, according to one account.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Sectarian violence in Iraq on Monday showed both sides in the conflict at their brutal worst, as Iraqi police officers were reported to have killed scores of Sunni insurgent prisoners along a highway in the south, and militants in the north turned over the bodies of 15 Shiite civilians they had killed, including women and children, only to bomb the cemetery during their funerals, according to one account.

headline: Alabama: Police Chief to Step Down
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Mayor Todd Strange of Montgomery said Monday that Chief Kevin J. Murphy of the police would retire amid allegations of mismanagement.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Todd Strange of Montgomery said Monday that Chief Kevin J. Murphy of the police would retire amid allegations of mismanagement. Mayor Strange said officials had received complaints about Chief Murphy, and a city inquiry found evidence of “abusive supervision.” Chief Murphy acknowledged that he was “strict” but denied mistreating employees. Chief Murphy will remain on administrative leave for several months before retiring. He has been on leave for much of June after his twin brother, who was facing a felony charge following an automobile accident, committed suicide.

headline: More Egyptian Injustice

lead_paragraph: The conviction of three journalists by an Egyptian court on Monday for doing their jobs is the latest effort by the country’s military-backed rulers to crush all dissent. The alarming verdict sends a chilling and intimidating message not just to other journalists working in the country but to Egyptian citizens as well.

headline: Mexico Finds Itself Knee-Deep in Victory

headline: Brazil: Polio Virus Detected in Sewage
abstract: For the first time since 1994, the polio virus has been detected in Brazil, the World Health Organization said Monday.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since 1994, the polio virus has been detected in Brazil, the World Health Organization said Monday. The virus — minute amounts of which can be detected — was found in a sewage sample from an airport near Campinas, in southeastern Brazil. It was collected in March and matched a strain recently found in Equatorial Guinea on the central African coast. There are no reports of any cases of paralysis; for every child paralyzed by polio, health authorities estimate that 200 more are carrying and shedding the virus with few or no symptoms. Because about 95 percent of Brazilian children are immunized against polio, the W.H.O. says it is very unlikely that the virus will spread widely and has not suggested any restrictions on travel to or from the country.

headline: Egypt: Conviction in Sectarianism Case
abstract: A court in the city of Minya convicted a Christian reporter of promoting sectarianism and sentenced him to five years in prison.
lead_paragraph: A court in the city of Minya on Monday convicted a Christian reporter of promoting sectarianism and sentenced him to five years in prison. Egypt’s flagship state newspaper Al Ahram said that the reporter, Bishoy Armia, was charged with communicating with an American television station “in order to depict Egyptian Christians as victims of discrimination” and thus “instigate sectarianism.” The newspaper said that the reporter had converted to Christianity and that his former name was Mohamed Hegazy el-Sayed.
