He was a leader and the kind of inspirational force that every winning squad needs amid the crucible of playoff pressure. On Tuesday, he will be at the N.H.L. award ceremony in Las Vegas, where he is a finalist for the Masterton Trophy, presented to the player who most exemplifies perseverance, sportsmanship and dedication to hockey.

headline: Searching for Answers in Very Old DNA
abstract: The geneticist Svante Paabo created his own research field by sequencing the genomes of ancient humans.
lead_paragraph: As he puts it in the subtitle of his memoir, “Neanderthal Man,” Svante Paabo goes in search of lost genomes. Dr. Paabo, a 59-year-old Swede who leads his own laboratory at the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology in Leipzig, Germany, was the first to extract and sequence the genomes of the ancient humans called Neanderthals and Denisovans, and to compare them with those of modern humans. Genes, and the stories they tell, are texts he reads.

headline: Bipartisan Report Tallies High Toll on Economy From Global Warming
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'United States Economy', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Corporations']
abstract: Treasury secretaries dating to the Nixon years backed a new report predicting a heavy loss of coastal properties, a shift of farming northward, and dangerous outdoor conditions because of climate change.
lead_paragraph: More than a million homes and businesses along the nation’s coasts could flood repeatedly before ultimately being destroyed. Entire states in the Southeast and the Corn Belt may lose much of their agriculture as farming shifts northward in a warming world. Heat and humidity will probably grow so intense that spending time outside will become physically dangerous, throwing industries like construction and tourism into turmoil.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (TruTV) MOTOR CITY MASTERS Ten car designers show off their expertise and creativity as they divide into teams to build two fully functional (though not street-legal) concept cars in each episode; challenges focus on technology, interiors, body trim and functionality. Each round will be judged by Jean Jennings, former editor in chief of Automobile Magazine; the car designer Harald Belker; and a celebrity, with designers eliminated one by one until only two remain for the final build-off. The winner will receive a 2014 Camaro Z28 and $100,000, and be named a brand ambassador for General Motors. Brooke Burns (above, far left, with Ms. Jennings and Mr. Belker) hosts; Jesse Metcalfe is the guest judge in this series premiere.

headline: Mapping the Risk of Bird Flu’s Spread

headline: Death Penalty Overturned for Wife Who Killed Abuser
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Domestic Violence', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]

lead_paragraph: The Chinese Supreme People’s Court has overturned a death sentence imposed on a woman who killed her husband after years of abuse, in a decision women’s rights advocates and death penalty opponents hailed as a major step forward for women and the rule of law in China. The court ruled that the case must be retried.

headline: Green Bean Salad With Lime Vinaigrette and Red Quinoa
abstract: Red quinoa is a colorful contrast to the green beans in a salad that is full of texture.
lead_paragraph: This is a green bean salad with quinoa as opposed to a quinoa salad with green beans. Red quinoa is secondary to the green beans here. The two ingredients provide a colorful contrast. The salad is alive with texture, the crisp-tender green beans with the crunchy almonds and the chewy, comforting quinoa. The flavors here are Mexican: lime juice, chile, cilantro, white or red onion. It’s simple to put together but the sum is complex.

headline: Mediterranean Cucumber and Yogurt Salad With Red or Black Quinoa
abstract: Red quinoa adds color and substance to a typically Mediterranean mix of yogurt and finely diced cucumber.
lead_paragraph: The idea of embellishing a yogurt soup or salad with quinoa comes from Deborah Madison, who uses black quinoa in a brilliant recipe for a soup in her book “Vegetable Literacy.” I used red quinoa to add texture, color and substance to this typical Mediterranean combination – finely diced cucumber, garlic, and thick plain yogurt. Use mint or dill, or a combination, and make sure to dice the cucumber very small.

Roosevelt give speeches from the House floor. headline: In Kodak’s Hometown, Memory and History
abstract: Alex Webb and his wife, Rebecca Norris Webb, went to Rochester to document the fabled, if worn, home of Kodak. They returned to explore a city with a rich history and culture.
lead_paragraph: Alex Webb and Rebecca Norris Webb, a husband and wife photography team, documented Rochester after Eastman Kodak’s bankruptcy in their new book, “Memory City,” published by Radius Books. Previously they published “Violet Isle,” a volume on modern-day Cuba. Ms. Norris Webb’s book “My Dakota” was featured on Lens in  2012, while Mr. Webb’s book “The Suffering of Light” was featured on Lens in 2011. He is a member of Magnum Photos. Their conversation with James Estrin has been edited.

headline: When Advance Directives Are Ignored
keywords: ['Elder Care', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies']
abstract: Medical personnel are more likely to pay attention to one type of advance directive, a study finds.
lead_paragraph: In the final two years of her mother’s life, Lisa McAllister started carrying copies of her mother’s do-not-resuscitate and power-of-attorney forms in her purse and her car. Her mother was cycling between the hospital, assisted living and rehab — “a round robin of craziness,” said Ms. McAllister, a retired copy editor — and was clear about not wanting to be kept alive with substantially diminished quality of life.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on the drone memo, an emissions ruling, Israel’s hunt, high-seas slavery and jailed journalists.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration made public a memo explaining the rationale behind a 2011 drone strike that killed an American citizen, Anwar al-Awlaki, in Yemen, The New York Times reports. “But the rationale provides little confidence that the lethal action was taken with real care,” the editorial board writes. “Instead, the memo turns out to be a slapdash pastiche of legal theories — some based on obscure interpretations of British and Israeli law — that was clearly tailored to the desired result.” The board remains unpersuaded that Mr. Awlaki’s due-process rights were given proper consideration. “More documents must be made public. The public is still in the dark on too many vital questions.”

Then she found herself in the middle of one of the most riveting trials in years, accused of illegally intercepting voice mails and other crimes, alongside her husband and her former deputy, who it turned out, was also her lover.

headline: Q. and A.: Michael Tien on Why He Thinks Occupy Central Is a Mistake
abstract: Michael Tien, a leader of the pro-establishment New People’s Party, says democrats could forfeit an opportunity to achieve a more accountable government.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong democracy activists and many “pan-democratic” lawmakers are pushing for new rules for the 2017 election for the territory’s leader, the chief executive, under which any candidate who collects a certain number of signatures can get on the ballot. In the face of opposition from the central government in Beijing, they’re putting their support to the test this month, conducting an informal referendum to gauge public support. So far more than 730,000 votes have been cast in the 10-day poll, and its organizers have vowed to occupy Hong Kong’s central business district in protest if Beijing insists on an electoral system that limits the ballot to its approved candidates.

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft Sees Quantum Computing as Technology’s Next Frontier
abstract: The company’s new venture is aimed at designing fast computers that can solve a variety of problems by exploiting the weird physical properties of subatomic particles.
lead_paragraph: Modern computers are not unlike the looms of the industrial revolution, John Markoff reports: They follow programmed instructions to weave intricate patterns. With a loom, you see the result in a cloth or carpet. With a computer, you see it on an electronic display.

lead_paragraph: Chinese state media on Tuesday defended the spread of Confucius Institutes worldwide, lashing back at a recent call for North American universities to rethink their links with the cultural and language programs, which are backed by the Chinese government.

headline: Consumers Will Spend More on Health Care in 2015, Report Predicts

lead_paragraph: Growth in health care spending is expected to tick upward next year, in part because consumers who delayed treatment during the economic downturn are now seeking care they postponed, according to a report released on Tuesday.

headline: Tangled Passages
abstract: Long, convoluted sentences are a disservice to harried readers. We don’t have to use See-Spot-run syntax, but we should do the hard work of ironing out our sentences so readers don’t have to.
lead_paragraph: As we’ve often noted, long, convoluted sentences are a disservice to harried readers, who may be scanning the paper on the subway or checking their phone in the checkout line. We don’t have to use See-Spot-run syntax, but we should do the hard work of ironing out our sentences so readers don’t have to.

headline: Morning Agenda: Monitor for Credit Suisse Named
abstract: A regulator is close to picking a corporate monitor for Credit Suisse. | The dismissal of American Apparel’s chief raises corporate-governance questions. | The Supreme Court erects new hurdles to class actions for securities fraud. | Three traders leave Steven A. Cohen’s family office.
lead_paragraph: Neil Barofsky, an old foe of the 2008 bank bailouts, has managed to secure a familiar role: watchdog for one of the world’s biggest banks, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. New York State’s financial regulator is said to be close to picking Mr. Barofsky, a former federal prosecutor, as the corporate monitor for Credit Suisse after the bank’s guilty plea to helping American clients evade taxes. Credit Suisse agreed to hire a monitor as part of a related settlement. Separately, a monitor was also installed late last year at BNP Paribas, the giant French bank suspected of violating sanctions provisions.

lead_paragraph: HATTIESBURG, Miss. — With an unusual assist from African-American voters and other Democrats who feared his opponent, Senator Thad Cochran on Tuesday beat back a spirited challenge from State Senator Chris McDaniel, triumphing in a Republican runoff and defeating the Tea Party in the state where the movement’s hopes were bright.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: It’s Valentine’s Day at the Litch
abstract: Love is not for the meek.
lead_paragraph: Season 2, Episode 6 It’s Valentine’s Day, and love is in the air at the Litch. Crazy, complicated prison love, making it not so much different from love everywhere else. This episode has an almost giddy looseness to it, with dialogue and scenes bleeding into one another – from prison staff into inmates, from Litchfield into Larry’s Brooklyn (Larry – “my sweet, kind, unfocused fiancé,” as Piper describes him). The looseness conveys the messiness of the business at hand – as do the closeups of inmates giving their definitions of love to an off-camera interviewer. (Who turns out to be Piper, with an interest in interviewing that is somewhat duplicitous. More on that below, and while it’s not really much of a spoiler, this is probably a good place to issue the standard spoiler alert.)

headline: Sperm Donation Puts a New Layer on an Old Friendship
abstract: Becoming the sperm donor for my friend and her wife is changing our friendship, but we’re learning (the hard way) that it’s strong enough to hold.
lead_paragraph: For years, my friend Tori and I have had a standing weekly dinner date. We’ve been known to close down a restaurant or two during these epic evenings, gabbing about nothing and everything, all over a glass or three of wine. Tori’s wife, Kelly, often joins us too but I suspect these are mostly on the nights she would like her partner home at a reasonable hour.

headline: Improving Article Accessibility

headline: You Should Have Been a Doctor?
abstract: When a chart of wage data went viral, it may have revealed Americans’ anxieties about our jobs, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, a user named Dan Lin posted this chart to Reddit. It depicts the average yearly salary for 820 different jobs in America, based on 2013 data. The chart quickly made the media rounds — and the way it’s been interpreted may tell us something about how we look at jobs and the economy today.

headline: Rise in Home Prices Is Slowing, and That’s a Good Thing
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', "Standard & Poor's Case-Shiller Home Price Index", 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']

lead_paragraph: The latest readings on United States home prices are the latest confirmation of a slowdown in that area: Prices are still rising in most cities, but much more slowly than they were a few months ago. And that’s news we should cheer.

headline: Beijing Company Drops Objection to ‘Transformers’ Film

Instead, it said it was now blaming “a third party.'’

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']

headline: On Wellness | A Summer Workout From a Personal Trainer to the Fashion Set
abstract: Will Torres talks T through an at-home summer training session based on basic gym-class moves and amped up with a weighted bag of sand.
lead_paragraph: Squats, push-ups, lunges, sit-ups: these are the physical drills most of us have been familiar with since elementary school gym class. And according to Will Torres — the personal trainer behind Willspace whose clientele includes Calvin Klein, Julia Restoin-Roitfeld, Andy Cohen and the model Ashley Smith — they’re the basis to achieving your ideal body. That may sound like an overly simplistic notion, especially in this era of hybridized fitness routines, but at Torres’s intimate West Village studio, it’s the focus on precision and consistency that render these timeless workouts effective. “There’s no point in progressing to a new exercise if you haven’t perfected fundamental movements like hinging and torque,” Torres says. “And you don’t need a lot of equipment.”

headline: Sympathy for the Trustafarians
abstract: It’s the political economy, stupid.
lead_paragraph: A number of people have asked me to comment on Greg Mankiw’s defense of inherited wealth. It’s a strange piece, oddly disconnected from the real concerns about patrimonial capitalism. But let me focus on two key problems with Mankiw’s analysis – one purely economic, one involving political economy.

headline: Scoop Shops, Snack Bars, Soda Fountains: Share Your Ice Cream Photos

headline: Free-Agent Axis Tilts From Anthony to James
abstract: The move will allow LeBron James to explore opportunities with other teams and puts leverage on the Heat to improve their roster.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony enjoyed the unique privilege of being the N.B.A.'s most coveted free agent for a little more than 36 hours. That ended Tuesday morning when it was revealed that LeBron James had informed the Miami Heat through his agent, Rich Paul, that he intended to exercise the early termination option on his contract and become a free agent July 1.

headline: Daunting Path to Publication
abstract: In “The Most Dangerous Book: The Battle for James Joyce’s ‘Ulysses,’ ” Kevin Birmingham explores censorship.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Birmingham’s new book about the long censorship fight over James Joyce’s “Ulysses” braids eight or nine good stories into one mighty strand. It’s about women’s rights and heroic female editors, about World War I, about anarchism and modernism, about tenderness and syphilis, about how literature can bend an era’s consciousness, about moral panic and about the Lost Generation and the tent it pitched at Sylvia Beach’s Paris bookstore. It isolates a great love story, that of Joyce and Nora Barnacle, one that comes with a finger-burning side order of some of the most cheerfully filthy correspondence in literary history.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Keeps Jennifer Lopez, Keith Urban and Harry Connick Jr.

headline: Islamic Extremists Pose New Risks for Religious Minorities in Iraq
abstract: A small sect in northern Iraq, along with Christian minorities, faces existential threats with the rise of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: The incursion of Islamic extremists in Nineveh province, in northern Iraq, is bad for a lot of people, but perhaps no group has more to lose than a minority religious group known as the Yazidis.

headline: M. Patmos’s Sustainable Shades for Selima
abstract: The knitwear designer and the eyewear company team up for glasses and sunglasses handmade in Paris from naturally shed water buffalo horn.
lead_paragraph: Marcia Patmos’s women’s wear line M.Patmos may be known for its innovative cashmere knitwear and casual-chic separates, but the brand is equally noteworthy for its commitment to sustainability: Patmos sources organic fibers when possible and employs women’s artisan collectives around the globe. Now, the designer has joined forces with the eyewear mainstay Selima Optique for a limited-edition frame shape — available in an optical or sunglass version — made with water buffalo horn that has been naturally shed by the animals. Each pair is hand-cut in a family-owned atelier in Paris.

headline: Board Cites Confusion by Crew in Air Crash
abstract: The Asiana pilots hit the sea wall just short of the runway in San Francisco because they did not understand crucial details of the cockpit automation, the National Transportation Safety Board said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Boeing 777 arriving in San Francisco on a clear, bright day hit the sea wall just short of the runway because the crew did not understand crucial details of the cockpit automation, the National Transportation Safety Board said Tuesday, recommending changes in training and flight manuals and in the airplane itself.

headline: Sudan Said to Revive Notorious Militias
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The government’s new Rapid Support Forces are a version of the janjaweed militias that terrorized people in Darfur, and have been attacking villages again, a rights group said.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Sudanese government has reconstituted the janjaweed, notorious militias that terrorized the restive Darfur region for years, making them an official, uniformed force that has recently burned down huts and attacked civilians, according to a new report prepared by the Enough Project, an activist group that aims to prevent genocide.

headline: On a Day of Few Surprises, Nadal’s Victory Restores Natural Order
abstract: After a slow start, Rafael Nadal powered past Martin Klizan in his first-round match at Wimbledon. Roger Federer, Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova also won easily.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — It is not often that intrigue and doubt accompany the top-ranked men’s tennis player to the opening round at Wimbledon. It was as if they were stored in the racket bag that Rafael Nadal had slung over his shoulder as he entered Centre Court on Tuesday.

headline: Internet Shares Mexico Coach Miguel Herrera’s Joy and Emotion
abstract: Herrera’s sideline demeanor has made him an Internet sensation during this World Cup, but the job he has done with Mexico’s previously struggling team has been remarkable.
lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — He is one of the most visually delightful characters at this World Cup. He is a charismatic, savvy leader. He is competitive mania personified.

headline: Rebekah Brooks Acquitted in Hacking Case
abstract: Rebekah Brooks, the former head of Rupert Murdoch’s newspaper holdings in Britain, was acquitted of phone hacking, and the lawyer for her former assistant spoke after his client was acquitted as well.
lead_paragraph: Rebekah Brooks, the former head of Rupert Murdoch’s newspaper holdings in Britain, was acquitted of phone hacking, and the lawyer for her former assistant spoke after his client was acquitted as well.

headline: At the La Brea Tar Pits, A Gala Event Celebrating Flintstones-Style Hair
abstract: The photographer Angie Smith captured an evening of big-wigged revelry at the Los Angeles fossil excavation site.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the photo diary of Angie Smith.

headline: Tysons, a Northern Virginia Crossroads, Waits Impatiently for the Train
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Transit Systems', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Building (Construction)']
abstract: Construction has taken off in the area once known as Tysons Corner as developers anticipate the arrival of the Washington Metro’s new Silver Line.
lead_paragraph: It was known as Tysons Corner, a rural crossroads 13 miles from downtown Washington.

headline: Uruguay’s Suárez, Known for Biting, Leaves Mark on World Cup
abstract: For the third time in the past four years, Uruguay’s star striker, Luis Suárez, appeared to bite a player on the other team when he clashed with Italy’s Giorgio Chiellini in the second half.
lead_paragraph: NATAL, Brazil — The most ruthless soccer players often use their hands or elbows or knees to rough up opposing players. The most reckless — or dirtiest — might even use their cleats. Then there is Luis Suárez.

headline: The South American World Cup Bracket
abstract: Colombia won Group C on Tuesday, as expected, and it will join Brazil, Chile and Uruguay in the same part of the Round of 16.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday’s later World Cup matches created a fascinating dynamic for the rest of the tournament: Colombia won Group C, creating an all-South American portion of the bracket.

headline: Hachette Adds Heft to Combat Amazon
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'E-Books and Readers']
abstract: Adding Perseus’s imprints strengthens Hachette’s nonfiction catalog and gives it more leverage in its dispute with Amazon over e-book pricing.
lead_paragraph: Hachette Book Group is bulking up and diversifying, steps that could improve its long-term negotiating position with Amazon, the giant online retailer.

headline: Dylan’s ‘Like a Rolling Stone’ Manuscript Sells for More Than $2 Million
abstract: Sotheby’s auction, “History of Rock and Roll From Presley to Punk,” also included a guitar owned by John Lennon.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan’s handwritten, working manuscript for his 1965 hit “Like a Rolling Stone” was sold at Sotheby’s auction on Tuesday for $2,045,000, just over the maximum estimated bid of $2 million.

headline: A Celebrity Steps Back Into the Spotlight
abstract: The food at the recently reopened Tavern on the Green does not live up to the setting.
lead_paragraph: Restaurant critics are supposed to be impartial, but I can’t help feeling some proprietary interest in Tavern on the Green. Not a financial interest, except insofar as a profitable Tavern is good for the city’s budget, which, in a fractions-of-pennies way, is good for me as a grumpy taxpayer. It’s more like a civic interest. Tavern on the Green belongs to the city and sits inside the most beautiful public park in which I’ve ever rowed, cycled, struck out in softball, misidentified a confusing fall warbler and illegally consumed alcoholic beverages. I’d let the city keep those fractional pennies if that helped Tavern on the Green live up to its setting.

headline: Colombia vs. Japan: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Like many Western Hemisphere nations, Colombia has had a strong start to the Cup. Expect Juan Cuadrado to send in dangerous crosses that bother Japan’s defense.
lead_paragraph: Like many Western Hemisphere nations, Colombia has had a strong start to the Cup. Expect Juan Cuadrado to send in dangerous crosses that bother Japan’s defense. Japan has just one goal at the Cup and could only draw woeful Greece. This will be a tough spot.

headline: Getting a 9-Year-Old’s View of the Common Core
abstract: Javier Hernández answers questions about his story exploring the Common Core academic standards through the eyes of a child.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Javier Hernández explored the Common Core program, a recommended set of academic standards, through the eyes of a 9-year-old student. The piece struck a chord with readers. It drew over 500 impassioned comments and many letters to the editor, several of which were published yesterday. Here, Javier answers questions about the origins of the story and what the reporting was like.

headline: A Year After the Chaos, Many Ranking Points to Defend
abstract: Monica Puig, Tsvetana Pironkova and Karin Knapp, who all reached the Round of 16 at Wimbledon last year while ranked outside the top 50, lost in the first round Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — A year after one of the most turbulent Wimbledons in memory, the unexpected stars of an edition of the tournament nicknamed Wimbleweird returned with hopes of rekindling that same feeling.

headline: Greece vs. Ivory Coast: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: After two noble failures at the World Cup, Ivory Coast is on the cusp of finally making the knockout stages. Gervinho has been outstanding and he could well run riot against Greece.
lead_paragraph: After two noble failures at the World Cup, Ivory Coast is on the cusp of finally making the knockout stages. Gervinho has been outstanding and he could well run riot against Greece.

headline: Order denying habeas to Shaker Aamer
abstract: Order denying request for habeas relief to Shaker Aamer on health grounds.
lead_paragraph: Order denying request for habeas relief to Shaker Aamer on health grounds.

headline: United Methodists’ Decision to Overturn Defrocking of Frank Schaefer
keywords: ['Methodist Church', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A United Methodist Church appeals committee — a nine-member panel made up of laypeople and clergy — issued this ruling Tuesday. The panel decided to overturn the punishment of Frank Schaefer on the grounds that it was too harsh.
lead_paragraph: A United Methodist Church appeals committee — a nine-member panel made up of laypeople and clergy — issued this ruling Tuesday. The panel decided to overturn the punishment of Frank Schaefer on the grounds that it was too harsh.

headline: Petition for habeas corpus on health grounds
abstract: Shaker Aamer, a Saudi citizen and former British resident detained at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, asked a Federal District Court judge to order his release on grounds of poor health.
lead_paragraph: Shaker Aamer, a Saudi citizen and former British resident detained at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, asked a Federal District Court judge to order his release on grounds of poor health.

headline: A Harlem Cultural Connector Makes Her Artistic Debut
abstract: Felicia Gordon, the founder of the Sugar Hill Culture Club, is exhibiting her creative work for the first time in a new show, “New York, Naturally.”
lead_paragraph: A chance meeting with an old friend on a subway platform leads to a creative epiphany: it’s one of those only-in-New-York stories, the type that seems more rom-com plotline than real life. But that’s exactly what happened to Felicia Gordon, the founder of the Sugar Hill Culture Club (a loosely knit group of creatives from Harlem to Berlin that has collaborated on everything from short films to a line of sweatshirts worn by Rihanna), who has her first-ever show as an artist in a Harlem pop-up gallery this week.

headline: Guantanamo Detainee Disposition List
abstract: A 2009-2010 inter-agency task force that reviewed each detainee still at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, when President Obama took office came up with this list of disposition recommendations.
lead_paragraph: A 2009-2010 inter-agency task force that reviewed each detainee still at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, when President Obama took office came up with this list of disposition recommendations.

headline: A Contemporary Design Yields to the Demands of Prehistory
abstract: The architect Peter Zumthor has modified plans for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art to sidestep the La Brea Tar Pits.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Swiss architect Peter Zumthor has modified his grand plans to transform the campus of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, altering the shape of his building to stretch across bustling Wilshire Boulevard and away from the neighboring La Brea Tar Pits, according to renderings provided by the museum on Tuesday. Critics of the original design had raised environmental concerns, saying it would have cast a shadow over tar pits rich with Ice Age fossils.

headline: I.R.S. Hearing Over Lost Emails
abstract: John Koskinen, the Internal Revenue Service commissioner, defended himself against Republicans’ accusations of a cover-up over lost emails.
lead_paragraph: John Koskinen, the Internal Revenue Service commissioner, defended himself against Republicans’ accusations of a cover-up over lost emails.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Taxi Brooklyn’
abstract: The new NBC series is about a cop who partners with a cabby.
lead_paragraph: The new NBC series is about a cop who partners with a cabby.

headline: New York Is Star in Video Pitch for Democratic Convention
abstract: The de Blasio administration released a video intended to market the city’s charms and diversity for a national audience in a bid to host the 2016 event.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s bid to make Brooklyn the home of the 2016 Democratic National Convention has attracted all manner of buzz. But with five other cities contending for the event, it is up to Mayor Bill de Blasio’s team to seal the deal with party leaders.

headline: Odd Couple, Chic Borough
abstract: In “Taxi Brooklyn,” an NBC cabby-and-cop buddy series starring Jacky Ido and Chyler Leigh, the taxi driver is the hero.
lead_paragraph: Leo Romba (Jacky Ido) is an expert body-language reader and a stunning tactical driver, can tell which part of Peru a dab of cocaine comes from, and can throw a perp up against a wall without wrinkling his shirt. In “Taxi Brooklyn,” a goofy tale of an unlikely alliance between cop and cabby, he is the seer and the center of all power, a hero for a troubled borough.

headline: Siemens May Seek Another Alstom Tie-Up
abstract: Pooling together Alstom’s and Siemens’s train-making units can create significant medium-term savings, Olaf Storbeck writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Once the dust settles over the Alstom bidding war, Siemens and its French rival may want to revisit the most compelling aspect of the German company’s losing bid: a merger of both groups’ train-making units. Such a union would create the train equivalent of Airbus, the European aircraft maker.

headline: Apologies Become a Tool, Not a Goal
abstract: The reason that so many apologies seem unsatisfying is that neither side really wants the apology, David Greenberg writes in an Apology Watch column. But there are strategies for reaching authenticity.
lead_paragraph: In 35 years as a corporate insider, adviser and critic, I’ve been on both sides of dozens of apologies played out in the public domain — and the most striking common denominator is how few of those apologies were either genuinely given or received. In fact, I’d suggest that one reason for supporting Dov Seidman’s call for an apology cease-fire is that the modern apology has strayed far from its purpose — acknowledgment and redress of a wrong — and is simply a tactic played out in a larger zero-sum game of winners and losers.

headline: Reform Conservatism and Climate Change
abstract: Explaining an alleged “deafening silence” on a difficult policy debate.
lead_paragraph: When the “Room to Grow” collection of reform conservative essays dropped last month, some of the most frequent criticisms from liberals focused on topics that the book did not address: In particular, comprehensive immigration reform (the subject of my last post) and climate change legislation. Vox’s Matt Yglesias, for instance, thought it noteworthy that a book “hailed as representing the best, freshest conservative thinking on the pressing issues of the day” has “nothing to say” on how American policymakers should tackle climate change, and he offered the following theory as to why:

headline: Bain Capital’s Andrew Balson Starts New Private Equity Fund
abstract: Andrew B. Balson, a longtime managing director at Bain Capital, has left to start a new investment fund to be based in Boston.
lead_paragraph: Andrew B. Balson, a longtime managing director at the Boston-based private equity firm Bain Capital, has left to start a new investment fund.

headline: Five Things to Ponder About the Mississippi Runoff
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Midterm Elections (2014)']
abstract: Chris McDaniel holds a modest lead in the polls over Senator Thad Cochran, but Mr. Cochran might have made progress in his bid for support among black voters.
lead_paragraph: The polls in Mississippi closed at 8 p.m. Eastern as voters chose whether Senator Thad Cochran or State Senator Chris McDaniel should be the Republican nominee for the Senate in November. We are analyzing vote returns live here. Meanwhile, here are the five outstanding questions to watch this evening.

headline: David Waltuck Is Back in the Kitchen
abstract: After five years, the chef is back with a new restaurant and partner.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: 3-D Mammography Test Appears to Improve Breast Cancer Detection Rate
abstract: Tomosynthesis, or 3-D mammography, detects more cancers and causes fewer false alarms than regular tests, say researchers who compared data from 13 screening centers.
lead_paragraph: Adding a newer test to digital mammograms can increase the detection rate for breast cancer and decrease nerve-racking false alarms, in which suspicious findings lead women to get extra scans that turn out normal, a study found.

headline: Federal District Court Ruling on No-Fly List
abstract: A Federal District Court judge in Oregon struck down redress procedures for people put on the so-called “no-fly” list who seek to regain a right to board airplanes.
lead_paragraph: A Federal District Court judge in Oregon struck down redress procedures for people put on the so-called “no-fly” list who seek to regain a right to board airplanes.

headline: Federal District Court ruling Upholds FISA Amendments Act
abstract: A Federal District Court judge in Oregon rejected a request to throw out a conviction because of evidence derived from the FISA Amendments Act of 2008.
lead_paragraph: A Federal District Court judge in Oregon rejected a request to throw out a conviction because of evidence derived from the FISA Amendments Act of 2008.

headline: Turk Who Killed Staten Island Tourist Gets Life Sentence
abstract: Ziya Tasali, who said he struck Sarai Sierra with a rock in a scuffle in Istanbul in January 2013 after she refused to kiss him, denied raping her.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A Turkish man who admitted killing a tourist from Staten Island last year, after, he said, she resisted his kiss, was found guilty of murder on Tuesday and sentenced to life in prison.

abstract: A wedding procession inside a Muslim concentration camp in Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: A wedding procession inside a Muslim concentration camp in Myanmar.

headline: Climbing for Coconuts
abstract: A villager climbed a coconut tree inside a confined Muslim village in Myanmar. He gave the coconut to some thirsty reporters from The Times.
lead_paragraph: A villager climbed a coconut tree inside a confined Muslim village in Myanmar. He gave the coconut to some thirsty reporters from The Times.

headline: Myanmar Hospitality: A Rescue Boat
abstract: A rescue boat appeared for two Times reporters as sun was falling, a cyclone was approaching and a curfew for foreigners was just 20 minutes away.
lead_paragraph: A rescue boat appeared for two Times reporters as sun was falling, a cyclone was approaching and a curfew for foreigners was just 20 minutes away.

headline: European Banks Balk at Cheap Loans, Worried About Strings Attached
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: Why would banks refuse to take money that would come at practically no cost? Because low-cost is not the same as risk-free.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — It sounds like an offer too good to refuse: nearly unlimited loans at an annual interest rate of only 0.25 percent.

headline: There May Not Be a There There, or Gold
abstract: “Donogoo,” a 1930 French farce by Jules Romains, revived by Mint Theater Company, tosses barbs at targets like academia, psychiatry and big business.
lead_paragraph: Psst! Wanna buy some collateralized debt obligations? How about a nice credit default swap? Wait! I’ve got just the thing: shares in a plan to exploit the gold reserves of Donogoo-Tonka, that lush South American Eden.

headline: Helped by Federer, and Now Surpassing Him
abstract: Stan Wawrinka, who won a first-round match in straight sets at Wimbledon on Tuesday, has relegated Roger Federer to the No. 2 player in Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Once in a lifetime, everyone should have a Stan Wawrinka experience, the chance to step out of the shadow, take the baton from a world-renowned maestro and say, “Step aside, partner, let me show you how to lead this concerto.”

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Giorgio Armani Spring/Summer 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: ExIm Irony
abstract: The worst time to give up on mercantilism.
lead_paragraph: So it looks quite likely that the Tea Party will claim a scalp from the business lobby, and kill the Export-Import Bank. And there is a case for doing away with the lender – except that this is the worst possible time for it.

headline: A Rarity Bursts Into Bloom
abstract: William Forsythe has been overseeing the Boston Ballet’s rehearsals for “The Second Detail,” which opens the troupe’s season at Lincoln Center on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — “Don’t be afraid to love ballet,” William Forsythe called out as a quartet of Boston Ballet dancers stepped into fifth position on point — feet tight together, arms high — their hips twisting and their heads tilted up toward delicately curved hands. “Show us why you love it!”

headline: British Tabloids After Brooks Verdict
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'News of the World Phone Hacking', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Ravi Somaiya, a Times media correspondent, on the fallout from the acquittal of Rebekah Brooks, the former Murdoch newspaper editor, on charges of phone hacking.
lead_paragraph: Ravi Somaiya, a Times media correspondent, on the fallout from the acquittal of Rebekah Brooks, the former Murdoch newspaper editor, on charges of phone hacking.

headline: In Vermont, a Festival of Cheese
abstract: The annual Vermont Cheesemakers Festival will feature workshops and samplings (and wine and beer too).
lead_paragraph: More than 40 Vermont cheesemakers and dozens of specialty food, beer, wine, and spirits producers will gather on July 20 for the sixth annual Vermont Cheesemakers Festival in Shelburne, presented by the Vermont Cheese Council.

headline: Enigmatic Moves and Flashes of Drama Against a Towering Cityscape
abstract: An untitled work by Tere O’Connor takes shape outdoors with the city as backdrop.
lead_paragraph: The incongruity of dancing in the financial district is something to which many New Yorkers have grown accustomed. Over the years, dancers have performed in many of the spaces there. At 1 p.m. on Monday, Michael Ingle and Silas Riener, modern dancers of distinction, performed a 30-minute duet by the choreographer Tere O’Connor on a lawn at the Elevated Acre on Water Street.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Iraq, Lebanon, England and New York.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Iraq, Lebanon, England and New York.

headline: NBC Completes Upfront Sales as CW Nears Finish Line
abstract: NBC executives said Tuesday that they achieved their growth targets for the sale of commercial time before the start of the 2014-15 television season.
lead_paragraph: Two additional big English-language broadcast networks – NBC and CW – have declared that they have finished, or largely finished, the sale of commercial time before the start of the 2014-15 television season in what is known as the upfront market.

headline: A Prime Portfolio in Manhattan, Coming Back to Life
abstract: After a long fight, the Extell Development Company has won control of several buildings near Madison Square Park long left vacant by F.M. Ring Associates.
lead_paragraph: In a city that can seem to be wringing every last drop of value out of its real estate, while giving block after block a squeaky-clean gloss, a Manhattan loft building at 13 West 27th Street stuck out glaringly on a recent tour.

headline: A Luxe Throwback Timepiece From Baume & Mercier
keywords: ['Collectors and Collections', 'Men and Boys', 'Watches and Clocks']
abstract: A new ’50s-inspired style, just a couple of months old, has already become the line’s signature piece.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the photographer Rob Kulisek captures a timepiece from Baume & Mercier.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Crisis in Greece and at Home
abstract: Nikos Pilos specializes in covering crisis. For the last 10 years, that has kept him busy chronicling his homeland’s economic and social problems.
lead_paragraph: Nikos Pilos specializes in covering crisis. For the last 10 years, that has kept him busy chronicling his homeland’s economic and social problems.

headline: Readers Divided on the Legality of Drone Strikes
abstract: Many commenters are fine with the killing of Anwar al-Awlaki, an American citizen.
lead_paragraph: For many readers who commented on our editorial this morning about the legal underpinning of a fatal drone strike, the issue is an easy one: Anwar al-Awlaki may have been an American citizen, but he was obviously a terrorist, because he had aligned himself with a branch of Al Qaeda. Thus the United States was right in 2011 to kill him (and his son) in a drone strike in Yemen.

headline: Big Ten Joins Pac-12 in Pressing the N.C.A.A. to Make Changes
abstract: The leaders of the Big Ten conference’s 14 universities released a statement Tuesday seeking a greater emphasis on academics within college sports.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — For the second time in a month, every university president belonging to an athletic conference has jointly issued a public letter calling for change within the N.C.A.A.

headline: Nostalgia on the Air
abstract: “Girl Meets World” and “Mystery Girls,” comedies rooted in shows of the 1990s, make their debuts.
lead_paragraph: It’s ’90s teenage-show nostalgia week on Walt Disney Company networks, where a pair of new shows are built on memories of series that went off the air just as the current century was starting.

headline: Everything You Need for the Perfect Picnic
abstract: For a fine time dining alfresco, tote the proper tools and bring food and drink that piques your palate.
lead_paragraph: To Share: They’ll Even Let You Borrow the Basket

headline: A Hunt to Find the Next Generation of Financial Advisers
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Financial Planners', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The average financial adviser in the United States is older than 50, creating a problem for asset management firms that must figure out how to attract and retain fresh talent.
lead_paragraph: Joseph H. Clinard Jr. is 76 and spends his days planning for retirement — just not his own.

headline: The Life Behind a Fashionable Front
abstract: “Yves Saint Laurent” stars Pierre Niney as the French fashion designer.
lead_paragraph: More dutiful than elegant, “Yves Saint Laurent” is one of two new dramas about that beatified French fashion designer. The other feature, Bertrand Bonello’s “Saint Laurent,” had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival last month and posits, with flair and humor, a certain sensual mystery about the shy but passionate couturier and his work. Jalil Lespert’s authorized biopic is the first out of the gate in the United States, however, and it trots out a polite recounting of Saint Laurent’s life in its prime.

headline: Archivist Faults I.R.S. for Not Reporting Loss of Emails
keywords: ['Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling', 'Archives and Records', 'E-Mail', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: David S. Ferriero, the chief archivist at the National Archives, said the agency should have reported the destruction of the emails of Lois Lerner in a hard drive crash.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service did not follow the law when it failed to report a hard drive crash that destroyed emails belonging to a senior official at the center of a scandal over the agency’s treatment of conservative-leaning political groups, the nation’s top archivist said Tuesday.

headline: From Liner Notes to Front Lines of Advocacy
abstract: “The Pleasures of Being Out of Step” is a documentary about the music critic and First Amendment defender Nat Hentoff.
lead_paragraph: “The Pleasures of Being Out of Step: Notes on the Life of Nat Hentoff” is very much in step with the enthusiasms of its nobly bearded 89-year-old subject, the critic Nat Hentoff. The director David L. Lewis presents a man who’s all about the voice — letting it sing, as in the instrumental improvisations of the jazz he loves, and keeping it alive, through his dogmatic defense of the First Amendment.

headline: Ford Expands Truck Recall After Supplier Reviews Records
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Ford had announced a recall of 372 F-150 pickups from the 2014 model year, but increased the number of recalled trucks to nearly 5,700.
lead_paragraph: Ford said Tuesday that it was increasing the number of 2014 F-150 pickups it was recalling for a possible steering loss problem from the 372 announced earlier this month to almost 5,700, including about 4,600 in the United States.

headline: Gentlemen Take a Bow in a Theater Tribute
abstract: Chapman Roberts dreamed up this three-hour extravaganza as both a performance platform for, and a celebration of, African-American men of the theater.
lead_paragraph: “The good Lord created black people, and black people created everything else!”

headline: The Self-Promotion Backlash
abstract: Americans are frequently encouraged to “build our personal brands,” but, writes ANNA NORTH, some say the emphasis on touting our own achievements could be working against us.
lead_paragraph: From “building your personal brand” to “stepping up your social media presence,” we’re constantly inundated with advice about how to promote ourselves. But some are saying that the pressure to self-promote could, ultimately, be hurting us.

headline: Still Together, but Prickly
abstract: Alex & Sierra, the winners of the final season of “The X Factor,” drew mostly from their still-untitled debut album at Rockwood Music Hall on Monday.
lead_paragraph: At Rockwood Music Hall on Monday night, Alex Kinsey and Sierra Deaton told a story of how reality television works to create its own reality. As a duo, Alex & Sierra, they were contestants, and eventual winners, on last year’s season of “The X Factor,” the show’s last. A couple, they were visibly enamored of each other. The notoriously sour Simon Cowell was their mentor.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Mediations and Mutiny Backstage
abstract: Glenn Dicterow discusses leaving his job as the longest-serving concertmaster in the New York Philharmonic’s history.
lead_paragraph: The open, empty violin case backstage at Avery Fisher Hall stood as a stark reminder that Glenn Dicterow, the longest-serving concertmaster in the history of the New York Philharmonic, would retire after Saturday night’s concert. It awaited the return of the 1727 Guarneri del Gesù violin that the Philharmonic had lent him as its first among equals.

headline: Improvising With Passion
abstract: “Transformation: Rhythm’s Roots,” presented on Friday by the City Parks Foundation, examined, through dance and music, the centuries of African-American experience.
lead_paragraph: “Transformation: Rhythm’s Roots,” a collaboration between the veteran jazz musician Owen Brown Jr. and the first-rate tap dancer Jason Samuels Smith, advertises itself as a musical response to the recent Oscar-winning film “12 Years a Slave.” But its subject is actually much broader: the hundreds of years of African-American experience from enslavement to the present.

headline: Arias in the Park on a Summer’s Eve
abstract: Three rising stars — Amber Wagner, Jamie Barton and Russell Thomas — barnstormed their way through daunting arias and duets on Monday at Central Park SummerStage.
lead_paragraph: If you’re an opera lover looking for a typical young-artist concert, there are four outdoor dates coming up in July to satisfy you, courtesy of the Metropolitan Opera’s annual Summer Recital Series. Three up-and-comers from the company’s roster will be traveling through New York City parks with sunny standards, including the Barcarolle from Offenbach’s “Les Contes d’Hoffmann,” and “Là ci darem la mano” from Mozart’s “Don Giovanni.”

headline: Spoons for the Picky
abstract: In Brooklyn, there is a revival of handmade home items.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning there was the Word, and the Word was naughty, and then Jonathan Adler put it on a throw pillow.

headline: No Matter the Political Climate, the Conversation on Twitter Turns to the Weather
abstract: It seemed like many voters on social media were more concerned with today’s weather than with the state’s political climate.
lead_paragraph: Voters headed back to polling places in Mississippi on Tuesday to cast ballots in the runoff between Senator Thad Cochran and his Tea Party-backed challenger, State Senator Chris McDaniel. In keeping with a race that has generated its share of political conflict, Mr. Cochran’s and Mr. McDaniel’s partisans were active on Twitter describing Mississippi’s second day at the polls this month in a way that was helpful to their candidates. But it seemed like many voters on social media were more concerned with today’s weather than with the state’s political climate.

headline: World Cup Fashion
abstract: The World Cup — a.k.a. one of the largest sports fashion catwalks in the world.
lead_paragraph: The World Cup — a.k.a. one of the largest sports fashion catwalks in the world.

headline: The World Cup Winners
abstract: What the soccer players wear during their games now may soon influence fashion.
lead_paragraph: If you, like me, have walked down a city street sometime in the last two weeks — any city street, really, in any city — there’s a good chance you passed someone (or, indeed, many someones) wearing, say, a lurid yellow shirt trimmed in green, or a slightly twee white polo-neck edged in blue, or a blood-red tee with black stripes. And then you, like me, may have scratched your head and thought, “Where are they getting their fashion cues from?”

headline: Ford Reveals All-New 2015 Edge Crossover
abstract: The redesigned Edge has many standard safety features and an optional 2-liter turbocharged EcoBoost 4-cylinder engine.

abstract: It’s too late to prevent climate change by reducing carbon emissions now. But it could help prevent even more serious damage 50, 75 and 100 years from today.
lead_paragraph: Climate change is not an event in your children’s future. It is bearing down upon you now. And there is nothing you — or anyone else — can do to prevent the hit.

headline: Waiting in the Wings, a Ballerina to Save the Day
abstract: American Ballet Theater’s “Swan Lake” delivers some unexpected human drama and heroism.
lead_paragraph: For the role of Odette-Odile in “Swan Lake” a dancer must achieve one of ballet’s most extreme transformations: from fragile and distant as the swan queen, Odette, to devilish and seductive as the antiheroine, Odile. On Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House, where American Ballet Theater began its weeklong run of the ballet, that metamorphosis was interrupted by a more real-world kind of fragility. An announcement at intermission informed us that because of an injury, Gillian Murphy, our leading lady thus far, would not complete the performance; Hee Seo would take her place, swooping in for the Black Swan pas de deux and Odette’s final lakeside moments.

keywords: ['Censorship', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'News and News Media']

Was he shooting his CNN show (titled “Parts Unknown”) in a remote desert or on top of a snowy Himalayan peak?

lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Whether a person is a Shiite or a Sunni Muslim in Iraq can now be, quite literally, a matter of life and death.

headline: The Tappan Zee Bridge Loan
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Sewers and Sewage', 'Editorials', 'Water']
abstract: A proposal to use money that provides clean water in New York on a new bridge across the Hudson needs more scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: When it rains hard in New York, outdated municipal waste treatment plants often fail, sending untreated sewage into state waterways. Upgrading old plants and building new ones has long depended heavily on the federal Clean Water State Revolving Fund. It is capitalized with state and federal money, makes loans to needy municipalities and is constantly under pressure from budget-conscious legislators on Capitol Hill.

headline: Indie Music’s Digital Drag
abstract: Small labels contend that consolidation by the major record companies has left them squeezed in negotiations with the online music services that now account for a majority of their revenue.
lead_paragraph: The booze flowed freely in New York last week at the Libera Awards, a three-year-old alternative Grammys for the world of independent music, as awards went to prestige indie acts like Arcade Fire and Arctic Monkeys and executives at small labels congratulated one another about what a great year it was for their music.

headline: Iran: Harvard Scholar’s Body Cremated After Request for Burial in Iran Falters
abstract: A Harvard scholar who wanted to be buried in Iran, a request that angered hard-liners there, has been cremated by his family in Boston, the Iranian news media reported Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Richard Nelson Frye, a renowned Harvard scholar who wanted to be buried in Iran, a request that angered Iranian hard-liners, has been cremated by his family in Boston, the Iranian news media reported Tuesday. The Iranian Students’ News Agency quoted Dr. Frye’s Iranian colleague Turaj Daryaii as saying the family had waited more than two months for official Iranian permission to bury him in Isfahan, the ancient capital of the Persian Empire, before deciding to cremate him on June 8. It was not clear what the family intended to do with his ashes. Dr. Frye, who died on March 27 at age 94, had dedicated his career to Iran’s culture and language, and he had written the burial request into his will. He was widely regarded in Iran as a friend, even among some conservatives, but his death coincided with growing resentment by Iranian hard-liners over signs of reconciliation with the United States after decades of estrangement. A month after Dr. Frye died, the leader of Friday Prayer in Isfahan denounced his burial request, calling him a spy and a robber of cultural artifacts.

headline: France: Court Rules on End-of-Life Case
abstract: France’s highest administrative court, the Conseil d’État, ruled Tuesday that a feeding tube could legally be removed from a 38-year-old man in a persistent vegetative state, whose care has been part of a long, bitter public fight involving the country’s end-of-life legislation.
lead_paragraph: France’s highest administrative court, the Conseil d’État, ruled Tuesday that a feeding tube could legally be removed from a 38-year-old man in a persistent vegetative state, whose care has been part of a long, bitter public fight involving the country’s end-of-life legislation. Before a 2008 accident left the man, Vincent Lambert, a former psychiatric nurse, paralyzed and unresponsive, he had repeatedly said he did not wish to be kept alive in such a condition, according to his wife and several family members, who have sought for him to be allowed to die. Given that, the court found that the feeding tube that has kept Mr. Lambert alive could be considered “unreasonable” medical “obstinacy,” and could be legally removed. Mr. Lambert’s parents, who oppose that, have appealed to the European Court of Human Rights, and Mr. Lambert will be kept alive during the months or years of that court’s examination of the case. French law prohibits any medical acts explicitly intended to end a patient’s life, but authorizes doctors to withdraw treatment or administer lethal doses of painkillers under certain circumstances.

headline: Washington State to Require Approval of Packaging for Edible Marijuana Products
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Containers and Packaging', 'Children and Childhood', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Labeling and Labels']
abstract: The state has watched legalization take effect in Colorado, and sees children’s access as a concern.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Washington State will require its approval of all packaging for edible marijuana products, Gov. Jay Inslee said Tuesday, a pre-emptory move to ban cartoons, toy images and any other labels that might appeal to children.

headline: De Blasio Offers Easier Access to City Money for Special Education
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio unveiled a series of changes to make it easier for special-needs students in New York to receive private schooling at public expense.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio unveiled a series of changes on Tuesday to make it easier for special-needs students in New York to receive private schooling at public expense, a practice that has led to frequent litigation as the city has tried to keep such spending under control.

headline: Woods Is Returning to Action, but Is No Longer in a Rush
abstract: Since back surgery in March, Tiger Woods has been taking a steady approach to his return and is now preparing for his first major of the year.
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md. — After all the best doctors and all the best aids put Tiger Woods back together again, he returns to competition knowing that he will have only one guide, one source of feedback.

headline: Premium-Cigar Exemption Traced
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Cigars', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Documents released by the federal government on Tuesday provided clues about how premium cigars got special treatment in federal tobacco regulations proposed recently.
lead_paragraph: Documents released by the federal government on Tuesday provided clues about how premium cigars got special treatment in federal tobacco regulations proposed recently. The rules, written by the Food and Drug Administration, originally subjected all cigars to federal regulation. But a proposal to exempt premium cigars surfaced after the rules were submitted to the White House for editing last year, the documents show. Matthew L. Myers, president of the Campaign for Tobacco Free Kids, an advocacy group, said an exemption, if made final, would set a troubling precedent for the future of tobacco regulation.

headline: ISIS and SISI

abstract: Why two Arab governing models are doomed.
lead_paragraph: The past month has presented the world with what the Israeli analyst Orit Perlov describes as the two dominant Arab governing models: ISIS and SISI.

headline: Tea Party Mischief on Exports
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Editorials']
abstract: If the Export-Import Bank is dismantled, American companies that sell goods abroad could move their operations to countries that provide generous support.
lead_paragraph: In one of their odder quests, some Tea Party members have decided that the United States must shut down the Export-Import Bank of the United States, an obscure but important federal agency that helps American businesses sell their goods abroad.

headline: Corruption Sweep at Rikers Island Leads to 22 Arrests
abstract: Law enforcement officials searched the jail’s George Motchan Detention Center well into Monday night, leading to the arrests of two correction officers and the uncovering of stashes of marijuana, tobacco and weapons.
lead_paragraph: A sweep by law enforcement authorities at Rikers Island, part of a monthslong investigation into wrongdoing at the jail complex, led to the arrests of two correction officers on Monday night and more than 20 inmates on Tuesday, officials said.

headline: Shinzo Abe’s Bid to Shake Up Corporate Japan
keywords: ['Corporations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A crosshatch of stock holdings allows Japan’s big corporations to protect one another from outside attempts to shake up management. The prime minister has taken aim at the practice.
lead_paragraph: Even for the land that invented Toyota-style efficiency, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is on a tear. His ruling Liberal Democratic Party pushed 98 percent of its bills through Parliament, a success rate not seen in Japan for over a decade.

headline: Refusals to Pay High Drug Prices
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: Reining in the rising costs for some prescription medicines holds both promise and peril for patients.
lead_paragraph: Pharmacy benefit managers are ramping up efforts to rein in the rising prices that drug makers are charging for some prescription medicines. The trend holds both promise and peril for patients who depend on the drugs to control their illnesses.

headline: Guantánamo Detainee Rebuffed
abstract: A Federal District Court judge on Tuesday rejected a request by a high-profile detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
lead_paragraph: A Federal District Court judge on Tuesday rejected a request by a high-profile detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, that the judge order his release because he is suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder and other mental and physical ailments. The habeas corpus challenge was brought in April on behalf of Shaker Aamer, 45, a Saudi citizen and former British resident. Judge Rosemary M. Collyer gave her rejection in a terse one-page order; an accompanying memorandum opinion explaining her reasoning was sealed. The Justice Department’s filings in the case were also sealed, but Judge Collyer ordered it to file a public version of her order and its documents by July 9.

headline: Cracker Jack Wants to Break Out of the Ballpark
abstract: A new campaign, aimed at mothers between 25 to 45, plays off the fact that the snack is known for the prize inside its box.
lead_paragraph: IT would be impossible to put a dollar value on how much “Take Me Out to the Ball Game,” the 1908 song ritually sung by baseball fans during the seventh-inning stretch, has had for the 121-year-old snack named in the refrain, “Buy me some peanuts and Cracker Jack.” But in a segment for “On the Media,” the syndicated public radio show produced by WNYC, Mike Pesca once tried to assess the value, equating it with Cracker Jack placing an advertisement along outfield walls of all of the major league’s 30 stadiums, a marketing campaign that would cost the brand about $25 million a year.

headline: Massachusetts: Court Allows Public to Vote on Repealing Casino Law
abstract: The state’s highest court ruled Tuesday that a proposal to repeal the state’s expanded casino gambling law can appear on the ballot this fall.
lead_paragraph: The state’s highest court ruled Tuesday that a proposal to repeal the state’s expanded casino gambling law can appear on the ballot this fall. The ruling by the Supreme Judicial Court overturned a decision by Attorney General Martha Coakley, setting the stage for what is likely to be a closely watched and expensive campaign. The 2011 law allows for up to three resort-style casinos and one slots parlor to be built in the state. Casino opponents say they have more than twice as many signatures than required to get the question on the ballot; those signatures are being certified. One license has been provisionally awarded in Springfield, pending the outcome of the repeal effort; the slots parlor is under construction in Plainville.

headline: Blue, as in Happy
abstract: Uruguay was favored to win Group D, but after losing in the opener to Costa Rica, the team looked like it was buried and would need its own Houdini to escape. Enter the brilliant but mercurial Luis Suárez.
lead_paragraph: NATAL, Brazil — Victory, even in the group stage of the World Cup, can make Uruguayans feel like champions again.

headline: Manhattan District Attorney’s Office Showing No Leniency in Daredevil Cases
keywords: ['Parachutes and Parachute Jumping', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Stunts and Stuntmen', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', '1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'District Attorneys', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Speed Limits and Speeding']
abstract: Prosecutors are aggressively pursuing charges against World Trade Center parachutists and a speeding driver that would result in jail time and criminal records for the defendants.
lead_paragraph: Three men who parachuted off the World Trade Center and a speeding driver who circled Manhattan in 24 minutes have attracted plenty of fans on YouTube — thrilling helmet- or dashboard-camera videos of their stunts have been played tens of thousands of times.

headline: After Opening Way to Rebels, Turkey Is Paying Heavy Price
abstract: Many Turks now blame their government for facilitating the rise of extremists in Syria and the new insurgency in Iraq, including the kidnapping of 80 Turkish citizens.
lead_paragraph: HABUR BORDER GATE, Turkey — In normal times, hauling 50,000 pounds of frozen chicken into Iraq is a routine job for Turfan Aydin, a Turkish trucker who has been working the route for years. But the cross-border trade has suddenly all but halted, locked up by the insurgent offensive in Iraq and the kidnapping of 80 Turkish citizens.

headline: Vast Stretches of Minnesota Are Flooded as Swollen Rivers Overflow
abstract: After heavy winter snows and torrential spring rains, floods spread throughout the state, from Canada to Iowa.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Minnesota was besieged on Tuesday by some of its most widespread flooding in years. Water spilled onto streets in downtown St. Paul, crops of soybeans and corn were damaged and a state of emergency was declared in 35 counties.

headline: Tying Federal Aid to College Ratings
abstract: A report outlines ways Congress can use a rating system to help guide the allocation of federal student loans and grants.
lead_paragraph: College and university leaders have been up in arms since President Obama announced last year that the administration would soon deploy a rating system that evaluates schools based on factors like affordability, graduation rates, student earnings and how well institutions serve low-income students. Mr. Obama wants Congress to use the ratings to help guide the allocation of federal student loans and grants.

keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Airport Security', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Search and Seizure', 'Terrorism', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']

headline: A String of Sexual Assaults Puts a Bronx Area on Alert
abstract: The female victims, ranging in age from 12 to 21, were all alone, all on their way to school, and all attacked in the same way by the same hooded man.
lead_paragraph: Young people in some parts of the Bronx have a lot to contend with as warmer months arrive. There is a lack of organized activities, residents complain, and few summer jobs. More alarming, around playgrounds, parks and some weekend parties, bullets fly with increasing frequency.

headline: A Battery of Newfound Offense Helps the Mets Romp Yet Again
