headline: Yanks’ Rally Goes for Naught As Misplays Prove Undoing
abstract: New York erased a six-run Toronto lead in the sixth and seventh innings, but gave back the lead in the bottom of the ninth on a throwing error by Yangervis Solarte.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The Yankees’ slumbering bats erupted Tuesday night, but poor defense — including two misplays in the same inning by shortstop Derek Jeter — ultimately cost the Yankees in a 7-6 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays.

headline: John McClure Dies at 84; Produced Classic Records
abstract: Mr. McClure was a producer and engineer who helped shape some of the most celebrated classical recordings of the 20th century, including acclaimed sessions with Bruno Walter, Igor Stravinsky and Leonard Bernstein.
lead_paragraph: John McClure, a producer and engineer who helped shape some of the most celebrated classical recordings of the 20th century, including acclaimed sessions with Bruno Walter, Igor Stravinsky and Leonard Bernstein, died on June 17 at his home in Belmont, Vt. He was 84.

headline: A Senator Wins a Race He Mulled Not Running
abstract: Thad Cochran, the six-term Republican senator from Mississippi, defeated a Tea Party challenger in a runoff after a campaign for which he sometimes showed little enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — The question seemed to tug at Senator Thad Cochran throughout his bumpy re-election campaign in Mississippi: Why, after a long, distinguished career — 42 years in Congress, including six terms in the Senate — was he seeking a seventh term?

headline: Establishment Choice Is G.O.P. Pick for Colorado Governor
abstract: Bob Beauprez, a buffalo rancher and former congressman, defeated three rivals, including Tom Tancredo, in Colorado’s Republican primary and will take on Gov. John W. Hickenlooper in November.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Bob Beauprez, a buffalo rancher and a former congressman and community banker, defeated three rivals in a crowded Republican primary election on Tuesday to become his party’s choice to take on Colorado’s governor this November, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Toronto’s Baseball Revival Playing to Reduced Audiences
abstract: In first place in the American League East for more than a month, Toronto still does not have the full trust of its fans after last season’s last-place finish.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — In a city where the last playoff baseball game took place 20 seasons ago, the Blue Jays have been in first place for more than a month. The last time that happened, in 1993, Toronto won the World Series.

headline: Croatian Tennis Star Cilic Rebounds From Suspension, Coached by His Idol
abstract: After seeing his ranking plummet during a ban from play for four months when he tested positive for a stimulant, Marin Cilic found a new appreciation for the game.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Marin Cilic was not yet born when Goran Ivanisevic made his Wimbledon debut in the summer of 1988, beginning an often tortuous history at the All England Club.

headline: Former White House Aide Wins G.O.P. Congressional Primary in New York
abstract: Elise Stefanik, 29, an aide in the administration of George W. Bush, hopes to reclaim for the G.O.P. a district that was once a Republican stronghold.
lead_paragraph: A pair of young Republican candidates emerged from bruising primaries on Tuesday in two congressional districts in New York State where Republicans hope to win Democratic-held seats in November.

headline: Tour a New Building Made of Corn and Mushrooms at MoMA PS1
abstract: In this exclusive video, T tours “Hy-Fi,” a new structure in the Long Island City, Queens museum’s courtyard built with bricks comprised of shredded corn stalks and fungus.
lead_paragraph: Each year, the Museum of Modern Art and MoMA PS1 co-sponsor of the Young Architects Program — a contest in which emerging talents compete for the chance to build a temporary structure in PS1’s courtyard in Long Island City. The projects remain on-site for the duration of each summer, providing both shade and interactivity for PS1 visitors and attendees of the museum’s popular “Warm Up” outdoor concert series.

headline: Time Inc. to Start 120 Sports, a Digital Network, With Pro Leagues
keywords: ['Television', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The new digital network, backed by Time Inc., is hoping to compete with networks like ESPN, using short clips and fast talking.
lead_paragraph: It’s a sports network catering to the shortened attention spans of the mobile and social media generation: 240 clips, each two minutes long, across eight hours of daily programming.

headline: For Fitness, Push Yourself
abstract: To realize the greatest benefits from exercise, we probably need to ramp up our workouts.
lead_paragraph: Intense exercise changes the body and muscles at a molecular level in ways that milder physical activity doesn’t match, according to an enlightening new study. Though the study was conducted in mice, the findings add to growing scientific evidence that to realize the greatest benefits from workouts, we probably need to push ourselves.

headline: Word of the Day | satirical
abstract: This word has appeared in 312 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: satirical •\sə-ˈtir-i-kəl\• adjective

headline: Eli Wallach, Multifaceted Actor on Stage and Screen, Dies at 98
abstract: Mr. Wallach was one of his generation’s most prominent and prolific character actors in film, onstage and on television for more than 60 years.
lead_paragraph: Eli Wallach, who was one of his generation’s most prominent and prolific character actors in film, onstage and on television for more than 60 years, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

headline: Big Jump in Turnout Is Key in Thad Cochran’s Victory
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Democratic black voters play a role in an incumbent senator’s Republican runoff win, possibly a decisive one.
lead_paragraph: Turnout hadn’t increased in a Senate runoff primary election in 30 years until Tuesday night, when a momentous surge of voters allowed Senator Thad Cochran to defeat Chris McDaniel, a Tea Party-backed state senator, in Mississippi’s Republican Senate runoff.

headline: In Rematch, Rangel Holds Lead in a Tight House Primary Race
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Representative Charles B. Rangel, seeking a 23rd term, held a slim lead in a fierce battle early Wednesday with State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat in their primary election contest.
lead_paragraph: Representative Charles B. Rangel, seeking a 23rd term, held a slim lead in a fierce battle early Wednesday with State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat in their primary election contest, a rematch that was largely fought along ethnic and generational lines.

headline: Voters in Mississippi React to Senator Thad Cochran’s Runoff Victory on Twitter
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Following a heated runoff in the Republican Senate primary between Senator Thad Cochran and Chris McDaniel, voters in Mississippi were ready to sound off on social media about what the race meant.
lead_paragraph: After the heated campaign in the Republican Senate runoff between Senator Thad Cochran and State Senator Chris McDaniel, voters in Mississippi were ready to sound off on social media about what the race meant. Their perspectives suggested that although this particular day of voting was over, the lessons from the contest were not settled.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (ABC Family) YOUNG & HUNGRY Gabi (Emily Osment), a sassy food blogger hoping to become the personal chef of Josh (Jonathan Sadowski, above with Ms. Osment), a wealthy tech entrepreneur, must prepare a romantic meal for him and his girlfriend as a test to get the job. But when the dinner goes awry, Gabi transforms the disaster into a chance not only for employment but maybe even love. Ashley Tisdale is an executive producer of this new series, inspired by the musings of Gabi Moskowitz, the San Francisco food blogger behind Brokeass Gourmet. Annie Potts, Kym Whitley, Rex Lee and Aimee Carrero round out the cast.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 25, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 25, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “This is a football World Cup, not about morality, cheap morality.”

headline: Corrections: June 25, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on June 25, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Today’s World Cup Matches: June 25, 2014
abstract: Argentina (Group F) and France (Group E) are in great shape, but other teams also have hopes of advancing.
lead_paragraph: What to watch for in today’s games, as teams from Groups E and F battle to advance in the World Cup. For the complete rundown of advancing scenarios, please visit The Upshot.

headline: Cochran and McDaniel Address Supporters
abstract: Senator Thad Cochran and State Senator Chris McDaniel delivered remarks to their supporters after the Republican primary.
lead_paragraph: Senator Thad Cochran and State Senator Chris McDaniel delivered remarks to their supporters after the Republican primary.

headline: Student Crossword | Building Blocks of Vocabulary
abstract: Test your knowledge of vocabulary and its foundations by playing our crossword.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of vocabulary and its foundations by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: To: Chinese Embassy, United States; Address: No. 1 Liu Xiaobo Plaza
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: A congressional committee in the United States has approved a measure that would rename a street outside the Chinese Embassy in Washington “Liu Xiaobo Plaza,” after the imprisoned political dissident.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:42 a.m.ET|

headline: Sanskrit Newspaper Sees Business Model in New Government
abstract: The editor of a Sanskrit-language weekly newspaper hopes to gain valuable advertising revenue from the newly elected Hindu nationalist government.
lead_paragraph: The Saturday after Narendra Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party’s historic victory in the country’s parliamentary elections was announced, some 40,000 subscribers to a weekly Sanskrit newspaper woke up to a resounding headline:

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Cool at 13, Adrift at 23
abstract: What does a study show about what happened to risk-taking, socially precocious 13-year-olds in later years?
lead_paragraph: In “Cool at 13, Adrift at 23,” Jan Hoffman writes about a new study that followed risk-taking, socially precocious middle school students for a decade.

headline: Bobby Flay’s Chicken Surprise
abstract: Making an old standby delicious, with help from a celebrity chef.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Flay opened a new restaurant, Gato, a few months ago on Lafayette Street in Manhattan. Flay has been a celebrity for the better part of two decades. But he works in the open kitchen at Gato the way people do when they come to New York to make a name for themselves: head down, concentrating, hard. “It’s all I want to do now,” he said recently.

headline: Kendrick Lamar, Hip-Hop’s Newest Old-School Star
abstract: The young M.C. is on a quest to become the best rapper in the world.
lead_paragraph: ‘Everybody just wants to have fun, be with the scene,” Kendrick Lamar said when we met in his cramped quarters inside the Barclays Center in Brooklyn last fall. “Certain people get backstage, people that you would never expect. . . . You ain’t with the media! You ain’t into music! You ain’t into sports! You’re just here.” The rapper, now 27, had just finished his set as the opening act on this stretch of Kanye West’s Yeezus tour, and he was sitting low in an armchair in his trademark black hoodie surrounded by exactly those people.

headline: Ask Well: Diagnosing Fatty Liver
abstract: A reader asks: How do they diagnose fatty liver disease? What harm does it cause the body in its early stages, before cirrhosis, liver cancer and liver failure?
lead_paragraph: Recently, in “Threat Grows From Liver Illness Tied to Obesity,” Anahad O’Connor described the growing epidemic of nonalcoholic fatty liver, an illness that affects at least one in five Americans, including many teenagers. Here he responds to reader questions about fatty liver.

headline: Crisis in Greece and at Home
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: Nikos Pilos specializes in covering crisis. For the last 10 years, that has kept him busy chronicling his homeland’s economic and social problems.
lead_paragraph: Nikos Pilos’s career highlights include a stint in Lebanon during the 1988 civil war, coverage of the Yugoslav wars a couple of years later and 100 days living with civilians outside the Green Zone during the height of the Iraq war.

headline: Elvis Costello Treats Carnegie Hall to a Solo Show
abstract: At the first of two Carnegie Hall concerts, Elvis Costello offered an intimate engagement with old favorites and new songs.
lead_paragraph: If Elvis Costello had dived any deeper into his catalog for his solo concert on Tuesday, opening a two-night stand at Carnegie Hall, he would have needed scuba gear. It wasn’t the kind of solo show by an established rocker that treats a bunch of old favorites as guitar-strumming singalongs for longtime fans. The hall was often silent as Mr. Costello offered something else: a continuing, challenging, intimate engagement with his songs, old and new.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: New York Today: Reading Room Refugees
abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: library habitues regroup, grumpy weather, and Charles Rangel’s slim lead.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this damp Wednesday.

headline: China Unveils New Map of South China Sea
abstract: A vertical map representing China’s claims in the South China Sea shows two disputed clusters of islands entirely within Chinese territory.
lead_paragraph: China is standing tall over its expansive claims to territory in the South China Sea. This week, Hunan Map Publishing House unveiled a new map of China — a vertical representation of the country that includes the vast body of water south of Hainan Island. China’s assertions of ownership in the South China Sea have put it at odds with at least four Southeast Asian nations, which have competing claims, and with the United States, which has said that China’s actions in the region — including having a state-owned oil company place an exploratory oil rig near the Vietnamese coast in May — are creating instability.

headline: New Area of Seafloor Is Mapped in Jet Search
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Satellites', 'Ships and Shipping']
abstract: A ship has begun mapping the Indian Ocean floor in preparation for a renewed search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, though the effort has been complicated by a lack of satellite images.
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — A commercial vessel under contract from the Australian government has begun mapping the floor of the southern Indian Ocean in preparation for a renewed search for Malaysia Airlines’ missing Flight 370, but that search has been complicated by a complete lack of satellite images of the new search area from the week after the plane disappeared.

headline: David Cameron’s Losing Battle
abstract: The British prime minister’s case against Jean-Claude Juncker could well boomerang and feed anti-E.U. sentiments in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Selecting the president of the European Commission, the powerful executive branch of the European Union, has always entailed a lot of politicking and bluster, and there’s been no shortage of that in advance of a meeting of European leaders later this week. The difference this time is that Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain is staunchly opposed to the likely pick, Jean-Claude Juncker of Luxembourg, and that is shaping into a potential turning point for the entire European project. Mr. Cameron has a good case, but he should make sure that his looming defeat does not turn into an irrevocable march toward the “Brexit,” a British exit from the European Union.

headline: In Our Pages: June 26
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: France orders the closing of a refugee camp in the south in 1939; Robert F. Kennedy visits Berlin in 1964.
lead_paragraph: 1939: Camp Ordered Abandoned

headline: Why Government Pension Funds Became Addicted to Risk
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Government Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'Hedge Funds', 'Retirement']
abstract: The steady decline in interest rates has pushed pension funds away from bonds and toward riskier investments.
lead_paragraph: A public pension fund works like this: The government promises to make payments to its employees after they retire; it invests money now and uses those investments, and the returns on them, to make those promised payments later.

headline: Citizen of the State of New York
abstract: Is state citizenship the answer to immigration reform?

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on a lending bank, American hypocrisy, phone hacking, early parole and militarized police.
lead_paragraph: “Some Tea Party members have decided that the United States must shut down the Export-Import Bank of the United States,” a federal agency that helps American businesses sell their goods abroad, writes The New York Times’s editorial board. “The bank provides loans and loan guarantees to foreign businesses to help them buy American products and services.” The board is critical in particular of the efforts of Representative Jeb Hensarling, Republican of Texas, who is “leading the charge” against the bank and appears oblivious to the fact that “if the United States dismantled the bank unilaterally, as some lawmakers are advocating, American companies could lose billions of dollars in overseas orders and decide to move their operations to other countries that provide generous export financing.”

headline: In the Darkness of Myanmar’s Camps, Lighter Moments of Life
keywords: ['Concentration Camps', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Rohingya (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: Adam B. Ellick, a senior video journalist at The Times who made a documentary with the columnist Nicholas Kristof about Myanmar’s oppressed Muslim minority, found a few uplifting moments.
lead_paragraph: Adam B. Ellick has been a senior video journalist at The Times for eight years. This month a documentary that he made with the columnist Nicholas D. Kristof drew so much attention from the international Muslim community that, for the first time, The Times released an Arabic translation of the video. It was released on Monday. Below, Adam shares some footage that was cut from the main documentary.

headline: What We Learned By Doing Employee Reviews
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Small Business']
abstract: In Part 3 of a series, a business owner explains what he learned about his operation from talking to his employees.
lead_paragraph: This series of posts started with an explanation of why I decided to re-institute employee reviews.

headline: Delivery Drones Grounded by F.A.A.
abstract: Regulators this week reiterated the ban on the use of commercial drones, stressing that it included drones for delivery.
lead_paragraph: Delivery drones have barely taken off and they’re already being grounded.

headline: Iran Secretly Sending Drones and Supplies Into Iraq, U.S. Officials Say
keywords: ['International Relations', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)']
abstract: Iran is directing surveillance drones from an airfield in Baghdad and supplying Iraqi forces with tons of military equipment and other supplies, according to American officials.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Iran is directing surveillance drones over Iraq from an airfield in Baghdad and is supplying Iraqi forces with tons of military equipment and other supplies, according to American officials.

headline: Daily Report: Small Music Labels Say YouTube Employs Strong-Arm Tactics
abstract: Small labels contend that consolidation by the major record companies has left them squeezed in negotiations with the online music services that now account for a majority of their revenue.
lead_paragraph: Last year was seen as a great one for indie music, but anxiety about competition and fairness in the digital marketplace runs deep in the independent sector of the music industry. Small labels complain that consolidation by the major record companies has left them squeezed in negotiations with the online music services that now account for a majority of their revenue, Ben Sisario reports.

headline: German Leader Shrugs Off British Opposition on E.U. Post
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel said any attempt by Britain to block the nomination of Jean-Claude Juncker as the next head of the European Commission would fail.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany made it clear on Wednesday that Britain would fail if it tried to stop the nomination of Jean-Claude Juncker as the next head of the European Commission.

headline: East African Court Blocks Paved Serengeti Highway
keywords: ['ANIMALS', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries']
abstract: A court ruling means massive migrations of wildlife will not have to contend with a paved road in the Serengeti.
lead_paragraph: Since 2010, conservationists and wildlife biologists have been fighting Tanzania’s plan to build a paved national highway through the northern part of Serengeti National Park — directly across a migratory path for millions of wildebeests and other grazing mammals.

headline: The Lively Soul of a Decaying City
abstract: Two Manhattan galleries are showcasing works from artists based in Detroit, a city whose artistic history has been too often unsung.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — “There are cities that get by on their good looks, offer climate and scenery, views of mountains or oceans, rockbound or with palm trees,” Elmore Leonard wrote. “And there are cities like Detroit that have to work for a living.”

headline: North Korea Warns U.S. Over Film Mocking Its Leader
abstract: A government spokesman called “The Interview,” a comedy in which two Americans are recruited to kill Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, “an act of war.”
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — For years, anaylsts have said that one of the best kept secrets inside North Korea was that the despotic and often virulently anti-American leader at the time, Kim Jong-il, was a closet fan of Hollywood blockbusters, especially James Bond films. His son, the nation’s current leader, appeared to have picked up the bug, allowing the “Rocky” theme to be played at a special state concert.

headline: Angela Ahrendts Finally Speaks at Apple, and It Is Not What You Expect
abstract: In a LinkedIn post, the former Burberry chief executive offers some observations on starting again.
lead_paragraph: O.K., that’s a bit of an exaggeration. Angela Ahrendts, the former Burberry chief executive lured away to revitalize Apple retail and e-tail did not exactly speak — she wrote a diary entry-cum-inspirational post about her new job, titled “Starting Anew,” on LinkedIn.

headline: Judge Dismisses British Hacking Jury, Hung on Remaining Charges
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The jurors had been deliberating on charges that a onetime tabloid editor and aide to the prime minister paid police officers for royal telephone directories.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was an unspectacular denouement to Britain’s spectacular phone hacking trial: The jury was dismissed Wednesday after failing to reach a verdict on two outstanding charges against Andy Coulson, a former tabloid editor who had been found guilty of conspiracy to intercept voice mail messages a day earlier.

headline: Listen Up | A Brazilian Rock Band to Get You Into the World Cup Groove
abstract: The “uterus-space-groove-rock” quartet Wannabe Jalva is set to go global with their new single, “Mainline,” which debuts exclusively here.
lead_paragraph: It’s World Cup season, and native Brazilians can’t get enough of the attention. “My country is living and breathing soccer more than usual,” says Rafael Rocha, the frontman for the band Wannabe Jalva, which is based in Porto Alegre in the south of the country. “Brazil has kind of stopped for a bit.” Rocha and his bandmates Felipe Puperi, Fernando Paulista and Tiago Abrahão are in an especially celebratory mood these days: they’ve just finished their upcoming, as-yet-untitled EP, and are planning to take their sound — which they’ve curiously taken to calling “uterus-space-groove-rock” — global. “That’s a term we put together only because everybody needs a label,” Rocha explains. “We have so many influences, from newer acts like Queens of the Stone Age to older ones like the Doors. We also have a funk and soul vibe going on. Our music somehow links all of that together … we try not to place any boundaries on ourselves.”

headline: AbbVie Signals It Will Continue to Pursue Irish Drug Maker Shire
abstract: Though AbbVie, based in Chicago, stopped short of raising its $46 billion takeover offer, its presentation and investor call on Wednesday made the case for a deal with Shire.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:28 p.m. |

headline: ABC Anchor Shift Signals Morning’s Triumph
abstract: The news division said it would give George Stephanopoulos responsibility for breaking news and elections, while Ms. Sawyer will focus on investigations.
lead_paragraph: ABC News on Wednesday announced sweeping changes among its top news personalities, with Diane Sawyer to step down as anchor of the network’s evening newscast in August, replaced by David Muir, a rising star anchor at the network.

headline: Princess Cristina of Spain Is Charged in Corruption Case
abstract: A judge concluded that there was enough evidence that she had profited personally and helped her husband with his suspect business activities.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Spanish monarchy was dragged deeper into a corruption case on Wednesday when Princess Cristina was charged with tax fraud and money laundering by a judge investigating whether her husband and business associates had embezzled millions of dollars in public funds earmarked for sports events.

headline: Economy in First Quarter Was Worse Than Everybody Thought
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Gross National Product (GNP)']
abstract: Revised estimates of first-quarter gross domestic product show it was the worst quarter since the recession ended five years ago.
lead_paragraph: The beginning of the year was not just bad for the United States economy; it was — on paper at least — the worst quarter since the last recession ended five years ago.

headline: Barnes & Noble to Spin Off Nook Unit as Sales Continue to Fall
keywords: ['Barnes & Noble Nook', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'E-Books and Readers']
abstract: Barnes & Noble said on Wednesday that it planned to spin off its Nook business, once viewed as the company’s best hope for surviving in an age of a dominant Amazon.com.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:16 p.m. | When it introduced the Nook e-reader in the fall of 2009, Barnes & Noble celebrated it as its answer to Amazon.com and its popular Kindle device.

headline: Morning Agenda: Searching for Young Financial Advisers
abstract: The average financial adviser in the United States is older than 50. | A longtime managing director at Bain Capital is starting a new investment fund. | The law at the heart of the latest Christie inquiry. | The publisher Hachette has agreed to buy Perseus.
lead_paragraph: A HUNT FOR YOUNG FINANCIAL ADVISERS  |  Wall Street has an aging problem. The average financial adviser in the United States is older than 50, a number that shows no sign of getting lower because relatively few young people are interested in the work, Rachel Abrams writes in DealBook. Now, as Wall Street turns more to asset management, it must figure out how to attract and retain a fresh pool of talent that is increasingly looking to find its riches elsewhere.

headline: My Yearly Camp Permethrin Dance
abstract: The week before my two eldest children headed off for a month of open-air sleeping in the woods of northwest Virginia, I made a permethrin solution and soaked their clothes in it.
lead_paragraph: The season of sleep-away camp is upon us, and in our house that means it’s time for the yearly pesticide ritual.

headline: Panel on Suárez Can Weigh Past Incidents as It Decides Punishment
abstract: If the Uruguay player Suárez is found to have bitten Giorgio Chiellini of Italy, he will face his third suspension in four years for biting an opposing player in a game.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The FIFA disciplinary committee investigating Uruguay striker Luis Suárez for apparently biting an opponent during a World Cup match Tuesday has broad authority to consider any evidence, including Suárez’s two past biting incidents, and determine any punishment.

headline: Why You Should Root for Nigeria (or Brazil, Mexico or Ghana)
abstract: An economist has developed a utilitarian index to determine which country’s victory would bring the most happiness.
lead_paragraph: Most of the world considers soccer’s quadrennial World Cup to be the most important sporting competition of all. A growing number of Americans have embraced the event, but many are only vaguely aware of it, and, aside from the United States, not so sure for whom to root.

headline: On a Bronx Street, a Long-Absent Weasel Returns to the City
abstract: A mammal called a fisher, hunted to local extinction long ago for its silky fur, was seen prowling in University Heights.
lead_paragraph: An unfamiliar creature is slinking through the streets of the Bronx.

headline: Aereo Loses at Supreme Court, in Victory for TV Broadcasters
abstract: The United States Supreme Court ruled Wednesday that Aereo, a streaming TV service, had violated broadcast network copyrights — a decision that may ultimately mean the end of the start-up.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Aereo made an all-or-nothing bet. The digital start-up threatened to upend the media industry and transform the way people watch television.

headline: On the Social Responsibility of Wonks
abstract: Taking political realities seriously.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein agonizes over the role of wonkish analysis (which spell-check keeps trying to change to “monkish”) in a political environment in which “facts and smart policy are on the run.” It’s something I worry about too.

headline: Sunni Militants Advance Toward Large Iraqi Dam
abstract: The military has told employees at the Haditha Dam to be prepared to open the floodgates if government forces are unable to hold back the ISIS militants.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi security officials said Wednesday that fighters with the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria were advancing on the Haditha Dam, the second-largest in Iraq, raising the possibility of catastrophic damage and flooding.

headline: Argentina vs. Nigeria: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Argentina has clinched advancement, and will top the group with a win or draw. Nigeria will also advance, unless it loses and Iran beats Bosnia, in which case tie breakers will come into play.
lead_paragraph: Argentina has clinched advancement, and will top the group with a win or draw. Nigeria will also advance, unless it loses and Iran beats Bosnia, in which case tie breakers will come into play.

headline: Bosnia-Herzegovina vs. Iran: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Nothing but pride for one nation; possibly everything for the other. Bosnia is out, and Iran only advances with a win, a Nigeria loss, and favorable goal differential. That could require Iran to score two or three times, which seems like a tall order.
lead_paragraph: Nothing but pride for one nation; possibly everything for the other. Bosnia is out, and Iran only advances with a win, a Nigeria loss, and favorable goal differential. That could require Iran to score two or three times, which seems like a tall order.

headline: Supreme Court Decision in Aereo Case
abstract: Citing copyright law, the justices rejected the streaming service’s model of capturing broadcast signals and delivering them to subscribers.
lead_paragraph: Citing copyright law, the justices rejected the streaming service’s model of capturing broadcast signals and delivering them to subscribers.

headline: Major Ruling Shields Privacy of Cellphones
abstract: In a unanimous decision, the Supreme Court ruled that the vast amount of data contained on modern cellphones must be protected from routine inspection.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a sweeping victory for privacy rights in the digital age, the Supreme Court on Wednesday unanimously ruled that the police need warrants to search the cellphones of people they arrest.

headline: Rangel Leads in Democratic House Primary
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Democratic primary between Representative Charles B. Rangel and his challenger State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat is still too close to call despite a declaration of victory from Mr. Rangel.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic primary between Representative Charles B. Rangel and his challenger State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat is still too close to call despite a declaration of victory from Mr. Rangel.

headline: With History in Mind, Black Voters in Mississippi Aided Cochran
abstract: African-Americans, who coordinated their support for Thad Cochran, said the sacrifice of the Rev. George Lee, who tried to register blacks to vote in the 1950s, was felt in Tuesday’s vote.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Voting rights for black people did not come easily in Mississippi in 1955, but the Rev. George Lee was not one to give up. Using his pulpit and his printing press, he tried to sign up African-Americans in the Delta to vote, despite threats to his life.

headline: ‘Think They Got Killed?’ 1964, L.B.J. and Three Civil Rights Icons
abstract: A secret taping system allows us to eavesdrop as the president and those around him react to a case that transfixed the nation.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago this week, three young civil rights activists — Michael Schwerner, James Chaney and Andrew Goodman — vanished in Neshoba County, Miss.

headline: Mountain Lakes, N.J.: A ‘Resort Getaway’ to Call Home
abstract: Historic homes on spacious lots are scattered throughout the borough, which is on the National Register of Historic Places.
lead_paragraph: Before Herbert J. Hapgood came to Mountain Lakes in 1910, the area was largely woodlands. Over the next dozen years, Mr. Hapgood built a planned community of hundreds of large, Arts-and-Crafts-style houses on lush grounds as summer homes for wealthy New Yorkers. After the Lackawanna Railroad built a station here in 1912, families began seeing Mountain Lakes as a permanent residence.

headline: A Closer Look at 10 of Masterpiece London’s Finest Offerings
abstract: Here, the annual fine art and antique fair’s chairman joins the director of the Victoria and Albert Museum, Elizabeth Hurley and Sir Paul Smith in discussing their favorite finds at this year’s event.
lead_paragraph: Sandwiched between Royal Ascot and the Henley Royal Regatta, the fifth edition of Masterpiece London, the annual fine art and antiques fair, opens its doors tomorrow. For one week, everything from 19th-century Italian paintings to a 2013 Italian Maserati will be up for sale on the South Grounds of the historic Royal Hospital Chelsea.“The London Season has made its return,” says the event’s chairman, Philip Hewat-Jaboor, “and I see Masterpiece very much as the glue that cements the astonishing array of activities in these summer months.”

headline: At 30 Rock, Recreating Rotunda With a Nod to the Past
abstract: Seeking to give visitors an “elevated experience,” and better manage tourist traffic, NBCUniversal has plans to reconstruct a mezzanine lounge for visitors.
lead_paragraph: There was a time in the 1930s and ’40s when the excitement of attending an NBC broadcast at Rockefeller Center began long before you were ushered into Studio 6B, where Bob Hope held forth, or the astonishing 1,500-seat Studio 8H, home of Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra.

headline: The No-Fly List Is Unconstitutional
abstract: Once on, it’s not only difficult to get off but almost impossible to find out why, exactly, one was added in the first place.
lead_paragraph: The federal government’s no-fly list, which prevents those suspected of terrorist ties from boarding flights in the United States or flying through American airspace, is reported to include more than 20,000 names—a number that metastasized after the Sept. 11 attacks. There’s a low evidentiary standard for getting on the list. Once on, it’s not only difficult to get off but almost impossible to find out why, exactly, one was added in the first place.

headline: Germany Can Inflict Pain on the U.S., as It Has Before
abstract: This German soccer squad is not about to waltz to a cowardly draw with the Americans in their World Cup match on Thursday, even if it would suit both teams.
lead_paragraph: How can Germany make the United States suffer this time?

headline: N.F.L. Makes Open-Ended Commitment to Retirees in Concussion Suit
abstract: The guarantee is part of a revised settlement in a contentious lawsuit filed by about 5,000 retired players who accused the league of hiding the dangers of concussions from them.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has made an open-ended commitment to pay cash awards to retired players who have dementia and other conditions linked to repeated head hits, according to documents filed in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania on Wednesday.

headline: Teddy Roosevelt’s Confederate Uncles
abstract: How the future president’s Southern relatives shaped his worldview as president.
lead_paragraph: On June 19, 1864, the Confederacy lost one of its most effective weapons of the Civil War: In the Battle of Cherbourg off the coast of France, the Union warship Kearsarge sunk the notorious Confederate commerce raider, the Alabama. In its two-year career, the Alabama had claimed 65 ships, totaling $6 million, a huge hit to the Union war effort. The Alabama continued to wreak posthumous havoc after the war; since it had been built in England, in the late 1860s the United States pressed a claim for damages, even threatening to invade Canada as compensation.

headline: House Hunting in ... South Wales
abstract: The recession halted the rise in values, but agents said prices had fallen very little, if at all, on the Gower Peninsula.

headline: For Budding Book Lovers
abstract: In two new picture books, precious books go missing, and have to be found — or recreated.
lead_paragraph: Reliability is one of the things book lovers cherish about books. The words books contain are the same on every reading; set a book down, and there it stays, until you are ready to pick it up again. But in two new picture books, “My Pet Book,” written and illustrated by Bob Staake (“The Red Lemon,” “Bluebird,” “The Donut Chef”) and “Brother Hugo and the Bear,” written by Katy Beebe and illustrated by S.D. Schindler, precious books go missing, and have to be found — or recreated.

headline: What It Takes to Legalize Sex Work
abstract: As Canada reconsiders its prostitution laws, the debate around sex work has spread to related issues of women’s rights, JAKE FLANAGIN writes.
lead_paragraph: A bill introduced in Canada by Prime Minister Stephen Harper’s Conservative government would criminalize buying sexual services but would not necessarily make selling them illegal. It follows a Canadian Supreme Court ruling last year that overturned most laws governing the sex trade.

headline: Rangel Wins House Primary Rematch

headline: ‘What Would You Think of Living in Luxembourg?’
abstract: His whole life spent in New York State, an author and his family reinvent normal at the intersection of France, Belgium and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the opposite of fun: One of your 5-year-old twins has fallen from a tall, dangerous playground apparatus, and possibly broken a bone, and so you are in an emergency room where English is not spoken, trying to have a type of conversation for which Berlitz doesn’t prepare you, and the pain and suffering and maybe long-term well-being of your kid hang in the balance.

headline: Restaurant Report: Suliko Restorani in Hollywood, Fla.
abstract: Homey, rich tastes of Georgia — of the former Soviet Union — in South Florida.
lead_paragraph: If you know Suliko Restorani, it’s probably because of the word-of-mouth reviews that flow among Soviet-bloc immigrants living in South Florida. Unmarked and unadvertised, Suliko opened in July 2013 at the back of Aquarius, a nondescript condominium in Hollywood, Fla., and quickly became the go-to spot for Russian speakers, until recently a majority of patrons.

headline: Scene City: Broadway Comes to Central Park

headline: Malaria Prevention, With Both Reward and Risk
abstract: Drug interventions in some African countries can help prevent the disease, but can also speed the spread of antibiotic resistance. To some, it’s worth the trade-off.
lead_paragraph: Alassane Dicko shivered and sweated through part of his childhood. Sick with frequent bouts of malaria, he often missed school. His older brother died of malaria, and so did his best friend. This disease can be cured with a pill, yet it claims about 1,700 lives each day — mainly children in sub-Saharan Africa who don’t take this medicine within a week of falling sick. Even when kids survive, some remain disabled or irrecoverably behind in school. That’s why Dicko, now a malaria researcher at the University of Bamako in Mali, took matters into his own hands when he became a father.Dicko gives malaria medicine to his children before they get the disease during the rainy season — the period when the mosquito-borne illness peaks in Mali. Tourists do something similar by taking malaria drugs prophylactically on trips to Africa, but for decades, health officials have said that Africans should not do so, because the widespread use of a drug eventually renders that drug ineffective. However, Dicko, who studies malaria prevention, has come to believe that the immediate health benefits are worth that risk.After a decade of clinical trials demonstrated that the preventive measure reduces malaria cases by 75 percent, medical authorities reversed their position against it, in areas where it’s most effective. They decided that the number of lives saved outweighs the cost of losing these drugs eventually. “For every drug you give, you will increase the risk of drug resistance,” Dicko says. “But these drugs are efficacious right now, so why don’t we use them and save thousands of lives?”

headline: 36 Hours in Stockholm
abstract: The center of the Swedish capital is lovely and historic, but there are new galleries, boutiques and breweries farther out worth exploring.
lead_paragraph: If Stockholm residents seem particularly smug these days, it’s for good reason. The Swedish capital has long ranked among the loveliest in Europe, with an inner-city beauty characterized by stately architecture and graceful waterways. But openings in outlying neighborhoods — galleries in the north, boutiques in the south, a craft brewery in the suburbs, art in the archipelago — are expanding the limits of the city worth exploring. Add to that Stockholm’s exciting restaurant scene, born from the popular New Nordic food movement, and the hometown pride is perfectly understandable.

At 34, without a title in a Grand Slam event since 2008 and with just one third-round appearance at a major since 2012, who can resist the temptation of asking?

headline: Classical Playlist: Verdi, Schubert, Michael Gordon and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: VERDI: ‘Don Carlo’Jon Vickers, Gré Brouwenstijn, Tito Gobbi and other singers.The Covent Garden Orchestra and Opera Chorus, Carlo Maria Giulini, conductor(Andromeda; three CDs)This live 1958 recording of Verdi’s “Don Carlo” from the Royal Opera in London, though not an ideal performance, is great to have. Of particular interest is Jon Vickers in the title role. Here, Vickers is early in his career before it became clear that he would be the great dramatic tenor of his generation, bringing a powerhouse voice and expressive intensity to roles like Wagner’s Tristan and Verdi’s Otello. This is Vickers in a more youthful, lyric mode, but still singing with chilling power and ardency, despite occasional moments of strain in his high range. The cast boasts Gré Brouwenstijn as Elisabetta, Tito Gobbi as Rodrigo, Fedora Barbieri as Eboli, and Boris Christoff as Filippo II. The great Carlo Maria Giulini conducts a majestic account of the score. The performance comes through cleanly on this remastered recording. (Anthony Tommasini)

Let’s stop it.”

headline: In Iraq, Switching Allegiance Once Again

abstract: Watching a recent ISIS video of militants forcing Iraqi soldiers to switch allegiance, a former Marine wonders what happened to the Iraqi soldiers he helped train in Anbar Province, some of them Sunnis with little chance for promotion in the Shiite-led army.
lead_paragraph: For a few days last week before YouTube pulled the video, “Clanging of the Swords IV” gave a graphic visual account of the violence unfolding in Iraq. The hourlong reel is a mash-up of attacks, allegedly by militants with the Sunni extremist group Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, against Iraqi security forces: drive-by shootings; roadside bombings; a beheading. Like most jihadi videos, it has a soundtrack of atonal religious chanting.

headline: Movement and Space Have a Meet-Up
abstract: Jill Sigman’s "(Perma)Culture” examines how dance movements alter the perception of space.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Jill Sigman, it’s safe to say, is fueled by a sensitivity for perceiving the movement in nature and the nature in movement. Her latest work, “(Perma)Culture,” performed last Thursday at Danspace Project, gathers eight dancers, dozens of ceramic objects, several pieces of sod and a timekeeper — Mary Suk — to explore connections between movement research and permacultural design.

headline: ‘Boomerang Kids’ Article Prompts a Rich Range of Views
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Parenting', 'Recession and Depression', 'Youth']
abstract: Within an hour of its publication online on Friday, a New York Times Magazine story had more than 1,000 comments.
lead_paragraph: Within an hour of its publication online on Friday, a New York Times Magazine story about “boomerang kids” – young adults who move back in with their parents after graduating from college – was a hit. During that morning’s news meeting, Karron Skog, the day editor, and Ian Fisher, an assistant managing editor, said they would give the story more prominent promotion based on its web traffic and comment numbers. By 5 p.m. the story had drawn nearly 1,000 comments; by Sunday, when the piece ran in print, it had 1,657 comments.

headline: German Artist Wins the BP Portrait Award With Depiction of Homeless Man
abstract: A portrait of a homeless man, “Man With a Plaid Blanket,” by Thomas Ganter, won the award for $50,922.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A portrait of a homeless man, “Man With a Plaid Blanket,” by Thomas Ganter, has won the BP Portrait Award, the National Portrait Gallery announced here on Tuesday. Mr. Ganter, who is the first German artist to win the prize, an annual award aimed at encouraging artists to focus on portrait-painting, received £30,000 or roughly $50,922 at an award ceremony hosted by the actor Nigel Havers. The prize, which is sponsored by BP, also includes a commission to paint a portrait for the National Portrait Gallery’s permanent collection.

lead_paragraph: Benjamin Scheuer is the center of attention. After a performance of “The Lion,” his coming-of-age solo musical, audience members mill about Manhattan Theater Club’s studio space, where the show is playing. The ladies flock to him first, perhaps attracted by his linen suit, mop of sandy hair and slight British lilt, a product of his bicontinental heritage.
