abstract: The department said that Dr. Robert L. Jesse, the acting under secretary for health, and Will A. Gunn, the general counsel, would be leaving.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Veterans Affairs said Wednesday that two senior officials would be leaving their posts as the department’s acting secretary moved to remake the agency and rebuild trust amid a scandal over falsified waiting lists that were used at many hospitals to hide delays faced by veterans.

headline: To the Cup, the Long Way Round
abstract: Why take an expensive direct flight to the World Cup in Brazil, when you can take a more adventurous journey through four countries over 16 days?
lead_paragraph: It can take about 16 hours and two flights to get from New York City to Natal, Brazil, where the United States took on Ghana in their World Cup opener last week.

headline: Messi Lifts Spirits of Argentines, Even Those Without Tickets
abstract: Lionel Messi and Ahmed Musa each scored two goals, but Argentina defeated Nigeria on Wednesday. Both teams advanced to the knockout stages.
lead_paragraph: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil — An estimated 50,000 Argentines completed the trek to this World Cup city by Wednesday morning. Many of the soccer pilgrims were wearing long faces along with their Lionel Messi jerseys as they roamed the parks and the streets and took in the hazy view of Guaíba Lake while carrying hand-lettered signs that read, “Compro” (“I’m buying”).

headline: Oculus Portrays Accuser as Opportunist, in Lawsuit Over Virtual Reality Technology
abstract: In a filing Wednesday in the Federal District Court in Dallas, Oculus said ZeniMax was largely indifferent to virtual reality in general and Oculus in particular until Facebook announced a $2 billion agreement to acquire Oculus.
lead_paragraph: Oculus VR fired back at ZeniMax Media on Wednesday in its first formal response to accusations that it stole ZeniMax virtual reality technology.

headline: Machiavelli in Mississippi
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Cochran comeback and the politics of voting.
lead_paragraph: There are moments when debates about policy and ideology and The Direction of the Republican Party have to take a back seat to an appreciation of politics-as-politics: The second oldest profession, the game of thrones and transactions, the sleazy science of relationships and favors and dealmaking and turnout and (with apologies to Charlie Sheen) winning. And the spectacle of Thad Cochran — which is to say, yes, the Haley Barbour political machine — pulling out an unlikely comeback in the Mississippi Senate run-off by persuading African-American Democrats to turn out in a G.O.P. primary is such an occasion: A time to savor some of the historical ironies at work, to appreciate the establishment’s back-to-the-wall strategery, and to let the Penn Warren-ish phrase “Barbour brothers” roll over and over on your tongue.

headline: The Art of the ‘Vacationship’
abstract: Kristin Newman, a comedy writer, talks about finding romance while on vacation.
lead_paragraph: “I love to do the thing you’re supposed to do in the place you’re supposed to do it.”

headline: Lana Del Rey Scores Her First No. 1 Album
abstract: The singer achieved the top ranking despite having done little of the standard high-profile promotional appearances that usually precede a major release.
lead_paragraph: Lana Del Rey, the pouty, retro torch singer for the millennial generation, scored her first No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart with her new album, “Ultraviolence” (Polydor/Interscope), beating out new releases by the young British vocalist Sam Smith and the rock band Linkin Park.

headline: Rate Manipulations May Distort Banks’ Market Risk Models
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The question for regulators and investors is whether the manipulation of benchmark rates like Libor has created a mirage of well-capitalized financial institutions, writes Mayra Rodríguez Valladares in Another View.
lead_paragraph: Mayra Rodríguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm in New York. She also teaches at Financial Markets World and the New York Institute of Finance.

headline: What Are You Really Worth to Your Employer?
abstract: Banks and other companies buy life insurance on their employees, reaping tax-free windfalls.
lead_paragraph: Chief executives are always going on about how employees are their companies’ most valuable assets. They say it even as wages stagnate and executive pay skyrockets. They say it amid layoffs and as non-executive jobs are shifted overseas along with company profits.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': When To Hold Back, When to Let Go
abstract: John Lithgow on how he’s learned to modulate his energy in rehearsing “King Lear,” after sitcom experience “conducted at a pace far over the speed limit.”
lead_paragraph: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: League of His Own
abstract: A fictional portrayal of the manager credited with transforming the Liverpool football club.
lead_paragraph: If ever there was a time to interest the American reading public in a 700-page novel about a real-life British soccer coach, it might just possibly be now, with David Beckham an A-list celebrity (and underwear model), and the 2014 World Cup underway.

headline: Barclays Faces New York Lawsuit Over Dark Pool and High-Frequency Trading
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Eric T. Schneiderman filed civil fraud charges against the British bank, contending that it favored high frequency traders over other investors.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:25 p.m. | The top law enforcer in New York State, Eric T. Schneiderman, filed civil fraud charges on Wednesday against Barclays over its private stock trading platform, contending that it favored high-frequency traders over other investors.

headline: A Group Show Celebrates the Art of Cycling
abstract: “Joyride,” an exhibition at Marlborough Broome Street, kicks off the 14th annual Bicycle Film Festival with works by such artists as Ai Weiwei, Francesco Clemente and Kiki Smith.
lead_paragraph: Opening tonight at Marlborough Gallery’s Broome Street location is “Joyride,” a group art show that inaugurates the 14th edition of the annual Bicycle Film Festival. For the exhibition — the latest in an annual series of art events tied to the festival — artists such as Ai Weiwei, Tim Barber, Francesco Clemente, Andrew Guenther, KAWS, Richard Prince, Tom Sachs and Kiki Smith have contributed cycling-themed work. Some, like Clemente and Guenther, created pieces specially for the show.

headline: In Inheritance Battle, Judge Sides Against the Perelmans
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: A judge ruled against Samantha Perelman, the daughter of the billionaire investor Ronald O. Perelman, who had tried to argue that her uncle, the head of Hudson Media, had unduly cut her out of part of her inheritance.
lead_paragraph: The bitter legal fight involving Samantha Perelman, the daughter of the billionaire investor Ronald O. Perelman, came to an end on Wednesday, when a superior court judge ruled that Ms. Perelman’s uncle did not cut her out of her inheritance by unfairly manipulating her dying grandfather.

headline: Small Blasts Across Cairo Disrupt Calm Since Election
abstract: Five small bombs exploded around the capital in the first such attacks since the election of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi this month.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Five small bombs exploded around Egypt’s capital within two hours on Wednesday, injuring six people in the first such attacks since the election of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi this month.

headline: Between the Lines of the Cellphone Privacy Ruling
abstract: In a pathbreaking case on Fourth Amendment privacy rights and modern technology, the Supreme Court unanimously ruled that the police must obtain warrants before searching the digital contents of cellphones taken from people who are placed under arrest. Here are some key points in the opinion by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and a concurrence by Justice Samuel Alito.
lead_paragraph: In a pathbreaking case on Fourth Amendment privacy rights and modern technology, the Supreme Court unanimously ruled that the police must obtain warrants before searching the digital contents of cellphones taken from people who are placed under arrest. Here are some key points in the opinion by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and a concurrence by Justice Samuel Alito.

headline: Red Bulls and M.L.S. Return to Field
abstract: The Red Bulls and the rest of the teams in Major League Soccer return to action this weekend after a break during the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: They’re back. Well almost.

headline: Google Unveils Android Expansion
abstract: Sundar Pichai, a senior vice president at Google, spoke about Android’s expansion during his keynote address at the Google I/O developers conference in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Sundar Pichai, a senior vice president at Google, spoke about Android’s expansion during his keynote address at the Google I/O developers conference in San Francisco.

headline: Dallas and Cleveland Are Finalists for G.O.P Convention
abstract: The two cities made the final list after Denver and Kansas City, Mo., were eliminated from contention.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The 2016 Republican National Convention will be held in Cleveland or Dallas, the party announced Wednesday.

headline: Goldman Sachs Reorganizes Investment Banking Division
abstract: The move by Goldman to combine its consumer retail and health care investment banking groups comes as drug company takeovers and retail advisory deals are on the rise.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is combining its consumer retail and health care investment banking groups, according to an internal memorandum sent on Wednesday. The move comes as drug company takeovers and retail advisory deals are on the rise.

headline: G.M. Holds a Corvette Track Day for Potential Customers
abstract: The company used Polk data to find the drivers, sent them letters and let them flail new Corvette Stingrays on the track.
lead_paragraph: MILLVILLE, N.J. — There is probably no better way to sell sports cars than to get people talking about how hot they are on a track. Last week, more than 170 people statistically selected by Chevrolet were able to do just that, getting to drive the 2014 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray at New Jersey Motorsports Park.

headline: The Supreme Court Saves Cellphone Privacy
abstract: In a gratifying ruling, all nine justices embraced the digital age by protecting cellphones from being searched without a warrant.
lead_paragraph: The nine justices of the Supreme Court — whose average age is 68 — often admit to being unfamiliar with modern technology, if not befuddled by it. While listening to oral arguments in April, Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. asked, with apparent sincerity, why anyone other than a criminal would carry two cellphones.

headline: Medium Hires Tech Writer Steven Levy as It Moves From Platform to Publisher
abstract: Mr. Levy is the most prominent writer hired full time by the site, which began as a place where anyone can write but is adding more professionals.
lead_paragraph: Medium, the online writing system created by Evan Williams, one of the founders of Twitter, has been something of a tabula rasa. Its publishing system and pretty interface have drawn raves, but as a media business it has been tough to pin down.

headline: With ‘Boyhood,’ a Portrait Every Year
abstract: Accompanying David Marchese’s story about Richard Linklater’s film ”Boyhood,” a 12-year project, is a slideshow of portraits of Ellar Coltrane, who grows up onscreen as the main character. The photographer, Matt Lankes, recently talked a bit about working on a movie for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: Accompanying David Marchese’s story about Richard Linklater’s film ”Boyhood,” a 12-year project, is a slideshow of portraits of Ellar Coltrane, who grows up onscreen as the main character. In taking these pictures, Matt Lankes developed a relationship with Coltrane that he hopes will continue beyond the film’s completion. Lankes recently talked a bit about working on a movie for more than a decade.

headline: The First Rule of Stir-Fries: Be Prepared
abstract: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist and cookbook author, lays the groundwork for stir-fries, and answers readers’ questions.
lead_paragraph: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist and cookbook author, is working with the Ruder family (Renee, her husband, Chris, and their three daughters, ages 11, 9 and 7) to help these meat lovers adopt a plan of eating two vegetarian meals a week without feeling deprived; and to take advantage of a C.S.A., a community-supported agriculture program basket often filled with foods to which they are unaccustomed. This week, while Renee is out of town, Martha lays the groundwork for stir-fries, and answers readers’ questions.

headline: What the Aereo Decision Means for TV
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled that Aereo violated copyright law, granting television networks a much-desired win that will preserve the status quo — at least for now.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled that Aereo violated copyright law, granting television networks a much-desired win that will preserve the status quo — at least for now.

headline: Buffeted by Tumult, Jewish Population in Tunisia Dwindles
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Synagogues']
abstract: Tunisia has been a center of Jewish life since Roman times, but only about 2,000 Jews remain in the country — down from more than 100,000 in 1948.
lead_paragraph: DJERBA, Tunisia — On a recent Sabbath morning, just five men sat reciting prayers in the sanctuary of the Ghriba synagogue, the oldest synagogue in North Africa and the holiest place for the Orthodox Jews who live here on the resort island of Djerba.

headline: Contentment at a Hell’s Kitchen Diner
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Two broke friends turned existential angst into joy when they looked around and realized, in a good way, that it didn’t get better than this.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary,

headline: David Muir’s Youth Appeal
abstract: Some highlights of Mr. Muir’s on-air style. The anchor will take the reins of ABC’s evening news in a move that executives hope will appeal to younger viewers.
lead_paragraph: Some highlights of Mr. Muir’s on-air style. The anchor will take the reins of ABC’s evening news in a move that executives hope will appeal to younger viewers.

headline: Smithsonian Festival Will Stay at National Mall for Now
keywords: ['National Mall (Washington, DC)', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: The annual Folklife Festival can stay at the mall until 2019 while the organizers work out the logistics and expense of complying with regulations to preserve the mall’s expensive new turf.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The turf war on the National Mall has reached a cease-fire, for now.

headline: For Many Mormon Athletes, Mission Is to Play
keywords: ['Basketball', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Athletics and Sports']
abstract: Jabari Parker’s decision to forgo formal missionary work for the N.B.A. raised eyebrows among some fellow Mormons, but others say he will still be an ambassador for his church.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, an N.B.A. team will select Jabari Parker, a 19-year-old basketball prodigy, with one of the top picks in the 2014 draft.

headline: House Panel Seeks to Block Washington Marijuana Law
abstract: The action by the House Appropriations Committee is a stumbling block for a new law decriminalizing small amounts of marijuana in the District of Columbia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Appropriations Committee passed a measure on Wednesday to bar the District of Columbia from using either federal or local funds in carrying out a new law decriminalizing the possession of small amounts of marijuana, a move that could block the law if approved by Congress.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Valentino Spring/Summer 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Raf Simons: Spring 2015 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: A Selfless Man: David Peace Talks About Bill Shankly and ‘Red or Dead’
abstract: Mr. Peace’s new novel is about the soccer manager Bill Shankly.
lead_paragraph: The British novelist David Peace’s “Red Riding” quartet, which was turned into three films, followed the hunt for a serial killer in Yorkshire. His 2006 novel “The Damned Utd,” about the Leeds United soccer manager Brian Clough, was turned into a movie starring Michael Sheen.

headline: Opening and Sales for the Week of June 26
abstract: Tia Cibani will open a summer pop-up; Pret-à-Surf has collaborated with J. Crew and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: Openings

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Three’s a Trend | At the Spring/Summer 2015 Men’s Wear Shows, Printed Shirts and Ties Get Matchy-Matchy
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: Designers showed shirt-and-neckwear combinations that utilized the same humorous pattern.
lead_paragraph: There are so many competing guides, tutorials and rules out there for creating the right shirt-and-tie combination that it all seems a bit arbitrary and overcomplicated. Judging from what we’ve seen at the spring/summer 2015 Milan and Pitti Uomo shows, there might a be a less confusing (and more cheeky) approach to try: shirts and ties that implement the same humorous print. Massimiliano Giornetti, the creative director of Salvatore Ferragamo, paired a tie with a matching shirt emblazoned with grazing giraffes. Marc Jacobs, whose collection featured cool interpretations of pastels and flamingo imagery, showed a shirt and tie, both in a pink fern print, under a dusty rose checked suit that somehow still maintained an edge. The Z Zegna show, which was at Pitti Uomo in Florence this season, displayed a smart balance of athletic wear and fine Italian tailoring. One example was a pentagonal polka dot shirt with an elasticated hem, worn with a matching tie and trainers.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Iraq, England, the Philippines and Washington, D.C.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Iraq, England, the Philippines and Washington, D.C.

headline: Talented Bulgarian Leads Youthful Assault on Big 4
abstract: Grigor Dimitrov, a 23-year-old Bulgarian and one of the top young men’s tennis players, cruised to victory Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — There is an unmistakable buzz around the hallowed Centre Court when Grigor Dimitrov, a 23-year-old Bulgarian, steps onto the manicured lawn. It is not merely in anticipation that his special lady friend, Maria Sharapova, might make an unscheduled appearance in the players’ box.

headline: Longer Heart Monitoring Backed for Stroke Patients
abstract: Two new studies suggest that atrial fibrillation may be the unrecognized cause of many strokes, and that patients should be monitored for a month to find out.
lead_paragraph: More than a half-million Americans every year have an ischemic stroke, the most common form, which disrupts blood flow to the brain. And at least a quarter of these cases have no apparent underlying cause.

headline: Newly Released Books
abstract: New books include a collection of Jane Gardam’s stories and David Guterson’s “Problems With People.”
lead_paragraph: CLOSED DOORSBy Lisa O’Donnell249 pages. Harper. $26.99.

headline: In a Balancing Act, Carving Space From Ledge to Ledge With a Strut
abstract: Souleymane Badolo, a dancer and choreographer from Burkina Faso, performed “Virgule de l’histoire” (“Comma of history”) as part of the River to River Festival.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday afternoon in the courtyard next to the John Street United Methodist Church in Lower Manhattan, a striking man stood on a narrow concrete ledge and gazed at a small crowd gathered beneath him. The man was Souleymane Badolo, a dancer and choreographer from Burkina Faso who has lived and worked in New York since 2009. The crowd came to watch his “Virgule de l’histoire” (“Comma of history”), part of the River to River Festival.

headline: Italy Gets Real
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Design', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: At Italy’s men’s fashion week, craftsmanship and pride stood out.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Her face a mask of immobility, her skin spray-tanned to the color of bacon, Anna Dello Russo — camera-magnet and editor at large for Vogue Japan — grasped a hand-held clad in the season’s hot accessory, a phone case resembling a bottle of Chanel No. 5.

headline: The Return of Real Blood and Other Medical Norms
abstract: The second season of “NY Med,” a hospital documentary series on ABC, features medical cases of true urgency.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Mehmet Oz, the cardiac surgeon and television personality, has been making headlines for all the wrong reasons lately, but when he turns up in the premiere of the new season of “NY Med,” ABC’s documentary hospital series, he’s not much of a distraction. That’s because his patient, a young man who turns out to have a tear in his aorta, is in such agony that he commands all your attention.

headline: Another Spelling Production
abstract: The wife of the TV megaproducer Aaron Spelling has a new book out, just one of her many endeavors.
lead_paragraph: Candy Spelling uses the Internet, but she can’t bring herself to try dating sites. “They scare me,” she said.

headline: A Mystical Offering of Grateful Devotion
abstract: Savion Glover’s tap-dance piece “OM” features three sections and several co-stars.
lead_paragraph: With each passing summer Savion Glover slips into the Joyce Theater with a new show that strives to strip tap to its purest spirit. There’s always a mood to go with it. Will Mr. Glover be playful? Withdrawn? Bizarre? This season, he’s intent on showing a more mystical side; “OM” — unsettling, yet hypnotic — falls under weird. Performed on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, the work relies on a spiritual beat to sync the past with the present that begins with Mr. Glover’s decisive feet and emanates through his body in waves of remembrance, homage, allegiance. This is worship.

headline: Senior U.S. Prosecutor Who Fought Wall St. Is Departing
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Insider Trading', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Lorin L. Reisner, who helped overhaul the S.E.C.’s enforcement unit before heading the criminal division of the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan, is expected to join a law firm.
lead_paragraph: After five years of tussling with Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and the giant hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors, Lorin L. Reisner is ready for a change.

headline: War’s Lingering Requiem in Vietnam
abstract: A museum in Vietnam memorialized the work of photographers who died covering the conflict. It includes indelible images by Western and North Vietnamese photographers.
lead_paragraph: A museum in Vietnam memorialized the work of photographers who died covering the conflict. It includes indelible images by Western and North Vietnamese photographers.

headline: Updating the Gold Standard to Platinum
abstract: Platinum blond is the shade for summer.
lead_paragraph: For the last decade, Kaitlyn Cullinane has had her light-brown hair highlighted with golden tones in the winter and lighter ones during the warmer months. This year she decided to try something a little more dramatic.

headline: Even Advice Isn’t Free Anymore
abstract: Some people are charging for the kind of career advice once offered for free, and the growing freelance economy may be to blame, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: Are your friends always coming to you for advice? Maybe you could start a business. Charging for what might once have been informal counsel is becoming more common — and the growing freelance economy may be behind the shift.

headline: Deal to End Senate Rift May Give Democrats Full Control in Albany
abstract: The move, brokered in part by Mayor Bill de Blasio, could leave Democrats in full control of the state government as soon as early next year.
lead_paragraph: A group of independent Democrats who share control of the New York State Senate with Republicans agreed on Wednesday to reunite with their fellow Democrats, a move that could shift the balance of power in Albany.

headline: The Man Who Hated Gravity, Part 2
abstract: More on Roger Babson, and on the real danger facing George Clooney and Sandra Bullock in “Gravity.”
lead_paragraph: In my recent column about Roger Babson, the eccentric tycoon who tried to save humanity from the deadly force of gravity, I noted that for all its perils — death by avalanche, drowning and so forth — gravity is far from a complete villain. It sustains life on earth by holding in the atmosphere. But as you get higher above the planet, the air becomes steadily thinner until, in space, a person without a protective suit would die as surely as a swimmer pulled to the bottom of a lake. Danger lurks above and below.

headline: Knicks Agree to Trade Chandler and Felton to Mavericks
abstract: In Phil Jackson’s boldest move to date, the Knicks agreed to send Raymond Felton and Tyson Chandler to the Mavericks in exchange for a package including Jose Calderon.
lead_paragraph: Phil Jackson has been fairly methodical in his short tenure as the Knicks’ president.

headline: At Google I/O Conference, Protesters Inside and Out
abstract: Inside the Google I/O developer conference, people were cheering for Google. Outside, people were protesting against Google, accusing it of playing a role in housing problems and evictions in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Inside the darkened auditorium of the Google I/O developer conference in San Francisco, 6,000 people cheered, yelled and clapped as Google executives showed off the company’s latest wares.

headline: Which Way Do the Sneaker Prints Lead?
abstract: In London, Milan and Paris, journalists and models prefer leather lace-ups.
lead_paragraph: Is the runway a two-way street? The thought occurred to one observer as he wended his way through the men’s fashion weeks. One particular style of shoe — the white sneaker, low-topped, often in leather — recurred again and again, on the runway and in the front rows. It raised the question: Do trends trickle down, or do they trickle up?

headline: A Provocateur Prepares to Show His Quiet Side
abstract: A first look at Loewe’s men’s line under the creative direction of Jonathan Anderson, and its new advertising campaign
lead_paragraph: Two days before his men’s wear presentation for Loewe, the first since his appointment as creative director last September, Jonathan Anderson was standing at the company’s soon-to-be-former headquarters on the Rue François Ier in Paris. It would be a goodbye of sorts to the place where he has spent much of his time these last eight months. The presentation will be held at the new offices, on St.-Sulpice. The space will be not only an office and headquarters, but for the first time, the home of the design team, which Mr. Anderson has imported from the label’s native Madrid.

headline: United Church of Christ Joins Sponsors of Gay Games
abstract: A church known for its longtime support of diversity will be a sponsor event which is held every four years.
lead_paragraph: A PROTESTANT denomination known for its longtime support of religious diversity and inclusion has agreed to become a sponsor of the 2014 edition of the Gay Games, to be held in northeast Ohio from Aug. 9 to 16.

headline: Q. and A.: William C. Kirby on ‘Can China Lead?’
abstract: In the book “Can China Lead?”, three business school professors looked at the motors for and the constraints against greatness that China is experiencing. One of the authors, William C. Kirby, explains what they found.
lead_paragraph: In the book “Can China Lead?: Reaching the Limits of Power and Growth,” William C. Kirby and F. Warren McFarlan of Harvard Business School and Regina M. Abrami of the Wharton School explore whether China will become the world’s leading power.

headline: Summer With a Fringe Built In
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Dresses', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Shopping Bags', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: Borrowing flourishes from recent fall runways; Versace and Superga team up on a sneaker and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: Texture was big on the fall runways, which were a frenzy of fur and feathers in artful assemblages and rainbows of colors. No need, though, to wait to try out an artsy-craftsy look for yourself. For summer, think fur-like. Ryan Roche, who works in upstate New York, uses crocheted cashmere for her lovely furry fringe sweaters. Maria Cornejo used a synthetic feather effect for a shrug and as trim on a silk dress. Other labels, like Chloé and Samuji, a young Finnish line to watch, have affixed fringe all over lightweight sweaters and linen dresses. At a recent Acria event to raise money for H.I.V. research and education, the fashionable art director Sofía Sanchez Barrenechea wore an ostrich feather and faille tulip dress from Jason Wu’s spring 2010 collection, proving that not every soiree calls for a brand-new frock, just one you want to reach out and touch.

headline: Little in Common, Save a Continent
abstract: The New York Asian Film Festival, opening on Friday, features 60 feature films.
lead_paragraph: The New York Asian Film Festival, whose 13th edition begins on Friday, can kindly be described as eclectic. Other festivals may stick to a theme or reflect a particular curatorial vision. The Asian Film Festival is all over the place. (And it’s a very big place.).

headline: Shedding Light on Nazi-Occupied Paris
abstract: Published nearly 70 years ago in France, “The Diary of the Dark Years” captures a writer’s firsthand account of the Nazi occupation in Paris.
lead_paragraph: If Jean Guéhenno had never existed, France would surely have had to invent him. A model writer and intellectual who neither collaborated nor accommodated the enemy, he refused to publish a single word as long as his country was under Nazi control. A leading essayist of the Popular Front, regularly skewered by the far right, he vowed, as of July 1940, to confine his thoughts and feelings to a private journal. It is a mystery why “Diary of the Dark Years, 1940-1944,” first published in 1947 and still a standard reference in France, is only now appearing in English in a fine translation by David Ball. Is there something about our own political climate that allows us finally to hear Guéhenno’s voice clearly?

headline: Classic Folk, Tested for Signs of Jazz
abstract: With a new ensemble, Tierney Sutton performed much of her recently released Joni Mitchell tribute album, “After Blue,” at Birdland on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The West Coast singer Tierney Sutton would seem to be an ideal translator of Joni Mitchell songs into a jazz idiom because so many of them traverse traditional boundaries of pop, rock and folk to be their own thing, whatever you want to call it. Ms. Sutton, who does her own version of the same thing, recently released a mildly experimental Mitchell tribute album, “After Blue” (BFM Jazz), that plays with the songs’ rhythms, inserts improvisatory vocal passages and takes other liberties without bending them out of shape.

headline: Team Player Is Honored With a Solo
abstract: The 34-year career of the violinist Glenn Dicterow as the New York Philharmonic’s concertmaster is concluding with his solo performance in Beethoven’s Triple Concerto.
lead_paragraph: A festival and a tribute are happily crossing paths in the last week of the New York Philharmonic’s subscription season at Avery Fisher Hall. This week’s program, first performed on Tuesday evening, is the third and last in the orchestra’s Beethoven festival built around the five piano concertos, with Yefim Bronfman as soloist and Alan Gilbert conducting.

headline: Rare Stradivari Viola Fails to Attract Buyer
abstract: Maybe the rare-instruments market is showing signs of coming back to earth a bit, or maybe Sotheby’s and Ingles & Hayday simply asked for too much money for a fiddle.Whatever the reason, the “Macdonald” viola — a rare Stradivari viola — failed to attract a buyer when a sealed-bid sale came to an end on Wednesday and no one had offered to pay the record $45 million asking price.
lead_paragraph: Maybe the rare-instruments market is showing signs of coming back to earth a bit, or maybe Sotheby’s and Ingles & Hayday simply asked for too much money for a fiddle.

headline: More Calls to Fix Music Royalty Rules, but No Accord
abstract: The witnesses agreed that the current system — with various rules for radio, satellite and streaming — was unfair. But there was no consensus on improving it.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, a House Judiciary subcommittee heard from a group of music executives that the complex licensing system is broken, but no consensus emerged about how to fix it. On Wednesday, the same committee heard from a different group of executives that the licensing system is broken, and once again there was no agreement on how to fix it.

headline: Kicking Up Their Heels in Tribute
abstract: The Public Theater pays tribute to “A Chorus Line” and its composer, Marvin Hamlisch, during its annual Shakespeare in the Park gala.
lead_paragraph: Few shows inspire the same level of nostalgia as “A Chorus Line” does. It opened at the Public Theater in April 1975, moved to the Shubert Theater on Broadway three months later and went on to play 6,137 performances. In the process, it won the Pulitzer Prize, seven Drama Desk awards and nine Tony Awards.

headline: Like Lunch With Monet
abstract: Ladurée, a SoHo restaurant, opens a 2,600-square-foot French-accented garden.
lead_paragraph: The garden that opened last month at Ladurée, the restaurant and shop in SoHo, is a 2,600-square-foot oasis designed to evoke Paris. Elisabeth Holder, a president of Ladurée in the United States, said that the green powder-coated metal chairs are airy interpretations of their counterparts at the Luxembourg Garden and the Tuileries, while the black metal trellises on arched windows were inspired by the Hôtel Plaza Athénée. (Visitors will also note that an antique fountain burbles like a messenger from Proust.)

headline: Furnishings Made of Rope: Knotty but No Problem
keywords: ['Rope and Twine', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The utilitarian material has been finding its way into all manner of furniture and decorative objects.
lead_paragraph: At Thom Filicia’s weekend house, bathroom mirrors are framed in rope, chairs are made out of it and a thick length serves as a stair rail.

headline: Capturing Detroit’s Local Flavor
abstract: Gregory Holm, a photographer with no professional food experience, opens an Art Deco-style restaurant called Antietam in a city he knows very well.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, Gregory Holm, a photographer and filmmaker, and Matthew Radune, an architect, soaked and froze an abandoned home in Detroit creating a luminous ice sculpture that made a ticklish point about the city’s many foreclosures. The same year, Mr. Holm built a soundstage in an empty fire station and produced a concert with local composers, a youth choir and eccentric instruments like a fire-powered organ.

headline: After the Cows Left Home
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: A 19th-century Bavarian farmhouse is integrated with its renovated barn to create a streamlined modern interior. (No silos here.)
lead_paragraph: In the town of Moorenweis, in southern Germany, there are a number of imposing Alpine-style chalets. But the house that Michael Schnabl, 38, and his wife, Bernadette, a 35-year-old actress, chose to make their own was a 19th-century Bavarian farmhouse with a rundown barn.

headline: Botany’s New Boys
abstract: In Des Moines, members of a band of young male gardeners hope that the plants don’t die before they get old.
lead_paragraph: Des Moines — A medium-size state capital does not become a competitive global city without a public display of shrubbery. As theories of urban development go, that’s a novel one. Yet nabobs in Iowa appear to believe in it so strongly that they are raising $18.2 million to close the dogwood gap.

headline: Melissa Leo’s Theater in the Round
abstract: The actress’s handmade stone-encrusted renovation may take the rest of her life to complete. Gaudí would be impressed.
lead_paragraph: STONE RIDGE, N.Y. — From the road, Melissa Leo’s 200-year-old farmhouse would seem to be standard issue for Ulster County, with all the usual trappings: on the porch, a hammock, some wind chimes, a few director’s chairs, an armless mannequin wearing a flowery dress and a baseball cap, her arms strewed about her feet; up above, an enormous peace sign (Woodstock is less than 20 miles away).

headline: At World Cup, Two Unknowns Are Surprise Stars
abstract: ESPN’s World Cup coverage has brought attention to the show “Men in Blazers,” hosted by two Englishmen.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been watching ESPN’s nightly World Cup wrap-up show, you have probably seen them — not beneath the swaying palm trees on the Rio de Janeiro beachfront set with the rest of the on-air talent, but squished together in an eight-by-five-foot room. Two scruffy, balding Britons, clutching a miniature banana as a make-believe microphone, riffing on the day’s games. Maybe you’ve even heard them describe the Brazilian star Neymar as “a Japanese manga character come to life,” or the Portuguese forward Cristiano Ronaldo as “a petulant show pony.”

headline: Stretching to Infinity and Beyond
abstract: A paper screen by David Weeks offers many uses and limitless dimensions.
lead_paragraph: Since 1996, the New York designer David Weeks has been turning out furniture, lighting, toys and even wallpaper with gorilla heads. His latest project, the Infinity Screen, is a series of interlocking four-by-six-inch paper modules that can grow to any dimension. The piece came about when the W Hotel in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., commissioned Mr. Weeks to design a light installation that required no electricity. He used die-cut paper coated in shiny Mylar to create a fixture that resembled a chandelier. When the project was done, he decided to explore other uses for the technique. “It was an exercise in form,” he said. The panels ($250 a square yard) are made of card stock paper and can be used as a room divider or window covering. A stainless-steel mounting bracket is $150 per 36-inch length. Mr. Weeks will produce the screen in other materials or in printed versions for custom projects. Information: 212-966-3433 or davidweeksstudio.com.

headline: Rustic, Raw and Thoroughly Modern
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: “Cape Cod Modern: Midcentury Architecture and Community on the Outer Cape” tells of a cache of remarkable buildings and their brainy bohemian occupants.
lead_paragraph: “Cape Cod Modern: Midcentury Architecture and Community on the Outer Cape,” by Peter McMahon and Christine Cipriani (Metropolis Books, $33), reveals one of the East Coast’s best-kept architectural secrets: an enclave of disarmingly unpretentious houses, many inspired by chicken coops and oyster houses. Often made with scavenged wood mixed with raw lumber straight from the yard, the buildings were designed by Marcel Breuer, Eero Saarinen, Serge Chermayeff, Maurice Smith and serious amateurs. In this rich cultural setting, left-leaning figures including Mary McCarthy, Edmund Wilson, Dwight Macdonald and Noam Chomsky dined on plywood tables, bathed nude in brisk waters on principle and exercised elastic morals among the unpainted two-by-fours. It was a summer camp for consenting, distinctly un-Puritanical intellectuals. And the party needn’t be over. Many of the houses are in the Cape Cod National Seashore conservation park, with some recently restored for summer rental and for artists in the off-season.

headline: A Burst of Vivid Colors
abstract: Niche Modern’s Crystalline Collection includes four blown-glass pendant lamps in eight hues.
lead_paragraph: Niche Modern’s Crystalline Collection of blown-glass pendant lamps includes four shapes that vaguely allude to molecular structures. “Deep down in the core of my being, I love order and mathematics,” said Jeremy Pyles, who founded the company with his wife, Mary Welch. But the main reason that the group burst onto the scene in a flash of eight mostly vivid colors, including a blue inspired by the palette of the Hotel Condesa in Mexico City, had to do with their bulbs. Niche Modern’s existing lamps offered few options for low-energy bulbs, or for the 240-volt varieties used overseas, where the company has been brightening a growing number of hotels and restaurants. The Crystalline series will accommodate both models of the stylish Plumen compact fluorescent light bulb, as well as Niche Modern’s specialty incandescent bulb. The collection is available through July 15 at Lumens.com and following that through Niche Modern. From $550. Information: nichemodern.com.

headline: Sales at Fishs Eddy, Ethan Allen, John Robshaw and DLV Designs
keywords: ['Glassware', 'Beds and Bedding', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Discounts on glassware, seating, art, bedding and more.
lead_paragraph: Fishs Eddy is discounting some tabletop, glassware and accessories by 50 percent, in-store only, while supplies last (the Dog Decal tray, originally about $23, is about $11); 889 Broadway (East 19th Street), 212-420-9020.

headline: The Collections | The Top Five Spring/Summer 2015 Men’s Wear Shows in Milan
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Spring (Season)', 'Suits (Apparel)']
abstract: T’s men’s fashion editors share their favorite collections.
lead_paragraph: In Milan, the best spring/summer 2015 men’s shows were true to the names behind them. Fashion houses celebrated their signature style with throwbacks to archival silhouettes and prints, while newer creative directors seamlessly incorporated their own visions into the DNA of the iconic brands they design for. These five collections represent refreshing new directions anchored in timeless design.

headline: Senior Teams at European Championships in Croatia
abstract: A diagramed deal from the first round of the European Championships.
lead_paragraph: In the 1960s and ’70s, the battle for the medals at the European Bridge Championship was among just a few countries. Back then, it was vital for the contenders to score as many victory points as possible against the weaker nations. In particular, the strong teams gained many points from superior declarer play and defense. Today, bidding has assumed a more important role. Also, competitive bidding has become much more aggressive.

headline: Seeing Loneliness or Something Like It
abstract: The 2014 River to River Festival includes performances at Governors Island, Pier 15 and a South Street Seaport bar.
lead_paragraph: The weather is always a collaborator in River to River, the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council’s annual festival of site-specific performance, and last weekend it was in peak form. The festival’s organizer, Sam Miller, deserved nothing less; his lineup this year is stellar. Lucid skies, light breezes and just-right temperatures made a dancegoer rejoice in the concept of piers, lawns and seaside cafes as theatrical spaces, as did the stealthy use of those spaces by the artists who occupied them.

headline: Lending Mozart a Left Hand
abstract: The Knights chamber orchestra and the pianist Timo Andres presented Mr. Andres’s revision of Mozart’s unfinished “Coronation” Concerto in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: In a time that has brought us renovations and revisions of Vivaldi’s “Four Seasons,” Beethoven’s Seventh Symphony and Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring,” among other overhauls, do we really need a recomposition of Mozart’s “Coronation” Concerto?

headline: A Carbon Tax and Climate Change
abstract: Responses to a Sunday Review article by Henry M. Paulson Jr., the former Treasury secretary, and a column by Paul Krugman.

headline: Bidding Farewell to a Home of Visionary Art With Space Travel and a Vodka Shot
abstract: The Incubator Arts Project is presenting its final show, an ambitious, cryptic and yet tuneful sci-fi stage production.
lead_paragraph: Welcome aboard Ozet, a colossal spacecraft launched from Moscow in 1929 carrying nearly 700 eager pioneers and a lake full of sturgeon.

headline: Disney Hopes New (and Nostalgic) Formula Will Draw Tweens
abstract: In “Girl Meets World,” Disney Channel tries to strip away Internet conventions.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Disney Channel has a history of serving up programming that defines pop culture for pre-teenage girls: “Lizzie McGuire,” “Hannah Montana,” “Wizards of Waverly Place,” “High School Musical.” But that cable network has not found a new live-action juggernaut in years and its overall ratings are declining.

headline: The Supreme Court Justices Have Cellphones, Too
abstract: On technology, the court seems free of ideological baggage.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen years ago, the Rehnquist court interrupted a string of law enforcement victories to rule that when looking for illegal drugs, the police couldn’t simply walk down the aisle of an intercity bus and squeeze the bags and soft-sided luggage on the overhead rack.

headline: Putting Teeth in Her Look
abstract: An epicenter of French boho.
lead_paragraph: The Haut Marais neighborhood in Paris is the epicenter of bohemian bourgeois French style. “What I like about this neighborhood is that it is romantic and fashionable,” said Johanna Lebrun, who was in the area riding her Peugeot bike from the 1950s. “The idea is not necessarily to show off wealth, but to show a cool attitude.” Wearing a floral, flowing Vanessa Bruno dress (which she said was like wearing a painting) and carrying a 50-year-old Hermès bag, Ms. Lebrun was channeling just that attitude. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Navigating National Parks With Light and Rich Digital Guides
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Wilderness Areas']
abstract: Visitors can get details on attractions, animals, camps, parking, the weather and more on their mobile devices.
lead_paragraph: IT wasn’t long ago that a trip to a national park meant packing books, paper maps, a guide to help identify plants and wildlife, and tools like a compass. Now apps can help with all these things.

headline: World Cup 2014: A Tie Sends France Through and Ecuador Out
abstract: France and Ecuador drew, 0-0, eliminating Ecuador from the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The goals came so easy, and so often, for France in its first two games at the World Cup that one could be forgiven for assuming it might never end. Three against Honduras. Five against Switzerland.

headline: App Smart | Visiting National Parks
abstract: Kit Eaton explores three apps that will help you get the most out of your trip to Yellowstone, Yosemite or hundreds of other parks.
lead_paragraph: Kit Eaton explores three apps that will help you get the most out of your trip to Yellowstone, Yosemite or hundreds of other parks.

headline: GoPro’s I.P.O. Prices at Top of Range, Leading a Wave of Newly Public Companies
abstract: GoPro is only one of nearly 20 companies looking to make their market debuts this week, a pace unseen since the height of the dot-com boom in 2000.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:19 p.m. | Since its founding in 2004, GoPro has become the biggest name in action videos, its tiny cameras attached to hundreds of surfboards, sports bikes and skydiving helmets.

headline: Michael Walrond on His Loss to Charles Rangel
abstract: Michael A. Walrond drew about 8 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary for New York’s 13th Congressional District. Here, he talks about what it was like to run against and lose to Representative Charles Rangel.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Michael A. Walrond, the senior minister at First Corinthian Baptist Church in Harlem, whom I wrote about in last Sunday’s magazine, drew about 8 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary for New York’s 13th Congressional District. “We are extremely proud of the campaign we have organized, and Mike’s visionary leadership will continue to impact our community through his work at First Corinthian Baptist Church,” his campaign said in a statement yesterday. Walrond called later and said he was relieved the campaign was over and talked about what it was like to run against and lose to Representative Charles Rangel.

headline: League of Legends Sets Game Championship for Korean Stadium
abstract: At least 40,000 people are expected to pack into Sangam Stadium in Seoul, South Korea, in October to watch teams compete for victory in League of Legends, an online multiplayer battle game for PCs.
lead_paragraph: Months after the FIFA World Cup in Brazil ends, another World Cup venue will host a very different kind of competition: a championship battle between players of one of the world’s most popular online games.

headline: Egyptian Activists to Stand Trial for Protesting Ban on Protests
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Political Prisoners', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: A prosecutor in Cairo plans to charge 23 activists with violating a new law banning unsanctioned protests for attending a rally last week.
lead_paragraph: A prosecutor in Cairo plans to charge 23 opposition activists with violating a new law banning unsanctioned protests for attending a rally last Saturday against the ban.

headline: Creativity Unleashed, With the Help of a Little Pi
abstract: Raspberry Pi, a tiny computer the size of a credit card, has captured the imaginations of students, educators and tinkerers around the world since it became available in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Raspberry Pi, a tiny computer the size of a credit card, has captured the imaginations of students, educators and tinkerers around the world since it became available in 2012. Earlier this month, the organization behind the computer announced that it had sold its three millionth device.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Constitution (US)', 'Impeachment']

lead_paragraph: John A. Boehner, the House speaker, said he intended to file a lawsuit accusing President Obama of failing to carry out laws passed by Congress.

headline: Boehner to Seek Bill to Sue Obama Over Executive Actions
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a letter to lawmakers, Speaker John A. Boehner expressed concern with what he — and many in the Republican conference — considered the president’s unconstitutional overreach.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner announced Wednesday that he would introduce legislation next month allowing the House to sue President Obama over his use of executive actions.

headline: Grimm’s Threats May Have Broken House Rules, Ethics Report Says
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Threats and Threatening Messages']
abstract: Representative Michael G. Grimm’s verbal attack on a television journalist in the Capitol was reviewed by the Office of Congressional Ethics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Michael G. Grimm of New York, who is already facing criminal charges, may also have violated House ethics rules in January when he threatened a reporter for the NY1 television station who was interviewing him in the Capitol, the Office of Congressional Ethics has concluded.

headline: His Earlier Stints Ended by Felonies, Ex-Mayor of Providence Announces He’ll Run Again
abstract: Vincent A. Cianci Jr., the garrulous and polarizing former mayor of Providence, R.I., on Wednesday announced that he wanted his old job back.
lead_paragraph: Ending months of self-generated suspense, Vincent A. Cianci Jr., the garrulous and polarizing former mayor of Providence, R.I., whose two stints in office collapsed in felony convictions, announced on his radio talk show Wednesday that he wanted his old job back.

headline: Thad Cochran’s Debt to Mississippi
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Editorials', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Black voters crossed party lines to help Senator Thad Cochran defeat a Tea Party candidate. He should return the favor by supporting a stronger Voting Rights Act.
lead_paragraph: The prospect of electing an intemperate Tea Party candidate who was openly nostalgic for Confederate days was so repellent to many black voters in Mississippi that they did a remarkable thing on Tuesday, crossing party lines to help give the Republican Senate nomination to Thad Cochran, in office for 36 years. Now it’s time for Mr. Cochran to return the favor by supporting a stronger Voting Rights Act and actively working to reduce his party’s extreme antigovernment policies.

headline: Paula Kent Meehan, Co-Founder of a Hair-Care Giant, Dies at 82
abstract: With her hairdresser, she founded Redken, a company that changed the way shampoos and rinses were made and marketed.
lead_paragraph: In the 1950s, Paula Jane Baer, an aspiring actress who had adopted the stage name Paula Kent, came to the realization that she would never match the success of her junior high friend Debbie Reynolds.

headline: The Iraqi Friends We Abandoned
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Visas']
abstract: Trapped by apathy and bureaucracy, they wait in vain for visas.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “LET’S be perfectly coldblooded about it,” President Richard M. Nixon mused to Henry A. Kissinger. “South Vietnam is probably never gonna survive anyway.” It was August 1972, and Nixon was worried about the inevitable collapse of South Vietnam after American forces withdrew. Mr. Kissinger concurred: “We’ve got to find some formula that holds the thing together a year or two. If we settle it, say, this October, by January ’74 no one will give a damn.”

headline: Speaking to My Father in a Dead Dialect
abstract: The language he spoke is leaving me now. And he is leaving me, too.
lead_paragraph: The 18th-century Italian philosopher Giambattista Vico believed that as a civilization progressed, it lost touch with its creative origins. An ancient warrior would never declare “I’m angry”; he would wax metaphorical with “my blood boils.” The Roman poet Horace went a step further, believing that when words died they took memories with them. Just as forests change their leaves each year, so, too, do words: new languages “bloom and thrive” but only after “the old race dies.”

headline: World Cup 2014: Germany Players Cautious, Calling U.S. ‘Very Dangerous’
abstract: The United States and Germany play their final match in the group stage on Thursday in one of the most anticipated games of the World Cup’s first round.
lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — Sunil Gulati, the president of U.S. Soccer, is aware of the narrative surrounding the team, of how perceptions of it have changed over the years, of how quickly those can flip.

headline: Tense Vote Spares Polish Government After Recordings Scandal
keywords: ['Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Prime Minister Donald Tusk and his administration were retained Wednesday, despite controversy over secret tapes of officials’ private conversations that surfaced last week.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — The Polish Parliament voted Wednesday to retain the embattled government of Prime Minister Donald Tusk, despite an embarrassing scandal involving several top officials whose private, often profane conversations in upscale Warsaw restaurants had been bugged for more than a year.

headline: God and Mammon
abstract: Has contemporary American capitalism become incompatible with Christian values?

headline: Snakes and Thorny Brush, and Children at the Border Alone
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Smuggling', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Children and Childhood', 'Human Trafficking']
abstract: An area downstream of the Anzalduas Dam on the Rio Grande is a prime crossing ground for families and children seeking to enter the United States.
lead_paragraph: HIDALGO, Tex. — Border agents drove their patrol vehicles one recent day at dusk through this spit of land on the bank of the Rio Grande. Here, in a place known as the Devil’s Corner, smugglers on the Mexican side have chosen to bring thousands of women and children to American soil.

headline: Michael Bradley, Motor in U.S. Midfield, Needs a Tuneup
abstract: Even though Bradley has had two inconsistent games at the World Cup, the United States is counting on him in Thursday’s pivotal match against Germany.
lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — If Landon Donovan was the face of United States soccer, then Michael Bradley was — and is — its motor. Bradley is a mainstay in the American lineup, operating in the midfield and generally acting as a conduit between the team’s defense and attack.

headline: Judge Rejects Effort to Compel Christie to Keep Promise on New Jersey’s Pension Fund
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Government Employees']
abstract: While a Superior Court judge agreed that Gov. Chris Christie was legally required to make a $1.58 billion payment to the pension fund, she deemed the state too impoverished to comply.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — A judge on Wednesday denied a bid by public employee unions to force Gov. Chris Christie to make the pension payments he promised in signature legislation three years ago, ruling that the state’s “staggering” $1.7 billion budget deficit left him simply unable to meet that commitment.

headline: S.E.C. Stops City in Illinois From Selling Municipal Bonds
abstract: Regulators say the City of Harvey sold $14 million in bonds under false pretenses since 2008 and was planning to bring more to market.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators went to court on Wednesday to keep a city in Illinois from bringing its bonds to market, an unprecedented step they called necessary to halt a widening securities fraud.

headline: In Puerto Rico, a Proposal for Revamping Debt
abstract: With fear of financial trouble looming, Puerto Rico’s governor proposed a new law meant to regain the confidence of bondholders.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico’s governor, signaling worsening financial trouble for the island, on Wednesday proposed a legal means to revamp the debt of some its largest public corporations, which provide vital services like electricity.

headline: His Back Mending, Tiger Woods’s Shot Is Next
abstract: Preparing to play in his first competitive round in three months on Thursday, Tiger Woods started poorly in the Quicken Loans National pro-am Wednesday but a grip adjustment improved his stroke.
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md. — After hitting the 10th tee shot of his comeback, Tiger Woods settled into a folding chair to the side of the first tee. The sign taped to the back of the reserved seat read, “Wounded Warrior.”

headline: Facebook Mirrors Tech Industry’s Lack of Diversity
abstract: The social networking company disclosed that 31 percent of its workers globally are women. In the United States, Facebook’s management is overwhelmingly white and male.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to the gender and ethnic diversity of its work force, Facebook‘s record is on par with the rest of Silicon Valley. It’s overwhelmingly male, white and Asian. And white men dominate the management ranks.

headline: Sales of Hillary Clinton’s New Memoir Drop Sharply in 2nd Week
abstract: Sales of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s new memoir, “Hard Choices,” declined 43.5 percent to 48,000 copies in its second week on the shelves, according to Nielsen BookScan.
lead_paragraph: Sales of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s new memoir, “Hard Choices,” declined 43.5 percent to 48,000 copies in its second week on the shelves, according to Nielsen BookScan.

headline: Larry Page on Google’s Many Arms
abstract: For a company whose future depends on people handing over their information in return for handy online services, Google’s very ambitions may now stand as its biggest hurdle.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One way to think of Google is as an extremely helpful, all-knowing, hyper-intelligent executive assistant. Already, it can remind you about your flight, open up your boarding pass when you get to the airport and offer you driving directions to your hotel when you land.

headline: Stalemate Over Garment Factory Safety in Bangladesh
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: In several cases where hazardous conditions were uncovered, there has been considerable resistance to closing a factory, as owners worry about losing orders and workers fear losing their jobs.
lead_paragraph: Eight times now, the European-dominated Accord on Fire and Building Safety in Bangladesh — a group of more than 150 retailers and brands — has forced the temporary closing of garment factories after its inspectors found dangerous conditions.

headline: Another of the Hollywood Sexual Abuse Suits Is Dropped
abstract: Lawyers for Michael Egan, who had accused various Hollywood executives and filmmakers of sexual abuse, dropped a suit against Garth Ancier.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Another of the sexual abuse lawsuits filed in Hawaii against various Hollywood executives and filmmakers by Michael Egan, this one against Garth Ancier, the longtime television executive, was voluntarily dismissed on Wednesday. Lawyers for Mr. Egan filed a brief notice of the dismissal with the United States District Court for the District of Hawaii. The dismissal was filed “without prejudice,” meaning that the claims of statutory rape and other abuse could be refiled.

headline: G.M. Halts Sale of Cruze Sedan Over Takata Air Bags
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The car company says the mechanics of the air bags may be faulty, causing improper inflation.
lead_paragraph: General Motors ordered dealers to stop selling the 2013 and 2014 versions of its most popular car, the Chevrolet Cruze sedan, because of a problem with air bags made by the Japanese supplier Takata, whose products are already the subject of a large recall of other vehicles.

headline: In a U.S. Court, Iraqis Accuse Blackwater of Killings in 2007
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Mercenaries and Private Military Contractors', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Defense Contracts']
abstract: More than four dozen Iraqi citizens are scheduled to travel to Washington to testify against the Americans who they say fired wildly on unarmed citizens, leaving 17 Iraqis dead.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The witness wore a suit with no tie, the top button of his gray shirt undone. He had told this story many times, and now that he was in the United States, telling his story at last to a jury, he appeared neither hurried nor anxious.

headline: Obama’s Weakness, or Ours?
abstract: Critics scoff at President Obama for his caution on foreign policy. But that’s actually smart.
lead_paragraph: The odds are that you think President Obama’s foreign policy is a failure.

headline: In Ghana’s Bags: Gear and $3 Million in Cash
abstract: Ghana’s players were to be paid $3 million in appearance fees after threatening to boycott their match against Portugal on Thursday, with the money — all in cash — sent by plane.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — An airplane laden with cash descended into Brazilian airspace, or so Ghana’s national soccer team was told on Wednesday, and the question for each player shifted away from the topics of how to stop Portugal’s Cristiano Ronaldo or whether Ghana had a realistic chance to advance to the second round of the World Cup.

headline: Mississippi Goes for the Money
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: The runoff in Mississippi was not your average Senate primary race. It featured Brett Favre, Chuck Woolery and even some aggrieved farm animals.
lead_paragraph: Mississippi has sent us a message. I believe it boils down to: We Want Our Stuff.

headline: Russia and Others Seek Extended Ukraine Truce, but Separatists Balk
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin said that Russia had made a commitment to ease the conflict by revoking an order that provided for the use of the Russian Army in Ukraine.

headline: U.S. Chided for Delays Over Treaty on Weapons
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Mines, Explosive', 'Explosions (Accidental)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: Though the United States is the biggest contributor in helping to rid land mines from old conflict zones, the International Campaign to Ban Landmines said it still has not signed an international treaty.
lead_paragraph: The American peace activist who pioneered a treaty that bans antipersonnel land mines chided the Obama administration on Wednesday for not yet having signed it after five years of review. The activist, Jody Williams, said that China — which also has not signed — now appears to have far fewer of these weapons than the United States.

headline: Bergdahl to Be Questioned About Leaving Army Post

Bowe Bergdahl will face investigators seeking to determine his legal future in about two weeks, Army officials said Wednesday, as they described the parameters of an inquiry to decide whether the onetime prisoner of war in Afghanistan intended to desert when he walked away from his combat outpost in 2009.

headline: Sri Lanka: Advisers Set for Inquiry
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Tamils (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: The United Nations named three international experts on Wednesday to be advisers on an inquiry into human rights abuses in the final months of Sri Lanka’s war against ethnic Tamil insurgents in 2009.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations named three international experts on Wednesday to be advisers on an inquiry into human rights abuses in the final months of Sri Lanka’s war against ethnic Tamil insurgents in 2009. The three are Martti Ahtisaari, a former president of Finland and Nobel Peace Prize-winning diplomat; Silvia Cartwright, who served as a judge on the war crimes tribunal in Cambodia; and Asma Jahangir, a veteran human rights defender from Pakistan. The United Nations Human Rights Council voted in March to authorize the inquiry. Its 12-member team of investigators is supposed to present preliminary findings as early as September. Whether the experts will be allowed entry into Sri Lanka, which has resisted such an inquiry, remains unclear.

headline: South Korea: A Familiar Premier
abstract: President Park Geun-hye reversed her decision to replace her current prime minister, after two successive appointees stepped aside amid controversies over their qualifications.
lead_paragraph: President Park Geun-hye reversed her decision to replace her current prime minister, after two successive appointees stepped aside amid controversies over their qualifications. Prime Minister Chung Hong-won had offered to resign in late April, as the government came under fire for failing to prevent the sinking of a ferry on April 16 that left more than 300 people dead. Ms. Park accepted his resignation but asked him to stay in office while she looked for a replacement. But her first choice, a former Supreme Court justice named Ahn Dae-hee, was forced to withdraw his name amid questions over his earnings. Her second choice, Moon Chang-keuk, a retired conservative newspaper columnist, bowed out on Tuesday. Critics accused him of being unpatriotic after it was revealed that he said during a church lecture in 2011 that Korea’s colonization by Japan in the early 20th century was “God’s will.” This was the first time in South Korean history that a president retained a prime minister who had resigned.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Logo) TRAILBLAZERS On the anniversary of the striking down of the Defense of Marriage Act, this special honors Edie Windsor, who challenged the act’s constitutionality, and the lawyer Roberta Kaplan, who took the case to the Supreme Court. Other honorees include the basketball player Jason Collins, the first openly gay male athlete in a major American sport; Netflix’s “Orange Is the New Black,” for its portrayal of rarely seen television characters; and John Abdallah Wambere, the Ugandan gay rights advocate and refugee. Former President Bill Clinton talks about Ms. Windsor and Ms. Kaplan in a taped message. Daniel Radcliffe, Adam Levine, Jared Leto, Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, Ed Sheeran, Nate Ruess, Demi Lovato and Iggy Azalea appear at this event, filmed on Monday at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in New York. A Great Big World and Sia, with the New York City Gay Men’s Chorus, perform.

headline: Climate Campaign Can’t Be Deaf to Economic Worries, Obama Warns
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'United States Economy', 'Coal', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: President Obama told environmental advocates that fighting global warming will require acknowledging Americans’ concerns about higher energy costs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama acknowledged Wednesday that his efforts to combat climate change — in particular, Environmental Protection Agency regulations to slash carbon pollution from cars and coal-fired power plants — could raise fuel and electricity prices. And he told environmental advocates that in order to make a credible case for such climate policies, officials would need to acknowledge Americans’ worries about the economic effects.

headline: Issue of Pay for 2 Sets of Workers Tugs at Palestinian Pact
abstract: The Palestinian prime minister says he does not have enough money to pay both workers hired by Hamas and those employed by the Palestinian Authority.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Abu Raid al-Samouni, 46, a driver and office cleaner in the Foreign Ministry headquarters here, leaves for work before his 14 children wake up each morning, to avoid their pleas for spare change to buy candy. Like the other 42,000 workers hired while the militant Islamic group Hamas ran the Gaza government over the past seven years, Mr. Samouni has received only part of his $350 monthly salary since October; in April and May, there was no paycheck at all.

headline: Mark Sanford’s Path of Most Resistance
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Governors (US)', 'ADULTERY']
abstract: The South Carolina governor went from potential presidential contender to late-night punch line. Now he’s just a junior congressman trying to find his way in a divided G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: It had been a 14-hour day of campaign-style barnstorming, but at nearly 11 p.m. there was something Mark Sanford felt compelled to show me. We were hiking across the Coosaw Plantation, an enviable slice of Southern landscape that Sanford’s family owns. Nestled in the marshy South Carolina coastline, it has ancient live oaks and twisting palmettos, cascading Spanish moss and views of the Coosaw River and the Atlantic beyond. But I could see none of it as we walked in the pitch black.

headline: What’s the Matter With Eastern Kentucky?
abstract: Coal country is the most disadvantaged part of our nation. Why have decades of federal intervention failed?
lead_paragraph: There are many tough places in this country: the ghost cities of Detroit, Camden and Gary, the sunbaked misery of inland California and the isolated reservations where Native American communities were left to struggle. But in its persistent poverty, Eastern Kentucky — land of storybook hills and drawls ­ — just might be the hardest place to live in the United States. Statistically speaking.
