lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mark J. Carney, the governor of the Bank of England, announced measures on Thursday to try to cool England’s blistering housing market, a sector that he and other policy makers have identified as the greatest potential threat to Britain’s economic recovery.

headline: Graduates’ Red Guard Photos Cast Doubt on What They Learned
abstract: Photos of graduating students playing out a scene from the Cultural Revolution have gone viral on Chinese websites and brought comments about the suppression of public discussion of history.
lead_paragraph: The photographs show a young man, held down in a bowing position by what appear to be five Red Guards, the youthful fanatics who terrorized China in the name of Chairman Mao Zedong during the Cultural Revolution. A conical hat sits on his head, a leather belt chokes his throat, and a sign denouncing him as a traitor hangs from his neck with a nylon cord. But the young man is barely suppressing a grin, and the tableau was staged as part of a university graduation celebration.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on cellphone privacy, cheap solar, legalizing marijuana and uncounted immigrants.
lead_paragraph: “The nine justices of the Supreme Court — whose average age is 68 — often admit to being unfamiliar with modern technology, if not befuddled by it,” writes The New York Times editorial board. “Yet in a gratifyingly sweeping ruling on Wednesday, the court embraced a central reality of the digital age and protected cellphones from being searched without a warrant during an arrest, except in rare circumstances.” The board is wholly supportive of the ruling. Despite government arguments to the contrary, “the expectation of privacy in a phone’s contents outweighs the immediate needs of law enforcement.”

headline: Daily Report: Google’s Far-Reaching Agenda
abstract: Google’s software will soon reach ever further into our lives, sitting on just about every other device you encounter — and the company’s far-reaching ambitions may now stand as its biggest hurdle.
lead_paragraph: One way to think of Google is as an extremely helpful, all-knowing, hyper-intelligent executive assistant. Already, it can remind you about your flight, open up your boarding pass when you get to the airport and offer you driving directions to your hotel when you land.

headline: No Order in the Court Without Yiddish
abstract: Joseph Berger has relied on his knowledge of Yiddish throughout 30 years as a reporter at The Times, including at a state senator’s trial that ultimately hinged on Yiddish.
lead_paragraph: Once the sounds of Yiddish filled the streets of New York. Not so much anymore. But a Times reporter, Joseph Berger, grew up with Yiddish. His knowledge of the language helped him cover a recent corruption trial in which a key government informer was a Hasidic developer who employed Yiddish in many of his recorded conversations.

headline: In Our Second Round of Employee Reviews, a Problem Emerges
keywords: ['Engineering and Engineers', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Small Business', 'Vocational Training']
abstract: In Part 4 of a series, a business owner explains how instituting employee reviews forced him to take another look at an employee who had been extremely productive for 20 years.
lead_paragraph: This series of posts started with an explanation of why I decided to re-institute employee reviews.

headline: Challenges Are Many in Predicting House Races
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Pollsters can’t afford to survey each of 435 congressional races, so a generic question must suffice. But that can miss a lot.
lead_paragraph: In the months leading up to midterm elections, pollsters have a limited number of tools to explain what could happen to the composition of the House of Representatives. And this year, their tools may be more blunt than usual.

headline: North Korea Fires 3 Short-Range Projectiles
abstract: The action came a day after Pyongyang warned of retaliation against an American comedy film in which two Americans are recruited to kill Kim Jong-un.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea fired three short-range projectiles off its east coast on Thursday, a day after it warned of retaliation against the release of an American comedy film involving a plot to kill its leader, Kim Jong-un.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Senior Prosecutor’s Departure
abstract: Lorin L. Reisner is the latest prosecutor to leave government for the private sector. | Puerto Rico’s governor proposes a law to revamp corporations’ debt. | The New York attorney general files civil fraud charges against Barclays. | GoPro is set for its market debut.
lead_paragraph: Lorin L. Reisner, who helped overhaul the enforcement unit of the Securities and Exchange Commission before heading the criminal division of the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan, is leaving government for the private sector, Ben Protess writes in DealBook. He is expected to join a law firm, though it is not clear which one. Mr. Reisner announced his decision on Wednesday afternoon in an email to the United States attorney’s office, where he has been the criminal division chief since January 2012.

headline: Singular Collection, Multiple Mysteries
abstract: As the adaptation “Dubliners: A Quartet” is presented this weekend, a writer ponders a paperback edition of “Dubliners” tied to his family history.
lead_paragraph: AFTER my Irish mother died, 15 years ago now, my siblings and I took eons to shake our paralysis of grief and deal with the physical things she left behind. When finally I mustered the energy, or courage, I found, to my surprise, a 1958 paperback edition of “Dubliners” in her night stand.

headline: In Our Pages: June 27
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Paris prepares for the most important boxing match in recent years in 1914; Ponies and dogs are entitled to a “first bite” in 1939.

headline: Conventional Steps in a New Frame
abstract: The Dutch National Ballet tries a multimedia take on “The Tempest,” choreographed by Krzysztof Pastor, with video design by Shirin Neshat and Shoja Azari.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — When a ballet offers you video on stage, a stark set and imaginative lighting, you probably have the strong impression that you are seeing an innovative work. When that work is new, and boasts a collaboration with a famous artist, and is promoted by attractive posters showing a naked body, you are likely to be even more certain.

headline: Live Stream | Louis Vuitton’s Spring 2015 Collection at Paris Men’s Fashion Week
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: The latest men’s collection from Louis Vuitton at Paris Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The latest men’s collection from Louis Vuitton at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Alcoa Buys Jet Engine Parts Maker Firth Rixson for $2.85 Billion
abstract: The deal for Firth Rixson is expected to bolster annual revenue by 20 percent at Alcoa’s aerospace unit, its biggest so-called value-added business, while supplementing its traditional metals operations.
lead_paragraph: Alcoa, seeking to build out its aerospace division, agreed on Thursday to buy Firth Rixson, a maker of jet engine parts, for at least $2.85 billion in cash and stock.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Fallout from Mississippi Runoff
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Thad Cochran’s defeat of Chris McDaniel, his Tea Party-backed challenger, in Mississippi has underscored rifts within the Republican party and has left activists wondering how to respond.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning from a sunny Washington.

headline: Taking the Time to Listen
abstract: Bob Farrell, chief executive of Kewill, a transportation software company, has learned to listen to his employees, sometimes fighting the urge to interrupt.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Bob Farrell, chief executive of Kewill, a transportation software company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Reviewing Google’s Smartwatches  — the LG G and the Samsung Gear Live
abstract: These smartwatches do all sorts of things, but they don’t really make style statements.
lead_paragraph: Google stole a wearables beat on Apple Wednesday at its developers conference in San Francisco by announcing that two watches that use the Android operating system (and can be paired with phones) — one from LG and one from Samsung — would go on sale immediately afterward in the United States. So immediately afterward, I went online to check out “Android Wear.” And my heart sank.

headline: Uighur Scholar Will Fight Charges of Separatism in China, Lawyer Says
abstract: Ilham Tohti, a critic of Beijing’s policies in the ethnically divided region of Xinjiang, said through his lawyer that he was innocent.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Ilham Tohti, a prominent Uighur scholar charged with separatism after he repeatedly criticized China’s increasingly uncompromising policies in Xinjiang, his ethnically divided homeland, told his lawyers on Thursday that he would fight the charges, one of the lawyers said.

headline: New York’s Ban on Big Sodas Is Rejected by Final Court
abstract: The State Court of Appeals declined to reinstate New York City’s limits on sales of jumbo sugary drinks, exhausting the city’s legal options.
lead_paragraph: The Bloomberg big-soda ban is officially dead.

headline: On a Sidewalk in Harlem: A Birth Story
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: There was no time to get to the hospital when the contractions intensified for a woman at home in Harlem.

abstract: Barclays investors and clients appeared to be spooked on Thursday by a lawsuit accusing the bank of fraud in how it marketed its private stock trading platform.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:01 p.m. | Several large brokerage houses on Thursday stopped sending orders to the private stock trading system run by Barclays, concerned by a new lawsuit claiming that the bank committed fraud.

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Job Growth Is Up, Production Down
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Gross National Product (GNP)', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Economic indicators that used to move in tandem are now pointing in opposite directions. One possible cause: A shrinking labor force.
lead_paragraph: The most important indicators of our economic health are telling very different stories. On Wednesday, news reports made much of the fact that gross domestic product fell at an annual rate of 2.9 percent in the first quarter of this year, a decline largely attributable to bad weather. That brings growth over the past year to a disappointing 1.5 percent. Yet the labor market continues to deliver good news, and over the same period, the unemployment rate fell by more than a full percentage point.

headline: David Leavitt: By the Book
abstract: The author of “The Two Hotel Francforts” was struck reading “Middlemarch” in Rome at age 20. “That feeling of being unequal to antiquity — no one has ever described it so well as Eliot.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “The Two Hotel Francforts” was struck reading “Middlemarch” in Rome at age 20. “That feeling of being unequal to antiquity — no one has ever described it so well as Eliot.”

headline: The Ringtone That’s Driving You Mad
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: What to do when someone constantly leaves their cellphone unattended at work, and it blurts out an annoying ringtone? The Workologist has some suggestions.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: A Man in Constant Motion
abstract: The jookin master Lil Buck is taking his Memphis dance skills to new levels and new audiences, from Aspen to Las Vegas to Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The dancer known as Lil Buck was walking across a stage in slow motion, four beautifully exaggerated steps, like a moment out of “The Matrix.” It was the springtime benefit for the Institute of Contemporary Art here, and he was improvising to a string quartet.

headline: Turmoil for Ghana, and Fruitless Win for Portugal
abstract: Ghana’s loss, after its disgruntled players nearly boycotted the game, concluded a day of few celebrations.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — The fact that 11 players from Ghana stepped onto the field to face Portugal at the appointed time was a victory in itself. After a week of infighting and boycott threats by its players, the Ghana Football Association on Thursday suspended two of its stars heading into the match, raising doubts about whether the team was equipped to play amid the turmoil.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Raf Simons Spring/Summer 2015

headline: You Can Skip the Lines at the Theme Park, But You Can’t Skip the Lesson
keywords: ['AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Theme parks, smelling money, now make it easy for parents to pay more to avoid the sweaty lines. But what lessons do kids learn when some of them march past the others to board the rides without waiting?
lead_paragraph: Theme parks, smelling money, now make it easy for parents to pay more to avoid the sweaty lines that can bring out the worst in children. But what lessons do kids learn when some of them march past the others to board the rides without waiting?

headline: Living With Cancer: The New Medicine
abstract: For almost two years, I have benefited from the new medicine derived from the new science, much to my surprise.
lead_paragraph: In his 2010 book “The Emperor of All Maladies,” Dr. Siddhartha Mukherjee lamented the gap between “the new science” going on in research laboratories and “the old medicine” most cancer patients receive. Yet for almost two years, I have benefited from the new medicine derived from the new science, much to my surprise.

headline: What Not to Pack
abstract: It won’t get wrinkled if you don’t pack it: a what-to-leave-out list for those who want to travel light.
lead_paragraph: If you want to travel light, it’s not merely what you pack that matters — it’s what you don’t pack.

headline: Uruguay Star Barred 9 Games and 4 Months in Biting Incident
abstract: Luis Suárez, who was suspended twice before for biting opponents, will miss the rest of the World Cup and the start of the English Premier League season.
lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — Luis Suárez, the enigmatic striker from Uruguay who has starred for Liverpool in England’s Premier League, was suspended for nine games and barred from all soccer-related activities for four months Thursday after FIFA’s disciplinary committee determined that he bit an opponent during Uruguay’s 1-0 World Cup victory over Italy.

headline: Julius Rudel, Longtime Impresario and Conductor of City Opera, Dies at 93
abstract: The Austrian-born conductor had led the organization, called “the people’s opera,” for 22 years and continued to be its backer.
lead_paragraph: Julius Rudel, the Austrian-born conductor who raised the New York City Opera to a venturous golden age with highbrow music for the masses and a repertory that, like him, bridged the Old and New Worlds, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: U.S. Phasing Out Its Counterterrorism Unit in Philippines
abstract: American Special Forces will continue to help Philippine security forces counter a smaller, lingering Islamist threat, but the size of the mission will drop to a dozen or so advisers from its current 320 service members.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — An elite American military counterterrorism unit that has been operating in the southern Philippines for more than a decade is being phased out, the Pentagon’s Pacific Command said Thursday.

headline: U.S. vs. Germany: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Germany has advanced and must draw to win the group. The U.S. tops the group with a win, but candidly will be happy with a draw and advancement.
lead_paragraph: Although Germany has scored six goals in two games, it has done so with a deliberate passing style, rather than a frenzied attack. Look for more of the same, especially since a draw is good enough for Germany to win the group. The United States may look for a slow pace too, especially after having played its previous game in the steamy rain forest. The U.S. tops the group with a win, but candidly will be happy with a draw and advancement.

keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday unanimously  struck down a Massachusetts law that barred protests, counseling and other speech near abortion clinics.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Imperial Tobacco Group of Britain said on Thursday that the initial public offering of its Compañía de Distribución Integral Logista Holdings unit could value the company at 1.86 billion euros, or about $2.53 billion.

headline: Supreme Court Rebukes Obama on Right of Appointment
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The justices ruled that President Obama had violated the Constitution when he appointed officials to the National Labor Relations Board during a brief Senate break.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court issued a unanimous rebuke to President Obama on Thursday, saying he had overreached in issuing recess appointments during brief breaks in the Senate’s work.

lead_paragraph: General Motors dealers across the country can begin selling the popular Chevrolet Cruze sedans again after the Detroit automaker lifted an order to freeze sales because of a problem with some of the cars’ air bags.

headline: NEA Names 4 New Jazz Masters
abstract: The award is a high honor for jazz musicians in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Three veteran musicians and a longtime Chicago nightclub owner have been awarded the 2015 National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters Fellowship, a high honor for jazz musicians in the United States. They are Carla Bley, the keyboardist, bandleader and composer, known for her big and small bands and ambitious collaborations with Charlie Haden and Gary Burton, among others; George Coleman, the saxophonist and bandleader, who first became a standard-bearer through his work with Miles Davis and Herbie Hancock in the mid-’60s; Charles Lloyd, the saxophonist, flutist and bandleader, who made popular jazz records in the late 1960s, largely dropped out of jazz for a decade afterward, and has been on a consistent climb since; and Joe Segal, owner of the Jazz Showcase in Chicago since 1947. Each of the recipients, announced on Wednesday, will receive $25,000. They will be honored at an awards ceremony and concert at Jazz at Lincoln Center on April 20, 2015.

headline: Ghana vs. Portugal: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Ghana attacked brightly in a 2-2 draw with Germany, but it will have to deal with the suspension of two star players. Injury-riddled Portugal is increasingly relying on the magic of Cristiano Ronaldo, who is still nursing a knee injury of his own.
lead_paragraph: Both of these teams must win to hope to advance and both will be dealing with injuries or suspensions.

headline: Where Are the Hardest Places to Live in the U.S.?

lead_paragraph: Annie Lowrey writes in the Times Magazine this week about the troubles of Clay County, Ky., which by several measures is the hardest place in America to live.

headline: U.S. Moves On With Assist From Portugal
abstract: Germany beat the United States on Thursday to win Group G, but the Americans advanced to the knockout stages after Portugal beat Ghana, 2-1.
lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — This time, there was no moment. No tingle in the spine, no shiver in the neck, no blood rush to the ears. There was no memory that will live on in hearts and minds and YouTube videos forever.

abstract: Maybe teens are not fleeing Facebook. To improve creativity and productivity, buy an espresso machine.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: For Gene Melchiorre, a Regretful Turn Brought a Unique N.B.A. Distinction
abstract: Melchiorre, known as Squeaky, is the only No. 1 pick to never play in the N.B.A.; he was barred for life after the point-shaving scandal of 1951.
lead_paragraph: At the dead end of a private, wooded road about 20 miles north of Chicago sits a two-story house belonging to Gene Melchiorre, a short, pigeon-toed grandfather of 15 known by his many friends as Squeaky. Family photos decorate his office, but one artifact is unlike the others: a 63-year-old comic book drawing of a giant, youthful Melchiorre wearing a No. 23 basketball jersey, a superhero in short shorts.

headline: Gluten-Free Dining in Italy
abstract: Perhaps surprisingly, the land of pasta and pizza is welcoming, even sympathetic, to travelers who avoid eating gluten.
lead_paragraph: My wife is gluten-intolerant, and hasn’t eaten wheat in three years. And so, at first thought, my plan for an Italian vacation bordered on insanity. While I’m a huge fan of Italian food, for Jen a week and a half of pasta, pizza and bread — the holy trinity of the Italian table — sounded like a nightmare. As far as she was concerned, 10 days in Italy meant 10 days condemned to salads dressed with oil and vinegar. Even dessert wouldn’t be safe: gelato and tiramisù typically contain wheat.

headline: New Group’s New Season Will Be Star-Studded
abstract: Holly Hunter, Bill Pullman, Dianne Wiest and Jesse Eisenberg are among the featured performers.
lead_paragraph: Off Broadway’s New Group theater company will mount three plays during its 2014-15 season featuring Academy Award winner Holly Hunter and Bill Pullman as a married couple; Oscar winner Dianne Wiest and Tony Award winner Tonya Pinkins as rival secretaries; and Jesse Eisenberg as a destructive wastrel, the troupe announced on Thursday.

headline: New York Schools Chief Advocates More ‘Balanced Literacy’
abstract: Chancellor Carmen Fariña wants schools to adopt aspects of a method that the Education Department turned away from several years ago.
lead_paragraph: The reading lesson began like any other. Tara Bauer, a teacher at Public School 158 on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, took her perch in front of a class of restless fourth graders and began reciting the beginning of a book about sharks.

headline: Kerry Turns Up Pressure on Russia Over Ukraine, Warning of New Sanctions

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Amid a flurry of diplomatic consultations aimed at preserving a fragile cease-fire in eastern Ukraine, Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday that Russia faced the prospect of toughened sanctions unless it took steps over the coming “hours” to pressure armed separatists in eastern Ukraine to give up the fight.

headline: The War on Cereal
abstract: A new report finds vitamin-fortified cereals could have disturbing health effects for children, ANNA NORTH writes. As yogurt’s breakfast encroachment continues, can flakes survive?
lead_paragraph: It’s a dark time for cereal in America. First yogurt threatened its dominance. And now a new report suggests that the very vitamins added to make cereal more “healthy” could be dangerous for children.

lead_paragraph: Demographic change has put the Republican Party at an apparent disadvantage in national elections, but the party has the opportunity to make gains among two groups of voters who have become disappointed with the Obama administration.

lead_paragraph: John Harney, the founder of Harney & Sons, a specialty tea company that helped restore the American palate for high-quality teas, died on June 17 at his home in Salisbury, Conn. He was 83.

abstract: The Apollo Theater’s 2014-15 season will include the third annual Africa Now! festival and a performance by the New Orleans Jazz Orchestra.

headline: Comptroller Approves Deal for 5 Convicted in Jogger Case
keywords: ['Central Park Jogger Case (1989)', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Sex Crimes']

headline: After Gobbling Up Corvettes at Museum, Sinkhole Becomes a Star
abstract: The 60-foot sinkhole devoured eight landmark cars at the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, but also created a hot new tourist magnet.
lead_paragraph: BOWLING GREEN, Ky. — When the earth opened under the National Corvette Museum in early February, creating a 60-foot-deep sinkhole that devoured eight landmark Corvettes, museum officials, Bowling Green residents, and ’Vette lovers everywhere reacted in stunned disbelief.

headline: Auxilium, a Small Player, Buys QLT and Does an Inversion, Too
abstract: Auxilium Pharmaceuticals, based in Pennsylvania, agreed to acquire QLT of Canada in one of the smallest inversions in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Most of the corporate inversions that have grabbed headlines recently have been attempted by multibillion-dollar stalwarts of United States industry like Pfizer, Chiquita and Medtronic. But smaller companies can benefit from striking deals to move abroad, too.

headline: A Congressional Plea for Meatless Mondays
abstract: Rep. Tony Cárdenas of California has urged the Congressional Animal Protection Caucus to observe Meatless Mondays.

headline: What the Camera Sees, and Doesn’t See
abstract: A life-changing illness led Kim Weston to return to her roots, both in art and family, exploring the ties between relatives and the past.
lead_paragraph: A life-changing illness led Kim Weston to return to her roots, both in art and family, exploring the ties between relatives and the past.

headline: NeonGrid Wants to Be the IMDb for Online Videos
abstract: The start-up is hoping to become a resource for credits for content that appears on YouTube, Vimeo and similar websites.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — To find credit information for Hollywood’s various disciplines, from acting to hair styling to casting, the go-to source is the Internet Movie Database, or IMDb. Broadway has its own version. Looking to track appearances by vehicles in films? Click over to the Internet Movie Cars Database.

headline: Project Night Night: Bedtime Treasures for Kids with Little of Their Own
abstract: A “Night Night Package,” delivered in a shelter, helps to make children who have little of their own feel more at home, welcome and safe.
lead_paragraph: When Josephine Ambrose, 22, escaped domestic violence a year ago, she left everything behind except her now 1-year-old son and 3-year-old daughter. The family has been living in shelters ever since, and the transition has been hard on the two children. However, their new “friends” might just make it a bit easier.

headline: Facing an Unseeded Opponent, Nadal Gains a Win and Relief
abstract: Lukas Rosol, who stunned Rafael Nadal in 2012, lost this time at Wimbledon, 4-6, 7-6 (6), 6-4, 6-4.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — It was the luck of the draw that brought Rafael Nadal and Lukas Rosol together in the second round at Wimbledon for the second time in three years. The first time still stands as Rosol’s greatest victory and, perhaps, Nadal’s worst defeat.

headline: From the Archives: Amex Marines Hurl Back Foe in Fierce Hand Fighting

Beyoncé is regal, Jay Z brash. Beyoncé, a picture of steely intensity; Jay Z, a paragon of casual cool. Beyoncé, a gut puncher fluent in devastation; Jay Z, happy to devastate.

headline: Marco Rubio Raises the Bar
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Debates (Political)', 'Income Tax', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: A senator’s speech, and a step forward for his party.
lead_paragraph: Before I continue with my string of posts on the theme of reform conservatism’s correct views on everything, let me make a brief foray into real-world politics: Yesterday Senator Marco Rubio gave a domestic policy speech, co-hosted by Hillsdale College and the YG Network, that’s worth reading if you’re interested in what a reformist vision looks like when it’s an actual Republican politician (rather than a tribe of conservative scribblers) giving it form and substance. Naturally, it strikes me as a very impressive and encouraging speech. But I think I would say that even if I were less inclined to agree with its policy specifics, because purely as a rhetorical matter, it does something that Mitt Romney didn’t manage to do in 2012 until, well, basically the first presidential debate: That is, it tries to meet non-conservative voters where they are and talk about the issues that they say they care about, rather than lecturing them on what they should be concerned about (too few people are paying income tax! Obama doesn’t like entrepreneurs!) and assuming that they’re already persuaded. It’s a speech rooted in conservative principle without being trapped by the conservative talking points, in other words, and that’s something we saw very little of in the 2012 campaign.

Many of these structures had sat empty for a decade or more before restoration efforts began infusing a vibrancy into this once-somewhat-downtrodden city.

headline: In Store | Courtshop, Jeans-Maker to Indie Rock Goddesses, Opens in its Natural Habitat: Brooklyn
abstract: The denim company is opening its second New York store on Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg — walking distance for some of its celebrated clients.
lead_paragraph: Jeans and rock ‘n’ roll have always been bedfellows. Lately, some of the most stylish names on the indie scene — Caroline Polachek of Chairlift and Ramona Lisa, Alexis Krauss of Sleigh Bells, Victoria Legrand of Beach House, Megan James of Purity Ring, Angel Deradoorian of Avey Tare’s Slasher Flicks — have been sporting pairs by the New York-based label Courtshop, known for its rock-starish high-waisted cuts and palatable price points. Now, in addition to its boutique in NoLIta, the brand is setting up shop in the neighborhood where many of its customers live and play: Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The new store opens tonight with a party at which Polachek herself will make an appearance in the D.J. booth. She plans on picking up a few things for her summer wardrobe, too. “I quite like their shorts, which is surprising since normally I’d never be caught dead in shorts,” she says. “The fit makes me feel like Laura Dern in ‘Jurassic Park,’ or a sexy-awkward ’70s camp counselor. In other words, totally ideal.”

headline: Troubled Inquisitor
abstract: A novel in dialogue between a man and a series of people he has kidnapped and chained up in a decommissioned military base.
lead_paragraph: Political novels are full of pitfalls, particularly for a novelist with strong political leanings. Writers may craft their world however they like, so they need not deal with the complexities of reality if it inconveniences their narrative. Ayn Rand’s philosophy can work in “Atlas Shrugged,” for example, because it’s a fantasyland of her creation. A better approach can be found in “The Brothers Karamazov,” in which Dostoyevsky makes his ideological opponents his most articulate characters. Great writers force themselves to confront the challenges the world can throw against what they believe. The poet Tom Sleigh explains this as “the difference between exploring a political emotion, say, rather than a political conviction.” Whereas a political emotion is concerned with the lived experience of how politics impact people’s lives, a political conviction is primarily didactic — it “weaves no web, traps no chaotically buzzing flies — it’s hygienic, and easily put aside when the moment of outrage or conversational animus has passed.”

headline: Deep Cover: Alice Goffman’s ‘On the Run’
abstract: For six years, Alice Goffman saw America’s penal system through the eyes of young black men in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: “On the Run” is, first and foremost, a remarkable feat of reporting. Its author, Alice Goffman, a young sociologist, had an ethnography assignment for an undergraduate class at the University of Pennsylvania, and she, the daughter of the renowned sociologist Erving Goffman (1922-82), didn’t take it lightly. She hung out with an older African-American food service worker at the university, and one thing led to another. Before long, she had moved into an apartment in a poor, largely black neighborhood in Philadelphia, her housemate a young man whose family lived down the block. Goffman became such a part of the fabric of the community that she was harassed by the police, witnessed someone getting pistol-whipped, was even set up on a blind date. And all the while she was furiously taking notes, trying to make sense of what at first glance appeared to be utter chaos going on around her.

headline: A Call to Rally
abstract: The bloated democracies of the West need to become as lean as their autocratic competitors, this manifesto urges.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere along the long, bumpy road of human evolution — between the emergence of Davos Man and the TEDification of everything — a new breed of journalist emerged, specially adapted to the corporatized landscape of the modern media biome. Call him Aspen Man, after his proclivity for Ideas. (Aspen Woman exists, too, but the breed skews male.) Like all journalists, Aspen Man feeds upon stories, studies and statistics, but his unique genius lies in his ability to transform the resulting partly digested mix into brain candy for well-heeled aficionados of Malcolm Gladwell and Thomas Friedman.

headline: Between the Lines of the Recess Appointments Decision
abstract: The Supreme Court on Thursday handed down a major decision concerning a president’s power to appoint executive branch officials when the Senate is in recess without going through the confirmation process. The court rejected the validity of four appointments President Obama made in January 2012, when the question of whether the Senate was in recess was in dispute. While on the surface the ruling was a blow to executive power, on a deeper level it was also a victory for executive power because it rolled back an appeals court ruling that had gone much further in restricting such authority.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Thursday handed down a major decision concerning a president’s power to appoint executive branch officials when the Senate is in recess without going through the confirmation process. headline: In the Company of Known Strangers
abstract: Travails pull a family together for home improvements, on the surface and beneath.
lead_paragraph: I pulled into the gravel driveway of my childhood home, parked my ailing Ford Ranger and practiced the mantra I had invented during my two-day drive from Salt Lake City to Coos Bay, Ore.: “Take a deep breath. Don’t argue with your father. Do this for your mother.”

headline: Celebrate Summer 2014: Ways to Teach the Season
abstract: Every year as summer hits full swing, we post a list of ideas for teaching and learning about the joys — and challenges — of the season. All students 13 or older are invited to post their answers to the 12 questions we’ve asked.
lead_paragraph: Every year as summer hits full swing, we post a list of ideas for teaching and learning about the joys — and challenges — of the season.

headline: John Carney Narrates a Scene From ‘Begin Again’
abstract: John Carney discusses a sequence from the film featuring Keira Knightley and Mark Ruffalo.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director John Carney (“Once”) brings his latest film about musicians, “Begin Again,” to the big screen. In this video, he discusses a musical sequence featuring Keira Knightley and Mark Ruffalo.

headline: Hey, Taking Off My Clothes Is Hard Work
abstract: Joe Manganiello, an actor-turned-director, was inspired by his role in “Magic Mike” to make a documentary about the Dallas strip club La Bare.
lead_paragraph: “La Bare” takes its title from the club it chronicles, a male strip joint in Dallas. The name proves unfortunately apt for a rambling, superficial documentary that straddles the line between exposé and infomercial. Directed by the actor Joe Manganiello (who was inspired by his role in Steven Soderbergh’s “Magic Mike,” set in the world of male revues), this celebratory film argues that male stripping is more strenuous than its female counterpart: It requires a full-fledged act and an athlete’s regimen. We learn a bit about the stagecraft, such as how audience volunteers are selected and why underpants with flies are forbidden.

headline: Artifice, Historical Transcendence and Cactus Plants
abstract: Boston Ballet’s first of two 50th-anniversary programs at Lincoln Center presents works by William Forsythe, José Martinez and Alexander Ekman.
lead_paragraph: Celebrating the close of its 50th-anniversary season, Boston Ballet has come to Lincoln Center with two programs at the David H. Koch Theater. The second program, which opens on Friday, includes two masterpieces of different stages of radical modernism, Vaslav Nijinsky’s 1912 “Afternoon of a Faun” and George Balanchine’s 1972 “Symphony in Three Movements.” The first program, which opened on Wednesday, is all postmodern, all chic, all wiseguy, all full of theater games, all laden with production concepts and entirely loathsome.

headline: Caseworker, Into the Woods
abstract: Smith Henderson’s debut novel, “Fourth of July Creek,” follows a social worker in Montana in 1980 investigating a survivalist’s treatment of his son.
lead_paragraph: The unforgettable hero of “Fourth of July Creek” is Pete Snow, a social worker charged with rescuing troubled children in the wilds of northern Montana. At work, he is preternaturally kind and helpful, even in the face of unbearable situations. In this rugged country, way off the grid, it seems there’s no horror he hasn’t seen, from “newly suicided fathers and their wreckage” to “the mother who calls your office wondering if you could take her child, God is telling her to kill him, you better hurry.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Syria and More – Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Syria and More – Pictures of the Day

headline: Paying for Quality Education
abstract: Universities continue to rely on adjunct professors to teach. But students, ANNA ALTMAN writes, are wondering whether the trend will diminish the value, and return on investment, of their college degrees.
lead_paragraph: Early this year, President Obama announced “version 1.0” of his college-rating system at least in part to help clarify what constituted a good investment for students.

headline: Events in New Jersey for June 29-July 5, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: U.S. Prepares for Sale of Bitcoins Seized in Its Raid on Silk Road
abstract: The United States Marshals Service has arranged an online auction for nearly 30,000 of the Bitcoins it took from the now-defunct Silk Road market.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:46 p.m. | On its face, it looked like a typical government raid: Federal agents shut down an online drug marketplace, seizing millions of dollars of ill-gotten gains in the process.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, the Netherlands, Russia and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, the Netherlands, Russia and Germany.

headline: U.N. Official Says Syrian Rules Are Preventing Aid Delivery
abstract: New bureaucracy by the Syrian government has kept food and medicine from reaching civilians trapped by war, the Security Council is told.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the Security Council reached a hard-won consensus to help United Nations aid agencies deliver food and medicine to Syrians trapped by war, compliance with its resolution has been low. On Thursday, the United Nations’ top aid official told the council that new Syrian bureaucracy had made compliance even lower.

headline: Forced to Hand Over Data, Facebook Files Appeal
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Search and Seizure', 'Social Media', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The New York district attorney’s office demanded account details of 381 people for an investigation that led to indictments on Social Security fraud charges.
lead_paragraph: Facebook and the Manhattan district attorney’s office are in a bitter fight over the government’s demand for the contents of hundreds of Facebook accounts.

headline: Facebook Case Over Search Warrants for User Information
abstract: Facebook has argued that Manhattan prosecutors violated the constitutional rights of its users last year by demanding the nearly complete account data of 381 people, from pages they liked to their photos and private messages.
lead_paragraph: Facebook has argued that Manhattan prosecutors violated the constitutional rights of its users last year by demanding the nearly complete account data of 381 people, from pages they liked to their photos and private messages.

headline: Fewer Loan Applications
abstract: Economists insist that the housing market is on an upward trend, but abnormal conditions left over from the recession continue to be a drag.
lead_paragraph: Spring failed to inspire a surge in home sales nationally this year, even though mortgage rates are still reasonably low. Although economists insist that the housing market is on an upward trend, abnormal conditions left over from the recession continue to be a drag.

headline: Howard Makes Enough Stops to Keep the U.S. Going
abstract: The United States, needing only a tie against Germany to advance to the Round of 16, began the game on their heels.
lead_paragraph: The United States, needing only a tie against Germany to advance to the Round of 16, began the game on their heels.

headline: Let the Mass Destruction Begin
abstract: “Transformers: Age of Extinction” is an action-packed movie with thunderous showers of metal, glass, masonry and earth.
lead_paragraph: “Transformers: Age of Extinction,” the fourth film in an apparently inexhaustible, profoundly exhausting series based on Hasbro toys, raises, not for the first time, a basic question: Who are these movies for? This one, like its predecessors, is likely to make a lot of money all over the world, but that only makes the matter more puzzling. The “Transformers” franchise seems like the most baldly and cynically commercial calculation imaginable — it is merchandising-based entertainment at its purest — and yet somehow it does not pander.

headline: Globalfest to Make Its Summer Debut
abstract: The international music festival, which has taken place in January since 2003, is expanding to offer a day of free programming on July 27.
lead_paragraph: Eleven musical acts, three film screenings, family-friendly performances and an underground bass stage will mark Globalfest’s summer debut, at Lincoln Center on July 27, organizers announced on Thursday.

headline: Court Rules Against Aereo, but Not Against Innovation
abstract: ANNA ALTMAN writes the Supreme Court’s decision may mean the end of Aereo, but not, according to many, of innovation in TV.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday morning, the Supreme Court handed down a 6-3 ruling that it was unlawful for Aereo, a television streaming service, to capture and stream broadcast television signals to subscribers. The court found that Aereo’s service violated the Copyright Act by not securing permission from broadcasters to enact “public performances” of their programs. This result is a largely seen as a boon to networks and a threat to start-ups, particularly those that use cloud-based technology to allow file sharing.

headline: Say Hi, but Don’t Pry
abstract: Advice on saying hello in an awkward situation, responding to high school graduation announcements, coping with a boyfriend’s Facebook family and the trip to the barbershop.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I were sitting in the waiting room of a fertility clinic, when I recognized a woman who was a friend from college 18 years ago. I hadn’t seen or spoken with her since. Would it have been O.K. to say hello to her in this situation? Could I have asked if she’s married and what she’s up to, the way I would any other friend? How about explaining that we were not there for IVF treatment but for a follow-up, since we lucked out and got pregnant on our own?

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Dries Van Noten Spring/Summer 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Torture Details for U.S.S. Cole Bombing Suspect
abstract: A judge said prosecutors had to provide defense attorneys with never-revealed information about his years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Defense lawyers for terrorism suspects at Guantanamo Bay have long complained — and with good reason — that ongoing government resistance to sharing details about mistreatment while in U.S. custody makes it hard, if not impossible to provide adequate legal representation.

headline: Elizabeth A. Sackler to Lead Brooklyn Museum Board
abstract: The Brooklyn Museum has a new leader for its board, Elizabeth A. Sackler.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth A. Sackler has been named chairwoman of the Brooklyn Museum, the first woman in the museum’s nearly 200-year history to serve in that position.

headline: World Cup Captivates America, Except for Ann Coulter
abstract: The conservative commentator blasts the sport, and its defenders blast back.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans were excited to learn on Thursday that the United States would advance to the next round of World Cup competition. One who probably was not: Ann Coulter.

headline: With Rangel’s Win, Another Chapter in the Gang of Four
abstract: For decades the Gang of Four’s influence went virtually unchallenged, and for now Rangel seems to be holding on. Here’s a selection of what has been said over the years about the Gang of Four and their influence in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, Representative Charles B. Rangel won the primary election contest to represent New York’s 13th District in Congress. Darren Sands wrote about the campaign in last Sunday’s magazine, noting that Rangel’s political strength in the community began in the 1980s, when the Coalition for a Just New York ‘‘rallied minority voters and African-American and Latino candidates.’’ The most prominent among the coalition was the ‘‘Gang of Four,’’ which included Charles Rangel, David N. Dinkins, Basil Paterson and Percy Sutton. Sands says that for decades the Gang of Four’s influence went virtually unchallenged, and for now Rangel seems to be holding on. Here’s a selection of what has been said over the years about the Gang of Four and their influence in Harlem:

headline: The Genre, if Not the Song, Remains the Same
abstract: “Begin Again,” starring Keira Knightley, Mark Ruffalo and Adam Levine, is the director John Carney’s follow-up to “Once.”
lead_paragraph: Before it was a Tony Award-winning Broadway musical, “Once” was a scruffy and charming movie, written and directed by John Carney, about a man and a woman united by their love of music and their unstated but obvious attraction to each other. Filmed at street level in the lived-in parts of a picturesque city, it managed to be touristic and authentic at the same time, partly because the central pair consisted of a native and an outsider. Mr. Carney pulled off the enviable trick of dressing unabashed romantic sentiment in a style that felt rough and real, so that every cliché he touched felt shiny and new.

headline: Fear of Packing
abstract: How did we ever manage without Baggies?
lead_paragraph: We all have our favorites when it comes to the life-changing inventions of the 20th century, and mine is the Baggie.

headline: Rapper Convicted of Murder, Racketeering and Drug Dealing
keywords: ['Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Ronald Herron, who performs as Ra Diggs, was found guilty of running a drug ring in two Brooklyn housing projects and of killing three people involved with drugs.
lead_paragraph: After one day of deliberations, a federal jury on Thursday found a Bloods gang leader from the Gowanus Houses in Brooklyn guilty of all 21 counts he had been tried for, including three murders, racketeering and drug trafficking.

headline: Senior U.S. Prosecutor Joins Paul Weiss
abstract: Lorin L. Reisner, the former head of the criminal division of the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan, will be a partner in the firm’s litigation department.
lead_paragraph: A day after Lorin L. Reisner announced that he was stepping down as head of the criminal division of the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan, the law firm Paul Weiss on Thursday named him as a partner in its litigation department.

headline: Clip: ‘Transformers: Age of Extinction’
abstract: A scene from the movie.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the movie.

headline: The Dark Side Gets Its Due
abstract: The new Morbid Anatomy Museum in Brooklyn aims to highlight the obscure, the forgotten and the strangely beautiful.
lead_paragraph: Most of us don’t stop for death until it kindly, or unkindly, stops for us. And then there is the new Morbid Anatomy Museum, which will throw the Grim Reaper an enthusiastic welcome party when it opens its doors this weekend in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn.

headline: A 3,000-Mile Road Trip to the World Cup
abstract: Dado Galdieri, a photographer, followed Chilean fans driving to Brazil in hopes of seeing their team make the finals.
lead_paragraph: Dado Galdieri, a photographer, followed Chilean fans driving to Brazil in hopes of seeing their team make the finals.

headline: Inner Musings on a Precarious Descent
abstract: Death casts a long shadow over the recent work of Michael Hersch, including his new opera, “On the Threshold of Winter.”
lead_paragraph: On certain college campuses, Michael Hersch’s new opera, “On the Threshold of Winter,” would come with a boldface trigger warning. The two-act monodrama, which received its searing premiere on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is about illness and death. Its texts, taken from deathbed poems by the Romanian writer Marin Sorescu, offer an unflinching look at the rage, despair and sense of isolation he felt in his final weeks in a Bucharest hospital ward.

headline: Art as Architecture and as Currency
abstract: Solo shows by Katrin Sigurdardottir, Liz Glynn and Jory Rabinovitz at SculptureCenter in Long Island City, Queens, offer refreshingly un-Koonsian ideas about sculpture.
lead_paragraph: For refreshingly un-Koonsian ideas about sculpture, look no further than the three solo exhibitions now at SculptureCenter. One is a large-scale installation by the midcareer Icelandic artist Katrin Sigurdardottir; the other two are smaller projects by the emerging American artists Liz Glynn and Jory Rabinovitz. Shiny objects and artisanal craftsmanship play a role here, as they do in Jeff Koons’s survey at the Whitney, but so do imperfection, evanescence and parsimoniousness.

headline: Crumbs Bake Shop Set to Delist From Nasdaq
abstract: The cupcake chain, which went public in 2011, says that Nasdaq has denied its request to keep its common stock listed.
lead_paragraph: The cupcake craze may be getting stale.

headline: A Shift in the Beautiful Game
abstract: Spain, Italy, England – all gone home. With the U.S. team reaching the next stage of competition, some predictions are due.
lead_paragraph: When Spain, Italy and England have all gone home, and the United States is through to the Round of 16 of the World Cup, something has shifted in the beautiful game. Jurgen Klinsmann’s U.S. team has been gritty, cohesive and occasionally explosive, as when Jermaine Jones almost burst the net with his equalizing rocket against Portugal. America, less naïve with each recent World Cup, deserves its place in the knock-out phase.

abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Stuck in Steerage for the Postapocalypse
abstract: Bong Joon-ho’s “Snowpiercer” envisions a postapocalyptic world on a train, where first class is fabulous and the economy cars are a lot like hell.
lead_paragraph: In the mood for allegory? Have a look at Bong Joon-ho’s “Snowpiercer,” which proceeds from a fantastical premise rich with real-world relevance. After a human-engineered planetary catastrophe (trying to arrest the planet’s warming, we accidentally froze it solid), the remaining people are stuck on a train that never stops moving. A few thousand survivors live in railway cars, sorted into a rigid and ruthlessly enforced social order. In the back are huddled masses fed on gelatinous, insect-based black protein bars and kept in line by a combination of propaganda and brute force. Toward the front, the more fortunate enjoy access to schools, nightclubs, fresh food and the reassurance that they deserve everything they have. An unseen, quasi-mythical entrepreneur is in charge, and a group of rebels have decided to challenge his power and the extreme inequality he represents.

headline: F.C.C. Issues Snapshot of U.S. Internet Service
abstract: As much as 30 percent of households do not have a connection faster than dial-up speed, according to government figures released this week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The number of homes in the United States that subscribe to Internet service has grown at a 15 percent annual rate over the last decade, to 85 million. But as much as 30 percent of households do not have a connection faster than dial-up speed, according to government figures released this week.

lead_paragraph: A KING OF THE MIDWAY,

headline: A Matchmaker in Reverse
abstract: The Chinese comedy “The Breakup Guru” opens the heart of a man who makes his living shutting down relationships.
lead_paragraph: The jokes and sight gags fly in exhausting profusion in “The Breakup Guru,” Deng Chao and Yu Baimei’s antic, scattershot romantic comedy. Mr. Deng plays the titular fixer, Mei Yuangui, a successful specialist in terminating the relationships of celebrities and socialites through entrapment, public humiliation and other unsavory methods. (These tactics are accompanied by a lot of mugging and extreme grimacing.) Now, with three trusty helpers, Yuangui has one last job: to help a smarmy, Western-style motivational speaker and “successologist” (Liang Chao) unload his Beijing mistress, Ye Xiaochun (Yang Mi). To that end, Yuangui resolves to trick the mistress into falling for none other than himself. Somehow, for all his overemphatic mannerisms, he succeeds.
