lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Environmental Agency Approves $511 Million Loan for Tappan Zee Replacement
abstract: The loan, which has been criticized by environmental and transportation groups, must still be approved by the Thruway Authority and the Public Authorities Control Board.
lead_paragraph: The New York State agency that lends federal money for sewer plants and other clean-water projects on Thursday approved a $511 million loan to the Thruway Authority for 17 projects that are part of the building of a twin-span replacement for the Tappan Zee Bridge across the Hudson River.

headline: From Letter Carrier to a Name in Lights
abstract: In “Postman Pat: The Movie,” a locally beloved character is seduced by fame and commercial success.
lead_paragraph: In various incarnations, the animated children’s series “Postman Pat” has been a staple of British television since 1981. The title character is a letter carrier who, along with his cat, Jess, brings joy and generosity to the farm community of Greendale.

headline: Spare Times for Children for June 27-July 3
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: Bug Day

headline: Michaels I.P.O. Prices at $17, at Low End of Range
abstract: The arts and craft retailer raises $472 million in the offering, but its private equity owners — Bain Capital and Blackstone — have already reaped a $714 million dividend.
lead_paragraph: The Michaels Companies, the arts and crafts retailer that has spent nearly eight years in private ownership, is ready to make its public markets debut.

headline: Two Lives, Ruthlessly Exploited
abstract: The documentary “Bound by Flesh” recounts the lives of Violet and Daisy Hilton, conjoined twins who became a famous vaudeville act.
lead_paragraph: Every few years, it seems, someone rediscovers the Hilton sisters, the conjoined twins who spent decades as a sideshow attraction and then a vaudeville act in the heart of the last century. They are having a moment again: A new production of “Side Show,” the stage musical inspired by their lives, has recently opened at the Kennedy Center in Washington, and now “Bound by Flesh,” a straightforward documentary by Leslie Zemeckis, is being given a theatrical release.

headline: Spare Times for June 27-July 4
abstract: A guide to fairs and cultural festivals, literary events, walking tours and more in New York City.
lead_paragraph: NYC Pride Events (Friday through Sunday) The monthlong celebration of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender diversity concludes this weekend with something for everyone. A free rally with performances will kick things off on Friday, from 6 to 9:30 p.m., at Pier 26, in Hudson River Park, at North Moore Street, TriBeCa. It will be followed by a dance party for men, starting at 11 p.m. at BPM, 516 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Women will get their own party at Pier 26 on Saturday, from 4 to 10 p.m.

headline: This Week’s Movies | June 27, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Transformers: Age of Extinction,” “Snowpiercer” and “Begin Again.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Transformers: Age of Extinction,” “Snowpiercer” and “Begin Again.”

headline: Mixed Emotions at a Gathering to Say Goodbye
abstract: In “Archipelago,” a Joanna Hogg film, a family’s intimacies are laid bare.
lead_paragraph: Joanna Hogg — where have you been all my movie-loving life? That thought buzzed through my head after, with intensifying greediness, I tore through this British director’s three features: “Unrelated,” “Archipelago” and “Exhibition.” They’re finally receiving American distribution, so if you’re lucky enough to be in New York, run over to the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center and catch them now.

headline: Stiff Drinks and Stiff Upper Lips: Britons on a Tuscan Holiday
abstract: In “Unrelated,” the British director Joanna Hogg demonstrates her gift for observational drama and upper-middle-class portraiture.
lead_paragraph: Because it has no conventional action or schematic story, “Unrelated,” Joanna Hogg’s dyspeptic portrait of upper-middle-class Britons on a summer holiday in Tuscany, is the antithesis of popcorn entertainment. The guests, who span two generations, convene in a spacious rented villa equipped with a large swimming pool and caretakers. The movie observes their leisure activities with a chilly documentary objectivity.

headline: Lost to the Grim Realities of India
abstract: “Siddharth,” by Richie Mehta, traces a father’s search that takes him far and wide through India’s poverty.
lead_paragraph: Mahendra Saini (Rajesh Tailang), the meek, sad-eyed protagonist of Richie Mehta’s touching film “Siddharth,” is a resident of New Delhi, with a wife, a son approaching puberty and a younger daughter. He ekes out a living on the streets fixing zippers, touting his service through a bullhorn, but business has been bad. In the film’s opening moments, he says goodbye to his son, Siddharth, who is leaving on a bus to work in a factory in distant Ludhiana. The boy’s employer, Om Prakash (Amitabh Srivasta), is a distant cousin of Mahendra’s brother-in-law, Ranjit (Anurag Arora). Both are hardened in ways that Mahendra is not.

headline: Slain Libyan Rights Activist Documented Her Last Hours Online
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: One of Libya’s most prominent civil rights activists, Salwa Bugaighis, was assassinated in her home in Benghazi on Wednesday, shortly after she posted an image of militiamen outside her home on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: Just hours before she was assassinated on Wednesday, one of Libya’s most prominent civil rights activists, Salwa Bugaighis, logged on to Facebook to urge her fellow citizens of Benghazi to head to the polls and vote, despite violent clashes in the streets between Islamist militias and the forces of a renegade general.

headline: When Boy Meets Girl in Ben Franklin Wigs
abstract: In “They Came Together,” the director David Wain goes after the romantic comedy genre with a metaphoric jackhammer and more.
lead_paragraph: In “They Came Together,” a sloppy, fitfully funny broadside at the romantic comedy, the director David Wain goes after that oft-abused genre with a metaphoric jackhammer — as well as a bat, a machete, a couple of knives, one or two missiles and the sort of sizzling cartoon bomb that Wile E. Coyote used to hurl. Mr. Wain has some expert help with his demolition work, namely his stars, Amy Poehler and Paul Rudd, who with another dozen or so cutups, embody assorted romantic comedy stereotypes with wide smiles, seasoned technique and unfettered spleen.

headline: After More Than 100 Days Away, Tiger Woods Plays Like His Partners: Raggedly
abstract: Tiger Woods, returning to the PGA Tour from back surgery, shot a 74 in the first round of the Quicken Loans National. The leader, Greg Chalmers, posted a five-under 66.
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md. — If it had been a band from the swing era, the Tiger Woods trio would have been booed off the stage Thursday at Congressional Country Club. But it was a golf group, and the crowd, which lined up five deep around the 10th tee and formed a human outline around the 208-yard par-3 hole, was overwhelmingly supportive from start to finish.

headline: In Prisons, Sky-High Phone Rates and Money Transfer Fees
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The jails and prisons get commissions from phone and financial companies, which then charge very high rates to inmates who have no other choices.
lead_paragraph: Inside the razor wire on Eagle Crest Way, in rural Clallam Bay, Wash., telephone calls start at $3.15. Emails out, beyond the security fence, run 33 cents. Money transfers in, to what pass for bank accounts, cost $4.95.

headline: Navigating the New Publishing World
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'E-Books and Readers']
abstract: Readers discuss an Op-Ed essay by Tony Horwitz about his experience with digital publishing.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 178 Years Late, a Briton Replenishes the Alamo
keywords: ['ALAMO (SAN ANTONIO, TEX)', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Memorabilia and Souvenirs', 'Music']
abstract: Phil Collins, the London-born singer and drummer, arrived in Texas to talk about his donation of more than 200 pieces of Alamo memorabilia and artifacts to the state.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Phil Collins, a member of Genesis and a staple of 1980s-era MTV, arrived at the Alamo here on Thursday carrying a sword and a dagger. Jerry Patterson, the Texas land commissioner, brought two guns, one tucked in his cowboy boot and the other in his waistband.

headline: A Trial in a Troubling Context
abstract: The documentary “Whitey,” about the Boston gangster Whitey Bulger, tells of his murder case last year.
lead_paragraph: James J. Bulger, better known as Whitey, was a notorious and widely feared criminal in Boston in the 1970s and ’80s. He disappeared after being tipped off about an impending arrest in 1994, and after that was a famous fugitive. Captured three years ago in California — where he had been living quietly with his longtime girlfriend — Mr. Bulger was tried last summer on a host of charges, including 19 counts of murder. His trial is the subject of “Whitey,” a gripping and troubling new documentary by Joe Berlinger.

headline: Resilient Dreamers
abstract: Patti Smith and Klaus Biesenbach have teamed up to start a new festival to celebrate the re-opening of Fort Tilden and their adopted community in the Rockaways.
lead_paragraph: Patti Smith and Klaus Biesenbach have teamed up to start a new festival to celebrate the re-opening of Fort Tilden and their adopted community in the Rockaways.

headline: Action by Argentina Seems to Defy Judge’s Order on Bond Payments
abstract: Argentina announced Thursday that it had deposited $539 million with the Bank of New York Mellon for the purpose of paying its main bondholders, a move that would defy a federal judge’s order.
lead_paragraph: Argentina made a puzzling and potentially provocative move on Thursday in its landmark legal battle with New York hedge funds, which are suing the country over bonds that it defaulted on over 10 years ago.

headline: Jookin in the Spotlight
abstract: Lil Buck, born Charles Riley, has bounced from music videos to a Super Bowl halftime show to Lincoln Center. He introduced mainstream audiences to jookin, a street dance born in his hometown, Memphis.
lead_paragraph: Lil Buck, born Charles Riley, has bounced from music videos to a Super Bowl halftime show to Lincoln Center. He introduced mainstream audiences to jookin, a street dance born in his hometown, Memphis.

headline: Finally, a Tide of Celebration in the Rockaways
abstract: Rockaway!, a site-specific festival in Queens, includes works by Patti Smith, who, with Klaus Biesenbach of MoMA PS1, created the event to celebrate the community.
lead_paragraph: PATTI SMITH has been visiting the Rockaways in Queens since the 1970s, when she would venture around the secluded Fort Tilden, the national park and beach, with Robert Mapplethorpe.

headline: Why Immigrant Children Are at Our Door
abstract: Readers respond to a news article, “U.S. Moves to Stop Surge in Illegal Immigration.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: No Conclusion in Inquiry Into Scott Walker’s Campaign Fund-Raising
abstract: A special prosecutor looking into the Wisconsin governor’s campaign fund-raising said there was not enough evidence to charge anyone with a crime.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A special prosecutor investigating possible illegal fund-raising coordination between the Wisconsin campaign of Gov. Scott Walker and conservative groups has reached no conclusion as to whether there is enough evidence to charge anyone with a crime, the prosecutor’s lawyer said in a statement issued Thursday.

headline: Shapes of an Extroverted Life
abstract: The Whitney Museum of American Art’s largest survey devoted to a single artist chronicles Jeff Koons’s ever-changing provocations.
lead_paragraph: There are so many strange, disconcerting aspects to Jeff Koons, his art and his career that it is hard to quite know how to approach his first New York retrospective, the Whitney Museum of American Art’s largest survey devoted to a single artist.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Comedy and Carnage
abstract: “Jackpot” is a throwback to the “Pulp Fiction”-style deadpan noirs that proliferated in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: There are few circumstances in which it’s comforting to find yourself under interrogation, but Oscar (Kyrre Hellum), the hero of “Jackpot,” is in an especially tight spot. Can he explain how he ended up surrounded by eight dead bodies in a Swedish sex shop — the last man standing, despite never having fired a shot?

headline: In Gaza, Work but No Pay
abstract: Being a government employee in Gaza does not guarantee a paycheck, as workers hired by rival political factions fight for scarce funds.
lead_paragraph: Being a government employee in Gaza does not guarantee a paycheck, as workers hired by rival political factions fight for scarce funds.

headline: Fans Hospitalized in Latest Dance Music Setback
abstract: Three dozen Avicii fans were hospitalized after a concert at TD Garden in Boston on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: In the latest headache for the growing business of electronic dance music, three dozen fans were hospitalized in Boston on Wednesday night after going to a concert by the star D.J. Avicii, apparently for problems related to drugs and alcohol.

headline: Leave Iraq to the Iraqis
abstract: Michael W. Cotter, a former United States ambassador to Turkmenistan, raises questions about possible American military involvement in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: With Aplomb, Young Star Passes Test
abstract: Despite faltering in the second set, Madison Keys, 19, defeated Klara Koukalova, 7-6, 6-7 (3), 6-2, on Thursday to advance to the third round at Wimbledon.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — If adversity is the best education, the 5-foot-10-inch Madison Keys experienced a competitive growth spurt after dropping the second set of her second-round match here Thursday against the physically overmatched but persistent Klara Koukalova of the Czech Republic.

headline: Money Splits a City Still Mourning Its Firefighters
abstract: The question of money has driven broad divisions in Prescott, Ariz., that persist even as the first anniversary of a tragedy that killed 19 firefighters draws near.
lead_paragraph: PRESCOTT, Ariz. — Smoke drifted from the fire that tore through the chaparral brush on nearby mountains after the flames had claimed the lives of 19 firefighters almost a year ago, immersing this tight community in heartache. In the months that followed, tributes — on storefronts, on bumper stickers and along the mesh-iron fence surrounding Station 7, the firefighters’ home base — stood as glaring reminders of a tragedy no one here has forgotten.

headline: Israel Names Prime Suspects in Abductions
abstract: Describing Marwan Qawasmeh and Amer Abu Aisha as “Hamas activists,” Israel said it had been hunting for the two since the kidnapping of three teenagers came to light.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Marwan Qawasmeh and Amer Abu Aisha, both residents of the West Bank city of Hebron, were last seen on the night of June 12, shortly before three Israeli teenagers went missing while hitchhiking a few miles to the north.

headline: Make College Accessible
abstract: Joshua Wyner of the Aspen Institute responds to an Upshot article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Libraries and the Young
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Books and Literature', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Libraries and Librarians']
abstract: Roz Rubinstein of the Waterford (Conn.) Public Library responds to a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: For British Spy in Iraq, Affection Is Strong but Legacy Is Unfulfilled
abstract: Gertrude Bell, who worked to stabilize Iraq after World War I, won hearts and minds but was unable to meld a mix of religious sects into a stable nation.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A picture of Gertrude Bell, the British diplomat and spy, still hangs on a wall in the Alwiya Club, the Baghdad clubhouse for the social elite that she established, and black-and-white photographs of her can be found in the collections of the city’s old families.

headline: Militarism and Humiliation Cast Shadow on Germany
abstract: A century after World War I began, German leadership in Europe is both desired and resented, an ambivalence keenly felt by both the Germans and their wary neighbors.
lead_paragraph: KIEL, Germany — On June 28, 1914, Kaiser Wilhelm II was preparing to indulge in a favorite pastime: racing his yacht Meteor at a regatta that is still held each year in this seafaring stronghold. When he learned of the assassination in Sarajevo of Archduke Franz Ferdinand, the heir to the Hapsburg Empire, he hastened to Berlin. But he quickly returned to this Baltic Sea port, on which he lavished so much money and time in his frantic race to match or outdo British naval superiority.

headline: The War to End All Wars? Hardly. But It Did Change Them Forever.
abstract: World War I destroyed kings, kaisers, czars and sultans; it demolished empires; it introduced chemical weapons; it brought millions of women into the work force.
lead_paragraph: ZONNEBEKE, Belgium — To walk the orderly rows of headstones in the elegant graveyards that hold the dead of World War I is to feel both awe and distance. With the death of the last veterans, World War I, which began 100 years ago, has moved from memory to history. But its resonance has not faded — on land and geography, people and nations, and on the causes and consequences of modern war.

headline: Belgians Share Their Land With War’s Reminders
keywords: ['World War I (1914-18)', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A century after hundreds of thousands died around Ypres, their remains are still being found, and shells are still exploding.
lead_paragraph: YPRES, Belgium — The padlocked cage beside the driveway on the Butaye family farm near this town in western Belgium is almost full of rusting bombs again. Since January, Stijn Butaye has collected 46 mortar shells on his family’s 100 acres, World War I munitions he found among the sugar beet and potato fields, sometimes with the help of his metal detector.

headline: In Sarajevo, Divisions That Drove an Assassin Have Only Begun to Heal
abstract: Nationalist and sectarian passions continue to haunt Bosnia, which was ravaged by a civil war just two decades ago and is even now the scene of dueling efforts to define Gavrilo Princip’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — As the 100th anniversary approaches, the clusters of visitors have thickened at the street-corner museum in Sarajevo’s old town that stands where Gavrilo Princip claimed his place in history on June 28, 1914, firing the shots that killed Archduke Franz Ferdinand and his wife, Sophie, and setting off World War I.

headline: A Battle in Ukraine Echoes Through the Decades
abstract: Divided loyalties among the citizenry during World War I are still seen in today’s struggle with Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT MAKIVKA, Ukraine — In a conflict that cost millions of lives, destroyed four empires and introduced Europe to the horrors of chemical weapons and total war, the battle on a pine-covered mountain in what is today western Ukraine was a modest affair. A few hundred soldiers died, and the outcome was so muddled that all sides claimed victory.

headline: When the Americans Turned the Tide
keywords: ['World War I (1914-18)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Germans were pushing toward Paris in 1918 when untested American troops helped stop them at the Marne River in a pivotal World War I battle.
lead_paragraph: CHÂTEAU-THIERRY, France — Fifty miles to Paris. That was all that separated a hardened German Army from, perhaps, the end of the Great War. By early 1918, the Germans were rolling through northern France, and French commanders feared they were planning a decisive attack against the capital. First, though, they had to cross a ribbon of green water known as the Marne. And traverse a small forest known as Belleau Wood.

headline: Murdoch’s Letter on Slaughter at Gallipoli
abstract: In 1915, Keith Arthur Murdoch wrote an 8,000-word letter to Prime Minister Andrew Fisher of Australia, describing what he called “one of the most terrible chapters in our history.”
lead_paragraph: In 1915, Keith Arthur Murdoch wrote an 8,000-word letter to Prime Minister Andrew Fisher of Australia, describing what he called “one of the most terrible chapters in our history.”

headline: Destroying Bombs From World War I
abstract: France’s Department of Mine Clearance is responsible for collecting and destroying unexploded shells still found by the thousands nearly 100 years after the Battle of Verdun.
lead_paragraph: France’s Department of Mine Clearance is responsible for collecting and destroying unexploded shells still found by the thousands nearly 100 years after the Battle of Verdun.

headline: The Bomb Collector of Ypres
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Collectors and Collections', 'World War I (1914-18)']
abstract: World War I relics, including unexploded shells, are exhibited by Stijn Butaye, 26, on his family farm.
lead_paragraph: World War I relics, including unexploded shells, are exhibited by Stijn Butaye, 26, on his family farm.

headline: At Gallipoli, a Campaign That Laid Ground for National Identities
abstract: For the Turks and the Australians, the Gallipoli campaign has taken on an outsize importance as the bloody event that became the foundation of a modern national consciousness.
lead_paragraph: CANAKKALE, Turkey — The trenches are still there, carved in the green hills of the slim Gallipoli Peninsula just across the Dardanelles, the waterway that connects the Aegean and Marmara Seas on the way to Istanbul from the port city of Canakkale. Gravestones adorn the beachheads and lands farther inland, marking the lives of the young men — Britons, Frenchmen, Australians, New Zealanders and their enemies, the Ottoman Turks — who died there, almost a century ago.

headline: Tourists Flock to Damaged Cars
abstract: A sinkhole that swallowed eight cars in the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky., is now attracting tourists.
lead_paragraph: A sinkhole that swallowed eight cars in the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky., is now attracting tourists.

headline: Heedless of Traffic Laws
abstract: A reader criticizes New York City drivers and calls for greater enforcement of existing laws.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Florida Court Overturns Death Sentence for 1985 Killing
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Sex Crimes', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Re-examined DNA evidence pointed to the victim’s boyfriend, who is in prison for attempted sexual battery of a child.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — With new DNA evidence in hand, a divided Florida Supreme Court on Thursday overturned the death sentence and conviction of Paul C. Hildwin, a man found guilty nearly three decades ago of strangling a woman in Hernando County, Fla. The woman, Vronzettie Cox, 42, whose body was found in the trunk of a car, had been raped.

headline: Tribe, Purveyor of Hummus, Hopes to Narrow Sabra’s Lead With New Campaign
abstract: The No. 2 hummus brand, Tribe, is introducing commercials shot in the style of a National Geographic documentary, complete with British-accented voice-over.
lead_paragraph: HUMMUS, the dip made with chickpeas, is believed to have been eaten for millenniums, but it has flown off deli section shelves in recent years as if it were a novelty. Sales in the United States of refrigerated flavored spreads, a category dominated by hummus, grew 21 percent, to $695.5 million, for the 52 weeks ending May 18, according to IRI, a market data firm.

headline: U.S. Defense Is Bolstered by a New Man in the Middle
abstract: Omar Gonzalez replaced Geoff Cameron in the heart of the United States defense and had a strong game in a 1-0 loss to Germany.
lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — Because the memory of Portugal’s fifth-minute goal against the United States on Sunday was still so fresh, the last thing the team and its fans needed to see Thursday afternoon was another early defensive miscue.

headline: Lock ’Em Up Nation
abstract: In an absurd prosecution, the federal government is trying to take away the freedom of a retired couple growing pot to ease their bodily pains.
lead_paragraph: How did the United States, land of the free, become the world’s top jailer? It’s a question asked by visitors from other democracies, and the American citizen who wakes from a stupor to find that our prisons are stuffed with people serving interminable sentences for nonviolent crimes.

headline: In Atlanta, Some Dispute Murder Charge Against Father in Hot-Car Death of Boy
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The question comes down to whether a 2011 Hyundai Tucson should be considered the scene of a crime or of a horrible mistake.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The legal drama that has gripped this city for more than a week comes down to whether a 2011 Hyundai Tucson should be considered the scene of a crime or of a horrible mistake.

headline: Where Killings Are Common, Death of Activist Stuns Benghazi
abstract: The killing of Salwa Bugaighis silenced a lawyer who helped propel the 2011 uprising and who tried to broaden Libya’s notions of rights and citizenship.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Salwa Bugaighis, a Libyan lawyer and civil rights activist, stood on the roof of her home in Benghazi on Wednesday and watched as armed groups fought gun battles on the edges of town.

headline: Guantánamo Detainees’ Lawyers Urge Obama to Approve Release to Uruguay
abstract: Also this week, a military judge overseeing a war-crimes tribunal issued an order that generated new dispute over how much classified information the C.I.A. must give defense lawyers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawyers for six low-level detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, whom Uruguay has offered to resettle sent a letter to the Obama administration on Thursday urging it to act on the deal, which has been awaiting the signature of Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel since March.

headline: Artful Guises in the Belle Epoque
keywords: ['Movies', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)']
abstract: Criterion releases George Franju’s “Judex” (1963), a remake of a silent 1916 French serial, and Shout! Factory assembles an Angela Mao Ying martial arts set.
lead_paragraph: Popular culture at its most pop produces our modern mythology of superheroes, monsters and galactic conspiracies. But not all myths are created equal. Writing about mid-1950s sci-fi films, the British critic Raymond Durgnat discovered a necessary dialectic that he called “the wedding of poetry and pulp.”

headline: The Supreme Court Was Right to Allow Anti-Abortion Protests
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'ABORTION', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: The First Amendment protects speech we hate just as vigorously as speech we support.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Even as a committed supporter of a woman’s — increasingly imperiled — right to choose, I must acknowledge that the Supreme Court got it right on Thursday.

headline: Obama: ‘You Guys Are the Reason I Ran’
abstract: In remarks delivered Thursday, President Obama discussed the ways in which he relates to the problems of common Americans.
lead_paragraph: In remarks delivered Thursday, President Obama discussed the ways in which he relates to the problems of common Americans.

headline: High Tension and a Cold Shoulder at Border of Two Koreas
abstract: On the front line of what is technically the continuing war between North and South Korea, daily life is an odd mix of high tension and mundane routine.
lead_paragraph: PANMUNJOM, South Korea — Lt. Cmdr. Daniel McShane dashed from the rainstorm into the sentry post. Minutes earlier, he had walked up to a strip of concrete that marks the de facto border with North Korea and, through an interpreter, read out a request: An American colonel wanted to meet face to face with his North Korean counterpart.

headline: Clip: ‘Earth to Echo’
abstract: A scene from the film, directed by Dave Green.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, directed by Dave Green.

headline: In a Diner With Obama, a Serving of Ordinary Life
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Minimum Wage', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: The president visited with a woman who had written to him about her struggles as part of a White House effort to reach ordinary Americans.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — In the first episode in a series the White House is marketing as “Day in the Life” visits ahead of the midterm elections in November, President Obama spent part of Thursday with a mother who had written to him about her struggles.

headline: The Incompetence Dogma
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: But Obamacare wasn’t supposed to work! What were all those cries of impending disaster about?
lead_paragraph: Have you been following the news about Obamacare? The Affordable Care Act has receded from the front page, but information about how it’s going keeps coming in — and almost all the news is good. Indeed, health reform has been on a roll ever since March, when it became clear that enrollment would surpass expectations despite the teething problems of the federal website.

headline: Cavaliers Pick Wiggins at No. 1, Bringing N.B.A. Draft Speculation Full Circle
abstract: In the end, the top three selections were essentially what observers expected all along, with Andrew Wiggins, Jabari Parker and Joel Embiid picked by the Cavaliers, Bucks and 76ers.
lead_paragraph: As the college basketball season hummed along, speculation of who would be the top pick in the N.B.A. draft shifted from Andrew Wiggins to Jabari Parker to Joel Embiid. On Thursday, as Adam Silver conducted his first draft as commissioner, things came full circle, and it was Wiggins who walked onto the Barclays Center stage sporting a Cleveland Cavaliers hat as the No. 1 overall pick.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 26, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbersfor New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Here Are the 43,634 Properties in Detroit That Were on the Brink of Foreclosure in 2014
abstract: A mosaic, created with images from Google Maps Street View, shows one of the many enormous challenges facing Detroit as it tries to climb out of debt.
lead_paragraph: A mosaic, created with images from Google Maps Street View, shows one of the many enormous challenges facing Detroit as it tries to climb out of debt.

headline: Secrets of the Universe, Embedded in Pop Ditties
abstract: In the science-fiction movie “Radio Free Albemuth,” based on a book by Philip K. Dick, humans receive secret communications from an extraterrestrial source as they endure despotic rule.
lead_paragraph: Airless and earthbound, “Radio Free Albemuth”  resembles a weird artifact from the early days of science-fiction television — a lost episode of “The Outer Limits” or “Tales of Tomorrow.” Based on the novel of the same title by Philip K. Dick (published posthumously in 1985), this lifeless adaptation only proves that making entertaining movies out of hard-to-swallow ideas is as challenging as you might think.

headline: Most Will Be Able to Automatically Renew Coverage Under Health Law
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The Obama administration announced that most people would be able to renew subsidized health insurance coverage without filing an application.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration announced Thursday that most people would be able to renew subsidized health insurance coverage without filing an application and without going back to HealthCare.gov, the website that frustrated millions of consumers last fall.

headline: Redrawn Lines Seen as No Cure in Iraq Conflict
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations', 'Kurds', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Fragmentation appears inevitable, but the tensions that divide may fuel new conflicts over ideology and natural resources.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Over the past two weeks, the specter that has haunted Iraq since its founding 93 years ago appears to have become a reality: the de facto partition of the country into Sunni, Shiite and Kurdish cantons.

headline: Bleak Prognosis From Both Sides of Aisle in House for Immigration Overhaul
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: For Republican lawmakers, distrust of the president and opposition from the Tea Party make action on immigration a daunting prospect.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two leading House lawmakers — one Republican and one Democrat — declared efforts to overhaul the nation’s broken immigration system all but dead for the year, the result of hardening Tea Party opposition and growing mistrust of President Obama among congressional Republicans.

headline: A Dark Horse Is Adjusting to Rising Expectations
abstract: For Belgium, making its first World Cup appearance since 2002, the business of being a soccer power has required a little getting used to.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO — It was always the neighboring Dutch who painted their houses orange for the World Cup, drove orange cars and wore orange outfits until everything and everyone in the Netherlands was the color of a traffic cone.

headline: Politicians’ Prescriptions for Marijuana Defy Doctors and Data
abstract: There is no rigorous scientific evidence that marijuana effectively treats the symptoms of many of the illnesses for which states have authorized its use.
lead_paragraph: New York moved last week to join 22 states in legalizing medical marijuana for patients with a diverse array of debilitating ailments, encompassing epilepsy and cancer, Crohn’s disease and Parkinson’s. Yet there is no rigorous scientific evidence that marijuana effectively treats the symptoms of many of the illnesses for which states have authorized its use.

headline: In the Eye of a European Political Storm Stands a Quiet Enigma
abstract: Jean-Claude Juncker, a former prime minister of Luxembourg, has become the European Union’s most divisive figure in his run for president of its executive branch, while revealing little of himself.
lead_paragraph: LUXEMBOURG — As millions of Greeks faced misery amid Europe’s debt crisis, Jean-Claude Juncker, the Luxembourger helping to oversee their rescue, was asked at a news conference what would happen if Greece failed to meet the demands of the lenders who had bailed out the country.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Powerful New Consensus
abstract: Not since 1940 have the justices agreed so often.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — FOR years, particularly after the 2000 election, talk about the Supreme Court has centered on its bitter 5-to-4 divisions. Yet it is worth reflecting on a remarkable achievement: The court has agreed unanimously in more than 66 percent of its cases this term (and that figure holds even if Monday’s remaining two cases, on the Affordable Care Act’s contraceptive coverage and on public-sector unions, are not unanimous). The last year this happened was 1940.

headline: As a Bandwagon Fills, a Team Fails Forward
abstract: The United States soccer team is not the most elegant, but it’s endearing and, more important, advancing.
lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — The United States soccer players seemed to pass the ball to Germany more often than they did to their own teammates. Late in the game, two Americans — Jermaine Jones and Alejandro Bedoya — were left splayed on the field after running into each other and knocking heads. Jones had also hit the turf earlier when he ran at full speed into the referee.

headline: This Weekend: A Jeff Koons Retrospective
keywords: ['Art', 'Museums', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'ANATOMY AND PHYSIOLOGY', 'Hurricane Sandy']
abstract: Make this weekend an art-filled one. There’s the Jeff Koons retrospective at the Whitney, a new morbid museum in Brooklyn and an arts festival in the Rockaways.
lead_paragraph: Make this weekend an art-filled one. There’s the Jeff Koons retrospective at the Whitney, a new morbid museum in Brooklyn and an arts festival in the Rockaways.

headline: The Road to Dov Charney’s Ouster at American Apparel
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Boards of Directors', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The plan to fire American Apparel’s founder and chief executive took shape in a private dining room at the Redeye Grill in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: In a dimly lit private dining room at the Redeye Grill in Manhattan, four board members of American Apparel and their lawyer plotted out their next 24 hours over steaks and red wine.

headline: In Botched Case of Park Jogger, an Altered Life
abstract: The police appeared to have lost track of Matias Reyes after the jogger attack, even though he had been identified as a suspect in the rape two days before.
lead_paragraph: After the man was finished raping the 20-year-old college student and searching her apartment for money, he announced that he had to kill or blind her. He held an ice pick to her eyes, then found a blade. Already he had bound her with telephone wire ripped from the wall.

headline: A 100-Year Legacy of World War I
abstract: World War I demolished empires and destroyed kings, kaisers and sultans. It introduced chemical weapons and aerial bombing. It brought women into the work force and hastened their legal right to vote.
lead_paragraph: World War I demolished empires and destroyed kings, kaisers and sultans. It introduced chemical weapons and aerial bombing. It brought women into the work force and hastened their legal right to vote.

headline: They Don’t Make ’Em Like They Used To
abstract: Why has the quality of our houses and bridges declined so much?
lead_paragraph: ARROWSIC, Me. — TO reach our house in Maine, my wife and I drive hundreds of miles on highways, cross scores of bridges and even go through a tunnel or two. And as we come down the home stretch on a dirt lane full of rocks and ruts, I am reminded of how a piece of private real estate is a microcosm of our national infrastructure.

headline: As Pakistan Advances Against Taliban, Fleeing Civilians Pour Into Northern Towns
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States International Relations', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: Officials said that more than 500,000 refugees had arrived in Bannu, Waziristan, by Thursday morning.
lead_paragraph: BANNU, Pakistan — Pakistan stepped up its drive against the Taliban in North Waziristan on Thursday with heavy strikes and a commando raid on Miram Shah, the district’s largest town, in what military officials described as the prelude to a major ground offensive.

headline: Songs and Scars From Father to Son
abstract: A father-son story is at the heart of Benjamin Scheuer’s one-man show, “The Lion,” from Manhattan Theater Club.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Scheuer, the writer and star of “The Lion,” has a pretty mane of blond hair and a wide, friendly smile that’s cuter than a dozen kitty videos. When he bounds onstage to open the show, guitar in hand and dressed in a natty suit with the tie slightly askew, he looks as if he’s just stepped off a fashion runway, or leapt to life from off an Abercrombie & Fitch shopping bag (albeit fully clothed).

headline: The Disturbing Anthrax Accident
keywords: ['ANTHRAX', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Epidemics', 'Medicine and Health', 'Editorials']
abstract: A slip-up at a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention laboratory, one of the best, carries a stark warning about the deadly risks of working with pathogens.
lead_paragraph: It is distressing that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is supposedly expert at handling extremely dangerous pathogens, was so sloppy this month that it potentially exposed more than 80 people at its laboratories in Atlanta to deadly anthrax spores. The incident carries a stark warning that even the best laboratories can slip up, with potentially catastrophic consequences should they be working, as some are, with germs that can spread a lot more readily than anthrax.

headline: Mangrove Menace
abstract: Friday fun with Peter A. Collins.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — This was the world’s easiest and most enjoyable Friday puzzle I can remember doing in quite a while until I got to the bottom half. That’s when things fell apart for me.

headline: BNP Paribas Expected to Plead Guilty and Pay $8.9 Billion Fine
abstract: New York has promised not to pull the bank’s license, but certain parts of its business will be suspended.
lead_paragraph: BNP Paribas is set to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty to state and federal authorities, according to people briefed on the case. The move would be the culmination of a widespread investigation into the French bank for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States.

headline: The Spiritual Recession
keywords: ['Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: We will dishonor American heritage if we remain indifferent to the triumphs and failures of the global democratic project.
lead_paragraph: For the past few centuries, the Western world has witnessed a contest of historic visions. On the one side was the dream of the beautiful collective. Human progress was a one-way march toward socialism. People would liberate themselves from religion, hierarchy and oppression. They would build a new kind of society where equality would be the rule, where rational planning would replace cruel competition.

headline: In the Shadows of Shrines, Shiite Forces Are Preparing to Fight ISIS
abstract: Security officials in Iraq’s Shiite holy twin cities, Karbala and Najaf, scoff at the extremist Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, saying their defense forces are ready to meet the threat.
lead_paragraph: KARBALA, Iraq — A dozen miles outside this shrine city, on the edges of the uninhabitable western Iraqi desert, a group of paramilitary policemen provides the only visible line of defense against the extremist Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

headline: Parts Supplier Delphi Is Scrutinized in G.M. Recall
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Automobiles', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Roads and Traffic']

headline: A Unanimous Supreme Court: A Blow to Presidential Appointments
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Constitution (US)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Editorials']
abstract: The court’s ruling restricting the use of recess nominations denies the partisan realities of Congress.
lead_paragraph: When one branch of government routinely abuses its constitutional power in order to prevent another from functioning, the Supreme Court is expected to take notice and stop the abuse. Unfortunately the court failed to do so on Thursday in an important balance-of-power case, raising the prospect that President Obama and his successors could have trouble making necessary appointments to executive posts as the nation’s politics become more sharply polarized.

keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Credit and Debt', 'Homeowner Affordability and Stability Plan', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']

Lew, the Treasury secretary, said on Thursday at a conference observing the fifth anniversary of Making Home Affordable, a suite of federal programs aimed at helping homeowners after the financial crisis.

abstract: In the Bronx’s Ghanaian community, the largest in the city, the usual drama of the World Cup was heightened by team-related controversies.
lead_paragraph: The faithful filed into a tiny back storeroom of the Malata African Market in the Bronx, making their way past the bins of giant yams and the freezer of dried fish, and took their seats in rickety rows.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Remote-Control Brace
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first wearable motorized device that helps people with spinal cord injuries to walk.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first wearable motorized device that helps people with spinal cord injuries to walk. The device, called ReWalk, consists of a fitted metal brace that supports the legs and parts of the upper body, and a motor that moves the hips, knees and ankles. Users can command it to stand up, sit or walk using a wireless remote control worn on the wrist, but they must be assisted by another person, the agency said.

lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — As the Mets took the field here Thursday, Bobby Abreu went to left field, Curtis Granderson to right and Juan Lagares to center.

headline: Knicks Draft Cleanthony Early of Wichita State

lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Draft night has not always been kind to the Knicks. Not that anyone needs reminding, but there have been missteps over the years, including the selections of projects. Renaldo Balkman, anyone?

lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed a Queens Library reform bill into law Thursday, a move intended to bring order to a system that has recently been under fire over its use of funds.

abstract: Although the state does not levy property taxes, the issue isn’t going away, and state lawmakers have the means to affect rates.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

lead_paragraph: During a special session of the Texas Legislature more than a year ago, a resolution calling for the impeachment of Wallace Hall, a University of Texas System regent, was filed in the House — and according to the leadership, it could have passed.

headline: At Border, Immediacy of a Crisis Supersedes Politics
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Volunteers and Community Service']

lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Tex. — The child whose dull eyes came alive when a shelter volunteer handed her a floppy-eared, pink bunny doll does not know she and her mother, who crossed the border with her, are in the middle of a political firestorm.

headline: John Tull, Lawyer Whose Illness Created a Bioterrorism Scare, Dies at 65
abstract: Mr. Tull’s diagnosis of bubonic plague during a visit from New Mexico caused alarm in New York, where the disease had not been seen in more than 100 years.
lead_paragraph: John Tull, a New Mexico lawyer who was found to have bubonic plague during a visit to New York in November 2002, prompting alarm that the infection might have been caused by bioterrorism, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 65.

headline: The Runway Is Clear
abstract: Charlie Evers owns a marina and seaplane base on the Bronx waterfront where Katharine Hepburn learned to fly and Jimmy Buffett has touched down.
lead_paragraph: If Willy Wonka ran a boatyard, it might be along the lines of Evers Marina and Seaplane Base, on the Bronx waterfront.

headline: Detroit Needs Residents, but Sends Some Packing
keywords: ['Foreclosures', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Population', 'Property Taxes', 'Poverty', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: In a city that needs to keep its residents, there is a virtual pipeline out, with more than one in 10 homes subject to foreclosure because of back property taxes.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Ronald Ford Jr. has watched neighbors move away and brick houses on his family’s block crumble to nothing, but he says he wants to stay put and give a chance to city leaders who now promise a renaissance. “I’d like to try to go with the new Detroit if that’s really coming,” Mr. Ford, 49, said, standing outside the house on the city’s east side that he describes as precious, “like a family heirloom.”

headline: Ask Well: Fatty Liver and Diet
abstract: A reader asks: My 22-year-old son has been diagnosed with fatty liver. What kinds of foods should be avoided in his diet?
lead_paragraph: Recently, in “Threat Grows From Liver Illness Tied to Obesity,” Anahad O’Connor described the growing epidemic of nonalcoholic fatty liver, an illness that affects at least one in five Americans, including many teenagers. Here he responds to reader questions about what to eat if you have fatty liver.

lead_paragraph: savor •\ˈsa-vər\• noun and verb

headline: For Young Offenders, a New Confidence Game
abstract: The Hocus Pocus Project, an outreach program at New York juvenile detention centers, is teaching magic to young offenders with the hope that it improves their behavior.
lead_paragraph: At the Crossroads Juvenile Center in Brownsville, Brooklyn, shrill buzzers announce the movement of sliding doors, and visitors leave all metal objects in lockers by the entrance. The residents are as young as 10 years old, awaiting trial on charges ranging from trespassing to murder.

headline: Kenya’s Future Clouds as Tensions Rise and Tourists Flee
abstract: Investors worldwide have flocked to Kenya’s debut Eurobond, even as terrorism damages the country’s tourism and hundreds of thousands remain jobless.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The line at the water tank in the Kibera slum is not as long as it used to be. It’s not because of a sudden advent of indoor plumbing. It’s because fewer people can afford a 10-cent jerrycan of water.

headline: Niki Acosta: Camp Boss Covers All the Bases
abstract: When 200 or so young New Yorkers converge in Battery Park City on June 30 for the first day of a camp run by Asphalt Green, there is one thing they will not have in common with the manager Ms. Acosta: She never went to camp as a child.
lead_paragraph: When 200 or so young New Yorkers converge in Battery Park City on June 30 for the first day of a camp run by Asphalt Green, there is one thing they will not have in common with the manager Niki Acosta: She never went to camp as a child. “I went to Y.M.C.A. programs, but it was only weekly, or sporadically,” Ms. Acosta, 28, said the other day in her office, where she was immersed in preparations. Now in her second year at the nonprofit’s downtown outpost (there is also a 5.5-acre campus on the Upper East Side), she said, she has been “gearing up for the first day of camp since September of last year.” Ms. Acosta lives in one half of a two-family house in Woodside, Queens, with a poodle named Otis.

headline: What’s on Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Starz) BLUE JASMINE (2013) Cate Blanchett, above, won an Oscar for her role as Jasmine French, a Park Avenue matron fallen on hard times after her husband, Hal (Alec Baldwin), lands in prison for bilking his clients out of millions — leaving her with little more than her pearls, white Chanel jacket, Hermès bag and monogrammed Louis Vuitton luggage. Destitute, in a manner of speaking, Jasmine flies first-class to San Francisco to begin life anew with her sister, Ginger (Sally Hawkins), whose scrappy existence and brutish men (Andrew Dice Clay and Bobby Cannavale) Jasmine can barely stomach without self-medicating with vodka and Xanax. Then she meets a diplomatic type (Peter Sarsgaard) with an appreciation for her decorating talents and designer threads, and starts to see light at the end of her terribly dark tunnel. With intimations of Ruth Madoff and Blanche DuBois, this shattered woman is “brilliantly brought to quivering life by Ms. Blanchett,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, in Woody Allen’s “most sustained, satisfying and resonant film since ‘Match Point.’ ” What did Jasmine know about her husband’s unscrupulous business dealings, and when did she know it? “These questions come to haunt ‘Blue Jasmine,’ and as the past catches up with the present, they help drive this moving, sometimes funny film toward its shattering end,” Ms. Dargis added.

headline: N.H.L. Draft Prospect Is Familiar With Pressure
abstract: Aaron Ekblad, an 18-year-old defenseman in the Ontario Hockey League, is ranked by some as the No. 2 prospect in this weekend’s N.H.L. draft.
lead_paragraph: Considered by many as the most N.H.L.-ready prospect in this weekend’s draft, Aaron Ekblad is no stranger to playing under immense pressure.

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 27, 2014.

headline: Shia LaBeouf Arrested for Disorderly Conduct at Studio 54
abstract: The actor Shia LaBeouf was removed from New York’s Studio 54 during a performance of “Cabaret,” for being disorderly during the performance, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The actor Shia LaBeouf was removed from the Studio 54 theater in Midtown on Thursday and arrested after disrupting a performance of the musical “Cabaret.”

headline: People’s Daily Takes Firm Stance Against Urine Consumption
abstract: The Communist Party newspaper said the practice, which has received a recent burst of publicity, has no medical value.
lead_paragraph: If imbibing urine is not your cup of tea, People’s Daily — the solemn voice of the Chinese Communist Party — is with you on that one. On Friday, the newspaper took time off from its usual encomiums to party leaders to warn people against drinking their own pee.

headline: First if No Longer Foremost
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: One book introduces readers to some of the signature trials and towering jurists of the Federal District Court in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: It is called the nation’s Mother Court because it was created even before the United States Supreme Court, in 1789, when New York City was the nation’s capital. (In truth, though, the court for what became the Southern District of New York was first only because the opening of the federal court in New Jersey was delayed after a jurist became indisposed.) In “The Mother Court: Tales of Cases That Mattered in America’s Greatest Trial Court” (American Bar Association Publishing), James D. Zirin, a trial lawyer and former federal prosecutor, engagingly introduces readers to some of the signature trials and towering jurists of the Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: The Taco Truck Stops Here
abstract: In Sunset Park at Fifth Avenue and 37th Street, there’s almost always a huddle around the Tacos El Bronco truck, a quilted-stainless-steel mobile kitchen that is parked from lunchtime until near dawn.
lead_paragraph: The sidewalks of Sunset Park are rarely empty. Most mornings, elderly Chinese women gather on a grassy hillside in the Brooklyn neighborhood to do calisthenics to pop tunes. In the evenings, Latino kids race up and down the sloping blocks. And even in a humid drizzle, at least two dozen people lounge against a chain-link fence across from the Jackie Gleason Bus Depot at Fifth Avenue and 37th Street, waiting for tacos.

headline: An Icon of Indian Roads Is Set Out to Pasture
abstract: In the final stage of a long decline, Hindustan Motors announced in May that it would suspend production of the Ambassador, a car that was once synonymous with style and status.
lead_paragraph: “When the Ambassador car was born in 1957 to a newly independent India, it was the height of style and status,” Nida Najar wrote in The New York Times. “It was standard issue to senior civil servants and government officials; its possession implied status, and its ubiquity was a sign of an earlier, seemingly simpler India.”

headline: Student Crossword | Africa

headline: Lawsuit Adds to Concern Over China Commodities Fraud
abstract: A coal producer in China has filed a lawsuit to reclaim $170 million, naming among the defendants the Chinese company at the center of an investigation into aluminum and copper financing fraud.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s commodities fraud scandal continues to widen, with more companies reporting losses on bogus aluminum and copper financing deals, while Chinese authorities now say gold contracts have also been faked to secure more than $15 billion in loans.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | U.S. Moves On With Assist From Portugal
abstract: How far do you think the United States will advance in the World Cup? Do you think the Americans have a shot at winning the whole thing? Who do you think will win the 2014 World Cup?
lead_paragraph: In “U.S. Moves On With Assist From Portugal,” Sam Borden writes about the results of Thursday’s United States-Germany World Cup game.

headline: UniCredit’s Online Unit Raises at Least $916 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: FinecoBank priced its offering of 181.9 million shares at 3.70 euros a share, on the low end of its expected range. The pricing values the company at €2.24 billion, or about $3.05 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — FinecoBank, an online banking and brokerage arm of the Italian lender UniCredit, said on Friday that it had raised at least 673 million euros, or about $916 million, in its initial public offering in Italy.

headline: U.S. Lays Groundwork to Reduce Land Mines and Join Global Treaty
keywords: ['Mines, Explosive', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Washington announced that the military would no longer produce or acquire antipersonnel land mines, or replace old ones that expire.
lead_paragraph: After five years of study, the Obama administration put the United States on a course Friday to eventually sign the global treaty that bans antipersonnel land mines, announcing steps that will gradually reduce the American stockpile and find ways to adjust for any military disadvantage in purging the weapons.

headline: What the Camera Sees, and Doesn’t See
abstract: A life-changing illness led Kim Weston to return to her roots, both in art and family, exploring the ties between relatives and the past.
lead_paragraph: The photograph from January 2013 is ethereal: a close-up of goldfish swimming in an aquarium. The water that sustains them is ominously cloudy. Yet, they survive.

headline: Defying Russia, Ukraine Signs E.U. Trade Pact
abstract: Moscow warned that the signing of the economic agreement, which had set off protests and fighting in Ukraine, would have “serious consequences.”
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Dealing a defiant blow to the Kremlin, President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine signed a long-delayed trade pact with Europe on Friday that Moscow had bitterly opposed. He then declared he would like his country to one day become a full member of the European Union.

headline: New York Today: Pick Your Pool
abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: time to swim, a sunny weekend, and a misbehaving actor.
lead_paragraph: Good morning to you on this summer-break Friday.

headline: In Taiwan, Chinese Official Confronted With Voices of Democracy
abstract: Demonstrators haven’t been alone in advocating democracy during a trip to Taiwan by Zhang Zhijun, the mainland’s highest-ranking official to visit the island. Some local leaders have also been raising the issue.
lead_paragraph: Zhang Zhijun, the highest-ranking Chinese official to visit Taiwan, has said he wanted to hear the voices of its people during his four-day trip to the self-governed island. Demonstrators in Taiwan have tried to meet that request, following him since the start of his visit on Wednesday. And while the official meetings have been less confrontational, with talk of increasing trade and travel across the Taiwan Strait, some local leaders have also talked up Taiwan’s democratic values, a sharp contrast with Communist-ruled China, which considers Taiwan as part of its territory.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: A Minimum Wage That Makes More Sense
abstract: Accounting for regional price differences is sound strategy when setting state or local minimum wages.
lead_paragraph: Travel around this country a bit and, assuming your purchases are not confined to airports and big hotel chains, you will find that prices vary a great deal. Prices in New York State are 15 percent above the national average, while those in Arkansas are 12 percent below average. Housing is about twice as costly in Massachusetts as in Mississippi.

headline: Daily Report: Effort by Facebook to Safeguard Data From the Law Fails, For Now
abstract: The New York district attorney’s office demanded account details of 381 people for an investigation that led to indictments on Social Security fraud charges.
lead_paragraph: Facebook and the Manhattan district attorney’s office are in a bitter fight over the government’s demand for the contents of hundreds of Facebook accounts, Vindu Goel and James C. McKinley Jr. report.

headline: The Agriculture Secretary Sees a Smart (Phone) Solution to GMO Labeling Fight
abstract: Can smart phones and scannable label codes offer clarity on GMOs in food? The secretary of agriculture thinks so.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been at the Aspen Ideas Festival, which has focused this week on next steps for healthy living, including better food choices.

headline: New Signs That China Is Scrutinizing Foreign NGOs
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Philanthropy', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A notice that briefly appeared on a local government website describes a “penetrating” security review of foreign nongovernmental organizations in China.
lead_paragraph: An image being passed around the social media site Weibo — posted by the Chinese newsmagazine Phoenix Weekly, among others — shows several men straining to hoist a flag atop rubble, a reference to the iconic World War II image of American troops hoisting the United States flag at Iwo Jima.

headline: Sorry, Harry Reid: Koch Industries Probably Pays a Lot of Corporate Tax
abstract: The company has generally refused to disclose its corporate structure.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, the economist Austan Goolsbee said something he would come to regret: On a White House conference call, in his capacity as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, he named Koch Industries as an example of a large company that does not pay corporate income tax because of the way it is organized.
