abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: A Photographer Hunting for Light
abstract: On Our Walls takes readers inside the building to see the news images that decorate the walls of The Times.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue, the walls are decorated with news images from the past. In this series we’ll take you inside the building to see the photographs — many of them rich in history — and the stories behind them.

headline: In Class Action Against Apple and Others, Concerns From the Judge
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Four prominent Silicon Valley companies — Apple, Google, Intel and Adobe — are offering $324 million to get rid of a case that says they conspired in secret no-poaching deals to keep their engineers. The judge isn’t convinced the deal is fair.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley, at least according to myth, is all about risking everything on an idea. You seize a dream and do not let it go until you make it or they come and repossess your desk. Failure in the valley is admired. It makes you smarter, tougher, more likely to succeed next time.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 3 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
abstract: Our Summer Reading Contest is in its third week. To participate, just write in below by 7 a.m. Eastern on July 4 and answer the question, “What interested you most in The Times this week?”
lead_paragraph: In the news this week: Supreme Court rulings on abortion protests, cellphone searches and more.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on buffer zones, recess appointments, a response to the Iraq crisis, the Common Core, and the food industry.
lead_paragraph: “In the world as Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia imagines it, anti-abortion advocates resemble Eleanor McCullen, a self-described ‘mother and grandmother’ who stands outside a reproductive-health clinic in Boston and attempts to gently ‘counsel’ approaching women out of getting an abortion,” writes The New York Times Editorial Board, in response to the Court’s decision to strike down a Massachusetts law that established buffer zones around abortion clinics. The editorial says the ruling “ignores what actually happens on the ground,” including “a long and sometimes violent history of protest at reproductive-health clinics.”

headline: Report Underscores Lingering Doubts in Search for Missing Plane
abstract: As Australia prepares a new search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet, a report notes that it could have fallen in an area up to 19 times as large as the new search zone.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — As Australia prepares a yearlong search for the jet carrying Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 in an area of ocean floor the size of Croatia or West Virginia, a government report underscores the lingering uncertainty about where the plane went down, noting that it might have fallen in an area of the southern Indian Ocean up to 19 times as large as the new search area.

headline: Why Is the World Silent?
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: We worked for good in Morsi’s Egypt. Must we be “disappeared” by the military?
lead_paragraph: TORA, Egypt — In a few days’ time, I will complete 365 days of imprisonment, more than half spent in solitary confinement and under severe limitations in the maximum-security Scorpion wing of Tora prison in Cairo. I have spent the past year thinking about what drove me to where I am today. I have also been thinking about an explanation for why politicians, human rights activists and the media have largely been silent about my case.

headline: China’s Anticorruption Campaign Unseats a Powerful Party Chief in Guangzhou
abstract: The abrupt downfall of Wan Qingliang stands out from many other recent graft investigations because Mr. Wan still held a position of considerable power.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Communist Party chief of Guangzhou, one of China’s most populous and wealthiest cities, has been held for investigation by the party’s anticorruption agency, state-run media announced on Friday, one day after he admonished city officials to embrace President Xi Jinping’s campaign against lax discipline.

headline: Morning Agenda: $8.9 Billion Penalty for BNP
abstract: BNP Paribas is set to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty. | Brokerage firms shunned Barclays’ trading pool on Thursday. | The federal government is auctioning off nearly 30,000 Bitcoins. | Argentina appeared to defy a judge’s order on debt payments.
lead_paragraph: BNP TO PLEAD GUILTY AND PAY $8.9 BILLION FINE  |  BNP Paribas is set to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty to state and federal authorities, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. The move would be the culmination of a widespread investigation into the French bank for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States. The plea deal, which authorities hope to announce on Monday, will include a statement of facts that outlines how BNP, France’s largest bank, hid the names of Sudanese clients when processing transactions through its American operations.

headline: Oh You Silly Thing, of Course He’s Gay
abstract: “Vicious,” a British series soon to be broadcast on PBS, follows two partners in a gay relationship of nearly 50 years.
lead_paragraph: As he descends a staircase in the opening scene of “Vicious,” a new comedy making its PBS debut on Sunday, Ian McKellen overhears his lover, played by Derek Jacobi, reacting to bad news he received on the telephone.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: All They’re Missing Is a Black Market Etsy
abstract: Demand is up, and so is supply at Litchfield.
lead_paragraph: Season 2, Episode 7 The world is too much with our friends at Litchfield as their various commercial enterprises kick into high gear. And this episode, “Comic Sans,” brings the mounting sense that all this getting and spending will not end well.

headline: How Islamic Fundamentalists Will Rule Mosul
abstract: For evidence of how the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria will impose radical Shariah law in Iraq, just look at eastern Syria, where the group is dominant.
lead_paragraph: From the way they have run Raqqa city and parts of eastern Syria, we can make an educated guess as to how jihadis from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) will govern Mosul. Women probably won’t be able to go out on their own. Coke and other Western products will likely be banned. Suspected thieves may well be detained and might risk amputation, execution or public flogging. As the group sweeps through Iraq in a surprise advance that’s left everyone from Assad to Obama wondering how to halt it, Mosul’s residents just need to look next door for evidence of the extremist group’s notoriously harsh governing tactics.

headline: While You Were Watching World Cup 2014
abstract: Nobody was watching the skies.
lead_paragraph: Nobody was watching the skies.

headline: Today in Small Business: How Much Cash Can I Take Out?
abstract: The difference between high-performers and workaholics. Keeping personal and business finances separate. And the shunning of malls.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Among Gay C.E.O.s, the Pressure to Conform
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Books and Literature', 'Corporations']
abstract: John Browne, the former chief of BP, resigned in 2007 after published revelations about a gay lover. Seven years later, there are no publicly gay chief executives at any Fortune 500 company.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, John Browne, Lord Browne of Madingley, resigned as chief executive of the British oil giant BP after being outed as gay by the tabloid The Mail on Sunday: “The True story about Lord Browne — by ex-rent boy lover.”

headline: Milan Fashion Week Crowd Honors Dorchester Boycott
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Shariah (Islamic Law)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Boycotts', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: In reaction to the Sultan of Brunei’s new Shariah penal code, few fashion guests were seen at his Principe di Savoia hotel.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — It was nearing midnight. On television screens in the bar of the Principe, on the last day of the men’s wear shows here, a World Cup match was playing. Unusually for this venue, every kick and call could be heard. Roughly half the tables were filled with couples or groups drinking quietly, and at the overstaffed bar, at least five servers waited to fill orders.

headline: Chinese Workers at Iraq Power Plant Said to be Headed to Safety
abstract: More than 1,000 Chinese workers at a power plant north of Baghdad were evacuated to the capital city after previous attempts to move them to safety had failed, reports say.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,000 Chinese workers at a power plant north of Baghdad were being evacuated to the capital city after previous attempts to move them to safety had failed, associates of the workers and Chinese state media said on Friday.

headline: Reliving Childhood Excursions
abstract: The makers of the movie “Earth to Echo” drew inspiration from 1980s movies including “E. T.” and “Stand by Me.”
lead_paragraph: For children of the 1980s, there was no shortage of opportunities to see kids like themselves being heroes, while also being kids, on the big screen. Movies like “E. T.” and “Stand by Me” were hallmarks, placing young people in extraordinary situations and giving them room to explore new worlds just a bike ride away. They showed boys and girls on adventures of their own making, with their parents often on the sidelines. If the new science-fiction film “Earth to Echo,” due in theaters on Wednesday, bears a resemblance to these ’80s movies, it’s because the men behind it were raised on them.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Junya Watanabe Spring/Summer 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: After 25 Years, Modest Gains at Mumbai Breast Milk Bank
abstract: Newborns whose mothers are unable to breastfeed are given stored breast milk to protect them from potentially life-threatening infection.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — On a recent afternoon, 27-year-old Ashwini Agarwal adjusted her sari as she emerged from the crowded outpatient department at the Lokmanya Tilak Hospital, a public facility that houses the oldest of India’s roughly 14 breast milk banks, established a quarter of a century ago.

headline: An Education of the Heart: The Glenwood Towers Senior Center Prom
abstract: Eighth graders, and the senior citizens they’ve been visiting all year, come together for an unexpectedly joyous celebration.
lead_paragraph: “Can I have this dance?” a woman in a strapless black sundress said, offering her hand to my son. It was 93 degrees out on the patio at the senior center in downtown Raleigh, N.C. Aidan, dressed in his only suit and a striped tie, said, “of course.” I heard Esther counting the steps for him as she guided him into a waltz. One-two-three. One-two-three.

headline: Russia Abruptly Cancels Rocket Launch
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin demanded an explanation for the decision to abandon the long-awaited inaugural mission of the Angara rocket.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The long-awaited inaugural launch of a new Russian space rocket, the Angara, was abruptly canceled on Friday just minutes before takeoff, the Russian space agency Roscosmos reported.

headline: Shiite Cleric in Iraq Urges Quick Decision on New Government
abstract: A spokesman for Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani also called for Iraq to remain united, even as a Kurdish leader claimed more territory.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s top Shiite cleric on Friday urged the country’s divided political factions to select a prime minister by early next week in a public call for a political solution that increases the pressure on the embattled prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

headline: In Our Pages: June 28
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The Salvation Army had a fight with the police in 1889; Malawi set its independence date in 1964.
lead_paragraph: 1889: Salvation Army Versus Police

headline: She’s No One’s Idea of a Grandma
abstract: Susan Sarandon, who plays a wayward grandmother in the new comedy “Tammy,” is also preparing for the arrival of her first grandchild.
lead_paragraph: Susan Sarandon was mildly disappointed that she wouldn’t make the trek to Burning Man this summer. She attended that free-spirited Nevada desert festival for the first time last year, and said she felt safely inconspicuous since “there’s a lot of girls walking around with amazing bodies and no clothes on, so you’re not that interesting.” She even thought about bringing some of Timothy Leary’s ashes with her on a return visit.

headline: Lawyers Defend Hong Kong Rule of Law in Show of Unity Against Beijing
abstract: Hundreds of lawyers marched in Hong Kong to demonstrate their concern that a recent policy paper issued by Beijing poses a threat to the rule of law in the city.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of lawyers, many clad in black, marched in Hong Kong on Friday to demonstrate their concern that a recent policy paper issued by Beijing poses a threat to the rule of law in the city.

headline: A New Search Zone for Malaysian Jet
abstract: Officials expanded the hunt for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 into an area farther south. An investigation concluded that the plane was likely on autopilot before it vanished.
lead_paragraph: Officials expanded the hunt for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 into an area farther south. An investigation concluded that the plane was likely on autopilot before it vanished.

headline: Is The Times Ignoring a Scandal at the I.R.S.?
abstract: Some readers complain that The Times was slow to respond to a recent development.
lead_paragraph: Has The Times been interested enough in the politically charged events involving the Internal Revenue Service?

headline: What’s News in Washington: Obama Returns, Powers Diminished
abstract: President Obama returns to the White House from his “day in the life” trip to Minnesota with his executive powers slightly diminished following the Supreme Court’s decision to curb the ability of presidents to make recess appointments.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning from Washington.

headline: A Nudge to Save a Bit More
abstract: Some financial firms are providing online tools to help customers see what their peers are saving for retirement, in the hope of stepping up their game.
lead_paragraph: If you’re an active participant in social media, it’s nearly impossible to avoid a running tally of everyone else’s spending. New cars and home renovations are all over Facebook. Vacation photos, exotic meals and charity benefits are a fixture on Instagram.

headline: The Art Crowd Returns to Kent, England
abstract: The seaside towns of the Isle of Thanet once attracted the likes of Dickens and Turner. After a long downturn, artists are returning.
lead_paragraph: The Isle of Thanet, a thumb of land protruding from the Kent Coast in England, has always been a draw for creative types. T. S. Eliot wrote there, referencing “Margate Sands” in “The Waste Land”; Broadstairs was a favored getaway of Charles Dickens; and the 19th-century painter J. M. W. Turner supposedly said “the skies over Thanet are the loveliest in all Europe” — a sentiment no doubt shared by many of the artists who are again coming to the area.

headline: Not So Fast on the Use of Google Glass in Britain
abstract: In a blog post, Andrew Paterson, a senior British technology regulator, said that Glass users were free to use the headset for personal use, but that restrictions would apply for businesses.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – For tech-savvy Britons, the debut in this country of Google’s Glass headset on Monday was greeted with much fanfare.

headline: Q. & A. | Fashion Designer Duro Olowu on Curating His Second Art Show
abstract: The British designer talks with T about moving between creating collections and assembling exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: “Do you think it’s a bad idea to put this on the floor?” asked the fashion designer Duro Olowu yesterday as one of his assistants positioned a bulbous ceramic vessel near the entrance of the Salon 94 Bowery gallery. As he directed art handlers and gallery assistants to arrange a hodgepodge of sculptures, textiles and framed artworks into dense vignettes in preparation for his second gallery show as curator, “More Material,” which opens to the public today, Olowu seemed as hands-on as he would designing a dress in his studio.

headline: A World Cup of the Americas Ends Upbeat First Phase
abstract: Global soccer has taken some well-earned flak in recent years, but this edition of the game's showcase event has been a golden ticket to compelling action.
lead_paragraph: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil — The opening phase of this World Cup ended with Algerians celebrating, and they were hardly the only ones feeling upbeat after a first round to remember.

headline: A Fashionable Role for Julian Assange?
abstract: Ben Westwood, son of Vivienne, says he has asked the Wikileaks founder to model his debut men’s wear collection.
lead_paragraph: No, this is not a joke. Ben Westwood, the 51-year-old son of that agent provocateur Dame Vivienne Westwood, on Friday proved himself heir to his mother’s crusading mantle by announcing he was planning to have Julian Assange, the Wikileaks founder, model in his debut fashion show in London this September.

headline: Presenting ‘Play-Doh’
abstract: The artist Jeff Koons unveils his new sculpture “Play-Doh” in a retrospective at the Whitney Museum. The piece took 20 years to complete.
lead_paragraph: The artist Jeff Koons unveils his new sculpture “Play-Doh” in a retrospective at the Whitney Museum. The piece took 20 years to complete.

headline: In Paris, the Bastille Neighborhood Recaptures Its Cool
abstract: Once cool then neglected, the Bastille area is now home to some of France’s most famous restaurateurs, chefs and designers.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen years ago, Bastille was the emerging cool neighborhood of Paris. Then, as the masses discovered the south side of the 11th Arrondissement, the inevitable backlash occurred. The city’s self-appointed tastemakers declared the area fini and decamped for points north and west. Bastille descended into a haven of grungy student bars, low-end creperies and charmless fast-food outlets. Over the last year, however, some of France’s most famous restaurateurs, chefs and designers have planted their flags in the neighborhood where the famous prison once stood. Style-savvy upstarts have done likewise, further elevating the area’s profile for epicures and night owls. Little by little, a new crowd is storming Bastille.

headline: At the Month-Mark, Modi Reflects
abstract: The newly elected prime minister reaches out to the public in a blog post about his first 30 days in office.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On Thursday, as the government headed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi completed 30 days in office, Mr. Modi, with a perceptible confidence in his political persona, reached out to the public through a blog post.

headline: Sleep as a Competitive Advantage
abstract: Too many of us live by the myth that one less hour of sleep gives us one more hour of productivity, Tony Schwartz writes in the Life@Work column. In reality, lost sleep not only leaves us more fatigued, but also takes a toll on our cognitive capacity.
lead_paragraph: At 6 p.m. last Friday, I boarded a plane for Bangalore, India. At 1 p.m. Tuesday, I arrived back in New York after two days of meetings and traveling 34 hours across nine time zones. As you can imagine, I didn’t see much of Bangalore.

headline: R.B.S. to Spend $1.7 Billion on Mobile Banking Growth
abstract: The bank said it planned to add nearly 100 automated teller machines and transform its branches to centers for financial advice and education. It will also upgrade its mobile platforms.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Royal Bank of Scotland is making a major bet that consumers in the future will do most of their banking on mobile phones or tablets.

headline: After Buffer Zone Ruling, Abortion Rivals Prepare to Square Off Anew
abstract: Both sides are planning their next steps after the Supreme Court ruled anti-abortion activists cannot be barred from approaching clinic entrances and visitors.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Lorraine Loewen, 74, says she comes here once a week to demonstrate against abortion outside of the Planned Parenthood League of Massachusetts health care center.

headline: The Perils of Anaerobic Driving
abstract: Plus: Gazprom vs. the prom; fireworks displays, ranked.
lead_paragraph: Plus: Gazprom vs. the prom; fireworks displays, ranked.

headline: The Real Hedwigs
abstract: Burlesque boys around the world.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway success of “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” suggests that gender-bending male performance has moved closer to the American mainstream, but it has also been flourishing in clubs around the world. The photographer Magnus Arrevad spent close to five years in several countries, documenting men applying makeup, dressing in elaborate costumes and performing. One of them, Eric Gorsuch, who goes by Mr. Gorgeous, says he has witnessed the transformation of the art form in real time. “I’m superlucky in that I feel like, even looking five years ago till now, so many people today are aware of and acknowledge different kinds of sexuality — gay, straight, bisexual, whatever,” he says. “When society becomes a little more aware of other people’s lifestyles, it allows people to make decisions artistically. For me, if it was 10 years ago, I don’t think I would feel as confident being a male performer doing a parody of a stocking peel in high heels.” Julie Bosman

headline: How to Solve an 88-Year-Old Literary Mystery
keywords: ['Research', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Revisiting a snowy night in 1926 that changed the life of E.E. Cummings.
lead_paragraph: As Edward and Rebecca Cummings passed the town of Center Ossipee, N.H., in their new 1926 Franklin sedan, it began to snow. They left their home in Cambridge, Mass., hours before, driving a car with high seats, no defroster and a top speed of about 50. Rebecca took over the driving for the last part of the trip to their summer place at Silver Lake.

headline: Reply All: The 6.15.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: THE NEXT FRONT IN THE TERRORISM FIGHT

headline: Looking for the Russia I Once Knew
abstract: Two decades later, the country was still inside me. But all around me, it had changed.
lead_paragraph: On my last night in Petrozavodsk, in the last months of the Soviet Union, I stood in an unlit back alley buying boots off a soldier from the nearby army base. They were knee-high, and black, and illegal. It was midnight. I was 14. For about a month, I’d lived with a host family as part of a student exchange. In a week, leaving the country, I would wait, sweating, at Sheremetyevo airport while security rummaged through random suitcases, hoping they wouldn’t choose mine. Soviet Army surplus is ubiquitous now, but in 1991, you had to buy it on the black market and smuggle it out. If you got caught, I figured, you probably stayed in Moscow while the rest of your exchange group flew home.

headline: Who Made That Slip ’N Slide?
abstract: An improvement over belly-flopping onto wet concrete.
lead_paragraph: Long before Apple and Amazon were founded in humble garages, another quintessentially if decidedly lower-tech American success story began the same way — only the garage was used as a human launching pad.

headline: Carl Hart: ‘Crack Wasn’t the Real Problem’
keywords: ['Addiction (Psychology)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The professor debunks the myths behind the “war on drugs.”
lead_paragraph: The Columbia professor talks to Amy Chozick about what the public, politicians and even Public Enemy don't get about drug addiction.

headline: Is It Wrong to ‘Spoil’ World Cup Results?
keywords: ['Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Soccer', 'World Cup 2014 (Soccer)', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The ethics of discussing games in real time.
lead_paragraph: A friend of mine is a soccer fan, but instead of checking scores and highlights of the World Cup while he’s at work, he records every game to watch later on — usually in the evening, sometimes the next day. He gets annoyed when friends “ruin” the outcome of a game before he has had the chance to see it in full; he acts as if we’ve just spoiled the conclusion of “Breaking Bad.” Do I have an ethical obligation not to discuss the outcome of games in my friend’s company until he has caught up? J. S., COLUMBUS, OHIO

headline: The Brave New World of Three-Parent I.V.F.
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Babies and Infants', 'Genetic Engineering', 'In Vitro Fertilization', 'Infertility', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Science and Technology', 'Mitochondria']
abstract: A new treatment could sidestep certain hereditary diseases by altering the genetic makeup of the egg. Is there anything wrong with that?
lead_paragraph: In August 1996, at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J., a 39-year-old mechanical engineer from Pittsburgh named Maureen Ott became pregnant. Ott had been trying for almost seven years to conceive a child through in vitro fertilization. Unwilling to give up, she submitted to an experimental procedure in which doctors extracted her eggs, slid a needle through their shiny coat and injected not only her husband’s sperm but also a small amount of cytoplasm from another woman’s egg. When the embryo was implanted in Ott’s womb, she became the first woman on record to be successfully impregnated using this procedure, which some say is the root of an exciting medical advance and others say is the beginning of the end of the human species.

headline: Image of the Day: June 27
abstract: A memorial ceremony at the Imphal War Cemetery in Manipur to honor the soldiers who died during World War II.

headline: Weekend Auto Calendar: Goodwood Is Addicted to Winning
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Racing', 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Nascar Sprint Cup Series']
abstract: The Goodwood Festival of Speed features Formula One racers; Nascar to hold races at Kentucky Speedway.
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: Reform Conservatism on Work and Poverty
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Poverty', 'Recession and Depression', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A response to Thomas Edsall’s critique of the welfare system’s rightward shift.
lead_paragraph: Turning back to this week’s official theme, reform conservatism’s liberal critics, I want to discuss a recent column from my colleague Thomas Edsall that, without mentioning our quasi-movement by name, raises one of the sharpest objections to our program of any left-of-center piece I’ve seen. Where reform conservatives tend to argue for a welfare system and tax code organized more explicitly around work and family, Edsall’s piece makes the case that we’ve already tried something like that approach — have been trying it, in fact, since the early 1990s — and that it has worked out pretty badly, failing completely at its stated work-promoting aims while making life increasingly desperate for the very poor.

headline: U.S. Catfish Program Could Stymie Pacific Trade Pact, 10 Nations Say
abstract: Ten Asian and Pacific nations have complained that the Agriculture Department’s catfish inspection program, which was added to the 2008 farm bill, violates international law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ten Asian and Pacific nations have told the Office of the United States Trade Representative that the Agriculture Department’s catfish inspection program violates international law, and their objections could hamper Obama administration efforts to reach a major Pacific trade agreement by the end of next year.

headline: Mary Rodgers, Author and Composer in a Musical Family, Dies at 83
abstract: Ms. Rodgers, born into American musical theater royalty, composed the music for “Once Upon a Mattress” and wrote the novel “Freaky Friday.”
lead_paragraph: Mary Rodgers, who wrote songs and children’s books and, by virtue of genetics and serendipity as well as talent, lived at the red-hot center of American musical theater, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83.

headline: Shares of Michaels, Arts and Crafts Retailer, Are Flat on Debut
abstract: The arts and crafts retailer raised about $472 million in its initial public offering.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:41 p.m. |

headline: Five Guys and a Mean-Looking Dude
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A group of middle schoolers ordering food in Brooklyn, and coming up short, learned that generosity sometimes comes with a surly face.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Kris Van Assch: Spring 2015 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Letters: Carter’s Woman Question
abstract: Readers react to recent reviews of “The Redeemer” and “Call to Action,” Boris Fishman’s “A Replacement Life” and more.
lead_paragraph: Carter’s Woman Question

headline: Starting From Scratch
abstract: John Banville is one of several authors to write mystery novels under a pseudonym in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Robert Galbraith’s “The Silkworm” is reviewed this week, and with all due respect to Galbraith, the extent of his success may be due entirely to J. K. Rowling. The mystery is the second written by the Harry Potter creator under the pseudo­nym. “I was yearning to go back to the beginning of a writing career in this new genre, to work without hype or expectation and to receive totally unvarnished feedback,” she wrote on her website last year after being unmasked. Oh, well.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: FORTY-ONE FALSE STARTS: Essays on Artists and Writers,  by Janet Malcolm. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.) Whether she’s observing artists and writers present (David Salle, Thomas Struth) or past (Edith Wharton, the Bloomsbury group), what resonates most here is Malcolm’s cool intelligence and psychoanalytic knack for noticing. The title essay, a 1994 profile of Salle, starts over 41 times, parodying Salle’s own violent juxtaposition of images.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: SONG OF THE SHANK,  by Jeffery Renard Allen. (Graywolf, paper, $18.) Allen’s masterly novel blends the personal story of the enslaved autistic piano prodigy Thomas Wiggins with the history of the Civil War and Reconstruction.

headline: Filmmakers
abstract: New books by Mark Harris, Donna Kornhaber, Noah Isenberg and Steven Awalt.
lead_paragraph: FIVE CAME BACK  A Story of Hollywood and the Second World War  By Mark Harris  Penguin Press, $29.95.

headline: Ghost of the Confederacy
abstract: Michael Korda searches for the human being behind our conception of Robert E. Lee.
lead_paragraph: Robert E. Lee occupies a remarkable place in the pantheon of American history, combining in the minds of many, Michael Korda writes in this admiring and briskly written biography, “a strange combination of martyr, secular saint, Southern gentleman and perfect warrior.” Indeed, Korda aptly adds, “It is hard to think of any other general who had fought against his own country being so completely reintegrated into national life.”

headline: The Awakening
abstract: Megan Abbott’s novel centers on teenage desire and the outbreak of a mysterious illness.
lead_paragraph: Le Roy, N.Y., a former factory town ­between Rochester and Buffalo, became famous three years ago when 14 girls and one boy were afflicted with undiagnosed verbal and physical tics. Cheerleaders writhing and snarling on the “Today” show: It’s not hard to understand why Megan Abbott, a reliable producer of noir page turners, based her seventh novel, “The Fever,” on the Le Roy outbreak. In real life, the underpinnings of the ­teenagers’ outbursts turned out to be psychological. But in “The Fever,” Abbott attributes the epidemic to a curious brand of black magic.

headline: Marooned
abstract: In Mark Billingham’s “The Bones Beneath,” Inspector Tom Thorne is part of a group stranded on an island off the coast of Wales with two murderers.
lead_paragraph: To quote a line that’s sure to make hearts flutter: “We’re almost completely cut off here.” In THE BONES BENEATH (Atlantic Monthly, $25), “we” is a party composed of Mark Billingham’s supersleuth, Inspector Tom Thorne; a skeleton staff of police officers and crime scene investigators; and two murderers. “Here” is a mountainous island off the coast of Wales, said to be the resting place of 20,000 saints. And being “cut off” from civilization is fair warning that the characters in this thriller are likely to revert to savagery.

headline: Fed’s Balance Sheet Punctuated by a Big Question Mark
abstract: The central bank’s balance sheet has ballooned to nearly $4.3 trillion in assets, and how the Fed decides to handle it will have significant consequences, William D. Cohan writes in the Street Scene column.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of the Federal Reserve’s creative but controversial quantitative easing program — the five-year plan of buying billions of dollars in debt securities each month and forcing down interest rates to historically low levels — the central bank’s balance sheet has ballooned to nearly $4.3 trillion in assets from $800 billion, leaving one large unanswered question hanging over the marketplace: What does the Fed intend to do with all those bonds?

headline: Photographers on the Front Lines of the Great War
abstract: A century after the start of World War I, the trail blazed – and lessons learned – by pioneering photojournalists on the front lines still resonate..
lead_paragraph: A century after the start of World War I, the trail blazed – and lessons learned – by pioneering photojournalists on the front lines still resonate..

headline: Nixon and Pelé: No Meeting of the Minds
abstract: Richard Nixon and Pelé had a quick and awkward meeting in 1973. Nixon had something else on his mind: Watergate.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, May 8, 1973, at midday, Richard Nixon received the soccer star Pelé, member of the Brazilian team that won the World Cup championship of 1970. (In 1999, the International Olympic Committee voted Pelé “Athlete of the Century.” He is now 73 and retired.)

headline: Art Matters | The Gallery Queen of Palm Beach Takes L.A.
abstract: Sarah Gavlak — the premier gallery in the elite Florida winter retreat — heads west with a new space on Highland Avenue in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Most art dealers have opened their happy-go-lucky summer shows and are gearing up to close for the dog days come August. Last night, however, Sarah Gavlak — whose Gavlak Gallery in Palm Beach has survived many a balmy winter as the only game in town — opened a new space in Los Angeles. And this time, Gavlak has plenty of competition in her new backyard. The L.A. gallery occupies a former manufacturing plant on Highland Avenue below Santa Monica Boulevard — just a couple of storefronts up from Hannah Hoffman gallery, around the corner from Regen Projects, and just a block or so down from Kohn Gallery’s roomy new digs that opened just last month.

headline: Bargains With a ‘But’
abstract: New York’s income-restricted co-ops, though still relatively inexpensive, often require large down payments.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom on the Upper West Side listed for $875,000 has been languishing since December. A $385,000 two-bedroom in Manhattan Valley has been available for six months. And a studio in Chelsea with a $299,000 price tag only recently went into contract after nearly a year and $60,000 in price cuts.

headline: Dov Charney, Vying to Regain Control of American Apparel, Seeks to Increase His Stake
abstract: A regulatory filing revealed that Dov Charney had partnered with an investment firm to buy shares in American Apparel.
lead_paragraph: The pressure is mounting at American Apparel, the retailer of American-made clothing that fired its founder, Dov Charney, last week.

headline: Gunslingers
abstract: A novel about the unsavory but fascinating friends Wyatt Earp and Doc Holliday.
lead_paragraph: Wonderful title. Head-scratcher of a novel.

headline: L’Étranger
abstract: Andrew Hussey discusses France’s colonial legacy in North Africa and the violence it has spurred at home.
lead_paragraph: “How long can we keep on kidding these people?” George Orwell asked in 1939 after a walk through Marrakesh’s vast squalor in French-ruled Morocco. Orwell, who himself had earlier been a colonial British official in Burma, went on: “How long before they turn their guns in the other direction?”

headline: Fortune’s Daughter
abstract: Meryl Gordon recounts the life of Huguette Clark, who went from Jazz Age socialite to hospital-bound recluse.
lead_paragraph: At the end, she loved watching SpongeBob and the Smurfs, bidding (by proxy) on antique French dolls and writing enormous checks to her nurse, sometimes two in one day. When she died in 2011 at 104, Huguette Clark was flush with property — apartments totaling 42 rooms on Fifth Avenue, a 23-acre estate in Santa Barbara and a 22-room mansion in New Canaan, Conn., that she had never bothered to ­furnish. (In 1961, her Santa Barbara caretaker quit because he was suffering from the isolation: Clark had reportedly not visited the place since 1953.) Yet despite such splendid real estate, Clark had chosen to spend the final two decades of her life in a series of modest hospital rooms attended by a small circle of extremely well-paid retainers, including her doctor, her nurse, her accountant and her lawyer.

headline: These Ages of Shoddy
abstract: Are we building worse than we used to?
lead_paragraph: Henry Petroski, an engineer who’s also a fine writer, has a lament about the decline of good construction in today’s Times. It’s a great read; I’m trying to figure out whether I believe in his premise.

headline: Neighborhood Watch
abstract: A series of fires in a New England town exposes tensions between summer and year-round residents.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of the night, a jet-lagged woman, unable to sleep, goes for a walk along a country road in the New England town where her family has summered for generations. Frankie Rowley, newly returned from years of relief work in Africa, is certainly lost in the middle of her life’s journey, and in a dark night, if not precisely in a dark wood. Unsure of her place in the world, unsure whether she has a place in the world, Frankie has come to Pomeroy, N.H., for a life-reassessment disguised as a visit to her parents, who have decided to live full time in their summer house following her father’s retirement from teaching. It’s only after a car passes Frankie on the road, its headlights sweeping past in a disorienting arc, that she realizes the smell of smoke has been in the air for some time.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: J. K. Rowling, whose “Silkworm” (written as Robert Galbraith) is No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list, has found herself caught up in a couple of recent controversies.
lead_paragraph: Inner Bloke: Back in 2006, when J. K. Rowling was at work on her seventh and final Harry Potter novel, an unnamed publishing insider told The Daily Express in Britain that “she will soon be in a position where she doesn’t have to write if she doesn’t want to, and if she does, she can write whatever she chooses.” Here’s the update, eight years and three non-Potter books later: Rowling wants to write. But she could do without the distractions of fame; that’s why she adopted the pseudonym Robert Galbraith for her Cormoran Strike crime series, also projected to last seven volumes. (“The Silkworm,” the second entry in the series, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 2, while its predecessor, “The Cuckoo’s Calling,” is No. 8 on the trade paperback list.) “When I ‘unmasked’ myself to my editor,” Rowling says on the official Robert Galbraith website, “one of the first things he said was ‘I never would have thought a woman wrote that.’ Apparently I had successfully channeled my inner bloke!”

headline: Li Na Ousted at Wimbledon; Novak Djokovic Advances
abstract: After her loss on Friday to Barbora Zahlavova Strycova, Li Na has now twice been one of the fastest top players to the exits in the last two Grand Slam events.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — After leading out of the gates at the beginning of the year, Li Na has now twice become one of the fastest top players to the exits at the last two Grand Slam events.

headline: Between Innings
abstract: A nonlinear look at 150 years of baseball history, with an eye to the social, cultural and political forces behind the game.
lead_paragraph: The sport of deciphering baseball — of finding embedded within the history, structure, statistics and conventions of our national pastime some secret cultural code that might cast light on our cryptic national character — was born in 1954. Seven years earlier, Jackie Robinson had signed with the Brooklyn Dodgers to break the sport’s color line, finally giving baseball the conditio sine qua non for any democratic claims it might make. Two years before that, American servicemen in Europe had celebrated Germany’s surrender by gleefully retrofitting the Nuremberg stadium into a ballpark, holding regular games where Hitler had recently rallied the Nazis.

headline: As Bad as It Gets
abstract: With Wrigley Field celebrating its centennial, George F. Will takes a deeply personal look at his hapless Chicago Cubs.
lead_paragraph: Between 1921 and 1970, the Chicago Bears won eight N.F.L. championships as tenants of Wrigley Field. The Yankees and Tigers have clinched the World Series there, but the Cubs, who have played in the park since 1916, never have. In fact, they haven’t won a World Series since 1908, a stretch of futility longer than that of any other North American sports franchise. What’s the problem?

headline: As Iraq Smolders, The Times Fortifies Its Baghdad Bureau
abstract: A pared-down bureau coalesces into a journalism team as Iraq becomes an intense story again.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD – Three weeks ago, the Times bureau consisted of two rooms in the BBC house in central Baghdad. The nonresident bureau chief, Tim Arango, had moved to Istanbul, though he had been back many times in the past year as the storm clouds gathered, and the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria grew ever stronger.

headline: Moving In, Slowly, to ‘Billionaires’ Row’
keywords: ['Luxury Goods and Services', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: At One57, more than two dozen owners have gotten the keys to their units. But many are in no rush.
lead_paragraph: As soon as Linda Phillips and her husband heard about One57, a luxury 90-story skyscraper that is nearing completion on West 57th Street, they raced from the pied-à-terre they rented at the Time Warner Center across Columbus Circle to take a look.

headline: Saudi King Promises Help in Delicate Effort to Unite Factions in Iraq
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry enlisted the support of the monarch, as well as a Syrian opposition leader, for a multi-sect government.
lead_paragraph: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia assured American officials on Friday that he would use his influence with Sunni leaders in Iraq to try to speed the formation of a multisect government there, a senior State Department official said.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
abstract: Is the little-known Export-Import Bank under Congressional scrutiny because of crony capitalism?
lead_paragraph: For a government agency that’s flown under the radar for most of its 80-year history, the Export-Import Bank of the United States is getting a lot of attention recently: It’s now at the center of a fight in Congress over the role of government in business. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar look at why the Export-Import Bank is under such scrutiny, and what it means for business in general.

headline: 50 Ways to Love Your Quinoa
abstract: I continue to find new uses for quinoa, which keeps well in the refrigerator after it’s cooked and adds protein and textures to these easy salads, including some inspired by the ideas of the vegetarian cookbook author Deborah Madison.
lead_paragraph: You’d think I would eventually run out of ideas for quinoa. I’ve posted over 50 recipes on this page over the years. But ideas keep coming and I keep loving this grain (O.K., Paleos, I know, it’s a seed, not a grain. But we use it on the plate like a grain, so that’s what I’ll continue to call it.)

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The French Intifada’
abstract: This week, Andrew Hussey talks about “The French Intifada”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the week’s literary news; Alice Goffman discusses “On the Run”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Andrew Hussey talks about “The French Intifada”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the week’s literary news; Alice Goffman discusses “On the Run”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Ukraine Signs European Union Trade Deal
abstract: President Petro O. Poroshenko spoke at the signing ceremony of the trade deal between Ukraine and the European Union in Brussels.
lead_paragraph: President Petro O. Poroshenko spoke at the signing ceremony of the trade deal between Ukraine and the European Union in Brussels.

headline: When Negativity Is What We Need
abstract: A new study finds that people with low self-esteem prefer validation of their negative feelings to more upbeat reassurance. Some, writes ANNA NORTH, say it’s further proof that positive thinking doesn’t work.
lead_paragraph: If your friend is feeling bad about himself, you might try to convince him that everything’s actually O.K. But a new study suggests this kind of reassurance doesn’t necessarily make people with low self-esteem feel better, and some say it’s further evidence against the idea that positive thinking heals all wounds.

headline: Mysterious Art: An Installation Inspired by the Bermuda Triangle
abstract: The work “Triangle” is a work featured in the Bermuda Biennial.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago the Bermuda Triangle entered international pop-culture consciousness with a cover article in the pulp magazine Argosy describing a treacherous patch of sea that seemed to swallow up aircraft and ships with alarming and mysterious frequency.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Driven | 2015 Subaru Legacy 2.5i
abstract: All-wheel drive and invisibility come standard.
lead_paragraph: All-wheel drive and invisibility come standard.

headline: New York Parish Fears Losing Daily Dose of ‘Spiritus Sancti’
abstract: The Church of the Holy Innocents, the only New York City church that offers the Latin Mass daily, is among churches that might be closed.
lead_paragraph: As the Rev. Justin Wylie took the pulpit at the Church of the Holy Innocents in Manhattan last month, anger and anxiety emanated from the pews. The church is the only one in New York City to offer a daily traditional Latin Mass, but an archdiocesan panel had recommended that it be closed.

headline: Defending Devotees of the Latin Mass in New York
abstract: The remarks of Rev. Justin Wylie, a visiting priest from South Africa, who defended the traditionalist parishioners of Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Innocents on West 37th Street in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: At the end of his sermon on May 18, the Rev. Justin Wylie, a visiting priest from South Africa, defended the traditionalist parishioners of Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Innocents on West 37th Street in Manhattan. He told them that even if the Archdiocese of New York follows through with a recent recommendation to close their church, they should still insist that the archdiocese provide devotees of the Latin Mass with a spiritual home.

headline: After a Dismal Quarter, a Rosy Outlook
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Consumer Confidence (Economic Indicator)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: For the first time since January 2008, more people believe business is good than believe it is bad, even though data says the economy contracted by 2.9 percent last quarter.
lead_paragraph: THROUGHOUT the economic recovery since the Great Recession officially ended in the summer of 2009, consumers have generally remained doubtful that the economy really has gotten better. Now, as they finally conclude that the business climate has improved, a hitherto perfect recession indicator has sounded a warning.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Snowpiercer’
abstract: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “Snowpiercer.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “Snowpiercer.”

headline: Photographers on the Front Lines of the Great War
abstract: A century after the start of the First World War, the trail blazed – and lessons learned – by pioneering photojournalists on the front lines still resonate.
lead_paragraph: A century after the start of the First World War, the trail blazed – and lessons learned – by pioneering photojournalists on the front lines still resonate.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Begin Again’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Begin Again.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Begin Again.”

headline: What Happened to the Facebook Phone? Not Very Much, It Seems
abstract: It is a rare product misstep for Facebook. Its Home software was supposed to turn an Android smartphone into a Facebook phone. But it never caught on with users.
lead_paragraph: Facebook has long wanted to be a major part of how you use your smartphone. Now, it looks as if the company has all but abandoned one of its major strategies to do so.

headline: Video: The 2015 Subaru Legacy Feels Better Than It Looks
abstract: The 2015 Legacy has a winning formula with its capable all-wheel drive and fuel-efficient powertrain, but its looks may leave some feeling uninspired.
lead_paragraph: It’s better to look good than to feel good, or so said Billy Crystal channeling Fernando Lamas. Why choose? These days, you can have it all in the midsize sedan segment. The current Fusion, Optima, Mazda 6 and Chrysler 200 all look mah-velous. More important, sales numbers reflect their fashion-forward confidence.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Transformers 4’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Transformers: Age of Extinction.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Transformers: Age of Extinction.”

headline: Days of Imperial Pleasures and Regrets
abstract: It was “Old Filth” that brought the English author Jane Gardam to the attention of most of the Americans who know her writing.
lead_paragraph: SANDWICH, England — Jane Gardam’s most famous novel, “Old Filth,” begins with stage directions and elliptical dialogue, which it’s tempting to imitate in describing Ms. Gardam, a writer who unites literary critics in puzzlement over why she isn’t more famous.

headline: Where Old Curiosity Shops Abounded
abstract: Fifty years ago, East 57th Street was a refuge for peculiar little buildings and odd businesses like the Todhunter shop.
lead_paragraph: Just when did we let 57th Street slip out of our hands? I mean the fashionable address that had room for the funny little shop, the offbeat bookstore, the aged brownstone, the fragment of a mansion? It is hard to put a finger on any particular new development that crossed the line, but one disappearance sums up for me the long-lost magic of the street.

headline: Military Multipliers of Death
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Submarines and Submersibles', 'Military Aircraft', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: In World War I, technical advances in warfare on land, sea and even the air put deadly new tools in the hands of millions, and death and destruction resulted on a scale without precedent.
lead_paragraph: In World War I, technical advances in warfare on land, sea and even the air put deadly new tools in the hands of millions, and death and destruction resulted on a scale without precedent.

headline: Broken Windows, Broken Parks
abstract: While neighbors are pushing to improve the quality of their lives by calling attention to misbehavior and littering in public parks, police enforcement doesn’t seem to be a priority.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago in an interview with The New York Times, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton signaled his distaste for subway showmen, suggesting that their music-fueled cartwheeling was not just a disruption of mass-transit reading habits but, rather, symbolized a sort of latent urban menace. Two decades after he last ran the country’s largest police force, broken-windows policing, the practice of combating minor offenses in an effort to deter more serious ones, hasn’t lost its fascination for Mr. Bratton.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s ‘Hard Choices’ Blocked in China
abstract: The American publisher of Mrs. Clinton’s new memoir said its accounts of discussions with Chinese officials were too politically sensitive for the censors.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The new memoir of Hillary Rodham Clinton, “Hard Choices,” which gives blow-by-blow accounts of tough discussions with Chinese officials, particularly on human rights, has been blocked in China, according to the American publisher.

headline: A Show House With Lots to Show
abstract: The event, which benefits the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, features living spaces from 18 designers.
lead_paragraph: Starting on Sunday, Holiday House Hamptons will showcase indoor and outdoor living spaces created by 18 interior and landscape designers, each honoring a holiday of its creator’s choosing and often of the designer’s invention. Presented by Hamptons Cottages & Gardens magazine, the event benefits the Breast Cancer Research Foundation.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘The French Intifada’
abstract: Andrew Hussey discusses “The French Intifada,” and Alice Goffman talks about “On the Run.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Mitchell Cohen reviews Andrew Hussey’s “The French Intifada: The Long War Between France and Its Arabs.” Mr. Cohen writes:

headline: What to Look for in the ‘Penny Dreadful’ Finale on Sunday
abstract: Will the monster brewing inside Vannessa finally show up?
lead_paragraph: With just one episode left, the witching hour may finally be upon us.

headline: Martin Indyk, U.S. Mideast Envoy, Steps Down
abstract: Mr. Indyk led the yearlong American effort to revive Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations, the negotiations faltered.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department said Friday that Martin S. Indyk, who led the yearlong American effort to revive Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations, was resigning from his position as special envoy.

headline: Allergan, Maker of Botox, Acquiesces to Special Shareholder Meeting
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: An agreement with Pershing Square Capital Management makes it clear that the calling of a special meeting will not activate Allergan’s poison pill.
lead_paragraph: Allergan, the maker of Botox, and Pershing Square Capital Management have struck an agreement that will allow for the calling of a special meeting of Allergan shareholders, the latest development in the slow-moving $53 billion takeover effort by Pershing Square and Valeant Pharmaceuticals.

headline: ‘Smart Beta’ Investing Lets the Yardstick Pick the Stocks
abstract: A passive investment approach that relies on criteria like volatility or dividends has attracted investor money but also its share of critics.
lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to investing money, most people want to be smart about it. So an increasingly popular strategy with smart in its name has intrigued certain investors, while turning off others who see it as little more than a marketing gimmick.

headline: My-House-Is-Your-House Rules
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: For every owner who writes a hyper-specific set of instructions, there’s another whose inability to answer his phone or email becomes a major plot point of your vacation.
lead_paragraph: Painted seashells, a lurid conch, a Pierrot-themed weather vane, a giant starfish waving an American flag, two raffia chickens with googley eyes, an ambitious amount of tern art: If you had to categorize the contents of the beach house I rented that summer under one artistic school, you’d probably go with Alcoholic Gift Shop.

headline: The Times Critics’ Guide to the ‘Transformers’ Movies
abstract: How did Times movie critics review the rest of the series? Amusingly.
lead_paragraph: With “Transformers: Age of Extinction” opening Friday, viewers may be wondering what critics for The New York Times had to say about the previous installments in this enduring saga of flying robot battles. Wonder no more. If you want the current review, it is here.

headline: Yes, if You Cut Taxes, You Get Less Tax Revenue
keywords: ['Small Business', 'Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: In 2012, Kansas passed a big and unusual tax cut in the name of small business. But now the state is grappling with a shortage in tax revenue that is straining its budget.
lead_paragraph: Kansas has a problem. In April and May, the state planned to collect $651 million from personal income tax. But instead, it received only $369 million.

headline: Cameron’s Protests Rebuffed as European Commission Leader Is Chosen
abstract: Despite bitter opposition from Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, European Union leaders voted to appouint Jean-Claude Juncker as the next president of the bloc.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Despite bitter opposition from Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, European Union leaders voted on Friday to name Jean-Claude Juncker as the next president of the bloc’s powerful bureaucracy, bringing an end to a struggle that had pitted some of the group’s top leaders against each other.

headline: Argentina’s Bond Payment Is Rebuffed by U.S. Judge
abstract: Argentina deposited $539 million with the Bank of New York Mellon for the purpose of paying its main class of bondholders.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:35 p.m. | A federal judge on Friday delivered a stern warning to Argentina after the country deposited $539 million with the Bank of New York Mellon for the purpose of paying its main class of bondholders.

headline: The Times’s Coverage Related to Patrick Lavin
abstract: From the 19th century.
lead_paragraph: From the 19th century.

headline: Historical Documents Related to Patrick Lavin
abstract: Testimony from the manslaughter indictment of Patrick Lavin and the coroner’s report on the killing of Casper Pfost, as well as Patrick Lavin’s retirement certificate.
lead_paragraph: Testimony from the manslaughter indictment of Patrick Lavin and the coroner’s report on the killing of Casper Pfost, as well as Patrick Lavin’s retirement certificate.

headline: A Copper, a Dust-Up and Death
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Archives and Records', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: After Terrence Lavin discovered a long-hidden family secret — that his great-great-grandfather had been charged with killing a man — he went on a search for the victim’s descendants.
lead_paragraph: I found it after reading through the indictment, consulting archival maps and applying the measurements where the original tenements once stood, in Chelsea. Now, on an innocuous patch of crab grass between the corner of a red brick building and a concrete walkway winding through the Chelsea-Elliott housing complex, I was standing on the spot where, 125 years ago, my great-great-grandfather killed a man.

headline: 2 Carmakers to Share a Plant in Mexico
abstract: Daimler and Renault-Nissan will expand their collaboration by investing in and sharing a plant that will produce models for both companies.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Daimler and Renault-Nissan significantly expanded their automaking alliance on Friday, saying they would jointly build a production plant in Mexico to build a new generation of compact Mercedes and Infiniti cars.

headline: Looking to Cars, Trucks Step Up Safety
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Trucks and Trucking']
abstract: Measures, like collision-avoidance systems, could play more of a role in preventing accidents caused by distractions and driver fatigue.
lead_paragraph: Large trucks may be involved in fewer crashes than passenger vehicles, but their size almost guarantees that the consequences of those collisions will be severe.

headline: Letter to Obama Administration About Guantanamo Uruguay Deal
abstract: Lawyers for six Guantanamo detainees who were offered resettlement by Uruguay earlier this year sent this letter to top Obama administration officials on June 26. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel has not acted on the deal.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for six Guantanamo detainees who were offered resettlement by Uruguay earlier this year sent this letter to top Obama administration officials on June 26. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel has not acted on the deal.

headline: Seeking Divine Intervention, or at Least Some Lucky Shorts
abstract: Whether by wearing the same shorts during a winning streak or trusting in a talisman, fervent soccer fans in Brazil often believe match results are in their control.
lead_paragraph: SALVADOR, Brazil — There is a saying in this coastal city of mixed religious heritages and creeds that goes more or less like this: If superstition decided soccer matches, all matches would end in a tie.

headline: Inventive Cocktails That Pack a Low-Proof Punch
abstract: These summer cocktail recipes err on the side of easy-to-drink and favor sake, wine and vermouth over the harder stuff.
lead_paragraph: For all the many virtues of a potent Manhattan, Martini or Sazerac, the all-spirit cocktail doesn’t lend itself well to, say, postwork happy hours or, for that matter, pleasant mornings-after. Happily for the congenitally thirsty, a new wave of complex and inventive low-proof cocktails is popping up, and they’re a far cry from that less-potent fallback drink, the white-wine spritzer. Coming on the heels of the relentless rise of the Aperol Spritz, these new, lighter drinks appeal as much to those with an aversion to strong liquors as they do to the heartiest of drinkers after one dirty martini too many. And as Dinah Sanders, author of “The Art of the Shim: Low-Alcohol Cocktails to Keep you Level,” says, “The more subtle ingredients these drinks often feature don’t overwhelm the palate, so they are generally more food-friendly.” Thanks to exotic sakes, a variety of vermouths, a growing range of bitters, flavorful teas, infused syrups, fresh herbs and wines of all colors and ranges of effervescence, the sky’s the limit in creating easier-to-drink concoctions, as evidenced in the following five recipes.

headline: Head of Dollar General to Retire
abstract: The announcement by Richard W. Dreiling, the chairman and chief executive of the discount retailer, comes as a smaller competitor, Family Dollar, is under pressure from the activist investor Carl C. Icahn.
lead_paragraph: Richard W. Dreiling, the chairman and chief executive of the discount retailer Dollar General, said on Friday that he was retiring. The move is effective May 30, 2015, or until the company names a successor.

headline: Eastern Garter Snake: The Well-Tempered Slitherer
abstract: The eastern garter snake generally has a mild disposition and is an auspicious addition to your garden.
lead_paragraph: It is not entirely surprising that children who find an eastern garter snake (Thamnophis sirtalis) excitedly tell their friends they found a “garden snake.” This innocuous New York City resident is as happy slithering through neighborhood parks or backyards as through wilder terrain.

headline: Voter-Fraud Claims and Activist’s Suicide Add to Turmoil in Mississippi
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Elections, Senate', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: The primary fight between Senator Thad Cochran and his Tea Party challenger descended into voter fraud accusations, and a tragic note was introduced when a Tea Party leader committed suicide.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The long and bitter Republican primary fight between Senator Thad Cochran and his Tea Party challenger descended into accusations of voter fraud on Friday, with the defeated candidate, State Senator Chris McDaniel, making clear he would not accept the results anytime soon.

headline: What to Do When Twitter Locks You Out
abstract: Plus, using Google Play gift cards for online purchases.
lead_paragraph: Opening a Locked Twitter Account

headline: Technology as a Path to Product Transparency
abstract: A look at online portals that can offer consumers a view of the labor and environmental conditions behind the products on store shelves.
lead_paragraph: After I posted yesterday on Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack’s push for using scannable codes to provide consumers with information on food ingredients from genetically modified crops, Ben Grossman-Cohen of the anti-poverty group Oxfam International sent a reaction that merits publication as a “Your Dot” contribution.

headline: An International Art Festival in the Azores
abstract: Walk & Talk, a public art festival on the Azorean island Sao Miguel, will feature international artists (and guided tours of past installations).
lead_paragraph: Sao Miguel, one of the nine Azorean islands that huddle in the Atlantic, has long attracted visitors with its pastoral setting dotted with cows, waterfalls and volcanoes. But Ponta Delgada, the capital, is transforming into a center for the avant-garde with Walk & Talk, an annual international public art festival.

headline: TUI of Germany Reaches Agreement to Acquire British TUI Travel
keywords: ['Cruises', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The deal, if consummated, would create the world’s largest integrated leisure travel business, worth 4.5 billion pounds, or about $7.7 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The German hotel and cruise ship operator TUI said on Friday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the British travel and leisure company TUI Travel, in which it is already a majority shareholder.

headline: Taking a Spin: An Odd Turn for Republicans
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: A head-scratching result in this week’s simulation of our election model: The Republicans take control of the Senate, but Mitch McConnell loses in Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: This week’s spin of Leo’s Senate wheels, our weekly demonstration of the uncertainty remaining before the election, offers head-scratching results.

headline: Lawmaker in Manhattan Pleads Guilty to 2 Felonies
abstract: Gabriela Rosa, a Democrat in her first term representing a district of Upper Manhattan, was forced to leave office for making false statements.
lead_paragraph: A New York assemblywoman in her first term became the latest state lawmaker to be forced out of office as she pleaded guilty on Friday to two felonies in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Barclays Investors Express Investment Bank Fears
abstract: The drop in the share price of Barclays after it was accused of favoring high-frequency traders over other investors in its dark pool reflects more general fears of investment banking, Dominic Elliott writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The market’s reaction to allegations that Barclays duped clients in its dark pool reflects more general fears of investment banking. Shares in the bank dropped as much as 9 percent on Thursday after the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, accused Barclays of misleading investors by playing down the number of “predatory” high-frequency traders on its private trading platform for equities. Barclays says it takes the allegations “very seriously.”

headline: Our Economic Growth Is a Mystery. Obamacare Is the Reason.
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Gross Domestic Product']
abstract: What is good for the country in the short run is at odds with what is good in the long run.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you decide to replace the engine of a car. You have two goals: To make the car go faster, you put in a more powerful engine, say eight cylinders rather than six. But you also want to make it more fuel efficient, so you add some sophisticated new technologies to cut back on its gas guzzling.

headline: San Francisco Noir
abstract: A search for a bygone genre, with Dashiell Hammett as guide, yields its own set of mysteries.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco is well known for its transformations, the most recent one fueled by tech money that has seemingly scrubbed much of the city clean. Evidence of it tends to be easy to mock: the $4 artisanal toast, the shuttle buses carrying workers from the city interior to Silicon Valley, the preponderance of reclaimed wood. But for almost a century, the city has been indelibly linked with an enigmatic genre that might be considered an antidote to all of that: noir.

headline: New Father? New C.E.O.? There’s a Boot Camp for You
abstract: Although many programs are in-person, boot camps are now so varied that some take place online or in books. But do they work?
lead_paragraph: IN the face of the yelling, B. J. Perlmutt hesitated, then took the plunge. After all, this was boot camp, and wasn’t the point to break you down and make you a man? He was sweating a little but competently finished the task.

headline: Five Stories of Luxury
abstract: A classic Greek Revival townhouse, with multiple outdoor spaces, on a tree-lined block in Greenwich Village is poised to enter the market.
lead_paragraph: A classic brick Greek Revival townhouse at 10 West 10th Street, one of the more idyllic of the tree-lined residential blocks in Greenwich Village, is poised to enter the market at $24.75 million.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Comme des Garçons Spring/Summer 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: Obama Chides G.O.P. for Blocking Economic Measures
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama portrayed congressional Republicans as cowed by activists who refuse any bipartisan compromise.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — President Obama rebuked congressional Republicans on Friday for opposing his economic initiatives, saying they should be held accountable for not doing enough for the middle class.

headline: Retirement Plans Thrown Into Disarray by a Divorce
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Retirement', 'Personal Finances', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Getting a divorce late in life can sabotage retirement plans as assets are cut in half and expenses as a divorced single rise.
lead_paragraph: AFTER enduring a divorce four years ago, Mike Miller’s vision for a golden retirement got an unexpected makeover. Mr. Miller had been married for more than 30 years, and now he was single. His longtime dream of a shared retirement was shattered. He was also facing another unwelcome outcome: living in a smaller home and taking fewer vacations.

headline: Transition Ahead for ‘The View,’ as Two Hosts Depart
abstract: Ms. Shepherd and Ms. McCarthy will end their runs on the talk show in August as part of a plan to help it evolve, ABC said.
lead_paragraph: The latest cast changes at ABC’s daily talk show “The View” may signal a more sweeping transition, as two hosts will depart by the end of the summer, and the new participants may include the show’s first permanent male host.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: Alice in Wonderland syndrome, a type of hospital unknown to most of the world and a study on the “cool” kids. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: Alice in Wonderland syndrome, a type of hospital unknown to most of the world and a study on the “cool” kids. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Shia LaBeouf Arraigned on Disorderly Conduct Charge
abstract: Shia LaBeouf is charged with disorderly conduct and criminal trespass after disrupting a performance of “Cabaret.”
lead_paragraph: The actor Shia LaBeouf was arraigned on Friday morning on charges of disorderly conduct and criminal trespass after an incident the previous evening at Studio 54, where he was removed after disrupting a performance of the musical “Cabaret.”

headline: Amid the Rap Music, Echoes of an Orchestra Playing in a Dark Past
abstract: Esther Bejarano, 89, who had to perform in the Auschwitz Girls’ Orchestra, joined the German duo Microphone Mafia five years ago to further her musical activism.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — AT various points during shows, the German rapper Kutlu Yurtseven gestures to a bandmate sitting demurely off to the side. That’s the cue for 89-year-old Esther Bejarano, a diminutive woman with a snow-white pixie cut, to jump in with a song. “When will the heavens open up, again, for me?” is one favorite, the refrain of a local carnival tune. “When will they open up?”

headline: John Boehner Deflects Attention by Suing the President
abstract: His lawsuit is utterly frivolous.
lead_paragraph: President Obama was generous on Thursday in referring to Speaker John Boehner’s proposed lawsuit against him as a “stunt,” a word generally used to mean a playful attempt to get attention. In fact, the suit is a mean-spirited attempt to deflect attention — specifically from the House’s refusal to engage in the act of governing.

headline: Big Ticket | A Grand Gothic Duplex for $16.5 Million
keywords: ['Luxury Goods and Services', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: An upper Fifth Avenue duplex, with 12 rooms and 5,400 square feet of space, is the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A 12-room duplex on upper Fifth Avenue, with a Gothic decorating theme but no Central Park views from its grand primary rooms, sold for $16.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The monthly maintenance is $11,048.

headline: AT&T Names Silver Lake Co-Founder to Its Board
abstract: Glenn Hutchins of Silver Lake, which has made a number of prominent investments in technology, will become a director of the telecommunications giant.
lead_paragraph: To fill an empty seat on its board, AT&T has turned to one of the country’s top investors in technology.

headline: Venus Williams Flashes Old Form at Wimbledon, but It Is Fleeting
abstract: Venus Williams’s three-set loss to Petra Kvitova represented her best opportunity to advance to the fourth round of a Grand Slam event in about three years.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — It has been six years since Venus Williams last won a Grand Slam singles championship, a title that came here at Wimbledon.

headline: Broth Spoils the Cooks
abstract: Little Sheep Mongolian Hot Pot, which opened in Edison last month, might be a novelty in New Jersey, but some consider it the Applebee’s of China.
lead_paragraph: It’s got hot caldrons, sour plum juice and sliced lotus roots and it seats up to 200 people. Little Sheep Mongolian Hot Pot, which opened in Edison last month, might be a novelty in New Jersey, but some consider it the Applebee’s of China.

headline: Comme des Garçons: Spring 2015 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Depression Economics and Climate Policy
abstract: This is the time we should be acting.
lead_paragraph: There’s been a bit of back and forth over “reform conservatism” — which is, depending on your point of view, either an important new trend or an attempt by reasonably sane conservatives to pretend that they aren’t part of an essentially insane movement. And climate change, where the current GOP orthodoxy essentially revolves around a crazy conspiracy theory, is the flash point.

headline: A Beverage for Brazil and the World Cup
abstract: Capturing the mood of the tournament with a drink that has Brazil’s national liquor as its base.

headline: Kanye: the Professor, Prada’s Revolutionary Runway and Fendi’s Latest Leather Accessory
abstract: Plus, Frank Gehry’s $136 Million design for Louis Vuitton, Lindsey Lohan’s latest episode and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: The Book Review’s ‘Killer’ Cover
abstract: The main challenge at Book Review this week was to have an illustrator create a cover image for a review of “The Silkworm” by Robert Galbraith (a.k.a. J.K. Rowling) with very little to go on.
lead_paragraph: There was no question that this week’s cover was going to be Harlan Coben on “The Silkworm” by Robert Galbraith (a.k.a. J.K. Rowling). This is Coben’s first review for us, and we’ve had our eye on him as a reviewer for years. And of course, like most media outlets, we missed the first Robert Galbraith novel, before J.K. Rowling was unmasked as the true author. We weren’t going to lose that opportunity again.When the review came in, it more than lived up to our expectations. Here was one of the masters of literary genre fiction writing on someone who is relatively new to the genre, though of course a gigantic success elsewhere in the book world. It was a strong and logical, yet also slightly unexpected match between book and reviewer.

headline: Two Stars With Intertwining Peaks
