abstract: Robert Fairchild and Tiler Peck, two principal dancers with the New York City Ballet, were married at the Chapel of the Good Shepherd in Chelsea on June 22.
lead_paragraph: Robert Fairchild and Tiler Peck, two principal dancers with the New York City Ballet, were married at the Chapel of the Good Shepherd in Chelsea on June 22.

headline: Soros Dabbles in Shareholder Activism
abstract: George Soros’s first foray into activism gives underperforming companies a reason to be nervous, Christopher Swann writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Is George Soros turning activist? His $29 billion hedge fund has famously confronted governments. But facing off with a $1 billion United States oil and gas company is novel. The move gives underperforming corporate bosses another scourge to fear.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: New Dylan Thomas Drinking Song Discovered
abstract: A song apparently written by Dylan Thomas in a London bar comes to light.
lead_paragraph: Just in time to comfort British World Cup fans still crying into their beer, a new drinking song by Dylan Thomas is to be published.

headline: Afghan Candidate and Thousands of Supporters Continue Protests
abstract: Tension seemed amplified in a second demonstration in support of Abdullah Abdullah, who has complained of widespread ballot fraud in the recent presidential election.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Thousands of supporters of the presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah poured into the streets of Kabul on Friday, blocking roads and clogging squares as they demanded that allegations of election fraud be addressed before ending the political crisis that has stratified Afghanistan for the last two weeks.

headline: More on How We Chose the Hardest Places to Live
abstract: Readers offered some lively discussion about our interactive map, raising questions and critiques that are worth addressing.
lead_paragraph: Our interactive map yesterday on the hardest places to live in the United States provoked, not surprisingly, some lively discussion in the comments section. Several of those comments raised thoughts that were worth addressing.

headline: Vatican Defrocks Ambassador in Abuse Inquiry
abstract: The former ambassador to the Dominican Republic is the first papal nuncio known to be removed from the priesthood because of accusations of child sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: The Vatican has defrocked its former ambassador to the Dominican Republic, an archbishop from Poland who was accused of sexually abusing boys while he served as the pope’s representative in the Caribbean nation.

headline: Eric Clapton Says He May Stop Touring
abstract: The rigors of travel – “It takes so long to get anywhere” – have Eric Clapton pondering an end to touring.
lead_paragraph: First Philip Roth quits writing books and giving readings. Now Eric Clapton quits touring?

headline: The Trauma of Parenthood
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Parenting', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Millions of new mothers — and fathers — show signs of clinical depression.
lead_paragraph: EVERYONE knows that being the parent of an infant is hard. There’s the sleeplessness, the screaming fits to tend to, the loss of autonomy, the social isolation and the sheer monotony of it.

headline: Death by Netflix?
abstract: Research shows binge-watching could be hazardous to your health. But, writes ANNA NORTH, Americans may already love it too much to stop.
lead_paragraph: Binge-watching has now joined a pantheon already occupied by fast food, alcohol, and sitting on couches: It is extremely popular, and in large amounts, it appears to be deadly.

headline: A Crush of Summer Flavors
keywords: ['Desserts', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Sorbet', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: Make your own light tasting and refreshing sorbet.
lead_paragraph: There are many kinds of frozen concoctions to help you navigate the summer heat.

headline: The Hardest Place to Live in America
abstract: What does concentrated rural misery look like? Like eastern Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: What does concentrated rural misery look like? Like eastern Kentucky.

headline: Givenchy: Spring 2015 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: And Sometimes They Dance
abstract: After a long off-and-on courtship, two principal dancers at the New York City Ballet exchange vows.
lead_paragraph: This is a boy-meets-girl-at-a-barre love story.

headline: Persecution Captured on Film
abstract: Three videos of how Burma’s muslim minority faces persecution when trying to get medical care or an education.
lead_paragraph: As readers of the blog may know, I’m the journalism student from the University of Notre Dame that accompanied Nicholas Kristof on his annual win-a-trip journey in Burma. While reporting on the ground, I captured a number of my experiences and interviews with members of the Rohingya Muslim minority on film. As always, reader comments and questions are welcome!

headline: Ford Introduces Side-Curtain Air Bags for 15-Passenger Vans
abstract: Although it’s nearly 15 feet long and 3 feet tall, the 11-gallon side impact air bag for Ford’s 15-passenger vans fills in a fraction of a second.
lead_paragraph: Ford announced Wednesday that it had developed its largest air bag for the 15-passenger Transit van.

headline: Pro-Abdullah Rallies Held in Kabul
abstract: Thousands of protesters in Kabul showed support for presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah’s allegations that mass fraud had been committed in Afghanistan’s presidential runoff.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of protesters in Kabul showed support for presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah’s allegations that mass fraud had been committed in Afghanistan’s presidential runoff.

headline: A Casual Stage Where Steak Is the Star
abstract: Union Republic in Jersey City hosts a butcher shop, a grocery area and artwork for sale, but the main attraction remains the restaurant’s food, guided by Gregory Torrech, the chef and co-owner.
lead_paragraph: Union Republic houses an expertly outfitted butcher shop, so it is not surprising that its porterhouse and rib-eye steaks, marbled but not gristly and sautéed so quickly that the caramelized exteriors spurt when punctured, are first-rate. Not to be outdone, its mushroom-studded risotto, taco with cubes of silky beef cheeks and even its vegan bowl of cauliflower, leeks and ramen noodles are also exemplary. They are reason enough to head to this latest outpost of innovative cooking in downtown Jersey City.

headline: Investors Who Bought Foreclosed Homes in Bulk Look to Sell
keywords: ['Foreclosures', 'Private Equity', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Rising home prices and a declining supply of inexpensive foreclosed houses have led some investment companies to lock in profits by unloading homes.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, buying foreclosed homes to rent out was the sure-thing trade for investment firms backed by money from private equity companies, hedge funds and pension systems. But with the supply of cheap foreclosed homes dwindling, some early investors are looking to cash out a bit by flipping homes to competitors.

headline: Weekend Reading: Advancing on Bank Penalties
abstract: With a guilty plea and fine expected for BNP Paribas, Wall Street’s attention now turns to two big civil investigations into the mortgage crisis.
lead_paragraph: Following DealBook’s report that BNP Paribas is expected to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion fine, Wall Street’s attention will soon turn to two civil investigations into the mortgage crisis.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': Playing to the Camera
abstract: With a photographer on the scene, John Lithgow finds rehearsal opposite Annette Bening to be more charged than he expected.
lead_paragraph: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: Coach Boldly Moves U.S. Forward
abstract: The decisions Coach Jurgen Klinsmann has made, and the way he has executed them, are a back story to the United States’ captivating run at the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — In late March, just before Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national men’s soccer team, went into the meeting in which he demoted Martin Vasquez, his longtime assistant, he asked a staff member with U.S. Soccer to knock on the door and interrupt after about five minutes.

headline: The U.S.-Germany Match Through a Social Media Lens
abstract: An analysis of the social media reaction to the United States-Germany soccer match details the hope, angst and relief experienced during the game.
lead_paragraph: The United States-Germany soccer match on Thursday was a roller coaster of emotions. And an analysis of the social media communications before, during and after the match shows the minute-by-minute shifts in sentiment and in subjects discussed, as the American team lost to Germany but moved on in the World Cup competition.

headline: How Records in Group Play Predict World Cup Success
abstract: Since 1986, when a version of the current tournament format began, no team has won the title without winning at least two of three group matches.
lead_paragraph: Teams’ performance in the World Cup’s group stage often says a lot about how they’ll fare in the knockout rounds. Since 1986, when a version of the current format began, no team has won the championship without winning at least two of three group matches. And six of the seven champions in that time did not lose any group-stage matches — going either 3-0-0 or finishing with two wins and a draw in the group stage.

headline: Hip-Hop From a Holocaust Survivor
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Music', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Concentration Camps', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Esther Bejarano, a survivor of the Auschwitz concentration camp, may be the last thing you’d expect in a hip-hop singer. She uses her music to spread a message against fascism.
lead_paragraph: Esther Bejarano, a survivor of the Auschwitz concentration camp, may be the last thing you’d expect in a hip-hop singer. She uses her music to spread a message against fascism.

headline: AT&T Sells Its Stake in Mexican Telecom América Móvil to Carlos Slim
abstract: The sale comes as AT&T prepares to acquire the satellite operator DirecTV.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:46 p.m. | AT&T said on Friday that it was selling its $5.6 billion stake in América Móvil, the Mexican telecommunications company, back to its majority shareholder, the billionaire Carlos Slim Helú. The sale comes as AT&T seeks to acquire the satellite television operator DirecTV in a $48.5 billion deal.

headline: Berluti: Spring 2015 Menswear
abstract: PARIS
lead_paragraph: PARIS

headline: Michael Arrington Drops Suit After Rape Accuser Recants
abstract: Last spring, Jennifer Allen began sharing a harrowing tale of rape and abuse at the hands of a former boyfriend — the tech investor and blogger, Michael Arrington. Now Ms. Allen has retracted those accusations in a settlement with Mr. Arrington, who agreed to drop a defamation lawsuit against her as a result.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, Jennifer Allen began sharing a harrowing tale of abuse she said she had received at the hands of a former boyfriend — Michael Arrington, the tech investor and blogger.

headline: Follow That Cab! Vintage Checkers Flock to Brooklyn
keywords: ['Antique and Classic Cars', 'Automobiles', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: The Checker cab returns to New York City, in a big yellow exhibition of more than 50 cars and those celebrated jump seats.
lead_paragraph: For a few hours, Box Street, a semi-industrial thoroughfare in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, seemed a whole lot like Kzoo.

headline: Revisiting a Checkered Past
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars']
abstract: The Checker cab, a New York City icon, was back on the streets of Brooklyn for a gathering of the Checker Car Club of America.
lead_paragraph: The Checker cab, a New York City icon, was back on the streets of Brooklyn for a gathering of the Checker Car Club of America.

headline: Confinement as a Kind of Freedom
abstract: Bernardo Bertolucci, in a wheelchair after back surgeries, returns with his first film in nearly a decade, “Me and You.”
lead_paragraph: The first voice you hear in “Me and You,” Bernardo Bertolucci’s first film in nearly a decade, is that of an unseen psychiatrist asking his patient, “Allora?” (“So?”) Then the point of view shifts and you see the doctor sitting in a wheelchair, rolling himself closer to his desk and his patient, a troubled 14-year-old boy who looks at the floor and answers, “Nothing.”

headline: A Ride Across America | In Kansas, A Man Cave Becomes a Thriving Family Farm
abstract: Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, is biking across the U.S. talking to people about food. In his fourth dispatch, he meets a Pittsburg, Kan. man who, after losing his job due to the recession, found success — and love — when he started his own vegetable business.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, they’ll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

headline: Making Everything Shipshape
abstract: Tacoma, Wash., Seattle and other West Coast ports are spending billions on upgrades to keep themselves competitive in the overall fight for foreign trade.
lead_paragraph: TACOMA, Wash. — As construction crews 5,000 miles away are working to widen the Panama Canal to allow much larger ships to sail straight to the East Coast, this historic port city and others along the West Coast are doing everything they can to avoid becoming superfluous.

headline: With Alstom Deal, G.E. Gains Bigger Foothold as Utility Supplier
abstract: By adding Alstom’s steam turbine factory in Belfort, France, and a gas turbine plant in Baden, Switzerland, G.E. will have the skill and scale to expand as electric utilities worldwide embrace gas-fueled power plants.
lead_paragraph: BELFORT, France – The Alstom and General Electric turbine factories in this French city near the Swiss and German borders sit just a stone’s throw apart. They are so close, in fact, that their employees share a cafeteria, and two-company families are not uncommon.

headline: Fighting for Movies With Pen and Thumb
abstract: “Life Itself,” a new documentary about Roger Ebert, remembers the famous film critic and interviews filmmakers whose work he wrote about.
lead_paragraph: “Life Itself,” the new documentary about Roger Ebert, examines many facets of the nation’s most famous film critic: his newsman background, his exhaustively chronicled battle with cancer that ended in his death last year, his drinking, his wit, his love for his wife, Chaz.

headline: This Time, the Cake Is Fully Baked
abstract: The redesigned Genesis looks much more distinctive inside and out, and it has the length and tailoring of a big European sedan.
lead_paragraph: When Hyundai dipped a toe in the luxury-car waters in 2009, it followed an underdog formula set by Toyota’s Lexus division two decades earlier: Mimic the established brands’ design, undercut them on price and overdeliver on features.

headline: “Is This Cold War II?”
abstract: What’s next for Russia, the United States, and Ukraine? A panel of former New York Times contributors debated the question this week.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday June 25, the New York Times and Chatham House convened a panel of former New York Times op-ed contributors in London to debate the future of the West’s relations with Russia in the wake of the Ukraine crisis. The panel included John Mearsheimer, a professor of political science at the University of Chicago and the author of “The Tragedy of Great Power Politics”; Chrystia Freeland, a former Financial Times editor and now a member of the Canadian Parliament; Michael McFaul, the former American ambassador to Russia and now a professor at Stanford University; and Dmitri Trenin, the director of the Carnegie Moscow Center. Roger Cohen, a columnist for The New York Times, moderated. Panelists debated whether the recent crisis was caused by Vladimir Putin’s zero-sum view of geopolitics, whether the Ukrainian people will have a say in the eventual outcome and whether Russia is really a rival to the United States. An edited transcript follows.

headline: 2015 Hyundai Genesis: Upgrading the Upgrade
abstract: An upward striver fulfills its potential with a splash of style and a new dash of spice.
lead_paragraph: An upward striver fulfills its potential with a splash of style and a new dash of spice.

headline: Fewer Breaks, but Belinda Bencic Makes the Most of Them
abstract: Belinda Bencic of Switzerland converted six of seven break points on Friday, beating Victoria Duval of the United States, who converted only four of her eight.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — All points in tennis are not worth the same. Some are critical to the final outcome. Others are simply building blocks to reach it.

headline: Digital Success Comes to Radio Broadcaster
abstract: Clear Channel has gained a significant audience with its streaming app, which works on smartphones and on some connected cars.
lead_paragraph: For years, radio stations have watched as online upstarts like Pandora and Spotify attracted a new generation of listeners. Now, one conventional broadcast network, Clear Channel Media and Entertainment, seems to be gaining a significant audience with its own streaming app.

headline: A Designer Transformed
abstract: Ed Welburn, the G.M. designer, has a small part in the new “Transformers” movie, where he gets to yell at Mark Wahlberg and get away with it.
lead_paragraph: The “Transformers” film franchise has locked the Chevrolet Camaro deep in the subconscious of millions of children who know it as Bumblebee, a robot that disguises itself as a sporty coupe.

headline: Transformers and the Summer Blockbuster
abstract: The numbers behind “Transformers: Age of Extinction”- expected to gross one billion dollars - and other summer blockbusters this year.
lead_paragraph: The numbers behind “Transformers: Age of Extinction”- expected to gross one billion dollars - and other summer blockbusters this year.

headline: Detroit’s Troubles: A Mosaic Says What Words Can’t
abstract: Today, an interactive graphic accompanied a front-page article about home foreclosures in Detroit. Two graphics editors explain how the project came about.
lead_paragraph: Today, an ambitious interactive graphic accompanied a front-page article by Monica Davey about the high rate of home foreclosures in Detroit. The graphic was presented as a mosaic of the more than 43,000 properties that were subject to foreclosure this year. Haeyoun Park, a graphics editor for the national desk, and Matthew Bloch, a graphics and multimedia editor, worked on the project and shared some details about how it came to be.

headline: Love With the Proper Dose of Disdain
abstract: “Vicious,” on PBS, stars Ian McKellen and Derek Jacobi as longtime lovers who share an apartment.
lead_paragraph: “Vicious” is not the most informative title. It sounds like a nasty little thriller on FX or Cinemax. As it turns out, it’s a British sitcom on PBS, but it’s nasty, all right. Where else on television are you going to see two superb classically trained actors calling each other a rotting corpse or a big bitch?

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.

headline: Hot Streets for Chilly Lawyers
abstract: “Reckless,” a crime melodrama set in Charleston, S.C., has a hint of depth in one plotline.
lead_paragraph: “Reckless,” a summer crime-lawyer-melodrama mishmash that begins on Sunday on CBS, is determined to be vacuous, even though, every so often, it hints that it could be more substantive if it wanted to be. That makes it maddening; you’d like to commit to it, but you know that more clichés and indifferent acting are right around the corner.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 27
abstract: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region includes a look at a Congressional primary race and a Central Park luncheon.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region includes a look at a Congressional primary race and a Central Park luncheon.

headline: 3 Freed in Central Park Jogger Case Thank Supporters
keywords: ['Central Park Jogger Case (1989)', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: At a news conference, three of the five men whose convictions were overturned praised Mayor Bill de Blasio for settling their lawsuit against New York City.
lead_paragraph: Three of the five men whose convictions were overturned in the 1989 beating and rape of a female jogger in Central Park appeared in front of City Hall on Friday, thanking their supporters and praising Mayor Bill de Blasio for agreeing to settle their longstanding lawsuit against the city.

headline: Pliés With an Elephant, And Other Tales for Men
abstract: The New Jersey company 10 Hairy Legs, devoted to the range of male dancing, is bringing area premieres to New York Live Arts.
lead_paragraph: It can’t be easy for a company called 10 Hairy Legs to live up to the playful audacity of its name. Randy James formed his New Jersey repertory troupe in 2012, intending to explore a range of male dancing. (Hence the hair.) That name turned out to be the most offbeat thing about the group, which performed five dances on Thursday, at the start of its run at New York Live Arts.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Saudi Arabia and Elsewhere
abstract: Saudi Arabia and More – Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia and More – Pictures of the Day

headline: Pictures of the Day: Saudi Arabia and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Saudi Arabia, Sudan, India and China.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Saudi Arabia, Sudan, India and China.

headline: Before Night Falls
abstract: In Arthur Nazaryan’s photographs of a hospice nurse and her patients, death shapes the scene by its absence, not its presence.
lead_paragraph: Death typically appears in photographs as an intruder: an unbidden force that sweeps down on a battlefield or leaves survivors pained and bereft. We see the images and know that just hours or moments earlier, the subjects’ lives were intact, the world complete and in order. In Arthur Nazaryan’s photographs of a hospice nurse and her patients, death plays a different role, shaping the scene by its absence, not its presence. It is the reason the characters are assembled, the order toward which the chaos of life is resolving itself; not just their lives, but ours as well.

headline: Building a Full Meal, Bite by Bite by Bite
abstract: The big surprise at Bartaco in Westport is how good so many of the nibbles are and how easily you can make a full meal of them.
lead_paragraph: They say there is nothing new under the sun, but the Bartaco concept may be an exception. Bartaco in Westport, an indoor-outdoor locale, offers a limited menu, more snacklike than full service, in a noisy, lively atmosphere, with seating for 110 inside, and for 25 more outside, facing the Saugatuck River.

headline: Tiger Pulls Man From Boat in India
abstract: A man poaching crabs in the Sunderbans Tiger Reserve in the eastern state of West Bengal was killed by a tiger that leapt into his boat and dragged him into a mangrove swamp.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A man poaching crabs in an eastern Indian tiger reserve was killed by a tiger that leapt into the man’s boat and dragged him into a mangrove swamp in front of his son and daughter.

headline: Lana Del Rey, Downcast Superstar
abstract: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss Lana Del Rey and her new record, “Ultraviolence.”
lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss Lana Del Rey and her new record, “Ultraviolence.”

headline: Under Cover: The Wonder of an Egg
abstract: A final moment in Kim Tingley’s cover story about three-parent I.V.F. prompted the idea to put a microscopic image of an egg on the cover.
lead_paragraph: When Jake Silverstein, the magazine’s editor, read the final paragraphs of Kim Tingley’s cover story about three-parent I.V.F., in which she describes a researcher removing nuclear DNA from a human egg, he was struck by an idea for the cover.

headline: Popcast: Lana Del Rey, Downcast Superstar
abstract: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss Lana Del Rey and her new album, “Ultraviolence.”
lead_paragraph: The singer Lana Del Rey of Los Angeles, nee Lizzie Grant of Lake Placid, N.Y., elicited some opprobrium in 2011 and 2012, through songs and videos and a first album (“Born to Die”) and a “Saturday Night Live” performance that all seemed, to some, thin or calculated or grandiose or overposed.

headline: Bringing the British Countryside to Life
abstract: The Yale Center for British Art in New Haven contains more than 300 objects ranging from centuries-old manuscripts to contemporary artists’ books.
lead_paragraph: As Elisabeth Fairman, of the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven, puts it, the exhibition “Of Green Leaf, Bird and Flower’: Artists’ Books and the Natural World” is something of “a walk through the countryside.”

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week Spring 2015 Accessories
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: Highlights from the men’s collections in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from the men’s collections in Paris.

headline: Time Doesn’t Dim Its Sparkle
abstract: A tasting of Dom Pérignon across decades shows it is more than a status symbol.
lead_paragraph: Time is easily quantifiable yet unknowable, at least as it affects wine. We know wine ages in the bottle, but how will it evolve, and why? We can estimate based on experience, but we are never really sure.

headline: Nepal’s Premier Is Being Treated for Lung Cancer
abstract: Prime Minister Sushil Koirala is undergoing radiation therapy in New York, and his indefinite absence could further paralyze Nepalese politics.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Sushil Koirala of Nepal is undergoing radiation therapy in New York to treat a cancerous tumor found on his lung, and his indefinite absence could further paralyze Nepalese politics.

headline: Christian Sudanese Woman and Her Family in Protection of U.S. Embassy
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Capital Punishment', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Mariam Ibraheem Ishag and her family were detained at the airport in Khartoum by Sudanese authorities who said her travel documents were forged.
lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan — A Christian Sudanese woman who was detained at the airport in Khartoum with her family by Sudanese authorities after an appeals court overturned her conviction and death sentence for abandoning Islam and ordered her set free is now in the protection of the United States Embassy here, her lawyer said on Friday.

headline: A Bridge Deal From Judy Kay-Wolff
abstract: Kay-Wolff celebrated her 80th birthday this month.
lead_paragraph: A few women have been married to more than one member of the bridge Hall of Fame. Judy Kay-Wolff, for example, who celebrated her 80th birthday this month.

headline: The Bride Didn’t Always Wear White
abstract: From the royal to the celebrity, gowns are on display at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Queen Victoria wasn’t much of what you would call a fashion plate, especially in her later years. As a widow, she would rarely venture out into public, and when she did, she would be swathed in funereal black, perpetually in mourning for her husband.

headline: 25th Reunion Takes a Turn for the Explosive
abstract: In “The Muscles in Our Toes,” by Stephen Belber, friends plot a rescue mission for a friend held by terrorists.
lead_paragraph: At most 25th high school reunions, the drama does not rise above the discovery that the prom queen got fat, or the mousy kid who disappeared into the scenery founded an Internet company valued at a few billion dollars. There’s much more in store for the friends reassembling to recall semi-halcyon days in “The Muscles in Our Toes,” a fairly preposterous play by Stephen Belber (“Tape,” “Match”) making its New York premiere in a Labyrinth Theater Company production directed by Anne Kauffman.

headline: The United States of Los Tigres
abstract: The California band Los Tigres del Norte, which has made more than 50 albums and sold millions of records, is all but invisible to mainstream English-speaking America.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — About four hours before a Friday night show late last month, the five members of Los Tigres del Norte, the premier band in the accordion-driven musical genre known as norteño, were quietly eating dinner at the restaurant of their hotel here. None of the other diners seemed to have any notion of who they were, and neither did the staff — until a Spanish-speaking waiter spotted them and shyly approached their table.

headline: Riot Music and Puppy-Love Songs
abstract: A review of new albums by Rae Sremmurd, Luis Coronel, Becky G, White Lung, Cakes Da Killa and Against the Current.
lead_paragraph: Rae Sremmurd

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: If the State Fair Were X-Rated (or at Least a Strong R)
abstract: “Funland: Pleasures and Perils of the Erotic Fairground,” at the Museum of Sex, is an immersive experience meant to invert ordinary senses of propriety, privacy and taste.
lead_paragraph: Should this review begin with a warning that it deals with the conventionally unmentionable? Or that it refers to images here unprintable?

headline: How the National Anthem Has Unfurled
abstract: In its bicentennial year, “The Star-Spangled Banner” will be performed in a manner Francis Scott Key might recognize.
lead_paragraph: When the baritone Thomas Hampson sings “The Star-Spangled Banner” at the Library of Congress in Washington on Thursday, it won’t sound quite like the familiar tune belted out at ball games and presidential inaugurations.

headline: Prosecutors Ask at Least 8 Years for Martoma in Insider Trading Case
abstract: Prosecutors are recommending that Mathew Martoma be sentenced to at least eight years in prison, if not significantly more.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are recommending that Mathew Martoma, a former trader who worked for the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen, be sentenced next month to at least eight years in prison for insider trading, if not significantly more.

headline: Ireland’s First Billionaire Ordered to Sell Assets to Repay Loans
abstract: Anthony O’Reilly, the former chief executive and chairman of the H.J. Heinz Company, was ordered to sell his assets to repay loans to one bank exceeding $30 million.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Anthony O’Reilly, Ireland’s first billionaire and the former chief executive and chairman of the H.J. Heinz Company, has been declared insolvent, and on Friday he was ordered to sell his assets immediately to repay loans to one bank exceeding $30 million.

headline: Prophet Goes to Church
abstract: Reggie Wilson’s “ ... Moses(es)” returned to the stage on Wednesday, this time at the St. Cornelius Chapel on Governors Island.
lead_paragraph: In the stage version of “ ... Moses(es),” performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last December, the choreographer Reggie Wilson began by introducing himself to the assembled crowd. His dancers followed suit, adding how long they’d spent as members of his Fist & Heel Performance Group. Mr. Wilson then stuffed armloads of silver tinsel into a suitcase. He packs a lot into his dances.

headline: Disparate but Connected
abstract: The photographer Wolfgang Tillmans has long been occupied with what he has called the “objectness” of a photograph.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Wolfgang Tillmans has long been occupied with what he has called the “objectness” of a photograph, its role as a thing in the world and not just as “a conduit of information,” and this has often led to explorations of the relationship between painting and photography in the digital age. A tightly focused exhibition opening Tuesday at the Philadelphia Museum of Art takes Mr. Tillmans’s fascinations and runs with them.

headline: Marathon Tribute to Philip Guston
abstract: Art can start relationships, and end them.
lead_paragraph: Art can start relationships, and end them. The composer Morton Feldman and the painter Philip Guston had been close for years when Feldman attended an opening of Guston’s in 1970. The work on display was figurative, an abrupt turn from the abstraction Guston had been known for. Feldman was stunned silent. Telling the story much later, he said that the episode ended their decades-long friendship. The two men never saw each other again.

headline: Toasting 30 Years of Raw Exuberance
abstract: The name Urban Bush Women suggests a fierce and perhaps frightening tribe — something to avoid, if it didn’t also sound like something you really wanted to join.
lead_paragraph: The name Urban Bush Women suggests a fierce and perhaps frightening tribe — something to avoid, if it didn’t also sound like something you really wanted to join.

headline: At 50, a Debut Keeps 4 Guys Young
abstract: Those pivotal appearances on “The Ed Sullivan Show” weren’t the only Beatles milestones 50 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Those pivotal appearances on “The Ed Sullivan Show” weren’t the only Beatles milestones 50 years ago. This year is also the 50th anniversary of the release of “A Hard Day’s Night,” the first of the band’s five feature films and, in many minds, the best.

headline: Same Beck, Different Mood
abstract: “I’m so tired of being alone,” cries Beck at the top of “Blue Moon,” the lead single from his muted and deliberative current album, “Morning Phase.”
lead_paragraph: “I’m so tired of being alone,” cries Beck at the top of “Blue Moon,” the lead single from his muted and deliberative current album, “Morning Phase” (Capitol). “I-so-lation,” he sings a couple of tracks later, in the existential refrain of “Wave.” The purity of the sentiment, and the completeness of his commitment, could easily give you an impression about his state of mind: desolate, draggy, half-numb, forlorn. The last time Beck made an album that felt like this — “Sea Change,” a dozen years ago — that impression might have been partly true.

headline: Inequality Is Not Inevitable
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Income Inequality', 'Recession and Depression', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Inexorable laws of economics aren’t tearing us apart. Our policies are.
lead_paragraph: AN insidious trend has developed over this past third of a century. A country that experienced shared growth after World War II began to tear apart, so much so that when the Great Recession hit in late 2007, one could no longer ignore the fissures that had come to define the American economic landscape. How did this “shining city on a hill” become the advanced country with the greatest level of inequality?

headline: Eking Out a Living to Chase a Dream
abstract: The young cast members of “The Mysteries” at the Flea Theater in TriBeCa perform free, while holding down or looking for jobs by day.
lead_paragraph: The boldface names in “The Mysteries” belong to the characters: God, Jesus, Lucifer, the rest of the biblical crowd. The actors playing them off Off Broadway, at the Flea Theater in TriBeCa, are not famous — but they’re young, hopeful and ravenous enough about performing to do it free.

headline: Damned People Got No Reason to Live
abstract: “Randy Newman’s Faust: The Concert” is getting a one-night-only Encores! Off-Center production.
lead_paragraph: When Randy Newman released “Faust” as a star-studded concept album in 1995, Rolling Stone magazine wrote that it “breathes new life into a musical-theater tradition hijacked by the likes of Andrew Lloyd Webber.” The very next year, this wry song cycle about a contemporary deal with the Devil hit the stage in a flashy production directed by Michael Greif. Yet after receiving mixed notices in Los Angeles and Chicago, Mr. Newman’s “Faust” receded into the limbo of might-have-been theater successes that got derailed on the road to Broadway.

headline: Following 9 Trips From ‘I Do’ to ‘I Did’
abstract: Twenty years ago Doug Block began shooting wedding videos to support his true passion, documentary filmmaking.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago Doug Block began shooting wedding videos to support his true passion, documentary filmmaking. Sure, the money was good. But he soon discovered a far more intriguing aspect. “I could stand just feet away,” he says, “as two ordinary people experience one of the most extraordinary days of their lives.” But after the vows had been uttered and the videos sent on their way, he couldn’t help but wonder what happened next.

headline: Intensity, Instantly, and Hints of Coltrane
abstract: At Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola, the Azar Lawrence Quintet is focusing on music from Mr. Lawrence’s new album, “The Seeker.”
lead_paragraph: With improvised music, you get used to seeing a band warm up by degrees. It comes with the aesthetic form, and also with the business model, if it’s a band performing sporadic multiple-night stands. Jazz is full of groups reconvening, recohering, then pacing themselves across a few nights and days. The quintet led by the saxophonist Azar Lawrence, from Los Angeles, is of that form and that model. For the last three years or so, it’s been playing gigs in clubs — often on the East Coast, where all its other members are based — and then everyone scatters and does different things.

headline: The Hoodie as a Tease, and Other Statements From a Sampler of Mixed Moves
abstract: The language of hip-hop inspires a program at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — “Unreal Hip-Hop,” a showcase organized by the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival, seems designed to defy expectations. The performance on Thursday opened with a figure in a hoodie, hunched over and facing away in dim light. That’s an image closely associated, like hip-hop, with black males. This figure, though, turned out to be a white B-girl.

headline: Hewitt Grinds Back From Two Sets Down, but His Upset Bid Fails
abstract: Lleyton Hewitt forced the 6-foot-8 Jerzy Janowicz out of his rhythm but ultimately lost in five sets in a match that consumed 3 hours 47 minutes over two days.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — It is often said that professional tennis does not have competitive contrast. Those objecting to that state of affairs should have appreciated Lleyton Hewitt’s attempt Friday afternoon to cut the goliath known as Jerzy Janowicz down to size, inch by tormented inch.

headline: Speak Your Own Truth, on Your Own Terms
abstract: Billie Jean King and Jason Collins share a bond as gay athletes who hope to pave a path for those who follow.
lead_paragraph: Billie Jean King loves to connect.  The 70-year-old tennis legend — winner of 39 Grand Slam titles, the Presidential Medal of Freedom and, most famously, the “Battle of the Sexes” match against Bobby Riggs in 1973 — peppers questions like forehand volleys.  Within three minutes of walking into Boulud Sud, near Lincoln Center, Ms. King had learned that the restaurant manager’s mother rowed crew for Syracuse University; asked her interviewer’s partner’s name (and tossed it off casually through the afternoon); and compared notes on the French Open with the waiter.

headline: At Festival, Footfalls of Farewell
abstract: The successful Trey McIntyre Project will disband this summer. Its final program includes works inspired by Edward Gorey and Queen.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — The Doubtful Guest, the title character of a 1957 illustrated book by Edward Gorey, is a peculiar creature, with a flat head, a knitted scarf and wings that suggest a penguin’s flippers. It shows up at an Edwardian manor house and stays for 17 years (by the book’s end) with no indication that it might ever leave.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Jeff Koons’ Big Bloom
abstract: The last big week of the social season held one final grand surprise: the Jeff Koons retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
lead_paragraph: The last big week of the social season held one final grand surprise: the Jeff Koons retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

headline: Surgical Complications
abstract: Eight of 16 of the military’s largest hospitals had high rates of surgical complications, such as infections or improperly done procedures, according to a review from the American College of Surgeons.
lead_paragraph: Eight of 16 of the military’s largest hospitals had high rates of surgical complications, such as infections or improperly done procedures, according to a review from the American College of Surgeons.

headline: American Realism by Way of Woodstock
abstract: A retrospective of Eugene Speicher at the Samuel Dorsky Museum of Art in New Paltz, N.Y., examines his career in the context of American realism, but also as an artist who spent months each year in nearby Woodstock.
lead_paragraph: Fortunes in the art world — and particularly those defined by the market — change quickly. Take Eugene Speicher (1883-1962), a painter whom Esquire magazine called America’s most important living painter in 1936, but whose name few people know today (and even fewer can pronounce: “Spiker”). “Along His Own Lines: A Retrospective of New York Realist Eugene Speicher,” organized by Valerie Ann Leeds at the Samuel Dorsky Museum of Art in New Paltz, N.Y., seeks to redress this, examining Mr. Speicher’s career in the context of American realism, but also as an artist who spent months each year in nearby Woodstock.

headline: Scenes from San Francisco
abstract: In search for noir, with Dashiell Hammett as guide.
lead_paragraph: In search for noir, with Dashiell Hammett as guide.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Big Bloom
abstract: The last big week of the social season held one final grand surprise: the Jeff Koons retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
lead_paragraph: BIG BLOOM The last big week of the social season held one final grand surprise: the Jeff Koons retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art that occupies the entire museum, including the front moat. On the top floor is Mr. Koons’s latest work, “Play-Doh,” a monumental pile of color. The owners of the work are Maria and Bill Bell. Many of the women’s dresses at the opening Tuesday echoed the colors of the sculpture and recalled the colors of the Fauve painters of early-20th-century Paris and the smaller “Split-Rocker,” left. It contrasts with the colossal “Split-Rocker,” below, covered in over 50,000 dwarf marigolds, zinnias, petunias, wax begonias, impatiens and geraniums, installed above the statue of Prometheus in Rockefeller Center. The sculpture, which exploded to 37 feet tall, was unveiled at a luncheon.

headline: Bulletins From the Gut, From a Quartet at Work in the Park
abstract: Warpaint, a four-woman Los Angeles band, appeared as part of the Celebrate Brooklyn! concert series.
lead_paragraph: Musical patterns are neat, stable, definite, predictable. Feelings and relationships — well, they aren’t. But they can all be hypnotic, compelling, even obsessive. Warpaint, the four-woman Los Angeles band that headlined Celebrate Brooklyn! on Thursday night, places its songs at that complicated intersection: where a grid of repetition meets the amorphous crosscurrents of emotion and desire.

headline: Evening Hours | Including the Stars
abstract: Music, art and dancing to start the summer.
lead_paragraph: Music, art and dancing to start the summer.

headline: Same-Sex Marriages, 10 Years Later
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: Ten years after Massachusetts legalized gay marriage, the couples whose same-sex wedding announcements were the first to appear in The Times reflect on what marriage means to them.
lead_paragraph: So, what happens to a marriage over the course of 10 years? Make that a gay marriage.

headline: Exploring the Continuity of the Radical
abstract: At the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum, there are new projects by contemporary artists and solo shows of recent works by established artists whose early careers were nurtured by the museum’s founder.
lead_paragraph: Since April, the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum has been commemorating its 50th anniversary with a yearlong series of changing exhibitions. Its galleries are filled with artworks that honor its legacy while highlighting the impact of that legacy on artists practicing today.

headline: Rulings on Abortion and Appointment
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Constitution (US)']
abstract: Readers react to two recent Supreme Court rulings on protests at abortion clinics and recess appointments.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Howard Baker, Who Put the Nation Ahead of Himself
abstract: Adam Clymer, a former Times correspondent, recalls the senator’s work to pass the Panama Canal treaties.

headline: Helping a Child With Homework: Two Views
abstract: Readers including Howard Schneiderman, a sociologist, respond to a Sunday Review article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Wheelies: The Electrified Audi Edition
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: Audi rolls out its plug-in hybrid A3 E-tron in Europe; Curt Clawson, former chief executive of a parts supplier, is sworn into Congress.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Something for Tout le Monde
abstract: The menu at Vox in North Salem has changed little over the years, retaining much of its French flavor. Nonetheless, the listing has something for every appetite.
lead_paragraph: Next month, Vox will celebrate its 10th anniversary. This charming restaurant and bar has been a beacon to those navigating the sharp curves of Route 116 in the woodsy isolation of North Salem.

headline: Checkpoint Showdown
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Search and Seizure']
abstract: As the immigration debate focuses on border security, some say that American freedoms are being compromised by interior Border Patrol checkpoints, like the one north of Arivaca, Ariz.
lead_paragraph: As the immigration debate focuses on border security, some say that American freedoms are being compromised by interior Border Patrol checkpoints, like the one north of Arivaca, Ariz.

headline: Watching the Workers
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Workplace Environment', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: A reader recalls a conversation with a telephone operator for a report on worker monitoring.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Good Marital Advice
abstract: A rabbi responds to a column by David Brooks, “Rhapsody in Realism.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: All the World’s His Stage
abstract: The director of Shanghai Shakespeare says the Chinese have fully embraced the playwright’s works.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ergen Sidelined in Battle With Falcone Over LightSquared
abstract: The bitter battle between the billionaires Charles W. Ergen and Philip A. Falcone over LightSquared, the bankrupt wireless broadband company, appears to be nearing an end. The twist is Mr. Ergen is no longer involved.
lead_paragraph: The bitter battle between the billionaires Charles W. Ergen and Philip A. Falcone over LightSquared, the bankrupt wireless broadband company, appears to be nearing an end. The twist is that Mr. Ergen is no longer involved.

headline: She Did It Her Way
abstract: Reasons to visit Rosebank on Staten Island include the Alice Austen House, and Bayou, a New Orleans-themed restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Staten Island has been called the forgotten borough and was home to a nearly forgotten, boundary-pushing photographer named Alice Austen. At the ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, open since 1985 in the working-class neighborhood of Rosebank, some details of her life are still blurred.

headline: Presbyterians Remove Guide After Criticism
abstract: The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) removed the study guide “Zionism Unsettled” from its website after critics said the publication denigrated Israel and Jews.
lead_paragraph: After months of outrage over a publication that critics say denigrates Israel, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) announced Friday that it was no longer selling the study guide “Zionism Unsettled” on the church’s website.

headline: Shoulder Injury Sends Mets’ Wright Back to New York
abstract: The third baseman will have a magnetic resonance imaging test on his left shoulder, which he aggravated during Thursday’s game in Pittsburgh.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Mets third baseman David Wright stood outside the visitors’ clubhouse Friday afternoon and explained why he had been scratched from the lineup with a sore left shoulder.

headline: Seaside With Kindred Spirits of Cookery
abstract: “Craig Claiborne and Pierre Franey: Cookbook Revolutionaries in East Hampton” at the East Hampton Historical Society’s Clinton Academy Museum, includes more than 70 images, several hand-drawn menus, various cookware used by the duo and more.
lead_paragraph: Epic picnics on the beach and fancy dinners prepared in well-equipped and abundantly stocked East Hampton kitchens are among the delectable events evoked by photographs and artifacts in “Craig Claiborne and Pierre Franey: Cookbook Revolutionaries in East Hampton.” The exhibition, at the East Hampton Historical Society’s Clinton Academy Museum, includes more than 70 images, an Al Hirschfeld caricature of both men, several hand-drawn menus and various cookware used by the duo, including a fish steamer, a duck press and a bouillabaisse pot.

headline: Afrezza, a New Inhaled Insulin, Is Approved by the F.D.A.
abstract: The approval is a huge milestone for MannKind Corporation, but concerns linger about the drug’s potential effect on patients’ lungs.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a form of insulin that is inhaled rather than injected, providing a new option for millions of Americans with diabetes.

headline: Texas: Booking of Migrants to Take Place at 4 Sites
abstract: Families caught crossing the border illegally in the Rio Grande Valley will be sent initially to Customs and Border Protection stations in Texas and California, border officials said Friday.
lead_paragraph: Adults with children caught crossing the border illegally in the Rio Grande Valley will be sent initially to Customs and Border Protection stations in Laredo and El Paso, and also to San Diego and El Centro in California, border officials said Friday. Families will be booked for deportation at those sites, and some will remain in detention. Facing a surge of Central American migrants in South Texas, border authorities have been releasing most families with children there. They will soon open a 700-bed detention center for families at a law enforcement training center in Artesia, N.M.

headline: Woods Misses Cut in His Return But Finds ‘a Lot of Positives’
abstract: In his first tournament in more than 100 days, Tiger Woods missed the 36-hole cut by four strokes after “a ton of little, simple mistakes” at the Quicken Loans International in Bethesda, Md.
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md. — A major winner rebounded from an opening 74 to make the cut at the Quicken Loans National, but his name was not Tiger Woods. Justin Rose, the 2013 United States Open winner, pieced together a six-birdie, no-bogey round of six-under 65 on Friday at Congressional Country Club to vault from a tie for 83rd into a tie for 11th, three strokes off the lead shared by four players.

headline: Border Patrol Scrutiny Stirs Anger in Arizona Town
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Search and Seizure', 'Smuggling']
abstract: Arivaca, Ariz., is surrounded by checkpoints where everyone is stopped and questioned, no matter how long they have lived there.
lead_paragraph: ARIVACA, Ariz. — Every time Jack Driscoll drives the 32 miles from this remote outpost in southeastern Arizona to the closest supermarket, or to doctor’s appointments, or to a pharmacy to fill his prescriptions, he must stop at a Border Patrol checkpoint and answer the same question: “Are you a U.S. citizen?”

headline: World Cup 2014: Brazil Defeats Chile on Penalty Kicks, 1-1
abstract: Brazil, the tournament favorite and host, narrowly escaped defeat after Chile’s Gonzalo Jara hit the post with his final penalty kick. Brazil advances to the quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: Brazil, the tournament favorite and host, narrowly escaped defeat after Chile’s Gonzalo Jara hit the post with his final penalty kick. Brazil advances to the quarterfinals.

headline: World Cup 2014: Colombia Defeats Uruguay, 2-0
abstract: Colombia continued its impressive run after finishing its group 3-0 with a 2-0 victory, led by James Rodriguez and his two goals.
lead_paragraph: Colombia continued its impressive run after finishing its group 3-0 with a 2-0 victory, led by James Rodriguez and his two goals.

headline: If Franz Ferdinand Had Lived
keywords: ['World War I (1914-18)', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: The assassination of the Hapsburg empire’s would-be reformer opened a Pandora’s box of nationalist agitation that still roils Europe.
lead_paragraph: FOR over 25 years, Archduke Franz Ferdinand paced up and down in his palaces and castles waiting impatiently for the death of the ever more ancient emperor, his hated uncle Franz Joseph I. As we all know, his wait was in vain.

headline: A Place to Pull Over
abstract: Joe’s Garage and Grill, a three-month-old restaurant in Riverhead, has a menu with an automotive theme.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever dined in a garage? Joe’s Garage and Grill, a three-month-old restaurant in Riverhead, comes close to providing that experience. The floor is concrete and the rows of windows roll up like garage doors. The automotive theme continues on the menu, where appetizers are listed under Start Your Engines and sandwiches are referred to as The Pile Up.

headline: Friday Night Music: Attack of the Brooklyn Hipsters (Sylvan Esso)
abstract: Actually, really cool.
lead_paragraph: OK, at one level this is almost a caricature of hipsterdom. But at the same time Sylvan Esso is really, really good …

headline: Tensions Continue to Simmer as Attacks in Gaza Escalate
abstract: Two Palestinian men suspected of being militants were killed in an Israeli missile strike in Gaza on Friday, according to the military and witnesses.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Two Palestinian men suspected of being militants were killed in an Israeli missile strike in Gaza on Friday, according to the military and witnesses, and Israel’s minister of defense warned that he would not tolerate rocket fire from Gaza against Israel or any other attempt to harm Israeli civilians and soldiers.

headline: On Air Force One, No Lightening Up on Burgers and Cake
keywords: ['AIR FORCE ONE (JET)', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The food on the president’s plane is plentiful in quantity and broad in appeal, but not always the perfect mirror of the nutritional recommendations coming out of the first lady’s office.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A blue-cheese burger with lettuce, tomato and garlic aioli, accompanied by Parmesan-sprinkled fries. Chocolate fudge cake. Pasta shells stuffed with four cheeses, topped with meat sauce and shredded mozzarella, and served with a garlic breadstick. Cake infused with limoncello. Buffalo wings with celery, carrots and homemade ranch dip.

headline: At Wimbledon, Ana Konjuh Spun Her Tale of Faith
abstract: Konjuh, a 16-year-old Croat, became the youngest player to reach Wimbledon’s third round since 1999 before losing to Caroline Wozniacki.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Ana Konjuh has a tattoo on her left wrist that reads, “Faith.” Faith in her prodigious ability, which has helped her become one of the most promising women in the game. Faith in the continuing twists and turns of fate that played an integral role in her move from her quiet hometown, Dubrovnik, Croatia, to Zagreb at 10, leading her to her mentor, the former French Open champion Iva Majoli.

headline: Hong Kong’s Democracy Supporters Chafe at Inequality and Beijing’s Sway
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: An informal vote on how to select Hong Kong’s leader reflects resentment that the Beijing-oriented political-business machine is rigged against the people.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — On a recent morning, Agnes Chow, 17, and another teenage activist rode a van through the streets of Hong Kong, urging people through a loudspeaker to vote in an informal referendum for a more democratic way to pick the city’s top leader. But the vote, which has been condemned as illegal by the Chinese government, was about much more than the city’s leadership, she said.

headline: Key Piece in Limbo, Knicks’ President Forges Foundation
abstract: Phil Jackson this week turned his focus from wooing Carmelo Anthony to revamping the Knicks’ roster, an act that could prove to be the most effective appeal to Anthony.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Phil Jackson made clear that he was finished with the formal recruiting process, if it was even fair to describe it that way in the first place. There would be no genuflecting at the altar of Carmelo Anthony, no passionate overtures, no grand promises — other than a well-formulated plan to (eventually) turn the Knicks into a contender.

headline: Airlines’ Rivalry Amplifies Fight Over Bank Guarantees
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Delta, watching Persian Gulf carriers make inroads into Europe, is concerned that loan guarantees from the Export-Import Bank in Washington will help them do the same in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The rise of Persian Gulf airlines has been a boon to Boeing as they snap up its large jets, sometimes with the help of loan guarantees from Washington.

headline: The Accidental Escapee, or the Eyewitness in the Back Seat
abstract: Peter Zacharakis was under arrest and in a police vehicle when another handcuffed prisoner took the wheel.
lead_paragraph: Bryan McMenamin was all over the news last week when, hands cuffed behind his back after being arrested in a drug bust, he jumped from the back of a police S.U.V. into the driver’s seat and, cuffed hands somehow in front, drove off.

headline: Three Homers by Yankees Compound the Red Sox’ Struggles
abstract: Kelly Johnson, Brett Gardner and Brian McCann hit home runs, and Boston failed to score in the opener of a three-game series in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: In the off-season, as the Boston Red Sox were basking in the glow of their World Series victory and the Yankees were retooling, and the teams’ front-office executives were again lobbing insults at each other, the rivalry seemed to have regained some of its acerbity.

headline: While Iraq Burns
abstract: If they want to try to save their state, the prime minister and other Iraqi leaders must join together.
lead_paragraph: In the face of a violent offensive by Sunni militants, Iraq’s future as a unified state is becoming less and less likely. As the Sunni militants take hold of a large swath of northwest Iraq, the Kurds, who operate a semiautonomous province in northeast Iraq, are edging toward independence, leaving Shiites controlling Baghdad and regions in the south. Yet Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki seems to have no interest in finding a new way forward from a catastrophe his policies ignited.

headline: The Second Chance Act Proves Its Worth
keywords: ['Second Chance Act', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Probation and Parole', 'Editorials', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'States (US)']
abstract: A study finds that states reduce recidivism rates when they commit to measures that help ex-prisoners to transition.
lead_paragraph: With corrections costs exceeding $60 billion a year, state and local governments are rightly focused on making sure that newly released prisoners stay out of jail instead of coming back in through a revolving door.

headline: New General Motors Recall Includes Best Sellers
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: G.M. said it was recalling more than half a million more vehicles, including full-size pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles that can suddenly switch into neutral.
lead_paragraph: Adding to the mounting toll of its safety crisis, General Motors said on Friday that it was recalling more than half a million more vehicles, including full-size pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles that can suddenly switch into neutral.

headline: Bobby Womack, Royalty of the Soul Era, Dies at 70
abstract: Mr. Womack was nicknamed the Preacher for his authoritative, church-trained voice and the way he introduced songs with long discourses on life.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Womack, who spanned the American soul music era, touring as a gospel singer in the 1950s, playing guitar in Sam Cooke’s backup band in the early ’60s, writing hit songs recorded by Wilson Pickett and the Rolling Stones and composing music that broke onto the pop charts, died on June 27 at his home in Tarzana, Calif. He was 70.

headline: World Cup 2014: A Defiant Chile Seeks to Ruin a Tournament for Its Hosts
abstract: Chile has never defeated Brazil in a World Cup, but doing so on Saturday would send a shock through the host nation, as well as the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil — Groups of Chilean fans moved about the streets here on the eve of their team’s game against Brazil. Some were on foot, some rode in packed cars with the red, white and blue flag of Chile fluttering from windows, and many yelled their familiar chant, “Chi Chi Chi, Le Le Le,” while locals looked on, distinctly unamused.

headline: Report Finds Health Unit of V.A. Needs Overhaul
abstract: A report to President Obama from a top adviser points to a multitude of problems, just as demand for services is increasing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Veterans Health Administration has a corrosive culture that has led to poor management, a history of retaliation toward employees, cumbersome and outdated technology, and a shortage of doctors, nurses and physical space to treat its patients, according to a review presented to President Obama on Friday by one of his top advisers on veterans’ issues.

headline: Taliban Mount Major Assault in Afghanistan
abstract: The group has attacked police outposts and government facilities in several districts of northern Helmand Province, sending the police and military officials scrambling to shore up defenses.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In one of the most significant coordinated assaults on the government in years, the Taliban have attacked police outposts and government facilities across several districts in northern Helmand Province, sending police and military officials scrambling to shore up defenses and heralding a troubling new chapter as coalition forces prepare to depart.

headline: Upon Return to Uruguay, Luis Suárez Is Met With Support

lead_paragraph: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil — Barred from soccer for the next four months for biting an opponent and obliged to leave his team in the midst of the World Cup, Luis Suárez arrived home in Uruguay before sunrise Friday and was met with cheers and a presidential hug on the tarmac.

lead_paragraph: Paul Kirby waved his baton at the group of musicians gathered in the cavernous United Palace Theater in Manhattan on a recent Saturday. Sweat cascaded down his brow as the string orchestra played in front of him.

headline: Syria: Dispute Unsettles Rebel Coalition
abstract: The interim government said that it would fire the head of the Supreme Military Council of the Free Syrian Army and refer its members to a commission investigating corruption.
lead_paragraph: As President Obama asks Congress for $500 million to help Syria’s rebels, the dysfunction and infighting that have long undermined their fight against the Syrian government spilled into the open again on Friday. The leader of the interim government established by the exile opposition, the Syrian National Coalition, said in a statement that he was firing the head of the Supreme Military Council of the Free Syrian Army and referring its members to a commission to investigate accusations of corruption. The military council responded that the interim government had made a “grave legal error” and did not have any power over it — a position that was supported by the leader of the Syrian National Coalition, Ahmad Assi al-Jarba. Despite being endorsed by the West as the leaders of the struggle against President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, none of the bodies involved in the dispute are currently playing a significant role in the civil war. The coalition is widely seen as ineffective, its interim government is little more than a list of names, and the military council has been overshadowed on the ground by rebel formations and extremist groups that have been more active.

headline: Rations Reduced as Demand Grows for Soup Kitchens
abstract: A nightly food run by the Coalition for the Homeless is drawing bigger crowds than ever before in some parts of Manhattan and the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Old Cantonese women lined up behind a white van, clutching plastic bags to carry away their meals for the night. Behind them came young children clamoring for milk, homeless men in tattered shirts and Mexican immigrants who spoke only Spanish.

headline: For Women Who Saw Combat, a Place to Find Inner Peace
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Buddhism', 'Meditation', 'Monasteries and Monks', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A retreat at a monastery in Northern California uses the principles of Zen Buddhism, and the solitude of its rural location, to help provide relief to female veterans.
lead_paragraph: JAMESBURG, Calif. — As Melannie Lovercheck was packing last Saturday for her week away from home, she reached into a closet, knelt beneath her Navy lieutenant’s uniform on its hanger and grabbed a pair of black Crocs. The choice seemed logical enough. Where she was going, she would need some kind of waterproof footwear to get from her cabin to the shower room.

lead_paragraph: Rollin W. King, a co-founder of Southwest Airlines, the low-cost carrier that helped to change the way Americans travel, died Thursday in Dallas. He was 83. The cause was complications from a stroke he had a year ago, his son Edward King of Dallas said.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE COUNSELOR (2013) Michael Fassbender (above right, with Brad Pitt) portrays the title character — a corrupt, high-flying Texas lawyer who gets in over his head in a drug deal with Reiner (Javier Bardem), a nightclub owner involved with a Mexican cartel promising a 4,000 percent return — in this thriller directed by Ridley Scott from a screenplay by Cormac McCarthy. Mr. Pitt is the Counselor’s wary business associate, Cameron Diaz is Reiner’s predatory girlfriend and Penélope Cruz is the woman the Counselor intends to marry. “From all the ellipses, as well as the eccentric, mesmerizing poetry of his dialogue, Mr. McCarthy appears to have never read a screenwriting manual in his life. (That’s a compliment; this is his first produced film script.),” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about what she called a “terrifying, implacable new movie.” In Mr. McCarthy, she added, Mr. Scott “has found a partner with convictions about good and evil rather than canned formula.”

headline: Americans Think We Have the World’s Best Colleges. We Don’t.
abstract: The United States may have many of the best elite colleges, but over all, our higher-education system has many of the same problems found in K-12.
lead_paragraph: Americans have a split vision of education. Conventional wisdom has long held that our K-12 schools are mediocre or worse, while our colleges and universities are world class. While policy wonks hotly debate K-12 reform ideas like vouchers and the Common Core state standards, higher education is largely left to its own devices. Many families are worried about how to get into and pay for increasingly expensive colleges. But the stellar quality of those institutions is assumed.

headline: Lucy Liu’s Directorial Debut on Human Trafficking
abstract: Lucy Liu writes about directing a film about a woman’s tireless efforts to rescue her daughter, who was forced into prostitution.
lead_paragraph: I traveled to Mumbai in 2010 to direct my first film “MEENA,” based on the first chapter of Nick and Sheryl’s book Half The Sky: Turning Oppression Into Opportunity for Women Worldwide. Even though MEENA is only a 20 minute film and took 5 days to shoot, it has taken nearly four years for it to finally be seen by an audience. The earlier feedback we received was that the content was too strong and that viewers would feel uncomfortable with the aggressive nature of violence in conjunction with children. The premiere of Meena this week was truly transformative. I felt excited and reinvigorated to be surrounded by an audience who were not only engaged by the film’s message, but also curious about how they can become more actively involved in learning about child protection.

abstract: Congress needs to provide funding so unopened rape kits can be analyzed.

Medical personnel collect saliva, semen, blood, hair and other DNA evidence from victims after an attack in so-called rape kits. These kits, however, often sit unopened for years in police evidence rooms or public crime labs.
