headline: China’s Threat to Wild Tigers
abstract: A luxury market in skins, meat and wine endangers the rare cat.
lead_paragraph: EARLIER this year, a police raid on a house party in Leizhou, Guangdong Province, in southern China, revealed a decadent diversion apparently popular among some of China’s elite: watching a tiger being slaughtered and butchered, then gorging on meat that’s considered an exotic delicacy.

headline: A Child of Grass Courts Dreams Anew
abstract: Cara Black, a winner of 10 Grand Slam titles, grew up in Zimbabwe playing on grass courts that her father built. She is back at Wimbledon this year.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — A long Wimbledon day had stretched into evening, and finally darkness, by the time Cara Black settled into a chair, with another victory registered in an illustrious doubles career that has brought her 10 Grand Slam titles with partners female and male. She was tired, expressionless, but only until a question was asked about her beloved grass courts.

headline: The Power of a Deed
abstract: Millions of Jews followed the Rebbe, who had a belief in the importance of the individual act.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY is the observance of the 20th anniversary of the death of Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson — universally known as the Rebbe — who for decades was the charismatic leader of millions of Jews. Commemorations are planned; several biographies have just been released.

headline: Covering New War, in Shadow of Old One
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Public Editor (Times Column)']
abstract: As things heat up again in Iraq, readers are watchful for news coverage and opinion writing that reminds them of past mistakes.
lead_paragraph: THE lead-up to the war in Iraq in 2003 was not The Times’s finest hour. Some of the news reporting was flawed, driven by outside agendas and lacking in needed skepticism. Many Op-Ed columns promoted the idea of a war that turned out to be both unfounded and disastrous.

headline: Britain’s Strange Identity Crisis
abstract: The vote on Scotland’s referendum to stay in or leave the United Kingdom will bring major change, either way.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — THE United Kingdom is lying on the psychiatrist’s couch. Suddenly the country seems uncertain of its identity, its place in the world, its relationships with its closest family members and its neighbors.

headline: Is Obesity O.K.?
abstract: Readers discuss an advice columnist’s assertion that pretending that obesity is not a problem may prevent hurt feelings but compromise health.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss an advice columnist’s assertion that pretending that obesity is not a problem may prevent hurt feelings but compromise health.

headline: ‘Jane’ Didn’t Get the Help She Needed
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Juvenile Delinquency', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: “Jane Doe” has a life story at the age of only 16 that is a good example of how the juvenile justice system is failing many of those most in need.
lead_paragraph: IF you want to understand just how miserable a childhood can be, 16-year-old “Jane Doe” is a good place to start.

headline: Life in Iraq Grinds On, Whoever Is in Charge
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: Whether Shiites or ISIS is in charge, residents just want to live their lives.
lead_paragraph: HIS name was Thamir, and he was a pool hustler. He was good enough that when a translator shouted in the pool hall that I wanted to meet the best player in Husayba, the gaggle of men parted, opening the way to him. Thamir grinned wryly, pressed an index finger against his chest and lifted his chin in that universal gesture: You want to talk to me?

headline: They Said It Couldn’t Be Done
abstract: Despite the caveats and delays, Syria has handed over the last of its known stockpile of chemical weapons.
lead_paragraph: Less than a year ago, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his forces were sporadically using chemical weapons on rebels and civilians in the civil war. Today, the stockpile that he grudgingly admitted to under international pressure is gone.

headline: How the Terrorists Got Rich
abstract: They’re making money off trade, taxes and charity, and we’re not keeping up.
lead_paragraph: A FEW feet from the Bab al-Salam border crossing near the Turkish town of Kilis, there is a shabby cafe where the most interesting items for sale are not found on the menu. The cafe is the final stop for young radicalized men from Europe or North Africa who are planning to slip past the lax Turkish border officers and into Syrian territory. This is where they exchange their passports for cash. When one of us visited the cafe in January, a Belgian passport was for sale for $8,000. A buyer could have it altered for movement to Europe or visa-free travel to the United States. New passport photos were being snapped in the parking lot.

headline: Dale Chihuly
abstract: The glass artist on flip phones, foie gras and his Ford Fairlane.
lead_paragraph: Dale Chihuly is a widely collected glass sculptor whose work has been installed in venues as varied as the Victoria and Albert Museum in London and the Bellagio Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas.

headline: Arsonists and Firefighters
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Kurds', 'Israeli Settlements', 'Palestinians', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Some argue that it is not inevitable that the Middle East erupt in sectarian conflagration.
lead_paragraph: WHAT’S the real fight in the Middle East today? Is it just sectarian (Sunnis versus Shiites) and national (Israelis versus Palestinians and Arabs versus Persians)? Or is it something deeper? I was discussing this core question with Nader Mousavizadeh, a former senior United Nations official and the co-founder of Macro Advisory Partners, a geopolitical advisory firm, and he offered another framework: “The real struggle in the region,” he said, “is between arsonists and firefighters.”

headline: Stopping Campus Rape
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Dormitories']
abstract: There are changes colleges could make in campus life that would address the root causes of sexual assaults.
lead_paragraph: IN the debate over sexual violence on college campuses, two things are reasonably clear. First, campus rape is a grave, persistent problem, shadowing rowdy state schools and cozy liberal-arts campuses alike.

headline: Why Teenagers Act Crazy
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Brain', 'Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: It’s not their fault. It’s all in the timing of brain development.
lead_paragraph: ADOLESCENCE is practically synonymous in our culture with risk taking, emotional drama and all forms of outlandish behavior. Until very recently, the widely accepted explanation for adolescent angst has been psychological. Developmentally, teenagers face a number of social and emotional challenges, like starting to separate from their parents, getting accepted into a peer group and figuring out who they really are. It doesn’t take a psychoanalyst to realize that these are anxiety-provoking transitions.

headline: What ‘Nurse Jackie’ Gets Right About the E.R.
abstract: For all its lead character’s flaws, it’s the best depiction of a hospital on TV.
lead_paragraph: A lot of nurses hate the Showtime series “Nurse Jackie,” which will wrap up its sixth season on Sunday evening. Actually, to be precise, they hate the show’s lead character, the emergency department nurse Jackie Peyton. There’s much to dislike: She is an adulterer, a liar, an unreliable mother and, most significantly, addicted to prescription painkillers. (That’s hardly giving anything away, but be warned: spoilers ahead.)

headline: Once a Militant Stronghold in Iraq, Now a Battleground Again
abstract: The village of al-Daira lies in an area the American military once called the Triangle of Death. Militants are now pressuring Baghdad by trying to sever Iraq’s principal highway.
lead_paragraph: AL-DAIRA, Iraq — At one house, Iraq’s national flag fluttered atop a building that Iraqi soldiers had captured from militants two days before.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 29
abstract: The escalating violence in Iraq, where Sunni militants are threatening the U.S.-backed government, will dominate the discussions on the Sunday talk shows.
lead_paragraph: President Obama asked Congress for $500 million to train and equip “appropriately vetted” members of the Syrian opposition on Thursday as concerns rise about the conflict spilling into Iraq. Ten days ago, Mr. Obama said he would send 300 American military advisers to assess Iraq’s military as it faces Sunni militants.

headline: ‘Be Not Afraid of My Body’
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: My Baptist girlfriend’s mother probably suspected I was gay when she gave me a book of Walt Whitman’s poetry.
lead_paragraph: MY first encounter with Walt Whitman was complicated.

headline: The Right to Write
abstract: Who owns a story, the person who lives it or the person who writes it?
lead_paragraph: I sat on a panel once with another novelist and a distinguished African-American critic, to discuss Harriet Beecher Stowe’s novel “Uncle Tom’s Cabin.” The critic said, “Of course, as a white woman, Stowe had no right to write the black experience.” The other novelist said lightly, “No, of course not. And I had no right to write about 14th-century Scandinavians. Which I did.”

headline: After the Game, Reality Sinks In for a Lineman
abstract: Kendrick Payne, a former defensive lineman in college at California, watched the O’Bannon case unfold a few miles from where he works as a driver for a ride-sharing company.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Kendrick Payne picked up a passenger in his silver Nissan Altima one afternoon last week in downtown Oakland, across the street from the federal courthouse. Payne, a former defensive lineman at the University of California, wore an old Bears workout shirt with his No. 96 printed on the back. His N.F.L. dreams all but gone, he works as a driver for Lyft, a ride-sharing company.

headline: What Is Your Experience in the American Military’s Health Care System?
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: If you have had a first-hand experience with the nation’s military’s health care system, as a patient, family member or worker, please tell us your story.
lead_paragraph: If you have had a first-hand experience with the nation’s military’s health care system, as a patient, family member or worker, please tell us your story.

headline: Struggling Met Contributes By Controlling the Playlist
abstract: Although he has struggled to find his swing and his place in the Mets’ outfield this season, Chris Young orchestrates the music in the clubhouse.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — After every Mets home win, the players pour into the clubhouse, bobbing their heads as the hip-hop song “Get Like Me,” by David Banner, thumps through the speakers. For 15 minutes, music blares and the mood is light. Then the clubhouse is opened to the news media, and the players go their separate ways.

headline: With Surge of Chaos in Iraq, a Familiar Problem Knocks on Biden’s Door
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Recent events in Iraq could vindicate an idea advanced by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. in 2006: to split the country into three largely autonomous regions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the first summer of the Obama administration, Iraq has been considered Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s account. But when President Obama called a critical meeting on June 16 to confront the crisis that had suddenly erupted there, Mr. Biden was landing in Brazil to go to a World Cup soccer game.

headline: In Military Care, a Pattern of Errors but Not Scrutiny
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Hospitals', 'Malpractice', 'Veterans', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: An examination of the nation’s military hospitals by The New York Times finds a system where avoidable, sometimes deadly, errors are chronic and scrutiny is sporadic.
lead_paragraph: FORT SILL, Okla. — Jessica Zeppa, five months pregnant, the wife of a soldier, showed up four times at Reynolds Army Community Hospital here in pain, weak, barely able to swallow and fighting a fever. The last time, she declared that she was not leaving until she could get warm.

headline: Rays Cast Aside Emotions as Reality Derails Plans
abstract: The Tampa Bay Rays, facing the prospect of David Price leaving as a free agent after next season, may trade the talented left-hander.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The secret to the success of the Tampa Bay Rays, before this season’s startling and spectacular collapse, has been that there are no hard decisions, only necessary ones. A move that may seem wrenching to an outsider is not that way to the Rays.

headline: Stagflation and the Fall of Macroeconomics
abstract: Why it mattered more than it should have.
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis and Mark Thoma write about the rise of New Classical Macroeconomics — basically the rejection of Keynes and the attempted assimilation of macro into micro. Unusually, I have some bones to pick with both, although we clearly agree on the big stuff.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Berluti Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

lead_paragraph: The situation is reaching a critical point as refugees flee the violence.

headline: Colombia vs. Uruguay: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Colombia has been hugely impressive, finishing its group 3-0 and even scoring four goals with its reserves in its final game against Japan. Uruguay had a less auspicious campaign.
lead_paragraph: Colombia has been hugely impressive, finishing its group 3-0 and even scoring four goals with its reserves in its final game against Japan. Uruguay had a less auspicious campaign, beating England through Luis Suarez magic, then scrapping a win over Italy that included several disputed calls.

headline: A Reignited War Drives Iraqis Out in Huge Numbers
abstract: Iraqis have fled their homes in recent weeks, filled with fear and uncertainty — and a painful sense of familiarity. More than a million Iraqis have been displaced this year, and for many it was not the first time.
lead_paragraph: DARBANDIKHAN, Iraq — As Sunni rebels advanced across Iraq in recent weeks, hundreds of thousands of Iraqis were driven from their homes. For many, it was not the first time.

headline: Underdog Stuns Serena Williams, and Herself, at Wimbledon
abstract: Alizé Cornet of France, the 25th seed, expressed disbelief after her third-round victory over Williams, a five-time Wimbledon champion.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Top-seeded Serena Williams was cruising toward the second week of Wimbledon, breezing through two rounds and the first set of the third, before Alizé Cornet of France turned the match, and the women’s side of the tournament, inside out.

headline: Kicker vs. Keeper
abstract: Kasey Keller, a former U.S. national team goalkeeper, walks us through the psychology of four memorable World Cup standoffs.
lead_paragraph: Kasey Keller, a former U.S. national team goalkeeper, walks us through the psychology of four memorable World Cup standoffs.

headline: World Cup 2014: Brazil Survives Shootout Against Chile
abstract: After Brazil goalkeeper Júlio César had made two shootout saves, Gonzalo Jara hit the right post, and the ball bounced back across the mouth of the goal and safely away.
lead_paragraph: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil — With the pressure of an anxious nation bearing down on them with each passing minute, the Brazilian players teetered on the brink of a defeat that would have wounded a country’s soul.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Schohoaja.

headline: Cuomo Plan Seeks to End New York’s AIDS Epidemic
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said he would announce on Sunday a plan for more-aggressive testing and treatment, a result of months of negotiations with AIDS activists.
lead_paragraph: Borrowing an idea from leading AIDS researchers, the Cuomo administration said on Friday that it had developed a plan to aggressively identify, track and treat people with H.I.V. infection with the aim of reducing new infection to the point that by 2020, AIDS would no longer reach epidemic levels in New York State.

headline: Islanders Take Brash Player, Ignoring Doubts of Other Teams
abstract: Josh Ho-Sang has a reputation for cockiness that made some franchises wary of drafting him, but not the Islanders or their general manager, Garth Snow.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Islanders could be a little more intriguing in the near future, and not just because of the team’s move to Brooklyn a year from now.

headline: Offering to Disarm in Congo, After 20 Years of War
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The gesture is a new twist in a war that has pitted Central African tribes and nations against one another for 20 years, but officials are skeptical of the militants’ intentions.
lead_paragraph: KIGOGO, Democratic Republic of Congo — Shortly after midday in this village nestled in clouds, the progenitors of the long, dirty war across Central Africa came out of the jungle and laid down their guns.

headline: Uruguay to Appeal Suárez’s Suspension, Though His Return Is Unlikely
abstract: A long-shot bid to overturn or reduce the penalty will almost certainly not be heard until after the World Cup ends on July 13.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Uruguay’s soccer federation informed FIFA on Friday night that it would file an appeal to the suspension that ousted its best player from the World Cup for biting an opponent.

headline: Kids Behind Bars
abstract: Readers comment on my column about a 16-year-old girl, “Jane Doe,” who underscores how our system fails kids.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column is about the failure of our criminal justice system for kids, including the way we vastly over-rely on the juvenile detention toolbox and under-rely on the education, economic opportunity and early intervention toolboxes. As my column notes, the United States incarcerates kids at a rate 10 to 20 times higher than in some other industrialized countries; I should have added that it’s 100 times the rate of a few countries.

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: 11 Die in India as Buildings Collapse
abstract: Two buildings more than 1,000 miles apart, one in Chennai and the other in New Delhi, fell within hours of each other on Saturday, trapping construction workers.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Two buildings more than 1,000 miles apart in India collapsed within hours of each other on Saturday, killing 11 people and trapping dozens of others in the rubble.

headline: Despite High Unemployment, Portugal Looks Far Afield for Workers
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Foreign Workers', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Minimum Wage', 'Unemployment', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: A low minimum wage and relatively generous unemployment benefits make tough agricultural labor a hard sell, so companies import workers from as far away as Thailand.
lead_paragraph: ODEMIRA, Portugal — Portugal may have 15 percent unemployment, but that does not mean that Reiter Affiliated Companies, an American fruit producer, can find local people to pick berries on its 76-hectare farm here.

lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Downright tricky, indeed. This puzzle by Byron Walden is not that difficult to solve, but have you figured out the theme? That’s the real forehead-slapper in this Sunday’s cruciverbal adventure.

headline: Creeping Up on Unsuspecting Shores: The Great Lakes, in a Welcome Turnaround
abstract: Scientists attribute the resurgence of water levels to an unusually cold winter that limited evaporation as well as heavy precipitation in the winter and spring.
lead_paragraph: EPHRAIM, Wis. — Like a slowly draining bathtub, this sparkling inlet of Lake Michigan had seen its clear, cool waters recede for years.

headline: World Cup 2014: James Rodríguez Leads Colombia Over Uruguay
abstract: Rodríguez, a young midfielder, scored both of Colombia’s goals, showing the talent that prompted A.S. Monaco to pay $61 million to acquire him.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — His name is James, but he pronounces it Hahm-ez, and that was the way the Colombian fans shouted it on Saturday night. They have been singing James Rodríguez’s praises all along, in fact, but in the flurry of goals and teams and story lines in this World Cup, there was a chance a few people had not yet noticed Rodríguez. Everyone knows him now.

headline: Department of Justice News Release

lead_paragraph: Ahmed Abu Khatallah, made his first appearance today in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia on a federal terrorism offense arising from his alleged participation in the September 11-12, 2012, terrorist attacks in Benghazi, Libya.

lead_paragraph: NAPASKIAK, Alaska — No roads go this deep into the tundra, especially not for Democrats.

headline: Obama to Seek Funds to Stem Border Crossings and Speed Deportations
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Children and Childhood', 'Deportation']
abstract: President Obama will seek $2 billion for border enforcement to cope with the influx of illegal Central American migrants, including unprecedented numbers of unaccompanied minors.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will ask Congress to provide more than $2 billion in new funds to control the surge of illegal Central American migrants at the South Texas border, and to grant broader powers for immigration officials to speed deportations of children caught crossing without their parents, White House officials said on Saturday.

headline: Revelry in Sarajevo, Where Shots Started a World War

lead_paragraph: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — The Austrian colonel, in the field-green uniform worn for formal occasions, was not amused, and had no hesitation in saying so.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The way the Wimbledon referee Andrew Jarrett remembered it, his conversation with David Nalbandian was quick, funny and to the point.

lead_paragraph: Both stars of the New York City Ballet, Tiler Peck and Robert Fairchild have been dancing together since they were young.

headline: Cup Overflows: You Won’t See Joy Like This in the End Zone
abstract: Unlike the relatively restrained players in American sports leagues, goal scorers at the World Cup unleash celebrations ranging from joyous to defiant to bizarre.
lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — After Pablo Armero of Colombia scored against Greece, he and his teammates broke into a raucous dance routine that evoked the “Shout” scene from the film “Animal House.”

headline: For Wendy Davis, Filibuster Goes Only So Far in Race to Be Governor of Texas
abstract: Wendy Davis’s campaign for governor is expected to set a fund-raising record, but even supporters point to missteps in her race and question her chances at election.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — She is in sneakers again.

headline: At 40, Austin Rock Club Celebrates Rare Longevity
abstract: Hole in the Wall, a University of Texas-area club, recently had its 40th anniversary, and the members of Fastball slammed through several frenzied rock songs for the occasion.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN — The band Fastball is best known for “The Way,” one of its mid-tempo 1998 hits, but this month in Austin, to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the opening of Hole in the Wall, it slammed through several frenzied rock songs from its 1996 debut, “Make Your Mama Proud,” which the group had not played in 15 years. “No wonder we were so skinny back then,” the frontman Miles Zuniga joked.

headline: Niese Stops Pirates as Mets Get Good News on Wright
abstract: A magnetic resonance imaging test on the captain David Wright revealed only bruising on his left rotator cuff, suggesting he would probably avoid a stint on the disabled list.
lead_paragraph: Before Saturday, the first half of the Mets’ season had been, in a word, forgettable.

headline: In a Surprise, Carlsen Shows He’s a Three-Speed Champ
abstract: Magnus Carlsen has long dominated conventional play, but he is now also world champion of the rapid and blitz forms of the game.
lead_paragraph: Magnus Carlsen is now the world champion of chess at all speeds.

headline: Fund-Raising as a Barometer of a Statewide Campaign’s Success
abstract: The end of June is the midyear mark for political fund-raising, and politicians’ reports are an acid test of their campaigns, a sign of who is competitive.
lead_paragraph: It is somewhat crass to talk about money when you are supposed to be talking about good old American democracy, but the list of statewide campaigns that have succeeded without cash is short.

headline: Best Insurance for Texas Workers? ‘Don’t Get Injured’
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', "Workers' Compensation Insurance", 'Labor and Jobs', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The land of an economic “miracle” routinely leads the nation in worker fatalities while offering some of the weakest protections and hardest-to-obtain benefits in the country.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN — Almost anywhere in the vast Lone Star State, one can find evidence of the “Texas miracle” economy that policy makers like Gov. Rick Perry have talked about in their political speeches.

headline: Turn One-and-Done Into None-and-Done
abstract: History shows that teenagers have had great success in the N.B.A., and the league should welcome prodigies and celebrate their achievements.
lead_paragraph: One of Adam Silver’s top priorities since he became the N.B.A. commissioner this year has been to raise the draft eligibility age. The current minimum, 19 or one year removed from high school graduation, was established in the 2005 collective bargaining agreement.

headline: Yankees Looking for Additions, Possibly a Pitcher
abstract: General Manager Brian Cashman made it clear that the Yankees expect to be players in the hunt for midseason acquisitions, with another starting pitcher the main priority.
lead_paragraph: With his team in third place in the American League East before Saturday’s game against the Boston Red Sox, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman said he had been actively engaging with other teams about trade options ahead of the nonwaiver trade deadline July 31.

headline: Brooklyn Man, 32, Is Killed in Hit and Run

headline: Opting Out, Dwyane Wade Enables Heat to Increase Roster Flexibility
abstract: Wade informed the Miami Heat that he — like LeBron James earlier in the week — would opt out of his contract, increasing the likelihood that the team’s main cast would stick around.
lead_paragraph: The likelihood that LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh would stay with the Miami Heat for another run at an N.B.A. title with a retooled roster increased Saturday when Wade informed the team that he, like James earlier in the week, would opt out of his contract.

headline: On One Pitch, a Scintillating Outing Turns Sour for Tanaka

lead_paragraph: There is no wrong pitch with Masahiro Tanaka, catcher Brian McCann said. McCann just wanted a different one.

headline: Mira Slovak, a Daring Pilot Who Won Freedom, Then Races, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Slovak, known as the Flying Czech, lived a life of high-speed adventure, including hydroplane championships, after escaping Communist Czechoslovakia by hijacking his own commercial plane.
lead_paragraph: Mira Slovak, who as a young airline pilot in 1953 fled Communist Czechoslovakia by hijacking his own commercial flight to West Germany, died on June 16 at his home in Fallbrook, Calif. Mr. Slovak, who went on to become a hydroplane racing champion, a stunt flyer and an airline pilot, was 84.

headline: Lester Stymies Jeter to Preserve Red Sox’ Win
abstract: Few batters have tormented Jon Lester like the Yankees’ Derek Jeter, who came up in the eighth with the score tied and a runner on base. Lester got Jeter to hit into a double play.
lead_paragraph: All night, Jon Lester felt comfortable throwing his sinker away from hitters, so in the eighth inning Saturday at Yankee Stadium, nothing else mattered. Not the unfavorable count, or the tie score, or the runner on first with no outs, or the success enjoyed against him by the man standing in the batter’s box, Derek Jeter.

headline: North Korea Plans to Indict Two Americans; Defies U.N. by Firing Ballistic Missiles
abstract: The official news agency said that the Americans would be tried on charges of committing “hostile acts,” a report that came a day after the country launched two missiles off its east coast.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said Monday that it planned to indict and try two Americans it has held on charges of committing “hostile acts” against the country, just a day after it fired two ballistic missiles off its east coast, flouting a United Nations ban on the country’s testing of such missiles.

lead_paragraph: What to watch for in today’s World Cup matches, two elimination games in the knockout phase of the tournament. (Times are Eastern.)

headline: 1914: Assassination of the Archduke Francis Ferdinand was a conspiracy
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: In 1914, the assassination of Archduke Francis Ferdinand was the outcome of a conspiracy; Dublin elects its first woman Lord Mayor in 1939.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — That the assassination of Archduke Francis Ferdinand, the heir to the thrones of Austria and Hungary, and of the Duchess of Hohenberg, his consort, was the result of a widespread plot, the extent of which the actual actors were perhaps unaware of, now appears to be beyond doubt. In case the attempt on the Archduke’s life in Sarajevo failed, other bombs, it is stated, were to have been exploded on the railway as the Royal train was on its return journey from the Bosnian capital. Serious disturbances have taken place in Sarajevo and other towns in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Yesterday, another bomb was thrown at a street corner in Sarajevo by a young man, a Mussulman being wounded by the explosion. Martial law has been proclaimed in the town. The bodies of Archduke Francis Ferdinand and the Duchess of Hohenberg were embalmed during Sunday night, and were removed yesterday by special train to Metkovich, Dalmatia, on their way to Vienna. The funeral will take place on Friday, the interment being in the mausoleum on the Archduke’s estate at Artstetten. Emperor Francis Joseph will not be present at this ceremony, but will attend a requiem mass on the following day. A representative of a Prague bank in which Archduke Francis Ferdinand’s will had been deposited has arrived in Vienna with the document. It is stated that certain questions of State in which the Archduke was interested will be confided by the Emperor to the new heir to the throne. — From The New York Herald, European Edition, June 30, 1914.

headline: Hong Kong Poll Turnout Buoys Democracy Activists
abstract: An unofficial referendum on democratic changes in Hong Kong attracted votes equal to more than a fifth of the city’s electorate, organizers said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — An unofficial referendum on making the selection of Hong Kong’s chief executive more democratic has attracted votes equal to more than a fifth of the city’s electorate, organizers said Sunday, the referendum’s final day. They voiced hopes that the higher-than-anticipated participation would, along with a protest march scheduled for Tuesday, increase the pressure on the mainland Chinese government to give ground on the issue.

headline: Russian Jets and Experts Sent to Iraq to Aid Army
abstract: The experts’ arrival was seen as an implicit rebuke to the United States, where concerns in Congress about the political viability of Iraq’s government have stalled aircraft sales to Iraq.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi government officials said Sunday that Russian experts had arrived in Iraq to help the army get 12 new Russian warplanes into the fight against Sunni extremists, while the extremists declared their leader the caliph, or absolute ruler, of all jihadi organizations worldwide.

headline: The Battle Over Vaccinating Grandparents
abstract: Before the birth of my first baby, I asked my parents and my in-laws to get the T.D.A.P. vaccine. My mother and in-laws agreed. My father refused.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t understand why I need the whooping cough vaccine. I’ve raised kids. We have friends whose kids have raised kids. Our nieces and nephews have kids. Why is this the first time we’re hearing about grandparents getting vaccinated?”

headline: Central Bankers, Worried About Bubbles, Rebuke Markets
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: In its annual report, the Bank for International Settlements expressed concern about investors driving up asset prices with little regard for the risks.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — An organization representing the world’s main central banks warned on Sunday that dangerous new asset bubbles were forming even before the global economy has finished recovering from the last round of financial excess.

headline: A Matchup to Recall a 32-Year-Old Injustice
abstract: In 1982, Algeria upset West Germany, 2-1. The Germans later beat Austria, 1-0, as the teams effectively spent 80 minutes trying not to score. This time, Germany is Algeria’s opponent in the Round of 16.
lead_paragraph: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil — Soccer and fairness are hardly constant companions. Dominate play, create chance after chance, and your team can still lose on a lucky bounce, on a referee’s judgment call or on the roulette wheel of a shootout.

headline: Mexico vs. Netherlands: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: The Netherlands scored 10 goals in its first three games, and Robin van Persie and Arjen Robben have looked like world-beaters. Mexico, which barely scraped into the Cup, has restored some national pride with two good wins and a game draw against Brazil.
lead_paragraph: The Netherlands scored 10 goals in its first three games, and Robin van Persie and Arjen Robben have looked like world-beaters. Mexico, which barely scraped into the Cup, has restored some national pride with two good wins and a game draw against Brazil.

abstract: Dave Morin’s start-up firm, Path, which first offered a photo-sharing app, now hopes ephemeral messaging will help it rise again.

headline: Assisting in Life — and Death
abstract: Patients’ rights advocates are making swift strides toward the decriminalization of assisted death, writes JAKE FLANAGIN. But others are hesitant to give governments a say on such a delicate issue.
lead_paragraph: Saturday was a watershed moment for the American suicide-prevention effort. In response to decades of public advocacy, San Francisco transit authorities unanimously approved a $76 million plan to construct suicide barriers on the Golden Gate Bridge — where 46 people jumped to their death last year alone. “The time of healing can only begin when the drip-drip-drip of bodies into the raging waters has stopped,” a mother of one jumper told Michael Cabanatuan of The San Francisco Chronicle.

headline: Japanese Protester Sets Himself on Fire at Train Station in Tokyo
abstract: The man set himself aflame at Tokyo’s busiest train station in what appeared to be a protest against efforts to weaken Japan’s antiwar Constitution.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In a ghastly spectacle of a sort rarely seen in this orderly city, a man set himself on fire in front of horrified crowds at Tokyo’s busiest train station on Sunday in what appeared to be a lone protest against efforts to weaken Japan’s antiwar Constitution.

headline: Meshach Taylor, an Actor on TV’s ‘Designing Women,’ Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Taylor was nominated for an Emmy Award in 1989 for the role of Anthony Bouvier, an ex-convict who became a partner at an Atlanta design firm with four women.
lead_paragraph: Meshach Taylor, the actor best known as the friendly colleague of four Southern women on the popular sitcom “Designing Women,” died on Saturday at his home near Los Angeles. He was 67.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (HBO) THE LEFTOVERS Three years after 2 percent of the world’s population suddenly disappeared on Oct. 14, for no discernible reason — Was it an act of God? A natural phenomenon? — the residents of the fictional Mapleton, N.Y., are still searching for answers in this dystopian series created by Tom Perrotta, adapted from his novel, and Damon Lindelof, a mastermind behind ABC’s “Lost.” Churches have closed while cults have formed, including the Guilty Remnant, whose followers wear white, take a vow of silence and chain smoke. One member is Laurie (Amy Brenneman), the mother of Jill (Margaret Qualley), a high schooler, and Tom (Chris Zylka), who has joined another cult led by a man who claims that he can hug the pain out of people. Laurie is also the wife of Kevin Garvey (Justin Theroux, the town’s chief of police, above, speaking with Amanda Warren), whose colleagues worry that he may be losing his mind as he tries to maintain order. The show “may never explain what happened to the people who disappeared, but the measure of its worth is that it may not have to,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “As with any good drama, the mystery lies in human nature more than in the supernatural. Once the show gets going, and it takes more than one episode to do so, ‘The Leftovers’ bores into the characters and the fissures that crack their community so astutely that the cause is almost secondary.”

The movie industry’s broader reaction was more muted pending a final box-office tally; Sunday estimates have a way of declining a bit on Monday, when actual grosses are reported and headline writers have moved on.

abstract: The nation’s election commission is set to announce preliminary results, although Abdullah Abdullah has accused officials of rigging the vote against him.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After a potential opening last week to ease Afghanistan’s political crisis, the presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah signaled on Sunday that more deadlock was ahead, promising again that he would not accept any decisions made by the country’s election commission after the panel rejected a list of his demands.

headline: The Great War Still Echoes

lead_paragraph: To many in the United States and, indeed, around the globe, World War I is a historical afterthought, a foggy precursor to World War II.

headline: Dutch Mount Dramatic Rally With Theatrical Fall
abstract: The decisive goal in the Netherlands’ victory over Mexico was set up by Arjen Robben’s fall — some might say dive — under a challenge from Mexico’s captain, Rafael Márquez. Klaas-Jan Huntelaar scored on the penalty kick.
lead_paragraph: FORTALEZA, Brazil — Mexico’s coach, Miguel Herrera, has become an icon during this World Cup for his impassioned exhortations in front of the team bench. Herrera has stomped and stamped, whirled and whipped, flailed and frothed over everything from referee decisions to near misses to, most notably, goals scored by his players.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Paul Smith Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: Russia and Others Confer on Halting Ukraine Fighting, Which Goes on Despite Cease-Fire
abstract: The fighting in eastern Ukraine has continued despite a cease-fire called by the government in Kiev that insurgent leaders said they would join.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The leaders of Russia, Ukraine, Germany and France spoke by telephone on Sunday about how to stop the fighting in eastern Ukraine, which has continued despite a cease-fire called by the government that insurgent leaders said they would join.

headline: Pick for V.A. Is Former Corporate Chief
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama is expected to to nominate Robert A. McDonald, who ran Procter & Gamble, to be the secretary of Veterans Affairs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday intends to nominate Robert A. McDonald, a former chief executive of Procter & Gamble, to be the next secretary of Veterans Affairs, a White House official said Sunday, betting that a global corporate officer can turn around a government health system that has been rocked by allegations of mismanagement and cover-ups of long patient waiting times.

headline: Saint Laurent: Spring 2015 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Parking Dance in New York City
abstract: Every day, drivers across New York double-park their cars as street sweepers pass by, a practice known as alternate-side parking. A new bill before the City Council could change the dance.
lead_paragraph: Every day, drivers across New York double-park their cars as street sweepers pass by, a practice known as alternate-side parking. A new bill before the City Council could change the dance.

headline: New York Council Bill Aims to Ease a Parking Burden
abstract: Legislation that will have a hearing before the City Council would allow drivers to return to parking spaces once street sweepers pass on alternate-side-parking days.
lead_paragraph: It is the New York City driver’s public shame — a sentence of solitary front-seat confinement levied against those for whom subways, buses and taxis are insufficient.

headline: With This Video Camera, I Thee Shoot
abstract: A documentary by the filmmaker Doug Block (who has a sideline as a wedding videographer) revisits couples whose ceremonies he has shot over the years.
lead_paragraph: Ever wonder what’s running through the mind of the person shooting your wedding video as he eats your hors d’oeuvres and walks backward down the aisle? If you hired Doug Block, there’s no need to wonder. He’s thinking, “You know what, this would make a pretty good documentary!”

headline: Mets Are Hurt, for a Day, by a Trade That’s Working for 2 Teams
abstract: The Pirates capped a 3-1 series that, for the Mets, at least served as a reminder that Lucas Duda has developed into a serviceable first baseman since Ike Davis was traded.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Two months had passed since the Mets had traded Ike Davis, and the drama was gone. The team and the player had moved on; both seemed content. They had history — injuries, trade rumors, a competition with Lucas Duda, all of which had seemed so serious at the time — but time had smoothed the rough edges.

headline: After Supreme Court Ruling, Aereo’s Rivals in TV Streaming Seize Opening
abstract: A victory for traditional American broadcasters in a copyright case does little to protect them from an Internet-powered onslaught.
lead_paragraph: Mark Ely saw an opportunity, and he took it.

headline: Where Passion Rules, Morality Stands Little Chance
abstract: Robert Wilson puts his spin on Monteverdi’s “L’Incoronazione di Poppea” for the Paris Opera.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Nero and Poppea never touch in Robert Wilson’s new production of Monteverdi’s “L’Incoronazione di Poppea” for the Paris Opera, which ends its run at the Palais Garnier on Monday. Their love affair, which drives anyone who gets in its way to death or exile, is one of the most violent portrayed in opera. Yet even during their final, rapturous duet, “Pur ti miro,” on Saturday, the tenor Jeremy Ovenden and the mezzo-soprano Karine Deshayes maintained a sliver of space between their outstretched hands.

headline: On the Legal Front Lines of Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: “Redeeming the Dream” centers on the lawyers Theodore B. Olson and David Boies and their fight to end California’s law against same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: For more than four years a group of prominent lawyers led by Theodore B. Olson and David Boies, along with political consultants and Hollywood celebrities, campaigned against Proposition 8, the ban on same-sex marriages approved by California voters in 2008. The group, the American Foundation for Equal Rights, had two primary goals: to secure a judicial victory in the Supreme Court extending marriage to gay couples nationwide and to increase support for the cause through a public-relations blitz.

headline: Ooh, a Maypole! And Love Interests, With Feathers
abstract: American Ballet Theater’s “Swan Lake,” as seen through three casts at the Metropolitan Opera House last week.
lead_paragraph: Siegfried, the prince in “Swan Lake,” spends a lot of time surrounded by women who don’t seem to interest him. In American Ballet Theater’s production, he invariably appears more excited by the arrival of a maypole at his birthday party (Act I) than by the young ladies lining up to dance with him. In Act III, when princesses of the world parade through his court, enticing him with their national dances — Hungarian, Spanish, Italian, Polish — he wants none of them for his bride. “No,” he mimes to the Queen Mother, who has urged him to choose one, causing a flurry of disbelief among his courtiers.

headline: Despite Legal Challenges, Sale of Hopi Religious Artifacts Continues in France
abstract: Prompted by another auction, the American Embassy in Paris attempted to stop the sale of Native American artifacts in France last week.
lead_paragraph: The thought of Americans lecturing the French about cultural sensibilities seems like a hard sell in a country still shielding its language from idiomatic blasphemies like “le weekend” and “hashtag.” But the United States Embassy in Paris spent several days last week educating French officials about the strong emotions that have led Native American tribes like the Hopi and Navajo to sue Parisian auction houses — unsuccessfully, time and again — over the sale of sacred objects.

headline: One Who Plays For Pay
abstract: Start out your solving week with a puzzle by Ed Sessa.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Happy Monday, everyone! It’s a vowel run.

headline: Gilbert & Sullivan Announces Season
abstract: A witch’s curse, embattled lovers and a gondolier with royal blood will be part of the 2014-15 lineup for the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players, the organizers have announced.
lead_paragraph: A witch’s curse, embattled lovers and a gondolier with royal blood will be part of the 2014-15 lineup for the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players, the organizers have announced. The season, which will take place at New York University’s Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, is to begin on Oct. 12 with a benefit gala celebrating the group’s 40th anniversary. That will be followed on Nov. 1 and 2 by “Ruddigore,” in which the Baronet of Ruddigore tries to escape a curse that forces him to commit a daily crime. “H.M.S. Pinafore,” Dec. 26-31, tells the comedic story of a lowly sailor’s plan to elope with the captain’s daughter before finding out that he isn’t as lowly as everyone — including himself — thinks he is. The theme of mistaken identity continues with the season’s final production, “The Gondoliers,” May 15-17. More information is at nygasp.org.

headline: 1939: First Woman Elected Mayor of Dublin
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Dublin elects its first woman Lord Mayor in 1939.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The first woman Lord Mayor of Dublin in history was elected last night. She was Mrs. Tom Clarkes, widow of Fenian leader executed after the 1916 Easter uprising, who herself has been an active Nationalist. The decisive vote which put her into office was cast by the outgoing Lord Mayor, Alderman Alfred Byrne, whom she has previously tried to oust from office on six different occasions. Byrne had been Lord Mayor for nine years. — From The New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 30, 1939.

headline: Remembering World War I in the Conflict’s Flash Point
abstract: The Vienna Philharmonic chose its material carefully for a concert held in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, that remembered World War I.
lead_paragraph: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — If there was a moment that captured better than any other the light and the dark in Sarajevo’s centenary weekend, marking 100 years since the events here that unleashed the demons of World War I, it came with the opening bars of Beethoven’s “Ode to Joy.”

headline: All Jooked Up With Everywhere to Go
abstract: The King of Jookin competition in Memphis teaches volumes about a dance genre and its revelations.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Breakthroughs in an art form happen rarely. Yet on Saturday night in this city, at an event advertised as “launching the World Jookin Federation,” breakthroughs seemed to keep happening all evening long.

headline: Hot Spots, Anyone? Racy Preferred
abstract: Vice, the youth-oriented news entity, is expanding its web presence as it is courted by Fox and Time Warner.
lead_paragraph: The website is called Vice News, so it’s fair to expect racy images in a film titled “Posing as a Prostitute in a Turkish Brothel: Correspondent Confidential.”

headline: Boxed In, With Room for Creativity
abstract: “NYC Makers: The MAD Biennial,” the first show that Glenn Adamson conceived as director of the Museum of Arts and Design, opens on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: For the first show he conceived as director of the Museum of Arts and Design, Glenn Adamson is thinking inside the box.

headline: England Beats Poland at European Championships
abstract: The European Championships are continuing in Opatija, Croatia.
lead_paragraph: The European Championships are continuing in Opatija, Croatia. Teams are vying for medals and to qualify for next year’s world championships: the Bermuda Bowl, Venice Cup and d’Orsi Senior Bowl.

headline: News Corp. Slowly Putting Phone-Hacking Scandal Behind It
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: The acquittal of Rebekah Brooks, the most senior executive charged in a phone-hacking case in Britain, is the latest development in the company’s apparent recovery.
lead_paragraph: Less than three years ago, a phone-hacking scandal at Rupert Murdoch’s British newspapers was seen by some as the beginning of the end of his media empire.

headline: Little Lambs: A Pastoral
abstract: Our local “lambing event” was a magical outing for my young daughter. For the grown ups, it was somewhat more complicated.
lead_paragraph: The local butchers own a farm near the English village where I live and staged a “lambing event” there this spring. They put up a plywood sign cut in the shape of a curly-fleeced lamb on the lane that ran past their drive, which promised fun for all ages and a taste of the countryside. I saw it on the way home from work and decided to take my 4-year-old daughter, Rosy, along as a treat on the weekend. Rosy loves animals and the chance of letting her get close to some of the stars of her nursery rhymes was unmissable.

headline: Blame War, Not Safaris
abstract: Hunters aren't the problem in the Central African Republic.
lead_paragraph: Safari hunting strikes many people as distasteful in the best of times, and during a conflict, as morally outrageous. The Central African Republic is at war again, and two loose-knit coalitions — one mostly Muslim, the other mostly Christian — are massacring each other. Yet the trophy hunting goes on. A few intrepid foreigners are traveling to the eastern parts of the republic to kill Lord Derby Eland, the largest antelope in Africa, and its shy forest cousin, the bongo.

headline: Japan’s Foundering Finances
abstract: The Abe administration is still waiting for its economic reforms to take off.
lead_paragraph: The Abe administration is still waiting for its economic reforms to take off.

headline: Why Not Just Weigh the Fish?
abstract: When scientists dismiss philosophy as an antiquated relic of our pre-scientific past, they are making a very large and dubious assumption.
lead_paragraph: Morale these days has fallen pretty low along the corridors of philosophy departments. From one side, we get the mockery of the scientists. Freeman Dyson calls philosophy today “a toothless relic of past glories.” According to Neil deGrasse Tyson, majoring in philosophy “can really mess you up.” Stephen Hawking declares that “philosophy is dead.” From another side, we have to cope with the apostasy of our own leading figures. John Searle describes the field as being in “terrible shape.” Peter Unger says that philosophers are “under the impression that they’re saying something new and interesting about how it is about the world, when in fact this is all an illusion.” What’s going on? Has philosophy gone horribly amiss? Or are there broader cultural factors at work, perhaps something to do with a general decline in respect for the humanities?

headline: New NPR Chief, Jarl Mohn, Vows to Foster Diversity
keywords: ['Public Broadcasting', 'Radio', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'News and News Media', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: With an overwhelmingly white staff and audience, the station will work to attract a broader group of people, drawing on the new chief executive’s experience in California.
lead_paragraph: When Jarl Mohn takes the helm as NPR’s chief executive on Tuesday, he will call on lessons learned from public radio in Los Angeles to address what he says is one of NPR’s most pressing priorities: increasing its reach into communities of color.

headline: Let Them Eat Cash
abstract: Help the poor by giving them money. They won’t waste it.
lead_paragraph: A CHINESE millionaire tried to give $300 (and lunch) to homeless men and women in New York last week. This didn’t sit well with the nonprofit New York City Rescue Mission. The Rescue Mission offered to help with lunch, but wouldn’t cooperate in handing out cash. So midway through a meal of sesame-crusted tuna and filet of beef, some 200 homeless people discovered that they would not be getting money. Instead, the Rescue Mission would accept $90,000 on their behalf. You can imagine the anger and humiliation.

headline: Anthrax? That’s Not the Real Worry
abstract: Labs are working with virulent flu strains that could start a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: OFFICIALS at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently discovered that at least 75 workers there had been exposed to possible anthrax infection.

headline: Rubble in India Is Combed, and Builders Arrested
abstract: Two buildings collapsed over the weekend in New Delhi and Chennai, India, killing at least 21 people and trapping others in the debris, officials said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Rescuers digging through the rubble of a 12-story building that collapsed on Saturday in heavy rains in the southern city of Chennai had by Sunday evening recovered the bodies of 11 people and rescued 21 survivors, with possibly many more people still trapped under the rubble, officials said.

headline: Admissions Criteria at Top City Schools
abstract: Readers discuss the paucity of blacks and Latinos at New York City’s elite public schools.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Rising Toll of Forest Fires: Will Congress Act?

abstract: Jay M. Pasachoff of Williams College writes that “unvaccinated students are hazards to the health of other students.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: A reader tells of a frank exchange and a changed perspective.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: The American Civil Liberties Union of Maryland writes that the curfew “will further criminalize youths.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 30
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Bruised Captain Inspires Belgians
abstract: Vincent Kompany is the leader of the Belgium squad that will face the United States on Tuesday, and while he is one of the world’s top central defenders, he is also injury-prone.
lead_paragraph: MOGI DAS CRUZES, Brazil — Vincent Kompany, Belgium’s captain, jumped to head a corner kick during a World Cup qualifying match against Serbia last June. He hoped to land with a goal. Instead, he fell to the ground with a bloodied face, a broken nose, a fractured eye socket and a concussion.

headline: The Water Crisis in the West
abstract: What are the best ways to share water and ensure it lasts for the foreseeable future?

headline: Tribune Company Hopes to Turn WGN America Into Cable Network
abstract: With its first original drama, “Salem,” and a new series, “Manhattan” on the way, the Tribune Company plans to turn its superstation into a full-fledged cable network.
lead_paragraph: Every cable TV network needs one thing to thrust itself into the consciousness of viewers: a signature show that attracts ratings and passionate advocates.

headline: Awakening the ‘Dutch Gene’ of Water Survival
keywords: ['Levees and Dams', 'Global Warming', 'Floods', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Education', 'Education (K-12)', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: The dikes of the country’s water management system work so well that experts say they worry that citizens will begin to take staying dry for granted.
lead_paragraph: NOORDWIJK, the Netherlands — Along a rugged, wide North Sea beach here on a recent day, children formed teams of eight to 10, taking their places beside mounds of sand carefully cordoned by candy-cane striped tape. They had one hour for their sand castle competition. Some built fishlike structures, complete with scales. Others spent their time on elaborate ditch and dike labyrinths. Each castle was adorned on top with a white flag.

headline: For Women, a Bigger Share of the Brightest Stages at Wimbledon
abstract: Male players have often had more exposure on Wimbledon’s primary courts, but at this tournament there has been a swing toward the women.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Lindsay Davenport has been coming to Wimbledon, the world’s most prestigious tennis championship, for more than 20 years, but she had never seen anything quite like the second day of this year’s tournament.

headline: Long List of Contenders After Serena Williams’s Defeat
abstract: With both Williams sisters losing in the third round at Wimbledon, only one American woman still has a chance to advance.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Three times this year, Serena Williams has arrived at a Grand Slam event as the top seed and heavy favorite, and three times she has lost before the business end of the tournament.

headline: For Email Newsletters, a Death Greatly Exaggerated
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'E-Mail', 'Newsletters', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Email newsletters, old-school artifacts that were supposed to die with dial-up connections, are not only still around, but very much on the march.
lead_paragraph: Here at the Media Equation, we pride ourselves on keeping our readers abreast of the newest technologies and approaches in reaching audiences. So it gives us great pleasure to reveal a radical publishing technology that is catching on in news media companies big and small. Ladies and gentlemen, behold: email.

headline: Newsletters You Might Actually Be Happy to Find in Your Inbox
abstract: Some newsletters to follow and others that have been recommended.
lead_paragraph: Like most people, I’m careful about handing my email address to anyone, much less somebody who promises to send me messages every working day. But because they sit in my inbox and can be opened (or ignored) at a time of my choosing, I’ve found newsletters keep me in the know about specific topics — which in my case includes media comings and goings. Here are a few newsletters that I follow and others that I hear great things about.

headline: Verizon to Return to Its Former Midtown Tower, but on a Smaller Scale
abstract: The decline of landline telephones means the company, now mostly wireless, has less need for the cavernous spaces that used to house wires and switching equipment.
lead_paragraph: When New York Telephone first moved into its headquarters near Times Square, the company was a monolith that controlled virtually all telecommunications in New York City through a network of wires that snaked into nearly every building. The equipment that connected all those phone lines filled half of the headquarters tower and dozens of other buildings scattered throughout the city.

headline: Kidd’s Power Play Is Bold, if Not Out of Character
abstract: For the Nets, the summer became a lot murkier over the weekend when it was revealed that Jason Kidd’s brief tenure as the team’s coach was most likely coming to an abrupt end.
lead_paragraph: The lead-in to free agency tends to be a tumultuous time in the N.B.A. Players are weighing their options. Front offices are deciding whom to retain and recruit. Through it all, however, each coach usually has a sense of his team’s direction amid the long off-season.

headline: With Two Victories as a Rookie, the Son of a Nascar Great Roars on His Own
abstract: Chase Elliott, the son of the former Nascar champion Bill Elliott, has won two races in the Nationwide Series and is in second in the points standings five months into his rookie season.
lead_paragraph: MOORESVILLE, N.C. — The next great Nascar driver has the deep Southern twang of a country singer, a poise that belies his age and a name that was born for this sport.

headline: ‘Live in Levi’s’ Campaign Reunites Levi Strauss With Its Old Agency, FCB
abstract: After 16 years away, the Levi’s jeans brand is returning to an agency that it had worked with for almost seven decades and declaring that its dungarees feel good enough to live in.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the duo Peaches and Herb, known as “the sweethearts of soul,” got back together, they sang, “Reunited and it feels so good.” Now, an apparel brand reuniting after 16 years with an agency that was its soul mate for almost seven decades is declaring that its clothing feels good enough to live in.

headline: Math Under Common Core Has Even Parents Stumbling
keywords: ['Tests and Examinations', 'Mathematics', 'Education (K-12)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Homework', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Parents feeling helpless when confronted with first-grade math work sheets are adding to the political debate about whether the Common Core is another way in which Washington is taking over people’s lives.
lead_paragraph: GREENWELL SPRINGS, La. — Rebekah and Kevin Nelams moved to their modest brick home in this suburb of Baton Rouge seven years ago because it has one of the top-performing public school districts in the state. But starting this fall, Ms. Nelams plans to home-school the couple’s four elementary-age children.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Account assignments, miscellaneous news from advertising agencies and more.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: Charlatans, Cranks and Kansas
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'United States Economy', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Corporate Taxes']
abstract: The state’s economy is in terrible shape after huge income-tax cuts — another case of big money selling bad ideas.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago Kansas embarked on a remarkable fiscal experiment: It sharply slashed income taxes without any clear idea of what would replace the lost revenue. Sam Brownback, the governor, proposed the legislation — in percentage terms, the largest tax cut in one year any state has ever enacted — in close consultation with the economist Arthur Laffer. And Mr. Brownback predicted that the cuts would jump-start an economic boom — “Look out, Texas,” he proclaimed.

headline: A Disregarded Request From a Beloved Senator Shakes Up Hawaii’s Primary
keywords: ['Endorsements', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Voting and Voters', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Neil Abercrombie’s decision to defy one of the most popular politicians in Hawaii history has come back to rock the governor and the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: WAIANAE, Hawaii — For over 50 years, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, a Democrat, was the closest thing modern-day Hawaii had to political royalty: He began representing the state in Washington two years before its most famous citizen was even born. As he lay dying in 2012, Mr. Inouye asked the governor, Neil Abercrombie, to appoint Representative Colleen Hanabusa, a protégée and the daughter of a gas station owner here, to fill his seat.

headline: Online Museum for Springsteen
abstract: An online museum displaying more than 300 pieces of Bruce Springsteen memorabilia is to officially open its figurative doors on Monday.
lead_paragraph: An online museum displaying more than 300 pieces of Bruce Springsteen memorabilia is to officially open its figurative doors on Monday. The virtual museum, blindedbythelight.com, is the product of five years of planning, eight years of amassing a collection of thousands of items and more than three decades of adoration for the Boss by the site’s founder, Michael Crane. Plans are to add 30 to 50 items a month to the site, where they will tell a story that fans might not otherwise see, Mr. Crane said by phone on Sunday from Israel. “For a Bruce fan, this gives you insight into your hero and the way he grew up,” he said. Among the items is an eighth-grade report card, above right, featuring mostly low grades, including D’s in composition, physical education and music. The young Springsteen “didn’t have a great time in Catholic school,” Mr. Crane said. “He wasn’t allowed to be who he wanted to be and to express himself.” Mr. Crane said his favorite item is a photo of Mr. Springsteen and his father on a 1972 visit to Mexico. “Bruce has described their relationship as tumultuous,” Mr. Crane said, “so it’s cool to see Bruce as just a kid laughing with his dad.” Admission is $9.99, which allows a month of access to the site, the ability to download a font that replicates Mr. Springsteen’s handwriting style, the use of a ticket and memorabilia exchange, and entry to a monthly raffle. Mr. Springsteen has no formal involvement with the site.

headline: House Hypocrisy on Insider Trading
keywords: ['Insider Trading', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials']
abstract: Lawmakers rebuff an attempt to enforce a law banning insider trading by members of Congress and their aides.
lead_paragraph: It was quite the ballyhooed reform of Capitol Hill ethics — an explicit ban on insider trading by members of Congress and their aides enacted two years ago in a bipartisan wave of approval by the Senate and House.

headline: Medical Boards Draft Plan to Ease Path to Out-of-State and Online Treatment
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Doctors', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Videophones and Videoconferencing', 'States (US)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The plan opened the door to greater use of telemedicine and could alleviate the doctor shortage, a growing problem as millions of people gain insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Officials representing state medical boards across the country have drafted a model law that would make it much easier for doctors licensed in one state to treat patients in other states, whether in person, by videoconference or online.

headline: New Wave of African Writers With an Internationalist Bent
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Novelists with ties to Africa are gaining prominence in the publishing world as they become more cosmopolitan, and America does, too.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, when the young Nigerian writer Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie was struggling to get her first novel, “Purple Hibiscus,” published, an agent told her that things would be easier “if only you were Indian,” because Indian writers were in vogue. Another suggested changing the setting from Nigeria to America. Ms. Adichie didn’t take this as commentary on her work, she said, but on the timidity of the publishing world when it came to unknown writers and unfamiliar cultures, especially African ones.

headline: Pushback on Home Care
keywords: ['Home Health Care', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Minimum Wage', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Editorials']
abstract: A lawsuit against a new wage protection rule is the latest move in a misguided campaign by some states and groups representing home care agencies.
lead_paragraph: The salvos keep coming from opponents of a new federal rule to ensure that home care workers are paid at least the minimum wage and time and a half for overtime. The rule, many years in the making, reverses a misguided policy from 1974 that has long denied home care workers those basic wage protections.

headline: New Rules to Address Campus Rape
abstract: The Department of Education’s guidelines could bring more order to the process and help colleges meet federal requirements on safety.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials have started paying close attention to sexual assault on college campuses. A White House task force last month issued recommendations on how to combat the problem, and this month the Department of Education published draft rules clarifying how universities can meet federal requirements on campus safety.

headline: Ancient Sport Grows, but Not to U.S. Women
abstract: Women’s combat sports have been on a good run in the United States, but sumo wrestling is still waiting to take off.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — Tiffany Tran stands 5 feet 1 inch tall and weighs 166 pounds. She is a vegetarian studying for a master’s in biology. She is also a sumo wrestler.

headline: With Rainbow Neckerchiefs, Celebrating Pride and Progress at Parade
abstract: Boy Scouts in full uniform participated in New York City’s gay pride parade en masse for the first time.
lead_paragraph: The color guard leading the annual Gay Pride March down Fifth Avenue in Manhattan on Sunday carried flags of sky blue, navy blue, red-white-and-blue and rainbow. But, for these marchers, the colors that mattered most were the ones they wore.

headline: Facebook Tinkers With Users’ Emotions in News Feed Experiment, Stirring Outcry
abstract: Last week Facebook revealed that it had manipulated the news feeds of over half a million randomly selected users to change the number of positive and negative posts they saw.
lead_paragraph: To Facebook, we are all lab rats.

headline: Gov. Christie’s Money Trail
abstract: The governor of New Jersey has found yet another questionable way to preserve his reputation as an anti-taxer.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who is toying with the idea of running for president, has yet to show sufficient interest in managing the public’s money in ways that benefit the public. He talks plenty tough, but can he make hard decisions that help ordinary people, even when it might hurt him politically?

headline: Miles From Her Top Competitors, a Young Star Still Outswims Them
abstract: Katie Ledecky lowered her own world records in the 1,500- and 800-meter freestyles at a low-level competition outside Houston.
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md. — The headwaiter at the steakhouse a few miles from Katie Ledecky’s home smiled broadly when Ledecky walked through the door one night last week with her parents and older brother. He asked her if she was dining out to celebrate her two recent world-record-breaking swims.

headline: With a Lunge and a Parry, a Goalkeeper Helps Costa Rica Advance
abstract: Keylor Navas knocked away a shot by Theofanis Gekas to help Costa Rica prevail on penalty kicks after Greece had tied the game in added time.
lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — Not every team can conjure attacks out of thin air with grace and panache. Not every goal is a firecracker that enchants the neutral fan. Not every game can be an instant classic, even if this rollicking World Cup has thus far made it seem so.

headline: New N.S.A. Chief Calls Damage From Snowden Leaks Manageable
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The director of the National Security Agency, Adm. Michael S. Rogers, described the steps the agency is taking to ensure that no one else can download the information taken by Edward J. Snowden, a former defense contractor.
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — The newly installed director of the National Security Agency says that while he has seen some terrorist groups alter their communications to avoid surveillance techniques revealed by Edward J. Snowden, the damage done over all by a year of revelations does not lead him to the conclusion that “the sky is falling.”

headline: G.M. to Set Payouts in Crashes Caused by Flawed Switches
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Reparations']
abstract: Kenneth R. Feinberg, a compensation expert who handled the 9/11 settlements, is to announce the plan for General Motors payouts on Monday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A prominent compensation expert hired by General Motors is scheduled to announce a plan here on Monday to distribute money to victims of accidents caused by the automaker’s defective ignition switch.

headline: Flawed Saudi Response Is Cited in Outbreak of the Middle East Virus MERS
abstract: Cases of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome have more than tripled since the end of 2013, leading health experts to cite grave flaws in the way Saudi health officials have handled the crisis.
lead_paragraph: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — As the virus tore through the city’s largest hospital, jumping from bed to bed and afflicting scores of people, terror filled the wards.

headline: State Department Documents on Blackwater Episode
abstract: Documents related to a 2007 inquiry of Blackwater’s Iraq operations and a State Department investigator’s report that the private security firm’s manager there had threatened to kill him.
lead_paragraph: Documents related to a 2007 inquiry of Blackwater’s Iraq operations and a State Department investigator’s report that the private security firm’s manager there had threatened to kill him.

headline: For Goalkeepers in Brazil, Catching Grief Is Part of the Job
abstract: Long ridiculed with terms such as “chicken man” and “lettuce hands,” Brazilian goalkeepers received a huge boost when Júlio César helped propel his team past Chile and into the World Cup quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — For years, it has gone without saying in Brazil that fathers do not let their children grow up to be goalkeepers.

headline: Before Shooting in Iraq, a Warning on Blackwater
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Defense Contracts', 'Mercenaries and Private Military Contractors', 'Terrorism', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: Not long after the security firm’s top manager in Iraq told a State Department investigator “that he could kill” him, an inquiry was abandoned. Weeks later, the firm’s guards killed 17 civilians in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just weeks before Blackwater guards fatally shot 17 civilians at Baghdad’s Nisour Square in 2007, the State Department began investigating the security contractor’s operations in Iraq. But the inquiry was abandoned after Blackwater’s top manager there issued a threat: “that he could kill” the government’s chief investigator and “no one could or would do anything about it as we were in Iraq,” according to department reports.

headline: A Historic Warship, Reborn as a Tourist Draw, May See Another Revival
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Boats and Boating', 'Museums', 'Cruises', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: A New York sightseeing business plans to refurbish Circle Line X, a former World War II ship that is known for its long service to the city’s tourism industry, into a mini-museum.
lead_paragraph: Not many veterans of World War II are coming out of retirement these days, but the rusty old troop carrier known as Circle Line X may be put back to work soon, just a few blocks from Times Square.

headline: One Son Missing, Another Dead, and 2 Mothers Across a Divide
abstract: The mothers, one Israeli and the other Palestinian, have taken on conspicuous roles in their communities because of their losses.
lead_paragraph: The mothers, one Israeli and the other Palestinian, have taken on conspicuous roles in their communities because of their losses.

headline: After West Bank Kidnapping, 2 Mothers Embody a Divide
abstract: Israel’s security crackdown has raised questions about the asymmetry of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the value of lives on both sides.
lead_paragraph: NOF AYALON, Israel — It was about 4 a.m. on a Friday when the police banged on Rachel Fraenkel’s door in this Jerusalem suburb looking for her 16-year-old son, Naftali, and a friend he studies with at a yeshiva in the West Bank. The night before, Naftali had texted his parents saying he was going to hitchhike back home. They had no idea he had never arrived.

headline: Women as Sumo Warriors

lead_paragraph: American sumo wrestlers of all shapes and backgrounds descended on Jackson Hole, Wyo., for the United States Sumo Championships. The women were a small, but proud, contingent.
