headline: An Adjustment Essential to the Yankees’ Future
abstract: The question of who will replace Derek Jeter is pushed to the background as the Yankees work to help Brian McCann transition to his new place in a new league.
lead_paragraph: Brian McCann made seven All-Star teams in nine seasons with the Atlanta Braves, but he also offered something intangible. He became, in some ways, the soul of his team. To the Yankees, McCann’s talent and character were worth $85 million in free agency.

headline: NASA Launching Satellite to Track Carbon
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Satellites', 'Global Warming', 'Earth', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Carbon Dioxide']
abstract: The Orbiting Carbon Observatory-2 is scheduled to lift off Tuesday with the aim of getting better data on how carbon moves into and out of the atmosphere — a key to understanding climate change.
lead_paragraph: On an average day, some 100 million tons of carbon dioxide is liberated from oil and coal by combustion, wafting into the air. The gas traps heat in the atmosphere, resulting in the gradual warming that has alarmed scientists and much of the public.

headline: Judy Vargas
abstract: Judy Vargas lives in the colonia of Gardendale, Tex., with her grandmother and three young children, whom she supports by cooking at a local restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Judy Vargas lives in the colonia of Gardendale, Tex., with her grandmother and three young children, whom she supports by cooking at a local restaurant.

headline: Netanyahu Says Security Control Is Vital in Any Accord
abstract: Pointing to the rise of Islamic extremism, the Israeli prime minister appeared to toughen his requirements, further dimming the prospects for renewed talks.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declared Sunday in a hard-hitting policy speech here that under any future peace agreement with the Palestinians, Israel would insist on maintaining security control of the West Bank “for a very long time.”

headline: ‘True Blood’ Recap: Jason Had the Best Dream…
abstract: But funny is not the way to describe this episode of “True Blood.”
lead_paragraph: Season 7, Episode 2 Talk about fan service! On Sunday night, “True Blood” opened with its two resident studs, the Viking vamp Eric (Alexander Skarsgard) and the Louisiana lech Jason (Ryan Kwanten), getting it on — shirtless, kissing, dim light, chamber music on the soundtrack. It was as if Cinemax had broken into the HBO satellite feed.

headline: Sore Forearm Keeping Beltran From Field Duty
abstract: Carlos Beltran said on Sunday that tightness in his arm, not inflammation in his elbow that kept him out for 21 games, was preventing him from throwing.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Beltran said before Sunday’s game against the Boston Red Sox that stiffness in his right forearm had been preventing him from throwing.

lead_paragraph: Germany overcame an aggressive Algerian counterattack and broke through for two goals in extra time for a 2-1 victory that sent it into the quarterfinals.

headline: World Cup 2014: France Defeats Nigeria, 2-0

lead_paragraph: France broke a scoreless tie late in the match and ended up with a 2-0 victory over Nigeria. France now heads to Rio, to meet Germany or Algeria in the quarterfinal in the Maracana.

headline: Allen Grossman, a Poet’s Poet and Scholar, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Grossman was typically referred to as a poet’s poet for his brainy and lyrical poems that were proudly high-minded and often written in a voice described as conversationally academic.
lead_paragraph: Allen Grossman, an award-winning poet whose work bridged the Romantic and Modernist traditions, claiming nobility and power for poetry as a tool for both engaging the world and burrowing into the self, died on Friday in Chelsea, Mass. He was 82.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Social activity was measured for the 48 games in World Cup group play from the day before each match through two days after. The first United States game, where it defeated Ghana, generated the most activity the day after, with a score of 155,332.
lead_paragraph: Social activity was measured for the 48 games in World Cup group play from the day before each match through two days after. The first United States game, where it defeated Ghana, generated the most activity the day after, with a score of 155,332.

headline: Boom Meets Bust in Texas: Atop Sea of Oil, Poverty Digs In
keywords: ['Poverty', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Rural Areas', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality', 'Natural Gas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Series']
abstract: A boom has helped produce fortunes for some in Texas, but poverty endures in shantytowns without basic services like water and sewers.
lead_paragraph: GARDENDALE, Tex. — From the window of her tin-roofed trailer, Judy Vargas can glimpse a miraculous world. It is as close as the dust kicked up by the trucks barreling by but seems as distant as Mars.

headline: Amid de Blasio’s Pre-K Push, a Bid to Boost Learning at a Weak Point in the Pipeline
abstract: With prekindergarten classes set to grow under Mayor Bill de Blasio’s ambitious plan, the ad hoc in-home day care providers that serve thousands of city children are getting fresh attention.
lead_paragraph: Mildred Augustin has been providing day care from her home in the Bronx since 2002.

headline: ‘Halt and Catch Fire’ Recap: A Cold Cup of Joe
abstract: The show is getting better, but Joe is still as troublesome as ever.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 5 They got the computer working! Well, some important parts of it, at least. Now they just need to find a screen. For that, they’ve got to figure out a way to stop offending the Japanese. And they also need to get right with their dads, because it turns out that when you’re trying to revolutionize the personal computer industry, daddy issues are a primary concern.

headline: Rent Cuts for Housing Homeless Hit a Snag
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Homeless Persons', 'Evictions']
abstract: The de Blasio administration is working to reduce the high rates it pays to private landlords to house homeless people, but at least one such landlord is threatening to sue the city and evict families if his rent payment is cut.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has long criticized New York City’s use of privately owned apartment buildings to house homeless families, and his administration has, in its first six months, taken steps to reduce the amount that the city pays for these units.

headline: ‘The Leftovers’ Recap: Trying to Explain What Cannot Be Explained
abstract: Tom Perotta’s novel comes to HBO.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 1 “Dogs are just animals, man. They see something like that, and they just snap. All bets are off right there. No more chasing sticks. …They just go primal, man. Same thing’s going to happen to us, it’s just taking longer.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 30, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 30, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “It feels the same to us. The money that they have, we didn’t have it before. And we don’t have it now.”

headline: Michael Brown, 93, Dies; Industrial Musicals Gave Wings to ‘Mockingbird’
abstract: Mr. Brown wrote industrial musicals for American corporations, which were meant to rally employees, and used some of his earnings to support Harper Lee while she wrote “To Kill a Mockingbird.”
lead_paragraph: Michael Brown, a cabaret performer and songwriter known for his sprightly contributions to the industrial musical, an American entertainment genre that literally sang the praises of vacuums and zippers and autos and steel — and who, as an improbable result of this work, bestowed on his friend Harper Lee the wherewithal to write her only novel, “To Kill a Mockingbird” — died on June 11 at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Now Docking Downtown: An Oyster Bar on a Boat
abstract: Grand Banks, whose partners include a co-founder of Diner and Marlow & Sons, will serve fresh seafood and cocktails on a 72-year-old vessel at Hudson River Park's Pier 25 starting Thursday.
lead_paragraph: For Alex Pincus, the question wasn’t whether Manhattan needed a floating oyster bar and mini-maritime museum on a 72-year-old codfish schooner, but rather where to put it. Now, his vision has become reality in the form of Grand Banks, which will begin serving food and drinks Thursday afternoon on a boat docked off Hudson River Park in TriBeCa.

headline: A Cooperative Hub for Emerging Talent Opens in TriBeCa
abstract: Colony, a new exhibition space and collective for emerging and midcareer designers in New York, offers its members a mutually beneficial business model.
lead_paragraph: It’s often said that good design solves a problem. And a year and a half ago, Jean Lin learned that some New York designers had problems of their own. “They had nowhere to show their work in Manhattan,” says Lin, the co-founder of the charitable design organization Reclaim NYC. “They’re not in a showroom like Ralph Pucci, but they’ve grown out of their 450-square-foot bay in Red Hook.” So Lin, along with the marketing consultant Michael Maloney, created Colony, a multipurpose design exhibition space on New York’s Canal Street, which opened to the public last week.

headline: Keeping Your Cool
abstract: Summer heat waves are becoming more frequent and increasingly intense. They put both young and old, the physically active and the sedentary, at risk of a heat-related illness and death.
lead_paragraph: Last year, New York’s first documented heat-related death occurred on July 8, after three consecutive days with temperatures at 90 degrees or above. The victim was a 57-year-old man on Staten Island. The summer before, a record-breaking eight-day heat wave killed four people, three of them with health problems.

headline: Diana McLellan, Gossip Columnist With an Ear to Washington, Dies at 76
abstract: The British-born Mrs. McLellan, who wrote for three Washington papers, gained a devoted readership by skewering the powerful in the nation’s capital.
lead_paragraph: Diana McLellan, a grande dame of Washington gossip who perforated the pretentious, skewered the powerful and sometimes felt honor-bound to keep fact-checkers from coming between her bons mots and her “darlings,” as she called the devoted readers of her syndicated newspaper column, died on Thursday in Easton, Md. She was 76.

headline: Long a Tormentor of the Yankees, Ortiz Adds Yet Another Chapter
abstract: David Ortiz hit a three-run home run in the third inning, the 450th homer of his career, as the Red Sox jumped on the rookie starter Chase Whitley.
lead_paragraph: In the past decade of the Yankees-Red Sox rivalry, few things have endured quite like David Ortiz, the hulking Boston slugger who, even at age 38 and in his 18th major league season, continues to stir up some of his most inimitable qualities against his fiercest rivals.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 A.M. (TCM) TCM REMEMBERS ELI WALLACH This 11-hour marathon pays tribute to Mr. Wallach, who died on Tuesday at 98, through five of his performances, starting with Curtis Bernhardt’s “Kisses for My President” (1964), with Polly Bergen as the first female president, Fred MacMurray as her ego-bruised husband and Mr. Wallach as a rowdy Latin American dictator. Dore Schary’s “Act One” (1963), in which George Hamilton channels the playwright Moss Hart and Mr. Wallach the producer Warren Stone, follows at 11; “How the West Was Won” (1963), John Ford’s epic about three generations of pioneers, with Mr. Wallach as a train robber, at 1 p.m.; John Huston’s “The Misfits” (1961), starring Marilyn Monroe as a newly divorced showgirl, Clark Gable as an aging cowboy and Mr. Wallach as the ranch hand who devises a plan to round up wild mustangs and sell them to a dog food manufacturer, at 3:45; and Elia Kazan’s “Baby Doll” (1956), Mr. Wallach’s first film — and reportedly his favorite — in which he starred alongside Carroll Baker (above with Mr. Wallach) and Karl Malden as a Sicilian cotton-gin owner who seduces the child bride of his rival, at 6.

headline: Her Father Becomes a Citizen
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Almost 50 years after trading Dublin’s lilts for a Manhattan commute, a man made the change official, and then wondered how people would know he was an American.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: ‘Penny Dreadful’ Recap: Did the Finale Surprise?
abstract: A lot happened, but the outcomes were more or less as expected.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 8 Before I begin unpacking everything – and I mean everything – that went down in the Season 1 finale, “Grand Guignol,” a brief clarification/apology: I’m afraid I misinterpreted a fairly central aspect of Vanessa’s two demonic visitors in recent episodes of “Penny Dreadful.” In both instances – explicitly the first time (in all senses of the word) and more obliquely the second time – the encounter is meant to be a figment of Vanessa’s imagination. I spoke of first Sir Malcolm and then Ethan being possessed by this force; this is inaccurate. The reason why she (or whoever) conjured these two particular men was and is a topic worthy of discussion, but only once the facts are straight. I hope they are now, and I’m sorry it took me so long to get there.

headline: Despite Protests, China Official Calls Taiwan Trip a Success
abstract: Zhang Zhijun, the head of China’s Taiwan Affairs Office, cut short meetings on his final day on the island after protesters hit his bodyguards with paint.
lead_paragraph: The highest-level Chinese official to visit Taiwan since the two sides split at the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949 described his trip as a success even as he had to cut short his final day of appearances because of aggressive protests.

headline: Q. and A.: Edmund Malesky on Vietnam and China

lead_paragraph: Edmund J. Malesky, an associate professor of political economy at Duke University, has spent years studying the politics of Vietnam. More recently, he has been working on a governance project involving China. His scholarship on the two countries, both ruled by Communist parties with close ties, has given him a basis for a comparative perspective on the nations’ politics and political economies. In early May, a Chinese state-owned oil company moved an exploratory oil rig into waters off the disputed

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Water Levels on the Rise in the Great Lakes
abstract: Why are water levels of the Great Lakes rising after many years of decreasing?
lead_paragraph: In “Creeping Up on Unsuspecting Shores: The Great Lakes, in a Welcome Turnaround,” Julie Bosman writes about the rising water levels in these bodies of water.

headline: Philips to Combine Lighting Units Into Stand-Alone Company
abstract: The Dutch electronics giant said it was exploring “strategic options” to raise capital for the soon-to-be combined LED and automotive lighting businesses, which together posted sales of 1.4 billion euros, or about $1.9 billion, in 2013.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Philips, the Dutch electronics giant, said on Monday that it would combine its LED and automotive lighting businesses into a stand-alone company and that it was exploring “strategic options” to raise capital from investors for the combined business.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Kim Tingley on the Promise and Problems of Three-Parent I.V.F.

lead_paragraph: Kim Tingley, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about three-parent I.V.F. Her last feature for the magazine was about a Harvard researcher’s attempts to understand suicide.

headline: Photographers on the Front Lines of the Great War
keywords: ['Cameras', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Museums', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Photography', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: A century after the start of World War I, the trail blazed – and lessons learned – by pioneering photojournalists on the front lines still resonate.
lead_paragraph: In 1914, as the outbreak of World War I brought mass slaughter to Europe’s battlefields, photojournalism evolved rapidly in the muddy trenches, where 19th century tactics met 20th century weapons. Machine guns, airplanes, tanks, flamethrowers, poisonous gas and submarines were widely used for the first time against doomed troops that were sent by their generals into frontal attacks that left millions dead.

headline: Former Nokia Chief to Join Perella Weinberg as Advisory Partner
abstract: Jorma Ollila, the chairman of Royal Dutch Shell, will provide counsel to Perella Weinberg and its clients, particularly those in Europe.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Jorma Ollila, formerly chief executive of the Finnish mobile phone maker Nokia, has joined the boutique investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners as an advisory partner.

headline: Transforming China’s Movie Landscape
abstract: Chinese officials painted a picture of an East-West box office battle last weekend, with America seemingly winning with “Transformers” despite pleas to support a Chinese movie, “The Breakup Guru.”
lead_paragraph: Listening to the head of China’s national film authority, it’s as if the Autobots of “Transformers: Age of Extinction,” are locked in battle not with the Decepticons but with Mei Yuangui, the wily main character in a Chinese-produced romantic comedy, “The Breakup Guru.”

headline: Assessing Zac Posen’s and Claudio Del Vecchio’s Ambitious Plans for Brooks Brothers
abstract: The designer wants to concentrate on work wear for women, and the chief executive says he hopes changes will double sales.
lead_paragraph: Zac Posen and Claudio Del Vecchio, the chief executive of Brooks Brothers, are pretty good at keeping secrets — they were in talks for a year before both sides agreed that Mr. Posen would become the women’s wear creative director for the quintessentially American brand, a deal announced on Friday — but now that the news is out, they’re spilling. What do they have planned?

headline: Daily Report: Start-Ups’ Modern Tools Help Small Merchants Compete
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Small Business', 'Start-ups', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: While start-ups like Uber are frequently seen as the enemy of traditional independent merchants, some new tech companies see big opportunities in serving local stores.
lead_paragraph: Operators at KES Dispatch in Mount Kisco, N.Y., keep track of the company’s taxis on a yellow legal pad. They communicate with cars using a two-way radio. Drivers navigate their journeys largely by memory. And in the age of Uber and Lyft, Hiroko Tabuchi reports, the company is desperate to modernize.

headline: China Ends Animal Testing Rule for Some Cosmetics
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'ANIMALS', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Product Tests', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The move was praised by animal rights advocates, who say it is an important step in reducing the use of lab animals in product testing.
lead_paragraph: China has removed a controversial animal test requirement for some types of cosmetics, a move praised by animal rights advocates who hope it signals an end to a practice widely scorned elsewhere.

headline: Feeble Inflation and Lending Persist in Euro Zone
abstract: Consumer prices rose 0.5 percent in the bloc in June, far below the official target, while private sector lending shrank, keeping pressure on the E.C.B.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Dangerously low inflation in the euro zone persists while lending to the private sector continues to shrink, official data showed on Monday, problems that will confront European Central Bank officials as they meet this week to plot monetary policy.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on New Jersey schemes, a meticulous trial, a viral outbreak and Russian profanity.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times editorial board writes that Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey “has yet to show sufficient interest in managing the public’s money in ways that benefit the public.” “He has used dubious strategies to avoid raising taxes,” the board adds, citing multiple instances that have hurt the state. A recent one involves the diversion of funds from a Port Authority of New York and New Jersey Hudson River tunnel project to rebuild the deteriorating Pulaski Skyway; it’s being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the office of the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus Vance Jr. The board says, “Mr. Christie has presented himself nationally as a straight-talking politician who can work with Democrats and attract voters from both parties. That image is taking a beating.”

headline: Vanessa Friedman on Fashion, Politics and Money
abstract: The new fashion director and chief fashion critic for The Times and International New York Times tells us what readers can expect from her in the Styles section.
lead_paragraph: Vanessa Friedman, formerly The Financial Times’s first fashion editor, started as fashion director and chief fashion critic for The Times and The International New York Times one month ago. She told us a bit about how she started writing about fashion and what readers can expect from her in the Styles section.

headline: When a 20-Year Employee Becomes a Problem
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Small Business']
abstract: In the last post of a five-part series, a business owner talks about how he wrestled with a difficult decision — whether to fire an employee who had been extremely productive.
lead_paragraph: This is the last of a series of posts that started with an explanation of why I decided to reinstitute employee reviews.

headline: How Hillary Clinton Is Like John McCain
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Being out of the partisan fray is good for your image. When normal politics resume, poll numbers quickly return to earth.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s artificially inflated poll numbers have made her seem like an especially strong presidential candidate, but the Clinton bubble is quickly coming to an end.

headline: The Lost Emails of the I.R.S. Point to a Wider Problem
abstract: Federal agencies are hampered by outdated computing infrastructure and by regulations that won’t require modern techniques until the end of 2016 at the earliest.
lead_paragraph: During last Monday’s congressional hearing into the Internal Revenue Service’s loss of emails, Blake Farenthold, a Texas Republican, offered what on first glance seemed a simple solution to archiving agency email: “I went on Amazon and found you could buy a terabyte hard drive for $59. Buy two of them, so $120.”

headline: China’s Antigraft Push Snares an Ex-General
abstract: In the most far-reaching public move so far in President Xi Jinping’s drive against corruption, the Communist Party leadership expelled a retired military commander.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In the most far-reaching public move so far in President Xi Jinping’s drive against corruption in China, the Communist Party on Monday expelled a retired military commander, Xu Caihou, and handed him over for an investigation into accusations that he took huge bribes in return for military promotions.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Shift on Foreclosed Homes
abstract: Bulk investors in foreclosed homes are looking to sell. | Morgan Stanley’s chief has focused on safer ways of making money. | A settlement is expected with BNP Paribas over sanctions violations. | Prosecutors seek a stiff sentence for Mathew Martoma for insider trading.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, buying foreclosed homes to rent out was the sure-thing trade for investment firms backed by money from private equity companies, hedge funds and pension systems, Matthew Goldstein writes in DealBook. But now, with the supply of cheap foreclosed homes dwindling, some early investors are looking to cash out a bit by flipping homes to competitors.

headline: 1964: France to Curb Vacation Costs
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The French government wants to hold down the cost of a vacation in France in 1964.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French Finance Ministry launched a campaign today [June 30] to hold down the cost of vacation in France. “Operation Vacation,” which begins tomorrow and ends Sept. 15, involves a program of vigilance over the cost of hotels, restaurants, tours, amusements and retail shops in 20 of France’s 90 departments most frequented by vacationers and tourists. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 1, 1964.

headline: What the Reduction in Tonsillectomies Teaches Us About Medicine
abstract: Strict guidelines for how to treat certain conditions in certain patients, and allowing physicians to use their judgment, both have a role.
lead_paragraph: When I was a child, one of my favorite books was “Curious George Goes to the Hospital.” It told the story of a little monkey who swallowed a puzzle piece, needed an operation to get it out, and got ice cream to soothe his sore throat afterward. It seemed at the time to be a thinly veiled story about tonsillectomy. One of the driving forces behind the publication, I’m sure, was that so many children had their tonsils removed that it was helpful to have a book explaining to children how such a hospitalization would go.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: An actor in a United Airlines commercial looks familiar.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: Bill Harvey, a founder of the research and analytics unit at TiVo, wins the Erwin Ephron Demystification Award.
lead_paragraph: Brand Lab, Minneapolis, hired an employee and promoted another. Brian Gioielli joins as development director; he had most recently been director for major and alumni giving at the Minneapolis College of Art and Design. And Monica Mason, outreach director, becomes program director.

headline: Questions and Answers on the Contraceptives Case
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Freedom of Religion']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday is expected to rule on a pair of challenges to a part of President Obama’s health care law that requires many employers to provide insurance coverage for contraceptives. Here is a look at the parties, the lawyers and the issues in the case.

headline: Andy Coulson to Face Retrial in Royal Phone Hacking Case
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: A jury failed to reach a verdict last week on charges that the former tabloid editor and spokesman for Prime Minister David Cameron illegally obtained royal telephone directories.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prosecutors said Monday that they would seek a retrial for Andy Coulson, a former spokesman for Prime Minister David Cameron who once edited Rupert Murdoch’s best-selling tabloid in Britain, on charges of illegally acquiring royal telephone directories from police officers.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Contraceptives Mandate for Some Corporations
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Corporations', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 that family-owned corporations cannot be required under the Affordable Care Act to pay for insurance coverage for contraception.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that requiring family-owned corporations to pay for insurance coverage for contraception under the Affordable Care Act violated a federal law protecting religious freedom. It was, a dissent said, “a decision of startling breadth.”

headline: What’s News in Washington: Supreme Court Ends Its Term
abstract: A holiday-shortened week is set for a busy start, with the Supreme Court set to end its term Monday with a ruling on whether for-profit corporations can decline to provide insurance coverage for contraception on religious grounds.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning from Washington.

headline: PPG to Buy Mexican Paint Maker Consorcio Comex for $2.3 Billion

lead_paragraph: The Mexican paint maker Consorcio Comex has agreed to sell itself to PPG Industries, just months after an earlier sale agreement fell apart.

headline: I Think About Divorce a Lot, but Not Because I Want One
abstract: I think a lot about divorce. Not because I want one, but because I want to avoid getting one.
lead_paragraph: I was driving home while listening to “Older Americans’ Breakups Are Causing A ‘Graying’ Divorce Trend” on NPR. A man was interviewed who left his wife after 34 years. When asked why he left, he said, “The best thing in common that my ex-wife and I had was raising kids.” When their two sons grew up, he said, “we just didn’t have enough activities, passions, interests that were in common. And when the boys were gone, that just became more and more — to me — obvious.” The story gave an alarming statistic: “Americans over 50 are twice as likely to get divorced as people of that age were 20 years ago.”

headline: Pakistani Forces Begin Assault on Militant Strongholds
abstract: After two weeks of air and artillery strikes during which over 500,000 people fled the area, soldiers moved into a town in North Waziristan.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For a decade now, the tribal town of Miram Shah in North Waziristan has been a slow-burning embarrassment to the Pakistani military.

headline: Toshiba and GDF Suez Push Ahead on British Nuclear Plant
abstract: Plans for the facility, to be located in northwest England, buck the global trend away from nuclear power after the Fukushima disaster in 2011.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Toshiba, the Japanese industrial giant, and the French utility GDF Suez have announced plans for moving ahead with a new British nuclear power station, adding momentum to the country’s atomic energy program.

headline: Highlights from the Supreme Court’s Decision in Hobby Lobby Case
abstract: The Supreme Court is expected to rule Monday on whether for-profit corporations may advance claims based on religious freedom. The decision should come shortly after 10 a.m., concluding the court’s term.

headline: Merlin Properties of Spain Slips in Trading Debut
abstract: Merlin, which was formed in March, priced its initial public offering of 125 million shares at 10 euros a share last week, valuing the company at about $1.67 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Shares of Merlin Properties Socimi, a Spanish real estate trust, traded down slightly on their debut in Spain on Monday.

headline: As Recalls Expand, G.M. Offers Plan for Victims of Faulty Ignition Switch
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Reparations']
abstract: After years of delay, the automaker is moving rapidly to try to handle death and injury claims from accidents caused by a faulty ignition switch.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — General Motors on Monday became consumed once again by the safety crisis it cannot seem to shake, announcing the recall of 8.4 million more vehicles worldwide — most of them for an ignition defect similar to the flaw that the company failed to disclose in other models for more than a decade.

headline: A Vintage-Style Model Designed in Honor of a Fallen WWI Hero
abstract: Bell & Ross has created a timepiece inspired by the legacy of Georges Guynemer, complete with the emblem of the French aviator’s squadron.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the photographer Rob Kulisek captures a timepiece from Bell & Ross.

headline: 1939: Reporter Doesn’t Expect War
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A correspondent argues Germany hasn’t enough raw materials to wage war in 1939.
lead_paragraph: Cornelius Vanderbilt Jr., Liberty magazine’s roving correspondent, returned to Paris from Rome yesterday after a month’s flying survey of Poland, Germany, Czecho-Slovakia, Hungary and other European trouble zones. “I’ll bet my shirt there’ll be no war,” said Mr. Vanderbilt, on his arrival last night at the Hotel Crillon. “Germany hasn’t enough wheat, oil, steel and other raw materials to wage a war successfully.” Mr. Vanderbilt said Germany “is in for a partial, if not a total crop failure in its bread basket.” As for the raw material situation, Mr. Vanderbilt said German economists estimate the Reich needs 20,000,000 tons of steel annually, but can count on only 7,000,000 tons. — New York Herald Tribune, July 1, 1939.

headline: On the Next Docket: How the First Amendment Applies to Social Media
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Social Media', 'Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Constitutional Amendments', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: A man says the violent rap lyrics he posted on social media were art, but he was locked up for threatening his ex-wife. The Supreme Court will weigh in next term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just four years ago, the Supreme Court issued a hesitant and muddled decision in a privacy case, saying it was best to move slowly when ruling on an “emerging technology before its role in society has become clear.”

headline: Secrecy of Dark Pools Can Blur Both Ways
abstract: A lack of transparency for dark pools is almost sure to invite abuses, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: It should not come as any great surprise that a brokerage firm, like the proverbial used-car salesman, would take a few liberties with the truth while trying to sell something. But the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, has taken on Barclays by filing a civil suit related to the marketing of its dark pool trading platform, which the bank portrayed as safe for investors when it let plenty of sharks swim in the deep end.

headline: Oldies But Goodies
abstract: There’s nothing wrong with long-established truths.
lead_paragraph: Ah — so we learn that Ezra Klein’s Vox is under attack — as is the current Democratic agenda — because it’s “tired”, recycling ideas from the 60s and even earlier.

abstract: A century after the start of World War I, the trail blazed – and lessons learned – by pioneering photojournalists on the front lines still resonate..
lead_paragraph: A century after the start of World War I, the trail blazed – and lessons learned – by pioneering photojournalists on the front lines still resonate..

lead_paragraph: The activist investor Nelson Peltz has built up a stake of nearly 2.5 percent in Bank of New York Mellon.

headline: Supreme Court Ruling on Union Fees Is a Limited Blow to Labor
abstract: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. said there was a type of government worker — a partial public employee — who could choose not to pay union fees.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court dealt a limited blow to organized labor on Monday by ruling that some government employees did not have to pay any fees to the unions representing them. But the court declined to strike down a decades-old precedent that required many public sector workers to pay union fees. Writing for the 5-to-4 majority, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. concluded that there was a category of government employees — a partial public employee — who can opt out of joining a union and not be required to contribute union fees.

headline: How Music May Make Babies Team Players
abstract: Researchers found that toddlers who were bounced to the beat of a song tended to be more helpful.
lead_paragraph: Moving with a partner to the musical beat may make people more cooperative — even babies as young as 14 months.

headline: For Hotel Guests, a Key and an Airport Lounge
abstract: Airport lounges have long been a way for airlines to offer exclusive waiting areas for elite-class travelers; now a few hotels are entering the game.
lead_paragraph: Airport lounges have long been a way for airlines to offer exclusive waiting areas for elite-class travelers; now a few hotels are entering the game.

headline: France vs. Nigeria: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: France broke a scoreless tie late in the match and ended up with a 2-0 victory over Nigeria. France now heads to Rio, to meet Germany or Algeria in the quarterfinal in the Maracana.
lead_paragraph: France failed to score against Ecuador in its last match, but had sent out a B team. Patrice Evra, Mathieu Debuchy and Yohan Cabaye, part of the team that scored eight goals in its first two games, should all return. Nigeria advanced at the expense of Bosnia and Iran, but steps up in class here.

headline: Police Accuse Queens Man of Strangling His Son, 8

lead_paragraph: The man called 911 shortly after 10 p.m. on Sunday with a disturbing message: His wife had left him, and now he believed that he and his 8-year-old son were better off dead.

keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Futures and Options Trading', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Visas', 'World War II (1939-45)']

headline: Bolshoi Director Back at Work After Hospitalization
abstract: Sergei Filin, who was injured in an acid attack in January 2013, is back at work after being hospitalized for an allergic reaction.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sergei Filin, the Bolshoi Ballet director who suffered burns and a loss of vision in an acid attack in January 2013, is back at work after being hospitalized for an allergic reaction that led him to be put in intensive care on Friday.  The Russian news agency Interfax reported on Sunday that Mr. Filin had been released from the Sklifosovsky Research Institute. George Golukhov, the head of the Moscow Department of Health, was quoted as saying his condition was “normal.”

headline: Supreme Court Declines Case Contesting Ban on Gay ‘Conversion Therapy’
abstract: The court’s action let stand a federal appeals court ruling that said California had an interest in banning professional treatments it considered harmful.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court declined on Monday to hear a challenge to a California law that bans “conversion therapy” aimed at changing the sexual orientation of gay and lesbian minors.

headline: New York Summer Stories: In 1887, Mosquitoes by Myriads
abstract: This week, The New York Times will share stories of city summers from the archive. We’ll start with an article that might not pass muster today.
lead_paragraph: It’s hot. It smells. The parks are crowded and so is Long Beach.

headline: We’re Moving
abstract: India Ink will be moving to the World page of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: From now on, you will find us at a new address: nytimes.com/world. We will continue to produce web-only India Ink sketches, analyses, narratives and news stories, but they will appear on the World page, along with the rest of the newspaper’s coverage.

headline: A Little Bit of Realism Can Result in a Lot More Happiness
abstract: Tempering expectations with reality can forestall much disappointment, a financial planner writes.
lead_paragraph: Expectations are funny things. When we start to expect something, we also start to count on it. Once we start counting on something to happen, we start to make plans. Then, if we aren’t careful, we even start to act as if it’s already a reality. In our minds it becomes something that’s guaranteed to happen.

headline: More Bodies Pulled From Collapsed Building in India
abstract: Negligence charges have been filed against the builders, architect and structural engineer over the collapse in the southern city of Chennai.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The deaths from the collapse of a 12-story building in the southern Indian city of Chennai rose to 19 on Monday even as some of those trapped were pulled out alive through heavy rains.

headline: A Ravenous Beetle, the Science of Good Fortune and Disco Clams
abstract: How tiny emerald ash borers may threaten a vast ecosystem; the psychology behind our belief in winning streaks; scientists discover the secret behind a clam’s brilliant undersea light show.
lead_paragraph: How tiny emerald ash borers may threaten a vast ecosystem; the psychology behind our belief in winning streaks; scientists discover the secret behind a clam’s brilliant undersea light show.

headline: New York Towns Can Prohibit Fracking, State’s Top Court Rules
abstract: The Court of Appeals affirmed a lower-court ruling, saying that local zoning ordinances may be used to ban the gas drilling process.
lead_paragraph: In a decision with far-reaching implications for the future of natural gas drilling in New York State, its highest court ruled on Monday that towns can use zoning ordinances to ban hydraulic fracturing, the controversial extraction method known as fracking.

headline: The Perils of Too Much Happy Talk
abstract: A new study shows that while parents say they want their children to be caring, they may be sending the message that personal happiness matters more. And this could be hurting kids, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: Most parents want their kids to be happy. But a new study suggests that too much emphasis on happiness might be teaching kids that caring for other people is secondary. And this could actually make kids less happy.

headline: Neil Young and Crazy Horse to Tour With a Substitute Bassist

lead_paragraph: Just as Neil Young was preparing to tour Europe with his occasional backing band, the often raggedly glorious Crazy Horse, the band’s bassist, Billy Talbot, suffered what a spokesman for Reprise Records described in a statement as “a mild stroke.”

headline: Older People Often Overtreated for Diabetes, Study Suggests
abstract: Calculating how much medication an older patient should get and on what schedule is often complicated by erratic meals, vision loss, depression and dementia.
lead_paragraph: Most people with diabetes are treated with drugs (notably metformin) that don’t put them at risk of unusually low blood sugar, or hypoglycemia, a potentially dangerous side effect. But as patients age and develop other chronic medical conditions, it becomes more difficult for them to tolerate these medications.

headline: Kidd’s Stunt Gives Nets a Chance to Upgrade

headline: Netherlands’ Robben Absolved of Wrongdoing

lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil — FIFA said it would not open disciplinary proceedings against the Netherlands forward Arjen Robben, who admitted to diving in Sunday’s victory over Mexico.

headline: Orecchiette With Fresh and Dried Beans and Tomatoes
abstract: Once the beans are done, this pasta dish takes only 15 minutes.
lead_paragraph: Orecchiette is a great pasta to use with beans, which lodge in the hollows of the little ears. I used lush Good Mother Stallard beans, an heirloom bean that I ordered from Rancho Gordo for this dish, but you can substitute supermarket pinto or borlottis. Cook them simply and use some of the broth for the sauce. If you have marinara sauce on hand you can use that; otherwise take advantage of the tomatoes arriving in farmers’ markets and your garden, and chop up a few of them. No need to cook them if you don’t want to.

lead_paragraph: Isabella Boylston, who has danced in “Giselle,” “La Bayadère,” and “Swan Lake” with American Ballet Theater this season, is taking on a new role with the company: principal dancer.

headline: Ken Watanabe Will Star Opposite Kelli O’Hara in ‘The King and I’
abstract: The Lincoln Center Theater production, which would be Mr. Watanabe’s American stage debut, is scheduled to open April 16 at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.
lead_paragraph: Five-time Tony nominee Kelli O’Hara (“The Bridges of Madison County”) and the Japanese film star Ken Watanabe (an Oscar nominee for “The Last Samurai”) will play Anna and the King of Siam in the Lincoln Center Theater production of the Rodgers and Hammerstein classic, “The King and I.” The theater on Monday announced those and other details on the revival, which is scheduled to begin previews March 12, 2015, and opens April 16, 2015, at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

headline: Monday Quandary: Nothing Left at the End of the Day

headline: Between the Lines of the Contraception Decision

lead_paragraph: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., writing for the court, declared that family-owned corporations like Hobby Lobby cannot be forced to pay for insurance coverage for contraception for employees over their religious objections.

headline: The Courts and the Changing Culture War
abstract: The Hobby Lobby case, the courts, and the right-left role reversal.
lead_paragraph: For a generation or more, the lines of debate around religious liberty and religion in the public square were relatively clear. As with other culture war issues, religious conservatives tended to be majoritarians and small-d democrats, supporting the rights of legislatures and town councils and school boards to make decisions about issues ranging from creches on greens to school prayer to the disbursement of education dollars to religious schools without interference from the judicial branch. And there was an assumption among many observers — and not only on the religious right — that on matters related to believers’ involvement in civic life, the courts were a kind of vanguard force for secularism, whose efforts would tend to collide with public sentiment and lead to conflict with the democratic branches of government.

headline: Blast Kills 2 Police Officers Near Presidential Palace in Cairo
abstract: The officers were trying to defuse explosive devices planted outside the palace.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Two police officers were killed Monday in Cairo while trying to defuse explosive devices planted outside Egypt’s presidential palace, the Interior Ministry said.

headline: ScienceTake | Navigating Air and Water
abstract: For flying and swimming creatures obstructions can be something to avoid, or helpful reference points.
lead_paragraph: For flying and swimming creatures obstructions can be something to avoid, or helpful reference points.

headline: Video: How to Draw a Phish Song
abstract: Mike Hamad, a music writer, creates impressionistic diagrams charting the dynamics within a song. It all started with Phish.
lead_paragraph: When you’re listening to a great piece of music, what are you imagining?

headline: China Sentences 113 to Prison in Xinjiang Region
abstract: Courts in the western region of Xinjiang sentenced the defendants for a wide range of crimes, including organizing and taking part in terrorist organizations, state media reported.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Courts in the Kashgar area of the western Chinese region of Xinjiang have sentenced 113 people to prison terms for a wide range of crimes, including organizing and taking part in terrorist organizations, according to a state media report from Xinjiang.

headline: How Bumblebees and Zebra Fish Navigate Their Worlds
abstract: A study compared how two species in different mediums, air and water, reacted to apparent obstacles as they were moving.
lead_paragraph: All moving animals do their best to avoid running into things. And most living things follow a tried and true strategy — Watch where you’re going!

headline: The Political Repercussions of the Hobby Lobby Decision
abstract: This was a political decision and it is proper for Democrats to use it as a weapon in the midterm election campaign.
lead_paragraph: Normally it’s not a good idea to jump right into the political implications of a major Supreme Court decision like Hobby Lobby, but in this case there’s no point in waiting. This was a political decision and it is absolutely proper for Democrats to use it as a weapon in the midterm election campaign.

headline: The Who to Tour for 50th Anniversary
abstract: The group will tour the British Isles in the fall, with future dates to be announced.
lead_paragraph: You’ve heard this before: the Who’s next tour, which will begin in December and stretch into 2015, will definitely, absolutely, positively be the band’s last. Pete Townshend, the band’s guitarist and composer, said as much in interviews last October, although only a few days later, his colleague Roger Daltrey – the group’s singer and only other surviving original member – told Rolling Stone that after the 2015 tour, the Who might record some new music and perhaps play occasional concerts, maybe in the context of a theater residency.

headline: Americans Are Shut Out From Final 16s at Wimbledon
abstract: The withdrawal of Madison Keys and the defeat of John Isner on Monday ensured that the Round of 16 at Wimbledon will have no American for the first time since 1911.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — With one felled by an uncooperative leg and another by a booming serve, two Americans exited Wimbledon on Monday and help set another low point in recent American tennis history.

headline: Beyond Rangel, Harlem Wrestles With Its Identity
abstract: The primary campaign of Representative Charles B. Rangel offered a look at a neighborhood that is very much in flux.
lead_paragraph: On the streets of Harlem the weekend before the Democratic primary for his congressional seat, Representative Charles B. Rangel and his closest opponent, a Dominican-born state senator, Adriano D. Espaillat, carried on an age-old campaign tradition, snaking along their routes in dueling caravans, blasting songs like “Ain’t No Stoppin’ Us Now” and “I Believe I Can Fly” from the loudspeakers of their campaign trucks.

headline: How Hobby Lobby Ruling Could Limit Access to Birth Control
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The Supreme Court ruling gives weight to the argument that morning-after pills and intrauterine devices are more like abortion than contraception.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruling in the Hobby Lobby case raises at least two questions: How will it affect access to contraception, and what do the drugs and devices the company objected to on religious grounds actually do?

headline: Leprosy, Still Claiming Victims
abstract: New research suggests that the leprosy parasite is a paradox encapsulated — at once rugged and feeble, exacting and inept.
lead_paragraph: Throughout his adolescence, José Ramirez Jr., now a clinical social worker in Houston, had a shifting array of bewildering symptoms.

headline: Obama Says He’ll Order Action to Aid Immigrants
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama said he would act to move resources away from the interior of the country in the face of Republican refusals to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Monday he would use his executive power to make potentially sweeping changes to the nation’s immigration system without Congress, acknowledging the death of his more than yearlong effort to enact compromise legislation granting legal status to 11 million immigrants here illegally.

headline: Insurer Warns Some Pooled Pensions Are Beyond Recovery
abstract: More than a million people with federally insured pensions risk losing them in a few years, a government study said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: More than a million people risk losing their federally insured pensions in just a few years despite recent stock market gains and a strengthening economy, a new government study said on Monday.

headline: German Chemical Company’s Curious Goal
abstract: Evonik is buying a 9 percent stake in the soccer team Borussia Dortmund, emulating Adidas, Audi, Allianz and Bayern Munich. But the potential benefits of its deal are hazy at best, writes Olaf Storbeck of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: A $400 million tie-up between the specialty chemical maker Evonik Industries and the German soccer team Borussia Dortmund has few merits for the company’s shareholders. Evonik, Germany’s third-largest chemical company, hopes that the alliance with the club will turn its brand into a global household name. The snag is that Evonik doesn’t do any business with end users.

headline: In Recall Blitz, G.M. Risks Its Reputation
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The automaker said 8.4 million vehicles worldwide were being recalled, bringing its total for the year to more than 29 million.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The deeper General Motors digs into its vast portfolio of vehicles, the more safety problems it finds.

headline: Court Out of Step With Public on Contraception Coverage
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A recent poll found a slim majority of people in the United States think employers should have to include birth control in their health insurance.
lead_paragraph: The ruling by the Supreme Court on Monday in the Hobby Lobby case runs counter to general public opinion, a recent poll shows.

headline: A Malted Milk Crawl in New York
abstract: The old-fashioned flavoring is like a sweet version of umami.
lead_paragraph: Malt is like a sweet version of umami, the so-called fifth flavor that pops up in ingredients like soy, mushrooms and monosodium glutamate. Just as umami makes savory flavors come alive, malt does the same for sweet. It’s an old-fashioned flavor, a bit tough to describe, but a little nutty, buttery, even earthy.

headline: Are Your Food and Clothes Produced With Slave Labor?
abstract: It’s hard for consumers to know whether a seafood supplier in Thailand or a clothes manufacturer in Bangladesh built its business on the backs of indentured or otherwise abused workers.
lead_paragraph: All consumers should be outraged by the idea that they’ve bought something – from shrimp to shirts – produced with slave labor. Yet as numerous reports have documented, that is a serious and growing possibility, particularly in the United States, the world’s biggest importer.

headline: France Gives Cold Shoulder to Amazon
abstract: The French Senate has passed legislation, nicknamed the anti-Amazon law, designed to protect local bookstores.
lead_paragraph: In a backlash against the retail giant Amazon, France is preparing to impose new restrictions this summer that would bar online merchants from offering free shipments of discounted books.

headline: French Start Slow and Finish Strong
abstract: Paul Pogba’s header in the 79th minute and an own goal by Joseph Yobo in stoppage time propelled France to a victory over Nigeria on Monday.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — In 2010, France was the shame of the World Cup, a team in open revolt against its coach, Raymond Domenech, and it failed to win a game. But four years later, under a new coach, France is among the final eight teams in the tournament, and this time, it has played four games without losing.

headline: Germany vs. Algeria: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Germany overcame an aggressive Algerian counterattack and broke through for two goals in extra time for a 2-1 victory that sent it into the quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: Will Algeria’s dogged play be enough to slow the relentless passing attack of Germany?

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Spring/Summer 2015 Paris Shows
abstract: A peek at what some of the peacocks in Paris were wearing.
lead_paragraph: A peek at what some of the peacocks in Paris were wearing.

headline: Hostile Bid for Club Med Threatens Existing Deal
abstract: Andrea C. Bonomi, an Italian private equity investor, announced a hostile offer, threatening a deal agreed to last year.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — An Italian private equity investor on Monday announced a hostile offer for Club Méditerranée, threatening a deal agreed to last year in which the vacation resort group would be acquired by French and Chinese investors.

headline: Find Another Name, Belgian Court Tells DSK Sex Club
abstract: A legal victory for the man known widely by those initials: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the French politician and former head of the International Monetary Fund.
lead_paragraph: TOURNAI, Belgium — A court in this southwestern Belgian town on Monday ordered a newly opened sex club called the DSK to change its name. The ruling was another legal victory for the man known widely by those initials: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the French politician and former head of the International Monetary Fund who faced charges, later dropped, of sexually assaulting a hotel housekeeper in New York in 2011.

headline: You Say Soft, I Say Serve
abstract: Somewhere between the re-emergent frozen yogurt and artisanal ice creams, there is soft serve, a staple that is due our love.
lead_paragraph: A few days a week at my office, we conduct something known as the 4 p.m. shame spiral. A small group of us makes a discreet exit from our building to the fro-yo joint across the street, where we pile all manner of cereal and macerated fruit over an overly generous portion of frozen yogurt that has oozed from a giant machine.

headline: Striker Vows His Biting Days Are Over
abstract: After initially denying that he had bitten Italy’s Giorgio Chiellini, Luis Suárez of Uruguay admitted he had and apologized via Twitter on Monday.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Uruguay striker Luis Suárez has issued a public apology for biting an opponent in a World Cup match last week, his third on-field biting incident since 2010, and pledged that there will “never again” be a similar incident.

headline: Movie Aliens, Scary and Cute
abstract: Two new science-fiction movies, “Earth to Echo” and “The Signal,” take different approaches to the question of what else might be out there.
lead_paragraph: When I was a kid, the scariest movie I never saw was “Invaders From Mars,” which recounts a sneak alien incursion through the eyes of a boy. It came out in 1953, when my own life revolved around the baseball field the dads in the neighborhood had built in the vacant lot across the street.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Marquez Makes It Eight in a Row
abstract: With eight out of eight MotoGP races won this season, Marquez dominates; Simon Pagenaud won the IndyCar finale on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Marc Marquez continued his extraordinary 2014 season on Saturday with his eighth victory in eight races in the MotoGP grand prix at TT Circuit Assen in the Netherlands. Marquez, riding a Honda, battled the whole race against rainy weather and a surprising challenge from Andrea Dovizioso, a rider for Ducati. Various mistakes and pits stops for bike changes kept Marquez from securing the lead until the 16th of 26 laps around the track. His win streak duplicates a feat last accomplished by Giacomo Agostini in 1971.

headline: Facebook Says It’s Sorry. We’ve Heard That Before.
abstract: Facebook apologized for its study of how people’s emotions are affected by social media posts. And it’s not the first mea culpa for the company.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, being wrong on the Internet means having to say you’re sorry.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | June 24-June 30, 2014
abstract: Iraq, the World Cup, the Supreme Court and Facebook: How well did you follow the news this week?
lead_paragraph: Iraq, the World Cup, the Supreme Court and Facebook: How well did you follow the news this week?

headline: BNP Paribas Admits Guilt and Agrees to Pay $8.9 Billion Fine to U.S.
abstract: Authorities announced a criminal case against France’s biggest bank for transferring money on behalf of countries blacklisted by the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:07 p.m. | After months of heated negotiations, state and federal authorities on Monday announced a criminal case against BNP Paribas, taking aim at France’s biggest bank for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States.

headline: Israeli Reaction to Discovery of Bodies
abstract: Israeli citizens reacted after the bodies of three missing teenagers in the occupied West Bank were found Monday after a nearly three-week search.
lead_paragraph: Israeli citizens reacted after the bodies of three missing teenagers in the occupied West Bank were found Monday after a nearly three-week search.

headline: After the Trees Disappear
abstract: The emerald ash borer is devastating trees from Minnesota to New York, and there is little scientists can do but study what effect the trees’ extinction will have on the ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: This past winter was the coldest Detroit had experienced in 36 years. Across the upper Midwest, cities shivered, and more than 90 percent of the surface area of the Great Lakes froze solid.

headline: Photo Diary | A Weekend of Art and Community in the Rockaways
abstract: Scenes from the Rockaway arts festival diary of Dustin Aksland.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Rockaway arts festival diary of Dustin Aksland.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Iraq, India, Ukraine and South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Iraq, India, Ukraine and South Africa.

headline: Inside Mark Sanford’s Man Cave
abstract: As part of his spiritual convalescence after his 2009 political scandal, Mark Sanford built a single-room cabin with his sons, on the eastern edge of his family’s 3,000-acre plantation in the South Carolinian coastal county of Beaufort. He offered us a look inside.
lead_paragraph: Mark Sanford finished out the two years of his governor’s term after news broke in 2009 that he left his state for five days for an assignation with his mistress, Maria Belen Chapur — not for a hike of the Appalachian Trail, as he initially said. With his political career practically dead when he left office, he retreated to his family’s 3,000-acre plantation in the South Carolinian coastal county of Beaufort. As part of a spiritual convalescence there, he built a single-room cabin with his sons, on the eastern edge of the property. He took me on a late-night tour there in March, while I was interviewing him for my article about his political recovery in last Sunday’s magazine. ‘‘It doesn’t look like much, but it was pretty hard,’’ Sanford told me. ‘‘It’s not an advanced building by any stretch of the imagination.’’ Inside, the cabin is packed with items from Sanford’s political rise and fall and his family life. I asked him about some of the items.

headline: Falling for the Photo in Staten Island
abstract: Fifty years ago, a daring and ambitious young photographer met his match between the towers of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, a daring and ambitious young photographer met his match between the towers of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.

headline: G.M. Internal Investigation Report
abstract: The results of an investigation overseen by Anton R. Valukas, a former United States attorney, into the company’s handling of a defective ignition switch.
lead_paragraph: The results of an investigation overseen by Anton R. Valukas, a former United States attorney, into the company’s handling of a defective ignition switch.

headline: Is It Better to Buy or Rent?
abstract: The answer to the question depends on many factors. Compare the costs of buying and renting equivalent homes.
lead_paragraph: The answer to the question depends on many factors. Compare the costs of buying and renting equivalent homes.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: At Morgenstern’s Finest, a Swirl of Innovation
abstract: Nicholas Morgenstern could become to ice cream what Jim Lahey of Sullivan Street Bakery is to bread: a Mr. Wizard perfectionist who never stops tinkering.
lead_paragraph: Despite the old-fashioned charms of its Delft-blue paint job, the inspiration for Nicholas Morgenstern’s new ice cream parlor on the Lower East Side — where the whipped cream for $13 salted caramel pretzel sundaes is made à la minute — isn’t rooted in nostalgia.

headline: Mental Health and the Pistorius Trial
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Prostheses']
abstract: Although Oscar Pistorius was found not to have been mentally ill when he killed his girlfriend, the issue of his mental health will most likely persist at his murder trial.
lead_paragraph: Although Oscar Pistorius was found not to have been mentally ill when he killed his girlfriend, the issue of his mental health will most likely persist at his murder trial.

headline: A Very Quiet Opening Week for ‘Holler if Ya Hear Me’
abstract: The new Broadway musical based on the lyrics and life of the rapper Tupac Shakur was the lowest-grossing show on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: “Holler if Ya Hear Me,” the new Broadway musical inspired by the lyrics and life of the rapper Tupac Shakur, had little to shout about at the box office in its first full week of post-opening performances.

headline: Small Town Officials Fight Fracking…. and Win
abstract: A New York State court ruled that communities may ban the industrial drilling process.
lead_paragraph: The hydraulic fracturing debate in New York State has been so intense that Gov. Andrew Cuomo imposed a moratorium two years ago to study the issue.

headline: Guideline Calls Routine Pelvic Exams Unnecessary
abstract: There is no evidence that pelvic exams of healthy women are useful and plenty to suggest they provoke fear and pain, the American College of Physicians says.
lead_paragraph: Doctors should stop performing routine pelvic exams, a key component of regular physicals for women, an influential medical group said Monday.

headline: In Performance | Benjamin Scheuer
abstract: The singer-songwriter Benjamin Scheuer performs “Cookie-tin Banjo,” a number from his autobiographical solo musical “The Lion.”
lead_paragraph: The singer-songwriter Benjamin Scheuer performs “Cookie-tin Banjo,” a number from his autobiographical solo musical “The Lion.”

headline: The Hobby Lobby Fallout
abstract: The Supreme Court’s ruling in favor of Hobby Lobby in a suit to allow private companies to deny employees contraceptive coverage raises important questions on the nature of religious liberty, writes JAKE FLANAGIN.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled in a 5 to 4 decision today that requiring privately owned companies to pay for insurance coverage for contraception violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, a federal law protecting liberties guaranteed by the First Amendment.

headline: Frank Cashen, Who Turned Lowly Mets Into Swaggering Champions, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Cashen assembled World Series champions in Baltimore and New York by nurturing farm systems and making shrewd trades.
lead_paragraph: Frank Cashen, the sportswriter turned baseball executive who built pennant-winning teams with the Baltimore Orioles and then transformed the Mets from perennial losers to the World Series champions of 1986, died on Monday at a hospital near his home in Easton, Md. He was 88.

headline: For Owners and Brokers, Web Rentals Upend the Hamptons Season
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Summer (Season)', 'Landlords', 'Real Estate Brokers', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The Internet has turned more Hamptonites into prospering landlords and left local officials busy trying to keep a cork on all the new activity, which can violate the law.
lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — The photos could hardly do the place justice, and not just because they were pixelated. No picture could have captured those strands of silver and gold shooting through the clouds as the sun set over Lake Montauk, the sloops and fishing boats bobbing alongside the once-rare-now-everywhere yachts.

headline: Apple Expands iTunes U Education App for iPads
abstract: Apple will soon take another step toward persuading schools to ditch textbooks in favor of iPads by giving instructors a tool to teach from the tablet.
lead_paragraph: Apple will soon make another bid to persuade schools to replace textbooks with iPads. Next week, it will introduce a tool for instructors to teach from the tablet.

headline: A Lucy and Ethel for an Age After Blogs
abstract: In Emily Gould’s “Friendship,” two young women, having made a start in New York in their 20s, now try to find their way in their 30s.
lead_paragraph: “Overshare” was chosen by Webster’s New World Dictionary as the “word of the year” in 2008, and no one overshared more that year than the blogger Emily Gould.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week in 140 Characters
abstract: What you missed from the men’s shows including Dior, Kenzo and Valentino.

headline: Using Brains, Not Guns, in World War I Trenches
abstract: Valiant Hearts: The Great War, a video game from France, is based on real battles in the First World War.
lead_paragraph: Late in the new World War I video game Valiant Hearts: The Great War, a French soldier named Émile is running into battle. The scene is the real and awful Second Battle of the Aisne, and it unfurls, as do so many other notable moments from the war in the game, like an interactive tapestry or a playable cartoon for grown-ups.

headline: After Tightening Pensions, Germany Eases Rules for Some
abstract: The decision to allow some workers to retire early with full pension benefits has drawn rebukes from younger workers and from countries that Berlin had urged to adopt austerity measures.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Back in 2007, Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government voted to lift the retirement age gradually to 67 from 65, in line with policies being adopted by the United States and other countries concerned about the costs of supporting an aging population. Economists say that move not only stabilized Germany’s public pension system, but also put Berlin in a position to insist during the subsequent financial crisis that other European governments follow suit.

headline: Unwitting Father Confessor in Flight
abstract: A reluctant flier finds that seatmates open up to him with the private details of their lives.
lead_paragraph: TRAVELING is just part of the deal if you’re running a business. I’m C.E.O. and founder of Rosenzweig and Company, a global executive search firm, and I have to travel a lot. I don’t like airports, and I don’t really like flying, so I try to be as efficient as possible with scheduling.

headline: Mick Jagger Teases Monty Python: ‘Wrinkly Old Men Trying to Relive Their Youth’
abstract: In a YouTube video, Mr. Jagger chides the members of Monty Python for being over the hill: “Who wants to see that again?”
lead_paragraph: With Monty Python about to begin its run of reunion (and farewell) shows at the 02 Arena in London on Tuesday, Mick Jagger and Charlie Watts of the Rolling Stones have made a video clip – commissioned by the Pythons, and shown at the troupe’s news conference about the shows on Monday – in which they tease the comedians as being past their sell-by date.

headline: A Belgian Food Truck Feeds the Hungry Fashion Set in Paris
abstract: During the MAN trade show, the two cooks behind Meteor served up decadent dishes from their mobile kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend in Paris, fashion editors and buyers took breaks from the back-to-back spring/summer 2015 men’s runways to stretch their legs at the MAN trade show, where a diverting lineup included more than just gazing at clothes. The show’s three-day run kicked off with an exhibition of Mote Sinabel Aoki’s photographs; eased into a friendly tournament of petanque, a French ball game; and culminated with a garden party at l’Institut Suédois à Paris. Throughout it all, MAN’s guests noshed on decadent dishes — crispy-skinned roasted chicken over greens, salted mackerel with juniper-roasted cauliflower cream, aged rib-eye, gazpacho, a green pea salad — served out of the Meteor food truck. The photographer Adrian Crispin was on the scene to capture the delicious offerings of Maarten van Essche and Floris Van Looy — and their stylish customers — before the two cooks drove their fine mobile eatery off to their next destination: a seashore in their hometown of Belgium (Ostend, Zeedijk 10), where they’ll be parked this Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

headline: Making It Work, but on Wheels
abstract: TruTV’s “Motor City Masters” and History’s “Biker Battleground Phoenix” feature competitions to design vehicles.
lead_paragraph: “Project Runway” — yes, it’s still on — begins a new season on July 24 on Lifetime, but perhaps you can’t wait that long to watch high-strung contestants bitch at one another as they design something utterly frivolous, while all over the world people are confronting real problems that have life-or-death consequences.

headline: Shell Game
abstract: Powdered eggshells can be a useful source of dietary calcium, comparable to a supplement, but crunching on coarse bits will probably not have much nutritional effect.
lead_paragraph: Q. I often include about half of one eggshell in the cup with my soft-boiled breakfast egg. Is eating it good for my health or bad?

headline: Young Life Under a Cloud
abstract: “Han Gong-ju,” a film from South Korea, follows a girl essentially exiled to a remote school.
lead_paragraph: The latest in a cluster of South Korean films to address sexual violence against girls and young women — including “Poetry” (2011), “Don’t Cry, Mommy” (2012) and the 2013 doubleheader of “Hope” and “My No-Mercy Home” — “Han Gong-ju” confronts a culture more inclined to shame victims than perpetrators.

headline: After Loud Complaints From French, Silence as BNP Penalty Is Announced
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The penalties announced on Monday ended up more lenient than proposed. The deal, a French official said, “seems workable.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As the American authorities announced a record penalty on Monday against BNP Paribas for violating United States rules on trading with blacklisted countries, the French political establishment had an unusual reaction: silence.

headline: Congress, Religion and the Court
abstract: Does the Religious Freedom Restoration Act go too far?

headline: The Iraq Stain
abstract: Even worse than we knew.
lead_paragraph: I don’t write much about Iraq and all that these days, but this report from James Risen brings back the horror of the whole thing. And I don’t just mean the fact that we were lied into war; that most of our media and policy elite rushed to join the bandwagon; that the venture led to awesome waste of lives and money.

headline: 2014 N.B.A. Draft Fashion Picks
abstract: The league’s new class of style-conscious players make their debut.
lead_paragraph: The league’s new class of style-conscious players make their debut.

headline: Clue to Disease’s Spread in a 6,200-Year-Old Grave
abstract: The oldest Schistosoma egg ever found was unearthed recently in Syria, suggesting that ancient Mesopotamians may have helped spread the parasite that causes bilharzia.
lead_paragraph: The oldest Schistosoma egg ever found was unearthed recently in an archaeological dig in Syria, and its surroundings suggest that ancient Mesopotamians may have contributed to the spread of schistosomiasis, a parasitic disease.

headline: The A.P. Plans to Automate Quarterly Earnings Articles
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Company Reports']
abstract: Articles based on companies’ quarterly reports are quite formulaic, and The Associated Press says that automating the process will free up its staff.
lead_paragraph: The Associated Press announced Monday that it would use computer automation to perform one of the most formulaic tasks for business reporters — writing articles about the quarterly earnings of companies.

headline: Boston Ballet Visits New York With a Bulging Suitcase
abstract: Boston Ballet’s season at the Koch Theater included works that show the troupe’s strengths and weaknesses.
lead_paragraph: All ballet companies have their self-contradictions. Boston Ballet is both a much better company than it allowed New York to see last week in its season at the David H. Koch Theater and, occasionally, a more dismaying one. The troupe has the world’s finest current production of “The Sleeping Beauty,” at least two of America’s best classical ballerinas (Kathleen Breen Combes and Misa Kuranaga, wholly unalike), a staging of Balanchine’s “Jewels” with (as seen in 2009) several exhilarating points of text and style absent from New York City Ballet’s, and many other productions that make me wish I had time to visit Boston more often. Its choice of ballets by living choreographers is, however, much more problematic.

headline: Cult Favorite ‘Community’ Is Saved From Cancellation by Yahoo
abstract: The sitcom, which ran on NBC for five seasons, will return for at least 13 more episodes on Yahoo Screen.
lead_paragraph: As might be appropriate for a cult comedy, “Community” has been saved again from the cancellation crypt.

headline: Bacon Painting Sets Pace for Auctions in London
abstract: A Francis Bacon triptych brought $45.4 million, well above its estimate, at Sotheby’s in London on Monday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Since Francis Bacon’s “Three Studies of Lucian Freud” (1969) sold at Christie’s for $142.4 million in New York last November a rash of paintings by that Irish-born artist have emerged for sale. The auction at Sotheby’s on Monday night, which kicked off the contemporary art sales here, will be remembered for buoyant bidding on a triptych by Bacon from 1964, which brought $45.4 million, well above its $33.6 million high estimate.

headline: More Time for Sifting Among Clues
abstract: The disappearance of the bandleader Glenn Miller is among the mysteries undertaken by a longer-form “History Detectives” in July.
lead_paragraph: Hors d’oeuvres, sports highlights, book excerpts — bite-size anything becomes unsatisfying after a while, and you may find yourself craving a full meal, a full game, a full novel. If you’re a history buff, the long-running PBS series “History Detectives” may by now feel like an endless diet of crudités, so you might be intrigued by the news that for July the show is altering its format to allow longer investigations.
