lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Mindfulness Backlash
abstract: Mindfulness is now suggested as a cure for practically everything. But some argue that its newfound popularity stems from a misunderstanding of its true nature — a misunderstanding that could even be dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Mindfulness has reached such a level of hipness that it is now suggested as a cure for essentially every ailment. Anxious? Broke? Sneezing? Definitely try meditating.

headline: Intersection | Toronto’s Nostalgic Style
abstract: In Toronto’s vintage Kensington Market neighborhood, Vicki Nguyen, a retail clerk, says her outfit was inspired by the idea of a 1930s English boy.
lead_paragraph: In Toronto’s vintage Kensington Market neighborhood, Vicki Nguyen, a retail clerk, says her outfit was inspired by the idea of a 1930s English boy.

headline: Reports on BNP Sanction Violations
abstract: The French bank agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States.
lead_paragraph: The French bank agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States.

headline: Return of a Player’s Sex Romps
abstract: Trey Songz, OOIOO and Rubén Blades have come out with new albums.
lead_paragraph: “I’d like to have dessert for starters,” Trey Songz sings on “Cake,” the first song from his new album, “Trigga.” Of course, it is the first song — Trey Songz isn’t much given to subtlety, nuance or skipping the lurid details.

headline: Saving Lives and Pushing Paper
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Hospitals', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Movies']
abstract: A sense of estrangement pervades a documentary that tracks the training of a handful of E.R. doctors in Los Angeles and the challenges they face as they move to a new building and adapt to new regulations.
lead_paragraph: A keen sense of loss permeates “Code Black,” an affecting love letter from a young doctor to his hospital. Over the years, plenty of similar romances have been immortalized in book form, but this may be the first to play out as a documentary, and is surely the first to emerge from our newly reformed health care climate. You’d think you’d be in for some celebration.

headline: The Broadway Star Who Got Away
abstract: The Tony award-winning actress Karen Olivo has traded the Broadway lights for a more quiet life in Madison, Wis.
lead_paragraph: Fans of Karen Olivo could hardly have been surprised when she belted out what Charles Isherwood of The New York Times called a “rafter-rattling performance” of “Come to Your Senses” at City Center last weekend. They knew this Tony Award-winning actress could sing, so her well-received turn in the Encores! Off-Center presentation of “Tick, Tick ... Boom!,” which grapples with the sacrifices it takes to make a life in the theater, was to be expected.

headline: A Sibling Rivalry Played Out Over Keyboards
abstract: “The Other Mozart,” a one-woman show by Sylvia Milo, tells the story of Wolfgang’s sister.
lead_paragraph: “Do you know what it says on my gravestone?” the woman asks. “ ‘Maria Anna von Berchtold zu Sonnenburg. The sister of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.’ ”

headline: City Smells Confound Flower-Seeking Moths
abstract: A study found that car exhaust and other urban fumes can hurt moths’ ability to find flowers.
lead_paragraph: Car exhaust and other urban fumes can disrupt moths’ ability to make their way to flowers, a new study reports.

headline: Faulty Air Bags From Takata Sold to Subaru and Mitsubishi
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: An air bag inflator that has been linked to millions of recalled vehicles and two deaths was also sold to the two Japanese automakers, Takata says.
lead_paragraph: The Takata Corporation said Monday that its defective air bags, already responsible for the recall of more than three million vehicles worldwide, were sold to two additional automakers, Subaru and Mitsubishi.

headline: The Supreme Court Justices Who Ruled For Hobby Lobby
abstract: Via Facebook.
lead_paragraph: Post by Nicholas Kristof.

headline: A Solar Show With Mixed Reviews
abstract: The peak of the sunspot cycle has produced few spectacular bursts, and much speculation about how much more can be expected.
lead_paragraph: Solar maximum is now.

headline: When Airlines Serve Alcohol, and the Beverage Cart Requires a Bouncer
abstract: Alcoholic beverages can make passengers unruly, especially when mixed with medications. The conditions for trouble, and diverted flights, are particularly ripe on international flights.
lead_paragraph: When Joshua Konowe, a technology entrepreneur, took his seat in an emergency exit row on a flight to Belgium last fall, he was unaware that his seatmate had washed down an anti-anxiety pill with her glass of wine.

headline: Life Outside the Hospital; Consequences of Cool; You’re So Far Away
abstract: Letters to the editor and online comments.
lead_paragraph: Long-Term Care

headline: Pinnacle Foods Cancels Deal With Hillshire
abstract: The move, which allows Pinnacle to collect a $163 million breakup fee, clears the way for Hillshire Brands to sell itself to Tyson Foods for $7.7 billion.
lead_paragraph: Pinnacle Foods said on Monday that it was terminating its merger agreement with Hillshire Brands, clearing the final obstacle for Hillshire to sell itself to Tyson Foods for $7.7 billion.

headline: After Favorable Schedule and Easy Wins, Murray Arrives at a Test
abstract: During another rainy day at Wimbledon, Andy Murray and Grigor Dimitrov won to set up the most anticipated match of the tournament.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — A heralded title defense that for four matches has practically been a stroll on the grass is about to become much more interesting and possibly threatening for Andy Murray. Well-rested, on schedule despite recent inclement weather and in fine form, he is looking at a quarterfinal against Grigor Dimitrov, a presumed star on the rise.

headline: An Outpouring of Pride
abstract: Thousands of people, of all ages, races and sexual orientations, celebrated their respect for themselves and others in Manhattan on Sunday at the Gay Pride March. Here are a few of the participants.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people, of all ages, races and sexual orientations, celebrated their respect for themselves and others in Manhattan on Sunday at the Gay Pride March. Here are a few of the participants.

headline: Science Events: Heroic Apes and Abandoned Railways
abstract: July events at the intersection of science and culture.
lead_paragraph: July events at the intersection of science and culture.

headline: Ana María Matute, Spanish Novelist Marked by Civil War, Dies at 88
keywords: ['Spanish Civil War (1936-39)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Ms. Matute’s explorations of alienation and the loss of innocence that children experienced during and after the Spanish Civil War made her one of Spain’s most acclaimed writers.
lead_paragraph: Ana María Matute, a novelist whose explorations of alienation and the loss of innocence children experienced during and after the Spanish Civil War made her one of Spain’s most popular and acclaimed writers, died on Wednesday in Barcelona. She was 88.

headline: After Bitcoin Auction, Winning Bidders Remain Elusive
abstract: As the United States Marshals Service began notifying winning and losing participants late on Monday afternoon, many in the Bitcoin world were still trying to figure out who won and the what they paid.
lead_paragraph: Since Friday, when the United States Marshals Service auctioned off nearly 30,000 Bitcoins, investors and Bitcoin enthusiasts alike have been eagerly awaiting the results. As the agency began notifying winning and losing participants late on Monday afternoon, many in the Bitcoin world were still trying to figure out who won and the what they paid.

headline: Twitter Buys TapCommerce, a Mobile Advertising Start-Up
abstract: Twitter makes another acquisition of a mobile ad technology company. This one is meant to improve ad targeting.
lead_paragraph: Twitter on Monday announced that it had acquired TapCommerce, a start-up in Manhattan focused on advertising tailored to smartphone apps.

headline: Extremists in Iraq Attack Shiite Shrine, Killing 6
abstract: The raid by militants on the sacred Al Askari Mosque in Samarra, rebuilt after attacks in 2006 that set off a wave of sectarian violence, left six people dead.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Sunni extremists fired mortars into a shrine in Samarra that is sacred to Shiites late Monday, killing six people and damaging the shrine, according to a report on Iraqi state television.

headline: A Grope and a Shrug
abstract: With American Apparel’s sexually audacious founder and other prominent men, do we excuse the inexcusable?
lead_paragraph: It was fully a decade ago that Dov Charney, the founder and (at that point) chief executive of American Apparel, decided that the right way to behave in front of a female journalist doing a profile of him was to masturbate. Not once, mind you. “Eight or so times,” according to the story, in Jane magazine, which is no longer around.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Google’s Street View Appeal
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: A long-running privacy lawsuit may damage the company’s efforts to expand its technology to the home, the body and vehicles.
lead_paragraph: The United States Supreme Court on Monday allowed a case accusing Google of wiretapping to proceed, undermining the search company’s efforts to put a troublesome episode to rest even as it plans to become more deeply embedded in consumers’ lives.

headline: Should Facebook Manipulate Users?
abstract: As guinea pigs, we deserve to know what researchers are doing.
lead_paragraph: SHOULD we worry that technology companies can secretly influence our emotions? Apparently so.

headline: A Woman at War
abstract: The story of a Sarah Rosetta Wakeman, who hid her identity to fight for the Union.
lead_paragraph: On June 19, 1864, Pvt. Lyons Wakeman died of dysentery in the Marine U.S.A. General Hospital in New Orleans, after having marched 200 miles and seen combat at the Battle of Pleasant Hill, part of the Union’s Red River campaign in Louisiana. But it would be years before Wakeman’s real identity was revealed: Lyons Wakeman was born a woman, Sarah Rosetta Wakeman.

headline: Questioning the Merits of Propping Up City Hall
abstract: Milwaukee City Hall, built in the 1890s and still one of the largest of its kind in the country, is slowly sinking.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — City Hall, built in the 1890s and still one of the largest of its kind in the country, is slowly sinking.

headline: Dov Charney Raises Stake in American Apparel
abstract: S.E.C. filings show that Dov Charney, the company’s founder and former chief executive, has enlarged his ownership stake and may be within striking distance of regaining control of the company.
lead_paragraph: Dov Charney, the recently ousted founder of American Apparel, may be back in play.

headline: Those Who Can Afford It Have a Better Way to Fly
abstract: Travelers with means have alternatives to increasingly crowded commercial flights, from Gulfstreams to custom-outfitted Boeing and Airbus planes.
lead_paragraph: WE are on the cusp of the Fourth of July weekend, when the fun really begins in air travel, as summer crowds push into already packed planes, challenging the laws of both physics and good manners.

headline: Pretrial Detention Extended for Egyptians Who Protested Ban on Protests
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Nearly two dozen Egyptian activists, arrested at a protest march last weekend, will remain in pretrial detention until Sept. 13, a judge ruled.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two dozen Egyptian activists, arrested at a protest march on June 21, will remain in pretrial detention until Sept. 13, a judge ruled on Sunday, the news site Aswat Masriya reported.

headline: Feud Between Oligarchs Seen as Cause of Bank Run in Bulgaria
abstract: A digital smear campaign prompted fearful depositors to withdraw almost $550 million from one of Bulgaria’s largest banks on Friday.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Even in an Eastern European country with a history of financial panics and political intrigue, it was an alarming picture.

headline: Hobby Lobby Made Fight a Matter of Christian Principle
keywords: ['Religion-State Relations', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: The chain of craft shops, which fought a contraceptives mandate to the Supreme Court, has not been afraid to take on secular America.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the family behind Hobby Lobby, fighting the Affordable Care Act’s contraceptives mandate all the way to the Supreme Court was a calling, not a choice.
